tr: Just like a breath dispersing on the surface of the gloomy wall mirror behind the girl, in which some headless, all crippled, black children were lined up and offering Sodom apples in black baskets to black goddesses, his thoughts scattered – and Mr. Lorry greeted Miss Manette with a formal nod.
es: The image dissipated almost as quickly as the stain produced by breath on the not very clean cornucopia placed behind the young woman, and enclosed in a frame that offered a procession of headless black cupids, many of them limping or maimed, who offered black baskets full of Dead Sea fruits to some black female idols, and he bowed deeply and solemnly before Miss Manette.

en: “Pray take a seat, sir.”
vi: − Please have a seat, sir. -
tr: "Please have a seat, sir."
es: —Please have a seat, sir—said a clear and musical voice, with a foreign accent, though barely noticeable.

en: In a very clear and pleasant young voice; a little foreign in its accent, but a very little indeed.
vi: That youthful voice was very gentle and clear, with a hint of a foreign accent, but it was fleeting.
tr: The girl had a crystal-clear, very sweet, and youthful voice; it had a slight foreign accent, but it wasn't very noticeable.
es: —Please have a seat, sir—said a clear and musical voice, with a foreign accent, though barely noticeable.

en: “I kiss your hand, miss,” said mr Lorry, with the manners of an earlier date, as he made his formal bow again, and took his seat.
vi: − May I kiss your hand, miss, - Mr. Lorry said with old-fashioned courtesy as he respectfully bowed again and then sat down.
tr: With the courtesy of old days, bowing slightly in a formal manner, "With your permission, may I kiss your hand, young lady," said Mr. Lorry and then sat back down.
es: —I kiss your hand, miss—replied Mr. Lorry, making another bow in the old-fashioned manner, before taking a seat.

en: “I received a letter from the Bank, sir, yesterday, informing me that some intelligence—or discovery—”
vi: − Yesterday I received a letter from the Bank, sir, informing me that there is news... or a discovery...
tr: "Yesterday, I received a letter from the bank, sir, about some news – or rather, a discovery."
es: —Yesterday I received a letter from the Bank, sir, in which they told me that it had been found out... or discovered...

en: “The word is not material, miss; either word will do.”
vi: − Words are not important, miss, you can use any term.
tr: "Words have no physical form, young lady, either one works.""
es: —The word is the least important thing, miss: both express the idea.

en: “—respecting the small property of my poor father, whom I never saw—so long dead—”
vi: − ... something about the small property of the poor father whom I had never met... who had passed away long ago...
tr: "It was about a small property left by my poor father whom I never saw – he passed away a long time ago."
es: —... Something about the few possessions my poor father left behind, whom I had the misfortune of never knowing...

en: mr Lorry moved in his chair, and cast a troubled look towards the hospital procession of negro cupids.
vi: Mr. Lorry fidgeted in his chair and anxiously glanced at the group of pitiful black angels carved on the mirror frame.
tr: Mr. Lorry fidgeted in his chair and glanced uneasily at the black children lined up in the frame of the mirror.
es: Lorry squirmed in the chair, casting anguished glances at the mournful procession of black cupids, as if hoping to find in the absurd little baskets they carried the light that his intelligence denied him.

en: As if they had any help for anybody in their absurd baskets!
vi: As if they could help with those ridiculous baskets!
tr: As if they could help him by leaving those meaningless baskets!

en: “—rendered it necessary that I should go to Paris, there to communicate with a gentleman of the Bank, so good as to be despatched to Paris for the purpose.”
vi: − ... said that I need to go to Paris, to contact a gentleman from the bank, who is very trustworthy and has been sent to Paris for this matter.
tr: "I absolutely have to go to Paris, I need to meet with an official from the bank there, and this person will also be in Paris for this reason.""
es: And that, consequently, it was absolutely necessary for me to make a trip to Paris, where I would have to get in touch with a gentleman from the Bank, sent to the capital of France for that purpose.

en: “Myself.”
vi: − That's me.
tr: "That person is me.""
es: —That gentleman is me, miss.

en: “As I was prepared to hear, sir.”
vi: − Just as I thought, sir.
tr: "I was expecting it to be like this, sir."
es: —I supposed so, sir.

en: She curtseyed to him (young ladies made curtseys in those days), with a pretty desire to convey to him that she felt how much older and wiser he was than she.
vi: She curtsied to him (back then, young women often greeted like that) with the good intention of expressing respect for the age and superior wisdom of the person opposite.
tr: The young girl greeted Mr. Lorry with a curtsy (in those days, young ladies would greet like this), as if she wanted to show that the man was much older and wiser than herself.
es: The girl made a graceful curtsy (in those times, young ladies made curtsies).

en: He made her another bow.
vi: He bowed to the girl once more.
tr: Mr. Lorry also nodded to her once again.
es: The gentleman bowed deeply.

en: “I replied to the Bank, sir, that as it was considered necessary, by those who know, and who are so kind as to advise me, that I should go to France, and that as I am an orphan and have no friend who could go with me, I should esteem it highly if I might be permitted to place myself, during the journey, under that worthy gentleman’s protection.
vi: − I replied to the bank, sir, that if knowledgeable people with good intentions advised me, and if it was deemed necessary, I would go to France. However, since I no longer have parents and no friends who can accompany me, I would be very grateful if that esteemed person could protect me on the journey.
tr: "Then I immediately replied to the bank, sir, thanking them for informing me of this and advising me to go to France, and I asked them to find someone to accompany me since I have no one, saying I would be very pleased if a respectable gentleman could watch over me."
es: I replied to the Bank that if the people who extend their benevolence towards me to the point of advising me considered the trip necessary, I would certainly go to France, but that, given that I am an orphan and have no friends who can accompany me, I would appreciate it as a special favor if they allowed me to place myself, during the journey, under the protection of the worthy gentleman with whom I was to make contact in Paris.

en: The gentleman had left London, but I think a messenger was sent after him to beg the favour of his waiting for me here.”
vi: That gentleman has left London, but I think it is necessary to send a liaison to catch up with him and ask him to agree to wait for me here.
tr: "That gentleman had already set off from London; I believe they sent a messenger after him to ask him to wait for me here.""
es: The gentleman had already left London, but I believe they sent a messenger asking him to wait for me here.

en: “I was happy,” said mr Lorry, “to be entrusted with the charge.
vi: − I am very pleased to be entrusted with this responsibility, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "I am happy to be deemed worthy of such a task," said Mr. Lorry, and added, "Fulfilling it will be an even greater happiness for me."
es: —I considered myself happy to receive the assignment, and I will consider myself much happier fulfilling it, miss—replied Mr. Lorry.

en: I shall be more happy to execute it.”
vi: - I am even happier to carry it out.
tr: "I am happy to be deemed worthy of such a task," said Mr. Lorry, and added, "Fulfilling it will be an even greater happiness for me."
es: —I considered myself happy to receive the assignment, and I will consider myself much happier fulfilling it, miss—replied Mr. Lorry.

en: “Sir, I thank you indeed.
vi: − Sincerely thank you, sir.
tr: "Thank you very much, sir.
es: —Thank you very much, sir; believe me, I give them to you from the heart.

en: I thank you very gratefully.
vi: I am very grateful to you.
tr: I am truly grateful to you.
es: —Thank you very much, sir; believe me, I give them to you from the heart.

en: It was told me by the Bank that the gentleman would explain to me the details of the business, and that I must prepare myself to find them of a surprising nature.
vi: The bank informed me that you would explain the matter in detail to me, and I should be mentally prepared for some shocking events.
tr: They told me at the bank that this gentleman would explain the matter to me in all its details, and they even said to be prepared to be surprised.
es: The Bank informed me that the gentleman would explain the details of the matter to me, and that I should be prepared to receive surprising news.

en: I have done my best to prepare myself, and I naturally have a strong and eager interest to know what they are.”
vi: I am already prepared, and of course, I am eager to know what this matter is.
tr: But I am ready for everything, and I am almost dying of curiosity."
es: I have done everything possible to prepare myself, and you can be sure that I have a genuine desire to know what it is about.

en: “Naturally,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Certainly, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Of course," said Mr. Lorry, "You are right, I..."
es: —I find it very natural—replied Lorry.

en: “Yes—I—”
tr: "Of course," said Mr. Lorry, "You are right, I..."
es: —Yes... perfectly natural... I...

en: After a pause, he added, again settling the crisp flaxen wig at the ears, “It is very difficult to begin.”
vi: After a moment of hesitation, he continued speaking while smoothing the sides of his curly brown wig: − It is indeed very difficult to start.
tr: After pausing for a moment, she adjusted her shiny yellow wig back over her ears and added:
es: He paused, adjusted his toupee back over his ears, and finally replied: —The truth is that it is so difficult to begin...

en: He did not begin, but, in his indecision, met her glance.
vi: He didn't get straight to the point but hesitated, looking into the girl's eyes.
tr: "I don't know where to start." Gene had fallen silent, but in that moment of hesitation, he met the young girl's gaze.
es: And he did not begin. In his indecision, his eyes met those of his interlocutor.

en: The young forehead lifted itself into that singular expression—but it was pretty and characteristic, besides being singular—and she raised her hand, as if with an involuntary action she caught at, or stayed some passing shadow.
vi: Her youthful forehead furrowed into that distinctive wrinkle - yet still beautiful and full of character - she raised her hand as if in an involuntary reaction, or as if trying to grasp a fleeting illusion.
tr: The young forehead had taken on the same special expression again – in addition to being special, it was also sweet and characteristic – and as if trying to catch a shadow, he involuntarily raised his hand.
es: On her forehead, a few wrinkles appeared, her expression changed, and her hand rose to the level of her eyes, as if she wanted to grasp some shadow that had just crossed before them.

en: “Are you quite a stranger to me, sir?”
vi: − Surely you have met me before, haven't you?
tr: "Could I possibly know you from somewhere, sir?" "Is that so?"
es: —Have we ever met before, sir?—he asked.

en: “Am I not?” mr Lorry opened his hands, and extended them outwards with an argumentative smile.
vi: − Really? - Mr. Lorry spread his hands and opened his arms with a smile implying denial.
tr: Mr. Lorry opened his hands to the sides and smiled mischievously.
es: —Do you believe so?—asked Lorry, extending his arms and smiling.

en: Between the eyebrows and just over the little feminine nose, the line of which was as delicate and fine as it was possible to be, the expression deepened itself as she took her seat thoughtfully in the chair by which she had hitherto remained standing.
vi: Between her eyebrows and right above her petite nose, with extremely delicate and slender features, a deep expressive wrinkle appeared as she thoughtfully sat down on the chair she had been standing next to.
tr: As the young girl settled into the chair she had been standing by for a while with a thoughtful demeanor, the expression on her face, between her eyebrows and above her tiny nose, deepened into the most delicate and pleasant line possible.
es: The delicate and fine line that had formed between the girl's eyebrows became deeper and more energetic as she sat down in the chair beside which she had been standing until then.

en: He watched her as she mused, and the moment she raised her eyes again, went on:
vi: He looked at the pensive girl and waited for her to look up before continuing: −
tr: Mr. Lorry observed the girl lost in thought and continued as soon as he lifted his eyes again:
es: Lorry watched her silently, and when after a while the young woman raised her eyes again, he hastened to ask:

en: “In your adopted country, I presume, I cannot do better than address you as a young English lady, Miss Manette?”
vi: In the country you have adopted as your homeland, I suppose I should call you "Miss" as I do the young ladies of England, Miss Manette? −
tr: "In this country, which you have accepted as your homeland, the most suitable description for you would probably be an English young lady, wouldn't it?""
es: —I suppose that in your adopted homeland you would like to be treated and spoken to as an English lady; isn't that right, Miss Manette?

en: “If you please, sir.”
vi: Yes, sir, as you wish.
tr: "As you wish, sir."
es: —As you wish, sir.

en: “Miss Manette, I am a man of business.
vi: − Miss Manette, I am a man of business.
tr: "Miss Manette, I am a businessman.
es: —I am a businessman, Miss Manette, and I have been tasked with handling and successfully completing a business matter.

en: I have a business charge to acquit myself of.
vi: I have a responsibility to fulfill.
tr: I have tasks that need to be completed.
es: —I am a businessman, Miss Manette, and I have been tasked with handling and successfully completing a business matter.

en: In your reception of it, don’t heed me any more than if I was a speaking machine—truly, I am not much else.
vi: While you listen to my presentation, please consider me as nothing more than a speaking machine.
tr: Just see me as a talking machine – I am truly nothing more than that.
es: When you hear all the details related to it from my lips, do not see in me anything more than a talking machine, for in truth, a talking machine I am.

en: I will, with your leave, relate to you, miss, the story of one of our customers.”
vi: Miss, allow me to recount the story of one of our clients.
tr: Now, young lady, with your permission, let me tell you the story of one of our clients."
es: With your permission, Miss Manette, I will tell you the story of one of our clients.

en: “Story!”
vi: − The story!
tr: "A story?""
es: —History!

en: He seemed wilfully to mistake the word she had repeated, when he added, in a hurry, “Yes, customers; in the banking business we usually call our connection our customers.
vi: He seemed to deliberately misunderstand the word the girl had just repeated as he hastily continued: − Yes, client; in the banking industry, we often refer to customers as clients.
tr: Mr. Lorry hastily added, deliberately twisting the word the girl was emphasizing, "Yes, customers; we call everyone connected with us in the banking sector a customer.
es: It seems that Lorry must have mistaken one word for another, for no sooner had his interlocutor repeated the word story than he hastily replied: —Yes, miss: from one of our clients. Those of us who are in the banking business usually call all our acquaintances clients.

en: He was a French gentleman; a scientific gentleman; a man of great acquirements—a Doctor.”
vi: He is a French gentleman; a gentleman in the field of science; a highly educated and knowledgeable person... a doctor.
tr: This gentleman was French; a scientist; he had achieved great success – he was a Doctor."
es: The client I am referring to was a French gentleman, a man of great talent and intellectual gifts... a doctor.

en: “Not of Beauvais?”
vi: − Not in Beauvais, is it? −
tr: "Was he from Beauvais?"
es: —Wouldn't it be from Beauvais, huh?

en: “Why, yes, of Beauvais.
vi: Oh, yes, in Beauvais.
tr: "Ah yes, he was from Beauvais.
es: —Precisely from Beauvais.

en: Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the gentleman was of Beauvais.
vi: Just like Lord Manette, this gentleman is also in Beauvais.
tr: Just like your father, Monsieur Manette, this gentleman was also from Beauvais.
es: Just like Mr. Manette, your father, the gentleman in question was from Beauvais: just like Mr. Manette, your father, he was a notable figure in Paris, where I had the honor of meeting him.

en: Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the gentleman was of repute in Paris.
vi: Just like Lord Manette, this gentleman is a well-known figure in Paris.
tr: Again, just like your father, Monsieur Manette, this gentleman was also one of the respected figures of Paris.
es: Just like Mr. Manette, your father, the gentleman in question was from Beauvais: just like Mr. Manette, your father, he was a notable figure in Paris, where I had the honor of meeting him.

en: I had the honour of knowing him there.
vi: I had the honor of knowing him there.
tr: I had the honor of meeting him there.
es: Just like Mr. Manette, your father, the gentleman in question was from Beauvais: just like Mr. Manette, your father, he was a notable figure in Paris, where I had the honor of meeting him.

en: Our relations were business relations, but confidential.
vi: Our relationship was a business one, but very close.
tr: Our relationship was based on business, but it was secret.
es: Our relationship was purely and exclusively business, but confidential.

en: I was at that time in our French House, and had been—oh!
vi: At that time, I was working at the branch in France, and it has been... oh!
tr: At that time, I was in the French branch of the bank, I stayed there for quite a while, that is – oh!
es: At that time, I was at our French office, and this was... a trifle!

en: twenty years.”
vi: Twenty years already.
tr: twenty years."
es: Twenty years ago!

en: “At that time—I may ask, at what time, sir?”
vi: − At that time... may I ask, when was that, sir? − I just mentioned it, miss, twenty years ago.
tr: "When you say then – exactly what time are you referring to, sir?"
es: —In those times... Excuse my curiosity, sir, but I would like to know...

en: “I speak, miss, of twenty years ago.
vi: − At that time... may I ask, when was that, sir? − I just mentioned it, miss, twenty years ago.
tr: "I am talking about twenty years ago, young lady.
es: —I am speaking of twenty years ago, miss.

en: He married—an English lady—and I was one of the trustees.
vi: He got married... to an English lady... and I was one of the witnesses at the wedding.
tr: This gentleman was married to an English lady, and I used to handle his affairs.
es: He married an English lady... and I was one of his trustees.

en: His affairs, like the affairs of many other French gentlemen and French families, were entirely in Tellson’s hands.
vi: His personal affairs, like those of many other French gentlemen and French families, were all entrusted to Tellson's.
tr: In fact, all his affairs, like those of all other French gentlemen and families, were handled by Tellson Bank.
es: The Tellson Bank handled all his business, as it did for almost all French gentlemen and families.

en: In a similar way I am, or I have been, trustee of one kind or other for scores of our customers.
vi: Similarly, I am, or have been, the authorized person for all sorts of personal matters of the clients.
tr: Similarly, now I look after the various accounts of our clients.
es: Just as I was a trustee for that gentleman, I am or have been for dozens of the firm's clients.

en: These are mere business relations, miss; there is no friendship in them, no particular interest, nothing like sentiment.
vi: These were purely business relationships, miss; not friendships, no special interest, no emotions at all.
tr: These are just business relationships, young lady; they contain neither friendship, nor special interest, nor emotion.
es: These are purely business relations, miss, free of friendship, free of interest, free of affection, relations in which there is nothing that resembles feeling.

en: I have passed from one to another, in the course of my business life, just as I pass from one of our customers to another in the course of my business day; in short, I have no feelings; I am a mere machine.
vi: Throughout my business life, I moved from one task to another, just as I moved from one client to another in a working day; in short, I had no emotions; I was just a machine.
tr: Just like the many clients I visit during the day, throughout my entire business life I have always gone from client to client; in short, I have no emotions; I am merely a machine.
es: Throughout my life, I have moved from one to another without any leaving traces or almost any memories in me, exactly the same as I deal with the countless clients who come to the Bank daily with such varied purposes.

en: To go on—”
vi: Let me continue...
tr: Where was I..."
es: In a word, miss: I have no feelings, I have no affection for anyone, I am a machine, I am a...

en: “But this is my father’s story, sir; and I begin to think”—the curiously roughened forehead was very intent upon him—“that when I was left an orphan through my mother’s surviving my father only two years, it was you who brought me to England.
vi: − But it sounds like a story about my father, sir; and I begin to think that, - that strangely furrowed brow directed straight at him, - when I became an orphan because my mother passed away only two years after my father, it was you who brought me back to England.
tr: "But this is my father's story, sir, and if I'm not mistaken," –the girl's forehead wrinkled with curiosity, her gaze fixed intently on the man– "it was you who brought me to England after I lost my mother two years after my father and became an orphan.
es: —But you are telling me the story of my father, sir, and I begin to suspect that, when my mother died, who only survived my father by two years, leaving me orphaned and alone in the world, it was you who took me to England.

en: I am almost sure it was you.”
vi: I am almost certain it was you.
tr: I'm sure of it."
es: I would almost dare to say that it was you.

en: mr Lorry took the hesitating little hand that confidingly advanced to take his, and he put it with some ceremony to his lips.
vi: Mr. Lorry took the small hand that was hesitantly offered to him and raised it to his lips somewhat ceremoniously.
tr: Mr. Lorry, taking the girl's hand which first extended hesitantly and then confidently, ceremoniously brought it to his lips.
es: Mr. Lorry took the tiny hand that trustingly sought his, and ceremoniously brought it to his lips.

en: He then conducted the young lady straightway to her chair again, and, holding the chair-back with his left hand, and using his right by turns to rub his chin, pull his wig at the ears, or point what he said, stood looking down into her face while she sat looking up into his.
vi: Then he immediately helped the girl sit back down as before, with his left hand holding the back of the chair, his right hand alternately stroking his chin and tugging at the sides of his wig, or gesturing as he spoke, while he looked down at the girl as she looked up at him.
tr: Then he led her to her chair and, while holding the back of the chair with his left hand, he alternately stroked his chin, adjusted his wig towards his ears, or pointed to something he was saying; the girl watched from her seat, and Mr. Lorry from where he stood, observing each other.
es: Mr. Lorry took the tiny hand that trustingly sought his, and ceremoniously brought it to his lips.

en: “Miss Manette, it was I.
vi: − Miss Manette, it is I.
tr: "Miss Manette, yes it was me.
es: —I was, indeed, Miss Manette—replied Lorry.—

en: And you will see how truly I spoke of myself just now, in saying I had no feelings, and that all the relations I hold with my fellow-creatures are mere business relations, when you reflect that I have never seen you since.
vi: You will see how honest I am about myself when I say that I have no feelings, and all my dealings with others are purely business transactions, if you remember that I have not seen you again.
tr: You see how truthful I was when I said I had no feelings and that my connections were purely business, then I never saw you again.
es: The fact that since then I have never seen you again will convince you of the accuracy of my words, will convince you of the truth with which I assured you a moment ago that I have no feelings, and that all the relationships I maintain or have maintained with my fellow beings have been exclusively business-related. No! No sentimentality!

en: No; you have been the ward of Tellson’s House since, and I have been busy with the other business of Tellson’s House since.
vi: Not at all; since then you have been cared for by Tellson's, and I have been busy with other matters for Tellson's.
tr: But of course, even though I have been involved in various other matters, you have been under the guardianship of Tellson Bank since that time.
es: You have been since then the ward of Tellson's Bank, and I have had enough to do since then working on the affairs of Tellson's Bank.

en: Feelings!
vi: Feelings!
tr: Feelings!
es: Feelings!

en: I have no time for them, no chance of them.
vi: I have no time, no opportunity for such things.
tr: I have no time to spare for them at all.
es: I lack the time and the will to afford myself the luxury of having them!

en: I pass my whole life, miss, in turning an immense pecuniary Mangle.”
vi: All my life, ma'am, I have only known how to work for a gigantic financial machine.
tr: My life has been spent turning a great money wheel."
es: I have spent my entire life moving and turning over immense masses of money.

en: After this odd description of his daily routine of employment, mr Lorry flattened his flaxen wig upon his head with both hands (which was most unnecessary, for nothing could be flatter than its shining surface was before), and resumed his former attitude.
vi: After finishing his strange description of his usual daily work, Mr. Lorry pressed both hands flat against his yellow-brown wig (an unnecessary action as the shiny hair could not be any flatter), then continued in the same manner: − Miss, as you have seen, the story so far resembles that of your poor father.
tr: After this strange description of the work routine, Mr. Lorry pressed his bright light yellow wig firmly onto his head with both hands (what an unnecessary action this was, as that shiny surface was already quite flat) and resumed his previous posture.
es: Having made this singular description of his daily routines, Mr. Lorry smoothed his silky wig with both hands, an unnecessary operation, as it was impossible to smooth it more than it already was, and resumed his previous posture.

en: “So far, miss (as you have remarked), this is the story of your regretted father.
vi: After finishing his strange description of his usual daily work, Mr. Lorry pressed both hands flat against his yellow-brown wig (an unnecessary action as the shiny hair could not be any flatter), then continued in the same manner: − Miss, as you have seen, the story so far resembles that of your poor father.
tr: "So, young lady –as you also mentioned– this was the story of your poor father up to this point.
es: —So far, miss, what I have just narrated is, as you have guessed, the story of your father.

en: Now comes the difference.
vi: Now comes the difference.
tr: But now it changes.
es: The differences come now.

en: If your father had not died when he did—Don’t be frightened!
vi: If your father had never died... Don't be alarmed!
tr: What if the father you thought was dead had not died –Don't be afraid, dear!
es: If your father had not died when he did... Don't be frightened!

en: How you start!”
vi: You are startled!
tr: How you flinched!"
es: You are trembling like a leaf on the tree!

en: She did, indeed, start.
vi: Indeed, the girl was startled.
tr: The young girl was truly startled.
es: It was true.

en: And she caught his wrist with both her hands.
vi: And she clasped both her hands around his wrist.
tr: She tightly grabbed Mr. Lorry's wrist with both hands.
es: The young woman was trembling convulsively and, without uttering a word, extended both hands in a pleading gesture.

en: “Pray,” said mr Lorry, in a soothing tone, bringing his left hand from the back of the chair to lay it on the supplicatory fingers that clasped him in so violent a tremble: “pray control your agitation—a matter of business.
vi: − Calm down, - Mr. Lorry said in a soothing voice as he withdrew his left hand from the back of the chair and placed it on the girl's trembling fingers that were clasped tightly. - Please calm down... it's just business.
tr: "Please," said Mr. Lorry in a calming tone, placing his left hand, which he had pulled from behind the chair, onto the pleading fingers that were trembling violently on his wrist, "please calm down – this is just business after all.
es: —Please, miss...! —exclaimed Lorry with extreme gentleness. —Control yourself... Calm that agitation... What do feelings have to do with this?... We are talking about business...

en: As I was saying—”
vi: I was just saying that...
tr: What was I saying-"
es: You see: I was saying...

en: Her look so discomposed him that he stopped, wandered, and began anew:
vi: Her eyes were so bewildered that he had to stop speaking, lost in thought, and then start over: − I just said that if Monsieur Manette had never died; if he had suddenly disappeared without a trace; if he had been taken far away to some terrible place, which would not be hard to guess but impossible to trace; if he had a fellow countryman who was an enemy with the privilege that, in my lifetime, I know, even the boldest on the other side of the channel only dared to mention him in whispers; for instance, the privilege to fill in blank warrants that could throw anyone into the indefinite oblivion of prison; if this man's wife had pleaded with the King, the Queen, the Court, and the Church for news of her husband but still received no response... if so, then your father's story would be the story of that unfortunate gentleman, the doctor in Beauvais.
tr: Mr. Lorry was so disturbed by the girl's gaze that he fell silent, waited for a while, and then continued from where he left off.
es: The look the girl gave the narrator unsettled him so completely that he hesitated, stammered, had to make a rather long pause, and finally replied:

en: “As I was saying; if Monsieur Manette had not died; if he had suddenly and silently disappeared; if he had been spirited away; if it had not been difficult to guess to what dreadful place, though no art could trace him; if he had an enemy in some compatriot who could exercise a privilege that I in my own time have known the boldest people afraid to speak of in a whisper, across the water there; for instance, the privilege of filling up blank forms for the consignment of any one to the oblivion of a prison for any length of time; if his wife had implored the king, the queen, the court, the clergy, for any tidings of him, and all quite in vain;—then the history of your father would have been the history of this unfortunate gentleman, the Doctor of Beauvais.”
vi: Her eyes were so bewildered that he had to stop speaking, lost in thought, and then start over: − I just said that if Monsieur Manette had never died; if he had suddenly disappeared without a trace; if he had been taken far away to some terrible place, which would not be hard to guess but impossible to trace; if he had a fellow countryman who was an enemy with the privilege that, in my lifetime, I know, even the boldest on the other side of the channel only dared to mention him in whispers; for instance, the privilege to fill in blank warrants that could throw anyone into the indefinite oblivion of prison; if this man's wife had pleaded with the King, the Queen, the Court, and the Church for news of her husband but still received no response... if so, then your father's story would be the story of that unfortunate gentleman, the doctor in Beauvais.
tr: "Where were we? If Monsieur Manette had not died; if one day he had suddenly, quietly disappeared; if the ground had swallowed him up, even if we could guess what terrible place he had gone to, we would not know the way to reach him at all; then, on the other side, if he had an enemy somewhere who possessed a privilege that even the most daring people hesitated to mention; that is to say, these privileged people could fill out some papers and send anyone they wanted to prison and leave them forgotten for as long as they wished; if his wife had begged the king, the queen, the court, the church for news of him, all in vain – then your father's story would be the same as that of this unfortunate gentleman, the doctor from Beauvais."
es: —I was saying that if Mr. Manette had not died, that if instead of dying he had disappeared unexpectedly and silently, evaporating, so to speak, that if it had not been an impossible task to guess the dreadful place where he would have been buried, although it was possible to reach him, if he had had the misfortune of incurring the animosity of some compatriot of his, vested with a power that the bravest men of my time did not dare to mention without trembling, the power to fill out orders or decrees signed in blank, by virtue of which it was easy to condemn any mortal to imprisonment and temporary or perpetual oblivion, if that gentleman's wife had implored compassion from the king, the queen, the court, the clergy, and the nobility, seeking news of her absent husband, without managing to soften any heart, then the story of the doctor from Beauvais that I am recounting would indeed be that of your father.

en: “I entreat you to tell me more, sir.”
vi: − I beg you, please explain further.
tr: "Please, continue telling the story, sir."
es: —For God's sake, sir, tell me more!

en: “I will.
vi: − I will speak.
tr: "Alright.
es: —For God's sake, sir, tell me more!

en: I am going to.
vi: I am about to speak now.
tr: I will tell.
es: —That's what I'm getting at: but do you have enough courage to listen to what I have to say?

en: You can bear it?”
vi: Can you bear it?
tr: But can you handle it?"
es: —I can bear anything except the uncertainty that your words leave me in.

en: “I can bear anything but the uncertainty you leave me in at this moment.”
vi: − I can bear anything, except the uncertainty you are making me endure.
tr: "If there's one thing I can't stand, it's this uncertainty."
es: —I can bear anything except the uncertainty that your words leave me in.

en: “You speak collectedly, and you—are collected.
vi: − She spoke very calmly, and she... also appeared calm.
tr: "Your voice is calm now, you have calmed down too.
es: —You speak calmly... and surely you are already composed: magnificent!

en: That’s good!”
vi: That's good!
tr: Good!" (Despite saying this, Mr. Lorry's demeanor showed that he was not very satisfied.)
es: —You speak calmly... and surely you are already composed: magnificent!

en: (Though his manner was less satisfied than his words.)
vi: His tone was not as satisfied as his words suggested.
tr: Good!" (Despite saying this, Mr. Lorry's demeanor showed that he was not very satisfied.)
es: —continued Lorry, with an expression that contradicted his last words.

en: “A matter of business.
vi: - It's just business.
tr: "This is a business matter.
es: —We are talking about business... nothing but business.

en: Regard it as a matter of business—business that must be done.
vi: Just consider it a job, something that needs to be completed.
tr: See this as a business matter – a task that needs to be handled.
es: Do not see in what I say anything more than a business... that can be done... that, in all likelihood, will turn out well.

en: Now if this doctor’s wife, though a lady of great courage and spirit, had suffered so intensely from this cause before her little child was born—”
vi: Then if the wife of this doctor, although a woman of great courage and determination, also had to suffer immensely because of that situation before giving birth to a child...
tr: Now, although this doctor's wife is an extremely brave and noble lady, she had suffered such great pains while her little baby was still in her womb..."
es: Let's continue: if the good doctor's wife, a lady of exceptional courage and great presence of mind, endured such sharp pains and sufferings as a result of what I have just mentioned, before her son came into the world...

en: “The little child was a daughter, sir.”
vi: − That child must be a girl, sir.
tr: "Was this little baby a girl, sir?"
es: —The son was a daughter, sir!...

en: “A daughter.
vi: − Little girl.
tr: "Yes, she was angry.
es: —Well...!

en: A-a-matter of business—don’t be distressed.
vi: It's... it's just work... don't be sad.
tr: This –this is a matter related to work– don't worry.
es: What difference does it make? Sex does not alter the business...

en: Miss, if the poor lady had suffered so intensely before her little child was born, that she came to the determination of sparing the poor child the inheritance of any part of the agony she had known the pains of, by rearing her in the belief that her father was dead—No, don’t kneel!
vi: Dear miss, if this poor lady had suffered so much before the child was born, to the extent that she was determined to spare her child from any suffering that she herself had endured, by raising the child and teaching it to believe that its father was dead...
tr: Young lady, this poor woman suffered such great pains when her little baby was still in her womb, that she raised her child telling him that his father was dead so that he wouldn't experience the agony she went through –No, please stand up!
es: I mean, miss, that if the poor lady suffered such severe pains before her daughter was born, in order to prevent this sad inheritance of her agonies from reaching her, she nursed and raised her in the belief that her father had died...

en: In Heaven’s name why should you kneel to me!”
vi: Don't, don't kneel down! Oh my God, why are you kneeling in front of me! −
tr: For God's sake, why are you kneeling?"
es: Do not kneel, for God's sake...! In the name of Heaven!... Why do you fall to your knees at my feet?

en: “For the truth.
vi: For the truth.
tr: "To hear the truth.
es: —To beg you to tell me the truth...!

en: O dear, good, compassionate sir, for the truth!”
vi: Oh, please, merciful sir, have pity, tell the truth! −
tr: Oh merciful, kind-hearted sir, please tell me the truth now, I beg you!"
es: For pity's sake, sir, hide nothing from me!...

en: “A—a matter of business.
vi: It's... it's just about work.
tr: "This is a matter of business.
es: —I will tell you everything... But calm down, for heaven's sake!

en: You confuse me, and how can I transact business if I am confused?
vi: You are making me confused, and how can I solve work matters when I'm confused?
tr: You are confusing me, and if you confuse me like this, how can I do my work?
es: We are dealing with a... a... business, miss, and its details confuse me... and it's not possible... I can't handle business properly if my ideas are confused and obscured.

en: Let us be clear-headed.
vi: We need to be clear-headed.
tr: Let's get our heads together first.
es: Let's try to clear our heads.

en: If you could kindly mention now, for instance, what nine times ninepence are, or how many shillings in twenty guineas, it would be so encouraging.
vi: Please kindly tell me, for instance, how much is nine times nine pence, or how many shillings are in twenty guineas, that would be much better.
tr: For example, now, try to say how much nine times nine pence is or how many shillings twenty guineas make.
es: If you can tell me right now... for example, how many pence are in nine coins of nine pence each, or how many shillings are in twenty guineas, it will greatly calm my spirit, as it will be a palpable proof of your calmness and serenity.

en: I should be so much more at my ease about your state of mind.”
vi: I would feel more at ease about your state of mind.
tr: Then I can be convinced that you are in your right mind."
es: If you can tell me right now... for example, how many pence are in nine coins of nine pence each, or how many shillings are in twenty guineas, it will greatly calm my spirit, as it will be a palpable proof of your calmness and serenity.

en: Without directly answering to this appeal, she sat so still when he had very gently raised her, and the hands that had not ceased to clasp his wrists were so much more steady than they had been, that she communicated some reassurance to mr Jarvis Lorry.
vi: Without bothering to respond to that plea, Manette sat silently after he had helped her onto the chair. The girl's hands still gripped Mr. Jarvis Lorry's wrist, but they no longer trembled as they had earlier, which made him somewhat reassured.
tr: The young girl sat calmly in her place without answering the questions, and Mr. Jarvis Lorry felt somewhat relieved because the girl's hands, still clasped to her wrist, were no longer trembling as they had before when the man gently lifted her from her seat.
es: Without directly responding to this call, the girl allowed herself to be lifted from the ground and sat back down with such composure that she imparted to her interlocutor the courage that he was beginning to lack.

en: “That’s right, that’s right.
vi: − Good, good.
tr: "Ah, like this, now it's perfect.
es: —Very good!

en: Courage!
vi: Be brave!
tr: Courage!
es: Like that...! Much courage!

en: Business!
vi: It's work time!
tr: Work!
es: Business and nothing but business!

en: You have business before you; useful business.
vi: You have work to take care of; important work.
tr: Work comes first; useful work.
es: A business presents itself, a positive business, with returns.

en: Miss Manette, your mother took this course with you.
vi: Miss Manette, your mother decided this for you.
tr: Miss Manette, your mother struggled a lot in her time.
es: Your mother, Miss Manette, adopted with you the code of conduct that I previously hinted at.

en: And when she died—I believe broken-hearted—having never slackened her unavailing search for your father, she left you, at two years old, to grow to be blooming, beautiful, and happy, without the dark cloud upon you of living in uncertainty whether your father soon wore his heart out in prison, or wasted there through many lingering years.”
vi: And until she passed away... surely with a broken heart... she never stopped searching for your father in vain, leaving you, then just two years old, to grow up fresh, beautiful, and happy, with a life unclouded by the worry of whether your father had perished early in prison or was languishing there for many years.
tr: Until the last moment, she never gave up searching for your father in vain, and when she died – who knows what great sorrows she was in, poor woman – you were two years old, and for all those years, without worrying whether your father was rotting in prisons or had already perished, you grew up as a cheerful and beautiful girl."
es: When she died... I believe from sorrow... without having ceased for a moment to search for her husband, and without ever finding out anything, she left you, a two-year-old girl, on the path to grow up beautiful, happy, without sorrows, free from the dark cloud that would have embittered your existence, if at her death she had revealed to you the story of your father, without being able to add whether he had died in prison or if he continued to be buried in the dungeon, suffering the tortures of being buried alive.

en: As he said the words he looked down, with an admiring pity, on the flowing golden hair; as if he pictured to himself that it might have been already tinged with grey.
vi: When he uttered those words, he looked down at Manette's flowing blonde hair with an expression of both admiration and pity, as if he were silently imagining that her hair might already have many strands of gray.
tr: After finishing his sentence, he looked at the girl's long golden hair with a mixture of admiration and compassion; as if he were imagining those hairs with streaks of gray.
es: He uttered the last words, casting a gaze of infinite compassion upon the golden hair before him, as if telling himself that, thanks to the compassionate discretion of the mother, those strands did not yet abound with silver threads.

en: “You know that your parents had no great possession, and that what they had was secured to your mother and to you.
vi: − Surely you know that your parents do not have much wealth, and whatever they had has been entirely devoted to you and your mother.
tr: "You know that your family doesn't have much wealth, and what they do have is already in your and your mother's name.
es: —You know perfectly well that your parents did not enjoy a great fortune, and that what they possessed passed to your mother and you.

en: There has been no new discovery, of money, or of any other property; but—”
vi: There has been no new discovery regarding money or any other assets; but...
tr: There hasn't been any newly discovered money or property or anything; but-"
es: As far as money and material goods are concerned, no new discoveries have been made; but...

en: He felt his wrist held closer, and he stopped.
vi: He felt his wrist being squeezed tighter, and he stopped speaking.
tr: Mr. Lorry felt the girl's hand grasp his wrist even tighter and fell silent.
es: The narrator felt delicate hands forcefully gripping his wrists, and he stopped speaking.

en: The expression in the forehead, which had so particularly attracted his notice, and which was now immovable, had deepened into one of pain and horror.
vi: The wrinkle on that forehead, which had particularly caught his attention, now became immobile, etched deeply into a terrifying pain.
tr: The special expression that had previously caught his attention had settled firmly on the girl's forehead, now accompanied by pain and fear.
es: The expression on the girl's face was one of sorrow and horror.

en: “But he has been—been found.
vi: − But he... they found him.
tr: "But – but now he has been found.
es: —But he has been found... him.

en: He is alive.
vi: He is still alive.
tr: He is alive.
es: He lives, yes... very changed... I consider it probable; shattered, a wreck, reduced to a shadow of what he was... it's possible; but he lives, and we must harbor hopes that he will improve.

en: Greatly changed, it is too probable; almost a wreck, it is possible; though we will hope the best.
vi: Changed a lot, perhaps; almost an invalid, possibly; even so, we must hope for the best, still alive.
tr: He must have changed a lot, naturally; he is probably in a ruined state; but let's look at the bright side of things.
es: He lives, yes... very changed... I consider it probable; shattered, a wreck, reduced to a shadow of what he was... it's possible; but he lives, and we must harbor hopes that he will improve.

en: Still, alive.
vi: Changed a lot, perhaps; almost an invalid, possibly; even so, we must hope for the best, still alive.
tr: At least he is still alive.
es: He lives, yes... very changed... I consider it probable; shattered, a wreck, reduced to a shadow of what he was... it's possible; but he lives, and we must harbor hopes that he will improve.

en: Your father has been taken to the house of an old servant in Paris, and we are going there: I, to identify him if I can: you, to restore him to life, love, duty, rest, comfort.”
vi: Your father has been taken to an old servant's house in Paris, and we will go there. My job is to correctly identify him, if possible; your job is to bring him life, love, filial duty, peace, and comfort.
tr: Your father is now staying in Paris, at the house of an old servant of his, and we are going there. I, if I can, to identify him, and you, to give him life, love, responsibility, comfort, and peace again."
es: His father has been taken to the house of a former servant of his, who resides in Paris, and we are going to meet him: I, to identify him, if I can; you, to embrace him, to restore his life, affection, calm, and rest.

en: A shiver ran through her frame, and from it through his.
vi: A shiver ran through her body, and it spread to him as well.
tr: The young girl's body shivered, and so did the man's.
es: The girl shuddered from head to toe.

en: She said, in a low, distinct, awe-stricken voice, as if she were saying it in a dream,
vi: She spoke in a low, halting voice, full of fear as if she were speaking in a dream: −
tr: As if in a dream, the girl spoke in a low, deep, and fearful voice:
es: Trembling, moved, with a strange voice, like someone speaking in a dream, she said:

en: “I am going to see his Ghost!
vi: We will see the ghost of my father!
tr: "So, I will see his ghost!"
es: —I'm going to see his ghost!... His ghost!...

en: It will be his Ghost—not him!”
vi: It will be the ghost of my father... not my father himself!
tr: "It really can't be him – It must be his ghost!""
es: Not him!

en: mr Lorry quietly chafed the hands that held his arm.
vi: Mr. Lorry quietly stroked the hands that were clinging to his arm.
tr: Mr. Lorry quietly rubbed the girl's hands that were holding his arm.
es: Lorry gently detached the hands that were gripping his arm.

en: “There, there, there!
vi: − There, there, there!
tr: "Hold on, hold on!
es: —Calm down, calm down, miss! —he said.

en: See now, see now!
vi: It's clear now, it's clear!
tr: Let's see what we'll see, how we'll see it!
es: —It's all over now.

en: The best and the worst are known to you, now.
vi: You now know the best and the worst things.
tr: Now you know everything.
es: You know all the good and all the bad.

en: You are well on your way to the poor wronged gentleman, and, with a fair sea voyage, and a fair land journey, you will be soon at his dear side.”
vi: You must set out to meet that poor wronged gentleman, just one peaceful sea voyage and another peaceful land journey, and you will soon be with your loved one.
tr: To see your poor father who has been wronged, we will first travel by sea and then by land, and very soon you will be by your dear father's side."
es: Let's go meet the unfortunate knight, unjustly punished, and after a happy sea voyage, followed by another no less fortunate by land, you will very soon have the sweet pleasure of embracing him.

en: She repeated in the same tone, sunk to a whisper, “I have been free, I have been happy, yet his Ghost has never haunted me!”
vi: The girl repeated the old tone, this time like a whisper: − I have lived freely, I have lived joyfully, but my father's ghost has never haunted me!
tr: The young girl continued in the same tone, her voice turning into a whisper, "How free, how happy I was, my father's ghost had never appeared to me!"
es: —I have lived peacefully, I have lived happily, and his ghost has never haunted me! —exclaimed the girl with the same tone of voice as before.

en: “Only one thing more,” said mr Lorry, laying stress upon it as a wholesome means of enforcing her attention: “he has been found under another name; his own, long forgotten or long concealed.
vi: − One more thing, - Mr. Lorry said, emphasizing each word with the good intention that the girl must listen, - they have found your father under another name; his real name has been forgotten or kept hidden for a long time.
tr: To draw the girl's attention to his words, Mr. Lorry emphasized, "There is one more thing," he said, "your father was found under another name; his own name had long been forgotten or hidden.
es: —Lend me another observation—replied Lorry, emphasizing the word, undoubtedly to ensure the attention of his listener. When they found him, he was using another name. His own, either they forgot it a long time ago, or someone has had an interest in hiding it.

en: It would be worse than useless now to inquire which; worse than useless to seek to know whether he has been for years overlooked, or always designedly held prisoner.
vi: Now, asking for the name wouldn't be of any benefit; asking who was negligent or intentionally kept him imprisoned all these years wouldn't be of any benefit either.
tr: Whether he was overlooked in prison all these years or deliberately kept, it is best not to delve too deeply.
es: It would be worse than useless to try to find out if one or the other occurred: it would be worse than useless to try to inquire if they forgot about him, or if deliberately and intentionally they have kept him imprisoned for so many years: it would be worse than useless to conduct any kind of investigation, and it would be, because besides being useless, we would expose ourselves to great dangers.

en: It would be worse than useless now to make any inquiries, because it would be dangerous.
vi: Now, asking anything would do more harm than good.
tr: Investigating the reasons for this could be dangerous.
es: It would be worse than useless to try to find out if one or the other occurred: it would be worse than useless to try to inquire if they forgot about him, or if deliberately and intentionally they have kept him imprisoned for so many years: it would be worse than useless to conduct any kind of investigation, and it would be, because besides being useless, we would expose ourselves to great dangers.

en: Better not to mention the subject, anywhere or in any way, and to remove him—for a while at all events—out of France.
vi: It is best not to bring that matter up, anywhere, in any form, he must be taken out of France... at least for a while.
tr: Let's not discuss this matter anywhere, in any way, and let's get him out of France as soon as possible –by any means necessary– We must get him out of France.
es: It is preferable a thousand times not to even speak of the matter, and to get his father out of France.

en: Even I, safe as an Englishman, and even Tellson’s, important as they are to French credit, avoid all naming of the matter.
vi: Even I, being safe because I am a British citizen, and even this Tellson's Bank, despite its powerful influence due to its high reputation with the French, avoid bringing up this matter.
tr: Even though I am safe as an Englishman, and even Tellson, whom the French hold in high regard, avoids talking about this matter.
es: I myself, despite being shielded from such dangers by being an English citizen, and even the Tellson Bank, with all the importance it has in France, do not dare to even mention the matter.

en: I carry about me, not a scrap of writing openly referring to it.
vi: I do not carry a single piece of paper that directly mentions this matter.
tr: I do not carry even the smallest piece of paper related to this matter with me.
es: I do not carry a single line, a single written word that clearly refers to him.

en: This is a secret service altogether.
vi: This is entirely a secret operation.
tr: It is a completely confidential matter.
es: In a word: it is a secret.

en: My credentials, entries, and memoranda, are all comprehended in the one line, ‘Recalled to Life;’ which may mean anything.
vi: All the authorizations, guarantees, and confirmations given to me are encapsulated in one phrase "resurrection," interpret it as you will.
tr: All my documents, records, and notes are hidden in a single line; "Recalled to Life"; this can mean anything.
es: All the credentials that authorize me to resolve it, all the instructions I have received as an agent, are reduced to a single word: "Resurrected"...

en: But what is the matter!
vi: But saying it is as good as saying nothing!
tr: But what happened to you?
es: But what is this!...

en: She doesn’t notice a word!
vi: She wouldn't listen anyway!
tr: Ah, she doesn't hear me at all!
es: She hasn't heard a word of what I've been saying!

en: Miss Manette!”
vi: Miss Manette!
tr: Miss Manette?"
es: Miss Manette!

en: Perfectly still and silent, and not even fallen back in her chair, she sat under his hand, utterly insensible; with her eyes open and fixed upon him, and with that last expression looking as if it were carved or branded into her forehead.
vi: Sitting still like a statue, not even leaning back in the chair, still clinging to his arm but Manette had completely fainted; her eyes still wide open looking at him, the final look of astonishment seemed to be carved or deeply etched into her forehead.
tr: The young girl had turned to stone, she didn't even slump in her chair, sitting there completely numb under Mr. Lorry's hand; she stared at the man with eyes wide open, as if this final expression was etched or branded on her forehead.
es: The girl remained in the chair, perfectly still, perfectly calm, perfectly silent, perfectly upright, perfectly insensible, her eyes open and fixed on Lorry's face, but with that singular expression that the eyes sculpted under the forehead of a statue have.

en: So close was her hold upon his arm, that he feared to detach himself lest he should hurt her; therefore he called out loudly for assistance without moving.
vi: Manette clung tightly to Mr. Lorry's arm to the point that he feared he would hurt her if he tried to remove her hand; so he had to endure and loudly called for help.
tr: The young girl held onto his arm so tightly that Mr. Lorry couldn't move for fear of hurting her and called out for help.
es: Her fingers continued to grip his arm with such force that he did not dare to release them for fear of hurting her, for which reason he shouted for help, but without moving.

en: A wild-looking woman, whom even in his agitation, mr Lorry observed to be all of a red colour, and to have red hair, and to be dressed in some extraordinary tight-fitting fashion, and to have on her head a most wonderful bonnet like a Grenadier wooden measure, and good measure too, or a great Stilton cheese, came running into the room in advance of the inn servants, and soon settled the question of his detachment from the poor young lady, by laying a brawny hand upon his chest, and sending him flying back against the nearest wall.
vi: A coarse-looking woman barged into the room ahead of the group of servants in the inn. Even in his bewildered state, Mr. Lorry noticed that she was entirely red, from her red hair to her unusually tight-fitting attire, and the enormous bonnet on her head that looked both like a guard's helmet and a large wooden grain measure, or a big round of cheese. This person immediately resolved the issue of separating the old man from the poor young girl by placing a strong hand on his chest and shoving him back against the nearest wall.
tr: A strange-looking woman entered with hotel staff behind her; even in his flustered state, Mr. Lorry noticed that the woman was dressed entirely in red, had red hair, and was wearing a peculiar tight outfit with a massive hat on her head that looked like either a soldier's cap or a large wheel of cheese. Mr. Lorry's problem of being unable to move from his spot was resolved when the woman pushed him against the nearest wall with her strong hand.
es: At the shouts, a woman of fierce appearance came running, red from head to toe, for red was the color of her face, red her hair, red her dress, red the monumental hat, similar to those worn by grenadiers or to an enormous Stilton cheese. Hot on the heels of the woman, who burst into the room, came all the maids of the inn. The first woman used little courtesy to solve the conflict of freeing Lorry's arm from the fingers that, clenched, held it, for with the first slap struck against the chest of the gentleman from Tellson's Bank, she sent him crashing against the nearest wall.

en: (“I really think this must be a man!” was mr Lorry’s breathless reflection, simultaneously with his coming against the wall.)
vi: ("What kind of woman is as strong as a man!" That was Mr. Lorry's thought as he crashed into the wall, almost out of breath.) −
tr: (When Mr. Lorry was pressed against the wall, breathless, he thought to himself, "This must be a man!")
es: —That woman is a man!

en: “Why, look at you all!” bawled this figure, addressing the inn servants.
vi: Hey, look at you all! - She shouted at the helpers.
tr: This person shouted at the servants, "Hey, why are you staring like that?"
es: —Lorry murmured to himself, as he bumped into the wall.

en: “Why don’t you go and fetch things, instead of standing there staring at me?
vi: - Why aren't you getting the necessary things and just standing there staring at me?
tr: "Instead of just standing there and staring, go and bring something!
es: —What are you looking for here, you silly girls?—roared the red woman, addressing the maids.—Why don't you go scrub, instead of standing there, staring at me like idiots?

en: I am not so much to look at, am I?
vi: What's there to look at?
tr: As if there's something to look at!
es: Am I some kind of monkey, by any chance?

en: Why don’t you go and fetch things?
vi: Why aren't you getting the things?
tr: Hurry up!
es: Get to work!

en: I’ll let you know, if you don’t bring smelling-salts, cold water, and vinegar, quick, I will.”
vi: I'm telling you, if you don't bring salt to smell, cold water, and vinegar here quickly, I'll go get them myself.
tr: Bring me ammonia spirit, cold water, vinegar immediately, or you'll regret it!"
es: You will soon know who I am if you don't bring me salts, cold water, vinegar, and everything else I need right away!

en: There was an immediate dispersal for these restoratives, and she softly laid the patient on a sofa, and tended her with great skill and gentleness: calling her “my precious!” and “my bird!” and spreading her golden hair aside over her shoulders with great pride and care.
vi: The servants immediately dispersed to fetch items to help revive her, while she gently laid Manette on the couch, tending to her with utmost skill and tenderness, constantly calling her "darling!" and "dear!" and proudly and carefully smoothing the girl's flowing blonde hair over her shoulders.
tr: They all scattered around like chicks to bring things to revive the girl, and he laid the young girl on the couch and attended to her with great skill and gentleness. He called her "my precious!" and "my bird!" and with great pride and care, he brushed her golden hair back.
es: The dispersion was general and immediate. The maids flew in search of the requested restoratives, while the red matron placed the patient on a sofa with great skill and gentleness, calling her "precious," "my little daughter," "dove," etc., etc.

en: “And you in brown!” she said, indignantly turning to mr Lorry; “couldn’t you tell her what you had to tell her, without frightening her to death?
vi: − And you, the man in the brown coat! - She angrily turned back to Mr. Lorry. - If there's something worth saying, then say it, but why scare her to death like this?
tr: Turning to Mr. Lorry, he said angrily, "You with the brown coat! Couldn't you have said what you had to say without scaring her so much?
es: —And you, you brute—she shouted next, turning furiously against Mr. Lorry,—couldn't you tell her your famous story without scaring her to death? Look at how you've made her!

en: Look at her, with her pretty pale face and her cold hands.
vi: Look at her, her face is pale, and her hands are ice-cold.
tr: Look at her, the poor thing's beautiful face has turned completely white, and her hands are ice cold.
es: Pale as a corpse, cold as ice!

en: Do you call that being a Banker?”
vi: How can a bank employee act like that?
tr: Is this how banking is done?"
es: Aren't you ashamed to call yourself a banker?

en: mr Lorry was so exceedingly disconcerted by a question so hard to answer, that he could only look on, at a distance, with much feebler sympathy and humility, while the strong woman, having banished the inn servants under the mysterious penalty of “letting them know” something not mentioned if they stayed there, staring, recovered her charge by a regular series of gradations, and coaxed her to lay her drooping head upon her shoulder.
vi: Mr. Lorry became flustered by the difficult question, to the point that he could only stand from a distance, looking on with a sympathetic and humble expression, trying to suppress his emotions while the strong woman, after driving away the servants with a mysterious threat of punishment - "I'll show you" - without clarifying what they would know if they dared to stand there staring, continued her task of gradually reviving Manette and comforting the girl who had her head resting on her shoulder.
tr: Mr. Lorry was so flustered by this difficult question that he could do nothing but look on with a feeble interest and humility. Meanwhile, the strong woman who had dispersed the servants with the threat of showing them "what's what" if they continued to stand around, had gradually calmed the girl and managed to get her to rest her drooping head on her shoulder.
es: To such an extent did Mr. Lorry become bewildered by a question so difficult to answer, that he could do nothing but look from afar with an expression of extraordinary sympathy and humility, while the tremendous woman, after once again driving away the servants who had returned with water, vinegar, and salts, under the mysterious penalty of "letting them know something she had no reason to mention" if they continued staring at her in amazement, set to work and managed, after a long time, to get the girl to begin showing signs of life.

en: “I hope she will do well now,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Hopefully, she has recovered, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "I think he's coming to," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —It seems that he is feeling better—observed Mr. Lorry.

en: “No thanks to you in brown, if she does.
vi: − Even if I recover, it won't be thanks to that man in the brown robe.
tr: "Not thanks to you but the one in brown.
es: —But it won't be because of what you have done—replied the matron harshly.

en: My darling pretty!”
vi: Oh, little girl!
tr: Poor little thing!"
es: — My daughter!

en: “I hope,” said mr Lorry, after another pause of feeble sympathy and humility, “that you accompany Miss Manette to France?”
vi: − I hope, - Mr. Lorry continued after a moment of compassionate and humble hesitation, - that you can accompany Miss Manette to France, right? − Such sweet talk! -
tr: "I hope," said Mr. Lorry, pausing again with faint interest and humility, "that you will agree to accompany Miss Manette to France?""
es: —Would you have any objection—asked Lorry with great humility, after a few moments—to accompanying her to France?

en: “A likely thing, too!” replied the strong woman.
vi: The strong woman retorted.
tr: "Look at this!" said the strong woman.
es: —You don't know how to say anything but nonsense!

en: “If it was ever intended that I should go across salt water, do you suppose Providence would have cast my lot in an island?”
vi: - If my fate forces me to cross the sea and go abroad, would God banish me to some island?
tr: "If it were my destiny to cross this salty water, would God have placed me on this island?"
es: If Providence had arranged for me to ever cross the pond, do you think it would have made me be born on an island?

en: This being another question hard to answer, mr Jarvis Lorry withdrew to consider it.
vi: This was yet another difficult question to answer, so Mr. Jarvis Lorry had to retreat to his private room to ponder.
tr: The woman had asked another difficult question to answer, and Mr. Jarvis Lorry left them to ponder it.
es: As answering such a question was also extremely difficult, Mr. Maurice Lorry thought it best to withdraw to ponder.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: 5. Tavern
tr: V
es: V.

en: The Wine-shop
vi: A large barrel of wine fell and broke on the street.
tr: Wine Shop
es: THE TAVERN

en: A large cask of wine had been dropped and broken, in the street.
vi: A large barrel of wine fell and broke on the street.
tr: A large wine barrel had fallen and broken in the street; the barrel had rolled, its hoop had come off, and it lay in front of the wine shop's door, shattered like a walnut shell.
es: A barrel of wine had fallen in the street, breaking into pieces.

en: The accident had happened in getting it out of a cart; the cask had tumbled out with a run, the hoops had burst, and it lay on the stones just outside the door of the wine-shop, shattered like a walnut-shell.
vi: While it was being unloaded from the cart, the incident occurred; the barrel rolled too quickly, the hoops came loose, and it shattered like a walnut shell on the stone pavement in front of the tavern.
tr: A large wine barrel had fallen and broken in the street; the barrel had rolled, its hoop had come off, and it lay in front of the wine shop's door, shattered like a walnut shell.
es: The accident occurred while taking the barrel out of a cart. It fell to the ground, began to roll, the hoops jumped off, and it burst open like the shell of a monstrous nut in front of the door of a tavern.

en: All the people within reach had suspended their business, or their idleness, to run to the spot and drink the wine.
vi: Everyone nearby immediately stopped their work or ceased idling to rush over and drink the wine on the spot.
tr: Everyone around had left their work or laziness to come to the scene to drink wine.
es: All the people in the vicinity suspended their tasks or ended their idleness to run to the scene of the accident and drink the wine.

en: The rough, irregular stones of the street, pointing every way, and designed, one might have thought, expressly to lame all living creatures that approached them, had dammed it into little pools; these were surrounded, each by its own jostling group or crowd, according to its size.
vi: The rough, uneven, and sharp-edged paving stones, seemingly arranged solely to cripple any living creature that approached, blocked the flowing wine, forming small puddles; around each puddle, people gathered, crowding in groups depending on the size of the puddle.
tr: The rough and irregular stones of the street, facing different directions, gave the impression that they were designed specifically to cripple every living being passing over them; the spilled wine had formed puddles among the stones, and at the head of each puddle, there was a crowd jostling proportionally to its size.
es: The rough, uneven, and pointed stones that made up the cobblestones of the street, seemingly placed on purpose to make as many limping people as fortunate mortals who had the luck to pass over them, had distributed the red liquid, forming a variety of ponds of different sizes, all of which were surrounded by larger or smaller groups, depending on their extent.

en: Some men kneeled down, made scoops of their two hands joined, and sipped, or tried to help women, who bent over their shoulders, to sip, before the wine had all run out between their fingers.
vi: Some knelt down, cupping their hands to scoop up the wine and sip it; or raised their hands high to let some women leaning over their shoulders drink before the wine trickled through their fingers.
tr: Some men were kneeling, using their cupped hands to drink the wine before it could slip through their fingers, either drinking it themselves or helping the women leaning over their shoulders to drink.
es: Many men, lying face down, collected the wine in the hollow of their hands and drank, or made the women who eagerly leaned over their shoulders drink, before the liquid escaped through their fingers.

en: Others, men and women, dipped in the puddles with little mugs of mutilated earthenware, or even with handkerchiefs from women’s heads, which were squeezed dry into infants’ mouths; others made small mud-embankments, to stem the wine as it ran; others, directed by lookers-on up at high windows, darted here and there, to cut off little streams of wine that started away in new directions; others devoted themselves to the sodden and lee-dyed pieces of the cask, licking, and even champing the moister wine-rotted fragments with eager relish.
vi: Others, both men and women, dipped chipped earthenware cups into the puddles; or even soaked their headscarves in the liquid to wring it into the mouths of infants they were carrying; some scooped up mud to build barriers to stop the wine from spreading; some, following the instructions of those watching from high windows, ran around to redirect the flow of wine that had started to move in another direction; some focused solely on licking the wet remnants of wine from broken barrel pieces, even gleefully gnawing on the damp, wine-soaked wood.
tr: Another group of men and women, with cracked earthenware in their hands, were huddled around the puddles; some women even dipped their headscarves into the wine and squeezed it into their babies' mouths; some were busy making small dams out of mud to prevent the wine from flowing away; some were running back and forth following the words of those watching from the windows above to block the small streams of wine; some, in a state of ecstasy, were licking the soaked barrel pieces, even gnawing on the wooden pieces that had absorbed the wine with great appetite.
es: Others, men and women, collected it with small earthenware vessels or soaked the women's headscarves, which they then wrung out into their mouths or those of the children: some built mud dams to stop the flow of the wine, while others, following the shouted advice from onlookers at the windows, jumped here and there to divert the course of new streams, and there were even those who, seizing the half-rotten fragments of the barrel, sucked and licked them with indescribable anxiety.

en: There was no drainage to carry off the wine, and not only did it all get taken up, but so much mud got taken up along with it, that there might have been a scavenger in the street, if anybody acquainted with it could have believed in such a miraculous presence.
vi: With no drains for the wine to escape, people not only drank all the spilled wine but also swallowed the mud carried along with it, cleaning it up so thoroughly that one might think a street sweeper had just passed by, if anyone familiar with this impoverished neighborhood could believe in such a miraculous occurrence.
tr: There was no channel for the wine to flow through, and quite a bit of mud was swallowed along with the wine; the place was as clean as if a street sweeper had passed through, so much so that anyone who saw it could believe that this miraculous event had taken place.
es: It can be assured that the crowds collected not only the last drop of wine but also the last molecule of earth that had come into contact with it. The street was left as if all the city's street-sweeping brigades had just passed through, if the city had known the brilliant institution of street sweepers.

en: A shrill sound of laughter and of amused voices—voices of men, women, and children—resounded in the street while this wine game lasted.
vi: The loud laughter, the enthusiastic voices - men's, women's, and children's alike - made the street lively with this drinking game.
tr: Throughout this wine game, the street – filled with the voices of men, women, and children – echoed with cheerful laughter and screams.
es: While the fun of the wine lasted, the street was filled with the clamor of joyful laughter and shouts of jubilation, launched by dozens of throats of men, women, and children.

en: There was little roughness in the sport, and much playfulness.
vi: A game that is somewhat crude but full of joy.
tr: There was a bit of roughness and plenty of clowning around involved.
es: The distraction was a bit crude and very lively.

en: There was a special companionship in it, an observable inclination on the part of every one to join some other one, which led, especially among the luckier or lighter-hearted, to frolicsome embraces, drinking of healths, shaking of hands, and even joining of hands and dancing, a dozen together.
vi: A game with a special camaraderie, clearly everyone is eager to join in; especially for those who are carefree or luckier than others, this camaraderie urges them to embrace each other joyfully; toast to health; shake hands; even a dozen people might hold hands and dance.
tr: A completely different sense of camaraderie enveloped everything; they acted with the instinct to move together, and those who were more cheerful and carefree among them were always entwined, drinking to each other's health, shaking hands, and forming circles to dance.
es: Those who took part in it showed a special tendency towards affinities and confidences, which resulted in toasts of questionable taste, handshakes, hugs, and whimsical dances, in which those who had drunk the most, or those of a more jovial and fun character, took special part.

en: When the wine was gone, and the places where it had been most abundant were raked into a gridiron-pattern by fingers, these demonstrations ceased, as suddenly as they had broken out.
vi: When the wine is gone, and the places with the most wine left are just streaks of fingers scraping, this lively gathering ends as abruptly as it began.
tr: When the wine ran out and the ponds were replaced by grill-like fingerprint marks, the commotion ended as suddenly as it had begun.
es: When the wine ran out, and the stones and earth that had been soaked were dry and clean, the demonstrations of joy ceased as abruptly as they had begun.

en: The man who had left his saw sticking in the firewood he was cutting, set it in motion again; the women who had left on a door-step the little pot of hot ashes, at which she had been trying to soften the pain in her own starved fingers and toes, or in those of her child, returned to it; men with bare arms, matted locks, and cadaverous faces, who had emerged into the winter light from cellars, moved away, to descend again; and a gloom gathered on the scene that appeared more natural to it than sunshine.
vi: The man who earlier left the saw stuck in the log now resumes sawing; the woman who earlier hastily put down the jar of hot ashes to soothe the aching, bony fingers and toes of herself or her children now picks up the jar again; the few men in sleeveless shirts, with disheveled hair and haggard faces who had come up from the basements to warm themselves in the winter sun now disperse and return to the basement; and the scene once again sinks into its familiar gloom rather than remaining cheerful.
tr: The man who had left his saw on the wood he was cutting returned to his work; the woman who had left the ash-filled bucket she used to ease the aching hunger of her and her child's fingers outside her door returned to her brazier; the bare-armed, disheveled-haired, pale-faced men who had come out of their cellars into the winter sun went back down again, and a gloom that seemed much more natural than the recent daylight settled over the surroundings.
