es: The individual who had left his saw leaning against the log he was sawing, grabbed it and set it in motion again; the woman who had left her pot cooking in front of her house door, returned to attend to it; the men with bare arms, dirty hair, and cadaverous faces who had emerged into the daylight minutes before, descended once again into the depths of the dark caves, and the shadows enveloped with their mantle a scene that, in reality, was painful to behold in the light of the sun.

en: The wine was red wine, and had stained the ground of the narrow street in the suburb of Saint Antoine, in Paris, where it was spilled.
vi: Wine is the red wine that has dyed the narrow street of Saint Antoine district in Paris red.
tr: The spilled red wine had painted the narrow street in the suburb of St. Antoine in Paris red.
es: The wine that the shattered barrel contained was red, and it stained the narrow street of the San Antonio suburb where it had spilled.

en: It had stained many hands, too, and many faces, and many naked feet, and many wooden shoes.
vi: Wine also dyed many hands and faces, many bare feet and many wooden shoes red.
tr: Of course, it had also stained many people's hands, faces, bare feet, and wooden clogs.
es: It also stained many hands and many faces and many bare feet and many clogs.

en: The hands of the man who sawed the wood, left red marks on the billets; and the forehead of the woman who nursed her baby, was stained with the stain of the old rag she wound about her head again.
vi: The woodcutter's hand left red marks on the logs; the forehead of the breastfeeding mother was stained red by the wine that soaked the rag now wrapped around her head.
tr: Red stains had formed on the handle of the saw of the man cutting wood; the forehead of the woman feeding her baby was stained because of the old cloth she had wrapped around her head again.
es: The hands of the man who was sawing the log left reddish marks on the boards, and the forehead of the woman who was nursing her tender child was also stained when it collided with the forehead of the old witch with whom she embraced and danced in moments of fleeting joy.

en: Those who had been greedy with the staves of the cask, had acquired a tigerish smear about the mouth; and one tall joker so besmirched, his head more out of a long squalid bag of a nightcap than in it, scrawled upon a wall with his finger dipped in muddy wine-lees—blood.
vi: Those who had eagerly gnawed on the wine barrel pieces now had fiercely red-streaked mouths; and a mischievous person, also smeared red with a filthy long nightcap almost falling off his head, dipped his finger into the mushy wine residue and scrawled a word on the wall - BLOOD.
tr: The wine marks were still visible at the corners of the mouths of those bloodthirsty people who had attacked the barrel planks with greed, and a tall fool, whose clothes were filthy and whose nightcap, resembling a dirty sack, was almost falling off his head, had written this on the wall with his finger smeared with mud and wine: BLOOD.
es: Those who eagerly seized the remnants of the barrel and sucked and licked them, left the revelry with reddish circles on their mouths that gave them the appearance of fierce tigers, and there was one, undoubtedly more fond of jokes than the others, who with his finger dipped in the mixture formed by the mud and the wine, scrawled the word blood on the wall.

en: The time was to come, when that wine too would be spilled on the street-stones, and when the stain of it would be red upon many there.
vi: Then there will come a time when that red liquid will also flow over the stone road, and it will also soak many people there.
tr: The days when this type of wine would flow in the streets and its stain would cover everything were near.
es: The day would come when blood would be spilled in torrents, and many of those who took part in the aforementioned diversion would be drenched in blood from head to toe!

en: And now that the cloud settled on Saint Antoine, which a momentary gleam had driven from his sacred countenance, the darkness of it was heavy—cold, dirt, sickness, ignorance, and want, were the lords in waiting on the saintly presence—nobles of great power all of them; but, most especially the last.
vi: And now the fog has covered Saint Antoine after a brief moment of brightness, the face of the neighborhood named after the saint* is once again as dark as before with cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and poverty - the five companions of the saint, each powerful, but the last one is the most dreadful.
tr: Now a huge cloud had covered St. Antoine, and although a light briefly escaped from his holy bulk, the predominant element was a dense darkness – and the cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and hunger that accompanied this saintly being – each was almost a powerful noble; especially the last one.
es: Once the street of San Antonio returned to its usual state and condition, from which it had been momentarily taken by a fortuitous incident, it remained sad, dark, and gloomy, groaning under the scepter of cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and hunger, all of them powerful nobles, but particularly the one mentioned last.

en: Samples of a people that had undergone a terrible grinding and regrinding in the mill, and certainly not in the fabulous mill which ground old people young, shivered at every corner, passed in and out at every doorway, looked from every window, fluttered in every vestige of a garment that the wind shook.
vi: At every street corner, entering every threshold, standing in every window, wrapped in every ragged garment fluttering in the wind, are the people who have been crushed and ground in the machine of poverty.
tr: Examples of people, ground repeatedly in a mill – and this was certainly not a mill that rejuvenated the old – were shivering at every corner, entering and exiting every door, looking out of every window, fluttering under every garment played by the wind.
es: In every corner, one could see crouched figures of the unfortunate who had been pressed and crushed one hundred times over by the heavy stones of the mill, shivering from the cold and collapsing from hunger.

en: The mill which had worked them down, was the mill that grinds young people old; the children had ancient faces and grave voices; and upon them, and upon the grown faces, and ploughed into every furrow of age and coming up afresh, was the sigh, Hunger.
vi: The machine that molded them is a machine that turns the young into the old; children with elderly faces and serious voices; and on every face, both young and old, deeply etched in the wrinkles of age, there is a glaring sign: Hunger.
tr: The mill that ground them was a mill that aged the young; the faces of children looked old, and their voices were serious. And on these adult faces, in every line progressing like the mark of a plow, the same thing was seen, Hunger.
es: The mill that had crushed them was not that fabulous mill that has the property of turning the old into young people full of life, but the one that turns the young into old. The boys had the faces of old men, and the children had deep and grave voices.

en: It was prevalent everywhere.
vi: Hunger is evident everywhere.
tr: Hunger was everywhere.
es: Their backs bent under the weight, not of years, but of hunger, which was the mistress and lady of those neighborhoods.

en: Hunger was pushed out of the tall houses, in the wretched clothing that hung upon poles and lines; Hunger was patched into them with straw and rag and wood and paper; Hunger was repeated in every fragment of the small modicum of firewood that the man sawed off; Hunger stared down from the smokeless chimneys, and started up from the filthy street that had no offal, among its refuse, of anything to eat.
vi: Hunger oozes from the tall houses, in the tattered clothes hanging on poles and lines; hunger patched, mended, combined, and glued together with straw, rags, wood, and paper; hunger manifests itself in every splinter of wood from the sawyer; hunger glares down from the smokeless chimneys, strides along the filthy, garbage-strewn streets where not a single edible scrap can be found.
tr: It hung from the miserable clothes thrown out of high buildings, lined up in rows; Hunger was patched into these with straw, rags, wood splinters, and paper; it showed itself in every piece of wood the man cut with his saw. Hunger stared out from the chimneys that did not smoke, stood tall in the filthy street where there wasn't a single crumb of food in the garbage.
es: Hunger was the word repeated in all the houses, hunger the fateful phantom mounted on the miserable rags hanging from poles or ropes stretched in front of the filthy shacks, hunger repeated all the fragments of sawdust falling under the carpenter's saw, hunger the dreadful monster that, finding no filth in the streets to feed on, climbed to the top of the chimneys, which also offered no smoke to its voracity; hunger was the inscription read in the shelves of all the bakers, hunger the word stamped on all the breads, expensive, of poor quality, and lacking in weight.

en: Hunger was the inscription on the baker’s shelves, written in every small loaf of his scanty stock of bad bread; at the sausage-shop, in every dead-dog preparation that was offered for sale.
vi: Hunger carves its name on the shelves of the baker, writes on each tiny, stale loaf of bread in the meager stock; leaves its mark at the sausage shop selling concoctions made from dead dog meat.
tr: Hunger was an inscription on the shelves of the bakeries, written over the few remaining dry loaves of bread; it was in the shop where sausages made from rotten meat were sold.
es: Hunger was the word repeated in all the houses, hunger the fateful phantom mounted on the miserable rags hanging from poles or ropes stretched in front of the filthy shacks, hunger repeated all the fragments of sawdust falling under the carpenter's saw, hunger the dreadful monster that, finding no filth in the streets to feed on, climbed to the top of the chimneys, which also offered no smoke to its voracity; hunger was the inscription read in the shelves of all the bakers, hunger the word stamped on all the breads, expensive, of poor quality, and lacking in weight.

en: Hunger rattled its dry bones among the roasting chestnuts in the turned cylinder; Hunger was shred into atomics in every farthing porringer of husky chips of potato, fried with some reluctant drops of oil.
vi: Hunger crackles, rattling through the dry bones among the roasted chestnuts in the oven; hunger disintegrates into atoms in the low-grade bowls containing slices of unpeeled potatoes, fried with a few precious drops of oil.
tr: Hunger rattled its dry bones among the chestnuts cooking in the cylindrical stove; it spread over every slice of potato frying with a few reluctant drops of oil.
es: Hunger was the word repeated in all the houses, hunger the fateful phantom mounted on the miserable rags hanging from poles or ropes stretched in front of the filthy shacks, hunger repeated all the fragments of sawdust falling under the carpenter's saw, hunger the dreadful monster that, finding no filth in the streets to feed on, climbed to the top of the chimneys, which also offered no smoke to its voracity; hunger was the inscription read in the shelves of all the bakers, hunger the word stamped on all the breads, expensive, of poor quality, and lacking in weight.

en: Its abiding place was in all things fitted to it.
vi: As the person is, so is the dream.
tr: The never-ending presence of hunger had permeated everywhere and everything.
es: The districts where he had established his headquarters could not be more suitable for the purpose.

en: A narrow winding street, full of offence and stench, with other narrow winding streets diverging, all peopled by rags and nightcaps, and all smelling of rags and nightcaps, and all visible things with a brooding look upon them that looked ill.
vi: A narrow, winding road, full of unpleasant and foul things, branching into many other narrow, winding roads, everywhere one sees people in ragged clothes wearing nightcaps, everyone reeking, filthy, with miserable, sickly faces.
tr: A narrow, winding street where all kinds of faults and filth brewed, intersected by other narrow and winding streets, people wearing tattered clothes and nightcaps on their heads, smelling just like those tattered clothes and caps, and a morbid gloom in everything visible.
es: A narrow and winding street, a filthy and foul-smelling dump, from which even narrower and more winding alleys branched off, inhabited by human rags and smelling of human rags, in which only people and things that caused nausea could be seen.

en: In the hunted air of the people there was yet some wild-beast thought of the possibility of turning at bay.
vi: In the appearance of those people, there still lies the instinct of resistance of wild beasts being hunted to the end.
tr: Even in their disheveled state, people carried a terrifying hope within them to escape from the corner they were trapped in.
es: In the grim expression of its inhabitants, one could glimpse fierce longings to turn things upside down.

en: Depressed and slinking though they were, eyes of fire were not wanting among them; nor compressed lips, white with what they suppressed; nor foreheads knitted into the likeness of the gallows-rope they mused about enduring, or inflicting.
vi: Though gloomy and desperate, their eyes still blaze with fire; their tightly pressed lips are pale from restraint; their foreheads, furrowed like ropes on a gallows, still harbor thoughts of resignation or revenge.
tr: Though they were overwhelmed and weary, flames were shooting from the eyes of some; their lips were tightly shut, turning white from the things they couldn't say; their furrowed brows had turned into the noose they thought would either be placed on their heads or on the heads of others.
es: There was no shortage of emaciated faces with eyes that emitted flames, nor of clenched lips, nor of horribly furrowed brows.

en: The trade signs (and they were almost as many as the shops) were, all, grim illustrations of Want.
vi: The signs on every shop almost all harshly illustrate poverty.
tr: The pictures on all the signs (which were almost as numerous as the shops) depicted Hunger.
es: Even the shop signs were vivid illustrations of need.

en: The butcher and the porkman painted up, only the leanest scrags of meat; the baker, the coarsest of meagre loaves.
vi: The butcher shops only depict the least nutritious scraps of meat; the bakeries show thin loaves made from the worst flour.
tr: The butcher and the pork seller had hung pictures of the scrawniest cuts of meat, while the baker had pictures of the stalest loaves.
es: In the butcher shops and pork shops, they painted scrawny cattle, and in the bakeries, tiny, fraudulent loaves of bread.

en: The people rudely pictured as drinking in the wine-shops, croaked over their scanty measures of thin wine and beer, and were gloweringly confidential together.
vi: The tavern signs crudely depict people sitting and drinking inside, with grim and suspiciously secretive faces beside their meager portions of beer and liquor.
tr: The coarse demeanor of people drinking in the wine shops was also depicted, with men conversing with sullen faces over the small amounts of diluted wine and beer in their glasses.
es: The only industry that seemed to be experiencing a period of flourishing prosperity was that of tools and weapons.

en: Nothing was represented in a flourishing condition, save tools and weapons; but, the cutler’s knives and axes were sharp and bright, the smith’s hammers were heavy, and the gunmaker’s stock was murderous.
vi: Nothing is depicted as prosperous, except for tools and weapons; yet the axes on the hardware store signs look sharp and gleaming, the hammers on the blacksmith signs look heavy, and the goods in the gun shops look menacing.
tr: Aside from tools and weapons, nothing was depicted in its entirety; the knives and axes of the cutler were sharp and shiny, the hammers of the blacksmith were heavy, and the goods of the armorer were lethal.
es: The butchers' knives and axes were shiny, perfectly sharpened, the blacksmiths' hammers weighed many pounds, and the armories were packed with instruments of death.

en: The crippling stones of the pavement, with their many little reservoirs of mud and water, had no footways, but broke off abruptly at the doors.
vi: The cobblestone streets are dangerously uneven, with muddy puddles, lacking sidewalks that abruptly cut off in front of houses.
tr: The small puddles of mud and water and the loose cobblestones led nowhere, abruptly ending at doorsteps.
es: The streets, full of potholes, deposits of mud and corrupted water, lacked sidewalks.

en: The kennel, to make amends, ran down the middle of the street—when it ran at all: which was only after heavy rains, and then it ran, by many eccentric fits, into the houses.
vi: In contrast, the sewers run right down the middle of the street - if they aren't clogged, which they only clear after heavy rains, and when they do, ironically, the water floods into the houses.
tr: In contrast, the open sewage channels flowed through the middle of the street – if they flowed at all – which only happened after heavy rain, finding various ways to seep into the houses.
es: The streets, full of potholes, deposits of mud and corrupted water, lacked sidewalks.

en: Across the streets, at wide intervals, one clumsy lamp was slung by a rope and pulley; at night, when the lamplighter had let these down, and lighted, and hoisted them again, a feeble grove of dim wicks swung in a sickly manner overhead, as if they were at sea.
vi: On both sides of the street, at regular intervals, there is a rickety lamp hanging high by a rope and pulley; in the evening, the lamplighter lowers them, lights them, and then raises them again, a cluster of dimly burning wicks swaying overhead as if they were seasick offshore.
tr: Along the streets, at wide intervals, there were shaky lanterns hanging from a rope and pulley; at night, when the lamplighter lowered and lit them before pulling them back up, they would sway above like a faint ember from the dim wicks, as if they were floating on the sea.
es: The lanterns, which hung at very long intervals from ropes, cast a sickly light that was not enough to dispel the darkness, just as the lights of lanterns placed high on the yards do not dispel the darkness of the sea.

en: Indeed they were at sea, and the ship and crew were in peril of tempest.
vi: And indeed they are offshore, and both the ship and its crew are in peril from the storm.
tr: Indeed, they were at sea, and the ship and its crew were facing the danger of a storm.
es: To tell the truth, Paris was a sea, and both the ship and those who manned it were in grave danger of shipwreck.

en: For, the time was to come, when the gaunt scarecrows of that region should have watched the lamplighter, in their idleness and hunger, so long, as to conceive the idea of improving on his method, and hauling up men by those ropes and pulleys, to flare upon the darkness of their condition.
vi: Because it will soon come to the time when the ragged, gaunt figures like scarecrows in this area, who have long been sitting idly with empty stomachs watching the night lamp-lighters, will think of a way to improve their dark situation by using those ropes and pulleys to hang people.
tr: The ragged-looking scrawny ones on the boulevard, with their idle and hungry states, would regret not following the lamplighter; yet, if they could comprehend and develop the man's method, when the time came, they could illuminate the darkness they were in by hanging people at the ends of these ropes and pulleys.
es: The day was bound to come when the famished inhabitants of those regions, by force of contemplating the miserable lanterns, would conceive the project of introducing improvements to the system and would hang men from those ropes to illuminate the darkness of their situation.

en: But, the time was not come yet; and every wind that blew over France shook the rags of the scarecrows in vain, for the birds, fine of song and feather, took no warning.
vi: But that time has not yet come, and every gust of wind blowing through France still desperately stirs the tattered rags of the scarecrows, because the birds with the most beautiful feathers and the sweetest songs have not yet felt any fear or need for caution.
tr: But the time had not yet come, and while the winds blowing over France were pointlessly fluttering the clothes of these ragged-looking ones, the chirping beautiful feathered birds were indifferent to everything.
es: However, the time had not yet come, and although all the breezes blowing over France were precursors of strong gales, the little birds with silky plumage remained unaware.

en: The wine-shop was a corner shop, better than most others in its appearance and degree, and the master of the wine-shop had stood outside it, in a yellow waistcoat and green breeches, looking on at the struggle for the lost wine.
vi: The tavern is a shop located right at the corner of the street, its exterior and value are quite better than many other shops, and the owner is wearing a yellow tight shirt and green tight pants that go past the knees, having been standing at the door watching the scene of people scrambling to drink spilled wine.
tr: The wine shop was on the corner, better than many other shops both in appearance and quality, and the owner of the shop, wearing a yellow vest and green pants, was standing in front of the door, looking at the mess caused by the spilled wine.
es: The tavern in front of which the scene that the readers of this story have just witnessed took place offered a better appearance than most of the taverns in those neighborhoods, and its owner, dressed in a yellow vest and green breeches, was calmly watching the struggle of those who ran to claim the spilled wine.

en: “It’s not my affair,” said he, with a final shrug of the shoulders.
vi: − Not my business, - he said with a decisive shrug.
tr: He shrugged his shoulders sharply, "It's none of my business," he said.
es: —I don't care—he exclaimed, shrugging his shoulders.—The warehouse employees dropped it; they will bring me another barrel.

en: “The people from the market did it.
tr: "The market vendors knocked it over.
es: —I don't care—he exclaimed, shrugging his shoulders.—The warehouse employees dropped it; they will bring me another barrel.

en: Let them bring another.”
vi: If the store's people broke this barrel, they have to deliver another one.
tr: Let them bring another one."
es: —I don't care—he exclaimed, shrugging his shoulders.—The warehouse employees dropped it; they will bring me another barrel.

en: There, his eyes happening to catch the tall joker writing up his joke, he called to him across the way:
vi: Then his eyes accidentally caught sight of the tall, lanky guy jokingly writing on the wall, he called out across the street: −
tr: At that moment, his eye caught the tall jester who was busy writing his piece, and he called out from across the street:
es: The innkeeper then happened to see the individual who was writing the word blood on the wall, and asked him:

en: “Say, then, my Gaspard, what do you do there?”
vi: Hey there, Gaspard, what are you doing over there?
tr: "Hey Gaspard, what are you doing there?""
es: —Hey, Gaspar; what are you doing there?

en: The fellow pointed to his joke with immense significance, as is often the way with his tribe.
vi: The guy, extremely pleased with himself, pointed to his prank, like mischievous kids often show off to each other.
tr: Adam, thinking he was a joker, pointed to what he had written as if it were something immensely important.
es: He responded with one of those significant gestures that are so common among people of his kind, and whose meaning often goes unnoticed, as happened in this case.

en: It missed its mark, and completely failed, as is often the way with his tribe too.
vi: The prank wasn't funny, didn't cause any laughter at all, just like the antics of this rowdy bunch.
tr: But, in a manner befitting clowns like himself, he missed the mark and failed miserably.
es: He responded with one of those significant gestures that are so common among people of his kind, and whose meaning often goes unnoticed, as happened in this case.

en: “What now?
vi: − So what?
tr: As the owner of the wine shop was crossing the street, he said, "What are you doing, man?
es: —Are you trying to earn your way into a madhouse?—replied the innkeeper, crossing the street and smearing a handful of mud he picked up from the ground over the word written on the wall.

en: Are you a subject for the mad hospital?” said the wine-shop keeper, crossing the road, and obliterating the jest with a handful of mud, picked up for the purpose, and smeared over it.
vi: Do you want to go to the mental hospital? - The bartender said as he crossed the street, scooped up a handful of mud, and smeared it on the wall to erase the mischievous writing. -
tr: Are you out of your mind?" and to erase the man's mischief, he took a handful of mud from the ground and smeared it over the writing.
es: —Are you trying to earn your way into a madhouse?—replied the innkeeper, crossing the street and smearing a handful of mud he picked up from the ground over the word written on the wall.

en: “Why do you write in the public streets?
vi: Why are you scribbling on public streets?
tr: "Why are you writing on public places?

en: Is there—tell me thou—is there no other place to write such words in?”
vi: Is there no other place... tell me... is there really no other place to write this?
tr: Tell me – couldn't you find another place to write this?"
es: Can't you find another place, tell me, to write words like that?

en: In his expostulation he dropped his cleaner hand (perhaps accidentally, perhaps not) upon the joker’s heart.
vi: Whether accidentally or not, he protested while wiping his still clean hand on the chest of the prankster.
tr: While scolding the man, he had placed his relatively clean hand (perhaps accidentally, perhaps not) on the jester's heart.
es: While he was formulating the second question, the innkeeper placed his less dirty hand (perhaps by chance, perhaps intentionally) over the region of his interlocutor's heart.

en: The joker rapped it with his own, took a nimble spring upward, and came down in a fantastic dancing attitude, with one of his stained shoes jerked off his foot into his hand, and held out.
vi: The other guy slapped his hand, jumped up, then landed and stood with his leg raised in a strange dance pose, yanking off his dirty shoe and holding it out in front of him.
tr: The jester lightly slapped this hand, jumped with an agile movement, and landed with a magnificent dance move, holding one of his stained shoes that had flown off his foot.
es: The latter struck his chest with his own, made a prodigious leap, and remained motionless, in a fantastic dance posture with his left arm on his hip and his right arm raised, holding between the thumb and index finger of his right hand a dirty shoe that he had previously taken off one of his feet.

en: A joker of an extremely, not to say wolfishly practical character, he looked, under those circumstances.
vi: In this appearance, that clownish guy looked extremely cunning, if not outright vicious.
tr: In that state, he looked like an extremely skillful individual.
es: The latter struck his chest with his own, made a prodigious leap, and remained motionless, in a fantastic dance posture with his left arm on his hip and his right arm raised, holding between the thumb and index finger of his right hand a dirty shoe that he had previously taken off one of his feet.

en: “Put it on, put it on,” said the other.
vi: "Put your shoes on, put them on," the innkeeper said.
tr: "Wear it, come on, wear it quickly," said the other.
es: The innkeeper crossed the street again and entered his establishment.

en: “Call wine, wine; and finish there.”
vi: "Go find some wine to drink, it's over."
tr: "Give the wine its due and finish it."
es: He was a man of about thirty years, with a martial air and a bull's neck.

en: With that advice, he wiped his soiled hand upon the joker’s dress, such as it was—quite deliberately, as having dirtied the hand on his account; and then recrossed the road and entered the wine-shop.
vi: After saying that, he deliberately wiped his dirty hand on the thug's shirt because that guy was the reason his hand got dirty; then he crossed the street and entered the tavern.
tr: Upon this advice, the man wiped his dirty hand on the jester –as if to say it got dirty because of him, looking him straight in the eye– and then crossed back over and entered the wine shop.
es: He must have had a fiery temperament, for although the day was one of the coldest the Parisians had experienced in that harsh winter, he was in shirtsleeves and had them rolled up almost to his shoulders.

en: This wine-shop keeper was a bull-necked, martial-looking man of thirty, and he should have been of a hot temperament, for, although it was a bitter day, he wore no coat, but carried one slung over his shoulder.
vi: The owner of the shop was about thirty years old, with a thick neck and a military demeanor, surely a hot-tempered person because even in the freezing cold, he only draped his coat over his shoulder instead of wearing it.
tr: The owner of the wine shop was a man in his thirties, with a thick neck and a bold appearance, and judging by the fact that he had thrown his coat over his shoulder despite the harsh weather, he seemed to have a rather warm disposition.
es: He must have had a fiery temperament, for although the day was one of the coldest the Parisians had experienced in that harsh winter, he was in shirtsleeves and had them rolled up almost to his shoulders.

en: His shirt-sleeves were rolled up, too, and his brown arms were bare to the elbows.
vi: The sleeves of his shirt were rolled up high, exposing his sun-tanned arms up to the elbows.
tr: The sleeves of his shirt were rolled up, revealing his tanned arms up to the elbows.
es: He must have had a fiery temperament, for although the day was one of the coldest the Parisians had experienced in that harsh winter, he was in shirtsleeves and had them rolled up almost to his shoulders.

en: Neither did he wear anything more on his head than his own crisply-curling short dark hair.
vi: On his head, he wore nothing to cover his short, tightly curled black hair.
tr: There was nothing covering his head except for his short, curly, dark hair.
es: As for headwear, he wore nothing but his natural covering: a mass of black, coarse, and curly hair.

en: He was a dark man altogether, with good eyes and a good bold breadth between them.
vi: His skin was dark, and his sharp eyes were set wide apart.
tr: He was a handsome man with beautiful eyes and a tanned complexion, with a pleasant gap between them.
es: He had a dark complexion and good eyes, with an implacable gaze.

en: Good-humoured looking on the whole, but implacable-looking, too; evidently a man of a strong resolution and a set purpose; a man not desirable to be met, rushing down a narrow pass with a gulf on either side, for nothing would turn the man.
vi: Overall, his face appeared cheerful but also stubborn; clearly a very determined and principled person; someone no one would want to confront when he was charging down a narrow path between two deep chasms, for nothing could make this person turn back.
tr: He generally seemed to be a good-natured person, but he could also be ruthless; clearly, he was a determined, resolute man, and it was better not to cross paths with him. Even if he had to pass through a narrow passage with cliffs on both sides, he would not turn back from his path.
es: He was evidently a man of great resolve and unyielding purposes, one of those men with whom it would be dangerous to meet on a narrow path bordered by two abysses, for it is certain that he would not turn back for anything or anyone.

en: Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in.
vi: Mrs. Defarge, his wife, was sitting behind the counter in the shop when he walked in.
tr: When the man walked into the shop, Madam Defarge – that is, his wife – was sitting behind the counter.
es: Mrs. Defarge, the wife of the tavern keeper in question, was sitting behind the counter when he entered the establishment.

en: Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of manner.
vi: She was a stout woman around his age, with vigilant eyes that seemed to rarely look directly at anything, a large hand adorned with rings; a serene face with sharp features, and an extremely calm demeanor.
tr: Madam Defarge was a stout woman of her husband's age, with alert eyes that seemed to look at nothing, a large hand full of rings, a face with strong, sturdy features, and a calm demeanor.
es: She was a woman of robust constitution, approximately the same age as her husband, with watchful eyes, although very rarely did she seem to look at any particular object, large hands covered with rings, a face with energetic lines, a reserved expression, and an air of perfect composure.

en: There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided.
vi: Mrs. Defarge exuded something that made one think that this mistress rarely made mistakes in matters of money calculation.
tr: She had an air about her that gave the impression she never made a mistake in any calculation she undertook.
es: One of Mrs. Defarge's characteristics was never making mistakes that would harm her interests in any of the establishment's operations.

en: Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head, though not to the concealment of her large earrings.
vi: Unable to bear the cold, Mrs. Defarge wrapped herself tightly in a fur coat, with a large, brightly colored scarf twisted around her head but still revealing large hoop earrings.
tr: Since Madam Defarge was sensitive to the cold, she was wrapped in furs and had tied a brightly colored scarf around her head, but her large earrings were still visible.
es: Extremely sensitive to the cold, she was wrapped in furs and covered her head with a brightly colored shawl that completely covered her, though it left visible the large earrings that adorned her ears.

en: Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick.
vi: The knitting lay in front of her, but she had stopped knitting to pick her teeth with a toothpick.
tr: She had set aside her knitting to pick her teeth with a toothpick.
es: She had her knitting in front of her, but she had left it on the counter to devote a few minutes to cleaning her teeth, which she was doing with a toothpick.

en: Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but coughed just one grain of cough.
vi: Her left hand supporting her right elbow as she picked her teeth, Mrs. Defarge said nothing when her husband walked in, only clearing her throat softly.
tr: Since she was busy supporting her right elbow with her left hand, she didn't say anything when her husband arrived, merely contenting herself with a slight cough.
es: Absorbed in her occupation, with her right elbow resting on her left hand, Mrs. Defarge said nothing when her husband entered the establishment, but she let out a barely perceptible little cough.

en: This, in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way.
vi: Accompanying the throat clearing, her thick dark eyebrows above the toothpick raised slightly, signaling to her husband to look around at the customers in the shop to see who had come in while he was across the street.
tr: Accompanied by this cough, the way she raised her dark eyebrows, which were like thin lines, was a gesture indicating that there had been customers while her husband was outside and that it would be good for him to attend to them.
es: The little cough, combined with a slight arching of her eyebrows, black as a raven's wing and perfectly arched, indicated to her husband the convenience of taking a look at the customers, among whom there might be someone new who had arrived at the tavern while he was out on the street.

en: The wine-shop keeper accordingly rolled his eyes about, until they rested upon an elderly gentleman and a young lady, who were seated in a corner.
vi: Understanding the intention, the shop owner glanced around until his eyes stopped at a spot where an elderly nobleman and a young lady were sitting in the corner of the room.
tr: Upon this, the wine seller's eyes wandered around until they caught sight of the elderly gentleman and the young lady sitting in a corner.
es: The innkeeper cast his eyes around the room, soon fixing them on a gentleman, already advanced in years, and a young lady, seated in one of the corners.

en: Other company were there: two playing cards, two playing dominoes, three standing by the counter lengthening out a short supply of wine.
vi: There were still many customers in the bar: two people were playing cards, two were playing dominoes, and three were standing by the counter trying to savor their meager glasses of wine.
tr: The others were still there: two people playing cards, two people playing dominoes, and three men leaning against the counter, sipping their small amounts of wine little by little.
es: There were other patrons as well: two playing cards at a table, another two entertaining themselves at another table, their faculties focused on the domino pieces, and three more who, standing by the counter, were trying to stretch out the wine they had been served as much as possible.

en: As he passed behind the counter, he took notice that the elderly gentleman said in a look to the young lady, “This is our man.”
vi: As he walked behind the counter, he noticed the distinguished old man giving the girl a look that implied: "This is my person."
tr: When the wine seller went behind the counter, the elderly gentleman signaled to the young lady with his eyes and said, "This is the man we've been waiting for."
es: The innkeeper, while passing behind the counter, could notice that the elderly gentleman was saying with his eyes to his young companion:

en: “What the devil do you do in that galley there?” said Monsieur Defarge to himself; “I don’t know you.”
vi: “What are you people doing coming to this godforsaken place?” Mr. Defarge muttered to himself. “I don't know them at all.”
tr: Monsieur Defarge muttered to himself, "What is this man saying? I don't even know him."
es: —That's our man.

en: But, he feigned not to notice the two strangers, and fell into discourse with the triumvirate of customers who were drinking at the counter.
vi: He pretended not to see the two strangers and started a conversation with the three customers drinking at the counter.
tr: He pretended not to notice these two strangers and engaged in conversation with the three customers drinking in front of the counter.
es: The innkeeper pretended not to notice the presence of the two unknown characters and struck up a conversation with the trio who were drinking by the counter.

en: “How goes it, Jacques?” said one of these three to Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − How did it go, Jacques? - One of the three asked Defarge. -
tr: "So how's it going, Jacques?" one of them said to Monsieur Defarge.
es: —How's it going, Santiago—asked one of the three to the good Defarge,—have they drunk all the wine that came out of the barrel?

en: “Is all the spilt wine swallowed?”
vi: Is all the spilled wine gone? −
tr: "Did they clean up the spilled wine?"
es: —How's it going, Santiago—asked one of the three to the good Defarge,—have they drunk all the wine that came out of the barrel?

en: “Every drop, Jacques,” answered Monsieur Defarge.
vi: Not a drop left, Jacques, - Defarge replied.*
tr: "To the very last drop, Jacques," said Monsieur Defarge.
es: —To the last drop, Santiago—replied Defarge.

en: When this interchange of Christian name was effected, Madame Defarge, picking her teeth with her toothpick, coughed another grain of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.
vi: Hearing this exchange of names, Madame Defarge, still holding a toothpick, cleared her throat again and raised her eyebrows a little higher.
tr: While they were talking to each other, addressing each other by the same name, Madam Defarge, who was still picking her teeth with a toothpick, lightly coughed again and raised her eyebrows, forming a thin line, once more.
es: As soon as the interlocutors exchanged their first names, Mrs. Defarge coughed a little more and raised her eyebrows again.

en: “It is not often,” said the second of the three, addressing Monsieur Defarge, “that many of these miserable beasts know the taste of wine, or of anything but black bread and death.
vi: − How often do they get to drink, - the second person in the trio said to Mr. Defarge, - those poor wretches rarely get to taste wine or anything other than black bread and death.
tr: "Generally," said the Second of the three men to Monsieur Defarge, "these wretched creatures do not know the taste of wine; what they know is a dark bread, and death.
es: —Rarely—observed the second of the patrons at the counter—do those miserable beasts have the chance to know what wine tastes like, or anything other than black bread and death: isn't that right, Santiago?

en: Is it not so, Jacques?”
vi: Isn't that right, Jacques? −
tr: Isn't that right, Jacques?"
es: —Rarely—observed the second of the patrons at the counter—do those miserable beasts have the chance to know what wine tastes like, or anything other than black bread and death: isn't that right, Santiago?

en: “It is so, Jacques,” Monsieur Defarge returned.
vi: That's right, Jacques, - Mr. Defarge replied.
tr: "Right, Jacques," replied Monsieur Defarge.
es: —It's true, Santiago—replied the innkeeper.

en: At this second interchange of the Christian name, Madame Defarge, still using her toothpick with profound composure, coughed another grain of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.
vi: The second time she heard them call each other "Jacques," still calmly picking her teeth, Madame Defarge cleared her throat softly and raised her eyebrows a little higher.
tr: While they addressed each other by the same name for the second time, Madam Defarge, who was still picking her teeth with a toothpick in great tranquility, coughed lightly once more and raised her eyebrows, forming a thin line, once again.
es: After the second exchange of first names, another little cough followed, accompanied by the raising of Mrs. Defarge's eyebrows.

en: The last of the three now said his say, as he put down his empty drinking vessel and smacked his lips.
vi: The last person in the trio finally spoke up after setting down the empty glass of wine and smacking his lips.
tr: This time, after the last of the three men put down his emptied glass and smacked his lips, he started to speak.
es: After the second exchange of first names, another little cough followed, accompanied by the raising of Mrs. Defarge's eyebrows.

en: “Ah!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Ah!

en: So much the worse!
vi: That makes it even worse!
tr: Very bad, very!"
es: —exclaimed the third drinker, finishing the last sip and leaving the glass on the counter.

en: A bitter taste it is that such poor cattle always have in their mouths, and hard lives they live, Jacques.
vi: Those poor people always swallow their bitterness, living a life as hard as oxen, Jacques.
tr: "The poor always have a bitter taste in their mouths, Jacques, and their lives are even worse."
es: —They always have bile in their mouths, those sheep, and they live a dog's life!

en: Am I right, Jacques?”
vi: Am I right, Jacques? −
tr: "Am I wrong, Jacques?"
es: Am I right, Santiago?

en: “You are right, Jacques,” was the response of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: You are right, Jacques, - Defarge agreed.
tr: "You are right, Jacques," replied Monsieur Defarge.
es: —You are right, Santiago—was the bartender's reply.

en: This third interchange of the Christian name was completed at the moment when Madame Defarge put her toothpick by, kept her eyebrows up, and slightly rustled in her seat.
vi: This third time of calling the name ended just as Madame Defarge took out the toothpick, her eyebrows still raised, and shifted noisily in her chair.
tr: When the men addressed each other by the same name for the third time, Madam Defarge had also put her toothpick aside, raised her eyebrows even higher, and shifted slightly in her seat.
es: After the third exchange of first names, Madame Defarge put down the toothpick and made an insignificant movement.

en: “Hold then!
vi: − Wait! Hold on!
tr: "That's right, indeed!
es: —It's true...! Distract them!

en: True!” muttered her husband.
vi: - The husband mumbled.
tr: You're right!" grumbled her husband.
es: —her husband murmured very quietly.

en: “Gentlemen—my wife!”
vi: - Gentlemen... this is my wife!
tr: "Gentlemen... this is my wife!"
es: —Gentlemen...

en: The three customers pulled off their hats to Madame Defarge, with three flourishes.
vi: The three guests lifted their hats and waved their hands respectfully to Mrs. Defarge.
tr: Three customers took off their hats and greeted Madam Defarge with a showy gesture.
es: I have the pleasure of introducing my wife.

en: She acknowledged their homage by bending her head, and giving them a quick look.
vi: To acknowledge their respect, she bowed in return, quickly glancing at all three of them.
tr: She also slightly bowed her head in response to their greetings and gave them a once-over.
es: The three patrons took off their hats and greeted the innkeeper with individual nods of their heads, to which she responded by slightly bowing her own and looking at them one by one.

en: Then she glanced in a casual manner round the wine-shop, took up her knitting with great apparent calmness and repose of spirit, and became absorbed in it.
vi: Then she calmly looked around the tavern as usual, serenely and leisurely picked up her knitting, and focused on it.
tr: Then, glancing around the wine shop, she picked up her knitting with tremendous calm and tranquility and immersed herself in her work.
es: Then, she casually glanced around, calmly picked up her knitting, and began to work.

en: “Gentlemen,” said her husband, who had kept his bright eye observantly upon her, “good day.
vi: − Wishing you gentlemen a good day, - the husband, who had been watching his wife without taking his eyes off her, spoke again.
tr: With his bright eyes still obediently on his wife, the wine merchant said, "Gentlemen, the bachelor room you asked about and wanted to see is on the fifth floor as I was heading out.
es: —Gentlemen—replied the innkeeper, who had observed his wife with a scrutinizing look,—the room you expressed a desire to see when I went out to the street, is on the fifth floor.

en: The chamber, furnished bachelor-fashion, that you wished to see, and were inquiring for when I stepped out, is on the fifth floor.
vi: - The room set up for single men that you wanted to see and were inquiring about while I was out, that room is on the fifth floor.
tr: With his bright eyes still obediently on his wife, the wine merchant said, "Gentlemen, the bachelor room you asked about and wanted to see is on the fifth floor as I was heading out.
es: —Gentlemen—replied the innkeeper, who had observed his wife with a scrutinizing look,—the room you expressed a desire to see when I went out to the street, is on the fifth floor.

en: The doorway of the staircase gives on the little courtyard close to the left here,” pointing with his hand, “near to the window of my establishment.
vi: The entrance to the staircase is in the small courtyard right next to the left here, - he pointed, - near the window of this tavern.
tr: You can reach the courtyard immediately to the left of the stairs," he indicated with his hand, "from beside that window.
es: The staircase starts from the left courtyard, next to the window of the...

en: But, now that I remember, one of you has already been there, and can show the way.
vi: But I remember now, one of you has already been there and can lead the way.
tr: But now I remember that one of you has been there before, let him show you the way.
es: But now I remember that one of you has already been there, and can guide the others.

en: Gentlemen, adieu!”
vi: Adieu, goodbye!
tr: Come on, gentlemen, adieu!"
es: Goodbye, gentlemen!

en: They paid for their wine, and left the place.
vi: The three others paid and left.
tr: The men paid for their wine and left.
es: The drinkers paid for what they had consumed and left.

en: The eyes of Monsieur Defarge were studying his wife at her knitting when the elderly gentleman advanced from his corner, and begged the favour of a word.
vi: While Mr. Defarge was intently watching his wife knit, the distinguished old man in the corner of the tavern approached and asked to speak privately.
tr: While Monsieur Defarge's eyes were on his wife who was knitting, the elderly gentleman got up from his corner, approached, and said he wanted to talk to him.
es: The innkeeper's eyes seemed to study his wife and the knitting she was doing, when the elderly gentleman stood up expressing a desire to speak a few words with Defarge.

en: “Willingly, sir,” said Monsieur Defarge, and quietly stepped with him to the door.
vi: − Willingly, sir, - Mr. Defarge agreed and quietly followed the old man out of the tavern.
tr: "With pleasure, sir," said Monsieur Defarge, and they quietly proceeded towards the door.
es: —With great pleasure, sir—he replied, accompanying the old man to the door of the establishment.

en: Their conference was very short, but very decided.
vi: The exchange was very brief and decisive.
tr: The conversation was very short but quite heated.
es: The conference was brief, but its effects were as swift as they were decisive.

en: Almost at the first word, Monsieur Defarge started and became deeply attentive.
vi: Almost upon hearing the first sentence, Mr. Defarge was startled and showed utmost attention.
tr: From the very first word, Monsieur Defarge listened to him intently.
es: Not four words had been exchanged when Defarge made a gesture of surprise, and before a minute had passed, he signaled to the old man and hurried out into the street.

en: It had not lasted a minute, when he nodded and went out.
vi: The conversation lasted less than a minute before he nodded and went outside.
tr: Not even a minute had passed when he nodded and went outside.
es: Not four words had been exchanged when Defarge made a gesture of surprise, and before a minute had passed, he signaled to the old man and hurried out into the street.

en: The gentleman then beckoned to the young lady, and they, too, went out.
vi: The distinguished old man signaled to the girl, and both of them went out.
tr: Not even a minute had passed when he nodded and went outside.
es: The gentleman nodded to the young lady, and both followed the innkeeper, leaving Madame Defarge absorbed in her knitting.

en: Madame Defarge knitted with nimble fingers and steady eyebrows, and saw nothing.
vi: Madame Defarge continued knitting with swift fingers, her eyebrows not moving, pretending not to see anything.
tr: Madame Defarge continued knitting without moving her eyebrows, her fingers moving rapidly, and she saw nothing else.
es: The gentleman nodded to the young lady, and both followed the innkeeper, leaving Madame Defarge absorbed in her knitting.

en: mr Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette, emerging from the wine-shop thus, joined Monsieur Defarge in the doorway to which he had directed his own company just before.
vi: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette left the tavern, following Mr. Defarge to the entrance of the staircase that he had previously directed his customers to.
tr: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette left the wine shop and went to Monsieur Defarge, to the entrance where the man had just described the room to the men.
es: Mr. Maurice Lorry and Miss Manette, who were the visitors to the tavern, as the readers will have undoubtedly guessed, found the innkeeper by the door that moments earlier he had indicated to the three patrons with whom we have seen him exchange a few words.

en: It opened from a stinking little black courtyard, and was the general public entrance to a great pile of houses, inhabited by a great number of people.
vi: The door was located in a dark, foul-smelling courtyard, serving as a common entrance for many houses, home to many people.
tr: This led to a small, dark courtyard that smelled terrible and was used as a passage to an area with a bunch of houses and a lot of people living there.
es: Mr. Maurice Lorry and Miss Manette, who were the visitors to the tavern, as the readers will have undoubtedly guessed, found the innkeeper by the door that moments earlier he had indicated to the three patrons with whom we have seen him exchange a few words.

en: In the gloomy tile-paved entry to the gloomy tile-paved staircase, Monsieur Defarge bent down on one knee to the child of his old master, and put her hand to his lips.
vi: At the dimly lit brick-paved entrance leading to the dimly lit brick-paved staircase, Mr. Defarge knelt on one knee before the daughter of his former master and lifted her hand to his lips to kiss.
tr: In this gloomy, tiled entrance that opened onto gloomy, tiled stairs, Monsieur Defarge knelt before his former employer's daughter and brought her hand to his lips.
es: In the gloomy entrance that led to the equally gloomy staircase, the innkeeper knelt on one knee and brought to his lips the hand of the daughter of his former master.

en: It was a gentle action, but not at all gently done; a very remarkable transformation had come over him in a few seconds.
vi: It was a gesture of kindness, but the manner of its expression did not appear so; in an instant, his demeanor had visibly changed.
tr: Although it was a polite gesture, it was not done in an overly polite manner; within a few seconds, the man's entire demeanor had changed.
es: It was a homage, a testimony of submission, though executed with a demeanor that was anything but gentle.

en: He had no good-humour in his face, nor any openness of aspect left, but had become a secret, angry, dangerous man.
vi: His face no longer bore a cheerful or open expression but had become one of secrecy, fury, and danger.
tr: The cheerful, clear-faced man was gone, replaced by a mysterious, angry, and dangerous man. Mr. Defarge warned Mr. Lorry at the top of the stairs with a firm attitude.
es: A few seconds had sufficed to radically transform Defarge; his face no longer reflected good humor, nor was it a mirror of frankness: on the contrary, in his reserved expression, in his angry attitude, in the fury that sparkled in his eyes, it was easy to read the dangerous man.

en: “It is very high; it is a little difficult.
vi: − It's way up high; a bit difficult to go up.
tr: "It's quite high up; you might find it difficult.
es: —It is very high... the ladder is heavy...

en: Better to begin slowly.”
vi: So start slowly. -
tr: Take it slow."
es: I think you would do well to climb more calmly—said the innkeeper with a harsh tone to Mr. Lorry, at the moment he began to climb the ladder.

en: Thus, Monsieur Defarge, in a stern voice, to mr Lorry, as they began ascending the stairs.
vi: In a stern voice, Mr. Defarge said to Mr. Lorry as they climbed the stairs.
tr: The other whispered, "Alone?""
es: I think you would do well to climb more calmly—said the innkeeper with a harsh tone to Mr. Lorry, at the moment he began to climb the ladder.

en: “Is he alone?” the latter whispered.
vi: − He is alone? - Mr. Lorry whispered.
tr: The other whispered, "Alone?""
es: —Are you alone?—asked Lorry.

en: “Alone!
vi: − Alone!
tr: "Alone!
es: —Alone!

en: God help him, who should be with him!” said the other, in the same low voice.
vi: Only God, who else would be with him! - Mr. Defarge also lowered his voice.
tr: May God help him, who else would be with him anyway?" said the other in the same low voice.
es: Good heavens! Who do you want to accompany you?

en: “Is he always alone, then?”
vi: − So he's always alone? −
tr: "Always only then."
es: —Always alone?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Always.

en: “Of his own desire?”
vi: − Because he wants it that way? −
tr: "Does he want it that way himself?"
es: —Because that is what he desires?

en: “Of his own necessity.
vi: Because he needs it that way.
tr: "That's how it needs to be.
es: —Because the circumstances demand it.

en: As he was, when I first saw him after they found me and demanded to know if I would take him, and, at my peril be discreet—as he was then, so he is now.”
vi: It's always like that, ever since I first met him, after they found me, asked me if I would take him in and keep it secret to avoid danger... he was like that then and he is still the same now.
tr: Even then, I mean the day they found me, asked me to take him with me, and told me to keep my mouth shut – even then, when I first saw him, he was alone, and he is still alone now."
es: Just as he was when I saw him the day they came to ask me if I wanted to have him in my house and be discreet while running the consequent risk... just as he was then, he is now.

en: “He is greatly changed?”
vi: − Has he changed a lot?
tr: "Has he/she changed a lot?"
es: —Very changed?

en: “Changed!”
vi: − Changed!
tr: "Of course it has changed!"
es: —Changed!...

en: The keeper of the wine-shop stopped to strike the wall with his hand, and mutter a tremendous curse.
vi: The innkeeper stopped, swung his arm, punched the wall, and let out a fierce curse.
tr: The owner of the wine shop paused to punch the wall and let out a hefty curse.
es: The innkeeper slammed his fist against the wall and uttered a horrendous curse.

en: No direct answer could have been half so forcible.
vi: There could be no more emphatic answer than half of that curse.
tr: No response could be half as effective as what he did.
es: Any clear and precise response would not have produced half the effects that that explosion of fury did.

en: mr Lorry’s spirits grew heavier and heavier, as he and his two companions ascended higher and higher.
vi: Mr. Lorry's mood grew heavier as he and the other two climbed higher and higher.
tr: As he climbed the stairs with the others, Mr. Lorry felt more and more anxious with each step.
es: Mr. Lorry's melancholy increased as he ascended the steep staircase.

en: Such a staircase, with its accessories, in the older and more crowded parts of Paris, would be bad enough now; but, at that time, it was vile indeed to unaccustomed and unhardened senses.
vi: Such a staircase, along with its dependencies, in the more crowded and older areas of Paris, must have been worse compared to today; but even at that time, it was unpleasant for those who were not familiar and hardened.
tr: In the relatively older and more crowded areas of Paris, it would be natural for such a staircase to look bad with all its details, but that day, for these genteel individuals who knew nothing of misery, this place was utterly disgusting.
es: Painful, very painful, it would be today to climb the stairs of one of the oldest houses located in one of the most populated neighborhoods of Paris; but at the time to which this story refers, it was almost impossible for those who did not have their senses atrophied by force of habit.

en: Every little habitation within the great foul nest of one high building—that is to say, the room or rooms within every door that opened on the general staircase—left its own heap of refuse on its own landing, besides flinging other refuse from its own windows.
vi: Every residence within the stinking nest that was this tall house, in other words, every room, apartment behind any door that opened onto this common staircase - left a pile of their garbage at the top of the stairs of each floor, along with throwing other waste out the window.
tr: The inhabitants of every small dwelling in this high filth nest of a building –in other words, every room or rooms opening onto the staircase– had piled all their rubbish onto their own landing and thrown the rest out of the windows.
es: All the neighbors of those immense hives left the garbage and filth on the landings of the main staircase, where they piled up without anyone caring to remove them, thus generating a mass of decomposition sufficient to poison the air, if it were not already saturated with the intangible impurities that are the natural result of misery and deprivation.

en: The uncontrollable and hopeless mass of decomposition so engendered, would have polluted the air, even if poverty and deprivation had not loaded it with their intangible impurities; the two bad sources combined made it almost insupportable.
vi: Even if it didn't carry the lingering smell of poverty, that heap of desperate decay and uncontrollable proliferation would have been enough to poison the entire atmosphere; but when both garbage and poverty join forces, the stench becomes unbearable.
tr: This out-of-control heap of hopeless trash had covered everything so much that even if the invisible filth of poverty and deprivation had not been added to it, it would have been enough to pollute the air; the combination of these two was truly unbearable.
es: All the neighbors of those immense hives left the garbage and filth on the landings of the main staircase, where they piled up without anyone caring to remove them, thus generating a mass of decomposition sufficient to poison the air, if it were not already saturated with the intangible impurities that are the natural result of misery and deprivation.

en: Through such an atmosphere, by a steep dark shaft of dirt and poison, the way lay.
vi: To move forward, one had to pass through that atmosphere, crossing the dark, steep, filthy, and noxious stairwell.
tr: But to continue on their way, they had to breathe this air, dive into this steep, dark pit of filth and poison.
es: Combined, the two sources of corruption created an unbearable atmosphere.

en: Yielding to his own disturbance of mind, and to his young companion’s agitation, which became greater every instant, mr Jarvis Lorry twice stopped to rest.
vi: Mr. Jarvis Lorry had to pause twice to catch his breath, exhausted by his own anxious thoughts and the restlessness of the young lady accompanying him.
tr: Mr. Jarvis Lorry, unable to bear his increasing anxieties and the excitement of his young companion, stopped and rested twice.
es: Mr. Lorry, yielding to the discomfort caused by climbing that dark, dirty, and poisoned well, as well as to the agitation he observed in his young companion, which multiplied by the moment, stopped twice to rest.

en: Each of these stoppages was made at a doleful grating, by which any languishing good airs that were left uncorrupted, seemed to escape, and all spoilt and sickly vapours seemed to crawl in.
vi: Each time he stopped at the miserable ventilation window, it seemed that any desirable fresh air had already escaped, and the foul, stinking vapors from outside had seeped in.
tr: Each of these pauses was taken in front of sorrowful window grilles where a piece of clean, beautiful, and melancholy air had flown away, replaced by a foul vapor.
es: Each of those rests seemed to take away the last reserves of uncorrupted air, filling the space they left free with mephitic emanations that sprang from all sides.

en: Through the rusted bars, tastes, rather than glimpses, were caught of the jumbled neighbourhood; and nothing within range, nearer or lower than the summits of the two great towers of Notre-Dame, had any promise on it of healthy life or wholesome aspirations.
vi: Through the rusty bars of the ventilation window, one could almost taste rather than see this chaotic area; and within the range from here to the two tall towers of Notre-Dame Cathedral, nothing closer or lower promised a life of tranquility or lofty aspirations.
tr: Instead of the views of that chaotic neighborhood, the air was noticeable through the rusty bars, and as far as could be seen, there was no sign of healthy living or hope anywhere near or below the tops of Notre-Dame's two great towers.
es: Each of those rests seemed to take away the last reserves of uncorrupted air, filling the space they left free with mephitic emanations that sprang from all sides.

en: At last, the top of the staircase was gained, and they stopped for the third time.
vi: Finally, they reached the top of the staircase, and they stopped for the third time.
tr: Finally, they reached the last step and stopped for the third time.
es: They finally reached the top of the stairs, where they stopped for the third time.

en: There was yet an upper staircase, of a steeper inclination and of contracted dimensions, to be ascended, before the garret story was reached.
vi: They still had to climb another staircase, steeper and narrower, to reach the attic floor.
tr: However, before reaching the attic, a steeper and narrower staircase stretched out before them.
es: They still had to climb another section, steeper than the previous ones, and of extremely reduced dimensions, before reaching the attic.

en: The keeper of the wine-shop, always going a little in advance, and always going on the side which mr Lorry took, as though he dreaded to be asked any question by the young lady, turned himself about here, and, carefully feeling in the pockets of the coat he carried over his shoulder, took out a key.
vi: The innkeeper always went a little ahead, staying close to Mr. Lorry, as if he was afraid the girl might ask any questions; here, he turned around, carefully rummaged through the pockets of the coat draped over his shoulder, and pulled out a key.
tr: As if afraid that the young lady might ask a question, the owner of the wine shop, who had been walking slightly ahead and on Mr. Lorry's side since the beginning of the stairs, turned around here and carefully searched the pockets of the coat he was carrying on his shoulder, producing a key.
es: The innkeeper, who was walking ahead and constantly trying to keep a respectable distance from the young lady, as if he feared she might ask him a question, upon reaching the attic door, put his right hand into his pocket and took out a key.

en: “The door is locked then, my friend?” said mr Lorry, surprised.
vi: − Does this door need to be locked, my friend? - Mr. Lorry asked in surprise.
tr: "Is the door locked, my friend?" said Mr. Lorry, in a surprised manner.
es: —Ah! —exclaimed Lorry, unable to hide his surprise.—Is the door locked?

en: “Ay. Yes,” was the grim reply of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − Oh, yes, - Mr. Defarge's cruel reply.
tr: Monsieur Defarge said, "Yes, indeed," with a serious demeanor.
es: —Yes—replied Defarge curtly.

en: “You think it necessary to keep the unfortunate gentleman so retired?”
vi: − Do you think it is necessary to lock up this unfortunate person?
tr: "Is it necessary to keep the unfortunate man locked up like this?"
es: —Do you consider it necessary to keep that unfortunate gentleman in such extreme confinement?

en: “I think it necessary to turn the key.”
vi: − I think it is necessary to turn the key.
tr: "I think it's worth turning the key."
es: —I consider it necessary to have the door locked—murmured the person addressed, lowering his voice significantly and furrowing his brows terribly.

en: Monsieur Defarge whispered it closer in his ear, and frowned heavily.
vi: - Mr. Defarge whispered close to his ear and frowned.
tr: Monsieur Defarge had whispered this into Mr. Lorry's ear, his eyebrows furrowed sternly.
es: —I consider it necessary to have the door locked—murmured the person addressed, lowering his voice significantly and furrowing his brows terribly.

en: “Why?”
vi: − Why? −
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why?

en: “Why!
vi: Why, you ask?
tr: "Why, you ask?
es: —Why!

en: Because he has lived so long, locked up, that he would be frightened—rave—tear himself to pieces—die—come to I know not what harm—if his door was left open.”
vi: Because he has lived in captivity for so long that if you leave the door open now, he will panic, go mad, tear himself apart, die, or do any number of terrible things you can't predict.
tr: The poor man lived locked up for so long that if we were to leave this door open, he would be scared – go mad – tear himself apart – die – who knows what he might do."
es: Because he has lived locked up for so many years that he would be frightened, horrified, he would throw himself headfirst against the walls, he would die... I don't know the extremes he would go to... if he were left with the door open!

en: “Is it possible!” exclaimed mr Lorry.
vi: − To that extent! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed.
tr: "Is such a thing possible?" shouted Mr. Lorry.
es: —Is it possible!

en: “Is it possible!” repeated Defarge, bitterly.
vi: − To that extent! - Defarge bitterly repeated.
tr: Defarge sternly repeated, "Is such a thing possible?"
es: —Possible?

en: “Yes.
vi: - Indeed.
tr: "Of course.
es: It would be infallible, yes!

en: And a beautiful world we live in, when it is possible, and when many other such things are possible, and not only possible, but done—done, see you!—under that sky there, every day.
vi: And what a wonderful world we live in when such things can still happen, and when many other similar things can happen, and not only can happen but have actually happened... Have happened, do you hear!... Under this sky, every day.
tr: In this beautiful world we live in, such a thing is possible, many other things are possible too, and not only possible but such things really happen every day under this sky – they truly happen!
es: —replied Defarge with a bitter tone. —Indeed, we cannot complain about the attractions offered by a world in which these and other atrocities are possible, nor about the beauty of a sky that impassively watches the horrors you are witnessing...!

en: Long live the Devil.
vi: Long live the devil.
tr: The devil enters a person's mind.
es: The devil rules us!... Long live hell!

en: Let us go on.”
vi: Let's move on.
tr: Anyway, let's get back to our work."
es: Let's go in, sir, let's go in!

en: This dialogue had been held in so very low a whisper, that not a word of it had reached the young lady’s ears.
vi: The two people whispered, so no words reached the girl's ears.
tr: They had spoken so quietly that the young girl did not hear a single word of it.
es: The dialogue that has been copied was held in such a low voice that not a single word reached the girl's ears.

en: But, by this time she trembled under such strong emotion, and her face expressed such deep anxiety, and, above all, such dread and terror, that mr Lorry felt it incumbent on him to speak a word or two of reassurance.
vi: But by this time, she was trembling violently with strong emotion, her face showing extreme anxiety, and more than that, full of terror and horror, making Mr. Lorry feel obliged to say a few reassuring words.
tr: But when they reached the door, she was trembling intensely under the influence of such a strong emotion – and there was such deep concern, moreover, fear and anxiety on her face that Mr. Lorry felt the need to say a few words to comfort her.
es: However, the emotion that dominated her was so intense, her face reflected such an expression of fright and such vivid anxiety, that Mr. Lorry felt it necessary to address her with some words aimed at lifting her depressed spirits.

en: “Courage, dear miss!
vi: − Be brave, miss!
tr: "Be strong, young lady!
es: "Courage, my dear miss!" he said.

en: Courage!
vi: Be brave!
tr: Be strong for a bit!
es: "Courage!"

en: Business!
vi: It's just work!
tr: Let's get our work done!
es: We are pursuing a business, whose painful phase will pass in a moment.

en: The worst will be over in a moment; it is but passing the room-door, and the worst is over.
vi: In just a moment, this terrible feeling will end; just pass through the door and this terrible feeling will be gone.
tr: The hardest part of the job will be over in a minute; once you pass through this door, the hardest part will be over.
es: As soon as we pass through this door, we will have overcome the worst.

en: Then, all the good you bring to him, all the relief, all the happiness you bring to him, begin.
vi: After that, all the good things you bring to him, all the compensation, all the happiness you bring, will begin.
tr: After that, it's all good, you'll give her kindness, peace, and happiness.
es: In a few seconds, the unfortunate one will be able to begin to savor all the good, all the comfort, all the happiness that you are going to provide him.

en: Let our good friend here, assist you on that side.
vi: Let our dear friend here support you on one side.
tr: Now let this kind-hearted brother of ours take your other arm.
es: Our good friend Defarge will help us...

en: That’s well, friend Defarge.
vi: That's right, my friend Defarge.
tr: Ah, that's good, Brother Defarge.
es: Our good friend Defarge will help us...

en: Come, now.
vi: Let's go!
tr: Alright now.
es: To business, to business!

en: Business, business!”
vi: Work, work!
tr: Let's continue with our work!"
es: To business, to business!

en: They went up slowly and softly.
vi: They went up, slowly, gently, this staircase was short, and soon they reached the top.
tr: They climbed the stairs slowly and silently.
es: As they turned a very sharp corner, they found three men who were looking through the keyhole and the cracks of the door that our visitors were about to open.

en: The staircase was short, and they were soon at the top.
vi: They went up, slowly, gently, this staircase was short, and soon they reached the top.
tr: There weren't many steps, and soon they were at the top.
es: As they turned a very sharp corner, they found three men who were looking through the keyhole and the cracks of the door that our visitors were about to open.

en: There, as it had an abrupt turn in it, they came all at once in sight of three men, whose heads were bent down close together at the side of a door, and who were intently looking into the room to which the door belonged, through some chinks or holes in the wall.
vi: Upon arrival, just as they rounded the corner at the top of the stairs, they suddenly saw three people bending over, heads close together, on one side of the door, intently peering into the room through the cracks and holes in the wall.
tr: There, as soon as they turned the corner, they unexpectedly found three men right in front of them, leaning against the side of the door, peering excitedly through various cracks and holes in the wall into the room where the door was open.
es: As they turned a very sharp corner, they found three men who were looking through the keyhole and the cracks of the door that our visitors were about to open.

en: On hearing footsteps close at hand, these three turned, and rose, and showed themselves to be the three of one name who had been drinking in the wine-shop.
vi: Hearing the approaching footsteps, all three turned around, stood up straight, and it turned out they were the same three men named Jacques who had been drinking in the tavern earlier.
tr: Upon hearing the approaching footsteps, all three immediately straightened up and turned around, revealing that they were the trio with the same names who were drinking in the wine shop.
es: The men in question turned out to be the same ones who moments before were drinking while standing by the counter.

en: “I forgot them in the surprise of your visit,” explained Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − I forgot about them because you came by unexpectedly, - Mr. Defarge explained.
tr: "I had forgotten these due to the surprise of your visit," explained Monsieur Defarge.
es: —The surprise your visit caused me made me forget them—said Defarge by way of explanation.

en: “Leave us, good boys; we have business here.”
vi: - Go on, my friends; we have work to do here.
tr: "Come on, you children go; we have work to do here."
es: — Please be so kind as to leave us, friends.

en: The three glided by, and went silently down.
vi: The three people squeezed past them and quietly went down.
tr: The three of them slipped past and quietly went down.
es: The three men disappeared silently.

en: There appearing to be no other door on that floor, and the keeper of the wine-shop going straight to this one when they were left alone, mr Lorry asked him in a whisper, with a little anger:
vi: On this floor, there didn't seem to be any other doors; the innkeeper went straight to that door after the three others had disappeared from sight.
tr: Since there was no other door on the floor and the owner of the wine shop headed straight for this door when they were alone, Mr. Lorry whispered with a slightly angry demeanor:
es: —Have you made Mr. Manette an object of exhibition?—asked Lorry in a very low voice with an angry expression.

en: “Do you make a show of Monsieur Manette?”
vi: Mr. Lorry seemed angry and lowered his voice to ask Defarge: − − You let people look at Mr. Manette?
tr: "Did you make Monsieur Manette into a showpiece?""
es: —Have you made Mr. Manette an object of exhibition?—asked Lorry in a very low voice with an angry expression.

en: “I show him, in the way you have seen, to a chosen few.”
vi: − − I let a few selected people see him, as you have seen.
tr: "I show it, as I am showing you right now, only to a select few.""
es: —I display it, as you have just seen, to a very select group of chosen individuals.

en: “Is that well?”
vi: − Should we?
tr: "Is this a good thing?"
es: —And do you think that's right?

en: “I think it is well.”
vi: − I think we should.
tr: "I think it's good."
es: —Yes, sir: I think it's fine.

en: “Who are the few?
vi: − Who are those few?
tr: "Who are these chosen people?"
es: —And those chosen ones, who are they?

en: How do you choose them?”
vi: How do you select them?
tr: "According to what criteria do you choose them?""
es: How do you choose them?

en: “I choose them as real men, of my name—Jacques is my name—to whom the sight is likely to do good.
vi: − I choose the honest ones, those with the same name as mine... my name is Jacques... seeing him will be beneficial for them.
tr: "I choose men who have the same name as mine – by the way, my name is Jacques – and who are presentable.
es: —I choose those who are true men... and are named like me: Santiago; men who should see it...

en: Enough; you are English; that is another thing.
vi: That's enough; you are English, you wouldn't understand.
tr: Anyway, that's enough; you are English; that's a different matter.
es: But you are English, and it is useless to give you explanations that you will not understand.

en: Stay there, if you please, a little moment.”
vi: Please stay there, wait a moment.
tr: Please wait here for a moment."
es: Please be kind enough to wait a moment.
