en: With an admonitory gesture to keep them back, he stooped, and looked in through the crevice in the wall.
vi: With a wave of his hand, he motioned them to step back, then he bent down to look through the gap in the wall.
tr: Defarge, with a cautionary demeanor, signaled with his hand for them to stay back and bent down to look through the crack in the wall.
es: By means of a gesture, he recommended to his companions that they remain still, and he pressed his face against a crack in the wall.

en: Soon raising his head again, he struck twice or thrice upon the door—evidently with no other object than to make a noise there.
vi: After that, he raised his head and knocked hard on the door two or three times - clearly with the sole purpose of making noise.
tr: Straightening up shortly after, he knocked on the door two or three times – clearly intending to make noise.
es: Moments later, he raised his head, knocked on the door two or three times, with no other purpose, undoubtedly, than to make noise, passed the key through it several times with the same intention, finally put it in the lock, and opened it making as much noise as possible.

en: With the same intention, he drew the key across it, three or four times, before he put it clumsily into the lock, and turned it as heavily as he could.
vi: With the same intention, he dragged the key across the door three or four times before clumsily inserting it into the lock and deliberately turning it with all his might.
tr: With the same intention, he also struggled three or four times to insert the key into the lock – barely managing to fit it in – and turned it as slowly as possible.
es: Moments later, he raised his head, knocked on the door two or three times, with no other purpose, undoubtedly, than to make noise, passed the key through it several times with the same intention, finally put it in the lock, and opened it making as much noise as possible.

en: The door slowly opened inward under his hand, and he looked into the room and said something.
vi: The door slowly opened inward under Defarge's hand, he looked inside and said something.
tr: The door slowly opened inward, Defarge glanced into the room and said something.
es: Slowly and silently, the door opened from the outside in, pushed by the hand of the innkeeper.

en: A faint voice answered something.
vi: A vague voice answered something.
tr: A feeble voice responded.
es: He leaned his head forward and said something.

en: Little more than a single syllable could have been spoken on either side.
vi: Neither side said more than a single word.
tr: Both sides uttered a single monosyllabic word.
es: A very weak voice replied.

en: He looked back over his shoulder, and beckoned them to enter.
vi: He glanced over his shoulder and signaled for the other two to come in.
tr: Defarge signaled them to enter by looking over his shoulder.
es: The innkeeper turned his face and indicated to his companions to follow him.

en: mr Lorry got his arm securely round the daughter’s waist, and held her; for he felt that she was sinking.
vi: Mr. Lorry wrapped his arm tightly around the girl's waist because he feared she might collapse.
tr: Mr. Lorry extended his arm around the young girl's waist and held her tightly; because she seemed about to faint.
es: Lorry wrapped his arm around the girl's waist, who was about to faint.

en: “A-a-a-business, business!” he urged, with a moisture that was not of business shining on his cheek.
vi: − Ah, work, just work! - He urged, but the sparkling tear on his cheek had nothing to do with work.
tr: "This, this is just a job, just a job!" he insisted, but the wetness glistening on his cheek said otherwise.
es: —Bu... siness... my dear... busi... ness! —exclaimed Lorry, turning his eyes towards the girl, from which something emerged that is not usually a product of business.

en: “Come in, come in!”
vi: - Come in, come in!
tr: "Come inside, come on!"
es: —Come in... come in!

en: “I am afraid of it,” she answered, shuddering.
vi: − I'm afraid of this, - the girl replied, trembling.
tr: "I'm scared," said the girl, trembling.
es: —I'm scared!

en: “Of it?
vi: − This?
tr: "Why are you afraid?"
es: —replied the young woman.

en: What?”
vi: What?
tr: "Why are you afraid?"
es: —Fear of what?

en: “I mean of him.
vi: − I mean that person.
tr: "I am afraid of him.
es: —Him... my father!

en: Of my father.”
vi: It's my father.
tr: Of my father."
es: —Him... my father!

en: Rendered in a manner desperate, by her state and by the beckoning of their conductor, he drew over his neck the arm that shook upon his shoulder, lifted her a little, and hurried her into the room.
vi: Frenzied by the girl's distress and the guide's beckoning gesture, Mr. Lorry pulled her arm around his neck, slightly lifted her, and quickly drew her into the room.
tr: On one hand, the girl's condition, and on the other, the hurried signals from his guides, left Mr. Lorry helpless. He took the trembling arm over his shoulder and lifted the girl slightly into the room.
es: Finding himself in a critical situation, due to the young woman's state of mind on one hand, and on the other hand the signals his guide was making for them to enter, Lorry lifted the former in his arms and crossed the door.

en: He sat her down just within the door, and held her, clinging to him.
vi: He set her down just inside the threshold and kept her close to him.
tr: As soon as they entered through the door, he put down the girl who was clinging tightly to him and held her.
es: Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window.

en: Defarge drew out the key, closed the door, locked it on the inside, took out the key again, and held it in his hand.
vi: Defarge took out the key, closed the door, locked it from the inside, and then took the key out and held it in his hand.
tr: Defarge took out the key, closed the door, locked it from the inside, and held the key in his hand after removing it again.
es: Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window.

en: All this he did, methodically, and with as loud and harsh an accompaniment of noise as he could make.
vi: Every action was careful and deliberately made loud and noisy.
tr: He did all of this in a very systematic manner, making the loudest and harshest noises possible.
es: Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window.

en: Finally, he walked across the room with a measured tread to where the window was.
vi: Finally, he crossed the room, his steps cautious, and went to the window.
tr: Finally, he walked heavily towards the place where the window was.
es: Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window.

en: He stopped there, and faced round.
vi: He stopped there and turned to face the room.
tr: He stopped there and turned his face.
es: He stopped next to it and turned halfway around.

en: The garret, built to be a depository for firewood and the like, was dim and dark: for, the window of dormer shape, was in truth a door in the roof, with a little crane over it for the hoisting up of stores from the street: unglazed, and closing up the middle in two pieces, like any other door of French construction.
vi: Once used as a storage for firewood and similar items, this attic room was dim and dark; because that dormer window was actually an opening to the roof, equipped with a small crane to pull goods up from the street; it had no glass panes but consisted of two shutters folding in the middle like all French-style doors.
tr: The attic, which was made to store wood and similar things, had a rather dim and mysterious appearance; the skylight was actually a door opening to the roof and had a small pulley mechanism used to get things from the shops below; it was unpolished and, like all other doors in French buildings, it was double-winged.
es: The attic, built to be a wood storage, barely received the visit of a very scarce light, as the window, extremely narrow and almost closed to avoid the cold, hindered the passage of light so much that it was impossible to see absolutely anything.

en: To exclude the cold, one half of this door was fast closed, and the other was opened but a very little way.
vi: To avoid the cold, one shutter was tightly closed, and the other was only slightly ajar.
tr: To block the cold, one wing of the door was tightly closed, while the other was left slightly ajar.
es: The attic, built to be a wood storage, barely received the visit of a very scarce light, as the window, extremely narrow and almost closed to avoid the cold, hindered the passage of light so much that it was impossible to see absolutely anything.

en: Such a scanty portion of light was admitted through these means, that it was difficult, on first coming in, to see anything; and long habit alone could have slowly formed in any one, the ability to do any work requiring nicety in such obscurity.
vi: Through that narrow gap, very little light came in, making the room pitch dark, and it was very difficult to see anything upon first entering; one had to stay for a long time to gradually get used to it and be able to do any meticulous work in such darkness.
tr: In this way, so little light came in that it was difficult to see anything upon first entering, and to do any work requiring descending in such darkness, one had to be doing it for a long time.
es: The attic, built to be a wood storage, barely received the visit of a very scarce light, as the window, extremely narrow and almost closed to avoid the cold, hindered the passage of light so much that it was impossible to see absolutely anything.

en: Yet, work of that kind was being done in the garret; for, with his back towards the door, and his face towards the window where the keeper of the wine-shop stood looking at him, a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very busy, making shoes.
vi: Yet, such meticulous work was being done right in this attic room.
tr: However, the very work being done in the attic was just like this; the person, with his back to the door and his face turned towards the window where the owner of the wine shop stood watching him, was an old man with white hair, sitting on a low stool, hunched over, making shoes with all his might.
es: And yet someone was working in that gloomy room, for next to the window he was facing, with his back turned to the door, there was a man with hair as white as snow, sitting on a very low stool and ardently engaged in the task of sewing shoes.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: With his back to the room door and facing the window where the innkeeper was standing and looking, a white-haired man sat on a low bench, bent forward, busy making shoes.
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: The Shoemaker
vi: 6. The Shoemaker
tr: Shoemaker
es: THE SHOEMAKER

en: Good day!” said Monsieur Defarge, looking down at the white head that bent low over the shoemaking.
vi: − Hello! - Mr. Defarge said while looking down at the silver-haired head bent over making shoes.
tr: Monsieur Defarge, bending over the shoe in his hand, said to the white-haired man working, "Good day!"
es: —Good morning—said the innkeeper, fixing his eyes on the white-haired head of the shoemaker.

en: It was raised for a moment, and a very faint voice responded to the salutation, as if it were at a distance:
vi: The head lifted slightly and responded to the greeting with a very soft voice, as if it came from afar: − Hello! −
tr: The white-haired head lifted for a moment and responded to the greeting with a feeble voice, as if the sound was coming from a great distance:
es: —Good morning.

en: “Good day!”
vi: The head lifted slightly and responded to the greeting with a very soft voice, as if it came from afar: − Hello! −
tr: "Good day!"
es: —Good morning.

en: “You are still hard at work, I see?”
vi: Are you still working hard?
tr: "I see you're still working hard."
es: —Always so hardworking, huh?

en: After a long silence, the head was lifted for another moment, and the voice replied, “Yes—I am working.”
vi: After a long silence, the head lifted again and that voice replied: − Yes... I am working.
tr: After a long silence, the head lifted again and responded, "Yes – I am working.""
es: After a while of anguished silence, the shoemaker raised his head and replied:

en: This time, a pair of haggard eyes had looked at the questioner, before the face had dropped again.
vi: This time, a pair of vacant eyes looked at the questioner before the face dropped again.
tr: This time, before his head fell forward again, he looked at the man asking the questions with a pair of weary eyes.
es: —Yes... I am working.

en: The faintness of the voice was pitiable and dreadful.
vi: That feeble voice was both pitiable and frightening.
tr: The frailty of the voice evoked both pity and suspicion within a person.
es: The languor of that voice hurt the ear.

en: It was not the faintness of physical weakness, though confinement and hard fare no doubt had their part in it.
vi: It was not the frailty of a physically exhausted body, although certainly, the captivity and harsh treatment had contributed.
tr: It did not contain a physical weakness, but undoubtedly the impact of being imprisoned and enduring harsh conditions was significant.
es: It was not that languor that follows the decline of strength, physical weakness, no, although it is undeniable that insufficient nourishment, hardships, and mistreatment received during the terrible captivity played some part in it: its special and typical characteristic came from the fact that it was a languor produced by solitude and lack of use of the voice.

en: Its deplorable peculiarity was, that it was the faintness of solitude and disuse.
vi: The pitiable aspect was due to the voice having long been unused in solitude.
tr: The pitiful state of the voice stemmed from loneliness and not being used for a long time.
es: It was not that languor that follows the decline of strength, physical weakness, no, although it is undeniable that insufficient nourishment, hardships, and mistreatment received during the terrible captivity played some part in it: its special and typical characteristic came from the fact that it was a languor produced by solitude and lack of use of the voice.

en: It was like the last feeble echo of a sound made long and long ago.
vi: The reply sounded like the dying echo of a sound that had faded long ago.
tr: It was as if it were the last faint echo of a voice that had sounded long ago.
es: It was something like the echo of a sound that was born many years before and at a considerable distance: a voice that had lost the life, the timbre of a human voice, a voice that produced in the senses the same impression that the sight of a most beautiful and delicate color turned by the hand of centuries into a faint stain of indefinable hue would produce, a voice that vividly reflected the despair of a lost and abandoned human being so eloquently that any traveler whom hunger and fatigue had overcome in the solitudes of the arid desert he was traversing would recognize in its timbre the voice of his home, the voice of the loved ones he left in the world, before bowing his head to draw his last breath.

en: So entirely had it lost the life and resonance of the human voice, that it affected the senses like a once beautiful colour faded away into a poor weak stain.
vi: The voice had lost all vitality and resonance of human speech to the extent that it was no different from a once beautiful color now faded into a pathetic, blurry stain.
tr: It was so far removed from the liveliness and resonance of a human voice that it gave the impression of a once beautiful color having turned into a pale stain.
es: It was something like the echo of a sound that was born many years before and at a considerable distance: a voice that had lost the life, the timbre of a human voice, a voice that produced in the senses the same impression that the sight of a most beautiful and delicate color turned by the hand of centuries into a faint stain of indefinable hue would produce, a voice that vividly reflected the despair of a lost and abandoned human being so eloquently that any traveler whom hunger and fatigue had overcome in the solitudes of the arid desert he was traversing would recognize in its timbre the voice of his home, the voice of the loved ones he left in the world, before bowing his head to draw his last breath.

en: So sunken and suppressed it was, that it was like a voice underground.
vi: The voice was deep and muffled, as if it were rising from the depths of the earth.
tr: This voice was so deep and suppressed that it seemed to come from underground.
es: It was something like the echo of a sound that was born many years before and at a considerable distance: a voice that had lost the life, the timbre of a human voice, a voice that produced in the senses the same impression that the sight of a most beautiful and delicate color turned by the hand of centuries into a faint stain of indefinable hue would produce, a voice that vividly reflected the despair of a lost and abandoned human being so eloquently that any traveler whom hunger and fatigue had overcome in the solitudes of the arid desert he was traversing would recognize in its timbre the voice of his home, the voice of the loved ones he left in the world, before bowing his head to draw his last breath.

en: So expressive it was, of a hopeless and lost creature, that a famished traveller, wearied out by lonely wandering in a wilderness, would have remembered home and friends in such a tone before lying down to die.
vi: The voice of a lost and despairing person, so sorrowful that one might think a starving, exhausted wanderer, isolated in the wilderness, would utter such a mournful sound of longing for home and friends before collapsing in death.
tr: It was so affecting that only a hopeless and lost creature, a traveler exhausted from wandering alone in the desert, on the brink of death from hunger, could produce such a voice while reminiscing about its home and friends before lying down to die.
es: It was something like the echo of a sound that was born many years before and at a considerable distance: a voice that had lost the life, the timbre of a human voice, a voice that produced in the senses the same impression that the sight of a most beautiful and delicate color turned by the hand of centuries into a faint stain of indefinable hue would produce, a voice that vividly reflected the despair of a lost and abandoned human being so eloquently that any traveler whom hunger and fatigue had overcome in the solitudes of the arid desert he was traversing would recognize in its timbre the voice of his home, the voice of the loved ones he left in the world, before bowing his head to draw his last breath.

en: Some minutes of silent work had passed: and the haggard eyes had looked up again: not with any interest or curiosity, but with a dull mechanical perception, beforehand, that the spot where the only visitor they were aware of had stood, was not yet empty.
vi: A few minutes of silent work passed, and the vacant eyes looked up again, not out of attention or curiosity, but merely a vague mechanical sense in front of them, at the spot where those eyes knew the sole guest had stood, and now still wasn't empty.
tr: Adam worked quietly for a while longer, then his weary eyes looked up again; it wasn't interest or curiosity, but a soulless realization, the spot where his visitor had stood a moment ago was still not empty.
es: After a few minutes that the old man spent working silently, oblivious to everything around him, he looked up again. In his eyes, there was not a trace of interest, not a trace of curiosity: they simply reflected that mechanical perception, that unconscious awareness that the space where an object or a person was previously seen remains occupied.

en: “I want,” said Defarge, who had not removed his gaze from the shoemaker, “to let in a little more light here.
vi: − I want to open the door a bit more to let in more light, - Defarge, who had not taken his eyes off the shoemaker, said.
tr: "I say," said Defarge, without taking his eyes off the shoemaker, "it would be good if a little more daylight came in."
es: —I would like to let a little more light in—said Defarge, whose eyes had not left the shoemaker for an instant.

en: You can bear a little more?”
vi: - Can you endure it a bit longer?
tr: Can you bear it?"
es: — Can you bear it?

en: The shoemaker stopped his work; looked with a vacant air of listening, at the floor on one side of him; then similarly, at the floor on the other side of him; then, upward at the speaker.
vi: The shoemaker paused; his eyes looked down at the floor beside him as if he hadn't heard anything, then looked at the floor on the other side, and finally looked up at the speaker.
tr: The shoemaker stopped his work; with a distracted demeanor, he looked to his right, then to his left, and finally at the man speaking above him.
es: The questioned person paused his work; he cast his eyes on the ground, to the right and left, as if looking for something, and then raised them towards the one who had just questioned him, finally asking:

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say?
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What were you saying?

en: “You can bear a little more light?”
vi: − Can you bear a bit more light?
tr: "Can you endure a bit more light?"
es: —I was asking if you could tolerate a little more light.

en: “I must bear it, if you let it in.”
vi: − I have to, if you want. -
tr: "If I have to endure, I will endure."
es: —I will have to tolerate her, if you let her in.

en: (Laying the palest shadow of a stress upon the second word.)
vi: The shoemaker's voice vaguely emphasized the second word.
tr: (There was a faint hint of emphasis on the second word.)
es: Defarge opened the window a little more.

en: The opened half-door was opened a little further, and secured at that angle for the time.
vi: The slightly ajar door was pushed open a bit more and temporarily secured at that angle.
tr: The half-open wing opened a bit more and was fixed at a certain angle.
es: Defarge opened the window a little more.

en: A broad ray of light fell into the garret, and showed the workman with an unfinished shoe upon his lap, pausing in his labour.
vi: A broad beam of light shone into the attic room, revealing that the craftsman had stopped his work, with an unfinished shoe resting on his lap.
tr: With a broad beam of light entering the attic, the craftsman who had paused his work and was sitting with an unfinished shoe in his lap came into view.
es: The rays of light that penetrated the attic perfectly illuminated the shoemaker, who had an unfinished shoe on his thigh.

en: His few common tools and various scraps of leather were at his feet and on his bench.
vi: At his feet and on the bench were some common tools and pieces of leather of various sizes.
tr: At his feet and on his workbench were a few tools and various pieces of leather.
es: Scattered on the floor, or placed on the bench, were various tools of the trade.

en: He had a white beard, raggedly cut, but not very long, a hollow face, and exceedingly bright eyes.
vi: He had a white, scraggly beard, not very long, a deeply sunken face, and strangely bright eyes.
tr: He had a short, patchy white beard, a sunken face, and bright, sparkling eyes.
es: He was a man with a beard trimmed in any manner, but not of excessive length.

en: The hollowness and thinness of his face would have caused them to look large, under his yet dark eyebrows and his confused white hair, though they had been really otherwise; but, they were naturally large, and looked unnaturally so.
vi: His haggard, emaciated face made his eyes appear larger beneath still-black eyebrows and disheveled white hair, although in reality, they were not; but his already large eyes now seemed unusually large.
tr: His face was so sunken and thin that even if his eyes, peering out from under his dark eyebrows and tangled hair, were small, they would certainly appear large; but his eyes were naturally large and did not look natural at all.
es: In his gaunt and emaciated face, two eyes shone extraordinarily, which would have seemed large and slanted, even if they were not naturally so.

en: His yellow rags of shirt lay open at the throat, and showed his body to be withered and worn.
vi: His tattered yellow shirt, open at the collar, exposed a wrinkled, wasted body.
tr: His withered old skin was visible through the open collar of his shabby yellow shirt.
es: The yellowish shirt he wore open at the chest revealed flabby flesh as white as paper.

en: He, and his old canvas frock, and his loose stockings, and all his poor tatters of clothes, had, in a long seclusion from direct light and air, faded down to such a dull uniformity of parchment-yellow, that it would have been hard to say which was which.
vi: Both he, his old canvas cloak, his sagging socks, and all his tattered, ragged clothes had not been exposed to sunlight and fresh air for so long that everything had turned the same dry yellow color, making it hard to distinguish between the man and his clothing.
tr: Both the man himself, his sack-like work clothes, his loose socks, in short, all those rags he wore had not seen light or air for so long that they had all taken on a lifeless pale yellow like parchment paper, making it hard to distinguish one from the other.
es: His skin, the old canvas blouse that covered the upper part of his body, the stockings, which, full of wrinkles, served as a wrapping for his fleshless calves, and in a word, all his garments, had acquired, by being deprived of the contact of air and light, a parchment tone that made it extremely difficult to determine the material used in their manufacture.

en: He had put up a hand between his eyes and the light, and the very bones of it seemed transparent.
vi: He raised a hand to shield his eyes from the light, which seemed to penetrate even through the bones.
tr: He put his hand in front of his eyes to block the light, his bones were so visible that it gave the impression of being transparent.
es: He had placed his hand like a screen between his eyes and the light, and all the bones of that hand were visible.

en: So he sat, with a steadfastly vacant gaze, pausing in his work.
vi: Stopping his work, he sat there with a blank, vacant stare.
tr: The man, with fixed eyes, paused his work and sat like that for a while.
es: He never looked at the person speaking to him without first lowering his eyes to the ground and moving them in all directions, as if he had lost the habit of associating space with sound; he never spoke without rambling, never remembered what he had just been asked, nor even what he himself was saying.

en: He never looked at the figure before him, without first looking down on this side of himself, then on that, as if he had lost the habit of associating place with sound; he never spoke, without first wandering in this manner, and forgetting to speak.
vi: He neither looked at the figure in front of him nor glanced to his side first before looking up at the other person, as if he had lost the habit of associating position with sound; he did not speak without first searching for the source of the voice, and then forgot to utter a word.
tr: Before looking at the person standing in front of him, he would always look to the right and then to the left; it was as if he had lost the habit of connecting sound with place; he never spoke without looking around like that, and then he would forget what he was going to say.
es: He never looked at the person speaking to him without first lowering his eyes to the ground and moving them in all directions, as if he had lost the habit of associating space with sound; he never spoke without rambling, never remembered what he had just been asked, nor even what he himself was saying.

en: “Are you going to finish that pair of shoes to-day?” asked Defarge, motioning to mr Lorry to come forward.
vi: − Did you finish those shoes today? - Defarge asked while signaling Mr. Lorry to come over.
tr: Defarge, while signaling Mr. Lorry to come with his hand, asked the man, "Will you finish those shoes today?"
es: —Do you plan to finish that pair of shoes today?—asked Defarge, signaling to Lorry to come closer.

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say? −
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What are you saying?

en: “Do you mean to finish that pair of shoes to-day?”
vi: Are you planning to finish the pair of shoes today?
tr: "Do you absolutely have to finish those shoes today?"
es: —Do you plan to finish those shoes today?

en: “I can’t say that I mean to.
vi: − I don't know if I can finish them.
tr: "It doesn't necessarily have to end.
es: —I can't say if I think it or not.

en: I suppose so.
vi: Probably will finish.
tr: I think... I don't know."
es: I think I do; but I don't know.

en: I don’t know.”
vi: Can't say for sure.
tr: I think... I don't know."
es: I think I do; but I don't know.

en: But, the question reminded him of his work, and he bent over it again.
vi: But that question reminded the worker of his job, and he bent down to continue working.
tr: But this question reminded him of the work he had left aside, and he bent over the task in front of him again.
es: The question reminded her of the task, and she devoted herself to it once again.

en: mr Lorry came silently forward, leaving the daughter by the door.
vi: Mr. Lorry quietly walked in, leaving the girl standing at the doorway.
tr: Mr. Lorry left the young girl by the door and quietly advanced towards them.
es: Mr. Lorry approached silently, leaving the girl by the door.

en: When he had stood, for a minute or two, by the side of Defarge, the shoemaker looked up.
vi: As Mr. Lorry stood for about one or two minutes beside Defarge, the shoemaker looked up.
tr: As he stood by Defarge for a minute or two, the shoemaker looked up.
es: He had been standing next to Defarge for one or two minutes when the shoemaker raised his head.

en: He showed no surprise at seeing another figure, but the unsteady fingers of one of his hands strayed to his lips as he looked at it (his lips and his nails were of the same pale lead-colour), and then the hand dropped to his work, and he once more bent over the shoe.
vi: He did not show any sign of surprise at seeing another person, but while looking at the newcomer, one of his hands brought trembling fingers to his lips (both the lips and the fingernails were the same leaden gray color), and then the hand went back to his work, once again bending over the shoe.
tr: He did not seem at all surprised to see a second person, but at that moment the trembling fingers of one hand found his lips (both his lips and nails were the same pale lead color), then his hand returned to his work and once again bent over the shoe.
es: He did not show the slightest surprise at seeing two people instead of one.

en: The look and the action had occupied but an instant.
vi: The glance and the movement happened swiftly.
tr: This glance and manner were very fleeting.
es: He did not show the slightest surprise at seeing two people instead of one.

en: “You have a visitor, you see,” said Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − You have a visitor, - Mr. Defarge said.
tr: "You have a visitor," said Monsieur Defarge.
es: "You have a visitor," observed Defarge.

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say? −
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What are you saying?

en: “Here is a visitor.”
vi: There is a guest coming to visit.
tr: "You have a visitor.""
es: —This gentleman has come to visit you.

en: The shoemaker looked up as before, but without removing a hand from his work.
vi: The shoemaker looked up as before, but his hands did not stop working.
tr: The shoemaker looked up just like before, but this time he didn't stop what he was doing.
es: The shoemaker looked up again, but did not stop working.

en: “Come!” said Defarge.
vi: − Hey! - Defarge said.
tr: "Look!" said Defarge.
es: "This gentleman," replied Defarge, "knows a lot about shoes."

en: “Here is monsieur, who knows a well-made shoe when he sees one.
vi: - This gentleman here can tell just by looking at the shoe whether it's well-made or not.
tr: "There is a gentleman here who understands good shoes.
es: "This gentleman," replied Defarge, "knows a lot about shoes."

en: Show him that shoe you are working at.
vi: Show him the shoe you're working on.
tr: Show him the shoe you made.
es: "Show him the one you are making so he can appreciate your work."

en: Take it, monsieur.”
vi: Here it is, sir.
tr: Look, Monsieur."
es: "Take it, sir."

en: mr Lorry took it in his hand.
vi: Mr. Lorry reached out to take the shoe.
tr: Mr. Lorry took the shoe in his hand.
es: Lorry took the shoe in her hand.

en: “Tell monsieur what kind of shoe it is, and the maker’s name.”
vi: − Please let this gentleman know what style these shoes are and who made them.
tr: "Tell the gentleman what type of shoe this is and the name of the maker.""
es: —Tell this gentleman what kind of shoe it is, and the name of the worker who makes it.

en: There was a longer pause than usual, before the shoemaker replied:
vi: After a longer-than-usual silence, the shoemaker finally replied: − I forgot what you asked.
tr: There was a longer silence than before, then the shoemaker replied:
es: There was a longer pause than usual before the shoemaker responded.

en: “I forget what it was you asked me.
vi: After a longer-than-usual silence, the shoemaker finally replied: − I forgot what you asked.
tr: "I forgot what you asked.
es: —I have forgotten the question—he said at last. —

en: What did you say?”
vi: What did you just say?
tr: What did you say?"
es: What were you saying?

en: “I said, couldn’t you describe the kind of shoe, for monsieur’s information?”
vi: − I asked if you could tell this gentleman the style of the shoe? −
tr: "I had said, could you tell what type of shoe this is for the gentleman?"
es: —I asked you to kindly tell this gentleman what kind of shoe this is.

en: “It is a lady’s shoe.
vi: This is a woman's shoe.
tr: "This is a woman's shoe.
es: —It is a lady's shoe... a walking shoe, suitable for a young lady.

en: It is a young lady’s walking-shoe.
vi: A walking shoe for a young lady.
tr: A walking shoe for a young lady.
es: —It is a lady's shoe... a walking shoe, suitable for a young lady.

en: It is in the present mode.
vi: It's the current trend.
tr: Latest fashion.
es: It is fashionable, although the truth is I have never seen the fashion.

en: I never saw the mode.
vi: I've never seen this fashion before.
tr: I don't know fashion.
es: It is fashionable, although the truth is I have never seen the fashion.

en: I have had a pattern in my hand.”
vi: I made it based on an existing model. -
tr: But I had a model in my hand."
es: It is fashionable, although the truth is I have never seen the fashion.

en: He glanced at the shoe with some little passing touch of pride.
vi: He looked at the shoe, his face showing a hint of pride. − Which cobbler made these shoes?
tr: But I had a model in my hand."
es: —And the name of the shoemaker?—asked Defarge.

en: “And the maker’s name?” said Defarge.
vi: - Defarge said.
tr: "I wonder what the name of the person who did it is?" said Defarge.
es: —And the name of the shoemaker?—asked Defarge.

en: Now that he had no work to hold, he laid the knuckles of the right hand in the hollow of the left, and then the knuckles of the left hand in the hollow of the right, and then passed a hand across his bearded chin, and so on in regular changes, without a moment’s intermission.
vi: Now with nothing left to do, he kept threading the fingers of his right hand into the palm of his left hand, then threading the fingers of his left hand into the palm of his right hand, then bringing one hand up to his chin to stroke his beard. These actions repeated incessantly in that exact sequence.
tr: Since the shoemaker's hands were idle, he first placed his right hand in his left palm, then his left hand in his right palm, then ran his hand over his bearded chin, and continued to do this at regular intervals without any pause.
es: The unfortunate man placed the knuckles of his right hand in the palm of his left, then reversed the order, placing the knuckles of the latter in the palm of the former, next he passed both over his beard and then over his forehead.

en: The task of recalling him from the vagrancy into which he always sank when he had spoken, was like recalling some very weak person from a swoon, or endeavouring, in the hope of some disclosure, to stay the spirit of a fast-dying man.
vi: Every time he spoke, his mind wandered; reminding him was akin to rousing a fainted person or trying to sustain the life of someone on the brink of death in hopes of extracting some revelation.
tr: When he spoke, it was like trying to bring a very weak person to consciousness or trying to preserve the soul of a dying man with a glimmer of hope.
es: The task of pulling him out of the abstraction in which he always became immersed after speaking did not yield in importance and difficulty to that of reviving a fainted person or of infusing a bit of artificial life into an almost dead body from which some revelation is hoped to be obtained.

en: “Did you ask me for my name?”
vi: − Are you asking my name? −
tr: "Did you ask my name?"
es: —Did you ask my name?

en: “Assuredly I did.”
vi: That's right.
tr: "Yes, I asked for his name.""
es: —Indeed, that's what I asked.

en: “One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”
vi: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
tr: "One Hundred Five, North Tower.""
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: “Is that all?”
vi: − Is that all?
tr: "Is that all?""
es: —Nothing else?

en: “One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”
vi: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
tr: "One Hundred Five, North Tower.""
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: With a weary sound that was not a sigh, nor a groan, he bent to work again, until the silence was again broken.
vi: Letting out a sound that was neither a sigh nor a groan, he bent over to work again until the silence was once more broken.
tr: He bent over his work again, emitting a tired sound that resembled neither a sigh nor a moan, until the silence was broken.
es: Exhaling something that was neither a sigh nor a moan, he returned to the task, which he did not pause until Mr. Lorry, staring at him intently, asked:

en: “You are not a shoemaker by trade?” said mr Lorry, looking steadfastly at him.
vi: − You are not a professional shoemaker, are you? - Mr. Lorry asked while staring intently at the shoemaker.
tr: "Actually, you are not a shoemaker, are you?" said Mr. Lorry, without taking his eyes off him.
es: —Your profession has not been that of a shoemaker, has it?

en: His haggard eyes turned to Defarge as if he would have transferred the question to him: but as no help came from that quarter, they turned back on the questioner when they had sought the ground.
vi: His weary eyes turned towards Defarge as if wanting to transfer the question to him; but receiving no help from that direction, his eyes searched the ground for an answer before looking up at the questioner.
tr: The man's weary eyes turned to Defarge as if to transfer the question to him; but when no help came from that side, he looked around and then turned to the one who asked the question.
es: The interrogated man turned his sunken eyes towards Defarge, as if expecting him to answer the question for him, but since no help came from that direction, he directed them towards his interrogator, not without first fixing them on the ground:

en: “I am not a shoemaker by trade?
vi: − I'm not a professional shoemaker?
tr: "Actually, am I not a shoemaker?
es: —Hasn't my profession been that of a shoemaker?

en: No, I was not a shoemaker by trade.
vi: Yes, I'm not a professional shoemaker.
tr: No, I wasn't actually a shoemaker.
es: No: it hasn't been.

en: I-I learnt it here.
vi: I... I learned the trade here.
tr: I... I learned this here.
es: I learned... I learned the trade... there.

en: I taught myself.
vi: I taught myself.
tr: By myself.
es: I taught myself.

en: I asked leave to—”
vi: I asked for permission...
tr: I asked for permission for the thing-"
es: I asked to be allowed...

en: He lapsed away, even for minutes, ringing those measured changes on his hands the whole time.
vi: He was again lost in thought for several minutes, his hands constantly twisting together as if rummaging through that span of time.
tr: There he hesitated, for minutes, repeating the same routine movements with his hands again.
es: He lost, upon reaching this point, the thread of what he was saying.

en: His eyes came slowly back, at last, to the face from which they had wandered; when they rested on it, he started, and resumed, in the manner of a sleeper that moment awake, reverting to a subject of last night.
vi: Finally, his gaze slowly turned towards the face he had lost; fixing on it when found, he continued to answer like someone who had just woken up and wanted to return to the unfinished conversation from the night before: − I had asked for permission to study on my own, and it was very difficult, it took a long time, but I was finally granted permission, and I have been making shoes ever since.
tr: Then his eyes finally, slowly, turned back to the face they had left earlier, and as they focused on it, the shoemaker continued from where he had left off, with the demeanor of someone who had just woken up and returned to a topic discussed the previous night.
es: His gaze wandered errantly from one place to another until he found again the person he was speaking with, and continued, with the tone of someone who, upon waking up, resumes a conversation that sleep had interrupted:

en: “I asked leave to teach myself, and I got it with much difficulty after a long while, and I have made shoes ever since.”
vi: Finally, his gaze slowly turned towards the face he had lost; fixing on it when found, he continued to answer like someone who had just woken up and wanted to return to the unfinished conversation from the night before: − I had asked for permission to study on my own, and it was very difficult, it took a long time, but I was finally granted permission, and I have been making shoes ever since.
tr: "I asked for permission to learn on my own for something, and after they made me struggle for a long time, they gave it to me. Since then, I have been making shoes."
es: —I asked to be allowed to learn on my own, and I learned through time and difficulties. Since then, I have done nothing but make shoes.

en: As he held out his hand for the shoe that had been taken from him, mr Lorry said, still looking steadfastly in his face:
vi: As the shoemaker reached out to take back the shoe, Mr. Lorry said, his eyes still fixed on the face of the person opposite: "Dr. Manette, do you not remember anything about me?"
tr: When the shoemaker reached for the shoe taken from his hand, Mr. Lorry, his eyes still persistently on the man, said:
es: At the moment he reached out his hand to take the shoe from Lorry's, the latter asked him:

en: “Monsieur Manette, do you remember nothing of me?”
vi: As the shoemaker reached out to take back the shoe, Mr. Lorry said, his eyes still fixed on the face of the person opposite: "Dr. Manette, do you not remember anything about me?"
tr: "Monsieur Manette, don't you remember me at all?"
es: —Mr. Manette, don't you remember me?

en: The shoe dropped to the ground, and he sat looking fixedly at the questioner.
vi: The shoe fell to the ground, and the shoemaker sat staring intently at the questioner.
tr: The shoe fell to the ground and the shoemaker fixed his eyes on the man asking the questions.
es: The shoe fell to the ground and the cobbler remained motionless, his eyes fixed on the face of the person who was asking him.

en: “Monsieur Manette”; mr Lorry laid his hand upon Defarge’s arm; “do you remember nothing of this man?
vi: − Mr. Manette, - Mr. Lorry grasped Defarge's arm, - do you not remember anything about this person?
tr: "Monsieur Manette," said Mr. Lorry, placing his hand on Defarge's arm; "do you not remember this man?
es: —Mr. Manette—repeated Lorry, placing a hand on Defarge's shoulder. —Don't you remember this man?

en: Look at him.
vi: Look at him.
tr: Take a look at him.
es: Look at him closely!

en: Look at me.
vi: Look at me.
tr: Look at me.
es: Look at me too!

en: Is there no old banker, no old business, no old servant, no old time, rising in your mind, Monsieur Manette?”
vi: Does your mind not recall anything about the old banker, the old work, the old servant, the old times, Mr. Manette?
tr: Do the old banker, your old job, your old servant, the old times not come to mind, Monsieur Manette?"
es: Don't the figures of your former banker, the memory of your old business, the image of your old servant rise in your mind?

en: As the captive of many years sat looking fixedly, by turns, at mr Lorry and at Defarge, some long obliterated marks of an actively intent intelligence in the middle of the forehead, gradually forced themselves through the black mist that had fallen on him.
vi: While the man who had been imprisoned for so many years stared intently, shifting his gaze from Lorry to Defarge, the traces of clear recognition that had long been erased from his forehead now slowly struggled to tear through the dark clouds shrouding his memory.
tr: The man who had been imprisoned for years sat down and stared alternately at Mr. Lorry and Defarge, the traces of intelligence that had almost faded from the center of his forehead slowly dispersing the dark fog that had settled over him.
es: While the unfortunate man, recently freed from the tomb where he had been buried alive for so many years, fixed his gaze now on Mr. Lorry, now on Defarge, his forehead revealed that in the depths of his brain, some sparks of intelligence were waging a fierce battle with the profound darkness that, reigning as the sole mistress, paralyzed all his activity.

en: They were overclouded again, they were fainter, they were gone; but they had been there.
vi: The signs of recognition were covered, faded, appearing and lingering.
tr: Then his mind clouded again, becoming vague and completely disappearing; but for a while, they were there.
es: The darkness intensified, unwilling to lose its dominion; the sparks weakened and eventually died out; but they had shone, and what once shines, what once awakens, is not entirely extinguished, it can shine again. Thus it happened indeed.

en: And so exactly was the expression repeated on the fair young face of her who had crept along the wall to a point where she could see him, and where she now stood looking at him, with hands which at first had been only raised in frightened compassion, if not even to keep him off and shut out the sight of him, but which were now extending towards him, trembling with eagerness to lay the spectral face upon her warm young breast, and love it back to life and hope—so exactly was the expression repeated (though in stronger characters) on her fair young face, that it looked as though it had passed like a moving light, from him to her.
vi: And that very same expression was repeated on the forehead of the beautiful girl who had been stealthily making her way along the wall to a spot where she could see the shoemaker. She stood there, her hands initially raised in fear, as if to ward off the other person from her sight, now reaching out, trembling with the desire to embrace that ghostly face, to bring life and hope to him with her love. More clearly imprinted, the expression on the girl's forehead was the same as that of the shoemaker, as if it had been transmitted like a beam of light from him to her.
tr: The expression on the beautiful face of the young girl who had slowly moved to a point from where she could see him from the wall and was now watching him from where she stood was the same; at first, she brought her hands to her face out of a mixture of fear and compassion, not to prevent herself from seeing him, but now her hands were reaching out to him, trembling with the excitement of pressing his ghost-like face to her warm chest and giving him life and hope again – the expression on the girl's beautiful, young face was so identical to the man's (but the girl's expression was stronger) that it gave the impression that a moving light had passed from the man to the girl.
es: When moments later his gaze fell upon the youthful face of the girl who, crawling along the wall, had approached, and standing with outstretched hands, watched him, first with a mixture of infinite compassion and terror, and later with a fervent longing to press that spectral head against her chest and a fervent desire to instill in his soul the warmth of life, the light of love and hope, intelligence emerged again, but more powerfully than the first time, at the mysterious conjuring of the spark that, emanating from the young woman's soul, went to ignite that of the old man.

en: Darkness had fallen on him in its place.
vi: The darkness once again covered the worker's forehead.
tr: A darkness had fallen over the man again.
es: The shadows, stubbornly resisting, finally remained masters of the field.

en: He looked at the two, less and less attentively, and his eyes in gloomy abstraction sought the ground and looked about him in the old way.
vi: He looked at the two men in front of him, becoming more and more distracted, then his gloomy eyes wandered around the floor as before.
tr: He looked at the two men with much less attention than before, and his eyes found their place again in that dim reverie, and just like before, he looked to the right and to the left.
es: The old man looked at the people in front of him with less attention than before, and his eyes sought the ground with the air of gloomy abstraction that was peculiar to them.

en: Finally, with a deep long sigh, he took the shoe up, and resumed his work.
vi: Finally, with a long sigh, he picked up the shoe and continued his work.
tr: Finally, with a long and deep sigh, he picked up the shoe from the ground and continued his work.
es: After a few seconds, he sighed, picked up the shoe, and resumed his task.

en: “Have you recognised him, monsieur?” asked Defarge in a whisper.
vi: − Do you recognize him? - Defarge whispered.
tr: "Do you remember him, monsieur?" asked Defarge in a whisper.
es: —Have you recognized him, sir?—whispered Defarge in Lorry's ear.

en: “Yes; for a moment.
vi: − Yes, just for a moment.
tr: "Yes; for a moment.
es: —I deemed it impossible at first, but even if only for brief moments, I managed to recognize the face that was so familiar to me once... Shh... silence!

en: At first I thought it quite hopeless, but I have unquestionably seen, for a single moment, the face that I once knew so well.
vi: At first, I thought it was hopeless, but clearly, in just a fleeting moment, I recognized the face that had once been so familiar to me.
tr: At first, I had no hope at all, but then suddenly, that face I once knew so well came to life in my mind.
es: —I deemed it impossible at first, but even if only for brief moments, I managed to recognize the face that was so familiar to me once... Shh... silence!

en: Hush!
vi: Shh!
tr: Shh!
es: Let's move a little further away!

en: Let us draw further back.
vi: Let's move back a bit further.
tr: Anyway, let's step back a bit.
es: Let's move a little further away!

en: Hush!”
vi: Shh!
tr: Slowly!"
es: Let's move a little further away!

en: She had moved from the wall of the garret, very near to the bench on which he sat.
vi: The girl had moved from the wall of the attic room to very close to the shoemaker's bench.
tr: The young girl had moved away from the wall of the attic and had approached the bench where the man was sitting.
es: The girl had separated from the wall and was silently approaching the bench where the old man was sitting.

en: There was something awful in his unconsciousness of the figure that could have put out its hand and touched him as he stooped over his labour.
vi: It was truly frightening; he kept bending over his work, completely unaware of the presence of someone so close that they could touch him by simply reaching out.
tr: The shoemaker was so engrossed in his work that it was a grave situation that he was unaware of a hand that could reach out and touch him at any moment.
es: It was a simply impressive scene.

en: Not a word was spoken, not a sound was made.
vi: Not a word; not a sound.
tr: There wasn't a sound.
es: No one uttered a word. Not the slightest sound came to disturb that august silence.

en: She stood, like a spirit, beside him, and he bent over his work.
vi: She stood still like a ghost beside him, while he remained bent over the shoe.
tr: The girl stood next to the man like a ghost for a while, and the man continued to bend over his work.
es: The girl, resembling a spirit, stood beside the shoemaker, and he worked with fervor.

en: It happened, at length, that he had occasion to change the instrument in his hand, for his shoemaker’s knife.
vi: After a very long time, he finally put down the tool in his hand to pick up the skinning knife.
tr: At one point, he had to put down the tool in his hand and pick up the utility knife.
es: It happened that after a while, the old man needed to switch the tool he was working with for the cobbler's knife.

en: It lay on that side of him which was not the side on which she stood.
vi: The knife was lying on the far side from where the girl stood.
tr: The utility knife was on the ground, on the opposite side of where the girl was standing.
es: He picked it up, and when he was about to use it, he stopped.

en: He had taken it up, and was stooping to work again, when his eyes caught the skirt of her dress.
vi: He picked up the knife, bent down to work again, and his eyes caught the hem of her dress.
tr: The shoemaker had just picked it up from the ground and was about to bend over his work again when his eyes caught the hem of the girl's dress.
es: His eyes had just seen a skirt.

en: He raised them, and saw her face.
vi: He looked up and saw the girl.
tr: When he lifted his head, he met her face.
es: Slowly, they rose until they found the girl's face, and there they stopped.

en: The two spectators started forward, but she stayed them with a motion of her hand.
vi: The two others started to step forward, but she gestured to stop them.
tr: The two men watching them seemed about to step forward, but the young girl signaled them to stop with her hand.
es: Slowly, they rose until they found the girl's face, and there they stopped.

en: She had no fear of his striking at her with the knife, though they had.
vi: They were afraid the shoemaker might use the knife to harm the girl, but she was not.
tr: The girl was never afraid that the shoemaker would attack her with the knife, but the others were afraid of this.
es: Gusts of terror crossed the forehead of the unfortunate man; his lips moved as if they wanted to pronounce words that his throat refused to articulate, his breathing became labored and panting, and finally he was heard to murmur:

en: He stared at her with a fearful look, and after a while his lips began to form some words, though no sound proceeded from them.
vi: He looked at Manette with a fearful gaze, and after a moment, his lips moved but no words came out.
tr: The shoemaker looked at the girl with fear-filled eyes, and soon his lips began to move, but no meaningful sound was coming out yet.
es: Gusts of terror crossed the forehead of the unfortunate man; his lips moved as if they wanted to pronounce words that his throat refused to articulate, his breathing became labored and panting, and finally he was heard to murmur:

en: By degrees, in the pauses of his quick and laboured breathing, he was heard to say:
vi: Then slowly, amidst heavy, rapid breaths, a sentence emerged word by word: −
tr: Then, amidst his hurried and weary breaths, something came out of his mouth in broken fragments:
es: Gusts of terror crossed the forehead of the unfortunate man; his lips moved as if they wanted to pronounce words that his throat refused to articulate, his breathing became labored and panting, and finally he was heard to murmur:

en: “What is this?”
vi: What is this?
tr: "Who is this?"
es: —What is this?

en: With the tears streaming down her face, she put her two hands to her lips, and kissed them to him; then clasped them on her breast, as if she laid his ruined head there.
vi: Tears streaming down her cheeks, the girl raised her hands to her lips to send the shoemaker a kiss, then clasped her hands over her chest as if cradling his sorrowful head.
tr: As tears streamed down her cheeks, the girl brought her hands to her lips and sent a kiss to the man; then, as if she were resting his devastated head on her chest, she clasped her hands over her chest.
es: The girl, down whose cheeks streams of tears were running, brought her hands, which were clasped in a pleading gesture, to her lips, kissed them, and then crossed her arms over her chest as if she held the beloved head of the old man between them.

en: “You are not the gaoler’s daughter?”
vi: − Aren't you the daughter of the jailer?
tr: "Are you the jailer's daughter?"
es: —Are you the jailer's daughter?—he asked.

en: She sighed “No.”
vi: − No, - the girl sighed.
tr: The young girl sighed and said, "No."
es: —No—she sighed.

en: “Who are you?”
vi: − Who are you?
tr: The young girl sighed and said, "No."
es: —Who are you, then?

en: Not yet trusting the tones of her voice, she sat down on the bench beside him.
vi: Not trusting her own voice, she sat down on the bench next to him.
tr: The girl was too excited to speak, she sat quietly next to the man.
es: Understanding the impossibility of articulating a word, the young woman took a seat on the bench next to the old man.

en: He recoiled, but she laid her hand upon his arm.
vi: The shoemaker retreated but she had grabbed his arm.
tr: The shoemaker seemed to move aside, but the girl placed her hand on his arm.
es: He wanted to move away, but felt the sweet pressure of his companion's hand on his arm, and, leaving the knife on the bench, he remained contemplating her.

en: A strange thrill struck him when she did so, and visibly passed over his frame; he laid the knife down softly, as he sat staring at her.
vi: As soon as her hand touched him, a strange shiver clearly spread throughout his body; the shoemaker gently put the knife down, his eyes never leaving the girl.
tr: As a result, the man's body shivered with a strange excitement; he put the knife aside and fixed his eyes on the girl.
es: He wanted to move away, but felt the sweet pressure of his companion's hand on his arm, and, leaving the knife on the bench, he remained contemplating her.

en: Her golden hair, which she wore in long curls, had been hurriedly pushed aside, and fell down over her neck.
vi: Manette's golden curls were hastily tossed to the sides and flowed down around her neck.
tr: The girl's long, curly golden hair was hastily tossed to the side, cascading down her neck.
es: The girl's golden hair, styled in long ringlets, fell over her shoulders.

en: Advancing his hand by little and little, he took it up and looked at it.
vi: The shoemaker's hand inched closer to her, lifting a lock of hair to look at it.
tr: The man slowly reached out his hand, took hold of the girl's hair, and examined it.
es: The old man slowly and timidly reached out a hand to touch it; their eyes lit up, but the light that had momentarily shone in his intelligence faded, and, letting out a sigh, he bowed his head and tried to resume his work.

en: In the midst of the action he went astray, and, with another deep sigh, fell to work at his shoemaking.
vi: His mind suddenly wandered again, he sighed once more, then bent over the shoe he was working on.
tr: But at that moment, his mind became confused, and with a deep sigh, he bent over the shoe again.
es: The old man slowly and timidly reached out a hand to touch it; their eyes lit up, but the light that had momentarily shone in his intelligence faded, and, letting out a sigh, he bowed his head and tried to resume his work.

vi: His mind suddenly wandered again, he sighed once more, then bent over the shoe he was working on.
tr: But at that moment, his mind became confused, and with a deep sigh, he bent over the shoe again.
es: The old man slowly and timidly reached out a hand to touch it; their eyes lit up, but the light that had momentarily shone in his intelligence faded, and, letting out a sigh, he bowed his head and tried to resume his work.

en: Original
vi: His mind suddenly wandered again, he sighed once more, then bent over the shoe he was working on.
tr: But at that moment, his mind became confused, and with a deep sigh, he bent over the shoe again.
es: The old man slowly and timidly reached out a hand to touch it; their eyes lit up, but the light that had momentarily shone in his intelligence faded, and, letting out a sigh, he bowed his head and tried to resume his work.

en: But not for long.
vi: But not for long.
tr: It didn't take too long.
es: His abstraction lasted very little time.

en: Releasing his arm, she laid her hand upon his shoulder.
vi: Releasing the shoemaker's arm, the girl placed her hand on his shoulder.
tr: The girl removed her hand from the man's arm and placed it on his shoulder.
es: After directing two or three glances at the shoe, as if to make sure it was still on his knee, he resolutely placed it on the bench, brought his hands to his neck, and untied a dirty and blackened cord that surrounded it, from which hung a small cloth bag.

en: After looking doubtfully at it, two or three times, as if to be sure that it was really there, he laid down his work, put his hand to his neck, and took off a blackened string with a scrap of folded rag attached to it.
vi: After two or three times looking at that hand full of suspicion as if to make sure it was really there, he put his work down again, raised his hand to his neck, and removed a darkened string with a small, tattered piece of cloth tied to it.
tr: The shoemaker, after turning around a few times and looking suspiciously at the girl's hand as if to make sure she was still there, set the shoe aside, brought his hand to his collar, and pulled out a tarnished string with a folded piece of cloth tied to the end.
es: After directing two or three glances at the shoe, as if to make sure it was still on his knee, he resolutely placed it on the bench, brought his hands to his neck, and untied a dirty and blackened cord that surrounded it, from which hung a small cloth bag.

en: He opened this, carefully, on his knee, and it contained a very little quantity of hair: not more than one or two long golden hairs, which he had, in some old day, wound off upon his finger.
vi: The shoemaker placed the cloth bundle on his knee, carefully opened it, and inside was a small amount of hair, just a few long golden strands that he had long ago wrapped around his finger.
tr: He carefully opened it on his knees; inside, there was a very small amount of hair, a few strands of long golden hair that he used to wrap around his finger in the old days.
es: Placing the bag on his knee, he carefully opened it and took out two locks of hair, which he examined closely.

en: He took her hair into his hand again, and looked closely at it.
vi: He lifted a lock of her hair and examined it closely.
tr: Then he held the girl's hair again and looked at it carefully.
es: Placing the bag on his knee, he carefully opened it and took out two locks of hair, which he examined closely.

en: “It is the same.
vi: − Exactly the same.
tr: "The same."
es: —It's the same one! —he murmured.

en: How can it be!
vi: How can that be!
tr: How could it be!
es: —How is it possible?

en: When was it!
vi: Since when!
tr: When was it!
es: When did it happen?

en: How was it!”
vi: How is that possible!
tr: How did it happen!"
es: How did it happen?

en: As the concentrated expression returned to his forehead, he seemed to become conscious that it was in hers too.
vi: When the wrinkles of thought appeared on the shoemaker's forehead, he seemed to notice that the girl's forehead had the same expression.
tr: The entire intensity of his expression had shifted to the man's forehead, and he noticed that the same expression was on the girl as well.
es: His forehead lit up more than ever.

en: He turned her full to the light, and looked at her.
vi: He turned her fully towards the light to look at her.
tr: He turned her towards the light and looked again.
es: Turning towards the girl, he took her head in his hands, positioned it so that the light from the window fell fully on her face, and after a long moment of silent contemplation, he said:

en: “She had laid her head upon my shoulder, that night when I was summoned out—she had a fear of my going, though I had none—and when I was brought to the North Tower they found these upon my sleeve.
vi: − She rested her head on my shoulder that night when I was summoned... she feared this departure, even though I did not... and when I was taken to the North Tower, people saw these few strands of hair on my sleeve.
tr: "She had rested her head on my shoulder, it was the evening I was summoned – she was afraid I would leave, but I was not afraid at all – and when I was taken to the North Tower, they found these on me.
es: —That night, the night they called me out, she had rested her head on my shoulder... She feared that I would go out... I didn't feel the slightest apprehension... and when they locked me in the North Tower, they found this hidden in my sleeve...

en: ‘You will leave me them?
vi: “Will you leave them with me?
tr: 'Would you leave these with me?
es: «Will you allow me to keep it?»—I asked them.

en: They can never help me to escape in the body, though they may in the spirit.’
vi: These strands of hair cannot help me escape physically, though they might free my spirit.”
tr: They won't help me escape from here, but they will be good for my soul.'
es: —They shall not facilitate the escape of my body... although thanks to them, my spirit will frequently pass through the bars».

en: Those were the words I said.
vi: Those were the words I said.
tr: That's what I told them.
es: Those were the words I said to them... I remember them as if I had just spoken them.

en: I remember them very well.”
vi: I still remember it very clearly.
tr: I remember it very well."
es: Those were the words I said to them... I remember them as if I had just spoken them.

en: He formed this speech with his lips many times before he could utter it.
vi: His lips moved for a long time before he could speak.
tr: His lips had done quite a bit of preparation to be able to utter these words.
es: For a long time, his lips moved before he managed to articulate the words that are transcribed, but when he could speak, he did so perfectly, albeit very slowly.

en: But when he did find spoken words for it, they came to him coherently, though slowly.
vi: But when he did speak, he was very articulate, though slow.
tr: But as they slowly spilled from his mouth, they were quite coherent.
es: For a long time, his lips moved before he managed to articulate the words that are transcribed, but when he could speak, he did so perfectly, albeit very slowly.

en: “How was this?—Was it you?”
vi: − How can that be?... Is that her?
tr: "How did this happen? Was it you?"
es: —I don't understand...—he added. — Was it you?

en: Once more, the two spectators started, as he turned upon her with a frightful suddenness.
vi: Once again, Mr. Lorry and Defarge were startled when the shoemaker suddenly turned to look at the girl, so abruptly that it was frightening.
tr: As the shoemaker turned towards the girl, the two men once again rushed forward in a panic.
es: The two silent witnesses of the scene advanced alarmed upon observing the abruptness with which the old man turned towards the girl; but she, perfectly calm, said to them in a very low voice:

en: But she sat perfectly still in his grasp, and only said, in a low voice, “I entreat you, good gentlemen, do not come near us, do not speak, do not move!”
vi: But while he held her tightly, Manette remained very still and softly said: − Please, sirs, please, do not come near us, do not speak, do not move.
tr: But the young girl, with the man's eyes still on her, continued to sit calmly and said in a low voice, "Please, gentlemen, do not approach, do not say anything, do not move from your place!"
es: —I beg you, my good sirs, not to come closer, not to speak, not to move.

en: “Hark!” he exclaimed.
vi: − Listen! - He exclaimed.
tr: "Stop!" the man shouted.
es: —Shh!

en: “Whose voice was that?”
vi: - Whose voice is that?
tr: "Whose voice was that?"
es: —exclaimed the old man.—Who is speaking?

en: His hands released her as he uttered this cry, and went up to his white hair, which they tore in a frenzy.
vi: Along with the shout, his hands released the girl and frantically tore at his own gray hair.
tr: With this outcry, he removed his hands from the girl and brought them to his disheveled white hair.
es: He put the curls back in the little bag and wanted to tie the string around his neck again, but without taking his eyes off the young woman and shaking his head with an expression of somber pain.

en: It died out, as everything but his shoemaking did die out of him, and he refolded his little packet and tried to secure it in his breast; but he still looked at her, and gloomily shook his head.
vi: This outburst too would pass, like so many things that had faded from his mind except for shoemaking. He folded the small cloth bundle and tried to tie it around his neck as before, but he still kept his eyes fixed on the girl and shook his head sadly.
tr: He had lost her, he had lost everything except his shoemaking skills; he folded his small package again and tucked it safely into his bosom; but his eyes were still on the young girl and he shook his head pensively.
es: He put the curls back in the little bag and wanted to tie the string around his neck again, but without taking his eyes off the young woman and shaking his head with an expression of somber pain.

en: “No, no, no; you are too young, too blooming.
vi: − No, no, no; you are too young, too fresh.
tr: "No, no; you are very young, very fresh.
es: —No, no, no!

en: It can’t be.
vi: It cannot be her.
tr: You cannot be her.
es: —he replied. —It is not possible!...

en: See what the prisoner is.
vi: Look at the appearance of this prisoner.
tr: Look at this prisoner.
es: You are too young, too much of a child! You see the effects of being buried in a prison!...

en: These are not the hands she knew, this is not the face she knew, this is not a voice she ever heard.
vi: This is not the familiar hand, this is not the familiar face, this is not the voice she used to hear.
tr: These are not the hands he knows, this is not the face he knows, this is a voice he has never heard.
es: These are not the hands she knew, nor this the face she saw, nor this the voice that sounded so sweet in her ears...

en: No, no.
vi: No, no.
tr: These are not the hands he knows, this is not the face he knows, this is a voice he has never heard.
es: No, no!

en: She was—and He was—before the slow years of the North Tower—ages ago.
vi: She is... and he is... before going through so many long years in the North Tower... a long time ago.
tr: That woman, that man – before all those years in the North Tower – they are long gone.
es: She... and he... Many years ago... many eternities... before the slow centuries of the North Tower...

en: What is your name, my gentle angel?”
vi: What is your name, oh gentle angel?
tr: What is your name, beautiful angel?"
es: Tell me! What is your name, beautiful angel?

en: Hailing his softened tone and manner, his daughter fell upon her knees before him, with her appealing hands upon his breast.
vi: Seeing the shoemaker's tone had softened, his daughter knelt before him, placing her pleading hands on his chest.
tr: Upon the softening of the man's tone and demeanor, the young girl knelt down and placed her beautiful hands on her father's chest:
es: The daughter fell to her knees at the feet of the unhappy father, her hands clasped in front of her chest.

en: “O, sir, at another time you shall know my name, and who my mother was, and who my father, and how I never knew their hard, hard history.
vi: − Oh, dear sir. There will come a time when you will know my name, know who my mother is, know who my father is, and understand why I am familiar with the harsh and painful story of my parents.
tr: "Ah sir, another time you will learn the names of my mother, my father, and myself, and how it is that I never knew their difficult story.
es: —Oh, sir! —he exclaimed. —On another occasion, you will know my name, who my mother was, and who my unfortunate father was, whose painful story never reached my ears!

en: But I cannot tell you at this time, and I cannot tell you here.
vi: But right now, I cannot tell you, and I cannot say it here.
tr: But now, especially here, I cannot tell you.
es: I cannot say it at this moment or in this place.

en: All that I may tell you, here and now, is, that I pray to you to touch me and to bless me.
vi: At this moment, all I can ask is for you to hold me, bless me.
tr: The only thing I can tell you here and now is, I beg you, hold me, bless me.
es: The only thing I can tell you now, right here, is to embrace and bless me!

en: Kiss me, kiss me!
vi: Kiss me, kiss me!
tr: Kiss me, kiss me please!
es: Yes...!

en: O my dear, my dear!”
vi: Oh, dear sir, dear sir!
tr: For heaven's sake!"
es: Kiss me... kiss me!

en: His cold white head mingled with her radiant hair, which warmed and lighted it as though it were the light of Freedom shining on him.
vi: Your cold silver hair mingles with the golden hair of the young girl, the youthful head warming and illuminating the old head as if the light of Freedom is shining upon it.
tr: The man's cold white head mingled with the girl's radiant hair, which shone like the "light of freedom" and both warmed and illuminated her.
es: The snow-white hair mingled with the golden hair.

en: “If you hear in my voice—I don’t know that it is so, but I hope it is—if you hear in my voice any resemblance to a voice that once was sweet music in your ears, weep for it, weep for it!
vi: − If you hear my voice... I don't know if it's right, but I hope so... if you hear my voice like that of someone who was once melodious music to your ears, then please weep, please weep!
tr: "If you have likened my voice to the one that once caressed your ear – I don't know if it is so, but I hope it is – let your tears flow!
es: —If my voice... I don't know if it will be so, but I hope... if my voice awakens in you echoes of another voice that in better years sounded in your ears like delightful music... cry for her... cry for her!

en: If you touch, in touching my hair, anything that recalls a beloved head that lay on your breast when you were young and free, weep for it, weep for it!
vi: If you stroke, stroke my hair, and remember a beloved head that once leaned on your chest in the free days of youth, then please weep, please weep!
tr: If touching my hair reminded you of the beloved head you rested against your chest in your youthful and free days, let your tears flow!
es: If my hair reminds you of a beloved head that happily and joyfully rested on your chest when you were young and free, cry for her, cry for her!

en: If, when I hint to you of a Home that is before us, where I will be true to you with all my duty and with all my faithful service, I bring back the remembrance of a Home long desolate, while your poor heart pined away, weep for it, weep for it!”
vi: If I tell you that a family is waiting for us, where I will wholeheartedly fulfill my duty to take care of you, if I make you remember a family that has long been lonely while your heart has been yearning, then please weep, please weep!
tr: If when I spoke to you about a Home where I could serve you with all my respect and reverence, it reminded you of a Home that dissolved in the old days while your poor heart melted away, let your tears flow!"
es: If upon seeing yourself in the home that awaits us, memories of another home arise in your mind, deserted and ruined many years ago, another home that fell to pieces while your heart languished and died within the black walls of a dungeon, cry for it... cry for it!

en: She held him closer round the neck, and rocked him on her breast like a child.
vi: The girl hugged the shoemaker tightly around the neck and rocked him like a baby.
tr: The young girl grabbed the shoemaker by the neck, pressed him against her chest, and rocked him like a child.
es: The young woman, while saying these words, held the old man's white head in her arms and rocked it as if he were a child.

en: “If, when I tell you, dearest dear, that your agony is over, and that I have come here to take you from it, and that we go to England to be at peace and at rest, I cause you to think of your useful life laid waste, and of our native France so wicked to you, weep for it, weep for it!
vi: − Oh, my dear, if I tell you that your suffering has ended, that I have come here to dispel your pain, that we will go to England to live in peace, if I make you remember the precious life that was taken away, remember the cruel homeland of France, then please cry, please cry!
tr: "If, when I tell you that your suffering has ended, that I have come here to put an end to it, that we will go to England and live in peace and comfort, it reminds you of how your life has been wasted and the terrible things that have happened to you in our homeland France, let your tears flow!
es: —Cry too, dear... dear sir, if when I tell you that your agonies are over forever, that I have come to take you with me to England, where you can enjoy peace and perhaps happiness, I am the cause of you remembering a life that could have been so useful to your fellow men, and that, however, has been wasted! Cry, shed bitter tears over our homeland, over France, which has been so cruel to you!

en: And if, when I shall tell you of my name, and of my father who is living, and of my mother who is dead, you learn that I have to kneel to my honoured father, and implore his pardon for having never for his sake striven all day and lain awake and wept all night, because the love of my poor mother hid his torture from me, weep for it, weep for it!
vi: And if ever I tell you my name, the name of my living father, the name of my deceased mother, you will understand that I must kneel before that revered father to ask for forgiveness because I did not search for him daily, nor did I mourn him nightly, because my poor mother, out of love for me, kept my father's suffering a secret, then please cry, please cry!
