es: Soon you will have the opportunity to meet this patriot, whose conduct has been sublime.

en: That, his position and attitude were, on the whole, sublime.
vi: That, the status and character of this person are all noble.
tr: He was a person of utmost nobility in both position and demeanor.
es: Soon you will have the opportunity to meet this patriot, whose conduct has been sublime.

en: That, he had been the prisoner’s friend, but, at once in an auspicious and an evil hour detecting his infamy, had resolved to immolate the traitor he could no longer cherish in his bosom, on the sacred altar of his country.
vi: That, this person was once a friend of the accused, but at the fortunate yet unfortunate moment, discovered the crimes of the friend he dearly loved, and decided to sacrifice that traitor on the sacred altar of the Fatherland.
tr: This person was a friend of the defendant, but on a fateful and troublesome day, upon realizing his disgrace, he decided that he could no longer embrace this traitor or harbor him at the sacred altar of his homeland.
es: He had been an intimate friend of the traitor, but as soon as he discovered his infamies, he decided to sacrifice a friendship, which he could no longer keep in his heart, on the sacred altar of patriotism.

en: That, if statues were decreed in Britain, as in ancient Greece and Rome, to public benefactors, this shining citizen would assuredly have had one.
vi: That, if England, like ancient Greece and Rome, issued decrees to erect statues of the nation's benefactors, this distinguished Citizen would surely be honored.
tr: If statues were erected in England, as in ancient Rome and Greece, for those who had benefited the public, this extraordinary citizen would certainly have had a statue.
es: If England ever erects statues, as Greece and Rome did in honor of those who sacrificed their deepest affections for the sake of the homeland, there is no doubt that this eminent citizen will have his own.

en: That, as they were not so decreed, he probably would not have one.
vi: That, since England has no such decree, this person will not have a statue erected.
tr: But since there was no such decision, he probably would not have a statue.
es: If England ever erects statues, as Greece and Rome did in honor of those who sacrificed their deepest affections for the sake of the homeland, there is no doubt that this eminent citizen will have his own.

en: That, Virtue, as had been observed by the poets (in many passages which he well knew the jury would have, word for word, at the tips of their tongues; whereat the jury’s countenances displayed a guilty consciousness that they knew nothing about the passages), was in a manner contagious; more especially the bright virtue known as patriotism, or love of country.
vi: That, virtue is inherently contagious; especially the shining virtue of patriotism, or love for the country - a sentiment recorded by poets (in many verses which the Attorney General knows the jury must have memorized word for word; hearing this, the jurors' faces showed guilty consciences because they did not know a single verse).
tr: As poets have said, Virtue had a contagious nature (he thought many of the jurors knew many poems by heart, line by line; yet the jurors' faces bore a guilty expression indicating they knew nothing about poems); especially what was known as patriotism and love of country was a radiant virtue.
es: Virtue, as countless poets have affirmed, whose names I will not cite because all my listeners have them on the tip of their tongues, is eminently contagious, and above all, the sacred virtue of patriotism, the love of the homeland.

en: That, the lofty example of this immaculate and unimpeachable witness for the Crown, to refer to whom however unworthily was an honour, had communicated itself to the prisoner’s servant, and had engendered in him a holy determination to examine his master’s table-drawers and pockets, and secrete his papers.
vi: That, the noble example of this unimpeachable witness to the Kingdom, whom we are not worthy to honor by name, spread to the servant of the accused and inspired that servant to nobly rummage through the master's pockets and drawers and hide many documents.
tr: This example of purity and perfection, who was to testify on behalf of the King and whom it was an honor to even speak of, had contacted the defendant's servant and inspired in him a sacred determination to rummage through his master's desk drawers and pockets and to hide certain documents.
es: It is not surprising, then, that the high and sublime example of the immaculate and impeccable witness I refer to, whose name honors anyone who pronounces it, was contagious to a servant of the same accused, and inspired in him the holy resolution to search the drawers of the tables and the pockets of his master, to seize or take note of his most secret documents.

en: That, he (mr Attorney-General) was prepared to hear some disparagement attempted of this admirable servant; but that, in a general way, he preferred him to his (mr Attorney-General’s) brothers and sisters, and honoured him more than his (mr Attorney-General’s) father and mother.
vi: That, he (the Attorney General) is ready to hear slanderous insults against this admirable servant; but that, he cherishes this servant more than his own siblings (of the Attorney General) and respects this servant more than his own parents (of the Attorney General).
tr: The prosecutor was actually ready to hear derogatory remarks about this commendable servant; but he preferred him over his own brothers and showed him more respect than he did to his own parents.
es: There will be detractors who sink their teeth into the reputation of this admirable servant, slanderers who will expose the peccadilloes of his past life in the public pillory, but even so, I must protest that his present conduct makes him deserving of all my respect, I must say that he deserves more consideration than my own brothers, more consideration than my own parents.

en: That, he called with confidence on the jury to come and do likewise.
vi: That, he confidently calls upon the jury to do as he does.
tr: He then invited the jurors to act in the same manner.
es: I do not doubt, I cannot doubt that those who listen to me will do the same.

en: That, the evidence of these two witnesses, coupled with the documents of their discovering that would be produced, would show the prisoner to have been furnished with lists of his Majesty’s forces, and of their disposition and preparation, both by sea and land, and would leave no doubt that he had habitually conveyed such information to a hostile power.
vi: That, the evidence from these two witnesses, along with the documents they discovered and are about to present to the court, will show that the accused had obtained lists of the Royal forces, along with deployment plans, both naval and military, and undoubtedly had regularly transmitted such information to the enemy forces.
tr: The evidence presented by these two witnesses and the other documents they had obtained would show how the defendant was equipped with information about Her Majesty's armies, and furthermore, it was an undeniable fact that he had always conveyed information about the structuring and preparations on land and sea to enemy forces.
es: The statements of the two named witnesses, together with the documents that will be exhibited in due course, demonstrate as clearly as sunlight that the prisoner possessed numerical relations of His Majesty's military forces, explanatory states of their disposition and preparation, and there is no doubt that these relations, these states, he carried, as he has carried so many others, to an enemy power.

en: That, these lists could not be proved to be in the prisoner’s handwriting; but that it was all the same; that, indeed, it was rather the better for the prosecution, as showing the prisoner to be artful in his precautions.
vi: That, it cannot be proven that these lists were written by the accused's own hand; but this does not lessen the severity and instead facilitates the prosecution; that, it shows the accused's cunning precautions.
tr: Perhaps it could not be proven that the lists were written in the defendant's handwriting; but this changed nothing; in fact, it was better for the case as it showed how cunning the defendant was in taking precautions.
es: I confess that it has not been possible to prove that these relations and these states are in the handwriting of the accused, but that does not matter, it means nothing, and in any case, it will be an aggravating circumstance, since it will highlight the cunning malice of the accused.

en: That, the proof would go back five years, and would show the prisoner already engaged in these pernicious missions, within a few weeks before the date of the very first action fought between the British troops and the Americans.
vi: That, the evidence shows that five years ago, the accused undertook these dangerous tasks, just weeks before the first battle between the British army and the Americans*.
tr: The evidence dated back five years and showed that the defendant had undertaken this harmful duty even then, a few weeks before the first clashes between the British and American armies.
es: The evidence goes back five years, clearly demonstrating that the prisoner was already then carrying out infamous and pernicious missions, that he was already selling out the homeland weeks before the first battle between English and American forces was fought.

en: That, for these reasons, the jury, being a loyal jury (as he knew they were), and being a responsible jury (as they knew they were), must positively find the prisoner Guilty, and make an end of him, whether they liked it or not.
vi: That, for these reasons, the jury, being loyal (as he knows they are) and responsible (as they know they are) - must unequivocally find the accused guilty and must sentence him to death, whether they wish to or not.
tr: For these reasons, the patriotic (he was sure of this) and responsible (he was also sure of this) jurors should definitely declare this defendant Guilty, and whether they were pleased with this situation or not, they should end his life.
es: All these reasons will necessarily influence the mind of the Jury, if it is a loyal Jury, as I know it is, if it is a responsible Jury, as I consider it to be, to declare the prisoner guilty, and to rid the world of a traitor. Ah, gentlemen of the jury!

en: That, they never could lay their heads upon their pillows; that, they never could tolerate the idea of their wives laying their heads upon their pillows; that, they never could endure the notion of their children laying their heads upon their pillows; in short, that there never more could be, for them or theirs, any laying of heads upon pillows at all, unless the prisoner’s head was taken off.
vi: That, they cannot eat or sleep well; that, they cannot accept the idea of their wives eating or sleeping well; that, they cannot tolerate the thought of their children eating or sleeping well; in short, no one, whether themselves or their wives and children, can eat or sleep well anymore if the accused is not beheaded.
tr: Unless this defendant's head was cut off, neither the jurors could rest their heads on their pillows in peace, nor could they tolerate their wives resting their heads on their pillows, nor could they bear the thought of their children resting their heads on their pillows; in short, none of them would be able to rest their heads on their pillows in peace and tranquility.
es: As long as there is a head on the prisoner's shoulders, it is not possible for your heads to rest peacefully on the pillows of your beds, it is not possible for the heads of your tender wives to rest peacefully on the pillows of their beds, it is not possible for the little heads of your dear children to rest peacefully on the pillows of their beds.

en: That head mr Attorney-General concluded by demanding of them, in the name of everything he could think of with a round turn in it, and on the faith of his solemn asseveration that he already considered the prisoner as good as dead and gone.
vi: That head, the Attorney General demands the jury to sever, in the name of all that is good and reasonable that he can think of, and with unwavering belief, he solemnly concludes that he considers the accused as surely dead.
tr: The Chief Prosecutor concluded his speech by reiterating his demand for the defendant to be found guilty in the name of everything conceivable; in fact, as a result of all the legal claims he had put forward, the defendant was already dead to him.
es: The Crown Prosecutor asks you by the most sacred, by what is most dear to you, by the oath you have taken, by the august and excellent King who governs us, by the homeland, which is our mother, to sentence the prisoner to be hanged, beheaded, and quartered."

en: When the Attorney-General ceased, a buzz arose in the court as if a cloud of great blue-flies were swarming about the prisoner, in anticipation of what he was soon to become.
vi: When the Attorney General stopped speaking, the entire courtroom buzzed like a swarm of blue flies surrounding the defendant, eagerly awaiting the fate he would face.
tr: When the chief prosecutor's speech ended, a murmur broke out in the courtroom; it was as if a swarm of horseflies, sensing what was about to happen, had gathered around the defendant.
es: When the Crown prosecutor stopped speaking, the courtroom filled with muffled murmurs. It seemed as if the air had filled with swarms of blue flies buzzing around the defendant's head, aware of the state in which they would soon find him.

en: When toned down again, the unimpeachable patriot appeared in the witness-box.
vi: When the noise subsided, the unimpeachable patriot appeared in the witness stand.
tr: When the noise subsided, the impeccable patriot had taken his place in the witness stand.
es: When the buzzing ceased, the impeccable citizen, the sublime patriot cited by the Crown prosecutor, appeared in the witness stand.

en: mr Solicitor-General then, following his leader’s lead, examined the patriot: John Barsad, gentleman, by name.
vi: After that, the Deputy Attorney General, following the guidance of the Attorney General, questioned the patriot: a gentleman named John Barsad.
tr: The deputy chief prosecutor, under the leadership of his superior, began to question the patriotic witness; the gentleman's name was John Barsad.
es: The Attorney General, strictly adhering to his chief's instructions, then examined the patriot. His name was John Barsad, and he was a gentleman.

en: The story of his pure soul was exactly what mr Attorney-General had described it to be—perhaps, if it had a fault, a little too exactly.
vi: His self-declaration of a clear conscience was similar to what the Attorney General had described; perhaps the only reproach was that it was almost identical to the Attorney General's words.
tr: This good man's story was exactly as the Chief Prosecutor had told it – in fact, it was too much the same.
es: The story of his pure and immaculate soul turned out to be the one the Crown prosecutor had succinctly presented in his accusation.

en: Having released his noble bosom of its burden, he would have modestly withdrawn himself, but that the wigged gentleman with the papers before him, sitting not far from mr Lorry, begged to ask him a few questions.
vi: After unburdening his noble heart, he should have humbly withdrawn, but the barrister wearing a wig, holding a stack of papers, sitting in front of him not far from Mr. Lorry, requested to ask a few questions.
tr: After the man had unburdened himself of the load he carried in that noble bosom, he was about to withdraw modestly when the wigged man with papers in front of him, sitting just a little beyond Mr. Lorry, wanted to ask him a few questions.
es: After he had answered the questions directed at him, he would have modestly withdrawn, had the gentleman with the enormous wig and bulky bundles of papers, who was seated a short distance from Mr. Lorry, not expressed a desire to ask him some other questions.

en: The wigged gentleman sitting opposite, still looking at the ceiling of the court.
vi: Meanwhile, the gentleman wearing a wig opposite the barrister continued to gaze at the ceiling.
tr: The wigged man sitting directly opposite was still looking at the ceiling.
es: The second wigged man continued to stare at the ceiling. Here is, in summary, the interrogation to which the great patriot was subjected by the gentleman with the wig:

en: Had he ever been a spy himself?
vi: Has the witness ever worked as a spy?
tr: Had he ever committed espionage?
es: —Have you ever been a spy?

en: No, he scorned the base insinuation.
vi: No, he despises such a vile insinuation.
tr: No, he had grimaced at the suggestion.
es: —Never—replied the citizen indignantly.

en: What did he live upon?
vi: How does the witness make a living?
tr: How did he make a living?
es: —What do you live on?

en: His property.
vi: From personal assets.
tr: With his private properties.
es: —From my income.

en: Where was his property?
vi: Where did the witness's assets come from?
tr: Where was his private property?
es: —What do those incomes consist of?

en: He didn’t precisely remember where it was.
vi: The witness does not remember exactly where they came from.
tr: He didn't remember exactly where it was.
es: —I don't have to give explanations about this matter.

en: What was it?
vi: What are those assets?
tr: What was it?
es: —Where are your assets located?

en: No business of anybody’s.
vi: It's a private matter and cannot be disclosed.
tr: It was nobody's business.
es: —I don't remember it precisely.

en: Had he inherited it?
vi: Did the witness inherit those assets?
tr: Had he inherited it from someone?
es: —Have you inherited?

en: Yes, he had.
vi: Yes, he admits.
tr: Yes, it was an inheritance.
es: —Yes.

en: From whom?
vi: Whose inheritance?
tr: From whom had he inherited it?
es: —Whose?

en: Distant relation.
vi: Distant relatives.
tr: From a distant relative.
es: —From a distant relative.

en: Very distant?
vi: Very distant?
tr: Was this relative very distant?
es: —Very far?

en: Rather.
vi: Quite distant.
tr: A bit.
es: —Enough.

en: Ever been in prison?
vi: Ever been to prison?
tr: Had he ever been imprisoned?
es: —Have you ever been prosecuted?

en: Certainly not.
vi: Definitely not.
tr: Absolutely not.
es: —Never.

en: Never in a debtors’ prison?
vi: Ever been imprisoned for debt?
tr: Had he never been in a debtor's prison?
es: —Has he not even been in jail for debts?

en: Didn’t see what that had to do with it.
vi: I don't understand what that has to do with this.
tr: What did this have to do with the case?
es: —I don't know what that has to do with the matter being debated.

en: Never in a debtors’ prison?
vi: Ever been imprisoned for debt?...
tr: Had he never been in a debtor's prison?
es: —Have you been in jail for debts?

en: —Come, once again.
vi: There, asking again!
tr: The question came again.
es: —Again?

en: Never?
vi: Yes or no?
tr: Never?
es: —Answer, please.

en: Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: Yes, he had been.
es: —Yes.

en: How many times?
vi: How many times?
tr: How many times?
es: —How many times?

en: Two or three times.
vi: Two or three times.
tr: Two or three times.
es: —Two or three.

en: Not five or six?
vi: Not five or six times?
tr: Could it be five or six times?
es: —Could it be five or six?

en: Perhaps.
vi: Maybe.
tr: Maybe.
es: —Maybe.

en: Of what profession?
vi: What is the witness's occupation?
tr: What was his profession?
es: —Your profession?

en: Gentleman.
vi: Noble.
tr: A gentleman.
es: —Gentleman.

en: Ever been kicked?
vi: Ever been kicked by someone?
tr: Had he ever been kicked?
es: —Have you ever been kicked?

en: Might have been.
vi: Maybe.
tr: Possibly.
es: —Maybe so.

en: Frequently?
vi: Frequently?
tr: Often?
es: —Often?

en: No. Ever kicked downstairs?
vi: No. Ever been kicked down the stairs?
tr: No. Had he ever been kicked down the stairs?
es: —No. —Have you ever been kicked out of a house? —No. —Haven't they kicked him down the stairs?

en: Decidedly not; once received a kick on the top of a staircase, and fell downstairs of his own accord.
vi: Definitely not; once kicked at the top of the stairs, and the witness rolled down voluntarily.
tr: Absolutely not; once he had been kicked at the top of the stairs and had fallen down on his own.
es: —I repeat, no. On one occasion, I received a few kicks at the top of a staircase and rolled down it, but it was because I wanted to, by my own will, deliberately.

en: Kicked on that occasion for cheating at dice?
vi: Kicked for cheating at dice, right?
tr: Was he kicked for cheating at dice?
es: —On the occasion you refer to, weren't you kicked out for cheating, for making tricks in a dice game?

en: Something to that effect was said by the intoxicated liar who committed the assault, but it was not true.
vi: The drunk who assaulted me said something like that, but it's not true.
tr: The drunk who attacked him had said so, but it wasn't true.
es: —Something like that said the lying drunk who kicked me, but it was false.

en: Swear it was not true?
vi: Dare to swear it's not true?
tr: Could he swear it wasn't true?
es: —Do you swear it was false?

en: Positively.
vi: Absolutely.
tr: Of course.
es: —Without the slightest hesitation.

en: Ever live by cheating at play?
vi: Ever made a living by cheating at gambling?
tr: Had he ever made a living by cheating at gambling?
es: —Have you never sought the means to live in the traps of the game?

en: Never.
vi: Never.
tr: Never.
es: —Never.

en: Ever live by play?
vi: Ever made a living by gambling?
tr: Had he ever made a living by gambling?
es: —Haven't you even lived off gambling?

en: Not more than other gentlemen do.
vi: Just like everyone else.
tr: As much as other gentlemen played.
es: —I have played as all other gentlemen play.

en: Ever borrow money of the prisoner?
vi: Ever borrowed money from that defendant?
tr: Had he ever borrowed money from a prisoner?
es: —Has the prisoner lent you money?

en: Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: Ever pay him?
vi: Paid it back?
tr: Had he paid him back?
es: —And has he paid for it?

en: No.
vi: No.
tr: No.
es: —No.

en: Was not this intimacy with the prisoner, in reality a very slight one, forced upon the prisoner in coaches, inns, and packets?
vi: Isn't the witness's relationship with the defendant actually very superficial, only due to chance encounters on carriages, in inns, and on steamships?
tr: Was his relationship with the prisoner, which wasn't that close, limited to forced conversations in the stagecoach, inn, or on the steamboat?
es: —The friendship that has bound him with the prisoner, in reality a light friendship, was it not one of those we usually call obligatory, that is, a friendship cultivated in stagecoaches, inns, and ships?

en: No.
vi: No.
tr: No.
es: —No.

en: Sure he saw the prisoner with these lists?
vi: Are you sure the witness saw the defendant with these lists?
tr: Was he sure he had seen these lists in the prisoner's possession?
es: —Have you seen the records and lists in the prisoner's possession?

en: Certain.
vi: Absolutely.
tr: He was sure.
es: —Yes.

en: Knew no more about the lists?
vi: Know anything more about these lists?
tr: Did he know anything else about these lists?
es: —Can you say something more about those lists?

en: No.
vi: No.
tr: No.
es: —No.

en: Had not procured them himself, for instance?
vi: Isn't it true that the witness personally tried to obtain these documents?
tr: Could he have produced them himself?
es: —No.

en: No. Expect to get anything by this evidence?
vi: No. With these exhibits, does the witness hope to receive any reward?
tr: No. Was there anything he would receive in exchange for this evidence?
es: —No. —Do you expect your statement to bring you any advantage or benefit?

en: No.
vi: No.
tr: No.
es: —No.

en: Not in regular government pay and employment, to lay traps?
vi: The witness is not on the government payroll and hired to harm others, right?
tr: Was he receiving money from the government to set traps?
es: —Not even a fate as a government-hired spy?

en: Oh dear no.
vi: Oh heavens, no.
tr: Absolutely not.
es: —No.

en: Or to do anything?
vi: Or to do anything else?
tr: Or for anything else?
es: —Not any other job either?

en: Oh dear no.
vi: Oh heavens, nothing else.
tr: Oh, no!
es: No.

en: Swear that?
vi: Dare to swear?
tr: Would he swear?
es: —Do you swear?

en: Over and over again.
vi: Swear a thousand times, no.
tr: Of course.
es: —A thousand and one times.

en: No motives but motives of sheer patriotism?
vi: The witness has no motive other than patriotism, right?
tr: Was his only reason for being there his patriotism?
es: —Does it obey motives other than those of patriotism?

en: None whatever.
vi: No other motive.
tr: Absolutely.
es: —No.

en: The virtuous servant, Roger Cly, swore his way through the case at a great rate.
vi: It was the turn of the virtuous servant Roger Cly to take the oath before the interrogation.
tr: The virtuous servant Roger Ciy took a long oath on the witness stand.
es: The virtuous servant of the prisoner, Rogerio Cly, was called to testify, and he took his oath with great determination.

en: He had taken service with the prisoner, in good faith and simplicity, four years ago.
vi: He had been working for the defendant for four years and knew nothing.
tr: Four years ago, he had started working alongside the defendant with all his goodwill and naivety.
es: Four years earlier, he had entered the service of the prisoner, simply and in good faith.

en: He had asked the prisoner, aboard the Calais packet, if he wanted a handy fellow, and the prisoner had engaged him.
vi: He had asked the defendant on the Calais train if the defendant needed a servant, and the defendant had hired him.
tr: On the Calais ship, he had asked the defendant if he needed an assistant, and the defendant had taken him on; it wasn't out of kindness that he wanted to be hired by the defendant, such a thing had never crossed his mind.
es: On board the ship that serviced Calais, he asked the prisoner if he needed a servant, and the latter accepted him.

en: He had not asked the prisoner to take the handy fellow as an act of charity—never thought of such a thing.
vi: It was not out of charity that he asked the defendant to let him serve - he had no such thought.
tr: On the Calais ship, he had asked the defendant if he needed an assistant, and the defendant had taken him on; it wasn't out of kindness that he wanted to be hired by the defendant, such a thing had never crossed his mind.
es: On board the ship that serviced Calais, he asked the prisoner if he needed a servant, and the latter accepted him.

en: He began to have suspicions of the prisoner, and to keep an eye upon him, soon afterwards.
vi: Soon after, he began to suspect the defendant and kept an eye on him.
tr: But later, he started to suspect the defendant and began to watch him.
es: Very shortly after, the prisoner's behavior seemed suspicious to him, and he resolved to spy on him.

en: In arranging his clothes, while travelling, he had seen similar lists to these in the prisoner’s pockets, over and over again.
vi: While arranging the defendant's clothes during travels, he had seen lists similar to these in the defendant's pockets many times.
tr: While preparing the defendant's clothes for travel, he constantly saw similar lists in the defendant's pockets.
es: During the various trips he made in his company, he saw several times in his master's clothes lists and records similar to those held by the authorities.

en: He had taken these lists from the drawer of the prisoner’s desk.
vi: He had taken these lists from the defendant's desk drawer.
tr: He had also taken these lists from the defendant's desk drawer.
es: He was the one who took some of those lists from a drawer in his master's desk.

en: He had not put them there first.
vi: He had not placed those papers in the drawer from the beginning.
tr: It wasn't the first time he had seen them.
es: He was the one who took some of those lists from a drawer in his master's desk.

en: He had seen the prisoner show these identical lists to French gentlemen at Calais, and similar lists to French gentlemen, both at Calais and Boulogne.
vi: He had seen the defendant show similar lists to many French people in Calais, and similar lists to many French people in both Calais and Boulogne.
tr: He had seen the defendant show the same lists to the French in Calais, and similar ones to the French in both Calais and Boulogne.
es: He saw that his master showed other identical lists to a French gentleman in Calais and others to other French gentlemen, both in Calais and in Boulogne.

en: He loved his country, and couldn’t bear it, and had given information.
vi: He was patriotic and could not accept that, so he went to report it.
tr: He loved his country, he couldn't tolerate this, so he informed the necessary people.
es: A lover of his country, his conscience rebelled against such dark treacheries and he reported the facts.

en: He had never been suspected of stealing a silver tea-pot; he had been maligned respecting a mustard-pot, but it turned out to be only a plated one.
vi: He had never been suspected of stealing a silver teapot; he had been falsely accused of stealing a mustard pot, but it turned out to be just silver-plated.
tr: He had never been suspected of stealing a silver teapot; there had been a slander about a mustard pot, but that had also turned out to be a coating.
es: Regarding his honesty, he assured that it was so impeccable that no one ever dared to accuse him of stealing a silver teapot, for although there were slanderers who once accused him of stealing a butter dish, upon verification, it turned out it was not silver but silver-plated metal.

en: He had known the last witness seven or eight years; that was merely a coincidence.
vi: He had known the previous witness for seven or eight years; it was just a coincidence.
tr: He had known the last witness for seven or eight years; but it was entirely coincidental.
es: He had known the witness who preceded him in the statement for seven or eight years, but they only ever interacted by coincidence.

en: He didn’t call it a particularly curious coincidence; most coincidences were curious.
vi: He did not find it a strange coincidence because all coincidences are strange.
tr: It couldn't be called a strange coincidence; coincidences were mostly strange anyway.
es: He did not claim that these were extraordinarily curious coincidences, undoubtedly because it is public and notorious that coincidences are generally so.

en: Neither did he call it a curious coincidence that true patriotism was his only motive too.
vi: Nor did he find it a strange coincidence that his sole motive was patriotism.
tr: Moreover, he didn't see his sole motive of patriotism as a strange coincidence.
es: He did not claim that these were extraordinarily curious coincidences, undoubtedly because it is public and notorious that coincidences are generally so.

en: He was a true Briton, and hoped there were many like him.
vi: He was a true Englishman and hoped many others were like him.
tr: He was a true Briton and hoped that many people were like him.
es: He did not claim that these were extraordinarily curious coincidences, undoubtedly because it is public and notorious that coincidences are generally so.

en: The blue-flies buzzed again, and mr Attorney-General called mr Jarvis Lorry.
vi: The entire courtroom was once again filled with the buzzing of bluebottle flies, and the Attorney General called Mr. Jarvis Lorry to the stand.
tr: The flies buzzed again and summoned Chief Prosecutor Mr. Jarvis Lorry.
es: The muffled buzzing of the blue flies was heard for the second time, and the Crown prosecutor called Mr. Maurice Lorry.

en: “mr Jarvis Lorry, are you a clerk in Tellson’s bank?”
vi: − Mr. Jarvis Lorry, are you an employee of Tellson's Bank? −
tr: "Mr. Jarvis Lorry, you work at Tellson's Bank, don't you?"
es: —Are you an employee of Tellson's Bank, Mr. Maurice Lorry?

en: “I am.”
vi: Yes, I am.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “On a certain Friday night in November one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five, did business occasion you to travel between London and Dover by the mail?”
vi: − On a Friday in November 1775, did you travel from London to Dover by mail coach for work?
tr: "Did you travel from London to Dover by mail coach for business on a Friday night in November 1775?"
es: —On the night of a Friday in the month of November of the year one thousand seven hundred seventy-five, did you make a journey from London to Dover by the mail coach?

en: “It did.”
vi: − Yes, I did.
tr: "I went."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Were there any other passengers in the mail?”
vi: − Were there any other passengers on the mail coach?
tr: "Was there any other passenger in the car?"
es: —Were there other travelers in the coach?

en: “Two.”
vi: − Two people.
tr: "There were two more people.""
es: —Yes, sir: two.

en: “Did they alight on the road in the course of the night?”
vi: − Did they get off the bus along the way during the night?
tr: "Did these people get off on the road at night?"
es: —Did they leave the coach that night, before reaching Dover?

en: “They did.”
vi: − That's right.
tr: "They got off."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “mr Lorry, look upon the prisoner.
vi: − Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant over there.
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look carefully at the face of the defendant.
es: —Look at the prisoner, Mr. Lorry, and tell us if he was one of those travelers.

en: Was he one of those two passengers?”
vi: Is the defendant one of those two passengers?
tr: Was this person one of the two passengers?"
es: —Look at the prisoner, Mr. Lorry, and tell us if he was one of those travelers.

en: “I cannot undertake to say that he was.”
vi: − I cannot answer this question.
tr: "It's very hard to say this."
es: —I can't say that it was.

en: “Does he resemble either of these two passengers?”
vi: − Does the defendant resemble either of the two passengers?
tr: "Does he look like one of those two travelers?""
es: —Does he look like any of your travel companions?

en: “Both were so wrapped up, and the night was so dark, and we were all so reserved, that I cannot undertake to say even that.”
vi: − Both were wearing cloaks that covered them completely, it was pitch dark, and we were all cautious, so I can't even answer this question.
tr: "Both were tightly wrapped up, it was a very dark night, and everyone was in their own world; it is really hard to say anything.""
es: —The two were so cloaked, the night was so dark, and the three of us kept such secrecy, that it is impossible for me to answer the question.

en: “mr Lorry, look again upon the prisoner.
vi: − Mr. Lorry, please look at the defendant once more.
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant's face once more.
es: —Examine the prisoner more closely, Mr. Lorry.

en: Supposing him wrapped up as those two passengers were, is there anything in his bulk and stature to render it unlikely that he was one of them?”
vi: Suppose the defendant were cloaked like the other two passengers, would the defendant's build and height resemble either of those two passengers?
tr: If you consider the defendant being wrapped up like those two passengers, can you say that in terms of build and stance, he resembles neither of them?"
es: Picture him cloaked, in the same manner as his travel companions, and tell us if, given his height and build, it is impossible that he was one of the two travelers.

en: “No.”
tr: "No."
es: —It is not impossible.

en: “You will not swear, mr Lorry, that he was not one of them?”
vi: No. − Mr. Lorry, do you dare swear that the defendant is not one of those two passengers? −
tr: "Well, can you swear that you are not one of them, Mr. Lorry?"
es: —Would you not swear that the defendant was none of them?

en: “No.”
vi: No.
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: “So at least you say he may have been one of them?”
vi: − So at the very least, you believe the defendant could be one of those two people, right? −
tr: "So, you're saying it could be one of those two passengers?"
es: —Then you admit that you could be one of them, don't you?

en: “Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes.
es: —Then you admit that you could be one of them, don't you?

en: Except that I remember them both to have been—like myself—timorous of highwaymen, and the prisoner has not a timorous air.”
vi: It's just that I remember both of those people... looking like me... Everyone was afraid of the highway robbers, but this person did not seem to be afraid at all.
tr: Only the other two passengers – just like me – were afraid of highway robbers, whereas this defendant doesn't seem scared at all."
es: —I admit the possibility, but... but I remember perfectly that my two travel companions were... and I was too... terribly afraid of thieves, and it seems to me that the defendant is not one to be easily frightened.

en: “Did you ever see a counterfeit of timidity, mr Lorry?”
vi: − Have you ever seen someone pretend to be shy, Mr. Lorry?
tr: "Have you ever witnessed false cowardice, Mr. Lorry?"
es: —And have you never seen fake fear... I mean, people who pretend to feel a fear they don't actually feel?

en: “I certainly have seen that.”
vi: − I'm sure I have.
tr: "Of course I saw it.""
es: —No, sir.

en: “mr Lorry, look once more upon the prisoner.
vi: − Mr. Lorry, please look at the defendant once more.
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant's face once more.
es: —Please identify the defendant again, Mr. Lorry.

en: Have you seen him, to your certain knowledge, before?”
vi: Are you certain that you have met the defendant before?
tr: Have you ever seen him before?"
es: Do you remember seeing him on any occasion?

en: “I have.”
vi: − I have met him.
tr: "Yes, I had seen it.""
es: —Yes.

en: “When?”
vi: − When? −
tr: "When?""
es: —When and where?

en: “I was returning from France a few days afterwards, and, at Calais, the prisoner came on board the packet-ship in which I returned, and made the voyage with me.”
vi: That was a few days later, when I returned from France, and in Calais, this person boarded the ship that brought me back to the country, and traveled on the same trip with me.
tr: "A few days later, I was returning from France, and he boarded the steamer I boarded in Calais, and we traveled together."
es: —Upon my return from France, a few days after the stagecoach incident, I found him in Calais aboard the ship on which I was coming back, and we made the journey together.

en: “At what hour did he come on board?”
vi: − At what time did the defendant board the train?
tr: "When did he/she get on the ferry?""
es: —What time did the prisoner board?

en: “At a little after midnight.”
vi: − A little after midnight.
tr: "A little past midnight.""
es: —Already late at night.

en: “In the dead of the night.
vi: − Right in the middle of the night.
tr: "In the dead of night.
es: —Already late at night.

en: Was he the only passenger who came on board at that untimely hour?”
vi: Was the defendant the only passenger to board the train at that late hour? −
tr: Was he the only passenger boarding at that hour?"
es: He was the only passenger on the boat, except for us, and he arrived at the last minute. —What time could it be?

en: “He happened to be the only one.”
vi: It happened that this person was the only one.
tr: "It was the only one by chance."
es: —A little past midnight. —And you say you arrived last? —It so happened that I arrived last, yes, sir.

en: “Never mind about ‘happening,’ mr Lorry.
vi: − Don't worry about the "coincidence," Mr. Lorry.
tr: "Forget about the coincidence, Mr. Lorry.
es: —Let's set aside the "coincidences."

en: He was the only passenger who came on board in the dead of the night?”
vi: The defendant was the only passenger who boarded the train at midnight, correct?
tr: He was the only passenger who boarded in the dead of night, wasn't he?"
es: He was the only passenger who arrived late at night, wasn't he?

en: “He was.”
vi: − That's right.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Were you travelling alone, mr Lorry, or with any companion?”
vi: − Were you traveling alone or with someone at that time, Mr. Lorry? −
tr: "Were you traveling alone, Mr. Lorry, or was there someone with you?""
es: —Were you traveling alone, or accompanied, Mr. Lorry?

en: “With two companions.
vi: With two companions.
tr: "There were two people with me.
es: —With two companions: a gentleman and a young lady.

en: A gentleman and lady.
vi: A gentleman and a lady.
tr: A gentleman and a lady.
es: —With two companions: a gentleman and a young lady.

en: They are here.”
vi: They are present in the court.
tr: Now they are here."
es: Both are here.

en: “They are here.
vi: − They are present at the court.
tr: "Yes, yes.
es: —Indeed: here they are.

en: Had you any conversation with the prisoner?”
vi: Did you have any conversation with the defendant at that time?
tr: Had you spoken with the defendant at that time?"
es: Did you speak with the prisoner?

en: “Hardly any.
vi: − Absolutely not.
tr: "Not much.
es: —Very little.

en: The weather was stormy, and the passage long and rough, and I lay on a sofa, almost from shore to shore.”
vi: It was stormy, the journey was long, and the sea was rough, I was mostly lying on the sofa from one shore to the other.
tr: The weather was stormy, the journey was long and difficult; I lay down on a seat and slept almost the entire way."
es: The weather was stormy, the journey was long and arduous, and I spent it lying on the couch from beach to beach.

en: “Miss Manette!”
vi: − Miss Manette!
tr: "Miss Manette!"
es: —Miss Manette!

en: The young lady, to whom all eyes had been turned before, and were now turned again, stood up where she had sat.
vi: The girl stood up from her seat, and all the eyes that had been looking at her earlier now turned back towards her.
tr: Everyone turned their eyes again to the young lady they had just looked at, and she also stood up.
es: The young lady, towards whom all eyes had previously turned and towards whom they turned again when she was called, stood up.

en: Her father rose with her, and kept her hand drawn through his arm.
vi: Her father stood up as well, still holding his daughter's arm.
tr: Her father also stood up with her, still holding her arm.
es: At the same time as she did, her father stood up.

en: “Miss Manette, look upon the prisoner.”
vi: − Miss Manette, please look at the defendant.
tr: "Miss Manette, look at the defendant's face."
es: —Examine the prisoner, Miss Manette.

en: To be confronted with such pity, and such earnest youth and beauty, was far more trying to the accused than to be confronted with all the crowd.
vi: For the convict, facing such mercy and such youthful beauty was far more difficult than facing this entire crowd.
tr: For the defendant, facing this symbol of youth and beauty was much harder than facing the entire crowd.
es: A thousand times more painful was it for the accused to find himself facing that young, beautiful girl, who looked at him with longing compassion, than to face the curious gazes of the crowds that filled the room.

en: Standing, as it were, apart with her on the edge of his grave, not all the staring curiosity that looked on, could, for the moment, nerve him to remain quite still.
vi: Even though he did not waver when standing close to the grave, challenging all the curious eyes watching him, he still momentarily lost his composure before the girl's gaze.
tr: At that moment, the crowd, who had their eyes fixed on him as if waiting at the head of a grave, was not enough to calm him down.
es: Without blinking, without a single muscle in his face altering, he endured the terrible accusation of the Crown prosecutor; the statements of the prosecution witnesses did not manage to change his expression, but seeing from the edge of the grave the look, not of curiosity, but of pity, from the girl, all his nerve, which was considerable, was not enough to restrain the agitation in his chest, and in the desperate efforts made to remain calm, his lips turned pale, all the blood flowed back to his heart.

en: His hurried right hand parcelled out the herbs before him into imaginary beds of flowers in a garden; and his efforts to control and steady his breathing shook the lips from which the colour rushed to his heart.
vi: The convict's right hand hastily swept aside the herbs in front of him, turning them into imaginary flower beds; and the effort to maintain steady breathing caused his lips to tremble and turn pale, as if the blood was flowing back to his heart.
tr: He hastily threw the grass in front of him into imaginary flower beds in a garden. While trying to control his breath and calm down, his trembling lips had turned completely white, and all the color had rushed to his heart.
es: Without blinking, without a single muscle in his face altering, he endured the terrible accusation of the Crown prosecutor; the statements of the prosecution witnesses did not manage to change his expression, but seeing from the edge of the grave the look, not of curiosity, but of pity, from the girl, all his nerve, which was considerable, was not enough to restrain the agitation in his chest, and in the desperate efforts made to remain calm, his lips turned pale, all the blood flowed back to his heart.

en: The buzz of the great flies was loud again.
vi: The swarm of blue flies buzzed noisily again.
tr: The buzzing of the big flies had increased again.
es: Without blinking, without a single muscle in his face altering, he endured the terrible accusation of the Crown prosecutor; the statements of the prosecution witnesses did not manage to change his expression, but seeing from the edge of the grave the look, not of curiosity, but of pity, from the girl, all his nerve, which was considerable, was not enough to restrain the agitation in his chest, and in the desperate efforts made to remain calm, his lips turned pale, all the blood flowed back to his heart.

en: “Miss Manette, have you seen the prisoner before?”
vi: − Miss Manette, have you ever met the defendant before? −
tr: "Miss Manette, had you seen the defendant before?"
es: —Did you know the prisoner, Miss Manette?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, I have.
tr: "Yes, sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Where?”
vi: − Where? −
tr: "Where did you see it?"
es: —Where did you meet him?

en: “On board of the packet-ship just now referred to, sir, and on the same occasion.”
vi: On the mail ship just mentioned, sir, and on the same occasion.
tr: "As mentioned earlier, sir, on the ferry, the same night."
es: —Aboard the ship they mentioned earlier and on the same occasion.

en: “You are the young lady just now referred to?”
vi: − Are you the young lady who was just mentioned?
tr: "So, the lady mentioned earlier is you.""
es: —Are you the young lady mentioned by Mr. Lorry?

en: “O! most unhappily, I am!”
vi: − Oh! Unfortunately, that is me!
tr: "Ah! Unfortunately, it is so, sir!""
es: —Unfortunately, sir, it is I!

en: The plaintive tone of her compassion merged into the less musical voice of the Judge, as he said something fiercely: “Answer the questions put to you, and make no remark upon them.”
vi: The girl's sorrowful and compassionate voice was drowned out by the aggressive and not-so-gentle voice of the Judge: "Answer the question directly without making any comments."
tr: The young girl's tearful voice full of compassion. When the judge spoke in a stern manner, it got lost within his voice, which was not at all harmonious. "Only answer the questions asked of you and do not make any comments."
es: The tones of compassion that the girl managed to infuse into her voice did not soften that of the judge, who replied with a certain severity: —The witness shall answer the questions asked without making observations or comments...

en: “Miss Manette, had you any conversation with the prisoner on that passage across the Channel?”
vi: − Miss Manette, did you have any conversation with the defendant during the crossing of the strait? −
tr: "Miss Manette, did you ever share a cabin with the defendant while crossing the English Channel?""
es: Miss Manette, did you have any conversation with the prisoner during the crossing of the Channel?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, sir.
tr: "Yes sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Recall it.”
vi: − Please tell the story again.
tr: "Tell me."
es: —Refer her.

en: In the midst of a profound stillness, she faintly began: “When the gentleman came on board—”
vi: The entire courtroom fell silent as the young woman softly said, "When that gentleman boarded the train..."
tr: In the deepening silence, the young girl began to speak in a faint voice: "When the gentleman boarded the ferry-"
es: Amidst an imposing silence, the girl began with a weak voice: —When that gentleman came on board...

en: “Do you mean the prisoner?” inquired the Judge, knitting his brows.
vi: − You mean the defendant, right? - The judge asked, frowning.
tr: The judge frowned and asked, "Are you talking about the defendant?"
es: —Are you referring to the prisoner?—asked the judge, frowning.

en: “Yes, my Lord.”
vi: − Yes, Your Honor.
tr: "Yes, sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Then say the prisoner.”
vi: − Then we must call him the defendant.
tr: "Then call him the defendant.""
es: —Well, when you have to name him, call him the prisoner.

en: “When the prisoner came on board, he noticed that my father,” turning her eyes lovingly to him as he stood beside her, “was much fatigued and in a very weak state of health.
vi: − When the defendant boarded the ship, he saw my father, - the girl directed a loving gaze at the person standing next to her, - too tired and in poor health.
tr: "When the defendant boarded the ferry, my father," at this moment the girl lovingly turned her eyes towards her father standing next to her, "noticed that he was very exhausted and ill.
es: —When the prisoner came on board, he noticed that my father was very fatigued and in a very delicate state of health.

en: My father was so reduced that I was afraid to take him out of the air, and I had made a bed for him on the deck near the cabin steps, and I sat on the deck at his side to take care of him.
vi: My father was so weak that I feared he would have difficulty breathing, so I made a bed for him on the deck near the steps leading to the cabin, and I sat on the deck next to him to take care of him.
tr: My father was so weak that I was afraid to move him, and I made him a bed on the deck, next to the stairs leading to the cabins; then I sat down beside him to take care of him.
es: Such was my father's exhaustion that, fearing the lack of air might harm him, I prepared a bed for him on the deck, next to the cabin stairs, and I sat beside him to attend to him.

en: There were no other passengers that night, but we four.
vi: That night, there were no other passengers except the four of us.
tr: That night, there were no other passengers besides the four of us.
es: There were only four passengers.

en: The prisoner was so good as to beg permission to advise me how I could shelter my father from the wind and weather, better than I had done.
vi: The defendant kindly asked for permission to show me how to shield my father from the wind and rain, even better than I could.
tr: The defendant even kindly asked for my permission to suggest what I should do to better protect my father from the wind and cold weather.
es: The prisoner was so kind that, after asking me to excuse his boldness, he showed me how to place my father sheltered from the air and the damp, something I had not known how to do.

en: I had not known how to do it well, not understanding how the wind would set when we were out of the harbour.
vi: I couldn't do it because I didn't know which direction the wind would blow when the ship left the port.
tr: I didn't know how to do it. I couldn't tell which direction the wind would blow from when we left the port.
es: The prisoner was so kind that, after asking me to excuse his boldness, he showed me how to place my father sheltered from the air and the damp, something I had not known how to do.

en: He did it for me.
vi: He helped me with it.
tr: He helped me.
es: He lavished my father with attentions and kindnesses that I cannot forget, and I am sure he did so from the heart.

en: He expressed great gentleness and kindness for my father’s state, and I am sure he felt it.
vi: He showed great care and kindness towards my father's health condition, and I firmly believe he was sincere.
tr: He showed great kindness and concern towards my father, and I'm sure he was sincere while doing it.
es: He lavished my father with attentions and kindnesses that I cannot forget, and I am sure he did so from the heart.

en: That was the manner of our beginning to speak together.”
vi: We started talking to each other like that.
tr: Thus, we started talking."
es: This is how we began to talk.

en: “Let me interrupt you for a moment.
vi: − Let me interrupt you for a moment.
tr: "Well, I will ask something.
es: —Allow me to interrupt you.

en: Had he come on board alone?”
vi: The defendant boarded the train alone, didn't they? −
tr: Did he board the ferry alone?"
es: Did you arrive alone on board?

en: “No.”
vi: No.
tr: "No"
es: —No, sir.

en: “How many were with him?”
vi: − How many people went with him?
tr: "How many people were with you?""
es: —How many were accompanying you?

en: “Two French gentlemen.”
vi: − Two French gentlemen.
tr: "There were two French gentlemen."
es: —Two French gentlemen.

en: “Had they conferred together?”
vi: − Did they discuss anything with each other?
tr: "Did they talk?""
es: —What were you discussing with the prisoner?

en: “They had conferred together until the last moment, when it was necessary for the French gentlemen to be landed in their boat.”
vi: − They discussed until the last minute, when those French gentlemen had to leave the ship and board their boat.
tr: "They talked until the last moment, that is, until the time the French had to return to their boats."
es: —They spoke with the prisoner until the last moment. When the ship was weighing anchor, they bid him farewell and jumped into their boat.

en: “Had any papers been handed about among them, similar to these lists?”
vi: − Did they exchange any documents similar to these lists?
tr: "Was there a paper exchange similar to these lists between them?"
es: —Did they exchange among themselves any papers similar to these?

en: “Some papers had been handed about among them, but I don’t know what papers.”
vi: − They exchanged some documents, but I don't know what kind of documents.
tr: "There was an exchange of papers between them, but I don't know what it was about."
es: —They exchanged some papers, but I don't know how or what they were.

en: “Like these in shape and size?”
vi: − Does it resemble the shape and size of these documents?
tr: "Were the papers of this size and shape?"
es: —Similar to these in size and shape?

en: “Possibly, but indeed I don’t know, although they stood whispering very near to me: because they stood at the top of the cabin steps to have the light of the lamp that was hanging there; it was a dull lamp, and they spoke very low, and I did not hear what they said, and saw only that they looked at papers.”
vi: − Maybe, but honestly I don't know, even though they were whispering right next to me; because there was a lamp hanging at the top of the steps leading down to the bedroom, they stood there for the light; the light was very dim, and they spoke very softly, I couldn't hear what they were saying, I only saw them looking at the documents.
tr: "It might be, but I can't be sure despite their whispering very close to me; they were standing at the top of the stairs leading down to the cabins to take advantage of the light from the hanging lamp; the light was dim and they were speaking very softly, I couldn't hear what they were talking about, I only saw that they were looking at papers.""
es: —It is possible, but I cannot assure it, although I was very close to the place where they were talking. The night was very dark and the prisoner and the French gentlemen positioned themselves at the top of the chamber stairs, under the hanging lantern. They, however, held the conversation in such a low voice that I did not hear a word. I did see, though, that they were reading papers, and nothing more.

en: “Now, to the prisoner’s conversation, Miss Manette.”
vi: − Now let's talk about the conversation with the defendant, Miss Manette.
tr: "Now let's return to your conversation with the defendant, Miss Manette."
es: —Repeat to us the conversation you had with the prisoner, Miss Manette.

en: “The prisoner was as open in his confidence with me—which arose out of my helpless situation—as he was kind, and good, and useful to my father.
vi: − The defendant seemed straightforward and trustworthy... because in that situation I didn't know what to do... because he was also kind and gentle with me just like he was with my father.
tr: "The defendant – perhaps due to my helplessness – was very reassuring and very kind, good, and helpful to my father," she said, bursting into tears, and added, "If I say anything that would harm him, I can never repay my debt to him."
es: —The prisoner was very frank with me... he placed great trust in me... he was very kind, very good... he treated my father with tender care... and I wouldn't want—finished the young woman, in a sea of tears—I wouldn't want to repay his favors with statements that might harm him.

en: I hope,” bursting into tears, “I may not repay him by doing him harm to-day.”
vi: I hope that... - the girl burst into tears - ... that today I don't have to repay him with words that harm him.
tr: "The defendant – perhaps due to my helplessness – was very reassuring and very kind, good, and helpful to my father," she said, bursting into tears, and added, "If I say anything that would harm him, I can never repay my debt to him."
es: —The prisoner was very frank with me... he placed great trust in me... he was very kind, very good... he treated my father with tender care... and I wouldn't want—finished the young woman, in a sea of tears—I wouldn't want to repay his favors with statements that might harm him.

en: Buzzing from the blue-flies.
vi: The swarm of green flies buzzed again.
tr: A hum rose from their backs again.
es: The blue horseflies started buzzing again.

en: “Miss Manette, if the prisoner does not perfectly understand that you give the evidence which it is your duty to give—which you must give—and which you cannot escape from giving—with great unwillingness, he is the only person present in that condition.
vi: − Miss Manette, if the defendant does not fully understand that you were extremely reluctant to provide the evidence that you had a duty to provide, the evidence that you must provide, and the evidence that you could not avoid providing, then everyone here except the defendant understands.
tr: "Miss Manette, if the defendant does not understand that you are obligated to provide this evidence – that is, you must provide it – and that you cannot escape from this, there is nothing that can be done.
es: —Miss Manette—replied the prosecutor,—if the prisoner does not realize that you are giving the testimony that it is your duty to give... that you are obliged to give... that you cannot be excused from giving, against your will and with great reluctance, it must be admitted that he is blind.

en: Please to go on.”
vi: Please continue speaking.
tr: Please continue."
es: Please continue.

en: “He told me that he was travelling on business of a delicate and difficult nature, which might get people into trouble, and that he was therefore travelling under an assumed name.
vi: − He told me that he was doing a delicate and difficult job, one that could cause trouble for many people, so he used a fake name when traveling.
tr: "He told me that he was traveling because of a delicate and difficult task that could cause trouble for people, and that's why he was using an alias.
es: —He told me that his journey was motivated by matters of a highly delicate and compromising nature, matters that might possibly cause serious conflicts between different peoples, and for this reason, he was traveling under an assumed name.

en: He said that this business had, within a few days, taken him to France, and might, at intervals, take him backwards and forwards between France and England for a long time to come.”
vi: He said that this job, in a few days, would take him back to France, and he might have to travel back and forth between France and England many times over the coming period.
tr: He had gone to France for a few days for this task and explained that he might travel back and forth between France and England at intervals for a longer period."
es: He told me that these matters had taken him to France a few days earlier, and that probably, for a more or less long period, they would oblige him to make frequent trips between England and France.

en: “Did he say anything about America, Miss Manette?
vi: − Did the defendant say anything about the matter in America, Miss Manette?
tr: "Did Miss Manette say anything about America?
es: —Did he speak of America, Miss Manette?

en: Be particular.”
vi: Please be clear.
tr: Think carefully."
es: Please be kind enough to specify in detail.

en: “He tried to explain to me how that quarrel had arisen, and he said that, so far as he could judge, it was a wrong and foolish one on England’s part.
vi: − He tried to explain to me how the conflict had arisen, and he said that, in his opinion, the British side was wrong and foolish.
tr: "He tried to explain to me how the dispute started and said that what England did was, in his opinion, wrong and foolish.
es: —He tried to explain to me the causes that led to the conflict, and he told me that, in his opinion, the wrong and the injustice were on the side of England.

en: He added, in a jesting way, that perhaps George Washington might gain almost as great a name in history as George the Third.
vi: He jokingly added that perhaps George Washington would become as famous in history as King George III.
tr: He also jokingly said that George Washington would go down in history as an important name, just like George III.
es: He added, in a humorous tone, that perhaps George Washington was destined to achieve as high a renown in history as George III.

en: But there was no harm in his way of saying this: it was said laughingly, and to beguile the time.”
vi: But he said this without any malice; it was just said to pass the time with some laughter.
tr: But he said this not with ill intent, but laughingly, for fun. He didn't mean it in a bad way, he said it with a smile, just for amusement."
es: But in all this there was not a shadow of malice: he said it laughing and to pass the time.

en: Any strongly marked expression of face on the part of a chief actor in a scene of great interest to whom many eyes are directed, will be unconsciously imitated by the spectators.
vi: Any prominent expression on the face of the main character in an engaging play will be unconsciously mimicked by the audience.
tr: In this intriguing scene where all eyes were directed, the audience would unconsciously mimic any stern expression that appeared on the lead actor's face.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: Her forehead was painfully anxious and intent as she gave this evidence, and, in the pauses when she stopped for the Judge to write it down, watched its effect upon the counsel for and against.
vi: The girl's forehead furrows with concentration and anxiety, turning to anguish as she testifies in court.
tr: When he explained this evidence, the young lady's forehead wrinkled with pain and she became attentive, and during the moments when the Judge paused to take notes, he looked at both the defense attorney and the prosecutor to see the impact of his words.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: Among the lookers-on there was the same expression in all quarters of the court; insomuch, that a great majority of the foreheads there, might have been mirrors reflecting the witness, when the Judge looked up from his notes to glare at that tremendous heresy about George Washington.
vi: During the moments she pauses for the Judge to take notes and observes the reactions of both the defense and prosecution officials, throughout the courtroom, every curious onlooker shares that same expression. To the extent that when the Judge puts down his pen and looks up, his face stern from the highly disrespectful remark about George Washington, the majority of foreheads in the room become mirrors reflecting the emotions of the girl witness.
tr: The same expression was on the faces of the spectators all around the courtroom; so much so that when the Judge looked up from his notes and stared intently regarding the dreadful misdeed related to George Washington, many of their foreheads were like mirrors reflecting the witness.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: mr Attorney-General now signified to my Lord, that he deemed it necessary, as a matter of precaution and form, to call the young lady’s father, Doctor Manette.
vi: The Attorney General now signaled to the Chief Justice, indicating that it was time to question Dr. Manette, the girl's father, in accordance with procedure and as a precaution.
tr: The Chief Prosecutor, in all his grandeur, expressed that it was necessary to summon the young lady's father, Doctor Manette, in terms of precaution and procedure.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: Who was called accordingly.
vi: This person was called to testify.
tr: Thus, Mr. Manette was called to the witness stand.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: “Doctor Manette, look upon the prisoner.
vi: − Dr. Manette, please look at the defendant over there.
tr: "Doctor Manette, look at the face of the defendant.
es: —Look at the prisoner, Dr. Manette: do you remember seeing him before?

en: Have you ever seen him before?”
vi: Have you ever met the defendant before?
tr: Have you ever seen him before?"
es: —Look at the prisoner, Dr. Manette: do you remember seeing him before?

en: “Once.
vi: − Once.
tr: "Once.
es: —Only once.

en: When he called at my lodgings in London.
vi: When this person visited my house in London.
tr: He had visited my house in London.
es: It was three or three and a half years ago that he visited me at my house in London.

en: Some three years, or three years and a half ago.”
vi: About three or three and a half years ago.
tr: About three or three and a half years ago."
es: It was three or three and a half years ago that he visited me at my house in London.

en: “Can you identify him as your fellow-passenger on board the packet, or speak to his conversation with your daughter?”
vi: − Did you recognize the defendant as the person who was on the same train, or did he talk to your daughter?
tr: "Don't you remember the passenger who was traveling next to you on the ferry and talking to your daughter?"
es: —Can you tell us if he was your travel companion during the crossing of the Canal, or repeat the conversation you had with your daughter?

en: “Sir, I can do neither.”
vi: − Your Honor, I am not aware of either of those things.
tr: "I don't remember such a thing, sir.""
es: —Neither one nor the other, sir.

en: “Is there any particular and special reason for your being unable to do either?”
vi: − Is there a specific and special reason why you were not aware of both of those things?
tr: "Could there be a specific reason why you can't remember these?""
es: —Are there any particular and special reasons that make it impossible for you to do what is being asked?

en: He answered, in a low voice, “There is.”
vi: − Yes, - he replied softly.
tr: Mr. Manette replied in a low voice, "There is.""
es: —They exist—replied the doctor in a very low voice.

en: “Has it been your misfortune to undergo a long imprisonment, without trial, or even accusation, in your native country, Doctor Manette?”
vi: − Doctor Manette, in France you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, or even without any charges, is that correct?
tr: "In your own country, you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, and without even being charged with any crime, weren't you, Doctor Manette?"
es: —Are these the misfortunes of having suffered a long captivity in your homeland, without being condemned, and even without being accused?

vi: − Imprisoned for a very long time, - his voice responded, moving everyone deeply.
tr: "In your own country, you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, and without even being charged with any crime, weren't you, Doctor Manette?"
es: —Are these the misfortunes of having suffered a long captivity in your homeland, without being condemned, and even without being accused?

en: Original
vi: − When you took that train, you had just been released from prison, hadn't you?
tr: "In your own country, you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, and without even being charged with any crime, weren't you, Doctor Manette?"
es: With a tone that penetrated to the depths of the hearts of all those present, he replied:

en: He answered, in a tone that went to every heart, “A long imprisonment.”
vi: − When you took that train, you had just been released from prison, hadn't you?
tr: In a tone that tore at everyone's heart, Mr. Manette replied, "For a very long time indeed."
es: —An eternal captivity!

en: “Were you newly released on the occasion in question?”
tr: "In the mentioned situation, had you just been released?""
es: —Had you recently regained your freedom when the trip I am referring to took place?

en: “They tell me so.”
vi: That's what they told me.
tr: "That's what they say."
es: —That's what they tell me.

en: “Have you no remembrance of the occasion?”
vi: − Do you not remember anything about that train journey? −
tr: "Don't you remember that moment at all?"
es: —Don't you remember?

en: “None.
vi: No. I lost my memory for a long time... I don't even know how long... from when I started making shoes in prison until I found myself in London with my daughter here.
tr: "No.
es: —I don't remember anything.

en: My mind is a blank, from some time—I cannot even say what time—when I employed myself, in my captivity, in making shoes, to the time when I found myself living in London with my dear daughter here.
vi: No. I lost my memory for a long time... I don't even know how long... from when I started making shoes in prison until I found myself in London with my daughter here.
tr: My mind has been blank since –I don't even know since when– from the times I started making shoes by myself in prison, to the moment I found myself in London beside my dear daughter, empty.
es: My brain was a deep night for some time... I can't say how long... from when I was making shoes in my cell until I found myself in London in the company of my dear daughter.

en: She had become familiar to me, when a gracious God restored my faculties; but, I am quite unable even to say how she had become familiar.
vi: I recognized my daughter when God restored my memory; but I still don't know how I came to meet my child.
tr: Thank God I remembered my daughter when the Almighty restored my skills; but I am not even in a position to say how I remembered her.
es: I got used to her presence... I don't know how...

en: I have no remembrance of the process.”
vi: I don't remember how it happened at all.
tr: I don't remember anything from that period."
es: I have no memory of the process... and finally, the merciful God saw fit to restore my faculties.

en: mr Attorney-General sat down, and the father and daughter sat down together.
vi: The Attorney General sat down, and the father and son also sat down at the same time.
tr: The Chief Prosecutor sat down, then the father and bz also took their places.
es: The Crown prosecutor concluded the questioning, and the father and daughter sat down again.

en: A singular circumstance then arose in the case.
vi: Then a strange situation occurred during the trial.
tr: Then, a strange development occurred in the trial.
es: A singular incident occurred at this point.

en: The object in hand being to show that the prisoner went down, with some fellow-plotter untracked, in the Dover mail on that Friday night in November five years ago, and got out of the mail in the night, as a blind, at a place where he did not remain, but from which he travelled back some dozen miles or more, to a garrison and dockyard, and there collected information; a witness was called to identify him as having been at the precise time required, in the coffee-room of an hotel in that garrison-and-dockyard town, waiting for another person.
vi: The main objective was to prove that the defendant, along with an unknown accomplice, had taken the Dover mail coach on a Friday night in November five years ago, had gotten off during the night to mislead, disembarked at a place he did not stay but went back about twelve miles or more, to a place with a military base and a shipyard, and then gathered information there; a witness was called to confirm that the defendant was present at that exact time, in the dining room of a hotel in the city with the military base and shipyard, waiting to meet another person.
tr: According to the information obtained, the defendant, five years ago. On that Friday night in November, had boarded the Dover Mail with an unidentified accomplice, then disembarked somewhere in the pitch dark of the night, but did not stay there long, had walked ten to fifteen kilometers back to a garrison and dockyard to gather information; but then a witness was called who claimed that at that time, the defendant was waiting for someone else in the tea lounge of a hotel in the town where the mentioned garrison and dockyard were located.
es: The object of the proceedings, the goal pursued in the process, was to demonstrate that the accused, in the company of another traitorous accomplice whose identity was a mystery until then, travelers, on the night of a Friday in the month of November five years ago, had dismounted during the journey in the mail coach from London to Dover, with the aim of misleading, at a place where they did not intend to stay, from where they retraced twelve or more miles to reach a stronghold with an arsenal, where they gathered the data they were seeking. A witness declared that on the indicated day and time, he had seen the prisoner in the dining room of a hotel in the mentioned stronghold and arsenal, waiting for another person.

en: The prisoner’s counsel was cross-examining this witness with no result, except that he had never seen the prisoner on any other occasion, when the wigged gentleman who had all this time been looking at the ceiling of the court, wrote a word or two on a little piece of paper, screwed it up, and tossed it to him.
vi: The defense lawyer was still questioning this witness without any results, except for the witness's admission that he had never met the defendant in any other circumstances, when the gentleman with the wig, who had been staring at the ceiling, wrote a few words on a piece of paper, crumpled it up, and tossed it to the lawyer.
tr: The defendant's lawyer had asked this new witness many questions, but received no answer other than that he had never seen the defendant at any other time; just then, the wigged man who had been watching the ceiling of the courtroom until that moment scribbled something on a piece of paper, crumpled it, and threw it to the lawyer.
es: The defendant's defense attorney was subjecting the witness to an interrogation as rigid as it was skillful, with no other result than ensuring that he had never, neither before nor after the indicated occasion, seen the prisoner, when the bewigged gentleman, who had been staring at the ceiling of the courtroom since the beginning of the trial, wrote two or three words on a small piece of paper, twisted it, and then threw it to the defense attorney.

en: Opening this piece of paper in the next pause, the counsel looked with great attention and curiosity at the prisoner.
vi: During a pause between two questions, the lawyer opened the piece of paper, read it, and then looked very attentively and curiously towards the defendant.
tr: During the first break, the lawyer opened this paper and looked at the defendant with great interest and curiosity.
es: After reading the small piece of paper, the defense attorney looked at the prisoner with extraordinary attention and curiosity.

en: “You say again you are quite sure that it was the prisoner?”
vi: − Do you dare to say again that you are certain this is the defendant?
tr: "Are you sure this person is the defendant?"
es: —Do you say that you have absolute certainty that it was the prisoner?—asked the witness.

en: The witness was quite sure.
vi: The witness is completely certain.
tr: The witness was quite sure.
es: —Absolutely.

en: “Did you ever see anybody very like the prisoner?”
vi: − Have you ever seen anyone who looks very much like this defendant? −
tr: "Have you ever seen someone who looks very much like the defendant?"
es: —Have you never seen anyone who resembles the prisoner?

en: Not so like (the witness said) as that he could be mistaken.
vi: Not similar enough to be mistaken for, - the witness said.
tr: He had not seen anyone who looked so similar that it would cause confusion (the witness had said exactly this).
es: —To no one who resembles them so much that it could lead to a mistake.

en: “Look well upon that gentleman, my learned friend there,” pointing to him who had tossed the paper over, “and then look well upon the prisoner.
vi: − Look carefully at that gentleman, he is my colleague, - the lawyer pointed towards the person who threw the piece of paper, - then look carefully at the defendant.
tr: The man who threw the paper pointed and said, "Look at the gentleman sitting over there, that wise person, and then look at the defendant.
es: —Take a good look at that gentleman,—he replied, pointing to the one who had just thrown him the note—and then, take a good look at the prisoner.

en: How say you?
vi: What did he say?
tr: What do you say?
es: What do you say?

en: Are they very like each other?”
vi: Do they look exactly alike?
tr: Don't they look very much alike?"
es: Isn't it true that they look quite alike?

en: Allowing for my learned friend’s appearance being careless and slovenly if not debauched, they were sufficiently like each other to surprise, not only the witness, but everybody present, when they were thus brought into comparison.
vi: Except for the careless and slovenly, if not downright shabby, appearance of our esteemed colleague, the other two were so alike that both the witness and everyone in the court were astonished when they recognized the resemblance.
tr: If we disregard the appearance of our wise friend, which, although not immoral, could be described as disheveled and slovenly, it could be said that when compared to each other, they resembled each other so much that it would astonish not only the witness but everyone present.
