es: However, despite the negligence and untidiness of the gentleman with the little paper, there was a rather remarkable resemblance between him and the prisoner, enough to surprise not only the witness but also everyone present in the courtroom.

en: My Lord being prayed to bid my learned friend lay aside his wig, and giving no very gracious consent, the likeness became much more remarkable.
vi: After the judge requested our esteemed colleague to remove his wig and he complied with a look of displeasure, the resemblance became even more strikingly clear.
tr: The judge, upon the prosecutor's request, ordered our wise friend to remove his wig, which made this resemblance even more apparent.
es: The president of the tribunal requested the aforementioned gentleman with the little paper to remove his wig, and the resemblance became much more notable.

en: My Lord inquired of mr Stryver (the prisoner’s counsel), whether they were next to try mr Carton (name of my learned friend) for treason?
vi: The judge asked Mr. Stryver (the defense attorney) whether they were intending to try Mr. Carton (our esteemed colleague) for treason.
tr: The judge asked Mr. Stryver (the defendant's lawyer) whether the other person they were going to try for treason was Mr. Carton (our wise friend).
es: The president asked Mr. Stryver, who was the defense attorney, if they were to prosecute Mr. Carton, the name of the gentleman with the little paper, for the crime of treason, to which the defense attorney replied no, but that he wished to ask the witness if he believed that what had happened once could not happen again, if he would have dared to speak with such certainty and confidence if he had previously seen that palpable example of his temerity, if the sight of a person who so closely resembled the prisoner would not have been a severe blow to his confidence, etc., etc.

en: But, mr Stryver replied to my Lord, no; but he would ask the witness to tell him whether what happened once, might happen twice; whether he would have been so confident if he had seen this illustration of his rashness sooner, whether he would be so confident, having seen it; and more.
vi: Mr. Stryver replied that no, but he would ask the witness whether he was certain that what had happened once could not happen again; whether the witness was so hasty as to be sure he had met the defendant if he had encountered such a look-alike before; and now that he had seen this, whether he could still be so sure, along with many other questions.
tr: Mr. Stryver told the judge no; but he would ask the witness to tell the judge the likelihood of something happening again once it had happened once; if he had seen his imprudence before, would he still speak so confidently or would he still speak confidently even after seeing it, were among the many questions on his mind.
es: The president asked Mr. Stryver, who was the defense attorney, if they were to prosecute Mr. Carton, the name of the gentleman with the little paper, for the crime of treason, to which the defense attorney replied no, but that he wished to ask the witness if he believed that what had happened once could not happen again, if he would have dared to speak with such certainty and confidence if he had previously seen that palpable example of his temerity, if the sight of a person who so closely resembled the prisoner would not have been a severe blow to his confidence, etc., etc.

en: The upshot of which, was, to smash this witness like a crockery vessel, and shiver his part of the case to useless lumber.
vi: The result was that the witness's credibility in court was shattered like a clay pot, and his testimony became a heap of useless fragments.
tr: The aim was to crush this witness and nullify his part of the case.
es: The result of this incident was to annihilate the witness, destroy the effect of his testimony, and strip all value from his statements.

en: mr Cruncher had by this time taken quite a lunch of rust off his fingers in his following of the evidence.
vi: At this point, Cruncher had thoroughly sucked the rusty, metallic taste from his fingers, substituting it for lunch while he listened to the testimonies.
tr: Mr. Cruncher had eaten all the rust off his fingers as if it were lunch while watching the witnesses.
es: The result of this incident was to annihilate the witness, destroy the effect of his testimony, and strip all value from his statements.

en: He had now to attend while mr Stryver fitted the prisoner’s case on the jury, like a compact suit of clothes; showing them how the patriot, Barsad, was a hired spy and traitor, an unblushing trafficker in blood, and one of the greatest scoundrels upon earth since accursed Judas—which he certainly did look rather like.
vi: Now he listened as Mr. Stryver refuted the incriminating evidence, much like tailoring a suit to fit the jury; the lawyer showed them that the patriot Barsad was actually a paid informant and traitor, a shameless human trafficker, and one of the most wicked men since Judas Iscariot - who, incidentally, bore a striking resemblance to Judas.
tr: Now he was watching with curiosity as Mr. Stryver fitted the defendant's case onto the jury like a well-tailored suit; he was telling them that the so-called patriot Barsad was a secret spy and traitor, and moreover, a shameless blood merchant, and the greatest traitor since the accursed Judas – to whom he indeed bore a resemblance.
es: The good Jeremiah Lapa, who was following the course of the trial without missing a word or gesture, had to listen as the defense turned the tables on the prosecutor and the witnesses who had served the Jury, saying that the exalted, the sublime patriot Barsad, was a mercenary spy, a vile traitor, a blood trafficker who knew neither decorum nor shame, the blackest-souled reptile that had existed in the world since the accursed Judas, to whom he bore a physical and moral resemblance, dishonored it with his presence.

en: How the virtuous servant, Cly, was his friend and partner, and was worthy to be; how the watchful eyes of those forgers and false swearers had rested on the prisoner as a victim, because some family affairs in France, he being of French extraction, did require his making those passages across the Channel—though what those affairs were, a consideration for others who were near and dear to him, forbade him, even for his life, to disclose.
vi: As for the virtuous servant Cly, he was Barsad's friend and accomplice, no better than him; the lawyer demonstrated how these two perjurers, who had sworn false oaths, had targeted the defendant and plotted his downfall; the defendant, being of French origin, had business that required him to travel frequently between the two countries - matters involving his closest and dearest associates, which he would never reveal even under the threat of death.
tr: He explained that the very virtuous servant Cly was his friend and partner and that he deserved such company; that the fraudsters and false witnesses had chosen the defendant as their victim due to family matters in France, after all, he was of French origin and had to cross the Channel frequently – but these family matters, which concerned those close to him, prevented him from explaining all this, even at the cost of his life.
es: He asserted that the mirror of a servant, the innocent Cly, was a friend and accomplice of Barsad, and certainly worthy of being so, that the ever-watchful eyes of those miserable forgers and perjurers had resolved to turn the prisoner into a victim of their greed, taking advantage of the fact that he, being of French origin, made frequent trips between England and France for family matters he could not explain, and that the prisoner would not explain, even if his silence cost him his life, because high considerations forbade him.

en: How the evidence that had been warped and wrested from the young lady, whose anguish in giving it they had witnessed, came to nothing, involving the mere little innocent gallantries and politenesses likely to pass between any young gentleman and young lady so thrown together;—with the exception of that reference to George Washington, which was altogether too extravagant and impossible to be regarded in any other light than as a monstrous joke.
vi: The lawyer proved that the testimony of the young lady, who everyone could see had suffered greatly while testifying, had been distorted and coerced into worthless evidence; it was merely polite, impartial conversation that any gentleman or lady might exchange upon meeting - except for the wildly outrageous comment about George Washington, which could only be seen as a crude joke and nothing more.
tr: The words forcibly taken and distorted from the young lady meant nothing, and everyone had witnessed how much she suffered while saying them; in that environment, such innocent conversation and courtesy between a young gentleman and lady were very natural; meanwhile, those excessive words about George Washington could be nothing but a bad joke.
es: He demonstrated that the statements made by Miss Manette, whose anguish in making them everyone had had the opportunity to appreciate, were of no importance, and were nothing more than innocent gallantries, very natural for a young man who encounters a charming girl on a journey, except for the part concerning George Washington, which in his opinion was so extravagant that it could only be considered a wildly inappropriate joke.

en: How it would be a weakness in the government to break down in this attempt to practise for popularity on the lowest national antipathies and fears, and therefore mr Attorney-General had made the most of it; how, nevertheless, it rested upon nothing, save that vile and infamous character of evidence too often disfiguring such cases, and of which the State Trials of this country were full.
vi: The lawyer argued that it would be a weakness in governance to undermine the effort to win the affection of the subjects through fear and hatred sown among the public, and this was something the Attorney General had exploited to the fullest; however, this meant nothing beyond the fact that the vile and despicable nature of the evidence often discredited such trials, and this was abundantly documented in our country's State Trials.
tr: It would appear as a weakness of the state to halt the attempts to apply the lowest levels of national hatred and fears, so the Attorney General had done his best; but it was to no avail, these disgraceful and vile pieces of evidence frequently tainted such cases, and there were many trials like this in the country. But the courts, which were packed to the brim, should not be occupied with such baseless cases.
es: He added that Justice would show palpable weakness if it persisted in the idea of pursuing a sterile populism by exploiting low antipathies and national fears that the Crown prosecutor had exploited in his report, which, in truth, had no more foundation than the meanness and vileness of a statement whose bad faith was glaringly obvious, a statement made with the deliberate intention of distorting the facts, a statement that tends to make Justice, to our shame, add a most lamentable error to the endless series of those it has committed.

en: But, there my Lord interposed (with as grave a face as if it had not been true), saying that he could not sit upon that Bench and suffer those allusions.
vi: But at this point, the judge interrupted (with a stern face as if the lawyer had not spoken the truth), declaring that he could not accept such insinuations during the trial.
tr: But there the Judge objected (with a stern expression on his face as if what was being said was not true) and said from his bench that he could not allow these insinuations.
es: The president, as if what the defender had just expressed was not an exact expression of the truth, interrupted the speaker with a grim face, to say, with a grave demeanor, that it was impossible for him to continue occupying his elevated seat if he was forced to tolerate such unpleasant allusions.

en: mr Stryver then called his few witnesses, and mr Cruncher had next to attend while mr Attorney-General turned the whole suit of clothes mr Stryver had fitted on the jury, inside out; showing how Barsad and Cly were even a hundred times better than he had thought them, and the prisoner a hundred times worse.
vi: Mr. Stryver then called a few more of his witnesses, and afterwards Cruncher attentively listened to the Attorney General turn the suit that Mr. Stryver had dressed the jury in inside out; the Attorney General proved that Barsad and Cly were even better people than he had ever imagined, while the defendant was a hundred times worse.
tr: Then Mr. Stryver called a few more witnesses, and while Mr. Cruncher waited, the Attorney General turned the suit that Mr. Stryver had dressed the jury in inside out; that is, he explained that both Barsad and Cly were much better people than the lawyer had thought, and the defendant was a much worse person.
es: The defense attorney questioned the few exculpatory witnesses, and subsequently, the audience had to admire the efforts made by the Crown prosecutor to turn inside out the case that the former had crafted for the Jury. The most striking part of his speech was to assert a thousand times over that the heroic Barsad and Cly were a thousand times more virtuous than initially stated, and the prisoner a thousand times more criminal.

en: Lastly, came my Lord himself, turning the suit of clothes, now inside out, now outside in, but on the whole decidedly trimming and shaping them into grave-clothes for the prisoner.
vi: Finally, it was the Chief Justice's turn to turn the suit inside out and right side out again, but overall he decided to cut it down into a shroud to drape over the defendant.
tr: Finally, the Judge turned that suit inside out, then right side out, but in the end, he decisively cut it and fashioned a shroud for the defendant.
es: In his final report, the president went over and over the case crafted by the prosecutor and tried to undo the seams of the one presented by the defense attorney, showing a clear tendency to prepare the prisoner's shroud with both.

en: And now, the jury turned to consider, and the great flies swarmed again.
vi: Now it's time for the jury to deliberate and the blue flies to swarm and buzz again.
tr: When it came time for the jury members' deliberation, the large flies gathered in the courtroom once again.
es: The Jury withdrew to deliberate, and the large blue flies once again made their unpleasant buzzing heard.

en: mr Carton, who had so long sat looking at the ceiling of the court, changed neither his place nor his attitude, even in this excitement.
vi: Right in this bustling scene, lawyer Carton - who had been sitting and staring at the ceiling - did not change his posture or attitude at all.
tr: Mr. Carton, who had been sitting with his eyes fixed on the ceiling of the hall for hours, had neither changed his position nor his demeanor even in this confusion.
es: The movement, the general murmurs, the anticipation that had taken hold of all the witnesses of the scene, did not cause Mr. Carton, who continued to sit and stare at the ceiling, to change his posture or position.

en: While his learned friend, mr Stryver, massing his papers before him, whispered with those who sat near, and from time to time glanced anxiously at the jury; while all the spectators moved more or less, and grouped themselves anew; while even my Lord himself arose from his seat, and slowly paced up and down his platform, not unattended by a suspicion in the minds of the audience that his state was feverish; this one man sat leaning back, with his torn gown half off him, his untidy wig put on just as it had happened to light on his head after its removal, his hands in his pockets, and his eyes on the ceiling as they had been all day.
vi: While his colleague Stryver was gathering the papers in front of him and whispering to those sitting nearby, occasionally glancing anxiously at the jury; while everyone attending the trial moved around and formed new groups to some extent; while even the judge left his seat and slowly paced back and forth on the platform, causing the crowd to suspect that he was inwardly impatient; only Carton remained leaning back in his chair, his old robe almost slipping off his shoulders, his disheveled wig haphazardly perched on his head as if protesting being removed earlier, his hands in his pockets, his eyes still fixed on the ceiling.
tr: His wise friend Mr. Stryver, who was gathering the papers in front of him, was whispering to those beside him while occasionally glancing anxiously at the jury; meanwhile, the Judge had risen from his seat and was pacing up and down the podium, causing the audience to suspect he had a fever; the man sitting back with his torn robe half fallen, his disheveled wig crooked after falling off, and his hands in his pockets still had his eyes on the ceiling.
es: Meanwhile, his friend Mr. Stryver, gathering the papers in front of him, conversed with the people closest to him and from time to time cast anxious glances at the Jury, while all the spectators moved about more or less, sometimes separating, sometimes coming together again, while even the president left his seat to walk around the platform, giving reason for those present to suspect that his state of mind was far from calm, Mr. Carton remained slouched in his seat, with his wig half askew, hands in his pockets, seemingly indifferent to everything and everyone, his eyes fixed on the ceiling as they had been all day.

en: Something especially reckless in his demeanour, not only gave him a disreputable look, but so diminished the strong resemblance he undoubtedly bore to the prisoner (which his momentary earnestness, when they were compared together, had strengthened), that many of the lookers-on, taking note of him now, said to one another they would hardly have thought the two were so alike.
vi: That very disdainful attitude not only made him appear somewhat disreputable but also diminished the undeniable resemblance to the defendant (a resemblance that was quite clear when he temporarily showed seriousness for everyone to compare their appearances), to the extent that many trial spectators now, upon noticing Carton, remarked to each other that they did not see much similarity between this man and the accused.
tr: The indifference in his manner not only gave him a disreputable air but also diminished his strong resemblance to the defendant (though the resemblance had increased a moment ago with the seriousness that arose when they were compared), so much so that most of the spectators who noticed him were whispering that they didn't look much alike.
es: Nevertheless, Mr. Carton noticed more details of the scene unfolding before his eyes than it seemed at first glance.

en: mr Cruncher made the observation to his next neighbour, and added, “I’d hold half a guinea that he don’t get no law-work to do.
vi: Cruncher made such a remark to the person standing next to him and added: − I'd bet half a guinea that this lawyer isn't hired by many to argue their cases.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was also sharing his observations with the man next to him: "I bet this man never wins a case.
es: Proof of this is that, when Miss Manette, overwhelmed by so many emotions, fainted into her father's arms, it was Carton who noticed it first and was the first to come to her aid, saying:

en: Don’t look like the sort of one to get any, do he?”
vi: Doesn't look like the kind of lawyer who has work to do, right?
tr: He doesn't look like the type who can win a case, does he?"
es: —Guard!

en: Yet, this mr Carton took in more of the details of the scene than he appeared to take in; for now, when Miss Manette’s head dropped upon her father’s breast, he was the first to see it, and to say audibly: “Officer! look to that young lady.
vi: However, this Carton fellow, despite appearances, was clearly observing everything in the court; because at this moment, when Miss Manette collapsed into her father's arms, it was he who first noticed and shouted: − Officer?! Take care of the young lady.
tr: Despite his indifferent appearance, Mr. Carton was watching everything in detail, and when Miss Manette's head fell onto her father's chest, he was the first to see it, and as soon as he saw it, he shouted in a voice that everyone could hear, "Hey, attendant! Quick, look after the young lady.
es: Attend to that young lady...

en: Help the gentleman to take her out.
vi: Help that gentleman take her outside.
tr: Help the gentleman so he can take the lady outside.
es: Help the gentleman to get her out of the room...

en: Don’t you see she will fall!”
vi: Can't you see she's about to faint?!
tr: She's about to faint!"
es: Don't you see she's about to faint?

en: There was much commiseration for her as she was removed, and much sympathy with her father.
vi: The crowd felt very sorry for the young lady and sympathized with the father as she was taken outside.
tr: As the girl was being taken outside, a great sense of pity for her and compassion for her father arose in the hall.
es: Everyone was moved to compassion upon seeing the young lady being taken out of the room, and there was no one who did not extend all their sympathies to the father.

en: It had evidently been a great distress to him, to have the days of his imprisonment recalled.
vi: The father was clearly extremely distressed, having to recall the days of his imprisonment.
tr: It was clear that recalling the prison days had disturbed her greatly.
es: The scene, which could not help but remind him of the endless years of his undeserved imprisonment, deeply affected him.

en: He had shown strong internal agitation when he was questioned, and that pondering or brooding look which made him old, had been upon him, like a heavy cloud, ever since.
vi: He was deeply moved when questioned, and from that moment on, he looked much older, his face perpetually gloomy and contemplative as if shrouded by dark clouds.
tr: During the interrogation, she felt a deep pain inside, and the pensive and thoughtful demeanor that made her look older had settled over her like a heavy cloud.
es: A good proof of this was the intense inner agitation that the interrogation caused him, an agitation that did not go unnoticed by anyone.

en: As he passed out, the jury, who had turned back and paused a moment, spoke, through their foreman.
vi: As he walked out, the jury turned around and took a break so that the foreman could speak to the court on their behalf.
tr: As she was leaving, the jury members returning to their seats remained silent for a moment, then the jury spokesperson spoke.
es: Moments later, the Jury appeared, and through its president, stated that, not having reached an agreement, they wished to withdraw again.

en: They were not agreed, and wished to retire.
vi: The jury did not have a unanimous opinion and wanted to retreat to the deliberation room.
tr: They couldn't come to a decision and wanted to reconvene.
es: Moments later, the Jury appeared, and through its president, stated that, not having reached an agreement, they wished to withdraw again.

en: My Lord (perhaps with George Washington on his mind) showed some surprise that they were not agreed, but signified his pleasure that they should retire under watch and ward, and retired himself.
vi: The Judge (probably still preoccupied with thoughts of George Washington) was somewhat surprised that the jury was not unanimous, but agreed to let them meet in private under supervision, and he himself temporarily withdrew.
tr: The judge was surprised when he heard they couldn't come to a decision (perhaps he still had George Washington on his mind), but after expressing that he would be pleased if they locked themselves in a room under supervision and talked, he also withdrew to another room.
es: The president of the Court, whose imagination was filled, if some malicious people are not mistaken, by the portrait of George Washington, expressed some surprise upon learning that the Jury had not reached an agreement, but agreed to let them retire again to deliberate, and, undoubtedly to imitate their conduct, he also withdrew.

en: The trial had lasted all day, and the lamps in the court were now being lighted.
vi: The trial had lasted all day, and the lights in the courtroom were now being turned on.
tr: The trial had lasted all day and the lamps in the hall had been lit.
es: The hearing had lasted all day and it was necessary to light the lamps in the Courtroom.

en: It began to be rumoured that the jury would be out a long while.
vi: People began to gossip that the jury would be deliberating for quite a while.
tr: Rumors had started circulating in the hall that the jury members wouldn't come for a long time.
es: Rumors circulated that the Jury's deliberations would be long, in view of which, the spectators began to file out to get some refreshments, and the defendant was taken to the most secluded part of the bar, where he took a seat.

en: The spectators dropped off to get refreshment, and the prisoner withdrew to the back of the dock, and sat down.
vi: The audience then dispersed for a break, and the defendant retreated to the back of the dock and sat down to await their fate.
tr: The spectators went outside to drink something, and the defendant went behind the section he was in and sat down.
es: Rumors circulated that the Jury's deliberations would be long, in view of which, the spectators began to file out to get some refreshments, and the defendant was taken to the most secluded part of the bar, where he took a seat.

en: mr Lorry, who had gone out when the young lady and her father went out, now reappeared, and beckoned to Jerry: who, in the slackened interest, could easily get near him.
vi: Mr. Lorry, who had just gone out following the girl and her father, now came back in and signaled to Jerry; the messenger easily reached him as the general curiosity around had subsided.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who had followed the young lady and her father outside, had now returned to the lounge and was signaling to Jerry. Jerry, whose interest in the matter had waned, immediately came over to him.
es: Mr. Lorry, who had gone out accompanying Miss Manette and her father, reappeared again and signaled to Jeremiah Lapa.

en: “Jerry, if you wish to take something to eat, you can.
vi: − Jerry, if you want to get something to eat, just go.
tr: "Jerry, if you want to get something to eat, go ahead.
es: —If you want to have something, Jeremiah, you can do so, but don't stray too far from here.

en: But, keep in the way.
vi: But stay nearby.
tr: But don't go too far.
es: —If you want to have something, Jeremiah, you can do so, but don't stray too far from here.

en: You will be sure to hear when the jury come in.
vi: You must pay attention to when the jury returns and follow them immediately without delay, because I need you to deliver the verdict to the bank.
tr: Stay within earshot of the jury's arrival.
es: It's essential that when the Jury enters, you are by my side, as the Bank is eagerly awaiting the news of the verdict.

en: Don’t be a moment behind them, for I want you to take the verdict back to the bank.
vi: You must pay attention to when the jury returns and follow them immediately without delay, because I need you to deliver the verdict to the bank.
tr: Don't be late even for a second, because I want you to deliver the verdict to the bank immediately.
es: It's essential that when the Jury enters, you are by my side, as the Bank is eagerly awaiting the news of the verdict.

en: You are the quickest messenger I know, and will get to Temple Bar long before I can.”
vi: You are the fastest messenger I know, surely you will reach Temple Bar long before I do.
tr: You are the fastest messenger I've ever seen, and I'm sure you'll be at Temple Bar long before me."
es: You are the fastest messenger I know and will be able to reach the Temple Court much sooner than I can.

en: Jerry had just enough forehead to knuckle, and he knuckled it in acknowledgment of this communication and a shilling.
vi: Jerry could only raise his finger to tap his forehead; he tapped his forehead to confirm this message and a shilling along with it.
tr: Jerry scratched his narrow forehead after hearing these words and being handed a shilling.
es: Lapa made a very graceful bow, I do not know whether it was due to the trust that Mr. Lorry placed in him, or because of the shilling he had just put in his hands.

en: mr Carton came up at the moment, and touched mr Lorry on the arm.
vi: At that moment, attorney Carton appeared and took Mr. Lorry's arm: − How is the lady? −
tr: At that moment, Mr. Carton came over and touched Mr. Lorry's arm.
es: At that point, Mr. Carton left his seat and touched Lorry on the shoulder.

en: “How is the young lady?”
vi: At that moment, attorney Carton appeared and took Mr. Lorry's arm: − How is the lady? −
tr: "How is the little lady?"
es: —How is the young lady?—he asked.

en: “She is greatly distressed; but her father is comforting her, and she feels the better for being out of court.”
vi: She is extremely miserable; but her father is comforting her, and once out of the court, she recovered.
tr: "Very sad; but her father is calming her down, she feels a bit better because she has left the courtroom.""
es: —Terribly distressed, but her father tries to console her, and she seems to be better than before leaving the room.

en: “I’ll tell the prisoner so.
vi: − I will let the prisoner know.
tr: "I will convey this to the defendant.
es: —I am going to tell the prisoner.

en: It won’t do for a respectable bank gentleman like you, to be seen speaking to him publicly, you know.”
vi: You know, it wouldn't be appropriate for someone as respectable as you from the bank to be seen talking openly with him.
tr: It would not be appropriate for a respectable banker like you to speak with him in front of everyone."
es: A gentleman as respectable as you should not speak to him in public.

en: mr Lorry reddened as if he were conscious of having debated the point in his mind, and mr Carton made his way to the outside of the bar.
vi: Mr. Lorry blushed as if he too were secretly pondering that matter, and so Carton walked slowly towards the outer edge of the dock.
tr: Mr. Lorry blushed because he had been weighing this in his mind for a while, and Mr. Carton proceeded towards the section where the defendant was.
es: Lorry blushed intensely, undoubtedly because he saw that his thoughts at that moment had been read, and Carton started walking towards the bar.

en: The way out of court lay in that direction, and Jerry followed him, all eyes, ears, and spikes.
vi: The exit from the court was also in that direction, and Jerry followed, wide-eyed, straining his ears, his hair standing on end.
tr: The exit of the court was in that direction, and Jerry, with his upright, attentive demeanor and stiff hair, followed him.
es: It goes without saying that Jeremiah Lapa followed him with all his eyes, with all his ears, and with all the spikes that adorned his scalp.

en: “mr Darnay!”
vi: − Mr. Darnay!
tr: "Mr. Darnay!"
es: —Mr. Darnay—called Carton.

en: The prisoner came forward directly.
vi: The prisoner stepped forward immediately.
tr: The defendant immediately stepped forward.
es: The prisoner stood up immediately.

en: “You will naturally be anxious to hear of the witness, Miss Manette.
vi: − I am sure you are eager to hear news about the witness, Miss Manette.
tr: "Naturally, you are worried about Miss Manette.
es: —It is natural that you wish to have news of the witness Miss Manette.

en: She will do very well.
vi: She will be fine.
tr: She will recover though.
es: She is better: the worst of her agitation has passed.

en: You have seen the worst of her agitation.”
vi: Earlier, you saw her being too emotional.
tr: You saw her at her worst."
es: She is better: the worst of her agitation has passed.

en: “I am deeply sorry to have been the cause of it.
vi: − I'm very sorry for causing this.
tr: "I'm very sorry for causing such a thing.
es: —With all my soul, I regret having been the cause of it.

en: Could you tell her so for me, with my fervent acknowledgments?”
vi: If you could convey this message to her, I would be very grateful.
tr: Also, please convey my thanks to him."
es: Would you be so kind as to convey it to her on my behalf?

en: “Yes, I could.
vi: − Alright.
tr: "Of course.
es: —I will do it, if you wish.

en: I will, if you ask it.”
vi: I will pass on the message, if you want.
tr: If you want, I can convey it."
es: —I will do it, if you wish.

en: mr Carton’s manner was so careless as to be almost insolent.
vi: Carton's attitude was so indifferent that it bordered on insolence.
tr: Mr. Carton had an almost indifferent attitude that bordered on arrogance.
es: Carton's attitude was so indifferent that it bordered on insolent.

en: He stood, half turned from the prisoner, lounging with his elbow against the bar.
vi: He stood there, lazily leaning his elbow on the rail, not bothering to look directly at the defendant.
tr: He stood there, turned sideways to the defendant, with his elbow resting on the bars of the defendant's box.
es: —I desire it very much, and I give you my most cordial thanks—replied the prisoner.

en: “I do ask it.
vi: − Please help me.
tr: "I am requesting from you.
es: —I desire it very much, and I give you my most cordial thanks—replied the prisoner.

en: Accept my cordial thanks.”
vi: I sincerely thank you.
tr: Accept my heartfelt thanks."
es: —I desire it very much, and I give you my most cordial thanks—replied the prisoner.

en: “What,” said Carton, still only half turned towards him, “do you expect, mr Darnay?”
vi: − Hey, Darnay, - Carton said without looking directly at the listener, - what sentence are you expecting?
tr: Carton, still turned sideways to the defendant, asked, "What kind of verdict do you think will come out, Mr. Darnay?"
es: —What are you waiting for, Mr. Darnay?—asked Carton, half turned away from his interlocutor.

en: “The worst.”
vi: − The heaviest sentence.
tr: "The worst.""
es: —The worst.

en: “It’s the wisest thing to expect, and the likeliest.
vi: − Waiting is the wisest choice, and that is the highest possibility.
tr: "This is the wisest and most likely thing to happen."
es: —You are doing well, since you expect what will probably happen.

en: But I think their withdrawing is in your favour.”
vi: But I think their retreating for a discussion is beneficial for you.
tr: "But the fact that they have gone inside to make a decision is in your favor.""
es: However, the new withdrawal of the Jury allows for some hope.

en: Loitering on the way out of court not being allowed, Jerry heard no more: but left them—so like each other in feature, so unlike each other in manner—standing side by side, both reflected in the glass above them.
vi: The court did not allow any further delay, Jerry walked out of the court hearing nothing more; despite the two people - identical in appearance but completely opposite in demeanor - standing next to each other, their reflections mirrored on the ceiling glass.
tr: It was hard to linger at the exit of the hall, so Jerry didn't hear any more. Leaving them side by side, alone with their reflections in the mirror above – although they looked very similar, their attitudes were completely different – he left.
es: Jeremías Lapa walked away without hearing more. There, beneath the large mirror that reflected both faces, remained the two men, so similar in features and so dissimilar in manners and attitude.

en: An hour and a half limped heavily away in the thief-and-rascal crowded passages below, even though assisted off with mutton pies and ale.
vi: An hour and a half dragged on slowly in the crowded corridors filled with ruffians below, regardless of how much beer and lamb pâté had been consumed.
tr: Even though he passed the time by eating a meat pastry and drinking beer, an hour and a half had been very difficult in the passages teeming with thieves and ruffians.
es: An hour and a half more passed slowly, heavily, eternally.

en: The hoarse messenger, uncomfortably seated on a form after taking that refection, had dropped into a doze, when a loud murmur and a rapid tide of people setting up the stairs that led to the court, carried him along with them.
vi: The hoarse-voiced messenger sat restlessly on a bench, and after a while of pondering, he suddenly fell asleep until the noise and the throng of people surging up the stairs leading to the court woke him up and swept him along.
tr: The hoarse-voiced messenger, who was dozing off on something not very comfortable after his meal, found himself caught in the loud buzz and flood of people climbing the stairs leading to the courtroom.
es: The bank messenger, after having his snack, had sat down and fallen asleep on a bench, when he was enveloped by the human tide that clamored as it once again invaded the Hall.

en: “Jerry! Jerry!” mr Lorry was already calling at the door when he got there.
vi: − Jerry! Jerry! - Mr. Lorry was standing at the doorway calling loudly as he just arrived.
tr: When he arrived at the court, Mr. Lorry was calling to him from the door, "Jerry! Jerry!"
es: —Jeremiah... Jeremiah!

en: “Here, sir!
vi: − Yes, I'm here!
tr: "I am here, sir!
es: —shouted Mr. Lorry, trying to get closer to the door.

en: It’s a fight to get back again.
vi: Chen struggled for a long time to get back.
tr: It was very difficult to come.
es: —Here I am, sir... but I have to elbow my way through if I want to get back in!

en: Here I am, sir!”
vi: I'm here, sir!
tr: But I came, sir!"
es: —Here I am, sir... but I have to elbow my way through if I want to get back in!

en: mr Lorry handed him a paper through the throng.
vi: Mr. Lorry reached through the crowd to hand him a piece of paper.
tr: Mr. Lorry handed a paper to the messenger in the crowd.
es: Lorry extended an arm and handed him a paper.

en: “Quick!
vi: − Hurry up!
tr: "Quick!
es: —Flying...!

en: Have you got it?”
vi: Did you get it? −
tr: Did you get it?"
es: Do you have it already?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, I got it.
tr: "Yes, sir!"
es: —Yes, sir.

en: Hastily written on the paper was the word “Acquitted.”
vi: Hastily written on the paper were the words "PARDONED".
tr: In the hastily written note, there were only two words "ACQUITTED."
es: On the paper, there was a single word written: "acquitted".

en: “If you had sent the message, ‘Recalled to Life,’ again,” muttered Jerry, as he turned, “I should have known what you meant, this time.”
vi: − If you text "Revive" like last time, - Jerry muttered as he turned away, - then this time I already understand what you mean.
tr: As Jerry was turning, he muttered to himself, "If you had sent a message saying 'Resurrected' again, I would understand what you were talking about this time."
es: —If this time you had written "Resurrected,"—murmured Lapa as he turned around—I would already know what all this means.

en: He had no opportunity of saying, or so much as thinking, anything else, until he was clear of the Old Bailey; for, the crowd came pouring out with a vehemence that nearly took him off his legs, and a loud buzz swept into the street as if the baffled blue-flies were dispersing in search of other carrion.
vi: Jerry had no chance to say or even think anything else until he was out of the Old Bailey Courthouse; because he had to run frantically to avoid being knocked over by the crowd pouring out, and the buzzing noise flooding the street was like a swarm of disappointed bluebottles dispersing to find another decaying corpse.
tr: He had no chance to speak, think, or do anything else until he got away from the Old Bailey Court; the crowd was flowing out with such excitement that Jerry's knees buckled, and the bewildered horseflies scattered around with an intense buzz, as if hoping to find another carcass.
es: It was the only thing he could say, or think, or do, until he found himself outside the Old Bailey, as the crowds poured out like an overflowing torrent, sweeping away and dragging along everything in their path.

vi: 4. Congratulations
tr: He had no chance to speak, think, or do anything else until he got away from the Old Bailey Court; the crowd was flowing out with such excitement that Jerry's knees buckled, and the bewildered horseflies scattered around with an intense buzz, as if hoping to find another carcass.
es: The murmurs were like the loud buzzing of bluebottle flies that disperse in disappointment upon finding themselves deprived of the rotten scraps they expected to find.

en: Original
vi: 4. Congratulations
tr: He had no chance to speak, think, or do anything else until he got away from the Old Bailey Court; the crowd was flowing out with such excitement that Jerry's knees buckled, and the bewildered horseflies scattered around with an intense buzz, as if hoping to find another carcass.
es: The murmurs were like the loud buzzing of bluebottle flies that disperse in disappointment upon finding themselves deprived of the rotten scraps they expected to find.

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: 4. Congratulations
tr: IV
es: IV.

en: Congratulatory
vi: 4. Congratulations
tr: Congratulations
es: CONGRATULATIONS

en: From the dimly-lighted passages of the court, the last sediment of the human stew that had been boiling there all day, was straining off, when Doctor Manette, Lucie Manette, his daughter, mr Lorry, the solicitor for the defence, and its counsel, mr Stryver, stood gathered round mr Charles Darnay—just released—congratulating him on his escape from death.
vi: Flowing out of the dimly lit corridors of the court, the final remnants of the human stew that had been boiling all day were now gradually drying up as Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and the defense attorney Stryver stood around Charles Darnay - just released, congratulating him on escaping death.
tr: As the last people from the crowd that had been bustling all day streamed out of the courtroom, which was dimly lit, Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and the defense attorney and solicitor Mr. Stryver gathered around Mr. Charles Darnay – the person who had just been acquitted – congratulating him for escaping death.
es: The last remnants of the human stew that had simmered all day in the courtroom were trickling through the dirty and gloomy corridors of the courthouse building, when Doctor Manette, Lucia, his daughter, Mr. Lorry, the defense lawyer, and the defense attorney formed a group around Charles Darnay, who had been released moments before, congratulating and celebrating him for having almost miraculously escaped death.

en: It would have been difficult by a far brighter light, to recognise in Doctor Manette, intellectual of face and upright of bearing, the shoemaker of the garret in Paris.
vi: Under a stronger light source, it might be difficult to recognize Dr. Manette with his intelligent face and upright posture as the shoemaker in the attic in Paris.
tr: It was difficult to connect the sharp-faced and upright Doctor Manette with the shoemaker in the attic in Paris, even in a brighter light.
es: The light was scarce, but even in the brightness of a summer sun, it would have been very difficult to recognize in the serene and intelligent face and upright body of the doctor the cobbler from the garret in Paris.

en: Yet, no one could have looked at him twice, without looking again: even though the opportunity of observation had not extended to the mournful cadence of his low grave voice, and to the abstraction that overclouded him fitfully, without any apparent reason.
vi: However, anyone who has looked at him closely once cannot help but look again; even if they do not have the chance to hear the melancholy tone in his gentle, solemn voice, or see the occasional absent-minded expression that inexplicably appears on his face.
tr: But no one could look at his face a second time; the opportunity to observe him did not extend to hearing the mournful harmony of his low and gloomy voice or noticing the occasional absent-mindedness that settled over him like a cloud for no reason.
es: Nevertheless, it was impossible to see him once without feeling an irresistible itch to examine him again, even if the observer had not had the chance to hear the gloomy rhythm of his deep voice, nor noticed the kind of cloud that overshadowed his countenance for no apparent reason.

en: While one external cause, and that a reference to his long lingering agony, would always—as on the trial—evoke this condition from the depths of his soul, it was also in its nature to arise of itself, and to draw a gloom over him, as incomprehensible to those unacquainted with his story as if they had seen the shadow of the actual Bastille thrown upon him by a summer sun, when the substance was three hundred miles away.
vi: Just like during the trial, any external trigger that reminds him of the years of prolonged suffering will cause that dark emotion to rise from the depths of his soul, but that dazed expression also often reveals itself, startling those who do not know Dr. Manette's past; as if they are seeing the actual Bastille casting its dark shadow on his face under the summer sun while in reality, that place of imprisonment is three hundred miles away from here.
tr: There was always a completely different reason deep within his soul that evoked this feeling – as it was during the trial – something related to his long-standing sorrowful state, but sometimes this feeling arose on its own, and then a sadness that those who did not know his story could never understand enveloped him, as if the shadow of the Bastille, three hundred kilometers away, fell upon him even in that summer sun.
es: And it was because he did not need external causes to evoke in his soul, as had happened in the Courtroom during the hearing, painful echoes of his past agonies; these arose spontaneously, and when they did, they enveloped him in something like a funeral veil that could not be seen by those who were unaware of his sad story.

en: Only his daughter had the power of charming this black brooding from his mind.
vi: Only the daughter had the power to dispel the dark clouds from her father's mind.
tr: The only person who could disperse these dark clouds in his mind was his daughter.
es: Only his daughter managed to drive away the dark memories that persistently haunted his mind.

en: She was the golden thread that united him to a Past beyond his misery, and to a Present beyond his misery: and the sound of her voice, the light of her face, the touch of her hand, had a strong beneficial influence with him almost always.
vi: She was the golden thread connecting him to the past before the calamity, and to the present after escaping captivity; her voice, her radiant face, her comforting hand, always had the supreme power to help him find joy in life.
tr: She was the golden thread that connected him to a Past beyond his suffering and a Present beyond this suffering; the tone of her voice, the light of her face, the touch of her hand always had a wonderful effect on her father.
es: Lucía was the golden thread that connected him to a past before his miseries and to a present after his sorrows. The sweet music of her voice, the joy reflected in her pretty face, the touch of her hand, almost always had a decisive beneficial influence on him, and I say almost always, because there had been occasions, although not many, when the girl's power had crashed against his sadness.

en: Not absolutely always, for she could recall some occasions on which her power had failed; but they were few and slight, and she believed them over.
vi: But it wasn't always so, for she also remembered times when her power had failed; however, those instances were rare and not very serious, so she thought they would not happen again.
tr: Actually, not always, because there were moments when even his daughter's power was not enough; but these were not too many, moreover, his daughter now believed that these had come to an end.
es: Lucía harbored the sweet hope that those cases would not be repeated.

en: mr Darnay had kissed her hand fervently and gratefully, and had turned to mr Stryver, whom he warmly thanked.
vi: Darnay warmly and appreciatively kissed the girl's hand, then turned to barrister Stryver and thanked him profusely.
tr: After Mr. Darnay kissed Miss Manette's hand with great enthusiasm and gratitude, he turned to Mr. Stryver and thanked him sincerely.
es: Darnay had savored the pleasure of kissing the young woman's hand, and after expressing his gratitude with fervent phrases, he turned to his defender, Mr. Stryver, to whom he warmly gave thanks.

en: mr Stryver, a man of little more than thirty, but looking twenty years older than he was, stout, loud, red, bluff, and free from any drawback of delicacy, had a pushing way of shouldering himself (morally and physically) into companies and conversations, that argued well for his shouldering his way up in life.
vi: Stryver, though just over thirty, looked as old as fifty, stout, loud, ruddy, straightforward, and completely lacking in tact; he often barged (both mentally and physically) into groups of people and conversations - this clearly showed the way he scrambled to get ahead in life.
tr: Although he was a little over thirty years old, Mr. Stryver, who looked twenty years younger, was a burly, loud-voiced, red-faced, straightforward, and not very courteous man, and the way he forcefully (both mentally and physically) threw himself into various communities and conversations was a sign of how he shouldered life.
es: Stryver, a man who was barely thirty years old, although he looked fifty, robust, stout, red-faced, boastful, and impervious to all kinds of delicate impulses, possessed the secret of adapting himself, morally and physically, to all kinds of companies and conversations, and it was to be supposed that just as he adapted to companies and conversations, he knew how to adapt to the thousand and one trivialities related to life.

en: He still had his wig and gown on, and he said, squaring himself at his late client to that degree that he squeezed the innocent mr Lorry clean out of the group: “I am glad to have brought you off with honour, mr Darnay.
vi: Still wearing his wig and barrister's gown, Stryver spoke while stepping in front of his new client to the point of pushing Mr. Lorry out of the group: − I am very pleased to have the honor of successfully defending you, Mr. Darnay.
tr: He still had his wig and gown on, and he approached his client in such a way that he ended up pushing poor Mr. Lorry aside. "I am very happy to have saved your honor, Mr. Darnay.
es: He was still wearing the robe and the wig. When he went to respond to his client, he spun on his heels in a way that excluded the innocent Mr. Lorry from the group, and said: —I infinitely celebrate having gotten you out of the ordeal with honor, Mr. Darnay.

en: It was an infamous prosecution, grossly infamous; but not the less likely to succeed on that account.”
vi: This was a vile case; extremely vile; but it's not just about wanting to convict.
tr: It was a tough case, really tough; but your chances of acquittal were not nonexistent."
es: You have been the victim of an infamous persecution, brutally infamous, but one that could very well have had the outcome your enemies sought.

en: “You have laid me under an obligation to you for life—in two senses,” said his late client, taking his hand.
vi: − I am indebted to you for saving my life forever, - the client said while shaking the lawyer's hand.
tr: Holding Mr. Stryver's hand, "I owe you my life – for two reasons," he said.
es: "The obligations I have contracted with you will never expire," replied the young man, warmly shaking the lawyer's hand.

en: “I have done my best for you, mr Darnay; and my best is as good as another man’s, I believe.”
vi: − I did my best, Mr. Darnay; and I think everyone should do their best like I did.
tr: "I did my best for you, Mr. Darnay, but surely someone else would have tried to do the same.""
es: —I have done for you as much as I could, Mr. Darnay, and I have the presumption to believe that I can do as much as any other man could.

en: It clearly being incumbent on some one to say, “Much better,” mr Lorry said it; perhaps not quite disinterestedly, but with the interested object of squeezing himself back again.
vi: To say that would force someone to praise "No one can compare," it was Mr. Lorry who said that, not entirely disinterestedly but with the intention of wanting to get back into the group.
tr: At this point, it was clear that someone needed to say, "But you did it much better!" and it was Mr. Lorry who said it; it couldn't be said that he was uninterested, but his main goal was to approach the group.
es: The last words required a mandatory response, which any of those in the group could and should give. Mr. Lorry gave it, probably out of interest, that is, to be readmitted into the group. —More, much more than any other man—he said.

en: “You think so?” said mr Stryver.
vi: − Do you think so? - Stryver said.
tr: "Is that what you think?" said Mr. Stryver.
es: —Do you really think so?—asked Stryver.—Absolutely.

en: “Well!
vi: - Well!
tr: "Well, you were here all day, you must have understood.
es: —Do you really think so?—asked Stryver.—Absolutely.

en: you have been present all day, and you ought to know.
vi: You've been here all day today, you must know well.
tr: "Well, you were here all day, you must have understood.
es: You have witnessed the entire trial, and you have reasons to know what you are saying.

en: You are a man of business, too.”
vi: You are also a man of work.
tr: After all, you are a businessman too."
es: Besides, you are a businessman.

en: “And as such,” quoth mr Lorry, whom the counsel learned in the law had now shouldered back into the group, just as he had previously shouldered him out of it—“as such I will appeal to Doctor Manette, to break up this conference and order us all to our homes.
vi: − That's right, - Mr. Lorry, who had now been nudged into the group by the lawyer in the same way he had been nudged out earlier, - and because that's right, I request Dr. Manette to conclude this consultation and for all of us to leave.
tr: "I say," said Mr. Lorry, whom the lawyer first excluded and then included in the group, "I say, it would be best if Dr. Manette ended this conversation and we all went home.
es: —And in that capacity—replied Lorry, whom the lawyer had brought into the group in the same manner as he had previously excluded him—in my capacity as such, I request Dr. Manette to bring this conference to an end, so that we may each retire to our respective homes.

en: Miss Lucie looks ill, mr Darnay has had a terrible day, we are worn out.”
vi: Miss Lucie doesn't look well, Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day, and we are all exhausted.
tr: Miss Lucie doesn't look well, Mr. Darnay has had a very difficult day, and we are all tired."
es: Miss Lucie is not feeling well, Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day, and we are all exhausted.

en: “Speak for yourself, mr Lorry,” said Stryver; “I have a night’s work to do yet.
vi: − Please don't speak for others, Mr. Lorry, - Stryver said, - I have work to do tonight.
tr: "Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry," said Stryver; "I have a lot more work to do.
es: —Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry, speak for yourself—said the lawyer.

en: Speak for yourself.”
vi: Please don't speak for others.
tr: Speak for yourself."
es: —I have a night of continuous work ahead of me.

en: “I speak for myself,” answered mr Lorry, “and for mr Darnay, and for Miss Lucie, and—Miss Lucie, do you not think I may speak for us all?”
vi: − I speak for myself, - Mr. Lorry replied, - and for you, Darnay, and for Miss Lucie, and... Miss Lucie, do you think I can speak on behalf of all of us?
tr: "Speaking for myself," said Mr. Lorry, "and even for Mr. Darnay and Miss Lucie, well, I can speak for all of us, can't I, Miss Lucie?"
es: —I speak for myself—replied Lorry—and for Mr. Darnay, and for Miss Lucie and...

en: He asked her the question pointedly, and with a glance at her father.
vi: - He asked her directly, his eyes glancing at her father again.
tr: He fixed his eyes on the young girl, while also glancing at her father.
es: Don't you think, Miss Lucie, that I can speak for all of us?—he asked, addressing the young woman, but looking at the same time at her father.

en: His face had become frozen, as it were, in a very curious look at Darnay: an intent look, deepening into a frown of dislike and distrust, not even unmixed with fear.
vi: The face of Doctor Manette at that moment had frozen into a very strange look directed at Darnay - a focused look, under furrowed brows that clearly revealed aversion and suspicion, with a hint of fear.
tr: Adam, however, was frozen, looking at Darnay with curious eyes; it was a determined look, with eyebrows furrowed in hatred and distrust, but devoid of fear.
es: The old man's face took on an indefinable expression as he directed an intense look at Darnay.

en: With this strange expression on him his thoughts had wandered away.
vi: With that peculiar expression, his mind had wandered elsewhere.
tr: Judging by the expression on his face, a lot of things were going through his mind.
es: Deep wrinkles appeared on the former's forehead, his lips tightened, and little by little his gaze expressed repugnance, suspicion, and fear.

en: “My father,” said Lucie, softly laying her hand on his.
vi: − Father, - Lucie said as she gently took her father's hand.
tr: Lucie gently placed her hand on her father's hand and said, "Father."
es: —My father! —she whispered in his ear, while squeezing his hand.

en: He slowly shook the shadow off, and turned to her.
vi: The gloomy expression gradually faded, and the father turned to look at his daughter.
tr: Adam slowly turned to his daughter, dispelling the shadows in his mind.
es: The old man, whose face gradually lit up, turned towards his daughter.

en: “Shall we go home, my father?”
vi: − Shall we go home, Father?
tr: "Shall we go home, daddy?""
es: —Shall we go home, my father?—replied the girl.

en: With a long breath, he answered “Yes.”
vi: After a sigh, there was a "Yes".
tr: Taking a deep breath, "Yes," said the man.
es: The doctor let out a very deep and very prolonged sigh, and replied: —Yes.

en: The friends of the acquitted prisoner had dispersed, under the impression—which he himself had originated—that he would not be released that night.
vi: The friends of the acquitted convict had long since dispersed, with the thought - originating from the man himself - that he would not be pardoned tonight.
tr: The friends of the acquitted defendant had dispersed early that night because they thought he would not be released – this impression had been created by the defendant himself.
es: The prisoner's friends, whom he had made believe that he would not be released that night, had already dispersed.

en: The lights were nearly all extinguished in the passages, the iron gates were being closed with a jar and a rattle, and the dismal place was deserted until to-morrow morning’s interest of gallows, pillory, whipping-post, and branding-iron, should repeople it.
vi: The lights in the corridors had almost all been extinguished, the iron gates were clanging shut, and this dreadful theater would remain desolate until the next morning when the delight of the gallows, the stocks, the whipping post, and the branding iron would draw the audience again.
tr: Almost all the lamps in the corridors were out, the iron doors were closing with a thousand creaks and clatters, and this gloomy place would remain empty until the next morning, until people filled it with gallows, collars, whipping areas, and branding irons.
es: Almost all the lights that illuminated the narrow corridors of the sinister building, which the next morning would be filled again with people eager for emotions, had been turned off.

en: Walking between her father and mr Darnay, Lucie Manette passed into the open air.
vi: Walking between her father and Darnay, Lucie Manette stepped out onto the street.
tr: Lucie Manette walked outside between her father and Mr. Darnay.
es: The defense attorney was the first to leave to go change clothes, and Lucie Manette called a carriage, said goodbye to Mr. Lorry and Darnay, and had herself driven home, accompanying her father.

en: A hackney-coach was called, and the father and daughter departed in it.
vi: A two-horse carriage was called, and the father and daughter got in and drove away.
tr: A carriage had been called, and the father and daughter got into it.
es: The defense attorney was the first to leave to go change clothes, and Lucie Manette called a carriage, said goodbye to Mr. Lorry and Darnay, and had herself driven home, accompanying her father.

en: mr Stryver had left them in the passages, to shoulder his way back to the robing-room.
vi: Stryver had just left everyone in the hallway to barge back into the dressing room.
tr: Mr. Stryver had left their side as he was going to the cup room.
es: The defense attorney was the first to leave to go change clothes, and Lucie Manette called a carriage, said goodbye to Mr. Lorry and Darnay, and had herself driven home, accompanying her father.

en: Another person, who had not joined the group, or interchanged a word with any one of them, but who had been leaning against the wall where its shadow was darkest, had silently strolled out after the rest, and had looked on until the coach drove away.
vi: Another person, who had neither joined the group nor spoken a word to anyone in it, but had been leaning against the wall in the darkest corner, now strolled out and stood watching until the carriage was out of sight.
tr: Another person, who had not joined the group and had not spoken a single word with them but leaned against the darkest corner of the wall, quietly straightened up after resting there for a while and watched until the carriage set off.
es: Another person, who had not been part of the group nor exchanged a word with any of its members, detached themselves from the wall against which they had been leaning and, as soon as the carriage was out of sight, silently approached Lorry and Darnay like a shadow, who had remained talking on the sidewalk.

en: He now stepped up to where mr Lorry and mr Darnay stood upon the pavement.
vi: He then stepped onto the sidewalk where Mr. Lorry and Darnay were standing.
tr: Then he went over to Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay, who were standing on the sidewalk.
es: —Hello, Mr. Lorry!

en: “So, mr Lorry!
vi: − Ah, Mr. Lorry!
tr: "Ah Mr. Lorry!
es: —he said.

en: Men of business may speak to mr Darnay now?”
vi: The man of business is now allowed to speak openly with Mr. Darnay, isn't he?
tr: So, as a businessman, you can now speak with Mr. Darnay.""
es: —It seems that business men now dare to speak with Darnay, eh?

en: Nobody had made any acknowledgment of mr Carton’s part in the day’s proceedings; nobody had known of it.
vi: No one mentioned Carton's role in today's trial; no one paid any attention to him.
tr: No one had thanked Mr. Carton for what he did in court that day; there was no one who appreciated its value.
es: —It seems that business men now dare to speak with Darnay, eh?

en: He was unrobed, and was none the better for it in appearance.
vi: Carton had taken off his barrister's gown and still looked as disheveled as before.
tr: He had taken off his robe, but he did not look any better than he did with it on.
es: What conflicts business causes!

en: “If you knew what a conflict goes on in the business mind, when the business mind is divided between good-natured impulse and business appearances, you would be amused, mr Darnay.”
vi: − Mr. Darnay, if only you knew what was wrestling in the mind of a person who only knows how to work, when that work-focused mind is divided between the urge of kindness and the outward professional demeanor, you would find it very interesting.
tr: "If you knew what contradictions exist in the mind of a businessman torn between goodwill and a sense of duty, you would be very amused, Mr. Darnay."
es: You would laugh, Darnay, if you knew the struggles that business men have to endure between their natural impulses and the demands of their position.

en: mr Lorry reddened, and said, warmly, “You have mentioned that before, sir.
vi: Mr. Lorry blushed and said passionately, "You mentioned that earlier, sir."
tr: Mr. Lorry blushed and said in an excited voice, "You have said this before, sir."
es: —You made that same remark before, Mr. Carton—replied Lorry, blushing to the whites of his eyes.

en: We men of business, who serve a House, are not our own masters.
vi: People of business like us, those who serve a company, cannot think only of ourselves.
tr: We, who work within a company, do not do anything for ourselves.
es: —We, the businessmen, those who serve a house, are not masters of ourselves.

en: We have to think of the House more than ourselves.”
vi: We must think of the company more than ourselves.
tr: We think of the company more than ourselves.
es: More than in ourselves, we have to think about the house.

en: “I know, I know,” rejoined mr Carton, carelessly.
vi: − I know, I know, - Carton replied nonchalantly.
tr: "I know, I know," said Mr. Carton indifferently.
es: —I know, I know, Mr. Lorry!

en: “Don’t be nettled, mr Lorry.
vi: - Don't be upset, Mr. Lorry, you are as wonderful as everyone else, I'm sure of it; I even dare to say that no one is like you.
tr: "Don't get upset, Mr. Lorry.
es: —replied Carton carelessly.—I would be sorry if you were upset.

en: You are as good as another, I have no doubt: better, I dare say.”
vi: - Don't be upset, Mr. Lorry, you are as wonderful as everyone else, I'm sure of it; I even dare to say that no one is like you.
tr: I'm sure you are as good as the others; even better.""
es: I know that you are not worse than the others, and I would even dare to say that you are much better.

en: “And indeed, sir,” pursued mr Lorry, not minding him, “I really don’t know what you have to do with the matter.
vi: − That's right, sir, - Mr. Lorry continued, not paying attention to Carton's sarcasm.
tr: Without paying much attention to what Carton said, Mr. Lorry continued, "As a matter of fact, I don't know why you are prolonging this issue."
es: —To tell the truth, sir, I fail to understand your interference.

en: If you’ll excuse me, as very much your elder, for saying so, I really don’t know that it is your business.”
vi: - Honestly, I don't know what your involvement in this matter is. Please forgive me, an older man than you, for saying this, but I truly don't know what your role in this matter is.
tr: "Sorry, I'm saying this because I'm older than you, but I don't understand why you are meddling so much in this matter.""
es: Forgive me if, taking advantage of my age, I speak to you with perhaps excessive frankness, but I don't see that you have anything to do with our affairs.

en: “Business!
vi: − Work!
tr: "Work?
es: —Matters!

en: Bless you, I have no business,” said mr Carton.
vi: Good Lord, I have no work, - Carton said.
tr: Honestly, I don't understand any job," said Mr. Carton.
es: Good heavens, sir! I have no matters.

en: “It is a pity you have not, sir.”
vi: − It's a pity for you, sir.
tr: "It's a pity, sir."
es: —It's a shame that you don't have them.

en: “I think so, too.”
vi: − I think so too.
tr: "I think so too."
es: —Agreed.

en: “If you had,” pursued mr Lorry, “perhaps you would attend to it.”
vi: − If you have any work, - Mr. Lorry continued, - perhaps you will devote yourself to it.
tr: "If you had understood," said Mr. Lorry, "you would be busy with him."
es: —Because if I had them, I would pay them some attention.

en: “Lord love you, no!—I shouldn’t,” said mr Carton.
vi: − God bless you, oh no... I'm not like that! - Carton said. − Hey, you!
tr: "Oh no, not at all! –Still, I wouldn't have," said Mr. Carton.
es: —No, my friend, no! Rest assured that I would not lend them any! —All right, sir!

en: “Well, sir!” cried mr Lorry, thoroughly heated by his indifference, “business is a very good thing, and a very respectable thing.
vi: - Mr. Lorry shouted, Carton's indifference made him angry. - Working is very good, very respectable.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who was quite angered by the man's indifference, said, "Look here, sir, doing business is a good thing, a respectable thing.
es: —exclaimed Lorry, filled with indignation at the indifference of his interlocutor.

en: And, sir, if business imposes its restraints and its silences and impediments, mr Darnay as a young gentleman of generosity knows how to make allowance for that circumstance.
vi: And let me tell you, if work requires us to restrain ourselves, to be silent, to accept, then this kind Mr. Darnay here understands those constraints very well.
tr: If business brings some restrictions, silences, and obstacles, the noble-hearted young Mr. Darnay knows how to deal with it.
es: —Say what you will, it is very good and very respectable to have business, and if on certain occasions business imposes silence, restrictions, and impediments, those who, like Mr. Darnay, are generous gentlemen understand it... Mr. Darnay... good night.

en: mr Darnay, good night, God bless you, sir!
vi: Goodbye Mr. Darnay, God bless you!
tr: Good night, Mr. Darnay, may God protect you!
es: —Say what you will, it is very good and very respectable to have business, and if on certain occasions business imposes silence, restrictions, and impediments, those who, like Mr. Darnay, are generous gentlemen understand it... Mr. Darnay... good night.

en: I hope you have been this day preserved for a prosperous and happy life.
vi: I hope from today you will have a successful and happy life ahead of you.
tr: I hope your life will henceforth be filled with prosperity and happiness.
es: I congratulate you with all the effusion of my soul and wish you a prosperous and happy life... Coachman!

en: —Chair there!”
vi: The carriage is here!
tr: There is a cab over there!"
es: I congratulate you with all the effusion of my soul and wish you a prosperous and happy life... Coachman!

en: Perhaps a little angry with himself, as well as with the barrister, mr Lorry bustled into the chair, and was carried off to Tellson’s.
vi: Perhaps a bit angry with himself as well as with that lawyer, Mr. Lorry hastily got into the single-horse carriage and headed to Tellson's Bank.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who was a bit angry not only at the lawyer but also at himself, hurriedly got into the cab and went to Tellson's.
es: A little uncomfortable with himself, and certainly more with his interlocutor, Mr. Lorry stormed into the carriage and had himself driven to Tellson's Bank.

en: Carton, who smelt of port wine, and did not appear to be quite sober, laughed then, and turned to Darnay:
vi: Still reeking of port wine and seemingly not fully sober, Carton then laughed and turned to Darnay: −
tr: Carton, who smelled of port wine and did not look very sober, laughed and turned to Darnay:
es: Carton, who smelled of wine and whose strong suit, judging by appearances, was not sobriety, burst into laughter and turned to Darnay.

en: “This is a strange chance that throws you and me together.
vi: It is indeed strange that you and I happen to meet.
tr: "This is a strange coincidence that brought you and me together.
es: —Strange whims chance has, Mr. Darnay! —exclaimed Carton.

en: This must be a strange night to you, standing alone here with your counterpart on these street stones?”
vi: Do you not find it strange to stand here alone tonight with someone who looks exactly like you on these cobblestones?
tr: It must be interesting for you to stand here tonight, on these cobblestones, with your colleague."
es: —Could you have supposed that tonight you would be here, treading the street stones, in the company of your alter ego?

en: “I hardly seem yet,” returned Charles Darnay, “to belong to this world again.”
vi: − I seem to no longer feel that I belong to this world, Charles Darnay replied.
tr: "I don't quite feel like I belong to this world again," replied Charles Darnay.
es: —How could I have supposed it, if even the fact of belonging to this world seems like a dream to me?—replied Darnay.

en: “I don’t wonder at it; it’s not so long since you were pretty far advanced on your way to another.
vi: − I'm not surprised; just recently you almost stepped into the afterlife.
tr: "I'm not surprised at all; there's a world of difference between how you were this morning and how you are now.
es: —It does not surprise me, after how close it was to the other one.

en: You speak faintly.”
vi: He spoke as if he were out of breath and about to faint.
tr: You don't have the energy to talk though."
es: I notice a certain weakness in your voice, Mr. Darnay.

en: “I begin to think I am faint.”
vi: − I think I'm about to faint.
tr: "I actually don't have the energy for anything."
es: —It's just that I'm beginning to believe that I feel weak, Mr. Carton.

en: “Then why the devil don’t you dine?
vi: − So why don't you eat something, for heaven's sake?
tr: "Why haven't you eaten anything yet?
es: —Why don't you eat, then?

en: I dined, myself, while those numskulls were deliberating which world you should belong to—this, or some other.
vi: I already ate, I ate while those idiots were debating which world you belong to... this side or that side.
tr: While those blockheads were deliberating on which side –this world or the next– they would keep you, I had eaten something.
es: I already ate, while those drones were agreeing on the world in which you would live.

en: Let me show you the nearest tavern to dine well at.”
vi: Let me show you the nearest pub with good food.
tr: Come, let me show you a good place nearby where you can eat."
es: I'm going to accompany you to the nearest tavern where you can eat whatever you like.

en: Drawing his arm through his own, he took him down Ludgate-hill to Fleet-street, and so, up a covered way, into a tavern.
vi: Linking arms with Darnay, the lawyer led him down Ludgate Hill to Fleet Street and from there, through a covered passageway, into a tavern.
tr: Carton pulled Darnay by the arm and they proceeded together from Ludgate Hill towards Fleet Street, then passed through a covered area and arrived at an inn.
es: Passing without further ceremonies his arm through Darnay's, Carton started walking towards Fleet Street, soon ending up in a tavern.

en: Here, they were shown into a little room, where Charles Darnay was soon recruiting his strength with a good plain dinner and good wine: while Carton sat opposite to him at the same table, with his separate bottle of port before him, and his fully half-insolent manner upon him.
vi: Upon arrival, they were shown into a small room where Charles Darnay immediately regained his strength with a simple yet delicious dinner accompanied by rich wine; meanwhile, Carton sat at the same table opposite him, with his own bottle of port in front of him, and his insolent demeanor became evident once more.
tr: Here, they were taken to a small room where Charles Darnay could have a nice meal and a good wine to quickly regain his strength; meanwhile, Carton sat at the same table, directly across from Darnay with a separate bottle of port wine in front of him, watching him with a slightly insolent manner.
es: The attendant accompanied the newcomers to a reserved little room, where Darnay regained his strength. Carton, seated at the same table across from Darnay, had a bottle of wine served to him.

en: “Do you feel, yet, that you belong to this terrestrial scheme again, mr Darnay?”
vi: − Do you now feel that you belong to this earthly realm again, Mr. Darnay?
tr: "Will you be able to feel like you belong to this mortal order again, Mr. Darnay?"
es: —Are you convincing yourself that you still belong to this earthly world, Darnay?—asked Carton.

en: “I am frightfully confused regarding time and place; but I am so far mended as to feel that.”
vi: − Still disoriented about time and place; but I have recovered enough to perceive them.
tr: "My concept of time and space has been terribly disrupted; but at least I pulled myself together enough to understand this.""
es: —I can barely grasp the time and place, but I confess that I have almost been convinced of what you say.

en: “It must be an immense satisfaction!”
vi: − That feeling must be wonderful!
tr: "This must be an immense happiness.""
es: —And he must have convinced himself of it with immense satisfaction!

en: He said it bitterly, and filled up his glass again: which was a large one.
vi: - Carton said bitterly, then poured another full glass of wine; a large glass. -
tr: His voice had hardened as he said this, and he refilled his glass; the glass was large.
es: —exclaimed Carton with a certain tone of bitterness, filling the glass again, which was certainly one of the largest.—

en: “As to me, the greatest desire I have, is to forget that I belong to it.
vi: As for me, my greatest desire is to forget that I belong to this world.
tr: "My greatest desire is to forget that I belong to this order.
es: As for me, I can say that my greatest desire would be to forget that I am a part of him.

en: It has no good in it for me—except wine like this—nor I for it.
vi: It is of no use to me... except for fine wine like this... and I am of no use to it either.
tr: Neither does it do me any good –except for good wines like this– nor do I do it any good.
es: Neither does the world have anything good for me... except for wine, nor do I have anything good for the world.

en: So we are not much alike in that particular.
vi: In this respect, you and I are nothing alike.
tr: In this respect, we do not resemble each other much.
es: In this particular matter, we are quite alike, we resemble each other quite a bit...

en: Indeed, I begin to think we are not much alike in any particular, you and I.”
vi: In fact, I started to think that we don't have anything in common at all, you and I.
tr: In fact, I have started to think that we do not resemble each other in any respect."
es: Of course, I am starting to believe that you and I also resemble each other in everything, don't we?

en: Confused by the emotion of the day, and feeling his being there with this Double of coarse deportment, to be like a dream, Charles Darnay was at a loss how to answer; finally, answered not at all.
vi: Confused by the myriad of emotions of the day and feeling as if he were dreaming when faced with the rude individual who shared his appearance, Charles Darnay did not know how to respond; and in the end, he said nothing.
tr: Charles Darnay, who was confused by the excitement of the day and saw his presence there with this rough-mannered twin as no different from a dream, did not know what to answer; in the end, he said nothing.
es: Carlos Darnay, still under the influence of the day's emotions, took quite a while to respond, simply because he didn't know what answer to give to his interlocutor's extravagant words. When he did, he showed perfect agreement.

en: “Now your dinner is done,” Carton presently said, “why don’t you call a health, mr Darnay; why don’t you give your toast?”
vi: A moment later, Carton continued: − Now that you have finished your dinner, why not raise a glass to your health, Mr. Darnay? Why don't you lift your glass and drink to a toast? −
