tr: Carton then said, "Well, now that your meal is finished, why don't you toast to his health, Mr. Darnay; come on, raise a glass to his honor.""
es: —Now that you have honored the meal, Mr. Darnay, why don't you raise a glass?

en: “What health?
vi: To what health?
tr: "To whose health?" "To whose honor?"
es: Why don't you make a toast?

en: What toast?”
vi: To what toast? −
tr: "To whose health?" "To whose honor?"
es: —Raise the glass? In honor of whom?

en: “Why, it’s on the tip of your tongue.
vi: Oh, you know but just don't want to say.
tr: "Come on, the name is on the tip of your tongue.
es: —In honor and for the health of the person whose name you have on the tip of your tongue.

en: It ought to be, it must be, I’ll swear it’s there.”
vi: It must be so, it definitely must be so, I swear to you.
tr: It must be, I'm sure it's there."
es: You must have it, you do have it, I would swear that I am not mistaken.

en: “Miss Manette, then!”
vi: − Congratulations to Miss Manette!
tr: "Miss Manette is in that condition!"
es: —I toast, then, to Miss Manette!

en: “Miss Manette, then!”
vi: − Congratulations to Miss Manette!
tr: "Miss Manette, is that you?"
es: —To the health of Miss Manette!

en: Looking his companion full in the face while he drank the toast, Carton flung his glass over his shoulder against the wall, where it shivered to pieces; then, rang the bell, and ordered in another.
vi: Looking straight at Darnay who was drinking the toast, Carton threw his own glass over his shoulder, the glass shattered against the wall, and then he rang the bell to have another glass brought in.
tr: As Darnay drank his wine, Carton, who was watching him intently, threw his glass over his shoulder against the wall, and the glass shattered into pieces; then he rang the bell to ask for more wine.
es: Fixing an insolent gaze on Darnay while downing the contents of his glass, Carton smashed his against the wall after drinking, where it shattered into pieces. He then rang the bell and asked for another.

en: “That’s a fair young lady to hand to a coach in the dark, mr Darnay!” he said, filling his new goblet.
vi: − Indeed, a beautiful lady for me to escort to the carriage at night, Mr. Darnay! - Carton said while filling a new glass.
tr: While filling the cup, "Miss Darnay is such a pleasant young lady that you would want to help her into her car in the dark!"
es: —She is a charming girl, in whose company it would be delightful to take a carriage ride, wouldn't it?—he asked, filling the glass that had just been brought to him with wine.

en: A slight frown and a laconic “Yes,” were the answer.
vi: A brief frown and a curt "Yes!"
tr: Darnay, slightly furrowing his brows, responded briefly and concisely; "Yes."
es: —Yes—answered Darnay curtly, with a slight frown.

en: “That’s a fair young lady to be pitied by and wept for by!
vi: − Truly a beautiful lady to have her shed tears of pity for me!
tr: "For such a lovely lady to pity a person and shed tears for him!
es: —Worthy of compassion and of having true madness done for her.

en: How does it feel?
vi: How does it feel?
tr: What kind of feeling is this, I wonder?
es: How is she feeling?

en: Is it worth being tried for one’s life, to be the object of such sympathy and compassion, mr Darnay?”
vi: Is it worth risking your life in court to be the object of such compassion and sympathy, Mr. Darnay?
tr: Was it worth being judged to receive such compassion and interest, Mr. Darnay?"
es: Indeed, it is worth the risk of being condemned to death in exchange for becoming the object of her sympathies and compassion: what do you say, Darnay?

en: Again Darnay answered not a word.
vi: Darnay still did not respond.
tr: Darnay did not respond to the gesture.
es: The questioned person remained silent.

en: “She was mightily pleased to have your message, when I gave it her.
vi: − The young lady was very pleased when she received your message that I delivered.
tr: "When I delivered your message, he was incredibly happy.
es: —She was extremely pleased to hear the message that you sent her through me.

en: Not that she showed she was pleased, but I suppose she was.”
vi: She didn't show it, but that's what I think.
tr: He didn't show it too much, but I understood."
es: She didn't tell me, but I suppose so.

en: The allusion served as a timely reminder to Darnay that this disagreeable companion had, of his own free will, assisted him in the strait of the day.
vi: That insinuation was a timely reminder for Darnay to recall that this unpleasant friend had proactively helped him in today's predicament.
tr: This reminded Mr. Darnay of how much this grumpy man had voluntarily helped him overcome the difficulties he faced that day.
es: The allusion was a way of reminding Darnay.

en: He turned the dialogue to that point, and thanked him for it.
vi: He steered the conversation in that direction and thanked Carton for conveying the message.
tr: At this point, he changed the subject and thanked him.
es: He remembered that his unpleasant companion had rendered him a service on that fateful day and thanked him, steering the conversation towards that incident.

en: “I neither want any thanks, nor merit any,” was the careless rejoinder.
vi: − I don't need any thanks and I don't expect any repayment, - the indifferent reply.
tr: "Do not feel grateful to me nor show respect," he replied indifferently again.
es: —I neither need your thanks nor deserve them—replied Carton with cold indifference.

en: “It was nothing to do, in the first place; and I don’t know why I did it, in the second.
vi: - First of all, this didn't take any effort, and secondly, I don't even understand why I helped.
tr: "First of all, it's nothing; besides, I don't know why I did it.
es: — Firstly, I didn't know what to do, and secondly, I don't know why I did what I did.

en: mr Darnay, let me ask you a question.”
vi: Mr. Darnay, let me ask you a question.
tr: Mr. Darnay, may I ask you something?"
es: Will you allow me to ask you a question, Mr. Darnay?

en: “Willingly, and a small return for your good offices.”
vi: − Gladly, as a small token of my appreciation for your help.
tr: "Of course, this way I can at least somewhat repay the kindnesses you have done.""
es: —As many as you like, the favors you have done for me give you that right.

en: “Do you think I particularly like you?”
vi: − Do you think I have any affection for you?
tr: "Do you think that I love you?"
es: —Do you think I like him?

en: “Really, mr Carton,” returned the other, oddly disconcerted, “I have not asked myself the question.”
vi: − Oh, Mr. Carton, - the other replied, strangely puzzled, - I really haven't asked myself that question.
tr: "Really, Mr. Carton," said the other with a strange weariness, "I have never thought of this before."
es: —The truth is... Mr. Carton...—replied Darnay, completely bewildered,—it never occurred to me to ask myself that question.

en: “But ask yourself the question now.”
vi: − So now ask yourself.
tr: "Now think about it then."
es: —Do it yourself now.

en: “You have acted as if you do; but I don’t think you do.”
vi: − You acted as if you had affection; but I don't think so.
tr: "You acted as if you loved, but I don't think you do."
es: —As if I deserved any sympathy from you, you behaved, but if I have to say what I feel, I think I don't deserve it.

en: “I don’t think I do,” said Carton.
vi: − I don't think so either, - Carton said.
tr: "I think so too," said Carton.
es: —And I believe the same as you—observed Carton.

en: “I begin to have a very good opinion of your understanding.”
vi: - I'm starting to appreciate your intellect now.
tr: "But I admired your understanding."
es: —I am beginning to form an excellent opinion of your intelligence.

en: “Nevertheless,” pursued Darnay, rising to ring the bell, “there is nothing in that, I hope, to prevent my calling the reckoning, and our parting without ill-blood on either side.”
vi: − However, - Darnay continued as he rang the bell to call the waiter, - I hope there is no reason to prevent me from asking for the bill and us parting ways without any animosity.
tr: "Come on," said Carton as he reached out to ring the bell, "if you don't mind, I'll ask for the bill and let's part as friends.""
es: —Which should not be an obstacle—replied Darnay, ringing the bell—for me to remain deeply grateful to you and for us to part without mutual ill will.

en: Carton rejoining, “Nothing in life!” Darnay rang.
vi: − No way! - Carton responded immediately. Darnay rang the bell.
tr: Carton immediately said, "No objection at all!" and Darnay rang the bell.
es: —Of course—replied Carton.

en: “Do you call the whole reckoning?” said Carton.
vi: - You paid for everything?
tr: "Will you pay the entire bill?" asked Carton.
es: —Are you saying that you are grateful to me? —I say it, and so it is.

en: On his answering in the affirmative, “Then bring me another pint of this same wine, drawer, and come and wake me at ten.”
vi: - Carton asked and spoke to the waiter after receiving an affirmative answer. - Well then, waiter, bring us another bottle of this wine, and wake me up at ten o'clock.
tr: When Darnay answered affirmatively, he added, "Then bring me another glass of the same wine, waiter, and come wake me up at ten o'clock."
es: —Then, waiter, bring me another pint of this same wine, and wake me up tomorrow at ten.

en: The bill being paid, Charles Darnay rose and wished him good night.
vi: After paying, Charles Darnay stood up to say goodbye.
tr: After Charles Darnay paid the bill, he stood up and wished Carton a good night.
es: After paying the bill, Darnay stood up, said good night, and headed towards the door.

en: Without returning the wish, Carton rose too, with something of a threat of defiance in his manner, and said, “A last word, mr Darnay: you think I am drunk?”
vi: Without bothering to say goodbye, Carton also stood up, speaking with a somewhat challenging tone: − One last word, Mr. Darnay.
tr: Without responding to this wish, Carton also stood up in a defiant and threatening manner and asked, "One last question for you, Mr. Darnay, do you think I'm drunk?"
es: Carton, without responding to the good night, also stood up, looked angrily at the one who was leaving, and said: —Two words, Mr. Darnay, do you think I am drunk?

en: “I think you have been drinking, mr Carton.”
vi: Do you think I'm drunk? − I think you've had quite a bit to drink, Mr. Carton.
tr: "It seems you've had quite a bit to drink, Mr. Carton.""
es: —I believe you have drunk a lot, Mr. Carton.

en: “Think?
vi: − Think?
tr: "Am I drunk?
es: —Do you just believe it?

en: You know I have been drinking.”
vi: You know very well that I have drunk a lot.
tr: You know I've drunk quite a bit."
es: You know perfectly well that I have been drinking.

en: “Since I must say so, I know it.”
vi: − Because I have to say that, but I know.
tr: "Yes, I know.""
es: —Since you insist, I will say that, indeed, I know you have been drinking.

en: “Then you shall likewise know why.
vi: − Then you must also know the reason.
tr: "Then let me tell you the reason for this.
es: —In that case, perhaps you also know why I have been drinking.

en: I am a disappointed drudge, sir.
vi: I am a lowly servant, sir.
tr: I am a defeated, heavy laborer.
es: I am a disillusioned, a disappointed man.

en: I care for no man on earth, and no man on earth cares for me.”
vi: I don't care about anyone in the world, and no one in the world cares about me.
tr: There is no one in this world that I value, and no one values me."
es: I do not care about the fate of any man on earth, nor does any man on earth even remember my existence.

en: “Much to be regretted.
vi: − It's a pity for you.
tr: "What a pity.
es: —Which remains a misfortune.

en: You might have used your talents better.”
vi: You should have used your talent better.
tr: You could have used your talents better."
es: You should have put your talent to better use.

en: “May be so, mr Darnay; may be not.
vi: − Probably so, Mr. Darnay; but not necessarily.
tr: "Maybe so, Mr. Darnay, but maybe not.
es: —You may be right, and you may be sadly mistaken.

en: Don’t let your sober face elate you, however; you don’t know what it may come to.
vi: But don't be too quick to rejoice over your composed demeanor, you don't know what lies ahead.
tr: Don't rely too much on your sober, sensible state; one never knows what the days will bring.
es: Do not be conceited, however, my friend, for you do not know what the future holds for you...

en: Good night!”
vi: Goodbye!
tr: Good night!"
es: Good night!

en: When he was left alone, this strange being took up a candle, went to a glass that hung against the wall, and surveyed himself minutely in it.
vi: Left alone, this strange man picked up a candle, went to the mirror hanging on the wall, and meticulously examined the reflection in the glass.
tr: This strange man, when left alone, took a candle in his hand and went to the mirror hanging on the wall, and carefully examined himself.
es: When he was alone, that singular man took the candlestick, approached a mirror hanging on the wall, and meticulously and thoroughly examined the image reflected on its smooth surface.

en: “Do you particularly like the man?” he muttered, at his own image; “why should you particularly like a man who resembles you?
vi: − Do you have any affection for this person? - Carton mumbled to his own reflection. - Why do you have any affection for someone who resembles you?
tr: "Do you love this man?" he muttered to himself; "why would a person love a man who resembles himself?
es: —Do you find that man likable?—he murmured, as if directing the question to his own reflection. — Why should you find a man who resembles you likable?

en: There is nothing in you to like; you know that.
vi: You have nothing worthy of affection; you know that well.
tr: There is nothing lovable about you.
es: Do you have anything that could please anyone? You know very well that you don't. I can't understand the reason for the change...

en: Ah, confound you!
vi: Ah, you wretched creature!
tr: Oh, come on!
es: Damned be you!...

en: What a change you have made in yourself!
vi: You have changed yourself so much!
tr: What have you changed about yourself in this life?
es: And indeed, the man who tells you what you could have been and what you really are deserves sympathy!

en: A good reason for taking to a man, that he shows you what you have fallen away from, and what you might have been!
vi: The valid reason to have affection for someone is because that person shows you what you once were, and what you could have become!
tr: Seeing the things you've lost and what you could have been might be a good reason to love him!
es: And indeed, the man who tells you what you could have been and what you really are deserves sympathy!

en: Change places with him, and would you have been looked at by those blue eyes as he was, and commiserated by that agitated face as he was?
vi: If you were in his place, would you be seen with those blue eyes like him, would you be pitied with that compassionate face like him?
tr: Just think for a moment if you switched places with him, would those blue eyes look at you the same way they look at him, and would that sad face ache for you with the same compassion?
es: And indeed, the man who tells you what you could have been and what you really are deserves sympathy!

en: Come on, and have it out in plain words!
vi: Come on, speak frankly!
tr: Come on, just say it openly!
es: Come on!... Say it once and for all, and with honesty!

en: You hate the fellow.”
vi: You despise that person.
tr: You hate him."
es: You despise that individual!

en: He resorted to his pint of wine for consolation, drank it all in a few minutes, and fell asleep on his arms, with his hair straggling over the table, and a long winding-sheet in the candle dripping down upon him.
vi: He again resorted to the bottle to drown his sorrows, finishing it off in just a few minutes, then slumped over his arms and fell asleep, his hair sprawled across the table, and the candle wax dripped down like a shroud covering his head.
tr: For solace, his hand went to the wine again, and in a few minutes, having finished it all, accompanied by the dripping long candle, he fell asleep with his hair spread out on the table, collapsed over his arms.
es: As if the wine were a fountain of solace for him, in very few minutes he made the pint of wine pass into his stomach and fell asleep at the same table, his head resting on his arms.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: 5. Jackal*
tr: V
es: V.

en: The Jackal
vi: 5. Jackal*
tr: Jackal
es: THE JACKAL

en: Those were drinking days, and most men drank hard.
vi: It was an era of wine, and most men drank like fish.
tr: In those days, people drank a lot, and most men drank until they were dead drunk.
es: In those times, universal worship was rendered to the bottle.

en: So very great is the improvement Time has brought about in such habits, that a moderate statement of the quantity of wine and punch which one man would swallow in the course of a night, without any detriment to his reputation as a perfect gentleman, would seem, in these days, a ridiculous exaggeration.
vi: Time has improved that vice to the extent that nowadays, one would be considered ridiculously exaggerated if they mentioned the average amount of wine and punch a person of that time could consume in one night without damaging the reputation of a noble gentleman.
tr: Time has brought about such great changes in habits that a reasonable explanation of how much wine a man could consume in one night without tarnishing his gentlemanliness would seem like a comical exaggeration today.
es: If I were to specify and detail here the amount of wine and punch that a man could consume in the course of a night, without his reputation as a perfect gentleman suffering the slightest detriment, I would surely be deemed a ridiculous exaggerator by the readers.

en: The learned profession of the law was certainly not behind any other learned profession in its Bacchanalian propensities; neither was mr Stryver, already fast shouldering his way to a large and lucrative practice, behind his compeers in this particular, any more than in the drier parts of the legal race.
vi: Compared to other high academic professions, the legal profession was not lacking in its number of heavy drinkers; barrister Stryver, too, having aggressively pushed his way into this lucrative profession, was no less proficient in both the drunkenness and sobriety of the legal breed.
tr: In these drinking bouts, the legal community was no less than others; of course, Mr. Stryver, as in the most tedious legal competitions, was never behind his peers in this matter either.
es: Men drank a lot, and certainly the luminaries of the forum and the notabilities in any other branch of human knowledge were no exception to the rule, as science has never been a barrier raised between its possessor and the altars of Bacchus. It is therefore not surprising that Mr. Stryver, a lawyer advancing with giant strides in his lucrative profession, rendered as constant worship to the bottle as the driest sponges in the community of pettifoggers.

en: A favourite at the Old Bailey, and eke at the Sessions, mr Stryver had begun cautiously to hew away the lower staves of the ladder on which he mounted.
vi: As a favored person at both the Old Bailey Criminal Court and the Sessions Court, Stryver had begun carefully cutting off the lower rungs of the ladder of fame he was climbing.
tr: Mr. Stryver, the favorite of Old Bailey and the trials, had begun to cautiously cut off the lower rungs of the ladder he was climbing. He was now being called to many trials and to Old Bailey, and they were even eager for his arrival.
es: Favorite at the Old Bailey and indispensable at the court called Sessions, Stryver separated the steps of the ladder with his foot as he left them behind.

en: Sessions and Old Bailey had now to summon their favourite, specially, to their longing arms; and shouldering itself towards the visage of the Lord Chief Justice in the Court of King’s Bench, the florid countenance of mr Stryver might be daily seen, bursting out of the bed of wigs, like a great sunflower pushing its way at the sun from among a rank garden-full of flaring companions.
vi: The Old Bailey and Sessions courts now had to summon this favored person into their eager embrace; every day one could see Stryver's flushed face, like a sunflower standing out in a garden full of wigs, pushing and shoving to catch the eye of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, competing with other brilliant peers to reach the sun.
tr: Every day, with his red face, he appeared before the Chief Justice in the High Court of Justice, and his head, among all those wigged heads, stood out like a giant sunflower reaching for the sun from among thousands of similar, neatly arranged, and brightly shining heads.
es: Every day, in one court or another, Stryver's red face emerged from among a layer of wigs, similar to the sunflower that raises its head above a bed of bright flowers.

en: It had once been noted at the Bar, that while mr Stryver was a glib man, and an unscrupulous, and a ready, and a bold, he had not that faculty of extracting the essence from a heap of statements, which is among the most striking and necessary of the advocate’s accomplishments.
vi: In the previous bar association, people used to notice that although Stryver was eloquent, unscrupulous, cunning, and bold, he lacked the ability to extract the essence from a pile of reports - the most necessary and admirable skill in the achievements of a barrister.
tr: Once, while discussing Baroda, they had mentioned Mr. Stryver as a talkative, unscrupulous, skilled, and brave man, but they had also remarked that he failed to grasp the essence within a multitude of expressions, which was one of the most striking and necessary skills for a lawyer.
es: They had observed in the forum that Stryver, at the beginning of his career, although he was a man with a loose tongue, unscrupulous, willing to do anything, bold and insolent, lacked the ability to extract the essence, the core of reports and testimonial evidence, which is so indispensable to any good lawyer, but later on, he made marvelous progress in this particular area.

en: But, a remarkable improvement came upon him as to this.
vi: But this had improved significantly.
tr: But he had shown significant improvement in this regard.
es: They had observed in the forum that Stryver, at the beginning of his career, although he was a man with a loose tongue, unscrupulous, willing to do anything, bold and insolent, lacked the ability to extract the essence, the core of reports and testimonial evidence, which is so indispensable to any good lawyer, but later on, he made marvelous progress in this particular area.

en: The more business he got, the greater his power seemed to grow of getting at its pith and marrow; and however late at night he sat carousing with Sydney Carton, he always had his points at his fingers’ ends in the morning.
vi: The more cases he handled, the better he seemed to get at digging to the core of the matter; and even if he spent the entire night carousing with Sydney Carton, by morning this barrister still had all the arguments ready for defense in court.
tr: As he took on more cases, he became stronger in extracting the essence and substance of the matter; even if he stayed up late drinking with Sydney Carton, he would have all his preparations completed by morning.
es: The more he worked, the more easily he reached the heart, the marrow of the matters, it being noteworthy that, even though he had the habit of spending sleepless nights emptying bottles in the company of Carton, the points he had to address the next morning neither faded from his mind nor became obscured.

en: Sydney Carton, idlest and most unpromising of men, was Stryver’s great ally.
vi: Sydney Carton - the most idle and useless person - was actually Stryver's right-hand man.
tr: The world's most idle and hopeless man, Sydney Carton, was Stryver's friend.
es: Sydney Carton, the laziest and most idle specimen of humanity, was Stryver's most powerful ally.

en: What the two drank together, between Hilary Term and Michaelmas, might have floated a king’s ship.
vi: The amount of alcohol these two consumed together, if accumulated from the beginning of the year to the end, would surely be enough to flow like a river.
tr: The amount of alcohol they consumed between Hilary Term and Michaelmas was enough to float the king's ship; Carton was always present at Stryver's every trial, looking up at the ceiling of the courtroom with his hands in his pockets; they moved in the same circles and even there, they would extend their drinking sessions until midnight, after which it was said that Carton would secretly, in broad daylight, stagger home like a miserable cat.
es: On the liquid that the two of them consumed, a three-deck ship could have perfectly floated.

en: Stryver never had a case in hand, anywhere, but Carton was there, with his hands in his pockets, staring at the ceiling of the court; they went the same Circuit, and even there they prolonged their usual orgies late into the night, and Carton was rumoured to be seen at broad day, going home stealthily and unsteadily to his lodgings, like a dissipated cat.
vi: There was no trial, anywhere, of Stryver's without Carton being there, hands in pockets, eyes fixed on the ceiling; they followed the circuit court together, and wherever they went, they extended their habitual all-night drinking sessions, and it was rumored that in the morning Carton would be seen sneaking, staggering back to the inn like a chased cat.
tr: The amount of alcohol they consumed between Hilary Term and Michaelmas was enough to float the king's ship; Carton was always present at Stryver's every trial, looking up at the ceiling of the courtroom with his hands in his pockets; they moved in the same circles and even there, they would extend their drinking sessions until midnight, after which it was said that Carton would secretly, in broad daylight, stagger home like a miserable cat.
es: Both led the same life, both extended their orgies until dawn, and more than once Carton was seen, with the sun already high, heading with unsteady steps to his home or to the courtroom.

en: At last, it began to get about, among such as were interested in the matter, that although Sydney Carton would never be a lion, he was an amazingly good jackal, and that he rendered suit and service to Stryver in that humble capacity.
vi: Eventually, those who cared about this matter gradually came to know that although Sydney Carton would never be a lion, he was an extraordinarily skilled jackal, and it was he who prepared all the legal matters for Stryver in that humble role.
tr: Ultimately, followers began to say that while Sydney Carton might never be a lion, he was a very good jackal, offering help and service to Stryver with this humble title.
es: There were no shortage of malicious people who claimed that Carton, if he was not and would never become a lion, was instead an excellent tiger, and that, in this capacity, he rendered invaluable services to his friend Stryver.

en: “Ten o’clock, sir,” said the man at the tavern, whom he had charged to wake him—“ten o’clock, sir.”
vi: − Sir, it's ten o'clock, - said the servant whom Carton had entrusted with the task of waking him, - it's ten o'clock, sir.
tr: The man whom Handa paid to wake him up said, "It is ten o'clock, sir."
es: —Ten o'clock, sir—said the tavern keeper whom Carton had instructed to wake him. —Ten o'clock at night.

en: “What’s the matter?”
vi: − What's the matter?
tr: "What happened?"
es: —What is happening?

en: “Ten o’clock, sir.”
vi: - Sir, it's ten o'clock already.
tr: "It is ten o'clock, sir.""
es: —It's ten o'clock, sir.

en: “What do you mean?
vi: − What do you mean?
tr: "So what?
es: —And what?

en: Ten o’clock at night?”
vi: Ten o'clock at night? −
tr: Is it ten at night?"
es: Ten o'clock at night?

en: “Yes, sir.
vi: Yes, sir.
tr: "Yes sir.
es: —Yes, sir.

en: Your honour told me to call you.”
vi: The gentleman instructed me to call.
tr: You had asked me to wake you up, remember."
es: You asked me to wake you up at that time.

en: “Oh!
vi: − Ah! I remember now.
tr: "Aha!
es: —Ah, yes!

en: I remember.
vi: − Ah! I remember now.
tr: I remember now!
es: Now I remember!

en: Very well, very well.”
vi: Very good, very good.
tr: Very nice, very nice."
es: Alright.

en: After a few dull efforts to get to sleep again, which the man dexterously combated by stirring the fire continuously for five minutes, he got up, tossed his hat on, and walked out.
vi: After several feeble attempts to go back to sleep but being skillfully awakened by the attendant who kept stoking the fireplace continuously for five minutes, Carton got up, put his hat on, and went out.
tr: Although he tried to fall back asleep, the man's noisy stirring of the fire for five minutes turned it into a skillful struggle, and Carton got up, put on his hat, and went outside.
es: Not without trying to sleep again, attempts that the innkeeper thwarted by constantly stoking the fire and making noise, Carton finally got up and went out.

en: He turned into the Temple, and, having revived himself by twice pacing the pavements of King’s Bench-walk and Paper-buildings, turned into the Stryver chambers.
vi: He turned towards the Temple area, after twice circling around to fully wake up on the sidewalk between King’s Bench Walk and Paper Buildings, he entered the office of barrister Stryver.
tr: He turned onto the road to Temple, and after pacing twice on the pavement in front of the King's Bench Court and the newspaper buildings, he came to himself and returned to Stryver's office.
es: After he had cleared his head by taking a regular walk, he headed to Stryver's office.

en: The Stryver clerk, who never assisted at these conferences, had gone home, and the Stryver principal opened the door.
vi: The secretary of Stryver - who never attended these meetings - had gone home, and Stryver himself opened the door.
tr: Stryver's clerk, who never participated in such meetings, had gone home, and Stryver himself opened the door.
es: The official of Stryver, who never attended the conferences he held with Carton, had left, and as a result, it was Stryver himself who had to open the door to the visitor.

en: He had his slippers on, and a loose bed-gown, and his throat was bare for his greater ease.
vi: Stryver was wearing slippers, a loose dressing gown, and his collar was open for comfort.
tr: He was wearing slippers, a loose nightgown, and had loosened his collar for comfort.
es: He was in a robe and slippers, and his eyes shone between two purplish circles similar to those that characterize all who live or have lived a dissipated life.

en: He had that rather wild, strained, seared marking about the eyes, which may be observed in all free livers of his class, from the portrait of Jeffries downward, and which can be traced, under various disguises of Art, through the portraits of every Drinking Age.
vi: Around his eyes were the clear signs of tension, the ferocity commonly seen in every indulgent person in the legal profession, from Jeffries* to the present, which one can trace through the various portraits disguised as art from the era that worshipped Bacchus.
tr: Around his eyes were wild, tense, and hardened traces that could be seen in all the freely living members of his class, similar to those in the portraits starting from Jeffreys and evolving with every new form of Art, drawn in all ages where there was a penchant for drinking.
es: He was in a robe and slippers, and his eyes shone between two purplish circles similar to those that characterize all who live or have lived a dissipated life.

en: “You are a little late, Memory,” said Stryver.
vi: − You arrived a bit late, Mr. Memory, - Stryver said.
tr: "You are a bit late, Mr. Memory," said Stryver.
es: —You're a little late, Carton—said Stryver.

en: “About the usual time; it may be a quarter of an hour later.”
vi: − Just like usual; probably about half an hour late.
tr: "I came as usual, just fifteen minutes late.""
es: —More or less at the usual time, maybe fifteen minutes later.

en: They went into a dingy room lined with books and littered with papers, where there was a blazing fire.
vi: They entered a filthy room, filled with books and cluttered with papers, where a fireplace was blazing and a kettle was steaming on the stove.
tr: They entered a filthy room filled with rows of books, papers scattered everywhere, and a burning fireplace.
es: Both entered the office, a not very large room, crowded with books and papers. A delightful fire was burning in it.

en: A kettle steamed upon the hob, and in the midst of the wreck of papers a table shone, with plenty of wine upon it, and brandy, and rum, and sugar, and lemons.
vi: And amidst that forest of papers, a table laden with wine, spirits, rum with sugar and lemon was revealed.
tr: A kettle was steaming on the stove, and on the table amidst the piles of paper resembling a wreck, various kinds of wine, brandy, rum, sugar, and lemon were shining.
es: On the work table, a teapot was steaming among piles of papers and bottles of rum, brandy, and wine, and among lumps of sugar and lemons.

en: “You have had your bottle, I perceive, Sydney.”
vi: − I'm sure you've already had a bottle, Sydney.
tr: "I guess you've knocked back quite a few bottles, Sydney.""
es: —I see that you have already finished your usual bottle, Carton.

en: “Two to-night, I think.
vi: − Two bottles tonight, probably.
tr: "I think I drank two bottles tonight.
es: —Tonight there were two.

en: I have been dining with the day’s client; or seeing him dine—it’s all one!”
vi: Earlier, I had dinner with the client from today's trial; or more accurately, I watched him eat... same difference!
tr: We had dinner with my client today; or rather, I watched him eat –same thing!"
es: I was eating with my client today... or watching him eat, for that matter, it's the same thing.

en: “That was a rare point, Sydney, that you brought to bear upon the identification.
vi: − Sydney, it's truly extraordinary that you put yourself forward for identification.
tr: "Drawing attention to your resemblance was a brilliant tactic, Sydney.
es: —You gave the matter a truly unique twist, Carton, by drawing my attention to the identification of the defendant.

en: How did you come by it?
vi: How did you come up with that idea?
tr: How did you come up with it?
es: How on earth did such a thing occur to you?

en: When did it strike you?”
vi: When did you notice the resemblance?
tr: When did you first notice it?"
es: —Bah!

en: “I thought he was rather a handsome fellow, and I thought I should have been much the same sort of fellow, if I had had any luck.”
vi: − I think he's quite a handsome guy, and I think I might have turned out like him if I had been lucky.
tr: "I realized he was quite handsome, and I thought if I had a bit of luck, I would resemble this man a little.""
es: I saw that he was a handsome young man, very good-looking, and I thought that I could have been like that, had luck favored me a little more.

en: mr Stryver laughed till he shook his precocious paunch.
vi: Stryver laughed, shaking his already corpulent belly.
tr: Mr. Stryver laughed heartily, making his already large belly bounce even more.
es: Stryver burst into laughter.

en: “You and your luck, Sydney!
vi: − You got lucky, Sydney!
tr: "You and luck, huh Sydney!
es: —Luck must be summoned by working, my friend, so... let's get to work!

en: Get to work, get to work.”
vi: Alright, get to work, get to work.
tr: Come on, let's get to work, let's get to work.""
es: —Luck must be summoned by working, my friend, so... let's get to work!

en: Sullenly enough, the jackal loosened his dress, went into an adjoining room, and came back with a large jug of cold water, a basin, and a towel or two.
vi: With a gloomy face, the Jackal loosened his tie and took off his coat, went to the next room, and returned with a jug of cold water, a basin, and some towels.
tr: The jackal, with a sullen face, unbuttoned his clothes and went to the next room, returning with a large jug of water, a basin, and a few towels.
es: With a more than moderately sullen face, the jackal quickly removed his clothes, entered the adjoining room, and soon came out with a bucket of water, a basin, and one or two towels.

en: Steeping the towels in the water, and partially wringing them out, he folded them on his head in a manner hideous to behold, sat down at the table, and said, “Now I am ready!”
vi: He dipped the towel in water, wrung it out, folded the wet towel, and haphazardly placed it on his head, then sat at the table, saying: − I'm ready!
tr: After soaking the towels in the water and wringing them out lightly, he carelessly wrapped one around his head and sat down at the head of the table, saying, "Yes, I'm ready now!"
es: He soaked the towels in cold water, wrapped them around his head, sat down in front of the table, and said: —We can begin now.

en: “Not much boiling down to be done to-night, Memory,” said mr Stryver, gaily, as he looked among his papers.
vi: − Tonight, there's not much work, Mr. Memory, - Stryver said cheerfully while looking through the papers.
tr: "There's not much going on tonight actually, Mr. Memory," said Mr. Stryver, looking at the papers, cheerfully.
es: —We don't have much work tonight, Carton.

en: “How much?”
vi: − How many files? −
tr: "How many cases are there?"
es: —How much?

en: “Only two sets of them.”
vi: There are only two.
tr: "Only two.""
es: —Two protocols.

en: “Give me the worst first.”
vi: − Give me the hardest one.
tr: "Give the bad news first.""
es: —Give me the worst one first.

en: “There they are, Sydney.
vi: − Here, Sydney.
tr: "Come on, Sydney.
es: —Here are the two...

en: Fire away!”
vi: Do it now!
tr: Good luck!"
es: Let's get to work!

en: The lion then composed himself on his back on a sofa on one side of the drinking-table, while the jackal sat at his own paper-bestrewn table proper, on the other side of it, with the bottles and glasses ready to his hand.
vi: The Lion then settled back on a sofa placed beside the liquor table, while on the other side was the Jackal sitting at a separate table cluttered with papers but still within reach of bottles and glasses. Both freely used the liquor table but in their own ways;
tr: Then, while the lion leaned back on the sofa next to the liquor table, the jackal went to his own table, which was covered with papers and had wine bottles and glasses right beside it.
es: The lion of the forum lounged on a sofa while the jackal took a chair. On the table, placed between the two, there were bottles and glasses.

en: Both resorted to the drinking-table without stint, but each in a different way; the lion for the most part reclining with his hands in his waistband, looking at the fire, or occasionally flirting with some lighter document; the jackal, with knitted brows and intent face, so deep in his task, that his eyes did not even follow the hand he stretched out for his glass—which often groped about, for a minute or more, before it found the glass for his lips.
vi: The Lion usually lay on his back, hands hooked into his waistband, eyes gazing at the fireplace or occasionally flipping through a simple file; the Jackal furrowed his brow, deeply immersed in work, his eyes not even following his hand as it reached for a glass - the hand often groped for a minute or more before finding the glass to bring to his lips.
tr: They both frequently reached for the liquor table but in different styles; the lion usually with his hands resting on his belt, looking at the fire or occasionally shuffling the papers in his hand; the jackal, on the other hand, was so engrossed in his work with a frown and a determined face that his eyes didn't even follow his hand reaching for the glass – thus, he often brought the glass to his lips by feel.
es: Both of them resorted to them frequently but in different ways: the lion drank, mostly absorbed or at most glancing indifferently at some unimportant document, but the jackal, with such ardor and enthusiasm, devoted himself to his task that his eyes almost never followed the movement of his hands when they reached for the glass, resulting in him groping for one or two minutes more than four times before finding the glass and bringing it to his lips.

en: Two or three times, the matter in hand became so knotty, that the jackal found it imperative on him to get up, and steep his towels anew.
vi: Two or three times, when the problem at hand became too difficult, the Jackal had to get up and wet his towel again.
tr: Two or three times, the matter at hand became so intricate that the jackal felt the need to get up and put the towels back in the water.
es: On two or three occasions, he must have found the matter he was studying so convoluted that he considered it necessary to get up from the chair and dampen the towels again.

en: From these pilgrimages to the jug and basin, he returned with such eccentricities of damp headgear as no words can describe; which were made the more ludicrous by his anxious gravity.
vi: After each pilgrimage to the water jug and basin, the Jackal returned with the wet towels draped over his head in an indescribably peculiar manner; looking even more absurd with his serious and tense expression.
tr: He would return from his visits to the pitcher and basin with wet towels wrapped around his head in such a way that it was impossible to describe the oddity, and adding his restless solemnity to this, he looked even more comical.
es: On two or three occasions, he must have found the matter he was studying so convoluted that he considered it necessary to get up from the chair and dampen the towels again.

en: At length the jackal had got together a compact repast for the lion, and proceeded to offer it to him.
vi: Finally, the Jackal managed to gather a full meal to offer to the Lion.
tr: In the end, the jackal prepared a hearty meal for the lion and placed it in front of him.
es: After a while, the jackal managed to prepare an acceptable meal for the lion and proceeded to offer it to him.

en: The lion took it with care and caution, made his selections from it, and his remarks upon it, and the jackal assisted both.
vi: The Lion carefully received it, meticulously selecting the meat from the bones, and made comments to the Jackal.
tr: After the lion examined it with great care and caution, he made comments by making selections from it, while the jackal assisted him.
es: The lion tried to digest it carefully and with exquisite precautions, separating some delicacies, dispensing with some components, and making judicious observations, which seemed agreeable to the jackal.

en: When the repast was fully discussed, the lion put his hands in his waistband again, and lay down to meditate.
vi: When the meal had been thoroughly consumed in this manner, the Lion hooked his hands into his waistband and lay down to ponder.
tr: After the matter was thoroughly discussed, the lion again put his hands on his belt and lay down, lost in thoughts.
es: Having digested the meal, the lion lay down on the sofa, while the jackal, after revitalizing himself again with libations and cold water compresses, dedicated himself to the preparation of the second meal, which was served to the lion in the same manner as the previous one.

en: The jackal then invigorated himself with a bumper for his throttle, and a fresh application to his head, and applied himself to the collection of a second meal; this was administered to the lion in the same manner, and was not disposed of until the clocks struck three in the morning.
vi: The Jackal then restored his strength with a full glass of wine poured down his throat, a fresh wet cloth applied to his head, and continued to prepare the second meal; this meal was again offered to the Lion as before, and only fully digested when the clock struck three in the morning.
tr: Then the jackal downed a glass filled to the brim to clear his head and prepared the second meal; this meal was also presented to the lion in the same manner, and when they were done, the clock showed three in the morning.
es: The clocks were already striking three in the morning.

en: “And now we have done, Sydney, fill a bumper of punch,” said mr Stryver.
vi: − Now that the work is done, have a glass of punch, Sydney, - Stryver said.
tr: "Well, now that we've finished, we can have a big glass of punch, can't we, Sydney?" said Mr. Stryver.
es: —Now that we have finished, Carton, we will have a punch.

en: The jackal removed the towels from his head, which had been steaming again, shook himself, yawned, shivered, and complied.
vi: The jackal removed the cloths that had been steaming from its head, stretched, yawned, shivered, and then followed suit.
tr: The Jackal took the steaming towels off his head, gave them a shake, yawned, shivered, and agreed with Stryver.
es: The jackal removed the towels from his head, yawned, stretched, and prepared the punch.

en: “You were very sound, Sydney, in the matter of those crown witnesses to-day.
vi: − Sydney, you were really impressive in handling the witnesses accusing you today.
tr: "You stood very firm in front of those witnesses today, Sydney.
es: —You were right, Carton, regarding the witnesses this morning: everything went perfectly.

en: Every question told.”
vi: Every question was worthwhile.
tr: With every question you asked."
es: —It seems to me that I always have it: will you dare to say otherwise?

en: “I always am sound; am I not?”
vi: − Aren't I always good?
tr: "I'm always healthy; isn't that right?""
es: —It seems to me that I always have it: will you dare to say otherwise?

en: “I don’t gainsay it.
vi: − I don't deny that.
tr: "I can't deny this.
es: —No, man, no!

en: What has roughened your temper?
vi: What made you so angry?
tr: Why are you upset?
es: You come today with a ruffled temper, my friend.

en: Put some punch to it and smooth it again.”
vi: Have another drink to cool down.
tr: Pour some more punch and relax."
es: It wouldn't hurt to sprinkle it with a good downpour of punch to soften it.

en: With a deprecatory grunt, the jackal again complied.
vi: Muttering complaints, the Jackal still obeyed.
tr: The Jackal grumbled discontentedly and surrendered again.
es: The jackal responded with a growl, but followed the advice.

en: “The old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School,” said Stryver, nodding his head over him as he reviewed him in the present and the past, “the old seesaw Sydney.
vi: − The guy Sydney Carton from the old days at Shrewsbury school, Stryver said while nodding as he compared his friend from the past to the present, - the teetering Sydney!
tr: "Sydney Carton, an old student of Shrewsbury School from years ago, huh?" said Stryver, evaluating him both in his current and past state, nodding his head, "Erratic Sydney.
es: —The good Sydney Carton, lawyer from the Faculty of Zorrilandia, is a kind of swing—observed Stryver.—

en: Up one minute and down the next; now in spirits and now in despondency!”
vi: One moment he's up, the next he's down; sometimes he's enthusiastic, other times he's despondent!
tr: One moment good, the next bad; one day cheerful, the next in a slump!"
es: As soon as he is up, he is down: in a minute he goes from being all fire to being all despair.

en: “Ah!” returned the other, sighing: “yes!
vi: − Ah! - The friend sighed in response. - Yes!
tr: "Ah!" sighed Carton; "You're right!
es: —Ah, yes!

en: The same Sydney, with the same luck.
vi: That same Sydney, with the same bad luck.
tr: The same Sydney, the same luck.
es: —replied Carton, letting out a sigh.

en: Even then, I did exercises for other boys, and seldom did my own.”
vi: Even back then, I used to do homework for my classmates but rarely did my own.
tr: Even back then, I would do other children's homework and not bother much with my own."
es: —Even as a student, I was motivated by the affairs of my classmates, very rarely by my own.

en: “And why not?”
vi: − Why didn't you do it?
tr: "Why then?"
es: —But why not?

en: “God knows.
tr: "Who knows?
es: —Who knows!

en: It was my way, I suppose.”
vi: Only God knows, I guess that's just how I am.
tr: This is just how I am."
es: By temperament, I suppose.

en: He sat, with his hands in his pockets and his legs stretched out before him, looking at the fire.
vi: He sat with his legs stretched out in front of him, hands in his pockets, eyes fixed on the fireplace.
tr: He sat with his hands in his pockets and watched the fire in the fireplace, stretching his legs forward.
es: He sat down, having said these words, with his hands in his pockets, legs stretched out, and looking at the fire.

en: “Carton,” said his friend, squaring himself at him with a bullying air, as if the fire-grate had been the furnace in which sustained endeavour was forged, and the one delicate thing to be done for the old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School was to shoulder him into it, “your way is, and always was, a lame way.
vi: - Carton, if you keep going like this, you won't get anywhere, just like in the past. - Stryver aggressively stood right in front of him with an overbearing attitude, as if the fireplace was a forge of relentless efforts, and the only thing needed to be done for the old Sydney Carton from Shrewsbury school was to throw him into that fire. -
tr: "Carton," said his friend with a condescending attitude; as if the grill in the fireplace was a hearth fueled by endless efforts and the best thing to do for the years of Sydney Carton who had attended Shrewsbury School was to push him, "you've been on the wrong path from the start.
es: —You cannot deny, Carton—said Stryver to the former student of the Faculty of Foxland,—that your temperament, your way of being, is and has always been flawed.

en: You summon no energy and purpose.
vi: You have no motivation and no purpose.
tr: You have neither effort nor purpose.
es: It suffers from a lack of energy, a lack of unity of purpose.

en: Look at me.”
vi: Look at me.
tr: Just look at me."
es: Look at me.

en: “Oh, botheration!” returned Sydney, with a lighter and more good-humoured laugh, “don’t you be moral!”
vi: − Oh, what a bother! - Sydney replied with a cheerful and somewhat enthusiastic laugh. - You, teaching me a lesson! −
tr: "Come on, man!" said Sydney, laughing softly and meekly, "don't lecture me now!"
es: —Sermons at this point?—exclaimed Carton, laughing cynically.

en: “How have I done what I have done?” said Stryver; “how do I do what I do?”
vi: How did I achieve what I have? - Stryver said. - How did I do what I wanted? −
tr: "How did I come to this state?" said Stryver; "How did I obtain what I currently possess?"
es: —Now is when I believe that thing about the preaching devil... —How could I have gotten to where I am? How do I hold the position I hold?

en: “Partly through paying me to help you, I suppose.
vi: Partly because you paid me to help you, I suppose.
tr: "You obtained some of it by giving me money to help you.
es: —Partly, thanks to my cooperation, I suppose.

en: But it’s not worth your while to apostrophise me, or the air, about it; what you want to do, you do.
vi: But don't bother calling me that way and don't act superior to me; do whatever you want.
tr: But none of it is worth you talking down to me or acting superior; you did what you wanted.
es: But let's leave these discussions that won't lead us to anything practical.

en: You were always in the front rank, and I was always behind.”
vi: You always charge ahead, while I always stay behind.
tr: You were always in the front rows, while I was always in the back."
es: You do whatever you want, you've always been in the forefront, and I, on the other hand, have always been in the background.

en: “I had to get into the front rank; I was not born there, was I?”
vi: − I have to push to the front; it's not like I was born into a prestigious family.
tr: "I had to be at the front; after all, I wasn't born there either, right?"
es: "I had to make my own way if I wanted to place myself in the front row, as I don't know that I was born into it," replied Stryver.

en: “I was not present at the ceremony; but my opinion is you were,” said Carton.
vi: − I wasn't there when you were born; but I know you are prestigious, - Carton said.
tr: "I wasn't there at your birth, but I think you were definitely born there," said Carton.
es: —I did not have the honor of witnessing the ceremony of your birth, but I believe that when you were brought into the world, you were placed among the privileged.

en: At this, he laughed again, and they both laughed.
vi: After finishing his sentence, he laughed and Stryver laughed along.
tr: He laughed again at this remark, and Stryver laughed too.
es: The two interlocutors burst into laughter.

en: “Before Shrewsbury, and at Shrewsbury, and ever since Shrewsbury,” pursued Carton, “you have fallen into your rank, and I have fallen into mine.
vi: Carton continued. "Before attending Shrewsbury, while at Shrewsbury, and after leaving Shrewsbury, you were always ahead, while I was always behind."
tr: "Before Shrewsbury, in Shrewsbury, and after Shrewsbury," continued Carton, "you were always at the forefront, and I was always behind.
es: —Before attending Zorrilandia University—replied Carton,—while we were attending, and after we graduated from it, you were in a different league from mine.

en: Even when we were fellow-students in the Student-Quarter of Paris, picking up French, and French law, and other French crumbs that we didn’t get much good of, you were always somewhere, and I was always nowhere.”
vi: "Even when we were both students in the Latin Quarter in Paris, learning French, studying French law, and other trivial French matters that seemed useless, you always stood out, while I remained obscure."
tr: During our student days in the student quarter of Paris, where we took lessons in French, French Law, and the French beauties who caused us trouble, you were always getting somewhere, and I was – nowhere."
es: Even when we were in Paris learning to mumble French and acquiring some notions of French law, and familiarizing ourselves with many other French trivialities that are of no use to us, you were something, while I was always Mr. Nobody.

en: “And whose fault was that?”
vi: − So whose fault is it?
tr: "So whose fault was this?"
es: —Whose fault was it?

en: “Upon my soul, I am not sure that it was not yours.
vi: − Deep down, I also think it's your fault.
tr: "Honestly, I'm not sure it's not yours.
es: —By my life, I won't be the one to claim that it wasn't your fault!

en: You were always driving and riving and shouldering and passing, to that restless degree that I had no chance for my life but in rust and repose.
vi: You are always trying to compete, scramble, and maneuver to get ahead, doing it so continuously that I have no other choice but to sit quietly and let my intellect go to waste.
tr: While I stood in a corner waiting to rust, you would always strive, struggle, and push things in ways I could never do.
es: You were so lively, you stood out so much, you moved, you stirred in such a way, that I don't know what else I could do but remain shrouded in shadows and condemned to rest...

en: It’s a gloomy thing, however, to talk about one’s own past, with the day breaking.
vi: But it's almost dawn, and talking about the past is very boring.
tr: But now, at this hour, just before dawn, talking about one's past is a tedious matter.
es: But let's leave this topic, for it is not very pleasant, by my faith, to talk about one's dark past at the break of day.

en: Turn me in some other direction before I go.”
vi: Change the subject before I get back.
tr: Come on, let's change the subject a bit before you go."
es: But let's leave this topic, for it is not very pleasant, by my faith, to talk about one's dark past at the break of day.

en: “Well then!
vi: − That's good!
tr: "Alright, fine!
es: —Perfectly—said Stryver, raising the glass.

en: Pledge me to the pretty witness,” said Stryver, holding up his glass.
vi: Let's toast to that beautiful witness, - Stryver said, raising his glass. -
tr: Let's drink to the honor of the beautiful witness then," said Stryver, raising his glass.
es: —We will talk about your pretty witness.

en: “Are you turned in a pleasant direction?”
vi: Do you agree with this topic?
tr: "Did you like this topic?"
es: Don't you think it's a more pleasant topic?

en: Apparently not, for he became gloomy again.
vi: Clearly not, as Carton became sullen again.
tr: Apparently, he hadn't left, because Carton was bored again.
es: It shouldn't have been, judging by the shadow that darkened his face.

en: “Pretty witness,” he muttered, looking down into his glass.
vi: − Beautiful witness, - he muttered, eyes looking down at his glass of wine. -
tr: He looked at his glass, murmuring to himself, "Beautiful witness."
es: —The beautiful witness! —he exclaimed, fixing his eyes on the bottom of the glass.

en: “I have had enough of witnesses to-day and to-night; who’s your pretty witness?”
vi: All day and night I've run into so many witnesses; who is your beautiful witness?
tr: "I've dealt with witnesses all day and night; who is this beautiful witness?"
es: —I have seen many witnesses today... Who are you referring to?

en: “The picturesque doctor’s daughter, Miss Manette.”
vi: − The charming daughter of the doctor, Miss Manette.
tr: "I'm talking about the interesting doctor's daughter, Miss Manette."
es: —To the precious daughter of the doctor, to Miss Manette.

en: “She pretty?”
vi: − Is she beautiful? −
tr: "Is she beautiful?"
es: —Is she pretty?

en: “Is she not?”
vi: Isn't she beautiful? −
tr: "Isn't it?"
es: —Isn't it, perhaps?

en: “No.”
vi: No.
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: “Why, man alive, she was the admiration of the whole Court!”
vi: − Oh my goodness, the whole Court is admiring her!
tr: "What are you saying, man, everyone in the courtroom was impressed by him!"
es: —But man of God!...

en: “Rot the admiration of the whole Court!
vi: − Nonsense, the whole Court is admiring her!
tr: "What do I care about the admiration of those in the courtroom!
es: It has been the admiration of the entire court! —To hell with the court and its admiration!

en: Who made the Old Bailey a judge of beauty?
vi: Who turned the Old Bailey into a beauty pageant?
tr: Is Old Bailey a place to judge beauty?
es: Who made the Old Bailey a judge of beauty?

en: She was a golden-haired doll!”
vi: − She's just a blonde doll!
tr: She was just a golden-haired baby!"
es: Pretty!... A doll with golden hair!...

en: “Do you know, Sydney,” said mr Stryver, looking at him with sharp eyes, and slowly drawing a hand across his florid face: “do you know, I rather thought, at the time, that you sympathised with the golden-haired doll, and were quick to see what happened to the golden-haired doll?”
vi: − Do you know, Sydney? - Stryver said, eyes fixed on Carton and slowly running his hand over his flushed face. - Do you know, during the trial I thought you had a thing for that blonde doll, so you immediately noticed what happened to that doll girl.
tr: Mr. Stryver, "You know Sydney," he said, looking sternly and running his hand over his red face, "you know, I thought you liked that golden-haired baby there, how you rushed immediately to see what happened to her."
es: —You know, Carton—asked Stryver, giving his friend a penetrating look and passing his right hand over his red face,—that I'm starting to believe you've sympathized too much with that golden-haired doll, and that your interest quickly noticed what was happening to that golden-haired doll?

en: “Quick to see what happened!
vi: − Immediately see what happened!
tr: "Did I run to see what happened?
es: —I warned too soon!

en: If a girl, doll or no doll, swoons within a yard or two of a man’s nose, he can see it without a perspective-glass.
vi: Whether it's a doll or not, if a girl faints right in front of a man, just one or two yards away, he would see it without needing a telescope.
tr: If a lady, baby or not, faints right in front of your eyes, you don't need binoculars to see it.
es: It seems to me that if a girl, doll or not, faints two yards from any Christian's nose, they can notice it without looking through a telescope.

en: I pledge you, but I deny the beauty.
vi: I drink to your health, not to your beauty.
tr: I raise my glass to her honor, but I don't admit that she's beautiful.
es: The topic of conversation doesn't displease me, but I deny the beauty part... I'm not drinking anymore!... I'm going to bed!

en: And now I’ll have no more drink; I’ll get to bed.”
vi: Now I won't drink any more, I'm going to sleep.
tr: I'm not drinking anymore; I'm going to sleep."
es: The topic of conversation doesn't displease me, but I deny the beauty part... I'm not drinking anymore!... I'm going to bed!

en: When his host followed him out on the staircase with a candle, to light him down the stairs, the day was coldly looking in through its grimy windows.
vi: When the host escorted Carton all the way to the stairs, holding a candle to light his way down, the cold daylight shone through the dirty windows.
tr: The host, holding a candle, was seeing his guest off down the stairs while the day was coldly peering through the dirty windows.
es: When the owner of the house accompanied Carton to the landing, to light his way with the candle he held in his hand as he descended the stairs, the uncertain glimmers of the new day began to filter through the fogged-up windows.

en: When he got out of the house, the air was cold and sad, the dull sky overcast, the river dark and dim, the whole scene like a lifeless desert.
vi: When he left the house, the weather was bleak and cold, the clouds hung low and gray, the river was dim and gloomy, and the whole scene resembled a dead desert.
tr: When Carton stepped outside, the air was cold and melancholic, the pale sky was cloudy, the river was dark and dim, and the whole scenery resembled a dead desert.
es: Once he reached the street, the jackal was seen breathing a cold and sad atmosphere, under a sky covered with clouds, bordering a river of dark waters and in places that seemed like the desert of life.

en: And wreaths of dust were spinning round and round before the morning blast, as if the desert-sand had risen far away, and the first spray of it in its advance had begun to overwhelm the city.
vi: Dust swirled, swirled like a mourning wreath in the early wind, as if the desert sand had risen in the distance, and the first wave of sand had come to bury the city.
tr: The morning wind was driving clouds of dust before it, swirling them in rings, as if the desert sands from far away had risen, and the first sprinkles from this were already beginning to settle over the entire city.
es: Whirlwinds of dust fled, spinning vertiginously before the morning breeze, as if far, far away, the sands of the desert had taken flight and their first clouds threatened to envelop the city.

en: Waste forces within him, and a desert all around, this man stood still on his way across a silent terrace, and saw for a moment, lying in the wilderness before him, a mirage of honourable ambition, self-denial, and perseverance.
vi: Inner strength exhausted and surrounded by desert, that person stops and stands still on a quiet street corner, suddenly seeing in the desolate expanse ahead the mirage of a lofty aspiration, selfless sacrifice, and steadfast perseverance.
tr: When this man, filled with burnout within and surrounded by this desert, stood for a moment in front of a silent terrace on his path, he saw the void stretching out before his honorable ambitions, dreams filled with self-sacrifice and determination.
es: Lacking internal stimuli to ignite his energies, and placed in the center of an endless wasteland, that man stood upright for a few minutes and saw, in the distant reaches of the desolate and sad steppe that stretched out before his gaze, mirages of noble ambition, reflections of selflessness and perseverance.

en: In the fair city of this vision, there were airy galleries from which the loves and graces looked upon him, gardens in which the fruits of life hung ripening, waters of Hope that sparkled in his sight.
vi: In that beautiful, illusory city are the airy verandas where love and compassion gaze upon him, the gardens where the fruits of life ripen, and the streams where hope sparkles in the eyes.
tr: In this beautiful dream, loves and beauties in the city were looking at him from joyful balconies, the fruits of life were ripening in the gardens, and the waters of Hope were sparkling brightly before his eyes.
es: In the enchanted city that emerged before his eyes, there were lofty galleries from where cherubs and graces smiled at him, beautiful gardens where the sweet fruits of life ripened, and waters of hope that leapt with a murmur.

en: A moment, and it was gone.
vi: Just a moment and the illusion vanished.
tr: Not a minute had passed before it all vanished.
es: The vision faded as quickly as it had appeared.

en: Climbing to a high chamber in a well of houses, he threw himself down in his clothes on a neglected bed, and its pillow was wet with wasted tears.
vi: Climbing up to a high room in a crowded building, he kept his clothes on and threw himself onto the crumpled bed, his pillow soaked with tears of regret.
tr: Climbing to his room at the top through the houses that seemed to accumulate like in a well, he threw himself onto his messy bed with his clothes still on, and his pillow became soaked with tears flowing in vain.
es: A little later, he climbed the steep stairs to his sad room and fell onto the disheveled clothes of his bed.

en: Sadly, sadly, the sun rose; it rose upon no sadder sight than the man of good abilities and good emotions, incapable of their directed exercise, incapable of his own help and his own happiness, sensible of the blight on him, and resigning himself to let it eat him away.
vi: Sadness, sadness, the sun rises; the bright sun illuminates a scene where nothing is more sorrowful than a person full of talent and goodwill who cannot find direction in life, cannot rise to create their own happiness, aware of the impending adversity yet still letting life wither away.
tr: The sun rose sadly; nothing that the sun shone upon was sadder than this man, who was devoid of the ability to use his talents and beautiful feelings, unable to do anything for his own benefit and happiness, moreover, aware of this dreadful state and, at the cost of being consumed by this dreadful state, giving up on himself.
es: His pillow was soaked with tears when a sickly, sad, melancholic sun rose, though not as much as that man of indisputable talent, of great gifts, and yet, incapable of feeling sweet emotions, incapable of navigating the paths of life, incapable of providing himself with well-being, incapable of savoring a drop of happiness, sensitive only to the eternal night in which he struggled and resigned to never leaving it.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Sadness, sadness, the sun rises; the bright sun illuminates a scene where nothing is more sorrowful than a person full of talent and goodwill who cannot find direction in life, cannot rise to create their own happiness, aware of the impending adversity yet still letting life wither away.
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: Hundreds of People
vi: 6. Group after group
tr: Hundreds of People
es: HUNDREDS OF VISITS

en: The quiet lodgings of Doctor Manette were in a quiet street-corner not far from Soho-square.
vi: The quiet house of Dr. Manette was located on a quiet street not far from Soho Square.
tr: Doctor Manette's Quiet House was at the corner of a quiet street just beyond Soho Square.
es: Dr. Manette resided in one of the city's quietest streets, not far from Soho Square.

en: On the afternoon of a certain fine Sunday when the waves of four months had rolled over the trial for treason, and carried it, as to the public interest and memory, far out to sea, mr Jarvis Lorry walked along the sunny streets from Clerkenwell where he lived, on his way to dine with the Doctor.
vi: On a beautiful Sunday afternoon, when the waves of time had swept away the memories of the treason trial four months earlier into the sea of public oblivion, Mr. Jarvis Lorry strolled along the sunlit streets from his home in Clerkenwell to Dr. Manette's house for dinner.
tr: Four months had passed since the treason trial, and the matter had drifted out of the public's interest and memory into the open seas, when Mr. Lorry, on a beautiful Sunday afternoon, walked along the sunny streets from his home in Clerkenwell to dine with the Doctor.
es: On a delightful Sunday afternoon, when the eternal waves of four months had passed over the criminal case for treason, relegating it to oblivion and dragging it out to sea to regions beyond public interest and memory, Mr. Maurice Lorry was striding briskly through the sunlit streets between Clerkenwell, where he lived, and the doctor's house, where he was to dine that evening.

en: After several relapses into business-absorption, mr Lorry had become the Doctor’s friend, and the quiet street-corner was the sunny part of his life.
vi: After several instances of being habitually engrossed in his work, Mr. Lorry had grown close to the doctor, and this quiet corner had become a bright part of his life.
tr: Having come together many times for business, Mr. Lorry and the Doctor had become friends, and that quiet street corner had become a sunny part of his life.
es: It is well for readers to know that Lorry, after several periods of complete withdrawal and total absorption in business, had eventually become an intimate friend of the doctor and saw the quiet street where he lived as the most delightful oasis of his life.

en: On this certain fine Sunday, mr Lorry walked towards Soho, early in the afternoon, for three reasons of habit.
vi: That beautiful Sunday afternoon, Mr. Lorry took a walk to Soho quite early for three familiar reasons.
tr: On this beautiful Sunday, Mr. Lorry had three reasons for making it a habit to walk towards Soho in the afternoon: First, on such lovely Sundays, he would generally go for a walk with the Doctor and Lucie before dinner; Second, on unpleasant Sundays, he had gotten used to spending the whole day with them as a family friend, chatting, reading books, watching outside from the window, in short, spending time with them in this manner; Third, when he had small problems that needed to be resolved in his mind, the Doctor's house was the best place to solve them.
es: Three very important reasons were driving Mr. Lorry, on this delightful Sunday, towards Soho Square in the early afternoon.

en: Firstly, because, on fine Sundays, he often walked out, before dinner, with the Doctor and Lucie; secondly, because, on unfavourable Sundays, he was accustomed to be with them as the family friend, talking, reading, looking out of window, and generally getting through the day; thirdly, because he happened to have his own little shrewd doubts to solve, and knew how the ways of the Doctor’s household pointed to that time as a likely time for solving them.
vi: First, because on beautiful Sunday afternoons, he usually took a walk with the doctor and Lucie before the meal; second, because on Sundays with bad weather, he was accustomed to visiting like a family member, chatting, reading, watching the scenery outside the window, to pass the time; third, because he happened to have a bit of a difficult matter to resolve, and he was so familiar with the doctor's family that he knew this was the best time to think.
tr: On this beautiful Sunday, Mr. Lorry had three reasons for making it a habit to walk towards Soho in the afternoon: First, on such lovely Sundays, he would generally go for a walk with the Doctor and Lucie before dinner; Second, on unpleasant Sundays, he had gotten used to spending the whole day with them as a family friend, chatting, reading books, watching outside from the window, in short, spending time with them in this manner; Third, when he had small problems that needed to be resolved in his mind, the Doctor's house was the best place to solve them.
es: First: because before lunch, he almost always used to go for a walk accompanying the doctor and his daughter Lucia. Second, because on Sunday afternoons, if it was not very pleasant, he would spend it with them, as a family friend, talking, reading, looking out the window, and constantly moving around, and third, because he wanted to resolve some intricate doubts, and he knew that nowhere was it as likely that he would find the solution as in the doctor's house.

en: A quainter corner than the corner where the Doctor lived, was not to be found in London.
vi: In London, there is no street corner better than the corner of Dr. Manette's house.
tr: There was no corner in London stranger than the one where the Doctor lived.
es: There was no more picturesque corner in all of London than the one where the doctor lived.

en: There was no way through it, and the front windows of the Doctor’s lodgings commanded a pleasant little vista of street that had a congenial air of retirement on it.
vi: It is a cul-de-sac, and from the front windows of this house, one can overlook a serene little street that is very suitable for a reclusive lifestyle.
tr: No road passed through there; the front windows of the Doctor's house overlooked a part of the street that had a pleasant air of seclusion.
es: Isolated from the main arteries of the city, there was hardly any traffic, and from the balconies at the front of the house, one could enjoy beautiful views that bore the stamp of tranquility.

en: There were few buildings then, north of the Oxford-road, and forest-trees flourished, and wild flowers grew, and the hawthorn blossomed, in the now vanished fields.
vi: At that time, there were still few houses north of Oxford Street, so tall trees grew like a forest, wildflowers bloomed everywhere, and hawthorn flowers flourished on the vacant lands that are now gone.
tr: At that time, there were very few buildings north of Oxford Road, and everywhere was covered with large trees, overgrown wildflowers, and blooming hawthorns; now, none of those fields remain.
es: The buildings were very scarce, and even more so towards the north of Oxford Road, in whose now vanished expansive fields, delightful groves stood, colorful flowers grew spontaneously, saturating the air with fragrant emanations, and lovely buds sprouted from the white hawthorns and the hawthorns.

en: As a consequence, country airs circulated in Soho with vigorous freedom, instead of languishing into the parish like stray paupers without a settlement; and there was many a good south wall, not far off, on which the peaches ripened in their season.
vi: Therefore, the countryside wind freely rushed into the spacious Soho area, not sluggish like a homeless beggar wandering into the parish*; not far to the south, the peach trees with supports would bear ripe fruit every season.
tr: Later, instead of wandering around like vagrant poor people without a home, this rural air took its freedom and blew freely in Soho; and nearby, there was a beautiful wall where peaches ripened when the season came.
es: As a result, the air circulated freely around Soho, whose inhabitants were not compelled to breathe the mephitic and poisonous atmosphere of the great centers where the poor suffocate and the rich languish. Near the doctor's balconies, there was more than one pear tree, whose fruits ripened in due time.

en: The summer light struck into the corner brilliantly in the earlier part of the day; but, when the streets grew hot, the corner was in shadow, though not in shadow so remote but that you could see beyond it into a glare of brightness.
vi: The summer sun shines on this corner of the street from early morning; but as the roads gradually heat up, this corner remains in the shade, though not so shaded as to be glaring when looking out into the sunlight.
tr: In the early hours of the day, the rays of the summer sun would shine brightly on the corner; but when the streets heated up, a shadow would fall on the corner, though it wasn't a very dense shadow, you could see the brilliance just a bit further away.
es: The rays of the summer sun radiantly penetrated that delightful retreat in the early hours of the day, but when they burned, when they turned the other districts of the city into a scorching oven, the little corner remained enveloped in shadows, although these were not so deep that they couldn't be penetrated by the brilliant glows of a distant sun.

en: It was a cool spot, staid but cheerful, a wonderful place for echoes, and a very harbour from the raging streets.
vi: It is a cool, quiet, yet cheerful place, a perfect spot for reminiscing; truly a haven away from the storms of the city streets.
tr: It was a cool corner, dignified yet cheerful, a wonderful place for the echoing of sounds, like a harbor to escape and take refuge from the angry streets.
es: It was, in a word, a cool, calm, and tranquil place, yet pleasant, a sheltered harbor against the roar and bustling agitation of the streets.

en: There ought to have been a tranquil bark in such an anchorage, and there was.
vi: In such a harbor, there must be a peaceful ship to shelter, and indeed there was.
tr: There must have been a calm ship anchored in such a harbor, and indeed there was.
es: An ideal anchorage was inconceivable without a tranquil boat, and indeed, it had one.

en: The Doctor occupied two floors of a large stiff house, where several callings purported to be pursued by day, but whereof little was audible any day, and which was shunned by all of them at night.
vi: Dr. Manette's house occupied two floors in a large, solid building, surrounded by many professional establishments during the day, though hardly a sound was heard, and at night, all was quiet.
tr: The doctor had settled on the two floors of a large and quiet house; many visitors came and went throughout the day, but they made little noise, and at night, not a sound was heard.
es: The doctor occupied two floors of a rather spacious house, at whose doors many knocked during the night, requesting services to be rendered the following day.

en: In a building at the back, attainable by a courtyard where a plane-tree rustled its green leaves, church-organs claimed to be made, and silver to be chased, and likewise gold to be beaten by some mysterious giant who had a golden arm starting out of the wall of the front hall—as if he had beaten himself precious, and menaced a similar conversion of all visitors.
vi: Across a courtyard rustling with the sound of sycamore leaves was a house with a shop inside that made church organs, silverware, and even gilding; on the wall of this house, right in front of the main door, instead of a signboard, there was a large golden arm symbol, as if some mysterious giant inside had gilded his entire body and thrust his arm out to the street, threatening to turn all passersby into precious metals.
tr: It was said that a church organ was being made, silver was being crafted, and gold was being hammered by a mysterious giant figure in a building at the back, reached through a courtyard with a plane tree rustling its green leaves; the man had hung a golden arm on the wall of the entrance hall as if he had forged himself out of gold, thus intimidating the visitors.
