es: At the back of the house, separated from it by a courtyard in the center of which grew a wild banana tree, there was a building where church organs were manufactured, and a mysterious giant chiseled silver and hammered gold, whose powerful arm seemed to emerge from the wall, casting golden flashes, as if the arm itself were made of gold and threatened to turn into gold all those who visited that place.

en: Very little of these trades, or of a lonely lodger rumoured to live up-stairs, or of a dim coach-trimming maker asserted to have a counting-house below, was ever heard or seen.
vi: Rarely were the faces or voices of these craftsmen seen or heard, nor those of the lodger rumored to live upstairs, or the dark-faced fellow who upholstered carriage seats and insisted he had a shop on the ground floor.
tr: No one had ever seen or heard of the solitary tenant said to live upstairs, or the thick-headed car decorator who was claimed to have an accounting office downstairs.
es: Hardly did these industries make the slightest noise, very rarely was a solitary visitor seen arriving, and even more rarely did a carriage cross those peaceful spots.

en: Occasionally, a stray workman putting his coat on, traversed the hall, or a stranger peered about there, or a distant clink was heard across the courtyard, or a thump from the golden giant.
vi: Occasionally, a stray worker in a coat would pass through the hall, or a stranger would appear, occasionally the faint clinking sound could be heard from across the courtyard, or the thumping of the golden giant.
tr: Occasionally, a stray worker would don his jacket and pace from one corner of the courtyard to the other; sometimes a stranger would be seen, and sometimes there would be a clatter from somewhere beyond the courtyard or thumping sounds from the giant man hammering gold.
es: It was true that from time to time a worker could be seen crossing the courtyard while putting on his jacket, or an unknown person drawn by curiosity, or the distant echo of a hammer blow from the golden giant would strike the ears, but these were the only exceptions, always necessary to prove the rule that this was the corner of echoes, the center of rest and silence, interrupted only by the chirping of sparrows that had their headquarters in the top of the wild banana tree.

en: These, however, were only the exceptions required to prove the rule that the sparrows in the plane-tree behind the house, and the echoes in the corner before it, had their own way from Sunday morning unto Saturday night.
vi: But these were exceptions that proved the rule that from Sunday morning to Saturday night, the place was dominated by the birds in the sycamore trees behind the house and the quiet echoes of the street corner in front.
tr: But these were merely exceptions that emphasized the rule that the sparrows perched on the plane tree behind the house and the echoes heard from the corner dominated this place from Sunday morning to Saturday night.
es: It was true that from time to time a worker could be seen crossing the courtyard while putting on his jacket, or an unknown person drawn by curiosity, or the distant echo of a hammer blow from the golden giant would strike the ears, but these were the only exceptions, always necessary to prove the rule that this was the corner of echoes, the center of rest and silence, interrupted only by the chirping of sparrows that had their headquarters in the top of the wild banana tree.

en: Doctor Manette received such patients here as his old reputation, and its revival in the floating whispers of his story, brought him.
vi: This is where Doctor Manette received a few patients who came to him due to his former reputation, which has now been restored thanks to rumors spreading about his imprisonment.
tr: Doctor Manette had gained many patients thanks to his old fame and the refreshing of this fame through a story passed from mouth to mouth.
es: The doctor Manette received in his house the patients brought to him by his former reputation combined with the floating breezes of the painful history of his life.

en: His scientific knowledge, and his vigilance and skill in conducting ingenious experiments, brought him otherwise into moderate request, and he earned as much as he wanted.
vi: His professional knowledge, along with his meticulousness and ability to conduct skillful experiments, also brought in more work, allowing the doctor to make a living.
tr: His scientific equipment and the caution and skill in his successful works also brought other patients to his door, allowing him to earn as much money as he wanted.
es: His scientific knowledge, his practice in the difficult exercise of his profession, and the ingenious experiments he engaged in, gave him a very enviable clientele and he earned more than enough to cover the necessities of life.

en: These things were within mr Jarvis Lorry’s knowledge, thoughts, and notice, when he rang the door-bell of the tranquil house in the corner, on the fine Sunday afternoon.
vi: These understandings, thoughts, and observations occupied Mr. Jarvis Lorry's mind as he rang the doorbell of the quiet house on this corner street on a beautiful Sunday afternoon.
tr: Mr. Jarvis Lorry had these thoughts in mind when he knocked on the door of this quiet house on the corner on that beautiful Sunday.
es: All this was perfectly known to the good Mauricio Lorry when he pulled the chain hanging along the door, and set in motion the inhabitants of the quiet house located in the delightful little corner I just described, on a Sunday afternoon.

en: “Doctor Manette at home?”
vi: − Is Dr. Manette home?
tr: "Is Dr. Manette at home?"
es: —Is the doctor at home?

en: Expected home.
vi: He is about to come home.
tr: He was going to arrive soon.
es: —No, sir.

en: “Miss Lucie at home?”
vi: − Is Miss Lucie home?
tr: "Is Miss Lucie at home?"
es: —And Miss Lucía?

en: Expected home.
vi: She is about to come home.
tr: He/She was going to arrive soon.
es: —Neither.

en: “Miss Pross at home?”
vi: − Is Miss Pross at home?
tr: "Well, is Miss Pross at home?"
es: —And Miss Pross?

en: Possibly at home, but of a certainty impossible for handmaid to anticipate intentions of Miss Pross, as to admission or denial of the fact.
vi: Probably, but the maid couldn't possibly know Miss Pross's intentions, so she neither denied nor confirmed.
tr: Most likely, she was at home, but he couldn't decide whether Miss Pross would want it to be said that she was at home or not.
es: Probably the latter was at home, but since the maid who opened the door did not know what her intentions were regarding admitting or denying the fact, she also replied that she was not.

en: “As I am at home myself,” said mr Lorry, “I’ll go upstairs.”
vi: − Because this is like my home too, I will go upstairs, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Well, since I'm here," said Mr. Lorry, "I'll go upstairs and take a look then."
es: —In any case, I'm going up—replied Lorry,—because I consider myself here as at home.

en: Although the Doctor’s daughter had known nothing of the country of her birth, she appeared to have innately derived from it that ability to make much of little means, which is one of its most useful and most agreeable characteristics.
vi: Though the doctor's daughter knew nothing about her native country, she seemed to have inherently inherited from her father's homeland the ability to adapt maximally under minimal conditions - one of the most useful and admirable traits of the French.
tr: Although the Doctor's daughter knew nothing about the country she was born in, she seemed to have an innate ability to do a lot with the little she had, which was one of the most useful and pleasant characteristics of this country.
es: Although the doctor's daughter learned nothing in her homeland, it is certain that it initiated her into that rare skill of doing much with scarce means, which was one of her most precious and pleasant characteristics.

en: Simple as the furniture was, it was set off by so many little adornments, of no value but for their taste and fancy, that its effect was delightful.
vi: The furniture in the house, though simple, was compensated by many small decorative items that, while not valuable, were elegant and pleasing to the eye, making them very interesting.
tr: The furniture was simple, but there were many decorative items around; they were not valuable, but the taste and elegance they reflected left a pleasant impression.
es: Modest and simple was the furniture in the house's rooms, and yet, some trinkets, which had no more real value than the exquisite taste with which they were placed, gave them a delightful effect.

en: The disposition of everything in the rooms, from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours, the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as mr Lorry stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him, with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this time, whether he approved?
vi: The arrangement of everything in the rooms, from the largest to the smallest items; the combination of colors, the subtle contrasts and diversity achieved by making the most of inexpensive items, thanks to skillful hands, a keen eye, and aesthetic sense, attracted the eye while revealing the person who created this setting to such an extent that, when Mr. Lorry looked around, it seemed as if the tables and chairs were silently asking with the same distinctive expression as the familiar wrinkles on Lucie's forehead: Are you satisfied?
tr: The arrangement of the items in the rooms, from the largest to the smallest; the harmony of colors, the delicate variety of small items, and the contrasts they created revealed sensitive hands, tasteful eyes, and a refined appreciation; thus, everything looked very pleasant and also reflected the person who brought them together; so much so that as Mr. Lorry stood looking around, all those tables and chairs seemed to come to life, asking him whether he liked them with their familiar expressions that he had grown accustomed to.
es: The arrangement of everything in the house, starting with the largest piece of furniture and ending with the most insignificant object, the combination of colors, and the contrast achieved thanks to trifles by delicate hands, clear-eyed gazes, and impeccable taste, offered such a pleasant ensemble in itself and portrayed its author so graphically, that it seemed as if, with a silent but eloquent language, they asked Mr. Lorry, while he gazed at them in rapture, if they deserved his approval.

en: There were three rooms on a floor, and, the doors by which they communicated being put open that the air might pass freely through them all, mr Lorry, smilingly observant of that fanciful resemblance which he detected all around him, walked from one to another.
vi: Each floor of the house had three rooms, with the doors wide open to let the fresh air in, and as Mr. Lorry moved from room to room, he delighted in noticing the resemblance between the furniture and the owner evident all around.
tr: There were three rooms on one floor, and the doors connecting them were left open to allow air to pass through easily; Mr. Lorry watched this pleasant harmony surrounding him with a smile and walked from one room to another.
es: The apartment had three main rooms, whose connecting doors were all open, so that the air could circulate through them like lords and masters. Lorry passed from one to another, smiling and pleased.

en: The first was the best room, and in it were Lucie’s birds, and flowers, and books, and desk, and work-table, and box of water-colours; the second was the Doctor’s consulting-room, used also as the dining-room; the third, changingly speckled by the rustle of the plane-tree in the yard, was the Doctor’s bedroom, and there, in a corner, stood the disused shoemaker’s bench and tray of tools, much as it had stood on the fifth floor of the dismal house by the wine-shop, in the suburb of Saint Antoine in Paris.
vi: The first room was the most beautiful, containing Lucie's belongings such as a birdcage, vases, books, a writing desk, a sewing table, and a watercolor box; the second room was the doctor's consulting room, which also served as the dining room; the third room was the doctor's bedroom, where sunlight spots continuously danced through the rustling branches of the plane tree outside, and here, in a corner, was the shoemaker's bench and untouched tool tray, just as it had been placed on the fifth floor of the eerie house next to the tavern in the suburbs of Saint Antoine in Paris.
tr: The first room was the most beautiful, containing Lucie's birds, flowers, books, easel, desk, and watercolor sets; the second was the Doctor's consultation room, which also served as the dining room; the third room, with its dappled shadows shifting according to the rustling leaves of the plane tree in the courtyard, was the Doctor's bedroom. In one corner of this room stood the shoemaker's bench and tool box, now unused, just as they had stood on the fifth floor of the gloomy house next to the wine shop in a side street of St. Antoine in Paris.
es: In the first room, which was the best, Lucía had her birds, her books, a writing desk, and a sewing box, as well as a box of colors; the second room was the doctor's consultation room, which also served as a dining room, and the third room, near whose balconies the leaves of the wild plane tree growing in the courtyard whispered, was the doctor's bedroom, in one of whose corners Lorry saw the cobbler's bench and tools, just as they had once been in the attic of the tavern in the San Antonio neighborhood of Paris.

en: “I wonder,” said mr Lorry, pausing in his looking about, “that he keeps that reminder of his sufferings about him!”
vi: His eyes stopped at that bench, Mr. Lorry said to himself: − Why does he keep this? To remember those painful times?
tr: Mr. Lorry paused for a moment and said to himself, "Why does this man keep these items that remind him of his past sufferings?""
es: —It surprises me—murmured Lorry in a clear and intelligible voice—that he keeps these objects which must necessarily remind him of his sufferings and miseries.

en: “And why wonder at that?” was the abrupt inquiry that made him start.
vi: − Understand for what? - The sudden question startled him.
tr: "Why are you surprised?" came a reply, causing Mr. Lorry to startle.
es: —And why should it surprise you?—asked a brusque voice suddenly, causing him to turn around quickly.

en: It proceeded from Miss Pross, the wild red woman, strong of hand, whose acquaintance he had first made at the Royal George Hotel at Dover, and had since improved.
vi: It was the voice of Miss Pross, the strong-armed, red-haired woman he had first met at the Royal George Hotel in Dover, who had since become familiar.
tr: This was the crazy Miss Pross with the very strong hands, whom he first met at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and later saw in other settings, with red hair.
es: The voice originated from Miss Pross's throat, who was the same red-faced, strong, and heavy-handed woman with whom Lorry became acquainted at the Hotel George in Dover.

en: “I should have thought—” mr Lorry began.
vi: - I thought... - Mr. Lorry began.
tr: "I should have guessed," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —I imagined...—Lorry began to say.

en: “Pooh!
vi: − Shh! Nonsense!
tr: "Amen!
es: —It seemed to her... what?—replied Miss Pross.—Some nonsense, no doubt!

en: You’d have thought!” said Miss Pross; and mr Lorry left off.
vi: - Miss Pross exclaimed and Mr. Lorry left his sentence unfinished. - How are you? -
tr: He should have guessed!" said Miss Pross, and Mr. Lorry gave up continuing the conversation.
es: Lorry did not answer.

en: “How do you do?” inquired that lady then—sharply, and yet as if to express that she bore him no malice.
vi: She continued, her tone gruff but clearly without any ill will towards him.
tr: "How are you?" the woman asked then – harshly but with an air that seemed to try to show she had no grudge against him.
es: —How are you?—asked the lady then, with a harsh voice, though without malice or intent to offend.

en: “I am pretty well, I thank you,” answered mr Lorry, with meekness; “how are you?”
vi: − Thank you, I am very well, - Mr. Lorry replied, humbly, - and how are you? −
tr: "Thank you, I am quite well," replied Mr. Lorry in a feeble voice, "How are you?" he asked.
es: —Very well, thank you... and you?

en: “Nothing to boast of,” said Miss Pross.
vi: It's a miserable life, - Ms. Pross replied.
tr: "There is nothing noteworthy," said Miss Pross.
es: —As discontent as can be.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? − Ah!
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Is it possible?

en: “Ah! indeed!” said Miss Pross.
vi: Of course, really!
tr: "Ah! So!" said Miss Pross. "I am very worried about my little bird."
es: —And very possible!

en: “I am very much put out about my Ladybird.”
vi: - said Miss Pross. - I'm quite upset about our dear mistress here.
tr: "Ah! So!" said Miss Pross. "I am very worried about my little bird."
es: What happens with Miss Lucía drives me crazy.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? −
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Is it possible? —But man of God!

en: “For gracious sake say something else besides ‘indeed,’ or you’ll fidget me to death,” said Miss Pross: whose character (dissociated from stature) was shortness.
vi: For heaven's sake, say something else instead of "really," you're driving me crazy, - Miss Pross, tall in stature but short on patience.
tr: "For God's sake, say something other than 'really' or I'll go mad," said Miss Pross; her character (unlike her stature) was somewhat stunted.
es: Haven't you learned more than those two words that you keep saying at every turn?

en: “Really, then?” said mr Lorry, as an amendment.
vi: − Oh, really? - Mr. Lorry adjusted.
tr: "Shall I say it correctly then," Mr. Lorry corrected.
es: Is it possible!... A little variation, if you don't want to drive me completely crazy! —Really?—asked Lorry, correcting himself.

en: “Really, is bad enough,” returned Miss Pross, “but better.
vi: − "Is that so," it's not great, - Miss Pross replied, - but it's better than nothing.
tr: "My health is not very good," replied Miss Pross, "but it is still better than the other one.
es: —It's not the happiest phrase, so to speak, but, in the end, it's better than his eternal "could it be possible."

en: Yes, I am very much put out.”
vi: That's right, I'm quite annoyed myself.
tr: Yes, I am very upset."
es: Well, yes, sir; what happens with the young lady drives me crazy.

en: “May I ask the cause?”
vi: − May I ask the reason?
tr: "May I ask the reason then?"
es: —Would it be indiscreet to ask the reason?

en: “I don’t want dozens of people who are not at all worthy of Ladybird, to come here looking after her,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − − I don't like a bunch of unworthy people coming here to gawk at the dear mistress, - said Miss Pross.
tr: "I don't want dozens of people who are not worthy of her to come here to see her," said Miss Pross.
es: —It gets on my nerves that dozens of people who are not worthy of her come to see her.

en: “Do dozens come for that purpose?”
vi: − A dozen people came to gawk?
tr: "Are dozens of people coming to see him?"
es: —Dozens?—asked Lorry in amazement.

en: “Hundreds,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Hundreds, actually, - replied Miss Pross.
tr: "Hundreds!" said Miss Pross.
es: —Hundreds—replied Miss Pross, one of whose characteristics, which is often seen in many people, was to exaggerate the original statement if she noticed that someone was questioning it.

en: It was characteristic of this lady (as of some other people before her time and since) that whenever her original proposition was questioned, she exaggerated it.
vi: Like many others before and after her, she had a habit of immediately exaggerating her claims when someone doubted them.
tr: One characteristic of Miss Pross (as with many people before and after her) was that when a word she said was scrutinized, she would exaggerate it.
es: —Hundreds—replied Miss Pross, one of whose characteristics, which is often seen in many people, was to exaggerate the original statement if she noticed that someone was questioning it.

en: “Dear me!” said mr Lorry, as the safest remark he could think of.
vi: − Poor thing! - That was the safest remark Mr. Lorry could think of.
tr: "Phooey!" said Mr. Lorry, this was the safest word that came to his mind.
es: —Good heavens! —exclaimed Lorry, who couldn't think of a more appropriate response.

en: “I have lived with the darling—or the darling has lived with me, and paid me for it; which she certainly should never have done, you may take your affidavit, if I could have afforded to keep either myself or her for nothing—since she was ten years old.
vi: − I have lived with the mistress... - Miss Pross chattered on, - or the mistress has lived with me and paid for my living since she was ten; indeed, the mistress should never have paid me, I swear to you, if only I could support myself or support her without needing a salary.
tr: "I have been living with my little one since he was ten years old, or rather, my little one has been living with me since he was ten and he pays me for it; actually, he shouldn't have to do that, I have tried to manage both myself and him all this time.
es: —Since the young lady was ten years old, I have lived with her... or she has lived with me, and she has paid me, which I would never have allowed, rest assured, if I had found the secret of taking care of myself and her for nothing.

en: And it’s really very hard,” said Miss Pross.
vi: It's really too hard!
tr: This is really very hard," said Miss Pross.
es: Oh! It is truly painful!

en: Not seeing with precision what was very hard, mr Lorry shook his head; using that important part of himself as a sort of fairy cloak that would fit anything.
vi: Not understanding exactly what was too hard, Mr. Lorry could only shake his head, using that important body part as a magical mask capable of expressing all emotions.
tr: Even though Mr. Lorry did not fully understand what the difficult thing was, he shook his head from side to side, as if he were using this important part of his body like a kind of magical cloak that fits every situation.
es: Lorry, not clearly seeing what could be painful, limited himself to shaking his head, using that part of his person as the most suitable cover to hide everything. —At all hours, countless people who are not worthy of my treasure, Mr. Lorry, hover around him.

en: “All sorts of people who are not in the least degree worthy of the pet, are always turning up,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − A whole bunch of people who aren't worthy at all of the dear mistress keep showing up, - said Miss Pross. -
tr: "There are a lot of people around my beautiful child who are not her equals," said Miss Pross.
es: No, they are not, not by a long shot!

en: “When you began it—”
vi: Ever since he caused the trouble...
tr: "When you started this..."
es: When you started the parade...

en: “I began it, Miss Pross?”
vi: − Did I cause this, Miss Pross? −
tr: "Did I start this, Miss Pross?"
es: —Did I start it, Miss Pross?

en: “Didn’t you?
vi: Who else?
tr: "Didn't you start it?"
es: —Of course!

en: Who brought her father to life?”
vi: Who brought the master’s father back to life? −
tr: "Who brought his father back to life?""
es: Who took his father out of the grave?

en: “Oh!
vi: Oh!
tr: "Ha!
es: —If that was the beginning...

en: If that was beginning it—” said mr Lorry.
vi: If that was caused by me then... - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: If this is what started it," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —If that was the beginning...

en: “It wasn’t ending it, I suppose?
vi: − So it hasn't ended yet, is that what you mean?
tr: "This wasn't the end, was it?
es: —I suppose you do not mean to say that was the end of it... I repeat that when the parade began, it was already quite unpleasant.

en: I say, when you began it, it was hard enough; not that I have any fault to find with Doctor Manette, except that he is not worthy of such a daughter, which is no imputation on him, for it was not to be expected that anybody should be, under any circumstances.
vi: Let me tell you, when you caused the trouble, it was already bad enough; it's not that I'm blaming Dr. Manette, it's just that he doesn't deserve to have such a daughter, and this isn't his fault either, because in this situation, how could anyone know who deserves what.
tr: I mean, when you started this job, it was already hard enough; I'm not saying anything about finding Doctor Manette, of course, but such a daughter is not worthy of him, in my opinion. Still, I'm not blaming her because, under these circumstances, no one can be expected to be guilty.
es: And note that it is not my intention to say that Dr. Manette is to blame, in whom I see no other fault than not being worthy of having a daughter like the one he has, and that is not attributable to him, since there is no person in the world who is worthy of it.

en: But it really is doubly and trebly hard to have crowds and multitudes of people turning up after him (I could have forgiven him), to take Ladybird’s affections away from me.”
vi: But it's twice, three times as painful when wave after wave of people keep coming to see the doctor; well, I can overlook him; just to end up taking away my beloved mistress.
tr: But for people to come to the Doctor in droves (I could forgive her for that) and try to steal my little bird's love from me is unbearable."
es: I might have been able to forgive the father, but admit that it is horribly painful to see crowds and swarms of people constantly moving around the father and stealing the affection of the daughter from me.

en: mr Lorry knew Miss Pross to be very jealous, but he also knew her by this time to be, beneath the service of her eccentricity, one of those unselfish creatures—found only among women—who will, for pure love and admiration, bind themselves willing slaves, to youth when they have lost it, to beauty that they never had, to accomplishments that they were never fortunate enough to gain, to bright hopes that never shone upon their own sombre lives.
vi: Mr. Lorry knew that Miss Pross had a very jealous nature, but by now he also understood that beneath this peculiar exterior was a person who was not at all self-centered—a trait only seen in women—who, out of love and admiration, would willingly become a slave to the youth she had lost, to the beauty she never possessed, to the achievements she unfortunately never attained, and to the bright hopes that never once shone into her own bleak life.
tr: Mr. Lorry knew how jealous Miss Pross could be, but he also knew the self-sacrificing creature that lay beneath all that eccentricity – a type only seen among women; these individuals would attach themselves with pure love and admiration, like slaves, to the youth they had lost, the beauty they never possessed, the skills they were never fortunate enough to acquire, and the bright hopes that would never shine upon their own gloomy lives.
es: Lorry knew that Miss Pross was the embodiment of jealousy, but at the same time, he was aware that, aside from her eccentricities, she was at the forefront of those pure beings devoid of all selfishness who, driven by motives of affection and admiration, willingly offer their necks to the chain of slavery, ready to sacrifice themselves for a youth they have lost, a beauty they never possessed, gifts and perfections they never had the fortune to attain, and hopeful dreams that never shed a ray of light on their somber lives.

en: He knew enough of the world to know that there is nothing in it better than the faithful service of the heart; so rendered and so free from any mercenary taint, he had such an exalted respect for it, that in the retributive arrangements made by his own mind—we all make such arrangements, more or less—he stationed Miss Pross much nearer to the lower Angels than many ladies immeasurably better got up both by Nature and Art, who had balances at Tellson’s.
vi: He understood life well enough to know that nothing surpasses the loyal service that comes from the heart, devoted and free from any self-interest, to the extent that he had to respect Miss Pross. In the mental hierarchy of respect he had arranged in his mind—which we all do to some extent—he awarded her a position close to the angels, far above many ladies of superior social standing, education, and with money deposited at Tellson's Bank.
tr: Mr. Lorry was worldly enough to know that there was nothing better than this loyal service given from the heart; he knew it was free from any material gain, and he held these individuals in great respect, so much so that in the vengeful plans he concocted in his mind – we all concoct these plans to some extent – he placed Miss Pross in much more favorable positions compared to those ladies who had accounts at Tellson's Bank and were abundantly endowed by both Nature and Art.
es: Lorry had a sufficiently perfect understanding of the world to know that nothing compares to the faithful and selfless services that reside in the heart, and consequently, Miss Pross's services earned his highest respect. In the mental classifications he made, for no one fails to make them, in greater or lesser numbers, he placed the red-haired and efficient lady much closer to the last rung of the angels than to many ladies who were incomparably better endowed than she, both by Nature and by Art, and who, in addition, possessed capitals deposited in the vaults of Tellson's Bank.

en: “There never was, nor will be, but one man worthy of Ladybird,” said Miss Pross; “and that was my brother Solomon, if he hadn’t made a mistake in life.”
vi: − Before or after, it has always been the same, there is only one person who truly deserves the beloved mistress, - said Miss Pross. - That is my brother Solomon, if only his life had not made mistakes.
tr: "No one has ever been worthy of my little bird, nor will anyone ever be, except for one person," said Miss Pross; "and that was my brother Solomon, but he made the mistake of his life."
es: —There has never been, nor will there ever be, a man worthy of the young lady—said Miss Pross. —That man was my brother Solomon... if he hadn't had a little slip in life.

en: Here again: mr Lorry’s inquiries into Miss Pross’s personal history had established the fact that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who had stripped her of everything she possessed, as a stake to speculate with, and had abandoned her in her poverty for evermore, with no touch of compunction.
vi: Additionally: Mr. Lorry had investigated Miss Pross's past and confirmed that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who had stripped his sister of all her assets to use as capital for speculation, leaving her to live in poverty for the rest of her life without a shred of remorse.
tr: The issue was this: as Mr. Lorry questioned Miss Pross, it became clear that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who squandered her possessions in gambling and left her in perpetual poverty without any remorse.
es: An observation: the investigations carried out by Lorry regarding Miss Pross's personal history had resulted in the discovery and verification of the fact that her brother Solomon was a miserable scoundrel who stole everything she owned under the pretext of speculating and trading, then left her abandoned in her misery without a shred of remorse.

en: Miss Pross’s fidelity of belief in Solomon (deducting a mere trifle for this slight mistake) was quite a serious matter with mr Lorry, and had its weight in his good opinion of her.
vi: It was because Miss Pross had unwavering faith in Solomon (considering his minor faults as trivial) that Mr. Lorry respected and always thought well of her.
tr: Mr. Lorry was deeply affected by the strength of Miss Pross's faith in Solomon (seeing his minor mistake as a small flaw), and her value in his eyes increased significantly.
es: The high opinion that Miss Pross had of her brother, despite his small slip, was a source of profound admiration for Mr. Lorry and contributed to greatly increasing the respect he felt for her.

en: “As we happen to be alone for the moment, and are both people of business,” he said, when they had got back to the drawing-room and had sat down there in friendly relations, “let me ask you—does the Doctor, in talking with Lucie, never refer to the shoemaking time, yet?”
vi: − By the way, now it's just you and me, and we are both people of work, - he said when they had returned to the living room and were chatting amicably. - I ask you... did the doctor, when talking to Lucie, ever mention the time he made shoes? −
tr: When they went to the living room and sat down facing each other, Mr. Lorry said, "Now that we are alone and both of us are doing business here, with your permission, I will ask you a question – Doctor, when talking to Lucie, does he ever mention the days he spent making shoes?"
es: —Since we find ourselves alone at this moment, and we are both business people—said Lorry when, moments later, they had both sat down in the parlor,—I will allow myself to ask you a question: In the conversations that the doctor has with his daughter, does he ever refer to the times when he made shoes?

en: “Never.”
vi: Not at all.
tr: "Never.""
es: —Never.

en: “And yet keeps that bench and those tools beside him?”
vi: − Does he still keep that bench with the tools next to him?
tr: "But he still keeps his old bench and tools."
es: —And yet, he keeps the stool and the tools of the trade in his room.

en: “Ah!” returned Miss Pross, shaking her head.
vi: − Oh! - Miss Pross replied, shaking her head.
tr: "Ah!" said Miss Pross, shaking her head.
es: —I have said that he never talks about it with his daughter—replied Miss Pross,—but I will be very careful not to assert that he does not talk to himself about it.

en: “But I don’t say he don’t refer to it within himself.”
vi: - But I didn't say that he doesn't remind himself silently.
tr: "I didn't say she had forgotten those days, though."
es: —I have said that he never talks about it with his daughter—replied Miss Pross,—but I will be very careful not to assert that he does not talk to himself about it.

en: “Do you believe that he thinks of it much?”
vi: − Do you think he thinks a lot about that?
tr: "Do you think he often thinks about those days?"
es: —Do you think he/she thinks about it often?

en: “I do,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Yes, - replied Ms. Pross.
tr: "I think he's thinking," said Miss Pross.
es: —Yes.

en: “Do you imagine—” mr Lorry had begun, when Miss Pross took him up short with:
vi: − So, can you imagine... - Mr. Lorry had just started to speak when Miss Pross interrupted him.
tr: Mr. Lorry had just begun to say, "Well, imagine that..." when Miss Pross interrupted him.
es: —Can you imagine?...

en: “Never imagine anything.
vi: − Imagining things again!
tr: "Never dream.
es: —I never imagine!

en: Have no imagination at all.”
vi: I never imagine anything at all.
tr: Never have an imagination."
es: —exclaimed Miss Pross, interrupting her interlocutor. —I have no imagination, nor do I need it.

en: “I stand corrected; do you suppose—you go so far as to suppose, sometimes?”
vi: − I was wrong; do you suppose that... ah, surely you must suppose something occasionally?
tr: - "Well, let me correct myself; do you think –you probably have no objection to thinking?"
es: —I will correct myself... Do you suppose... do you sometimes go so far as to suppose?

en: “Now and then,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Occasionally, - said Miss Pross.
tr: "It can happen from time to time," said Miss Pross.
es: —From time to time, yes.

en: “Do you suppose,” mr Lorry went on, with a laughing twinkle in his bright eye, as it looked kindly at her, “that Doctor Manette has any theory of his own, preserved through all those years, relative to the cause of his being so oppressed; perhaps, even to the name of his oppressor?”
vi: − Did you suppose, - Mr. Lorry continued, his eyes sparkling with joy as he looked at her appreciatively, - that Dr. Manette might know something about the reason for his oppression, even the name of his oppressor, and that he has kept it secret all these years?
tr: Mr. Lorry continued, turning his gaze, which was shining with a cheerful glow, affectionately towards Miss Pross. "Do you think that Dr. Manette has any idea about the reason for the suffering he endured for so many years, or perhaps even knows the name of the tyrant who brought him to this state?"
es: —Well then, do you suppose that Dr. Manette harbors any suspicion... or certainty, that has survived his past miseries, about the cause, the motives of his misfortune? Do you perhaps suppose that he even suspects or knows who his oppressor was?

en: “I don’t suppose anything about it but what Ladybird tells me.”
vi: − I don't suppose anything about this, but the dear mistress told me exactly the same.
tr: "Sanmam, ama yavru kuşumun dediğine göre..."
es: —I don't assume anything more than what the young lady tells me.

en: “And that is—?”
vi: − Meaning...? −
tr: "What is he/she saying?""
es: —And the young lady says...

en: “That she thinks he has.”
vi: It means the lady thinks he knows.
tr: "He thinks his father knows.""
es: —That he believes his father suspects or knows.

en: “Now don’t be angry at my asking all these questions; because I am a mere dull man of business, and you are a woman of business.”
vi: − Don't get angry when I ask these questions; because I am just a clumsy worker, while you are the person of the job.
tr: "Don't be mad at me for asking these things; after all, I'm a thick-headed businessman, and you're such a businesswoman.""
es: —Don't get upset if I ask you these questions. I am a businessman, quite obtuse, and you are a businesswoman.

en: “Dull?” Miss Pross inquired, with placidity.
vi: − Clumsy? - Miss Pross calmly asked back.
tr: "Thick-headed?" asked Miss Pross calmly.
es: —Obtuse?—inquired Miss Pross.

en: Rather wishing his modest adjective away, mr Lorry replied, “No, no, no.
vi: − No, no, no, - Mr. Lorry wanted to remove that modest adjective.
tr: Mr. Lorry responded, trying to dismiss this modest adjective, "No, no.
es: —No, no, no! —replied Lorry.

en: Surely not.
vi: - Certainly not.
tr: Of course not.
es: —You are not obtuse at all!

en: To return to business:—Is it not remarkable that Doctor Manette, unquestionably innocent of any crime as we are all well assured he is, should never touch upon that question?
vi: Alright, let's get back to work... Are you surprised that Dr. Manette never mentioned it, even though it's clear he didn't commit any crime, as we all know for sure?
tr: Returning to our matter, don't you find it strange that Doctor Manette, whom we all undoubtedly agree is innocent, has never brought up this subject?
es: But returning to the matter, allow me to ask: isn't it strange, incomprehensible, that Dr. Manette, innocent of any crime as we all know, always avoids touching on that issue with such care?

en: I will not say with me, though he had business relations with me many years ago, and we are now intimate; I will say with the fair daughter to whom he is so devotedly attached, and who is so devotedly attached to him?
vi: It's not necessary for the doctor to tell me, even though he and I have had a working relationship for many years and are now friends; I mean to tell his lovely daughter whom the doctor loves very much and who also loves her father?
tr: Despite having a professional relationship years ago and being quite close now, he hasn't mentioned it to me, let alone to his beautiful daughter, to whom he is deeply attached with mutual affection.
es: And it's not that I am surprised he doesn't bring it up with me, even though we had frequent business relations years ago and today we share a close friendship, but I am amazed that he doesn't talk about it with his daughter, who loves him so much and whom he adores...

en: Believe me, Miss Pross, I don’t approach the topic with you, out of curiosity, but out of zealous interest.”
vi: Believe me, Miss Pross, I bring this up not out of curiosity but out of deep concern for the doctor.
tr: Believe me, Miss Pross, the reason I'm bringing this up is not curiosity, but genuine concern."
es: Believe me, Miss Pross, it is not curiosity that dictates my words, but the deep affection I feel for the inhabitants of this house.

en: “Well!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Beautiful!
es: —Well then, as I believe... and when I believe something, I usually get close to reality, keep that silence that so amazes you because you are afraid to talk about the matter.

en: To the best of my understanding, and bad’s the best, you’ll tell me,” said Miss Pross, softened by the tone of the apology, “he is afraid of the whole subject.”
vi: The thing I know best, though not very well, you see, - said Ms. Pross in a lowered voice as if to justify herself, - is that the doctor is afraid of this whole matter.
tr: As far as I understand, as far as my mind comprehends," said Miss Pross, softened by Mr. Lorry's conciliatory manner of speaking, "the Doctor is afraid of this matter."
es: —Well then, as I believe... and when I believe something, I usually get close to reality, keep that silence that so amazes you because you are afraid to talk about the matter.

en: “Afraid?”
vi: − Afraid? −
tr: "Is he/she/it scared?"
es: —Fear?

en: “It’s plain enough, I should think, why he may be.
vi: It's an understandable reason, I think so.
tr: "I think this is a very understandable situation.
es: —It is clear as day, and I also find the fear very justified.

en: It’s a dreadful remembrance.
vi: It's a terribly horrifying reminder.
tr: He has a terrible past.
es: They are horrifying memories, not only because of what he suffered, but also because in his suffering his intelligence was shipwrecked.

en: Besides that, his loss of himself grew out of it.
vi: Moreover, he lost his memory because of that incident.
tr: Moreover, he lost his memory because of this.
es: Since he does not know how and when he lost it, and how and when he regained it, it is natural that he fears losing it again.

en: Not knowing how he lost himself, or how he recovered himself, he may never feel certain of not losing himself again.
vi: Not knowing how he lost his memory, nor how he regained it, perhaps he isn't sure that he won't lose it again.
tr: Since he doesn't know how he lost his memory or how he recovered it, one can't even be sure that he won't lose it again.
es: Since he does not know how and when he lost it, and how and when he regained it, it is natural that he fears losing it again.

en: That alone wouldn’t make the subject pleasant, I should think.”
vi: Just that alone is already quite unsettling, I think so.
tr: Just this alone is an annoying situation in my opinion."
es: As you can understand, this consideration alone would be enough to make talking about the matter unpleasant for him.

en: It was a profounder remark than mr Lorry had looked for.
vi: An insightful remark beyond Mr. Lorry's expectations.
tr: This was a deeper comment than Mr. Lorry had expected.
es: —It's true—replied Lorry, who was satisfied with the deep observation of his interlocutor.

en: “True,” said he, “and fearful to reflect upon.
vi: He said: − Yes, and afraid to think about the past.
tr: "True," said Mr. Lorry, "it's terrifying even to think about it.
es: —Out of necessity, it must inspire fear in him to speak of his ordeal...

en: Yet, a doubt lurks in my mind, Miss Pross, whether it is good for Doctor Manette to have that suppression always shut up within him.
vi: But in my heart, I feel uneasy, Miss Pross, wondering if it's good for Dr. Manette to always keep things hidden and not speak out.
tr: Still, I am not at ease, Miss Pross, I am not sure how right it is for Doctor Manette to suppress all these troubles within himself.
es: However, Miss Pross, I very much doubt that it is good for his peace of mind to keep such dreadful memories buried deep in his heart, and these doubts, and the unease they often cause me, are precisely what have led me to provoke these confidences.

en: Indeed, it is this doubt and the uneasiness it sometimes causes me that has led me to our present confidence.”
vi: Honestly, it's because of this worry that I often feel uncomfortable, so now I'm telling you.
tr: In fact, the reason I brought up this matter to you is because of this doubt and unease within me."
es: However, Miss Pross, I very much doubt that it is good for his peace of mind to keep such dreadful memories buried deep in his heart, and these doubts, and the unease they often cause me, are precisely what have led me to provoke these confidences.

en: “Can’t be helped,” said Miss Pross, shaking her head.
vi: − That's the way it is, said Miss Pross, shaking her head. -
tr: Miss Pross, shaking her head from side to side, said, "There is nothing to be done."
es: —Evil, if it truly is evil, has no remedy—replied Miss Pross, shaking her head.

en: “Touch that string, and he instantly changes for the worse.
vi: When it comes to that, he turns pale and feels sick immediately.
tr: "The moment you push a little, it gets worse.
es: —Touch that string, and the results will be counterproductive; so, it is better to remain silent.

en: Better leave it alone.
vi: It's best to leave it alone.
tr: The best thing is to leave him alone.
es: —Touch that string, and the results will be counterproductive; so, it is better to remain silent.

en: In short, must leave it alone, like or no like.
vi: In short, it must be left alone, whether we like it or not.
tr: In short, whether we like it or not, we must leave him alone.
es: How many times, in the late hours of the night, he jumps out of bed and begins to pace agitatedly, up and down, up and down, through his room!

en: Sometimes, he gets up in the dead of the night, and will be heard, by us overhead there, walking up and down, walking up and down, in his room.
vi: Sometimes in the middle of the night, he wakes up and we hear him pacing back and forth, back and forth in his room upstairs.
tr: Sometimes in the middle of the night, he gets out of bed, and we hear him above us, pacing back and forth, back and forth in his room.
es: How many times, in the late hours of the night, he jumps out of bed and begins to pace agitatedly, up and down, up and down, through his room!

en: Ladybird has learnt to know then that his mind is walking up and down, walking up and down, in his old prison.
vi: Her dear mistress knows that her father's mind is pacing back and forth, back and forth in the old prison.
tr: My little bird then understands that her father, in his mind, is pacing back and forth, back and forth in his prison cell.
es: Miss knows by now that when this happens, her father's imagination is pacing up and down, up and down, through the dungeon that served as his tomb for so many years.

en: She hurries to him, and they go on together, walking up and down, walking up and down, until he is composed.
vi: She hurriedly runs up, and then the father and daughter pace back and forth, back and forth together until he calms down.
tr: She immediately runs to her father's side, and then the two of them continue to walk back and forth in the room together, until her father calms down.
es: She then runs to her father's room and, standing by his side, paces with him up and down, up and down, until she is convinced he has calmed down.

en: But he never says a word of the true reason of his restlessness, to her, and she finds it best not to hint at it to him.
vi: But he did not say a word to his daughter about the reason for his unease, and she thought it best not to bring it up with him.
tr: But he doesn't say a word to his daughter about the real reason for his restlessness, and his daughter doesn't even touch on the subject.
es: But the doctor never explains the cause of his unrest, and his daughter never asks him.

en: In silence they go walking up and down together, walking up and down together, till her love and company have brought him to himself.”
vi: The two people kept walking back and forth together, walking back and forth together, until her love and companionship calmed him down.
tr: In silence, they go back and forth, back and forth together, until the Doctor regains his composure with his daughter's love and support."
es: The two of them pace together up and down, up and down, without uttering a word, until the presence of his daughter, and the blind love she has for him, bring the doctor back to himself.

en: Notwithstanding Miss Pross’s denial of her own imagination, there was a perception of the pain of being monotonously haunted by one sad idea, in her repetition of the phrase, walking up and down, which testified to her possessing such a thing.
vi: No matter how much Miss Pross denied her imagination, the sense of the suffering of someone tormented endlessly by a sorrowful event was revealed in the way she repeated the phrase "going back and forth," proving that she was not devoid of imagination.
tr: Although Miss Pross claimed she lacked the ability to imagine, her constant repetition of the words "up and down" revealed that she was in a state of pain that endlessly accompanied a certain sorrowful thought, which actually indicated that she did possess imagination.
es: Miss Pross had denied that she had any imagination, but the evidence that a sad idea haunted her gave the lie to her assertion, evidence highlighted by the repetition of the phrase "up and down," as there was no doubt that it was a fixed idea.

en: The corner has been mentioned as a wonderful corner for echoes; it had begun to echo so resoundingly to the tread of coming feet, that it seemed as though the very mention of that weary pacing to and fro had set it going.
vi: As mentioned above, this street corner is a wonderful place for reminiscing; this place has begun to echo the approaching footsteps, as if resonating with the weary rhythm of comings and goings that Ms. Pross just described.
tr: It had been mentioned that the sounds echoed wonderfully in the corner where the house was located; now, as if even the words "walking up and down" had started the echo, approaching footsteps were heard.
es: The doctor's house seemed like the house of echoes. At the mention of the doctor's agitated nocturnal walks, the sound of approaching footsteps responded, and to these, the end of the conference.

en: “Here they are!” said Miss Pross, rising to break up the conference; “and now we shall have hundreds of people pretty soon!”
vi: − They are back! - Miss Pross said as she stood up, interrupting the conversation. - Now we will see a hundred people coming right away!
tr: "Here they come!" said Miss Pross, who had stood up to pause their conversation; "soon hundreds of people will crowd in here!"
es: —They are here! —exclaimed Miss Pross, standing up quickly. —It won't be long before people arrive at this house by the hundreds.

en: It was such a curious corner in its acoustical properties, such a peculiar Ear of a place, that as mr Lorry stood at the open window, looking for the father and daughter whose steps he heard, he fancied they would never approach.
vi: This corner of the street has a peculiar acoustic feature, like an eardrum that amplifies all sounds to the extent that Mr. Lorry, standing at the wide-open window, could hear the footsteps of the father and daughter but couldn't find them, thinking they would never return.
tr: It was a rather peculiar and privileged corner with its acoustic properties. In this place that resembled the inside of an ear, Mr. Lorry stood in front of the open window, looking at the father and daughter whose footsteps he heard, feeling as if they would never reach there.
es: Such marvelous acoustic conditions were gathered in that house that it could very well have been called the ear of the district. Lorry, who was leaning out the window and could perfectly hear the sound of the father and daughter's footsteps, thought they would never arrive.

en: Not only would the echoes die away, as though the steps had gone; but, echoes of other steps that never came would be heard in their stead, and would die away for good when they seemed close at hand.
vi: The echoes not only faded as the footsteps went further away but were followed by the echoes of other footsteps that never arrived, and just when it seemed the footsteps were near, the echoes would vanish forever.
tr: With the fading of the footsteps, not only did the echoes fade away; the echoes of other invisible footsteps came in their place, and as they approached, the others completely disappeared.
es: Not only did the echoes of the approaching footsteps reach him, but also many others that faded away just when they seemed closest.

en: However, father and daughter did at last appear, and Miss Pross was ready at the street door to receive them.
vi: But finally, the father and daughter appeared, and Miss Pross was already standing at the main door to welcome them inside.
tr: The father and daughter finally appeared, and Miss Pross immediately ran to the door to greet them.
es: Finally, the doctor appeared, giving his arm to his daughter, and they were received at the door of the house by Miss Pross.

en: Miss Pross was a pleasant sight, albeit wild, and red, and grim, taking off her darling’s bonnet when she came up-stairs, and touching it up with the ends of her handkerchief, and blowing the dust off it, and folding her mantle ready for laying by, and smoothing her rich hair with as much pride as she could possibly have taken in her own hair if she had been the vainest and handsomest of women.
vi: Miss Pross looked fierce, aggressive, and intense, but she was truly endearing when she took off Lucie's bonnet as her beloved mistress went upstairs, then dusted the hat with a few handkerchiefs, set Lucie's cloak aside, and proudly brushed her mistress's magnificent hair as if it were her own and she were the most beautiful and proud woman in the world.
tr: Although Miss Pross was a crazy, red-haired, surly woman, she looked very pleasant when her dear little one came upstairs, as she took off her hat, dusted it with the corner of her handkerchief, folded her cloak and put it aside, and arranged her thick hair with great pride as if it were her own and as if she were the most arrogant and beautiful woman in the world.
es: It was charming to see Miss Pross, despite her ugliness, her bright red color, and her frowning expression, hurrying to take off her lady's hat as she climbed the stairs; how, to avoid staining it, she wrapped her fingers with a handkerchief, how she tried to remove the dust by blowing on it, how she fluffed her splendid blonde hair with as much pride and satisfaction as she would have done with her own, assuming she had been the most beautiful and vain woman in creation.

en: Her darling was a pleasant sight too, embracing her and thanking her, and protesting against her taking so much trouble for her—which last she only dared to do playfully, or Miss Pross, sorely hurt, would have retired to her own chamber and cried.
vi: Equally endearing was the sight of Lucie hugging her caretaker in thanks and then playfully protesting that she had gone to too much trouble for her beloved mistress - Lucie only dared to protest in a joking manner, otherwise Miss Pross would be hurt and retreat to her room to cry.
tr: Her dear little one also looked very pleasant as she hugged Miss Pross, thanked her, and said she was sorry for causing her so much trouble. The young girl had said her last words half-jokingly, otherwise Miss Pross would have been terribly upset, locked herself in her room, and cried.
es: It was also charming to see the lady hugging her maid, thanking her and protesting against so much attention and work, though protesting with a smile on her lips, for if she did not, Miss Pross, deeply hurt, would have retired to her room to spend the day crying.

en: The Doctor was a pleasant sight too, looking on at them, and telling Miss Pross how she spoilt Lucie, in accents and with eyes that had as much spoiling in them as Miss Pross had, and would have had more if it were possible.
vi: The doctor also seemed pleased as he watched the scene, telling Miss Pross that she spoiled Lucie too much, with a tone and look that were just as indulgent as the caretaker's, and if he could, he would spoil her even more.
tr: The doctor also looked very pleasant as he watched them and told Miss Pross how much she spoiled Lucie. However, at that moment, both his speech and his eyes were at least as indulgent as Miss Pross's, and if possible, he would have spoiled her even more.
es: It was no less charming to see the doctor gazing at them with rapture and to hear him tell Miss Pross that she was spoiling Lucie with so much attention and care, but with such a sweet tone and tender look that it was enough, and even more than enough, to spoil Miss Pross and a hundred more like her, and finally, it was also charming to see Mr. Lorry adjusting his wig and mentally thanking his lucky star that, if it made him a confirmed bachelor, it allowed him to glimpse, in his old age, the pure joys of a home.

en: mr Lorry was a pleasant sight too, beaming at all this in his little wig, and thanking his bachelor stars for having lighted him in his declining years to a Home.
vi: Mr. Lorry was also pleased, his face brightening under his wig, and he silently thanked his solitary fate for leading him to find a family in his later years.
tr: Mr. Lorry, with his small wig on his head, also looked very pleasant as he watched all this with laughing eyes and thanked his fortune for providing a Home that illuminated his world at this advanced age.
es: It was no less charming to see the doctor gazing at them with rapture and to hear him tell Miss Pross that she was spoiling Lucie with so much attention and care, but with such a sweet tone and tender look that it was enough, and even more than enough, to spoil Miss Pross and a hundred more like her, and finally, it was also charming to see Mr. Lorry adjusting his wig and mentally thanking his lucky star that, if it made him a confirmed bachelor, it allowed him to glimpse, in his old age, the pure joys of a home.

en: But, no Hundreds of people came to see the sights, and mr Lorry looked in vain for the fulfilment of Miss Pross’s prediction.
vi: But not seeing hundreds of people flocking to gawk, Mr. Lorry waited in vain, as Miss Pross's prediction did not come true.
tr: But not hundreds of people had come to see these beauties, and Mr. Lorry looked around in vain to see if Miss Pross's prediction would come true.
es: Everything was charming, but the hundreds of people who were supposed to revolve around Lucie were nowhere to be seen, and Mr. Lorry waited in vain for Miss Pross's prophecy to come true.

en: Dinner-time, and still no Hundreds of people.
vi: It's mealtime, yet there's no sign of any groups arriving.
tr: Dinner time had arrived, but there were still hundreds of people missing.
es: The time to sit at the table had come, but the hundreds were not arriving.

en: In the arrangements of the little household, Miss Pross took charge of the lower regions, and always acquitted herself marvellously.
vi: In the organization of this small family, the kitchen work was handled by Miss Pross, and she managed everything perfectly on her own.
tr: The organization of household chores on the lower floors was under Miss Pross's management, and she had always handled this task admirably until now.
es: In the distribution of household chores, Miss Pross had reserved the scepter of the lower regions of the house for herself, and it must be confessed that she wielded it marvelously.

en: Her dinners, of a very modest quality, were so well cooked and so well served, and so neat in their contrivances, half English and half French, that nothing could be better.
vi: Although not luxurious, the meals she cooked were very skillfully prepared and beautifully presented, with dishes that were a delicate blend of English and French styles, extremely delicious.
tr: The modest meals were always so delicious, so beautifully served, and the dishes of the semi-English, semi-French cuisine were so nicely prepared that it was hard to find better ones.
es: It was impossible to bring her meals, modest in themselves, to a greater degree of perfection, but they were admirably cooked and even more admirably served, according to a taste that was half French and half English.

en: Miss Pross’s friendship being of the thoroughly practical kind, she had ravaged Soho and the adjacent provinces, in search of impoverished French, who, tempted by shillings and half-crowns, would impart culinary mysteries to her.
vi: Very practically, Miss Pross expressed her affection through her culinary skills, scouring Soho and the surrounding areas to find impoverished French expatriates, enticing them with shillings and half-crowns to share their cooking secrets.
tr: Resourceful Miss Pross, whose friendships were based on mutual benefit, had turned the neighborhoods of Soho and its surroundings upside down to find poor French people, from whom she learned all sorts of kitchen secrets in exchange for a few pennies.
es: Since Miss Pross's dedication was eminently practical, she had scoured every corner of Soho and the adjacent territories in search of poor French people who, tempted by the cheerful jingle of shillings and half-crowns, revealed to her all the mysteries of the culinary art.

en: From these decayed sons and daughters of Gaul, she had acquired such wonderful arts, that the woman and girl who formed the staff of domestics regarded her as quite a Sorceress, or Cinderella’s Godmother: who would send out for a fowl, a rabbit, a vegetable or two from the garden, and change them into anything she pleased.
vi: From these sons and daughters of Gaul, she learned wonderful cooking tips, to the extent that the two maids, one old and one young, in the house saw her as nothing short of a witch or the fairy godmother of Cinderella - who would have them bring back a chicken, a rabbit, or some garden vegetables and transform them into anything she wished.
tr: She had learned such amazing tips from the destitute children of the Gauls that the woman and young girl working at home almost saw Miss Pross as a sorceress or the fairy godmother of Cinderella – the one who sent them poultry, rabbit, or a few vegetables from the garden and transformed them into whatever she wished.
es: She learned so many wonderful skills from those sons and daughters of Gaul that the woman and the girl who made up the household staff saw her as a sorceress, a grandmother of Cinderella capable of taking a chicken, a rabbit, or a couple of potatoes in her hands and turning them into whatever dish she fancied.

en: On Sundays, Miss Pross dined at the Doctor’s table, but on other days persisted in taking her meals at unknown periods, either in the lower regions, or in her own room on the second floor—a blue chamber, to which no one but her Ladybird ever gained admittance.
vi: On Sundays, Miss Pross would sit and eat with the doctor and his daughter, but on other days she insisted on having her meals at times nobody knew, either in the kitchen or in her private room on the second floor - a blue room that only her beloved mistress was allowed to enter.
tr: Miss Pross only had dinner at the Doctor's table on Sundays; on other days, she always ate at different times either downstairs or in her own room on the second floor – that blue room which no one entered except her little bird.
es: Miss Pross would sit at the doctor's family table on Sundays, but on the other days of the week, she would usually eat at unknown hours, either in the lower regions or in her room, located on the second floor, which was off-limits to everyone except Miss Lucie.

en: On this occasion, Miss Pross, responding to Ladybird’s pleasant face and pleasant efforts to please her, unbent exceedingly; so the dinner was very pleasant, too.
vi: But today, Miss Pross delighted in showing off all her skills to pamper her beloved and graceful mistress, so the meal was also excellent.
tr: At such times, Miss Pross would relax considerably, unable to resist the sweet face of her little bird and its efforts to make her happy, making the meal very enjoyable.
es: At the Sunday meal referred to in this account, Miss Pross, responding to the joy reflected on the doctor's daughter's face and wishing to please her, allowed herself an unusual liveliness, and as a result, the time the diners spent at the table was most pleasant.

en: It was an oppressive day, and, after dinner, Lucie proposed that the wine should be carried out under the plane-tree, and they should sit there in the air.
vi: It was a sweltering day, so after the meal, Lucie suggested everyone take the wine out under the plane tree to enjoy the cool breeze.
tr: The weather was quite oppressive, and after the meal, Lucie suggested continuing with their wine outdoors, sitting under the plane tree.
es: It was a day of scorching heat, in view of which, at dessert, Miss Lucía proposed going to drink the wine under the wild plane tree in the courtyard, where they could enjoy a more pleasant atmosphere.

en: As everything turned upon her, and revolved about her, they went out under the plane-tree, and she carried the wine down for the special benefit of mr Lorry.
vi: Since everyone was interested and agreed with her suggestion, they all went out there, and she personally brought a glass of wine for Mr. Lorry.
tr: Since the world revolved around her, they all moved under the plane tree together, and Lucie helped Mr. Lorry carry the wine.
es: As everyone was eager to please the spoiled one of the house, they immediately went out to the courtyard and took a seat under the plane tree, where Lucía, who for some time had assigned herself the role of Mr. Lorry's cupbearer, poured the wine.

en: She had installed herself, some time before, as mr Lorry’s cup-bearer; and while they sat under the plane-tree, talking, she kept his glass replenished.
vi: Lucie had long taken on the role of wine bearer for Mr. Lorry; as everyone chatted under the plane tree, she never let his glass run dry.
tr: The young girl, acting as Mr. Lorry's attendant, had settled under the tree a bit earlier than the others, and when they all arrived and started chatting, she continued to refill Mr. Lorry's empty glass.
es: As everyone was eager to please the spoiled one of the house, they immediately went out to the courtyard and took a seat under the plane tree, where Lucía, who for some time had assigned herself the role of Mr. Lorry's cupbearer, poured the wine.

en: Mysterious backs and ends of houses peeped at them as they talked, and the plane-tree whispered to them in its own way above their heads.
vi: The walls of the surrounding houses watched them converse, while the branches of the weeping willow above them whispered to them.
tr: While they were talking, the mysterious houses around them secretly watched them, and the plane tree whispered something of its own from above.
es: Rooftops of nearby houses seemed to peek their heads over the courtyard fences while the gathered ones talked, and the leaves of the plane tree whispered in their ears the murmuring words typical of their varnished tongues.

en: Still, the Hundreds of people did not present themselves.
vi: Even so, no groups or crowds were seen.
tr: Hundreds of people were still nowhere to be found.
es: The meal had ended, but the hundreds of visitors did not show up.

en: mr Darnay presented himself while they were sitting under the plane-tree, but he was only One.
vi: Darnay arrived while they were relaxing, but he was the only one.
tr: While they were sitting under the tree, Mr. Darnay arrived, but he was just one person.
es: When the diners were seated under the banana tree, young Darnay arrived, but he was just one.

en: Doctor Manette received him kindly, and so did Lucie.
vi: Dr. Manette warmly welcomed this guest, and so did Lucie.
tr: They greeted Doctor Manette and Lucie politely.
es: The doctor Manette gave him a cordial welcome, and his daughter did the same.

en: But, Miss Pross suddenly became afflicted with a twitching in the head and body, and retired into the house.
vi: But Miss Pross suddenly contorted her face and body and retreated into the house.
tr: But Miss Pross's head and body suddenly started twitching, and she immediately threw herself into the house, feeling uncomfortable.
es: Miss Pross, suddenly overcome by a sensation of tingling in her head and the rest of her body, withdrew into the house.

en: She was not unfrequently the victim of this disorder, and she called it, in familiar conversation, “a fit of the jerks.”
vi: She was often tormented by this condition, and in intimate conversations, she referred to it as "having a fit."
tr: She would occasionally suffer from this ailment and had named this condition "foolish fellow fit."
es: It seems that she was frequently a victim of that disorder, which she, within the family, used to call "a nervous attack."

en: The Doctor was in his best condition, and looked specially young.
vi: The doctor is in excellent health and looks much younger.
tr: The doctor was more cheerful than ever, as if he had rejuvenated.
es: The doctor was in an excellent mood and seemed very young.

en: The resemblance between him and Lucie was very strong at such times, and as they sat side by side, she leaning on his shoulder, and he resting his arm on the back of her chair, it was very agreeable to trace the likeness.
vi: At times like these, he resembles Lucie a lot, and when the two sit next to each other, the girl leaning on her father's shoulder, and he resting his arm on the back of her chair, it's delightful to see their similar faces.
tr: In such moments, his resemblance to Lucie became even more apparent, especially when they sat side by side and the girl rested her head on her father's shoulder. When the doctor also put his arm around the back of his daughter's chair, it was impossible not to notice this resemblance.
es: Sitting next to his daughter, whose head was resting on his shoulder, the striking resemblance between them was so evident that even the most shortsighted person would notice it.

en: He had been talking all day, on many subjects, and with unusual vivacity.
vi: He has been talking non-stop about various topics with an unusual liveliness.
tr: The doctor had spent the whole day talking with unusual liveliness, jumping from one topic to another.
es: The conversation touched on many and very varied topics, with the doctor being one of those who showed the most liveliness and animation.

en: “Pray, Doctor Manette,” said mr Darnay, as they sat under the plane-tree—and he said it in the natural pursuit of the topic in hand, which happened to be the old buildings of London—“have you seen much of the Tower?”
vi: − Doctor Manette, - Darnay spoke up as they sat under the tree, joining in on the topic that had come up by chance about the old buildings of London, - have you visited the Tower of London yet?
tr: "Please tell me, Doctor Manette," said Mr. Darnay, as they sat under the plane tree – his question was related to the topic they were discussing, which was the old buildings in London – "Have you ever seen the Tower of London?"
es: On an occasion when they were talking about the most notable buildings in London, Darnay asked him: —Tell me, doctor, have you visited the Tower?

en: “Lucie and I have been there; but only casually.
vi: − Lucie and I have been there; but only briefly.
tr: "We went with Lucie, but we didn't explore much.
es: —I visited it with Lucía on one occasion, but briefly, without stopping—replied the doctor.

en: We have seen enough of it, to know that it teems with interest; little more.”
vi: We haven't seen everything, but enough to know that the tower is full of interesting things, that's all.
tr: It's definitely a very interesting place, though."
es: —We saw enough to appreciate that it is indeed worthy of interest, but nothing more.

en: “I have been there, as you remember,” said Darnay, with a smile, though reddening a little angrily, “in another character, and not in a character that gives facilities for seeing much of it.
vi: − I have been there already, as you know, - Darnay said with a smile, though his face reddened slightly with a hint of irritation at the memory, I stayed longer even though I didn't get to see everything.
tr: "I had gone, as you remember," said Darnay with a smile, but at the same time slightly flushed with anger, "under a different identity and in a position where I had little opportunity to see around.
es: —I have been there, as you remember—replied Darnay with a slightly forced smile,—but not as a tourist nor in conditions to see much of it.

en: They told me a curious thing when I was there.”
vi: While I was there, I heard a strange story.
tr: While I was there, they told me something strange."
es: A little story was told to me during my stay that powerfully caught my attention.

en: “What was that?” Lucie asked.
vi: − What's going on? - Lucie asked.
tr: "What did they tell you?" asked Lucie.
es: —Why don't you tell it to us?—asked Lucía. —With great pleasure.

en: “In making some alterations, the workmen came upon an old dungeon, which had been, for many years, built up and forgotten.
vi: − When repairing some parts of the tower, a group of workers accidentally discovered an old dungeon, built many years ago and forgotten.
tr: "While some changes were being made inside, the workers came across an old dungeon that had been built years ago and then forgotten.
es: It seems that, during the course of some construction work that had to be done, the workers found an ancient dungeon, used in a remote time and forgotten for many years.

en: Every stone of its inner wall was covered by inscriptions which had been carved by prisoners—dates, names, complaints, and prayers.
vi: Every stone of the inner wall was covered with writings carved by prisoners... dates, names, complaints, and prayers.
tr: The surface of each stone on the inner wall was covered with carvings made by prisoners – dates, names, complaints, and prayers.
es: All the interior stones were full of inscriptions carved into the stone by the prisoners. The inscriptions were dates, names, complaints, curses, prayers, etc.

en: Upon a corner stone in an angle of the wall, one prisoner, who seemed to have gone to execution, had cut as his last work, three letters.
vi: On a cornerstone in a corner of the dungeon, a prisoner who seemed to have been executed had carved his final words, just three letters.
tr: On a stone in the corner of the wall, a prisoner who was apparently being taken for execution had carved his final work, that is, three letters.
es: On the stone of a corner of the wall, a convict, condemned to death, in all probability, carved four letters at the last moment.

en: They were done with some very poor instrument, and hurriedly, with an unsteady hand.
vi: These words were hastily carved by a trembling hand and a worn-out tool.
tr: The letters were carved with a makeshift tool, hastily and with a trembling hand.
es: He must have used a tool not well-suited for the purpose, and did the work hastily and with an unsteady hand.

en: At first, they were read as D. I. C.; but, on being more carefully examined, the last letter was found to be G.
vi: At first, people read the three letters as D. A. C.; but upon closer inspection, the last letter was actually an O.
tr: At first, they read it as H. A. Z.; but upon closer inspection, they realized that the first letter was K.
es: Upon examining the letters, everyone initially believed they were G. A. V. A., but a closer observation revealed that the first letter was not G, but C.

en: There was no record or legend of any prisoner with those initials, and many fruitless guesses were made what the name could have been.
vi: There were no records or notes of a prisoner with such initials, and people kept guessing without knowing whose name those letters stood for.
tr: They could not find any record or information of a prisoner whose name or surname started with these letters, but many empty guesses were made about what this person's name could have been.
es: There was no record in the archives of any prisoner whose name and surname corresponded to those initials.

en: At length, it was suggested that the letters were not initials, but the complete word, DIG.
vi: Eventually, it was concluded that the letters were not initials but a complete word, ĐÀO.
tr: In the end, they decided that these letters were not the initials of a name, but a whole word, KAZ.
es: After much thought and consideration, it was realized that the letters in question were not initials, but a complete name: Cava.

en: The floor was examined very carefully under the inscription, and, in the earth beneath a stone, or tile, or some fragment of paving, were found the ashes of a paper, mingled with the ashes of a small leathern case or bag.
vi: They carefully examined the dungeon floor right below the inscription, and in the soil beneath a stone, or a brick, or some kind of tile, were the ashes of a piece of paper mixed with the ashes of a small leather box or pouch.
tr: The ground beneath the writing was examined with great care, and they found the ashes of papers mixed with the ashes of a small leather suitcase or bag under a stone, brick, or a piece of stone flooring.
es: Some excavations were carried out, which resulted in the discovery, beneath a slab or tile, of some fragments of paper, mixed with pieces of a small box or leather pouch.

en: What the unknown prisoner had written will never be read, but he had written something, and hidden it away to keep it from the gaoler.”
vi: It was never possible to read what the prisoner had written on the paper, but it was certain that they had written something and hidden it from the jailer.
tr: What the unknown prisoner wrote will never be read, but he wrote something, and then hid it so the guard wouldn't see it."
es: No one has been able to find out what the condemned man wrote on the paper, although it was clear that something was written. Undoubtedly, he buried it so that the warden would not find it.

en: “My father,” exclaimed Lucie, “you are ill!”
vi: − Dad, - Lucie exclaimed, - you're sick!
tr: "Daddy," Lucie suddenly cried out, "are you feeling unwell?"
es: —My father! —exclaimed Lucía. —Are you feeling ill?

en: He had suddenly started up, with his hand to his head.
vi: The doctor suddenly started, raising a hand to his head.
tr: The doctor suddenly jerked his hand to his head.
es: This question was prompted by the fact that the doctor stood up violently and put his hands on his head.

en: His manner and his look quite terrified them all.
vi: His expression and demeanor terrified everyone.
tr: His state and appearance greatly alarmed everyone.
es: His face reflected horrible fright.

en: “No, my dear, not ill.
vi: − No, child, I'm not sick.
tr: "No, my dear, I'm not unwell.
es: —No, my daughter, I am not sick—replied the doctor.

en: There are large drops of rain falling, and they made me start.
vi: A few large raindrops fell and startled me.
tr: The rain has started to drizzle, that's why I shivered.
es: —It is starting to rain... very large drops are falling and I got scared thoughtlessly.

en: We had better go in.”
