es: At the moment the carriage turned a corner near a fountain, one of the wheels jumped, hundreds of throats let out a scream, and the horses reared and backed up.

vi: Finally, as the carriage charged into a corner by the fountain, one of the wheels suddenly jerked up terrifyingly, followed by the loud cries of many people and the horses rearing up wildly.
tr: Finally, as it turned a corner near a fountain, the wheels jolted slightly in an annoying way and screams rose from the crowd, the horses reared up and lunged forward.
es: It is almost certain that the carriage would have continued its unperturbed, reckless race if it hadn't been for this last inconvenience, as it was what carriages used to do in that happy era, even if they left the street strewn with corpses, why would they do otherwise?

en: Original
vi: Finally, as the carriage charged into a corner by the fountain, one of the wheels suddenly jerked up terrifyingly, followed by the loud cries of many people and the horses rearing up wildly.
tr: Finally, as it turned a corner near a fountain, the wheels jolted slightly in an annoying way and screams rose from the crowd, the horses reared up and lunged forward.
es: It is almost certain that the carriage would have continued its unperturbed, reckless race if it hadn't been for this last inconvenience, as it was what carriages used to do in that happy era, even if they left the street strewn with corpses, why would they do otherwise?

en: But for the latter inconvenience, the carriage probably would not have stopped; carriages were often known to drive on, and leave their wounded behind, and why not?
vi: If the horses do not stop, this carriage will not stop; usually, the carriage just keeps going, leaving the injured behind, so why stop?
tr: But a car would not be stopped for such a problem; cars always went on like this and left the injured behind, there was no reason for the opposite.
es: It is almost certain that the carriage would have continued its unperturbed, reckless race if it hadn't been for this last inconvenience, as it was what carriages used to do in that happy era, even if they left the street strewn with corpses, why would they do otherwise?

en: But the frightened valet had got down in a hurry, and there were twenty hands at the horses’ bridles.
vi: But the servant hastily got off the carriage and twenty hands held the reins tightly. − What is happening? -
tr: But the frightened servant got out of the car in a hurry; twenty hands had reached for the reins of the horses.
es: But the frightened footman had jumped to the ground and twenty hands grabbed the horses' reins at once.

en: “What has gone wrong?” said Monsieur, calmly looking out.
vi: The official calmly looked outside.
tr: "What's the problem?" asked Monsieur calmly, looking outside.
es: —What's happening?—asked the gentleman, poking his calm face through the door.

en: A tall man in a nightcap had caught up a bundle from among the feet of the horses, and had laid it on the basement of the fountain, and was down in the mud and wet, howling over it like a wild animal.
vi: A tall man wearing a hat just lifted a bundle wrapped in cloth from the base of the horses and placed it on the fountain pedestal, then sat down heavily in the mud, howling like a wild beast.
tr: A tall man with a nightcap on his head had picked up the pile that had fallen between the horses' legs and placed it at the base of the fountain. Now, covered in mud and soaking wet, he was howling like a wild animal.
es: A tall man, with a cap on his head, had taken a bundle from between the horses' legs, which he placed on the base of a fountain, and leaning over it, howled like a wild animal.

en: “Pardon, Monsieur the Marquis!” said a ragged and submissive man, “it is a child.”
vi: − Excuse me, Marquis! - A ragged person said humbly. - Yes, a child.
tr: "Sorry, Monsieur Marquis!" said a shabbily dressed and obedient man, "it's a child."
es: —Excuse me, Mr. Marquis—said a ragged individual with a humble voice and demeanor,—it's a child.

en: “Why does he make that abominable noise?
vi: − Why is that guy screaming so horribly?
tr: "Why is this man making such disgusting noises?"
es: —And why is he making that deafening noise?

en: Is it his child?”
vi: Is it his child?
tr: "Is that his child?""
es: You say it's a child?

en: “Excuse me, Monsieur the Marquis—it is a pity—yes.”
vi: − Sorry, Marquis! - It's really unfortunate... yes, that's right.
tr: "Excuse me, Monsieur Marquis –unfortunately– yes."
es: —Excuse me, Mr. Marquis... It is a... shame... yes, that's it.

en: The fountain was a little removed; for the street opened, where it was, into a space some ten or twelve yards square.
vi: The fountain is located a bit away from the road because the road here leads into an open space of about ten or twelve square yards.
tr: The fountain was a little further; the street opened into a small square.
es: The fountain was a few yards away.

en: As the tall man suddenly got up from the ground, and came running at the carriage, Monsieur the Marquis clapped his hand for an instant on his sword-hilt.
vi: When the tall man stood up and rushed towards the carriage, the Marquis immediately grasped the hilt of his sword.
tr: When the tall man suddenly got up from the ground and started running towards the carriage, Monsieur Marquis immediately reached for the hilt of his sword.
es: The tall man who was leaning over the bundle suddenly straightened up and ran hurriedly towards the carriage, causing the Marquis to place his hand on the hilt of his sword.

en: “Killed!” shrieked the man, in wild desperation, extending both arms at their length above his head, and staring at him.
vi: − It's dead! - This person screamed, in desperate frenzy, raising both arms straight above his head and glaring at the nobleman.
tr: Adam, in a terrible desperation, with his hands raised in the air, his eyes fixed on the man, was shouting, "You killed him!"
es: —Dead! —roared the tall man with signs of savage despair, fixing his eyes on the Marquis and raising both arms.

en: “Dead!”
vi: - Dead!
tr: "He's dead!"
es: —Murdered!

en: The people closed round, and looked at Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: The crowd gathered closer, looking at the Marquis.
tr: A crowd of people had gathered around. They were looking at Monsieur Marquis.
es: The crowds gathered around the carriage.

en: There was nothing revealed by the many eyes that looked at him but watchfulness and eagerness; there was no visible menacing or anger.
vi: The wide-open eyes revealed nothing more than caution and eagerness; there was no sign of threat or anger.
tr: There was great curiosity and excitement in all their eyes, but not the slightest hint of threat or anger.
es: All eyes were focused on the person of the Marquis, but in them, nothing could be read but anxiety, fear, no anger or threat.

en: Neither did the people say anything; after the first cry, they had been silent, and they remained so.
vi: They didn't say a word; after the initial outcry, everything fell silent and remained so.
tr: They weren't saying anything either; after the first shout, they had fallen silent and hadn't made a sound since.
es: Everyone was silent. After the first shout, an imposing silence followed.

en: The voice of the submissive man who had spoken, was flat and tame in its extreme submission.
vi: The voice of the obsequious person from earlier sounded awkward and bland with an utterly servile tone.
tr: The voice of the obedient man speaking to the Marquis had come out in a very monotonous and docile manner, in the most obedient way possible.
es: The voice of the one who had spoken to the magnate remained extremely submissive.

en: Monsieur the Marquis ran his eyes over them all, as if they had been mere rats come out of their holes.
vi: The Marquis rolled his eyes at the crowd as if they were a bunch of rats crawling out of their holes.
tr: Monsieur Marquis turned his eyes and looked at them as if they were mice that had come out of their holes.
es: The Marquis cast his eyes over the huddled groups, regarding them with the indifference with which he would have looked at a herd of frightened rats.

en: He took out his purse.
vi: He took out his wallet.
tr: He took out his wallet.
es: Without changing his stance, he took out a pocket.

en: “It is extraordinary to me,” said he, “that you people cannot take care of yourselves and your children.
vi: − I find it very strange, - the Marquis said, - that your common folk do not care for themselves or their children.
tr: "How is it," he said, "that you can't take care of yourselves and your children, I just don't understand.
es: —It surprises me greatly—he said—that you can't even take care of your own children.

en: One or the other of you is for ever in the way.
vi: One or another of you is always getting in my way.
tr: Someone always gets in our way.
es: Frequently, you cross my path in a way that cannot help but be bothersome to me.

en: How do I know what injury you have done my horses.
vi: I wonder if any of you have injured my horses.
tr: Who knows how much my horses have been harmed?
es: Don't you realize that your recklessness could harm my horses?

en: See!
vi: Here!
tr: Look!
es: Come on!...

en: Give him that.”
vi: Give it to that one.
tr: Give that to him."
es: Give him this!

en: He threw out a gold coin for the valet to pick up, and all the heads craned forward that all the eyes might look down at it as it fell.
vi: He tossed a gold coin for the servant to pick up, and all heads turned, eyes straining to see where the coin would roll.
tr: He threw a gold coin to the child, and all heads turned to follow the coin as it fell to the ground.
es: Accompanying the action with the word, he threw a gold coin at the lackey's feet.

en: The tall man called out again with a most unearthly cry, “Dead!”
vi: The tall man let out another boundless, sorrowful scream: "Dead!"
tr: The tall man let out an incredible scream again, "He's dead!"
es: —Dead... murdered! —the tall man shouted again.

en: He was arrested by the quick arrival of another man, for whom the rest made way.
vi: He fell silent as the crowd parted for a quick-footed person to approach.
tr: Everyone quickly made way for a man approaching him.
es: Another man arrived at that moment, to whom everyone made way.

en: On seeing him, the miserable creature fell upon his shoulder, sobbing and crying, and pointing to the fountain, where some women were stooping over the motionless bundle, and moving gently about it.
vi: Seeing this person, the miserable one rested their head on the newcomer's shoulder and sobbed uncontrollably, pointing towards the fountain, where several women were crouching and gently moving around the motionless bundle of cloth.
tr: The poor man, upon seeing him, rested his head on his shoulder and began to sob uncontrollably, while also pointing to the fountain over which the women were bending motionlessly and moving around with compassion.
es: The one who had just shouted fell into his arms as soon as he saw him, remaining there for a long time, crying and sobbing.

en: They were as silent, however, as the men.
vi: But they were as silent as the men.
tr: The women were as silent as the men.
es: The one who had just shouted fell into his arms as soon as he saw him, remaining there for a long time, crying and sobbing.

en: “I know all, I know all,” said the last comer.
vi: − I know, I know everything, - the newcomer said.
tr: "I know it all, I know it all," said the last man who arrived.
es: —I know everything... I know everything—said the newcomer.

en: “Be a brave man, my Gaspard!
vi: - Be brave, Gaspard!
tr: "Be brave, Gaspard!
es: —Courage, Gaspar!

en: It is better for the poor little plaything to die so, than to live.
vi: The poor boy dying like that is better than him living.
tr: It is better for that poor little child to die than to live.
es: It is preferable to die as the child did than to live the life that awaited him.

en: It has died in a moment without pain.
vi: He died instantly without any pain.
tr: He died in an instant without suffering at all.
es: He died without pain, without suffering, and on the other hand, had he continued living, those would have relentlessly pursued him.

en: Could it have lived an hour as happily?”
vi: If he had lived another hour, he might not have been as happy.
tr: If he had lived, would he have had a moment of happiness?"
es: He died without pain, without suffering, and on the other hand, had he continued living, those would have relentlessly pursued him.

en: “You are a philosopher, you there,” said the Marquis, smiling.
vi: − You there, you truly are a philosopher, - the Marquis said with a smile. -
tr: "Hey you, you are a philosopher," said the Marquis with a smile, "What is your name?""
es: —You are a philosopher—said the Marquis, smiling.

en: “How do they call you?”
vi: What is your name?
tr: "They call him Defarge.""
es: — What is your name?

en: “They call me Defarge.”
vi: − My name is Defarge.
tr: "They call him Defarge.""
es: —Defarge.

en: “Of what trade?”
vi: − What is your occupation?
tr: "What do you do?"
es: —What is your occupation?

en: “Monsieur the Marquis, vendor of wine.”
vi: − My lord Marquis, I run a tavern.
tr: "I am selling wine, Monsieur Marquis."
es: —I am a wine seller, Mr. Marquis.

en: “Pick up that, philosopher and vendor of wine,” said the Marquis, throwing him another gold coin, “and spend it as you will.
vi: − Take it, philosopher bartender, - the Marquis said while tossing another gold coin to the man, - spend it on whatever you want.
tr: Throwing another gold coin, "Philosopher and wine seller, here, take this," he said, "and spend it as you wish.
es: —Take this, philosopher and wine seller, and spend it as you please—replied the Marquis, throwing another gold coin at his feet.

en: The horses there; are they right?”
vi: Are those horses okay?
tr: How are the horses? Are they well?"
es: — Let's see! Are the horses ready?

en: Without deigning to look at the assemblage a second time, Monsieur the Marquis leaned back in his seat, and was just being driven away with the air of a gentleman who had accidentally broke some common thing, and had paid for it, and could afford to pay for it; when his ease was suddenly disturbed by a coin flying into his carriage, and ringing on its floor.
vi: Without bothering to look back at the crowd that had gathered, the Marquis leaned back in his seat; he had just been driven away in a carriage with the nonchalance of a gentleman who had accidentally damaged an item, paid for it, and had plenty of money to spare, when a coin flew into the carriage and clattered onto the floor.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, without bothering to look at the crowd once more, leaned back and was leaving with the air of a gentleman who had accidentally broken something ordinary and paid for it, having the means to do so, when his mood was spoiled by the coin tossed into the carriage, which was jingling on the floor.
es: Without deigning to look at the crowds a second time, the Marquis settled back into his seat. The carriage began to move again and its happy occupant had forgotten the incident, as if he had just broken a trinket and paid for it, when his Olympian serenity was disturbed by the violent entry of a gold coin into the interior of the carriage.

en: “Hold!” said Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: − Stop! - The Marquis exclaimed.
tr: "Stop!" said Monsieur Marquis.
es: —Stop! —shouted the Marquis.—Stop the horses!...

en: “Hold the horses!
vi: - Stop the horse!
tr: "Stop the horses!" "Who threw this?""
es: —Stop! —shouted the Marquis.—Stop the horses!...

en: Who threw that?”
vi: Who threw that?
tr: "Stop the horses!" "Who threw this?""
es: Who threw this?

en: He looked to the spot where Defarge the vendor of wine had stood, a moment before; but the wretched father was grovelling on his face on the pavement in that spot, and the figure that stood beside him was the figure of a dark stout woman, knitting.
vi: He looked back at the spot where the innkeeper Defarge had been standing, but right there was the wretched father with his face down on the pavement, and behind him stood a dark-skinned woman knitting.
tr: The wine seller looked at the spot where Defarge had stood a minute ago, but at that exact spot, the wretched father was now throwing himself to the ground in despair, and right next to him was a dark-haired, stout woman knitting.
es: He looked angrily at the spot where he had just left Defarge, but saw nothing more than the unfortunate father embracing the corpse of his son, and a woman standing, who was looking at him with a frown.

en: “You dogs!” said the Marquis, but smoothly, and with an unchanged front, except as to the spots on his nose: “I would ride over any of you very willingly, and exterminate you from the earth.
vi: − You dog! - The Marquis said calmly, his face unchanged except for a spot on the tip of his nose. - I am very willing to crush any of you and wipe you all off the face of this earth.
tr: "You dogs!" said the Marquis, but in a soft tone, with no change in his face except for the spots on his nose. "I would crush you all with great pleasure and send you to the other world.
es: —Dogs! —murmured the Marquis. —I would gladly run over all of you to rid the world of your disgusting presence!

en: If I knew which rascal threw at the carriage, and if that brigand were sufficiently near it, he should be crushed under the wheels.”
vi: If I knew which bastard threw money into the carriage and if that scoundrel were nearby, he would be crushed under these wheels.
tr: If I knew which scoundrel threw this at the carriage and if he were near this miserable carriage, we would have run over him by now."
es: If I knew who the scoundrel was that threw the coin, and had him close enough, by God, I would crush him under the wheels of my carriage!

en: So cowed was their condition, and so long and hard their experience of what such a man could do to them, within the law and beyond it, that not a voice, or a hand, or even an eye was raised.
vi: Fully aware of their lowly status and long accustomed to the suffering that a high-ranking official could inflict upon them, regardless of the law, no voice was raised, no hand was lifted, and not even a single glance was directed upwards.
tr: People had been so suppressed and had known for so long what such a man could do to them within and beyond the laws and the difficulties of it that no one could raise their voice, hand, or even their eyes.
es: Such was the fear of the mobs, so great the horror they felt for what men of the Marquis's social class could do to them, within and outside the law, that not a voice, nor a hand, nor a glance was raised.

en: Among the men, not one.
vi: Not a single one, among the men.
tr: Not a single man among them moved.
es: All the men remained silent, their eyes fixed on the ground.

en: But the woman who stood knitting looked up steadily, and looked the Marquis in the face.
vi: But the woman standing and knitting continued to stare directly at the Marquis.
tr: But the woman who was knitting persistently looked up, and the place she was looking at was the face of the Marquis.
es: Only the woman we referred to earlier dared to fix her angry gaze on the Marquis, who did not even notice her.

en: It was not for his dignity to notice it; his contemptuous eyes passed over her, and over all the other rats; and he leaned back in his seat again, and gave the word “Go on!”
vi: The dignity of the high official did not allow him to notice this; the Marquis’s contemptuous gaze swept over her, over all those rats; then he reclined back in his seat and uttered a word: “Move on!”
tr: The Marquis could not tolerate the fact that he noticed these glances; after casting his disdainful eyes over the woman and the other mice, he leaned back again and said, "Continue!"
es: His lofty gaze passed over her head and over the other rats, and comfortably settled on the plush cushions of his carriage, he ordered the coachman to continue the journey.

en: He was driven on, and other carriages came whirling by in quick succession; the Minister, the State-Projector, the Farmer-General, the Doctor, the Lawyer, the Ecclesiastic, the Grand Opera, the Comedy, the whole Fancy Ball in a bright continuous flow, came whirling by.
vi: The carriage moved forward and other carriages rushed by in a convoy behind; the minister’s carriage, the advisor’s carriage, the tax collector’s carriage, the doctor’s carriage, the lawyer’s carriage, the church’s carriage, the theater troupe’s carriage, the colorful masquerade procession all rushed by continuously.
tr: The car started moving and other cars quickly followed; the Minister, the Planner, the Tax Collector, the Doctor, the Lawyer, the Priest, the Grand Opera and Comedy, and the guests of the Masquerade Ball were shining brightly as they sped along in the cars chasing one another.
es: Through the same place, many other carriages crossed in a frenzied race and rapid succession. The one of the minister, the one of the state arbiters, the one of the general overseer, the one of the doctor, the one of the lawyer, the one of the clergyman.

en: The rats had crept out of their holes to look on, and they remained looking on for hours; soldiers and police often passing between them and the spectacle, and making a barrier behind which they slunk, and through which they peeped.
vi: The rats had crawled out of their holes to watch, and continued to watch for hours; soldiers and police often stood between the rats and the spectacular procession, but the rats still peeked through the gaps in the human fence.
tr: To see them, the mice had come out of their holes and had been watching for hours; the soldiers and police mingling with the crowd in these cars were secretly observing them from behind the barrier they had formed.
es: The rats timidly poked their heads out at the entrance of their holes.

en: The father had long ago taken up his bundle and bidden himself away with it, when the women who had tended the bundle while it lay on the base of the fountain, sat there watching the running of the water and the rolling of the Fancy Ball—when the one woman who had stood conspicuous, knitting, still knitted on with the steadfastness of Fate.
vi: The father had long since disappeared with the bundle of cloth; the women who had tended to the bundle when it lay on the fountain’s pedestal now sat there watching the water flow and the masquerade procession pass by; all the while, only the knitting woman stood prominently, her hands moving swiftly as an immutable fate.
tr: The father had already taken his small pile and retreated to a corner; the women who had been bending over and looking at the pile under the fountain were now sitting and watching both the flow of water and the guests coming out of the Masquerade Ball – the only woman knitting with the determination of Fate was still knitting, standing out from everyone else.
es: The father, who had been left without a son, withdrew; the rats retreated to the depths of their holes, and on the base of the fountain, there remained only the woman who had dared to look sternly at the Marquis, rigid as Fate.

en: The water of the fountain ran, the swift river ran, the day ran into evening, so much life in the city ran into death according to rule, time and tide waited for no man, the rats were sleeping close together in their dark holes again, the Fancy Ball was lighted up at supper, all things ran their course.
vi: The fountain water kept flowing; the river kept rushing; the day quickly turned into night, countless lives in this city rushed towards death as per the law of nature, time waited for no one, the rats huddled together in their dark holes to sleep, the masquerade was resplendent again at dinner time, everything proceeded as usual.
tr: The water of the fountain was flowing, the water of the river was flowing, the day was turning into night, and many lives in the city were heading towards death as per the order, time and seasons were waiting for no one, the mice had retreated to their dark holes and were sleeping huddled together, while the Masquerade Ball was shining brightly at dinner, everything was flowing in its own course.
es: The water of the fountain flowed murmuring, the waters of the river ran fast and turbulent, the day was running to its end, the life of the city was running to death driven by Time, which waits for no one, the rats were already sleeping in their dark holes, the dance of extravagance continued among lights and dinners, and all things, to put it once and for all, continued their course.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: 8. The high-ranking official in the countryside
tr: VIII
es: VIII.

en: Monseigneur in the Country
vi: 8. The high-ranking official in the countryside
tr: Monseigneur in the Village
es: THE LORD IN THE FIELD

en: A beautiful landscape, with the corn bright in it, but not abundant.
vi: The scenery is beautiful, adorned with the bright colors of fresh cereals, but sparse.
tr: It was a beautiful view, the corn was shining, but there wasn't much of it.
es: A charming landscape, where wheat fields can be seen, although not abundant.

en: Patches of poor rye where corn should have been, patches of poor peas and beans, patches of most coarse vegetable substitutes for wheat.
vi: Many plots of land that should have been used to grow cereals were instead used to grow poor-quality rye, many fields of beans of all kinds of poor quality, and many fields of the worst vegetables replaced wheat.
tr: In places where there should have been corn, there were barren fields of rye, peas, and beans, and instead of wheat, there were fields of poor vegetables stretching out.
es: Pieces of land sown with rye where wheat could have been grown, pieces sown with beans and peas, pieces sown with vegetables of all kinds, and it is that inanimate nature, harmonizing its tastes with those of humanity, showed a decided tendency towards vegetation that was more apparent than real.

en: On inanimate nature, as on the men and women who cultivated it, a prevalent tendency towards an appearance of vegetating unwillingly—a dejected disposition to give up, and wither away.
vi: Like the men, the women who were farming, those insentient beings all exuded an air of reluctantly living, reluctantly existing - a weary intention to let go and wither away.
tr: This soulless nature had reflected on the people who cultivated it, as if they were planting and harvesting everything reluctantly – they were in a state of indifference, ready to give up and fade away at any moment.
es: Pieces of land sown with rye where wheat could have been grown, pieces sown with beans and peas, pieces sown with vegetables of all kinds, and it is that inanimate nature, harmonizing its tastes with those of humanity, showed a decided tendency towards vegetation that was more apparent than real.

en: Monsieur the Marquis in his travelling carriage (which might have been lighter), conducted by four post-horses and two postilions, fagged up a steep hill.
vi: The Marquis sat in the carriage drawn by four horses with two coachmen laboriously ascending a steep hill (the carriage should have been lighter).
tr: Monsieur the Marquis was climbing a steep hill in a traveling carriage (which could have been lighter) driven by four horses and two drivers.
es: The travel carriage of the Marquis, which, by the way, could have been less heavy, drawn by four horses and guided by two postilions, was laboriously climbing a steep hill.

en: A blush on the countenance of Monsieur the Marquis was no impeachment of his high breeding; it was not from within; it was occasioned by an external circumstance beyond his control—the setting sun.
vi: The reddish hue on the Marquis's face did not betray his noble lineage; it did not come from within but was due to an external factor beyond control - the setting sun.
tr: The redness on Monsieur the Marquis's face was not due to anything about himself, that is, not because he doubted his good upbringing, but from an external source beyond his control – the setting sun.
es: The high color of the nobleman's cheeks did not argue against his high lineage. Its origin was not internal, but rather the effect of an unavoidable external circumstance: the sunset.

en: The sunset struck so brilliantly into the travelling carriage when it gained the hill-top, that its occupant was steeped in crimson.
vi: The twilight sun shone on the carriage as it rolled up the hill, so bright that it dyed the people inside red.
tr: As the car approached the top of the hill, the evening sun hit the inside of the car so strongly that the passenger inside turned completely red.
es: The tangential rays of the sun penetrated the travel coach of the Marquis, enveloping him in halos of reddish light.

en: “It will die out,” said Monsieur the Marquis, glancing at his hands, “directly.”
vi: The Marquis glanced at his hands and exclaimed: − The sun will set soon.
tr: "It's about to set," said Monsieur Marquis, looking at his hands, "very soon."
es: —Soon it will be ready—exclaimed Mr. Marquis, looking at his hands with disgust.

en: In effect, the sun was so low that it dipped at the moment.
vi: Indeed, the sun at that moment was about to set.
tr: Indeed, the sun had descended so low that it set at that very moment.
es: Indeed, the sun was so close to its setting that it soon went down.

en: When the heavy drag had been adjusted to the wheel, and the carriage slid down hill, with a cinderous smell, in a cloud of dust, the red glow departed quickly; the sun and the Marquis going down together, there was no glow left when the drag was taken off.
vi: When the heavy brake was attached to the wheel and the carriage slid down the hill, that fiery red light quickly dissipated in the smell of scorched sun, in the cloud of dust; the sun disappeared at the same time the Marquis descended the hill and the twilight glow faded as the brake was removed from the wheel.
tr: When heavy chocks were placed on the wheels of the carriage and it began to slowly slide downhill in a cloud of ash and dust, the surrounding redness also disappeared; it was as if the sun and Monsieur Marquis had set together, for when the chocks were removed, not a trace of redness remained.
es: Having reached the top of the hill and with the heavy brakes applied to the wheels, as soon as the carriage began to roll down the slope, enveloped in clouds of dust, the reddish gleams faded: the sun and the Marquis were descending.

en: But, there remained a broken country, bold and open, a little village at the bottom of the hill, a broad sweep and rise beyond it, a church-tower, a windmill, a forest for the chase, and a crag with a fortress on it used as a prison.
vi: But there still remains a countryside with rolling hills stretching far, a small village at the foot of the hill, a wide piece of land and a hill behind, a church bell tower, a windmill, a forest for hunting, a cliff with a fortress used as a prison.
tr: At the foot of the hill, in a vast and disordered stretch of countryside, there was a small village; a little beyond this flat area, a church tower, a windmill, a grove for hunting, and a rocky outcrop with a castle used as a prison on its summit were rising.
es: Before the eyes of the Marquis stretched a broken territory, a village at the bottom of the hollow, a plain that ended in a hillock, a bell tower, a windmill, a forest abundant in game, and a fortress perched on the edge of a cliff.

en: Round upon all these darkening objects as the night drew on, the Marquis looked, with the air of one who was coming near home.
vi: The marquis glanced around at everything that was gradually darkening as night fell here, his face contented like someone about to return to his home.
tr: Mr. Marquis looked at all these objects, darkening as night fell, with the air of a man approaching his home.
es: The Marquis gazed at all the detailed objects, whose lines began to blur in the shadows of the night, with the expression of someone approaching their home.

en: The village had its one poor street, with its poor brewery, poor tannery, poor tavern, poor stable-yard for relays of post-horses, poor fountain, all usual poor appointments.
vi: The village had a destitute road, with a destitute brewery, a destitute tannery, a destitute inn, a destitute relay station for changing carriage horses, a destitute fountain, and all the familiar destitute amenities.
tr: In the village, there was a bad street where everything was bad: a bad brewery, a bad tannery, a bad restaurant, a bad stable where the postal horses were changed, and a bad fountain.
es: The village had a poor street, a poor brewery, a poor tannery, a poor tavern, a poor post relay, and a poor fountain.

en: It had its poor people too.
vi: The village also had destitute people.
tr: The people were also in bad condition.
es: Since all the services were poor, the inhabitants had to be poor, and indeed they were poor.

en: All its people were poor, and many of them were sitting at their doors, shredding spare onions and the like for supper, while many were at the fountain, washing leaves, and grasses, and any such small yieldings of the earth that could be eaten.
vi: All the villagers were destitute, many sitting in front of their doors, chopping the rare onions and similar items for dinner, while many others sat around the fountain washing vegetables and any meager produce that could be harvested from the land.
tr: They were all poor, and many of them were sitting in front of their houses, chopping thin onions and similar things for dinner, while some were at the fountain washing the leaves and various herbs they had gathered that were edible.
es: They all lived in misery, and many were sitting at the doors of their homes, preparing discarded onions and other similar items for their dinner, while others washed vegetables, herbs, and all kinds of edibles that the earth provides at the fountain.

en: Expressive signs of what made them poor, were not wanting; the tax for the state, the tax for the church, the tax for the lord, tax local and tax general, were to be paid here and to be paid there, according to solemn inscription in the little village, until the wonder was, that there was any village left unswallowed.
vi: Everywhere one looked, the cause of their destitution was apparent; taxes for the state, taxes for the church, taxes for the officials, taxes for the local authorities, and taxes for the nation, to be paid here and there, according to the solemn instructions recorded in this small village, to the point where one must wonder if there was any village not consumed by taxes.
tr: Everywhere bore the poignant traces of the things that impoverished them; according to the magnificent inscription in this small village, taxes to the state, the church, the king, local and general taxes would be paid until there was not a single village left unplundered.
es: It was not necessary to be very astute to discover the causes that reduced them to misery: just reading the solemn inscriptions placed in all visible spots of the village, detailing the taxes to be paid to the State, the Church, and the lord, along with local and general contributions, was more than enough, not only to understand why the inhabitants were poor, but to marvel that hunger and misery had not ended all their lives.

en: Few children were to be seen, and no dogs.
vi: Rarely seen are the shadows of children, and no dogs are seen at all.
tr: There were very few children around and no dogs at all.
es: Very few children were seen, not a single dog.

en: As to the men and women, their choice on earth was stated in the prospect—Life on the lowest terms that could sustain it, down in the little village under the mill; or captivity and Death in the dominant prison on the crag.
vi: For those men and women, their choices in life have been predetermined - to barely survive at the lowest level in this small village beneath the windmill; or to be imprisoned and die in the towering prison on the cliff.
tr: As for the men and women, their two options in this world were clear – either Life in the small village down by the mill, in the most miserable conditions, or captivity and Death in the prison that covered the top of the cliff.
es: As for the men and women, the choice the world offered them could not have been clearer: either live in the most miserable way in the village, under the crushing yoke of the lord, or die in the fortress perched on the cliff, destined to be a dungeon.

en: Heralded by a courier in advance, and by the cracking of his postilions’ whips, which twined snake-like about their heads in the evening air, as if he came attended by the Furies, Monsieur the Marquis drew up in his travelling carriage at the posting-house gate.
vi: Heralded by a post rider and the cracking sound of two coachmen's whips, the whips swirling like snakes around the horses' heads in the evening sky, the Marquis entered the village as if escorted by avenging goddesses*.
tr: The carriage of Monsieur the Marquis, accompanied by a herald going ahead and the driver's whip cracking and curling like a snake in the evening darkness as if Furies had descended upon them, stopped in front of the post office door.
es: Preceded by a mail coach and accompanied by the cracks of the postillions' whips, which sliced through the air like coiled serpents, the Marquis ordered his carriage to stop in front of the coaching inn's door.

en: It was hard by the fountain, and the peasants suspended their operations to look at him.
vi: The traveling carriage stopped in front of the post station next to the fountain, and the peasants paused their work to look up at the nobleman.
tr: The post office was next to the fountain, and the villagers paused their work to look at it.
es: Since it was very close to the fountain, the villagers who were there paused their tasks to look at him.

en: He looked at them, and saw in them, without knowing it, the slow sure filing down of misery-worn face and figure, that was to make the meagreness of Frenchmen an English superstition which should survive the truth through the best part of a hundred years.
vi: The Marquis looked at them, looked without paying any attention to the slow and certain erosion of hunger on those faces and the wretched, emaciated figures - an image that led the English, nearly a hundred years later, to still believe that all French people were as gaunt as that.
tr: He also looked at the villagers and, without knowing what he saw, he perceived in their pain-filled faces and bodies the weariness and exhaustion that would transform into an English superstition about the frailty of the French over a century.
es: He also looked at them and saw how they bowed their heads before him, in the same manner he had bowed his own before the lord, when a road worker happened to join the group.

en: Monsieur the Marquis cast his eyes over the submissive faces that drooped before him, as the like of himself had drooped before Monseigneur of the Court—only the difference was, that these faces drooped merely to suffer and not to propitiate—when a grizzled mender of the roads joined the group.
vi: The marquis looked down at the obsequious faces bowing before him, much like men of his kind would bow before superiors at court - except these faces bowed out of misery, not for seeking favor; at that moment, a gray-haired road laborer joined the group.
tr: As a gray-haired road worker mingled with the crowd, Monsieur the Marquis fixed his eyes on the obedient faces bowed before him, just as he bowed before the king – the only difference being that these faces bowed not out of sycophancy but out of pain.
es: He also looked at them and saw how they bowed their heads before him, in the same manner he had bowed his own before the lord, when a road worker happened to join the group.

en: “Bring me hither that fellow!” said the Marquis to the courier.
vi: − Bring that person over there to see me! - The marquis told the station master.
tr: "Bring that man to me!" said the Marquis to the messenger.
es: —Bring me that individual—said the Marquis to the messenger.

en: The fellow was brought, cap in hand, and the other fellows closed round to look and listen, in the manner of the people at the Paris fountain.
vi: Taking off their hats and holding them in their hands, the person was led forward, and the crowd gathered around to look and listen, just like the people at the fountain in Paris.
tr: The man was brought in with his hat in hand, and the others surrounded him and paid close attention, just like the people at the Paris fountain.
es: The road worker was brought before him, around whom the villagers gathered, eager to listen and see.

en: “I passed you on the road?”
vi: − Did we pass by you on the road?
tr: "Did I pass by you on the road?""
es: —Did I pass you on the way, right?

en: “Monseigneur, it is true.
vi: − Yes, sir, that's correct.
tr: "That's right, Monsignor.
es: —It is true, sir, I had the honor of the gentleman passing me on the road.

en: I had the honour of being passed on the road.”
vi: I am honored that you passed by me on the road.
tr: You honored me by passing by on the road."
es: —It is true, sir, I had the honor of the gentleman passing me on the road.

en: “Coming up the hill, and at the top of the hill, both?”
vi: − Even when the car goes uphill and at the top of the hill, right?
tr: "Both while climbing the hill and at the top, right?"
es: —Upon climbing the ramp and at the top of the hill, isn't it true?

en: “Monseigneur, it is true.”
vi: − Yes, sir.
tr: "Yes, Monsignor.""
es: —Sir, it is true.

en: “What did you look at, so fixedly?”
vi: − What have you seen that you are staring so intently?
tr: "Why did you stare at me like that then?"
es: —What were you staring at so intently?

en: “Monseigneur, I looked at the man.”
vi: − Your Excellency, I have seen a person.
tr: "I looked at the man, Monsignor.""
es: —I was watching the man, sir.

en: He stooped a little, and with his tattered blue cap pointed under the carriage.
vi: He bent down slightly and pointed the tattered green hat under the car.
tr: The man bent down a little and pointed under the car with his shabby blue hat.
es: When he answered, his pointed hat was pointing under the carriage.

en: All his fellows stooped to look under the carriage.
vi: Everyone around also bent down to look.
tr: Everyone bent down and looked under the car.
es: All the villagers focused their gazes on the same spot.

en: “What man, pig?
vi: − Who, you fool?
tr: "What man, you pig?" "Why did you look there?""
es: —What man, you piece of brute?

en: And why look there?”
vi: Why are you looking there?
tr: "What man, you pig?" "Why did you look there?""
es: —What man, you piece of brute?

en: “Pardon, Monseigneur; he swung by the chain of the shoe—the drag.”
vi: − Begging your pardon, sir; it's hanging on the chain of the claw... of the brake, sir.
tr: "Excuse me, Monsignor; the man was hanging onto the chains of the –chock– of the car.""
es: —Excuse me, sir, I mean the man who was hanging from the chain of the winch.

en: “Who?” demanded the traveller.
vi: − Who? - The officer interrogated.
tr: "Who?" asked the passenger.
es: —But who?

en: “Monseigneur, the man.”
vi: − Your Excellency, one person.
tr: "A man, Monsignor.""
es: —The man, sir.

en: “May the Devil carry away these idiots!
vi: − Damn these fools to hell!
tr: "May God punish you!
es: —Let the devil take this mob of idiots!

en: How do you call the man?
vi: What is that person's name?
tr: What's this man's name?
es: What is that man's name?

en: You know all the men of this part of the country.
vi: You know everyone in this area.
tr: You know everyone around here.
es: You know everyone around here: who was that man?

en: Who was he?”
vi: Who is that person?
tr: Who was this man?"
es: You know everyone around here: who was that man?

en: “Your clemency, Monseigneur!
vi: − Please, Your Excellency!
tr: "I beg your pardon, Monsignor!
es: —Mercy, sir!

en: He was not of this part of the country.
vi: That person is not from around here.
tr: He was not from around here.
es: He was not from this part of the country: I had never seen him in my life.

en: Of all the days of my life, I never saw him.”
vi: In my entire life, I have never met him.
tr: I have never seen him in my life."
es: He was not from this part of the country: I had never seen him in my life.

en: “Swinging by the chain?
vi: − Swinging on a chain?
tr: "He was hanging from the chain, huh?
es: —Suspended from the chain?

en: To be suffocated?”
vi: Do you want to suffocate? −
tr: Did he want to choke?"
es: Hanged?

en: “With your gracious permission, that was the wonder of it, Monseigneur.
vi: With all due respect, sir, I was wondering the same thing.
tr: "Excuse me, sir, but I thought the same way.
es: —With the gentleman's permission, I will say that his head was hanging like this.

en: His head hanging over—like this!”
vi: His head was thrown back... like this!
tr: His head was hanging down just like that from there!"
es: —With the gentleman's permission, I will say that his head was hanging like this.

en: He turned himself sideways to the carriage, and leaned back, with his face thrown up to the sky, and his head hanging down; then recovered himself, fumbled with his cap, and made a bow.
vi: He turned sideways, leaned against the carriage, threw his head back, face towards the sky; then he returned to his normal posture, wrung his hat in his hands, and bowed respectfully.
tr: Adam went over to the car, lay down on his back, lifted his face to the sky and let his head hang back; then, feeling around, he grabbed the hat he had dropped, stood up, and greeted with a nod.
es: The truck driver approached the rail and positioned himself with his face turned towards the sky and his head hanging down. Then, he returned to a normal posture and made a bow.

en: “What was he like?”
vi: − What does that person look like?
tr: "What was he/she like?""
es: —What did he look like?

en: “Monseigneur, he was whiter than the miller.
vi: − Your Excellency, he looks even whiter than a flour miller.
tr: "Monsignor, this man was whiter than the miller.
es: —Sir, he was whiter than a miller, the dust covered him from head to toe, he was whiter than a specter and taller than a specter.

en: All covered with dust, white as a spectre, tall as a spectre!”
vi: Dust covers him all over, pale as a ghost, tall as a ghost!
tr: He was covered in dust from head to toe, as white and tall as a ghost!"
es: —Sir, he was whiter than a miller, the dust covered him from head to toe, he was whiter than a specter and taller than a specter.

en: The picture produced an immense sensation in the little crowd; but all eyes, without comparing notes with other eyes, looked at Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: That description caused the whole crowd to stir; but all eyes, without being told, turned towards the Marquis.
tr: This depiction had created tremendous excitement in the small crowd; all eyes, without straying anywhere else. Were turned towards Monsieur Marquis.
es: The description produced an immense sensation in the audience.

en: Perhaps, to observe whether he had any spectre on his conscience.
vi: Perhaps to see if there was any ghost in his conscience.
tr: Perhaps to see if there was a place for ghosts in his beliefs.
es: Everyone turned their eyes towards the Marquis, perhaps believing that he carried some specter on his conscience.

en: “Truly, you did well,” said the Marquis, felicitously sensible that such vermin were not to ruffle him, “to see a thief accompanying my carriage, and not open that great mouth of yours.
vi: − Alright, I commend you, - said the Marquis, inwardly pleased knowing that a lowly creature like this wouldn't dare to anger him. - You saw a thief following my carriage and didn't even open your mouth.
tr: "It's good, Aman," said the Marquis, his voice coming out calmly as if to show that such riffraff wouldn't alarm him. "A thief sneaks into my car and you don't open that big mouth of yours to say anything.
es: —It cannot be denied that you have behaved like a man! —exclaimed the Marquis. —You see a thief climbing into my carriage, and you don't know how to open that huge mouth you have on your face.

en: Bah!
vi: Hmph!
tr: Shame on you!
es: Let him go, Mr. Gambelle, let him go!

en: Put him aside, Monsieur Gabelle!”
vi: Throw him out, Mr. Gabelle!
tr: Pull over, Monsieur Gabelle!"
es: Let him go, Mr. Gambelle, let him go!

en: Monsieur Gabelle was the Postmaster, and some other taxing functionary united; he had come out with great obsequiousness to assist at this examination, and had held the examined by the drapery of his arm in an official manner.
vi: Mr. Gabelle was the station master and also collected some other taxes; he had been obsequiously assisting with the interrogation and had importantly grabbed the sleeve of the questioned person.
tr: Mr. Gabelle was the postmaster and also dealt with some tax matters; he had rushed to help with the interrogation with great obsequiousness and had formally grabbed the sleeve of the interrogated man's arm.
es: Mr. Gambelle was the head of the post office and other services, and as the scene we are describing unfolded, in his desire to contribute to the successful outcome of the statement, he had grabbed the declarant by the arm.

en: “Bah! Go aside!” said Monsieur Gabelle.
vi: − Hmph! Get out of the way! - Mr. Gabelle said.
tr: "Come on, step aside!" said Monsieur Gabelle.
es: Mr. Gambelle was the head of the post office and other services, and as the scene we are describing unfolded, in his desire to contribute to the successful outcome of the statement, he had grabbed the declarant by the arm.

en: “Lay hands on this stranger if he seeks to lodge in your village to-night, and be sure that his business is honest, Gabelle.”
vi: − If that stranger tries to stay in this village tonight, arrest him, and make sure he has no malicious intent, Gabelle.
tr: "If this man tries to stay in your village tonight, catch him immediately and find out what he is trying to do, Gabelle.""
es: —Release that scoundrel, Mr. Gambelle, and if the stranger arrives at the village, arrest him and do not set him free until you are sure he is an honest man.

en: “Monseigneur, I am flattered to devote myself to your orders.”
vi: − Sir, it is truly an honor to follow your orders.
tr: "It is an honor for me to carry out your orders, Monseigneur.""
es: —It will be an honor for me to follow the gentleman's orders—replied Gambelle.

en: “Did he run away, fellow?—where is that Accursed?”
vi: − Where did he run off to, that boy?... Where is that wretched boy?
tr: "Where is Adam? Where did that wretch go?"
es: —Did that one escape...? But where has that damn one gone?

en: The accursed was already under the carriage with some half-dozen particular friends, pointing out the chain with his blue cap.
vi: That wretched boy had crawled under the car along with five or six acquaintances and was pointing at the chain with his green hat.
tr: The unlucky one had crawled under the car with half a dozen friends, pointing at the chain with his blue hat.
es: The damned one had gotten under the carriage, accompanied by half a dozen of his particular friends, to whom he was showing the chain of the gauge.

en: Some half-dozen other particular friends promptly hauled him out, and presented him breathless to Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: Five or six other acquaintances quickly pulled him out and dragged the panting boy to stand before the Marquis.
tr: The other half dozen friends immediately pulled him out and, breathless, brought him before Monsieur Marquis.
es: Another half dozen friends immediately dragged him out and took him to the presence of the lord.

en: “Did the man run away, Dolt, when we stopped for the drag?”
vi: − You fool, did that person run away when our car stopped to engage the brake?
tr: "Tell me, you fool, did this man escape when we stopped to remove the block?"
es: —Did that man escape when we stopped to throw the stone?

en: “Monseigneur, he precipitated himself over the hill-side, head first, as a person plunges into the river.”
vi: − Your Excellency, at that moment he jumped headfirst down the hillside, just like someone diving into a river.
tr: "Monsignor, the man threw himself down headfirst from the top of the hill, as if diving into a river.""
es: —He plunged headfirst from the top of the hill, just as if he had thrown himself into the sea.

en: “See to it, Gabelle.
vi: − Take care of this matter, Gabelle.
tr: "Come on, Gabelle.
es: —Make sure to find that out for me, Gambelle...

en: Go on!”
vi: Let's go!
tr: Let's go immediately!"
es: Move out!

en: The half-dozen who were peering at the chain were still among the wheels, like sheep; the wheels turned so suddenly that they were lucky to save their skins and bones; they had very little else to save, or they might not have been so fortunate.
vi: The people were staring at the chain still dragging between the wheels like a flock of sheep; the carriage moved so suddenly that it was fortunate their skin-and-bone bodies weren't crushed; they had nothing but skin and bones, otherwise, they might not have escaped unscathed.
tr: The half-dozen men looking at the chain were still between the wheels like sheep; the wheels turned so suddenly that the men barely saved their lives; in fact, they had very little to save in this life, otherwise, they might not have been so lucky.
es: In front of the wheels, examining the chain, were the half-dozen close friends of the trucker, resembling a flock of sheep. The wheels began to turn so unexpectedly that it was a miracle they managed to save their skins and bones, the only things they could save, fortunately for them.

en: The burst with which the carriage started out of the village and up the rise beyond, was soon checked by the steepness of the hill.
vi: The rapid speed of the carriage as it dashed out of the village and raced up the distant hill was soon hindered by the steep slope.
tr: The car, which left the village in a hurry, stalled on the steep hill shortly after.
es: The horses left the village at a gallop, but soon slowed down, as the hill's slope was so steep that they had to climb it at a walk.

en: Gradually, it subsided to a foot pace, swinging and lumbering upward among the many sweet scents of a summer night.
vi: Gradually, the carriage slowed down to a walking pace, swaying and laboriously climbing the hill in the fragrant summer night.
tr: They had slowed down to a walking pace, climbing the hill slowly and clumsily amidst the sweet scents of the summer night.
es: The horses left the village at a gallop, but soon slowed down, as the hill's slope was so steep that they had to climb it at a walk.

en: The postilions, with a thousand gossamer gnats circling about them in lieu of the Furies, quietly mended the points to the lashes of their whips; the valet walked by the horses; the courier was audible, trotting on ahead into the dull distance.
vi: Instead of the avenging goddesses, thousands of gnats swarmed around the two coachmen like a sheer curtain, and the tips of their whips now silently struck at this curtain of gnats rather than the horses; the servant walked beside the horses; the postman who went ahead had disappeared from sight, only the sound of his footsteps could be heard in the dim distance.
tr: The place of the Furias circling above the drivers was taken by thousands of small gnats that wrapped around their heads like a spider web, which the drivers tried to disperse quietly with the tips of their whips; the servant was walking beside the car; although the messenger trotting ahead was not visible, his voice could be heard.
es: The road bordered a small cemetery, where a cross with the image of Our Savior could be seen.

en: At the steepest point of the hill there was a little burial-ground, with a Cross and a new large figure of Our Saviour on it; it was a poor figure in wood, done by some inexperienced rustic carver, but he had studied the figure from the life—his own life, maybe—for it was dreadfully spare and thin.
vi: At the very peak of the hill was a small graveyard, with a cross on which there was a large statue of Christ the Savior; it was a crude wooden statue carved by some amateur villager, but he had studied the model from real life - possibly his own life - because the statue was terribly thin and frail.
tr: At the steepest point of the hill, there was a small grave with a Cross and a newly made large statue of Jesus on it; it was a poorly made wooden statue, as if carved by an inexperienced sculptor from the village, but it was so thin and scrawny that it clearly reflected the sculptor's life – perhaps even his own life.
es: It was a wooden image, made by unskilled hands, but the artist had studied from life and surely his model was his own body or that of one of his fellow villagers, as the image was horribly thin and gaunt.

en: To this distressful emblem of a great distress that had long been growing worse, and was not at its worst, a woman was kneeling.
vi: In front of the symbol of the great and worsening suffering - and it is not yet the worst - a woman is kneeling.
tr: A woman had knelt before this statue, which was a poignant symbol of these painful days that had been ongoing for a while but were expected to get even worse.
es: At the foot of that sorrowful emblem of immense misfortune, there was a woman kneeling.

en: She turned her head as the carriage came up to her, rose quickly, and presented herself at the carriage-door.
vi: Turning her head upon hearing the sound of a carriage approaching, she hastily stands up and goes to the door.
tr: When the car approached, she turned her head, immediately stood up, and moved towards the door.
es: She turned her head upon hearing the noise of the carriage, quickly stood up, and hurriedly ran towards the coach.

en: “It is you, Monseigneur! Monseigneur, a petition.”
vi: − It is truly you, Your Honor! Please, may the heavens shed light on this matter.
tr: "Ah Monsignor! I have a request from you."
es: —It's the gentleman! —he exclaimed, appearing at the door. —Sir, a favor!

en: With an exclamation of impatience, but with his unchangeable face, Monseigneur looked out.
vi: Letting out a sound of impatience but with an unchanged expression, the official looked out.
tr: Without changing the expression on his face, Monsignor shouted in an impatient tone.
es: The gentleman let out an exclamation of impatience.

en: “How, then!
vi: − Again!
tr: "What is it!
es: —What's up?

en: What is it?
vi: What is it?
tr: What do you want?
es: What do you need?

en: Always petitions!”
vi: Always begging!
tr: You always ask for something anyway!"
es: Always with requests!

en: “Monseigneur.
vi: − Your Excellency, please have mercy for the Lord's sake!
tr: "Monsignor.
es: —Sir, for the love of God!

en: For the love of the great God!
vi: − Your Excellency, please have mercy for the Lord's sake!
tr: For the love of God, help!
es: —Sir, for the love of God!

en: My husband, the forester.”
vi: My husband, the woodcutter.
tr: My husband, the forester."
es: My husband... the forest ranger!...

en: “What of your husband, the forester?
vi: − What happened to your woodcutter husband?
tr: "So what if your husband is a forester?
es: —What does your husband, the forest ranger, want?

en: Always the same with you people.
vi: You commoners are always like this.
tr: All of you have the same problem.
es: These people always ask for the same thing!

en: He cannot pay something?”
vi: Did your husband owe a debt he couldn't repay?
tr: Does he owe someone money?"
es: That he can't pay, huh?

en: “He has paid all, Monseigneur.
vi: − My husband has paid off all his debts, Your Excellency.
tr: "He had paid all his debts, Monsignor.
es: —He has paid for everything, sir!

en: He is dead.”
vi: My husband has died.
tr: He died."
es: He is dead!

en: “Well!
vi: − Good!
tr: "Good then!
es: —Better!

en: He is quiet.
vi: It is at peace now.
tr: He has found peace.
es: That way he will rest!

en: Can I restore him to you?”
vi: Do you want me to bring it back to life? −
tr: Should I bring him back to you?"
es: Do you think I can return it to you?

en: “Alas, no, Monseigneur!
vi: Oh, no, Your Excellency!
tr: "Oh no, Monsignor!
es: —Alas, sir... I know all too well that it's not true!

en: But he lies yonder, under a little heap of poor grass.”
vi: But my husband lies here, beneath this mound of withered grass.
tr: But there, lying under a clump of thin grass."
es: But he rests over there... under those wretched grasses!...

en: “Well?”
vi: − Then what?
tr: "Huh?"
es: —And well?

en: “Monseigneur, there are so many little heaps of poor grass?”
vi: − Your Honor, there are too many mounds of earth covered with withered grass around here...
tr: "Monsignor, there are so many tufts of thin grass around.""
es: —That there are many stretches of land covered with grass.

en: “Again, well?”
vi: − But why?
tr: "Well, what should I do then?"
es: —Well... so what?

en: She looked an old woman, but was young.
vi: She looks like an old lady, but she's still young.
tr: The woman looked old but was young.
es: That woman was young, although she seemed old.

en: Her manner was one of passionate grief; by turns she clasped her veinous and knotted hands together with wild energy, and laid one of them on the carriage-door—tenderly, caressingly, as if it had been a human breast, and could be expected to feel the appealing touch.
vi: In extreme anguish, she kept twisting her bony, vein-covered hands together violently, then placed one hand on the car door - gently, tenderly, as if that inanimate object were the chest of a person who could be moved by a pleading gesture.
tr: There was intense pain in her demeanor; she was clasping her veined and battered hands in front of her alternately with a mad strength, and with a tenderness and affection, as if touching a human's chest and as if that person could understand this affectionate touch, she was leaning them against the car door.
es: Her face reflected immense pain. Sometimes she energetically twisted her calloused hands, and other times she placed them on the carriage door, caressing it tenderly, as if she believed it was a human chest capable of being softened.

en: “Monseigneur, hear me!
vi: − Your Excellency, please listen to me!
tr: "Monsignor, please listen to me!
es: —May the lord have compassion on me!

en: Monseigneur, hear my petition!
vi: Your Excellency, please let the heavens shed light on this!
tr: Please heed my plea!
es: Listen to my plea!

en: My husband died of want; so many die of want; so many more will die of want.”
vi: My husband died of hunger; and many more will die of hunger.
tr: My husband died of poverty; many people are dying of poverty and many more will die because of it."
es: My husband has died of hunger... from the same illness that has taken so many others... from the same one that will take all of us in the village to the grave...

en: “Again, well?
vi: − And then what?
tr: "So what should I do then?
es: —But what are you telling me for?

en: Can I feed them?”
vi: Should we feed them?
tr: Should I feed them?"
es: Can I possibly feed all of you?

en: “Monseigneur, the good God knows; but I don’t ask it.
vi: − Your Excellency, with the sacred witness of the Lord, I am not asking you for that.
tr: "Monsignor, God is my witness to what has happened, but of course, I wouldn't ask such a thing from you.
es: —Sir... God knows it, but it is not food that I ask for.

en: My petition is, that a morsel of stone or wood, with my husband’s name, may be placed over him to show where he lies.
vi: I only ask for a piece of stone or wood with my husband's name to mark his burial place.
tr: My request from you is a piece of stone or wood, with my husband's name written on it, so that we can place it over where he lies.
es: The only thing I desire is that over the earth that covers my husband's corpse, a piece of wood or stone with his name on it be raised, so that everyone knows where he is buried.

en: Otherwise, the place will be quickly forgotten, it will never be found when I am dead of the same malady, I shall be laid under some other heap of poor grass.
vi: If not, this place will soon be forgotten, and no one will find the grave anymore once I also die of hunger and lie under some grass-covered mound.
tr: Otherwise, his place will be forgotten very quickly, and when I die from the same ailment, no one will be able to find this place, and I will probably be lying under another patch of thin grass.
es: If not, soon everyone will forget the place and they won't be able to bury me next to him when I die.

en: Monseigneur, they are so many, they increase so fast, there is so much want.
vi: Your Excellency; there are too many dead, increasing rapidly, and there is hunger everywhere.
tr: Monsignor, so many people are in this state, their numbers are increasing so rapidly, and poverty has engulfed everything.
es: If not, soon everyone will forget the place and they won't be able to bury me next to him when I die.

en: Monseigneur! Monseigneur!”
vi: Your Excellency! Please!
tr: Monsignor! Monsignor!"
es: Sir!... Sir!...

en: The valet had put her away from the door, the carriage had broken into a brisk trot, the postilions had quickened the pace, she was left far behind, and Monseigneur, again escorted by the Furies, was rapidly diminishing the league or two of distance that remained between him and his chateau.
vi: The servant pushed her away from the carriage door, the horses galloped away, the two coachmen spurred the horses to run faster, leaving the woman behind, while the Excellency - once again escorted by the avenging goddesses - was quickly shortening the miles to his private castle.
tr: The woman from Uşak had moved away from the door, the car had suddenly moved, the drivers drove the car quickly, leaving the woman behind, and the Monsignor, once again accompanied by the Furias, was rapidly closing the distance to his castle.
es: The lackey had separated the poor woman from the carriage, the horses had started a long trot, and the gentleman saw the league or two of distance that still separated him from his château rapidly diminish.

en: The sweet scents of the summer night rose all around him, and rose, as the rain falls, impartially, on the dusty, ragged, and toil-worn group at the fountain not far away; to whom the mender of roads, with the aid of the blue cap without which he was nothing, still enlarged upon his man like a spectre, as long as they could bear it.
vi: The fragrant summer night enveloped him, and as carefree as the falling rain, the night also enveloped the filthy, ragged, and weary laborers at the fountain not far away; the road worker, with the accompaniment of his green hat representing his self-worth, continued to gossip about the ghostly figure clinging to the vehicle, as long as there was someone to listen.
tr: The scents of the summer night had enveloped every corner, and these scents, like rain, without missing a single spot, were also rising over the dusty, shabby-looking, tired group standing by the nearby fountain; the road worker, with the help of his blue hat that he never took off his head, was still describing the ghost-like man to the people, as much as they could tolerate.
es: The road was good, and the time spent traveling it was not long.

en: By degrees, as they could bear no more, they dropped off one by one, and lights twinkled in little casements; which lights, as the casements darkened, and more stars came out, seemed to have shot up into the sky instead of having been extinguished.
vi: Gradually growing bored, one by one they left, the lights flickering in the small windows; then the lights in the windows also gradually went out, more stars appeared, as if they were lanterns that had not been extinguished but had soared up into the sparkling sky.
tr: As they began to tolerate it less and less, those around him dwindled one by one, and the lights flickered on the small window panes; then, as the windows darkened one by one and the number of stars increased, these lights appeared not as if they had gone out, but as if they had been thrown into the sky.
es: The shadows of a huge building and many very large trees were outlined.

en: The shadow of a large high-roofed house, and of many over-hanging trees, was upon Monsieur the Marquis by that time; and the shadow was exchanged for the light of a flambeau, as his carriage stopped, and the great door of his chateau was opened to him.
vi: The shadow of a large mansion with high roofs and many extending branches at that moment was enveloping the Marquis; and the darkness was replaced by the light of a torch when the carriage came to a stop, then the large gate of the castle opened to welcome him.
tr: The shadows of a large, high-roofed house and a multitude of trees hanging over it had just fallen upon Monsieur Marquis; when his carriage stopped and the large gate of his château opened for him, the shadows were replaced by the light of a torch.
es: It was the château of the Marquis, at whose main door the butler was waiting for him.

en: “Monsieur Charles, whom I expect; is he arrived from England?”
vi: − I am waiting for Sir Charles, has the young master from England arrived yet?
tr: "Did the Monsieur Charles I was expecting arrive from England?"
es: —Has Mr. Carlos, whom I am expecting, arrived from England?—he asked.

en: “Monseigneur, not yet.”
vi: − Sir, not yet.
tr: "No, Monsignor, they haven't come yet.""
es: —Not yet, Mr. Marquis—was the response.

en: CHAPTER
vi: − Sir, not yet.
tr: "No, Monsignor, they haven't come yet.""
es: —Not yet, Mr. Marquis—was the response.

en: IX.
vi: − Sir, not yet.
tr: IX
es: IX.

en: The Gorgon’s Head
vi: 9. The head of the Gorgon*
tr: Head of Gorgon
es: THE HEAD OF GORGON

en: It was a heavy mass of building, that chateau of Monsieur the Marquis, with a large stone courtyard before it, and two stone sweeps of staircase meeting in a stone terrace before the principal door.
vi: The Marquis's castle is a magnificent and splendid building, with a stone-paved courtyard in front and two curved stone staircases leading up to the two ends of the stone-paved veranda in front of the main door.
tr: The Chateau of Monsieur Marquis was a very imposing building, with a wide stone courtyard stretching out in front of it, and two winding stone staircases meeting on the stone terrace in front of the main door.
es: The château of the Marquis was an arrogant building, with thick and solid walls and vast proportions. From its spacious stone courtyard, two wide stone staircases started, which met at the stone terrace, like everything else, that preceded the main door.

en: A stony business altogether, with heavy stone balustrades, and stone urns, and stone flowers, and stone faces of men, and stone heads of lions, in all directions.
vi: An entire stone estate, with stone balconies, stone vases, stone flowers, stone faces, and stone lion heads everywhere.
tr: Everything was entirely made of stone, stone balustrades, stone-footed vases and flowers, and everywhere there were stone busts and stone lion heads.
es: The sturdy balustrades were made of stone, the vases were made of stone, the flowers were made of stone, the human faces were made of stone, the heads of the lions were made of stone, everything was made of stone.

en: As if the Gorgon’s head had surveyed it, when it was finished, two centuries ago.
vi: It was as if everything had turned to stone under the gaze of the Gorgon when the castle was completed two centuries ago.
tr: It was as if a Gorgon had cast its gaze around when this place was built two hundred years ago.
es: It seemed as if the head of Gorgon had presided, two centuries earlier, over the completion of that immense mass of stone and had devised its finishes and ornamental details.

en: Up the broad flight of shallow steps, Monsieur the Marquis, flambeau preceded, went from his carriage, sufficiently disturbing the darkness to elicit loud remonstrance from an owl in the roof of the great pile of stable building away among the trees.
vi: The torch leading the way, the Marquis stepped out of the carriage and ascended the low steps; his footsteps stirred the darkness, causing an owl perched on the roof of the grand stables, barely visible behind the trees, to hoot loudly in protest.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, after getting out of his carriage, ascended the wide and low stone steps accompanied by torches; as the light of the torch pierced the darkness, the loud reproach of the owl perched atop the barn among the trees was heard.
es: The torch that preceded the Marquis when, after getting out of his travel carriage, he began the ascent of the spacious stone staircase, shed enough light to provoke the protests of the owl that had its headquarters on the roof of the turret that crowned the stables and rose as if trying to scale the clouds, surrounded by trees of prodigious height.

en: All else was so quiet, that the flambeau carried up the steps, and the other flambeau held at the great door, burnt as if they were in a close room of state, instead of being in the open night-air.
vi: All around was so quiet that the torch being carried up the stairs and another torch placed at the main door burned as softly as if they were in a banquet hall rather than under the night sky.
tr: Other than that, everything was so quiet that it seemed as if the torch on the steps and the other torch hanging at the main door were burning in a closed room rather than in the open air.
es: Everything else remained quiet, so quiet that both the torch that preceded the Marquis on the grand staircase and the one that awaited his arrival in front of the honor door burned as if they were in the center of a closed room, and not exposed to the night breezes.

en: Other sound than the owl’s voice there was none, save the falling of a fountain into its stone basin; for, it was one of those dark nights that hold their breath by the hour together, and then heave a long low sigh, and hold their breath again.
vi: Besides the sound of the owl hooting, no other sound could be heard, except for the water from the fountain flowing into the stone basin; it seemed as if the dark night, having been holding its breath for hours, suddenly let out a long, lingering sigh and then held its breath again.
tr: Except for the sound of the fountain in the stone pool and the owl, there was not a sound; for it was one of those dark nights when, at every hour, the night held its breath, then let out a deep sigh, and then held its breath again.
es: Nor was any other noise heard except for the hooting of the owl, with the exception of the sound produced by the water from the fountain as it fell into the basin, for it was one of those nights that hold their breath for entire hours, only to exhale a sigh and remain breathless once again.

en: The great door clanged behind him, and Monsieur the Marquis crossed a hall grim with certain old boar-spears, swords, and knives of the chase; grimmer with certain heavy riding-rods and riding-whips, of which many a peasant, gone to his benefactor Death, had felt the weight when his lord was angry.
vi: The main door slammed shut behind him, the Marquis strode across the eerie, gloomy hall, where old hunting weapons like boar spears, swords, and hunting knives were displayed; and even more frightening with all kinds of horsewhips that many peasants had tasted before being granted mercy by death due to the lord's wrath.
tr: When the large door slammed shut behind him, Monsieur Marquis passed through a cruel hall containing some old spears, swords, and hunting knives used for boar hunting; it was becoming increasingly cruel due to the various riding crops and whips, who knows how many peasants, who had met merciful Death, had felt their weight on their backs when their master was angry.
es: The door of honor swung on its smooth hinges, and the Marquis entered a gallery whose walls displayed a great variety of ancient armor, and an abundance of darts, spears, swords, and hunting knives, along with a varied assortment of riding crops, whips, and lashes, whose weight more than one peasant had felt when their lord was enraged.

en: Avoiding the larger rooms, which were dark and made fast for the night, Monsieur the Marquis, with his flambeau-bearer going on before, went up the staircase to a door in a corridor.
vi: Avoiding the large, dark rooms that were locked tight tonight, the Marquis followed the torchbearer up the stairs to a hallway door.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, without stopping by the larger rooms that were pitch dark, followed his servant carrying a torch up the stairs and arrived at a door in the corridor.
es: Without even glancing at the large wings, shrouded in black darkness, the Marquis, always following the torch, arrived in front of a door at the end of the gallery.

en: This thrown open, admitted him to his own private apartment of three rooms: his bed-chamber and two others.
vi: The door opened to welcome him into a private suite with three rooms: a bedroom and two other rooms.
tr: This door led to his private suite of three rooms; there was a bedroom and two other rooms here.
es: Once it was opened, he found himself in his rooms, which were three, one of them his bedroom.

en: High vaulted rooms with cool uncarpeted floors, great dogs upon the hearths for the burning of wood in winter time, and all luxuries befitting the state of a marquis in a luxurious age and country.
vi: The rooms had high vaulted ceilings with cold stone floors without carpets, large grates in the fireplaces for burning wood in the winter, and every luxury befitting the Marquis's status in this opulent era and country.
tr: High vaulted ceilings, beautiful floorings without carpets, the hearth irons on the fireplace base used for burning wood in the winter months, and every kind of luxury were in a style befitting a marquis living in this age and land of luxury.
es: The rooms with high coffered ceilings, gathered all the luxury, all the refinement that befits a Marquis, who lives in a sumptuous century and in a nation that sacrifices everything to pomp.

en: The fashion of the last Louis but one, of the line that was never to break—the fourteenth Louis—was conspicuous in their rich furniture; but, it was diversified by many objects that were illustrations of old pages in the history of France.
vi: The furniture was luxurious in the style of several generations of Louis - before King Louis XIV but from a lineage that seemed destined to rule forever*; further diversified by other pieces bearing the marks of various periods in French history.
tr: The style of the penultimate member of the dynasty thought to never end – Louis the Fourteenth – was evident in all that rich furniture; but these were also diversified with items seen in the illustrations of the old pages of French history.
es: In the extremely rich furniture, the taste of the penultimate Louis of that sacred dynasty that was meant to be eternal, Louis XIV, predominated, although there were also objects that could pass as illustrations from the ancient pages of French history.

en: A supper-table was laid for two, in the third of the rooms; a round room, in one of the chateau’s four extinguisher-topped towers.
vi: A dining table was set for two people in the third room; the round room was located in one of the four pointed towers resembling a candle snuffer.
