tr: In the third room, a table for two had been set; it was a round room in one of the four towers of the castle, resembling candle snuffers.
es: In the center of the third room, a round chamber corresponding to one of the four towers flanking the building, there was a dining table set for two people.

en: A small lofty room, with its window wide open, and the wooden jalousie-blinds closed, so that the dark night only showed in slight horizontal lines of black, alternating with their broad lines of stone colour.
vi: The small room had a high ceiling, the windows were wide open but covered with wooden blinds, so only the black night could be seen as small horizontal lines alternating with large gray stripes.
tr: The room was small but had a proud atmosphere; its windows were wide open, and the wooden shutters were closed. On such a dark night, only thin black lines and broad stone-colored stripes were visible.
es: The room was small, and its window was open, although its shutters were closed.

en: “My nephew,” said the Marquis, glancing at the supper preparation; “they said he was not arrived.”
vi: − Setting the table for my nephew, are we? - The Marquis said, glancing at the dining table, hearing the servant say it was not yet ready.
tr: "My nephew," said the Marquis, looking at the table preparations; "according to what they say, he hasn't arrived yet."
es: —A place setting for my nephew?—murmured the Marquis upon entering. —

en: Nor was he; but, he had been expected with Monseigneur.
vi: The young master has not arrived yet, but the high-ranking official is waiting for him.
tr: He hadn't come yet; actually, they thought he would come with the Monsignor.
es: And yet, they just told me he hasn't arrived yet.

en: “Ah!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Ah!
es: He had not arrived, indeed, but at the castle, they were expecting him to arrive with the Marquis.

en: It is not probable he will arrive to-night; nevertheless, leave the table as it is.
vi: He might not come tonight; nevertheless, leave the table set.
tr: Then it is very unlikely that he will come tonight; still, let's leave the table as it is.
es: —It is unlikely that he will arrive tonight—added the Marquis, addressing the servant in charge of the dining room—but leave the table as it is.

en: I shall be ready in a quarter of an hour.”
vi: We will have dinner in fifteen minutes.
tr: I will be ready in fifteen minutes."
es: In a quarter of an hour, I will sit down to dinner.

en: In a quarter of an hour Monseigneur was ready, and sat down alone to his sumptuous and choice supper.
vi: Fifteen minutes later, the high-ranking official was ready, sitting alone to enjoy a lavish and sumptuous meal.
tr: The Monsignor was ready within fifteen minutes and sat alone at this magnificent and elegant table.
es: Indeed: fifteen minutes later, the Marquis took a seat in front of a sumptuous and select dinner.

en: His chair was opposite to the window, and he had taken his soup, and was raising his glass of Bordeaux to his lips, when he put it down.
vi: His chair faced the window, and after finishing the soup, he raised a glass of Bordeaux to his lips but immediately put it down. − What is that? -
tr: His chair was opposite the window, and just as he had finished his soup and was bringing the Bordeaux wine to his lips, he set the glass down on the table.
es: He sat with his back to the window. He had just finished eating the soup and was raising a glass of fine Bordeaux to his lips when he lowered his hand without drinking.

en: “What is that?” he calmly asked, looking with attention at the horizontal lines of black and stone colour.
vi: The marquis asked calmly, his eyes intently watching the alternating black and gray stripes on the curtain.
tr: "What was that?" he asked calmly, focusing his attention on the black and stone-colored horizontal lines.
es: —What is that?—he asked calmly, turning his face towards the lattices.

en: “Monseigneur? That?”
vi: − Your Excellency? What is it?
tr: "Yes, Monsignor? What did you ask?"
es: —What, Monseñor?

en: “Outside the blinds.
vi: − Outside the curtain.
tr: "A sound came from behind the shutters.
es: —Get out... Open the shutters.

en: Open the blinds.”
vi: Pull the curtain aside.
tr: Open the shutters."
es: —Get out... Open the shutters.

en: It was done.
vi: The curtain has been drawn.
tr: The shutters were opened.
es: The order was obeyed immediately.

en: “Well?”
vi: The curtain has been drawn.
tr: "What's there?"
es: —What's up?

en: “Monseigneur, it is nothing.
vi: − What? − Sir, there's nothing at all.
tr: "There is nothing, Monsignor.
es: —Nothing, sir: the treetops and the shadows of the night are the only things that can be seen.

en: The trees and the night are all that are here.”
vi: There are only trees, leaves, and darkness here.
tr: Only trees and darkness."
es: —Nothing, sir: the treetops and the shadows of the night are the only things that can be seen.

en: The servant who spoke, had thrown the blinds wide, had looked out into the vacant darkness, and stood with that blank behind him, looking round for instructions.
vi: The servant spoke after having fully opened the curtain, looked out at the empty black sky, and turned back to look at the Marquis awaiting orders.
tr: The servant who said this had fully opened the shutters and looked at the vast darkness stretching out in front of him, then pulled back inside and waited for the orders to be given to him.
es: —Nothing, sir: the treetops and the shadows of the night are the only things that can be seen.

en: “Good,” said the imperturbable master.
vi: − Good, - the master calmly said.
tr: "Alright, fine," said the calm gentleman.
es: —Alright—said his master, with unshakable calm.

en: “Close them again.”
vi: - Close it.
tr: "Then close the shutters again.""
es: —Close it again.

en: That was done too, and the Marquis went on with his supper.
vi: The curtain had closed, and the Marquis continued his meal.
tr: The shutters were closed again and the Marquis continued his meal.
es: The Marquis turned his attention back to his dinner.

en: He was half way through it, when he again stopped with his glass in his hand, hearing the sound of wheels.
vi: The Marquis, halfway through his meal, paused with a glass of wine in hand. There was the sound of a carriage rolling.
tr: He had just reached the halfway point of his meal when he heard the sound of wheels and put down his glass again.
es: He had reached about halfway through it when, for the second time, the glass he was raising to his lips stopped midway.

en: It came on briskly, and came up to the front of the chateau.
vi: The sound of the carriage quickly approached and then stopped right in front of the castle.
tr: The sounds approached quickly and stopped in front of the chateau.
es: The sound of a carriage rolling at a good pace could be heard approaching the castle.

en: “Ask who is arrived.”
vi: − Ask who is coming.
tr: "Ask who has come.""
es: —Ask who has arrived—said the Marquis to the servant.

en: It was the nephew of Monseigneur.
vi: He is the nephew of the high-ranking official.
tr: He was the nephew of the arriving Monsignor.
es: He was the nephew of the gentleman, to whom at the post house they had indicated that the Marquis would have already arrived at the castle.

en: He had been some few leagues behind Monseigneur, early in the afternoon.
vi: In the early afternoon, he was trailing the high-ranking official by a few miles.
tr: In the afternoon, he was a little behind the Monsignor on the road.
es: He was the nephew of the gentleman, to whom at the post house they had indicated that the Marquis would have already arrived at the castle.

en: He had diminished the distance rapidly, but not so rapidly as to come up with Monseigneur on the road.
vi: The nephew tried to shorten the distance quickly but couldn't catch up with his uncle on the road.
tr: Even though he had quickly closed the gap, it wasn't enough to catch up with the Monsignor.
es: He was the nephew of the gentleman, to whom at the post house they had indicated that the Marquis would have already arrived at the castle.

en: He had heard of Monseigneur, at the posting-houses, as being before him.
vi: At the relay station, he heard that the high-ranking official had already gone ahead.
tr: He had learned at the post offices that the Monsignor was a little ahead of him.
es: He was the nephew of the gentleman, to whom at the post house they had indicated that the Marquis would have already arrived at the castle.

en: He was to be told (said Monseigneur) that supper awaited him then and there, and that he was prayed to come to it.
vi: The servant said that dinner was ready upstairs and the master wanted him to join the meal.
tr: He was told that the meal was ready and he was expected at the table (the Monsignor had requested this).
es: —Go and tell him on my behalf that dinner is waiting, and that I beg him to come without delay.

en: In a little while he came.
vi: A moment later, he arrived.
tr: He came to the table shortly after.
es: Minutes later, the traveler entered the dining room, who was the same young man we have known in England under the name of Charles Darnay.

en: He had been known in England as Charles Darnay.
vi: In England, everyone called him Charles Darnay.
tr: In England, he was known as Charles Darnay.
es: Minutes later, the traveler entered the dining room, who was the same young man we have known in England under the name of Charles Darnay.

en: Monseigneur received him in a courtly manner, but they did not shake hands.
vi: The high-ranking official greeted the child politely, but the two did not shake hands.
tr: The Monsignor greeted him kindly, but they did not shake hands.
es: The Marquis received him with exquisite courtesy, but they did not shake hands.

en: “You left Paris yesterday, sir?” he said to Monseigneur, as he took his seat at table.
vi: − Uncle, did you leave Paris yesterday? - He asked the Marquis as he sat down at the table.
tr: While sitting at the table, he asked the Monsignor, "Did you leave Paris yesterday, sir?"
es: —Did you leave Paris yesterday?—asked the young man as he sat down at the table.

en: “Yesterday.
vi: − Yesterday.
tr: "Yes, I left yesterday.
es: —Yesterday, yes; and you?

en: And you?”
vi: And you? − I came straight here.
tr: What about you?"
es: —Yesterday, yes; and you?

en: “I come direct.”
vi: And you? − I came straight here.
tr: "I came directly."
es: —I came directly here.

en: “From London?”
vi: − From London? − Yes.
tr: "From London?""
es: —From London?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − You are wasting too much time, - the Marquis said with a smile.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “You have been a long time coming,” said the Marquis, with a smile.
vi: − You are wasting too much time, - the Marquis said with a smile.
tr: "It took you long enough," said the Marquis, laughing.
es: "It took you quite a while to get here," observed the Marquis, smiling.

en: “On the contrary; I come direct.”
vi: − On the contrary, I went straight ahead without stopping.
tr: "On the contrary; I came directly.""
es: —On the contrary, I made the trip very quickly.

en: “Pardon me!
vi: − Sorry!
tr: "Sorry about that!
es: —On the contrary, I made the trip very quickly.

en: I mean, not a long time on the journey; a long time intending the journey.”
vi: I didn't mean the travel time, but the time to decide to set off.
tr: I meant to say that it took you a long time to decide to come, not the journey itself."
es: —Excuse me, I didn't mean to say that you spent a lot of time on the road, but rather in deciding to make the trip.

en: “I have been detained by”—the nephew stopped a moment in his answer—“various business.”
vi: - I am hindered because... - the nephew replied hesitantly, - ... many things.
tr: "What kept me from coming," –the nephew paused for a moment– "was that some work came up."
es: —Yes... I have been forced to postpone it... various business matters.

en: “Without doubt,” said the polished uncle.
vi: − Certainly, - the polite uncle said.
tr: "Certainly," said the kind uncle.
es: —I suppose so—replied the uncle.

en: So long as a servant was present, no other words passed between them.
vi: With the servant present, they did not say another word.
tr: No other conversation took place between them during the time the servant was in the room.
es: They exchanged no more words while the servant was present.

en: When coffee had been served and they were alone together, the nephew, looking at the uncle and meeting the eyes of the face that was like a fine mask, opened a conversation.
vi: When the coffee had been served and only the two of them remained, the nephew looked at his uncle, straight into the eyes of that delicate mask-like face, and began the conversation.
tr: After the coffee service, when they were alone, the nephew looked into the uncle's face, which resembled a beautiful mask, and into his eyes, and broached the subject.
es: Once the coffee was served, and uncle and nephew were alone, the latter started the conversation, fixing his eyes on the face of the former, which seemed like a mask.

en: “I have come back, sir, as you anticipate, pursuing the object that took me away.
vi: − I have returned, sir, as you know, to continue the purpose that made me leave.
tr: "As you might guess, sir, I returned to pursue the matter that drove me away from here."
es: —I have returned, uncle, pursuing the same goal that forced me to leave.

en: It carried me into great and unexpected peril; but it is a sacred object, and if it had carried me to death I hope it would have sustained me.”
vi: That purpose has pushed me into immeasurable danger; but it is a sacred purpose and if I must die for it, I still wish to pursue it to the end.
tr: "Because of this, I found myself in unexpected, significant trouble, but this is a sacred purpose, and even if it led me to death, I would not abandon this purpose.""
es: I have faced immense danger; but the goal is so sacred that even if death had befallen me, my courage would not have faltered.

en: “Not to death,” said the uncle; “it is not necessary to say, to death.”
vi: − Don't say "die," - said the uncle, - there's no need to say "die."
tr: "Taking to death?" said the uncle; "Why is there a need to talk about death now?"
es: —Not death, dear—replied the uncle;—that lady should not even be named.

en: “I doubt, sir,” returned the nephew, “whether, if it had carried me to the utmost brink of death, you would have cared to stop me there.”
vi: − I doubt that, - the nephew replied, - if it were to push me to death, I wonder if you would stop me.
tr: "If this matter brought me to the brink of death," said the nephew, "I am not sure if you would do anything to save me, sir."
es: —I highly doubt, uncle—replied the nephew,—that you would have extended a hand to me, even seeing me placed on the very edge of death.

en: The deepened marks in the nose, and the lengthening of the fine straight lines in the cruel face, looked ominous as to that; the uncle made a graceful gesture of protest, which was so clearly a slight form of good breeding that it was not reassuring.
vi: The deep lines on the tip of the nose and the fine wrinkles running across that ruthless face looked more ominous than benign; the uncle made a polite gesture of protest, but it was clearly just a sign of courtesy rather than reassurance.
tr: Upon this, the deep scars on your uncle's nose and the distinct and straight lines on his cruel face took on a sinister appearance; with a dignified hand gesture that reflected his good upbringing rather than being comforting, he objected.
es: The uncle's nostrils flared and the lines on his face deepened, giving his appearance a more cruel expression; but the Marquis made a graceful gesture of protest, which was not at all reassuring due to its overly palpable effect of the nobleman's refined manners.

en: “Indeed, sir,” pursued the nephew, “for anything I know, you may have expressly worked to give a more suspicious appearance to the suspicious circumstances that surrounded me.”
vi: − Sir, - the nephew continued, - in fact, as far as I know, you may have deliberately arranged things to make my already suspicious circumstances even more suspicious.
tr: "Actually, sir," continued the nephew, "if it were up to me, you would do everything in your power to make my already suspicious situation even more suspicious.."
es: —Speaking frankly—replied the nephew,—if my information is correct, you have done everything possible to give weight to the suspicions arising from the overly suspicious circumstances that surrounded me.

en: “No, no, no,” said the uncle, pleasantly.
vi: − No, no, no, - the uncle said, in a cheerful voice.
tr: "No, no, no," said the uncle sweetly.
es: —No, no, no, no! —replied the uncle, laughing.

en: “But, however that may be,” resumed the nephew, glancing at him with deep distrust, “I know that your diplomacy would stop me by any means, and would know no scruple as to means.”
vi: − But whether there is or not, - the nephew looked at the Marquis with outright suspicion, - I know your strategy is to stop me by any means, and you will not shy away from any measure.
tr: Glancing at the Marquis with deep suspicion, the nephew continued, "Even if you don't do it yourself, you will involve your men and, with ruthlessness, somehow stop me.""
es: —We will not discuss that point—continued the nephew, looking at his interlocutor with evident distrust.

en: “My friend, I told you so,” said the uncle, with a fine pulsation in the two marks.
vi: − My dear child, I already told you, - the uncle said, the two creases on the tip of his nose gently flaring.
tr: "Look my dear, I told you," said the uncle, leaving a barely noticeable pause between two sentences.
es: —I am aware that, in exchange for stopping me on the way, you will exhaust all the resources of your special diplomacy, just as I am also aware that in terms of resources, you are not very scrupulous.

en: “Do me the favour to recall that I told you so, long ago.”
vi: - Please remember what I told you, a long time ago.
tr: "Please remember what I told you a long time ago."
es: —My dear nephew, I will allow myself to beg you to try to remember, to keep in mind what I told you a long time ago, a very long time ago.

en: “I recall it.”
vi: − I haven't forgotten.
tr: "I remember."
es: —I remember it perfectly.

en: “Thank you,” said the Marquis—very sweetly indeed.
vi: − Thank you, - the Marquis said, in an exceedingly sweet voice.
tr: "Thank you," said the Marquis, his voice sounding truly sweet.
es: —Thank you very much—replied the Marquis, with a voice that sounded like a musical instrument.

en: His tone lingered in the air, almost like the tone of a musical instrument.
vi: The resonance of that voice kept humming like a musical instrument.
tr: His voice resonated in the room like the sound of a musical instrument.
es: —Thank you very much—replied the Marquis, with a voice that sounded like a musical instrument.

en: “In effect, sir,” pursued the nephew, “I believe it to be at once your bad fortune, and my good fortune, that has kept me out of a prison in France here.”
vi: The nephew continued: − Honestly, I believe that it was both due to your bad luck and my good fortune that I wasn't thrown into prison in this land of France.
tr: "If you look at it closely, sir," continued the nephew, "the only reason I haven't ended up in prison here in France is because of your misfortune and my good fortune.""
es: —Indeed, uncle; I firmly believe that I owe it to his bad luck, and to my good star, that I am not currently confined in some prison in France.

en: “I do not quite understand,” returned the uncle, sipping his coffee.
vi: − I don't quite understand what you mean, - the uncle replied while sipping his coffee.
tr: "I didn't quite understand what you meant," replied the uncle, sipping his coffee.
es: —I don't quite understand—replied the uncle, taking a sip of coffee.

en: “Dare I ask you to explain?”
vi: Could you explain it more clearly?
tr: "Could you speak a bit more clearly?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to explain? —With great pleasure.

en: “I believe that if you were not in disgrace with the Court, and had not been overshadowed by that cloud for years past, a letter de cachet would have sent me to some fortress indefinitely.”
vi: − I think that if you hadn't fallen out of favor with the court, and if it weren't for that ominous cloud over the past few years, you would have already thrown me into prison indefinitely with just one order.
tr: "If your relationship with the Palace had not soured and this stain had not clung to you for so many years, it would have been a simple matter to throw me into a dungeon with a letter bearing the king's signature.""
es: I mean to say that, had you not fallen into disgrace at court, had you not been under the dark shadow of that cloud that has been enveloping you for some years, I would not have lacked a lettre de cachet that would have opened the doors of a fortress for me indefinitely.

en: “It is possible,” said the uncle, with great calmness.
vi: − It's possible, - the uncle said very calmly. -
tr: "It's possible," said the uncle with great composure.
es: —It is very possible—replied the uncle, with unshakable calm—that the honor of the family might have driven me to bother you to that extent.

en: “For the honour of the family, I could even resolve to incommode you to that extent.
vi: For the honor of the family, I might even decide to take action to that extent.
tr: "I could give you such a trouble for the honor of the family."
es: —It is very possible—replied the uncle, with unshakable calm—that the honor of the family might have driven me to bother you to that extent.

en: Pray excuse me!”
vi: Sorry! − I understand that, luckily for me, at the reception the day before yesterday, you were still treated coldly as usual, - the nephew noted.
tr: Sorry, please!"
es: —It is very possible—replied the uncle, with unshakable calm—that the honor of the family might have driven me to bother you to that extent.

en: “I perceive that, happily for me, the Reception of the day before yesterday was, as usual, a cold one,” observed the nephew.
vi: Sorry! − I understand that, luckily for me, at the reception the day before yesterday, you were still treated coldly as usual, - the nephew noted.
tr: "I was in good spirits, but the Reception two days ago was, as usual, quite boring," said the nephew.
es: —Fortunately for me, I observe that at the reception the day before yesterday you encountered the same coldness as always—said the nephew.

en: “I would not say happily, my friend,” returned the uncle, with refined politeness; “I would not be sure of that.
vi: − I don't think it's luck, my dear, - the uncle replied, his voice still polite and courteous. - I'm not so sure about that.
tr: "If I were you, I wouldn't say I'm in good spirits, my dear," replied the uncle with tremendous politeness; "Don't be so sure about that.
es: —Forgive me for saying, my dear nephew, that I, in your place, would not assert that my misfortune at court is a fortune for you.

en: A good opportunity for consideration, surrounded by the advantages of solitude, might influence your destiny to far greater advantage than you influence it for yourself.
vi: Prison is also a good opportunity to reflect in suitable solitude, and it might influence your fate even better than you steering your own destiny.
tr: The chance of a good reputation surrounded by the advantages of solitude can influence your fate much more than what you do on your own.
es: It is very likely that the reflections that solitude in a jail would have suggested to you would have had a more beneficial influence on your future destiny than your actions enjoying freedom.

en: But it is useless to discuss the question.
vi: But what good is it to discuss that.
tr: However, there's no point in discussing this matter.
es: But it is useless to discuss this matter.

en: I am, as you say, at a disadvantage.
vi: As you said, I am at a disadvantage.
tr: As you said, things are against me.
es: I find myself, as you say, in a disadvantageous position.

en: These little instruments of correction, these gentle aids to the power and honour of families, these slight favours that might so incommode you, are only to be obtained now by interest and importunity.
vi: Such small corrective measures, such gentle tools to support the authority and prestige of the family, such minor favors might be very inconvenient for you, requiring interest and pleading to obtain.
tr: These small initiatives that help improve the situation, the elegant aids that contribute to the power and honor of families, these tiny favors that disturb you so much are now only obtained through self-interest and sycophancy.
es: Today, only interest or importunities achieve those small instruments of correction, those gentle means to strengthen the power and honor of families, those insignificant favors that could have bothered you so much.

en: They are sought by so many, and they are granted (comparatively) to so few!
vi: Many seek them but very few are granted!
tr: There are many people chasing after these, but (relatively) very few get them!
es: So many covet them, and so few (comparatively) obtain them!

en: It used not to be so, but France in all such things is changed for the worse.
vi: It used to be different, but France has changed for the worse.
tr: It wasn't like this before, but France has gone very bad in these matters.
es: It was not like this in the past, but things have changed a lot, and they change every day, and it is noteworthy that they go from bad to worse.

en: Our not remote ancestors held the right of life and death over the surrounding vulgar.
vi: Our ancestors not long ago held the power of life and death over the coarse commoners around.
tr: The generations just before us held the rights to decide the lives and deaths of these insolent people around.
es: Our ancestors enjoyed the power of life and death over their vassals and common people.

en: From this room, many such dogs have been taken out to be hanged; in the next room (my bedroom), one fellow, to our knowledge, was poniarded on the spot for professing some insolent delicacy respecting his daughter—his daughter?
vi: From this room, many such beasts were dragged out to be hanged; in the next room, now my bedroom, one was stabbed to death on the spot for daring to speak impertinently about his daughter! What was his daughter worth?
tr: Many dogs were taken from this room to be hanged; in the next room [my bedroom], we know a man was stabbed because of the derogatory remarks he made about a girl, yes, about the girl.
es: How many of those dogs have left this very room to be hanged immediately! As far as I know, in my bedroom an insolent rogue who dared to utter some tasteless joke about his daughter was stabbed to death...

en: We have lost many privileges; a new philosophy has become the mode; and the assertion of our station, in these days, might (I do not go so far as to say would, but might) cause us real inconvenience.
vi: We have lost many privileges; new philosophies have become fashionable; in these times, asserting the family's status might, I don't say certainly but might, cause us real trouble.
tr: We've lost many privileges; there's a new philosophy in effect now and making a claim about this situation these days could cause us serious problems (saying it will cause would be too much, so I say could cause].
es: We have lost many privileges; that is the truth. A new philosophy has come into fashion, and I cannot deny that today, if we insisted on defending all our rights, we might encounter serious inconveniences.

en: All very bad, very bad!”
vi: Everything is very bad, very bad!
tr: The situation is bad, very bad!"
es: Things are getting bad, very bad!

en: The Marquis took a gentle little pinch of snuff, and shook his head; as elegantly despondent as he could becomingly be of a country still containing himself, that great means of regeneration.
vi: The marquis took a light pinch of snuff and shook his head elegantly, appearing deeply disappointed with the country that housed him, the great man capable of restoring the family's status.
tr: Mark took a pinch of snuff and shook his head from side to side; he was in a state of the most elegant despair about this new development in the country he was still in.
es: The Marquis took a pinch of snuff and shook his head with the expression of someone who regrets that a country disregards such excellent means of regeneration.

en: “We have so asserted our station, both in the old time and in the modern time also,” said the nephew, gloomily, “that I believe our name to be more detested than any name in France.”
vi: − We have affirmed our position, both past and present, - the grandson said in a sorrowful tone, - to the extent that I believe our family's honor in this nation of France is more hated than any other lineage.
tr: "We have made our stance so clear since ancient times," said the nephew in a sad voice, "that there is no family more hated than ours in all of France."
es: —In such a way we have asserted our social position, both in past times and in our days—replied the nephew with a somber tone,—that we have managed to make France pronounce our names with aversion and hatred.

en: “Let us hope so,” said the uncle.
vi: − Let's hope so, - the uncle said.
tr: "Let's look at the situation this way," said the uncle.
es: —Which we should congratulate ourselves for—observed the uncle.

en: “Detestation of the high is the involuntary homage of the low.”
vi: - Resentment towards superiors is the involuntary respect of the lowly.
tr: "Hating the upper class is a kind of respect that the lower class shows involuntarily."
es: —Aversion and hatred are the highest and most involuntary tributes that the small pay to the great.

en: “There is not,” pursued the nephew, in his former tone, “a face I can look at, in all this country round about us, which looks at me with any deference on it but the dark deference of fear and slavery.”
vi: − Throughout this land, - the nephew continued, in the same tone, - I see no face looking at me with any hint of respect, only the dark obedience of fear and servitude.
tr: My nephew continued in his previous tone, "In these lands," he said, "the ill-fated respect that people will have for us stems solely and exclusively from fear and captivity."
es: —I do not find a single face in this country that looks at us with deference—replied the nephew. —In all of them, I read the respect engendered by fear and slavery.

en: “A compliment,” said the Marquis, “to the grandeur of the family, merited by the manner in which the family has sustained its grandeur.
vi: − That is indeed the praise of the authority of this family, - the Marquis said, - truly worthy of the way our family maintains its authority.
tr: "This is a compliment befitting the grandeur of our family," said the Marquis, "and it means we have somehow preserved this grandeur.
es: "—Which is not without flattery for the family and for the methods employed by the family to sustain its grandeur," said the Marquis, taking another pinch of snuff and crossing one leg over the other.

en: Hah!”
vi: Ha!
tr: Isn't that so?"
es: "—Which is not without flattery for the family and for the methods employed by the family to sustain its grandeur," said the Marquis, taking another pinch of snuff and crossing one leg over the other.

en: And he took another gentle little pinch of snuff, and lightly crossed his legs.
vi: And he took a light sniff of another pinch of tobacco and comfortably crossed his legs.
tr: Then he took another pinch of snuff and carelessly crossed his legs.
es: "—Which is not without flattery for the family and for the methods employed by the family to sustain its grandeur," said the Marquis, taking another pinch of snuff and crossing one leg over the other.

en: But, when his nephew, leaning an elbow on the table, covered his eyes thoughtfully and dejectedly with his hand, the fine mask looked at him sideways with a stronger concentration of keenness, closeness, and dislike, than was comportable with its wearer’s assumption of indifference.
vi: But when the nephew rested his elbows on the table, covering his contemplative and weary eyes with his hands, that delicate mask glanced at him with a sharp, scrutinizing, and hateful look, completely unlike the nonchalant expression it had previously worn.
tr: When the aunt's niece propped her elbows on the table and covered her face with her hands in a pensive manner, the pleasant mask looked at her sideways with a mixture of sharpness, kindness, and intimacy that was much stronger than the indifferent expression worn by its owner.
es: The illustrious man affected a glacial indifference; but when his nephew, with his elbows on the table, covered his eyes with his hands and remained absorbed in his reflections for a considerable amount of time, the Marquis's mask disappeared and he glanced sideways at his nephew with such an expression of rancor that it clashed severely with his initial indifference.

en: “Repression is the only lasting philosophy.
vi: − Suppression is the only sustainable philosophy, - the Marquis said.
tr: "The only enduring philosophy is oppression.
es: —The only philosophy with lasting effects is repression—observed the Marquis.

en: The dark deference of fear and slavery, my friend,” observed the Marquis, “will keep the dogs obedient to the whip, as long as this roof,” looking up to it, “shuts out the sky.”
vi: - That dark obedience of fear and slavery, young man, will make the beasts obey the whip, as long as this roof, - he looked up, - still covers the sky.
tr: This ill-fated reverence born out of fear and captivity, my dear," said the Marquis, looking at the ceiling, "ensures that as long as our heads are under this roof, the dogs obey the whip."
es: — That somber respect engendered by fear and slavery, my friend, will make the dogs remain obedient to the whip as long as this roof protects us from the elements.

en: That might not be so long as the Marquis supposed.
vi: That might not last as long as the Marquis thinks.
tr: This period might not be as long as the Marquis thought.
es: Perhaps the roof was destined to collapse sooner than the good Marquis believed.

en: If a picture of the chateau as it was to be a very few years hence, and of fifty like it as they too were to be a very few years hence, could have been shown to him that night, he might have been at a loss to claim his own from the ghastly, fire-charred, plunder-wrecked rains.
vi: If tonight I could show you the image of this castle just a few years later, and the image of fifty other mansions like it a few years later, you might not recognize which one is the residence among those terrifying, looted, and charred ruins.
tr: If that night he were shown a picture of the state of this castle a few years later, or even fifty years later that would pass like a few years, he would not believe that this dreadful ruin, burned to ashes and plundered, belonged to him.
es: If that night they had shown him a picture of what his castle would be like in a few years, and hundreds of castles similar to his, surely no one would have made him believe in the fidelity of the painting.

en: As for the roof he vaunted, he might have found that shutting out the sky in a new way—to wit, for ever, from the eyes of the bodies into which its lead was fired, out of the barrels of a hundred thousand muskets.
vi: As for the roof that you praise, you would surely see it covering the sky in a different way - that is, with eyes forever darkened when bodies have absorbed countless volleys of bullets fired from hundreds of thousands of guns.
tr: As for the roof he was so proud of, he could see that it was covered in a completely different way – with people whose eyes eternally spewed fire and hundreds of thousands of rifles from which bullets spread.
es: If that night they had shown him a picture of what his castle would be like in a few years, and hundreds of castles similar to his, surely no one would have made him believe in the fidelity of the painting.

en: “Meanwhile,” said the Marquis, “I will preserve the honour and repose of the family, if you will not.
vi: − As for now, - the Marquis continued, - I am the protector of the honor and peace of this family, something you do not wish to do.
tr: "By the way," said the Marquis, "if you won't protect the honor and peace of the family, I will."
es: —In the meantime—continued the Marquis,—it is my responsibility to safeguard the honor and peace of our family, whether you want it or not...

en: But you must be fatigued.
vi: But you must be tired.
tr: "But you must be very tired now."
es: But now I realize you must be exhausted: shall we end our discussion for tonight?

en: Shall we terminate our conference for the night?”
vi: Shall we end the conversation tonight?
tr: "Shall we end our conversation for tonight?""
es: But now I realize you must be exhausted: shall we end our discussion for tonight?

en: “A moment more.”
vi: − A little later.
tr: "One more minute."
es: —One more moment.

en: “An hour, if you please.”
vi: − One more hour, if you want.
tr: "If you want, we can talk for another hour."
es: —One hour, if that's your preference.

en: “Sir,” said the nephew, “we have done wrong, and are reaping the fruits of wrong.”
vi: − Sir, - the nephew said, - we have sown the wind and now we are about to reap the whirlwind.
tr: "Sir," said the nephew, "we made a mistake and now we are reaping the fruits of that mistake.""
es: —We have acted wrongly, uncle, and the fruits of our iniquity are ripening.

en: “We have done wrong?” repeated the Marquis, with an inquiring smile, and delicately pointing, first to his nephew, then to himself.
vi: − Are we sowing the wind? - The marquis repeated with an inquisitive smile, gently pointing his finger at his nephew and then at himself.
tr: "Did we make a mistake?" repeated the Marquis, with an inquisitive smile, first pointing gently at his nephew and then at himself.
es: —Have we done wrong?—repeated the uncle, smiling.

en: “Our family; our honourable family, whose honour is of so much account to both of us, in such different ways.
vi: − Our family, our noble family, that nobility means a great deal to both you and me, but in two very different ways.
tr: "Our family; our honorable family, means completely different things to both of us, it seems.
es: —Our family has committed a thousand errors, yes, our honorable family, whose honor is so important to both of us.

en: Even in my father’s time, we did a world of wrong, injuring every human creature who came between us and our pleasure, whatever it was.
vi: Even in my father's time, we indeed committed many wrongs, harming anyone who obstructed our pleasures, whatever those pleasures might be.
tr: Even in my father's time, we made a lot of mistakes, we harmed many people who came between us and our pleasures.
es: Even in my father's time, we committed a thousand iniquities, sacrificing without hesitation any human being who stood between us and our pleasures...

en: Why need I speak of my father’s time, when it is equally yours?
vi: Why should I speak of my father's time, when it was also your time?
tr: But why am I talking about my father's time, isn't it your time too?
es: But why speak of my father's time, when the same happens in yours?

en: Can I separate my father’s twin-brother, joint inheritor, and next successor, from himself?”
vi: Can I separate the twin brother, the co-heir, and the successor that you are from my own father?
tr: Is it possible to distinguish my father from his twin brother, his co-heir, his successor?"
es: Can I, perhaps, establish a separation between my father and his twin brother, his joint heir, his immediate and inevitable successor?

en: “Death has done that!” said the Marquis.
vi: − Death has already done that! - The Marquis said.
tr: "Death did this already!" said the Marquis.
es: —The hand of death called me to succeed it.

en: “And has left me,” answered the nephew, “bound to a system that is frightful to me, responsible for it, but powerless in it; seeking to execute the last request of my dear mother’s lips, and obey the last look of my dear mother’s eyes, which implored me to have mercy and to redress; and tortured by seeking assistance and power in vain.”
vi: − And it has bound me to an institution that I abhor, for which I am responsible but utterly powerless, - the nephew replied. - I must find a way to fulfill the last wish that my beloved mother expressed, to follow the final look of my beloved mother pleading for my forgiveness and to make amends for the past; and I have suffered in vain seeking help.
tr: "And left me within this terrible system," replied the nephew, "the responsibility is on me but I am powerless; I am trying to fulfill the last wish that fell from my dear mother's lips and to heed the last look in her eyes, as if she were asking me to show mercy and correct the wrongs, but now I am in the agony of searching for support and strength in vain."
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain.

en: “Seeking them from me, my nephew,” said the Marquis, touching him on the breast with his forefinger—they were now standing by the hearth—“you will for ever seek them in vain, be assured.”
vi: − If you ask me for help, - the Marquis said while lightly poking his nephew's chest with his index finger, as the two stood by the fireplace, - then you can rest assured that it will be forever hopeless.
tr: "If you are looking for them here, my nephew," said the Marquis, touching his nephew's chest with his index finger – they were now standing by the fireplace – "you can be sure you will be waiting forever."
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain.

en: Every fine straight line in the clear whiteness of his face, was cruelly, craftily, and closely compressed, while he stood looking quietly at his nephew, with his snuff-box in his hand.
vi: All the delicate lines on that pale face wrinkled brutally and cunningly as the Marquis, holding a snuffbox, stood silently watching his nephew.
tr: Mark stood where he was, silently watching his nephew with a snuffbox in his hand, while every line on his clean white face had deepened cruelly, cunningly, and almost uniformly.
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain.

en: Once again he touched him on the breast, as though his finger were the fine point of a small sword, with which, in delicate finesse, he ran him through the body, and said,
vi: Once again, the Marquis pointed at the chest of the person opposite as if his index finger were the tip of a sharp dagger that he would skillfully and deftly thrust through that body.
tr: Once again, he touched his nephew's chest with his index finger, as if his finger were the sharp tip of a small sword that delicately and skillfully etched a mark on his body, and said: "My dear, I will continue this system I am in until my last breath."'"
es: —If you seek it in me, my dear nephew, I assure you that you are wasting your time: you will never find it.

en: “My friend, I will die, perpetuating the system under which I have lived.”
vi: He said: − Dear child, I will protect the institution that I have lived for until death.
tr: Once again, he touched his nephew's chest with his index finger, as if his finger were the sharp tip of a small sword that delicately and skillfully etched a mark on his body, and said: "My dear, I will continue this system I am in until my last breath."'"
es: I have decided to go to the grave perpetuating the system under which I was born and have lived.

en: When he had said it, he took a culminating pinch of snuff, and put his box in his pocket.
vi: After finishing his words, he took one last satisfying puff of his cigarette and then put the cigarette case back into his pocket.
tr: After saying this, he took one last big pinch of snuff and put the box in his pocket.
es: He took another pinch of snuff, put the little box back in his pocket, and added:

en: “Better to be a rational creature,” he added then, after ringing a small bell on the table, “and accept your natural destiny.
vi: − It is best to live according to reason, - he added after ringing the small bell on the table to call the servant, - and to accept one's predestined fate.
tr: Then, after ringing the small bell on the table, he added, "It is best to be reasonable and accept your drawn fate.
es: —It is preferable to listen to the voice of reason and accept the natural destiny...

en: But you are lost, Monsieur Charles, I see.”
vi: But I see you have lost it, young master Charles.
tr: However, I see that you have lost this, Monsieur Charles."
es: But I observe that you are lost, my dear Carlos.

en: “This property and France are lost to me,” said the nephew, sadly; “I renounce them.”
vi: − This inheritance and my France, I have lost both, - the nephew said sadly.
tr: "All this property and France are lost to me," said the nephew sadly, "I have given up on all of them.""
es: —Lost to me are these properties and even France—replied the nephew bitterly.

en: “Are they both yours to renounce?
vi: - I have given up on both. − Neither of them belongs to you, so why give them up?
tr: "Are these yours?
es: —I renounce them. —But can you renounce them? I've always believed that to renounce, one must first possess.

en: France may be, but is the property?
vi: France, perhaps, but the inheritance?
tr: It might be France, okay, but this property, wealth?
es: I don't know if France is yours yet; but the assets of our family...

en: It is scarcely worth mentioning; but, is it yet?”
vi: That's not even worth mentioning; but does it belong to you yet?
tr: Maybe it's unnecessary to even talk about it, but do you think it's yours?"
es: Of course, it's hardly worth talking about; but do you consider them yours?

en: “I had no intention, in the words I used, to claim it yet.
vi: − I said that without any intention of claiming that right.
tr: "I did not intend to make such a claim.
es: —When I spoke as I did, it never occurred to me to allude to the rights I have over them, much less to claim their possession.

en: If it passed to me from you, to-morrow—”
vi: If I inherit from my uncle tomorrow...
tr: But if it passes from you to me, then tomorrow..."
es: If tomorrow they were to pass from your hands to mine...

en: “Which I have the vanity to hope is not probable.”
vi: − I dare say that is a vain hope.
tr: "I hope that such a thing would not be possible."
es: —What I have the vanity to consider very unlikely... —...

en: “—or twenty years hence—”
vi: − ... twenty or twenty years later...
tr: "Well, what about twenty years from now..."
es: Or twenty years from now...

en: “You do me too much honour,” said the Marquis; “still, I prefer that supposition.”
vi: − You honor me too much, - said the Marquis, - but I prefer that hypothesis.
tr: "Ah, how much you have honored me," said the Marquis; "still, I would prefer this assumption to be true.""
es: —You give me too much credit; but I prefer this assumption to the first.

en: “—I would abandon it, and live otherwise and elsewhere.
vi: − ... then I would also give up, and live in a different way, in a different place.
tr: "I would give up everything and live in a different way and in a different place.
es: —I would abandon them, to live elsewhere and a different kind of life.

en: It is little to relinquish.
vi: What is there to regret about this place filled only with suffering and decay.
tr: Leaving is not that difficult.
es: It wouldn't be much of an abandonment!

en: What is it but a wilderness of misery and ruin!”
vi: What is there to regret about this place filled only with suffering and decay.
tr: What meaning do these have amidst all this misery and ruin?"
es: After all, a dreadful desert that presents nothing but miseries and ruins!

en: “Hah!” said the Marquis, glancing round the luxurious room.
vi: − Ah! - The Marquis said while looking around the luxurious room.
tr: "Ha!" said the Marquis, glancing around the luxurious room.
es: —Yes?—exclaimed the Marquis, casting his gaze around that sumptuous room.

en: “To the eye it is fair enough, here; but seen in its integrity, under the sky, and by the daylight, it is a crumbling tower of waste, mismanagement, extortion, debt, mortgage, oppression, hunger, nakedness, and suffering.”
vi: − Here it looks beautiful, but in reality, if you look under clear skies and bright sunlight, the whole place is just a pile of useless ruins, chaos, robbery, debt, pawn, oppression, poverty, nakedness, and suffering.
tr: "It looks pleasing to the eye here, but when viewed as a whole, under this sky, in the daylight, it is actually a tower where waste, mismanagement, tyranny, debt, mortgage, oppression, hunger, nakedness, and pain are piled up.""
es: —I will not say that the sight does not find some attraction in those; but when studied in their essence, in the light of reason and justice, they are a crumbling tower of extortions, wastefulness, debts, injustices, oppressions, hunger, nakedness, and suffering.

en: “Hah!” said the Marquis again, in a well-satisfied manner.
vi: − Ah! - The marquis exclaimed with great satisfaction.
tr: "Ha!" said the Marquis again, with a satisfied demeanor.
es: —Yes?—repeated the Marquis with a tone of satisfaction.

en: “If it ever becomes mine, it shall be put into some hands better qualified to free it slowly (if such a thing is possible) from the weight that drags it down, so that the miserable people who cannot leave it and who have been long wrung to the last point of endurance, may, in another generation, suffer less; but it is not for me.
vi: − If this place were mine, I would entrust it to someone more capable to gradually, if possible, free it from the heavy burden it has long borne, so that the wretched people who cannot leave this land and have been exhausted for generations might suffer less in the future; but this place is not for me.
tr: "If one day these lands become mine, I would entrust them to skillful hands that would gradually liberate them from the weight that has driven them to collapse (if such a thing is possible), so that the people who cannot leave here and have long been at the end of their endurance, or rather the generations that come after them, would suffer less, but this place is not for me.
es: —If they come to be mine, I will entrust them to more competent hands than mine so that they can gradually be relieved, if I arrive in time, from the enormous weight that drags them to the precipice, so that the unfortunate ones who are tied to them suffer less in the future. I won't be able to do it; I know.

en: There is a curse on it, and on all this land.”
vi: This estate has been cursed, and so has this land.
tr: There is a curse here and over all these lands."
es: A curse weighs upon them, and not only upon them but also upon the entire nation.

en: “And you?” said the uncle.
vi: − And you? - The uncle said.
tr: "And you?" asked the uncle.
es: —And you?—asked the uncle.

en: “Forgive my curiosity; do you, under your new philosophy, graciously intend to live?”
vi: - May I be a bit curious; with that new philosophy, how do you plan to make a living? −
tr: "Forgive my curiosity, but is your intention to live according to this new philosophy?"
es: —Pardon my curiosity; do you expect to live off the manna from heaven under the shadow of your newly minted philosophy?

en: “I must do, to live, what others of my countrymen, even with nobility at their backs, may have to do some day—work.”
vi: To live, I have to work, like my fellow countrymen, even those of noble birth will have to work one day.
tr: "I will do what my fellow citizens, even the noble ones, will have to do one day to sustain their lives – I will work."
es: —I will have to live on the same thing that so many of my fellow countrymen live on, no matter how many their credentials, no matter how ancient their nobility: work.

en: “In England, for example?”
vi: − In England, for example? − Yes, sir.
tr: "In England, for example?"
es: —In England, for example?

en: “Yes.
vi: In that country, I will be able to preserve the family honor.
tr: "Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: The family honour, sir, is safe from me in this country.
vi: In that country, I will be able to preserve the family honor.
tr: There, no harm will come to me for our family's honor, sir.
es: The honor of the family can sleep peacefully.

en: The family name can suffer from me in no other, for I bear it in no other.”
vi: Leaving the country means I will not tarnish the family honor because I will no longer hold any title.
tr: Since I will not bear this name anywhere else, there will be no problem in other countries either."
es: I will not tarnish it by working while I am in this country, and I will not be able to tarnish it in another simply because, outside of here, I will not bear the family name.

en: The ringing of the bell had caused the adjoining bed-chamber to be lighted.
vi: The sound of the bell had signaled the servants to light the lamps in the adjacent bedroom.
tr: With the ringing of the bell, the lights in the adjacent bedroom turned on.
es: The Marquis rang a bell.

en: It now shone brightly, through the door of communication.
vi: Through the connecting door, that room was already brightly lit.
tr: The bright lights of the room reached the place where they were talking.
es: Immediately, the adjacent room lit up.

en: The Marquis looked that way, and listened for the retreating step of his valet.
vi: The Marquis looked towards the bedroom and listened to the retreating footsteps of the servant.
tr: The Marquis looked that way and listened to the receding footsteps of his servant.
es: The Marquis waited for the servant who had turned on the lights to leave, and when he heard the footsteps receding, he said, looking at his nephew with a smiling face:

en: “England is very attractive to you, seeing how indifferently you have prospered there,” he observed then, turning his calm face to his nephew with a smile.
vi: − England is indeed very appealing to you, even though you haven't been very successful there, - he remarked, and that calm face turned to smile at his nephew.
tr: Then, turning his cold face towards his nephew with a smile, he said, "England seems very appealing to you, of course things went well there."
es: —England has many attractions for you, although, to be honest, I'm not surprised considering how much you have prospered there.

en: “I have already said, that for my prospering there, I am sensible I may be indebted to you, sir.
vi: − As I said, to succeed there, I know I will owe you, sir.
tr: "As I said, I am grateful to you, sir, for things going smoothly.
es: —I have already expressed that I believe I owe you all the fortunes and prosperities I found there.

en: For the rest, it is my Refuge.”
vi: Besides that, it is my refuge.
tr: Other than that, it is a Sanctuary for me."
es: In any case, England is my refuge.

en: “They say, those boastful English, that it is the Refuge of many.
vi: − Those boastful Englishmen still say that England is a refuge for many people.
tr: "According to what they say, that is, according to the arrogant English, it was a Shelter for many people.
es: —If we are to believe the vain Englishmen, it is the refuge of many.

en: You know a compatriot who has found a Refuge there?
vi: Do you know a fellow countryman who also sought refuge over there?
tr: Do you know any other citizen who took refuge there?
es: Do you know of a compatriot of ours who sought refuge there?

en: A Doctor?”
vi: A doctor? − I know.
tr: A doctor or someone?"
es: I am referring to a doctor.

en: “Yes.”
vi: − With your daughter?
tr: "Yes."
es: —I know him.

en: “With a daughter?”
vi: − With your daughter?
tr: "Does he have a daughter?""
es: —Whom does a daughter accompany?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − Yes − Ah, - the Marquis said.
tr: "Var."
es: —Yes.

en: “Yes,” said the Marquis.
tr: "It means," said the Marquis.
es: —The same one.

en: “You are fatigued.
vi: You must be tired.
tr: "You are very tired now.
es: You're exhausted...

en: Good night!”
vi: Goodbye!
tr: Come on, good night!"
es: Good night.

en: As he bent his head in his most courtly manner, there was a secrecy in his smiling face, and he conveyed an air of mystery to those words, which struck the eyes and ears of his nephew forcibly.
vi: As he bowed very politely, his smiling face had a hidden look that made his words full of mystery; both the image and the sound struck the nephew's eyes and ears.
tr: While bowing his head gracefully, the Marquis had a mysterious expression on his smiling face, which added a mysterious air to his words that did not escape his nephew's eyes and ears.
es: The smile with which he accompanied the nod of his head that he made to his nephew as a courteous farewell and the tone with which he pronounced the last words, enveloped a mystery that could not help but impress the nephew.

en: At the same time, the thin straight lines of the setting of the eyes, and the thin straight lips, and the markings in the nose, curved with a sarcasm that looked handsomely diabolic.
vi: At the same time, the thin lines around his eyelids and his flat thin lips, along with the wrinkles at the tip of his nose, all curved with a sarcastic look, making the Marquis appear both handsome and strangely evil.
tr: Moreover, his eyes, which were thin and straight lines, along with his thin and straight lips and the mark on his nose, were twisted with a devilish charm of mockery.
es: The smile with which he accompanied the nod of his head that he made to his nephew as a courteous farewell and the tone with which he pronounced the last words, enveloped a mystery that could not help but impress the nephew.

en: “Yes,” repeated the Marquis.
vi: − Yes, - the Marquis repeated.
tr: "That's right," repeated the Marquis.
es: —Yes—repeated the Marquis.—A doctor with a daughter...

en: “A Doctor with a daughter.
vi: - A doctor along with his daughter.
tr: "A Doctor with a daughter.
es: —Yes—repeated the Marquis.—A doctor with a daughter...

en: Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: Yes.
es: Yes.

en: So commences the new philosophy!
vi: Thus begins a new philosophy.
tr: So this is what started your new philosophy!
es: This is how the new philosophy begins!...

en: You are fatigued.
vi: You are already tired.
tr: You must be very tired.
es: This is how the new philosophy begins!...

en: Good night!”
vi: Goodbye!
tr: Well, good night!"
es: Good night.

en: It would have been of as much avail to interrogate any stone face outside the chateau as to interrogate that face of his.
vi: Asking that face is no different from asking the stone statues outside the castle.
tr: Questioning the uncle's face was harder than questioning the stone faces in the castle's garden.
es: The young man fixed his eyes on her face as if he expected to find in it the explanation of the last words that had hurt his ears.

en: The nephew looked at him, in vain, in passing on to the door.
vi: The nephew looked at the Marquis in astonishment while walking out the door.
tr: The nephew looked at the Marquis in vain as he walked out the door.
es: A wasted effort. He would have achieved the same by questioning the faces of the stone statues that were so abundant in the castle.

en: “Good night!” said the uncle.
vi: − Goodbye! - The uncle said.
tr: "Good night!" said the uncle.
es: —Good night!

en: “I look to the pleasure of seeing you again in the morning.
vi: - I hope to see you again tomorrow morning.
tr: "I am glad we will see each other again tomorrow morning.
es: —added the uncle.—The desire to see you tomorrow morning will keep me awake all night...

en: Good repose!
vi: Good night!
tr: Rest now!
es: Rest well...

en: Light Monsieur my nephew to his chamber there!
vi: Light the torch to guide the young master back to his room!...
tr: Light the way for the gentleman who will be my nephew so he can go to his room!
es: Turn on the lights in my dear nephew's bedroom... And roast my dear nephew in bed, if you can!

en: —And burn Monsieur my nephew in his bed, if you will,” he added to himself, before he rang his little bell again, and summoned his valet to his own bedroom.
vi: Then burn the young master on his bed as well, - he muttered to himself before ringing the small bell once more, calling the servants to prepare his private room.
tr: –and if you can manage it, even closer," he muttered to himself, then rang the small bell again to call the servant to his own room.
es: —he added to himself, before ringing the bell again, calling the valet to his room.

en: The valet come and gone, Monsieur the Marquis walked to and fro in his loose chamber-robe, to prepare himself gently for sleep, that hot still night.
vi: The servants came and went, the Marquis in his loose nightgown walked back and forth to relax and fall asleep in the still, sultry night.
tr: The servant had come and gone, and Monsieur Marquis, on that warm, still night, was pacing back and forth in his room in his loose nightgown, slowly preparing himself for sleep.
es: The valet answered the call and went out again, leaving the Marquis in his underwear and ready to get into bed.

en: Rustling about the room, his softly-slippered feet making no noise on the floor, he moved like a refined tiger:—looked like some enchanted marquis of the impenitently wicked sort, in story, whose periodical change into tiger form was either just going off, or just coming on.
vi: Only the sound of rustling fabric and the soft footsteps on the floor could be heard, making no noise, he walked around the room like a majestic tiger - just like some wicked, unruly Marquis in legend punished by magic to transform into a tiger, and now was the moment he was changing back into a man or about to turn into a beast.
tr: As he walked around the room, his soft slippers made no sound, and he moved like a graceful tiger – he resembled an unashamed, incorrigible, magical marquis, constantly transforming either into a tiger or back from one, just like in fairy tales.
es: It took him a few minutes to do so. If someone had seen him dressed as he was and wearing slippers, pacing the room with a silent and lively step, similar to that of a royal tiger, they would probably have taken him for the famous enchanted marquis of legend, whose periodic transformations into a feline were either beginning then or ending at that moment.

en: He moved from end to end of his voluptuous bedroom, looking again at the scraps of the day’s journey that came unbidden into his mind; the slow toil up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, the descent, the mill, the prison on the crag, the little village in the hollow, the peasants at the fountain, and the mender of roads with his blue cap pointing out the chain under the carriage.
vi: He walked from one end to the other in the magnificent bedroom, while reluctantly recounting in his mind the events of the previous day's journey; the arduous and slow climb up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, the descent, the windmill, the prison on the cliff, the small village in the valley, the crowd of peasants by the water fountain, and the road worker with the green hat pointing at the chain under the carriage.
tr: Accompanied by a flood of fragmented images from the journey he took that day, he advanced from one end to the other in the opulent bedroom; their arduous climb up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, their descent from the hill, the mill, the prison atop the cliff, the village in the valley, the villagers at the fountain, and the road worker with the blue hat showing the chain under the car.
es: In the depths of his imagination, while he walked from one end of his voluptuous chamber to the other, the most striking incidents of the journey that had ended that night emerged: he saw himself lazily climbing the steep slope of the hill, contemplating with the eyes of his soul the sunset, the descent of the opposite side of the hill, the mill, the chain of the galga, the prison situated at the edge of the cliff, the village in the hollow, the peasants around the fountain, and the road worker at the moment of pointing with his pointed cap to the chain of his road coach.

en: That fountain suggested the Paris fountain, the little bundle lying on the step, the women bending over it, and the tall man with his arms up, crying, “Dead!”
vi: That water fountain reminded him of the one in Paris, the small cloth bundle lying on the pedestal, the women bending over the bundle, and the tall man raising his hands to the sky shouting "Death!".
tr: That fountain reminded him of the fountain in Paris, the small heap lying on the steps, the women gathered around it, and the tall man raising his arms and shouting "He's dead!"
es: The village fountain reminded him of the other fountain in Paris, and in it he saw the corpse of the child curled up on the base, the women bent over his little body, and the tall man who, with arms outstretched, shouted: "Dead!"

en: “I am cool now,” said Monsieur the Marquis, “and may go to bed.”
vi: − It's cool now, - the Marquis said, - it's probably time to sleep.
tr: "Oh, I feel a bit refreshed," said Monsieur Marquis, "I can lie down now."
es: —I'm getting cold—murmured Mr. Marqués. —To bed, to bed!

en: So, leaving only one light burning on the large hearth, he let his thin gauze curtains fall around him, and heard the night break its silence with a long sigh as he composed himself to sleep.
vi: So, leaving only a single torch burning brightly on the large fireplace, he let down the thin gauze curtains around the bed, and listened as the night shattered the silence with a sigh as he drifted into sleep.
tr: She covered the thin canopy surrounding the bed, leaving only the lamp burning on top of the large fireplace, and as she fell asleep, she heard the night break its silence with a deep sigh.
es: He lay down on the bed, let the luxurious curtains fall around him, and prepared to sleep.

en: The stone faces on the outer walls stared blindly at the black night for three heavy hours; for three heavy hours, the horses in the stables rattled at their racks, the dogs barked, and the owl made a noise with very little resemblance in it to the noise conventionally assigned to the owl by men-poets.
vi: The stone faces on the outer walls stared blindly into the dark night for three dragging hours; during those dragging three hours, the horses in the stable clattered their mangers, the dogs barked, and the owl hooted a sound that didn't quite match the one poets often attribute to it.
tr: For three intense hours, the stone faces on the outer walls of the building stared into the dark night with blind eyes; for three intense hours, the horses in the stables neighed, the dogs barked, and the owl hooted, making sounds that bore no resemblance to the traditional sounds depicted by poets.
es: For the span of three endless hours, the stone faces of the motionless sentinels placed outside the castle gazed into the darkness of the night; for the span of three endless hours, the restless horses struck the mangers in the stables with their hooves, and the owl emitted a peculiar sound that bore no resemblance to the song that men-poets have attributed to owls.

en: But it is the obstinate custom of such creatures hardly ever to say what is set down for them.
vi: But some stubborn species like owls never agree to speak according to the descriptions imposed on them.
tr: But it is customary for such creatures to behave unexpectedly.
es: For the span of three endless hours, the stone faces of the motionless sentinels placed outside the castle gazed into the darkness of the night; for the span of three endless hours, the restless horses struck the mangers in the stables with their hooves, and the owl emitted a peculiar sound that bore no resemblance to the song that men-poets have attributed to owls.

en: For three heavy hours, the stone faces of the chateau, lion and human, stared blindly at the night.
vi: For three tedious hours, the stone faces of the castle, both lion and human, stared blindly into the night.
tr: For three intense hours, the stone lions and human faces in the castle stared at the night with blind eyes.
es: Men and stone lions of the castle fixed their pupil-less eyes on the black veils of the night for the span of three mortal hours.

en: Dead darkness lay on all the landscape, dead darkness added its own hush to the hushing dust on all the roads.
vi: The deadly darkness enveloped the scene, the deadly darkness weighed heavily on the silent dust of the road, adding to the stillness all around.
tr: Dead darkness covered everywhere, dead darkness had added its own tranquility to the silent dust of the roads.
es: Black were the fields, black the forests, black the roads, black like a sea of ink the entire landscape.

en: The burial-place had got to the pass that its little heaps of poor grass were undistinguishable from one another; the figure on the Cross might have come down, for anything that could be seen of it.
vi: The black night blurred all the withered grass mounds in the graveyard, making them indistinguishable; even if the statue of Christ on the cross descended, no one would know.
tr: The place where the dead were buried had become so cramped that the mounds covered with sparse grass could no longer be distinguished from one another; for some unknown reason, the figure on the Cross had been taken down by someone.
es: In the village cemetery, it would have been impossible to distinguish one grave from another, and no one could have said whether the cross at whose foot the woman who asked a favor from the Marquis had knelt that afternoon was still standing or had fallen down.

en: In the village, taxers and taxed were fast asleep.
vi: In the village; both the tax collector and the taxpayer were sound asleep.
tr: In the village, tax collectors and taxpayers had fallen into a deep sleep.
es: In the village, exploiters and exploited slept deeply.

en: Dreaming, perhaps, of banquets, as the starved usually do, and of ease and rest, as the driven slave and the yoked ox may, its lean inhabitants slept soundly, and were fed and freed.
vi: Perhaps the emaciated common folk were dreaming of feasts, as the hungry often dream of food, as the exhausted slave dreams of leisure, as the burdened ox dreams of rest, and in their dreams, all are well-fed and free.
tr: In their dreams, they were probably seeing a feast table, as often happens to those who suffer from hunger, or the kind of comfort and peace that slaves and oxen plowing the fields might see; thus, while the scrawny inhabitants of the region slept soundly, they were filling their bellies and gaining their freedom.
es: Perhaps during sleep, the latter enjoyed sumptuous banquets, as often happens to those who perish from hunger, or tranquility and rest, like oxen accustomed to groaning under the yoke.

en: The fountain in the village flowed unseen and unheard, and the fountain at the chateau dropped unseen and unheard—both melting away, like the minutes that were falling from the spring of Time—through three dark hours.
vi: The village fountain flows unheard and unseen, the castle fountain drips unnoticed and unheard - both vanish into the night like each second and minute counting the rhythm of time throughout three dark hours.
tr: The fountain in the village flowed for three intense hours, unseen and unheard by anyone, and likewise, the fountain in the castle dripped unnoticed and unheard – both melted away like minutes flowing in the Fountain of Time.
es: Invisible and silent waters flowed from the village fountain, just like from the castle fountain, disappearing into the distance, like the minutes that continuously slip away from the hand of Time.

en: Then, the grey water of both began to be ghostly in the light, and the eyes of the stone faces of the chateau were opened.
vi: And then, the eerie streams of the two fountains begin to glow mysteriously at dawn, and the stone statue eyes on the castle facade open wide.
tr: Then, with the dawn of the new day, the gray waters of both began to appear like ghosts, and the eyes of the stone faces in the castle opened.
es: After three endless hours, the waters began to take on light gray tones, and the eyes of the stone faces of the castle started to light up.

en: Lighter and lighter, until at last the sun touched the tops of the still trees, and poured its radiance over the hill.
vi: The sky gradually brightened, brightened, until the sun finally rose to the treetops, quietly spreading its rays across the hills.
tr: Slowly, the surroundings brightened and finally the sun touched the tops of the motionless trees, pouring its light down from above.
es: The sun rose in the East, tinting the treetops and mountain peaks red.

en: In the glow, the water of the chateau fountain seemed to turn to blood, and the stone faces crimsoned.
vi: In the morning glow, the water in the castle's fountain turned to the color of blood, and the stone statues glowed red.
tr: In the redness, the water of the castle's fountain had turned the color of blood, and the stone faces had become bright red.
es: Its gleams gave a red hue to the waters that sprang from the castle's fountain and to the stone faces of men and lions.

en: The carol of the birds was loud and high, and, on the weather-beaten sill of the great window of the bed-chamber of Monsieur the Marquis, one little bird sang its sweetest song with all its might.
vi: The birds' music soared high, and on the large, weather-beaten window ledge of the Marquis' bedroom, a small bird poured all its melody into its song.
tr: Birds were singing cheerful songs loudly, and on the weather-worn sill of Monsieur Marquis's bedroom's large window, a small bird was singing its sweetest song with all its might.
es: The birds chirped talkatively, one of which, bolder than its companions, exhausted the repertoire of its most beautiful songs perched on the stone windowsill of the Marquis's chamber.

en: At this, the nearest stone face seemed to stare amazed, and, with open mouth and dropped under-jaw, looked awe-stricken.
vi: The song seemed to make the nearby stone statue widen its eyes, open its mouth, and gape in astonishment and fear.
tr: The nearest stone face, with its mouth wide open, seemed to be staring at it in astonishment, as if in horror.
es: The nearest stone sentinel watched the singer with mute astonishment, opened its mouth, and showed signs of the deepest terror.

en: Now, the sun was full up, and movement began in the village.
vi: At this moment, the sun had risen high, and the village below began its activities.
tr: The sun was now directly overhead and the village had come to life.
es: The gleams of the day star shook off the drowsiness that reigned as an absolute lord in the village.

en: Casement windows opened, crazy doors were unbarred, and people came forth shivering—chilled, as yet, by the new sweet air.
vi: The wide windows opened, the cracked doors unlatched, and the villagers stepped out onto the streets, shivering in the gentle chill of the new day.
tr: Window shutters were opened, the bolts of rickety doors were drawn, and people shivered as they poured out into the fresh and crisp –but cold– morning air.
es: Windows were opened, doors of the houses were unbarred, and people went out shivering into the street to engage in their daily tasks.

en: Then began the rarely lightened toil of the day among the village population.
vi: Then the villagers' daily tasks, rarely light, began.
tr: Then the villagers' rarely lightened, arduous hustle and bustle began.
es: Windows were opened, doors of the houses were unbarred, and people went out shivering into the street to engage in their daily tasks.

en: Some, to the fountain; some, to the fields; men and women here, to dig and delve; men and women there, to see to the poor live stock, and lead the bony cows out, to such pasture as could be found by the roadside.
vi: Some went to the water station; some went to the fields; here, men and women dug; there, women and men tended to the miserable livestock and led the emaciated cows to find the remaining patches of grass along the roadside.
tr: Some ran to the fountain; some to the fields; on one side, a group of men and women started digging and tilling the soil; on the other side, another group of men and women rushed to tend to the miserable animals and to take the emaciated cows to graze in the meadows they could find along the roadside.
es: Some went to the fountain, others to the field; some to plow, others to dig or to graze emaciated livestock.

en: In the church and at the Cross, a kneeling figure or two; attendant on the latter prayers, the led cow, trying for a breakfast among the weeds at its foot.
vi: In the church beneath the cross, one or two people knelt, joining in the newly intoned prayers, while the cow they had brought along tried to fill its stomach with the wild grass at its feet.
tr: A few people were kneeling in the church, praying before the Cross, while the cows outside were searching for breakfast grass at their feet.
es: In the church, two or three people remained, pleading with Heaven to preserve the life of some cow or a small number of sheep.

en: The chateau awoke later, as became its quality, but awoke gradually and surely.
vi: The castle woke up later but gradually, bit by bit, according to its noble nature.
tr: The castle, in accordance with its nobility, woke up later but gradually and confidently.
es: The castle woke up later, as befitted its high social rank.

en: First, the lonely boar-spears and knives of the chase had been reddened as of old; then, had gleamed trenchant in the morning sunshine; now, doors and windows were thrown open, horses in their stables looked round over their shoulders at the light and freshness pouring in at doorways, leaves sparkled and rustled at iron-grated windows, dogs pulled hard at their chains, and reared impatient to be loosed.
