vi: First, the boar spears and the hunting knives would gleam with steel in the early sunlight, glowing red as they once did when bathed in blood; then the main doors and windows would fling open; the horses in the stables would turn their heads to the light and welcome the fresh breeze rushing in through the threshold; the shimmering leaves would rustle before the iron-grilled windows; the dogs would tug at their chains, eager to be set free.
tr: First, the spears and knives used in boar hunting, which were kept in a separate section, turned red; then they shone sharply under the morning sun; following that, doors and windows were flung wide open, and the horses in the stables turned their heads towards the door to look at the incoming light and fresh air, leaves sparkled and rustled on the iron-barred doors, dogs impatiently jumped, pulling their chains quickly to break free.
es: The sun's rays first tinged the spears, swords, and lances red; later they sparked off the swords, windows began to open, the horses in the stables grew restless, and the dogs shook the chains that held them, barking wildly in demand of freedom.

en: All these trivial incidents belonged to the routine of life, and the return of morning.
vi: All those trivial matters were part of the morning routine.
tr: All these trivial events were part of everyday life and were repeated every morning.
es: All these were trivial incidents that repeated daily, routine details of ordinary life. But something less trivial, something that was neither routine nor ordinary, was happening that morning in the castle.

en: Surely, not so the ringing of the great bell of the chateau, nor the running up and down the stairs; nor the hurried figures on the terrace; nor the booting and tramping here and there and everywhere, nor the quick saddling of horses and riding away?
vi: Of course, except for the loud ringing of the bell in the castle, except for the sound of footsteps running up and down the stairs, except for the hurried figures on the veranda, except for the chaotic clatter of shoes everywhere, except for the hasty saddling and the thunderous gallop of horses.
tr: But neither the ringing of the castle's big bell, nor the hustle on the stairs, nor the frantic people on the terrace, nor the rising footsteps from around, nor the hurried saddling and riding of the horses could be considered as usual matters, of course.
es: The great bell was ringing with insistent fury; servants were running from one place to another; many people were crossing the terrace and in the stables, several horses were being saddled with agitation. Why?

en: What winds conveyed this hurry to the grizzled mender of roads, already at work on the hill-top beyond the village, with his day’s dinner (not much to carry) lying in a bundle that it was worth no crow’s while to peck at, on a heap of stones?
vi: What wind brought that urgency to the old road worker with silver hair, who had started working on the hilltop behind the village, beside a pile of rocks with a meager food package so scant that not even a crow would bother to peck at it?
tr: What wind had conveyed this rush to the gray-haired road worker, who had already started working, having placed his bundle, which contained food that even a crow wouldn't deign to peck at (there wasn't much), on a pile of stones on the hill beyond the village?
es: What sudden impulse had seized the road worker, moments before engrossed in his work, up there on the hilltop?

en: Had the birds, carrying some grains of it to a distance, dropped one over him as they sow chance seeds?
vi: Could it be that the birds had carried that urgency away like they carried grains of rice to distant places and had accidentally scattered it upon the old road worker's head?
tr: Had the birds, while sowing the seeds of fortune, dropped a piece of it on him?
es: Were the birds of the field trying to snatch away the meager lunch he had left on a pile of stones?

en: Whether or no, the mender of roads ran, on the sultry morning, as if for his life, down the hill, knee-high in dust, and never stopped till he got to the fountain.
vi: Whether or not that was the case, on that sweltering morning, he had run full speed down the hill, dust rising up to his knees, and ran straight to the fountain.
tr: For some unknown reason, the road worker, on that stifling morning, as if his life depended on it, ran nonstop down the hill to the fountain, covered in dust and dirt up to his knees.
es: Why was he running with such fury, downhill, as if his life depended on the speed of his race? Why did he sink his legs up to the knee in the dust, and devour distances without stopping to catch his breath, until he reached the fountain?

en: All the people of the village were at the fountain, standing about in their depressed manner, and whispering low, but showing no other emotions than grim curiosity and surprise.
vi: The entire village had gathered, standing around the fountain in a state of boredom and whispering in low voices, but showing no other emotion than cruel curiosity and surprise.
tr: The entire village had gathered at the fountain, standing there with their spirits low, whispering to each other, but apart from a serious curiosity and astonishment, there was no other emotion on their faces.
es: Around it, the entire population of the village had gathered, and there they remained with consternation painted on their faces, speaking in very low voices, though without revealing any emotions other than those of somber curiosity and deep surprise.

en: The led cows, hastily brought in and tethered to anything that would hold them, were looking stupidly on, or lying down chewing the cud of nothing particularly repaying their trouble, which they had picked up in their interrupted saunter.
vi: The dumb cows that had been led away earlier were now hastily dragged back and tied to anything that could hold them, standing or lying down chewing on things not worth the effort that they had grazed on during their interrupted wander.
tr: The cows that had been taken out to graze were hurriedly brought back and tied wherever they could be tied, either staring blankly around or lying down and chewing cud, but there was nothing in their mouths worth the trouble they had gone through from their interrupted stroll.
es: Around it, the entire population of the village had gathered, and there they remained with consternation painted on their faces, speaking in very low voices, though without revealing any emotions other than those of somber curiosity and deep surprise.

en: Some of the people of the chateau, and some of those of the posting-house, and all the taxing authorities, were armed more or less, and were crowded on the other side of the little street in a purposeless way, that was highly fraught with nothing.
vi: The people from the castle and the people from the service station, along with various tax officials, all more or less armed, had gathered into a group on the other side of the small road, bustling about without knowing what to do.
tr: Some people from the chateau, some from the post office, and all the tax collectors had armed themselves to some extent and were gathered on the other side of the small street, waiting aimlessly, which was quite worrisome.
es: At the mouth of the street, people from the castle, servants from the post house, and all the village authorities, more or less armed, could be seen.

en: Already, the mender of roads had penetrated into the midst of a group of fifty particular friends, and was smiting himself in the breast with his blue cap.
vi: The road worker had pushed his way into the middle of a group of about fifty acquaintances and was beating his chest with his green hat.
tr: The road worker had already plunged into a group of fifty people and was hitting his chest with his blue cap.
es: The road worker had already penetrated the center of a group, formed by about fifty of his close friends, with whom he spoke with signs of excitement.

en: What did all this portend, and what portended the swift hoisting-up of Monsieur Gabelle behind a servant on horseback, and the conveying away of the said Gabelle (double-laden though the horse was), at a gallop, like a new version of the German ballad of Leonora?
vi: What was the matter, what was so urgent that Mr. Gabelle had to hurriedly mount a horse, sitting behind the castle's servant, and both galloped away like lovers in the ballad of Leonora?
tr: What did all this signify? Moreover, what did it signify that Monsieur Gabelle was being hastily pulled by a servant on horseback, and that this person, like a new adaptation of the German Lenore ballad, was galloping away (despite the horse being heavily loaded)?
es: What did all this mean? Above all, what did the arrival of Mr. Gambelle mean, who, seated on the back of a horse also ridden by a servant from the castle, was approaching the village at full gallop, despite the double load, as if he wanted to represent, slightly modified, the German legend of Leonora?

en: It portended that there was one stone face too many, up at the chateau.
vi: The misfortune was that another stone face had appeared at the castle.
tr: All this indicated that one more stone face had been added to the many in the castle.
es: All this meant that, in the castle, the stone faces had increased by one that night.

en: The Gorgon had surveyed the building again in the night, and had added the one stone face wanting; the stone face for which it had waited through about two hundred years.
vi: The Gorgon god in the night glanced over this mansion once more and added a missing stone face; the stone face that the god had been waiting for two hundred years.
tr: Gorgo had looked at the building again at night and added a stone face to replace the missing one; it was the stone face the building had been waiting for about two hundred years.
es: The Gorgon who presided over the erection of the castle undoubtedly decided to visit his work during the night, noticed that a stone face was missing, the same one they had probably been waiting for for two hundred years, and added it.

en: It lay back on the pillow of Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: That stone face lay on the pillow of the Marquis.
tr: This face was now lying on Monsieur Marquis's pillow.
es: The stone face lay face up on the soft pillow of the Marquis's bed.

en: It was like a fine mask, suddenly startled, made angry, and petrified.
vi: It resembled a beautiful mask, suddenly terrified, angry, then turned to stone.
tr: After a sudden shock and anger, it was like a beautiful mask turned to stone.
es: It seemed like a very fine mask, with an expression that was a little scared or angry.

en: Driven home into the heart of the stone figure attached to it, was a knife.
vi: Stabbing through the heart of the stone figure attached to that face was a knife.
tr: There was a knife plunged into the heart of this stone figure.
es: Attached to the head was a man's trunk, also petrified, and embedded in the heart of that trunk was a knife.

en: Round its hilt was a frill of paper, on which was scrawled:
vi: Around the knife's hilt was tied a crumpled piece of paper with scrawled writing: "Get to the grave quickly.
tr: A paper with the following words scribbled on it was wrapped around the hilt:
es: Around the knife's handle was a paper, on which someone had scribbled the following words:

en: “Drive him fast to his tomb.
vi: Around the knife's hilt was tied a crumpled piece of paper with scrawled writing: "Get to the grave quickly.
tr: Take this to his grave immediately!
es: “Take him quickly to the grave.

en: This, from Jacques.”
vi: - JACQUES"
tr: This was written by Jacques
es: On behalf of Santiago.”

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: - JACQUES"
tr: X
es: X.

en: Two Promises
vi: 10. Two Promises
tr: Two Words
es: TWO PROMISES

en: More months, to the number of twelve, had come and gone, and mr Charles Darnay was established in England as a higher teacher of the French language who was conversant with French literature.
vi: Months passed and years came, after twelve months Charles Darnay had settled in England in the role of a senior French teacher well-versed in French literature.
tr: About twelve months had passed, and Mr. Charles Darnay had settled in England as a French teacher specializing in French Literature.
es: Twelve months passed. Carlos Darnay had established himself in England as a teacher of the French language and French literature.

en: In this age, he would have been a Professor; in that age, he was a Tutor.
vi: Nowadays, he would be called a professor; back then, he was referred to as a university tutor*.
tr: If it were this age, he would be a Professor; in that age, he was a private tutor.
es: Today he would be given the pompous title of professor; at that time he was called a tutor.

en: He read with young men who could find any leisure and interest for the study of a living tongue spoken all over the world, and he cultivated a taste for its stores of knowledge and fancy.
vi: He taught young men who were interested and concerned with learning a globally popular foreign language, nurturing in them an appreciation for the treasure trove of knowledge and the beauty of the French language.
tr: He worked with young gentlemen who had the time and interest to learn a living language spoken all around the world, and he had developed tastes for knowledge and appreciation in this field.
es: He taught young people who had time and wished to learn a living language that was spoken all over the world.

en: He could write of them, besides, in sound English, and render them into sound English.
vi: Additionally, he could write fluently in English on these subjects and translate works into English very well.
tr: Additionally, he could write beautifully and translate these writings into English in an elegant manner.
es: Teachers like Darnay were not easily found in those times.

en: Such masters were not at that time easily found; Princes that had been, and Kings that were to be, were not yet of the Teacher class, and no ruined nobility had dropped out of Tellson’s ledgers, to turn cooks and carpenters.
vi: Such teachers were not easy to find at that time; the royalty awaiting succession had not yet been exiled to teach for a living, nor had any nobleman exhausted their accounts at Tellson's Bank to the point of becoming a cook or carpenter.
tr: At that time, finding experts in this field was not easy; the Princes of the past and the Kings of the future were not included in the Teacher class, and no poor noble had emerged from Tellson's ledgers to become a cook or a carpenter.
es: Princes and kings were far from being able to be among those who could teach, and the ruined nobility did not think of straining their eyes working over the Ledgers of Tellson's Bank, nor of dedicating their skills to the culinary arts or carpentry.

en: As a tutor, whose attainments made the student’s way unusually pleasant and profitable, and as an elegant translator who brought something to his work besides mere dictionary knowledge, young mr Darnay soon became known and encouraged.
vi: As a tutor with the goal of making students find learning both interesting and useful, and as a talented translator who could bring many new meanings to translations beyond the limits of the dictionary, Darnay quickly became famous and was encouraged.
tr: Young Mr. Darnay quickly gained a reputation and attracted attention as a teacher who both entertained and taught useful things to his students with his skills, and as a meticulous translator who added much more than just vocabulary knowledge to translations.
es: The young Darnay soon became known, as he possessed the secret of making his students find his lessons enjoyable as a teacher, and as a translator, he knew how to put something more into his work than just the knowledge derived from grammar and the dictionary.

en: He was well acquainted, more-over, with the circumstances of his country, and those were of ever-growing interest.
vi: Moreover, he had a clear understanding of the current affairs in France, which were increasingly of interest to many people.
tr: Due to the conditions of the country and the growing interest, he became known by many people.
es: Since, moreover, he managed to assimilate the customs of the country in which he lived, it is not surprising that with some perseverance, he managed to prosper.

en: So, with great perseverance and untiring industry, he prospered.
vi: Therefore, through perseverance and determination, he succeeded.
tr: Thus, with great determination and unending efforts, he achieved prosperity.
es: Since, moreover, he managed to assimilate the customs of the country in which he lived, it is not surprising that with some perseverance, he managed to prosper.

en: In London, he had expected neither to walk on pavements of gold, nor to lie on beds of roses; if he had had any such exalted expectation, he would not have prospered.
vi: In London, he did not expect to walk on streets paved with gold or lie on rose-petal-strewn mattresses; if he had such lofty expectations, he would have already failed.
tr: Previously, in London, he had neither hoped to walk on golden pavements nor to lie on beds covered with rose petals; if his ambitions had been so high, he wouldn't have been this successful anyway.
es: When he moved to London, he did not do so driven by the hope of walking on sidewalks of gold or sleeping on a bed of roses. If he had harbored those hopes, he surely would not have prospered.

en: He had expected labour, and he found it, and did it and made the best of it.
vi: He only wanted to work and found a job, made efforts, and never lost heart.
tr: He had wanted to do a job, and he found it, did it, and even became the best among those who did it.
es: He expected work, found it, dedicated himself to it with fervor, and made the most of his labor: that was the secret of his prosperity.

en: In this, his prosperity consisted.
vi: His success stemmed from that.
tr: This was the real wealth.
es: He expected work, found it, dedicated himself to it with fervor, and made the most of his labor: that was the secret of his prosperity.

en: A certain portion of his time was passed at Cambridge, where he read with undergraduates as a sort of tolerated smuggler who drove a contraband trade in European languages, instead of conveying Greek and Latin through the Custom-house.
vi: Part of his time was spent teaching at Cambridge to students, a school that accepted him as a smuggler of tax-evading European languages rather than a merchant of Greek and Latin antiquities who goes straight through customs.
tr: He spent a portion of his time in Cambridge, where, in his work with students, he was like a kind of smuggler who was tolerated for engaging in the contraband trade of European languages instead of passing Greek and Latin through customs.
es: He spent part of his time in Cambridge, talking with the students and teaching them, almost surreptitiously, European languages, while disregarding Greek and Latin, which were already extensively taught at that educational institution, and the rest of the day he stayed in London.

en: The rest of his time he passed in London.
vi: The rest of his time was spent in London.
tr: He spent the rest of his time in London.
es: But let's move on to a less unpleasant matter.

en: Now, from the days when it was always summer in Eden, to these days when it is mostly winter in fallen latitudes, the world of a man has invariably gone one way—Charles Darnay’s way—the way of the love of a woman.
vi: And so, from the days when it was always summer in the Garden of Eden until it turned into the winter of the fallen world, the world of that gentleman followed a single focused path, the path of Charles Darnay - the path to the heart of a woman.
tr: Men on earth have always walked the same path—from the days of eternal summer in paradise to the winter days in today's sinful lands—on the path of Charles Darnay, in pursuit of a woman's love.
es: From the remote times when humanity enjoyed a perpetual summer, to those we suffer today, in which we have to settle for a no less perpetual winter, the world has invariably followed the same course; the course of Charles Darnay... the course of love for woman.

en: He had loved Lucie Manette from the hour of his danger.
vi: He had loved Lucie Manette from the moment his life was in danger.
tr: Since that hour when his life was in danger, he had loved Lucie Manette.
es: He had fallen in love with Lucie Manette on the day when danger loomed over his head.

en: He had never heard a sound so sweet and dear as the sound of her compassionate voice; he had never seen a face so tenderly beautiful, as hers when it was confronted with his own on the edge of the grave that had been dug for him.
vi: Never before had he heard a sound as gentle and lovely as her sympathetic voice; never before had he seen a face as beautiful and kind-hearted as hers when Lucie looked at him standing by the edge of the freshly dug grave.
tr: Until he met her at the edge of the grave dug for him, Charles had never heard a voice as sweet and pleasant as Lucie's, nor had he encountered a face as kind and beautiful as hers.
es: In his ears, no voice had ever resonated with such harmonious, delicate, tender tones as those she used on that occasion in her compassionate voice, nor had his eyes ever seen a face as enchanting, as angelic as Lucie's, when she saw him at the very edge of the grave that false accusers had opened at his feet.

en: But, he had not yet spoken to her on the subject; the assassination at the deserted chateau far away beyond the heaving water and the long, long, dusty roads—the solid stone chateau which had itself become the mere mist of a dream—had been done a year, and he had never yet, by so much as a single spoken word, disclosed to her the state of his heart.
vi: Yet he had never once expressed his feelings; the assassination a year ago at the desolate castle across the stormy sea and the long, dusty miles - the towering stone castle now just a hazy dream - and he still had not, even once, confessed his heart to Lucie.
tr: But he had not yet said anything to her about it; a year had passed since the murder committed in that desolate stone chateau –which had turned into a mist within a dream– far beyond the rising waters and long dusty roads, yet Charles Darnay had not uttered a single word to Lucie Manette about his feelings.
es: His lips, however, had not revealed the secret of his heart. The murder committed on the other side of the Channel, in a deserted castle, that robust stone castle, dated back a year, and young Darnay had revealed the state of his soul to no one.

en: That he had his reasons for this, he knew full well.
vi: He had a reason to remain silent; he knew all too well.
tr: There were clear reasons for this, and he knew them very well.
es: That Darnay had his reasons for acting in such a manner, he knew perfectly well; but whether those reasons had disappeared, or whether he could no longer keep the secret locked in his chest, the fact is that one summer day, upon his return from Cambridge, he made his way to the quiet corner of Soho, determined to open his heart to Doctor Manette.

en: It was again a summer day when, lately arrived in London from his college occupation, he turned into the quiet corner in Soho, bent on seeking an opportunity of opening his mind to Doctor Manette.
vi: Then one summer day, when he returned to London after his university teaching duties, Darnay turned into a quiet corner of Soho, determined to find an opportunity to express his feelings to Dr. Manette.
tr: Again on a summer day, in London, late on his return from work at the school, he turned to the quiet corner in Soho with the hope of finding an opportunity to share his thoughts with Doctor Manette.
es: That Darnay had his reasons for acting in such a manner, he knew perfectly well; but whether those reasons had disappeared, or whether he could no longer keep the secret locked in his chest, the fact is that one summer day, upon his return from Cambridge, he made his way to the quiet corner of Soho, determined to open his heart to Doctor Manette.

en: It was the close of the summer day, and he knew Lucie to be out with Miss Pross.
vi: It was a late summer day, and he knew Lucie would be out with Miss Pross.
tr: It was a summer evening, and he knew that Lucie had gone out with Miss Pross.
es: The day was drawing to a close, and he knew that Lucie would have gone out with Miss Pross.

en: He found the Doctor reading in his arm-chair at a window.
vi: I saw the doctor reading a book in the armchair by the window.
tr: He found the Doctor reading a book in a chair by the window.
es: He found the doctor reading by the window.

en: The energy which had at once supported him under his old sufferings and aggravated their sharpness, had been gradually restored to him.
vi: The source of vitality, once thought to be exhausted due to the struggles of past hardships, has gradually recovered.
tr: He was gradually regaining the strength that had supported him during his painful old days and had also intensified those pains.
es: The energies that once sustained him, preventing him from being overwhelmed by the weight of his tortures, had gradually restored him.

en: He was now a very energetic man indeed, with great firmness of purpose, strength of resolution, and vigour of action.
vi: He is now truly a person full of life, with a steadfast purpose, strong determination, and enthusiastic activity.
tr: He was now an extremely energetic man, capable of making sound decisions and possessing the determination and strength to implement them.
es: He was now a man strong in his purposes, energetic in his resolutions, vigorous in his actions.

en: In his recovered energy he was sometimes a little fitful and sudden, as he had at first been in the exercise of his other recovered faculties; but, this had never been frequently observable, and had grown more and more rare.
vi: That source of vitality sometimes also suddenly depletes as seen during the early stages of his recovery; however, such episodes do not occur frequently and are becoming increasingly rare.
tr: Just as he had initially experienced difficulties with the other skills he had regained, this returning energy sometimes disrupted his balance and routine, but it wasn't too bothersome and its frequency was decreasing day by day.
es: He studied a lot, slept little, endured great fatigue without effort, and was constantly seen content and happy.

en: He studied much, slept little, sustained a great deal of fatigue with ease, and was equably cheerful.
vi: He read a lot, slept little, was hardworking, and always cheerful.
tr: He works a lot, sleeps little, easily overcomes all that fatigue, and derives great happiness from all of it.
es: He studied a lot, slept little, endured great fatigue without effort, and was constantly seen content and happy.

en: To him, now entered Charles Darnay, at sight of whom he laid aside his book and held out his hand.
vi: Seeing Charles Darnay enter, he set the book aside and extended his hand for a shake.
tr: Now, seeing Charles Darnay enter the room, he put the book he was reading aside and extended his hand.
es: Upon seeing Charles Darnay enter his study, he put down the book and extended his right hand to the newcomer.

en: “Charles Darnay!
vi: − Charles Darnay!
tr: "Charles Darnay!
es: —Friend Darnay! —he exclaimed.

en: I rejoice to see you.
vi: It's so good to see you.
tr: I am glad to see you.
es: —How much pleasure your visit gives me!

en: We have been counting on your return these three or four days past.
vi: We had calculated that you must have returned here three or four days ago.
tr: We have been expecting you for three or four days.
es: For the past three or four days, we have been expecting your return.

en: mr Stryver and Sydney Carton were both here yesterday, and both made you out to be more than due.”
vi: Yesterday, both lawyer Stryver and Sydney Carton came here, and both said that this time you were gone longer than usual.
tr: Yesterday Mr. Stryver and Sydney Carton were here, both of them thought you would come earlier."
es: Yesterday, Mr. Stryver and Mr. Carton were here, and both agreed in saying that you have deprived us of your presence more than necessary.

en: “I am obliged to them for their interest in the matter,” he answered, a little coldly as to them, though very warmly as to the Doctor.
vi: − Thank them for their concern about me, - he replied, somewhat coldly at the mention of the two others, though still courteous with the doctor.
tr: "I am grateful for their concern," she replied, with a somewhat cold demeanor, but this coldness was not directed at the Doctor, but at them.
es: —I sincerely appreciate the interest those gentlemen show me—replied Darnay with some coldness.

en: “Miss Manette—”
vi: - Miss Manette...
tr: "Miss Manette..."
es: —And Miss Lucía?

en: “Is well,” said the Doctor, as he stopped short, “and your return will delight us all.
vi: − Still healthy, - the doctor interrupted, - and we are all happy that you have returned.
tr: "Good," said the Doctor briefly; "your arrival will make us all happy.
es: —Alright, thank you very much. Your return will be a source of joy for all of us...

en: She has gone out on some household matters, but will soon be home.”
vi: Lucie has gone out to take care of some household chores, but she will be back soon.
tr: He had gone out for some errands related to the house, but he will be back soon."
es: She has gone shopping, but she won't take long to return.

en: “Doctor Manette, I knew she was from home.
vi: − Dr. Manette, I know she is not home, so I take this opportunity to speak with you.
tr: "Doctor Manette, I knew that your daughter was not at home.
es: —I knew that he was out of the house, doctor.

en: I took the opportunity of her being from home, to beg to speak to you.”
vi: − Dr. Manette, I know she is not home, so I take this opportunity to speak with you.
tr: I waited for a moment when she was not at home to be able to talk to you."
es: Precisely, I took advantage of the occasion of his departure to request a conference with you.

en: There was a blank silence.
vi: Empty silence. − Really? -
tr: There was absolute silence.
es: The doctor fell silent.

en: “Yes?” said the Doctor, with evident constraint.
vi: The doctor clearly tried to stay calm.
tr: "Well?" said the Doctor with obvious tension.
es: —Yes?—he finally asked.

en: “Bring your chair here, and speak on.”
vi: - Bring a chair over here and we'll talk.
tr: "Pull up a chair and let's talk."
es: —Pull up a chair and we'll talk.

en: He complied as to the chair, but appeared to find the speaking on less easy.
vi: He brought the chair over but found it hard to speak.
tr: Charles immediately pulled the chair: but starting to talk was not that easy.
es: The young man brought a chair without difficulty, but it seems he found it to start the conference.

en: “I have had the happiness, Doctor Manette, of being so intimate here,” so he at length began, “for some year and a half, that I hope the topic on which I am about to touch may not—”
vi: − Doctor, - he said after a while, - I have had the honor of being warmly welcomed here for a year and a half now, so I hope that what I am about to say will not...
tr: "Doctor Manette, for the past one and a half years," he began shortly, "the closeness I have felt from you all has made me very happy, and therefore, the matter I will touch upon shortly..."
es: —I have had the pleasure of frequenting this house so often—he began to say at last—for a year and a half, that I hope the subject I am going to touch upon will not be...

en: He was stayed by the Doctor’s putting out his hand to stop him.
vi: The doctor raised his hand to stop him and kept it in front of him for a moment before withdrawing and saying: − Is it about Lucie? −
tr: When the doctor reached out his hand to stop him, Charles immediately fell silent.
es: The doctor interrupted him by extending a hand.

en: When he had kept it so a little while, he said, drawing it back:
vi: The doctor raised his hand to stop him and kept it in front of him for a moment before withdrawing and saying: − Is it about Lucie? −
tr: After holding his hand like that for a while, he spoke as he pulled it back:
es: The doctor interrupted him by extending a hand.

en: “Is Lucie the topic?”
vi: Yes, it is.
tr: "Is it about Lucie?"
es: —Is Lucía the topic in question?—he asked.

en: “She is.”
vi: − I always find it difficult to talk about Lucie.
tr: "Yes."
es: —It's Lucía.

en: “It is hard for me to speak of her at any time.
vi: − I always find it difficult to talk about Lucie.
tr: "Talking about him is always difficult for me.
es: —It always affects me deeply to talk about Lucía; but it is painful for me to hear you speak of her in the tone that you do, Darnay.

en: It is very hard for me to hear her spoken of in that tone of yours, Charles Darnay.”
vi: And it is also very hard for me to hear you speak about Lucie in that tone, Mr. Charles Darnay.
tr: Hearing someone mention him in that tone of voice is even harder, Charles Darnay."
es: —It always affects me deeply to talk about Lucía; but it is painful for me to hear you speak of her in the tone that you do, Darnay.

en: “It is a tone of fervent admiration, true homage, and deep love, Doctor Manette!” he said deferentially.
vi: − That is a voice of earnest admiration, sincere respect, and deep affection, Dr. Manette! - Darnay's words were full of reverence.
tr: Darnay said respectfully, "This tone of voice contains great admiration, sincere respect, and deep affection, Doctor Manette!"
es: —It is the tone of fervent admiration, of enthusiastic homage, of the deepest love, doctor—replied Darnay.

en: There was another blank silence before her father rejoined:
vi: After another moment of empty silence, the father finally replied: − I trust you.
tr: Before Lucie's father responded, there was absolute silence again.
es: Another pause longer than the previous one.

en: “I believe it.
vi: You are trustworthy, I know.
tr: "I believe.
es: —I believe it.

en: I do you justice; I believe it.”
vi: You are trustworthy, I know.
tr: I am sure of your honesty; I believe in you."
es: It is my pleasure to do you justice... I believe it.

en: His constraint was so manifest, and it was so manifest, too, that it originated in an unwillingness to approach the subject, that Charles Darnay hesitated.
vi: The doctor's restraint was evident because he did not want to talk about his daughter, and this attitude was so pronounced that it made Charles Darnay hesitant.
tr: It was so obvious that the Doctor's tension stemmed from his reluctance to discuss this matter that Charles Darnay hesitated.
es: The doctor's displeasure was so visible that Darnay, realizing he had touched on a subject that upset the father, hesitated.

en: “Shall I go on, sir?”
vi: − Can I continue, sir?
tr: "Shall I continue, sir?"
es: —May I continue, sir?—he asked.

en: Another blank.
vi: Another moment of emptiness.
tr: Another silence.
es: New pause.

en: “Yes, go on.”
vi: − Alright, continue.
tr: "Please, go ahead."
es: —Yes; please continue.

en: “You anticipate what I would say, though you cannot know how earnestly I say it, how earnestly I feel it, without knowing my secret heart, and the hopes and fears and anxieties with which it has long been laden.
vi: − You must have known beforehand what I was going to say, even though you couldn't know how seriously I would say it, how sincerely I would feel, if you didn't understand my innermost feelings, understand the many hopes, fears, and heavy worries I've carried for so long.
tr: "Even if you do not know how sincerely I say these things, how genuine my feelings are, the secret in my heart, and the hopes, fears, and excitements overflowing from this heart, you can guess what I am going to say.
es: —Guess what I am going to say, although it is impossible for you to guess with how much fervor I say it and with how much fervor I feel it, for that it would be necessary for your gaze to penetrate to the most intimate depths of my soul, to see there the hopes and fears, the yearnings and anxieties that overwhelm it under their weight.

en: Dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter fondly, dearly, disinterestedly, devotedly.
vi: Dear Dr. Manette, I love your daughter passionately, deeply, wholeheartedly, selflessly.
tr: Dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter with all my heart, sincerely, without expecting anything in return, and with great devotion.
es: My dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter with a deep, immense, selfless, fervent love; I love her as very few have loved in the world.

en: If ever there were love in the world, I love her.
vi: If there is love in this world, it is the love I have for her.
tr: If there is love in the world, it is the feeling I have for your daughter.
es: My dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter with a deep, immense, selfless, fervent love; I love her as very few have loved in the world.

en: You have loved yourself; let your old love speak for me!”
vi: You have loved before; let your past love speak for me!
tr: You have loved once too; let the love you experienced be the interpreter of my feelings!"
es: You have loved too, doctor: let the love that once quickened the beats of your heart speak for me!

en: The Doctor sat with his face turned away, and his eyes bent on the ground.
vi: The doctor sat listening, his face turned away, his eyes directed to the ground.
tr: The doctor was sitting with his head turned to the other side, his eyes cast down to the ground.
es: The doctor, who was listening to the young man with his head slightly turned and his eyes fixed on the ground, suddenly extended an arm upon hearing the last words, and exclaimed:

en: At the last words, he stretched out his hand again, hurriedly, and cried:
vi: Hearing the last sentence, he hastily reached out his hand and exclaimed: − Don't say that, sir!
tr: As soon as he heard the last words spoken by Charles Darnay, he reached out his hand again and exclaimed:
es: The doctor, who was listening to the young man with his head slightly turned and his eyes fixed on the ground, suddenly extended an arm upon hearing the last words, and exclaimed:

en: “Not that, sir!
vi: Hearing the last sentence, he hastily reached out his hand and exclaimed: − Don't say that, sir!
tr: "Please, sir!

en: Let that be!
vi: Let it go!
tr: Don't say that!
es: Don't talk about that!...

en: I adjure you, do not recall that!”
vi: Please don't mention the past!
tr: I beg you, don't mention that topic!"
es: Don't remind me of it, for heaven's sake!

en: His cry was so like a cry of actual pain, that it rang in Charles Darnay’s ears long after he had ceased.
vi: Like a cry of real pain, his words ended but the echo still resonated in Charles Darnay's ears.
tr: There was such great pain in the Doctor's cry that even when he stopped, Charles Darnay's ears rang for a long time.
es: Darnay remained silent.

en: He motioned with the hand he had extended, and it seemed to be an appeal to Darnay to pause.
vi: The hand extended trembled as if begging Darnay to stop speaking.
tr: As he moved his outstretched hand, it was as if he was begging Darnay to be silent.
es: Darnay remained silent.

en: The latter so received it, and remained silent.
vi: The young man understood and remained silent.
tr: Charles comprehended the situation and remained silent for a while.
es: Darnay remained silent.

en: “I ask your pardon,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, after some moments.
vi: − I'm sorry, - after a moment the doctor spoke softly.
tr: A few minutes later, "Forgive me," said the Doctor in a soft voice.
es: —Forgive me—replied the doctor after a few seconds.

en: “I do not doubt your loving Lucie; you may be satisfied of it.”
vi: - I have never doubted your love for Lucie; you can trust me.
tr: "I have no doubt that you love Lucie; therefore, you can be at ease."
es: —I do not doubt that you love Lucía...

en: He turned towards him in his chair, but did not look at him, or raise his eyes.
vi: Still sitting in the chair, he turned towards Darnay but did not look at him or raise his head, his hand still supporting his chin, his silver hair covering his face.
tr: The doctor turned to Darnay in his chair, but he still did not look at his face, not lifting his eyes from the ground.
es: Without looking at Darnay, without raising his eyes from the ground, with a sad countenance, he asked:

en: His chin dropped upon his hand, and his white hair overshadowed his face:
vi: Still sitting in the chair, he turned towards Darnay but did not look at him or raise his head, his hand still supporting his chin, his silver hair covering his face.
tr: His chin had fallen into his hands, and his white hair was shading his face.
es: Without looking at Darnay, without raising his eyes from the ground, with a sad countenance, he asked:

en: “Have you spoken to Lucie?”
vi: − Have you talked to Lucie yet?
tr: "Did you talk to Lucie?"
es: —Have you spoken of your love to Lucía?

en: “No.”
tr: "No."
es: —Never.

en: “Nor written?”
vi: Not yet. − Not even write a letter?
tr: "Well, did you write to him?"
es: —Has he/she written to you?

en: “Never.”
vi: − Not at all.
tr: "No, not at all."
es: —Never.

en: “It would be ungenerous to affect not to know that your self-denial is to be referred to your consideration for her father.
vi: − I would be narrow-minded if I pretended not to know that you have tried to avoid expressing your feelings to my daughter out of respect for her father.
tr: "It would be unfair not to see that you displayed this dedication thinking of his father.
es: —I would be quite ungrateful if I failed to acknowledge that your selflessness has been greatly influenced by your consideration for the father.

en: Her father thanks you.”
vi: I thank you.
tr: As his father, I thank you."
es: The father thanks you.

en: He offered his hand; but his eyes did not go with it.
vi: He extended his hand but his eyes did not follow.
tr: He reached out his hand, but he was still avoiding eye contact.
es: He offered his right hand to his interlocutor, but his eyes did not follow the movement of his hand.

en: “I know,” said Darnay, respectfully, “how can I fail to know, Doctor Manette, I who have seen you together from day to day, that between you and Miss Manette there is an affection so unusual, so touching, so belonging to the circumstances in which it has been nurtured, that it can have few parallels, even in the tenderness between a father and child.
vi: − I know, - Darnay said respectfully, - how could I not know, Dr. Manette, I have seen the two of you together every day, seen how much you and Miss Manette love each other, how deeply moved you are, how close you are, and I understand the circumstances you both have been through. Truly, the bond between father and daughter is rarely matched.
tr: "I know," said Darnay respectfully, "as someone who has spent a long time with you, how could I not know how special and touching the love between you and Miss Manette is, Doctor Manette? This love has developed under such circumstances that the affection between any other father and daughter pales in comparison to yours.
es: —I know—said Darnay with great respect—I know... how could I not know, having seen you most days? I know that between you and Lucie there exists a love so tender, so exceptional, so moving, so in harmony with the circumstances that have presided over its birth and development, that even in the tenderness that binds parents to their weak children, it would be difficult to find precedents.

en: I know, Doctor Manette—how can I fail to know—that, mingled with the affection and duty of a daughter who has become a woman, there is, in her heart, towards you, all the love and reliance of infancy itself.
vi: I know, Doctor... how could I not know,... that beyond the love and duty of an adult daughter, Lucie holds for you all the love and reliance of a child.
tr: I know that this woman, who loves you and feels responsible for you, also carries a love and trust from her infancy in her heart, Doctor Manette –how could I not know this?
es: I know, Doctor Manette, that along with the love of a daughter, who is now a woman, all the love of her childhood lives in her heart.

en: I know that, as in her childhood she had no parent, so she is now devoted to you with all the constancy and fervour of her present years and character, united to the trustfulness and attachment of the early days in which you were lost to her.
vi: I know that since childhood, Lucie has lived without her parents, so now she gives all her steadfast affection of the present years to her father, along with the trust and attachment she lacked as a child.
tr: Of course, I know that, due to her growing up without a mother and father in the past, and now, because of her temperament and the longing and attachment brought by the years she spent apart from you, she has devoted herself to you with great loyalty and enthusiasm.
es: I know that, precisely because she was deprived of her father's caresses during her childhood, she has now devoted herself to you with all the constancy, with all the fervor that her years and character give her.

en: I know perfectly well that if you had been restored to her from the world beyond this life, you could hardly be invested, in her sight, with a more sacred character than that in which you are always with her.
vi: I know very well that even if you had returned to this world from the other side, in her eyes, you could not be more sacred than you have been all this time.
tr: I know very well that even if you were to reunite with her in the afterlife, she would not appear more sacred than she does now.
es: I know perfectly well that if you had descended from heaven after your death to accompany your daughter on earth, you could not be more loved, more sacred, or more revered than you are today.

en: I know that when she is clinging to you, the hands of baby, girl, and woman, all in one, are round your neck.
vi: I know that when she holds her father tightly, the arms around his neck are those of a child, a young girl, and a grown woman all at once.
tr: When she embraces you, I know that the hands wrapping around your neck are simultaneously those of a baby, a young girl, and a mother.
es: I know that when your daughter embraces you, it is the arms of the child, the arms of the maiden, the arms of the woman that tenderly encircle your neck.

en: I know that in loving you she sees and loves her mother at her own age, sees and loves you at my age, loves her mother broken-hearted, loves you through your dreadful trial and in your blessed restoration.
vi: I know that through her love for her father, she sees and loves her young mother, sees and loves her young father, loves her suffering mother, and loves her father who faced terrifying ordeals and was fortunate to survive.
tr: I also know that, while loving you, she sees and loves her mother at her own age, sees and loves you at my age, loves her mother with a broken heart, loves you with that terrible trial and your joyful return to life.
es: I know that Lucie, loving you as she does today, loves a mother as young as she is and a father as young as I am; she sees and adores a sorrowful mother, submerged in unfathomable seas of bitterness, and she sees and adores a father buried alive.

en: I have known this, night and day, since I have known you in your home.”
vi: I have known this, through many days and nights, since I visited you in this house.
tr: I have seen this every moment since the first day I stepped into this house."
es: I know all this, I have been seeing it night and day, for to know it, it has been enough for me to see you in the sacredness of the home.

en: Her father sat silent, with his face bent down.
vi: The father sat in silence, his head bowed.
tr: Lucie's father sat silently with his face turned downward.
es: The father continued without changing his attitude, with his head bowed and his eyes downcast.

en: His breathing was a little quickened; but he repressed all other signs of agitation.
vi: His breathing was a bit more rapid, but he showed no signs of anger.
tr: His breathing had quickened a bit, but he had suppressed all other signs of excitement.
es: His breathing became a little uneven, but he did not show any other signs of agitation.

en: “Dear Doctor Manette, always knowing this, always seeing her and you with this hallowed light about you, I have forborne, and forborne, as long as it was in the nature of man to do it.
vi: − Dear Dr. Manette, because I have always known that, because I have always seen the two of you together in the radiance of that fatherly love, I have tried to restrain myself, and restrained myself to the utmost limits of human endurance.
tr: "Dear Doctor Manette, knowing this situation, always seeing this sacred light upon your daughter and you, I have always restrained myself as much as a person can.
es: —And knowing it, Doctor Manette, convinced that to interpose between you a love... my love, is equivalent to introducing into your heaven something that is less sublime than it, I have tried to impose silence on my heart, I have resisted to the utmost limit.

en: I have felt, and do even now feel, that to bring my love—even mine—between you, is to touch your history with something not quite so good as itself.
vi: I have felt, and even now feel, that if I were to let my love... even my love... come between the two of you, it would be like tarnishing that fatherly love with a lesser emotion.
tr: With my love for her –even with my love– if I were to come between you, I felt, and still feel, that I would add something not as good to what you have experienced.
es: —And knowing it, Doctor Manette, convinced that to interpose between you a love... my love, is equivalent to introducing into your heaven something that is less sublime than it, I have tried to impose silence on my heart, I have resisted to the utmost limit.

en: But I love her.
vi: But I love her.
tr: But I love her.
es: I can't anymore!... I love her!...

en: Heaven is my witness that I love her!”
vi: Heaven bear witness that I love her!
tr: God is my witness that I love her!"
es: Heaven is my witness that I love her!

en: “I believe it,” answered her father, mournfully.
vi: − I believe that, - the father replied sorrowfully, his voice filled with a sadness that sounded like a reproach.
tr: The doctor replied in a sorrowful voice, "I believe you."
es: —I believe it—replied the father with a sorrowful tone.

en: “I have thought so before now.
vi: - I have thought so before.
tr: "I had already thought about these things before.
es: —I had been suspecting it for a long time... I believe it.

en: I believe it.”
vi: I believe that.
tr: I believe you."
es: —I had been suspecting it for a long time... I believe it.

en: “But, do not believe,” said Darnay, upon whose ear the mournful voice struck with a reproachful sound, “that if my fortune were so cast as that, being one day so happy as to make her my wife, I must at any time put any separation between her and you, I could or would breathe a word of what I now say.
vi: − But sir, - Darnay said, - please do not think that if I am fortunate enough to have her as my wife, I would separate the father and daughter; if that were the case, I would not be able to or dare to utter a word of what I am saying now.
tr: "But do not think," said Darnay, hearing the reproach in the Doctor's sorrowful voice, "that if one day fate smiles upon me and I attain the happiness of marrying your daughter, I will separate you from each other. What I am saying now will be valid then as well.
es: —But I would feel—replied Darnay, who thought he detected a reproach in the doctor's sorrowful tone—I would feel that you also believed that, if my fortune were so immense that one day I could call her my wife, I would try to separate you or utter a single word different from those that are coming out of my mouth at this moment.

en: Besides that I should know it to be hopeless, I should know it to be a baseness.
vi: Moreover, I know very well that it is impossible to separate father and daughter, I know very well that doing so would be despicable.
tr: Even though such a baseness is not possible, I know this.
es: I fully understand that it would be useless; but in any case, I am not capable of committing such a vile act.

en: If I had any such possibility, even at a remote distance of years, harboured in my thoughts, and hidden in my heart—if it ever had been there—if it ever could be there—I could not now touch this honoured hand.”
vi: If I had that intention, no matter how distant in the future, if it were harbored in my mind, secretly in my heart... if I had that intention... if I had thought that way... then how could I dare to touch this revered hand at this moment.
tr: Still, if there were such a possibility, hidden in a corner of my mind and heart, that could emerge years later – impossible, but if there were – I could not shake this honorable hand now."
es: If such low thoughts even brushed my mind, I would not be worthy of touching this honorable hand—he added, extending his own to his interlocutor.

en: He laid his own upon it as he spoke.
vi: He placed his hand on his father's hand as emotions overflowed.
tr: While speaking, she had placed her hand on the Doctor's hand.
es: If such low thoughts even brushed my mind, I would not be worthy of touching this honorable hand—he added, extending his own to his interlocutor.

en: “No, dear Doctor Manette.
vi: − No, Dr. Manette.
tr: "No, dear Doctor Manette.
es: —No, my dear Doctor Manette; like you, I am kept away from France by a self-imposed exile; like you, I have fled from it to avoid seeing its mistakes, its oppressions, its miseries; like you, I have resolved to expatriate myself, live by the work of my hands, and place my hopes in a more prosperous future.

en: Like you, a voluntary exile from France; like you, driven from it by its distractions, oppressions, and miseries; like you, striving to live away from it by my own exertions, and trusting in a happier future; I look only to sharing your fortunes, sharing your life and home, and being faithful to you to the death.
vi: Like you, a person who voluntarily left France to live in exile; like you, forced to leave due to many hardships, oppression, and misfortunes; like you, having to strive to make a living by your own efforts and believe in a brighter future; I only want to share in your hardships, share life and family with you, and remain loyal to you until death.
tr: Like you, I was voluntarily exiled from France; like you, I fled from its madness, oppressions, and sufferings; just like you, I am trying to survive away from there through my own efforts and I believe that happy days await me; my only wish is to share your fate, your life, and your home and to honor you until I die.
es: My only aspiration is to share your fate, share your life and your home, and be faithful to you until death.

en: Not to divide with Lucie her privilege as your child, companion, and friend; but to come in aid of it, and bind her closer to you, if such a thing can be.”
vi: Not to deprive Lucie of the privileges of being a daughter, a friend, a companion to you, but to help strengthen the bond between father and daughter even more, if it is possible to do so.
tr: My aim is not to deprive Lucie, who is both your child, your friend, and your soulmate, of her privileges, but to support her and, if possible, to bind her to you even more."
es: I do not aspire to participate in the precious privilege of Lucie as your daughter and loving companion in life; rather, I seek to strengthen that privilege, to bind her more closely to you, assuming that is possible.

en: His touch still lingered on her father’s hand.
vi: His hand still lingered on the doctor's hand.
tr: Darnay's hand was still on Lucie's father's hand.
es: The young man's hand remained on his father's, who had his on the arms of the chair he was sitting in.

en: Answering the touch for a moment, but not coldly, her father rested his hands upon the arms of his chair, and looked up for the first time since the beginning of the conference.
vi: He held Darnay's hand for a moment to express his feelings, then rested both his hands on the armrest of the chair, and for the first time since they began talking, he looked up.
tr: For a moment, the Doctor responded to this touch in a manner that was not cold, but he immediately placed his hands on the arms of his chair and, for the first time since their conversation began, looked at Darnay's face.
es: For the first time since the beginning of the conference, the doctor raised his eyes from the floor.

en: A struggle was evidently in his face; a struggle with that occasional look which had a tendency in it to dark doubt and dread.
vi: On his face was a struggle; he was battling with the doubts and fears that occasionally arose in his mind.
tr: The conflict within him was reflected on his face; there was a rare expression of intense doubt and fear on his face.
es: His face reflected the struggle that was taking place within him.

en: “You speak so feelingly and so manfully, Charles Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and will open all my heart—or nearly so.
vi: − You speak very movingly and with great spirit, Charles Darnay, I thank you wholeheartedly, and I will also open my heart to you... or almost so.
tr: "You speak so sincerely and bravely, Charles Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and now I will open my heart to you completely – or let's say a large part of it.
es: —You speak with such tenderness, and at the same time with such firmness, Carlos Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and I am going to reveal to you... almost reveal my own.

en: Have you any reason to believe that Lucie loves you?”
vi: Do you have any reason to believe that Lucie loves you too?
tr: Has there been anything to make you think that Lucie loves you too?"
es: Do you have reasons to believe that Lucía returns your love?

en: “None.
vi: − Nothing.
tr: "No. Not at all."
es: —None.

en: As yet, none.”
vi: So far, there has been nothing.
tr: "No. Not at all."
es: —None.

en: “Is it the immediate object of this confidence, that you may at once ascertain that, with my knowledge?”
vi: − Is the main purpose of this conversation that you want to know Lucie's feelings through me?
tr: "Is the real reason you are opening up to me to get my permission to understand this?""
es: —The immediate purpose of this confidence, is it to ascertain this point right away and with my authorization?

en: “Not even so.
vi: − Absolutely not.
tr: "Not even that.
es: —Not even that.

en: I might not have the hopefulness to do it for weeks; I might (mistaken or not mistaken) have that hopefulness to-morrow.”
vi: It will be many weeks before I dare hope for that; but I hope, whether right or wrong, that you will allow me to know by tomorrow.
tr: Maybe it won't give me such hope for weeks. But maybe tomorrow I will see this hope (right or wrong)."
es: I don't expect to obtain that happiness for many weeks, although, naturally, I would like to be free of doubt by tomorrow.

en: “Do you seek any guidance from me?”
vi: − Do you need my advice? −
tr: "So, do you want me to show you the way?"
es: —Are you seeking my advice and guidance?

en: “I ask none, sir.
vi: No, sir.
tr: "I had no intention of asking such a thing, sir.
es: —Nor have I come with the intention of soliciting your advice and help; but I do believe that, if it is within your power to assist me, and you consider it just, you will provide me with some aid.

en: But I have thought it possible that you might have it in your power, if you should deem it right, to give me some.”
vi: But I think you have every right to advise me on something, if you see fit, and I will listen.
tr: But upon reflection, if you deem it appropriate, I would like to benefit from your ideas."
es: —Nor have I come with the intention of soliciting your advice and help; but I do believe that, if it is within your power to assist me, and you consider it just, you will provide me with some aid.

en: “Do you seek any promise from me?”
vi: − Do you need me to promise anything? −
tr: "Do you want me to make a promise?""
es: —So, what you are looking for is a promise from me.

en: “I do seek that.”
vi: Yes, indeed I do.
tr: "I would like to, sir.""
es: —Indeed; that's what I'm looking for.

en: “What is it?”
vi: − What? −
tr: "What word?""
es: —What promise is it?

en: “I well understand that, without you, I could have no hope.
vi: You know very well that without you, I have no hope.
tr: "I have understood very well that if you are not there, there is no hope at all.
es: —I am quite convinced that, without you, I can expect nothing: I am quite convinced that, even if Lucía loved me as I love her... and do not think that my presumption goes so far as to suppose such a thing, it would be of no use to me if my love were incompatible with the love she owes to her father.

en: I well understand that, even if Miss Manette held me at this moment in her innocent heart—do not think I have the presumption to assume so much—I could retain no place in it against her love for her father.”
vi: I understand clearly that even if at this moment there is an image of me in the innocent heart of Miss Manette, please do not think that I am presumptuous in assuming so, for I would still mean nothing if her father does not approve.
tr: If there is one more thing I have understood, it is that even if Miss Manette were to give me a place in her innocent heart right now – but don't think I am claiming such a thing – I wouldn't be able to hold on much against the love she has for her father."
es: —I am quite convinced that, without you, I can expect nothing: I am quite convinced that, even if Lucía loved me as I love her... and do not think that my presumption goes so far as to suppose such a thing, it would be of no use to me if my love were incompatible with the love she owes to her father.

en: “If that be so, do you see what, on the other hand, is involved in it?”
vi: − Let's assume that's the case, but what if the reality is different? What do you think then?
tr: "Well, do you also know what this means?"
es: —If that is the case, you will be well convinced of...

en: “I understand equally well, that a word from her father in any suitor’s favour, would outweigh herself and all the world.
vi: − I also understand clearly that a father's word expressing consent to someone pursuing her carries more weight than her own personal wishes and more than anything else in the world.
tr: "I know that a word from her father approving one of the suitors would mean everything to her.
es: —I am also convinced that a single word spoken by her father in favor of any suitor for her hand would weigh decisively on her mind, and precisely because I am convinced of this, Dr. Manette, I shall not request that word, even if my life depended on it—concluded the young man, with modesty, but with manly determination.

en: For which reason, Doctor Manette,” said Darnay, modestly but firmly, “I would not ask that word, to save my life.”
vi: For that reason, Doctor, - Darnay said humbly but firmly, - I do not wish to seek that word, even if it means my death.
tr: Therefore, Doctor Manette," said Darnay humbly but resolutely, "I will not ask such a thing from you."
es: —I am also convinced that a single word spoken by her father in favor of any suitor for her hand would weigh decisively on her mind, and precisely because I am convinced of this, Dr. Manette, I shall not request that word, even if my life depended on it—concluded the young man, with modesty, but with manly determination.

en: “I am sure of it.
vi: − I believe you.
tr: "I am sure of this.
es: —Of that I am sure, Charles Darnay.

en: Charles Darnay, mysteries arise out of close love, as well as out of wide division; in the former case, they are subtle and delicate, and difficult to penetrate.
vi: Charles Darnay, but both the closest and the most distant feelings are full of secrets; in close cases, feelings are always delicate, discreet, and unpredictable.
tr: Charles Darnay, secrets arise not only from great conflicts but also from deep affections; in the latter, they are delicate and very fragile, and difficult to unravel.
es: Mysteries often arise from deep loves and wide divisions: in the first case, the mysteries are subtle, delicate, and difficult to penetrate.

en: My daughter Lucie is, in this one respect, such a mystery to me; I can make no guess at the state of her heart.”
vi: In this matter, my daughter Lucie is truly a mystery; I cannot know whose image resides in my daughter's heart.
tr: In this regard, my daughter Lucie is a mystery to me; I have no idea where her heart lies."
es: In this respect, Lucie is a mystery to me: I cannot even approximately guess the state of her heart.

en: “May I ask, sir, if you think she is—”
vi: − May I ask, if you think that she... - Seeing him hesitate, the father understood and continued speaking.
tr: "Well sir, could it be that his-"
es: —Will you allow me to ask, doctor, if she...?

en: As he hesitated, her father supplied the rest.
vi: − Is there someone else pursuing you?
tr: When Darnay couldn't continue, Lucie's father completed the sentence.
es: —Will you allow me to ask, doctor, if she...?

en: “Is sought by any other suitor?”
tr: "Does she have another suitor?"
es: —Does she have any other suitors?

en: “It is what I meant to say.”
vi: That's what I meant to say.
tr: "Yes, this is what I wanted to ask.""
es: —That was what I meant to say.

en: Her father considered a little before he answered:
vi: The father thought for a moment before answering: − You have already seen Mr. Carton coming to this house.
tr: Lucie's father thought for a moment before responding.
es: The father replied after a few moments of reflection:

en: “You have seen mr Carton here, yourself.
vi: The father thought for a moment before answering: − You have already seen Mr. Carton coming to this house.
tr: "You had seen Mr. Carton here before.
es: —You have seen yourself that Mr. Carton and Mr. Stryver come to this house with some frequency; if anyone aspires to my daughter's hand, it will be one of the two.

en: mr Stryver is here too, occasionally.
vi: Attorney Stryver also occasionally visits.
tr: Mr. Stryver also comes occasionally.
es: —You have seen yourself that Mr. Carton and Mr. Stryver come to this house with some frequency; if anyone aspires to my daughter's hand, it will be one of the two.

en: If it be at all, it can only be by one of these.”
vi: If anyone is pursuing my daughter, it can only be one of those two.
tr: If there is such a thing, it can only be one of them."
es: —You have seen yourself that Mr. Carton and Mr. Stryver come to this house with some frequency; if anyone aspires to my daughter's hand, it will be one of the two.

en: “Or both,” said Darnay.
vi: − Or both, - Darnay said.
tr: "Or both," said Darnay.
es: —Or both—observed Darnay.

en: “I had not thought of both; I should not think either, likely.
vi: − I have never thought about either of them; I don't think that either of them has feelings for my daughter.
tr: "I didn't think that both would be interested; I don't really believe it.
es: —It hasn't occurred to me that it could be both; moreover, I don't even think it's likely to be either of them.

en: You want a promise from me.
vi: Whatever you want me to promise, just say it.
tr: You were asking for a promise from me.
es: But you have told me that you desire a promise from me: tell me what it is about.

en: Tell me what it is.”
vi: Whatever you want me to promise, just say it.
tr: Go ahead, say it."
es: But you have told me that you desire a promise from me: tell me what it is about.

en: “It is, that if Miss Manette should bring to you at any time, on her own part, such a confidence as I have ventured to lay before you, you will bear testimony to what I have said, and to your belief in it.
vi: − That is, if Miss Manette at some point voluntarily expresses feelings similar to those I have presumptuously shared with you, please recount what I have said and tell her that you believe in me.
tr: "If Miss Manette comes to you one day and opens her heart to you as I just dared to do, please take on my words and tell her that you believe in them.
es: "The promise I wish to obtain is that, if someday your daughter were to confide in you as I have just done, you would repeat my words to her, adding that you believe in their sincerity."

en: I hope you may be able to think so well of me, as to urge no influence against me.
vi: I hope you have a favorable opinion of me so that she won't be offended.
tr: I hope you think well of me and do not influence her negatively.
es: "I believe I deserve a sufficiently good opinion from you to not take a stance against me."

en: I say nothing more of my stake in this; this is what I ask.
vi: That is the only thing I dare to ask.
tr: I will not ask anything else from you for my own benefit, that's all.
es: "For my part, I will strictly fulfill the condition upon which I base my plea, because you have an indisputable right to its fulfillment."

en: The condition on which I ask it, and which you have an undoubted right to require, I will observe immediately.”
vi: To achieve that, I am willing to accept any conditions that you are fully entitled to impose.
tr: If there is anything you demand in return for this request, I can fulfill it immediately."
es: "For my part, I will strictly fulfill the condition upon which I base my plea, because you have an indisputable right to its fulfillment."

en: “I give the promise,” said the Doctor, “without any condition.
vi: − I promise you unconditionally, - the doctor said.
tr: "I promise," said the Doctor, "and I have no demands.
es: —I make the promise you desire, without any condition—replied the doctor.

en: I believe your object to be, purely and truthfully, as you have stated it.
vi: - I believe that what you say is sincere and noble.
tr: I believe that your purpose, as you say, is pure and sincere.
es: —I firmly believe that your purpose is as you have stated; I believe that you intend to perpetuate, and in no case weaken, the bonds that unite me to the one who is dearer to me than myself.

en: I believe your intention is to perpetuate, and not to weaken, the ties between me and my other and far dearer self.
vi: I believe your intention is to strengthen, not sever, the fatherly bond that ties me to my most beloved child.
tr: I also believe that your intention is not to weaken the bonds between me and my daughter, who is a part of my very soul, but to eternalize them.
es: —I firmly believe that your purpose is as you have stated; I believe that you intend to perpetuate, and in no case weaken, the bonds that unite me to the one who is dearer to me than myself.

en: If she should ever tell me that you are essential to her perfect happiness, I will give her to you.
vi: If Lucie were to confess that you are an indispensable happiness, I would give my daughter to you.
tr: If the day comes when she tells me that she has found true happiness with you, I will give her to you.
es: If one day my daughter tells me that you are necessary for her happiness, I will hasten to give her to you.

en: If there were—Charles Darnay, if there were—”
vi: If... Charles Darnay, if there were...
tr: Charles Darnay- if such a thing happens..."
es: If they existed, Charles Darnay, if they existed...

en: The young man had taken his hand gratefully; their hands were joined as the Doctor spoke:
vi: The young man gratefully grasped the doctor's hand; they shook hands tightly while the father continued: − ... any thought, any reason, any fear, anything, old or new, against the person whom my daughter truly loves... anything for which that person is not directly responsible,... I will overlook all of it for my daughter's happiness.
tr: The young man reached out to the Doctor's hand with gratitude; as the Doctor continued to speak, their hands joined.
es: The young man gratefully shook the doctor's hand. —...

en: “—any fancies, any reasons, any apprehensions, anything whatsoever, new or old, against the man she really loved—the direct responsibility thereof not lying on his head—they should all be obliterated for her sake.
vi: The young man gratefully grasped the doctor's hand; they shook hands tightly while the father continued: − ... any thought, any reason, any fear, anything, old or new, against the person whom my daughter truly loves... anything for which that person is not directly responsible,... I will overlook all of it for my daughter's happiness.
tr: "For my daughter's well-being, it is necessary to stay away from any intention, thought, or concern directed towards the man she truly loves – this man not being directly sommiu.
es: Whims, true motives, apprehensions, any other thing, old or recent, against the man whom my daughter truly loved... as long as the responsibility was not personally his... I would forget everything for the love of her.

en: She is everything to me; more to me than suffering, more to me than wrong, more to me—Well!
vi: Lucie is my everything, more meaningful than all the suffering, more meaningful than all the injustices I have to endure, more meaningful than... Oh!
tr: My daughter is my everything; beyond the pains I've endured, beyond the mistakes I've made, far beyond. Anyway!
es: She is everything to me.

en: This is idle talk.”
vi: Saying it is pointless.
tr: It's all empty talk."
es: In the face of her happiness, all the grievances I have received, all the torments that... I am saying what is irrelevant!

en: So strange was the way in which he faded into silence, and so strange his fixed look when he had ceased to speak, that Darnay felt his own hand turn cold in the hand that slowly released and dropped it.
vi: The way the doctor fell into silence was truly strange, and the intense gaze he had when he stopped speaking was equally peculiar, to the point that Darnay noticed his hand growing cold in the hand that was slowly letting go of him.
tr: The Doctor's slow descent into silence and the way he fixed his gaze on him after finishing his words were so strange that Darnay felt the hand that the Doctor slowly loosened and released starting to grow cold.
es: The tone the doctor gave to his words was so peculiar, the abrupt interruption so peculiar, the look he directed at his interlocutor so peculiar, that the latter felt the cold penetrate to the depths of his heart.

en: “You said something to me,” said Doctor Manette, breaking into a smile.
vi: − What did you just say to me? - Dr. Manette spoke, smiling. -
tr: "You had told me something," said Doctor Manette, suddenly smiling.
es: —Without realizing it, I have diverted the conversation—added the doctor, smiling. —

en: “What was it you said to me?”
vi: What did you tell me?
tr: "What was that thing you said?"
es: What was it that you were telling me?

en: He was at a loss how to answer, until he remembered having spoken of a condition.
vi: He didn't know how to respond until he suddenly remembered he had mentioned a condition.
tr: Although Darnay did not know how to respond for a moment, he soon remembered the matter.
es: Darnay did not know what to answer at first, until he remembered that he had spoken of a condition.

en: Relieved as his mind reverted to that, he answered:
vi: Feeling reassured, he replied: − Since you have trusted me so much, I must reciprocate with all my trust.
tr: With the relief this brought, he said:
es: Calmer then, he said:

en: “Your confidence in me ought to be returned with full confidence on my part.
vi: Feeling reassured, he replied: − Since you have trusted me so much, I must reciprocate with all my trust.
tr: "I must fully deserve the trust you have in me.
es: —To your trust, I have the unavoidable duty to respond with mine.

en: My present name, though but slightly changed from my mother’s, is not, as you will remember, my own.
vi: My current name, though slightly altered from my mother's name as you know, is not my real name.
tr: As you may recall, my current name, though similar to my mother's maiden name, is not my real name.
es: My current surname, although it barely differs from my mother's, is not mine, as you know.

en: I wish to tell you what that is, and why I am in England.”
vi: I want to tell you my true identity and the reason I am in England.
tr: I would like to tell you what it is and why I am in England."
es: I wish to tell you what my real surname is, and explain the reasons for my being in England.

en: “Stop!” said the Doctor of Beauvais.
vi: − Don't! - The doctor in Beauvais exclaimed.
tr: "Stop!" said the Doctor from Beauvais.
es: —No! Be quiet!

en: “I wish it, that I may the better deserve your confidence, and have no secret from you.”
vi: − I want it that way, to be more deserving of your trust. I don't want to hide anything from you.
tr: "I wanted there to be nothing I hid from you in order to be worthy of your trust."
es: The doctor brought both hands to his ears and then to Darnay's lips. —I wish so, because I would like to earn your trust and have no secrets from you.

en: “Stop!”
vi: − Don't!
tr: "Stop!"
es: —No!

en: For an instant, the Doctor even had his two hands at his ears; for another instant, even had his two hands laid on Darnay’s lips.
vi: For a moment, the doctor even raised both hands to cover his ears; a moment later, those same hands were placed on Darnay's lips.
tr: The doctor immediately covered his ears with both hands; he even brought his hands to Darnay's lips shortly after.
es: You will tell me when I ask you, but in no way now!

en: “Tell me when I ask you, not now.
vi: − When I ask, speak; do not speak now.
tr: "When I ask you, tell me, not now.
es: You will tell me when I ask you, but in no way now!

en: If your suit should prosper, if Lucie should love you, you shall tell me on your marriage morning.
vi: If your pursuit is successful, if Lucie loves you, then you will inform me on the morning of the wedding day.
tr: If things go well and Lucie loves you, you will tell me this on the morning of the wedding day.
es: If your aspirations are on the way to being realized, if Lucía reciprocates your love, you will make those revelations to me on the very morning of your wedding.

en: Do you promise?”
vi: Do you promise me that?
tr: Promise?"
es: Do you promise me?

en: “Willingly.
vi: − Willingly.
tr: "Of course.""
es: —With great pleasure.

en: “Give me your hand.
vi: − Give me your hand.
tr: "Give me your hand.
es: —Give me your hand.

en: She will be home directly, and it is better she should not see us together to-night.
vi: Lucie is coming back soon, and it's best if she doesn't see us meeting tonight.
tr: Lucie will come soon, and it's better if she doesn't see us together tonight.
es: My daughter will arrive any moment now, and I wouldn't want her to find us together tonight.

en: Go!
vi: Go!
tr: Now go!
es: Go away... and may God bless you!

en: God bless you!”
vi: God bless you!
tr: God bless you!"
es: Go away... and may God bless you!

en: It was dark when Charles Darnay left him, and it was an hour later and darker when Lucie came home; she hurried into the room alone—for Miss Pross had gone straight up-stairs—and was surprised to find his reading-chair empty.
