vi: It was already dusk when Darnay left, and it was even darker an hour later when Lucie arrived home; she hurried alone into the living room - for Miss Pross had gone straight upstairs - and was surprised to see her father's armchair empty.
tr: When Charles Darnay left the Doctor's side, it was already dark, and an hour had passed by the time Lucie arrived; the young girl immediately ran into the room alone –since Miss Pross had gone straight upstairs– and was surprised to see that the chair where he always read his book was empty.
es: The night had closed in when Charles Darnay left, and it took Lucia another hour to arrive. She hurried to the room where her father usually stayed, and was quite surprised to find the chair he invariably occupied while reading vacant.

en: “My father!” she called to him.
vi: − Dad! - She called the doctor.
tr: "Dad," she called out.
es: —Father! —he called.—

en: “Father dear!”
vi: - Dad?
tr: "Daddy!"
es: My dear father!

en: Nothing was said in answer, but she heard a low hammering sound in his bedroom.
vi: There was no answer, but she heard the faint sound of hammering coming from her father's bedroom.
tr: There was no answer, but faint hammering sounds were coming from his father's bedroom.
es: No one answered; but as repeated hammering sounds reached her ears from her father's bedroom, she ran towards it.

en: Passing lightly across the intermediate room, she looked in at his door and came running back frightened, crying to herself, with her blood all chilled, “What shall I do!
vi: Gently walking around the adjacent room, she stood at the doorway and looked in, then in a panic, she ran back, silently lamenting, her heart aching.
tr: He quietly passed through the room in between and looked into the man's room, and in fear, pale as a ghost, he exclaimed, "Oh, what am I going to do now!
es: She looked through the door and stepped back frightened, crying.

en: What shall I do!”
vi: "What to do? What to do?"
tr: What am I going to do!" he shouted, running back in a panic.
es: —What will I do, my God, what will I do?—he exclaimed.

en: Her uncertainty lasted but a moment; she hurried back, and tapped at his door, and softly called to him.
vi: She hesitated for just a moment, then hurriedly went back to knock on the door and gently called her father.
tr: Her hesitation was very brief; she immediately turned back, knocked on her father's door, and called out in a soft tone.
es: Only a moment did her uncertainties last. She knocked on the door with her knuckles and whispered her father's name.

en: The noise ceased at the sound of her voice, and he presently came out to her, and they walked up and down together for a long time.
vi: The hammering inside stopped immediately when her voice was heard, then the doctor came out to meet Lucie, and the father and daughter walked back and forth together for a long time.
tr: Upon the young girl's call, the noise ceased, and soon her father came out to join her; for a long time, they walked together, back and forth.
es: The hammering stopped immediately, her father came out, looked at her silently, and began to pace around the room. Lucía walked by his side.

en: She came down from her bed, to look at him in his sleep that night.
vi: That night, she left her bed and went down to her father's room to watch him sleep.
tr: That night, Lucie got out of bed and went to check on her father.
es: The next morning, Lucía entered the doctor's bedroom very early. She found him sleeping deeply.

en: He slept heavily, and his tray of shoemaking tools, and his old unfinished work, were all as usual.
vi: His sleep was heavy, and the tray of shoemaking tools along with the half-finished shoe from long ago were laid out exactly as they had been in the past.
tr: The man was sleeping deeply, and his set of shoemaking tools and the unfinished work were exactly where they had been left.
es: She did not observe any alteration in the shoemaker's bench, nor in the tools, nor in the unfinished shoe.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: 11. The prospect of marriage
tr: XI
es: XI.

en: A Companion Picture
vi: 11. The prospect of marriage
tr: Portrait of a Friend
es: AMONG COLLEAGUES

en: Sydney,” said mr Stryver, on that self-same night, or morning, to his jackal; “mix another bowl of punch; I have something to say to you.”
vi: − Sydney, pour another bowl of punch, - Stryver said to the Jackal that same night, or rather, early the next morning. - I have something to tell you.
tr: That same night or the morning of that same night, Mr. Stryver said to his jackal, "Sydney, make another bowl of punch. I have something to tell you."
es: —Prepare another punch, Sydney—said the lawyer Stryver that same night, already in the early hours, to his companion the jackal. —I have to make a confession to you.

en: Sydney had been working double tides that night, and the night before, and the night before that, and a good many nights in succession, making a grand clearance among mr Stryver’s papers before the setting in of the long vacation.
vi: Sydney has been working double shifts tonight, and the night before last, and the night before that, continuously for several nights to arrange for Stryver's paperwork before the long holiday begins.
tr: Sydney had worked overtime that night, the night before, and the night before that, and many consecutive nights, sitting and dealing with the documents that needed to be organized and sorted before Mr. Stryver went on a long vacation.
es: For several nights before, Sydney had been working diligently to reduce and finish the pile of papers waiting their turn on the desk before going on vacation.

en: The clearance was effected at last; the Stryver arrears were handsomely fetched up; everything was got rid of until November should come with its fogs atmospheric, and fogs legal, and bring grist to the mill again.
vi: Finally, everything is done; Stryver's pending matters have been resolved properly; there are no more entanglements until November arrives with its gloomy skies, murky laws, and everything goes smoothly.
tr: Finally, the organizing work was done, Stryver's debts were cleared, and they had gotten rid of all the tasks at hand, until both the literal and legal fog enveloped the surroundings in November and the mill started turning again.
es: Everything was up to date; there was nothing left to do but wait for the arrival of November, abundant in atmospheric fogs and legal fogs.

en: Sydney was none the livelier and none the soberer for so much application.
vi: Sydney was neither excited nor more alert after all the grueling work.
tr: Sydney, despite having so much work, was never lively and sober.
es: Sydney was not a paragon of sobriety and temperance: that night he had to increase by two the number of cold water-soaked towels he usually applied to his head, just as he also doubled the amount of wine consumed prior to applying the towels.

en: It had taken a deal of extra wet-towelling to pull him through the night; a correspondingly extra quantity of wine had preceded the towelling; and he was in a very damaged condition, as he now pulled his turban off and threw it into the basin in which he had steeped it at intervals for the last six hours.
vi: It took several more rounds of wet towels on his head to keep him awake through the night; and it also took about the same amount of weeks of drinking before applying the towels; now he looked truly miserable as he pulled the stack of towels off his head and tossed them into the basin he had been dipping them in every so often for the past six hours.
tr: To get through the night well, he had to use an extra load of wet towels; because he had consumed just as much wine before the towel phase; now he was in a terrible state, he took off the towel wrapped around his head and threw it into the basin he had been dipping it into and wetting every now and then for the past six hours.
es: Sydney was not a paragon of sobriety and temperance: that night he had to increase by two the number of cold water-soaked towels he usually applied to his head, just as he also doubled the amount of wine consumed prior to applying the towels.

en: “Are you mixing that other bowl of punch?” said Stryver the portly, with his hands in his waistband, glancing round from the sofa where he lay on his back.
vi: − Do you have another bowl of punch ready? - Stryver, lying on his back on the sofa with his hands hooked into his waistband, glanced around.
tr: The burly Stryver, lying on the couch with his hands on his belt, looked around and called out, "Are you making the punch?"
es: —Are you preparing the other punch?—asked Stryver, from the sofa on which he was lying on his back.

en: “I am.”
vi: - Brewing.
tr: "I'm preparing.""
es: —Yes.

en: “Now, look here!
vi: − Hey, look here!
tr: "Look now!
es: —Listen, then.

en: I am going to tell you something that will rather surprise you, and that perhaps will make you think me not quite as shrewd as you usually do think me.
vi: I will tell you something very surprising, and maybe it will show you that I am not as wise as you often think.
tr: I'm going to tell you something that will surprise you a lot, and you might see that I'm not as smart as you think I am.
es: I'm going to reveal something to you that will surely amaze you, and who knows, it might even make you think I'm much less clever than I appear.

en: I intend to marry.”
vi: I intend to get married.
tr: I want to get married."
es: I've been thinking about getting married.

en: “Do you?”
vi: − Him? − Yes.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —You?

en: “Yes.
vi: And not because of money.
tr: "Yes!
es: —Yes.

en: And not for money.
vi: And not because of money.
tr: But not for the money.
es: It will surprise you even more to know that I am not getting married for money.

en: What do you say now?”
vi: What do you say now?
tr: What are you saying?"
es: What do you say?

en: “I don’t feel disposed to say much.
vi: − I don't know anything to say.
tr: "I don't want to say much."
es: —I don't feel like saying much.

en: Who is she?”
vi: Who is she?
tr: "With whom?"
es: Who is she?

en: “Guess.”
vi: − Guess.
tr: "Guess what.""
es: —Guess it.

en: “Do I know her?”
vi: − Do I know them?
tr: "Do I know them?""
es: —Do I know her?

en: “Guess.”
vi: − Guess.
tr: "Guess.""
es: —Guess it.

en: “I am not going to guess, at five o’clock in the morning, with my brains frying and sputtering in my head.
vi: − I won't guess, it's already five in the morning and my mind is boiling.
tr: "At five in the morning, when my brain is so muddled and scattered, I can't predict anything.
es: —It doesn't seem like a good time to start guessing, at five in the morning with my head turned into an erupting volcano.

en: If you want me to guess, you must ask me to dinner.”
vi: If you want me to guess, you have to invite me to dinner.
tr: If you really want me to guess, we can have dinner together one evening."
es: If you want me to guess, invite me to eat.

en: “Well then, I’ll tell you,” said Stryver, coming slowly into a sitting posture.
vi: − Alright then, let me speak, - Stryver said as he slowly shifted to a sitting position.
tr: "Alright then, I'll tell you," said Stryver as he slowly sat down.
es: —Since you don't want to guess, I'll tell you myself—said Stryver, sitting lazily.

en: “Sydney, I rather despair of making myself intelligible to you, because you are such an insensible dog.”
vi: - Sydney, it's a waste of time to explain to you, because you are truly insensitive.
tr: "Sydney, I find it difficult to explain myself to you, because you are an insensitive fellow."
es: —Of course, I don't harbor the slightest hope of making myself understood by you, simply because you are and always have been an insensitive dog.

en: “And you,” returned Sydney, busy concocting the punch, “are such a sensitive and poetical spirit—”
vi: − And you, - Sydney replied while still busy mixing punch, - truly have a sentimental and poetic soul...
tr: While stirring the punch, Sydney turned to him and said, "But you," she said, "are so emotional and poetic."
es: —On the other hand, you have always been and still are a spirit full of sensitivity and poetry—replied Sydney with an ironic tone.

en: “Come!” rejoined Stryver, laughing boastfully, “though I don’t prefer any claim to being the soul of Romance (for I hope I know better), still I am a tenderer sort of fellow than you.”
vi: − Stop it! - Stryver laughed arrogantly, - although I don't like to consider myself a romantic; because I hope I'm better than that, I am still the kind of person who has more feelings than you.
tr: Laughing heartily, "Come on!" Stryver replied, "Although I don't claim to be someone with a romantic soul (but I hope to understand these things better one day), it's certain that I'm more sensitive than you.""
es: —Man!...—exclaimed Stryver, laughing. —I don't aspire to be a sentimental novel hero, but you can't deny that I'm softer than you.

en: “You are a luckier, if you mean that.”
vi: − You mean you're the luckier one, is that it.
tr: "You are luckier, if that's what you mean."
es: —You mean luckier.

en: “I don’t mean that.
vi: − I didn't mean that.
tr: "I didn't mean it like that.
es: —You mean luckier.

en: I mean I am a man of more—more—”
vi: What I meant is that I am a person... a person...
tr: What I meant to say is, I am more... more..."
es: —No; I meant to say more... more...

en: “Say gallantry, while you are about it,” suggested Carton.
vi: − Then just say outright that he is more gallant, - Carton suggested.
tr: "I suppose you mean gentleman," said Carton.
es: —Gallant: Did I get it right this time?

en: “Well!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Alright, let's say gentleman then.
es: —Well!

en: I’ll say gallantry.
vi: You could say it's gallant, - Stryver boasted to his friend who was mixing drinks.
tr: "Alright, let's say gentleman then.
es: Let's say gallant!

en: My meaning is that I am a man,” said Stryver, inflating himself at his friend as he made the punch, “who cares more to be agreeable, who takes more pains to be agreeable, who knows better how to be agreeable, in a woman’s society, than you do.”
vi: - What I mean is that, when it comes to women, I am someone who values making myself charming, someone who puts effort into being charming, someone who knows how to appear more charming than you.
tr: What I really mean is," said Stryver, continuing to puff himself up to his friend who was preparing punch, "I am a man who can make himself accepted by women, who can endure some difficulties to make himself accepted, and who knows better how to make himself accepted."
es: My intention was to say that I am a man who takes care to make myself more pleasant, that I take more interest in making myself more pleasant, that I know the way to make myself more pleasant to women than you do.

en: “Go on,” said Sydney Carton.
vi: − Go on, - Sydney Carton said.
tr: "Go on," said Sydney Carton.
es: —Go ahead—said Sydney Carton.

en: “No; but before I go on,” said Stryver, shaking his head in his bullying way, “I’ll have this out with you.
vi: − Wait a minute, - Stryver shook his head fiercely, - before continuing, I must finish this matter with you.
tr: "No; before continuing," said Stryver, shaking his head forcefully from side to side, "let me fully explain this matter to you.
es: —Calm down, my friend—replied Stryver, shaking his head. — Before going any further, I want to state the following:

en: You’ve been at Doctor Manette’s house as much as I have, or more than I have.
vi: You have been visiting Dr. Manette's house as frequently as I have, even more so.
tr: You have been at Doctor Manette's house as much as I have, if not more.
es: You have visited Doctor Manette's house as often, if not more often than I have, and frankly, I have been embarrassed by your harsh demeanor, the scowl you always wear there.

en: Why, I have been ashamed of your moroseness there!
vi: Oh, I'm really ashamed that you keep showing up there with that gloomy face!
tr: You can't imagine how embarrassed I was by your sulkiness there!
es: Your manners have been those of a bad-tempered dog and your demeanor so gloomy that I have felt ashamed of you, Sydney.

en: Your manners have been of that silent and sullen and hangdog kind, that, upon my life and soul, I have been ashamed of you, Sydney!”
vi: Your attitude is so silent, sullen, and gloomy that, I swear to you, I am ashamed of you, Sydney! −
tr: Every time I saw you in that sullen, silent state, I was mortified, Sydney!"
es: Your manners have been those of a bad-tempered dog and your demeanor so gloomy that I have felt ashamed of you, Sydney.

en: “It should be very beneficial to a man in your practice at the bar, to be ashamed of anything,” returned Sydney; “you ought to be much obliged to me.”
vi: It's very good for a lawyer to feel ashamed, - Sydney said, - you should be thanking me.
tr: "It is extremely beneficial for a man working in Baroda to feel ashamed of such things," replied Sydney, "so you should be grateful to me."
es: —You should be highly grateful to me, Stryver, because men of your profession are not usually ashamed of anything—replied Carton.

en: “You shall not get off in that way,” rejoined Stryver, shouldering the rejoinder at him; “no, Sydney, it’s my duty to tell you—and I tell you to your face to do you good—that you are a devilish ill-conditioned fellow in that sort of society.
vi: − Don't try to change the subject like that, - Stryver retorted aggressively, speaking as if picking a fight.
tr: Stryver responded to his sharp reply, "You won't get away with it like this," he retorted sharply, "no Sydney, it is my duty to tell you this – I'm telling you to your face for your own good – you behave very disgracefully and nonsensically in public.
es: —Don't dodge the issue, Sydney. I consider it my duty to tell you, and I tell it to your face, because I believe I'm doing you a favor, that you lack the qualities to be in society.

en: You are a disagreeable fellow.”
vi: - No, Sydney, it is my duty to let you know; and I will tell it to your face to wake you up; that you are an unpleasant and grumpy person towards women. You are a detestable person.
tr: You are a grumpy man."
es: You are a decidedly unpleasant companion.

en: Sydney drank a bumper of the punch he had made, and laughed.
vi: Sydney drank a full glass of freshly made punch and then laughed out loud.
tr: Sydney drank a full glass of the punch she had prepared and laughed heartily.
es: Sydney took a sip of punch and burst out laughing.

en: “Look at me!” said Stryver, squaring himself; “I have less need to make myself agreeable than you have, being more independent in circumstances.
vi: − Look at me! - Stryver said, puffing out his chest. - Being this rich and successful, I don't need to do much to be more charming than you.
tr: "Look at me for a moment!" said Stryver, gesturing with his hand, "compared to you, I don't need to prove myself at all, I am sufficient on my own in any situation.
es: —Look at me! —replied Stryver, standing up and striking an arrogant pose. —I have less need than you to make myself agreeable, since my position is a thousand times more independent than yours.

en: Why do I do it?”
vi: Why do I still try to be charming?
tr: But why am I doing this?"
es: Why, then, do I always manage to make myself agreeable?

en: “I never saw you do it yet,” muttered Carton.
vi: − I've never seen you do that, - Carton mumbled.
tr: "We have never seen you do anything either," Carton grumbled.
es: —In my life, I have never seen you do it.

en: “I do it because it’s politic; I do it on principle.
vi: − I do it because it is a strategy; it is my principle.
tr: "I am doing this politically; I am doing it out of principle.
es: —I make myself agreeable because it is required by refined manners and because it is in my blood.

en: And look at me!
vi: And look at me!
tr: Look at me!
es: I continue.

en: I get on.”
vi: I have succeeded completely.
tr: How far I've come."
es: —What you are not continuing, as I see, is the exposition of your matrimonial projects.

en: “You don’t get on with your account of your matrimonial intentions,” answered Carton, with a careless air; “I wish you would keep to that.
vi: − You haven't finished talking about your marriage plans, - Carton said indifferently. - I hope you continue with that.
tr: With an indifferent attitude, "You haven't made much progress with marriage yet," said Carton; "but don't give up, keep going.
es: As for the rest, do me the favor of not continuing.

en: As to me—will you never understand that I am incorrigible?”
vi: As for me... don't you ever understand that I am incorrigible?
tr: As for me, haven't you realized yet that I'm an incorrigible man?"
es: Will you never be convinced that I am incorrigible?

en: He asked the question with some appearance of scorn.
vi: The question revealed a hint of disdain.
tr: He had asked this question with a slight hint of disdain.
es: Carton asked this question with a sarcastic tone.

en: “You have no business to be incorrigible,” was his friend’s answer, delivered in no very soothing tone.
vi: − You don't have to act so incorrigible, - Stryver's voice was harsh.
tr: "You can't even be a man who can't be reformed," said his friend in a tone that was far from reassuring.
es: "To be incorrigible, you would need to have business, and I don't know that you have any," replied Stryver, a little annoyed.

en: “I have no business to be, at all, that I know of,” said Sydney Carton.
vi: − I have no need to put on airs, I know that, - Sydney Carton replied. -
tr: "Nothing will ever come of me anyway," said Sydney Carton.
es: —As far as I know, I don't have them...

en: “Who is the lady?”
vi: But who is that lady? −
tr: "Who is this lady?"
es: Who is the lucky one?

en: “Now, don’t let my announcement of the name make you uncomfortable, Sydney,” said mr Stryver, preparing him with ostentatious friendliness for the disclosure he was about to make, “because I know you don’t mean half you say; and if you meant it all, it would be of no importance.
vi: Now, don't get upset when I mention her name, Sydney, Stryver pretended to be friendly before revealing, - because I know you think one thing and say another; and even if you did say what you truly think, it wouldn't matter.
tr: "But if I tell you her name now, you might get upset, Sydney," said Stryver, as if he were preparing him with a showy sincerity for what he was about to explain, "because I know you don't mean half of what you say, but even if you did, it wouldn't matter.
es: —I would not want the mention of the name to cause you sorrow or displeasure—said Stryver, preparing with friendly circumlocutions the revelation he was about to make. —I know that you do not feel half of what you say, although, to tell the truth, if you felt it all, it would be the same, for it would not matter.

en: I make this little preface, because you once mentioned the young lady to me in slighting terms.”
vi: I have to preface this a bit because you have previously spoken of that lady to me with disdain.
tr: I made such an introduction because you had previously spoken honorably about this young lady."
es: I make this preamble because on one occasion you spoke quite lightly of the young lady whose name I am going to pronounce.

en: “I did?”
vi: − Me? − Exactly; and right in this office.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Me?

en: “Certainly; and in these chambers.”
vi: − Me? − Exactly; and right in this office.
tr: "Yes; and right here."
es: —You, yes; and in this very room.

en: Sydney Carton looked at his punch and looked at his complacent friend; drank his punch and looked at his complacent friend.
vi: Sydney Carton looked at the glass of wine and then at his complacent friend; he drained the glass and looked at his friend again.
tr: Sydney Carton first looked at the punch in his glass, then at his contented friend; then he drank his punch and looked again at his contented friend.
es: Carton treated himself to another glass of punch and looked at his friend.

en: “You made mention of the young lady as a golden-haired doll.
vi: − You once called that lady a blonde doll.
tr: "You had mentioned this young lady as the golden-haired doll.
es: —Referring to the young lady I allude to, you said she was a doll with golden hair.

en: The young lady is Miss Manette.
vi: That lady is Miss Manette.
tr: This young lady is Miss Manette.
es: The young lady I refer to is Miss Lucie Manette.

en: If you had been a fellow of any sensitiveness or delicacy of feeling in that kind of way, Sydney, I might have been a little resentful of your employing such a designation; but you are not.
vi: Sydney, if you had any delicate feelings or emotions towards women, I would have been upset by your contempt for her; but you are not that kind of person.
tr: If you were a man with a bit of sensitivity and kindness, Sydney, I might have been offended by the way you spoke of her, but you are not.
es: If you knew sensitivity, if you were a man of delicate feelings, it would have bothered me that you spoke of her as you did; but since you are neither sensitive nor delicate, I paid no attention to your frivolity.

en: You want that sense altogether; therefore I am no more annoyed when I think of the expression, than I should be annoyed by a man’s opinion of a picture of mine, who had no eye for pictures: or of a piece of music of mine, who had no ear for music.”
vi: You have no feelings at all; so being angry at you for saying that would be like being upset when someone without an eye for art criticizes my paintings, or someone without an ear for music criticizes my compositions.
tr: You have never had a share of such things; therefore, what you say doesn't bother me more than a person without an eye for beauty commenting on a painting I made or a person without an ear for music commenting on a composition I created."
es: You lack both qualities, and therefore, when your expression comes to my mind, I give it the same importance as I would to the opinion of a blind man who claimed a painting of mine was bad, or to that of a deaf-mute who pretended to find faults in a musical composition of mine.

en: Sydney Carton drank the punch at a great rate; drank it by bumpers, looking at his friend.
vi: Sydney Carton drank the liquor quickly; he finished a full glass, his eyes still on his friend.
tr: Sydney Carton took a big gulp of his drink; then, looking at his friend, he downed the glass that was filled to the brim.
es: Carton continued frequently visiting the punch bowl.

en: “Now you know all about it, Syd,” said mr Stryver.
vi: − Now I've told you everything, Sydney, - Stryver continued.
tr: "Now you know everything, Syd," said Mr. Stryver.
es: —You know it all already, Sydney—continued Stryver.

en: “I don’t care about fortune: she is a charming creature, and I have made up my mind to please myself: on the whole, I think I can afford to please myself.
vi: - I don't need wealth; she is a lovely person, and I have decided to seek happiness for myself; overall, I think I am well-qualified to be happy.
tr: "I have no interest in money or wealth. She is a magnificent creature and I have decided to be happy; I think I can succeed in being happy.
es: —I am marrying that girl, regardless of whether she has a fortune or not. She is a charming creature, and I have resolved to make her happy, and without boasting or immodesty, I believe I can say that I have achieved it.

en: She will have in me a man already pretty well off, and a rapidly rising man, and a man of some distinction: it is a piece of good fortune for her, but she is worthy of good fortune.
vi: She will have a wealthy husband in me; someone who is advancing quickly, someone with a bit of prestige; for her, having a husband like me is fortunate, but she also deserves to be fortunate.
tr: Even in my current state, I am quite wealthy, rapidly rising, and a man with many advantages. This is a great opportunity for her, but I mean, she also deserves this opportunity, of course.
es: I hold an enviable position, I am prospering and rising quickly, and I am not lacking in distinction. In a word: I am a treasure for her, and I am glad, for she deserves treasures.

en: Are you astonished?”
vi: Are you surprised?
tr: Are you surprised?"
es: Are you astonished by what you hear?

en: Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I be astonished?”
vi: - Why should I be surprised? - Still drinking, Carton replied.
tr: Carton, who was still busy drinking punch, said gruffly, "Why should I be surprised?"
es: —Why should it amaze me?—responded Sydney, between sips of punch.

en: “You approve?”
vi: − Do you approve?
tr: "So you approve."
es: —Do you approve of it?

en: Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I not approve?”
vi: Still drinking, Carton replied: − Why wouldn't I approve?
tr: Carton, who was still drinking punch, answered gruffly, "Why shouldn't I approve?"
es: —Why shouldn't I approve it? —Well!

en: “Well!” said his friend Stryver, “you take it more easily than I fancied you would, and are less mercenary on my behalf than I thought you would be; though, to be sure, you know well enough by this time that your ancient chum is a man of a pretty strong will.
vi: − Very good! - Stryver said to his friend. - You received this news more easily than I thought, and thought less about my benefit than I expected; although by now you surely know that your old friend is someone who, once decided, will act.
tr: "Alright!" said Stryver, "You got over it more easily than I expected and you didn't approach it as opportunistically as I thought, but of course, you know very well how determined your old friend is to get what he wants.
es: I see that you are taking it more calmly than I expected, and that, for my sake, you are less mercenary than I thought. It doesn't surprise me, after all, because you know perfectly well that your old schoolmate has always been distinguished by his strength of character.

en: Yes, Sydney, I have had enough of this style of life, with no other as a change from it; I feel that it is a pleasant thing for a man to have a home when he feels inclined to go to it (when he doesn’t, he can stay away), and I feel that Miss Manette will tell well in any station, and will always do me credit.
vi: That's right, Sydney, I'm tired of this lifestyle, it's too monotonous; I think it's a good thing for a man to have a family so that if he wants, he can go home; if he doesn't want to, he doesn't have to; I think Miss Manette would please any husband and would make me proud.
tr: Yes Sydney, I'm tired of this same old way of life; I think it's a very nice thing for a man to have a home he can go to when he wants (and escape from when he doesn't), and it seems to me that Miss Manette would be a good wife in any case and would bring me respect.
es: Yes, Sydney, yes; I am tired of the life I lead and the time has come to change it. I have become convinced that it is a delight for a man to have a home, to create a family, if he feels inclined to do so, and I am sure that Miss Manette will always beautify and honor it.

en: So I have made up my mind.
vi: So I've made up my mind.
tr: That's how I made my decision.
es: I am, therefore, resolved, firmly decided.

en: And now, Sydney, old boy, I want to say a word to you about your prospects.
vi: And now, Sydney, my old chum, I want to say a few words to you about your future.
tr: Now Sydney, big boy, I have some things to say about your "situation."
es: And now, Sydney, my dear friend, allow me to say a few words about your situation.

en: You are in a bad way, you know; you really are in a bad way.
vi: You are mistaken, you are truly mistaken.
tr: You know you're on a bad path, my friend; really on a bad path.
es: You are walking down false paths, on the wrong track; you know that as well as I do.

en: You don’t know the value of money, you live hard, you’ll knock up one of these days, and be ill and poor; you really ought to think about a nurse.”
vi: You don't know the value of money, you live frugally, and one day you will find yourself in illness and poverty. You need to think about finding someone to take care of you.
tr: You don't know the value of money, you're pushing yourself too hard, one day you won't be able to get up, you'll fall ill and be penniless; you should consider having a woman to take care of you."
es: You don't understand the value of money, you live a disordered life, you don't think about tomorrow, and in short, your behavior can only lead you to illness and misery. I think you need to find yourself a nurse.

en: The prosperous patronage with which he said it, made him look twice as big as he was, and four times as offensive.
vi: The pompous and boastful manner of Stryver's speech made him twice as arrogant and four times as obnoxious.
tr: Speaking like a well-off boss made him appear twice as big and four times as unpleasant as he actually was.
es: The protective tone with which Stryver spoke accentuated the impertinence of his words and made them doubly offensive.

en: “Now, let me recommend you,” pursued Stryver, “to look it in the face.
vi: − Listen, take my advice, - Stryver continued talking, - face the truth.
tr: Stryver continued his speech, "Now my advice to you is to open your eyes and look around.
es: —Do not be offended that I now recommend you study the matter head-on and without stupid prejudices as I have studied it, although our respective conditions differ greatly.

en: I have looked it in the face, in my different way; look it in the face, you, in your different way.
vi: I've faced the truth, in my own way; now you, face the truth in your way.
tr: I opened my eyes and found my way; you should open your eyes and find your way too.
es: —Do not be offended that I now recommend you study the matter head-on and without stupid prejudices as I have studied it, although our respective conditions differ greatly.

en: Marry.
vi: Get married.
tr: Get married.
es: Get married.

en: Provide somebody to take care of you.
vi: Find someone to take care of you.
tr: Find someone to take care of you.
es: Find someone to take care of you.

en: Never mind your having no enjoyment of women’s society, nor understanding of it, nor tact for it.
vi: Don't worry about not liking women, or not understanding them, or not being liked by them.
tr: It doesn't matter if you get bored among women, don't understand them, or lack refinement.
es: It doesn't matter if the company of women is not to your liking; it doesn't matter if you lack intelligence or tact to deal with them.

en: Find out somebody.
vi: Just find someone.
tr: You just find someone.
es: Find a respectable woman who has some assets, and marry her as soon as possible, the only way to prepare yourself in time against the calamities and uncertainties of life.

en: Find out some respectable woman with a little property—somebody in the landlady way, or lodging-letting way—and marry her, against a rainy day.
vi: Find a respectable woman with some property... a landlady or an innkeeper... and marry her, for when times get tough.
tr: Even if she doesn't have much money – maybe she has a house or a boarding house – let her be a respectable lady and marry her, save yourself.
es: Find a respectable woman who has some assets, and marry her as soon as possible, the only way to prepare yourself in time against the calamities and uncertainties of life.

en: That’s the kind of thing for you.
vi: That's your future.
tr: This is what you need.
es: I have finished.

en: Now think of it, Sydney.”
vi: Think about it, Sydney.
tr: Think about this carefully, Sydney."
es: Think about it, Sydney.

en: “I’ll think of it,” said Sydney.
vi: Think about it, Sydney.
tr: "I will think about it," said Sydney.
es: —I'll think about it—replied Sydney Carton.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: − Let me think, - Sydney replied.
tr: XII
es: Chapter XII.

en: The Fellow of Delicacy
vi: 12. The Elegant Gentleman
tr: The Polite Man
es: THE DELICATE KNIGHT

en: mr Stryver having made up his mind to that magnanimous bestowal of good fortune on the Doctor’s daughter, resolved to make her happiness known to her before he left town for the Long Vacation.
vi: Having wholeheartedly bestowed good fortune upon the doctor's daughter, Stryver decided to inform her of this joyous news before he left the city for an extended vacation.
tr: Mr. Stryver, who had decided to give a grand gift to the doctor's fortunate daughter, was determined to convey this happy news to her before leaving town for his long vacation.
es: Once Mr. Stryver resolved to secure Miss Manette's happiness, nothing was more natural than to let her know as soon as possible the joy that his magnanimity had bestowed upon her.

en: After some mental debating of the point, he came to the conclusion that it would be as well to get all the preliminaries done with, and they could then arrange at their leisure whether he should give her his hand a week or two before Michaelmas Term, or in the little Christmas vacation between it and Hilary.
vi: After some internal deliberation on the matter, he concluded that it would be best to handle the preliminary courtship immediately, and then arrange the wedding either during the regular court recess - either one or two weeks before the end of October or during the Christmas holiday.
tr: After pondering the matter for a while, he concluded that it would be good to make an attempt, and then they would have time to plan the wedding either a week or two before the Feast of St. Michael on September 29th, or sometime between Christmas and the Feast of St. Hilary of Poitiers on January 13th.
es: After mentally debating and with due deliberation on such an important matter, he concluded that he should take the preliminary steps right away, before going on vacation, leaving the setting of the wedding date for later, which could take place one or two weeks before Michaelmas, or during the brief Christmas holidays.

en: As to the strength of his case, he had not a doubt about it, but clearly saw his way to the verdict.
vi: Stryver viewed marriage as a lawsuit that he was sure to win and had already anticipated the court's verdict.
tr: As for the strength of his case, he had not the slightest doubt, but he could see the path to judgment.
es: That he had already won the lawsuit in advance was so evident that it would have been foolish to doubt it.

en: Argued with the jury on substantial worldly grounds—the only grounds ever worth taking into account—it was a plain case, and had not a weak spot in it.
vi: If he had to persuade the jury based on material advantages—the only basis worth considering—this case clearly had no weaknesses.
tr: This was a clear case argued with the jury on worldly grounds – the only grounds that could be taken seriously – and it had not the slightest weakness.
es: It was a clear case, without any weak points, one of those lawsuits where it is enough to file the complaint to obtain a favorable judgment.

en: He called himself for the plaintiff, there was no getting over his evidence, the counsel for the defendant threw up his brief, and the jury did not even turn to consider.
vi: He imagined himself as the plaintiff's representative, with solid, irrefutable evidence, then the defendant's counsel throwing in the towel, and the jury not even needing to deliberate.
tr: He called himself as the plaintiff, and it was impossible to deal with the evidence. The defendant's lawyer threw the case summary, but the jury did not even turn to look.
es: He could even spare himself the trouble of reasoning his request.

en: After trying it, Stryver, C. J., was satisfied that no plainer case could be.
vi: After the trial, Stryver, now imagining himself as the Judge, was satisfied that no trial could be clearer.
tr: Lawyer Stryver, C. J. was convinced that there could not be a simpler case than this.
es: Why?

en: Accordingly, mr Stryver inaugurated the Long Vacation with a formal proposal to take Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens; that failing, to Ranelagh; that unaccountably failing too, it behoved him to present himself in Soho, and there declare his noble mind.
vi: So Stryver began the long vacation by formally inviting Miss Manette to go to Vauxhall Gardens, an invitation that was declined; he then invited her to Ranelagh Gardens, which was also inexplicably declined, so he had to personally make his way to Soho and declare his noble intentions there.
tr: Therefore, Mr. Stryver began his long vacation with a formal proposal, inviting Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens; when that did not work, he suggested going to Ranelagh Gardens; when that also did not work, he decided it would be appropriate to go to Soho and reveal his noble intention.
es: The jury would rule in his favor without even deliberating: the famous lawyer was more than convinced of this. Consequently, Stryver began his vacation by proposing to Miss Manette to take her to the Vauxhall Gardens.

en: Towards Soho, therefore, mr Stryver shouldered his way from the Temple, while the bloom of the Long Vacation’s infancy was still upon it.
vi: That is why Stryver hurriedly went from the Temple area to Soho just as the holiday had begun.
tr: Thus, Mr. Stryver, with the freshness of the long holiday he had taken, left Temple and headed towards Soho.
es: After the offer was declined, he invited her to Ranelagh; and since, to his great surprise, this invitation was also not accepted, he resolved to declare the noble aspirations of his soul in the same little house in Soho.

en: Anybody who had seen him projecting himself into Soho while he was yet on Saint Dunstan’s side of Temple Bar, bursting in his full-blown way along the pavement, to the jostlement of all weaker people, might have seen how safe and strong he was.
vi: Anyone who saw him rushing towards Soho when he was still on the Saint Dunstan side of the Temple Bar gate, sprinting on the sidewalk, brushing aside any weaker pedestrians in his path, would see how strong and confident Stryver was.
tr: Those who saw him when he was still on the Saint Dunstan side of Temple Bar, upon seeing him in Soho, could understand how confident and strong he was from his swaggering walk, pushing and shoving poor people aside.
es: One morning, Stryver left the Temple Court and directed his steps towards the peaceful retreat where Dr. Manette lived.

en: His way taking him past Tellson’s, and he both banking at Tellson’s and knowing mr Lorry as the intimate friend of the Manettes, it entered mr Stryver’s mind to enter the bank, and reveal to mr Lorry the brightness of the Soho horizon.
vi: On the way past Tellson's Bank, since Stryver had both deposited money there and was acquainted with Mr. Lorry, who was close to the Manette family, he came up with the idea of entering the bank to inform him of the bright prospects on the horizon in Soho.
tr: As Mr. Stryver, who was passing by Tellson's Bank, thought of stopping by to talk to Mr. Lorry about the shining sun in Soho, since he was both a customer of Tellson's and a close friend of the Manettes, he decided to visit the bank.
es: Since Tellson's Bank was on his way, and knowing the close friendship between Mr. Lorry and the Manettes, it occurred to him to enter the Bank and reveal to him the radiant star that was casting bright rays on the horizon of Soho.

en: So, he pushed open the door with the weak rattle in its throat, stumbled down the two steps, got past the two ancient cashiers, and shouldered himself into the musty back closet where mr Lorry sat at great books ruled for figures, with perpendicular iron bars to his window as if that were ruled for figures too, and everything under the clouds were a sum.
vi: So he pushed the creaky door open, dashed down two steps, passed by two extremely old cashiers, and then barged into the musty room at the back where Mr. Lorry was sitting with some large ledger books with columns, by a window with vertical iron bars as if the window frame itself was a ledger sheet and everything under the clouds was money.
tr: Thus, with a slight rasp in his throat, he pushed the door open, stumbled down the two steps, passed by the two aged tellers, and threw himself into the musty compartment at the back where Mr. Lorry was seated over the large, lined ledgers kept for accounts; the vertical iron bars on the window stood like the lines separating the figures, and everything else under the sky seemed like their sum total.
es: He opened the door, which creaked harshly as it turned on its worn hinges, descended the two steps, and soon presented himself in the office where Lorry, bent over his books, was writing endless columns of perfectly aligned numbers.

en: “Halloa!” said mr Stryver.
vi: − Hello! - Stryver said. -
tr: "Hello!" said Mr. Stryver.
es: —Hello, Mr. Lorry! —exclaimed Stryver upon entering.

en: “How do you do?
vi: How are you?
tr: "How are you?
es: —How are you?

en: I hope you are well!”
vi: Hope you are doing well!
tr: Hope all is well."
es: —How are you?

en: It was Stryver’s grand peculiarity that he always seemed too big for any place, or space.
vi: Stryver had the notable characteristic of always seeming too grandiose in any space or place.
tr: In every environment he entered, everywhere, Mr. Stryver's most prominent feature was his large stature.
es: I suppose as well as always.

en: He was so much too big for Tellson’s, that old clerks in distant corners looked up with looks of remonstrance, as though he squeezed them against the wall.
vi: He was so grandiose for Tellson that the old employees in the far corners had to look up with disapproving eyes as if they were being pushed against the wall by him.
tr: He was too bulky for Tellson as well, so much so that the elderly clerks sitting in distant corners raised their heads and looked at him with reproachful eyes as if they were being squeezed against the wall.
es: I suppose as well as always.

en: The House itself, magnificently reading the paper quite in the far-off perspective, lowered displeased, as if the Stryver head had been butted into its responsible waistcoat.
vi: Even the Boss himself, who was majestically reading the newspaper in the farthest corner, had to reluctantly lower the paper as if Stryver had headbutted him in the stomach.
tr: The Manager, reading his newspaper over there, lifted his head with a stern expression as if Stryver's head was encroaching on his area of responsibility.
es: —Hello, Mr. Stryver!

en: The discreet mr Lorry said, in a sample tone of the voice he would recommend under the circumstances, “How do you do, mr Stryver?
vi: − Hello, Mr. Stryver.
tr: The prudent Mr. Lorry, in a tone that demonstrated how one should speak in such an environment, said, "How are you, Mr. Stryver?
es: —Hello, Mr. Stryver!

en: How do you do, sir?” and shook hands.
vi: How are you?
tr: How are you, sir?" and shook his hand.
es: —responded Lorry, shaking the hand that the lawyer extended to him.

en: There was a peculiarity in his manner of shaking hands, always to be seen in any clerk at Tellson’s who shook hands with a customer when the House pervaded the air.
vi: - Mr. Lorry responded tactfully with the exemplary tone he usually used in such circumstances.
tr: In the handshake, there was the manner of every clerk at Tellson's. When the manager was around, there was a certain demeanor while shaking a customer's hand.
es: —responded Lorry, shaking the hand that the lawyer extended to him.

en: He shook in a self-abnegating way, as one who shook for Tellson and Co.
vi: The way he shook hands was also unique, seen only when a Tellson employee shook hands with a customer in front of the Boss - a handshake that denied the self, representing only Tellson and the Corporation.
tr: It was as if it wasn't him shaking the hand, but the Tellson and Company itself.
es: —Very well, thank you; and you?

en: “Can I do anything for you, mr Stryver?” asked mr Lorry, in his business character.
vi: − How can I assist you, Mr. Stryver? - Mr. Lorry asked in a professional manner.
tr: "How can I assist you, Mr. Stryver?" asked Mr. Lorry, in his businessman's voice
es: Do you need something from me, Mr. Stryver?

en: “Why, no, thank you; this is a private visit to yourself, mr Lorry; I have come for a private word.”
vi: − Oh, no, thank you; this is just a personal visit, Mr. Lorry; I have a private matter to discuss with you.
tr: "No, thank you; this is a personal visit, Mr. Lorry; I have come to talk to you about something private."
es: —No... thank you very much. I have the desire to pay you a private visit, Mr. Lorry; the desire to say a few words to you in private. —Oh, whichever ones you want!

en: “Oh indeed!” said mr Lorry, bending down his ear, while his eye strayed to the House afar off.
vi: − Oh really! - Mr. Lorry tilted his ear towards the guest while his gaze wandered towards the Boss in the distance.
tr: "Is that so?" said Mr. Lorry, listening intently but his eyes had shifted to the Manager ahead.
es: —replied Lorry, closing the book and getting ready to listen.

en: “I am going,” said mr Stryver, leaning his arms confidentially on the desk: whereupon, although it was a large double one, there appeared to be not half desk enough for him: “I am going to make an offer of myself in marriage to your agreeable little friend, Miss Manette, mr Lorry.”
vi: − Here I am, - Stryver said confidently, placing his hands on a desk that was twice the size of a normal one but still seemed small before the grand Stryver, - here I am about to propose to your charming young friend, Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry.
tr: "I am going," said Mr. Stryver, confidently leaning his arms on the table; despite it being a large table, he occupied half of it. "I am going to propose marriage to your sweet little friend Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry."
es: —I'm going...—the lawyer began to say, resting his elbows on the table and in a confidential tone,—I'm going to make a marriage proposal to your dear and pleasant little friend Lucía Manette, Mr. Lorry.

en: “Oh dear me!” cried mr Lorry, rubbing his chin, and looking at his visitor dubiously.
vi: − Oh my goodness! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, rubbing his chin, his eyes doubtfully looking at the guest.
tr: "Good heavens!" shouted Mr. Lorry, rubbing his chin and looking at his visitor with suspicious eyes.
es: —Damn! —exclaimed Lorry, scratching his beard and looking perplexed at the lawyer.

en: “Oh dear me, sir?” repeated Stryver, drawing back.
vi: − Why should it be my death? - Stryver stepped back. -
tr: "Why, good heavens, sir?" said Stryver, drawing back.
es: —Demon?—repeated Stryver vividly.—Is that what you come up with to say to me?

en: “Oh dear you, sir?
vi: Or is it your death?
tr: "Good heavens, why, sir?
es: What does your exclamation mean, Mr. Lorry?

en: What may your meaning be, mr Lorry?”
vi: What do you mean, Mr. Lorry? −
tr: What did you mean, Mr. Lorry?"
es: What does your exclamation mean, Mr. Lorry?

en: “My meaning,” answered the man of business, “is, of course, friendly and appreciative, and that it does you the greatest credit, and—in short, my meaning is everything you could desire.
vi: What I mean is, - the man of business responded, - of course, in a friendly and appreciative manner, I mean that it is extremely well-deserved for you, and... In short, my point is that I hope you achieve everything you desire. But...
tr: "What I mean," the businessman began, "of course it involves friendship and appreciation and is extremely beneficial for you, in short, I mean there's nothing bad about it.
es: —It is an exclamation... friendly... personal... purely appreciative, that can mean whatever you wish it to mean.

en: But—really, you know, mr Stryver—” mr Lorry paused, and shook his head at him in the oddest manner, as if he were compelled against his will to add, internally, “you know there really is so much too much of you!”
vi: To be honest, Mr. Stryver... - Mr. Lorry paused and then shook his head, looking at the guest in a very peculiar way, as if he was forced to speak against his own will, - you know very well that you are exceedingly grand!
tr: But – actually, you know, Mr. Stryver –" Mr. Lorry, as if something had stopped him from continuing, nodded his head in the strangest manner, "you are a bit too, I mean actually, excessively grand."
es: The truth is, Mr. Stryver... it seems to me... I find...

en: “Well!” said Stryver, slapping the desk with his contentious hand, opening his eyes wider, and taking a long breath, “if I understand you, mr Lorry, I’ll be hanged!”
vi: − Hmph! - Stryver pounded his hand on the table, eyes wide open, and took a deep breath. - Mr. Lorry, if I understand what you mean, hang me!
tr: Stryver, striking Mr. Lorry's desk with his rough hand, said "Well then!" and took a deep breath, opening his eyes wide, "it's impossible to understand you either!"
es: —Enough! —replied the lawyer, slamming his hand on the table. —If I understand what you're saying, Mr. Lorry, hang me!

en: mr Lorry adjusted his little wig at both ears as a means towards that end, and bit the feather of a pen.
vi: Mr. Lorry adjusted the sides of his wig and bit the tip of the quill pen.
tr: Mr. Lorry adjusted his small wig from both sides of his ears to the back and bit his quill pen.
es: Lorry adjusted his toupee on his head and stood looking at his interlocutor, biting the bristles of his pen.

en: “D—n it all, sir!” said Stryver, staring at him, “am I not eligible?”
vi: − Damn it! - Stryver stared - So I'm not worthy? −
tr: Stryver, fixing his eyes on Mr. Lorry, said, "Damn it! Am I not suitable for her then?"
es: —Do you consider me ineligible?—asked Stryver, staring intently at his interlocutor.

en: “Oh dear yes!
vi: Oh no, you are!
tr: "Ah of course!
es: —Quite the contrary, Mr. Stryver!

en: Yes.
vi: You are!
tr: "Ah of course!
es: Yes... you are eligible.

en: Oh yes, you’re eligible!” said mr Lorry.
vi: Oh, you are very suitable! - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: Of course you are suitable!" said Mr. Lorry.
es: Yes... you are eligible.

en: “If you say eligible, you are eligible.”
vi: If you are not suitable, then who is?
tr: "If you see yourself as suitable, then you are suitable."
es: Yes... you are eligible.

vi: − So, am I not successful?
tr: "If you see yourself as suitable, then you are suitable."
es: —Am I not a good match?

en: Original
vi: - Stryver asked again.
tr: "If you see yourself as suitable, then you are suitable."
es: —Am I not a good match?

en: “Am I not prosperous?” asked Stryver.
vi: - Stryver asked again.
tr: "Am I not a successful and wealthy man?" asked Stryver.
es: —Am I not a good match?

en: “Oh!
vi: − Oh!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Good match; yes... why not?

en: if you come to prosperous, you are prosperous,” said mr Lorry.
vi: If you are not successful, then who else could be? - Mr. Lorry replied.
tr: If it's about success and wealth, of course you are," said Mr. Lorry,
es: —No progress?

en: “And advancing?”
vi: − And further advancement? −
tr: "Aren't I steadily rising in my job?"
es: No improvement?

en: “If you come to advancing you know,” said mr Lorry, delighted to be able to make another admission, “nobody can doubt that.”
vi: As for advancement, you needn't mention it, - Mr. Lorry was glad to have the opportunity to acknowledge once more, - no one could doubt that.
tr: "You are certainly rising," said Mr. Lorry, pleased to be able to confirm it once more, "let no one doubt it."
es: —Yes, sir... who doubts it?

en: “Then what on earth is your meaning, mr Lorry?” demanded Stryver, perceptibly crestfallen.
vi: − So what the hell do you mean by that, Mr. Lorry? - Stryver asked, clearly flustered.
tr: "So what do you mean by that, Mr. Lorry?" asked Stryver, with visible distress.
es: —Then, what the hell does his attitude mean?

en: “Well!
tr: "Um!
es: —Well... I... Tell me: where were you going now?

en: I—Were you going there now?” asked mr Lorry.
vi: Are you planning to go there now? - Mr. Lorry asked. − Come immediately!
tr: Were you- going there now?" asked Mr. Lorry.
es: —Well... I... Tell me: where were you going now?

en: “Straight!” said Stryver, with a plump of his fist on the desk.
vi: - Stryver pounded his fist on the table.
tr: "Yes!" said Stryver, banging his fist on the table with a thud.
es: —Straight to the point—replied Stryver, punching the table.

en: “Then I think I wouldn’t, if I was you.”
vi: − So if I were you, I think I wouldn't go.
tr: "In that case, if I were you, I wouldn't go."
es: —If I were in your place, I would leave it for a better occasion.

en: “Why?” said Stryver.
vi: − Why? - Stryver said.
tr: "Why?" asked Stryver.
es: —Why?—thundered the lawyer.

en: “Now, I’ll put you in a corner,” forensically shaking a forefinger at him.
vi: - Now you must tell me the truth. The index finger waved in front of the other person as if arguing in court. -
tr: Pointing his finger at him as if he were in court, he said, "I will corner you now."
es: —I am going to press you to the utmost limit.

en: “You are a man of business and bound to have a reason.
vi: You are a man of work, so you must have a reason.
tr: "You are a businessman and there must be a reason for what you say.
es: As a businessman, you are obliged to speak with justified reason.

en: State your reason.
vi: You speak.
tr: Explain your reason.
es: Give the reasons: why wouldn't you go?

en: Why wouldn’t you go?”
vi: Why don't you want to go?
tr: Why wouldn't you go there?"
es: Give the reasons: why wouldn't you go?

en: “Because,” said mr Lorry, “I wouldn’t go on such an object without having some cause to believe that I should succeed.”
vi: − Because, - Mr. Lorry replied, - I don't want to do it unless there's some evidence to believe that I will succeed.
tr: "Because," said Mr. Lorry, "if I had such an intention, I would not go without a reason to believe that I would succeed.""
es: —Because it is a matter that I would never address without having well-founded hopes of achieving the realization of my desire.

en: “D—n me!” cried Stryver, “but this beats everything.”
vi: − Damn it! - Stryver shouted. - I can't understand it at all!
tr: "Damn it!" shouted Stryver, "you really did it."
es: —Wrath of God! —shouted Stryver. —It's a reason that knocks you flat on your back!

en: mr Lorry glanced at the distant House, and glanced at the angry Stryver.
vi: Mr. Lorry glanced at the Boss in the distance and then looked at the furious Stryver.
tr: Mr. Lorry first glanced at the distant Manager and then at the angry Stryver.
es: Lorry did not respond.

en: “Here’s a man of business—a man of years—a man of experience—in a Bank,” said Stryver; “and having summed up three leading reasons for complete success, he says there’s no reason at all!
vi: − This is a man of work... an elder person... a person full of experience... in the bank, - Stryver said, - and after summarizing the three main reasons for my success, he then said there was no evidence to believe that!
tr: "A businessman –at this age– a man with this experience –a man working in a bank," said Stryver; "you are given three fundamental reasons for absolute success and you say you have no reason!
es: —Here is a businessman, a man of years, a man of experience... in a Bank, who after admitting the existence of the three main reasons, each of which is sufficient on its own to ensure success, comes out saying that there is no reason at all.

en: Says it with his head on!” mr Stryver remarked upon the peculiarity as if it would have been infinitely less remarkable if he had said it with his head off.
vi: And he said it so calmly! - Stryver emphasized the last sentence as if it would be extremely surprising if Mr. Lorry had said it while out of his mind.
tr: And you say this with your head held high!" Mr. Lorry had a strange belief, it seems, that if he said these things with his head bowed, they would somehow be less valid, according to Mr. Stryver.
es: If that isn't the most absurd of absurdities, then let God come and see it!

en: “When I speak of success, I speak of success with the young lady; and when I speak of causes and reasons to make success probable, I speak of causes and reasons that will tell as such with the young lady.
vi: − When I speak of success, I mean success with that lady; and when I speak of reasons for potential success, I mean reasons that are persuasive to that lady.
tr: "When I say success, I am talking about the success of reaching the young girl's heart; as for the reasons and justifications that will make this success possible, these are things that only this young lady would know.
es: —When I referred to success, I was thinking of Miss Manette, and when speaking of causes and reasons on which to base the hopes of seeing the desire fulfilled, I was referring to causes that were truly so for Miss Manette.

en: The young lady, my good sir,” said mr Lorry, mildly tapping the Stryver arm, “the young lady.
vi: Think of that lady, sir, - Mr. Lorry said while gently tapping Stryver's arm, - think about it.
tr: Only this young lady, dear sir," said Mr. Lorry, lightly tapping Stryver's arm, "This is something the young lady knows.
es: Yes... my good friend... the young lady, because the young lady is the sole and unappealable judge.

en: The young lady goes before all.”
vi: The lady's wishes are what matter most.
tr: The young lady's thoughts are more important than anything else."
es: Yes... my good friend... the young lady, because the young lady is the sole and unappealable judge.

en: “Then you mean to tell me, mr Lorry,” said Stryver, squaring his elbows, “that it is your deliberate opinion that the young lady at present in question is a mincing Fool?”
vi: − Mr. Lorry, are you trying to tell me that, - Stryver spread his elbows, - you mean to say that the young lady we are talking about is a capricious fool? −
tr: "Mr. Lorry, what you mean to tell me," said Stryver, placing his elbows, "is the young lady a delicate fool in this matter?""
es: —So, what you want to tell me, Mr. Lorry, is that the young lady, in your opinion, is a finicky fool.

en: “Not exactly so.
vi: Not exactly, Mr. Stryver, - Mr. Lorry blushed.
tr: "Of course not."
es: —So, what you want to tell me, Mr. Lorry, is that the young lady, in your opinion, is a finicky fool.

en: I mean to tell you, mr Stryver,” said mr Lorry, reddening, “that I will hear no disrespectful word of that young lady from any lips; and that if I knew any man—which I hope I do not—whose taste was so coarse, and whose temper was so overbearing, that he could not restrain himself from speaking disrespectfully of that young lady at this desk, not even Tellson’s should prevent my giving him a piece of my mind.”
vi: - I want to tell you that I do not want to hear anyone utter any disrespectful words about that young lady; if I know of anyone; I hope there is none; whose rude behavior and arrogant nature lead them to speak disrespectfully about that young lady right at my desk, then not even Tellson's Bank could stop me from giving them a good scolding.
tr: "What I want to tell you, Mr. Stryver," said Mr. Lorry, with a flushed face, "is that I will not allow anyone to speak disrespectfully about this young lady; if someone were to – and I hope no one does – lose control of their vulgarity and audacity and attempt to speak disrespectfully about her at this table, not even Tellson could prevent me from putting them in their place.""
es: —You interpret me in a hurtful way, Mr. Stryver—replied Lorry, red with anger.— What I meant to say, and what I am saying, is that I will not tolerate any tongue uttering a disrespectful word about Miss Manette, and that if I knew of any man... which I want to believe does not exist, any man of such coarse taste and impetuous temperament, who dared to speak with little respect of Miss Manette, the consideration of being at Tellson's Bank would not be enough for me to leave his rudeness unpunished.

en: The necessity of being angry in a suppressed tone had put mr Stryver’s blood-vessels into a dangerous state when it was his turn to be angry; mr Lorry’s veins, methodical as their courses could usually be, were in no better state now it was his turn.
vi: The act of being angry but having to speak in a restrained tone caused Stryver's blood vessels to dangerously swell when he got heated; Mr. Lorry's blood vessels, normally not visible, now also bulged when it was his turn.
tr: When it was his turn to get angry, the necessity of suppressing his anger had put Mr. Stryver's veins at risk; although Mr. Lorry's veins generally pulsed regularly, they were not in very good condition because it was his turn to get angry.
es: The need to contain within his chest the anger that struggled to explode had put Stryver in a dangerous state of mind; as for Lorry, despite having accustomed his blood to not be disturbed by anything or anyone, he found himself in a state of mind as dangerous as that of the lawyer.

en: “That is what I mean to tell you, sir,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − That's what I mean, sir, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "These were the things I wanted to say, sir," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —You know what I wanted to tell you, sir—replied Lorry.

en: “Pray let there be no mistake about it.”
vi: - Please don't misunderstand me.
tr: "Please, let there be no mistake."
es: —I would greatly appreciate it if you don't forget it.

en: mr Stryver sucked the end of a ruler for a little while, and then stood hitting a tune out of his teeth with it, which probably gave him the toothache.
vi: Stryver put the end of the ruler in his mouth, sucked on it for a while, and then tapped the ruler against his teeth in a rhythm that probably made them ache.
tr: After Mr. Stryver chewed on the end of a ruler for a while, he made noises by tapping his teeth, but this must have hurt his teeth as he stopped.
es: There followed a moment of silence, during which Stryver sucked on the end of a small iron square he had taken from the table.

en: He broke the awkward silence by saying:
vi: Stryver broke the silence: − I find this strange, Mr. Lorry.
tr: Breaking the strange silence, he said:
es: Finally, he broke the truly painful silence by saying:

en: “This is something new to me, mr Lorry.
vi: Stryver broke the silence: − I find this strange, Mr. Lorry.
tr: "I never expected this Mr. Lorry.
es: —What you are telling me, Mr. Lorry, is so new, so inconceivable, that I cannot quite understand it, despite the clarity of your words.

en: You deliberately advise me not to go up to Soho and offer myself—myself, Stryver of the King’s Bench bar?”
vi: You deliberately advise me not to go to Soho to propose; I, Stryver of the High Court Bar.
tr: Are you now advising me – Stryver of the King's Bench – not to go to Soho and not to make an offer?"
es: Are you truly advising me not to go to Soho and offer my hand... the hand of the famous lawyer Stryver, to the daughter of Doctor Manette?

en: “Do you ask me for my advice, mr Stryver?”
vi: − Do you want to hear my advice, Mr. Stryver? −
tr: "Do you want my advice, Mr. Stryver?"
es: —Are you asking me for honesty, Mr. Stryver?

en: “Yes, I do.”
vi: Yes, I want to hear it.
tr: "Yes, I do."
es: —Yes.

en: “Very good.
vi: − Very good.
tr: "Very good.
es: —Perfectly.

en: Then I give it, and you have repeated it correctly.”
vi: So, you just heard me say that, and you just repeated it exactly.
tr: Then let me tell you, and you should follow these exactly."
es: You have repeated word for word and letter for letter what I must reply.

en: “And all I can say of it is,” laughed Stryver with a vexed laugh, “that this—ha, ha!—beats everything past, present, and to come.”
vi: − Well, all I can say is... ha ha, - Stryver laughed irritably, - this matter is really... ha ha... incomprehensible, both past, present, and future.
tr: "All I will say," said Stryver, laughing in an offended manner, "is that your words –ha ha!– erase the entire past, present, and future.""
es: Do not present yourself in Soho, nor offer your hand... the hand of the brilliant lawyer Stryver, to the daughter of Doctor Manette. —And I reply that this... ha, ha, ha, ha!

en: “Now understand me,” pursued mr Lorry.
vi: − Now listen to me, - Mr. Lorry continued. -
tr: "Don't misunderstand me," continued Mr. Lorry.
es: beats all the past, present, and future nonsense hands down.

en: “As a man of business, I am not justified in saying anything about this matter, for, as a man of business, I know nothing of it.
vi: As a man of business, I have no right to speak about this personal matter; as a man of business, I don't know how to talk about this matter.
tr: "As a businessman, I cannot be certain of the accuracy of what I say on this matter, after all, I am a businessman and I do not understand much about these subjects.
es: —Let's dot the i's and cross the t's—added Lorry;—as a businessman, I can say nothing about the matter we are debating, because as a businessman, I know nothing: but as an old friend of the house, as a man who has rocked Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and her father, as a man who loves them both dearly, I can speak, and as such, I have spoken.

en: But, as an old fellow, who has carried Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and of her father too, and who has a great affection for them both, I have spoken.
vi: But I speak as an old man who once held Miss Manette in his arms when she was a child, as a trusted friend of both Miss Manette and her father, and as someone who deeply loves them both.
tr: However, I told you these things as an old man who has carried Miss Manette in his arms, been a reliable friend to her and her father, and loves both of them very much.
es: —Let's dot the i's and cross the t's—added Lorry;—as a businessman, I can say nothing about the matter we are debating, because as a businessman, I know nothing: but as an old friend of the house, as a man who has rocked Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and her father, as a man who loves them both dearly, I can speak, and as such, I have spoken.

en: The confidence is not of my seeking, recollect.
vi: It was you who came here to ask my opinion, remember that.
tr: Remember that I was not the one who brought up this matter.
es: —Let's dot the i's and cross the t's—added Lorry;—as a businessman, I can say nothing about the matter we are debating, because as a businessman, I know nothing: but as an old friend of the house, as a man who has rocked Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and her father, as a man who loves them both dearly, I can speak, and as such, I have spoken.

en: Now, you think I may not be right?”
vi: Now you think I'm wrong, don't you?
tr: Am I wrong now?"
es: Now then: do you think I could be wrong?

en: “Not I!” said Stryver, whistling.
vi: − Not at all! - Stryver hissed.
tr: "You are right!" said Stryver, vaguely.
es: —Not even in your dreams!

en: “I can’t undertake to find third parties in common sense; I can only find it for myself.
vi: - I can't understand the common reasoning of others; I only understand my own reasoning.
tr: "When it comes to common sense, I value my own opinions more than those of third parties.
es: Common sense is a rare plant that grows in few places. I have never hoped to find it outside of myself.

en: I suppose sense in certain quarters; you suppose mincing bread-and-butter nonsense.
vi: I believe I'm right on some issues, while you believe in nonsensical and trivial matters.
tr: I had thought some people were reasonable, but you say this delicate fool is a complete idiot.
es: I supposed that perhaps it existed where, apparently, according to you, only folly finds fertile ground.

en: It’s new to me, but you are right, I dare say.”
vi: It's strange, but you're right, I suppose.
tr: This was something I did not expect, but I suppose you are right."
es: I am disappointed, I confess, as I expected something else; but I believe you are right.

en: “What I suppose, mr Stryver, I claim to characterise for myself—And understand me, sir,” said mr Lorry, quickly flushing again, “I will not—not even at Tellson’s—have it characterised for me by any gentleman breathing.”
vi: − I believe in the things that I personally consider to be right, Mr. Stryver... Please understand, - Mr. Lorry blushed again, I do not allow... even here at Tellson's... anyone to speak on my behalf.
tr: "Mr. Stryver, what I think is a part of my personality. Please understand me, sir," said Mr. Lorry, suddenly turning bright red again, "I cannot accept anyone –even within Tellson's– interpreting my thoughts in this manner."
es: —I have neither spoken of fertilized or unfertilized grounds for folly to grow in, nor will I tolerate... inside or outside Tellson's Bank, anyone born offending people whose name can only be pronounced on one's knees!

en: “There!
vi: − Look!
tr: "So be it!
es: —shouted Lorry, growing furious again.

en: I beg your pardon!” said Stryver.
vi: I apologize to you! - Stryver exclaimed.
tr: I apologize!" said Stryver.
es: —Don't trouble yourself: I beg you to forgive phrases said without the intention of bothering anyone.

en: “Granted.
vi: − I pass.
tr: "Accepted.
es: —Forgiven, and thank you.

en: Thank you.
vi: Thank you.
tr: Thank you.
es: —Forgiven, and thank you.

en: Well, mr Stryver, I was about to say:—it might be painful to you to find yourself mistaken, it might be painful to Doctor Manette to have the task of being explicit with you, it might be very painful to Miss Manette to have the task of being explicit with you.
vi: Hey, Mr. Stryver, what I meant to say is... it might be distressing for you if you find yourself mistaken, it might be distressing for Dr. Manette to have to speak frankly with you, and it might be very distressing for Miss Manette to have to speak frankly with you.
tr: So, Mr. Stryver, what I meant to say was this: Seeing that you were mistaken might upset you, having to tell you some things plainly might upset Doctor Manette, and speaking frankly might also be very distressing for Miss Manette.
es: What I meant to say was the following: it would be painful for you to suffer a disappointment, it would be painful for Dr. Manette to find himself in the position of having to be explicit with you, and it would be very painful for Miss Lucía to find herself in the harsh necessity of speaking frankly to you.

en: You know the terms upon which I have the honour and happiness to stand with the family.
vi: I have the honor and good fortune to be close to that family, you know.
tr: You know under what circumstances I had the honor and happiness of being with them.
es: You know that I have the honor and the happiness of being a good friend of the family.

en: If you please, committing you in no way, representing you in no way, I will undertake to correct my advice by the exercise of a little new observation and judgment expressly brought to bear upon it.
vi: If you allow, I will try to observe and consider more clearly to give you more accurate advice without harming your intention to propose, or having to speak on your behalf.
tr: If you wish, without involving your name at all, I can try to observe a bit more and come to a judgment in order to review my advice.
es: Well then: if you want me, without representing you in any way, without involving you in anything at all, to make new observations that confirm or modify the impressions I have today, I offer myself for that right away.

en: If you should then be dissatisfied with it, you can but test its soundness for yourself; if, on the other hand, you should be satisfied with it, and it should be what it now is, it may spare all sides what is best spared.
vi: After that, if you are not satisfied with my advice, you can investigate for yourself; on the other hand, if you find that what I say aligns with what I have just mentioned, then both sides can avoid unpleasant matters.
tr: If you are not satisfied with the result, you can question its validity yourself, but if you are satisfied and reach the point where we are now, everyone will go their own way.
es: If the result of my new observations does not satisfy you, you will be free to personally verify their foundation; otherwise, we will have at least managed to avoid unpleasant scenes and situations.

en: What do you say?”
vi: What do you think?
tr: What do you say?"
es: What do you think of my plan?

en: “How long would you keep me in town?”
vi: − How long do I have to stay in this city waiting for you? −
tr: "How long do I need to stay in the city?"
es: —How long would it take you to answer me?

en: “Oh!
vi: Oh!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Oh!

en: It is only a question of a few hours.
vi: Just a few hours.
tr: Just a few hours of work.
es: It's a matter of a few hours!

en: I could go to Soho in the evening, and come to your chambers afterwards.”
vi: This afternoon I can go to Soho and then to your office.
tr: In the evening, I'll go to Soho, and then I'll come to you."
es: This afternoon I can go to Soho, and from there go straight to your house.

en: “Then I say yes,” said Stryver: “I won’t go up there now, I am not so hot upon it as that comes to; I say yes, and I shall expect you to look in to-night.
vi: − Then I agree, - Stryver said. - Now I will not go there anymore, I am not in a hurry to go there right away; I agree, and I will wait for you to come by tonight.
tr: "Alright then," said Stryver. "I won't go now, it's not that urgent; I accept and I am expecting you this evening.
es: —If that's the case, it seems fine to me. I will wait for you tonight...

en: Good morning.”
vi: Goodbye, sir.
tr: Good day."
es: Good morning!

en: Then mr Stryver turned and burst out of the Bank, causing such a concussion of air on his passage through, that to stand up against it bowing behind the two counters, required the utmost remaining strength of the two ancient clerks.
vi: So Stryver turned his back and dashed out of the bank, creating such a strong gust of wind behind him that the two elderly clerks, who were bowing deeply behind the two counters, had to muster all their strength just to stay upright.
tr: Then, as Mr. Stryver turned around and left the bank, he created such a dramatic atmosphere that the two elderly clerks standing behind the counters, who were greeting him, made every effort not to topple over.
es: The gentleman Stryver left the Bank building with a tempest of anger in his chest.

en: Those venerable and feeble persons were always seen by the public in the act of bowing, and were popularly believed, when they had bowed a customer out, still to keep on bowing in the empty office until they bowed another customer in.
vi: People always saw those feeble dignitaries bent over, and everyone believed that once they bowed to bid farewell to a client, they would remain hunched like that in the empty bank until they had to greet another client.
tr: These very esteemed frail individuals were always seen in a state of greeting, even to the extent that, according to common belief, when they bid farewell to someone, they would remain in that state until they welcomed a new customer, even if the office was empty.
es: He had enough insight to understand that the banker would not have expressed his opinions on the matter so clearly if he had not had such a solid foundation to support them, which amounted to a moral certainty.

en: The barrister was keen enough to divine that the banker would not have gone so far in his expression of opinion on any less solid ground than moral certainty.
vi: This lawyer was shrewd enough to understand that the old man in the bank would never reveal so much if he didn't have a solid basis to believe in what he was saying.
