tr: The lawyer was smart enough to know that the banker, besides his sharp instincts, could not express his thoughts to this extent without solid grounds.
es: He had enough insight to understand that the banker would not have expressed his opinions on the matter so clearly if he had not had such a solid foundation to support them, which amounted to a moral certainty.

en: Unprepared as he was for the large pill he had to swallow, he got it down.
vi: Those unexpected words were indeed a bitter pill too large for him to swallow, but he managed to swallow it.
tr: He was caught off guard by the big pill he had to swallow and he swallowed it.
es: He was far from thinking, when he entered the Bank, that such a bitter pill awaited him; but he had no choice but to swallow it.

en: “And now,” said mr Stryver, shaking his forensic forefinger at the Temple in general, when it was down, “my way out of this, is, to put you all in the wrong.”
vi: Once he had swallowed it, Stryver wagged his index finger as if arguing in court with the entire Temple Bar and silently threatened: "Now, the way out of this is to prove you are all wrong."
tr: "Now," said Mr. Stryver at Temple Bar, waving his finger around as if he were in court, "the only way to settle this is to prove that you are wrong."
es: —You have put yourself in an awkward situation, Stryver—he said to himself;—you have made a fool of yourself... Now's the time for your forensic talent to get out of this mess!

en: It was a bit of the art of an Old Bailey tactician, in which he found great relief.
vi: That was a little trick of courtroom tactics at the Old Bailey that often saved him during litigation.
tr: Kurnaz Old Bailey tactics were now easing his troubles.
es: It was clearly visible that the pill had gotten stuck in his throat and that the eminent lawyer was looking for a way to spit it out.

en: “You shall not put me in the wrong, young lady,” said mr Stryver; “I’ll do that for you.”
vi: Stryver reassured himself: "You won't be able to prove that I'm wrong, miss, I will prove that you are wrong."
tr: "You will show me that I am not mistaken, young lady," said Mr. Stryver; "I will make you do it."
es: —Ah, my dear miss! —he murmured after a few moments. —I will not be the one to bear the ridicule!... You will have the pleasure of keeping the fruit of the cucurbit family that you have reserved for me!

en: Accordingly, when mr Lorry called that night as late as ten o’clock, mr Stryver, among a quantity of books and papers littered out for the purpose, seemed to have nothing less on his mind than the subject of the morning.
vi: Therefore, when Mr. Lorry came to the office at ten o'clock in the evening, Stryver was sitting amidst a clutter of books and papers, seemingly no longer concerned with the morning's events.
tr: Therefore, when Mr. Lorry knocked on his door at the late hour of around ten at night, Mr. Stryver, amidst the books and papers he had deliberately scattered around, seemed as if the morning's matter had completely slipped his mind.
es: Indeed: that night, when Lorry arrived at the lawyer's house, he found him among stacks of papers and piles of books purposely placed on his desk, absorbed in his work and completely oblivious to the matter discussed that morning.

en: He even showed surprise when he saw mr Lorry, and was altogether in an absent and preoccupied state.
vi: He even appeared surprised to see Mr. Lorry and received the guest with the distracted demeanor of a busy person. − Oh! -
tr: Upon seeing Mr. Lorry, he showed a sign of surprise, appearing distracted and busy.
es: He even seemed surprised to see Lorry.

en: “Well!” said that good-natured emissary, after a full half-hour of bootless attempts to bring him round to the question.
vi: The kind-hearted marriage envoy, after half an hour of futilely steering the conversation towards this topic, had to remind.
tr: "Well!" said the kind-hearted envoy, after waiting in vain for an hour for him to bring up the subject.
es: —I have been in Soho—said the emissary, after more than half an hour spent in vain attempts to broach the subject.

en: “I have been to Soho.”
vi: - I have arrived at Soho.
tr: "I went to Soho today." "Did you go to Soho?"
es: —I have been in Soho—said the emissary, after more than half an hour spent in vain attempts to broach the subject.

en: “To Soho?” repeated mr Stryver, coldly.
vi: − To Soho? - Stryver asked nonchalantly. -
tr: Mr. Stryver repeated coldly.
es: —In Soho?—repeated Stryver with glacial indifference.

en: “Oh, to be sure!
vi: Oh, of course!
tr: "Oh, of course!
es: —Ah... yes!

en: What am I thinking of!”
vi: Where was my mind? −
tr: What am I saying!"
es: What a head I have!

en: “And I have no doubt,” said mr Lorry, “that I was right in the conversation we had.
vi: And I am certain, - Mr. Lorry said, - that I was right when we talked this morning.
tr: "Regarding the truth of what we have discussed," said Mr. Lorry, "I have no doubt left.
es: Would you believe that I didn't remember such a thing? —I no longer have the slightest doubt that the advice I gave you was extremely accurate.

en: My opinion is confirmed, and I reiterate my advice.”
vi: My opinion has been confirmed, and I repeat that advice.
tr: My opinion has been confirmed, and I reiterate my advice to you."
es: My impressions have been fully confirmed.

en: “I assure you,” returned mr Stryver, in the friendliest way, “that I am sorry for it on your account, and sorry for it on the poor father’s account.
vi: − I assure you, - Stryver replied, in a friendly tone, - I feel sorry for you and also for that poor father.
tr: "Believe me," replied Mr. Stryver, in his most friendly manner, "I felt sorry for you, and for your poor father as well.
es: —Believe me, I truly regret it very much for you—replied Stryver with perfect calm,—and no less truly for the poor father.

en: I know this must always be a sore subject with the family; let us say no more about it.”
vi: I understand that this matter must be very awkward for that family; let us not talk about it anymore.
tr: I know that this matter will always be a sad situation for this family; it's best to close this subject."
es: It is an incident that the family will always remember with sorrow, and that... But let's not talk about it.

en: “I don’t understand you,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − I don't understand your point, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "I don't understand you," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —I confess that I do not understand.

en: “I dare say not,” rejoined Stryver, nodding his head in a smoothing and final way; “no matter, no matter.”
vi: − Probably not, - Stryver nodded with a comfortable and decisive demeanor, not important, not important.
tr: "Never mind," replied Stryver, in a soothing and decisive manner; "it doesn't matter, it doesn't matter."
es: —I believe it; but it doesn't matter... it doesn't matter.

en: “But it does matter,” mr Lorry urged.
vi: − But this matter is indeed important, - Mr. Lorry emphasized.
tr: "Don't say that, it's an important matter," insisted Mr. Lorry.
es: —On the contrary—replied Lorry,—it matters, and I would like it to be explained.

en: “No it doesn’t; I assure you it doesn’t.
vi: − Not at all; I assure you, not at all.
tr: "No, it's not important; believe me, it's not.
es: —I repeat, it doesn't matter.

en: Having supposed that there was sense where there is no sense, and a laudable ambition where there is not a laudable ambition, I am well out of my mistake, and no harm is done.
vi: After mistakenly believing there was reason where there was none, and mistakenly believing there was noble aspiration where there was none, I realized my error and suffered no harm.
tr: I was mistaken in thinking that where there is no logic, there is logic, and where there is no enthusiasm, there is praiseworthy enthusiasm, but it's okay, it's not a problem.
es: I thought I saw common sense and laudable ambition where neither exists. I was mistaken, I am cured of my error, and the matter is concluded. Fortunately, my error is one that does not cause harm to the one who was its victim.

en: Young women have committed similar follies often before, and have repented them in poverty and obscurity often before.
vi: Young ladies often make similar foolish mistakes and often regret them when they find themselves in poverty and darkness.
tr: Other young ladies I knew before had done such foolish things, and then they regretted it in misery and poverty.
es: There are many young ladies who have committed similar follies, which they have come to regret when it was already too late, when they found themselves plunged into ruin and misery... Poor things!... I do not blame them! Indeed, they are worthy of compassion! Youth is so thoughtless!...

en: In an unselfish aspect, I am sorry that the thing is dropped, because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view; in a selfish aspect, I am glad that the thing has dropped, because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view—it is hardly necessary to say I could have gained nothing by it.
vi: For the person in question, I regret that this did not come to pass, because if it had, it would have been a misfortune for me, from a material gain perspective; but for myself, I am glad it did not come to pass, because if it had, it would also have been a misfortune for me, from a material gain perspective... needless to say, I would have gained nothing.
tr: If I think without being selfish, I am saddened that it didn't happen, because it would have been bad for me financially; if I look at it selfishly, again it would have been bad for me financially – I would have gained nothing from this.
es: Seeing what happened from a point of view free of all selfishness, I regret it, because it would have been a good deal for her, and if I look at it through the prism of my selfishness, I cannot help but celebrate a failure that saves me from making a disastrous deal. You will understand, without me having to say it, that I, far from gaining, was losing, and not a little.

en: There is no harm at all done.
vi: No harm has occurred.
tr: So, I have no loss.
es: Of course, so far it has done me no harm.

en: I have not proposed to the young lady, and, between ourselves, I am by no means certain, on reflection, that I ever should have committed myself to that extent.
vi: I have not proposed to that young lady, and just between you and me, looking back, I am not even sure if I need to get married that much.
tr: I made no offer to the young lady, and between us, thinking about it, I'm not even sure it was a good decision to bring it to that point.
es: I have not offered my hand to that young lady, and here between us, speaking frankly, I never thought of making such an offer.

en: mr Lorry, you cannot control the mincing vanities and giddinesses of empty-headed girls; you must not expect to do it, or you will always be disappointed.
vi: Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the whimsical and capricious nature of empty-headed girls; do not dream of it if you do not want to be disappointed.
tr: Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the delicate pride and frivolity of empty-headed girls; one should not have such an expectation, otherwise, you will always be disappointed.
es: Follow my advice, Mr. Lorry: never try to fight against the frivolities and follies of those flighty little heads if you don't want to reap disappointments in abundance... No... do me the favor!

en: Now, pray say no more about it.
vi: Now please don't say anything about that anymore.
tr: Now please, let's not talk about this any further.
es: Let's leave this conversation.

en: I tell you, I regret it on account of others, but I am satisfied on my own account.
vi: I've already said it, I feel sorry for them but happy for myself.
tr: As I said, I felt sorry for them but I am pleased for myself.
es: I repeat that I regret what happened for others but I am glad for what concerns me.

en: And I am really very much obliged to you for allowing me to sound you, and for giving me your advice; you know the young lady better than I do; you were right, it never would have done.”
vi: And I am very grateful to you for allowing me to ask for advice and for advising me; you understand that lady better than I do; you were right, this marriage will never happen.
tr: I am grateful to you for listening to me and advising me; after all, you know the young lady better than I do; you were right, this wouldn't have worked."
es: I will never thank you enough for the advice you gave me. You know that young lady much better than I do... You were right... I was about to make a blunder although I surely would not have gone through with it.

en: mr Lorry was so taken aback, that he looked quite stupidly at mr Stryver shouldering him towards the door, with an appearance of showering generosity, forbearance, and goodwill, on his erring head.
vi: Mr. Lorry was so astonished that he stood gaping at Stryver, who was aggressively pushing him towards the door, the barrister's face appearing to bestow upon the misguided man all his goodwill, patience, and tolerance.
tr: Mr. Lorry was so surprised that he stared blankly at Mr. Stryver, who had escorted him to the door with a shower of insincere thoughts disguised as great generosity, tolerance, and goodwill.
es: Such was Lorry's bewilderment and astonishment that he could think of nothing else but to stare stupidly at his interlocutor, whose face reflected generosity, nobility, and good intentions.

en: “Make the best of it, my dear sir,” said Stryver; “say no more about it; thank you again for allowing me to sound you; good night!”
vi: − Handle it yourself, dear sir, - Stryver said. - Don't mention this again; thank you once more for letting me ask your opinion; goodbye!
tr: "Let it be for the best for us, sir," said Stryver; "let's not talk about this anymore; thank you again for listening to me; good night!"
es: —Believe me, my dear friend! —repeated Stryver as he accompanied Lorry to the door,—follow my advice. Thank you very much...

en: mr Lorry was out in the night, before he knew where he was.
vi: Before he could understand anything, Mr. Lorry was thrown out into the night.
tr: Mr. Lorry found himself in the darkness of the night before he could understand what was happening.
es: Good night! Lorry found himself in the street before he realized what was happening to him.

en: mr Stryver was lying back on his sofa, winking at his ceiling.
vi: Stryver lay down on the sofa, winking at the ceiling.
tr: Mr. Stryver, on the other hand, was lying on his couch, winking at the ceiling.
es: Stryver lay on his back on the sofa, staring at the ceiling.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Stryver lay down on the sofa, winking at the ceiling.
tr: Thirteen
es: Chapter XIII.

en: The Fellow of No Delicacy
vi: 13. The Rude Guy
tr: Rude Man
es: THE INDELICATE SUBJECT

en: If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly never shone in the house of Doctor Manette.
vi: If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly never shone at Dr. Manette's house.
tr: Although Sydney Carton shone in other environments, he definitely did not shine in Doctor Manette's house.
es: If ever, or anywhere, Sydney Carton shone, it certainly was not in the abode of Mr. Manette.

en: He had been there often, during a whole year, and had always been the same moody and morose lounger there.
vi: He had been visiting for a whole year, always bringing a gloomy, dejected, and disheartened face there.
tr: For a year, he had frequently visited their home but always sat idly by with his grumpy demeanor and sullen face.
es: He visited it quite frequently for an entire year, and he was always sad, taciturn, pensive.

en: When he cared to talk, he talked well; but, the cloud of caring for nothing, which overshadowed him with such a fatal darkness, was very rarely pierced by the light within him.
vi: Whenever he wanted to talk, he spoke very well; but the indifferent look, like a cloud enveloping him in sorrowful darkness, was rarely pierced by the light in his heart.
tr: When he deigned to speak, he spoke well, but the light within him could rarely pierce through the deadly darkness of his indifferent attitude.
es: And it was not that he lacked oratory skills, no; he knew how to speak perfectly well when he set his mind to it; but the cloud that enveloped him was so dense that the luminous flashes of his intelligence very rarely managed to pierce through it.

en: And yet he did care something for the streets that environed that house, and for the senseless stones that made their pavements.
vi: However, he needed something from the neighborhood surrounding that house, the lifeless paving stones on the sidewalk there.
tr: He even loved the meaningless stones that formed the streets and sidewalks surrounding his house.
es: That the streets near the mentioned house, and even the insensible stones of the sidewalks, exerted a mysterious attraction on him, could not be questioned.

en: Many a night he vaguely and unhappily wandered there, when wine had brought no transitory gladness to him; many a dreary daybreak revealed his solitary figure lingering there, and still lingering there when the first beams of the sun brought into strong relief, removed beauties of architecture in spires of churches and lofty buildings, as perhaps the quiet time brought some sense of better things, else forgotten and unattainable, into his mind.
vi: Many nights he wandered around there, suffering and aimless, when the alcohol brought him no fleeting joy; many gloomy dawns also saw his lonely figure lingering there, still hesitating to leave as the first rays of sunlight highlighted the architectural beauty of the church spires and high-rise buildings, just as this quiet moment made his mind perceive better things that had been forgotten or were out of reach.
tr: On most nights when the wine couldn't give him temporary happiness, he would wander those streets, head clouded, miserably; as dawn broke with all its gloom, his lonely silhouette would appear, and when the first rays of the sun illuminated the beauties of the distant church towers and majestic buildings, he would still be wandering there, as if these silent hours evoked in his mind the feeling that good things, otherwise unthought of and unattainable, would happen.
es: More than one night he could have been found wandering like a lost soul in those places, especially when the wine failed to infiltrate his chest with a fictitious and transitory joy. More than one early morning, the pale glows of the dawning aurora revealed, not far from the doctor's house, the contours of a figure, which if it was not Sydney Carton himself, bore a notable resemblance to him. More than one morning, the first rays of the sun, while highlighting the architectural beauties of the church bell towers and the most notable buildings, brought discouragement to the chest of the solitary night wanderer, making him see that there are things that man, with all his good will, cannot achieve.

en: Of late, the neglected bed in the Temple Court had known him more scantily than ever; and often when he had thrown himself upon it no longer than a few minutes, he had got up again, and haunted that neighbourhood.
vi: Recently, the rumpled bed in Temple Court rarely lulled him to sleep; often he would throw himself onto the bed only to get up a few minutes later and wander to that neighborhood.
tr: Recently, he had been visiting his bed in Temple less frequently; most of the time when he did throw himself into bed, it didn't last long, and he would get up and go back to that neighborhood.
es: For some time before, the disordered bed that Carton had in the Temple Court rarely deserved the honor of being used by its owner, and it is noteworthy that, even when this happened by exception, Carton would get up after a few minutes to continue his wanderings.

en: On a day in August, when mr Stryver (after notifying to his jackal that “he had thought better of that marrying matter”) had carried his delicacy into Devonshire, and when the sight and scent of flowers in the City streets had some waifs of goodness in them for the worst, of health for the sickliest, and of youth for the oldest, Sydney’s feet still trod those stones.
vi: One August day, when Stryver was graciously allowed to go on vacation in Devonshire (after informing his friend the Jackal that he had "reconsidered and decided not to pursue marriage"), when the scenery and the fragrance of flowers on the streets bestowed a bit of goodness on the most unfortunate, a bit of health on the most ailing, and a bit of youth on the oldest, Sydney's steps once again wandered on the sidewalk.
tr: On a day in August, when Mr. Stryver (after informing his jackal that he now thought differently about marriage) carried his gentle presence to Devonshire, and the appearance and scent of the flowers in the city's streets began to bring goodness to the wicked, healing to the sick, and youth to the old, Sydney was still busy pacing the roads.
es: One day in the month of August, when Mr. Stryver, after informing his friend that "more careful reflections had led him to abandon his matrimonial plans," had transferred to Devonshire the treasures of finesse and delicacy inherent to his person, one of those August days when the wicked find in the chalice of flowers rich springs of goodness, the sick find health, and the old and worn-out find youth, Carton, a slave to his habit, wandered like a lost soul through the streets.

en: From being irresolute and purposeless, his feet became animated by an intention, and, in the working out of that intention, they took him to the Doctor’s door.
vi: From hesitance and aimlessness, his steps gradually quickened with a newly formed intention, and to carry it out, his steps led him to the doctor's house.
tr: His indecision and clueless state had ended, and with the purposes that gave him vitality and the thought of implementing them, he found himself at the Doctor's door.
es: He walked irresolutely and aimlessly; but suddenly his eyes lit up; his feet were animated by the breath of the intention that sprang in his mind, and those feet, faithful and submissive slaves to the latter, carried him straight to the door of Dr. Manette.

en: He was shown up-stairs, and found Lucie at her work, alone.
vi: He was invited upstairs and saw Lucie alone with her needlework.
tr: When they sent him upstairs, he found Lucie working alone.
es: Lucía, whom he found alone and absorbed in her tasks, received him with some unease, and it is even more than likely that if she could have had her way, she would have refused to receive him, for Carton's manner always inspired a certain feeling of mistrust in her.

en: She had never been quite at her ease with him, and received him with some little embarrassment as he seated himself near her table.
vi: She had never felt comfortable interacting with Sydney, greeting him with a bit of awkwardness as he sat down near the sewing table.
tr: The young girl had never been very comfortable around him, so when Sydney sat down next to the table, she greeted him a bit shyly.
es: Lucía, whom he found alone and absorbed in her tasks, received him with some unease, and it is even more than likely that if she could have had her way, she would have refused to receive him, for Carton's manner always inspired a certain feeling of mistrust in her.

en: But, looking up at his face in the interchange of the first few common-places, she observed a change in it.
vi: But just after looking up and saying a few initial pleasantries, she immediately noticed his expression change.
tr: However, after the usual pleasantries, the young girl noticed some changes in him.
es: However, as the first phrases were exchanged between them, she noticed something in the expression on her visitor's face that first reassured her, and then stirred compassion in her heart.

en: “I fear you are not well, mr Carton!”
vi: − You don't seem well, Mr. Carton! −
tr: "I didn't see you very well, Mr. Carton!"
es: "Do you feel unwell, Mr. Carton?" she asked.

en: “No.
vi: That's right.
tr: "I am not well.
es: "Do you feel unwell, Mr. Carton?" she asked.

en: But the life I lead, Miss Manette, is not conducive to health.
vi: But Miss Manette, living like I do, how could I be well?
tr: For the life I lead does not suit my health, Miss Manette.
es: —I am not well, it is true: but the life I lead, Miss Manette, is not the best way to enjoy good health.

en: What is to be expected of, or by, such profligates?”
vi: What is there to hope for in this wasted life?
tr: What can be expected from a libertine like me?"
es: What can we libertines expect!

en: “Is it not—forgive me; I have begun the question on my lips—a pity to live no better life?”
vi: Isn't it... forgive me for saying this,... isn't it a pity to live like that? −
tr: "I'm sorry, but –I can't help but ask– isn't it a sad situation that you can't live a better life?"
es: —And isn't it a pity?... I beg you to forgive me; but since, without realizing it, the beginning of the question slipped from my lips, I will finish it, although making it clear that nothing could be further from my mind than the intention to offend you. Isn't it a pity that you don't try to live a more orderly life?

en: “God knows it is a shame!”
vi: By God, life is truly miserable! −
tr: "Truly a painful situation.""
es: —It's something more than pity! God knows very well that it's a shame!

en: “Then why not change it?”
vi: Then why not change it?
tr: "Then why don't you change this?"
es: —So, why doesn't he correct himself?

en: Looking gently at him again, she was surprised and saddened to see that there were tears in his eyes.
vi: She looked at him gently, both surprised and saddened to see the tears in his eyes.
tr: The young girl looked meekly at Sydney and was surprised and saddened when she saw the tears streaming from her eyes.
es: Lucía, who looked directly at her interlocutor when she asked the question, saw, with a mix of surprise and sorrow, that Carton's eyes were filled with tears.

en: There were tears in his voice too, as he answered:
vi: His voice was choked as he replied: −
tr: As she replied, Sydney's voice was also filled with tears:
es: Tears also flowed in his voice when he replied:

en: “It is too late for that.
vi: It's too late.
tr: "It's too late now.
es: Tears also flowed in his voice when he replied:

en: I shall never be better than I am.
vi: I'll never get any better.
tr: I can never have a better life.
es: —It's no longer time... I will never be better than I am today... on the contrary... I will get worse... I will descend more and more...

en: I shall sink lower, and be worse.”
vi: I'll only become more and more degraded, worse and worse.
tr: I will only sink lower and get worse."
es: —It's no longer time... I will never be better than I am today... on the contrary... I will get worse... I will descend more and more...

en: He leaned an elbow on her table, and covered his eyes with his hand.
vi: He propped one elbow on the table, raising his hand to cover his eyes.
tr: He had his elbows resting on the girl's table, covering his eyes with his hand.
es: Resting his elbows on the table, he covered his eyes with his hands.

en: The table trembled in the silence that followed.
vi: The tabletop trembled in the ensuing silence.
tr: In the ensuing silence, the table was trembling.
es: The table trembled during the painful silence that followed.

en: She had never seen him softened, and was much distressed.
vi: She had never seen him so weak and miserable.
tr: The young girl had never seen him so weak and sorrowful before.
es: The table trembled during the painful silence that followed.

en: He knew her to be so, without looking at her, and said:
vi: Without even looking, she knew that she felt sorry for him.
tr: Without looking at the girl, Sydney knew how she might be feeling and said:
es: —Forgive me, Miss Manette—replied Carton.

en: “Pray forgive me, Miss Manette.
vi: Sydney said: − Excuse me, Miss Manette.
tr: "Please forgive me, Miss Manette.
es: —Forgive me, Miss Manette—replied Carton.

en: I break down before the knowledge of what I want to say to you.
vi: I am distressed because of what I want to confess to you.
tr: I broke down before I could say more to you.
es: —I carry a secret that weighs heavily on me and that I wish to reveal to you: would you be so kind as to deign to listen to me?

en: Will you hear me?”
vi: Would you be willing to listen to me? −
tr: Do you want to listen to me?"
es: —I carry a secret that weighs heavily on me and that I wish to reveal to you: would you be so kind as to deign to listen to me?

en: “If it will do you any good, mr Carton, if it would make you happier, it would make me very glad!”
vi: If it would make you feel better, Mr. Carton, if it would make you happier, I would very much like to hear it! −
tr: "If it will be of any benefit to you, Mr. Carton, if it will make you happy, then I will be pleased as well.""
es: "If listening to you will be beneficial for you, Mr. Carton, if it will provide you with a contentment that you apparently do not have now, speak, for in listening to you I will have special pleasure."

en: “God bless you for your sweet compassion!”
vi: You are so kind, may God bless you!
tr: "How compassionate you are. May God protect you!"
es: —God will undoubtedly reward you for the compassion with which you treat me.

en: He unshaded his face after a little while, and spoke steadily.
vi: After a moment, he removed his hand from his face and said, his voice calmer: −
tr: He calmly started to speak after removing his hand from his face.
es: Carton calmed down somewhat, removed his hands from his eyes, and replied with a firm tone:

en: “Don’t be afraid to hear me.
vi: Do not be afraid of what I am about to say.
tr: "What I have to say should not worry you.
es: —Do not be alarmed by my words nor be frightened if I tell you that I have already lived what I was meant to live, that I am like someone who has died very young.

en: Don’t shrink from anything I say.
vi: Please do not be apprehensive about what I say.
tr: Do not be afraid.
es: —Do not be alarmed by my words nor be frightened if I tell you that I have already lived what I was meant to live, that I am like someone who has died very young.

en: I am like one who died young.
vi: I am like someone who has died prematurely.
tr: I am like someone who died young.
es: —Do not be alarmed by my words nor be frightened if I tell you that I have already lived what I was meant to live, that I am like someone who has died very young.

en: All my life might have been.”
vi: My whole life may have been wasted.
tr: It has been this way all my life."
es: Nothing remains in me capable of bearing fruit... I am barren for good.

en: “No, mr Carton.
vi: − No, Mr. Carton.
tr: "No, Mr. Carton.
es: —No, Mr. Carton, no!

en: I am sure that the best part of it might still be; I am sure that you might be much, much worthier of yourself.”
vi: I am certain that the best things will come; I am certain that you will be prouder, more confident in yourself.
tr: I am sure there are much better days ahead for you; I am sure you will reach much better places."
es: You are young, there are still sediments of goodness in your soul. I am sure that, with a little bit of goodwill, you can become very worthy of yourself...

en: “Say of you, Miss Manette, and although I know better—although in the mystery of my own wretched heart I know better—I shall never forget it!”
vi: − You are very kind, Miss Manette, but I understand myself better; although from the depths of this sorrow I know that it is not true; but I will never forget your kind words!
tr: "Thank you Miss Manette, even though I know that what I said is true –even though my poor heart is a mystery, I know this– I will never forget what you said!"
es: —Tell me how I can make myself worthy of your pity, at least, miss, and although I know you are mistaken, although I read in the depths of my shipwrecked heart the deception in which you find yourself, I will never forget it.

en: She was pale and trembling.
vi: Lucie turned pale and trembled.
tr: The young girl's color had faded, and she was trembling.
es: A dense paleness covered the girl's cheeks: her hands trembled.

en: He came to her relief with a fixed despair of himself which made the interview unlike any other that could have been holden.
vi: Sydney tried to reassure her, but his attitude of desperate self-deprecation only made the conversation more peculiar.
tr: The man was so helpless that he didn't know what to say in front of her.
es: —If a miracle of God, assuming that divine omnipotence could reach so far, had made it possible for you, Miss Lucía, to reciprocate the love of the man who at this moment stands before your eyes, the love of this degraded, lost, libertine, drunken being, this repugnant remnant of humanity... which is nothing else but what I am... you know it very well, the happiness that would flood my soul, as great as it would be, would not prevent me from seeing that the union of our destinies would drag you down to the depths of my miseries, would plunge you into the abysses of pain and late repentance, would envelop you in waves of dishonor.

en: “If it had been possible, Miss Manette, that you could have returned the love of the man you see before yourself—flung away, wasted, drunken, poor creature of misuse as you know him to be—he would have been conscious this day and hour, in spite of his happiness, that he would bring you to misery, bring you to sorrow and repentance, blight you, disgrace you, pull you down with him.
vi: − Miss Manette, suppose you were to reciprocate the love of the man standing before you; a worthless, drunken, poor, misguided man whom you have known; then today, at this very moment, he knows well that instead of bringing you happiness, he would bring you hardship and poverty, bring you sorrow and regret, he would ruin you, disgrace you, and drag you down to the depths with him.
tr: "Miss Manette, even if it were possible for you to reciprocate the love of this man before you – the self-ruined, wasted, drunken, and worthless wretch – despite all your happiness, you would be aware every moment, every minute, that he brings you suffering, pain, and regret, that he disappoints you, ruins your life, and drags you down with him.
es: —If a miracle of God, assuming that divine omnipotence could reach so far, had made it possible for you, Miss Lucía, to reciprocate the love of the man who at this moment stands before your eyes, the love of this degraded, lost, libertine, drunken being, this repugnant remnant of humanity... which is nothing else but what I am... you know it very well, the happiness that would flood my soul, as great as it would be, would not prevent me from seeing that the union of our destinies would drag you down to the depths of my miseries, would plunge you into the abysses of pain and late repentance, would envelop you in waves of dishonor.

en: I know very well that you can have no tenderness for me; I ask for none; I am even thankful that it cannot be.”
vi: I know well that you have no feelings for me and I do not ask for that; in fact, I am even more grateful that it cannot happen.
tr: I know very well that you cannot harbor any love for me in your heart; I do not ask for such a thing; in fact, I am grateful that such a thing cannot be."
es: I am firmly convinced of this; as convinced as I am that your heart cannot hold any tenderness for me. I do not expect it, I do not ask for it! Moreover: I thank Heaven that has made it impossible!

en: “Without it, can I not save you, mr Carton?
vi: − But without that, can't I help you, Mr. Carton?
tr: After hesitating for a moment, Miss Manette said, "Even if there isn't such a thing, can't I help you, Mr. Carton?
es: —Couldn't I save you, Mr. Carton, without those affections you refer to? Couldn't I?...

en: Can I not recall you—forgive me again!—to a better course?
vi: Can't I help you return... forgive me for saying this again!... return to a better path?
tr: Can't I –forgive me but– lead you to a better life?
es: Forgive me again! Couldn't I show you a better path, guide you on straighter paths?

en: Can I in no way repay your confidence?
vi: Is there no way I can repay your trust?
tr: Isn't there a way to restore your confidence in yourself?
es: Must it be impossible for me to repay in some way the trust you place in me?

en: I know this is a confidence,” she modestly said, after a little hesitation, and in earnest tears, “I know you would say this to no one else.
vi: I know you trust me, - she said humbly after a moment of hesitation, with sincere tears in her eyes. - I know you wouldn't say this to anyone else.
tr: I know this is all about believing," she added humbly and with sincere tears, "I know you won't tell anyone about this.
es: Because I know it is a trust—added Lucie modestly, though with some hesitation—a trust that you would not place in anyone else, and that you place in me.

en: Can I turn it to no good account for yourself, mr Carton?”
vi: Can't you turn that trust into something good for me, Carton?
tr: Can't I turn this situation to your advantage, Mr. Carton?"
es: Couldn't we turn that trust to your benefit, Mr. Carton?

en: He shook his head.
vi: He shook his head.
tr: Sydney shook her head from side to side.
es: —No, Miss Lucía—replied Carton, shaking his head with an expression of bitter sadness.

en: “To none.
vi: − No way, Miss Manette, no way.
tr: "No, Miss Manette.
es: —Impossible.

en: No, Miss Manette, to none.
vi: − No way, Miss Manette, no way.
tr: There is no way.
es: —Impossible.

en: If you will hear me through a very little more, all you can ever do for me is done.
vi: If you are willing to listen to me a little more, you have already helped me immensely.
tr: If you listen to me a little more, you will have done the best you can.
es: If you would be so kind as to listen to me for a few more moments, you will have done for me all that you can do.

en: I wish you to know that you have been the last dream of my soul.
vi: I want you to understand that you have been the last hope of my life.
tr: I want you to know that you were the last dream I saw.
es: I want you to know that it has been the last dream of my soul: I want you to know that your image and that of your father, the sight of this home, which is such thanks to you, have reached the deep abyss of my degradation and stirred there shadows that I believed dead forever: I want you to know that, since I have known you, I feel the sting of remorse that I thought lifeless and ineffective, and whispers of ancient voices that I believed forever silenced sound in my ears.

en: In my degradation I have not been so degraded but that the sight of you with your father, and of this home made such a home by you, has stirred old shadows that I thought had died out of me.
vi: No matter how lowly I am, I am not so blind as to not see the scene of you and your father together, to see this house become a home thanks to your hands, which has rekindled in me so many things I thought I had forgotten forever.
tr: Seeing your father and this home with you in it, revives the dreams I thought were dead and pulls me further down.
es: I want you to know that it has been the last dream of my soul: I want you to know that your image and that of your father, the sight of this home, which is such thanks to you, have reached the deep abyss of my degradation and stirred there shadows that I believed dead forever: I want you to know that, since I have known you, I feel the sting of remorse that I thought lifeless and ineffective, and whispers of ancient voices that I believed forever silenced sound in my ears.

en: Since I knew you, I have been troubled by a remorse that I thought would never reproach me again, and have heard whispers from old voices impelling me upward, that I thought were silent for ever.
vi: Since I met you, I have been tormented by a regret that I thought had long been exhausted, I have heard whispers that I thought had forever fallen silent, reminding me to turn back from my wayward path.
tr: Since I met you, I have been feeling a guilt I thought had left me, and I hear those old whispers that I thought had silenced forever, trying to pull me up.
es: I want you to know that it has been the last dream of my soul: I want you to know that your image and that of your father, the sight of this home, which is such thanks to you, have reached the deep abyss of my degradation and stirred there shadows that I believed dead forever: I want you to know that, since I have known you, I feel the sting of remorse that I thought lifeless and ineffective, and whispers of ancient voices that I believed forever silenced sound in my ears.

en: I have had unformed ideas of striving afresh, beginning anew, shaking off sloth and sensuality, and fighting out the abandoned fight.
vi: I have vaguely thought about trying to change, to start my life anew, to cast off my debauched and stagnant life, and to continue the struggle for existence.
tr: There are vague thoughts in my mind calling me to start everything anew, to turn over a new leaf, to shake off the laziness and sensitivity, and to return to the struggle I had abandoned.
es: I have even come to seriously think about starting, about engaging in new struggles, about inaugurating a new life, about running with new courage to the arena so long abandoned!... Chimeras... illusions, dreams that can lead to nothing practical!

en: A dream, all a dream, that ends in nothing, and leaves the sleeper where he lay down, but I wish you to know that you inspired it.”
vi: A dream, just a dream, leads nowhere, and it leaves the dreamer lying there, but I want you to understand that it was you who sparked those thoughts in me.
tr: This is a dream with no end, leaving the dreamer where they lie, all of these are dreams, but I want you to know that you are the one who inspires these dreams."
es: But chimeras, dreams, and illusions evoked by you, inspired by you!

en: “Will nothing of it remain?
vi: − Are those things over now?
tr: "Does it really lead nowhere?
es: —But those illusions, those dreams, they must have left something in your soul...

en: O mr Carton, think again!
vi: Oh Mr. Carton, please reconsider!
tr: Oh Mr. Carton, please think a little more!
es: Oh Mr. Carton!

en: Try again!”
vi: Try harder! −
tr: Give it a try!"
es: Seek... ponder... try!

en: “No, Miss Manette; all through it, I have known myself to be quite undeserving.
vi: No, Miss Manette, I have long known that I am completely unworthy.
tr: "No, Miss Manette; I know that I am a man who deserves nothing.
es: —It's useless: I would be wasting my time, and besides, I don't deserve to live.

en: And yet I have had the weakness, and have still the weakness, to wish you to know with what a sudden mastery you kindled me, heap of ashes that I am, into fire—a fire, however, inseparable in its nature from myself, quickening nothing, lighting nothing, doing no service, idly burning away.”
vi: I know I am weak and cannot improve, but I want you to know that you suddenly have the power to ignite the ashes that I am into a flame... but that flame cannot escape my nature, it cannot drive anything, it cannot illuminate anything, it cannot help anything, and it will gradually die out.
tr: Perhaps it was a weakness to tell you how you brought me back to life, how you suddenly turned me, who was no different from a heap of ashes, into a burning fire, truly a weakness, but such a fire that, although it has penetrated me, it moves nothing, illuminates nothing, serves no purpose, it just burns inwardly."
es: And yet, to give you an idea of the inconceivable extremes to which human aberrations can go, I will confess that I have had the weakness, and still have the frankness, to wish that you know the prodigious speed with which I have been transformed, from a heap of extinguished and frozen ashes, into a living fire... although a fire entirely similar to my corrupted nature, a fire that animates nothing, that illuminates nothing, that serves no purpose, a fire that is lost.

en: “Since it is my misfortune, mr Carton, to have made you more unhappy than you were before you knew me—”
vi: − Carton, unfortunately, I have made you feel more unhappy than before you met me...
tr: "Mr. Carton, it is such a misfortune for me that you have become even more unhappy after getting to know me...""
es: —Since I have had the misfortune of making you more unfortunate than you were before you met me...

en: “Don’t say that, Miss Manette, for you would have reclaimed me, if anything could.
vi: − Don't say that, Miss Manette, if I can still be saved, only you can do it.
tr: "Don't say that, Miss Manette, if there is anything in this world that can do me good, it is you.
es: —Don't say that, Miss Lucía; if I were capable of redemption, you would have redeemed me; if my misfortunes could have an end, you would have put an end to them.

en: You will not be the cause of my becoming worse.”
vi: You are not the reason I have become worse.
tr: You cannot be the cause of my worsening."
es: It is not you, it could not have been you who caused my misfortune to be greater.

en: “Since the state of your mind that you describe, is, at all events, attributable to some influence of mine—this is what I mean, if I can make it plain—can I use no influence to serve you?
vi: − Because my mood, as I mentioned, is partly influenced by you... I don't know if you understand what I mean... is there really nothing you can do to help me?
tr: "If I had such an influence on the state of mind you described – I mean, what I want to say is – can't I use this influence for your benefit?
es: —I meant to say that, if the current state of his soul is due to my influences, wouldn't there be a way to channel those influences in a way that would be beneficial to him?

en: Have I no power for good, with you, at all?”
vi: Is there really nothing you can do to bring something good to me?
tr: Do I have no power at all to positively affect your life?"
es: Can't I do any good for him?

en: “The utmost good that I am capable of now, Miss Manette, I have come here to realise.
vi: − Miss Manette, the best thing I can do now is what I have done right here.
tr: "The best thing that could happen to me, Miss Manette, is to be here right now.
es: —The greatest, the only one I could desire, has already been provided to me.

en: Let me carry through the rest of my misdirected life, the remembrance that I opened my heart to you, last of all the world; and that there was something left in me at this time which you could deplore and pity.”
vi: Just let me live out this misguided life while always remembering today, the day I opened my heart to you, the only person in the world, and the day I realized I still have something worthy of your compassion.
tr: Let me live with the memory of the day I opened my heart to you for the rest of my misguided life, and let the thing you pity and grieve over now live with me forever."
es: Will you allow me to keep the memory that you were the last person to whom I opened my heart during the rest of my disordered life, and the belief that there is something in it that has deserved your compassionate pity, and with that, you do me the greatest good I could dream of.

en: “Which I entreated you to believe, again and again, most fervently, with all my heart, was capable of better things, mr Carton!”
vi: − I earnestly and wholeheartedly ask you to believe, and always believe, that you can make your life better, Mr. Carton! −
tr: "The thing I have pleaded for with all my heart and soul, Mr. Carton, could have led to very beautiful things in your life!"
es: —With all my soul, I would like to convince you, Mr. Carton, that with a little bit of effort and another bit of goodwill, you would achieve better things.

en: “Entreat me to believe it no more, Miss Manette.
vi: Please do not expect me to believe that, Miss Manette.
tr: "Please tell me to stop believing in this, Miss Manette!
es: —Her excellent heart deceives her, Miss Lucía.

en: I have proved myself, and I know better.
vi: I know myself better than anyone else.
tr: It's clear what I am, I know myself well.
es: Believe me: I have put myself to the test, and the result has been deplorable: I am incapable of redemption.

en: I distress you; I draw fast to an end.
vi: I have caused you concern, so I will end this conversation quickly.
tr: I will upset you; I am rapidly progressing down a bad path.
es: I know that I am causing you sorrow, and I will finish.

en: Will you let me believe, when I recall this day, that the last confidence of my life was reposed in your pure and innocent breast, and that it lies there alone, and will be shared by no one?”
vi: I only hope you will allow me to believe that later, when you remember today, the final confidences I have entrusted to your innocent and pure soul will remain secret, known to no one else, will you? −
tr: If we return to what I was saying, could I ask you to keep this last secret of my life hidden in your pure and innocent heart and not to reveal it to anyone?"
es: I have entrusted the sweetest secret of my life to a pure and innocent heart. When the memory of this day arises in my mind, will I be allowed to harbor the comforting belief that this heart has received it and keeps it, resolved not to confide it to anyone else?

en: “If that will be a consolation to you, yes.”
vi: Yes, if that helps put your mind at ease.
tr: "If this will be a consolation for you, yes."
es: —If that belief is a comfort to you, hold on to it.

en: “Not even by the dearest one ever to be known to you?”
vi: − Even your dearest loved ones should not know?
tr: "Even to the person who is most valuable to you, right?"
es: —Do you promise not to reveal it to anyone, not even to the person dearest to you today or who may be in the future?

en: “mr Carton,” she answered, after an agitated pause, “the secret is yours, not mine; and I promise to respect it.”
vi: − Mr. Carton, - the girl replied after a moment of confused silence, - the secret is yours, not mine, and I promise to keep it.
tr: After an uneasy silence, the young girl replied, "Mr. Carton, this secret is yours, not mine; I promise to keep it.""
es: —Mr. Carton—replied Lucie with agitation,—the secret is not mine, but yours: rest assured that I will know how to respect it.

en: “Thank you.
vi: − Thank you, miss.
tr: "Thank you.
es: —Thank you very much... and God bless you!

en: And again, God bless you.”
vi: Once again, may God bless you.
tr: God bless you."
es: —Thank you very much... and God bless you!

en: He put her hand to his lips, and moved towards the door.
vi: He kissed her hand goodbye, then walked to the door.
tr: Carton brought the young girl's hand to his lips and walked towards the door.
es: Carton took the hand that Lucía extended to him, brought it to his lips, and began to walk towards the door.

en: “Be under no apprehension, Miss Manette, of my ever resuming this conversation by so much as a passing word.
vi: − Please don't worry, Miss Manette, I will never speak of this matter again, not even a single word.
tr: "Do not worry Miss Manette, I will not bring up this matter again.
es: —Count on it, Miss Lucía, that I will never refer to the conversation we just had.

en: I will never refer to it again.
vi: I will not mention it again, from now on.
tr: This issue is closed here.
es: —Count on it, Miss Lucía, that I will never refer to the conversation we just had.

en: If I were dead, that could not be surer than it is henceforth.
vi: This promise is more certain than my own death.
tr: Consider me dead.
es: If I were to drop dead this instant, the secret would not be better kept, as far as I am concerned.

en: In the hour of my death, I shall hold sacred the one good remembrance—and shall thank and bless you for it—that my last avowal of myself was made to you, and that my name, and faults, and miseries were gently carried in your heart.
vi: I will carry this sacred memory with me to my grave... and I will be grateful to you, I will bless you... the one with the gentle heart who accepted my final confession, who accepted my honor, my faults, and my sorrows.
tr: Know that, on my deathbed, I will remember this sacred moment –and I will always be grateful to you for it– for I will have made my final confession to you and you will carry my name, my mistakes, and my pains in your heart.
es: A pure heart, an innocent heart is the holy ark where from today my name, my mistakes, my miseries, my final confession are kept...

en: May it otherwise be light and happy!”
vi: Wishing you always happiness and peace!
tr: Aside from this, I hope your heart will always be at ease and happy!"
es: Ah!

en: He was so unlike what he had ever shown himself to be, and it was so sad to think how much he had thrown away, and how much he every day kept down and perverted, that Lucie Manette wept mournfully for him as he stood looking back at her.
vi: Sydney Carton behaved nothing like he used to before, how sad it is to think about the life he squandered, the many days wasted in debauchery. Lucie Manette couldn't hold back a sorrowful cry as he looked back.
tr: Carton was so different from the way he had been before, and it was so painful to see how much he had consumed his life, despised himself, and hindered himself, that as he stood speaking with his back turned, Lucie Manette began to cry sorrowfully.
es: At the hour of my death, it will be an ineffable comfort for me to embrace this thought, which will be my sacred companion for the rest of my life!

en: “Be comforted!” he said, “I am not worth such feeling, Miss Manette.
vi: − Please stay calm! - He said. - I am not worthy of your tears, Miss Manette.
tr: "Calm down!" said Carton, "your tears are not worth it, Miss Manette.
es: Abundant tears ran down the cheeks of Lucía Manette.

en: An hour or two hence, and the low companions and low habits that I scorn but yield to, will render me less worth such tears as those, than any wretch who creeps along the streets.
vi: In one or two hours, when my lowly friends and those despicable but irresistible vices welcome me back, I will be even less deserving of these tears, worse than the wretches on the streets.
tr: Even in a couple of hours, no matter how angry I get, because of my wretched friends and habits that I cannot resist, I will become worse than the desperate people wandering these streets, and I will not be worth your tears at all.
es: —Don't cry, Miss Lucía, for I don't deserve anyone, much less an angel like you, to shed tears for me. Within one or two hours, vile friendships and vicious habits, which I despise but to which I succumb, will make me an object less worthy of those tears than the last human wreck dragging its miseries through the streets.

en: Be comforted!
vi: Please stay calm!
tr: Calm down!
es: I want, however, to make it clear that, if outwardly I will continue to be what I have been up to now, for you, my inner self will be what it is now.

en: But, within myself, I shall always be, towards you, what I am now, though outwardly I shall be what you have heretofore seen me.
vi: But in my heart, I will always be the person I am now to you, even though outwardly I will remain the person you have seen all along.
tr: Inside, my feelings towards you will always remain the same, but from the outside, I will appear just as you have always seen me.
es: I want, however, to make it clear that, if outwardly I will continue to be what I have been up to now, for you, my inner self will be what it is now.

en: The last supplication but one I make to you, is, that you will believe this of me.”
vi: The last thing I earnestly ask of you is to believe my words.
tr: My last request from you is to believe me on this matter."
es: My penultimate plea is to ask you to believe me.

en: “I will, mr Carton.”
vi: − I believe, Mr. Carton.
tr: "I believe, Mr. Carton.""
es: —I believe you, Mr. Carton, I believe you.

en: “My last supplication of all, is this; and with it, I will relieve you of a visitor with whom I well know you have nothing in unison, and between whom and you there is an impassable space.
vi: − I only request this one thing, and now I will free you from a guest whom I know is entirely incompatible with you, there is an immense distance between him and you.
tr: "I actually have one last request, and after that, I will rid you of this visitor with whom you have no common ground and between whom there is an insurmountable chasm.
es: —I am going to make my final plea to you, and then I will free you from the presence of a visitor in whose degraded soul your angelic one cannot find a single harmonious chord, and from whom you are separated by a bottomless and boundless abyss.

en: It is useless to say it, I know, but it rises out of my soul.
vi: It is pointless to say, I know, but these words come from the bottom of my heart.
tr: I know it's unnecessary to say this, but I can't help myself.
es: I know that saying it is useless; but it springs from my soul and I cannot keep it silent.

en: For you, and for any dear to you, I would do anything.
vi: I am willing to do everything for you, and for anyone you love.
tr: There is nothing I wouldn't do for you and your loved ones, Miss Manette.
es: For you, and for anyone you care about, I will do everything.

en: If my career were of that better kind that there was any opportunity or capacity of sacrifice in it, I would embrace any sacrifice for you and for those dear to you.
vi: If in the journey of life I still have any chance or ability to sacrifice for you and for your loved ones, I will do so without hesitation.
tr: If I had a better job and consequently an opportunity or situation to make a sacrifice for you or your loved ones, I would do it without hesitation.
es: To sacrifice a lost existence is no merit, I know; but if Providence were to give me the opportunity to sacrifice it, for you and for the people you care about, I would gladly do so.

en: Try to hold me in your mind, at some quiet times, as ardent and sincere in this one thing.
vi: Please remember me, in those moments of peace, and believe these sincere and earnest words.
tr: When you are alone, remember me with this vitality and sincerity.
es: Try to retain in your memory what I am saying.

en: The time will come, the time will not be long in coming, when new ties will be formed about you—ties that will bind you yet more tenderly and strongly to the home you so adorn—the dearest ties that will ever grace and gladden you.
vi: The time will come, not long from now, when the bonds of marriage will connect you with someone... the bond will gently and firmly bind you to the home that you will adorn with beauty... the beloved bond will bring you many blessings and joys.
tr: The day will come, and that day is very near, when you will form new bonds in your life, bonds that will bring you closer to your beloved home more sincerely and strongly, and these pleasant bonds will honor and make you happy forever.
es: The day will come, and it will not be long, when you will form new bonds, new bonds that will tie you very closely to the man who has the fortune to deserve you, the most tender, the sweetest, the most beautiful bonds that can bring joy to human existence.

en: O Miss Manette, when the little picture of a happy father’s face looks up in yours, when you see your own bright beauty springing up anew at your feet, think now and then that there is a man who would give his life, to keep a life you love beside you!”
vi: Oh Miss Manette, when the shadow of happiness of the father is the little boy looking up at you, when your lovely face is mirrored in the little girl growing up beside you, please occasionally remember that there is someone willing to trade his life to protect another life that you love!
tr: Ah Miss Manette, as a happy father looks sweetly at you and the little ones carrying your bright beauty grow at your feet, know both now and then that there is a man ready to give his life to ensure your happiness remains unspoiled!"
es: Oh, Miss Lucia! In the midst of the happiness that awaits you, when the happy face of your father is joined by that of another man who looks into your eyes, remember sometimes that in the world there lives a being ready to give his life at any moment in exchange for preserving the life of the mortal you love! The last favor I ask of you is not to forget my offer... Goodbye... goodbye!...

en: He said, “Farewell!” said a last “God bless you!” and left her.
vi: He says “Goodbye!” and utters for the last time “God bless you!” then leaves.
tr: "Goodbye!" he said finally, "God bless you!" and left the young girl's side.
es: May God bless you!

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: 14. An honest businessman
es: Chapter XIV.

en: The Honest Tradesman
vi: 14. An honest businessman
tr: Honest Tradesman
es: THE HONORABLE MINSTREL

en: To the eyes of mr Jeremiah Cruncher, sitting on his stool in Fleet-street with his grisly urchin beside him, a vast number and variety of objects in movement were every day presented.
vi: Carriages and horses flowed like water, and clothes were packed like sardines, passing daily before the eyes of Jeremiah Cruncher, who was sitting on a stool on the pavement of Fleet Street with a ghastly little brat beside him.
tr: Every day, a variety of people passed in front of Mr. Jeremiah Cruncher, who sat on his stool with his mischievous son on Fleet Street.
es: Many and very varied objects paraded before the eyes of Jeremías Lapa during the hours he spent daily sitting on his rustic bench on Fleet Street, accompanied by his unattractive offspring.

en: Who could sit upon anything in Fleet-street during the busy hours of the day, and not be dazed and deafened by two immense processions, one ever tending westward with the sun, the other ever tending eastward from the sun, both ever tending to the plains beyond the range of red and purple where the sun goes down!
vi: If it weren't for that father and son, who else could sit on Fleet Street during the bustling hours of the day without being dazzled and deafened by the two endless parades, one heading west following the sun, the other fleeing east away from the sun, both endlessly moving towards the distant fields beyond the multicolored twilight!
tr: Who wouldn't be bewildered by the sight of two immense caravans, one heading west with the sun and the other east, towards the plains beyond the reds and purples formed where the sun sets, while sitting on Fleet Street during these busy hours of the day?
es: Anyone who spent the liveliest hours of the day on Fleet Street, sitting on a bench or a chair, on a stone or on the hard ground, would inevitably end the day dazed and deafened, due to the two immense, endless processions that, despite following opposite directions, one from East to West, the other from West to East, inevitably walked towards the same end, towards the world that the red and purple rays of the sun never visit.

en: With his straw in his mouth, mr Cruncher sat watching the two streams, like the heathen rustic who has for several centuries been on duty watching one stream—saving that Jerry had no expectation of their ever running dry.
vi: With a straw in his mouth, Cruncher sat watching the two streams of movement like an ancient ferryman eternally tasked with guarding the river of the underworld - except he never wished for this flow to dry up.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, with a straw in his mouth, was watching these two currents like a boatman observing the flow of the river that has surrounded hell for centuries, but Jerry never believed that these currents would ever dry up.
es: The good Lapa, chewing the obligatory straw, watched the course of the two gigantic streams, similar to that gentle rustic who spent several centuries contemplating the course of a river, with the only difference between the two being that the latter feared the river would dry up, while Jeremiah was certain that the course of those streams would never be interrupted.

en: Nor would it have been an expectation of a hopeful kind, since a small part of his income was derived from the pilotage of timid women (mostly of a full habit and past the middle term of life) from Tellson’s side of the tides to the opposite shore.
vi: If it dried up, what would there be to look forward to, because a small part of his income came from leading timid women (most of whom were encumbered with cumbersome clothing and well past their prime) from the Tellson's side across the traffic to the other side.
tr: He hoped they wouldn't either, as a small portion of his income came from ferrying delicate ladies (mostly well-dressed, middle-aged ones) across to the other side on behalf of Tellson.
es: It is true that this certainty was for Lapa a source of cheerful hopes, since a large part of his income was earned by serving as a guide for women who wished to cross the street.

en: Brief as such companionship was in every separate instance, mr Cruncher never failed to become so interested in the lady as to express a strong desire to have the honour of drinking her very good health.
vi: Each time he escorted them, no matter how brief, Cruncher managed to befriend the ladies to express his desire to have the honor of raising a glass to their health.
tr: In these brief acquaintances, Mr. Cruncher would always show great interest in the ladies and felt a tremendous desire to reach the honor of toasting to their health.
es: Although, as a general rule, the ladies who sought his services were well into the decline of life, and on the other hand, the relationships established during the brief crossing were necessarily short-lived, such an impression did the fiery Jeremiah have of the fair sex that he never rendered such a service without expressing a fervent desire to be granted the honor of drinking to the health of his companion.

en: And it was from the gifts bestowed upon him towards the execution of this benevolent purpose, that he recruited his finances, as just now observed.
vi: And the small sums of money the ladies gave him when he performed this charitable act were an additional source of income, and that was why he sat there observing.
tr: Thus, he earned a part of his income, as he did now, from the money given as a reward for this benevolence.
es: Although, as a general rule, the ladies who sought his services were well into the decline of life, and on the other hand, the relationships established during the brief crossing were necessarily short-lived, such an impression did the fiery Jeremiah have of the fair sex that he never rendered such a service without expressing a fervent desire to be granted the honor of drinking to the health of his companion.

en: Time was, when a poet sat upon a stool in a public place, and mused in the sight of men.
vi: There was a time when poets often sat on benches, dreamily watching people pass by in public places.
tr: In the past, a poet used to sit on a stool in places where there were a lot of people and get lost in thoughts while watching the passersby.
es: There were times when poets would sit on a bench in the most public places to think, and meditate, and reflect in plain view of people.

en: mr Cruncher, sitting on a stool in a public place, but not being a poet, mused as little as possible, and looked about him.
vi: Also sitting on a bench in a public place, but not a poet, Cruncher looked around, trying to be as little dreamy as possible.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, who was sitting on a stool in the crowd, however, was not a poet and wasn't thinking much; he was just looking around.
es: Jeremías Lapa also sat on a bench in a public place; but since he was not a poet, he thought, reflected, and meditated as little as possible, and instead, he looked around a lot.

en: It fell out that he was thus engaged in a season when crowds were few, and belated women few, and when his affairs in general were so unprosperous as to awaken a strong suspicion in his breast that ms Cruncher must have been “flopping” in some pointed manner, when an unusual concourse pouring down Fleet-street westward, attracted his attention.
vi: It turned out that he was encountering a time when the streets were not crowded, devoid of slow ladies, and when business was not thriving, he began to suspect that his wife Cruncher at home must be "sitting down" cursing him; at that moment, he saw an unusual crowd pouring down Fleet Street heading west.
tr: However, it was now a season when the crowd and elderly women were not abundant, and business was generally going so poorly that a strong suspicion arose within Mr. Cruncher that Mrs. Cruncher had sighed, just at that moment an unusual crowd flowing from the west towards Fleet Street caught his attention.
es: He was going through one of those distressing moments when street traffic was sparse, and even sparser were the women who wished to cross it, one of those moments when his business looked so disheartening that our hero began to suspect that his wife might be kneeling and praying in some corner, when his attention was caught by an unusual torrent of people, surging down Fleet Street, following the very course of the sun, that is, towards the West.

en: Looking that way, mr Cruncher made out that some kind of funeral was coming along, and that there was popular objection to this funeral, which engendered uproar.
vi: Straining his eyes to look, Cruncher recognized a funeral procession coming, followed by a noisy crowd.
tr: After looking for a while, Mr. Cruncher decided that it was a funeral crowd; a large number of people protesting the funeral had caused a great commotion.
es: Upon examining the torrent, Lapa saw that it was a funeral procession which undoubtedly was not to the people's liking, as they were objecting to its passage.

en: “Young Jerry,” said mr Cruncher, turning to his offspring, “it’s a buryin’.”
vi: − Jerry, son, - Cruncher turned to his son, - there's a funeral.
tr: "Look Jerry," said Mr. Cruncher, turning to his son, "the funeral is coming."
es: —It's a burial, son—said Jeremías to his offspring.

en: “Hooroar, father!” cried Young Jerry.
vi: − Hooray, Dad! - little Jerry shouted.
tr: "Way to go, Dad!" shouted little Jerry.
es: "Long live... father!" shouted Lapa's son, doing four kicks in the air.

en: The young gentleman uttered this exultant sound with mysterious significance.
vi: The son uttered those words of joy with an air of mysterious importance.
tr: There was a mysterious situation in the cheerful shout that came from the little gentleman.
es: The little gentleman imbued his cry of joy with a mysterious significance that displeased the father to such an extent that he watched closely and soon seized the opportunity to grab his offspring by the ear.

en: The elder gentleman took the cry so ill, that he watched his opportunity, and smote the young gentleman on the ear.
vi: The father was annoyed by this, so he waited for a moment when no one was paying attention and then gave his son a slap.
tr: The older gentleman, however, did not like this shout very much; when he found the opportunity, he gave the little gentleman a slap on the ear.
es: The little gentleman imbued his cry of joy with a mysterious significance that displeased the father to such an extent that he watched closely and soon seized the opportunity to grab his offspring by the ear.

en: “What d’ye mean?
vi: − What are you up to?
tr: "What's going on?
es: —What is that?—shouted Jeremiah's father. —

en: What are you hooroaring at?
vi: What are you cheering for?
tr: Why are you shouting?
es: What does that cheer mean?

en: What do you want to conwey to your own father, you young Rip?
vi: Are you mocking your father, you little rascal?
tr: Are you trying to say something to your father, you scoundrel?
es: Is that the respect you have for your father?

en: This boy is a getting too many for me!” said mr Cruncher, surveying him.
vi: I can't stand you anymore! Cruncher stared at his son. -
tr: This child is getting too much now!" said Mr. Cruncher, eyeing him.
es: This boy is a rascal, a scoundrel, as scoundrelly as his cheers!

en: “Him and his hooroars!
vi: How dare you cheer?
tr: "As if he himself wasn't enough, he's also shouting 'long live'!
es: This boy is a rascal, a scoundrel, as scoundrelly as his cheers!

en: Don’t let me hear no more of you, or you shall feel some more of me.
vi: If I hear it again, you'll get another slap.
tr: Don't make a sound again or I'll come down on you.
es: Don't let me hear you again, if you don't want to feel my wrath!

en: D’ye hear?”
vi: Do you hear me?
tr: Did you hear me?"
es: Do you understand?

en: “I warn’t doing no harm,” Young Jerry protested, rubbing his cheek.
vi: − I didn't do anything wrong, - young Jerry protested while rubbing his cheek.
tr: "I didn't say anything bad," Little Jerry protested, rubbing his cheek.
es: —Was I hurting anyone?—exclaimed the boy in protest, rubbing his ear.

en: “Drop it then,” said mr Cruncher; “I won’t have none of your no harms.
vi: − Shut up, - Cruncher said, - I don't care what you did wrong.
tr: "Cut it short," said Mr. Cruncher; "Keep your words to yourself.
es: —What you weren't doing was right!

en: Get a top of that there seat, and look at the crowd.”
vi: Just sit in that chair and watch people.
tr: Get up on that stool and look at that rudeness."
es: —replied Lapa.—Get up on this bench and look at the crowds.

en: His son obeyed, and the crowd approached; they were bawling and hissing round a dingy hearse and dingy mourning coach, in which mourning coach there was only one mourner, dressed in the dingy trappings that were considered essential to the dignity of the position.
vi: The boy obeyed and the crowd moved forward; the masses shouted and screamed around a dark hearse and a dark funeral carriage, on which there was only one person, dressed in the somber attire essential for this solemn role.
tr: The child listened to his father's words, the crowd had approached; they were shouting and booing around a pale-colored hearse and again a pale-colored mourning carriage; inside the mourning carriage, there was a single mourner dressed in pale-colored clothes due to the gravity of his position.
es: The son obeyed. The crowds came shouting wildly and jumping around a dirty and old death cart, followed by a hearse just as dirty, old, and tarnished as the cart, occupied by a single representative of mourning, who displayed the funeral attire that she considered indispensable to the dignity of her position.

en: The position appeared by no means to please him, however, with an increasing rabble surrounding the coach, deriding him, making grimaces at him, and incessantly groaning and calling out: “Yah!
vi: But the funeral conductor was not at all pleased with this role as the crowd around the carriage grew increasingly chaotic, mocking him, frowning at him, and incessantly criticizing and shouting “Hey!
tr: He was not at all pleased with his situation, because the noisy crowd surrounding the carriage was mocking him, making faces, and continuously groaning, "Boo! Spies! Boo! Spies!" along with many other unrepeatable, unspeakable insults.
es: It did not seem, however, that her position was very desirable, as the mobs jumped around the carriage shouting until deafening her, making faces and contortions, mocking her respectable person, and hurling unpleasant apostrophes to her ear.

en: Spies!
vi: Spy! Hiss!
tr: He was not at all pleased with his situation, because the noisy crowd surrounding the carriage was mocking him, making faces, and continuously groaning, "Boo! Spies! Boo! Spies!" along with many other unrepeatable, unspeakable insults.
es: It did not seem, however, that her position was very desirable, as the mobs jumped around the carriage shouting until deafening her, making faces and contortions, mocking her respectable person, and hurling unpleasant apostrophes to her ear.

en: Tst!
vi: Hey hey!
tr: He was not at all pleased with his situation, because the noisy crowd surrounding the carriage was mocking him, making faces, and continuously groaning, "Boo! Spies! Boo! Spies!" along with many other unrepeatable, unspeakable insults.
es: It did not seem, however, that her position was very desirable, as the mobs jumped around the carriage shouting until deafening her, making faces and contortions, mocking her respectable person, and hurling unpleasant apostrophes to her ear.

en: Yaha! Spies!” with many compliments too numerous and forcible to repeat.
vi: Spy!” along with countless other unbearably harsh praises that cannot be recounted.
tr: He was not at all pleased with his situation, because the noisy crowd surrounding the carriage was mocking him, making faces, and continuously groaning, "Boo! Spies! Boo! Spies!" along with many other unrepeatable, unspeakable insults.
es: It did not seem, however, that her position was very desirable, as the mobs jumped around the carriage shouting until deafening her, making faces and contortions, mocking her respectable person, and hurling unpleasant apostrophes to her ear.

en: Funerals had at all times a remarkable attraction for mr Cruncher; he always pricked up his senses, and became excited, when a funeral passed Tellson’s.
vi: Funerals always had a great attraction for Cruncher; he would always strain his eyes and ears and become excited whenever a funeral passed by Tellson's.
tr: Funerals had always piqued Mr. Cruncher's interest; whenever a funeral passed by Tellson's, he would watch it with full attention and get excited.
es: Funerals were always a special source of excitement for Jeremías Lapa; it is not surprising, then, that on this occasion, involving a funeral with such a noisy entourage, it drove him to the point of asking the first person he encountered:

en: Naturally, therefore, a funeral with this uncommon attendance excited him greatly, and he asked of the first man who ran against him:
vi: So a funeral with an unusually large number of attendants like this one made him extremely happy, and he immediately asked the first person he came across: −
tr: Therefore, naturally, this unusual group accompanying the funeral had quite excited him, and he immediately asked the man running in front:
es: Funerals were always a special source of excitement for Jeremías Lapa; it is not surprising, then, that on this occasion, involving a funeral with such a noisy entourage, it drove him to the point of asking the first person he encountered:

en: “What is it, brother?
vi: What's this, mate?
tr: "Brother, what is this?
es: —What's up, brother?

en: What’s it about?”
vi: What's going on?
tr: What's happening?"
es: What's that?

en: “I don’t know,” said the man.
vi: − I don't know, - the other person said.
tr: "I don't know either," said the man.
es: —I don't know—replied the questioned one without stopping.

en: “Spies!
vi: - Spy!
tr: "Spies! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!...

en: Yaha!
vi: Hey hey!
tr: "Spies! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!

en: Tst! Spies!”
vi: Hiss! Spy!
tr: "Spies! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!

en: He asked another man.
vi: Cruncher asked another person: − Who died? − I don't know, - this person replied the same way but cupped his hands around his mouth to make a megaphone and shouted enthusiastically and strangely energetically, - Spy!
tr: He asked another man.
es: —Who is the dead person?—he asked another.

en: “Who is it?”
