vi: Cruncher asked another person: − Who died? − I don't know, - this person replied the same way but cupped his hands around his mouth to make a megaphone and shouted enthusiastically and strangely energetically, - Spy!
tr: "Who is this?"
es: —Who is the dead person?—he asked another.

en: “I don’t know,” returned the man, clapping his hands to his mouth nevertheless, and vociferating in a surprising heat and with the greatest ardour, “Spies!
vi: Cruncher asked another person: − Who died? − I don't know, - this person replied the same way but cupped his hands around his mouth to make a megaphone and shouted enthusiastically and strangely energetically, - Spy!
tr: "I don't know!" said the man, but he had brought his hand to his mouth and was shouting with incredible enthusiasm and tremendous zeal: "Spies! Boo! Boo! Spies!"
es: —I don't know—he also replied, placing his hands in front of his mouth like a megaphone, and shouting with redoubled fury:—Spies!

en: Yaha!
vi: Hey hey!
tr: "I don't know!" said the man, but he had brought his hand to his mouth and was shouting with incredible enthusiasm and tremendous zeal: "Spies! Boo! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!

en: Tst, tst!
vi: Hiss, hiss!
tr: "I don't know!" said the man, but he had brought his hand to his mouth and was shouting with incredible enthusiasm and tremendous zeal: "Spies! Boo! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!

en: Spi—ies!”
vi: Spyyyy...!
tr: "I don't know!" said the man, but he had brought his hand to his mouth and was shouting with incredible enthusiasm and tremendous zeal: "Spies! Boo! Boo! Spies!"
es: Spies!

en: At length, a person better informed on the merits of the case, tumbled against him, and from this person he learned that the funeral was the funeral of one Roger Cly.
vi: It was only after a while that Cruncher met someone who knew the real situation and found out that this funeral was for a certain Roger Cly.
tr: Finally, a man who knew more about this matter came across him, and from this man, he learned that the funeral was for someone named Roger Cly.
es: Lapa finally stumbled upon a person better informed about the case, thanks to whom he was able to find out that it was the burial of an individual named Rogerio Cly.

en: “Was he a spy?” asked mr Cruncher.
vi: − Is this guy a spy? - Cruncher asked.
tr: "What is the case?" asked Mr. Cruncher.
es: —Was he a spy?—asked Lapa.

en: “Old Bailey spy,” returned his informant.
vi: − The spy at the Old Bailey, - the knowledgeable person informed.
tr: "Old Bailey spy!" said the source of the news.
es: —Spy of the Old Bailey—replied the informant. —Spy... yes... spy of the Old Bailey!

en: “Yaha!
vi: − Hey hey!
tr: "Boo! Boo!
es: —Damn!

en: Tst!
vi: Stop!
tr: "Boo! Boo!
es: —Damn!

en: Yah!
vi: Hey!
tr: "Boo! Boo!
es: —Damn!

en: Old Bailey Spi—i—ies!”
vi: The spy from Old Baiiiii... ley! − Ah, that's right!
tr: Old Bailey spies!"
es: —Damn!

en: “Why, to be sure!” exclaimed Jerry, recalling the Trial at which he had assisted.
vi: - Jerry exclaimed as he recalled the trial he had participated in before.
tr: Remembering the trial he himself had attended, Jerry shouted, "Ah, of course!" "I had seen him."
es: —exclaimed Lapa, recalling the sight he had witnessed in the past.

en: “I’ve seen him.
vi: - I have met this guy before.
tr: Remembering the trial he himself had attended, Jerry shouted, "Ah, of course!" "I had seen him."
es: —I know him.

en: Dead, is he?”
vi: Is he dead?
tr: "He's dead, isn't he?"
es: Is he dead?

en: “Dead as mutton,” returned the other, “and can’t be too dead.
vi: − Dead as a doornail, - the other replied, - stone cold dead.
tr: "A corpse, a corpse," the other replied, "saying he died is an understatement.
es: —Dead like my grandmother!

en: Have ’em out, there!
vi: Drag them out here!
tr: Get them out!
es: And he should be even more dead!...

en: Spies!
vi: Spies!
tr: Spies!
es: Get out!... Spy!...

en: Pull ’em out, there!
vi: Tear them apart!
tr: Get them out!
es: Get out!... Spy!...

en: Spies!”
vi: Spies!
tr: Spies!"
es: Throw him in here!

en: The idea was so acceptable in the prevalent absence of any idea, that the crowd caught it up with eagerness, and loudly repeating the suggestion to have ’em out, and to pull ’em out, mobbed the two vehicles so closely that they came to a stop.
vi: This idea was too easily accepted when no one could think of anything else, so the crowd eagerly seized it, shouting and repeating the suggestion to drag and tear apart, while crowding around so tightly that the two carriages couldn't move an inch.
tr: In an environment where there were no other ideas, this idea was so reasonable that the crowd eagerly jumped on it, and while they kept reiterating their suggestions to get them out of the car, shouting loudly, the two vehicles got so close to each other that they had to stop.
es: Such a brilliant idea had to be inevitably accepted by those crowds, and so it was, indeed. Everyone eagerly seized upon the cry and repeated it a thousand times, as they drew so close to the hearse and the funeral carriage that they forced them to stop.

en: On the crowd’s opening the coach doors, the one mourner scuffled out by himself and was in their hands for a moment; but he was so alert, and made such good use of his time, that in another moment he was scouring away up a bye-street, after shedding his cloak, hat, long hatband, white pocket-handkerchief, and other symbolical tears.
vi: When the crowd managed to open the door of the funeral carriage, the only person in mourning attire frantically jumped out and was caught for a moment; but he was too quick and knew how to take advantage of the situation, so in a flash, he escaped into an alley after discarding his coat, hat, long mourning band, white handkerchief in his pocket, and even the symbolic tears.
tr: As someone from the crowd opened the car door, the only mourning passenger quickly threw himself out and found himself amidst the crowd, but he was so alert and agile that he threw off his cloak, hat, hatband, white handkerchief, and other symbols of mourning, and fled straight into the side streets.
es: In the blink of an eye, they seized the representative of the mourning; but he, who was anything but clumsy, so admirably knew how to make use of the time that in another blink of an eye he gave the crowds the slip by dashing down a side alley, not without leaving in their hands his cape, his hat, the veil that covered him to his knees, the obligatory white handkerchief, and other symbolic tears.

en: These, the people tore to pieces and scattered far and wide with great enjoyment, while the tradesmen hurriedly shut up their shops; for a crowd in those times stopped at nothing, and was a monster much dreaded.
vi: These mourning clothes were joyfully torn to pieces by the crowd and scattered everywhere while the shopkeepers hastily closed their stores; for at that time the crowd would not hesitate before anything and was as terrifying as a monstrous tyrant.
tr: While those around were tearing all these items into pieces with great pleasure and scattering them around, the shopkeepers hastily pulled down their shutters; in such times, such a mob knew no bounds and could turn into a terrifying monster.
es: The town entertained itself by tearing and scattering to the four winds the indicated objects and garments, demonstrating wild joy, while the merchants hurriedly closed the doors of their establishments, as the mob, in those happy times, was a highly dangerous monster, capable of devouring everything once it opened its jaws.

en: They had already got the length of opening the hearse to take the coffin out, when some brighter genius proposed instead, its being escorted to its destination amidst general rejoicing.
vi: The crowd had gone so mad that they opened the hearse door intending to pull out the coffin when a genius, smarter than the rest, came up with the idea to leave it as it was and all together escort the hearse to its final destination to celebrate the funeral.
tr: The crowd had gone so far as to open the car door and take out the coffin, but a bright-minded person suggested that instead of removing it from the car, they should accompany it cheerfully to its destination.
es: They had already opened the doors of the hearse to take out the coffin, when another genius proposed escorting it to its destination amidst general rejoicing.

en: Practical suggestions being much needed, this suggestion, too, was received with acclamation, and the coach was immediately filled with eight inside and a dozen out, while as many people got on the roof of the hearse as could by any exercise of ingenuity stick upon it.
vi: Any practical suggestion was necessary, so everyone enthusiastically accepted this proposal, and the hearse immediately became crowded with eight people squeezing inside, a dozen clinging outside; while the hearse also bore about the same number of people climbing on the roof and a bunch skillfully hanging around it in every possible way.
tr: Due to the need for practical suggestions, this proposal was also met with applause, and suddenly eight men filled the inside of the car, a dozen clung to the outside, and meanwhile, a large number swarmed onto the roof of the car with great skill.
es: The proposal, like all those that are eminently practical, deserved to be approved by acclamation, and immediately eight individuals stormed the coach while another six climbed onto the roof of the hearse.

en: Among the first of these volunteers was Jerry Cruncher himself, who modestly concealed his spiky head from the observation of Tellson’s, in the further corner of the mourning coach.
vi: Among the first volunteers was Jerry Cruncher, who timidly hid his spiky hair in the farthest corner of the hearse so that the people from Tellson's Bank wouldn't see him.
tr: Among those leading the way was Jerry Cruncher, who had curled up in a corner inside the mourning car and was humbly hiding his spiky hair to avoid being seen by those from Tellson's.
es: One of the first volunteers was Jeremías Lapa, who, in his modesty, hid himself and his head in a corner of the coach.

en: The officiating undertakers made some protest against these changes in the ceremonies; but, the river being alarmingly near, and several voices remarking on the efficacy of cold immersion in bringing refractory members of the profession to reason, the protest was faint and brief.
vi: The official employees of the funeral home opposed the change in funeral rites; but the river was alarmingly close, and many in the crowd noted that using cold water would effectively calm any stubborn staff member, so the funeral home staff only weakly and briefly protested.
tr: The funeral attendants initially protested a bit about this change in the ceremony, but the river was quite close, and when some of them started making remarks that dipping the stubborn attendants into the cold water would bring them to their senses, the objections ceased.
es: The funeral home employees protested against that alteration of the ceremony; but the distance to the river was alarmingly short, and several voices had already advocated the effectiveness of a cold immersion to bring the recalcitrant funeral employees to their senses, and as a result, the protests were weak and brief.

en: The remodelled procession started, with a chimney-sweep driving the hearse—advised by the regular driver, who was perched beside him, under close inspection, for the purpose—and with a pieman, also attended by his cabinet minister, driving the mourning coach.
vi: The funeral continued with the new rites, a chimney sweep took control of the hearse - under the guidance of the actual driver sitting precariously beside him to closely supervise the task - while a street vendor, also with an assistant advisor, drove the funeral carriage.
tr: The transformed procession set off with the chimney sweep as the driver – the actual driver sat next to him, carefully watching and guiding him; the mourning coach was driven by a minister and a pie seller.
es: The procession continued once it was reformed. A chimney sweep guided the hearse, advised by a professional coachman sitting next to him, and the driving of the car was handled by a baker, assisted in turn by a responsible minister.

en: A bear-leader, a popular street character of the time, was impressed as an additional ornament, before the cavalcade had gone far down the Strand; and his bear, who was black and very mangy, gave quite an Undertaking air to that part of the procession in which he walked.
vi: A bear trainer, a popular street performer of the time, was also enlisted as an additional decoration before the procession reached Strand Street; and his mangy black bear was the only one in the procession with a genuinely mournful expression.
tr: Before the cavalry regiment even reached the Strand, a bear handler, a street character much loved at the time, joined them, adding color to the procession; as for his very dirty black bear, it gave the procession a truly funereal atmosphere as it walked along.
es: A Hungarian with his bear, a very popular street type at that time, joined the procession; the bear, being black and very thin, perfectly harmonized with the funereal character of the procession of which it was a part.

vi: A bear trainer, a popular street performer of the time, was also enlisted as an additional decoration before the procession reached Strand Street; and his mangy black bear was the only one in the procession with a genuinely mournful expression.
tr: Before the cavalry regiment even reached the Strand, a bear handler, a street character much loved at the time, joined them, adding color to the procession; as for his very dirty black bear, it gave the procession a truly funereal atmosphere as it walked along.
es: A Hungarian with his bear, a very popular street type at that time, joined the procession; the bear, being black and very thin, perfectly harmonized with the funereal character of the procession of which it was a part.

en: Original
vi: A bear trainer, a popular street performer of the time, was also enlisted as an additional decoration before the procession reached Strand Street; and his mangy black bear was the only one in the procession with a genuinely mournful expression.
tr: Before the cavalry regiment even reached the Strand, a bear handler, a street character much loved at the time, joined them, adding color to the procession; as for his very dirty black bear, it gave the procession a truly funereal atmosphere as it walked along.
es: A Hungarian with his bear, a very popular street type at that time, joined the procession; the bear, being black and very thin, perfectly harmonized with the funereal character of the procession of which it was a part.

en: Thus, with beer-drinking, pipe-smoking, song-roaring, and infinite caricaturing of woe, the disorderly procession went its way, recruiting at every step, and all the shops shutting up before it.
vi: So, while drinking beer, smoking, singing loudly, and making all sorts of sorrowful and mocking gestures, the chaotic crowd kept moving forward, constantly drawing more people to join, and wherever they went, all the shops would shut their doors tightly.
tr: Thus, the boisterous procession advanced, drinking beers, puffing on pipes, singing songs, accompanied by an endless imitation of sorrow, and constantly adding new members to their ranks; everyone who saw them closed their shops.
es: In this manner, the disordered procession continued, growing at every step and forcing all the shops on the streets it passed through to close.

en: Its destination was the old church of Saint Pancras, far off in the fields.
vi: The destination was the old Saint Pancras church, far out in the fields.
tr: The place they were headed to was the old St Pancras Church, far away in the middle of the fields.
es: The end of the journey was the old church of San Pancracio, located outside the city, where it arrived in due time.

en: It got there in course of time; insisted on pouring into the burial-ground; finally, accomplished the interment of the deceased Roger Cly in its own way, and highly to its own satisfaction.
vi: The crowd eventually arrived, everyone poured into the cemetery; and finally, they completed the burial of the late Roger Cly in the manner they wanted, and everyone was satisfied.
tr: After a while, they reached their destination and all flowed into the cemetery like a flood; finally, they managed to bury the late Roger Cly in their own way and to their own satisfaction.
es: The burial of Rogerio Cly's corpse was carried out according to an extravagant ceremony, much to the satisfaction of the large accompanying crowd.

en: The dead man disposed of, and the crowd being under the necessity of providing some other entertainment for itself, another brighter genius (or perhaps the same) conceived the humour of impeaching casual passers-by, as Old Bailey spies, and wreaking vengeance on them.
vi: The dead had been buried, and the crowd now needed to find new entertainment for themselves. A brilliant mind (or perhaps the same person from earlier) came up with the fun idea of accusing passersby of being spies at the Old Bailey and venting their hatred on them.
tr: The dead had been buried, and the crowd was in a rush to find a new amusement when another genius (perhaps the same man) came up with the witty idea of accusing passersby of being Old Bailey spies and taking revenge on them.
es: Once the deceased was buried, the author of the previous humorous proposition, or perhaps another genius, as they are never lacking in crowds, conceived and proposed the diabolical idea, unanimously approved, of accusing passersby of being spies from the Old Bailey and calling for vengeance against all those whom chance brought to those places.

en: Chase was given to some scores of inoffensive persons who had never been near the Old Bailey in their lives, in the realisation of this fancy, and they were roughly hustled and maltreated.
vi: Dozens of innocent people who had never set foot near the Old Bailey were chased, knocked down, and assaulted.
tr: To bring this idea to life, they grabbed hold of a bunch of innocent people who had never even passed near Old Bailey in their entire lives and harassed them by pushing and shoving.
es: Dozens of innocent unfortunates who had never in their lives been within a thousand yards of the despised court were pursued like wild beasts, harassed, and mercilessly beaten.

en: The transition to the sport of window-breaking, and thence to the plundering of public-houses, was easy and natural.
vi: From this game, it was an easy and natural progression to smashing windows and then looting pubs.
tr: Naturally, from there, they moved on to the game of breaking windows and looting houses.
es: The transition from this game to breaking windows, knocking down doors and windows, and looting inns and taverns could not have been simpler, more natural, or more logical.

en: At last, after several hours, when sundry summer-houses had been pulled down, and some area-railings had been torn up, to arm the more belligerent spirits, a rumour got about that the Guards were coming.
vi: Eventually, hours later, when many summer houses had been torn down and many fences had been broken to make weapons for the more belligerent, a rumor spread that the guards were coming.
tr: Eventually, a few hours later, after some summer houses had been demolished and fences torn down, rumors spread that soldiers were coming to support the warrior spirits.
es: After several hours of looting, when several country houses had been stormed, many shops ransacked, and numerous iron fences destroyed, providing weapons to the most belligerent characters, word spread that the guards were coming.

en: Before this rumour, the crowd gradually melted away, and perhaps the Guards came, and perhaps they never came, and this was the usual progress of a mob.
vi: Upon hearing this news, the crowd gradually dispersed, and whether the guards came or not, this was the usual course of events for a frenzied mob.
tr: Even before the rumor spread, the crowd had gradually dispersed; the soldiers may or may not have come, but this was what happened in all stampedes.
es: The mere news was enough to disperse the mobs before the guards arrived, who perhaps did not even think of approaching the scene of the events.

en: mr Cruncher did not assist at the closing sports, but had remained behind in the churchyard, to confer and condole with the undertakers.
vi: Cruncher did not participate in the post-funeral entertainments but stayed in the cemetery to chat and comfort the undertaker's staff.
tr: Mr. Cruncher had not attended the closing celebration; he had stayed behind in the cemetery in the churchyard, talking to the funeral staff.
es: Jeremías Lapa did not take part in the recent disturbances; he preferred to remain in the cemetery, conversing with the funeral home employees and engaging in somber reflections.

en: The place had a soothing influence on him.
vi: This place made him feel at ease.
tr: This place had a calming effect on him.
es: The realm of death always exerted a calming influence on him.

en: He procured a pipe from a neighbouring public-house, and smoked it, looking in at the railings and maturely considering the spot.
vi: He got a pipe from a nearby pub and smoked while observing the surrounding fence, carefully examining the location.
tr: He had found a pipe in one of the nearby pubs, and was smoking it while looking at the fences and thinking about the commotion that had taken place.
es: Sitting on a grave, smoking a pipe he had acquired from the nearby tavern with philosophical calm, he meditated, his eyes fixed on the gate.

en: “Jerry,” said mr Cruncher, apostrophising himself in his usual way, “you see that there Cly that day, and you see with your own eyes that he was a young ’un and a straight made ’un.”
vi: “Jerry,” Cruncher muttered to himself again out of habit. "That day you already saw that guy Cly." "You saw with your own eyes that he was a young and decent man."
tr: Mr. Cruncher said to himself, as usual, "Jerry! That day you saw Cly with your own eyes, and you saw that he was young and strong.""
es: You see, Jeremías, what the world is like! —Lapa said to himself. —Not long ago you saw with your own eyes that Cly, young, robust, brimming with life, and now...

en: Having smoked his pipe out, and ruminated a little longer, he turned himself about, that he might appear, before the hour of closing, on his station at Tellson’s.
vi: After finishing his pipe and pondering a bit more, he also returned to make sure he was at the same spot before Tellson's closed.
tr: After smoking his pipe and drifting into thoughts for a while, it occurred to him that he needed to take his place at Tellson's before closing time.
es: After smoking his pipe, and after a considerable amount of time spent in deep meditations and sad reflections, he got up and started back to the city, intending to be at his post before the Bank's closing time.

en: Whether his meditations on mortality had touched his liver, or whether his general health had been previously at all amiss, or whether he desired to show a little attention to an eminent man, is not so much to the purpose, as that he made a short call upon his medical adviser—a distinguished surgeon—on his way back.
vi: It was unclear whether his thoughts about death had affected his inner courage or his overall health had been unstable recently, or if he just wanted to show some care to a respectable person; either way, on his way back, he stopped by the doctor's house - a well-known surgeon.
tr: Whether the thoughts about mortality he had been pondering had affected his liver, his health had been deteriorating for some time, or he simply wanted to show interest in an important personage, it was unknown, but on his way back, he paid a brief visit to the family doctor – a distinguished surgeon.
es: It has not been entirely possible to clarify whether his meditations had a pernicious influence on his liver, or if his health had already been deteriorating beforehand, or if his visit had no other purpose than to bestow an honor upon the person he visited: whatever the cause, the fact was that, on the way, he stopped for a few minutes at his doctor's house... the eminent veterinarian of the city.

en: Young Jerry relieved his father with dutiful interest, and reported No job in his absence.
vi: Jerry's son sat in for his father out of duty, reporting that there was no work at all during his father's absence.
tr: Little Jerry had taken responsibility and reassured his father, saying that nothing had happened in his absence.
es: The son expressed to the father with great interest that nothing had happened during his absence.

en: The bank closed, the ancient clerks came out, the usual watch was set, and mr Cruncher and his son went home to tea.
vi: The bank closed, the old decrepit clerks left, the night watchman arrived, and Cruncher and his son went home for tea.
tr: The bank closed, the old clerks left, the clock was set as usual, and Mr. Cruncher and his son went home to have tea.
es: The Bank closed the day's operations, the employees left, and Lapa, accompanied by his son, headed home.

en: “Now, I tell you where it is!” said mr Cruncher to his wife, on entering.
vi: − Hey, I'm telling you! - As soon as he walked in, Cruncher immediately spoke to his wife.
tr: When he came inside, "Look, let me tell you something now!" said Mr. Cruncher to his wife.
es: —Today you will know who I am—he said to his wife as soon as he crossed the threshold of the house.

en: “If, as a honest tradesman, my wenturs goes wrong to-night, I shall make sure that you’ve been praying again me, and I shall work you for it just the same as if I seen you do it.”
vi: - I'm an honest worker, and if my job tonight fails, it's definitely because you've cursed me. Even if I don't see with my own eyes what you're doing, I'll still give you a beating as usual.
tr: "As an honest tradesman, if my business goes wrong again tonight, I will be sure that you have cursed me and I will punish you as if I had seen it with my own eyes."
es: —If tonight I am in a bad mood like an honest tradesman, it will be proof that you have spent the day praying against me, and you will know what's what, just as if I had seen you dragged across the floor with my own eyes.

en: The dejected ms Cruncher shook her head.
vi: Mrs. Cruncher shook her head in despair.
tr: Mr. Cruncher nodded his head forward sadly.
es: His rib moved its head.

en: “Why, you’re at it afore my face!” said mr Cruncher, with signs of angry apprehension.
vi: − Oh, you dare to do that in front of me! - Cruncher exclaimed, his voice both angry and worried.
tr: "Why are you looking at my face like that?" shouted Mr. Cruncher, furious with rage.
es: —What! Do you dare to do it right under my nose?—he replied with an angry tone.

en: “I am saying nothing.”
vi: − I didn't say anything.
tr: "I didn't say anything.""
es: —If I don't say anything!

en: “Well, then; don’t meditate nothing.
vi: − Hmph, then don't think about anything.
tr: "Don't say good; don't even think about it.
es: —I already know; but you think!

en: You might as well flop as meditate.
vi: If you're not sitting down praying, you're scheming something.
tr: "Don't say good; don't even think about it.
es: Thinking is just as bad as talking!

en: You may as well go again me one way as another.
vi: One way or another, you're always cursing me.
tr: Whether you kneel down and pray or just think about it, it all leads to the same outcome.
es: You can ruin me just the same by praying as by meditating!

en: Drop it altogether.”
vi: Stop it all, you hear?
tr: Don't do anything."
es: I don't want you to do either!

en: “Yes, Jerry.”
vi: − Yes, sir.
tr: "Okay Jerry."
es: —Alright, Jeremías.

en: “Yes, Jerry,” repeated mr Cruncher sitting down to tea.
vi: − Yes, - Cruncher kept repeating as he sat down for tea.
tr: "Alright Jerry," repeated Mr. Cruncher as he sat down for tea.
es: —Alright, Jeremías.

en: “Ah!
vi: Well!
tr: "Oh! Again 'Alright Jerry'.
es: —Alright, Jeremías.

en: It is yes, Jerry.
vi: Yes.
tr: "Oh! Again 'Alright Jerry'.
es: —Alright, Jeremías.

en: That’s about it.
vi: Alright.
tr: Don't you know anything else?
es: —Yes!... Alright, Jeremías... Perfectly, Jeremías... Agreed, Jeremías...

en: You may say yes, Jerry.”
vi: Allow her to say "yes."
tr: Alright Jerry, alright Jerry."
es: Whatever you say, Jeremías...

en: mr Cruncher had no particular meaning in these sulky corroborations, but made use of them, as people not unfrequently do, to express general ironical dissatisfaction.
vi: Cruncher's grumblings didn't have any clear meaning, but he kept talking, just like everyone else does when they generally express sarcastic dissatisfaction.
tr: The words Mr. Cruncher kept repeating grumpily did not convey a specific meaning but rather expressed a sarcastic dissatisfaction, much like many people often do.
es: You think you can fool me with those words of agreement, don't you?

en: “You and your yes, Jerry,” said mr Cruncher, taking a bite out of his bread-and-butter, and seeming to help it down with a large invisible oyster out of his saucer.
vi: − Just say yes, - Cruncher took a bite of buttered bread and swallowed it quickly as if gulping down a large invisible oyster that had just been shucked.
tr: "You and your 'All right, Jerry,'" said Mr. Cruncher, taking a bite of his buttered bread as if he were swallowing it with the help of an invisible oyster taken from a saucer.
es: You think you can fool me with those words of agreement, don't you?

en: “Ah!
vi: - Ah!
tr: "Ah! I think so too.
es: Well, you are completely mistaken!

en: I think so.
vi: That works too.
tr: "Ah! I think so too.
es: Well, you are completely mistaken!

en: I believe you.”
vi: I trust you. − Are you going out tonight? -
tr: I believe you."
es: Well, you are completely mistaken!

en: “You are going out to-night?” asked his decent wife, when he took another bite.
vi: The kind wife asked as the husband took another bite.
tr: As Mr. Cruncher took a second bite of his bread, his polite wife asked, "Are you going out tonight?"
es: —Are you planning to go out tonight?—asked the woman.

en: “Yes, I am.”
vi: − Yes, there is.
tr: "Yes, I will go out."
es: —Yes; I plan to go out.

en: “May I go with you, father?” asked his son, briskly.
vi: − Can I come with you, Dad? - The boy quickly suggested.
tr: His son immediately blurted out, "Can I come with you too, Dad?"
es: —May I accompany you, father?—asked his child.

en: “No, you mayn’t.
vi: − No, that's not possible.
tr: "No, you cannot come.
es: —You won't be able to accompany me.

en: I’m a going—as your mother knows—a fishing.
vi: I have to go... your mother knows it,... go fishing.
tr: As your mother knows, I am going fishing.
es: Tonight I am going... your mother already knows...

en: That’s where I’m going to.
vi: I have to go there.
tr: Yes, that's right.
es: I am going fishing; fishing; that's it.

en: Going a fishing.”
vi: Go fishing.
tr: I am going fishing."
es: I am going fishing; fishing; that's it.

en: “Your fishing-rod gets rayther rusty; don’t it, father?”
vi: − Dad, your fishing rod is a bit rusty, isn't it?
tr: "But didn't your fishing rod rust, dad?""
es: —Every day the fish are getting smarter, aren't they, father?

en: “Never you mind.”
vi: − Let it be.
tr: "It's none of your business."
es: —It's none of your business.

en: “Shall you bring any fish home, father?”
vi: − Dad, will you bring the fish home? − If I don't bring it home, you'll go hungry tomorrow, - the father replied, shaking his head.
tr: "Will you bring fish, Dad?"
es: —Will he bring fish? —If I don't bring it, there will be a general uproar at home tomorrow—replied Lapa, shaking his head.

en: “If I don’t, you’ll have short commons, to-morrow,” returned that gentleman, shaking his head; “that’s questions enough for you; I ain’t a going out, till you’ve been long abed.”
vi: - Enough questions; as long as you haven't gone to bed and fallen asleep, I won't go anywhere.
tr: "If I don't bring it, there will be nothing to eat tomorrow," said the man, shaking his head; "come on, that's enough questions; I'll go after you fall asleep."
es: —And enough with the questions, kid. I won't leave until you have gone to bed.

en: He devoted himself during the remainder of the evening to keeping a most vigilant watch on ms Cruncher, and sullenly holding her in conversation that she might be prevented from meditating any petitions to his disadvantage.
vi: Throughout the rest of the evening, Cruncher did nothing but watch his wife very closely, constantly engaging her in conversation to prevent her from plotting or praying for any misfortune to befall him.
tr: Jerry did not take his eyes off Mrs. Cruncher for the rest of the evening and kept talking to her harshly so that she wouldn't start cursing him.
es: The rest of the evening he devoted to watching his wife and forcing her to talk constantly in order to prevent her from praying or meditating against him.

en: With this view, he urged his son to hold her in conversation also, and led the unfortunate woman a hard life by dwelling on any causes of complaint he could bring against her, rather than he would leave her for a moment to her own reflections.
vi: Therefore, Cruncher urged his son to talk to his mother as well, tormenting the poor woman with all sorts of complaints and grievances, not allowing her a single moment of peace for private thoughts.
tr: With this thought, he also forced his son to keep his mother engaged in conversation and subjected the poor woman to countless complaints to prevent her from being alone and lost in her thoughts.
es: With the same objective in mind, he also forced his son to chat endlessly with his mother, much to her displeasure, as she did not have a single second to devote to her reflections.

en: The devoutest person could have rendered no greater homage to the efficacy of an honest prayer than he did in this distrust of his wife.
vi: The most devout person who believes in the efficacy of sincere prayers could not believe more than Cruncher did that his wife only wished ill for her husband.
tr: Even the most devout person would not regard the effect of a sincere prayer as much as he did; he was so suspicious of his own blood.
es: The most devout person could not have paid a more eloquent tribute to the efficacy of an honest prayer.

en: It was as if a professed unbeliever in ghosts should be frightened by a ghost story.
vi: It's no different from someone who claims not to believe in ghosts but gets scared out of their wits when hearing ghost stories.
tr: It was like someone who claimed not to believe in ghosts being scared by a ghost story.
es: His fear of his wife's prayers was as if a person who swore up and down that they did not believe in ghosts or apparitions were horrified upon hearing ghost and apparition stories.

en: “And mind you!” said mr Cruncher.
vi: − That's urine! - Cruncher said. -
tr: "Look at me!" said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —It's a big deal that your prayers are a constant threat to our stomachs!

en: “No games to-morrow!
vi: Don't try any tricks tomorrow!
tr: "I don't want any trouble tomorrow!
es: —It's a big deal that your prayers are a constant threat to our stomachs!

en: If I, as a honest tradesman, succeed in providing a jinte of meat or two, none of your not touching of it, and sticking to bread.
vi: If this honest man brings back some pieces of meat, don't you two start complaining and refuse to eat the meat, only swallowing plain bread.
tr: If I manage to bring home a few pieces of meat as an honest tradesman, there's no skipping that and just eating bread.
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: If I, as a honest tradesman, am able to provide a little beer, none of your declaring on water.
vi: This honest man here, if he brings home some beer, don't just pretend to drink plain water.
tr: If I can also bring home some beer as an honest tradesman, there's no saying you'll just drink water.
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: When you go to Rome, do as Rome does.
vi: When in Rome, do as the Romans do.
tr: When in Rome, do as the Romans do.
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: Rome will be a ugly customer to you, if you don’t.
vi: If you don't follow the customs, the host will kick you out of the house.
tr: If you don't do this, Rome will treat you like a bad customer.
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: I’m your Rome, you know.”
vi: I am the host here, got it!
tr: I'm your Rome, don't you forget it."
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: Then he began grumbling again:
vi: Then he started grumbling again: − Food and drinks are served right to your mouth and you still complain!
tr: Then he started muttering again:
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: “With your flying into the face of your own wittles and drink!
vi: I don't understand why I have to work so hard to earn food and drinks, just because of your habit of sitting around praying and living immorally.
tr: "You are depriving your own bread and water!
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: I don’t know how scarce you mayn’t make the wittles and drink here, by your flopping tricks and your unfeeling conduct.
vi: I don't understand why I have to work so hard to earn food and drinks, just because of your habit of sitting around praying and living immorally.
tr: Because of your kneeling and praying and those merciless behaviors, no food or drink has entered the house.
es: —said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: Look at your boy: he is your’n, ain’t he?
vi: Look at your son! Is he really your son?
tr: Look at your son. Look! This child is yours, isn't he?
es: Look at your son...! Because I believe he is your son, right?

en: He’s as thin as a lath.
vi: He's so skinny.
tr: He has become skin and bones.
es: He's thinner than a rapier...

en: Do you call yourself a mother, and not know that a mother’s first duty is to blow her boy out?”
vi: You call yourself a mother but don't know that the first duty of a mother is to fatten up her child?
tr: Do you now call yourself a mother? Don't you know that a mother's first duty is to feed her child?"
es: You, who have the audacity to call yourself his mother, don't you know that the first, the most sacred duty of a mother is to make her son gain weight?

en: This touched Young Jerry on a tender place; who adjured his mother to perform her first duty, and, whatever else she did or neglected, above all things to lay especial stress on the discharge of that maternal function so affectingly and delicately indicated by his other parent.
vi: That statement hit Jerry Jr.'s sore spot, so he insisted that his mother fulfill this first duty, and regardless of whether she fulfilled any other duties, the most important thing was to show truly touching and delicious maternal love as his father had instructed.
tr: These words had touched Little Jerry; he called for his mother to fulfill her first duty, as the matter of fulfilling the maternal duty, which his father had expressed in an impressive and gentle manner, had created a much greater impact on the child than anything else the woman had done or neglected.
es: These words moved the son so deeply that he implored his mother to fulfill, above all else, the maternal role with the same delicacy indicated by his father.

en: Thus the evening wore away with the Cruncher family, until Young Jerry was ordered to bed, and his mother, laid under similar injunctions, obeyed them.
vi: The evening passed with the Cruncher family like that, until young Jerry was made to go to bed and his mother had to follow the same order.
tr: Little Jerry was sent to bed, and his mother was sent to sleep with a similar pacifier, thus ending the evening for the Cruncher family.
es: Thus the evening slipped away in the peaceful home of the Lapas, until mother and son were ordered to go to bed.

en: mr Cruncher beguiled the earlier watches of the night with solitary pipes, and did not start upon his excursion until nearly one o’clock.
vi: Cruncher sat alone, smoking several pipes to pass the time, waiting until nearly one in the morning before setting out.
tr: Mr. Cruncher spent the early hours of the night smoking his pipe alone and waited for the clock to strike one to go for his walk.
es: The head of the family passed the hours of the night smoking solitary pipes until a little past midnight, when he got up to go out.

en: Towards that small and ghostly hour, he rose up from his chair, took a key out of his pocket, opened a locked cupboard, and brought forth a sack, a crowbar of convenient size, a rope and chain, and other fishing tackle of that nature.
vi: At that dark, late hour, he got up from his chair, took a key from his pocket, opened a cupboard, and pulled out a sack, a large crowbar, ropes with chains, and other tools needed for this special fishing trip.
tr: As the first and eerie hour of the day approached, he got up from his chair, took a key out of his pocket, opened a locked cabinet, and took out a sack, a crowbar of appropriate size, a rope, a chain, and other fishing equipment.
es: Before that, however, he took from a cupboard, whose key he kept in his pocket, a sack, a rather thick iron bar, some ropes, a chain, and other similar fishing tools, which, once placed and arranged conveniently, he turned off the light and left.

en: Disposing these articles about him in skilful manner, he bestowed a parting defiance on ms Cruncher, extinguished the light, and went out.
vi: After skillfully tucking, wrapping, wearing, and hooking all those items around himself, Cruncher gave his wife a grumbling farewell, extinguished the light, and left.
tr: After carefully placing these items in the sack, he gave Mrs. Cruncher one last scornful look, turned off the light, and went outside.
es: Before that, however, he took from a cupboard, whose key he kept in his pocket, a sack, a rather thick iron bar, some ropes, a chain, and other similar fishing tools, which, once placed and arranged conveniently, he turned off the light and left.

en: Young Jerry, who had only made a feint of undressing when he went to bed, was not long after his father.
vi: Little Jerry, who had been pretending to change clothes and lie down, immediately got up and followed.
tr: Little Jerry, who just pretended to undress when he went to his room, went outside right after his father.
es: Minutes later, the curious child followed his father, having had the foresight to lie down dressed on the bed when he received the order to retire.

en: Under cover of the darkness he followed out of the room, followed down the stairs, followed down the court, followed out into the streets.
vi: Hidden in the darkness, he followed his father out of the room, down the stairs, into the yard, and then onto the street.
tr: He quietly left the room in the darkness that enveloped everything, went down the stairs, into the courtyard, and from there to the street.
es: Under the cover of night, he left his room, descended the stairs stealthily, and ventured through the deserted streets.

en: He was in no uneasiness concerning his getting into the house again, for it was full of lodgers, and the door stood ajar all night.
vi: Returning to this house was not difficult for him because the house was full of tenants and the door was ajar all night.
tr: He had no worry about how to return home because there were plenty of tenants in the building and the door would stay ajar all night.
es: As for returning to his father's house, he had no fear, for he knew very well that the door remained open all night.

en: Impelled by a laudable ambition to study the art and mystery of his father’s honest calling, Young Jerry, keeping as close to house fronts, walls, and doorways, as his eyes were close to one another, held his honoured parent in view.
vi: Driven by the commendable aspiration to learn the honest craft secrets of his father, young Jerry kept close to the house fronts, walls, and doorsteps as he walked, his eyes always closely following his esteemed father.
tr: With admirable determination, Little Jerry, trying to learn the intricacies and mysteries of his father's honorable work, followed him with his eyes on his honorable father, passing through door frames, wall edges, and door cracks.
es: Driven by the very commendable desire to learn the arts and mysteries of the nocturnal occupations of his honorable father, the boy, sticking to the walls of the houses, immersing himself in the doorways, tried not to lose sight of the hardworking author of his days for an instant.

en: The honoured parent steering Northward, had not gone far, when he was joined by another disciple of Izaak Walton, and the two trudged on together.
vi: As for the esteemed father, he had just headed a short distance north when he encountered another night fisherman, and the two proceeded together.
tr: The honorable father, heading north, had not gone far when another disciple of Izaak Walton joined him, and they continued their arduous walk together.
es: The latter took a northern direction, and he had not gone very far when he encountered a new disciple of Isaac Walton, in whose company he continued the journey.

en: Within half an hour from the first starting, they were beyond the winking lamps, and the more than winking watchmen, and were out upon a lonely road.
vi: After half an hour, they passed through the area with flickering streetlights and the patrol guards who had already closed their eyes, and then reached the deserted road.
tr: Half an hour after setting out, they passed the flickering street lamps and the even more flickering watchmen, and reached a deserted road.
es: Half an hour later, they both walked without a word along a lonely path, where neither the gaze of the street lamps nor that of the night watchmen could reach.

en: Another fisherman was picked up here—and that so silently, that if Young Jerry had been superstitious, he might have supposed the second follower of the gentle craft to have, all of a sudden, split himself into two.
vi: Here, they picked up another fisherman - so silently that if Jerry were superstitious, he would have thought the leisurely fisherman from earlier had suddenly split into two.
tr: Here, another fisherman joined them – the man had joined them so quietly that if Little Jerry had been a superstitious person, he might have thought that the second follower of the delicate task had suddenly split into two.
es: Another fisherman joined them on the path, but with such discretion and silence that if the boy had been superstitious, he surely would have believed that the man who first joined his father had suddenly and miraculously split into two.

en: The three went on, and Young Jerry went on, until the three stopped under a bank overhanging the road.
vi: The three men continued walking and Jerry followed them until the three fishermen stopped under a bank that jutted out close to the road.
tr: The trio continued on their way and Jerry followed these three men until they stopped under an earthen embankment on the road.
es: The three continued their march followed by Lapa's son, until they halted at the foot of an embankment whose slope rose above the path.

en: Upon the top of the bank was a low brick wall, surmounted by an iron railing.
vi: On the bank was a low brick wall with an iron fence.
tr: There was a low brick wall with iron railings on top of the embankment.
es: On top of the slope, there ran a low brick wall, crowned by an iron fence.

en: In the shadow of bank and wall the three turned out of the road, and up a blind lane, of which the wall—there, risen to some eight or ten feet high—formed one side.
vi: In the darkness of the bank and the fence, the three men left the main road and turned into a dead-end alley beside the fence - which was up to three meters high in some places.
tr: The trio, in the shadow of the embankment and the wall, turned into a narrow dead-end road; the wall still extended along one side of the road – two and a half to three meters high.
es: The men slid like ghosts along the slope, trying to take cover in its shadow, until they reached an indentation that gave access to a sort of alley, one side of which, formed by the brick wall, was about ten feet high.

en: Crouching down in a corner, peeping up the lane, the next object that Young Jerry saw, was the form of his honoured parent, pretty well defined against a watery and clouded moon, nimbly scaling an iron gate.
vi: Huddled in a dark corner, looking into the alley, young Jerry immediately saw the figure of his esteemed father clearly illuminated in the dim moonlight, swiftly climbing up the iron gate.
tr: The next thing Jerry, crouched in a corner and watching this narrow road, saw was the figure of his honest father, very clearly visible in front of the pale and cloud-covered moon, hurriedly testing the weight of an iron gate.
es: In the whitish light of the moon, the boy could see that the honest tradesman to whom he owed his existence was climbing the iron fence with unparalleled agility.

en: He was soon over, and then the second fisherman got over, and then the third.
vi: His father climbed over quickly, followed by the second fisherman, then the third.
tr: Soon after, his father jumped over it, followed by the second fisherman, and then the third fisherman jumped over.
es: He was immediately followed by the second fisherman, and then by the third.

en: They all dropped softly on the ground within the gate, and lay there a little—listening perhaps.
vi: All three gently jumped down to the ground inside the gate and lay still for a while - perhaps listening.
tr: They all made a soft landing over the gate and lay on the ground for a while – probably listening to their surroundings.
es: The three reached the ground inside the fence, where they remained for a few minutes, lying on the ground... probably listening.

en: Then, they moved away on their hands and knees.
vi: Then they crawled away on their hands and knees.
tr: Then they proceeded on their hands and knees.
es: Then they advanced, crawling on their hands and knees.

en: It was now Young Jerry’s turn to approach the gate: which he did, holding his breath.
vi: Now it's Jerry's turn to sneak to the gate; he holds his breath and creeps forward.
tr: Now it was Little Jerry's turn to jump from the door. He jumped, holding his breath.
es: The boy approached the gate, holding his breath.

en: Crouching down again in a corner there, and looking in, he made out the three fishermen creeping through some rank grass!
vi: Retreating into a dark corner to look, it noticed the shadows of three people fishing, crawling through the thick grass, surrounded by tombstones - they were in a vast cemetery - the white tombstones like ghosts and the church tower rising high like the ghost of a giant monster.
tr: When he crouched in a corner again and looked at them, he saw the three fishermen crawling among the thick grass and all those tombstones in the churchyard – it was a big yard – the tombstones looked like ghosts in white, and the church tower looked like the ghost of a terrible giant.
es: From a corner where he crouched, he saw the three fishermen crawling like snakes through the tall grass that covered the ground... and among many crosses and tombstones.

en: and all the gravestones in the churchyard—it was a large churchyard that they were in—looking on like ghosts in white, while the church tower itself looked on like the ghost of a monstrous giant.
vi: Retreating into a dark corner to look, it noticed the shadows of three people fishing, crawling through the thick grass, surrounded by tombstones - they were in a vast cemetery - the white tombstones like ghosts and the church tower rising high like the ghost of a giant monster.
tr: When he crouched in a corner again and looked at them, he saw the three fishermen crawling among the thick grass and all those tombstones in the churchyard – it was a big yard – the tombstones looked like ghosts in white, and the church tower looked like the ghost of a terrible giant.
es: They were in a cemetery, and they looked like dreadful ghosts being watched by an even more dreadful, more monstrous ghost: the tower of the nearby church, a terrifying giant tasked with guarding the peace of the dead.

en: They did not creep far, before they stopped and stood upright.
vi: The three people crawled a short distance and then stood up.
tr: Soon they stopped crawling, stood up, and began to fish.
es: They did not advance much further.

en: And then they began to fish.
vi: And they began their night fishing.
tr: Soon they stopped crawling, stood up, and began to fish.
es: The boy soon noticed that they straightened up and began to fish.

en: They fished with a spade, at first.
vi: At first, they fished with a shovel.
tr: They started fishing with a garden spade.
es: They first fished with a hoe.

en: Presently the honoured parent appeared to be adjusting some instrument like a great corkscrew.
vi: After that, Jerry's revered father seemed to be adjusting some tool that resembled a gigantic corkscrew.
tr: Then the honorable father continued with a tool that resembled a large corkscrew.
es: Shortly after, the honorable Lapa prepared an instrument similar to an enormous corkscrew.

en: Whatever tools they worked with, they worked hard, until the awful striking of the church clock so terrified Young Jerry, that he made off, with his hair as stiff as his father’s.
vi: No matter what tool they used, they worked diligently until the church clock's chimes struck a terrifying series, causing young Jerry to flee in fright, his hair standing on end just like his father's.
tr: No matter what tool they used, they were working hard, but the church clock struck so terribly that it scared Little Jerry so much that, with his hair standing up like his father's, he didn't know how to run away.
es: Whatever fishing tools they used, they handled them with unusual fervor. The spikes that crowned the boy's head acquired the steely hardness of his father's when the giant guardian of the city of the dead let out slow, resonant, grave, terrifying, the two o'clock in the morning.

en: But, his long-cherished desire to know more about these matters, not only stopped him in his running away, but lured him back again.
vi: However, the long-held desire to understand not only prevented it from running away but also pulled it back.
tr: But the desire to learn what was happening inside him, which he had been carrying for a while, soon stopped him and even made him turn back.
es: The boy embarked on a reckless escape; but his desire to know was so great that not only did he stop after a short distance, but it also prompted him to return to the gate.

en: They were still fishing perseveringly, when he peeped in at the gate for the second time; but, now they seemed to have got a bite.
vi: The three others were still persistently fishing at night when little Jerry peeked through the gate again; but this time, it seemed that a fish had taken the bait.
tr: When he hid by the door for the second time and watched them, they were still fishing with determination, but this time it seemed like something had been caught on the line.
es: He saw that the three men continued fishing, and assumed they had caught something upon observing that the fishermen seemed bent over and as if doubled, making efforts aimed at pulling out a very heavy fish.

en: There was a screwing and complaining sound down below, and their bent figures were strained, as if by a weight.
vi: From the dug hole came creaking and groaning sounds, and the three figures above were straining as if something very heavy was pulling them down.
tr: Sounds of struggling and whining came from below, and the bodies of the men, bent forward, tensed as if something was pulling them down.
es: He saw that the three men continued fishing, and assumed they had caught something upon observing that the fishermen seemed bent over and as if doubled, making efforts aimed at pulling out a very heavy fish.

en: By slow degrees the weight broke away the earth upon it, and came to the surface.
vi: Bit by bit, that heavy object was pulled up from the surrounding soil and emerged to the surface.
tr: Slowly, the weight slipped out of the soil and surfaced.
es: Indeed, it was so: little by little they were hoisting the fish until it surfaced.

en: Young Jerry very well knew what it would be; but, when he saw it, and saw his honoured parent about to wrench it open, he was so frightened, being new to the sight, that he made off again, and never stopped until he had run a mile or more.
vi: Little Jerry already knew what it was, but when he first saw it with his own eyes, and saw his esteemed father about to pry it out, he was so terrified that he ran away, this time sprinting non-stop for several kilometers.
tr: Little Jerry had understood what was going to come out, but when he saw it, moreover, when he saw that his honorable father was about to pull and open it, he was so terrified by this sight he was not used to that he started running without looking back, and only after running a mile or two did he stop.
es: The shape of the fish was unmistakable; but when the boy saw that his father was about to open it, he was seized by such panic that he took off in a frantic run, not stopping or slowing down until he had covered more than a mile of ground.

en: He would not have stopped then, for anything less necessary than breath, it being a spectral sort of race that he ran, and one highly desirable to get to the end of.
vi: At that moment, he ran as fast as he could, only stopping to catch his breath, as if it were a ghostly race and his utmost desire was to reach the finish line.
tr: Even if he didn't need to catch his breath, he wouldn't stop; it was as if he was racing against ghosts, and his only desire was for this race to end.
es: Not even then would he have stopped if he hadn't run out of breath, for he wasn't fleeing from images conjured by fear, but from specters that were haunting him terribly.

en: He had a strong idea that the coffin he had seen was running after him; and, pictured as hopping on behind him, bolt upright, upon its narrow end, always on the point of overtaking him and hopping on at his side—perhaps taking his arm—it was a pursuer to shun.
vi: The boy was convinced that the coffin he had just seen was chasing after him; and he imagined that terrifying object standing upright, leaping onto his back, about to catch up and grab him - perhaps it would seize his arm - and he had to run for his life.
tr: He had a strong belief that the coffin he had just seen was chasing him; it seemed to be hopping and bouncing after him, upright on its narrow side, and at any moment it could catch up to him and hop right beside him – maybe it would grab him by the arm – the chase never ended.
es: The coffin he had seen was right on his heels, jumping over the stones and dirt of the path in a perpendicular position and on its narrowest end, determined to catch up to him and place itself by his side... perhaps to cling to his arm.

en: It was an inconsistent and ubiquitous fiend too, for, while it was making the whole night behind him dreadful, he darted out into the roadway to avoid dark alleys, fearful of its coming hopping out of them like a dropsical boy’s kite without tail and wings.
vi: The ghostly coffin appeared and disappeared, present everywhere, so when the entire darkness behind him turned into a horror, the boy had to dash into the middle of the road to avoid the dark alleys, fearing that ghost would leap out from there like a bloated kite with no wings or tail.
tr: It was like a demon whose actions were unclear and whose emergence was unpredictable, and as it had made the night he left behind utterly terrifying, Little Jerry burst out from the dark side streets onto the main road and fled from it in terror, like a skinny child's tailless and wingless kite, leaping away in fright.
es: That diabolical coffin must have been a marvel of incongruity and ubiquity, for it would leap among the black rows of trees lining the path as soon as it would fly over the thick treetops, like a kite without a tail or wings.

en: It hid in doorways too, rubbing its horrible shoulders against doors, and drawing them up to its ears, as if it were laughing.
vi: The ghost also hid at the doorways, rubbing its ghastly shoulders against the doors, then hunching its shoulders and retracting its neck as if laughing loudly.
tr: The demon also hid in door cracks, rubbing its terrifying shoulders against the doors and pulling them up to its ears as if it were laughing.
es: It also hid in the doorways, against which it rubbed its horrible ribs, producing a sound similar to hollow laughter.

en: It got into shadows on the road, and lay cunningly on its back to trip him up.
vi: The ghost hid in the darkness on the road, lying on its back waiting to trip him.
tr: It blended into the other shadows on the road. It cunningly lay on its back on the ground to trip Little Jerry.
es: It constantly gained ground on the boy in that fantastic race.

en: All this time it was incessantly hopping on behind and gaining on him, so that when the boy got to his own door he had reason for being half dead.
vi: And there was always a ghost leaping behind, chasing closely, so that when the boy finally reached his house, he still hadn't recovered from the fright.
tr: All this time, it never stopped hopping behind the child and didn't leave him alone; when he finally reached the door of their house, Little Jerry was exhausted.
es: When the pursued reached the door of his house, he was half-dead with fear.

en: And even then it would not leave him, but followed him upstairs with a bump on every stair, scrambled into bed with him, and bumped down, dead and heavy, on his breast when he fell asleep.
vi: Even then, the ghost did not let him go but followed him upstairs, thumping on the steps, jumping onto the bed with him, and headbutting his chest, pushing him into a deep, exhausted sleep.
tr: But even then, the demon hadn't left him alone; it had followed him up the stairs with thudding steps, entered the bed with him, and when the child fell asleep, it settled heavily on his chest.
es: Not even after taking refuge inside did he find himself free from the relentless pursuit of the coffin, which climbed the stairs after him, jumping over the steps, and lay down in his bed, and climbed onto his chest when sleep or terror overcame the unfortunate curious one.

en: From his oppressed slumber, Young Jerry in his closet was awakened after daybreak and before sunrise, by the presence of his father in the family room.
vi: The sky had just begun to brighten, dawn had not yet broken when little Jerry, lying in the room, woke up from a heavy sleep because of his father's voice in the outer room.
tr: Little Jerry in his small room was awakened from this troubled sleep at dawn, before the sun had risen, by the sounds coming from his father and mother's bedroom.
es: The presence of Jeremías Lapa in the boy's narrow room ended his restless sleep before the first rays of the sun appeared over the earth.

en: Something had gone wrong with him; at least, so Young Jerry inferred, from the circumstance of his holding ms Cruncher by the ears, and knocking the back of her head against the head-board of the bed.
vi: His father must have encountered something unfavorable; at least, little Jerry could deduce that much when he saw Cruncher grabbing his wife's ears and banging her head against the headboard.
tr: Seeing his father holding Ms. Cruncher by the ears and banging the back of her head against the bedpost, it seemed things had gone wrong for his father; at least, that's what Little Jerry thought.
es: Fortune must have been unkind to him that night; at least, that is what his son inferred from the fact that he had his wife by the ears and was shaking her without consideration.

en: “I told you I would,” said mr Cruncher, “and I did.”
vi: − I told you already, - Cruncher said, - I said I would do it.
tr: "I told you, I would do it," said Mr. Cruncher, "and I did.""
es: —I offered it to you, and I'm fulfilling it!

en: “Jerry, Jerry, Jerry!” his wife implored.
vi: - Jerry, Jerry, Jerry! - The sister-in-law pleaded.
tr: "Jerry, Jerry, Jerry!" his wife pleaded.
es: —said Jeremiah. —For God's sake, Jeremiah! —exclaimed his wife with a pleading tone.

en: “You oppose yourself to the profit of the business,” said Jerry, “and me and my partners suffer.
vi: − When there's a profitable deal, you don't agree, - Jerry said, you keep wishing bad luck upon me and my friends.
tr: "We didn't gain anything because of you," said Jerry, "you are also causing trouble in our partnership.
es: —You insist on ruining my business, without considering that you are harming me and my associates.

en: You was to honour and obey; why the devil don’t you?”
vi: I tell you but you don't listen to me, you don't respect me, for what reason?
tr: You should have just stayed put, why didn't you listen to me?"
es: Your obligation is to obey: why don't you do it?

en: “I try to be a good wife, Jerry,” the poor woman protested, with tears.
vi: − I'm just trying to be a good wife, Jerry, - the miserable woman cried as she argued back.
tr: The poor woman, in tears, protested, "I'm trying to be a good wife, Jerry."
es: —I strive to be an honorable woman! —replied the unfortunate one, shedding tears.

en: “Is it being a good wife to oppose your husband’s business?
vi: − You say you want to be a good wife, but you curse your husband to have bad luck in his work?
tr: "Are you being a good wife by ruining your husband's work?
es: —And do you think that honesty consists of ruining your husband's business?

en: Is it honouring your husband to dishonour his business?
vi: You say you respect your husband, but you sabotage his work?
tr: Will you honor him by sabotaging his work?
es: Do you think you honor your husband by dishonoring his affairs?

en: Is it obeying your husband to disobey him on the wital subject of his business?”
vi: You say you listen to your husband, but why don't you listen to him on important matters?
tr: Are you obeying your husband by not following what he says about his important work?"
es: Do you think you honor your husband by dishonoring his affairs?

en: “You hadn’t taken to the dreadful business then, Jerry.”
vi: − When I said that, you weren't doing this terrible job, Jerry.
tr: "Back then, you weren't doing this terrible job, Jerry.""
es: —You shouldn't engage in such horrible businesses, Jeremiah!

en: “It’s enough for you,” retorted mr Cruncher, “to be the wife of a honest tradesman, and not to occupy your female mind with calculations when he took to his trade or when he didn’t.
vi: − Being a wife who lives a virtuous life is fortunate for you, Cruncher retorted, - but whether the husband works or doesn't work is not something for you women to calculate in your heads.
tr: "It's enough that you're the wife of an honest tradesman," retorted Mr. Cruncher, "so don't stick your nose into these matters with that woman's mind of yours.
es: —It should be enough for you to be the wife of an honest tradesman and not to let your narrow feminine understanding entertain calculations or judgments about the nature of the business your husband does or does not do.

en: A honouring and obeying wife would let his trade alone altogether.
vi: Being a wife who respects her husband and listens to her husband should let him work in peace.
tr: A woman who respects her husband and obeys him does not interfere in his affairs.
es: The woman who is honest and obedient does not meddle in what is the exclusive concern of her husband.

en: Call yourself a religious woman?
vi: Do you think you're pious?
tr: Do you now call yourself pious?
es: And you call yourself religious? You call yourself honest?

en: If you’re a religious woman, give me a irreligious one!
vi: If you're pious, I'd rather marry an irreligious woman!
tr: If you are a pious woman, go find me an impious one!
es: If you are religious, if you are honest, give me irreligious and dishonorable women!

en: You have no more nat’ral sense of duty than the bed of this here Thames river has of a pile, and similarly it must be knocked into you.”
vi: Your sense of responsibility is no better than a post stuck at the bottom of the Thames out there, it seems I have to hammer it into your head like hammering that post for you to understand..
tr: Your sense of duty is not even as much as that stake in the Thames River; that stake should be driven into you instead."
es: The altercation, which was being held in a low voice, came to an end when Jeremiah, removing his mud-covered boots, lay down on the ground, face up with his hands placed under his head as a pillow.

en: The altercation was conducted in a low tone of voice, and terminated in the honest tradesman’s kicking off his clay-soiled boots, and lying down at his length on the floor.
vi: The argument took place quietly and ended with the honest worker kicking off his clay-covered boots from his feet and lying down on the floor.
tr: This argument had taken place in a low voice and ended after the honest shopkeeper kicked off his muddy boots and lay down full length on the ground.
es: The altercation, which was being held in a low voice, came to an end when Jeremiah, removing his mud-covered boots, lay down on the ground, face up with his hands placed under his head as a pillow.

en: After taking a timid peep at him lying on his back, with his rusty hands under his head for a pillow, his son lay down too, and fell asleep again.
vi: After a moment of timidly glancing at his father lying on his back, with his rust-stained hands under his head as a pillow, the son also lay down to continue sleeping.
tr: After casting a timid glance at his father, who was lying on his back with his rusty hands under his head as a pillow, his son also lay down beside him and fell back asleep.
es: The son, in his desire to imitate the father, lay back down on the bed, soon falling asleep.

en: There was no fish for breakfast, and not much of anything else.
vi: That morning's breakfast had no fish, and there was nothing else either.
tr: There was no fish for breakfast, and there were very few other foods as well.
es: After lunch, which did not include any fish dishes, and one could say no other delicacies either, Mr. Jeremiah, who, by the way, was angrier than ever, well-groomed and washed, went out with his son and took the road to Tellson's Bank.

en: mr Cruncher was out of spirits, and out of temper, and kept an iron pot-lid by him as a projectile for the correction of ms Cruncher, in case he should observe any symptoms of her saying Grace.
vi: Cruncher was disheartened and irritable, holding the tin lid as if it were a missile ready to launch at his wife should he see any sign on her face that she was secretly praying.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was both grumpy and angry, and he had an iron pot lid with him to throw at Mrs. Cruncher if he noticed any sign of her saying a prayer of thanks.
es: After lunch, which did not include any fish dishes, and one could say no other delicacies either, Mr. Jeremiah, who, by the way, was angrier than ever, well-groomed and washed, went out with his son and took the road to Tellson's Bank.

en: He was brushed and washed at the usual hour, and set off with his son to pursue his ostensible calling.
vi: He brushed his teeth and washed his face at the usual time, then continued with his son to their daytime pretense work.
tr: After washing his face and combing his hair at the usual time, he set off with his son towards his ostensible duty.
es: After lunch, which did not include any fish dishes, and one could say no other delicacies either, Mr. Jeremiah, who, by the way, was angrier than ever, well-groomed and washed, went out with his son and took the road to Tellson's Bank.

en: Young Jerry, walking with the stool under his arm at his father’s side along sunny and crowded Fleet-street, was a very different Young Jerry from him of the previous night, running home through darkness and solitude from his grim pursuer.
vi: Tucking the stool under his arm, walking beside his father on the bustling, sunlit Fleet Street, young Jerry this morning was completely different from the young Jerry who, chased by a ghostly coffin, ran home alone in the dark last night.
tr: On the sunny and crowded Fleet Street, Little Jerry, walking beside his father with his stool under his arm, was very different from the Little Jerry who had fled from his cruel pursuer in the darkness and desolation of the previous night.
es: The young scion of the honorable tradesman who was walking beside him on Fleet Street was no longer the same person who the previous night had fled in terror along solitary paths from his terrible pursuer.

en: His cunning was fresh with the day, and his qualms were gone with the night—in which particulars it is not improbable that he had compeers in Fleet-street and the City of London, that fine morning.
vi: The boy's fear had dissipated with the night, and the new day had returned to him his familiar mischievous look - and many people jostling on Fleet Street and in the city of London on that beautiful morning felt the same way as the young boy.
tr: His spirits had been refreshed by the dawn of the new day, and his worries had ended with the night – after all, it was not unexpected to have his peers on Fleet Street and in the city of London on such a beautiful morning.
es: With the light of day, he regained his usual boldness, and his qualms and scruples ended with the night... in whose particulars it is more than likely that he had many companions on the lively Fleet Street.

en: “Father,” said Young Jerry, as they walked along: taking care to keep at arm’s length and to have the stool well between them: “what’s a Resurrection-Man?”
vi: − Dad, - Jerry said on the way, carefully walking a pace away from his father with a stool in between, - what kind of job is a body snatcher, dad?
tr: "Dad," said Little Jerry as they walked –he was trying to keep an arm's length distance and to hold the stool between himself and his father– "who is the one that brings a man out of the grave?"
es: —Father—said the boy during the journey,—what is a gravedigger?

en: mr Cruncher came to a stop on the pavement before he answered, “How should I know?”
vi: Cruncher paused for a moment on the sidewalk before answering: − How would I know?
tr: Mr. Cruncher paused on the sidewalk for a moment before answering, "How should I know?"
es: The good Lapa could not answer such an unexpected question without first standing as if nailed to the spot. —How should I know!

en: “I thought you knowed everything, father,” said the artless boy.
vi: − I thought you knew everything, dad, - the boy said honestly.
tr: "I used to think you knew everything, dad," said the child innocently.
es: —he finally replied. —I thought you knew everything, Father—replied the candid boy.

en: “Hem!
vi: − Huh! Fine!
tr: "Hmm!
es: —Hmm! Well... look!

en: Well,” returned mr Cruncher, going on again, and lifting off his hat to give his spikes free play, “he’s a tradesman.”
vi: - Cruncher continued walking, speaking as he removed his hat to let his spiky hair free, - it's a business trade.
tr: Well," replied Mr. Cruncher, continuing to walk and taking off his hat to free his spiky hair, "he is a tradesman."
es: —said Jeremías Lapa, after taking off his hat and scratching his forehead. —A gravedigger is an honest craftsman, a tradesman.

en: “What’s his goods, father?” asked the brisk Young Jerry.
vi: − Selling what, Dad? - Jerry quickly asked.
tr: "Well, what does he sell, dad?" asked the curious Little Jerry.
es: —What line of business are you in?

en: “His goods,” said mr Cruncher, after turning it over in his mind, “is a branch of Scientific goods.”
vi: − Those are goods... - Cruncher pondered for a moment before answering, - ... that belong to the category of scientific* goods.
tr: "The things he sells," said Mr. Cruncher, after weighing what he was going to say in his mind, "are used in some scientific studies."
es: —He trades... in scientific goods of a special nature.

en: “Persons’ bodies, ain’t it, father?” asked the lively boy.
vi: − A dead body, right father? - The kid cheerfully asked.
tr: "Human bodies, you mean, dad?" the child asked excitedly this time.
es: —On human corpses; right, father?

en: “I believe it is something of that sort,” said mr Cruncher.
vi: − I think it's pretty much the same, - Cruncher replied.
tr: "I suppose something like that," said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —I think you're not entirely off track, son.

en: “Oh, father, I should so like to be a Resurrection-Man when I’m quite growed up!”
vi: − Oh, father, I want to grow up to be a body snatcher like you!
tr: "Oh dad, when I grow up, I want to be a grave robber too then!"
es: —Oh father! I would like to be a gravedigger when I become a man! The proposition filled the father with noble pride.

en: mr Cruncher was soothed, but shook his head in a dubious and moral way.
vi: Cruncher felt happy inside, but still shook his head to show a sense of morality and doubt.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was relieved but shook his head from side to side in an undecided and virtuous manner.
es: However, shaking his head as if in doubt, he replied:

en: “It depends upon how you dewelop your talents.
vi: − It depends on how skilled you are.
tr: "It depends on how you develop your skills.
es: —It will depend on the heights your talents can reach.

en: Be careful to dewelop your talents, and never to say no more than you can help to nobody, and there’s no telling at the present time what you may not come to be fit for.”
vi: You must practice to become skilled, and never tell anyone what doesn't need to be said. For now, it's impossible to say whether you can do that job or not.
tr: Strive to improve your skills and don't promise people more than you can deliver; we can't know yet what will be suitable for you."
es: Try to encourage their development, to which the example I set will powerfully contribute. Today it is premature to talk about what you will do or not do in the future.

en: As Young Jerry, thus encouraged, went on a few yards in advance, to plant the stool in the shadow of the Bar, mr Cruncher added to himself: “Jerry, you honest tradesman, there’s hopes wot that boy will yet be a blessing to you, and a recompense to you for his mother!”
vi: Hearing that, little Jerry happily ran a few steps ahead of his father, placing the stool in the shade of the Temple Bar gate.
