tr: Encouraged by these words, when Jerry stepped a few paces ahead of his father to place the stool in the shadow of Temple Bar, Mr. Cruncher said to himself, "Honest tradesman Jerry, you'll see, this child will be a great blessing for you and will make up for his mother's shortcomings!"
es: Moments later, while the boy was going to place the bench in the shade of the Temple Court building, Jeremías Lapa murmured to himself: —Friend Jeremías, honorable craftsman; you can harbor well-founded hopes that your son will, in time, become a treasure that will compensate for your misfortune of having an unnatural wife.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Cruncher followed behind, thinking to himself: "Jerry, an honest man like you might find that this little boy will bring luck, making up for his mother!"
tr: XV
es: Chapter XV.

en: Knitting
vi: 15. Knitting
tr: Knitting
es: KNITTING

en: There had been earlier drinking than usual in the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: Mr. Defarge's wine shop had customers drinking wine earlier than usual.
tr: Drinking had started earlier than usual at Monsieur Defarge's wine shop.
es: That day, at Mr. Defarge's tavern, the libations had begun earlier than usual.

en: As early as six o’clock in the morning, sallow faces peeping through its barred windows had descried other faces within, bending over measures of wine.
vi: It's only six in the morning, and the haggard faces standing outside the barred windows looking in already see other faces inside buried in their glasses.
tr: At six in the morning, pale faces peering through the barred windows saw other faces bent over wine glasses inside.
es: When at six in the morning, pale faces approached the bars of the grates that protected the windows, they saw other pale faces bent over their respective wine cups.

en: Monsieur Defarge sold a very thin wine at the best of times, but it would seem to have been an unusually thin wine that he sold at this time.
vi: Mr. Defarge sells very bland wine even at the best of times, but now the wine he sells is even blander.
tr: Even in the best of times, Monsieur Defarge always sold wine diluted with water, but lately, the wine he sold was even more diluted.
es: As a general rule, the wine sold at Defarge's tavern had received the healthy waters of baptism, but the wine that these early Bacchic drinkers were consuming on this occasion must have been sour, or at least had the property of souring the temperament of those who drank it.

en: A sour wine, moreover, or a souring, for its influence on the mood of those who drank it was to make them gloomy.
vi: Bland and sour, just looking at the gloomy faces of the drinkers tells you what the wine is like.
tr: It was a sour wine, moreover, it soured its surroundings, because it affected the mood of those who drank it, making them melancholic.
es: As a general rule, the wine sold at Defarge's tavern had received the healthy waters of baptism, but the wine that these early Bacchic drinkers were consuming on this occasion must have been sour, or at least had the property of souring the temperament of those who drank it.

en: No vivacious Bacchanalian flame leaped out of the pressed grape of Monsieur Defarge: but, a smouldering fire that burnt in the dark, lay hidden in the dregs of it.
vi: The grapes pressed by Monsieur Defarge yield no passionate fervor for the drinkers, only a smoldering warmth hidden in the dregs.
tr: The sparks of Bacchic joy that sprang from Monsieur Defarge's pressed grapes were not bright flames, but a fire smoldering in the dark, hidden in the pulp of the grapes.
es: The juice of the grapes contained in Defarge's barrels did not ignite cheerful Bacchic flames, but a latent fire, a fire that burned without coming to the surface.

en: This had been the third morning in succession, on which there had been early drinking at the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: This is the third consecutive day that Mr. Defarge's tavern has had customers since early morning.
tr: For three consecutive days, early drinking had started at Monsieur Defarge's place.
es: Three mornings had already passed since the sacrifices to Bacchus began very early in Defarge's tavern.

en: It had begun on Monday, and here was Wednesday come.
vi: It started on Monday, and now it's already Wednesday.
tr: This situation had begun on Monday, and today was Wednesday.
es: They started on Monday and now it was Wednesday.

en: There had been more of early brooding than drinking; for, many men had listened and whispered and slunk about there from the time of the opening of the door, who could not have laid a piece of money on the counter to save their souls.
vi: The visitors came there more to ponder than to drink; since the tavern opened, many people have come to listen, whisper, and linger without spending a single penny at the counter to save their souls.
tr: In fact, people were more deep in thought than drinking; many didn't have a penny to pay the bill, yet as soon as the shop opened, they would slip inside, listen to the conversations, and whisper among themselves.
es: It is true that there was more talking and listening than drinking, for there was no shortage of early risers who entered the establishment as soon as the door opened, and for whom it would have been impossible to place a coin on the counter, even if their soul's salvation depended on it.

en: These were to the full as interested in the place, however, as if they could have commanded whole barrels of wine; and they glided from seat to seat, and from corner to corner, swallowing talk in lieu of drink, with greedy looks.
vi: But in the tavern, they acted as if they were extremely eager, as if they could easily buy all the barrels; and they moved from place to place, from corner to corner, their faces greedily absorbing words instead of wine.
tr: All they cared about was finding out what was happening, but they would wander from table to table, corner to corner, with an attitude as if they could buy all the wine barrels in the shop, greedily sipping the conversations instead of the wine.
es: Nevertheless, they showed the same contentment as if they had been served entire barrels of wine; you could see them moving from one bench to another, shifting from one corner to another, eagerly swallowing paragraphs of conversation instead of savoring sips of wine.

en: Notwithstanding an unusual flow of company, the master of the wine-shop was not visible.
vi: The guests were more numerous than usual, yet the owner was nowhere to be seen.
tr: Despite this unusual crowd, the owner of the wine shop was nowhere to be seen.
es: Although the crowd was larger than usual, the innkeeper had not considered it necessary to make himself visible.

en: He was not missed; for, nobody who crossed the threshold looked for him, nobody asked for him, nobody wondered to see only Madame Defarge in her seat, presiding over the distribution of wine, with a bowl of battered small coins before her, as much defaced and beaten out of their original impress as the small coinage of humanity from whose ragged pockets they had come.
vi: No one paid attention to the absence of the owner because those who entered the tavern were not looking for him, did not need to meet him, and no one was surprised to see only Mrs. Defarge sitting at the counter overseeing the sale of liquor; in front of her was a bowl containing chipped coins, the embossed faces on the coins worn down to unrecognizable shapes from countless times of rubbing against tattered pockets.
tr: Not that his absence was felt; no one entering through the door was looking for him or asking about him, and no one was pondering why only –sitting with a bowl containing money as tattered, worn, and frayed as the pockets they came from, managing the distribution of the wine– Madame Defarge was there.
es: The patrons should not have given importance to Defarge's absence, since no one asked about him, no one showed a desire to see him, no one was surprised to see Mrs. Defarge alone, sitting behind the counter, overseeing the distribution of wine and collecting counterfeit coins, from which the images and crests stamped by the die had disappeared. They were coins worthy of the ragged pockets from which they had come.

en: A suspended interest and a prevalent absence of mind, were perhaps observed by the spies who looked in at the wine-shop, as they looked in at every place, high and low, from the king’s palace to the criminal’s gaol.
vi: If any spy were to look into this tavern - as is their habit of prying everywhere, regardless of the place's status, from the royal palace to the dungeon - they would see an atmosphere of boredom and lethargy enveloping the interior.
tr: From the king's palace to the prisoners' dungeon, spies scattered everywhere probably observed a general distraction with suspended curiosity when they looked at this wine shop.
es: Boredom, absolute lack of interest, and an excess of annoyance were the only things that the spies, who undoubtedly watched from the street as they watched all places, high and low, from the king's palace to the criminal's cell, would have noticed in the tavern.

en: Games at cards languished, players at dominoes musingly built towers with them, drinkers drew figures on the tables with spilt drops of wine, Madame Defarge herself picked out the pattern on her sleeve with her toothpick, and saw and heard something inaudible and invisible a long way off.
vi: The card games dragged on wearily, the domino players thoughtfully built towers with the pieces, the drinkers dipped their fingers into spilled drops of liquor to doodle on the table, and Madame Defarge herself idly scratched at her sleeve with the tip of a toothpick, her distant expression as if she were hearing and seeing something silent and invisible.
tr: The card players had become sluggish, the domino players were building towers out of the pieces in deep thought, the wine drinkers were drawing shapes on their tables with spilled wine drops, and Madam Defarge, while fiddling with the patterns on her knitting with a toothpick, occasionally gazed into the distance as if she had seen or heard something.
es: The playing cards languished, the domino players built castles with the tiles, the drinkers drew faces on the tables with the drops of wine that fell from the cups, and Mrs. Defarge followed the patterns on her sleeve with a toothpick, as if she heard something that did not strike her eardrums and saw things that did not impress her retina.

en: Thus, Saint Antoine in this vinous feature of his, until midday.
vi: The Saint Antoine district at the tavern remained the same until noon.
tr: St. Antoine's drunken state continued until noon.
es: Until noon, the characteristics of San Antonio in its wine-like aspect did not change at all.

en: It was high noontide, when two dusty men passed through his streets and under his swinging lamps: of whom, one was Monsieur Defarge: the other a mender of roads in a blue cap.
vi: When the sun was at its peak, two dusty travelers passed through the streets, under the hanging lamps; one was Mr. Defarge, the other was a road worker wearing a blue hat.
tr: When two men passed through these streets and under their swinging lamps, covered in dust and dirt, the sun was directly overhead. One was Monsieur Defarge, the other was a road worker with a blue cap.
es: Shortly after twelve, two men covered in dust arrived, one of whom was Mr. Defarge, and the other a road worker, both with stern and thirsty expressions, who entered the tavern.

en: All adust and athirst, the two entered the wine-shop.
vi: Dirty and thirsty, the two men stepped into the tavern.
tr: Covered in dust from head to toe and parched with thirst, they rushed into the wine shop.
es: Shortly after twelve, two men covered in dust arrived, one of whom was Mr. Defarge, and the other a road worker, both with stern and thirsty expressions, who entered the tavern.

en: Their arrival had lighted a kind of fire in the breast of Saint Antoine, fast spreading as they came along, which stirred and flickered in flames of faces at most doors and windows.
vi: Their appearance was like lighting a fire right in the heart of Saint Antoine, wherever they went the fire spread, flickering on the faces standing at the entrances and windows.
tr: Their arrival had set St. Antoine's heart ablaze, spreading as they walked, igniting and trembling the faces of people at the doors and windows.
es: Their arrival ignited in the heart of San Antonio burning sparks that, spreading outside the tavern, soon turned into flames, and these in turn into human faces that filled all the doors and windows of the neighborhood.

en: Yet, no one had followed them, and no man spoke when they entered the wine-shop, though the eyes of every man there were turned upon them.
vi: However, no one followed, no one said anything when the two entered the tavern, although everyone's eyes were on them.
tr: Yet no one followed them, and when they entered the wine shop, no one said a word to them, but all eyes were on them.
es: No one followed the dusty travelers, no one addressed a single word to them, but everyone fixed their eyes on them.

vi: − Hello everyone!
tr: Yet no one followed them, and when they entered the wine shop, no one said a word to them, but all eyes were on them.
es: No one followed the dusty travelers, no one addressed a single word to them, but everyone fixed their eyes on them.

en: Original
vi: - Mr. Defarge spoke up.
tr: Yet no one followed them, and when they entered the wine shop, no one said a word to them, but all eyes were on them.
es: No one followed the dusty travelers, no one addressed a single word to them, but everyone fixed their eyes on them.

en: “Good day, gentlemen!” said Monsieur Defarge.
vi: - Mr. Defarge spoke up.
tr: "Hello gentlemen!" said Monsieur Defarge.
es: —Good morning!

en: It may have been a signal for loosening the general tongue.
vi: Perhaps that is a sign for every tongue to start working.
tr: It was as if this was a signal given to loosen the tongues of the people.
es: —answered a large chorus.

en: It elicited an answering chorus of “Good day!”
vi: Everyone simultaneously opened their mouths and said, "Hello!".
tr: In response, they all opened up and said in unison, "Hello!"
es: —answered a large chorus.

en: “It is bad weather, gentlemen,” said Defarge, shaking his head.
vi: − The weather is bad today, folks, - Defarge said, shaking his head.
tr: "The weather is very bad, gentlemen!" said Defarge, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —Bad weather, gentlemen—replied Defarge, shaking his head.

en: Upon which, every man looked at his neighbour, and then all cast down their eyes and sat silent.
vi: Hearing that, everyone looked at each other and then all bowed their heads down and sat in silence.
tr: Upon this, everyone looked at the person next to them, then lowered their eyes and sat quietly.
es: Each of those present looked at their neighbor, and then, everyone lowered their eyes to the ground and remained silent.

en: Except one man, who got up and went out.
vi: Except for one person who stood up and went outside.
tr: But one of them had stood up and gone outside.
es: Only one, as an exception, got up from their seat and left.

en: “My wife,” said Defarge aloud, addressing Madame Defarge: “I have travelled certain leagues with this good mender of roads, called Jacques.
vi: − Hey dear, - Defarge said loudly to Mrs. Defarge, - I traveled a stretch with this respectable road mender named Jacques.
tr: Defarge called out loudly, "Madam," to Madam Defarge: "Look, I have traveled to many places with this kind-hearted road worker named Jacques.
es: —My dear wife—continued Defarge,—I have traveled a portion of leagues in the company of this good walker, whose name is Santiago.

en: I met him—by accident—a day and half’s journey out of Paris.
vi: I met him, just by chance, when I was a day and a half out of Paris.
tr: I met him –by chance– in a place one and a half days away from Paris.
es: I found him... by chance, a day and a half from Paris.

en: He is a good child, this mender of roads, called Jacques.
vi: This guy is nice, this road mender named Jacques.
tr: His name is Jacques, this road worker is a good boy.
es: He is a good boy and his name is Santiago...

en: Give him to drink, my wife!”
vi: Give him a drink, dear!
tr: Give him a drink, madam!"
es: Give him a drink, dear!

en: A second man got up and went out.
vi: Another person stood up and went outside.
tr: A man got up and went outside.
es: Another man stood up and left the tavern.

en: Madame Defarge set wine before the mender of roads called Jacques, who doffed his blue cap to the company, and drank.
vi: Mrs. Defarge placed a glass of wine in front of road mender Jacques, he lifted his green hat to greet everyone and then drank.
tr: Madame Defarge took off her blue hat, greeted the crowd, and placed the wine in front of Jacques, the road worker, who drank it.
es: Mrs. Defarge served a glass of wine to the good road worker, who greeted her by taking off the blue cap that covered his head, and drank.

en: In the breast of his blouse he carried some coarse dark bread; he ate of this between whiles, and sat munching and drinking near Madame Defarge’s counter.
vi: In his chest pocket, he had a few pieces of black bread; from time to time he would take a bite and just sit at Mrs. Defarge's counter, drinking wine and nibbling.
tr: The man had taken out a black bread with grains from his coat; he occasionally took a bite from it, eating and drinking noisily next to Madame Defarge's counter.
es: He took a piece of rough, black bread from his bosom, sat down next to the counter, and began to eat and drink.

en: A third man got up and went out.
vi: Another person stood up and went outside.
tr: At that moment, a third man got up and left the shop.
es: Another patron, the third one, stood up and left the tavern.

en: Defarge refreshed himself with a draught of wine—but, he took less than was given to the stranger, as being himself a man to whom it was no rarity—and stood waiting until the countryman had made his breakfast.
vi: Defarge also quenched his thirst with a freshly poured glass of wine - but his glass was less full than the guest's, even though wine was something he never lacked - and he just stood waiting until the peasant finished his breakfast.
tr: Defarge took a sip of his wine—his wine was less than the man he brought with him, but after all, he always had it at hand—and refreshed himself, waiting for the peasant to finish his breakfast.
es: Defarge served himself another glass of wine, smaller than the one served to the road-mender, and waited for him to finish his refreshment.

en: He looked at no one present, and no one now looked at him; not even Madame Defarge, who had taken up her knitting, and was at work.
vi: Defarge didn't look at anyone around, and no one looked at him; not even Madame Defarge, who was engrossed in her usual knitting.
tr: The man was not looking at anyone there, and no one was looking at him now; not even Madam Defarge, who lifted her knitting and tended to the shop.
es: He neither looked at any of those present, nor did any of those present look back at him. Madame Defarge had taken the knitting in her hands and worked without looking up and without speaking.

en: “Have you finished your repast, friend?” he asked, in due season.
vi: − Finished eating, my friend? - Defarge spoke up after a while.
tr: "Have you finished your meal, my friend?" asked Defarge, when the time came.
es: —Have you finished lunch already?—asked the innkeeper to the laborer after noticing that he wasn't eating.

en: “Yes, thank you.”
vi: − Okay, thank you, sir.
tr: "Yes, thank you.""
es: —Yes; thank you very much.

en: “Come, then!
vi: − Then let's go!
tr: "Then come on!
es: —Yes; thank you very much.

en: You shall see the apartment that I told you you could occupy.
vi: You will see the room where you will stay as I mentioned.
tr: Let me show you the apartment I said you could stay in.
es: —Then, let's go: I will show you the room I mentioned you would occupy, and which I certainly assure you will be to your liking.

en: It will suit you to a marvel.”
vi: It will surely suit your taste very much.
tr: It's just the right place for you."
es: —Then, let's go: I will show you the room I mentioned you would occupy, and which I certainly assure you will be to your liking.

en: Out of the wine-shop into the street, out of the street into a courtyard, out of the courtyard up a steep staircase, out of the staircase into a garret—formerly the garret where a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very busy, making shoes.
vi: From the tavern to the street, from the street to the inner yard, from the yard up the steep stairs, from the stairs to the attic - where once lived the old man with silver hair, hunched over the workbench, diligently making shoes.
tr: From the wine shop to the street, from the street to a courtyard, from the courtyard to a steep staircase, and from the staircase to an attic – an attic where an old man with thin white hair was busy making shoes at a low workbench, his back hunched – they went.
es: From the shop, they went out to the street, from the street they entered a courtyard, in the courtyard they took a staircase, and at the end of the staircase they found an attic... which was once the dwelling of a man with hair as white as snow, who spent his days sitting on a stool and making shoes.

en: No white-haired man was there now; but, the three men were there who had gone out of the wine-shop singly.
vi: Now, that silver-haired person is no longer there; but the three people present are the ones who had just left the tavern one by one.
tr: There was no longer the white-haired man, but the three men who came out of the wine shop one by one were still there.
es: The one with hair as white as snow was not in the attic, but the three men who had previously left the tavern one by one were.

en: And between them and the white-haired man afar off, was the one small link, that they had once looked in at him through the chinks in the wall.
vi: And between them and the silver-haired person who has gone far away, there is a small connection: they had once stood outside, secretly watching that person through the cracks in the wall.
tr: However, there was a small connection between themselves and the white-haired man in the distance, which was that they had once watched him through the cracks in the wall.
es: The one with hair as white as snow was not in the attic, but the three men who had previously left the tavern one by one were.

en: Defarge closed the door carefully, and spoke in a subdued voice:
vi: Defarge carefully closed the door and then lowered his voice to say: "Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three!
tr: Defarge carefully closed the door and began to speak in a low voice.
es: Defarge carefully closed the door of the garret, and said in a low voice:

en: “Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three!
vi: Defarge carefully closed the door and then lowered his voice to say: "Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three!
tr: "Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three!
es: —Santiago First, Santiago Second, Santiago Third!

en: This is the witness encountered by appointment, by me, Jacques Four.
vi: This is the witness that I, Jacques Four, have arranged to meet."
tr: Here is the witness found by me, Jacques Four.
es: I present to you the witness found by me, Santiago Fourth.

en: He will tell you all.
vi: He will inform you clearly.
tr: He will tell you everything now.
es: He will tell you everything.

en: Speak, Jacques Five!”
vi: Speak, Jacques Five!
tr: Speak up, Jacques Five!"
es: You may speak, Santiago Fifth.

en: The mender of roads, blue cap in hand, wiped his swarthy forehead with it, and said, “Where shall I commence, monsieur?”
vi: The road mender, with his green cap in hand, wiped his dark forehead and said nervously: "Where should I start, sir?"
tr: The road worker, wiping his sunburned forehead with the blue hat in his hand,.said, "Where should I start, monsieur?"
es: The road worker, after drying his sweaty forehead with the blue cap he held in his hand, asked: —Where do I start?

en: “Commence,” was Monsieur Defarge’s not unreasonable reply, “at the commencement.”
vi: "Start from the beginning," Defarge's reply was not without reason.
tr: Mr. Defarge's response was not at all unreasonable, "From the beginning."
es: —You can start at the beginning—replied Defarge very logically.

en: “I saw him then, messieurs,” began the mender of roads, “a year ago this running summer, underneath the carriage of the Marquis, hanging by the chain.
vi: − So, gentlemen, - the road worker began, - last year around this time in the summer, I saw that person hanging under the Marquis's carriage, clinging to the chain.
tr: "When I saw him last summer, gentlemen," the road worker began, "he was hanging from a chain under the Marquis's carriage.
es: —I saw him, gentlemen—began the road worker,—it was a year ago this summer, under the carriage of the Marquis, hanging from the chain.

en: Behold the manner of it.
vi: This is how it happened.
tr: Picture it in your mind.
es: —I saw him, gentlemen—began the road worker,—it was a year ago this summer, under the carriage of the Marquis, hanging from the chain.

en: I leaving my work on the road, the sun going to bed, the carriage of the Marquis slowly ascending the hill, he hanging by the chain—like this.”
vi: At that time, I had finished my work and was about to go home, the sun was about to set, the Marquis's carriage was slowly going up the hill, and that person was hanging onto the chain... like this.
tr: My work on the road was finished, I was leaving, the sun was returning to its bed, and as the Marquis's carriage was slowly climbing the hill, he was hanging from a chain – just like this."
es: I had just finished my task, the sun was setting on the horizon, the Marquis's carriage was laboriously climbing the hill, and he was hanging from the chain like this.

en: Again the mender of roads went through the whole performance; in which he ought to have been perfect by that time, seeing that it had been the infallible resource and indispensable entertainment of his village during a whole year.
vi: The village porter used gestures to recount old stories, and by now he had mastered this performance, realizing that it was an indispensable and always enjoyable entertainment for the villagers throughout the past year.
tr: The road worker reenacted the incident; since his performance had become the village's sole absolute source and inevitable entertainment throughout the entire year, he had now perfected it.
es: The speaker graphically depicted a scene that he had represented thousands of times in the village over an entire year.

en: Jacques
vi: Jacques
tr: Jacques Bir; intervened and asked him if he had seen this man before.
es: Santiago Primero took the floor to ask the traveler if he had seen the man hanging from the chain before.

en: One struck in, and asked if he had ever seen the man before?
vi: Một interrupted and asked the road worker if he had ever seen the person under the car before.
tr: Jacques Bir; intervened and asked him if he had seen this man before.
es: Santiago Primero took the floor to ask the traveler if he had seen the man hanging from the chain before.

en: “Never,” answered the mender of roads, recovering his perpendicular.
vi: − Never, - the road worker said as he straightened up again.
tr: "I've never seen it," replied the road worker, as he returned to an upright position.
es: —Never—replied the one being questioned, regaining an upright position.

en: Jacques
vi: Jacques Ba asked how the road worker could later identify the man?
tr: Jacques
es: —Never—replied the one being questioned, regaining an upright position.

en: Three demanded how he afterwards recognised him then?
vi: Jacques Ba asked how the road worker could later identify the man?
tr: Three then asked how he could recognize him later.
es: Santiago Tercero asked how he had been able to recognize him later, having not seen him until that day.

en: “By his tall figure,” said the mender of roads, softly, and with his finger at his nose.
vi: By his tall stature, - the road worker replied quietly, picking his nose with one finger. -
tr: "From his tall height," said the road worker in a soft tone, placing his finger on his nose.
es: —I recognized him by his tall stature—said the road worker, placing the index finger of his right hand on his nose.

en: “When Monsieur the Marquis demands that evening, ‘Say, what is he like?’
vi: When the Marquis asked that evening, "Hey, what did that guy look like?"
tr: "When Monsieur Marquis asked me that evening, 'What does this man look like?'
es: —When that night the Marquis asked what signs he had, I replied: "He is tall like a specter."

en: I make response, ‘Tall as a spectre.’”
vi: I answered, "As tall as a ghost!".
tr: I said, 'He is tall like a ghost.'"
es: —When that night the Marquis asked what signs he had, I replied: "He is tall like a specter."

en: “You should have said, short as a dwarf,” returned Jacques Two.
vi: − Should have said "loắt choắt" like a dwarf, - Jacques Hai retorted.
tr: "I think you should have said as short as a dwarf," said Jacques Two.
es: —You should have said "small as a dwarf," observed Santiago Segundo.

en: “But what did I know?
vi: − But how could I have known at that time!
tr: "But how could I have known?
es: —And what did I know?

en: The deed was not then accomplished, neither did he confide in me.
vi: At that time, the event had not yet occurred, and that person had not confided in me either.
tr: The action was not yet complete, and he didn't trust me anyway.
es: The feat had not been committed, nor had he confided in me.

en: Observe!
vi: See!
tr: Just think!
es: But keep in mind that, even under those circumstances, I declared nothing, said nothing.

en: Under those circumstances even, I do not offer my testimony.
vi: But even in that situation, I did not reveal anything.
tr: Even in that situation, I didn't say much.
es: But keep in mind that, even under those circumstances, I declared nothing, said nothing.

en: Monsieur the Marquis indicates me with his finger, standing near our little fountain, and says, ‘To me!
vi: The Marquis pointed at me while standing near the fountain in my village and said, "Bring that brat to me for questioning!"
tr: Monsieur Marquis stood by our little fountain, pointed at me with his finger, and said, 'Bring me that scoundrel!'
es: A good proof of this is that the Marquis, pointing at me with his finger, shouted: "Bring me that scoundrel!"

en: Bring that rascal!’
vi: The Marquis pointed at me while standing near the fountain in my village and said, "Bring that brat to me for questioning!"
tr: Monsieur Marquis stood by our little fountain, pointed at me with his finger, and said, 'Bring me that scoundrel!'
es: No, no, gentlemen!

en: My faith, messieurs, I offer nothing.”
vi: To be honest, gentlemen, I did not reveal anything.
tr: Honestly, gentlemen, I didn't go and say anything."
es: I said nothing!

en: “He is right there, Jacques,” murmured Defarge, to him who had interrupted.
vi: − "He's right, Jacques," Defarge said softly to the person who had just interrupted.
tr: "You're right, Jacques," murmured Defarge to the person who interrupted.
es: —You are right, Santiago—said Defarge.

en: “Go on!”
vi: "Continue! − Alright!" the road worker said with a secretive air.
tr: "Alright, go on!"
es: —Continue.

en: “Good!” said the mender of roads, with an air of mystery.
vi: "Continue! − Alright!" the road worker said with a secretive air.
tr: "Good!" said the road worker with a mysterious air.
es: —Well then—continued the road worker with an air of mystery.—The tall man has gone missing and they are looking for him... since when?

en: “The tall man is lost, and he is sought—how many months?
vi: "That tall man disappeared, and they hunted for... how many months?
tr: "Then the tall man disappears, they look for him – how many months pass?
es: —Well then—continued the road worker with an air of mystery.—The tall man has gone missing and they are looking for him... since when?

en: Nine, ten, eleven?”
vi: Nine, ten, eleven months?
tr: Nine, ten, maybe eleven?"
es: Since nine, ten, eleven months?

en: “No matter, the number,” said Defarge.
vi: − The number of months doesn't matter," Defarge said.
tr: "Forget the number;" said Defarge.
es: —The number of months is the least relevant thing—replied Defarge.

en: “He is well hidden, but at last he is unluckily found.
vi: "He hid well, but unfortunately, he was eventually exposed.
tr: "It's well hidden but unfortunately, it gets found in the end.
es: —He was well hidden, but in the end, they unfortunately found him.

en: Go on!”
vi: Continue! −"
tr: Continue!"
es: Continue.

en: “I am again at work upon the hill-side, and the sun is again about to go to bed.
vi: Then I went back to work on the hillside, and the sun was about to set again.
tr: "One day, I am working on the hill again and the sun is about to set.
es: —Once again I am working on the hillside and the sun is also setting behind the Western mountains, just like the previous time.

en: I am collecting my tools to descend to my cottage down in the village below, where it is already dark, when I raise my eyes, and see coming over the hill six soldiers.
vi: I was packing up my tools to go down the hill to my home in the village below, it was already dusk, when I looked up and saw six soldiers coming over the hill.
tr: I am gathering my tools to return to my house in the village below, it has already darkened down there, then I lift my head and see six soldiers coming down the hill.
es: I gather my tools to go down to the village, where night has already fallen, when, as I lift my eyes, I see six soldiers appear at the top of the hill.

en: In the midst of them is a tall man with his arms bound—tied to his sides—like this!”
vi: In the midst of those soldiers was a tall man, his hands tied... tightly tied to his sides... like this!
tr: Right in the middle of them is a tall man with his arms tied – they tied them from the side like this!"
es: In the midst of the soldiers, I see a man with his arms tied to his sides... in this manner.

en: With the aid of his indispensable cap, he represented a man with his elbows bound fast at his hips, with cords that were knotted behind him.
vi: Using his inseparable hat as a prop, he mimicked the motion of a person with their elbows bound tightly to their waist, the rope knotted securely behind their back.
tr: He portrayed a man whose elbows were tightly bound to his hips, accompanied by the hat he never let go of, with knots tied at the back.
es: With the help of his indispensable blue hat, the speaker admirably represents a man whose elbows are tied to his waist.

en: “I stand aside, messieurs, by my heap of stones, to see the soldiers and their prisoner pass (for it is a solitary road, that, where any spectacle is well worth looking at), and at first, as they approach, I see no more than that they are six soldiers with a tall man bound, and that they are almost black to my sight—except on the side of the sun going to bed, where they have a red edge, messieurs.
vi: − I was standing to one side, gentlemen, next to the pile of rocks, watching some soldiers and prisoners pass by; since this road is deserted, anything happening here is worth watching. At first, when they arrived, I only saw six soldiers with a tall prisoner who was tied up, almost completely black so I couldn't see his face; except for the side facing the setting sun which was glowing red.
tr: "Then, gentlemen, I move to the side, over by the piles of stones, so I can see the soldiers and the prisoner passing by (after all, it's a deserted road, there's nothing worth looking at) as they approach, I see nothing but six soldiers and a tall man with his arms tied, and they are all pitch black –but those on the side where the sun is setting seem to be outlined with a red line, gentlemen.
es: —I step aside, gentlemen, positioning myself next to a pile, to watch the soldiers and their prisoner pass by, as it is a military road where nothing passes that is not worth watching, and when they approached, at first, I saw nothing but six soldiers escorting a bound man, a tall man, and that both soldiers and prisoner appeared black, except for the part facing the sunset, where I noticed some reddish lines.

en: Also, I see that their long shadows are on the hollow ridge on the opposite side of the road, and are on the hill above it, and are like the shadows of giants.
vi: Then I saw their shadows stretch long on the other side of the road, and on the hillside above, like the shadows of giants.
tr: Also, I see their long shadows cast on the ditch on the other side of the road and the hill above it, you would think that the shadows of giants had fallen."
es: I also observed that the shadows cast by their bodies crossed the road in its entirety, as if they were the shadows of giants.

en: Also, I see that they are covered with dust, and that the dust moves with them as they come, tramp, tramp!
vi: Then I saw them covered in dust, wherever they went, the dust rose up in clouds!
tr: "And they are all covered in dust, and as they march with a steady rhythm, the dust moves along with them!"
es: I also saw that they were covered in dust, and that they raised clouds of dust as they marched.

en: But when they advance quite near to me, I recognise the tall man, and he recognises me.
vi: But when they got really close, I recognized the tall man, and he recognized me.
tr: "But when they get close enough, I recognize the tall man, and he recognizes me.
es: When they passed in front of me, I recognized the tall man they had as a prisoner, and he recognized me as well.

en: Ah, but he would be well content to precipitate himself over the hill-side once again, as on the evening when he and I first encountered, close to the same spot!”
vi: Well, he must have been very eager to throw himself down that hillside and escape again, just like the afternoon when I first saw him, also near that very spot!
tr: Ah, just like the evening we first met, in the same places, how wonderful it would be if he threw himself down the hill again!""
es: Ah! I well know that the prisoner would have thrown himself headfirst down the hillside as he did the afternoon I first saw him in the same place!

en: He described it as if he were there, and it was evident that he saw it vividly; perhaps he had not seen much in his life.
vi: The guy described it as if he was there in person, clearly he had seen it vividly; perhaps in his life he rarely encountered such an event.
tr: He was describing it as if he had gone there again, and it was clear that he was reliving the events; perhaps he hadn't seen much in his life until now.
es: Next, he gave a detailed and vivid description of the scene he had just mentioned.

en: “I do not show the soldiers that I recognise the tall man; he does not show the soldiers that he recognises me; we do it, and we know it, with our eyes.
vi: − I didn't let the soldiers know that I recognized the tall man; he didn't let the soldiers know that he recognized me either; both sides acted the same way, both sides understood each other, just a glance was enough to understand.
tr: "I never let the soldiers know that I recognize the tall man; he doesn't let on that he recognizes me either, but we understand each other through our eyes, we see this.
es: —Neither did I let the soldiers understand that I had recognized the prisoner, nor did the prisoner let the soldiers see that he had recognized me. Instead, we conveyed it to each other through the language of the eyes.

en: ‘Come on!’ says the chief of that company, pointing to the village, ‘bring him fast to his tomb!’ and they bring him faster.
vi: "Go on!" then the commanding soldier pointed down to the village and said, "hurry to your grave!" then urged the prisoner to move faster.
tr: The soldier in charge points to the village and says, 'Come on! Take him to his grave immediately!' and the men speed up.
es: “Alive, alive!” said the leader of the soldiers.—“Let’s take him quickly to the pit!”; and indeed, they quickened their pace.

en: I follow.
vi: I followed.
tr: I'm following them too.
es: I followed them.

en: His arms are swelled because of being bound so tight, his wooden shoes are large and clumsy, and he is lame.
vi: His arms were swollen because they were tied too tightly, the large wooden shoes were cumbersome, and he limped.
tr: They've tied him up so tightly that his arms are swollen, his wooden shoes are huge and clumsy, and as if that weren't enough, he's also limping.
es: The prisoner’s arms were swollen due to the brutal pressure of the ropes, and since his clogs were too big and very heavy, he walked with a limp.

en: Because he is lame, and consequently slow, they drive him with their guns—like this!”
vi: Because he limped, he was slow, and the soldiers kept prodding him with their guns... like this!
tr: Of course, he walks slowly because he's limping, and the soldiers are pushing him with their rifles – exactly like that!"
es: One who limps cannot walk quickly, and since the soldiers wanted to make the journey swiftly, they drove the prisoner in this manner.

en: He imitated the action of a man’s being impelled forward by the butt-ends of muskets.
vi: He demonstrated the action of a person being pushed forward by the butt of a musket.
tr: He portrayed a man being pushed with a rifle butt.
es: The road worker imitated the movements of the man who is forced to walk with rifle butts.

en: “As they descend the hill like madmen running a race, he falls.
vi: − Then when the whole group ran down the hill like they were being chased by ghosts, he tripped and fell, and the soldiers laughed loudly as they pulled him up.
tr: "As they race down the hill like madmen competing with each other, the man falls to the ground.
es: —The prisoner fell flat on his face while they ran down the slope like madmen.

en: They laugh and pick him up again.
vi: − Then when the whole group ran down the hill like they were being chased by ghosts, he tripped and fell, and the soldiers laughed loudly as they pulled him up.
tr: The soldiers laugh and pick him up from the ground.
es: The soldiers burst out laughing and lifted him up.

en: His face is bleeding and covered with dust, but he cannot touch it; thereupon they laugh again.
vi: His face was bleeding, covered in dirt, but he couldn't raise his hand to wipe it; seeing this, the soldiers laughed even louder.
tr: The man's face is bleeding and covered in dirt, but he can't touch his face; so they laugh again.
es: His face was bleeding and covered in dirt, but the poor man couldn't bring his hands to it, which, seen by the soldiers, led to more laughter.

en: They bring him into the village; all the village runs to look; they take him past the mill, and up to the prison; all the village sees the prison gate open in the darkness of the night, and swallow him—like this!”
vi: They took him into the village; the whole village ran out to see; they took him past the mill and then up to the prison; all the villagers saw the prison gate open in the darkness and swallow the prisoner... like this!
tr: They bring him to the village; the whole village runs to see him; they walk him past the mill and onto the road leading to the prison; all the villagers witness the prison door opening and swallowing the man in the darkness of the night – just like that!"
es: They took him to the village, which came out en masse to see him, and from the village to the mill, and from the mill to the dungeon. The entire village saw how the dungeon door opened and swallowed the prisoner in this manner:

en: He opened his mouth as wide as he could, and shut it with a sounding snap of his teeth.
vi: The man tried to open his mouth as wide as possible and then snapped it shut, making his teeth clack together with a sharp sound.
tr: He opened his mouth as wide as he could and made a harsh sound by clashing his teeth together.
es: The road worker opened an enormous mouth, and closed it with a clatter produced by his teeth clashing violently.

en: Observant of his unwillingness to mar the effect by opening it again, Defarge said, “Go on, Jacques.”
vi: Seeing that the man didn't want to open his mouth quickly to prolong the suspense, Defarge said: − Continue, Jacques.
tr: Realizing that he did not want to open his mouth again to avoid ruining the effect he had created, Defarge said, "Go on, Jacques."
es: He wanted to represent the scene with such verisimilitude that he continued with his mouth closed until Defarge, after a long wait, said: —Go ahead, Santiago.

en: “All the village,” pursued the mender of roads, on tiptoe and in a low voice, “withdraws; all the village whispers by the fountain; all the village sleeps; all the village dreams of that unhappy one, within the locks and bars of the prison on the crag, and never to come out of it, except to perish.
vi: − The whole village returned, - the road worker continued, in a sneaky manner, whispering, - the whole village murmured by the fountain; the whole village went to sleep; the whole village dreamed of that unfortunate man being locked behind bars, padlocks in the prison on the cliff, and never leaving that place unless he died.
tr: Standing on his tiptoes and speaking in a low voice, "The whole village," the road worker continued, "is retreating and whispering by the fountain; then they all go to sleep; the whole village sees the same unhappy person in their dreams, imprisoned behind the locked doors and iron bars on the rocks, the prisoner who will only leave here as a corpse."
es: —The entire village withdraws,—continued the traveler, lowering his voice and standing on his tiptoes,—the entire village gathers around the fountain and speaks; the entire village retreats to their beds; the entire village dreams of that unfortunate one, who is found between walls and irons, locked in the dungeon that rises at the edge of the cliff, from which he will only emerge to die.

en: In the morning, with my tools upon my shoulder, eating my morsel of black bread as I go, I make a circuit by the prison, on my way to my work.
vi: In the morning, carrying my tools on my shoulder, quickly eating a few pieces of black bread, I went, I passed by that prison on my way to work.
tr: In the morning, with my tools on my shoulder, eating a piece of dark bread, I go to work, circling around the prison on my way.
es: The next morning, I throw my tools over my shoulders, take a piece of black bread, and taking a detour, pass by the prison before heading to work.

en: There I see him, high up, behind the bars of a lofty iron cage, bloody and dusty as last night, looking through.
vi: When I got there, I saw him, way up there, behind the bars of a tall iron cage, still covered in dust and blood as the night before, looking out.
tr: There, high up, I see him behind the bars of a majestic iron cage, his face covered in blood and dust just like the previous night, looking out.
es: There I see him, behind the sturdy bars of that iron cage, covered in blood and dust, just as he was the night before.

en: He has no hand free, to wave to me; I dare not call to him; he regards me like a dead man.”
vi: He was still tied up so he couldn't wave; I didn't dare call out; he looked at me as if he were already dead.
tr: Since his hands are tied, he can't wave; and I don't dare call out to him; at that moment, he is no different from a dead man."
es: He cannot extend a hand to me, because none have been left free; I do not dare to call out to him nor does he dare to speak to me; his appearance is that of a dead man.

en: Defarge and the three glanced darkly at one another.
vi: Defarge and the three others looked at each other sorrowfully, their faces dark, restrained, and full of hatred as they listened to the peasant's story; although they did not show it, their demeanor was full of authority.
tr: Defarge and the three men exchanged subtle glances.
es: Both Defarge and the three listeners exchange grim looks, looks that breathe hatred and vengeance, as they listen to the story from the lips of the traveler.

en: The looks of all of them were dark, repressed, and revengeful, as they listened to the countryman’s story; the manner of all of them, while it was secret, was authoritative too.
vi: Defarge and the three others looked at each other sorrowfully, their faces dark, restrained, and full of hatred as they listened to the peasant's story; although they did not show it, their demeanor was full of authority.
tr: While listening to the peasant's story, their expressions were filled with gloom, anger, and hatred; there was both a mysterious and stern air about them all.
es: The attitude of the three, although reserved, is authoritative, as if they constituted a very severe tribunal.

en: They had the air of a rough tribunal; Jacques One and Two sitting on the old pallet-bed, each with his chin resting on his hand, and his eyes intent on the road-mender; Jacques Three, equally intent, on one knee behind them, with his agitated hand always gliding over the network of fine nerves about his mouth and nose; Defarge standing between them and the narrator, whom he had stationed in the light of the window, by turns looking from him to them, and from them to him.
vi: They looked like ruthless judges; Jacques One and Two sat on the rickety bed, both resting their chins in their hands, eyes intently watching the road worker; Jacques Three knelt on one knee beside them, also watching intently, his restless hand rubbing the sensitive skin around his nose and mouth; Defarge stood between the three Jacques and the storyteller, while the storyteller blocked the light from the window, constantly looking from Defarge to the three others and then from the three others back to Defarge.
tr: The room was dominated by a heavy courtroom atmosphere; Jacques One and Jacques Two were sitting on an old bench, hands on their chins, listening intently to the road worker; Jacques Three, who was just as attentive, was kneeling right behind them, nervously and constantly rubbing around his mouth and nose; standing in the light reflected from the window between these three men and the storyteller, Defarge kept looking back and forth between the men and the road worker.
es: The First and Second Santiagos are seated on the old mattress, their respective chins resting on their hands and their eyes fixed on the narrator. The Third Santiago has one knee on the ground and continuously passes his nervous hand over his mouth and nose, while Defarge, standing between the group formed by the three Santiagos and the narrator, sometimes looks at the latter, sometimes turns his severe face towards the former.

en: “Go on, Jacques,” said Defarge.
vi: − Continue, Jacques, - Defarge said.
tr: "Continue, Jacques," said Defarge.
es: —Go ahead, Santiago—says Defarge.

en: “He remains up there in his iron cage some days.
vi: − He stayed on that iron cage for several days.
tr: "They kept the prisoner in the iron cage for a while.
es: —In that iron cage, they have him locked up for a number of days.

en: The village looks at him by stealth, for it is afraid.
vi: The whole village secretly watched because they were afraid.
tr: The villagers are secretly watching him because they are afraid of him.
es: The village sees him, but cautiously, for they are afraid.

en: But it always looks up, from a distance, at the prison on the crag; and in the evening, when the work of the day is achieved and it assembles to gossip at the fountain, all faces are turned towards the prison.
vi: But they always stood from afar, looking up at the prison on the cliff; then in the evening, when the day's work was done, everyone gathered at the fountain, all facing and looking up at that prison.
tr: But from a distance, they constantly watch this prison on top of the cliffs, and when all the work is done and they gather at the fountain to gossip, they all turn their faces towards the prison.
es: During the day, they watch the prison from afar, and at night, when the day's work is done and they gather by the fountain, all faces turn towards the jail.

en: Formerly, they were turned towards the posting-house; now, they are turned towards the prison.
vi: Previously, everyone looked towards the post station; but at that time, they all looked up at the prison.
tr: Previously, they always turned their faces towards the post office, but now they all face the prison.
es: Before, the object of the entire village's gaze was the post house: today it is the prison.

en: They whisper at the fountain, that although condemned to death he will not be executed; they say that petitions have been presented in Paris, showing that he was enraged and made mad by the death of his child; they say that a petition has been presented to the King himself.
vi: They whispered to each other by the fountain that even if he was sentenced to death, he wouldn't be executed; they said a petition had been submitted in Paris, stating that he went mad from grief over his child's death; they said the petition had been presented to the King himself.
tr: At the fountain, they whisper that although the man was sentenced to death, he will not be executed; they say a petition was sent to Paris for his pardon, explaining that the man went mad and lost control of himself after his child's death; another petition was personally submitted to the King.
es: In the conversations that the village holds by the fountain, they say that even if he were sentenced to death, the sentence would not be carried out; they say that petitions have been presented in Paris demonstrating that the unfortunate man went mad and did not know what he was doing as a result of his son's tragic death; they say that a petition has been presented to the King himself...

en: What do I know?
vi: How would I know about this!
tr: Who knows?
es: Who knows?

en: It is possible.
vi: It could be true.
tr: It's possible.
es: It could be!

en: Perhaps yes, perhaps no.”
vi: Maybe it is, maybe it isn't.
tr: Maybe it's true, maybe it's not."
es: I do not claim either yes or no.

en: “Listen then, Jacques,” Number One of that name sternly interposed.
vi: − Listen here, Jacques, - Number One coldly interrupted.
tr: Number one, "Listen then Jacques," he objected harshly.
es: —Listen carefully, Santiago! —interrupted Santiago Primero with a harsh tone. —

en: “Know that a petition was presented to the King and Queen.
vi: Indeed, a petition was presented to the King and Queen.
tr: "Know this. A petition was presented to the King and Queen.
es: Know that a petition has been presented to the King and Queen.

en: All here, yourself excepted, saw the King take it, in his carriage in the street, sitting beside the Queen.
vi: Except for you, everyone here saw the King receive the petition, right in his carriage while traveling through the streets, with the Queen sitting beside him.
tr: Everyone here except you saw the King receive this petition, he was in his carriage on the street, sitting next to the Queen.
es: Everyone here, except for you, knows that the King took it in his hands while he was riding in a carriage down the street, seated next to the Queen.

en: It is Defarge whom you see here, who, at the hazard of his life, darted out before the horses, with the petition in his hand.”
vi: It was Defarge, standing right here, who risked his life to dash forward and present that petition.
tr: The one you see before you now, with the petition in hand, risking his life by throwing himself in front of the horses, was Defarge."
es: Defarge, whom you are seeing, risked his life to stand in front of the horses holding the petition in his hand.

en: “And once again listen, Jacques!” said the kneeling Number Three: his fingers ever wandering over and over those fine nerves, with a strikingly greedy air, as if he hungered for something—that was neither food nor drink; “the guard, horse and foot, surrounded the petitioner, and struck him blows.
vi: − It's not over yet, Jacques! - The voice of Number Three, who was kneeling; his hands constantly rubbing around the sensitive skin area with a greedy look as if he was starving for something that wasn't food or drink. - The guards, both mounted and on foot, surrounded this petitioner and beat him up.
tr: "Listen to this too, Jacques!" said Jacques Three, who was kneeling: His fingers were incessantly, insatiably wandering over his face, as if craving something – but it was neither food nor drink; "the petitioner was surrounded by guards, horses, and infantry, and they started beating him up.
es: —Listen to me now, Santiago! —interjected Santiago Tercero, always with one knee on the ground and waving his nervous fingers.—The escort, both on foot and on horseback, fell upon the supplicant and bruised him with blows!

en: You hear?”
vi: Do you understand clearly?
tr: Do you understand?"
es: Do you understand?

en: “I hear, messieurs.”
vi: − Yes, we understand clearly, sirs.
tr: "I understand, gentlemen."
es: —I understand, gentlemen.

en: “Go on then,” said Defarge.
vi: − Then continue, - Defarge said.
tr: "Then go on," said Defarge.
es: —Go ahead, then—said Defarge.

en: “Again; on the other hand, they whisper at the fountain,” resumed the countryman, “that he is brought down into our country to be executed on the spot, and that he will very certainly be executed.
vi: − Then, there's more, - the peasant continued, - they are also whispering that he was taken down to my village to be executed on the spot, he will definitely be executed.
tr: "On the other hand, according to the whispers at the fountain," continued the villager, "he was brought here to be executed on the spot and will definitely be executed.
es: —There are also people who claim that he has been brought to our country to be executed here, and that he will inevitably be executed.

en: They even whisper that because he has slain Monseigneur, and because Monseigneur was the father of his tenants—serfs—what you will—he will be executed as a parricide.
vi: They are also gossiping that he killed a high official, and since the high official is like a parent to the tenants... or serfs... call it whatever you want... he will be executed like someone who killed their parents.
tr: They are even whispering that he will be executed as a patricide because he murdered the Monsignor, and since the Monsignor was the father of the peasants – the slaves – well, what can you do.
es: They also say that, since he killed the lord, and the lord is the father of his vassals, he will be executed as a parricide.

en: One old man says at the fountain, that his right hand, armed with the knife, will be burnt off before his face; that, into wounds which will be made in his arms, his breast, and his legs, there will be poured boiling oil, melted lead, hot resin, wax, and sulphur; finally, that he will be torn limb from limb by four strong horses.
vi: An old man at the fountain said that his right hand, the hand that held the knife, will be burned right in front of him; then both arms will be cut off, both legs will be cut off, his chest will be split open; then boiling oil, molten lead, hot pitch, melted wax with sulfur will be poured into the wounds; finally, he will be quartered by horses.
tr: According to an old man at the fountain, the convict's right hand, the one that held the knife, will be burned before his eyes; hot oil, molten lead, hot resin, wax, and sulfur will be poured into the wounds opened on his arm, chest, and legs; and finally, his arms and legs will be pulled in four different directions by four strong horses.
es: An old man says that they will burn his right hand alive, armed with a knife; that in the wounds they will open on his arms, chest, and legs, they will pour boiling oil, molten lead, burning resin, wax, and sulfur, and finally, that tied to the tails of four horses, he will be torn apart.

en: That old man says, all this was actually done to a prisoner who made an attempt on the life of the late King, Louis Fifteen.
vi: The old man said that in reality, a prisoner had already undergone this punishment for attempting to assassinate the late king, Louis XV.
tr: Then the same old man says that all of this was exactly applied to a convict who attempted to kill the late King, Louis XV.
es: The same old man claims that this is what they did to a criminal who attempted against the life of our late King Louis XV.

en: But how do I know if he lies?
vi: But whether he was telling the truth or not, I don't know.
tr: But I am just repeating what he said.
es: Could it be true? Could it be false?

en: I am not a scholar.”
vi: I never went to school.
tr: I don't know."
es: I don't know: I am not wise.

en: “Listen once again then, Jacques!” said the man with the restless hand and the craving air.
vi: − Then listen, Jacques! - Said the person with restless hands and a hungry look.
tr: "Then listen once more, Jacques!" said the greedy man with his hands fidgeting.
es: —Listen again, Santiago!

en: “The name of that prisoner was Damiens, and it was all done in open day, in the open streets of this city of Paris; and nothing was more noticed in the vast concourse that saw it done, than the crowd of ladies of quality and fashion, who were full of eager attention to the last—to the last, Jacques, prolonged until nightfall, when he had lost two legs and an arm, and still breathed!
vi: - That prisoner’s name was Damiens, and all those tortures were carried out in broad daylight, right in the streets of Paris; among the dense crowd that came to watch the execution, the most notable were the ladies and the affluent women; they were eager, watching intently until the very end... until the very end, do you hear, Jacques! That means until midnight, when that prisoner had already had both legs and one arm cut off, and was still breathing!
tr: "The name of that prisoner was Damiens, all of this happened in the streets of Paris, in broad daylight, and nothing was more interesting in that huge crowd than the eagerness of those elegant and fancy ladies to witness the prisoner's final moments – the final moments, Jacques, the final moments lasted until evening, even when both his legs and one arm were torn off, the man was still breathing!
es: —exclaimed the third of this name.—The convict you speak of was named Damiens, and the program you just described was carried out in broad daylight and on the streets of Paris. Regarding the impression it made on those who witnessed it, I will only tell you, Santiago, that the multitude of ladies of the highest nobility who came to witness the execution did not want to miss any detail; they watched it with rapture until the end... until the end, Santiago, which did not come until nightfall, hours after the unfortunate man had lost two legs and an arm... and he was still breathing! That happened...

en: And it was done—why, how old are you?”
vi: This happened when... oh, how old are you? −
tr: They did it all exactly – how old are you?"
es: But tell me, how old are you?

en: “Thirty-five,” said the mender of roads, who looked sixty.
vi: Thirty-five, - said the road worker, who looked as old as sixty.
tr: "Thirty-five," said the road worker who looked sixty years old.
es: —Thirty-five—replied the road worker, who looked sixty.

en: “It was done when you were more than ten years old; you might have seen it.”
vi: − So at that time you were just over ten years old; you could have witnessed this incident.
tr: "So this happened when you were around ten years old; you might have seen it.""
es: —Too many!

en: “Enough!” said Defarge, with grim impatience.
vi: − Enough! - Defarge's voice was impatient and fierce.
tr: "Enough!" said Defarge, with a grumpy impatience. "May God not punish you!
es: —murmured Defarge impatiently.

en: “Long live the Devil! Go on.”
vi: - Long live the devil! Continue.
tr: Go on, continue."
es: —murmured Defarge impatiently.

en: “Well!
vi: − Agreed!
tr: "Alright!
es: —Continue.

en: Some whisper this, some whisper that; they speak of nothing else; even the fountain appears to fall to that tune.
vi: Rumors spread this way and that; everyone was talking about the prisoner; even the fountain seemed to be gossiping about it.
tr: Some say one thing; some say another, but everyone is talking about this; it's as if even the fountain is flowing in the same tone.
es: —They talk about nothing else in the village: even the fountain seems to have learned the same refrain.

en: At length, on Sunday night when all the village is asleep, come soldiers, winding down from the prison, and their guns ring on the stones of the little street.
vi: Finally, on a Sunday night when the whole village was asleep; soldiers appeared, a winding procession from the prison down, the clinking of their weapons echoing on the village's stone streets.
tr: After a while, on Sunday night when the whole village is asleep, the soldiers come; they descend the prison road, and their weapons clink on the stones of the narrow street.
es: Finally, on a Sunday night, the soldiers arrive and head to the prison.

en: Workmen dig, workmen hammer, soldiers laugh and sing; in the morning, by the fountain, there is raised a gallows forty feet high, poisoning the water.”
vi: Laborers dug the ground, laborers hammered, soldiers laughed and sang; by morning, next to the fountain stood a gallows fifteen meters high, contaminating the entire water source.
tr: Workers are digging; workers are hammering nails; soldiers are singing and laughing; in the morning, next to the fountain, a ten-meter-high gallows, which pours its poison into the water, rises."
es: Workers digging, workers hammering, soldiers laughing out loud, and when day breaks, a forty-foot-high gallows stands next to the fountain, whose shadow poisons the waters.

en: The mender of roads looked through rather than at the low ceiling, and pointed as if he saw the gallows somewhere in the sky.
vi: The road laborer looked up at the low ceiling, but his gaze seemed to pierce through the roof, directed at some gallows in the sky.
tr: When the road worker turned his eyes to the low ceiling, he saw much more beyond it and pointed to the sky as if he had seen a gallows.
es: Workers digging, workers hammering, soldiers laughing out loud, and when day breaks, a forty-foot-high gallows stands next to the fountain, whose shadow poisons the waters.

en: “All work is stopped, all assemble there, nobody leads the cows out, the cows are there with the rest.
vi: − Everything came to a halt; everyone gathered there, no one took the cows out to graze, and the cows stood together with the people in one place.
tr: "All work stops, everyone gathers at the fountain, no one takes the cows to graze, they are there with the villagers.
es: Everyone stops working, everyone gathers there, the cows don't go out to the field because they don't want to miss the spectacle either.

en: At midday, the roll of drums.
vi: By noon, the sound of a drum was heard.
tr: At exactly noon, the drums thunder.
es: At noon, the drums thunder.

en: Soldiers have marched into the prison in the night, and he is in the midst of many soldiers.
vi: The soldiers had entered the prison during the night and now were leading the prisoner out.
tr: The soldiers went to the dungeon at night and brought the prisoner, now he stands in the midst of a bunch of soldiers.
es: The soldiers, who went to the prison the night before, return with him in the middle.

en: He is bound as before, and in his mouth there is a gag—tied so, with a tight string, making him look almost as if he laughed.”
vi: He was still tied up as before, with a rag stuffed in his mouth... tightly bound with a taut rope, making him look like he was grinning. -
tr: They tied the man as before, and there is a gag in his mouth – they tied his mouth so tightly that he looks like he is smiling."
es: The convict is tied up, they have put a gag in his mouth secured with a rope in such a way that it looks like he is smiling.

en: He suggested it, by creasing his face with his two thumbs, from the corners of his mouth to his ears.
vi: The man recalled that image by grimacing, pulling his mouth wide with his thumbs to his ears. -
tr: He tried to demonstrate this by pulling his face with his thumbs from the corners of his mouth to his ears.
es: The convict is tied up, they have put a gag in his mouth secured with a rope in such a way that it looks like he is smiling.

en: “On the top of the gallows is fixed the knife, blade upwards, with its point in the air.
vi: At the top of the gallows, a knife was embedded, its sharp blade pointing skyward.
tr: "They placed the knife on top of the gallows, with the sharp side facing up, the tip pointing to the sky.
es: At the top of the gallows, they have placed a knife with its point facing up.

en: He is hanged there forty feet high—and is left hanging, poisoning the water.”
vi: He was hung up fifteen meters high... and dangled there, contaminating the water tower below.
tr: They hanged him at a height of ten meters – by poisoning the water, he remained hanging there."
es: The convict is hanged forty feet high, and his corpse remains swinging... poisoning the fountain's waters with its shadow.

en: They looked at one another, as he used his blue cap to wipe his face, on which the perspiration had started afresh while he recalled the spectacle.
vi: They looked at each other, and the countryman used his green hat to wipe his face, which was covered in sweat, as he recounted the scene.
tr: The road worker had started sweating again at the sight before his eyes and used his blue hat to wipe his face while the others looked at each other.
es: The listeners exchanged somber looks, while the narrator wiped the sweat from his face with the blue cap.

en: “It is frightful, messieurs.
vi: − It was terrifying, gentlemen.
tr: "Very terrible, gentlemen.
es: —It's horrifying, gentlemen! —he replied.

en: How can the women and the children draw water!
vi: How could women and children fetch water to use!
tr: How will women and children get water from there now!
es: —How are the women and children supposed to drink water from the fountain?

en: Who can gossip of an evening, under that shadow!
vi: Who would dare to chat under that shadow anymore!
tr: Who will gossip under that shadow in the evening!
es: Who is the daring one that dares to speak during the night under that shadow?

en: Under it, have I said?
vi: The shadow of the gallows, did you hear clearly, gentlemen?
tr: Under it, didn't I say?
es: Under the shadow, I said?

en: When I left the village, Monday evening as the sun was going to bed, and looked back from the hill, the shadow struck across the church, across the mill, across the prison—seemed to strike across the earth, messieurs, to where the sky rests upon it!”
vi: When I left the village, on Monday evening at sunset, and stood on the hill looking back, the shadow of that hanging body fell over the church, over the mill, over the prison... it seemed to stretch across the ground, gentlemen, all the way to the horizon!
tr: On Monday evening, as the sun was about to set, when I left the village, when I turned around while climbing the hill, that shadow was still swaying in front of the church, the mill, and the prison – gentlemen, it seemed to cover everywhere under this sky, the entire earth!"
es: When I left the village on Monday afternoon, almost at sunset, I turned my head from the top of the hill and saw that the shadow covered the church, covered the mill, covered the prison on the cliff, covered all the land, gentlemen, that has the blue sky as its roof!

en: The hungry man gnawed one of his fingers as he looked at the other three, and his finger quivered with the craving that was on him.
vi: The hungry Jacques gnawed at his fingers while he watched the other three, his fingertips trembling with ravenous desire.
tr: The hungry man had started to gnaw on one of his fingers while looking at the other three, and his finger trembled under the effect of his hunger.
es: The listener who was kneeling on the ground seemed to be hungry for something... that was neither food nor drink.

en: “That’s all, messieurs.
vi: − That's it, gentlemen.
tr: "So it is, gentlemen.
es: —I have finished, gentlemen.

en: I left at sunset (as I had been warned to do), and I walked on, that night and half next day, until I met (as I was warned I should) this comrade.
vi: I left at sunset, as advised, and kept going all through that night and the following day, until I met this friend, just as I had been told.
tr: I left there at sunset (as I was asked) and walked through that night and until noon the next day, until I met this friend (as I was told).
es: I left the village moments before sunset, as I just mentioned, and walked all night and half of the following day, until I found, as I also mentioned, this comrade.

en: With him, I came on, now riding and now walking, through the rest of yesterday and through last night.
vi: I traveled with him, sometimes by carriage, sometimes on foot, until the end of yesterday and all through last night.
tr: Then, for the rest of the day and all through the night, we came here together, partly walking and partly on horseback.
es: In his company, I arrived here, sometimes on foot, sometimes on horseback, traveling all the rest of yesterday and all of last night.

en: And here you see me!”
vi: Now, I am here!
tr: And now, here I am before you!"
es: I have spoken.

en: After a gloomy silence, the first Jacques said, “Good!
vi: After a moment of sorrowful silence, Jacques One spoke: − Good!
tr: After a boring silence, Jacques Bir said, "Great!
es: —Alright—said Santiago Primero, after an imposing silence. —

en: You have acted and recounted faithfully.
vi: You did the right thing and have recounted it truthfully.
tr: You described and explained everything with all your sincerity.
es: You have acted and narrated faithfully.

en: Will you wait for us a little, outside the door?”
vi: Could you wait outside the door for a moment?
tr: Would you wait for us outside the door for a bit now?" he said.
es: Would you like to wait for us briefly outside, on the stairs?

en: “Very willingly,” said the mender of roads.
vi: − Gladly, - the road worker said.
tr: "With pleasure," said the road worker.
es: —With great pleasure—replied the road worker.

en: Whom Defarge escorted to the top of the stairs, and, leaving seated there, returned.
vi: Defarge led him to the top of the stairs, left him there, and then returned.
tr: After accompanying him to the top of the ladder and seating him, Defarge turned back.
es: Defarge accompanied him to the staircase, left him sitting on the last step, and went back into the attic.

en: The three had risen, and their heads were together when he came back to the garret.
vi: The three people stood up, huddling together to discuss as Defarge returned to the attic room.
tr: When Defarge returned to the attic, all three of them had stood up and were talking with their heads together.
es: The three Jacques had stood up and formed a very tight group.

en: “How say you, Jacques?” demanded Number One.
vi: − What do you think, Jacques? - Number One asked.
tr: "What do you say, Jacques?" asked number one.
es: —What do you say, Santiago?—asked the number one of this name.

en: “To be registered?”
vi: - Should we put him on the list?
tr: "Should it be recorded?"
es: —Shall we record it in our register?

en: “To be registered, as doomed to destruction,” returned Defarge.
vi: − Put him on the list, and he will be eliminated, - Defarge replied.
tr: "Let it be recorded as doomed to destruction," replied Defarge.
es: —Register him as condemned to destruction! —replied Defarge.

en: “Magnificent!” croaked the man with the craving.
vi: − Great! - Number Three groaned with hunger.
tr: "Magnificent!" shouted the greedy man in a hoarse voice.
es: —Magnificent! —exclaimed Santiago Tercero.

en: “The chateau, and all the race?” inquired the first.
vi: − That castle and the entire lineage? - Number One asked.
tr: "The castle and his entire family?" asked number one.
es: —The castle and the entire lineage?—replied the first one. —Yes; the castle and the entire race!

en: “The chateau and all the race,” returned Defarge.
vi: − That castle and the entire family, - Defarge replied. - Destroy them all.
tr: "The château and all its family," replied Defarge.
es: —roared Defarge—Complete extermination!

en: “Extermination.”
vi: − Perfect! -
tr: "Let them all be exterminated!"
es: —Sublime!

en: The hungry man repeated, in a rapturous croak, “Magnificent!” and began gnawing another finger.
vi: The glutton repeated the moan of pleasure and began to gnaw on another finger.
tr: The hungry man shouted enthusiastically again, "Magnificent!" and started gnawing on another finger.
es: —shouted the third Santiago.

en: “Are you sure,” asked Jacques Two, of Defarge, “that no embarrassment can arise from our manner of keeping the register?
vi: Jacques Hai asked Defarge: − Are you sure that keeping this list won't cause any trouble?
tr: "Are you sure that our record-keeping habit won't get us into trouble?" Jacques asked Defarge
es: —Are you certain that the system we've agreed upon for the registry won't cause us any trouble?

en: Without doubt it is safe, for no one beyond ourselves can decipher it; but shall we always be able to decipher it—or, I ought to say, will she?”
vi: The list is certainly safe because no one but us can decode it; but can we always ensure that we can decode it... or, should I say, can she always ensure it?
tr: Twice, "there is no danger for now because no one else can decipher this code, but will we always be able to decipher it – or rather, will your wife be able to decipher it?""
es: —Santiago Primero asked Defarge.—That it is secure, there is no doubt, since, except for us, no one is capable of deciphering it: but will we always be able to decipher it... or rather, will she be able to?...

en: “Jacques,” returned Defarge, drawing himself up, “if madame my wife undertook to keep the register in her memory alone, she would not lose a word of it—not a syllable of it.
vi: − Jacques, - Defarge replied, straightening up, - if my wife alone is responsible for remembering this list, she will remember it perfectly... not missing a single word.
tr: "Jacques," said Defarge, straightening up, "if my wife has committed this record to memory, she will not forget a single word – not even a syllable.
es: —Santiago—replied Defarge, standing up,—if my wife insists on keeping the entire record in her memory, rest assured that not a single word, not a single syllable of what it contains will be lost.

en: Knitted, in her own stitches and her own symbols, it will always be as plain to her as the sun.
vi: She has woven that list into her knitting with special stitches and symbols, she can look at it and see clearly without missing a single name.
tr: It is all woven with stitches and symbols according to her own method, it is as clear as day to her.
es: With knitting needles, she is capable of writing everything clearer than the sun.

en: Confide in Madame Defarge.
vi: Trust Madame Defarge.
tr: Trust Madame Defarge.
es: Trust my wife.

en: It would be easier for the weakest poltroon that lives, to erase himself from existence, than to erase one letter of his name or crimes from the knitted register of Madame Defarge.”
