vi: It would be easier for a coward to commit suicide than to erase a name or a crime from Madame Defarge's knitted list of elimination.
tr: Feeble cowards can easily be erased from this world, but not a single name or crime can be erased from the records woven by Madame Defarge."
es: The most cowardly poltroon, the most attached to the world who lives or has lived under the sky's cover, would find it easier to take his own life than to remove a single letter from the record written stitch by stitch by my lady.

en: There was a murmur of confidence and approval, and then the man who hungered, asked: “Is this rustic to be sent back soon?
vi: There were murmurs of trust and approval, then the hungry Number Three asked: − Are we going to kick that country bumpkin out?
tr: The men murmured among themselves in a manner that showed their trust and approval, and the greedy man said: "Will this peasant be sent back immediately?
es: Murmurs of approval greeted Defarge's words.

en: I hope so.
vi: I hope so.
tr: I hope so.
es: —What do we do with that rustic?—asked Santiago Tercero.

en: He is very simple; is he not a little dangerous?”
vi: He's not very smart, isn't that dangerous? −
tr: He is a very simple man; isn't this a bit of a dangerous situation?"
es: —Do we fire him? It seems excessively simple to me: won't it be dangerous for us?

en: “He knows nothing,” said Defarge; “at least nothing more than would easily elevate himself to a gallows of the same height.
vi: He doesn't know anything, - Defarge said, - and if he does manage to reveal something, he himself will be hanged too.
tr: "He knows nothing," said Defarge; "at least he is unaware of the things that would get him hanged from the same height of a gallows.
es: —He knows nothing—replied Defarge,—and the little he could say would only serve to get him to a scaffold as high as the one he was just describing to us.

en: I charge myself with him; let him remain with me; I will take care of him, and set him on his road.
vi: Leave him to me; just let him stay with me; I'll take care of him and send him on his own way.
tr: I take responsibility; let him stay with me; I will take care of him, then he can go his own way.
es: I'll take care of him; leave him to me. In due time, I'll let him go.

en: He wishes to see the fine world—the King, the Queen, and Court; let him see them on Sunday.”
vi: He wants to see this beautiful world... see the King, see the Queen, and see the Court; this Sunday I'll show him all those things.
tr: He wants to see the world of the nobles –the King, the Queen, the Palace; let him see them all on Sunday."
es: It seems he wishes to see the King, the Queen, the magnates, and the lords of the court: we will allow him to satisfy his desire on Sunday.

en: “What?” exclaimed the hungry man, staring.
vi: − What? - Number Three cried out in hunger, eyes wide open. -
tr: "What?" shouted the hungry man, staring intently.
es: —What! —exclaimed Santiago Tercero.

en: “Is it a good sign, that he wishes to see Royalty and Nobility?”
vi: How can someone who desires to see royalty and nobility be trustworthy?
tr: "Is it a good thing that he wants to see the royal family and the nobles?"
es: —Don't you think it's a bad sign that he wants to see the royalty and the nobility?

en: “Jacques,” said Defarge; “judiciously show a cat milk, if you wish her to thirst for it.
vi: − Jacques, - Defare said, - it is wise to show the cat milk if you want the cat to crave milk.
tr: "Jacques," said Defarge; "if you want a cat to be eager to drink milk, show it the milk from a reasonable distance.
es: —Santiago—replied Defarge,—show the cat the milk if you want to excite its thirst; show the mastiff its natural prey if you want it to fall upon it and tear it apart in due time.

en: Judiciously show a dog his natural prey, if you wish him to bring it down one day.”
vi: If you want the dog to hunt for you one day, it is wise to let the dog recognize the prey.
tr: If you show a dog its prey from a reasonable distance, one day it might catch it and bring it to you."
es: —Santiago—replied Defarge,—show the cat the milk if you want to excite its thirst; show the mastiff its natural prey if you want it to fall upon it and tear it apart in due time.

en: Nothing more was said, and the mender of roads, being found already dozing on the topmost stair, was advised to lay himself down on the pallet-bed and take some rest.
vi: No one said anything more, and they saw the road worker had fallen asleep at the top of the stairs, so they told him to go to the rickety bed inside the attic room to rest.
tr: Nothing else was discussed, and they advised the road worker, whom they found dozing at the top of the stairs, to lie down on the couch and rest a bit.
es: Nothing more was said at that time. The road worker, whom they found nodding off on the landing, was invited to lie down on the mattress.

en: He needed no persuasion, and was soon asleep.
vi: There was no need to persuade him; he fell asleep immediately after that.
tr: There was no need for insistence; the man soon fell asleep.
es: He did not need to be asked twice, and moments later, he was sleeping like a log.

en: Worse quarters than Defarge’s wine-shop, could easily have been found in Paris for a provincial slave of that degree.
vi: For a country bumpkin like this road worker, there was no better place in Paris than Defarge's tavern.
tr: For a provincial slave in his position, there were far worse places in Paris than Defarge's tavern.
es: Worse lodging than what Defarge's tavern offered could not have been found in Paris by an unfortunate like the wayfarer.

en: Saving for a mysterious dread of madame by which he was constantly haunted, his life was very new and agreeable.
vi: Except for the inexplicable fear that constantly haunted him regarding Madame Defarge, he found living here both novel and comfortable.
tr: Aside from the mysterious fear he often felt in the presence of Madame Defarge, his new life was quite pleasant.
es: If we disregard the mysterious fear that the tavern keeper's wife inspired in him, a fear that constantly haunted him, he led a life that could not be more pleasant.

en: But, madame sat all day at her counter, so expressly unconscious of him, and so particularly determined not to perceive that his being there had any connection with anything below the surface, that he shook in his wooden shoes whenever his eye lighted on her.
vi: But Madame Defarge sat at the bar all day, appearing to pay no attention to him and clearly determined not to consider him involved in any secret schemes, so cold that every time he saw her, his legs trembled with fear.
tr: But Madame seemed so unaware of his existence as she sat behind that counter all day, and so clearly showed that his presence meant nothing, that every time their eyes met, the peasant trembled in his wooden shoes.
es: But the fact is that the tavern keeper's wife spent the entire day sitting behind the counter, so indifferent to his presence, so determined not to acknowledge the presence of a stranger in the house, that he wandered around bewildered and suspicious.

en: For, he contended with himself that it was impossible to foresee what that lady might pretend next; and he felt assured that if she should take it into her brightly ornamented head to pretend that she had seen him do a murder and afterwards flay the victim, she would infallibly go through with it until the play was played out.
vi: For he was certain in his heart that he could never predict what she intended to do; and he was convinced that if Madame Defarge's gaudy head suddenly imagined that he had murdered and skinned someone, she would absolutely believe it to be true to the end.
tr: Moreover, he thought it was impossible to guess what was going through the woman's mind, and if she ever considered that he had committed a murder and then robbed the victim, she would certainly not leave him alone until the show was complete.
es: It is not surprising, then, that when Sunday arrived and he learned that the innkeeper's wife would join her husband to accompany him to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the plan, although his tongue said otherwise.

en: Therefore, when Sunday came, the mender of roads was not enchanted (though he said he was) to find that madame was to accompany monsieur and himself to Versailles.
vi: Therefore, when Sunday came, the road worker did not like (even though he said otherwise) seeing the mistress go along with the master and him to the Palace of Versailles.
tr: Therefore, when Sunday came and he learned that Madam Defarge would be accompanying the road worker Monsieur to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the situation (though, of course, he told them otherwise).
es: It is not surprising, then, that when Sunday arrived and he learned that the innkeeper's wife would join her husband to accompany him to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the plan, although his tongue said otherwise.

en: It was additionally disconcerting to have madame knitting all the way there, in a public conveyance; it was additionally disconcerting yet, to have madame in the crowd in the afternoon, still with her knitting in her hands as the crowd waited to see the carriage of the King and Queen.
vi: It was quite embarrassing when the mistress kept knitting all the way, on the public carriage; and even more embarrassing when at noon, amidst the crowd, she continued knitting non-stop while everyone was eagerly waiting to see the King and Queen's carriage.
tr: It was extremely annoying that Madam knitted throughout the journey on public transport; even more annoying was that she still carried her knitting among the crowd gathered to see the King and Queen's carriage in the afternoon.
es: His bewilderment increased when the innkeeper's wife did not stop knitting during the journey, and his bewilderment turned into horrible confusion that afternoon when, while waiting for the Queen to pass by, he had to remain next to the innkeeper's wife, whose hands were handling the knitting needles with true fervor.

en: “You work hard, madame,” said a man near her.
vi: − You work so hard, - a man standing next to her said.
tr: "You work very hard, madam," said the man next to her.
es: —Do you work a lot, ma'am?—said a man who passed by her side.

en: “Yes,” answered Madame Defarge; “I have a good deal to do.”
vi: − Yes, - Mrs. Defarge replied - I still have many things to knit.
tr: "Indeed," said Madam Defarge; "I have more work to do."
es: —Yes—replied Madame Defarge,—I have much to do.

en: “What do you make, madame?”
vi: − What are you knitting?
tr: "What are you doing, madam?"
es: —And what do you do, ma'am?

en: “Many things.”
vi: − All sorts of things.
tr: "A lot."
es: —Many things.

en: “For instance—”
vi: − For example...
tr: "For example..."
es: —For example...

en: “For instance,” returned Madame Defarge, composedly, “shrouds.”
vi: − For example, - Ms. Defarge replied calmly, - a shroud.
tr: "For example," said Madam Defarge calmly, "shrouds."
es: —For example—replied the innkeeper with the same calm as before—shrouds.

en: The man moved a little further away, as soon as he could, and the mender of roads fanned himself with his blue cap: feeling it mightily close and oppressive.
vi: The man quickly moved away, and the road worker raised his green hat to fan himself, feeling extremely suffocated standing next to the lady of the house.
tr: Adam distanced himself from the woman at the first opportunity and the road worker waved his blue hat like a fan in his hand. The place was excessively crowded and suffocating.
es: The stranger moved away as soon as he could. The poor road worker felt such a strange oppression in his chest that he had to fan himself with his cap.

en: If he needed a King and Queen to restore him, he was fortunate in having his remedy at hand; for, soon the large-faced King and the fair-faced Queen came in their golden coach, attended by the shining Bull’s Eye of their Court, a glittering multitude of laughing ladies and fine lords; and in jewels and silks and powder and splendour and elegantly spurning figures and handsomely disdainful faces of both sexes, the mender of roads bathed himself, so much to his temporary intoxication, that he cried Long live the King, Long live the Queen, Long live everybody and everything!
vi: If he needed the King and Queen to rescue him, he was fortunate not to have to wait long; the King with a firm jaw and the beautiful Queen appeared in a golden carriage, accompanied by their luxurious and trusted courtiers, a splendid entourage of joyful ladies and handsome ministers; the men and women adorned in silks, jewels, powdered faces, and painted lips, with their haughty manners and disdainful expressions, allowed the road worker to gaze in awe to the point of shouting Long live the King, long live the Queen, long live everyone and everything!
tr: If he needed a King and Queen to find himself again, he was very lucky because the solution came to him; for soon the big-faced King and the clean-faced Queen arrived in their gilded carriage, accompanied by the dazzling group of the palace favorites with sparkling eyes, smiling ladies, and elegant lords; ladies and gentlemen in jewels, silks, and powders, bodies that disregarded everyone with all their splendor and grace, and well-groomed and arrogant faces; the road worker was so captivated and lost in all this that he started shouting, "Long live the King, Long live the Queen, Long live everyone and everything!" as if he was unaware of the Jacques who popped up everywhere at any moment in those days.
es: If for his complete recovery he needed the presence of two crowned heads, it must be admitted that he could not complain about his luck, since moments later, a king with large jaws and a queen with a beautiful face appeared, comfortably seated in a golden carriage. With the sovereigns came the best, the most notable of their court. The poor road worker, upon seeing that charming army of smiling ladies and brilliant gentlemen, all covered in silks and lace, blondes and rich velvets, gold braid and dazzling jewelry, felt such waves of enthusiasm in his chest that, shouting at the top of his lungs, he cheered for the King and the Queen, the ladies and gentlemen, and even the carriages and the horses that pulled them.

en: as if he had never heard of ubiquitous Jacques in his time.
vi: As if he had never known anyone else named Jacques in his life.
tr: If he needed a King and Queen to find himself again, he was very lucky because the solution came to him; for soon the big-faced King and the clean-faced Queen arrived in their gilded carriage, accompanied by the dazzling group of the palace favorites with sparkling eyes, smiling ladies, and elegant lords; ladies and gentlemen in jewels, silks, and powders, bodies that disregarded everyone with all their splendor and grace, and well-groomed and arrogant faces; the road worker was so captivated and lost in all this that he started shouting, "Long live the King, Long live the Queen, Long live everyone and everything!" as if he was unaware of the Jacques who popped up everywhere at any moment in those days.
es: And he saw beautiful gardens and charming groves, and magnificent terraces and marvelous fountains, and he found the King and the Queen again, and cheered, until he was hoarse, for everything created, and his enthusiasm grew, and the enthusiasm gave birth to sympathy in his soul, and the sympathy to tenderness, and this, finding the limits of his chest too narrow, overflowed in torrents through his eyes in the form of tears.

en: Then, there were gardens, courtyards, terraces, fountains, green banks, more King and Queen, more Bull’s Eye, more lords and ladies, more Long live they all!
vi: After that, he saw many gardens, courtyards, watchtowers, fountains, and green hills, again seeing the King and Queen, again seeing the courtiers, ministers, and ladies, again Long live everyone!
tr: Then gardens, courtyards, terraces, fountains, trees, flowers, and again the King and Queen, again the palace favorites, lords, and ladies; more Long live, and finally, unable to bear all this emotional intensity, he burst into tears.
es: And he saw beautiful gardens and charming groves, and magnificent terraces and marvelous fountains, and he found the King and the Queen again, and cheered, until he was hoarse, for everything created, and his enthusiasm grew, and the enthusiasm gave birth to sympathy in his soul, and the sympathy to tenderness, and this, finding the limits of his chest too narrow, overflowed in torrents through his eyes in the form of tears.

en: until he absolutely wept with sentiment.
vi: To the point where he burst into tears from emotion.
tr: During this scene, which lasted about three hours, the road worker shouted a lot, cried, and showed accompanying emotional reactions, and throughout this time, Defarge held him tightly by the collar so that he wouldn't jump on the crowd he was declaring his loyalty to and tear them apart.
es: During the scene, which lasted three hours, during which he shouted until he was hoarse and cried until he exhausted the source of his tears, Defarge had to hold him by the neck with one hand to prevent him from, in his thoughtless enthusiasm, falling upon the objects of his fleeting devotion and destroying them with his big hands.

en: During the whole of this scene, which lasted some three hours, he had plenty of shouting and weeping and sentimental company, and throughout Defarge held him by the collar, as if to restrain him from flying at the objects of his brief devotion and tearing them to pieces.
vi: Throughout the approximately three-hour-long admiration, he also encountered many people crying out in emotion, and Defarge always held tightly to his collar as if fearing he would rush at these temporary objects of worship and tear them apart.
tr: During this scene, which lasted about three hours, the road worker shouted a lot, cried, and showed accompanying emotional reactions, and throughout this time, Defarge held him tightly by the collar so that he wouldn't jump on the crowd he was declaring his loyalty to and tear them apart.
es: During the scene, which lasted three hours, during which he shouted until he was hoarse and cried until he exhausted the source of his tears, Defarge had to hold him by the neck with one hand to prevent him from, in his thoughtless enthusiasm, falling upon the objects of his fleeting devotion and destroying them with his big hands.

en: “Bravo!” said Defarge, clapping him on the back when it was over, like a patron; “you are a good boy!”
vi: − Hooray! - Defarge, like a superior, patted the guy on the back when it was over. You did great!
tr: When everything was over, "Bravo!" said Defarge, patting the man on the back like a boss, "You are a good man!"
es: —Bravo! —exclaimed Defarge when the parade ended. —You are a good boy.

en: The mender of roads was now coming to himself, and was mistrustful of having made a mistake in his late demonstrations; but no.
vi: The road worker now suddenly realized and worried whether he had done anything wrong in his previous expressions; but no.
tr: The road worker was coming to himself. He had started to come to himself now and was wondering if he had done anything wrong in his earlier performance, but there was no problem.
es: The truck driver, who was beginning to come to his senses, feared he had made a blunder, but soon calmed down.

en: “You are the fellow we want,” said Defarge, in his ear; “you make these fools believe that it will last for ever.
vi: − You are exactly the person we need, - Defarge whispered in his ear, - you make those fools believe they will last forever.
tr: "You are the man we are looking for," said Defarge into the man's ear; "these fools think this grandeur will last forever.
es: —You are the man we need—Defarge said to him, pressing his lips to his ears.

en: Then, they are the more insolent, and it is the nearer ended.”
vi: Therefore, the more arrogant they are, the sooner they will perish. − There! -
tr: Then they become more arrogant and get closer and closer to the end."
es: — You will make those fools believe that their madness will last forever; their insolence will grow, and they themselves will hasten their end.

en: “Hey!” cried the mender of roads, reflectively; “that’s true.”
vi: The road worker exclaimed, looking thoughtful. -
tr: "Yaa!" shouted the road worker; "very true!"
es: —Quiet! —exclaimed the road worker. —Well, it's true!

en: “These fools know nothing.
vi: That's right. − Those fools don't know anything.
tr: "These fools know nothing.
es: —They are idiots and blind.

en: While they despise your breath, and would stop it for ever and ever, in you or in a hundred like you rather than in one of their own horses or dogs, they only know what your breath tells them.
vi: Even though they despise our lives and are ready to sacrifice your life or the lives of hundreds like you rather than give up their horses or dogs, they only know what you reveal to them.
tr: They can't stand your breathing, if it were possible, they would forever stop the breath of you and hundreds like you for one of their own horses or dogs, all they know is what your breath tells them.
es: They deeply despise you; they would watch your death and that of a thousand more like you with indifference; moreover, they would sacrifice those thousand lives without remorse in exchange for saving just one of their horses or dogs, and yet, they are puffed up by your screams.

en: Let it deceive them, then, a little longer; it cannot deceive them too much.”
vi: Keep deceiving them like that, for a little longer; it's worth deceiving them as much as possible.
tr: Let them believe this a little longer; it won't take much time anyway."
es: Let's deceive them for some more time, for no matter how great the deception is, it will never be as great as they deserve.

en: Madame Defarge looked superciliously at the client, and nodded in confirmation.
vi: Mrs. Defarge nodded in agreement and looked disdainfully at the country guest.
tr: Madam Defarge looked at the customer with a proud demeanor and then nodded in approval.
es: Mrs. Defarge looked at the road-mender and made approving gestures.

en: “As to you,” said she, “you would shout and shed tears for anything, if it made a show and a noise.
vi: She said to him: − As for you, you can shout and cry all you want, as long as you make a show of it, loudly.
tr: "As for you," said the madam, "you cry and shout for all kinds of show and pomp.
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: Say!
vi: Speak up!
tr: Isn't that right?
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: Would you not?”
vi: Can you do it?
tr: Speak!"
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “Truly, madame, I think so.
vi: − Honestly, I think I can, ma'am.
tr: "That's right, madam, I think so.
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: For the moment.”
vi: For the time being, I can.
tr: For the moment, it seems that way."
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “If you were shown a great heap of dolls, and were set upon them to pluck them to pieces and despoil them for your own advantage, you would pick out the richest and gayest.
vi: − If you see a pile of dolls and are told you can freely destroy and tear them apart, you would choose the most expensive and gorgeous one.
tr: "If they showed you a huge pile of babies and asked you to tear them apart and plunder them for your own benefit, you would go and choose the richest and sweetest one.
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: Say!
vi: Admit it!
tr: Isn't that right? Tell me!"
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: Would you not?”
vi: Isn't that right?
tr: "Yes madam, that's correct.""
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “Truly yes, madame.”
vi: − That's truly the case, ma'am.
tr: "Yes madam, that's correct.""
es: —It is true, madam.

en: “Yes.
vi: − Okay.
tr: "Yes madam, that's correct.""
es: —Very well.

en: And if you were shown a flock of birds, unable to fly, and were set upon them to strip them of their feathers for your own advantage, you would set upon the birds of the finest feathers; would you not?”
vi: And if you see a flock of birds that cannot fly and are told you can pluck their feathers as you wish, you would choose the one with the most beautiful feathers; wouldn't you?
tr: "Yes, and if they showed you a flock of birds that couldn't fly and asked you to pluck their feathers for your own benefit, you would go and choose the ones with the most beautiful feathers; isn't that right?"
es: And if they showed you a flock of birds with beautiful plumage, unable to take flight, and gave you permission to pluck their feathers for your own benefit, wouldn't you start with the ones that had the most beautiful feathers?

en: “It is true, madame.”
vi: − That's right, ma'am.
tr: "Yes, that's correct, madam.""
es: —That's right, ma'am.

en: “You have seen both dolls and birds to-day,” said Madame Defarge, with a wave of her hand towards the place where they had last been apparent; “now, go home!”
vi: − Today you have seen both the doll and the bird, - Mrs. Defarge gestured towards the position where the court had just passed.
tr: "Today you saw both the babies and the birds," said Madam Defarge, extending her hand toward the area where they were last seen; "now, go home!"
es: —Well, you just saw the pile of beautiful dolls and the flock of brightly colored birds: now, let's go home.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: - Now, go home.
es: Chapter XVI.

en: Still Knitting
vi: 16. Still knitting
tr: Continue Knitting
es: MORE STITCHES PER INCH

en: Madame Defarge and monsieur her husband returned amicably to the bosom of Saint Antoine, while a speck in a blue cap toiled through the darkness, and through the dust, and down the weary miles of avenue by the wayside, slowly tending towards that point of the compass where the chateau of Monsieur the Marquis, now in his grave, listened to the whispering trees.
vi: Madame Defarge and her husband leisurely returned to the heart of Saint Antoine, while a green speck of a hat trudged through the night, cutting through the dust, traversing long miles along the roadside, slowly heading straight towards the Marquis's castle, where he now lay in the grave listening to the rustling leaves.
tr: As Madam Defarge and her husband returned peacefully to the center of St. Antoine, they advanced through the darkness at a point with a blue hat, covering tiresome kilometers on dusty roads; they slowly headed towards the region where the château of Monsieur the Marquis, now lying in his grave, listened to the whispering rustle of the trees.
es: While Mrs. Defarge and her husband were returning in friendly company to the center of San Antonio, a blue cap was advancing, piercing the darkness and wrapped in thick clouds of dust along the roads leading to the place where the castle of the Marquis, at that time sleeping the eternal sleep, listened to the whispering conversations of the trees.

en: Such ample leisure had the stone faces, now, for listening to the trees and to the fountain, that the few village scarecrows who, in their quest for herbs to eat and fragments of dead stick to burn, strayed within sight of the great stone courtyard and terrace staircase, had it borne in upon their starved fancy that the expression of the faces was altered.
vi: The stone statues now had the leisure to listen to the sounds of trees and flowing water, to the extent that a few ragged villagers - who wandered into the castle's courtyard and wide-terraced staircase while searching for vegetables to eat and scraps of wood to burn - in their hunger-induced delirium, imagined that the faces of the statues had changed.
tr: They now had plenty of time to listen to the trees and the fountain with their stone faces, and when a handful of peasants, resembling scarecrows, reached the wide stone courtyard and the steps of the terrace while searching for grass to eat and twigs to burn, their hunger-stricken minds realized that the expressions on these faces had changed.
es: The stone faces had plenty of time to listen to the conversations held by the trees and the fountain, and they took such interest in it that the skeletons that populated the village and roamed the vicinity of the castle in search of some herbs to quell their hunger and some logs to feed the fire of their cold homes, if they happened to see the courtyard, double staircase, and terrace of the castle, they allowed their famished imagination to entertain the idea that the expression of the stone faces had undergone a profound alteration.

en: A rumour just lived in the village—had a faint and bare existence there, as its people had—that when the knife struck home, the faces changed, from faces of pride to faces of anger and pain; also, that when that dangling figure was hauled up forty feet above the fountain, they changed again, and bore a cruel look of being avenged, which they would henceforth bear for ever.
vi: There was a rumor circulating in the village - a rumor that clung to life as stubbornly as the villagers themselves - that when the knife struck its target, the faces of the statues shifted from arrogance to anger and pain; and when the culprit's body was hoisted twelve meters above the fountain, the faces changed once more to the savage look of the avenged, and have remained that way ever since.
tr: According to a new rumor in the village – rumors as pale and feeble as the villagers themselves – when the knife was plunged, these faces also changed, turning from proud faces into ones filled with pain and anger; moreover, as the hanged body swung and changed direction ten meters above the fountain, the expressions changed again, adopting the cruel gaze of someone who had taken revenge, and they would remain that way forever.
es: The wretched villagers assured that the expression of pride and disdain of the stone guardians of the castle turned into an expression of pain and anger when the knife struck the House, and they assured that from the moment the body of the murderer swung forty feet above the ground, the expression of pain and anger of those stone faces was replaced by one that breathed fierce vengeance, which would endure in them until the end of time.

en: In the stone face over the great window of the bed-chamber where the murder was done, two fine dints were pointed out in the sculptured nose, which everybody recognised, and which nobody had seen of old; and on the scarce occasions when two or three ragged peasants emerged from the crowd to take a hurried peep at Monsieur the Marquis petrified, a skinny finger would not have pointed to it for a minute, before they all started away among the moss and leaves, like the more fortunate hares who could find a living there.
vi: On the stone face of the statue at the large window of the bedroom where the murder occurred, two small indentations on the statue's nose were clearly visible, which no one had noticed before; occasionally, a few raggedly dressed villagers would separate from the crowd to sneak a peek at the petrified face of the Marquis, their bony fingers hastily pointing out the wrinkles to everyone for a moment, before they all scattered to search for something edible among the moss and foliage like a pack of wild rabbits, though the rabbits were luckier not to be as hungry as the people.
tr: Two small indentations had appeared on the nose carved into the stone face above the large window of the bedroom where the murder was committed, everyone had noticed them, although no one had seen them before; occasionally, two or three ragged peasants would break away from the crowd to steal a glance at the petrified Monsieur the Marquis, and as soon as one of them extended a skinny finger towards it, they would all scurry away like wild rabbits through the moss and leaves, fleeing to places where they could feel at ease.
es: The stone face that watched over the large window of the bedroom where the murder had been committed appeared one day with two fine nicks on its nose; and if ever, from among a group of ragged villagers, two or three stood out to approach the petrified Marquis, not a minute of contemplation would pass without them fleeing scared like hares pursued by agile greyhounds.

en: Chateau and hut, stone face and dangling figure, the red stain on the stone floor, and the pure water in the village well—thousands of acres of land—a whole province of France—all France itself—lay under the night sky, concentrated into a faint hair-breadth line.
vi: Castles and thatched huts, stone statues and dangling corpses of the condemned, red bloodstains on marble floors and clear water in village wells - thousands of acres - an entire province of France - the whole of France - submerged under the starry sky, all reduced to a fleeting strip of land.
tr: The castle and the hut, the stone face and the swinging body, the red stain on the stone floor, the pristine water in the village well – thousands of acres of land – all the countryside of France – the entirety of France – stretched out as a thin line under the dark sky.
es: Castle and huts, stone faces and flesh-and-blood faces, castle courtyard slabs stained red and pure waters enclosed in the village well, thousands of hectares of land... an entire province of France... all of France, sleep under the immense bluish vault, as if they were an imperceptible point, an atom lost in the immensity.

en: So does a whole world, with all its greatnesses and littlenesses, lie in a twinkling star.
vi: The entire world is the same, with all its grand and trivial matters hidden beneath the twinkling stars.
tr: Even the whole world, with all its grandeur and smallness, was lying within a twinkling star.
es: The world is nothing else, with all its greatness and insignificance, in relation to the brilliant star that twinkles above.

en: And as mere human knowledge can split a ray of light and analyse the manner of its composition, so, sublimer intelligences may read in the feeble shining of this earth of ours, every thought and act, every vice and virtue, of every responsible creature on it.
vi: Just as only the human intellect can separate light and analyze the spectrum clearly, only extraordinary minds can perceive, within the hazy light enveloping this world, all thoughts and actions, all sins and virtues for which everyone on earth is accountable.
tr: As if the ordinary human mind could dissect a beam of light and analyze its composition, thus the superior intellects could read the thoughts, behaviors, every kind of immorality, and virtue of every creature on our dimly shining world.
es: The wise men of the earth break, divide, decompose a ray of light and analyze its components; and in the same way, another intelligence more sublime than the human reads the weak glimmers that emanate from this earth we inhabit, and analyzes all thoughts and all actions, all vices and all virtues of the creatures endowed with intelligence.

en: The Defarges, husband and wife, came lumbering under the starlight, in their public vehicle, to that gate of Paris whereunto their journey naturally tended.
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Defarge sat in the public carriage, creaking under the starlight, following the familiar route towards the gates of Paris.
tr: The Defarges, husband and wife, slowly made their way under the stars in their carriage and arrived at one of the gates of Paris, the point they aimed to reach.
es: The public carriage in which the Defarges, husband and wife, made their return journey stopped at the gate of the city closest to their home, where the usual lanterns soon appeared, tasked with conducting the customary examinations and investigations.

en: There was the usual stoppage at the barrier guardhouse, and the usual lanterns came glancing forth for the usual examination and inquiry.
vi: The carriage had to stop at the checkpoint as usual, and the usual lanterns came out to inspect faces and ask questions.
tr: They were routinely stopped in front of the security barrier, and the usual lanterns were brightly shone on them for a general inspection and questioning.
es: The public carriage in which the Defarges, husband and wife, made their return journey stopped at the gate of the city closest to their home, where the usual lanterns soon appeared, tasked with conducting the customary examinations and investigations.

en: Monsieur Defarge alighted; knowing one or two of the soldiery there, and one of the police.
vi: Mr. Defarge got off the carriage; he knew one or two guards here, along with a policeman.
tr: Monsieur Defarge got out of the carriage; he knew a couple of the soldiers and police officers there.
es: Defarge jumped out of the carriage upon seeing two or three soldiers and a policeman he knew; the latter, with whom he had close ties of friendship, embraced him.

en: The latter he was intimate with, and affectionately embraced.
vi: He was very close with the policeman, and the two embraced warmly.
tr: He was familiar with the second one, and they embraced warmly.
es: Defarge jumped out of the carriage upon seeing two or three soldiers and a policeman he knew; the latter, with whom he had close ties of friendship, embraced him.

en: When Saint Antoine had again enfolded the Defarges in his dusky wings, and they, having finally alighted near the Saint’s boundaries, were picking their way on foot through the black mud and offal of his streets, Madame Defarge spoke to her husband:
vi: After the Defarges got off the carriage for the last time at the boundary of the area named Saint Antoine, the saint once again enveloped them in his dark wings; as they groped their way through the black mud and filth of the alleys, Madame Defarge asked her husband: − Tell me, what did Jacques the policeman say to you?
tr: St Antoine had once again embraced the Defarges with its dim wings, and as they finally got off the carriage near St Antoine and struggled to walk through the streets filled with pitch-black mud and filth, Madame Defarge said to her husband:
es: Arriving at the boundaries of the district placed under the protection of the wings of Saint Anthony, the Defarges left the carriage and walked to their house on foot, through dark and muddy streets. On the way, Mrs. Defarge asked her husband:

en: “Say then, my friend; what did Jacques of the police tell thee?”
tr: "Tell me, my friend; what did Officer Jacques say to you?"
es: —What did Santiago the police officer tell you?

en: “Very little to-night, but all he knows.
vi: He told me everything, but there is little news tonight.
tr: "He didn't say much tonight, but he told everything he knew.
es: —Everything he knows, even though it is very little.

en: There is another spy commissioned for our quarter.
vi: Another spy has been hired to investigate our area.
tr: They have placed another spy in our region.
es: They have appointed another spy for our neighborhood: maybe it's not the only one, but that one only knows about one.

en: There may be many more, for all that he can say, but he knows of one.”
vi: There may be more, but according to what he knows, there is only one. − Ah, got it!
tr: There might be many more, but he only knew about one."
es: They have appointed another spy for our neighborhood: maybe it's not the only one, but that one only knows about one.

en: “Eh well!” said Madame Defarge, raising her eyebrows with a cool business air.
vi: - Mrs. Defarge raised her eyebrows, looking indifferent.
tr: "Well, good!" said Madam Defarge, adopting a serious business air and raising her eyebrows.
es: —Alright—replied the innkeeper with her usual calm.

en: “It is necessary to register him.
vi: Then we need to put him on the list.
tr: "We need to record that too.
es: —It will have to be noted in the register.

en: How do they call that man?”
vi: Who is he?
tr: What's his name?"
es: What is that man's name?

en: “He is English.”
vi: − He is an Englishman.
tr: "He is an Englishman."
es: —It's English.

en: “So much the better.
vi: − The better.
tr: "Better." "What's his name?"
es: —Even better!

en: His name?”
vi: What name?
tr: "Better." "What's his name?"
es: Your name?

en: “Barsad,” said Defarge, making it French by pronunciation.
vi: − Barsad, - Defarge pronounced the name with a French accent.
tr: "Barsad," said Defarge, pronouncing it as if it were French.
es: —Barsad. —Barsad.

en: But, he had been so careful to get it accurately, that he then spelt it with perfect correctness.
vi: But he listened very carefully so he could go home and write it down accurately.
tr: But he had been so careful to understand the name correctly that he made no mistake when writing it.
es: —Perfect!

en: “Barsad,” repeated madame.
vi: − Barsad, - she repeated.
tr: "Barsad," repeated the madam.
es: —Perfect!

en: “Good. Christian name?”
vi: - Good. What is the first name?
tr: "Good. What is his first name?"
es: What is your first name?

en: “John.”
vi: − John.
tr: "John."
es: —Juan.

en: “John Barsad,” repeated madame, after murmuring it once to herself.
vi: − John Barsad, - she repeated, after muttering to herself.
tr: After Madam muttered this to herself once, she repeated, "John Barsad."
es: —Juan Barsad... Juan Barsad—repeated the innkeeper.

en: “Good.
vi: - Good.
tr: "Good.
es: —Very well.

en: His appearance; is it known?”
vi: And his appearance, do you know it?
tr: And his appearance; do we know it?"
es: Your address?

en: “Age, about forty years; height, about five feet nine; black hair; complexion dark; generally, rather handsome visage; eyes dark, face thin, long, and sallow; nose aquiline, but not straight, having a peculiar inclination towards the left cheek; expression, therefore, sinister.”
vi: − Age, around forty; height, about one meter seventy-five; black hair; tanned skin; overall quite handsome; black eyes, thin, long face, sallow complexion; a hooked nose rather than straight, particularly slightly bent towards the left cheek, giving his face a somewhat sinister look.
tr: "Approximately in his forties, 1.75 meters tall, black-haired, dark-skinned, with a face that could be considered pleasant; dark eyes, a thin, long, pale face, a nose like a beak, but not straight, crooked to the left; this has given his face a rather sinister expression."
es: —About forty years old, around five feet nine inches tall, black hair, sallow complexion, black eyes, thin, aquiline nose, but not straight: it has the peculiarity of being slightly twisted to the left, which naturally gives him a sinister expression.

en: “Eh my faith.
vi: − Unbelievable.
tr: "God bless you.
es: —It's a perfect likeness, upon my word!

en: It is a portrait!” said madame, laughing.
vi: Just like a portrait! - The wife said while laughing.
tr: You practically painted the man's portrait!" said the lady, laughing.
es: —exclaimed Madame Defarge, laughing.

en: “He shall be registered to-morrow.”
vi: - Tomorrow, he will be put on the list.
tr: "It will be recorded immediately tomorrow."
es: —I will record it tomorrow.

en: They turned into the wine-shop, which was closed (for it was midnight), and where Madame Defarge immediately took her post at her desk, counted the small moneys that had been taken during her absence, examined the stock, went through the entries in the book, made other entries of her own, checked the serving man in every possible way, and finally dismissed him to bed.
vi: They entered the tavern that had stopped selling (because it was already midnight), Mrs. Defarge immediately took her seat at the counter, counted the meager amount of money collected during her absence, checked the inventory, reviewed the entries in the ledger, made additional entries herself, interrogated the assistant bartender thoroughly before letting him go to sleep.
tr: They returned to the closed (because it was night) wine shop, and Madam Defarge immediately took her place at the counter, counted the coins that had accumulated in her absence, checked the supplies, examined the ledger they kept, took other notes herself, and after thoroughly inspecting the wine distributor in every possible way, sent him to bed.
es: Upon arriving at the tavern, which they found closed—it was past midnight—Mrs. Defarge took a seat behind the counter and devoted her attention to examining the day's accounts. She began by pouring out the jar in which the proceeds of the sales were kept onto the counter, counted the money, measured the inventory, read the entries and exits recorded in the designated book, corrected the entries, made some new ones and discussed others, and after thoroughly scrutinizing and pressuring the individual in charge of the establishment in a thousand ways, she sent him to bed.

en: Then she turned out the contents of the bowl of money for the second time, and began knotting them up in her handkerchief, in a chain of separate knots, for safe keeping through the night.
vi: After that, she poured all the money out of the bowl onto the table again, wrapped the coins in a handkerchief, tying them into separate bundles for safekeeping overnight.
tr: Then she once again turned the money bowl upside down and, to keep it safe at night, placed the money in her handkerchief, tying several knots one after the other.
es: Next, she made several equal piles from the coins taken out of the jar, which she tied into her handkerchief, soon turning it into a rosary of knots.

en: All this while, Defarge, with his pipe in his mouth, walked up and down, complacently admiring, but never interfering; in which condition, indeed, as to the business and his domestic affairs, he walked up and down through life.
vi: During that time, Defarge, with a pipe in his mouth, walked back and forth, content and admiringly watching his wife work but never interfering; indeed, in both business and family matters, he had spent his entire life just walking back and forth like that.
tr: Meanwhile, Monsieur Defarge, with his pipe in his mouth, walked up and down the shop with an indifferent admiration, but never interfered with his wife; in fact, this was true both in his business and family matters, he walked up and down in life.
es: Meanwhile, Defarge walked around the establishment, smoking his pipe and admiring with satisfaction his wife's prudent and wise domestic economy, though without interfering in it.

en: The night was hot, and the shop, close shut and surrounded by so foul a neighbourhood, was ill-smelling.
vi: The night was sultry and the tavern reeked because it was closed off and surrounded by a foul-smelling area.
tr: It was a hot night, and the tightly shut shop in an already stinking neighborhood reeked horribly.
es: Since the shop was narrow, and the ceiling was low, and the night was extremely hot with all the windows and doors closed, the atmosphere was extraordinarily stale.

en: Monsieur Defarge’s olfactory sense was by no means delicate, but the stock of wine smelt much stronger than it ever tasted, and so did the stock of rum and brandy and aniseed.
vi: Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not particularly keen, but the scent of wine in the cask seemed stronger than usual, and so did the barrels of rum, brandy, and anise liqueur.
tr: Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not very sensitive, but the smell of the wines in stock was many times sharper to his nose than their taste; likewise, the rum, cognac, and anise stock had a heavy odor.
es: Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not a marvel of delicacy, but even so, the vapors of the wine, combined with those of the rum and the brandy, bothered him to such an extent that he tried to keep them away from his nose by snorting and fanning himself with his hands.

en: He whiffed the compound of scents away, as he put down his smoked-out pipe.
vi: He waved away that mixture of smells with one last puff of his pipe before setting it down.
tr: As he set aside his extinguished pipe, he puffed in disdain at this mixture of smells.
es: Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not a marvel of delicacy, but even so, the vapors of the wine, combined with those of the rum and the brandy, bothered him to such an extent that he tried to keep them away from his nose by snorting and fanning himself with his hands.

en: “You are fatigued,” said madame, raising her glance as she knotted the money.
vi: − I'm tired, - the wife said, tying the money, her eyes looking up.
tr: "You seem very tired," said the madam, looking at her husband while tying a knot in the handkerchief.
es: —You are tired, my friend—said his wife, giving him a look while tying up the money.—

en: “There are only the usual odours.”
vi: The smell of alcohol is just normal.
tr: "It smells like always."
es: The smell you breathe here is the same as every day.

en: “I am a little tired,” her husband acknowledged.
vi: − I'm a bit tired, - the husband admitted.
tr: "I am a bit tired, yes," admitted her husband.
es: —Indeed; I am tired—replied Defarge.

en: “You are a little depressed, too,” said madame, whose quick eyes had never been so intent on the accounts, but they had had a ray or two for him.
vi: − I'm also a bit discouraged, - the sharp-eyed wife was not so focused on the money matters that she didn't notice her husband. -
tr: "You seem a bit bored," said the madam; although her hurried eyes were intensely focused on the account, she couldn't help but glance at her husband from time to time.
es: —And a little depressed and disheartened—replied the innkeeper's wife, whose piercing eyes, although focused on the accounts, spared one or two glances to examine her husband.

en: “Oh, the men, the men!”
vi: Oh, you men are something else!
tr: "Ah, these men, men!"

en: “But my dear!” began Defarge.
vi: − But dear! - Defarge began.
tr: "But my dear!" Defarge began to say.
es: —But...

en: “But my dear!” repeated madame, nodding firmly; “but my dear!
vi: − But darling! - The wife said, shaking her head vigorously. - But darling!
tr: "But my dear!" repeated the lady, shaking her head resolutely; "but my dear!
es: —No buts about it—replied the lady with firmness.

en: You are faint of heart to-night, my dear!”
vi: Tonight, I am discouraged, darling! −
tr: You are so spiritless tonight, darling!"
es: —I repeat, tonight you are disheartened.

en: “Well, then,” said Defarge, as if a thought were wrung out of his breast, “it is a long time.”
vi: Yes, indeed, - Defarge said as if his wife had understood his innermost thoughts, - it has been too long.
tr: "Actually," said Defarge, as if an idea had been torn from his chest, "it took a very long time."
es: —It takes so long! —exclaimed Defarge.

en: “It is a long time,” repeated his wife; “and when is it not a long time?
vi: − It is indeed long, - the wife repeated, - when has it ever been quick?
tr: His wife repeated, "It took too long; when did it not take long?
es: —Does it take so much time?... And what is it that doesn't require time?

en: Vengeance and retribution require a long time; it is the rule.”
vi: Revenge and punishment are long-term matters, it has to be that way.
tr: Revenge and retaliation take a long time; that's how it is."
es: Revenge and justice have always required it!

en: “It does not take a long time to strike a man with Lightning,” said Defarge.
vi: − Lightning strikes don't take much time, - Defarge said.
tr: "A lightning strike doesn't last very long, though," said Defarge.
es: —The lightning does not take long to strike a man—observed Defarge.

en: “How long,” demanded madame, composedly, “does it take to make and store the lightning?
vi: − How long does it take to create a lightning bolt?
tr: "Tell me," said the madam calmly, "How long does it take to produce and gather lightning?"
es: —And how long does it take for the necessary electricity to accumulate for the lightning to strike?

en: Tell me.”
vi: - The wife calmly asked.
tr: "Tell me," said the madam calmly, "How long does it take to produce and gather lightning?"
es: Tell me, if you know!

en: Defarge raised his head thoughtfully, as if there were something in that too.
vi: Defarge looked up thoughtfully, perhaps his wife had a point.
tr: Defarge, as if he had something on his mind, raised his head thoughtfully.
es: Defarge raised his head, but did not reply.

en: “It does not take a long time,” said madame, “for an earthquake to swallow a town.
vi: His wife continued: − An earthquake burying a city doesn't take much time.
tr: "It doesn't take long for an earthquake to swallow a city," said the madam.
es: —It takes little time for an earthquake to turn a city to dust.

en: Eh well!
vi: Ah right!
tr: "But how long does it take to prepare for that earthquake, you tell me that?""
es: Well then, how much time is needed to prepare an earthquake?

en: Tell me how long it takes to prepare the earthquake?”
vi: So how long does it take to create an earthquake, tell me?
tr: "But how long does it take to prepare for that earthquake, you tell me that?""
es: Well then, how much time is needed to prepare an earthquake?

en: “A long time, I suppose,” said Defarge.
vi: − A long time, I suppose, - Defarge said.
tr: "It will probably take a long time," said Defarge.
es: —A lot, I suppose—replied Defarge.

en: “But when it is ready, it takes place, and grinds to pieces everything before it.
vi: − But once it is ready, it happens and crushes everything in its path.
tr: "But when it is ready and comes to life, it will shatter everything in its path.
es: —But when it is ready, when it happens, the city bursts, is pulverized, reduced to impalpable atoms.

en: In the meantime, it is always preparing, though it is not seen or heard.
vi: Meanwhile, it always accumulates, even though no one sees, no one hears.
tr: Even if we hear or see nothing, it is constantly preparing right now.
es: —But when it is ready, when it happens, the city bursts, is pulverized, reduced to impalpable atoms.

en: That is your consolation.
vi: Just rest assured.
tr: Take comfort in this.
es: Console yourself!

en: Keep it.”
vi: Don't be discouraged.
tr: Do not forget it."
es: The earthquake is preparing itself even though no one sees it, even though no one hears it.

en: She tied a knot with flashing eyes, as if it throttled a foe.
vi: The wife tied another string of money, her eyes glaring as if she were strangling an enemy.
tr: With eyes gleaming as if he were strangling an enemy, he tied another knot.
es: With flashing eyes, he tied another knot; it seemed as if he were strangling an enemy.

en: “I tell thee,” said madame, extending her right hand, for emphasis, “that although it is a long time on the road, it is on the road and coming.
vi: − I already told myself, - the wife spread out her right hand to emphasize her words - revenge, even if it takes a long time, will eventually come.
tr: "Let me tell you this much," he said, extending his right hand to emphasize what he was about to say, "the journey may have been long, but that journey is coming to an end now.
es: —I assure you—he added, extending his right hand as if to give greater expression to his words—that no matter how late it may be, it is on its way, it is approaching by the moment.

en: I tell thee it never retreats, and never stops.
vi: I already said, it never turns back, it never stops.
tr: I'm telling you, it will never retreat and it will never stop.
es: I assure you that it always advances, it does not retreat, it does not stop.

en: I tell thee it is always advancing.
vi: I already said, it always moves forward.
tr: I'm telling you, it will always move forward.
es: I assure you that it always advances, it does not retreat, it does not stop.

en: Look around and consider the lives of all the world that we know, consider the faces of all the world that we know, consider the rage and discontent to which the Jacquerie addresses itself with more and more of certainty every hour.
vi: Look around and think about the lives of the many people you know, think about the faces of the many people you know, think about the rage and dissatisfaction that the Jacques brothers express more and more fiercely, every day, every hour.
tr: Take a look around and think of all the faces you know, think of all those Jacques' growing anger and discontent with each passing day.
es: Look around you and scrutinize the lives of all the people you know, observe the faces of the entire world, and you will see that the discontent, the rage that roars in the chest of the exploited increases day by day, hour by hour.

en: Can such things last?
vi: Will those things last forever?
tr: How much longer will this continue?
es: And do you think that this state of affairs can last?

en: Bah!
vi: Pfft!
tr: Hah!
es: Bah!

en: I mock you.”
vi: You are really funny.
tr: Don't worry about it anymore."
es: You are naive!

en: “My brave wife,” returned Defarge, standing before her with his head a little bent, and his hands clasped at his back, like a docile and attentive pupil before his catechist, “I do not question all this.
vi: − Brave wife, - Defarge replied, standing in front of his wife, head slightly bowed, hands clasped behind his back, looking like an obedient student attentively facing his catechism teacher, - I have no doubt about that.
tr: "My brave wife," said Defarge, with his head tilted to the side in front of his wife, his hands tied behind his back, like a well-behaved and good child being questioned by a religious teacher, "I am not questioning these things.
es: —My dear little wife—replied Defarge, standing up in front of his wife, lowering his head and with his hands behind his back, resembling a docile schoolboy in front of his teacher,—I do not doubt it...

en: But it has lasted a long time, and it is possible—you know well, my wife, it is possible—that it may not come, during our lives.”
vi: But this has been going on for too long, and it could be... you know, it could be... that we might never see it happen in our lifetime.
tr: But it took a very long time and maybe we won't live to see it – you know, my dear wife, this is possible."
es: The irritation exists: but it has been around for so long, that it is very possible... that it will not erupt in time for us to witness the cataclysm.

en: “Eh well!
vi: − Oh, really! So what?
tr: "Hey!
es: —And what?—replied the woman.

en: How then?” demanded madame, tying another knot, as if there were another enemy strangled.
vi: - The wife asked as she tied another string of money, adding another enemy being strangled.
tr: What does this mean now?" asked the madam, tying another knot as if she were strangling another enemy.
es: —Even if that were the case, so what?

en: “Well!” said Defarge, with a half complaining and half apologetic shrug.
vi: − Well! - Defarge shrugged, half lamenting, half regretting.
tr: "Well!" said Defarge, shrugging his shoulders with a manner that was partly complaining, partly apologetic.
es: —Well... we wouldn't have the joy of savoring the triumph.

en: “We shall not see the triumph.”
vi: - Then we won't see the victory, will we?
tr: "We may not see the victory."
es: —Well... we wouldn't have the joy of savoring the triumph.

en: “We shall have helped it,” returned madame, with her extended hand in strong action.
vi: − We have no choice, - the wife responded, her hand extended emphatically. -
tr: "But we will be helping her," replied the madam, extending her hands with a determined gesture.
es: —But indeed, the fact of having contributed to it—said the innkeeper energetically.

en: “Nothing that we do, is done in vain.
vi: What we are doing is not in vain at all.
tr: "Nothing we do is in vain.
es: —Nothing we do will be in vain.

en: I believe, with all my soul, that we shall see the triumph.
vi: I believe, with all my soul, that we will see victory.
tr: I wholeheartedly believe that we will see the victory.
es: I believe with all my soul that we will see the triumph; but even if I knew for certain that I would not have that joy, as long as there exists the neck of an aristocrat or a tyrant, I will not stop...

en: But even if not, even if I knew certainly not, show me the neck of an aristocrat and tyrant, and still I would—”
vi: But even if we don't see it, even if I am certain that we won't see it, just give me the neck of a cruel nobleman and I will...
tr: But even if we won't see those days, even if we have no hope left, show me the throat of a cruel ruler or noble, and I will still..."
es: I believe with all my soul that we will see the triumph; but even if I knew for certain that I would not have that joy, as long as there exists the neck of an aristocrat or a tyrant, I will not stop...

en: Then madame, with her teeth set, tied a very terrible knot indeed.
vi: Speaking of that, she gritted her teeth and clenched a string of money as if she wanted to tear someone apart. − There!
tr: Then, Madam clenched her teeth and tied another tight knot with all her might.
es: —Calm... calm!

en: “Hold!” cried Defarge, reddening a little as if he felt charged with cowardice; “I too, my dear, will stop at nothing.”
vi: - Defarge exclaimed, his face slightly red as if he felt accused of cowardice. - Me too, dear, I will not stop at anything.
tr: Feeling accused of cowardice and blushing slightly, Defarge said to his wife, "Hold on, dear! I am not afraid of anything either."
es: —exclaimed Defarge, whose face turned crimson as if he had been accused of being a coward. —

en: “Yes!
vi: − Correct!
tr: "Correct!
es: Nor will I, my dear, retreat for anything or anyone.

en: But it is your weakness that you sometimes need to see your victim and your opportunity, to sustain you.
vi: But your weakness is that sometimes you need to see the prey and the opportunity in order to maintain your determination to the end.
tr: But your weakness is feeling the need to see your victim and the opportunity in your hand in order to continue on your path.
es: —I know; but you are weak despite everything, and you are, because to keep your courage from faltering you need to see your victim at your feet.

en: Sustain yourself without that.
vi: You must be resolute without needing to do so.
tr: Continue on your path without these.
es: Try not to falter, even if it seems that the victim is far away.

en: When the time comes, let loose a tiger and a devil; but wait for the time with the tiger and the devil chained—not shown—yet always ready.”
vi: When the time comes, unleash the tiger and the demon within you; but for now, chain them up and wait for the right moment... do not reveal them... but always be ready.
tr: When the time comes, you will reveal the tiger and the devil within you; but for now, keep the tiger and the devil chained inside you –don't show them to anyone– yet always keep them ready."
es: When the time comes, unleash the tigers and demons you keep locked inside your chest, but in the meantime, keep them chained... hidden, but always ready.

en: Madame enforced the conclusion of this piece of advice by striking her little counter with her chain of money as if she knocked its brains out, and then gathering the heavy handkerchief under her arm in a serene manner, and observing that it was time to go to bed.
vi: The wife emphasized the conclusion of her advice by slamming a string of coins onto the bar counter as if she wanted to smash someone's brains out, then nonchalantly tucked the string of coins under her arm and told her husband it was time to go to bed.
tr: Madam, to increase the impact of her words, slammed her handkerchief full of money on the counter as if she were scattering her brains, then very calmly tucked the now heavier handkerchief under her arm and said it was time to go to bed.
es: The good innkeeper finished her advice by slamming a blow on the counter with the handkerchief turned into a heavy rosary; then she lifted it, and with unshakable calm indicated that it was already time to go to bed.

en: Next noontide saw the admirable woman in her usual place in the wine-shop, knitting away assiduously.
vi: The next noon, that respectable woman sat in her usual spot in the tavern, diligently knitting wool.
tr: The next day at noon, this admirable woman was once again knitting with great determination in her usual spot at the wine shop.
es: The next morning, he found that admirable woman in her usual spot, knitting with true fervor.

en: A rose lay beside her, and if she now and then glanced at the flower, it was with no infraction of her usual preoccupied air.
vi: And if she occasionally glanced at the rose placed beside her, the flower did not affect her familiar busy expression.
tr: There was a rose beside her, and although she occasionally glanced at the flower, her usual demeanor never changed.
es: Beside her, there was a rose to which she occasionally turned her eyes.

en: There were a few customers, drinking or not drinking, standing or seated, sprinkled about.
vi: The tavern had a few scattered customers, some drinking, some not.
tr: A few customers, some drinking, some not, some standing, some sitting, were scattered around the shop.
es: Some patrons, standing or sitting, were drinking and chatting.

en: The day was very hot, and heaps of flies, who were extending their inquisitive and adventurous perquisitions into all the glutinous little glasses near madame, fell dead at the bottom.
vi: It was very hot, and all the curious, daring flies that ventured to explore the sticky small glasses near her fell to the bottom, dead.
tr: It was a very hot day; swarms of flies, which had extended their curious and adventurous searches to the sticky little glasses next to the lady, had fallen to the bottoms of the glasses one by one and died.
es: The day was very hot, and the swarms of flies, which carried their audacity to the extreme of investigating the contents of the glasses near the lady, soon fell dead at the bottom.

en: Their decease made no impression on the other flies out promenading, who looked at them in the coolest manner (as if they themselves were elephants, or something as far removed), until they met the same fate.
vi: Their deaths did not stir the slightest sympathy from the other flies leisurely outside, indifferently watching their kind (as if they were elephants or some distant species), until they met the same fate.
tr: The other flies buzzing around did not seem at all affected by their deaths; they just looked at them with the utmost composure (as if they themselves were elephants or some other equally unrelated animal) until they shared the same fate.
es: Their unfortunate fate did not make the slightest impression on the other flies, who watched them unflinchingly and indifferently until the same misfortune befell them.

en: Curious to consider how heedless flies are!—perhaps they thought as much at Court that sunny summer day.
vi: How peculiar those indifferent flies were! - Perhaps those at the court on that bright summer day were just as calmly indifferent.
tr: How carefree flies are! –perhaps on that hot summer day, they could think no more than the Palace people.
es: How stupid flies are!

en: A figure entering at the door threw a shadow on Madame Defarge which she felt to be a new one.
vi: A person stepped over the threshold, casting a shadow on Madame Defarge's wine shop counter, and she immediately knew it was a stranger.
tr: Then, a person who entered cast his shadow over Madam Defarge; it was a type completely unfamiliar to the madam.
es: Mrs. Defarge saw the shadow of a person entering the tavern and understood that it was a new customer.

en: She laid down her knitting, and began to pin her rose in her head-dress, before she looked at the figure.
vi: Putting down her knitting, she pinned a rose to her headscarf and looked at the newcomer.
tr: Madam put aside her knitting and pinned her rose to the edge of her bonnet before attending to the man.
es: Before looking at the person's face, she placed the knitting on the counter and pinned the rose in her hair.

en: It was curious.
vi: Strangely.
tr: It was a strange situation.
es: The scene that followed could not have been more curious: as soon as the innkeeper's fingers touched the rose, conversations in the establishment ceased and all the patrons began to go out into the street.

en: The moment Madame Defarge took up the rose, the customers ceased talking, and began gradually to drop out of the wine-shop.
vi: Just as Madame Defarge picked up the flower, the guests inside immediately stopped chatting and began to leave the tavern one by one.
tr: With Madam Defarge raising her rose, the customers had stopped talking and started leaving the shop one by one.
es: The scene that followed could not have been more curious: as soon as the innkeeper's fingers touched the rose, conversations in the establishment ceased and all the patrons began to go out into the street.

en: “Good day, madame,” said the new-comer.
vi: − Hello ma'am, - the stranger spoke.
tr: "Good day, madam," said the stranger.
es: —Good morning, ma'am—said the newcomer.

en: “Good day, monsieur.”
vi: Hello, sir.
tr: "Good day, monsieur.""
es: —Good morning, sir—replied Mrs. Defarge, taking up her knitting again.

en: She said it aloud, but added to herself, as she resumed her knitting: “Hah!
vi: She spoke loudly, then continued knitting while muttering to herself: "Ah!
tr: She said this out loud, but when she took her knitting back in hand, she muttered to herself: "Ha!
es: —Ah! —she added to herself.

en: Good day, age about forty, height about five feet nine, black hair, generally rather handsome visage, complexion dark, eyes dark, thin, long and sallow face, aquiline nose but not straight, having a peculiar inclination towards the left cheek which imparts a sinister expression!
vi: Hello, around forty years old, about one meter seventy-five tall, black hair, generally quite handsome face, tan skin, black eyes, thin and long face, sallow skin, hooked nose rather than straight, especially slightly crooked towards the left cheek, making the face look somewhat sinister!"
tr: Good days, at forty years old, 1.75 meters tall, black hair, dark skin, generally a face that could be called pleasant; dark eyes, thin, long, pale face, nose like a beak but not straight, crooked to the left; this gave her a rather untrustworthy expression!
es: —About forty years old, around five feet nine inches tall, black hair, sallow complexion, black eyes, thin, aquiline nose, but not straight, with the particularity of being slightly twisted to the left, which naturally gives a sinister expression...

en: Good day, one and all!”
vi: Hello, everyone!" −
tr: Good day to you all!"
es: Truly a good day!

en: “Have the goodness to give me a little glass of old cognac, and a mouthful of cool fresh water, madame.”
vi: Please give me a small glass of aged cognac, and a glass of cool water, madam.
tr: "Could you please give me a small glass of old cognac and a large glass of cold water, madam?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to give me a small glass of old cognac and a sip of fresh water, ma'am?

en: Madame complied with a polite air.
vi: She politely serves the guests.
tr: The lady graciously fulfilled the man's request.
es: The barmaid served what the customer ordered.

en: “Marvellous cognac this, madame!”
vi: − This cognac is wonderful, madam!
tr: "This is a magnificent cognac, madam!""
es: —Delicious cognac, madam!

en: It was the first time it had ever been so complimented, and Madame Defarge knew enough of its antecedents to know better.
vi: It was the first time someone had praised it like that, and Mrs. Defarge, knowing the origin of the liquor, did not believe it.
tr: The cognac had never been praised so highly before, and Madam Defarge knew well the state of the previous ones.
es: As it was the first time she had heard her cognac praised, it is not surprising that the innkeeper suspected that the praise was due to reasons that perhaps were not precisely the quality of the liquor.

en: She said, however, that the cognac was flattered, and took up her knitting.
vi: Nevertheless, she thanked him for the compliment and continued knitting.
tr: Nevertheless, she told the man that he had praised the cognac too much and resumed her knitting.
es: She gave thanks, however, and continued knitting.

en: The visitor watched her fingers for a few moments, and took the opportunity of observing the place in general.
vi: The guest watched the nimble fingers of the innkeeper for a while, then took the opportunity to look around.
tr: After watching the woman's fingers for a few minutes, the stranger glanced around.
es: The stranger remained for a few moments observing Mrs. Defarge's hands, and in passing, taking note of the establishment.

en: “You knit with great skill, madame.”
vi: − You knit very well.
tr: "How beautifully you knit, madam.""
es: —You knit with marvelous speed—he said.

en: “I am accustomed to it.”
vi: − I'm used to it.
tr: "I'm used to it now."
es: —The habit... I am very accustomed to this work.

en: “A pretty pattern too!”
vi: − The patterns are also beautiful!
tr: "What a beautiful pattern it is!""
es: —And with a perfection that enchants.

en: “You think so?” said madame, looking at him with a smile.
vi: − You think so? - She smiled at the customer.
tr: "Do you think so?" said the madam, looking at him with a smile on her face.
es: —Do you think so?

en: “Decidedly.
vi: − Certainly.
tr: "Absolutely.
es: —With all my soul...

en: May one ask what it is for?”
vi: May I ask what you're knitting for?
tr: May I ask what you are knitting?"
es: And tell me: that stocking is...?

en: “Pastime,” said madame, still looking at him with a smile while her fingers moved nimbly.
vi: − Just for fun, - she said, her eyes still watching, her mouth still smiling, her fingers still moving swiftly.
tr: "I'm just keeping myself busy," said the woman, her fingers moving quickly, still with a smile on her face, looking at him.
es: —Pastime... a means of distraction—replied the innkeeper, looking at her interlocutor with a smile on her lips.

en: “Not for use?”
vi: − So, it's not for anything? −
tr: "So, you're not knitting anything specific?"
es: —Aren't you going to make use of it?

en: “That depends.
vi: It depends.
tr: "It depends on the situation."
es: —According to.

en: I may find a use for it one day.
vi: Who knows, one day it might be needed. If it is needed...
tr: "One day it might be useful."
es: Perhaps the day will come when I use them—said the innkeeper with a certain coquettishness.

en: If I do—Well,” said madame, drawing a breath and nodding her head with a stern kind of coquetry, “I’ll use it!”
vi: Well, - she took a breath and shook her head, as if both coquettish and serious, - then I'll use it!
tr: "If I finish it..." "well," said the madam, sighing and shaking her head with a cruel flirtation, "I'll use it!""
es: —Surely I will use them... if I make them well.

en: It was remarkable; but, the taste of Saint Antoine seemed to be decidedly opposed to a rose on the head-dress of Madame Defarge.
vi: The notable thing is that the preferences of the people in the Saint Antoine district seem to clearly conflict with the rose on Madame Defarge's headscarf.
tr: It was a remarkable situation. The taste of St. Antoine seemed to be in direct contrast with the rose on Madame Defarge's cap.
es: As curious as it may seem, the fact is that the taste of Saint Anthony showed a decided opposition to Mrs. Defarge displaying a rose in her hairstyle.

en: Two men had entered separately, and had been about to order drink, when, catching sight of that novelty, they faltered, made a pretence of looking about as if for some friend who was not there, and went away.
vi: Two people had successively entered the bar, intending to order drinks, but when they saw that decoration, they hesitated, pretended to look around as if searching for a friend who wasn't there, and then left.
tr: Two men had entered separately, and just as they were about to order their drinks, their eyes caught this change, causing them to hesitate, and then they left, pretending not to look at a friend who wasn't there.
es: Two men entered separately, approached the counter with the clear intention of ordering something to drink, and no sooner did they see the rose, they hesitated, looked around as if searching for a friend, whom they did not find, and immediately left.

en: Nor, of those who had been there when this visitor entered, was there one left.
vi: The people who were present in the bar when this strange guest entered had also all left, leaving no one behind.
tr: In fact, when this stranger entered, only one person remained from those who were already there.
es: Of all those who were in the establishment when the one conversing with the landlady entered, not a single one remained: they had all left.

en: They had all dropped off.
vi: Disappeared without a trace.
tr: Everyone else had left.
es: Of all those who were in the establishment when the one conversing with the landlady entered, not a single one remained: they had all left.

en: The spy had kept his eyes open, but had been able to detect no sign.
vi: The spy had observed carefully but saw no signs.
tr: The spy had kept his eyes wide open but had found nothing.
es: The spy, for readers will have understood by now that the individual in question was a spy, had not managed to catch any signals, even though he had been looking with a hundred eyes since he entered.

en: They had lounged away in a poverty-stricken, purposeless, accidental manner, quite natural and unimpeachable.
vi: Everyone was listlessly wandering in the same manner, hungry, aimless, indifferent, completely natural and beyond suspicion.
tr: People had left the shop in a manner that aroused no suspicion, sluggishly, in their miserable, aimless, and random states.
es: —Juan!

en: “John,” thought madame, checking off her work as her fingers knitted, and her eyes looked at the stranger.
vi: “John,” the shop owner thought to herself, her fingers weaving this name into the list, then looking at the stranger.
tr: Her fingers knitting furiously and her eyes on the stranger, while working her patterns, the lady thought to herself, "JOHN."
es: —thought Mrs. Defarge, knitting and keeping her eyes on the customer.
