en: “Stay long enough, and I shall knit ‘barsad’ before you go.”
vi: “Stay a little longer and I will have time to weave in your last name Barsad as well.” −
tr: "Stay a little longer so that I can knit 'BARSAD' before you leave.""
es: —If you stay here much longer, I will write Barsad right under your nose.

en: “You have a husband, madame?”
vi: Do you have a husband?
tr: "Are you married, madam?""
es: —Are you married, ma'am?

en: “I have.”
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Children?”
vi: Yes. − Children? −
tr: "Do you have children?"
es: —With children?

en: “No children.”
vi: No children.
tr: "No."
es: —Without children.

en: “Business seems bad?”
vi: − Business seems tough?
tr: "Things are probably going badly?"
es: —And business, is it going well?

en: “Business is very bad; the people are so poor.”
vi: − Business is very tough; the people are too poor.
tr: "Things are bad; people are very poor.""
es: —Business is very bad. People are so poor!...

en: “Ah, the unfortunate, miserable people!
vi: − Oh, the miserable, unfortunate people!
tr: "Oh unfortunate and miserable people!
es: —Ah, yes! Poor and unfortunate!

en: So oppressed, too—as you say.”
vi: And still so oppressed... as she said.
tr: Moreover, there is so much pressure on them – as you said."
es: And even shamefully oppressed!... as you say.

en: “As you say,” madame retorted, correcting him, and deftly knitting an extra something into his name that boded him no good.
vi: − You said it yourself, - she retorted, corrected, and swiftly added some symbol that was anything but flattering to this name.
tr: "As you said," the lady immediately corrected, and skillfully wove something ominous next to the man's name.
es: —As you say—corrected the barmaid, moving her fingers more quickly and adding something to the surname Barsad.

en: “Pardon me; certainly it was I who said so, but you naturally think so.
vi: − Excuse me, it was indeed I who spoke, not you, but of course you think so too.
tr: "Ah, pardon; I was the one who said that, of course, but you must be thinking the same thing."
es: —Excuse me: it's true that I was the one who said it, but I have no doubt that you think it.

en: Of course.”
vi: Of course.
tr: "Certainly.""
es: It can't be anything else.

en: “I think?” returned madame, in a high voice.
vi: − Me, think? - She replied in a high-pitched voice.
tr: "Is that so?" replied the madam loudly.
es: —Do I think about it?—replied the innkeeper.

en: “I and my husband have enough to do to keep this wine-shop open, without thinking.
vi: - My husband and I are already too busy running this pub. There's no time to think about anything else.
tr: "We have no time to think from trying to keep this wine shop running with my husband.
es: —Our establishment causes my husband and me too many headaches for us to afford the luxury of thinking.

en: All we think, here, is how to live.
vi: Here, we only think about how to survive.
tr: The only thing we think about here is how we will live.
es: The only thing we think about is making sure we have what we need to live.

en: That is the subject we think of, and it gives us, from morning to night, enough to think about, without embarrassing our heads concerning others.
vi: That's what we think about, and it's enough to keep us busy from morning till night, leaving no room to think about anything else.
tr: That's our whole concern, so our minds are occupied with many things day and night, we have no state to think about others.
es: This is the goal of all our musings, which provides a very broad field for all our thoughts.

en: I think for others?
vi: Me, think about something else?
tr: How are other people doing?
es: Me think for others?

en: No, no.”
vi: No way.
tr: There's nothing to be done."
es: Not in my lifetime!

en: The spy, who was there to pick up any crumbs he could find or make, did not allow his baffled state to express itself in his sinister face; but, stood with an air of gossiping gallantry, leaning his elbow on Madame Defarge’s little counter, and occasionally sipping his cognac.
vi: Coming here to gather any bits of information he could get, the spy did not allow his confusion to show on his sinister face but stood there pretending to chat casually, his elbows resting on Madame Defarge's wine counter, occasionally sipping a bit of cognac.
tr: The spy, who was there to gather the smallest crumb of information he could find, had managed not to let his astonishment show on his sinister face, but as he leaned his elbow on Madame Defarge's small counter and sipped his cognac little by little, he still stood there with the air of a gossiping hero.
es: The spy, who had entered determined to gather whatever he could, was very careful not to let his sinister face show his disappointment. On the contrary, he continued leaning on his elbows over the counter, directing the occasional compliment to the barmaid and taking a sip of cognac from time to time.

en: “A bad business this, madame, of Gaspard’s execution.
vi: − Truly dreadful, madam, the execution of Gaspard.
tr: "This is very bad, madam, I mean Gaspard's execution.
es: —The execution of Gaspard has been a judicial brutality, madam.

en: Ah! the poor Gaspard!”
vi: Oh! Poor Gaspard! - A very sympathetic sigh.
tr: Oh! Poor Gaspard!" she said, sighing deeply with sorrow.
es: Poor Gaspard!

en: With a sigh of great compassion.
vi: − Really? -
tr: Oh! Poor Gaspard!" she said, sighing deeply with sorrow.
es: —she exclaimed, letting out a sigh.

en: “My faith!” returned madame, coolly and lightly, “if people use knives for such purposes, they have to pay for it.
vi: The shop owner said nonchalantly.
tr: "Peace!" said the madam with a calm and carefree demeanor, "if people use knives for such purposes, they must bear the consequences.
es: —We do not agree—replied the innkeeper coldly. —It is only fair that those who allow their knives to be used as Gaspard used his, should pay for it.

en: He knew beforehand what the price of his luxury was; he has paid the price.”
vi: - Anyone who uses a knife for such things must pay the price. He already knew the price of that luxury and has paid it.
tr: He knew what this behavior would cost and he paid for it."
es: He knew perfectly well the price at which such luxuries are paid, and he has paid it: nothing more natural.

en: “I believe,” said the spy, dropping his soft voice to a tone that invited confidence, and expressing an injured revolutionary susceptibility in every muscle of his wicked face: “I believe there is much compassion and anger in this neighbourhood, touching the poor fellow?
vi: − I heard that... - the spy lowered his voice to a whisper as if to suggest a secret, every muscle on his fierce face bearing the suspicious look of a wounded revolutionary - I heard that the people here are very sympathetic and angry about that poor person.
tr: The spy, "If you ask me," he said, giving his voice a softness that evoked confidence and adding a revolutionary sensitivity to every nerve of his mischievous face; "If you ask me, the people in this neighborhood are filled with great compassion and anger because of this poor man.
es: —I believe—added the spy, lowering his voice and as if inviting his interlocutor to enter the realm of confidences, while giving his sinister face a resolutely revolutionary expression,—I believe that this whole neighborhood sympathizes with the fate of the unfortunate man and roars with fury against those who have sacrificed him.

en: Between ourselves.”
vi: Just telling you, ma'am.
tr: Let's keep it between us."
es: Just between the two of us, I find it justified.

en: “Is there?” asked madame, vacantly.
vi: − Is that so? - the shop owner asked absentmindedly.
tr: "Is that so?" said the madam, with empty eyes.
es: —But does that fury exist?

en: “Is there not?”
vi: − Isn't that so?
tr: "Isn't that so?"
es: —Haven't you noticed?

en: “—Here is my husband!” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − ... My house is here! - Mrs. Defarge said.
tr: "..." "Here comes my husband!" said Madam Defarge.
es: —Here is my husband—said Mrs. Defarge.

en: As the keeper of the wine-shop entered at the door, the spy saluted him by touching his hat, and saying, with an engaging smile, “Good day, Jacques!”
vi: The shop owner had just passed through the door when the spy lifted his hat in greeting and said with a deliberate smile, "Hello, Jacques!"
tr: When the owner of the wine shop walked in through the door, the spy touched his hat and greeted him, smiling sympathetically, "Good day, Jacques!" he said.
es: No sooner had the innkeeper entered the establishment, the spy greeted him by touching his hat and saying with an insinuating smile: —Good morning, Santiago.

en: Defarge stopped short, and stared at him.
vi: Defarge stood still, glaring at him.
tr: Defarge stayed where he was and fixed his eyes on the man.
es: Defarge stood rooted to the ground, his eyes fixed on the spy.

en: “Good day, Jacques!” the spy repeated; with not quite so much confidence, or quite so easy a smile under the stare.
vi: − Hello, Jacques! - He repeated, no longer entirely confident, and his smile turned awkward under that intense stare.
tr: "Good day, Jacques!" repeated the spy, but under these gazes, the confidence in his voice and the smile on his face had weakened.
es: —You are mistaken, my good sir.

en: “You deceive yourself, monsieur,” returned the keeper of the wine-shop.
vi: − You are mistaken, sir, - the innkeeper replied. -
tr: "There is a mistake, monsieur," replied the owner of the wine shop.

en: “You mistake me for another.
vi: You are mistaking me for someone else.
tr: "You must have confused me with someone else.
es: You are confusing me with someone else.

en: That is not my name.
vi: That is not my name.
tr: I am not Jacques.
es: My name is not Santiago: I am Ernesto Defarge.

en: I am Ernest Defarge.”
vi: My name is Ernest Defarge.
tr: My name is Ernest Defarge."
es: My name is not Santiago: I am Ernesto Defarge.

en: “It is all the same,” said the spy, airily, but discomfited too: “good day!”
vi: − It's all the same, - the spy said cheerfully, but also awkwardly.
tr: "What difference does it make," said the spy in a flippant manner but was annoyed, "still, have a good day!"
es: —It's the same—replied the spy with a smile on his lips, although unable to completely hide his annoyance.—The name is the least of it.

en: “Good day!” answered Defarge, drily.
vi: - Hello! − Hello! - Defarge replied coldly.
tr: "Good day!" said Defarge emotionlessly.
es: Good morning. —Good morning—replied Defarge curtly.

en: “I was saying to madame, with whom I had the pleasure of chatting when you entered, that they tell me there is—and no wonder!—much sympathy and anger in Saint Antoine, touching the unhappy fate of poor Gaspard.”
vi: − I just told you, I had the honor of conversing with your wife when you came in, about what people are saying, that the people of Saint Antoine are very sympathetic and angry... and rightly so!... About the unfortunate fate of poor Gaspard.
tr: "When you came in, I was telling the lady with whom I had the pleasure of conversing that St. Antoine was seething with pain and anger due to the poor fate of unfortunate Gaspard – and rightly so!"
es: —I was telling the lady, with whom I have had the honor of chatting for a while, that, according to what I am told, there reigns in the neighborhood... and it does not surprise me... as much sympathy for the unfortunate Gaspard as there is irritation against those who have inhumanely sacrificed him.

en: “No one has told me so,” said Defarge, shaking his head.
vi: − I haven't heard anyone say that, - Defarge shook his head.
tr: "I have never heard of such a thing," said Defarge, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —I have heard no one say such a thing—replied Defarge.

en: “I know nothing of it.”
vi: - I don't know anything about this.
tr: "I have no idea.""
es: —I don't know a word.

en: Having said it, he passed behind the little counter, and stood with his hand on the back of his wife’s chair, looking over that barrier at the person to whom they were both opposed, and whom either of them would have shot with the greatest satisfaction.
vi: After speaking, he walked around to the back of the bar, stood with his hand resting on the back of his wife's chair, and looked at the person sitting on the other side of the barrier facing both him and his wife, the person whom both he and his wife would gleefully shoot dead if given the chance.
tr: After saying this, Defarge went behind the small counter and stood there with his hand on the back of his wife's chair, both of them scrutinizing the man standing directly in front of them, whom they would drown in a spoonful of water if they could.
es: Having said this, he went behind the counter and positioned himself behind his wife. From the opposite side of the fragile barrier, the couple observed the individual whom they would have shot with the greatest pleasure.

en: The spy, well used to his business, did not change his unconscious attitude, but drained his little glass of cognac, took a sip of fresh water, and asked for another glass of cognac.
vi: Accustomed to the job, the detective pretended not to know, kept drinking the small glass of cognac, sipped some cool water, and then ordered another glass of cognac.
tr: The spy, who had now mastered his craft, still acted as if he was unaware of anything; he had finished his glass of cognac, taken a sip of water, and asked for another glass of cognac.
es: The spy, skilled in his trade, did not change his attitude of indifference. He finished the contents of the small glass that had been served to him, took a sip of fresh water, and ordered the second glass of cognac.

en: Madame Defarge poured it out for him, took to her knitting again, and hummed a little song over it.
vi: Madame Defarge poured wine for him, then picked up her knitting and continued, knitting while softly humming a song.
tr: Madam Defarge filled the man's glass, took up her knitting again, and started to hum a song.
es: Mrs. Defarge served it to him, after which she continued knitting with great fervor and humming a tune.

en: “You seem to know this quarter well; that is to say, better than I do?” observed Defarge.
vi: − It seems you know this area well; that is, even better than I do? - Defarge said.
tr: "It seems you know this area even better than I do, huh?" said Defarge.
es: —It seems that you know the neighborhood well—observed Defarge;—I mean, you know it better than I do.

en: “Not at all, but I hope to know it better.
vi: − Not at all, but I want to know more.
tr: "No, not really, but I want to learn better.
es: —No, my friend. I know it very little, but I hope to get to know it well.

en: I am so profoundly interested in its miserable inhabitants.”
vi: I am wholeheartedly concerned about the miserable residents here.
tr: I have a deep interest in the wretched inhabitants of these parts."
es: Its wretched inhabitants awaken a deep interest in me.

en: “Hah!” muttered Defarge.
vi: − Hmph! - Defarge muttered.
tr: "Hmph!" grumbled Defarge.
es: —Ah! —exclaimed Defarge.

en: “The pleasure of conversing with you, Monsieur Defarge, recalls to me,” pursued the spy, “that I have the honour of cherishing some interesting associations with your name.”
vi: − Thanks to the honor of speaking with you, Mr. Defarge, I remembered this matter, - the spy kept talking - the matter is that I also had the honor of knowing some interesting things related to you.
tr: "Monsieur Defarge, the happiness of speaking with you has given me the honor of recalling some individuals associated with your name," the spy continued.
es: "The pleasure of conversing with you, Mr. Defarge," continued the spy, "reminds me that I have had the honor of becoming familiar with incidents in which you have taken an active part."

en: “Indeed!” said Defarge, with much indifference.
vi: − Really? - Defarge said even more indifferently.
tr: "Is that so!" said Defarge, with a rather indifferent attitude.
es: —Really! —said Defarge indifferently.

en: “Yes, indeed.
vi: − Yes, it's true.
tr: "Yes, yes.
es: —Nothing more certain.

en: When Doctor Manette was released, you, his old domestic, had the charge of him, I know.
vi: When Doctor Manette was released from prison, it was he, his former servant, who took care of him, I know this.
tr: When Doctor Manette was released, I know that you took care of him as his former servant.
es: When Doctor Manette was released, you, who were once his servant, took charge of him.

en: He was delivered to you.
vi: The doctor was entrusted to him.
tr: They brought him to you.
es: He was entrusted to you.

en: You see I am informed of the circumstances?”
vi: I know the story well, you see?
tr: As you can see, I am aware of what happened."
es: So you see, I am well aware of the matter.

en: “Such is the fact, certainly,” said Defarge.
vi: − That's right, - said Defarge.
tr: "That's right!" said Defarge.
es: —It's true: you are right—he replied.

en: He had had it conveyed to him, in an accidental touch of his wife’s elbow as she knitted and warbled, that he would do best to answer, but always with brevity.
vi: While knitting and humming, his wife casually nudged him with her elbow, implying that he should respond, but as briefly as possible.
tr: His wife, while knitting, had accidentally nudged him with her elbow and murmured like a song that it would be good to give a quick answer without prolonging the conversation.
es: Accidentally, his wife's elbow, which continued to move the needles with great activity, brushed against his, and in the brushing, despite being accidental, Defarge saw an indication that he should answer the spy's questions, but briefly.

en: “It was to you,” said the spy, “that his daughter came; and it was from your care that his daughter took him, accompanied by a neat brown monsieur; how is he called?—in a little wig—Lorry—of the bank of Tellson and Company—over to England.”
vi: − It was you whom the doctor's daughter came to find, - the spy said, - and she took her father away from your place, accompanied by a gentleman in a fine brown coat; what was his name again?... wearing a small wig... Lorry... people from Tellson's Bank and the Association... went to England.
tr: "The girl had come to you," said the spy, "and she had taken her away from you, accompanied by a gentleman in a neat brown suit; what was his name? –he had a small wig on his head –Lorry from Tellson and Company– from England."
es: —The doctor's daughter presented herself to you—continued the spy. —She came in the company of a gentleman... what was his name?... A gentleman who wore a wig... Ah, yes! Lorry... His name was Lorry... from Tellson's Bank and Company... She came in the company of Mr. Lorry, took charge of her father's person, and took him to England.

en: “Such is the fact,” repeated Defarge.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge repeated.
tr: "It is true," repeated Defarge.
es: —That is how it was, indeed—repeated Defarge.

en: “Very interesting remembrances!” said the spy.
vi: − Very fond memories! - The spy said.
tr: "Very interesting things have stayed in my mind!" said the spy.
es: —One always remembers such incidents with pleasure—replied the spy.

en: “I have known Doctor Manette and his daughter, in England.”
vi: - I know Dr. Manette and his daughter in England.
tr: "I had met Doctor Manette and his daughter in England."
es: —I have met Dr. Manette and his daughter in England.

en: “Yes?” said Defarge.
vi: − Really? - Defarge said.
tr: "Is that so?" said Defarge.
es: —Yes?—asked Defarge.

en: “You don’t hear much about them now?” said the spy.
vi: − Have you heard any news about them lately? −
tr: "Don't you receive news from them anymore?" said the spy.
es: —Do you receive news from him frequently?—asked the spy.

en: “No,” said Defarge.
vi: No.
tr: "No," said Defarge.
es: —No—responded Defarge.

en: “In effect,” madame struck in, looking up from her work and her little song, “we never hear about them.
vi: − Actually, - Mrs. Defarge stopped knitting, stopped singing, looked up and interjected, - we haven't heard anything about them anymore.
tr: "Actually," Madam Defarge interjected, lifting her head from her work and pausing her song, "we can no longer hear from them.
es: —It's been a very long time since we've heard from them—interjected the innkeeper's wife.

en: We received the news of their safe arrival, and perhaps another letter, or perhaps two; but, since then, they have gradually taken their road in life—we, ours—and we have held no correspondence.”
vi: We did get news that they arrived safely, and received one or two letters; but since then, we've gone our separate ways... they and us... we no longer have any contact.
tr: We had heard that they arrived safely, then we received one or two more letters, but after that, they went their way, we went ours, and our connection was completely severed.
es: —We received news that they had arrived safely, and some time later a letter... maybe two; but then, they continued on their way, we on ours, and our correspondence has completely ceased.

en: “Perfectly so, madame,” replied the spy.
vi: − Yes, ma'am, - the spy replied.
tr: "You are right, madam," replied the spy.
es: —That's what usually happens—observed the spy.—The daughter is ready to get married.

en: “She is going to be married.”
vi: - That girl is about to get married. − Getting married soon? -
tr: "The doctor's daughter is going to get married soon."
es: —That's what usually happens—observed the spy.—The daughter is ready to get married.

en: “Going?” echoed madame.
vi: The shop owner said.
tr: "Is she going to get married?" repeated the madam.
es: —Is she about to get married?—repeated Madame Defarge.

en: “She was pretty enough to have been married long ago.
vi: - A pretty girl like her should have been married long ago.
tr: "She was such a lovely girl that I thought she must have already gotten married."
es: —She is quite beautiful enough to have been married long ago.

en: You English are cold, it seems to me.”
vi: You English people seem quite cold.
tr: "I think you English people are quite cold too.""
es: Of course, you English are blocks of ice instead of men!

en: “Oh!
vi: − Oh!
tr: "Aaa!
es: —Ah!

en: You know I am English.”
vi: You know I'm English.
tr: How do you know that I am English?""
es: Who told you that I am English?

en: “I perceive your tongue is,” returned madame; “and what the tongue is, I suppose the man is.”
vi: − From the voice, I can tell, - the shop owner replied, - and I think the voice reflects the person.
tr: "I understood your language," replied the madam, "and to me, a person is what their language is."
es: —I see that your language is English, and I have always believed that a man is of the same nationality as his language.

en: He did not take the identification as a compliment; but he made the best of it, and turned it off with a laugh.
vi: That guy did not take this recognition as a compliment; but he skillfully managed with a fake laugh.
tr: Although Casus did not see this observation as a compliment. he did not show that he was upset and brushed it off with a laugh.
es: Discovering his nationality did not amuse the spy at all, although he took great care to keep his discontent deep in his chest.

en: After sipping his cognac to the end, he added:
vi: After finishing his glass of cognac, he continued: − Yes, Miss Manette is about to get married.
tr: Then he downed the cognac and said:
es: He let out a laugh, finished the contents of his glass, and replied:

en: “Yes, Miss Manette is going to be married.
vi: After finishing his glass of cognac, he continued: − Yes, Miss Manette is about to get married.
tr: "Yes, Miss Manette is getting married.
es: —Well yes, Miss Manette is about to get married, but not to an Englishman, rather to a man who, like her, was born in France.

en: But not to an Englishman; to one who, like herself, is French by birth.
vi: But she is not marrying an Englishman; she is marrying someone like her, of French origin.
tr: But not to an Englishman; to someone who, like her, is French by birth.
es: —Well yes, Miss Manette is about to get married, but not to an Englishman, rather to a man who, like her, was born in France.

en: And speaking of Gaspard (ah, poor Gaspard!
vi: Speaking of Gaspard; (Oh dear, poor Gaspard!
tr: Speaking of Gaspard (oh poor Gaspard!
es: Speaking of Gaspard!... Poor Gaspard!...

en: It was cruel, cruel!), it is a curious thing that she is going to marry the nephew of Monsieur the Marquis, for whom Gaspard was exalted to that height of so many feet; in other words, the present Marquis.
vi: So cruel, so cruel!) the strange thing is that she is about to marry the nephew of the Marquis, the very man for whom Gaspard was hanged high up; in other words; Miss Manette's fiancé is the current Marquis.
tr: What a great cruelty, it was terrible!) how strange it is that Miss Manette is going to marry Monsieur Marquis's nephew, that is, the person who caused Gaspard to hang so many meters above; in other words, the new Marquis, Mr. Charles Darnay – his mother's maiden name was also D'Aulnais."
es: It was cruelty... an act of ferocity!... Well then, the man Miss Manette is going to marry is the nephew of the Marquis because of whom Gaspard danced at a height of forty feet above the ground; or rather: the current Marquis.

en: But he lives unknown in England, he is no Marquis there; he is mr Charles Darnay.
vi: But he lives in hiding in England, where he is not a Marquis at all; he is Charles Darnay.
tr: What a great cruelty, it was terrible!) how strange it is that Miss Manette is going to marry Monsieur Marquis's nephew, that is, the person who caused Gaspard to hang so many meters above; in other words, the new Marquis, Mr. Charles Darnay – his mother's maiden name was also D'Aulnais."
es: He lives in England under an assumed name, without flaunting the title of Marquis.

en: D’Aulnais is the name of his mother’s family.”
vi: He goes by the name D’Aulnais from his mother's side.
tr: What a great cruelty, it was terrible!) how strange it is that Miss Manette is going to marry Monsieur Marquis's nephew, that is, the person who caused Gaspard to hang so many meters above; in other words, the new Marquis, Mr. Charles Darnay – his mother's maiden name was also D'Aulnais."
es: He calls himself Charles Darnay; you know that his mother's surname was D'Aulnais.

en: Madame Defarge knitted steadily, but the intelligence had a palpable effect upon her husband.
vi: Mrs. Defarge continued knitting as usual, but this news had an obvious impact on her husband.
tr: Madam Defarge was still knitting resolutely, but the news she had received had a visible effect on her husband.
es: Mrs. Defarge had neither eyes nor hands, nor faculties for anything other than the knitting she was doing, but the news had a palpable effect on her husband.

en: Do what he would, behind the little counter, as to the striking of a light and the lighting of his pipe, he was troubled, and his hand was not trustworthy.
vi: Behind the bar, Defarge struck a match and lit his pipe, his trembling hands revealing his agitation.
tr: It was evident from his every move that he was struggling as he lit his pipe behind the small counter, his hands trembling.
es: His face reflected intense turmoil, despite his efforts to control himself, his hands trembled, and his inner agitation seeped through every pore of his body.

en: The spy would have been no spy if he had failed to see it, or to record it in his mind.
vi: That spy wouldn't be worthy of being called a spy if he didn't notice or pay attention to those signs.
tr: If the spy had missed this or failed to note it in his mind, he wouldn't be called a spy.
es: The spy would not have been worthy of his position if he had not noticed this and committed it to memory.

en: Having made, at least, this one hit, whatever it might prove to be worth, and no customers coming in to help him to any other, mr Barsad paid for what he had drunk, and took his leave: taking occasion to say, in a genteel manner, before he departed, that he looked forward to the pleasure of seeing Monsieur and Madame Defarge again.
vi: At least he won a point, though its value was uncertain, and with no more customers entering the shop for him to gather more information, Barsad paid for his drink and left; on his way out, he courteously expressed his desire to have the honor of meeting Mr. and Mrs. Defarge again.
tr: Although it was not very clear what Defarge's state proved, at least the spy had managed to hit him from somewhere, and since there were no other customers around to come to his aid with another piece of evidence, Mr. Barsad paid for his drinks and left the shop. Before leaving, he created an opportunity and in a polite manner. He did not forget to mention that he would be happy to see Monsieur and Madame Defarge again and that he was looking forward to it.
es: Having obtained that result, although without knowing if it could be of any use to him, Mr. Barsad, seeing that no customers were arriving whose conversations might have provided him with valuable information, paid for what he had taken and left, not without expressing, with great politeness, that he would have the pleasure of frequently visiting the establishment.

en: For some minutes after he had emerged into the outer presence of Saint Antoine, the husband and wife remained exactly as he had left them, lest he should come back.
vi: He had been outside Saint Antoine for a few minutes, yet the couple remained in their positions, fearing he might return.
tr: Even after the spy had moved far away from St. Antoine, the couple waited in the same position for a while, in case he might return.
es: Minutes later, when the spy had left the area protected by Saint Anthony, husband and wife continued exactly as if the spy had not left the shop, undoubtedly fearing that he might retrace his steps.

en: “Can it be true,” said Defarge, in a low voice, looking down at his wife as he stood smoking with his hand on the back of her chair: “what he has said of Ma’amselle Manette?”
vi: − Is it true? - Defarge asked in a low voice, his eyes looking down at his wife while he stood smoking, one hand resting on the back of her chair. − Is what he said about Miss Manette true?
tr: "I wonder," said Defarge in a low voice, standing behind his wife's chair, looking at her while puffing on his pipe, "could what the man said about Mademoiselle Manette be true?"
es: —Could it be true what that man said about Miss Manette?—asked Defarge in a low voice.

en: “As he has said it,” returned madame, lifting her eyebrows a little, “it is probably false.
vi: − That's what he said, - the wife replied; her eyebrows slightly raised, - it might not be true.
tr: "According to what he said," said the madam, raising her eyebrows slightly, "it is probably wrong.
es: —It is probably a lie; but I do not deny that it could be true—replied the woman.

en: But it may be true.”
vi: But it might be true.
tr: But it could also be right."
es: —Yes, it is...

en: “If it is—” Defarge began, and stopped.
vi: − If... - Defarge had just started speaking when he fell silent. − If what? -
tr: "If it's true," Defarge started to say, but fell silent.
es: Defarge did not finish his thought.

en: “If it is?” repeated his wife.
vi: The wife asked.
tr: "What if it's true?" his wife repeated. "..."
es: —What?—asked the woman.

en: “—And if it does come, while we live to see it triumph—I hope, for her sake, Destiny will keep her husband out of France.”
vi: − ... If it happens, when we are still alive to see the victory... I hope that, for her sake, fate will keep her husband away from France.
tr: If it is true and we can see the victory – for the girl's sake, I hope Fate keeps her husband away from France."
es: —Yes, it is... and given that things come in a way that we can see the triumph... for her, I will wish that Destiny keeps her husband far from France.

en: “Her husband’s destiny,” said Madame Defarge, with her usual composure, “will take him where he is to go, and will lead him to the end that is to end him.
vi: − Her husband's fate, - said Madame Defarge with her usual indifferent tone, - will lead him to where he must go, to the end he must meet.
tr: "Whatever her husband's fate is," said Madame Defarge with her usual calmness, "it will take him to where he is destined to go, that is, to the end that will finish him."
es: —The fate of your husband will take him where he must go—responded the innkeeper with glacial calm—and it will lead him to the end that is destined for him.

en: That is all I know.”
vi: That is all I know.
tr: That's all I know."
es: That is all I can tell you.

en: “But it is very strange—now, at least, is it not very strange”—said Defarge, rather pleading with his wife to induce her to admit it, “that, after all our sympathy for Monsieur her father, and herself, her husband’s name should be proscribed under your hand at this moment, by the side of that infernal dog’s who has just left us?”
vi: − But it's so strange... oh, but how could it not be strange... - Defarge almost pleaded with his wife to admit, - think about it, after all the affection we've given to the doctor, to his daughter, now under your knitting needles, her husband's name is next to the name of that scoundrel who just left? −
tr: Defarge, "But this is very strange – I mean, at least for now, isn't it very strange?" he said to his wife, almost as if begging for her to agree with him, "look, while feeling so much sympathy for her father and herself, you will now trap her future husband's name, the one who just left the shop, in your knitting next to that wretched dog?"
es: —But you will deny that it is very... strange... I say strange for lack of a better word... don't you find it strange that with all the sympathy we have always had for her father, and even for her herself, you are now condemning her husband with your own hand, based solely on what that hellhound who just left said?

en: “Stranger things than that will happen when it does come,” answered madame.
vi: When it happens, there will be even stranger things, - his wife replied.
tr: "When the day we've been waiting for comes, we will see even stranger things," replied the madam.
es: —Stranger things than that will happen when the day comes—replied Madame Defarge.

en: “I have them both here, of a certainty; and they are both here for their merits; that is enough.”
vi: − I have saved both names to the list, it's all done; both deserve it; that is enough.
tr: "I wrote both of them here, they will stay forever, and they both deserved this; that's enough.""
es: —I have both of them here; make no mistake; and they will be treated according to their merits. This should suffice for you.

en: She rolled up her knitting when she had said those words, and presently took the rose out of the handkerchief that was wound about her head.
vi: She had gathered up her knitting when she said those words, then removed the rose from her headscarf.
tr: After saying these words, she gathered her knitting and immediately removed the rose from the side of her head.
es: Having said these words, she picked up the stocking and removed the rose that adorned her head.

en: Either Saint Antoine had an instinctive sense that the objectionable decoration was gone, or Saint Antoine was on the watch for its disappearance; howbeit, the Saint took courage to lounge in, very shortly afterwards, and the wine-shop recovered its habitual aspect.
vi: Either the people of Saint Antoine intuitively knew that the offensive ornament had disappeared, or they had been waiting for the moment the rose was taken down; in any case, the people of this area soon after shuffled back, restoring the old vitality to the tavern.
tr: The people of St. Antoine either instinctively felt that this troublesome ornament had been removed or had witnessed its disappearance firsthand; whatever the case, the neighborhood residents suddenly rushed in, and the wine shop returned to its usual state.
es: Whether it was that Saint Anthony instinctively knew the hour, the precise moment when the innkeeper would make that innocent flower disappear which seemed to displease him so much, or whether he was watching for the moment of its disappearance, the fact is that the Saint did not take long to appear, and that, within a few seconds, the establishment had regained its usual animation.

en: In the evening, at which season of all others Saint Antoine turned himself inside out, and sat on door-steps and window-ledges, and came to the corners of vile streets and courts, for a breath of air, Madame Defarge with her work in her hand was accustomed to pass from place to place and from group to group: a Missionary—there were many like her—such as the world will do well never to breed again.
vi: In the afternoon, during this season, it was the time when people in Saint Antoine would show their faces on the streets, sit on their doorsteps or window sills, gather at street corners or in dirty courtyards to catch the breeze, and Madame Defarge, with her knitting in hand, was accustomed to moving from place to place, meeting one group after another - she was like a missionary (there were many like her); the kind of person whose absence would make the world a better place.
tr: In the evening, the people of St. Antoine once again took to the streets to get some fresh air, sitting on doorsteps and window sills, and emerging into the miserable street corners and courtyards. Madame Defarge, with her work in hand, was accustomed to wandering from one group to another.
es: When night fell, during the times of the year when the inhabitants of San Antonio would sit at their doorsteps or gather in streets and courtyards seeking fresh air to breathe, Mrs. Defarge, with her work in hand, would usually go from door to door and from group to group... a kind of missionary like so many others.

en: All the women knitted.
vi: All the women knitted.
tr: A woman who was a Missionary – there were many like her – was knitting furiously. All the women were knitting.
es: All the women would knit, undoubtedly so that this mechanical work would substitute for the jaws, which were forcibly idle most of the time.

en: They knitted worthless things; but, the mechanical work was a mechanical substitute for eating and drinking; the hands moved for the jaws and the digestive apparatus: if the bony fingers had been still, the stomachs would have been more famine-pinched.
vi: They knitted useless things; but this craft was a mechanical substitute for eating; the hands worked in place of the mouth and digestive organs - if those bony fingers were to remain still, the stomachs would growl more from hunger.
tr: They were knitting unnecessary things, but this mechanical work served as a substitute for eating and drinking; instead of jaws and digestive systems, their hands were working; if their skinny fingers were to stop, their stomachs would shrink even more.
es: Since the jaws and the digestive system could not move, the hands would move. If the idleness had extended to the fingers, the stomachs would have felt the rigors of hunger more.

en: But, as the fingers went, the eyes went, and the thoughts.
vi: Like nimble fingers; the eyes were also nimble, and the thoughts were nimble as well.
tr: As the fingers worked, the eyes also worked, and of course, so did the minds.
es: As the fingers moved, so did the eyes and thoughts; and as Madame Defarge went from door to door and from group to group, the fingers of the women she encountered worked with redoubled fervor, their eyes looked with greater fierceness, and the activity of their thoughts increased a hundredfold.

en: And as Madame Defarge moved on from group to group, all three went quicker and fiercer among every little knot of women that she had spoken with, and left behind.
vi: As Madame Defarge moved from one group to another, all three of these things worked faster and more fiercely in each group of women she had spoken to and then left.
tr: As Madame Defarge moved from one group to another, this trio became increasingly faster and more determined in each small group of women that Madame spoke to and left behind.
es: As the fingers moved, so did the eyes and thoughts; and as Madame Defarge went from door to door and from group to group, the fingers of the women she encountered worked with redoubled fervor, their eyes looked with greater fierceness, and the activity of their thoughts increased a hundredfold.

en: Her husband smoked at his door, looking after her with admiration.
vi: The husband stood smoking at the doorway, looking at his wife with admiration.
tr: Her husband was smoking a cigarette in front of the door, looking at his wife with admiration.
es: Her husband smoked by the door of the tavern, watching his life's companion with admiration.

en: “A great woman,” said he, “a strong woman, a grand woman, a frightfully grand woman!”
vi: “How rare are skillful women,” he thought to himself, “a strong, exceptional woman, incredibly talented!”
tr: " What an amazing woman," he said, "a strong, great, incredibly great woman this is!" he was saying.
es: —A great woman... a strong woman... a sublime woman! —he murmured.

en: Darkness closed around, and then came the ringing of church bells and the distant beating of the military drums in the Palace Courtyard, as the women sat knitting, knitting.
vi: Darkness gradually fell, then the church bells chimed and from afar echoed the rhythm of the Royal Guard's drums as the women sat knitting, still knitting.
tr: Darkness had enveloped the surroundings, and while the women sat knitting furiously, the church bells rang and the distant sounds of the soldiers' drums in the Palace courtyard could be heard.
es: Night fell; the church bells rang and the distant sound of drums echoed: the women continued knitting.

en: Darkness encompassed them.
vi: Darkness enveloped them.
tr: The darkness had settled heavily upon them.
es: Another darker night was approaching, another night in which the church bells, which now rang joyfully, would give their bronze to be melted into thundering cannons, in which the drum rolls would thunder through the air to drown out the voice of a condemned man... omnipotent that night, with the omnipotence granted by power and abundance, freedom and life.

en: Another darkness was closing in as surely, when the church bells, then ringing pleasantly in many an airy steeple over France, should be melted into thundering cannon; when the military drums should be beating to drown a wretched voice, that night all potent as the voice of Power and Plenty, Freedom and Life.
vi: Another night was surely approaching when the cheerful church bells now ringing from high towers across France would be melted down to cast formidable cannons; when the drumbeats that usually drowned out the cries of the wretched would roar in that night with the screams of Power and Plenty, of Freedom and Life.
tr: As the church bells rang – these bells that sweetly chimed from the towers rising over France would later blend with the sound of thundering cannons – another darkness was approaching with sure steps; the military drums that needed to be played to drown out the wretched voices would beat that night for "Power and Abundance, Freedom and Life."
es: Another darker night was approaching, another night in which the church bells, which now rang joyfully, would give their bronze to be melted into thundering cannons, in which the drum rolls would thunder through the air to drown out the voice of a condemned man... omnipotent that night, with the omnipotence granted by power and abundance, freedom and life.

en: So much was closing in about the women who sat knitting, knitting, that they their very selves were closing in around a structure yet unbuilt, where they were to sit knitting, knitting, counting dropping heads.
vi: Layer upon layer of darkness covered the women who sat knitting, still knitting, their hearts harboring dreams of seeing themselves gathered around a high platform yet to be erected, where they sat knitting, knitting, counting, counting each head as it fell.
tr: The women who ceaselessly knitted as they sat were very close to their destination, now surrounding an unfinished structure where they would sit knitting and counting the heads being executed.
es: The veils of the night enveloped the women who were knitting, just as they would soon envelop that other building, not yet constructed, where they would sit, also knitting but watching and counting at the same time the heads that fell one after another.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Layer upon layer of darkness covered the women who sat knitting, still knitting, their hearts harboring dreams of seeing themselves gathered around a high platform yet to be erected, where they sat knitting, knitting, counting, counting each head as it fell.
tr: XVII
es: XVII.

en: One Night
vi: 17. That night
tr: One Night
es: ONE NIGHT

en: Never did the sun go down with a brighter glory on the quiet corner in Soho, than one memorable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat under the plane-tree together.
vi: Never had the sun set so gloriously on the quiet corner of Soho as it did that memorable evening when the doctor and his daughter sat together under the elm tree.
tr: The sun had never set with such a bright halo in that quiet corner of Soho as it did on that unforgettable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat together under the plane tree.
es: Neither the tranquil refuge of Soho ever admired such a beautiful sunset as the memorable evening when Doctor Manette and his daughter watched it while sitting under the leafy plane tree that stood in the courtyard of the house, nor did the moon ever rise so radiant and splendid over the city of London as the night that found them sitting under the tree and bathed their faces and heads with a serene light filtered through the leaves.

en: Never did the moon rise with a milder radiance over great London, than on that night when it found them still seated under the tree, and shone upon their faces through its leaves.
vi: Never had the moon risen so gently over the vast city of London as it did that night when the father and daughter were still sitting there, and the moonlight filtered through the leaves, illuminating their faces.
tr: While the father and daughter sat under the tree, the moon, which shone on their faces through the leaves, had never risen over the vast London with such a sweet brightness as it did that evening.
es: Neither the tranquil refuge of Soho ever admired such a beautiful sunset as the memorable evening when Doctor Manette and his daughter watched it while sitting under the leafy plane tree that stood in the courtyard of the house, nor did the moon ever rise so radiant and splendid over the city of London as the night that found them sitting under the tree and bathed their faces and heads with a serene light filtered through the leaves.

en: Lucie was to be married to-morrow.
vi: Lucie will get married tomorrow.
tr: Lude was going to get married the next day.
es: Lucía was to be married the next day, and she wanted to dedicate her last night as a single woman to her father: it was due to this circumstance that she was sitting under the plane tree in the company of the author of her days.

en: She had reserved this last evening for her father, and they sat alone under the plane-tree.
vi: She has spent this last evening with her father, and it is just the two of them under the tree.
tr: She had reserved the last evening for her father, and they were sitting together under the sycamore tree.
es: Lucía was to be married the next day, and she wanted to dedicate her last night as a single woman to her father: it was due to this circumstance that she was sitting under the plane tree in the company of the author of her days.

en: “You are happy, my dear father?”
vi: − Are you happy, dear father? −
tr: "Are you happy, daddy?"
es: —Are you happy, dear father?

en: “Quite, my child.”
vi: Of course, my little girl.
tr: "Yes, my child.""
es: —Completely, my daughter.

en: They had said little, though they had been there a long time.
vi: The father and daughter sat for a long time but spoke little.
tr: Although they had been there for a while, they had spoken very little.
es: Although they had been at the mentioned place for some hours before, they had spoken very little.

en: When it was yet light enough to work and read, she had neither engaged herself in her usual work, nor had she read to him.
vi: There was still enough light to work and read, but she was not as busy as usual and did not read to her father.
tr: Even when there was still enough light to work or read something, Lucie had neither devoted herself to her task nor read a book to her father.
es: On other days, when the girl sat under the tree in the company of her father, she worked or read; but on this occasion, even during the time when she had enough light to work or read, she did neither.

en: She had employed herself in both ways, at his side under the tree, many and many a time; but, this time was not quite like any other, and nothing could make it so.
vi: Usually, when she was with her father under this tree, she would work or read, but this time was completely different; nothing could change today.
tr: She had often idled like this before, under the tree, beside her father, but this evening was not like the others, it couldn't be.
es: The circumstances had changed, and when these change, the routine is interrupted.

en: “And I am very happy to-night, dear father.
vi: − And I am also very happy tonight, Father.
tr: "I am very happy tonight, Daddy.
es: —I am also happy, very happy tonight, my father.

en: I am deeply happy in the love that Heaven has so blessed—my love for Charles, and Charles’s love for me.
vi: I am immensely happy in the love that God has blessed us with; the love I have for Charles and the love Charles has for me.
tr: This love –my love for Charles and Charles's love for me– makes me deeply happy.
es: The love that Heaven has blessed makes me happy... my love for Carlos and Carlos's love for me.

en: But, if my life were not to be still consecrated to you, or if my marriage were so arranged as that it would part us, even by the length of a few of these streets, I should be more unhappy and self-reproachful now than I can tell you.
vi: But if my life no longer allows me to worship you, or if this marriage is arranged to separate us, even if only by a few blocks, then I would now be indescribably sad and regretful.
tr: But if I still couldn't dedicate my life to you or if my marriage, even if just a few streets away, would separate me from you, you can't imagine how unhappy I would be, how bad I would feel.
es: However, if I could not continue dedicating my life to you, if my marriage imposed the obligation to separate from you, even if only the width of the street separated our houses, far from considering myself happy, I would feel miserable.

en: Even as it is—”
vi: Even though...
tr: Actually, even right now-"
es: Even so...

en: Even as it was, she could not command her voice.
vi: No matter how she tried, Lucie would always choke up and leave the sentence unfinished.
tr: At that moment, the young girl couldn't control her voice.
es: Even so, the emotion eventually completely overwhelmed her.

en: In the sad moonlight, she clasped him by the neck, and laid her face upon his breast.
vi: Under the sorrowful moonlight, she wrapped her arms around Mr. Manette's neck and rested her head on her father's chest.
tr: In the melancholy moonlight, the young girl hugged her father's neck and rested her head on his chest.
es: In the melancholic light of the moon, she threw her arms around her father's neck and rested her head on his chest.

en: In the moonlight which is always sad, as the light of the sun itself is—as the light called human life is—at its coming and its going.
vi: The moonlight was always sorrowful, sorrowful like the sunlight - brilliant and then extinguished - like the fleeting fate of human beings.
tr: The moonlight, which always disappeared with the emergence of daylight – that light which calls people to life – was always melancholic anyway.
es: The light of the moon, which is always sad, just as the light of the sun is sad... just as the light we call human life is sad, which shines today and is extinguished tomorrow, illuminated a simply moving scene.

en: “Dearest dear!
vi: − Dear father!
tr: "Dear father!
es: —Dear Father!

en: Can you tell me, this last time, that you feel quite, quite sure, no new affections of mine, and no new duties of mine, will ever interpose between us?
vi: Can you tell me one last time, are you really completely sure that no new feelings or new responsibilities of mine could ever separate the father-daughter bond?
tr: Would you tell me once more that you are sure the new loves and new duties entering my life will never come between us?
es: Are you convinced... firmly convinced, that new loves of mine, new duties of mine, will never come between us?

en: I know it well, but do you know it?
vi: I am certain of that, but what about you?
tr: I am sure of this, but do you think the same?
es: I am; but what about you?

en: In your own heart, do you feel quite certain?”
vi: Deep down, do you completely believe that?
tr: Do you believe this wholeheartedly?"
es: Does this certainty take root in the depths of your heart?

en: Her father answered, with a cheerful firmness of conviction he could scarcely have assumed, “Quite sure, my darling!
vi: The father responded with a cheerful and unmistakably genuine voice: − Absolutely certain, my dear!
tr: Her father replied with a sincere certainty to persuade his daughter, "Of course I'm sure, my dear!
es: —Completely, absolutely convinced! —replied the father with a tone of firm conviction.

en: More than that,” he added, as he tenderly kissed her: “my future is far brighter, Lucie, seen through your marriage, than it could have been—nay, than it ever was—without it.”
vi: Even more so, Lucie, - he added while tenderly kissing his daughter, - seeing you get married makes my future even brighter... oh, even more than if there were no marriage at all.
tr: Moreover," he added while kissing his daughter affectionately, "with your marriage, my future will be much brighter, Lucie – more than ever before."
es: —Even more so, my daughter! —he added, kissing her.— My future appears brighter in my eyes when seen through your marriage than it would if you remained single.

en: “If I could hope that, my father!—”
vi: − I only hope it's truly like that, Father! −
tr: "Oh, I hope it will be like that, daddy!""
es: —If I could believe you, my father...!

en: “Believe it, love!
vi: Believe me, my dear!
tr: "Believe me, my dear!
es: —Well, believe it, my darling, because it is so.

en: Indeed it is so.
vi: It truly is.
tr: This is the truth.
es: —Well, believe it, my darling, because it is so.

en: Consider how natural and how plain it is, my dear, that it should be so.
vi: Just think about it; it's clear and natural, isn't it?
tr: Think about how natural and right this situation is, this is how it should be.
es: Think that nothing could be more natural or logical.

en: You, devoted and young, cannot fully appreciate the anxiety I have felt that your life should not be wasted—”
vi: You are dear to me and still young, you can't fully understand my long-standing worry of not wanting your life to be wasted...
tr: You can't understand how much it upsets me to think that you, with your youthful and self-sacrificing nature, would waste your life..."
es: If you knew the anxiety that a father feels about the future of a beloved daughter...! If you could appreciate how great my desires are to prevent contingencies that might make you unhappy...!

en: She moved her hand towards his lips, but he took it in his, and repeated the word.
vi: Lucie raised her hand to her father's lips to stop him from speaking, but the doctor took his daughter's hand and repeated.
tr: The girl brought her hand to her father's lips, but he pulled her hand away and repeated his words.
es: The girl wanted to seal her father's lips with her hand, but he stopped her by taking hold of her hand, and continued thus:

en: “—wasted, my child—should not be wasted, struck aside from the natural order of things—for my sake.
vi: − ... Wasteful, my child... it must not be wasteful, it must not go against the natural order... just because of me.
tr: "... you must not waste your life, my child – you must not go against the laws of nature and waste your own life for my sake.
es: —Unfortunate, my daughter, yes; torn from the natural order of things... because of me.

en: Your unselfishness cannot entirely comprehend how much my mind has gone on this; but, only ask yourself, how could my happiness be perfect, while yours was incomplete?”
vi: You are not selfish, so you cannot fully understand how much I have worried about this; but you should ask yourself; how can my happiness be complete if you are at a disadvantage?
tr: You are so self-sacrificing towards me that you cannot fully understand what goes through my mind, but think about it, how can my happiness be complete when yours is lacking?"
es: Your selflessness, your lack of selfishness, it is not possible for you to understand how much that point has troubled me; but if you ask yourself how my happiness can be complete while yours is incomplete, perhaps you will understand my words.

en: “If I had never seen Charles, my father, I should have been quite happy with you.”
vi: If I had never met Charles, father, I would be completely happy without him.
tr: "If I hadn't known Charles, I would have lived quite happily with you, father."
es: —If I had never seen Carlos, my father, you alone would have been enough to make my happiness complete.

en: He smiled at her unconscious admission that she would have been unhappy without Charles, having seen him; and replied:
vi: The father smiled at his daughter's unintended confession, surely Lucie would be very sad without that young man in her life.
tr: The doctor smiled and responded with a confession, made unwittingly by his daughter, that revealed she could not be happy without Charles:
es: The father couldn't help but smile at that unconscious confession that his daughter would be unhappy without Carlos after having seen him, and he replied:

en: “My child, you did see him, and it is Charles.
vi: He replied: − My dear, you have met Charles, and you have had Charles.
tr: "My dear, the one you encountered was Charles.
es: —My daughter; you saw a man, and that man was Carlos; if it hadn't been Carlos, it would have been someone else; and if it hadn't been someone else, rest assured that the cause would have been me, in which case, the unfortunate period of my life would not only have enveloped me in its dark shadows, but also someone else, and that someone would have been you.

en: If it had not been Charles, it would have been another.
vi: If you hadn't met Charles, you would have met another young man.
tr: If it hadn't been Charles, it would have been someone else.
es: —My daughter; you saw a man, and that man was Carlos; if it hadn't been Carlos, it would have been someone else; and if it hadn't been someone else, rest assured that the cause would have been me, in which case, the unfortunate period of my life would not only have enveloped me in its dark shadows, but also someone else, and that someone would have been you.

en: Or, if it had been no other, I should have been the cause, and then the dark part of my life would have cast its shadow beyond myself, and would have fallen on you.”
vi: And if you didn't meet anyone else, then it would be my fault, and thus the dark part of my life would not only cause me pain but also bring suffering to you.
tr: On the other hand, if it hadn't been someone else, it would have been something that originated from me, and then the shadow of the dark part of my life would have surpassed me and fallen upon you."
es: —My daughter; you saw a man, and that man was Carlos; if it hadn't been Carlos, it would have been someone else; and if it hadn't been someone else, rest assured that the cause would have been me, in which case, the unfortunate period of my life would not only have enveloped me in its dark shadows, but also someone else, and that someone would have been you.

en: It was the first time, except at the trial, of her ever hearing him refer to the period of his suffering.
vi: Except for the previous court appearance, today is the first time the girl heard her father mention that painful time.
tr: For the first time since the trial, Lucie was hearing him speak of those painful days.
es: It was the first time, after the hearing of Darnay's case, that the doctor alluded to his misfortune.

en: It gave her a strange and new sensation while his words were in her ears; and she remembered it long afterwards.
vi: Her father's words echoed in her ears, causing her to feel an unusual emotion, and that feeling would remain deeply imprinted in her heart forever.
tr: Her father's words had stirred a strange and new feeling within her, and this feeling lingered in her mind for a long time.
es: —Look at it!

en: “See!” said the Doctor of Beauvais, raising his hand towards the moon.
vi: − Look! - The doctor in Beauvais pointed to the moon.
tr: The Doctor from Beauvais said, "Look!" pointing at the moon.
es: —exclaimed Doctor de Beauvais, extending his arm towards the moon and giving his words a tone that his daughter could not forget for a long time.

en: “I have looked at her from my prison-window, when I could not bear her light.
vi: - I have looked at the moon from the prison window, when I couldn't bear its light.
tr: "Even though I couldn't bear its light, I would always look at it from the window of my dungeon.
es: —I have seen it many times from the narrow window of my dungeon, when its light hurt me.

en: I have looked at her when it has been such torture to me to think of her shining upon what I had lost, that I have beaten my head against my prison-walls.
vi: I have looked at the moon with a heart aching, thinking about how that same moonlight was shining on what I had lost, hurting so much that I banged my head against the prison wall.
tr: Thinking that it shone over what I had lost would hurt me so much inside that I would bang my head against the walls of the dungeon as I looked.
es: I have gazed at it many times when it caused me such dreadful tortures to think that it shone upon the beings I had lost, that I would have gladly thrown myself headfirst against the walls of my prison.

en: I have looked at her, in a state so dull and lethargic, that I have thought of nothing but the number of horizontal lines I could draw across her at the full, and the number of perpendicular lines with which I could intersect them.”
vi: I have looked at the moon in utter despair, so despondent that I thought of nothing else but how many lines I would need to cross and slash to obliterate the whole round moon. -
tr: While staring with numb and lifeless eyes, I wouldn't think of anything else, only calculating the number of horizontal lines I could draw over it and the number of vertical lines that would intersect with them."
es: I have gazed at it while being in such a state of stupor and imbecility, that I could think of nothing else but the number of horizontal lines I could draw on its surface during the full moon, and the number of perpendiculars with which I could intersect the former.

en: He added in his inward and pondering manner, as he looked at the moon, “It was twenty either way, I remember, and the twentieth was difficult to squeeze in.”
vi: He looked at the moon and added, with a contemplative air. - It took twenty lines, both horizontal and vertical, I still remember, and it was very difficult to fit in the twentieth line.
tr: While gazing at the moon, lost in deep thoughts, he added, "I remember twenty horizontal, twenty vertical, and fitting the twentieth was difficult."
es: I remember calculating that twenty of each kind could fit—he added pensively—and the twentieth one fit with difficulty.

en: The strange thrill with which she heard him go back to that time, deepened as he dwelt upon it; but, there was nothing to shock her in the manner of his reference.
vi: The strange feeling when hearing her father recall the old days surged within Lucie as the doctor spoke; but he spoke without any intention of causing his daughter sorrow.
tr: As he reminisced about the old days, his father's strange excitement also deepened, but there was nothing surprising about him talking about these things.
es: I remember calculating that twenty of each kind could fit—he added pensively—and the twentieth one fit with difficulty.

en: He only seemed to contrast his present cheerfulness and felicity with the dire endurance that was over.
vi: It seemed that he merely wanted to compare the current happiness and joy with the extreme hardship of the past.
tr: It was as if he was comparing his current happiness and joy with his dreadful patience in the past.
es: I remember calculating that twenty of each kind could fit—he added pensively—and the twentieth one fit with difficulty.

en: “I have looked at her, speculating thousands of times upon the unborn child from whom I had been rent.
vi: − I have looked at the moon, countless times thinking about the unborn child from whom I was separated.
tr: "While looking at the moon, I thought of my unborn child thousands of times.
es: I have gazed at it thinking millions of times about the son from whom I was violently torn before he was born...

en: Whether it was alive.
vi: I don't know if it is still alive.
tr: Had it been born, I wondered?
es: I wondered if he had been born alive, if he was living, if the mother's pain had killed them both.

en: Whether it had been born alive, or the poor mother’s shock had killed it.
vi: I don't know if it was born healthy or if the mother's suffering took the life of the fetus.
tr: Had it been born healthy, or had it died from its poor mother's sorrow?
es: I wondered if he had been born alive, if he was living, if the mother's pain had killed them both.

en: Whether it was a son who would some day avenge his father.
vi: I don't know if it is a boy who might one day avenge me.
tr: Or was it a boy who would one day avenge his father?
es: I wondered if, in the case of being a boy, he would avenge his father, for while I was buried alive, there were times when an intolerable desire for vengeance dominated me; I wondered if he would ever come to know the sad story of his father's days, if perhaps he believed that his father had disappeared freely and voluntarily.

en: (There was a time in my imprisonment, when my desire for vengeance was unbearable.)
vi: Many times in prison, I have longed for revenge unbearably.
tr: (During the days I was in prison, my desire for revenge had become unbearable.)
es: I wondered if, in the case of being a boy, he would avenge his father, for while I was buried alive, there were times when an intolerable desire for vengeance dominated me; I wondered if he would ever come to know the sad story of his father's days, if perhaps he believed that his father had disappeared freely and voluntarily.

en: Whether it was a son who would never know his father’s story; who might even live to weigh the possibility of his father’s having disappeared of his own will and act.
vi: Not sure if it is the boy who is completely unaware of his father's story, or the one who even thinks that disappearing from his life was his father's voluntary wish.
tr: A boy who would never know his father's story; or perhaps he would even think that his father had disappeared of his own will and volition.
es: I wondered if, in the case of being a boy, he would avenge his father, for while I was buried alive, there were times when an intolerable desire for vengeance dominated me; I wondered if he would ever come to know the sad story of his father's days, if perhaps he believed that his father had disappeared freely and voluntarily.

en: Whether it was a daughter who would grow to be a woman.”
vi: Not sure if it is the girl who will later become a woman.
tr: Or it was a girl who would grow up to be a beautiful woman."
es: I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence.

en: She drew closer to him, and kissed his cheek and his hand.
vi: Lucie nestled close to her father, then kissed Dr. Manette's cheeks and hands.
tr: Lucie approached her father and kissed his cheek and hand.
es: I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence.

en: “I have pictured my daughter, to myself, as perfectly forgetful of me—rather, altogether ignorant of me, and unconscious of me.
vi: − I once imagined that the girl had completely forgotten her father... or rather, knew nothing about me, didn't care about me.
tr: "I always thought to myself that my daughter had completely forgotten me – even imagined that she was entirely unaware of me, that she never knew me.
es: I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence.

en: I have cast up the years of her age, year after year.
vi: Year after year, I counted my daughter's age.
tr: I kept calculating her age every year.
es: In my imagination, I saw her grow, live year after year; I saw her married to a man who was unaware of my sad fate.

en: I have seen her married to a man who knew nothing of my fate.
vi: I imagined my daughter had married someone who knew nothing about my fate.
tr: I envisioned her marrying a man who knew nothing of my fate.
es: In my imagination, I saw her grow, live year after year; I saw her married to a man who was unaware of my sad fate.

en: I have altogether perished from the remembrance of the living, and in the next generation my place was a blank.”
vi: And I faded away in the memories of the living, until the next generation no longer remembered me.
tr: I had been completely erased from the memories of the living and had no place in the next generation."
es: I considered myself dead to the world of the living, and I saw the generation following mine in which I did not appear.

en: “My father!
vi: − Dad!
tr: "Daddy!
es: —My father! —exclaimed the young woman, kissing her father with passion. —

en: Even to hear that you had such thoughts of a daughter who never existed, strikes to my heart as if I had been that child.”
vi: Even though I heard you say it was just imagination, I still feel heartbroken as if I were the daughter in your imagination! −
tr: The fact that you have thought about these things for a girl who doesn't exist, it burns my heart as if I were that child.""
es: That daughter to whom your thoughts referred has never existed, but, nevertheless, it almost hurts me as much to hear you speak as you do as if that daughter were me.

en: “You, Lucie?
vi: My daughter, Lucie?
tr: "Lucie, all these memories came alive after you comforted and healed me, and on this last night, they came between me and the moon.
es: —You, Lucía? Quite the opposite!

en: It is out of the Consolation and restoration you have brought to me, that these remembrances arise, and pass between us and the moon on this last night.
vi: If it weren't for you comforting and restoring my mind, there wouldn't be this last night to remember old memories and for us to talk under the moon...
tr: "Lucie, all these memories came alive after you comforted and healed me, and on this last night, they came between me and the moon.
es: Precisely those memories arise from the joy, from the comforts you have brought me, and since they are pleasant memories, I take pleasure in recalling them by the light of the moon on our last night...

en: —What did I say just now?”
vi: Where was I just now? −
tr: –What was I saying?"
es: What was I saying?

en: “She knew nothing of you.
vi: The daughter in that imagination knows nothing about her father, doesn't care about him.
tr: "He knew nothing about you.
es: —That your daughter knew nothing about you... that she didn't remember you.

en: She cared nothing for you.”
vi: The daughter in that imagination knows nothing about her father, doesn't care about him.
tr: He had no idea about you."
es: —That your daughter knew nothing about you... that she didn't remember you.

en: “So!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Correct!
es: —That your daughter knew nothing about you... that she didn't remember you.

en: But on other moonlight nights, when the sadness and the silence have touched me in a different way—have affected me with something as like a sorrowful sense of peace, as any emotion that had pain for its foundations could—I have imagined her as coming to me in my cell, and leading me out into the freedom beyond the fortress.
vi: But there are many other moonlit nights, when sorrow and silence evoke a different mood... a mood of serene melancholy as if all the pain has reached its limit... I see my daughter coming to the prison to visit her father, taking him out of captivity back to freedom.
tr: But on other nights when the moon shone, when sadness and silence affected me differently –like every emotion that is fundamentally the most painful, it affected me with a feeling similar to sorrowful peace– I would imagine her coming to my cell and taking me to freedom beyond the prison walls.
es: —It's true; but on other nights, when my sadness and the silence that surrounded me gave my emotions a different direction, when they produced in me something like a painful sensation of peace... like an emotion whose foundation was pain... I imagined my daughter entering my cell, taking me out of the fortress where I was imprisoned, and granting me freedom.

en: I have seen her image in the moonlight often, as I now see you; except that I never held her in my arms; it stood between the little grated window and the door.
vi: Under the moonlight, I often see the face of that daughter clearly, as clearly as I see you now; the only thing is that I can never hold her in my arms; that daughter just stands between the small barred window and the main door.
tr: Just as I see you now, I would often see her in the moonlight, but I could never hold her in my arms; she would stand between the small window with iron bars and the door.
es: Many, many times I have seen her image in the moonlight, just as I see yours at this moment. There was, however, a difference, and that is, I could never hold her in my arms, I always saw her cold, motionless, rigid in the center of the cell, in the space between the bars and the door...

en: But, you understand that that was not the child I am speaking of?”
vi: But you must understand that you are not the daughter I am talking about, right? −
tr: But you understand that the child I mentioned is not her, right?"
es: You understand that you were not the girl I speak of.

en: “The figure was not; the—the—image; the fancy?”
vi: That image... that illusion... isn't it just imagination? −
tr: "Was that image a symbol, a dream?""
es: —It wasn't; that's true... but your imagination made you believe...

en: “No.
vi: No.
tr: "No.
es: —No; none of that.

en: That was another thing.
vi: This is different.
tr: This was something else.
es: My visual organ, disturbed, is clear, I saw her motionless, and yet, the ghost that my intellectual faculties pursued was the ghost of another girl, different and more real.

en: It stood before my disturbed sense of sight, but it never moved.
vi: It stands before my bewildered eyes, but it never fades away.
tr: It stood in my line of sight in a disturbing way but didn't move at all.
es: My visual organ, disturbed, is clear, I saw her motionless, and yet, the ghost that my intellectual faculties pursued was the ghost of another girl, different and more real.

en: The phantom that my mind pursued, was another and more real child.
vi: The image in my imagination is of a different daughter and more real.
tr: The silhouette my mind was chasing was very different, a much more real child.
es: My visual organ, disturbed, is clear, I saw her motionless, and yet, the ghost that my intellectual faculties pursued was the ghost of another girl, different and more real.

en: Of her outward appearance I know no more than that she was like her mother.
vi: I know nothing about her appearance except that she resembles her mother.
tr: About its appearance, I know nothing except that it resembled its mother.
es: Of her external appearance, I only know that the image my eyes saw resembled her mother... and the other, the ghost... also resembled her... like you resemble her... but it was a different resemblance.

en: The other had that likeness too—as you have—but was not the same.
vi: And the illusion in front of me also has that resemblance... like you... but it is not her.
tr: The other one also looked like it – just like you – but it wasn't the same.
es: Of her external appearance, I only know that the image my eyes saw resembled her mother... and the other, the ghost... also resembled her... like you resemble her... but it was a different resemblance.

en: Can you follow me, Lucie?
vi: Do you understand what I mean, Lucie?
tr: Can you follow what I'm saying, Lucie?
es: Do you understand me, Lucia?

en: Hardly, I think?
vi: Probably not?
tr: It's a bit difficult, isn't it?
es: No, right?

en: I doubt you must have been a solitary prisoner to understand these perplexed distinctions.”
vi: I fear that you would have to live in solitary confinement to understand these indescribable differences.
tr: Maybe you had to be left alone in a dungeon to understand these complex distinctions."
es: I highly doubt that anyone who has not spent long centuries confined and separated from their loved ones can understand the subtle distinctions of a prisoner.

en: His collected and calm manner could not prevent her blood from running cold, as he thus tried to anatomise his old condition.
vi: Mr. Manette's calm and composed demeanor could not prevent Lucie from feeling a chill as her father tried to analyze his past emotions.
tr: The doctor's composed and calm demeanor, adopted in an effort to return to the old days, was enough to chill his daughter's blood.
es: Although the father's calm was perfect, the young woman felt ice running through her veins when she heard him dissect the state of mind he found himself in during times, fortunately past.

en: “In that more peaceful state, I have imagined her, in the moonlight, coming to me and taking me out to show me that the home of her married life was full of her loving remembrance of her lost father.
vi: − In quieter moments, I see under the moonlight, that girl comes and takes me outside, visiting her family home, a place filled with loving memories of her late father.
tr: "In relatively peaceful moments, I would imagine her coming to me in the moonlight and dream that she would take me to her nest to show me that it was filled with the loving memories of her deceased father.
es: —I imagined her coming to my dungeon by the light of the moon to tell me that her blessed married home was full of sweet memories of her father lost forever.

en: My picture was in her room, and I was in her prayers.
vi: In her room, there is a picture of me hanging, and in her prayers, she always mentions my name.
tr: My picture would be in her room and she would pray for me.
