es: In her study, my portrait occupied a prominent place and I was the one who inspired her prayers.

en: Her life was active, cheerful, useful; but my poor history pervaded it all.”
vi: Her life is full of energy, joy, and usefulness; but interspersed in that life is still the sorrowful story of mine.
tr: She was full of life, cheerful, and beautiful, but my pitiful story had permeated everywhere."
es: Her life was active, happy, useful; but it was filled, saturated with my sad story.

en: “I was that child, my father, I was not half so good, but in my love that was I.”
vi: − That girl is me, father, even though I am not half as good as she is, I still love you just as much.
tr: "Here I am, that child, my father. My life wasn't that good, but I loved you just the same."
es: —That daughter was me, my father. I was not, by any means, as good as you imagined, but my tender affection was not exaggerated by your fantasy.

en: “And she showed me her children,” said the Doctor of Beauvais, “and they had heard of me, and had been taught to pity me.
vi: − Then she let me meet her children, - said the doctor from Beauvais, - and they all knew about me, they were all taught to feel compassion for me.
tr: "Then he would show me his children," said the Doctor from Beauvais, "they knew about me and had taught me to pity them.
es: —He also taught his children, to whom he often spoke of me. All of them had learned to pity me.

en: When they passed a prison of the State, they kept far from its frowning walls, and looked up at its bars, and spoke in whispers.
vi: When they passed by the national prison, they moved away from the threatening walls, looked up at the high barred windows, and whispered.
tr: When they passed by a prison, they were kept away from its frowning walls and would look at the iron bars and whisper among themselves.
es: When they passed near one of those tombs called state prisons, they would avert their eyes from its grim walls, look fearfully at its bars, and speak in very low voices.

en: She could never deliver me; I imagined that she always brought me back after showing me such things.
vi: That girl could never set me free; I saw her always bringing me back to the dungeon after showing me such things.
tr: My daughter could not set me free, but after showing me all this, I imagined she would take me back to my cell.
es: My daughter could not give me freedom; but even so, it was enough for her to show me the things I have just mentioned, for consoling tears to run down my cheeks and for me to fall to my knees blessing her.

en: But then, blessed with the relief of tears, I fell upon my knees, and blessed her.”
vi: But in those moments, I shed tears of joy, I knelt down to bless her.
tr: Then I would relax and burst into tears, kneeling down to pray for her."
es: My daughter could not give me freedom; but even so, it was enough for her to show me the things I have just mentioned, for consoling tears to run down my cheeks and for me to fall to my knees blessing her.

en: “I am that child, I hope, my father.
vi: − I am that girl, I wish to be so, father.
tr: "I am that child, father, oh I hope so, my dear father."
es: —I am that daughter, yes, I am. Oh, my father!

en: O my dear, my dear, will you bless me as fervently to-morrow?”
vi: Oh father, oh father, will you bless me so fervently tomorrow?
tr: "Oh my dear father, my beloved father, will you pray for me with the same enthusiasm again tomorrow?""
es: Will you bless me tomorrow with the same fervor?

en: “Lucie, I recall these old troubles in the reason that I have to-night for loving you better than words can tell, and thanking God for my great happiness.
vi: − Lucie, the reason I recount the painful old times is because tonight I love you immensely, and I thank God for granting me this happiness.
tr: "Lucie, the reason I am telling you all these old troubles now is because I love you more than words can express and I thank God for giving me such great happiness.
es: —I remember those ancient tortures, dear Lucía, because it highlights more and more the joy that overwhelms me tonight.

en: My thoughts, when they were wildest, never rose near the happiness that I have known with you, and that we have before us.”
vi: No matter how wild my imaginations were back then, they could never bring me the happiness like the days we spent together, father and son, and what is yet to come.
tr: Even in the moments when I indulged in the most impossible dreams, I could not have imagined the happiness I feel now by your side and the beautiful days that lie ahead of us."
es: Never did my hopes, not even when they were most excessive, manage to represent to me a happiness as great as the one I have experienced since being by your side, as the one I hope to savor in the future.

en: He embraced her, solemnly commended her to Heaven, and humbly thanked Heaven for having bestowed her on him.
vi: Mr. Manette embraced his daughter, prayed for God's blessing on Lucie, and thanked God for giving him a beloved child.
tr: The doctor hugged his daughter, solemnly entrusted her to God, and humbly thanked for being granted his daughter.
es: He then embraced his daughter, solemnly blessed her, and fervently thanked God who had granted her to him.

en: By-and-bye, they went into the house.
vi: Then the father and daughter went into the house.
tr: A little later, they entered the house.
es: Shortly after, they entered the house embraced.

en: There was no one bidden to the marriage but mr Lorry; there was even to be no bridesmaid but the gaunt Miss Pross.
vi: The only person invited to the wedding was Mr. Lorry; there wasn't even a bridesmaid, only the haggard Miss Pross.
tr: There was no one invited to the wedding except Mr. Lorry; there wasn't even a bridesmaid other than the unpleasant Miss Pross.
es: No guests would attend the wedding ceremony, nor would any alterations be made to the doctor's residence because of the marriage.

en: The marriage was to make no change in their place of residence; they had been able to extend it, by taking to themselves the upper rooms formerly belonging to the apocryphal invisible lodger, and they desired nothing more.
vi: This wedding did not change the residence; the house simply had more people, as Charles and Lucie would move up to the rooms on the upper floor, which previously belonged to unseen, ephemeral lodgers, and the newlyweds desired nothing more than that.
tr: There would be no change in the place where they lived after the marriage; they had only expanded the house a bit, incorporating the rooms on the upper floor that previously belonged to the invisible imaginary tenant, and felt no need to do anything else.
es: They had limited themselves to expanding it a bit by taking the upper floor that until then had been occupied by an invisible tenant, which fulfilled their wishes.

en: Doctor Manette was very cheerful at the little supper.
vi: Dr. Manette was very cheerful during dinner.
tr: Dr. Manette was very cheerful at dinner.
es: Dr. Manette was very cheerful and lively during dinner.

en: They were only three at table, and Miss Pross made the third.
vi: The dinner table had only three people, with Miss Pross being the third.
tr: There were only three people at the table; the third person was Miss Pross, after all.
es: Three people sat at the table, the third being Miss Pross.

en: He regretted that Charles was not there; was more than half disposed to object to the loving little plot that kept him away; and drank to him affectionately.
vi: He regretted that Charles was not there, inwardly opposing the trivial emotional scheme that had caused his son-in-law's absence, and he raised his glass in silent sympathy for Charles.
tr: The Doctor was saddened by Charles's absence; he was almost going to oppose the loving little game that kept his almost-son-in-law away that day, and with these affectionate feelings, he raised his glass in his honor.
es: The doctor regretted that they had not invited Charles Darnay; he even felt tempted to scold those who had concocted the plot to keep him away, and he drank to his health.

en: So, the time came for him to bid Lucie good night, and they separated.
vi: So it was time to retreat to the room and bid farewell to her father.
tr: Then it was time for the Doctor to say goodnight to Lucie, and everyone retired to their rooms.
es: It was already very late when he said goodnight to Lucía and retired to his room.

en: But, in the stillness of the third hour of the morning, Lucie came downstairs again, and stole into his room; not free from unshaped fears, beforehand.
vi: But in the stillness of the night at three o'clock in the morning, Lucie went downstairs again, secretly entering her father's room, her heart still uneasy due to vague fears from before.
tr: But in the silence of the later hours of the night, Lucie came back downstairs and secretly entered her father's room; she had a multitude of fears she couldn't define.
es: At three in the morning, the young woman, not entirely free from fears and premonitions, got up and quietly entered her father's bedroom.

en: All things, however, were in their places; all was quiet; and he lay asleep, his white hair picturesque on the untroubled pillow, and his hands lying quiet on the coverlet.
vi: But everything remained in place; all around was calm; and the father was sleeping soundly, his silver hair spread like a painting on the soft pillow, and his hands lay still under the blanket.
tr: However, everything was in its place; not a sound was heard and her father was sleeping soundly, his snow-white hair was worth watching on his comfortable pillow and his hands were lying still on the bedspread.
es: Everything was in its place, everything in order, everything calm. The doctor slept peacefully, his long white hair falling over the pillow and his hands resting naturally on the quilt.

en: She put her needless candle in the shadow at a distance, crept up to his bed, and put her lips to his; then, leaned over him, and looked at him.
vi: She placed the cumbersome candle into the distant shadow, tiptoed to her father's bed, kissed his lips, and then kept looking down for a long time.
tr: The young girl placed the unnecessary candlestick somewhere away and, snuggling up to her father, planted a kiss on his lips; then she leaned over and looked at him.
es: The girl left the candlestick in a corner, approached the bed, and touched her father's withered lips with her fresh ones. Then she gazed at him intensely.

en: Into his handsome face, the bitter waters of captivity had worn; but, he covered up their tracks with a determination so strong, that he held the mastery of them even in his sleep.
vi: On that beautiful face, the bitterness of the days of captivity had faded, but the doctor had concealed all traces of the past with a determination so strong that even in his sleep he did not allow it to be revealed.
tr: The man's pleasant face had been worn down by the bitter waters of captivity, but the doctor had covered these marks with such strong determination that he managed to conceal them even in his sleep.
es: The bitter waters of captivity had left their marks on his perfect face; but so firm, so energetic was the resolution of that father, that even while sleeping he managed to conceal them.

en: A more remarkable face in its quiet, resolute, and guarded struggle with an unseen assailant, was not to be beheld in all the wide dominions of sleep, that night.
vi: That night, throughout the vast and boundless realm, it was impossible to find a face more peaceful, more determined, and more silently resistant in the struggle against the invisible attacker.
tr: That night, if all the faces in the realm of sleep were examined, none could be found as silent, as determined, and as cautious as his, in his struggle against an invisible aggressor.
es: In the vast realms of sleep, surely there was no other face that night as guarded against the gaze of any unexpected visitor as that of Doctor Manette.

en: She timidly laid her hand on his dear breast, and put up a prayer that she might ever be as true to him as her love aspired to be, and as his sorrows deserved.
vi: Lucie timidly placed her hand on his chest and prayed for the strength to be as filial as the suffering her father had endured.
tr: Lucie timidly placed her hand on her father's chest and prayed to always be able to stay by his side, after all the love she felt for him and all the suffering the man had endured.
es: Timidly, she placed a hand on that beloved chest and fervently asked God to grant her the ability to always be as faithful to him as his paternal love and past sufferings deserved.

en: Then, she withdrew her hand, and kissed his lips once more, and went away.
vi: Then she withdrew her hand, kissed her father's lips once more, and left the room.
tr: Then she withdrew her hand and, after kissing him on the lips once more, she left.
es: She then withdrew her hand, kissed that adored mouth once more, and left the bedroom.

en: So, the sunrise came, and the shadows of the leaves of the plane-tree moved upon his face, as softly as her lips had moved in praying for him.
vi: Thus, dawn arrived, and the shadows of the willow leaves danced on his face, gently like Lucie's lips whispering a prayer.
tr: The sun had now risen, and the shadows of the plane tree's leaves played softly on the man's face, as gently as his daughter's lips moved while she prayed for him.
es: When the sun was born, the shadows cast by the banana leaves on her face did not move with as much gentleness as Lucia's lips did when she directed her prayer to Heaven.

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: 18. Nine days
tr: XVIII
es: XVIII.

en: Nine Days
vi: 18. Nine days
tr: Nine Days
es: NINE DAYS Nature displayed all its splendor on the wedding day.

en: The marriage-day was shining brightly, and they were ready outside the closed door of the Doctor’s room, where he was speaking with Charles Darnay.
vi: The sun shone brightly on the wedding day, and three people were ready in front of the closed door of the doctor's room, where Mr. Manette was talking with Charles Darnay inside.
tr: On the wedding day, the weather was sparkling, and everyone was waiting in front of the closed door of the room where the Doctor was talking to Charles Darnay.
es: All those who were to attend the ceremony were already in place, waiting for the doctor to come out of his room, where he was talking with Charles Darnay.

en: They were ready to go to church; the beautiful bride, mr Lorry, and Miss Pross—to whom the event, through a gradual process of reconcilement to the inevitable, would have been one of absolute bliss, but for the yet lingering consideration that her brother Solomon should have been the bridegroom.
vi: They were preparing to go to the church: the beautiful bride, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross - for her, this marriage must have been a great joy if she hadn't held onto the thought that her brother Solomon should have been the groom, but gradually she had to accept this inevitable fact.
tr: They were all ready to go to the church; that is, the beautiful bride, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross – Miss Pross, who had gradually accustomed herself to this inevitable event, was happy indeed, but she still couldn't get rid of the thought that the groom should have been her own brother Solomon.
es: Next to the indicated room's door were the bride, radiant with beauty, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross... for whom the event, thanks to a gradual process of reconciliation with the inevitable, would have been a source of infinite happiness, if not for the slightly painful consideration that the groom should not be Charles Darnay but her brother Solomon.

en: “And so,” said mr Lorry, who could not sufficiently admire the bride, and who had been moving round her to take in every point of her quiet, pretty dress; “and so it was for this, my sweet Lucie, that I brought you across the Channel, such a baby!
vi: − That's how it is! - Mr. Lorry couldn't get enough of admiring the bride, bustling around her, examining every detail of her beautiful, simple wedding dress. - That's how it is! I carried you across the sea to be here today, dear Lucie, ever since you were just a baby.
tr: "Do you see?" said Mr. Lorry, who couldn't stop praising the bride, as he circled around her lovely, simple wedding dress; "Sweet Lucie, so I brought you across the Channel for this, oh how beautiful you are!
es: —The truth is that I made a great deal! —exclaimed Lorry, who couldn't stop admiring the bride.

en: Lord bless me!
vi: God bless me!
tr: Thank God!
es: —Just think about accompanying her on her journey across the Channel for this!

en: How little I thought what I was doing!
vi: At that time, I didn't think about anything!
tr: I didn't realize I was doing something so important!
es: My goodness, and how little I thought about what I was doing!

en: How lightly I valued the obligation I was conferring on my friend mr Charles!”
vi: I had no idea that one day I would have the important duty of entrusting you to Charles! −
tr: I didn't understand the significance of the task I entrusted to my friend Charles so well!"
es: And how little value I placed on the service I rendered to my good friend Charles Darnay on that occasion!

en: “You didn’t mean it,” remarked the matter-of-fact Miss Pross, “and therefore how could you know it?
vi: This marriage wasn't your idea, - Miss Pross said honestly, - so how could you have known back then?
tr: "You had no such intention," said the straightforward Miss Pross, "how could you have known?
es: —I don't know how you could give it more or less value than it deserved if you didn't remotely dream of what was going to happen!

en: Nonsense!”
vi: Nonsense! − Really?
tr: Nonsense!"
es: —observed Miss Pross.—Nonsense!

en: “Really?
vi: Ah; but don't cry, will you?
tr: "Is that so?
es: —Really?

en: Well; but don’t cry,” said the gentle mr Lorry.
vi: - Mr. Lorry said kindly.
tr: Alright, but don't cry," said the gentle Mr. Lorry.
es: Perhaps you are right... But don't cry—replied Lorry.

en: “I am not crying,” said Miss Pross; “you are.”
vi: − I am not crying, - Miss Pross replied. - You are the one crying. − Me, Miss Pross? -
tr: "I am not crying," said Miss Pross; "it is you who are crying." "Am I my Pross?"
es: —I am not crying; you are the one who is crying—replied Miss Pross.

en: “I, my Pross?” (By this time, mr Lorry dared to be pleasant with her, on occasion.)
vi: By now, Mr. Lorry dared to tease her whenever he had the chance.
tr: (Mr. Lorry had now found the courage to address her more intimately, given the situation.)
es: —Me, Pross of my sins?—asked Lorry, who now dared to joke with his interlocutor every now and then.

en: “You were, just now; I saw you do it, and I don’t wonder at it.
vi: − Who else could it be; I saw it with my own eyes, and I am not mistaken.
tr: "Yes, you were crying just a moment ago, I saw you and I wasn't surprised at all.
es: —You, yes. You are crying at this moment, I have seen it, and it is foolish to deny it to me. Besides, it does not surprise me.

en: Such a present of plate as you have made ’em, is enough to bring tears into anybody’s eyes.
vi: Your silver dish set is a gift that would bring tears to anyone's eyes, - said Miss Pross.
tr: You gave them such a beautiful dinner set that anyone who sees it would be moved to tears.
es: A gift like the one you have given to the young lady is enough to bring tears to the eyes of a stone statue. What a silver service!

en: There’s not a fork or a spoon in the collection,” said Miss Pross, “that I didn’t cry over, last night after the box came, till I couldn’t see it.”
vi: When the gift box arrived last night, every single fork and spoon made me cry my eyes out.
tr: Every fork and spoon in this set," said Miss Pross, "brought me to tears, I cried so much after the box arrived last night that I couldn't see."
es: I was crying last night over each of the forks, over each of the spoons in the collection from the moment the case arrived until I could see it opened.

en: “I am highly gratified,” said mr Lorry, “though, upon my honour, I had no intention of rendering those trifling articles of remembrance invisible to any one.
vi: − So I am very pleased, - Mr. Lorry said, - although I swear on my honor, I never intended to make anyone cry their eyes out because of those small gifts.
tr: "I am very happy," said Mr. Lorry, "but it was not my intention to blind your eyes with these insignificant objects that I gave as a memento."
es: —What fills me with immense pride, although I swear on my honor that it was not my intention for that small memento to cause anyone suffering.

en: Dear me!
vi: My God!
tr: Ah, yes!
es: Devil, devil!

en: This is an occasion that makes a man speculate on all he has lost.
vi: This is a time for a man to reflect on all that he has lost.
tr: In such situations, one realizes all the things they have lost.
es: Here is an occasion that forces a man to think with sorrow about what he has lost!

en: Dear, dear, dear!
vi: Heavens, heavens, heavens!
tr: Ahh, ah!
es: When I remember that fifty years ago there could have been a Mrs. Lorry in the world...!

en: To think that there might have been a ms Lorry, any time these fifty years almost!”
vi: Just think, in nearly fifty years there should have been a Mrs. Lorry by now! −
tr: Now, by my side, there could have been a wife of fifty years, a Mrs. Lorry!"
es: When I remember that fifty years ago there could have been a Mrs. Lorry in the world...!

en: “Not at all!” From Miss Pross.
vi: Not at all! - Miss Pross's voice.
tr: "It couldn't be!" came a response from Miss Pross.
es: —I deny it! —replied Miss Pross. —What!

en: “You think there never might have been a ms Lorry?” asked the gentleman of that name.
vi: − Do you think your department will never have a Mrs. Lorry? Mr. Lorry asked.
tr: "Do you think that there could never be a Ms. Lorry in my life?""
es: Do you think it was impossible for there to have been a Mrs. Lorry?

en: “Pooh!” rejoined Miss Pross; “you were a bachelor in your cradle.”
vi: − Hush! - Miss Pross argued. - You've been single since you were in the cradle.
tr: "Hmph!" said Miss Pross; "you are a born bachelor."
es: —Get out of the way! You've been single since you were rocked in your cradle!

en: “Well!” observed mr Lorry, beamingly adjusting his little wig, “that seems probable, too.”
vi: − Ah! - Mr. Lorry cheerfully said while adjusting his small wig, it's quite possible.
tr: "Eee!" said Mr. Lorry, his eyes laughing as he adjusted his small wig, "you might be right."
es: —I think it very likely—replied Lorry, adjusting his wig.

en: “And you were cut out for a bachelor,” pursued Miss Pross, “before you were put in your cradle.”
vi: − And fate had destined him to be single for life even before he was born, - Miss Pross insisted.
tr: "It was determined that you would remain single while you were still lying in your cradle," added Miss Pross.
es: —And before they put him in the cradle, they cut him out to be a lifelong bachelor.

en: “Then, I think,” said mr Lorry, “that I was very unhandsomely dealt with, and that I ought to have had a voice in the selection of my pattern.
vi: − Well then, - Mr. Lorry said, - I guess I'm out of luck, I should have had a say in choosing my own lifestyle.
tr: "Then I think there is a mistake in this matter, I should have been given a say in my own life.
es: —In which case, they did very wrong, for they should have listened to my vote before choosing the patron...

en: Enough!
vi: That's enough!
tr: Anyway!
es: —In which case, they did very wrong, for they should have listened to my vote before choosing the patron...

en: Now, my dear Lucie,” drawing his arm soothingly round her waist, “I hear them moving in the next room, and Miss Pross and I, as two formal folks of business, are anxious not to lose the final opportunity of saying something to you that you wish to hear.
vi: Now, my dear Lucie, - the old man gently wrapped his arm around the girl's waist, - I hear them moving about in the next room, so both Miss Pross and I, as the two people officially in charge, want to take this last opportunity to tell you a few things you might want to know.
tr: Now, dear Lucie," said Mr. Lorry, gently wrapping his arm around Lucie's waist. "I can hear their voices from inside, and Miss Pross and I, as knowledgeable individuals, do not want to miss the opportunity to tell you the things you want to hear.
es: I hear the sound of footsteps in the next room, my dear Lucía—he added, wrapping his arm around the bride's waist—and Miss Pross, and I, as formal and business-like people that we are, suspend our dispute, because we do not want to waste the opportunity that presents itself to say a few things to you that you will not dislike hearing.

en: You leave your good father, my dear, in hands as earnest and as loving as your own; he shall be taken every conceivable care of; during the next fortnight, while you are in Warwickshire and thereabouts, even Tellson’s shall go to the wall (comparatively speaking) before him.
vi: My dear, you have entrusted your compassionate father to decent and loving people just like yourself; we will take good care of him in every way for the next fortnight while you and your husband go to Warwickshire and around there, even putting aside, or nearly so, the work at Tellson's Bank to look after your father.
tr: You are leaving your dear father in hands as sincere and compassionate as yours, my beautiful girl; he will be very well taken care of; for the next two weeks, while you are in Warwickshire and its surroundings, even Tellson's is of no importance (compared to him).
es: You are going to leave your father, dear girl, in hands as loving and eager to serve him as yours, in hands that will go out of their way to attend to and care for him during the two weeks that the happy newlyweds are to spend in Warwickshire and its surroundings. Even Tellson's Bank will metaphorically step back to give way to you.

en: And when, at the fortnight’s end, he comes to join you and your beloved husband, on your other fortnight’s trip in Wales, you shall say that we have sent him to you in the best health and in the happiest frame.
vi: Then after the fortnight, your father will go with you and your husband to Wales for another fortnight, and you will see that we will return your father to you in the healthiest and happiest state.
tr: At the end of these two weeks, when your father comes to you and your dear husband for the other two weeks you will spend in Wales, you will see how healthy and happy we have sent him to you.
es: And when, after the fifteen days, you accompany your dear husband on the trip to Wales, which is to last another fifteen days, you will have to admit that we return him to you happier and more content than when you left him with us...

en: Now, I hear Somebody’s step coming to the door.
vi: There, I hear the footsteps of The Person coming to the door.
tr: It seems someone is approaching the door.
es: But someone is approaching the door, and this pretty young lady will allow a hardened bachelor to kiss her before that someone arrives and claims what is his.

en: Let me kiss my dear girl with an old-fashioned bachelor blessing, before Somebody comes to claim his own.”
vi: Let me kiss you, my dear, and give you the blessing of this old-fashioned bachelor before The Person comes to take you.
tr: Before someone else comes and kisses her, let me kiss my dear girl."
es: But someone is approaching the door, and this pretty young lady will allow a hardened bachelor to kiss her before that someone arrives and claims what is his.

en: For a moment, he held the fair face from him to look at the well-remembered expression on the forehead, and then laid the bright golden hair against his little brown wig, with a genuine tenderness and delicacy which, if such things be old-fashioned, were as old as Adam.
vi: He held Lucie's beautiful face in his hands for a long time, observing the expressions on her forehead that he remembered forever. Then, with affection and gentleness, he pressed her golden hair against his small brown wig. This sincere gesture, though old-fashioned, has been a way to express love since the dawn of humanity.
tr: To look at that familiar expression on her forehead, he held her beautiful face in his hands for a moment, then, with a tenderness and delicacy as old as Adam and Eve, he rested her golden hair against his own small brown wig.
es: The excellent Lorry spent a good while contemplating that beautiful face, then separated the silky golden curls, which mingled with his chestnut wig, and placed his lips on the smooth forehead with the delicacy with which Adam's contemporaries did these things.

en: The door of the Doctor’s room opened, and he came out with Charles Darnay.
vi: The doctor's office door was wide open, he and Charles Darnay walked out.
tr: The door of the Doctor's room opened and the Doctor and Charles Darnay came out.
es: The door of the doctor's room opened, and he came out followed by Charles Darnay.

en: He was so deadly pale—which had not been the case when they went in together—that no vestige of colour was to be seen in his face.
vi: The doctor's face was as pale as if there was no blood left - when the two went into the room, his complexion was not like that.
tr: The Doctor's face was so pale – it hadn't been like that when he went in – that there wasn't the slightest hint of color, yet although his demeanor was the same, Mr. Lorry's keen eye did not miss that the feeling of avoiding and fearing everything that used to envelop the Doctor had passed like a faint cold breeze.
es: A deadly pallor covered the face of the former, in which no traces of color remained, a pallor that did not exist when he was locked in his room with Darnay.

en: But, in the composure of his manner he was unaltered, except that to the shrewd glance of mr Lorry it disclosed some shadowy indication that the old air of avoidance and dread had lately passed over him, like a cold wind.
vi: But his calm demeanor did not change, only Mr. Lorry's sharp eyes noticed a sign of gloom as if a cold wind had just blown through, making the doctor appear somewhat fearful and evasive like before.
tr: The Doctor's face was so pale – it hadn't been like that when he went in – that there wasn't the slightest hint of color, yet although his demeanor was the same, Mr. Lorry's keen eye did not miss that the feeling of avoiding and fearing everything that used to envelop the Doctor had passed like a faint cold breeze.
es: His attitude, however, his expression, remained unchanged, although Lorry's keen eye discovered a certain somber indication that revealed the passage over his soul of the breath of repulsion and hatred that at other times, like a fleeting gust of cold wind, had struck him.

en: He gave his arm to his daughter, and took her down-stairs to the chariot which mr Lorry had hired in honour of the day.
vi: Mr. Manette offered his arm for his daughter to hold and then led her downstairs to the carriage that Mr. Lorry had hired for this special day.
tr: The doctor took his daughter by the arm and led her down the stairs to the carriage that Mr. Lorry had hired in honor of the day.
es: He gave his arm to his daughter and accompanied her to the carriage that Lorry, in consideration of the solemnity of the day, had rented.

en: The rest followed in another carriage, and soon, in a neighbouring church, where no strange eyes looked on, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married.
vi: The others followed in another carriage, and soon after, at a nearby church where no strangers were peeking, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married.
tr: The others followed them in another carriage, and a little later, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married in a nearby church, away from prying eyes.
es: The other people settled in another carriage, and minutes later, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were united with sweet and indissoluble bonds in the nearby church.

en: Besides the glancing tears that shone among the smiles of the little group when it was done, some diamonds, very bright and sparkling, glanced on the bride’s hand, which were newly released from the dark obscurity of one of mr Lorry’s pockets.
vi: Outside, tears glistened in the eyes of many as smiles shone brightly when the wedding ceremony concluded. On the bride's hand was the radiant, sparkling light of several diamonds that had just emerged from the dark pocket of Mr. Lorry.
tr: When the wedding ended, alongside the sparkling tears among the smiling faces of the small gathering, the diamonds that had just emerged from the dark mystery of Mr. Lorry's pocket were also shining brightly in the bride's hand.
es: In addition to the transparent tears that shone among smiles during the ceremony, some brilliant diamonds of the clearest waters sparkled in the bride's hand, which moments before had been freed from the darkness of one of Mr. Lorry's pockets, where they had been confined.

en: They returned home to breakfast, and all went well, and in due course the golden hair that had mingled with the poor shoemaker’s white locks in the Paris garret, were mingled with them again in the morning sunlight, on the threshold of the door at parting.
vi: They went home for breakfast, and everything went well. Then came the moment when the golden hair that once mingled with the silver strands of the poor shoemaker in the attic in Paris now once again mingled with the gray hair at the doorstep as they said their goodbyes.
tr: They returned home for breakfast; everything went well and just as the golden hair had mingled with the curls of the poor shoemaker's white hair in the attic in Paris, now, as they were saying goodbye at the doorstep, it mingled in the morning sunlight.
es: The newlyweds returned to the house, followed by the small circle of guests, had lunch, and later, the beautiful golden hair that once mingled its strands with the white locks of the poor shoemaker who ardently made shoes in an attic in Paris, came together again with the same, bathed in the morning sun's rays, on the doorstep at the moment of farewell.

en: It was a hard parting, though it was not for long.
vi: It was a difficult farewell even though the separation would not be long.
tr: Although it wouldn't be a long separation, it was a difficult farewell.
es: It was a painful separation, although its duration was to be short.

en: But her father cheered her, and said at last, gently disengaging himself from her enfolding arms, “Take her, Charles!
vi: But the father encouraged his daughter and finally gently separated from her tight embrace, he exclaimed: − Charles, take Lucie away!
tr: But her father had managed to cheer her up, and finally, as he gently extricated himself from her embracing arms, he said, "Come on, take her Charles!
es: The father encouraged his daughter, gently detached himself from her loving arms, and said with a lively expression:

en: She is yours!”
vi: Lucie is your wife now!
tr: My daughter is yours now!"
es: —Take it, Carlos! It's yours!

en: And her agitated hand waved to them from a chaise window, and she was gone.
vi: And the daughter's anxious hand waved goodbye to everyone through the carriage window, and then she departed.
tr: Lucie waved excitedly to them from the car window, and then the car disappeared from sight.
es: One minute later, through the window of a departing stagecoach, a hand waving a handkerchief emerged; it was Lucía's hand.

en: The corner being out of the way of the idle and curious, and the preparations having been very simple and few, the Doctor, mr Lorry, and Miss Pross, were left quite alone.
vi: In the secluded street corner frequented by curious idlers, the preparation for this wedding was very simple and neat, leaving only the doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross on the road.
tr: Due to the house being in a corner away from idle types and the curious, and because the wedding preparations were simple and minimal, Doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross were left alone as the car departed.
es: As the little corner of Soho was shielded from curious eyes and away from places frequented by idlers, and on the other hand, the preparations had been simple and unpretentious, once the newlyweds had left, the doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross were completely alone.

en: It was when they turned into the welcome shade of the cool old hall, that mr Lorry observed a great change to have come over the Doctor; as if the golden arm uplifted there, had struck him a poisoned blow.
vi: It wasn't until the three of them returned to the shadow of the old, cold hall that Mr. Lorry noticed Mr. Manette's face had changed dramatically, as if the golden arm symbol mounted high on the wall had just dealt the doctor a vicious blow.
tr: When they entered the shadow of the cool, old hall, Mr. Lorry noticed the significant change in the Doctor; it was as if the golden arm standing there had suddenly delivered a poisonous punch to him.
es: When the three of them re-entered the living room, it was then that Lorry noticed the terrible change that had just occurred in the doctor: it seemed as if the arm of the golden giant had struck him with a poisoned blow.

en: He had naturally repressed much, and some revulsion might have been expected in him when the occasion for repression was gone.
vi: The doctor, of course, had to suppress his emotions a lot, and if sudden changes were revealed when given the chance to let loose, it wouldn't be surprising.
tr: The doctor had naturally suppressed many emotions within himself, and it was not at all surprising that there was a sudden change in him with the disappearance of the source of pressure; on the other hand, what really worried Mr. Lorry was the old fearful, lost expression on the man's face.
es: It was natural that the violent efforts he necessarily had to make to keep his emotion locked within his chest would be followed by a similarly violent reaction as soon as the cause, the occasion for those efforts, disappeared.

en: But, it was the old scared lost look that troubled mr Lorry; and through his absent manner of clasping his head and drearily wandering away into his own room when they got up-stairs, mr Lorry was reminded of Defarge the wine-shop keeper, and the starlight ride.
vi: But Mr. Lorry became worried because Mr. Manette again bore the distraught expression of his previous suffering; when they went upstairs, the way the doctor absentmindedly ruffled his hair and entered his room like a lost soul reminded Mr. Lorry of the innkeeper Defarge and the journey under the starlight.
tr: Moreover, when they went upstairs, the doctor absentmindedly took his head in his hands and wandered around his room sorrowfully, which reminded Mr. Lorry of Defarge, the owner of the wine shop, and their progress along the star-lit road.
es: It was not, then, the reaction, it was not the flattening, that alarmed Mr. Lorry, but the derangement with which the doctor put his hands on his head, the gloomy monotony with which he began to pace as soon as he entered the room, and those symptoms alarmed him because they reminded him of the attic of Defarge's tavern and the condition in which he found the doctor there.

en: “I think,” he whispered to Miss Pross, after anxious consideration, “I think we had best not speak to him just now, or at all disturb him.
vi: − Probably... - after a moment of anxious thought, he whispered to Miss Pross. - Perhaps right now it's best if we don't say anything to the doctor or bother him.
tr: After thinking uneasily, Mr. Lorry whispered to Miss Pross, "I think," he said, "I think we shouldn't talk to him now, or even disturb him at all.
es: —I believe—he said in a very low voice to Miss Pross—that we should not speak to him at this moment nor distract him in any way.

en: I must look in at Tellson’s; so I will go there at once and come back presently.
vi: I have to stop by Tellson to check on some work; I'll go right away and be back soon.
tr: I need to go to Tellson's; I'll just go and come back quickly.
es: I am going to take a look at the Bank, from where I will return in a moment.

en: Then, we will take him a ride into the country, and dine there, and all will be well.”
vi: At that time, we will take a carriage to take the doctor on a countryside trip and have a meal there, then everything will be fine.
tr: Then we can take him for a walk in the countryside, have a meal somewhere around there, it will do us all good."
es: Upon my return, I will take him to the countryside, where we will eat after taking a good walk, and I hope that in this way we will be able to dispel the dark thoughts that seem to hover over his soul.

en: It was easier for mr Lorry to look in at Tellson’s, than to look out of Tellson’s.
vi: Mr. Lorry found it easier to visit Tellson's than to leave it.
tr: For Mr. Lorry, going to Tellson's was easier than returning from Tellson's.
es: Nothing was easier for Lorry than entering the Bank; but nothing was more difficult than leaving it.

en: He was detained two hours.
vi: He was held up there for two whole hours.
tr: They kept him at the bank for two hours.
es: The quick look he intended to take lasted two hours.

en: When he came back, he ascended the old staircase alone, having asked no question of the servant; going thus into the Doctor’s rooms, he was stopped by a low sound of knocking.
vi: When he returned, he went up the old staircase alone, without asking any servants, and went straight to the doctor's room. The faint sound of a knock made him stop in his tracks.
tr: When he returned, without asking the servant anything, he climbed the old stairs alone and just as he was about to enter the Doctor's room, he was stopped by the low sounds coming from inside.
es: When he returned to the house in Soho and went up the stairs, without asking the servant who came to open the door for him, as he was about to enter the doctor's room, which he was heading straight for, he stood as if nailed to the floor. Inside the room, loud and repeated blows could be heard.

en: “Good God!” he said, with a start.
vi: − My Lord! - He was startled. -
tr: "Good heavens!" he said, startled.
es: —Good God!

en: “What’s that?”
vi: What's the matter?
tr: "What is this?"
es: —he exclaimed, stepping back a pace—What is that?

en: Miss Pross, with a terrified face, was at his ear.
tr: Miss Pross was right beside him with a horrified look on her face.
es: Miss Pross, with terror painted on her face, murmured in his ear:

en: “O me, O me!
vi: Oh heavens, oh heavens!
tr: "Oh, oh!
es: —What a misfortune...! Poor us...!

en: All is lost!” cried she, wringing her hands.
vi: It's all ruined! - Miss Pross, her face horrified, wringing her hands, whispered into his ear. -
tr: We are ruined!" she was crying out, rubbing her hands.
es: Everything is lost, everything!

en: “What is to be told to Ladybird?
vi: How will we explain this to our dear mistress?
tr: "What are we going to tell my little bird now?
es: What do we tell the young lady? Who will tell her?

en: He doesn’t know me, and is making shoes!”
vi: He didn't recognize me, and just kept making shoes!
tr: The man did not recognize me, he is sitting and making shoes!"
es: Oh...! —he added, wringing his hands—She doesn't know me, Mr. Lorry, and she is making shoes!

en: mr Lorry said what he could to calm her, and went himself into the Doctor’s room.
vi: Mr. Lorry said a few comforting words to her and then went straight into the doctor's room.
tr: After Mr. Lorry had said everything he could to calm the woman, he entered the Doctor's room alone.
es: Lorry tried to calm her, though in vain, and entered the doctor's room.

en: The bench was turned towards the light, as it had been when he had seen the shoemaker at his work before, and his head was bent down, and he was very busy.
vi: The old bench was still facing the source of light as he had seen before, and the shoemaker was diligently, busily working.
tr: The shoemaking bench was turned towards the light just as he had seen it before, and the man was bent forward, working diligently.
es: He had moved the stool close to the window, just as he had it placed in the attic in Paris, and was working fervently, his head bent over the shoe.

en: “Doctor Manette.
vi: − Doctor Manette.
tr: "Doctor Manette!
es: —Doctor Manette!

en: My dear friend, Doctor Manette!”
vi: Friend, Doctor Manette!
tr: My dear friend." "Doctor Manette!"
es: —shouted Lorry.—My dear friend... my good Doctor Manette...!

en: The Doctor looked at him for a moment—half inquiringly, half as if he were angry at being spoken to—and bent over his work again.
vi: The doctor looked at him for a moment - half questioning, half angry at being disturbed - then bent down to continue his work.
tr: The doctor briefly lifted his head and looked at him – with eyes that were half inquisitive, half annoyed at being disturbed – before bending back over the work in front of him.
es: The doctor raised his head, looked at the person who called him with an expression of both surprise and anger, undoubtedly displeased that they dared to address him... and continued his task.

en: He had laid aside his coat and waistcoat; his shirt was open at the throat, as it used to be when he did that work; and even the old haggard, faded surface of face had come back to him.
vi: Mr. Manette had taken off his coat and waistcoat; his shirt was open at the collar just like in the old days; and even the gaunt, weary look of those times had returned.
tr: He had set aside his jacket and vest; the collar of his shirt was open, just like in the old days when he did this job; his face had once again taken on that pale, wild look.
es: He had stripped off his frock coat and waistcoat, wore his shirt unbuttoned and his chest bare, exactly as when they found him in the attic of the tavern.

en: He worked hard—impatiently—as if in some sense of having been interrupted.
vi: He worked diligently - seemingly anxious - as if the work had been delayed for a long time.
tr: He was working feverishly –impatiently– as if someone might come and interrupt him.
es: His face had even regained the old gaunt and somber look from the years of his misfortune, and he worked with extraordinary fervor, with impatience, like someone finishing an urgent task and not wanting to be interrupted.

en: mr Lorry glanced at the work in his hand, and observed that it was a shoe of the old size and shape.
vi: Mr. Lorry glanced at the shoe in the doctor's hand and recognized it as the one that had been left unfinished some time ago.
tr: When Mr. Lorry looked at the work in the doctor's hand, he saw that it was something of old style and measures.
es: Lorry looked at the shoe the doctor was stitching and saw that it was very old-fashioned.

en: He took up another that was lying by him, and asked what it was.
vi: He picked up the other one lying next to Mr. Manette and asked about the type of shoe.
tr: He took the other shoe standing next to the man and asked what it was.
es: He didn't dare to take it from his hands; but he picked up another one that was at the shoemaker's feet, and asked him what it was.

en: “A young lady’s walking shoe,” he muttered, without looking up.
vi: − The lady's walking shoes, - the doctor mumbled, not looking up.
tr: Without lifting his head from his work, the doctor murmured, "Walking shoes for a young girl."
es: —Walking shoe for a young lady—replied the doctor without raising his eyes.

en: “It ought to have been finished long ago.
vi: - It should have been done a long time ago.
tr: "It should have been finished already.
es: —I should have finished it a long time ago.

en: Let it be.”
vi: Leave it alone.
tr: But anyway."
es: Leave me alone.

en: “But, Doctor Manette.
vi: − Oh, Dr. Manette.
tr: "But Doctor Manette.
es: —But for God's sake, Dr. Manette!

en: Look at me!”
vi: Look at me!
tr: Look at me, please!"
es: —exclaimed Lorry. —Look at me!

en: He obeyed, in the old mechanically submissive manner, without pausing in his work.
vi: The doctor complied in a mechanical, submissive manner as before, his hands still not stopping their work.
tr: The doctor, with his old mechanical obedient manner, complied without interrupting his work.
es: The doctor obeyed with the old mechanical submission, but without interrupting his work.

en: “You know me, my dear friend?
vi: − Do you know me, my friend?
tr: "Do you remember me, dear friend?
es: —Don't you recognize me yet, my dear friend?

en: Think again.
vi: Think again.
tr: Please think.
es: Come to your senses, Doctor Manette!

en: This is not your proper occupation.
vi: This job is not really your profession.
tr: This is not your real job.
es: Your profession is not that of a shoemaker... it never has been.

en: Think, dear friend!”
vi: There was no way to make Doctor Manette say another word.
tr: Dear friend, please think again!"
es: It was a wasted effort to try to get a single word out of him.

en: Nothing would induce him to speak more.
vi: There was no way to make Doctor Manette say another word.
tr: Nothing could make him talk any more.
es: He would momentarily lift his head when Lorry told him to, but all the pleas and entreaties were in vain: he did not speak.

en: He looked up, for an instant at a time, when he was requested to do so; but, no persuasion would extract a word from him.
vi: He would look up for a moment whenever told to, but no matter how much he was questioned, he would not utter a sound.
tr: When asked, he would lift his head and look for a moment; but no matter how much effort was made to persuade him, not a single word would come out of his mouth.
es: He would momentarily lift his head when Lorry told him to, but all the pleas and entreaties were in vain: he did not speak.

en: He worked, and worked, and worked, in silence, and words fell on him as they would have fallen on an echoless wall, or on the air.
vi: He just kept working, working, working in silence, and Mr. Lorry's words seemed to fall into a void or bounce off an unresponsive wall.
tr: The Doctor worked silently and incessantly, and the words rained down on him as if they had fallen on a wall or into the air without an echo.
es: He worked, sewed with true fervor, and the words directed at him slid over his ears, as they would slide over a cold steel wall.

en: The only ray of hope that mr Lorry could discover, was, that he sometimes furtively looked up without being asked.
vi: The only glimmer of hope Mr. Lorry could see was that the doctor would occasionally glance up even when not asked to.
tr: The only glimmer of hope Mr. Lorry could see was the Doctor occasionally, even though he was not asked to, secretly lifting his head and looking.
es: A single ray of hope shone among the shadows of despair that enveloped Lorry, and it was that sometimes, the doctor would look at him furtively without being told to.

en: In that, there seemed a faint expression of curiosity or perplexity—as though he were trying to reconcile some doubts in his mind.
vi: At those moments, the doctor's eyes seemed to be tinged with curiosity or confusion, just like Mr. Manette trying to unravel the doubts in his mind.
tr: In such moments, there was a faint expression of curiosity and bewilderment on his face; as if his mind was occupied with doubts he was trying to dispel.
es: The ray of hope was weak, as it had no more foundation than the fact that his friend's glances seemed to indicate curiosity, perplexity of mind, something like a symptom that the doctor was trying to harmonize, reconcile certain doubts that had arisen in his soul.

en: Two things at once impressed themselves on mr Lorry, as important above all others; the first, that this must be kept secret from Lucie; the second, that it must be kept secret from all who knew him.
vi: Mr. Lorry immediately committed two most important things to memory; first, not to let Lucie know about this; second, to keep it hidden from those who knew the doctor.
tr: Suddenly, two things came to Mr. Lorry's mind, more important than anything else; first, this incident must be kept from Lucie; second, this incident must be kept from everyone who knew the Doctor.
es: Lorry opined that it was necessary to adopt two important resolutions, apart from others of lesser importance: the first, to prevent Lucie from learning about the misfortune, and the second, to prevent this from reaching the ears of any of the people who knew the doctor.

en: In conjunction with Miss Pross, he took immediate steps towards the latter precaution, by giving out that the Doctor was not well, and required a few days of complete rest.
vi: Together with Miss Pross, he promptly carried out the second important thing first, by spreading the news that the doctor was unwell and needed complete rest for a few days.
tr: By putting their heads together, Miss Pross and Mr. Lorry took an urgent measure against the second group by saying that the Doctor was not feeling well and needed to rest for a few days.
es: In agreement with Miss Pross, he immediately took the necessary precautionary measures to achieve the second result, which consisted of stating that the doctor was indisposed, and that his state of health required a few days of rest and absolute isolation.

en: In aid of the kind deception to be practised on his daughter, Miss Pross was to write, describing his having been called away professionally, and referring to an imaginary letter of two or three hurried lines in his own hand, represented to have been addressed to her by the same post.
vi: As for Lucie, Miss Pross, out of kindness, had to deceive her; she wrote a letter saying that the doctor had urgent business and had to be away, and in the letter, she fabricated a story about receiving a few hurried lines from the doctor informing them.
tr: As for the deception to be applied to his daughter, Miss Pross would write a letter to Lucie explaining that her father had been called away for work, and even a few imaginary lines supposedly written hastily by her father would be included in the same post.
es: To deceive his daughter, Miss Pross was to write a letter informing her that her father had had to leave for professional matters, and commenting on a letter received by mail and written by the doctor in a hurry, in which he merely stated that his absence would be brief.

en: These measures, advisable to be taken in any case, mr Lorry took in the hope of his coming to himself.
vi: Mr. Lorry was forced to use both of these methods in the hope that the doctor would soon regain his senses.
tr: Mr. Lorry had taken these sensible measures in the hope that the Doctor would come to his senses.
es: These measures were, so to speak, of a general nature, and Lorry adopted them in case the doctor's unfortunate crisis soon disappeared.

en: If that should happen soon, he kept another course in reserve; which was, to have a certain opinion that he thought the best, on the Doctor’s case.
vi: In that case, he had another contingency plan; that is, to seek some advice which he thought would be best for Dr. Manette's condition.
tr: If this happened soon, there was another plan in place; Mr. Lorry thought this would be the best for the Doctor.
es: In case this solution did not take long, he considered it necessary, or at least very convenient, to follow a plan from which he promised great results for the future, a plan that consisted of forming a well-founded and motivated opinion about his friend's state of mind.

en: In the hope of his recovery, and of resort to this third course being thereby rendered practicable, mr Lorry resolved to watch him attentively, with as little appearance as possible of doing so.
vi: Hopefully, the doctor will recover quickly, and thus it will be convenient for the third method. Mr. Lorry decided to observe Mr. Manette very carefully but as discreetly as possible.
tr: With hopes for the Doctor's recovery and eagerness to implement his third plan in the village, Mr. Lorry decided not to take his eyes off him; while doing so, he needed to remain inconspicuous.
es: In case this solution did not take long, he considered it necessary, or at least very convenient, to follow a plan from which he promised great results for the future, a plan that consisted of forming a well-founded and motivated opinion about his friend's state of mind.

en: He therefore made arrangements to absent himself from Tellson’s for the first time in his life, and took his post by the window in the same room.
vi: For the first time in his life, he arranged to temporarily leave his job at Tellson's and kept vigil by the window in the doctor's room.
tr: Therefore, for the first time in his life, he took leave from Tellson's and positioned himself in the same room as the Doctor, in front of the window.
es: In case this solution did not take long, he considered it necessary, or at least very convenient, to follow a plan from which he promised great results for the future, a plan that consisted of forming a well-founded and motivated opinion about his friend's state of mind.

en: He was not long in discovering that it was worse than useless to speak to him, since, on being pressed, he became worried.
vi: He immediately saw that trying to start a conversation with Mr. Manette would only make things worse, as the more he was pressed, the more confused the doctor became.
tr: It didn't take long for Mr. Lorry to realize that talking to the Doctor was of no use, and in fact, made the situation worse, because the more he was pressed, the more anxious the Doctor became.
es: Very soon he had to convince himself that talking to him was not only perfectly useless but also harmful, since when he pressed him with questions or observations, he would upset and excite him more and more.

en: He abandoned that attempt on the first day, and resolved merely to keep himself always before him, as a silent protest against the delusion into which he had fallen, or was falling.
vi: Mr. Lorry abandoned that idea on the very first day and decided to just sit silently in front of Mr. Manette, keeping a slight distance, as a way to counteract the doctor's delusions or prevent them from worsening.
tr: Mr. Lorry gave up on this attempt on the very first day and decided to keep his distance from him, as if silently protesting, in order to save him from the delusion he had fallen into or was falling into.
es: Consequently, he gave up talking to him and resolved not to leave him alone for a moment, to become a silent protest against the deception into which he had fallen or was falling.

en: He remained, therefore, in his seat near the window, reading and writing, and expressing in as many pleasant and natural ways as he could think of, that it was a free place.
vi: Therefore, he just sat by the window, reading or writing something, trying his best to appear comfortable and natural, as if in this room anyone was free to do whatever they wanted.
tr: Thus, Mr. Lorry spent the whole day sitting in the chair by the window, reading books, writing and drawing, and trying to show him in every pleasant and natural way he could think of that this was a free place.
es: To this end, and in his desire to carry out the noble mission he had imposed on himself while enveloping it in the utmost secrecy, for the first time in his life he took the necessary measures to remain indefinitely absent from the Bank, and took possession of an armchair placed next to the window of the doctor's room, where he spent his time reading or writing.

en: Doctor Manette took what was given him to eat and drink, and worked on, that first day, until it was too dark to see—worked on, half an hour after mr Lorry could not have seen, for his life, to read or write.
vi: On the first day, whatever food and drink was given to Dr. Manette, he ate and drank, and kept diligently making shoes until there was no more light - it had gotten so dark that Mr. Lorry could no longer read or write, yet Dr. Manette continued working for another half hour before putting away his tools to resume the next morning.
tr: Dr. Manette ate and drank what was given to him, and on that first day, he worked until he could no longer see – Mr. Lorry, despite his efforts, had stopped reading and writing half an hour earlier because he could no longer see.
es: The doctor Manette ate and drank what was served to him, and worked on the first day until he ran out of light, it being noteworthy that, when he had to leave his task, it had already been a good half hour since Lorry had had to put aside the book he was reading, simply because he could no longer see the letters.

en: When he put his tools aside as useless, until morning, mr Lorry rose and said to him:
vi: At that moment, Mr. Lorry stood up and said: −
tr: When the doctor set aside his tools to resume in the morning, Mr. Lorry stood up and said:
es: Lorry stood up when he saw that the doctor was putting away his tools, and asked him:

en: “Will you go out?”
vi: Do you want to go outside?
tr: "Shall we go outside?"
es: —Do you want to go out?

en: He looked down at the floor on either side of him in the old manner, looked up in the old manner, and repeated in the old low voice:
vi: The doctor bowed his head, looking at the floor on both sides as he used to, then looked up as he used to, and repeated in a soft voice as he used to: − Go outside? −
tr: The doctor looked down to the ground and to his sides with his usual demeanor, then he raised his head with his usual demeanor and finally repeated in his usual low voice:
es: The doctor fixed his eyes on the ground, moved them from one place to another as in times past, and finally raising them, he said:

en: “Out?”
vi: The doctor bowed his head, looking at the floor on both sides as he used to, then looked up as he used to, and repeated in a soft voice as he used to: − Go outside? −
tr: "Outside?'
es: —Going out?

en: “Yes; for a walk with me.
vi: Yes, take a walk with me.
tr: "Yes, let's go for a walk together.
es: —Yes... Come take a walk with me: why not?

en: Why not?”
vi: Why not?
tr: Shall we?"
es: —Yes... Come take a walk with me: why not?

en: He made no effort to say why not, and said not a word more.
vi: The doctor did not bother to answer, nor did he say anything further.
tr: The doctor made no effort to respond and did not say another word.
es: He did not attempt to explain why not, nor did he part his lips again; but Lorry, while watching him with a penetrating gaze, bending his body, with his elbows resting on his knees and his head on the palms of his hands, believed that the unfortunate man was asking himself: "Why not?"

en: But, mr Lorry thought he saw, as he leaned forward on his bench in the dusk, with his elbows on his knees and his head in his hands, that he was in some misty way asking himself, “Why not?”
vi: But Mr. Lorry seemed to see the doctor - while hunched over on the bench in the dark, elbows on knees, head in hands - faintly mouthing the question “Why not?”.
tr: But Mr. Lorry, while the Doctor was leaning over his workbench in the evening darkness with his elbows on his knees and his head in his hands, thought he heard him faintly ask himself, "Is it possible?"
es: He did not attempt to explain why not, nor did he part his lips again; but Lorry, while watching him with a penetrating gaze, bending his body, with his elbows resting on his knees and his head on the palms of his hands, believed that the unfortunate man was asking himself: "Why not?"

en: The sagacity of the man of business perceived an advantage here, and determined to hold it.
vi: With the sharpness of a professional, Mr. Lorry recognized the favorable condition, and he decided to maintain it.
tr: The businessman’s common sense had derived something useful from this and did not want to overlook it.
es: The sagacity of the businessman saw an advantage in this and resolved to make the most of it.

en: Miss Pross and he divided the night into two watches, and observed him at intervals from the adjoining room.
vi: Miss Pross and he took turns during the night in the next room to watch over the doctor.
tr: Miss Pross and Mr. Lorry, dividing the night into shifts, periodically checked on the Doctor from the adjacent room.
es: During the nights, they watched over the sick person from the adjoining room, sometimes Mr. Lorry, sometimes Miss Pross, for which they had established two shifts, corresponding to the two halves into which they divided the watch duty.

en: He paced up and down for a long time before he lay down; but, when he did finally lay himself down, he fell asleep.
vi: Mr. Manette paced back and forth for a long time before lying down on the bed, but once he lay down, he slept soundly.
tr: Before going to bed, the Doctor paced up and down the room for a long time, and as soon as he finally laid his head on the pillow, he fell asleep immediately.
es: The doctor usually spent some time pacing in his room before retiring to bed; but when he lay down, he slept deeply and enjoyed a peaceful sleep.

en: In the morning, he was up betimes, and went straight to his bench and to work.
vi: In the morning, he got up early and went straight to the bench to continue making shoes.
tr: In the morning, he got up without delay and started working at his bench.
es: Come morning, as soon as he got up, he went straight to his bench and began to work.

en: On this second day, mr Lorry saluted him cheerfully by his name, and spoke to him on topics that had been of late familiar to them.
vi: On the second day, Mr. Lorry cheerfully greeted the doctor by name and talked about topics that the two had recently been discussing.
tr: On the second day, Mr. Lorry cheerfully greeted the Doctor and talked about the topics they had become familiar with recently. He always spoke of these subjects.
es: On the second day of the crisis, Lorry greeted the doctor by calling him by his name, and then began to talk to him about matters that were very familiar to both of them.

en: He returned no reply, but it was evident that he heard what was said, and that he thought about it, however confusedly.
vi: Mr. Manette did not respond, but it was clear that he was listening to what Mr. Lorry was saying and was thinking about those matters, despite his disturbed mind.
tr: Even though he did not respond, it was clear that the Doctor heard what was being said and, no matter how complex, pondered over them.
es: The doctor did not respond, but it was evident that he heard what was being said to him and that he was thinking about it, albeit in a confused manner.

en: This encouraged mr Lorry to have Miss Pross in with her work, several times during the day; at those times, they quietly spoke of Lucie, and of her father then present, precisely in the usual manner, and as if there were nothing amiss.
vi: That encouraged Mr. Lorry to call Miss Pross in to help several times a day; during those times, they calmly talked about Lucie, about the father who was present, as if nothing had happened.
tr: This situation encouraged Mr. Lorry to involve Miss Pross at certain times of the day; during such times, the two of them would put their heads together and talk quietly about Lucie, her father, and the day's affairs as if nothing was amiss, with their usual demeanor.
es: This encouraged Lorry, who asked Miss Pross to come in and keep him company several times during the day, in order to constantly talk about Lucia and her father, who was present at the conversations, naturally and as if nothing had happened.

en: This was done without any demonstrative accompaniment, not long enough, or often enough to harass him; and it lightened mr Lorry’s friendly heart to believe that he looked up oftener, and that he appeared to be stirred by some perception of inconsistencies surrounding him.
vi: They tried to appear as if they were having a natural conversation, not too long, and not too often to avoid disturbing the doctor; and Mr. Lorry's friendly heart lit up when he saw that the doctor was looking up more often, showing some attention to the unusual things around him.
tr: During this time, they did not act overly exaggerated, did not prolong the conversation, nor did they speak so frequently as to disturb the Doctor; the fact that the Doctor began to lift his head more often and seemed affected by the inconsistencies around him somewhat eased Mr. Lorry's warm heart.
es: The results were not very successful, but neither were they so fruitless as to discourage Lorry from continuing the plan, as it managed, if nothing else, to dispel, even if only for brief moments, the state of indifference in which he was immersed.

en: When it fell dark again, mr Lorry asked him as before:
vi: When night fell again, Mr. Lorry asked as he did yesterday: − Dear Doctor, do you want to go outside?
tr: When darkness fell again, Mr. Lorry asked the Doctor as before:
es: When the night of this second day closed, Lorry repeated his question from the previous day:

en: “Dear Doctor, will you go out?”
vi: When night fell again, Mr. Lorry asked as he did yesterday: − Dear Doctor, do you want to go outside?
tr: "Dear Doctor, shall we go outside?"
es: —My dear doctor, do you want to go out?

en: As before, he repeated, “Out?”
vi: Just like yesterday, Mr. Manette repeated: − Go outside? −
tr: The doctor repeated as before; "Outside?""
es: And as on the previous day, the respondent answered:

en: “Yes; for a walk with me.
vi: Yes, take a walk with me.
tr: "Yes, let's go for a walk together.
es: —Go out?

en: Why not?”
vi: Why not?
tr: Shall we?"
es: —Go out?

en: This time, mr Lorry feigned to go out when he could extract no answer from him, and, after remaining absent for an hour, returned.
vi: This time, Mr. Lorry pretended to leave when he saw the doctor say nothing, and was absent for about an hour before returning.
tr: When Mr. Lorry received no response from him, he pretended to leave and disappeared for an hour before returning.
es: Lorry feigned an absence upon not being able to obtain another response, returning after an hour.

en: In the meanwhile, the Doctor had removed to the seat in the window, and had sat there looking down at the plane-tree; but, on mr Lorry’s return, he slipped away to his bench.
vi: During that time, Dr. Manette had moved to sit by the window and looked down at the plane tree; but seeing Mr. Lorry return, he quietly went back to the shoemaker's bench.
tr: During this time, the Doctor had moved to the window and was sitting, looking at the sycamore tree; but with Mr. Lorry's return, he immediately went back to his workbench.
es: While Lorry was away, the doctor removed the stool that was next to the window and sat in a chair, from where he was contemplating the plane tree in the courtyard; but as soon as Lorry entered the room, he returned to sit on the stool.

en: The time went very slowly on, and mr Lorry’s hope darkened, and his heart grew heavier again, and grew yet heavier and heavier every day.
vi: Time passed very slowly, and Mr. Lorry's hope gradually diminished, his heart growing heavier with each passing day, each day heavier than the last.
tr: Time was flowing very slowly and Mr. Lorry's hopes had faded, his heart had become heavy again, and with each passing day it grew heavier and heavier.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away.

en: The third day came and went, the fourth, the fifth.
vi: The third day passed, then the fourth, and then the fifth.
tr: The third day came and went, then the fourth, and then the fifth day.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away.

en: Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, nine days.
vi: Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, nine days.
tr: Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, and nine days.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away.

en: With a hope ever darkening, and with a heart always growing heavier and heavier, mr Lorry passed through this anxious time.
vi: Hope gradually dwindling, the heart increasingly weighed down with worry, Mr. Lorry had endured nine days like this.
tr: With his hopes gradually fading and his heart growing heavier with each passing day, Mr. Lorry went through difficult times.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away.

en: The secret was well kept, and Lucie was unconscious and happy; but he could not fail to observe that the shoemaker, whose hand had been a little out at first, was growing dreadfully skilful, and that he had never been so intent on his work, and that his hands had never been so nimble and expert, as in the dusk of the ninth evening.
vi: This secret remained kept, Lucie still happily unaware; but he couldn't help noticing the shoemaker, whose initially rusty hands had become frighteningly proficient, never before had he made shoes with such focus, and never before had his hands been so swift and skillful, in the twilight of the ninth day.
tr: The secret was well kept and Lucie was unaware and happy; but Mr. Lorry couldn't help but notice that the shoemaker's hands, which were slow at first, were becoming more skilled, never working with such enthusiasm before, and never moving as deftly and skillfully as they did in the twilight of this ninth day.
es: It was true that the misfortune had not left the doctor's room; it was true that it was a secret to everyone, that Lucía did not remotely suspect it and was happy and content; but the good banker could not help but see, with deep sorrow, that the shoemaker, whose hand was clumsy in the first days, was acquiring a marvelous skill, that the doctor was taking more and more pleasure in the trade, and that his hands never worked with as much fervor and dexterity as when night spread its black mantle over the ninth day after the misfortune.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: This secret remained kept, Lucie still happily unaware; but he couldn't help noticing the shoemaker, whose initially rusty hands had become frighteningly proficient, never before had he made shoes with such focus, and never before had his hands been so swift and skillful, in the twilight of the ninth day.
tr: Nineteen
es: 19th.

en: An Opinion
vi: 19. Discussion
tr: An Idea
es: AN OPINION

en: Worn out by anxious watching, mr Lorry fell asleep at his post.
vi: Exhausted from worrying and keeping watch, Mr. Lorry fell asleep in the next room.
tr: Mr. Lorry, exhausted from anxious watching, had fallen asleep at his post.
es: With his energies exhausted by long and anxious hours of incessant watchfulness, Mr. Lorry fell asleep at his post of honor.

en: On the tenth morning of his suspense, he was startled by the shining of the sun into the room where a heavy slumber had overtaken him when it was dark night.
vi: On the tense tenth morning, he was startled awake by the sunlight streaming into the room where sleep had overtaken him in the dark of night.
tr: On the tenth morning of this uncertain situation, Mr. Lorry woke up with a start as daylight streamed in; he must have fallen asleep under the weight that had settled on him in the pitch darkness of the night.
es: A ray as indiscreet as it was bright from the morning sun came to shake the heavy sleep that had overcome him the previous night, which was the tenth in the series of watchful nights.

en: He rubbed his eyes and roused himself; but he doubted, when he had done so, whether he was not still asleep.
vi: He rubbed his eyes and stood up; but even so, he was not sure he was fully awake.
tr: He rubbed his eyes and shook himself; but even while doing all this, he still wasn't sure if he was awake or not.
es: With a nervous hand, he rubbed his eyes, stood up, and ran to the entrance of the doctor's bedroom. There he stopped abruptly, wondering if he was asleep or awake. Reasons?

en: For, going to the door of the Doctor’s room and looking in, he perceived that the shoemaker’s bench and tools were put aside again, and that the Doctor himself sat reading at the window.
vi: Because when he stepped to the doctor's room door and looked in, he saw the shoemaker's bench and tools had been put away, and the doctor was sitting properly reading a book by the window.
tr: Because when he went to the Doctor's room and looked inside, he saw that the cobbler's bench and tools had been put aside again and the Doctor was reading a book in front of the window.
es: He had plenty: the stool, with the rest of the shoemaker's tools, was in a corner, and the doctor was calmly reading, lounging in an armchair by the window.

en: He was in his usual morning dress, and his face (which mr Lorry could distinctly see), though still very pale, was calmly studious and attentive.
vi: He was dressed in his usual morning attire, and his face (Mr. Lorry saw clearly) though still pale, was calm and attentive.
tr: He was wearing his usual morning attire, and although his face (as Mr. Lorry could clearly see) was still pale, it was adorned with a calm interest and attention.
es: He was wearing a morning suit, and his face, which Lorry could see perfectly, though a little pale, reflected absolute calm and placidity.

en: Even when he had satisfied himself that he was awake, mr Lorry felt giddily uncertain for some few moments whether the late shoemaking might not be a disturbed dream of his own; for, did not his eyes show him his friend before him in his accustomed clothing and aspect, and employed as usual; and was there any sign within their range, that the change of which he had so strong an impression had actually happened?
vi: Even when he was certain that he was truly awake, Mr. Lorry still felt dizzy for a moment, confused as to whether the shoe-making incident last night was a disturbing dream if he hadn't seen his friend in familiar attire and manner, doing his usual work; so, had all the signs of change that had worried him for the past nine days really happened?
tr: Although Mr. Lorry convinced himself that he was now awake, in his dazed state, he couldn't decide for a moment whether this recent shoemaking matter was a bothersome illusion created in his mind; after all, his friend was sitting right in front of him in his usual attire and appearance, engaged in his usual occupation, showing not the slightest sign of any change or discomfort.
es: A few pinches administered with a firm hand convinced Mr. Lorry that he was not asleep: this point was perfectly clarified and elucidated. But if he was awake then, hadn't he spent the previous days sleeping? The shoemaker, who had caused him so many headaches, could he not have been a dreamed character, a product of a prolonged nightmare? Was there any other explanation for the fact that he was now seeing, with his own perfectly awake eyes, his friend, dressed as usual, calm as usual, and reading as usual?

en: It was but the inquiry of his first confusion and astonishment, the answer being obvious.
vi: But that was just a question in the initial moments of confusion and astonishment, and the answer was already too clear.
tr: After the initial mental confusion and astonishment, everything was becoming a bit clearer.
es: And yet, if it hadn't been for his great confusion and lethargy, this last hypothesis would have fallen apart.

en: If the impression were not produced by a real corresponding and sufficient cause, how came he, Jarvis Lorry, there?
vi: If his worries had no legitimate real cause, then why was he, Jarvis Lorry, here?
tr: If these events weren't real and didn't have a valid reason, what was Jarvis Lorry doing there?
