es: If the unfortunate change caused by such a profound impression had been dreamed and not real, what was the banker from the famous Tellson doing in the quiet house in Soho?

en: How came he to have fallen asleep, in his clothes, on the sofa in Doctor Manette’s consulting-room, and to be debating these points outside the Doctor’s bedroom door in the early morning?
vi: Why had he fallen asleep, without changing clothes, on the sofa in Dr. Manette's consulting room, and why had he been standing, pondering various thoughts, in front of the doctor's bedroom door since early morning?
tr: Why had he fallen asleep on the couch in Dr. Manette's clinic, fully clothed, and why was he pondering these matters in front of the Doctor's bedroom door at this early hour of the morning?
es: How had he just found himself asleep, dressed and shod, on the couch in Dr. Manette's consultation room? Why were these doubts assailing him at such an early hour of the morning and precisely at the entrance to the doctor's bedroom?

en: Within a few minutes, Miss Pross stood whispering at his side.
vi: A few minutes later, Miss Pross was standing next to him, whispering.
tr: Within a few minutes, Miss Pross came to him and was whispering something.
es: Minutes later, Miss Pross was whispering some words in his ear.

en: If he had had any particle of doubt left, her talk would of necessity have resolved it; but he was by that time clear-headed, and had none.
vi: If he had any doubts left, her words would surely dispel them; but by then, he was fully alert and no longer doubted.
tr: If there had still been a shred of doubt left in him, Miss Pross's words would have surely dispelled it; but by that time, Mr. Lorry's mind had cleared, and he had no doubts left.
es: If any trace of doubt had remained in his mind, the words that struck his ears would have dispelled it, but none remained: his head was clear and the doubts had disappeared.

en: He advised that they should let the time go by until the regular breakfast-hour, and should then meet the Doctor as if nothing unusual had occurred.
vi: He advised Miss Pross to wait until the usual breakfast time and then meet the doctor as if nothing unusual had happened.
tr: He suggested waiting until the usual breakfast hour, and then meeting with the Doctor as if nothing had happened.
es: Given the new state of affairs, Lorry advised doing nothing until lunchtime, and then visiting the doctor as if nothing had happened.

en: If he appeared to be in his customary state of mind, mr Lorry would then cautiously proceed to seek direction and guidance from the opinion he had been, in his anxiety, so anxious to obtain.
vi: If the doctor was in his usual familiar state, Mr. Lorry would then cautiously seek the advice and guidance he had been eagerly wanting to know during the past anxious days.
tr: If the Doctor was in his usual natural state, Mr. Lorry, without letting his guard down, would ask him to give as much advice and wisdom as he could muster amidst all the troubles.
es: If his friend remained calm and in control, Lorry would cautiously and cleverly question him, trying to obtain something from him that could guide and direct him in the future.

en: Miss Pross, submitting herself to his judgment, the scheme was worked out with care.
vi: Following his advice, Miss Pross carefully did as instructed.
tr: The plan was carefully executed with Miss Pross, who had entrusted herself to Mr. Lorry's prudence.
es: The plan, which earned Miss Pross's approval, was executed with diligent care.

en: Having abundance of time for his usual methodical toilette, mr Lorry presented himself at the breakfast-hour in his usual white linen, and with his usual neat leg.
vi: After taking his usual leisurely time for meticulous grooming, Mr. Lorry appeared at breakfast in his familiar white linen suit and snug-fitting stockings.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who had plenty of time to dress according to his usual routine, took his place at breakfast in his white linen shirt and his usual silk stockings that showed off his well-shaped legs.
es: Lorry, who had plenty of time to spruce up, appeared at lunchtime neat and impeccable.

en: The Doctor was summoned in the usual way, and came to breakfast.
vi: Dr. Manette was invited to breakfast as usual, and he went to the dining room.
tr: The doctor was called to breakfast as usual, and he also attended.
es: The doctor was called as usual, and as usual, lunch was served.

en: So far as it was possible to comprehend him without overstepping those delicate and gradual approaches which mr Lorry felt to be the only safe advance, he at first supposed that his daughter’s marriage had taken place yesterday.
vi: If strictly following the cautious methods - Mr. Lorry saw it as the only safe way - it is understandable why at first Dr. Manette thought that his daughter's wedding had only taken place yesterday.
tr: Mr. Lorry thought that they could only make solid progress if they approached her gently and gradually, and from what they could understand in this way, the Doctor believed that his daughter's wedding had been the day before.
es: From the conversation, initiated and followed by Lorry with exquisite caution and tact, he inferred that the doctor believed his daughter's marriage had taken place the day before.

en: An incidental allusion, purposely thrown out, to the day of the week, and the day of the month, set him thinking and counting, and evidently made him uneasy.
vi: The seemingly random but actually intentional hints about the day, date, and month made the doctor keep counting and thinking, clearly showing that he was not at ease.
tr: A topic mentioned in passing, but actually brought up intentionally to reveal the current day and month, had made the Doctor think, calculate in his mind, and visibly unsettled him.
es: Proceeding methodically in his explorations, he casually dropped a reference to the day of the week and month they were in, a reference that visibly confused the doctor, but since in all other respects he reflected an evident serenity of judgment, Lorry resolved to seek the help he desired, and he expected that help from the doctor himself.

en: In all other respects, however, he was so composedly himself, that mr Lorry determined to have the aid he sought.
vi: Otherwise, he was extremely calm, to the point that Mr. Lorry decided there was no need to go far to seek anyone's guidance anymore.
tr: On the other hand, he was so composed in every other aspect that Mr. Lorry was determined to find the remedy he sought.
es: Proceeding methodically in his explorations, he casually dropped a reference to the day of the week and month they were in, a reference that visibly confused the doctor, but since in all other respects he reflected an evident serenity of judgment, Lorry resolved to seek the help he desired, and he expected that help from the doctor himself.

en: And that aid was his own.
vi: Dr. Manette himself would indicate what needed to be done.
tr: The remedy was the Doctor himself.
es: Proceeding methodically in his explorations, he casually dropped a reference to the day of the week and month they were in, a reference that visibly confused the doctor, but since in all other respects he reflected an evident serenity of judgment, Lorry resolved to seek the help he desired, and he expected that help from the doctor himself.

en: Therefore, when the breakfast was done and cleared away, and he and the Doctor were left together, mr Lorry said, feelingly:
vi: Therefore, when breakfast was over, the table cleared, and only the two of them remained, Mr. Lorry asked the doctor, his voice emotional: − Dear Mr. Manette, I am very eager to ask your opinion on a strange case that deeply concerns me; it is very strange to me, but for someone as knowledgeable as you, it might not be so.
tr: Thus, after breakfast was finished and the table was cleared, when Mr. Lorry and the Doctor were left alone, Mr. Lorry said to his friend in a compassionate voice:
es: Consequently, after lunch was finished and the table cleared, Lorry said with signs of keen interest:

en: “My dear Manette, I am anxious to have your opinion, in confidence, on a very curious case in which I am deeply interested; that is to say, it is very curious to me; perhaps, to your better information it may be less so.”
vi: Therefore, when breakfast was over, the table cleared, and only the two of them remained, Mr. Lorry asked the doctor, his voice emotional: − Dear Mr. Manette, I am very eager to ask your opinion on a strange case that deeply concerns me; it is very strange to me, but for someone as knowledgeable as you, it might not be so.
tr: "My friend Manette, let's keep this between us, but I am eager to get your opinions on a very strange matter that deeply concerns me; I mean, it seems very strange to me, but perhaps it won't seem as strange to you since you are more knowledgeable than I am.""
es: —My dear Manette, I wish for you to give me your opinion on a case that interests me extraordinarily, a very curious case... I mean, very curious to me, as perhaps you may find it natural and logical.

en: Glancing at his hands, which were discoloured by his late work, the Doctor looked troubled, and listened attentively.
vi: Glancing at his pale hands, worn from the recent shoe-making work, the doctor showed a look of embarrassment but continued to listen attentively.
tr: Doctor, who glanced at his hands that had changed color due to his recent busyness, seemed annoyed, but he listened to Mr. Lorry attentively.
es: The doctor listened with keen attention and looked with a troubled expression at his hands, calloused from the work of the last ten days.

en: He had already glanced at his hands more than once.
vi: He had glanced at his hands more than once.
tr: He had looked at his hands enough a moment ago.
es: He had already looked at them frequently before.

en: “Doctor Manette,” said mr Lorry, touching him affectionately on the arm, “the case is the case of a particularly dear friend of mine.
vi: − Dr. Manette, - Mr. Lorry said as he affectionately took the doctor's arm, - this is the case of a particularly close friend of mine.
tr: "Doctor Manette," said Mr. Lorry, touching his friend's arm affectionately, "this is a matter concerning a very close friend of mine.
es: —The case in question affects, my dear Manette—replied Lorry—a friend of mine, whom I care for very much.

en: Pray give your mind to it, and advise me well for his sake—and above all, for his daughter’s—his daughter’s, my dear Manette.”
vi: Please take care and guide that person... and above all, for that person's daughter... that person's daughter, Mr. Manette.
tr: Please listen very carefully to what I have to say and give me some advice on his behalf –more importantly, for the sake of his daughter– yes, his daughter, my dear friend."
es: This is why I earnestly ask you to examine it with genuine interest and advise me for the good of my friend... and above all, for the good of his daughter... my friend's daughter, my dear Manette.

en: “If I understand,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, “some mental shock—?”
vi: − As I understand it, - the doctor whispered, - it is a form of mental trauma...? − Correct! − Please explain clearly, - said the doctor.
tr: "As far as I understand," said the Doctor in a low voice, "this must be a mental shock?"
es: —If I understand correctly—replied the doctor in a very low voice,—it is a mental shock...

en: “Yes!”
vi: − As I understand it, - the doctor whispered, - it is a form of mental trauma...? − Correct! − Please explain clearly, - said the doctor.
tr: "Correct!"
es: —That's it!

en: “Be explicit,” said the Doctor.
tr: "Explain clearly," said the Doctor.
es: —Speak to me clearly and without omitting any details—said the doctor.

en: “Spare no detail.”
vi: Do not hide anything.
tr: "Do not skip any details."
es: —Speak to me clearly and without omitting any details—said the doctor.

en: mr Lorry saw that they understood one another, and proceeded.
vi: Mr. Lorry saw that they understood each other and continued.
tr: Seeing that they understood each other, Mr. Lorry continued speaking.
es: Lorry understood that they had come to an understanding, and continued like this:

en: “My dear Manette, it is the case of an old and a prolonged shock, of great acuteness and severity to the affections, the feelings, the—the—as you express it—the mind.
vi: − Dear Mr. Manette, this is a case of long-term injury, very severe and seriously affecting emotions, to...
tr: "Dear Manette, this is an old and long-standing type of shock and emotions, feelings, eeh –as you said– it affects the mind to a very large and intense extent.
es: —My dear Manette, it is a terrible shock, very old and lasting several years, a cruel, brutal shock, of affections, of feelings, of... faculties, of the mind... that's it: of the mind.

en: The mind.
vi: ...as you said, ...to the spirit. Spirit.
tr: The mind.
es: —My dear Manette, it is a terrible shock, very old and lasting several years, a cruel, brutal shock, of affections, of feelings, of... faculties, of the mind... that's it: of the mind.

en: It is the case of a shock under which the sufferer was borne down, one cannot say for how long, because I believe he cannot calculate the time himself, and there are no other means of getting at it.
vi: This is a case of injury that this person has endured for an unknown amount of time, because I think even this person cannot calculate the duration, and there is no way to calculate it.
tr: This is such a shock that, when it comes, it takes its victim to a completely different realm, how long it stays is unknown, because I think the person cannot understand how much time has passed and there is no other way to understand it.
es: How long the shock that overwhelmed and crushed the unfortunate person who was its victim lasted, is something I cannot specify, for only my friend could tell us, and he was not in a condition to calculate the time.

en: It is the case of a shock from which the sufferer recovered, by a process that he cannot trace himself—as I once heard him publicly relate in a striking manner.
vi: This is a case of injury that this person has overcome, through a recovery process that even this person does not fully understand... as I have heard this person recount publicly in a very moving manner.
tr: The patient comes out of this shock state in a way that he himself cannot explain –once he demonstrated this strikingly in front of everyone.
es: The one who suffered the shock managed to recover from its effects thanks to a process that he himself cannot explain... as I heard him say in public on an occasion when he gave a moving account of his misfortunes.

en: It is the case of a shock from which he has recovered, so completely, as to be a highly intelligent man, capable of close application of mind, and great exertion of body, and of constantly making fresh additions to his stock of knowledge, which was already very large.
vi: This is a case of injury that this person has fully recovered from, to the extent of returning to an extremely intellectual individual, capable of utilizing both mental and physical efforts, and continuously adding new knowledge to an already profound understanding.
tr: When he comes out of this shock, he completely returns to his old self, that is, he becomes a man who is extremely intelligent, competent in terms of mental functions, physically tremendously active, and constantly in pursuit of refreshing his already vast knowledge.
es: I say that he has recovered from the effects of the mental upheaval so completely, that today he is a man of very clear intelligence, a man who can engage in deep intellectual pursuits, with a vigorous soul and a strong body, a man who multiplies his knowledge every day, and recounts that he already possessed a rich store of it before.

en: But, unfortunately, there has been,” he paused and took a deep breath—“a slight relapse.”
vi: But unfortunately, recently... - Mr. Lorry paused to catch his breath, - ... there has been a slight relapse.
tr: But unfortunately" –he paused and took a deep breath– "his ailment relapsed."
es: Unfortunately... he has had... a small relapse.

en: The Doctor, in a low voice, asked, “Of how long duration?”
vi: − How long has it been? - The doctor asked softly.
tr: The doctor asked in a low voice, "How long did it last?"
es: The doctor asked eagerly: —How long?

en: “Nine days and nights.”
vi: − Nine days and nights.
tr: "Nine days, nine nights."
es: —It lasted nine days and nights.

en: “How did it show itself?
vi: − How does it manifest?
tr: "How did it manifest itself then?
es: —In what way did it manifest?—asked the doctor, looking at his hands again.

en: I infer,” glancing at his hands again, “in the resumption of some old pursuit connected with the shock?”
vi: I guess, - the doctor looked at his hands again, - continuing the old pursuit related to that injury?
tr: I wonder," meanwhile the Doctor glanced at his hands again, "did he return to an old habit connected to this shock?"
es: —Perhaps by returning to some old occupation related to his mental disturbance?

en: “That is the fact.”
vi: − That's exactly right.
tr: "That's exactly what happened."
es: —Indeed.

en: “Now, did you ever see him,” asked the Doctor, distinctly and collectedly, though in the same low voice, “engaged in that pursuit originally?”
vi: − So, have you ever seen, - the doctor asked, his voice clear and calm, though still gentle, - this person do that job before?
tr: "Well, have you ever seen him," he said, speaking slowly and calmly, "engaged in that task before?"
es: —Another thing: Did you ever have the opportunity to see him engaged in that occupation during his original illness prior to the relapse?—asked the doctor very calmly, albeit always in a very low voice.

en: “Once.”
vi: − Once.
tr: "I had seen it once."
es: —Only once.

en: “And when the relapse fell on him, was he in most respects—or in all respects—as he was then?”
vi: − And when it recurs, does this person resemble their former self in many aspects... or in every way?
tr: "Well, when the illness recurred, was it in some ways – or in every way – like what you saw?""
es: —After his relapse, did you find him the same as before in almost everything... or in everything?

en: “I think in all respects.”
vi: − I think they resemble in every way.
tr: "I think it was the same in every aspect."
es: —I think in everything.

en: “You spoke of his daughter.
vi: − He mentioned his daughter.
tr: "You mentioned your daughter.
es: —You mentioned earlier about a daughter of your friend: has the daughter heard about her father's relapse?

en: Does his daughter know of the relapse?”
vi: Does his daughter know about the relapse? −
tr: Does she know that this condition has recurred?"
es: —You mentioned earlier about a daughter of your friend: has the daughter heard about her father's relapse?

en: “No.
vi: No.
tr: "No.
es: —No: the relapse has remained surrounded by the strictest secrecy, and I don't think the daughter will ever come to suspect it.

en: It has been kept from her, and I hope will always be kept from her.
vi: This matter is kept secret, and I hope she will never find out.
tr: This situation was hidden from him, and I hope it will always be kept hidden.
es: —No: the relapse has remained surrounded by the strictest secrecy, and I don't think the daughter will ever come to suspect it.

en: It is known only to myself, and to one other who may be trusted.”
vi: Only I know, along with one other trustworthy person.
tr: Only I know this, and one other trustworthy person."
es: Only two people know about it: myself, and another person of absolute trust. —Delicate and generous foresight, my friend!

en: The Doctor grasped his hand, and murmured, “That was very kind.
vi: The doctor tightly grasped Mr. Lorry's hand and whispered: − It's truly precious.
tr: The doctor tightly held Mr. Lorry's hand and murmured, "You are very kind.
es: —exclaimed the doctor, shaking Lorry's hand effusively.

en: That was very thoughtful!” mr Lorry grasped his hand in return, and neither of the two spoke for a little while.
vi: So considerate!
tr: This is a very thoughtful gesture!" he said. Mr. Lorry also held his hand tightly in response, and they remained silent for a while.
es: The two interlocutors remained silent for a few moments.

en: “Now, my dear Manette,” said mr Lorry, at length, in his most considerate and most affectionate way, “I am a mere man of business, and unfit to cope with such intricate and difficult matters.
vi: Mr. Lorry squeezed the doctor's hand in return, and both remained silent for a long time before Mr. Lorry carefully and affectionately chose his words: − Well, Mr. Manette, I'm just a businessman, I don't know how to handle such difficult and complicated matters.
tr: "Now dear Manette," said Mr. Lorry a little later, in his most gentle and compassionate manner, "I am just a businessman and I am not very good at solving such intricate and difficult matters.
es: —I am a businessman, my dear Manette—said Lorry, breaking the silence and speaking with tones of deep affection,—and, therefore, a layman in such convoluted and difficult matters.

en: I do not possess the kind of information necessary; I do not possess the kind of intelligence; I want guiding.
vi: I don't have the appropriate knowledge nor the profound education; I need guidance.
tr: I don't have much knowledge; my mind doesn't grasp these things, I am asking you to guide me.
es: I lack the data to guide me, I lack the intelligence, the knowledge to lead me, I lack a person to advise me.

en: There is no man in this world on whom I could so rely for right guidance, as on you.
vi: There is no one in this world I earnestly hope to guide me as much as you.
tr: I can't trust anyone else as much as I trust you on this matter. There is no one in the world whose knowledge I can trust as much as yours on this matter.
es: In this world, there is no man in whom I can place my trust or who can dispel my doubts, except for you.

en: Tell me, how does this relapse come about?
vi: Please tell me, how did it recur?
tr: Can you tell me how this ailment recurs?
es: Tell me, what was the cause of the relapse?

en: Is there danger of another?
vi: Is there a risk of it happening again?
tr: Is there a risk of it happening again?
es: Is there a danger of another occurring?

en: Could a repetition of it be prevented?
vi: Is there any way to prevent a recurrence?
tr: Can its recurrence be prevented?
es: Assuming that the danger exists, are there means to prevent it?

en: How should a repetition of it be treated?
vi: If it recurs, how should it be treated?
tr: If it recurs, how should it be treated?
es: What are these means?

en: How does it come about at all?
vi: What is the cause of this situation?
tr: Why does such a thing happen?
es: What are these means?

en: What can I do for my friend?
vi: What can I do for my friend?
tr: What can I do for my friend?
es: What can I do to benefit my friend?

en: No man ever can have been more desirous in his heart to serve a friend, than I am to serve mine, if I knew how.
vi: No one has ever been as eager to help a friend as I am to help mine, if only I knew how.
tr: There is probably no one as eager as I am to help his friend, but if only I knew what to do.
es: There has never been a man in the world who so eagerly wished to serve a friend as I do mine, if I knew how; but I don't know what to do if the case repeats itself.

en: “But I don’t know how to originate, in such a case.
vi: But in this matter, I am powerless.
tr: I don't know what to do in such a situation.
es: There has never been a man in the world who so eagerly wished to serve a friend as I do mine, if I knew how; but I don't know what to do if the case repeats itself.

en: If your sagacity, knowledge, and experience, could put me on the right track, I might be able to do so much; unenlightened and undirected, I can do so little.
vi: If your profound intellect and experience could guide me, I could be of much more help; but groping in the dark like this, I am utterly useless.
tr: If you guide me with your intelligence, knowledge, and experience, I can do something; but without knowing the way, I can't do much.
es: If your sagacity, your knowledge, your experience, can show me the right path, I believe without immodesty that I could do much: without guidance, without external help, all my good intentions will flounder in the dark sea of my ignorance.

en: Pray discuss it with me; pray enable me to see it a little more clearly, and teach me how to be a little more useful.”
vi: Please discuss with me, help me understand better, and show me how I can be more useful.
tr: Please explain to me, help me see the situation more clearly, and guide me so I can help him."
es: Please, give me some explanations, enlighten me a little and show me how to be useful to my friend.

en: Doctor Manette sat meditating after these earnest words were spoken, and mr Lorry did not press him.
vi: Hearing those earnest words, Dr. Manette sat in deep thought for a while, and Mr. Lorry did not press him.
tr: After these heartfelt words, Doctor Manette fell into deep thought, and Mr. Lorry did not press him further.
es: Dr. Manette lowered his head and immersed himself in deep thoughts. Lorry waited calmly.

en: “I think it probable,” said the Doctor, breaking silence with an effort, “that the relapse you have described, my dear friend, was not quite unforeseen by its subject.”
vi: − I think, - the doctor struggled to break the silence, - my friend, the recurrence as you described is not entirely unforeseen by this person. − Is this person afraid of a relapse?
tr: "If you ask me, my dear friend," said the Doctor, forcing himself to break the silence, "the discomfort you described was not something the patient did not expect."
es: —It seems very likely to me—said the doctor after a while—that the relapse you have just described to me was foreseen by the one who was your victim.

en: “Was it dreaded by him?” mr Lorry ventured to ask.
vi: - Mr. Lorry boldly asked.
tr: Mr. Lorry dared to ask, "Well, was he afraid of it?"
es: —Perhaps foreseen and feared?—Lorry dared to ask.

en: “Very much.”
vi: - Mr. Lorry boldly asked.
tr: "A lot indeed."
es: —Perhaps foreseen and feared?—Lorry dared to ask.

en: He said it with an involuntary shudder.
vi: − Of course I am scared, - the doctor shuddered involuntarily.
tr: The doctor shuddered involuntarily.
es: —Temida, yes—exclaimed the doctor, involuntarily shuddering.

en: “You have no idea how such an apprehension weighs on the sufferer’s mind, and how difficult—how almost impossible—it is, for him to force himself to utter a word upon the topic that oppresses him.”
vi: - You cannot possibly understand how this fear constantly weighs on this person's mind, and how difficult it is... almost impossible... for this person to force themselves to speak out about the heavy burden in their heart.
tr: "You cannot know how much of a burden such a concern creates on the patient and how difficult –almost impossible– it is to force oneself to talk about a subject that upsets them so much."
es: —It is impossible for you to form an approximate idea of the enormous weight with which that fear weighs upon the patient's chest... nor of the near impossibility in which he finds himself to speak a word about the matter that oppresses him.

en: “Would he,” asked mr Lorry, “be sensibly relieved if he could prevail upon himself to impart that secret brooding to any one, when it is on him?”
vi: − If one were to confide that secret burden to someone when it torments them, - Mr. Lorry asked, - would this person feel relieved?
tr: "Well, I wonder," said Mr. Lorry, "if, when this happened to him, he could have shared this secret with someone, wouldn't he have felt a bit relieved?""
es: —And wouldn't that oppression ease—asked Lorry—if he decided to confide in someone the secret that apparently torments him?

en: “I think so.
vi: − I also think so.
tr: "They were probably comfortable.
es: —I believe so; but it is, as I just said, almost impossible.

en: But it is, as I have told you, next to impossible.
vi: But as I have said, it is almost impossible.
tr: But as I said, this is an almost impossible situation.
es: —I believe so; but it is, as I just said, almost impossible.

en: I even believe it—in some cases—to be quite impossible.”
vi: I even believe that... in some cases... it is completely impossible to do anything.
tr: In fact – in some cases – I think this is quite impossible."
es: It even seems to me... that it is absolutely impossible.

en: “Now,” said mr Lorry, gently laying his hand on the Doctor’s arm again, after a short silence on both sides, “to what would you refer this attack?”
vi: − Then, - Mr. Lorry gently placed his hand on the doctor's arm after a moment of silence from both, - in your opinion, what caused the relapse?
tr: After a brief silence, "Well," said Mr. Lorry, gently placing his hand on the Doctor's arm again, "what do you attribute this crisis to?"
es: Another pause ensued, which Lorry gently ended by asking: —To what do you attribute the relapse?

en: “I believe,” returned Doctor Manette, “that there had been a strong and extraordinary revival of the train of thought and remembrance that was the first cause of the malady.
vi: − I believe that something extraordinarily powerful occurred, triggering a stream of thoughts and memories about the original cause of the mental trauma.
tr: "I think," said Doctor Manette, "this was an extraordinary situation that made him intensely relive the initial cause of this ailment in his mind.
es: —In my opinion—replied Doctor Manette,—there has been a vigorous awakening of memories that were the determining cause of the initial illness, ideas associated with past tortures have been revived by the breath of some recent event.

en: Some intense associations of a most distressing nature were vividly recalled, I think.
vi: Then this person clearly recalled many extremely painful related events all at once, I think.
tr: I believe a series of powerful associations that caused him immense suffering formed in his mind.
es: —In my opinion—replied Doctor Manette,—there has been a vigorous awakening of memories that were the determining cause of the initial illness, ideas associated with past tortures have been revived by the breath of some recent event.

en: It is probable that there had long been a dread lurking in his mind, that those associations would be recalled—say, under certain circumstances—say, on a particular occasion.
vi: Perhaps for a long time, deep down, this person had feared remembering such related events... for instance, in such circumstances... for instance, on such an occasion.
tr: Perhaps there were fears within him for some time that these associations would be revived – in certain situations – for some reason.
es: It is very likely that in the patient's mind there had been accumulating for some time the fear of this vigorous awakening of painful memories... due to certain circumstances... due to a specific event...

en: He tried to prepare himself in vain; perhaps the effort to prepare himself made him less able to bear it.”
vi: This person tried to prepare defensively but in vain; perhaps the very effort to mentally prepare made this person even less able to withstand that fear.
tr: He tried in vain to prepare himself for these; perhaps all this preparation and effort weakened him."
es: In this case, the patient tried to take preventive measures... he surely would have taken them, but in vain. Who knows if the very efforts made to resist the blow incapacitated him to endure it!

en: “Would he remember what took place in the relapse?” asked mr Lorry, with natural hesitation.
vi: − When a relapse like that occurs, does the person remember what happened? - Mr. Lorry asked with a clearly hesitant voice.
tr: "Well, does he remember what he experienced during this illness?" asked Mr. Lorry with a natural hesitation.
es: —Do you think my friend remembers what he has done during the relapse?—asked Lorry, after hesitating for a few seconds.

en: The Doctor looked desolately round the room, shook his head, and answered, in a low voice, “Not at all.”
vi: Dr. Manette looked around the room, shook his head, and then quietly replied: − I don't remember anything at all.
tr: After the doctor sadly glanced around the room, he shook his head from side to side and replied in a low voice, "No, nothing.""
es: The doctor cast sad glances around, shook his head, and replied in a voice lower than ever: —Absolutely nothing!

en: “Now, as to the future,” hinted mr Lorry.
vi: − What about later? - Mr. Lorry reminded.
tr: "Then let's talk a little about the future," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Let's move on now to the forecast... to the future.

en: “As to the future,” said the Doctor, recovering firmness, “I should have great hope.
vi: − Later on, I think there is much hope, - the doctor regained his assertive tone. -
tr: "From the future," said the Doctor, gathering his strength again, "I am quite hopeful.
es: —The future—replied the doctor energetically—fills me with great hopes.

en: As it pleased Heaven in its mercy to restore him so soon, I should have great hope.
vi: The merciful God has allowed this person to recover so quickly, so I have much hope.
tr: If he got over this last crisis so quickly, one should not lose hope in God.
es: These hopes are based on the short duration of the relapse, thanks to Heaven.

en: He, yielding under the pressure of a complicated something, long dreaded and long vaguely foreseen and contended against, and recovering after the cloud had burst and passed, I should hope that the worst was over.”
vi: This person had succumbed to the pressure of a complex matter that he had long feared, anticipated, and wanted to resist; and now that the relapse is over, I hope that the worst is over.
tr: If he has been crushed under the pressure of a complex event he has been waiting for in fear and uncertainty for a long time, tried to overcome it, and was able to recover after the dark clouds dispersed, the future cannot be worse."
es: If we consider that the patient, after being struck down by the weight of something feared for a long time, something vaguely anticipated, something against which he vainly tried to protect himself, has recovered once the storm has passed, there are ample reasons to believe that the worst is over.

en: “Well, well!
vi: − Great, great!
tr: "Very good!" "I am really relieved."
es: —Very well...! Very well!

en: That’s good comfort.
vi: Truly wonderful.
tr: "Very good!" "I am really relieved."
es: Your words reassure me...

en: I am thankful!” said mr Lorry.
vi: I am grateful to you! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed. − I am grateful to you! -
tr: "Thank you very much!" said Mr. Lorry.
es: Thank you! —exclaimed Lorry. —Thank you!

en: “I am thankful!” repeated the Doctor, bending his head with reverence.
vi: The doctor said, bowing respectfully.
tr: "Thank you very much!" repeated the Doctor, bowing his head respectfully.
es: —repeated the doctor, bowing his head.

en: “There are two other points,” said mr Lorry, “on which I am anxious to be instructed.
vi: − There are two more issues I hope to be advised on, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "There are only two more issues," said Mr. Lorry, "for which I need your opinion.
es: —There are still two points on which I would like you to instruct me.

en: I may go on?”
vi: - May I continue? −
tr: Shall I explain?"
es: May I continue?

en: “You cannot do your friend a better service.”
vi: The more you say, the better it is for your friend, - the doctor extended his hand.
tr: "You cannot do a greater kindness for your friend than this."
es: —It is the greatest favor you can do for your friend—replied the doctor, extending his hand to him.

en: The Doctor gave him his hand.
vi: The more you say, the better it is for your friend, - the doctor extended his hand.
tr: The doctor extended his hand to Mr. Lorry.
es: —It is the greatest favor you can do for your friend—replied the doctor, extending his hand to him.

en: “To the first, then.
vi: − So, the first issue.
tr: "So, the first issue is this:
es: —First: my friend is studious by temperament and possesses uncommon energy.

en: He is of a studious habit, and unusually energetic; he applies himself with great ardour to the acquisition of professional knowledge, to the conducting of experiments, to many things.
vi: This person is eager to learn and has extraordinary determination; this person is extremely enthusiastic about acquiring specialized knowledge, conducting experiments, as well as many other tasks.
tr: My friend is inherently extremely hardworking and incredibly energetic; he makes great efforts to increase his knowledge, constantly reads, conducts experiments, and never remains idle.
es: He ardently pursues the acquisition of new professional knowledge, conducts laborious experiments, and engages in countless activities that demand intense mental effort.

en: Now, does he do too much?”
vi: So, is this person overworking their mind?
tr: Could it be that working this much has been too much for him?"
es: Tell me: don't you think he works excessively?

en: “I think not.
vi: − I don't think so.
tr: "I don't think so.
es: —I don't think so.

en: It may be the character of his mind, to be always in singular need of occupation.
vi: It could be that this person's mind is naturally like that, always busy.
tr: He's already used to keeping his mind occupied with things.
es: Perhaps the nature of his intelligence demands continuous mental work, whether the nature in question is innate and natural, or artificially modified, so to speak, as a consequence of sorrows and afflictions.

en: That may be, in part, natural to it; in part, the result of affliction.
vi: It might be partly due to their nature, and partly as a consequence of past hardships.
tr: This could be partly his nature, and partly the result of the troubles he's experienced.
es: Perhaps the nature of his intelligence demands continuous mental work, whether the nature in question is innate and natural, or artificially modified, so to speak, as a consequence of sorrows and afflictions.

en: The less it was occupied with healthy things, the more it would be in danger of turning in the unhealthy direction.
vi: The less they engage in healthy activities, the more their mind is at risk of weakening again.
tr: As long as he engages with healthy things, the risk of veering into an unhealthy direction decreases.
es: The less he occupies himself with intellectual matters, the greater the danger that his thoughts will take harmful directions.

en: He may have observed himself, and made the discovery.”
vi: Perhaps this person has observed themselves and discovered this.
tr: He might have arrived at this finding through self-observation."
es: It is likely that he himself, after observing himself carefully, has made the discovery to which I am referring.

en: “You are sure that he is not under too great a strain?”
vi: − Are you sure this person isn't under too much stress?
tr: "So, you are sure that he didn't push himself too hard?"
es: —Do you have any assurance that my friend's mental work is not excessive?

en: “I think I am quite sure of it.”
vi: − I think I'm absolutely sure.
tr: "If you ask me, that's the way it is."
es: —I have it; yes.

en: “My dear Manette, if he were overworked now—”
vi: − Mr. Manette, if this person overworks now...
tr: "Well, dear Manette, if he overexerts himself now...""
es: —But if he were overcome by excessive work...

en: “My dear Lorry, I doubt if that could easily be.
vi: − Mr. Lorry, I don't think that's the case.
tr: "Dear Lorry, I don't think so.
es: —I highly doubt that such a thing will happen, my dear Lorry.

en: There has been a violent stress in one direction, and it needs a counterweight.”
vi: When the mind is under extreme pressure on one side, the other side must counteract to maintain balance.
tr: For a while now, there has been a serious problem in his life, and now he needs to be occupied with other things."
es: When there is a violent tendency in a certain direction, it becomes indispensable to counterbalance it in some way, or otherwise, the equilibrium is broken.

en: “Excuse me, as a persistent man of business.
vi: − Excuse me, I am a person who only knows work.
tr: "I'm sorry, I'm just a bit of a persistent businessman.
es: —Excuse my insistence, my dear Manette, as it is known that we businessmen are persistent.

en: Assuming for a moment, that he was overworked; it would show itself in some renewal of this disorder?”
vi: Let's assume this person has overworked; in that case, will this mental disorder recur? − I don't think so, - Dr. Manette asserted confidently.
tr: If we assume that he overexerts himself, do you think this ailment will reappear?"
es: Assuming that the relapse we regret was the result of intense mental pressure, is there no danger of it happening again?

en: “I do not think so.
vi: Let's assume this person has overworked; in that case, will this mental disorder recur? − I don't think so, - Dr. Manette asserted confidently.
tr: "Madam.
es: —I don't believe it... I can't believe it—replied Dr. Manette with a tone of deep conviction.

en: I do not think,” said Doctor Manette with the firmness of self-conviction, “that anything but the one train of association would renew it.
vi: - I believe that only a single stream of association could cause a recurrence.
tr: For such a reason," said Doctor Manette, in a confident manner, "I don't believe his ailment will reappear.

en: I think that, henceforth, nothing but some extraordinary jarring of that chord could renew it.
vi: But from now on, I think that stream of association would need an extraordinarily strong impact to repeat.
tr: In my opinion, the only thing that could trigger a relapse from now on would be a shocking experience.
es: Only the exacerbation of a certain class of memories could provoke another relapse, only the violent vibration of the very string that caused the first one could be the cause of others.

en: After what has happened, and after his recovery, I find it difficult to imagine any such violent sounding of that string again.
vi: After what has happened, and when this person has recovered, I find it hard to imagine what could cause such an extreme impact.
tr: After all that has happened and following his recovery, I find it very unlikely that this dreadful affliction will seize him again.
es: Now then: after what has happened, I consider it almost impossible for new exacerbations of the memories I refer to, impossible for new vibrations of the sick string.

en: I trust, and I almost believe, that the circumstances likely to renew it are exhausted.”
vi: I believe, and can say with certainty, that the possibility of recurrence is no longer there.
tr: I believe that the circumstances which could cause this ailment to recur have now been eliminated."
es: I believe... I almost dare to assure that the circumstances that could lead to new setbacks have disappeared forever.

en: He spoke with the diffidence of a man who knew how slight a thing would overset the delicate organisation of the mind, and yet with the confidence of a man who had slowly won his assurance out of personal endurance and distress.
vi: Dr. Manette spoke with the hesitation of someone who understands how fragile the structure of the mind can be, yet with the determination of someone who has gradually regained self-control through suffering and endurance.
tr: Dr. Manette had spoken with the timidity of a man aware that the slightest thing could upset the delicate structure of the mind; on the other hand, there was also a self-confidence in his demeanor that had developed over time with the sufferings he had endured and the patience he had shown.
es: The doctor spoke with the timidity of someone who knows how little it takes to disturb the delicate organization of intelligence, and at the same time with the confidence of one who, tempered in the bitter waters of tribulations, has acquired that strength which is capable of impassively resisting the hurricanes of life.

en: It was not for his friend to abate that confidence.
vi: His friend had no right to undermine that belief.
tr: This confidence would not be shaken by his friend.
es: It would not be his friend who tried to combat that confidence.

en: He professed himself more relieved and encouraged than he really was, and approached his second and last point.
vi: Mr. Lorry had to pretend to be reassured, more cheerful, and moved on to discuss the second and final issue.
tr: Mr. Lorry felt much more relieved, encouraged by the Doctor's words, and moved on to the second matter.
es: On the contrary, he showed himself more hopeful and convinced than he actually was, and proceeded to address the second point.

en: He felt it to be the most difficult of all; but, remembering his old Sunday morning conversation with Miss Pross, and remembering what he had seen in the last nine days, he knew that he must face it.
vi: He found this the hardest point to address; but recalling the conversation with Miss Pross the previous Sunday and what he had witnessed over the past nine days, he knew he could not avoid it.
tr: He sensed that this would be very difficult; but thinking about the conversation he had with Miss Pross on a Sunday morning and what he had seen over the past nine days, he realized he needed to confront this situation.
es: This was much more difficult and thorny than the first: Lorry was very persuaded of this; but he recalled the conversation he had with Miss Pross on Sunday, took into account the painful scenes he had witnessed in the last nine days, and understood that he had a duty to face it.

en: “The occupation resumed under the influence of this passing affliction so happily recovered from,” said mr Lorry, clearing his throat, “we will call—Blacksmith’s work, Blacksmith’s work.
vi: − Due to the impact of the temporary relapse that fortunately passed, Mr. Lorry cleared his throat, - this person continued to do the work they used to do, let's call it... blacksmithing, yes, blacksmithing.
tr: "During this temporary ailment that my friend has managed to get through quite well," said Mr. Lorry, clearing his throat, "we can say that he was engaged in blacksmithing, yes, blacksmithing.
es: —During his relapse, fortunately now past, he devoted himself... to the trade of... locksmith—said Lorry, with evident hesitation. —Yes; that's it: to the trade of locksmith.

en: We will say, to put a case and for the sake of illustration, that he had been used, in his bad time, to work at a little forge.
vi: To illustrate the issue, let's assume that this person worked with a small forge during the time of hardship.
tr: To make the situation more concrete, let's say that in his old bad days, he worked in a small blacksmith's forge.
es: As an example to clarify the concepts, we will say that my friend, during the time of his mental imbalance, used to work in a forge.

en: We will say that he was unexpectedly found at his forge again.
vi: Let's assume that we unexpectedly saw this person working with that forge as before.
tr: Now, at completely unexpected moments, he thinks he is back in his forge.
es: We will add that, due to circumstances that need not be detailed, he has found that forge again.

en: Is it not a pity that he should keep it by him?”
vi: Isn't it pitiable that this person keeps that small forge close by?
tr: Isn't it very painful for him to live through it this way?"
es: Don't you think it's a shame that he keeps it by his side?

en: The Doctor shaded his forehead with his hand, and beat his foot nervously on the ground.
vi: The doctor raised his hand to cover his forehead, his foot tapping restlessly on the floor.
tr: The doctor raised his hand to his forehead and stomped his foot angrily.
es: The doctor ran his hand across his forehead.

en: “He has always kept it by him,” said mr Lorry, with an anxious look at his friend.
vi: Mr. Lorry continued speaking, his eyes anxiously watching his friend: − This person always keeps that forge.
tr: Mr. Lorry, "He always kept the hearth," he said, looking at his friend with worried eyes.
es: —He has it constantly in his sight—replied Lorry, looking anxiously at his friend. —

en: “Now, would it not be better that he should let it go?”
vi: Wouldn't it be better for him to discard that thing?
tr: "Wouldn't it be better for him to get rid of it from the house?"
es: Don't you think it would be better if he didn't see what must inevitably remind him of painful times?

en: Still, the Doctor, with shaded forehead, beat his foot nervously on the ground.
vi: The doctor’s hand still covered his forehead, his foot still tapping restlessly on the floor.
tr: The doctor was still tapping his foot nervously, with his hands on his forehead.
es: The doctor tapped the floor with a nervous foot.

en: “You do not find it easy to advise me?” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Do you find it difficult to instruct me on this matter? - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "It seems difficult to give advice," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Do you find the advice I ask of you so difficult?—insisted Lorry.

en: “I quite understand it to be a nice question.
vi: - I am well aware that this is a delicate question.
tr: "I think that would be a very appropriate decision.
es: —It seems to me the solution is very simple, however, I believe that...

en: And yet I think—”
vi: However, I think that...
tr: "I think that would be a very appropriate decision.
es: —It seems to me the solution is very simple, however, I believe that...

en: And there he shook his head, and stopped.
vi: At this point, he shook his head and fell silent.
tr: But I guess..." he trailed off, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —You must understand—replied Doctor Manette, turning to his interlocutor—that it is extremely difficult to explain, adhering to the inflexible rules of logic, the intimate operations of the mind of the poor man to whom you refer.

en: “You see,” said Doctor Manette, turning to him after an uneasy pause, “it is very hard to explain, consistently, the innermost workings of this poor man’s mind.
vi: − You see, - Dr. Manette turned to look at his friend after a moment of confused silence, - it is indeed difficult to thoroughly explain what is going on in the mind of this poor fellow.
tr: After a disturbing short silence, Doctor Manette turned to Mr. Lorry and said, "Now look," he said, "it is very difficult to fully explain what is going through this poor man's mind.
es: —You must understand—replied Doctor Manette, turning to his interlocutor—that it is extremely difficult to explain, adhering to the inflexible rules of logic, the intimate operations of the mind of the poor man to whom you refer.

en: He once yearned so frightfully for that occupation, and it was so welcome when it came; no doubt it relieved his pain so much, by substituting the perplexity of the fingers for the perplexity of the brain, and by substituting, as he became more practised, the ingenuity of the hands, for the ingenuity of the mental torture; that he has never been able to bear the thought of putting it quite out of his reach.
vi: This person had once desperately wished to do that work and was very happy to do it; surely this helped him alleviate his suffering greatly by replacing the complex activity of the mind with the complex activity of the hands; and in doing so, he became increasingly proficient, the dexterity of his hands helped him forget the torment in his mind to the extent that he could not bear the thought of being separated from that work.
tr: Once upon a time, he very earnestly wanted to find a job to occupy himself and was very happy when he found it; clearly, this job greatly alleviated his pain at the time; the confusion of his mind was replaced by the confusion of his fingers, and with this change, as he became more skilled, the dexterity of his fingers replaced the skill of self-tormenting; therefore, he never thought of parting with it.
es: In the past, he so fervently requested to dedicate himself to that trade, that when what he longed for was granted to him, he thanked Heaven from the depths of his soul. It is undeniable that, upon finding a means that allowed him to substitute the perplexity of his fingers for the perplexity of his brain, and with the dexterity of his hands the operations of his tortured mind when he acquired some practice in the trade, his torments were greatly alleviated, in which case, it is natural that he shows resistance to parting from what did him so much good.

en: Even now, when I believe he is more hopeful of himself than he has ever been, and even speaks of himself with a kind of confidence, the idea that he might need that old employment, and not find it, gives him a sudden sense of terror, like that which one may fancy strikes to the heart of a lost child.”
vi: Even now, when I see that he is more hopeful about himself than ever before, even speaking about himself with confidence, the thought of needing the old work and not having it suddenly horrifies him, like the fear in the heart of a child who has once been lost from his mother.
tr: Even now, although your friend is more hopeful and confident than ever, he panics with a feeling similar to that of a lost child, thinking that if one day he feels the need to return to this old occupation and cannot find it."
es: Even today, although I believe there is not the slightest danger of new relapses, even if his friend shares this confidence of mine, the idea that there could come a day when he might need the forge, and not find it, I believe would cause him a pain only comparable to that of a father threatened with being separated from his child.

en: He looked like his illustration, as he raised his eyes to mr Lorry’s face.
vi: He truly looked like a lost child when he looked straight into Mr. Lorry's eyes.
tr: The moment the doctor lifted his head and looked at Mr. Lorry's face, he resembled the person he had described.
es: —We do not agree—replied Lorry.

en: “But may not—mind!
vi: − But could it be... Please, sir!
tr: "But –damn!
es: —We do not agree—replied Lorry.

en: I ask for information, as a plodding man of business who only deals with such material objects as guineas, shillings, and bank-notes—may not the retention of the thing involve the retention of the idea?
vi: I need guidance, because a slow-witted person like me only knows how to deal with tangible things like coins, money, and paper bills... If you keep holding onto those tools, will you never forget that fear?
tr: As a businessman who has been dealing with material things, guineas, shillings, banknotes, and such for years, I may have asked you many questions, but– I am saying, doesn't keeping this object with you all the time keep the idea constantly in your mind?
es: —I know I am not an authority on the matter, for as a businessman, my intelligence extinguishes when I do not apply it to things as material as pounds sterling, shillings, and banknotes; but even so, I ask: does the preservation of the forge not tend to perpetuate the idea?

en: If the thing were gone, my dear Manette, might not the fear go with it?
vi: If those things are no longer there, Mr. Manette, wouldn't that fear disappear as well?
tr: If dear Manette had thrown this thing away, wouldn't the fear have gone away with it?
es: If the forge were to disappear, my dear Manette, would not the fear disappear with it?

en: In short, is it not a concession to the misgiving, to keep the forge?”
vi: In short, keeping that forge means constant worry and suffering, right?
tr: In short, doesn't preserving this blacksmith's forge mean the same as surrendering to fears?"
es: In a word: is it not a concession made to fear to preserve the forge?

en: There was another silence.
vi: Another moment of silence.
tr: There was another silence.
es: —You must also understand—replied the doctor after another moment of silence and with a trembling voice—that this is about an old colleague.

en: “You see, too,” said the Doctor, tremulously, “it is such an old companion.”
vi: − Well, you see, - the doctor's voice trembled, - it's like an old friend.
tr: "As you can appreciate," said the Doctor with a trembling voice, "this is a very old friend."
es: —An old companion whom I would distance from my side!

en: “I would not keep it,” said mr Lorry, shaking his head; for he gained in firmness as he saw the Doctor disquieted.
vi: − If it were me, I wouldn't keep it, - Mr. Lorry shook his head; the more anxious the doctor became, the more confident he felt.
tr: Shaking his head from side to side, "If it were me, I wouldn't keep him by my side," said Mr. Lorry; he had gathered his strength upon seeing the Doctor's concern.
es: —replied Lorry with great firmness, for it is worth noting that he was gaining it as the doctor was losing it.

en: “I would recommend him to sacrifice it.
vi: - I would advise this person to give it up.
tr: "I will advise him to sacrifice this friend.
es: —An old companion whom I would sacrifice without a shred of remorse!

en: I only want your authority.
vi: I just need your permission.
tr: I only seek your approval for this.
es: I only need your authorization.

en: I am sure it does no good.
vi: I am sure that keeping it is of no use.
tr: That hearth is of no use to him anymore.
es: Keeping it is harmful; I am sure of it.

en: Come!
vi: Come on!
tr: Come on, my dear friend, please give me this authority.
es: Keeping it is harmful; I am sure of it.

en: Give me your authority, like a dear good man.
vi: Please allow me, as a kind person.
tr: Come on, my dear friend, please give me this authority.
es: Grant me the permission I seek, my dear Manette...

en: For his daughter’s sake, my dear Manette!”
vi: For the sake of this person's daughter, Mr. Manette!
tr: For the sake of your daughter, dear Manette!"
es: You are good... you have a good heart... grant it to me for the sake of the peace of my poor friend's daughter...!

en: Very strange to see what a struggle there was within him!
vi: How strange it is to witness the doctor's inner turmoil!
tr: The doctor was clearly fighting a great battle within himself!
es: The struggle that took place in the doctor's chest between conflicting thoughts was fierce, terrible, and frightening.

en: “In her name, then, let it be done; I sanction it.
vi: − Then for the sake of that girl, do it; I give my permission.
tr: "Then, for my daughter's sake, let it be done; I find it appropriate.
es: After a while, he said: —In deference to his friend's daughter, I grant the authorization he asks for.

en: But, I would not take it away while he was present.
vi: But if it were me, I wouldn't do it in front of this person.
tr: But I advise against removing it while she is around.
es: I sanction the sacrifice of the forge; but it should not be done in front of his friend.

en: Let it be removed when he is not there; let him miss his old companion after an absence.”
vi: Dispose of those things when he is absent; let him remember his old friend after he has gone far away.
tr: It would be better to get rid of it when she is not here; let her miss her old friend after not seeing it for a while."
es: Take advantage of a moment of absence and spare him the pain of witnessing the destruction of what was his sole companion in past times.

en: mr Lorry readily engaged for that, and the conference was ended.
vi: Mr. Lorry agreed immediately and the consultation ended.
tr: Mr. Lorry gladly accepted immediately, and the matter was closed.
es: With true joy, Lorry accepted the solution, and the conference was concluded.

en: They passed the day in the country, and the Doctor was quite restored.
vi: They spent the whole day enjoying the countryside, and the doctor had completely recovered.
tr: They spent the day in the countryside, and the Doctor recovered quite a bit.
es: They spent the day in the countryside, which was enough to restore the doctor.

en: On the three following days he remained perfectly well, and on the fourteenth day he went away to join Lucie and her husband.
vi: For the next three days, he remained as healthy as ever, and on the fourteenth day, he set out to meet Lucie and her husband.
tr: He was also very well during the following three days, and on the fourteenth day, he set out to join his daughter Lucie and son-in-law.
es: During the next three days, he went about his normal life, and on the fourteenth day of his daughter's absence, he went to join her and her husband.

en: The precaution that had been taken to account for his silence, mr Lorry had previously explained to him, and he had written to Lucie in accordance with it, and she had no suspicions.
vi: Mr. Lorry had previously explained to Mr. Manette how they had fabricated a story to explain the doctor's absence, and Mr. Manette had used that pretext to write to Lucie, so she suspected nothing.
tr: Mr. Lorry had previously explained to him the precaution they had taken during the Doctor's silent period, and the Doctor had written something to Lucie accordingly, so she suspected nothing.
es: During the next three days, he went about his normal life, and on the fourteenth day of his daughter's absence, he went to join her and her husband.

en: On the night of the day on which he left the house, mr Lorry went into his room with a chopper, saw, chisel, and hammer, attended by Miss Pross carrying a light.
vi: The day the doctor left home, that night Mr. Lorry entered the doctor's room carrying an axe, a saw, a chisel, and a hammer, with Miss Pross assisting by holding a lamp.
tr: The night the doctor left the house, Mr. Lorry, with an axe, saw, chisel, and hammer in hand, accompanied by Miss Pross holding a lantern, went to his friend's room.
es: As soon as night fell on the day the doctor left his house, he entered the bedroom of our good friend Lorry, armed with a butcher's knife, a saw, a chisel, and a hammer.

en: There, with closed doors, and in a mysterious and guilty manner, mr Lorry hacked the shoemaker’s bench to pieces, while Miss Pross held the candle as if she were assisting at a murder—for which, indeed, in her grimness, she was no unsuitable figure.
vi: In the room, behind closed doors, in an atmosphere of mystery and guilt, Mr. Lorry smashed the shoemaker's bench to pieces while Miss Pross held the candle to illuminate the scene as if participating in a murder - judging by her fierce expression, Miss Pross indeed seemed well-suited to this scheme.
tr: There, behind closed doors, while Mr. Lorry, with a mysterious and guilty demeanor, was smashing the shoemaker's bench to pieces, Miss Pross, as if she were an accomplice to a murder – which suited her stern appearance quite well – held the light for him.
es: Miss Pross followed him in, holding a candlestick in her hand. Behind closed doors, in the mystery of the night, resembling someone committing a criminal act, Mr. Lorry smashed the shoemaker's bench to pieces, while Miss Pross held the light as if witnessing the commission of a murder.

en: The burning of the body (previously reduced to pieces convenient for the purpose) was commenced without delay in the kitchen fire; and the tools, shoes, and leather, were buried in the garden.
vi: The remains were chopped up to facilitate burning, and the cremation began immediately in the kitchen stove; the tools, shoes, and leather pieces were buried in the garden.
tr: Without any delay, the bench (broken into pieces as intended) was burned in the kitchen fire, and all the tools, shoes, and leather pieces were buried in the garden.
es: In the kitchen, the sinful bench, previously reduced to splinters, was then incinerated, and subsequently, the tools and implements of the trade, shoes, soles, and leather, received an honorable burial in the garden adjacent to the house.

en: So wicked do destruction and secrecy appear to honest minds, that mr Lorry and Miss Pross, while engaged in the commission of their deed and in the removal of its traces, almost felt, and almost looked, like accomplices in a horrible crime.
vi: For those with honest souls, this secretive destruction was truly cruel, so Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, while busily carrying out the act and erasing all traces, both inwardly and outwardly resembled two accomplices committing a heinous crime.
tr: As Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross carried out their actions and erased the traces of them, there was such a dreadful sense of destruction and secrecy that both felt and indeed looked like accomplices to a terrible murder.
es: Both Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, while executing the feat and making the traces disappear, considered themselves, and almost appeared to be, accomplices in a horrendous crime.

vi: For those with honest souls, this secretive destruction was truly cruel, so Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, while busily carrying out the act and erasing all traces, both inwardly and outwardly resembled two accomplices committing a heinous crime.
tr: As Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross carried out their actions and erased the traces of them, there was such a dreadful sense of destruction and secrecy that both felt and indeed looked like accomplices to a terrible murder.
es: XX.

en: Original
vi: 20. Request
tr: As Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross carried out their actions and erased the traces of them, there was such a dreadful sense of destruction and secrecy that both felt and indeed looked like accomplices to a terrible murder.
es: XX.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: 20. Request
tr: XX
es: XX.

en: A Plea
vi: 20. Request
tr: A Request
es: A PLEA

en: When the newly-married pair came home, the first person who appeared, to offer his congratulations, was Sydney Carton.
vi: When the newlywed couple returned, the first person to congratulate them was Sydney Carton.
tr: When the newlywed couple returned home, the first person to come and congratulate them was Sydney Carton.
es: The first person who showed up at Doctor Manette's house after the newlyweds returned from their honeymoon was Sydney Carton.

en: They had not been at home many hours, when he presented himself.
vi: He arrived a few hours after they got home.
tr: When Carton arrived, Lucie and Charles had not been home for long.
es: The first person who showed up at Doctor Manette's house after the newlyweds returned from their honeymoon was Sydney Carton.

en: He was not improved in habits, or in looks, or in manner; but there was a certain rugged air of fidelity about him, which was new to the observation of Charles Darnay.
vi: His clothes, appearance, and demeanor were no better, but Carton had a certain firmness and reliability that Charles Darnay had never seen before.
tr: There was no improvement in Carton's habits, appearance, or manners; but he had acquired an air of a strong, loyal friend that Charles Darnay had just begun to notice.
es: His attire, his manners, his gestures, his expression, could be said to be the same as always; but over the hard exterior, despite being extraordinarily rough, there was a certain air of fidelity that did not go unnoticed by the scrutinizing gaze of Charles Darnay.

en: He watched his opportunity of taking Darnay aside into a window, and of speaking to him when no one overheard.
vi: Waiting for a convenient moment, he pulled Darnay to the window to speak privately so that no one could hear.
tr: Carton was waiting for an opportunity to pull Darnay to the window and talk to him at a moment when no one would hear.
es: Carton took advantage of the first opportunity that presented itself to take Darnay to the recess of a window, where he spoke to him without their conversation reaching the ears of any of those present.

en: “mr Darnay,” said Carton, “I wish we might be friends.”
vi: − Mr. Darnay, - Carton said, - I hope we can be friends.
tr: "Mr. Darnay," said Carton, "I hope to be friends with you."
es: —I wish that we could be friends, Mr. Darnay—Carton began saying.

en: “We are already friends, I hope.”
vi: − We are already friends, I hope so.
tr: "Aren't we already like that?"
es: —I think we already are—replied Darnay.

en: “You are good enough to say so, as a fashion of speech; but, I don’t mean any fashion of speech.
vi: − You saying that is really kind and very polite; but my intention has nothing to do with politeness.
tr: "You are kind and gracious enough to say this; but there is no need for courtesy now.
es: —I appreciate you saying that, even if your words are plainly dictated by politeness. But I was not referring to that conventional friendship.

en: Indeed, when I say I wish we might be friends, I scarcely mean quite that, either.”
vi: Honestly, when I said I hoped we could be friends, I wasn't just being polite.
tr: When I said I hoped to be friends, I didn't exactly mean that."
es: When I tell you that I wish for us to be friends, I am alluding to another kind of friendship.

en: Charles Darnay—as was natural—asked him, in all good-humour and good-fellowship, what he did mean?
vi: Charles Darnay naturally had to ask again, very cheerfully and kindly, what Carton meant.
tr: Charles Darnay –as usual– asked with a cheerful and affectionate manner what she meant.
es: Carlos Darnay begged him to explain himself.

en: “Upon my life,” said Carton, smiling, “I find that easier to comprehend in my own mind, than to convey to yours.
vi: − I swear, - Carton said with a smile, - it's easy for me to understand myself but hard to make others understand my thoughts.
tr: "Throughout my life," said Carton, smiling, "I have struggled to express what was on my mind.
es: —By my life, I find it easier to understand the idea myself than to make it understandable to others!

en: However, let me try.
vi: But I will try to explain.
tr: But if you allow me, I will try to explain.
es: —replied Carton.—I will try, however.

en: You remember a certain famous occasion when I was more drunk than—than usual?”
vi: Do you remember that time when I was more... more drunk than usual?
tr: You remember that infamous evening when I was more drunk than ever, don't you?"
es: Do you remember that memorable occasion when I was more drunk than usual?

en: “I remember a certain famous occasion when you forced me to confess that you had been drinking.”
vi: − I still remember the time when you forced me to admit that you were too drunk.
tr: "I remember that famous evening when you forced me to say that you drank too much."
es: —I remember the memorable occasion when you forced me to declare that I had been drinking.

en: “I remember it too.
vi: − I remember too.
tr: "I remember too.
es: —I haven't forgotten it either.

en: The curse of those occasions is heavy upon me, for I always remember them.
vi: That time still haunts me because I can never forget it.
tr: The curse of such nights weighs heavily on me, and I always remember.
es: The curse that weighs on those occasions leaves such lasting traces on me that it can be said I never forget them.

en: I hope it may be taken into account one day, when all days are at an end for me!
vi: I hope that on the day of final judgment, my regret will be considered!
tr: I hope they take this into account when I reach the end of my life!
es: I harbor the hope that a day will come, the one that puts an end to my days on earth, when I will make amends for that occasion...

en: Don’t be alarmed; I am not going to preach.”
vi: Don't panic, I'm not preaching.
tr: Don't worry; I won't bore you."
es: Don't be alarmed, it is not my intention to preach.

en: “I am not at all alarmed.
vi: − I am not panicking.
tr: "I definitely did not panic.
es: —I'm not alarmed!

en: Earnestness in you, is anything but alarming to me.”
vi: With someone as sincere as you, why would I panic?
tr: The only thing that makes me anxious is your sincerity."
es: Your seriousness can never alarm me.

en: “Ah!” said Carton, with a careless wave of his hand, as if he waved that away.
vi: − Ah! - Carton nonchalantly waved his hand as if to dismiss Darnay's words.
tr: "Ah!" said Carton, waving his hand indifferently as if dismissing the matter.
es: —Well then: regarding the drunkenness in question... one of my countless drunken episodes, I was unbearably impertinent, talking to you about whether I found you likable or unlikable: I beg you to forget it and to consider my words as unsaid.

en: “On the drunken occasion in question (one of a large number, as you know), I was insufferable about liking you, and not liking you.
vi: - That time I was drunk; one of the many times like that, you know; I was rude when talking about whether I liked or disliked you.
tr: "When it comes to talking about whether I love you in my drunken state (as you know, there are plenty of examples like this), I was unbearable.
es: —Well then: regarding the drunkenness in question... one of my countless drunken episodes, I was unbearably impertinent, talking to you about whether I found you likable or unlikable: I beg you to forget it and to consider my words as unsaid.

en: I wish you would forget it.”
vi: I hope you can forget it.
tr: I hope you can forget it."
es: —Well then: regarding the drunkenness in question... one of my countless drunken episodes, I was unbearably impertinent, talking to you about whether I found you likable or unlikable: I beg you to forget it and to consider my words as unsaid.

en: “I forgot it long ago.”
vi: − I forgot a long time ago.
tr: "I already forgot.""
es: —I forgot them a long time ago.

en: “Fashion of speech again!
vi: − Don't be so formal!
tr: "How dare you speak like this!
es: —Once again, your words are inspired by compliments and social conventions!

en: But, mr Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to me, as you represent it to be to you.
vi: But Mr. Darnay, I am not as forgetful as you.
tr: But Mr. Darnay, I cannot forget some things as easily as you do.
es: I must say, Mr. Darnay, that I do not forget as easily as you pretend to forget.

en: I have by no means forgotten it, and a light answer does not help me to forget it.”
vi: I have no way to forget, and a random remark cannot help me forget.
tr: I can never forget my state that evening, and even your dismissive response does not help me forget it.'
es: I have not forgotten her, and I assure you that a light and indifferent response on your part will not help me forget her.

en: “If it was a light answer,” returned Darnay, “I beg your forgiveness for it.
vi: − If that was a careless remark, then I apologize to you, - Darnay replied.
tr: "If I made you think that I took this lightly," replied Darnay, "please forgive me.
es: —If my response has been flippant, I beg you to forgive me—replied Darnay.—

en: I had no other object than to turn a slight thing, which, to my surprise, seems to trouble you too much, aside.
vi: - I answered that way because I thought it was not important, but I am surprised that you are so concerned and want to move on.
tr: My only intention was to set aside a small matter that has caused you surprising distress.
es: My intention was to remove all importance from what, to my considerable surprise, concerns you too much.

en: I declare to you, on the faith of a gentleman, that I have long dismissed it from my mind.
vi: I tell you, on the honor of a gentleman, that I have long forgotten about it.
tr: I swear on my honor that this incident had long been erased from my mind.
es: I declare to you, on my word of honor, that I forgot the conversation of the night to which you refer a long time ago, and I understand that by forgetting it, I did not gain any merit.

en: Good Heaven, what was there to dismiss!
vi: Good Lord, what is there to it!
tr: Though, what was there to erase anyway!
es: For what, had you not rendered me that very day a service that no moderately grateful heart can or should forget?

en: Have I had nothing more important to remember, in the great service you rendered me that day?”
vi: Isn't there anything more important for me to remember, especially when you were the one who helped me that day? −
tr: If I have anything to remember, it should be the great kindness you showed me that day."
es: For what, had you not rendered me that very day a service that no moderately grateful heart can or should forget?

en: “As to the great service,” said Carton, “I am bound to avow to you, when you speak of it in that way, that it was mere professional claptrap, I don’t know that I cared what became of you, when I rendered it.
vi: That help, - Carton said - since you put it that way, I must confess to you, at that time I did it merely as a professional trick, I did it regardless of what consequences you might face...
tr: "When you mention great kindness now," said Carton, "I must confess that they were all professional tall tales.
es: —You put me in the position of telling you—replied Carton—that the great service you speak of was simply what we might call a professional prank, one of those tricks we lawyers often resort to in order to gain popularity.

en: —Mind!
vi: Please remember!
tr: At that time, I didn't really care what would happen to you.
es: A good proof of this is that, when I rendered it, I was completely indifferent to your fate.

en: I say when I rendered it; I am speaking of the past.”
vi: I am speaking of my feelings back then; I am talking about the past.
tr: –But look, I am saying at that time; I mean, I am talking about the past."
es: Note that I said when I rendered it; that is, I am speaking of past events.

en: “You make light of the obligation,” returned Darnay, “but I will not quarrel with your light answer.”
vi: − You are underestimating that gratitude again, - Darnay replied, - but I don't want to argue with your reckless words.
tr: "Now you are underestimating my debt of gratitude to you," said Darnay, "but I will not argue about your underestimation of this situation.""
es: —You insist on belittling my obligation, and yet, I, less finicky than you, am not offended by the lightness of your response.

en: “Genuine truth, mr Darnay, trust me!
vi: − That is the complete truth, Mr. Darnay, believe me!
tr: "This is the truth, Mr. Darnay, believe me!
es: —It is the naked truth, Mr. Darnay, the naked truth.

en: I have gone aside from my purpose; I was speaking about our being friends.
vi: I digressed; I was talking about our friends.
tr: Look, I have strayed away from the main topic I wanted to tell you; I was talking about being friends with you.
es: But I have strayed from the object I was pursuing. I was speaking of my desires for us to be friends.

en: Now, you know me; you know I am incapable of all the higher and better flights of men.
vi: There, you know me, you know I don't have the talent to rise higher, to be better like everyone else.
tr: Now, you know me; you know that I can't soar high like other men.
es: As you already know me, there is no need for me to tell you that my friendship can honor no one.

en: If you doubt it, ask Stryver, and he’ll tell you so.”
vi: If you still have doubts, just ask Stryver and he will tell you this.
tr: If you have any doubts about this, ask Stryver, he will tell you."
es: If you have any doubts, ask Stryver.

en: “I prefer to form my own opinion, without the aid of his.”
vi: − I prefer to have my own opinion, without needing to rely on him.
tr: "I prefer to give my opinion on this matter without his help.""
es: —I prefer to form an opinion without their assistance.

en: “Well!
vi: − Alright!
tr: "Good!
es: —Very well.

en: At any rate you know me as a dissolute dog, who has never done any good, and never will.”
vi: Anyway, you know that I am a worthless person, incapable of doing anything good and will never be able to.
