tr: In the end, you know me as a worthless person who is good for nothing and will never be.""
es: Therefore, you already know that I am a dissolute dog, incapable of anything good, now and always.

en: “I don’t know that you ‘never will.’”
vi: − I don't know about your "never ever" situation.
tr: "Will it never be useful, or not, I don't know.""
es: —We do not agree, my friend.

en: “But I do, and you must take my word for it.
vi: − But I know, and you must believe me.
tr: "But I know, and you should believe me.
es: —I assure you, and you must believe me.

en: Well!
vi: Well!
tr: "But I know, and you should believe me.
es: I continue.

en: If you could endure to have such a worthless fellow, and a fellow of such indifferent reputation, coming and going at odd times, I should ask that I might be permitted to come and go as a privileged person here; that I might be regarded as an useless (and I would add, if it were not for the resemblance I detected between you and me, an unornamental) piece of furniture, tolerated for its old service, and taken no notice of.
vi: If you can tolerate someone like me, a person with a bad reputation who occasionally visits this place, then I would like to come here as someone granted a favor; you can consider me as a discarded piece of furniture, kept because of its past usefulness, and no one bothers to notice. And I want to add that if it weren't for the fact that I discovered we look alike, I would just be a discard.
tr: Well, if you are going to accept a worthless, ill-reputed man like me into your home at odd times, at least allow me to come and go as a privileged man; see me as a useless piece of furniture with no special features if you want (of course, I must add that this has nothing to do with the similarity between you and me); like an old item kept for the sake of old times, which has been discarded.
es: If you find yourself strong enough to tolerate the presence in this house of a person who is worthless, and who moreover enjoys a questionable reputation, I will ask you as a special favor to allow me to come here or leave, without adhering to hours or rules, seeing in me nothing more than a useless piece of furniture and... I would gladly add abnormal, if it weren't for the physical resemblance between the two of us... a useless piece of furniture, reserved for rare services and one that you wouldn't even notice.

en: I doubt if I should abuse the permission.
vi: I will not abuse your permission.
tr: If you grant me this permission, I don't think I would misuse it.
es: I highly doubt that I will abuse the permission, if you grant it to me.

en: It is a hundred to one if I should avail myself of it four times in a year.
vi: I bet one hundred to one that I will only come here four times a year at most.
tr: I would probably only visit four or five times a year anyway.
es: There is a hundred to one chance that I will not use your indulgence more than four times a year.

en: It would satisfy me, I dare say, to know that I had it.”
vi: If permitted, I dare say I would want nothing more.
tr: But knowing that I have such a right would make me feel good."
es: It would be a satisfaction for me to know that I am abusing it.

en: “Will you try?”
vi: − Will you come? −
tr: "Would you really do this?"
es: —Will you do your best to take advantage?

en: “That is another way of saying that I am placed on the footing I have indicated.
vi: That was a subtle way of saying that my suggestion had been approved.
tr: "From what you say, I infer that I have a place here.
es: —We shall see.

en: I thank you, Darnay.
vi: Thank you, Darnay.
tr: Thank you, Darnay.
es: Do you authorize me to take the liberty I am requesting, Darnay?

en: I may use that freedom with your name?”
vi: May I call you by your first name to be more familiar?
tr: Well, may I address you by your name while exercising this right?"
es: Do you authorize me to take the liberty I am requesting, Darnay?

en: “I think so, Carton, by this time.”
vi: − I think so too, Carton, from now on.
tr: "Of course, Carton, as you wish.""
es: —Authorized, Carton.

en: They shook hands upon it, and Sydney turned away.
vi: They shook hands and Sydney turned on his heel.
tr: Upon this, they shook hands and Sydney left.
es: They shook hands and then Carton walked away.

en: Within a minute afterwards, he was, to all outward appearance, as unsubstantial as ever.
vi: Just a minute later, he once again had the completely disheveled appearance he wore every day.
tr: A few minutes had passed when he once again adopted that indifferent attitude towards the outside world.
es: A minute later, Carton was his usual extravagant self.

en: When he was gone, and in the course of an evening passed with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and mr Lorry, Charles Darnay made some mention of this conversation in general terms, and spoke of Sydney Carton as a problem of carelessness and recklessness.
vi: After the guest had left, in the evening sitting with Miss Pross, the doctor, and Mr. Lorry, Charles Darnay briefly mentioned this conversation and commented on Sydney Carton as a matter of carelessness and defiance.
tr: After Carton left, Charles Darnay was sitting and talking with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and Mr. Lorry in the evening. He mentioned, in general terms, the conversation he had with Sydney Carton and noted that Sydney Carton's problem was not caring about or valuing anything.
es: That night, in the conversations that followed dinner, in which Miss Pross, the doctor, Lorry, and the married couple took part, Sydney Carton was incidentally and generally discussed, portraying him as a living problem of indifference and recklessness.

en: He spoke of him, in short, not bitterly or meaning to bear hard upon him, but as anybody might who saw him as he showed himself.
vi: He spoke briefly, without implying any harshness or criticism towards his friend, only mentioning things that everyone had already seen Sydney reveal.
tr: There was no hostile or accusatory tone when he spoke about him; it was as if he was merely conveying something that anyone who looked at him could see.
es: Darnay said a few phrases about him which, although they could not be considered harsh or offensive, reflected a certain disdain.

en: He had no idea that this could dwell in the thoughts of his fair young wife; but, when he afterwards joined her in their own rooms, he found her waiting for him with the old pretty lifting of the forehead strongly marked.
vi: He did not expect that those words would be remembered by his beautiful young wife; but later, when he returned to their private room to meet Lucie, he saw her waiting with the familiar graceful wrinkle clearly etched on her forehead.
tr: He had never thought that these words would occupy his beautiful wife's mind; but later, when he went to their room to be with his wife, he found her waiting for him with her forehead distinctly tensed as before.
es: Little did he think that he had hurt the feelings of his beautiful wife. When later, after the gathering had ended, he found her in their room, he couldn't help but notice a certain worry in her.

en: “We are thoughtful to-night!” said Darnay, drawing his arm about her.
vi: − Do we have something to worry about tonight? - Darnay said as he wrapped his arm around her.
tr: "We seem to be a bit pensive tonight!" said Darnay, embracing his wife with his arms.
es: —I find you thoughtful tonight—said Carlos, passing his arm around her waist...

en: “Yes, dearest Charles,” with her hands on his breast, and the inquiring and attentive expression fixed upon him; “we are rather thoughtful to-night, for we have something on our mind to-night.”
vi: − That's right, Charles, - With her hand placed on her husband's chest, Lucie looked at him intently, questioning. - We have something to worry about tonight, because we have something to be concerned about tonight.
tr: With her hands on her husband's chest, "Yes, dear Charles," said Lucie, her eyes fixed on her husband with a questioning and attentive expression; "we are quite thoughtful tonight, because we have some things on our minds tonight."
es: —I am, my dear Carlos—replied Lucía, looking him straight in the eye,—I am thoughtful tonight because there is something on my mind that is bothering me.

en: “What is it, my Lucie?”
vi: − What is it, Lucie? −
tr: "What are they, my dear Lucie?""
es: —And what is it, my Lucía?

en: “Will you promise not to press one question on me, if I beg you not to ask it?”
vi: You have to promise not to press me on things I don't want to answer, okay?
tr: "I will tell you, but please promise me that you won't ask me anything about this, okay?"
es: —Do you give me your word not to let your curiosity go beyond what I desire?

en: “Will I promise?
vi: − Promise?
tr: "Should I give my word?
es: —And what is it that I will not promise to my love?

en: What will I not promise to my Love?”
vi: Is there anything I wouldn't promise you, my love?
tr: If my beloved asks, how could I not give my word?"
es: —And what is it that I will not promise to my love?

en: What, indeed, with his hand putting aside the golden hair from the cheek, and his other hand against the heart that beat for him!
vi: Truly, what wouldn't I promise when one hand brushes aside the golden lock of hair on your cheek and the other rests on your chest where your heart belongs to me!
tr: How could it be thought otherwise, with one hand on his heart that beat for her, while his golden hair, falling over his wife's cheek, was brushed aside with the other!
es: —I believe, Carlos, that poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you have shown him tonight.

en: “I think, Charles, poor mr Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you expressed for him to-night.”
vi: − Charles, I think Mr. Carton deserves more attention and respect than what you said about him tonight.
tr: "Charles, I think Mr. Carton deserves more attention and respect than what you said about him tonight.""
es: —I believe, Carlos, that poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you have shown him tonight.

en: “Indeed, my own?
vi: − Really, my love?
tr: "What did I say?"
es: —Really?

en: Why so?”
vi: Why do you say that?
tr: "Why then?""
es: And why?

en: “That is what you are not to ask me.
vi: − That's something you shouldn't ask.
tr: "Please don't ask me this!
es: —That is precisely what you should not ask me.

en: But I think—I know—he does.”
vi: But I think... I know... he deserves it.
tr: But I think – I know – they deserve this."
es: Just think... that I know for a fact that they deserve it.

en: “If you know it, it is enough.
vi: − If you know that, it's enough.
tr: "If you know, that's enough for me!
es: —If you are certain, there's nothing more to discuss.

en: What would you have me do, my Life?”
vi: So, what do you want me to do, my love?
tr: So, what do you want me to do, my dear?"
es: What do you want me to do, my love?

en: “I would ask you, dearest, to be very generous with him always, and very lenient on his faults when he is not by.
vi: − My love, I want you to always be generous with him, forgiving his mistakes when he's not around.
tr: "My love, I will always ask you to treat him very well and to be tolerant of his mistakes.
es: —The only thing I wish is that you always treat him with great generosity, and that you try to excuse his flaws when someone brings them to public attention in his absence.

en: I would ask you to believe that he has a heart he very, very seldom reveals, and that there are deep wounds in it.
vi: I want you to believe that he is a person whose heart is almost always closed, bearing many deep scars.
tr: Believe me, he has a deeply wounded heart and he very rarely opens it to people.
es: I also ask you to believe that in his chest beats a heart that very, very rarely reveals itself, a heart covered with very deep wounds.

en: My dear, I have seen it bleeding.”
vi: My love, I have seen that heart bleed.
tr: I have witnessed that heart bleeding, my love."
es: Believe me, my dear, for I assure you that I have seen it bleeding.

en: “It is a painful reflection to me,” said Charles Darnay, quite astounded, “that I should have done him any wrong.
vi: − I am truly heartbroken to know that I have treated him so poorly, Charles Darnay exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: "If I have behaved rudely," said Charles, in a bewildered state, "I am very sorry for that.
es: —He believes that I deeply regret having made him the object of my inconsiderations—said Darnay, still astonished by his wife's words.

en: I never thought this of him.”
vi: - I never thought he was that sensitive.
tr: I had never thought of it that way for him."
es: —It was not my intention to treat him unfairly.

en: “My husband, it is so.
vi: − That's right, my love.
tr: "But this is the situation, my dear husband.
es: —Well, you didn't do him justice, my dear Carlos.

en: I fear he is not to be reclaimed; there is scarcely a hope that anything in his character or fortunes is reparable now.
vi: I'm afraid he can't change; there's no hope of improving his character or fate.
tr: I don't think he will ever recover; I have no hope that either his personality or his fate will improve anymore.
es: I fear it must be impossible to make him change, that neither his character nor his special way of being are susceptible to modification; but I assure you he is a man capable of good deeds, even magnanimous actions.

en: But, I am sure that he is capable of good things, gentle things, even magnanimous things.”
vi: But I believe he is capable of doing many kind, good, and even chivalrous things.
tr: But I am sure he can do good things, beautiful things, even noble things."
es: I fear it must be impossible to make him change, that neither his character nor his special way of being are susceptible to modification; but I assure you he is a man capable of good deeds, even magnanimous actions.

en: She looked so beautiful in the purity of her faith in this lost man, that her husband could have looked at her as she was for hours.
vi: The pure trust given to that failure made Lucie so radiantly beautiful that her husband could silently gaze at her for hours.
tr: Lucie looked so beautiful with the purity of her faith in this lost man that her husband could gaze at this face for hours.
es: Lucía was so beautiful, her lovely face so radiant with the purest light of faith in a man deemed irredeemable by all, that her husband, unable to find words to respond, stood there entranced, gazing at her.

en: “And, O my dearest Love!” she urged, clinging nearer to him, laying her head upon his breast, and raising her eyes to his, “remember how strong we are in our happiness, and how weak he is in his misery!”
vi: − My dear! - Lucie nestled close to him, resting her head on his chest, looking up. - Please remember how happy we are while he is so miserable!
tr: Snuggling up to her husband, resting her head on his chest, and fixing her eyes on his, Lucie continued, "And there's this, my love! Don't forget that we draw strength from our happiness, while he becomes even weaker from the pain he endures!"
es: —Please me, my love! —exclaimed Lucía, letting her little head fall on her husband's chest and raising her eyes to him. —Reflect on how immense our happiness is, and how much he is to be pitied in his misery!

en: The supplication touched him home.
vi: Those earnest words moved Darnay.
tr: Charles was deeply affected by his wife's request.
es: The plea hit the mark.

en: “I will always remember it, dear Heart!
vi: − I will remember that forever, my love!
tr: "I will never forget this, my dear!
es: —I will never forget it, my little heart!

en: I will remember it as long as I live.”
vi: I will remember it for the rest of my life.
tr: I will remember it for the rest of my life."
es: I will remember it as long as I live!

en: He bent over the golden head, and put the rosy lips to his, and folded her in his arms.
vi: He bent down to her golden hair, kissed Lucie's rosy lips, and wrapped his arms around her.
tr: Charles leaned in towards her golden hair and planted a kiss on her rose lips, then hugged her tightly.
es: He leaned over that head adorned with rich golden attire, brought his lips close to Lucía's rose-like ones, and embraced her tightly.

en: If one forlorn wanderer then pacing the dark streets, could have heard her innocent disclosure, and could have seen the drops of pity kissed away by her husband from the soft blue eyes so loving of that husband, he might have cried to the night—and the words would not have parted from his lips for the first time—
vi: If some suffering wanderer were counting his steps through the night streets and heard her innocent confession, saw the tears of compassion welling up in her blue eyes, which her husband dried with kisses, he would surely cry out to the night for the first time - words that would never escape our lips: − God bless her for having compassion on me!
tr: If the wretched vagabond wandering the dark streets had seen her innocent words and the merciful tears flowing from her soft, loving blue eyes being wiped away by her husband's kisses, he would have cried all night – and once again these words would have escaped his lips:
es: If the nocturnal wanderer who at that moment walked absorbed through the lonely streets near the little corner of Soho, had been able to hear that plea dictated by the purest compassion, if he had been given to see some very clear pearls drunk by a loving husband in some blue and clean eyes like the sky, he would have exclaimed with rapture:

en: “God bless her for her sweet compassion!”
vi: If some suffering wanderer were counting his steps through the night streets and heard her innocent confession, saw the tears of compassion welling up in her blue eyes, which her husband dried with kisses, he would surely cry out to the night for the first time - words that would never escape our lips: − God bless her for having compassion on me!
tr: "God, protect that compassionate, beautiful heart!"
es: —May God bless her beautiful soul!

en: CHAPTER XXI.
vi: 21. Echoing footsteps
tr: 21st
es: XXI.

en: Echoing Footsteps
vi: 21. Echoing footsteps
tr: Echoing Footsteps
es: STEPS THAT RESONATE

en: A wonderful corner for echoes, it has been remarked, that corner where the Doctor lived.
vi: A strange corner of the street echoed with sounds, as mentioned in the previous part, the corner of the street had the house of the doctor.
tr: The corner where the Doctor lived was a corner that echoed perfectly.
es: The most admirable corner to gather the echoes was the one where Dr. Manette lived.

en: Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound her husband, and her father, and herself, and her old directress and companion, in a life of quiet bliss, Lucie sat in the still house in the tranquilly resounding corner, listening to the echoing footsteps of years.
vi: Always busy with the golden thread entwining her husband, her father, herself, and the old nanny who was also a companion, and a peaceful life, Lucie sat in the quiet house on that silent street corner full of echoes, listening to the footsteps of the years reverberating.
tr: Lucie sat in the tranquil house in the echoing corner, continuously winding the golden thread that silently and peacefully connected her husband, her father, herself, her old nanny, and her friend into a happy life, listening to the echoing footsteps of the years.
es: Lucía, always engaged in the pleasant task of twisting the golden thread that connected her to her husband, her father, herself, and her former director and companion, savored a life of uninterrupted happiness in that peaceful center of tranquility, listening to the echo of the footsteps of time.

en: At first, there were times, though she was a perfectly happy young wife, when her work would slowly fall from her hands, and her eyes would be dimmed.
vi: At first, even though she was a young wife full of happiness, there were moments when she let go of her work, her eyes tinged with sadness.
tr: Although she was an extremely happy young wife at first, there were times when she felt the work slipping away from her and her eyes grew dull.
es: Sometimes, especially at the beginning, even when she considered herself completely happy, her hands would drop the golden thread she was twisting onto her knees, and the pure blue of her eyes would cloud over: it was because among the echoes that resonated far in the distance, she thought she perceived something very light, very subtle, barely perceptible yet, and which, nevertheless, caused her a certain feeling of unease.

en: For, there was something coming in the echoes, something light, afar off, and scarcely audible yet, that stirred her heart too much.
vi: Because in those echoes, she felt something would come, something faint, distant, and vague that made her heart restless.
tr: There was something coming towards her with echoes, something vague, from afar, barely audible, but enough to make her heart race.
es: Sometimes, especially at the beginning, even when she considered herself completely happy, her hands would drop the golden thread she was twisting onto her knees, and the pure blue of her eyes would cloud over: it was because among the echoes that resonated far in the distance, she thought she perceived something very light, very subtle, barely perceptible yet, and which, nevertheless, caused her a certain feeling of unease.

en: Fluttering hopes and doubts—hopes, of a love as yet unknown to her: doubts, of her remaining upon earth, to enjoy that new delight—divided her breast.
vi: Her heart wavered between hope and doubt - the hope of a new and strange love; the doubt of not knowing how much longer she would remain in this world to enjoy that love.
tr: Hopes and doubts fluttered inside her – hopes of a love she had not yet known, and doubts that she would not be able to savor this new delight in the remaining days – always constricting her chest.
es: Then, her heart would be equally filled with soothing hopes and tormenting doubts: hopes of knowing a love she did not yet know and fears of not living long enough to savor the purest joys of that love.

en: Among the echoes then, there would arise the sound of footsteps at her own early grave; and thoughts of the husband who would be left so desolate, and who would mourn for her so much, swelled to her eyes, and broke like waves.
vi: Amidst those echoes, there were moments when the sound of her early footsteps descending into the grave resounded; and thinking of the husband left alone mourning his wife, she could not hold back the tears streaming down.
tr: Amidst the echoing sounds, she could hear the footsteps rising at her grave; then, when she thought of her devastated husband and how he would mourn for her, tears flowed like a flood.
es: Among the echoes that on those occasions struck her ears, were the sounds of her own footsteps walking towards the grave; and thinking of the loneliness in which she would leave her husband, of the sharp pain her death would cause him, tears would come to her eyes and overflow down her cheeks.

en: That time passed, and her little Lucie lay on her bosom.
vi: Time passed, and now she had little Lucie in her arms.
tr: Time passed and her little daughter Lucie was born.
es: Those times have passed.

en: Then, among the advancing echoes, there was the tread of her tiny feet and the sound of her prattling words.
vi: Then, amidst the echoes approaching, there were the tiny footsteps and the babbling of a child.
tr: Then, among these approaching echoes, her daughter's tiny steps and chirping sounds mingled.
es: In her arms now played an angel, named Lucía, like her; and then, dominating all the echoes of the advancing steps, always stood out those of tiny little feet mixed with silver sounds emitted by a tongue that begins to babble.

en: Let greater echoes resound as they would, the young mother at the cradle side could always hear those coming.
vi: Despite the loud reverberations, the young mother by the cradle only heard those waves of happiness.
tr: Yet, the young mother beside the cradle always heard the approaching great echoes.
es: The world could be deafened by the most thunderous echoes: the young mother, sitting by the cradle, only heard the soothing music of her little daughter's half-formed words.

en: They came, and the shady house was sunny with a child’s laugh, and the Divine friend of children, to whom in her trouble she had confided hers, seemed to take her child in his arms, as He took the child of old, and made it a sacred joy to her.
vi: Then the awaited echoes arrived, and this cool, shaded house was filled with the laughter of children; and God, the friend of children, the supreme being to whom she had entrusted her worries, seemed to have embraced her child - just as He had welcomed the Holy Infant - and transformed it into a divine joy for the young mother.
tr: As the sounds continued to approach, the dim house was illuminated with the child's laughter, and in the young mother's troubled days, the divine friend of children seemed to have taken her baby into its arms and made her a source of sacred joy.
es: The divine friend of children, to whom all mothers usually entrust the care of their children, had taken Lucía's child in his arms and turned him into an inexhaustible source of joy for her!

en: Ever busily winding the golden thread that bound them all together, weaving the service of her happy influence through the tissue of all their lives, and making it predominate nowhere, Lucie heard in the echoes of years none but friendly and soothing sounds.
vi: Always busy with the golden thread that binds everyone together, weaving her efforts to build happiness into their lives without revealing herself, Lucie hears in the echoes of time the tender, comforting reverberations.
tr: The golden thread that tirelessly connected them all was weaving Lucie's happiness into the lives of others, prioritizing it above everything else, so that Lucie heard warm and comforting sounds in the echoes of the years.
es: Lucía was always busy twisting the golden thread that bound the happy members of that family, always contributing to the fabric of everyone's lives with the weave of her beneficial influence, while carefully avoiding letting it dominate; in the echoes of the footsteps of the years, she heard nothing but friendly steps.

en: Her husband’s step was strong and prosperous among them; her father’s firm and equal.
vi: Among them are the echoes of her husband's steady and successful footsteps, and her father's stable and healthy steps.
tr: Among these, her husband's footsteps were strong and intense; her father's were steady and calm.
es: Among them, her husband's steps stood out for being strong and prosperous; her father's were firm and always the same, and Miss Pross's were impetuous and violent, an echo that awakened a thousand echoes, similar to the harsh neighing and stamping of a horse being punished.

en: Lo, Miss Pross, in harness of string, awakening the echoes, as an unruly charger, whip-corrected, snorting and pawing the earth under the plane-tree in the garden!
vi: There, under the lime tree in the garden, Miss Pross, like an untamed warhorse that has been bridled and tamed with a whip, is snorting, stamping, and stirring up other echoes!
tr: As for Miss Pross, she amplified the echoes like an unruly cavalry horse in its harness, snorting through her nose and pawing the ground under the plane tree in the garden when whipped!
es: Among them, her husband's steps stood out for being strong and prosperous; her father's were firm and always the same, and Miss Pross's were impetuous and violent, an echo that awakened a thousand echoes, similar to the harsh neighing and stamping of a horse being punished.

en: Even when there were sounds of sorrow among the rest, they were not harsh nor cruel.
vi: Even when sorrowful echoes resound, those reverberations are neither cruel nor harsh.
tr: Even in times of sorrowful voices, they were neither hurtful nor rude.
es: Not even on the rare occasions when echoes of joy were mixed with echoes of pain, was the latter cruel or lacerating.

en: Even when golden hair, like her own, lay in a halo on a pillow round the worn face of a little boy, and he said, with a radiant smile, “Dear papa and mamma, I am very sorry to leave you both, and to leave my pretty sister; but I am called, and I must go!” those were not tears all of agony that wetted his young mother’s cheek, as the spirit departed from her embrace that had been entrusted to it.
vi: Even when the golden hair like Lucie's, glowing with a halo around the head of the son lying on the pillow about to depart, and the boy says with a radiant smile, "Papa and maman, I am very sorry to leave you and my pretty sister; but God has called and I must go!" the tears wetting the mother's cheeks are not of utmost despair as the little soul leaves the arms entrusted by God.
tr: When the weary face of a little boy with golden hair similar to Lucie's was surrounded by a halo of light on the pillow, and with a radiant smile on his face, he said, "Dear mother and father, I am very sad to leave you and my sweet sister; but they are calling me, I must go!" even then, the tears wetting his young mother's cheeks were not tears of pain, but the soul entrusted to her had been taken away.
es: When on the pillow of a little bed fell in disarray the curls of a blonde hair, similar to Lucia's, framing the emaciated and transparent face of a child, who, smiling sweetly, said: "I am very sorry to leave my daddy and my mommy; I am also very sorry to part from my dear little sister; but they are calling me from above and I must answer the call," the tears that flooded the mother's cheeks were not tears of agony; for the fact that an angel leaves the covering that served as its dress should not tear them from her eyes.

en: Suffer them and forbid them not.
vi: Painful but accepting.
tr: Feel sorrow for him but do not hinder him.
es: When on the pillow of a little bed fell in disarray the curls of a blonde hair, similar to Lucia's, framing the emaciated and transparent face of a child, who, smiling sweetly, said: "I am very sorry to leave my daddy and my mommy; I am also very sorry to part from my dear little sister; but they are calling me from above and I must answer the call," the tears that flooded the mother's cheeks were not tears of agony; for the fact that an angel leaves the covering that served as its dress should not tear them from her eyes.

en: They see my Father’s face.
vi: They will meet again before God.
tr: He will meet God.
es: When on the pillow of a little bed fell in disarray the curls of a blonde hair, similar to Lucia's, framing the emaciated and transparent face of a child, who, smiling sweetly, said: "I am very sorry to leave my daddy and my mommy; I am also very sorry to part from my dear little sister; but they are calling me from above and I must answer the call," the tears that flooded the mother's cheeks were not tears of agony; for the fact that an angel leaves the covering that served as its dress should not tear them from her eyes.

en: O Father, blessed words!
vi: Oh, hallowed be Thy name!
tr: God bless him!
es: To the gentle fluttering of an angel's wings were joined the echoes born on earth, resulting in a murmur that was not entirely earthly, as it was animated by a breath from the heavens.

en: Thus, the rustling of an Angel’s wings got blended with the other echoes, and they were not wholly of earth, but had in them that breath of Heaven.
vi: Thus, the rustling of Angel wings blends with other echoes, reverberations not entirely earthly but imbued with the breath of Heaven.
tr: Thus, to the other echoes was added the fluttering of an angel's wings, and these were not earthly echoes, but ones that carried the breath of heaven.
es: To the gentle fluttering of an angel's wings were joined the echoes born on earth, resulting in a murmur that was not entirely earthly, as it was animated by a breath from the heavens.

en: Sighs of the winds that blew over a little garden-tomb were mingled with them also, and both were audible to Lucie, in a hushed murmur—like the breathing of a summer sea asleep upon a sandy shore—as the little Lucie, comically studious at the task of the morning, or dressing a doll at her mother’s footstool, chattered in the tongues of the Two Cities that were blended in her life.
vi: Whispering softly in the mother's ear, the sigh of the wind blowing over the small grave in the garden also carries the sound of little Lucie diligently and amusingly doing her morning duties, or dressing her doll on her mother's footstool, chattering in the language of both cities that are her homelands.
tr: Then the sighs of the winds blowing over the small grave in the garden joined them, and both came to Lucie's ear with a calm murmur, like the breeze of the sea that had fallen asleep on a beach in summer – meanwhile, little Lucie would be eagerly engaging in her morning activities or dressing her doll while chattering away in the language of the Two Cities that had intertwined with her life, at her mother's knee.
es: Also mingled with those faint sighs of the wind that kiss the flowers of the cemetery were sighs that Lucía's ear picked up, believing they were the breathing of a summer sea that sleeps upon a flat sandy beach while her little daughter, studying with comical seriousness the lessons of the morning, or engrossed in the task of dressing her dolls, chatted, mixing words from the two cities that had combined in her life.

en: The Echoes rarely answered to the actual tread of Sydney Carton.
vi: Those echoes rarely reflected the true footsteps of Sydney Carton.
tr: The echoes rarely responded to the footsteps of Sydney Carton.
es: Very rarely did the echoes respond to the real steps of Sydney Carton.

en: Some half-dozen times a year, at most, he claimed his privilege of coming in uninvited, and would sit among them through the evening, as he had once done often.
vi: About six times a year at most, he exercised the privilege of visiting this house without prior invitation, often spending the entire evening with everyone as he used to.
tr: Carton exercised his right to visit uninvited at most five or six times a year, and as he once frequently did, he would spend the entire evening with them.
es: Half a dozen times a year, at most, he exercised his privilege of showing up at the doctor's house uninvited and taking part in the evening gathering as he had so often done in the past.

en: He never came there heated with wine.
vi: He never came when he reeked of alcohol.
tr: He never went there while intoxicated.
es: He never showed up drunk or even half-drunk.

en: And one other thing regarding him was whispered in the echoes, which has been whispered by all true echoes for ages and ages.
vi: And there was another thing related to Carton that silently echoed, something that, through many generations, every true reverberation quietly continued.
tr: There was one more thing whispered about Carton among the echoes, and this had been whispered by all honest echoes for years.
es: But if the echoes of his steps rarely sounded in the little corner of Soho, it was very common to hear the brief and beautiful story that they whispered about him.

en: No man ever really loved a woman, lost her, and knew her with a blameless though an unchanged mind, when she was a wife and a mother, but her children had a strange sympathy with him—an instinctive delicacy of pity for him.
vi: A man who truly loves a woman, even if his love is unrequited but remains devoted without resentment, will always hold a special place in the hearts of her children when she becomes a wife and mother - a subtle compassion instinctively reserved for him.
tr: No man could love a woman this much, and even if he lost her, he couldn't remain so innocently and stubbornly attached to her, knowing that she was now a wife and mother, to the extent that even Lucie's children felt a strange sympathy for Carton – perhaps they pitied him with an instinctive sensitivity.
es: There has never existed a man madly in love with a woman, who has seen and treated her with pure eyes and immaculate thought after she has become a wife and mother. As if her tender little children understood her silent pain, they showed him a singular sympathy... something like a delicate instinct of compassion towards him.

en: What fine hidden sensibilities are touched in such a case, no echoes tell; but it is so, and it was so here.
vi: What hidden emotions resonate in such situations? There is no echo to reveal these occurrences, and it is the same for Carton.
tr: No echo could tell what secret emotions created this; but it was so, it was very obvious.
es: The echoes do not speak when these sensitivities, which have their seat in the deepest recesses of the soul, vibrate, but although silent, they whisper.

en: Carton was the first stranger to whom little Lucie held out her chubby arms, and he kept his place with her as she grew.
vi: He was the first stranger to whom little Lucie extended her chubby hands, and he held a place in her life.
tr: The first stranger to whom little Lucie extended her chubby arms was Carton, and he was always by her side as she grew up.
es: Carton was the first stranger to the house to whom little Lucía extended her chubby arms, and the child, moments before taking his flight to heaven, exclaimed: "Poor Carton!

en: The little boy had spoken of him, almost at the last.
vi: Even the little boy who passed away near the end still said, "Poor Carton!
tr: Even the little boy, while taking his last breath, was murmuring his name.
es: Carton was the first stranger to the house to whom little Lucía extended her chubby arms, and the child, moments before taking his flight to heaven, exclaimed: "Poor Carton!

en: “Poor Carton!
vi: Even the little boy who passed away near the end still said, "Poor Carton!
tr: "Poor Carton!
es: Carton was the first stranger to the house to whom little Lucía extended her chubby arms, and the child, moments before taking his flight to heaven, exclaimed: "Poor Carton!

en: Kiss him for me!”
vi: Kiss him for me!".
tr: Kiss him for me!"
es: I wish they would give him a kiss for me!"

en: mr Stryver shouldered his way through the law, like some great engine forcing itself through turbid water, and dragged his useful friend in his wake, like a boat towed astern.
vi: Stryver continued to push aggressively in the legal field, like a large engine-driven ship cutting through murky waters, dragging his capable friend behind like a small boat.
tr: Mr. Stryver, like a large boat trying to make its way through muddy water, was forging ahead on the path of law, dragging his useful friend in his wake like a dinghy at the stern of the boat.
es: Stryver penetrated the domains of law each day with greater vigor, like a powerful ship plowing through turbulent seas, and in his wake, Carton could be seen like a barge being towed.

en: As the boat so favoured is usually in a rough plight, and mostly under water, so, Sydney had a swamped life of it.
vi: As boats being towed are often those that have met with severe misfortune and mostly end up sinking, Sydney kept sinking deeper into that life.
tr: These privileged dinghies generally encounter difficulties, often bobbing up and down in the water, and thus Sydney was living such a sunken life.
es: The barge thus favored by the ship that took it in tow faces serious dangers, generally navigates with difficulty, and is almost always waterlogged. Carton also navigated the seas of life, lurching and exposed to capsizing at any moment.

en: But, easy and strong custom, unhappily so much easier and stronger in him than any stimulating sense of desert or disgrace, made it the life he was to lead; and he no more thought of emerging from his state of lion’s jackal, than any real jackal may be supposed to think of rising to be a lion.
vi: But Sydney's weakness and deeply ingrained habits, unfortunately, were too weak and too deeply ingrained for him to have any consciousness of wanting to abandon or feel ashamed; he chose that way of life, no longer thinking of escaping the state of being a Jackal to a Lion - unlike the true wild dogs that might dream of becoming a mighty lion.
tr: The indifferent and powerful state within him, even if not pleased, was so much easier and stronger than any kind of unpleasantness and disgrace that Carton could not deviate from the path he was on, and never considered giving up being the jackal to the lion, whereas it was expected that all true jackals would hope to become lions one day.
es: However, a deeply ingrained and firm habit, more ingrained and firmer in his heart than any of the stimulants we commonly call the perception of abandonment of misfortune, indicated the course he should follow, and Carton followed it, without ever thinking of leaving the lamentable state he found himself in, without having more aspirations to renounce his role as a jackal to a lion than a flesh-and-blood jackal has ever had to elevate itself to the category of a lion.

en: Stryver was rich; had married a florid widow with property and three boys, who had nothing particularly shining about them but the straight hair of their dumpling heads.
vi: Stryver, already wealthy, married a flamboyant widow with assets and three children, three kids who had nothing particularly outstanding except for their straight hair on their round heads.
tr: Stryver, on the other hand, had become wealthy; he had married a vigorous widow with a lot of property and three sons, who had no brilliance other than the straight hair shining on their dull heads.
es: Stryver was rich. He had married a widow who owned magnificent properties and was the mother of three children, none of whom had been endowed by the hand of nature with exceptional gifts, although they were distinguished by the thick mass of bristly spines that adorned their heads.

en: These three young gentlemen, mr Stryver, exuding patronage of the most offensive quality from every pore, had walked before him like three sheep to the quiet corner in Soho, and had offered as pupils to Lucie’s husband: delicately saying “Halloa!
vi: From every pore exuded the most obnoxious air of superiority, Stryver had once made these three noble offspring walk before him like three sheep to the quiet corner of Soho, and he had proposed to Lucie's husband to take them as students. Stryver had said very delicately: "Hey friend!
tr: Mr. Stryver, in his most unpleasantly domineering manner, herded these three young gentlemen like sheep to the corner in Soho and, after handing them over to Lucie's husband as students, said, "Hello!
es: Stryver, exuding protection from every pore of his body, had presented these three little gentlemen in the peaceful house in Soho, and offered them as disciples to Lucie's husband. With unparalleled delicacy, said the brilliant lawyer when making the presentation:

en: here are three lumps of bread-and-cheese towards your matrimonial picnic, Darnay!”
vi: Here are three pieces of cheese bread I brought for your marriage adventure, Darnay!"
tr: Their flesh is yours, their bones are mine. If you want to use these three pieces of flesh while going on a family picnic, Darnay!"
es: —I have the pleasure of contributing these three pieces of bread to your wedding lunch, Darnay.

en: The polite rejection of the three lumps of bread-and-cheese had quite bloated mr Stryver with indignation, which he afterwards turned to account in the training of the young gentlemen, by directing them to beware of the pride of Beggars, like that tutor-fellow.
vi: The fact that these three pieces of cheese bread were politely refused made Stryver unbearably angry, but later it became a useful lesson for him to teach the three noble offspring to beware of the pride of beggars, just like that fellow countryman tutor.
tr: The polite refusal of this offer of three pieces of flesh drove Mr. Stryver mad, and he decided to educate the young gentlemen himself. He first advised them to steer clear of the arrogance of Beggars, like this private tutor.
es: With very courteous words, Darnay declined those three pieces of bread, raising such a tempest of indignation in Stryver's noble chest, that from then on he made a special effort to ensure that in the souls of the little gentlemen in question, the idea of treating beggars like that famished teacher, whose only patrimony was pride, would be born and deeply rooted with the utmost disdain.

en: He was also in the habit of declaiming to ms Stryver, over his full-bodied wine, on the arts ms Darnay had once put in practice to “catch” him, and on the diamond-cut-diamond arts in himself, madam, which had rendered him “not to be caught.”
vi: When his belly was full of wine, Stryver would also passionately talk about Lucie, about the tricks she used to "trap" him, and about his own counter-tricks to "not get caught in the trap."
tr: On nights when he drank too much, he would sit across from Mr. Stryver and loudly recount the traps Ms. Darnay had set to "catch" him and the magnificent tactics he had used to avoid being "caught."
es: He also had the good habit of enumerating and explaining to his wife the arts that Lucie Manette once used to "catch" him, and the diamond wall he opposed to her artifices, thanks to which he was an "uncatchable" fish for that fisherwoman.

en: Some of his King’s Bench familiars, who were occasionally parties to the full-bodied wine and the lie, excused him for the latter by saying that he had told it so often, that he believed it himself—which is surely such an incorrigible aggravation of an originally bad offence, as to justify any such offender’s being carried off to some suitably retired spot, and there hanged out of the way.
vi: Stryver's colleagues at the Supreme Court would occasionally gather to drink their fill and listen to these tall tales, but no one believed them; they dismissed the fabrications because they thought Stryver repeated them so often that he himself came to believe them - anyone who said so and was heard by Stryver would only worsen their own fault beyond redemption, the only recourse being to drag the offender to some suitable secluded spot and hang them for their crime.
tr: His colleagues from the bar who attended these boozy and boastful gatherings would tolerate him, noting that Stryver had begun to believe his own lies – it was such an incorrigible situation that everyone avoided him as much as possible.
es: Some of his colleagues, who used to be his companions in his bacchanalian excesses, excused him by saying that he had repeated the lie in question so many times that he himself already believed it as a matter of faith... which, far from excusing an offense, aggravates it enough to justify the offended party taking the offender to a secluded and convenient place, and nicely and without annoying procedures, leaving him hanging from any tree with a noose.

en: These were among the echoes to which Lucie, sometimes pensive, sometimes amused and laughing, listened in the echoing corner, until her little daughter was six years old.
vi: Those were the echoes that Lucie, sometimes sad, sometimes joyful, had heard at the corner of this resonant street until her little daughter turned six years old.
tr: All these were among the echoes that Lucie sometimes listened to thoughtfully, sometimes with cheerful laughter, in her corner until her little girl turned six.
es: Such were, among others, the echoes that Lucía, sometimes pensive and other times amused and even laughing out loud, heard from the peaceful corner of Soho. The girl turned six years old.

en: How near to her heart the echoes of her child’s tread came, and those of her own dear father’s, always active and self-possessed, and those of her dear husband’s, need not be told.
vi: Oh, how affectionate were the echoes of the child's footsteps, along with the father's steps - always brisk and calm - and needless to say, the footsteps of the loving husband.
tr: There is no need to mention how the pitter-patter of her child's footsteps, the always lively and confident steps of her father, and the footsteps of her beloved husband warmed her heart.
es: The echoes of her steps along the paths of life resonated deep in her mother's heart, mingled with the equally delightful steps of the doctor, always calm and always active, and with those of her husband, always tender and always in love.

en: Nor, how the lightest echo of their united home, directed by herself with such a wise and elegant thrift that it was more abundant than any waste, was music to her.
vi: Needless to say, every gentle echo in this close-knit family, thanks to Lucie's skillful and clever management that made everything prosperous, was sweet music to her.
tr: Moreover, every little echo in their peaceful home, which Lucie managed with great delicacy and thrift, where nothing was wasted, sounded like a beautiful melody to the young woman's ears.
es: In Lucía's ears, the gentle echoes of that home, managed by herself, sounded like divine music, a home where opulence did not reign, but abundance did.

en: Nor, how there were echoes all about her, sweet in her ears, of the many times her father had told her that he found her more devoted to him married (if that could be) than single, and of the many times her husband had said to her that no cares and duties seemed to divide her love for him or her help to him, and asked her “What is the magic secret, my darling, of your being everything to all of us, as if there were only one of us, yet never seeming to be hurried, or to have too much to do?”
vi: Needless to say, how soothing were the echoes around Lucie when countless times Mr. Manette told her that her daughter, now married (if that was indeed the case), was even more devoted to her father than when she was single, and when countless times Darnay told her that it seemed his wife's filial piety did not diminish the love or support she gave to her husband, he asked her: "My dear, what magic is it that you manage everything so perfectly for everyone, as if the whole family were just one person, yet you never seem hurried or busy?"
tr: Especially when her father told her that he felt even more connected to her after she got married, and her husband said that none of her attentions and duties diminished her love and support for him, and asked her, "How do you manage to be everything to all of us? You attend to all our needs but never seem rushed or act as if you have too much to do?" these words sweetly echoed in Lucie's ears.
es: The echoes of what her father so often said, namely, that he found her more affectionate, if possible, married than when she was single, also sounded with exquisite sweetness.

en: But, there were other echoes, from a distance, that rumbled menacingly in the corner all through this space of time.
vi: But there were other echoes from afar that had been roaring and threatening this corner during that time.
tr: But all this time, there were also voices echoing in the distance and rumbling menacingly in the corner.
es: Other echoes were also sounding, in the distance, yes, but not so far as to be unheard, echoes that roared menacingly over the quiet corner.

en: And it was now, about little Lucie’s sixth birthday, that they began to have an awful sound, as of a great storm in France with a dreadful sea rising.
vi: Now, as little Lucie turned six years old, those echoes began to rumble terrifyingly like the horrifying stormy seas echoing from France.
tr: During these days when little Lucie's birthday was being celebrated, these voices began to emerge terribly, as if a great storm had broken out in France and the seas had risen tremendously.
es: It was around the date of Lucita's sixth birthday when its thunderous voice rose to the clouds, a voice like a terrible storm unleashed in France.

en: On a night in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine, mr Lorry came in late, from Tellson’s, and sat himself down by Lucie and her husband in the dark window.
vi: On a mid-July evening in 1789, Mr. Lorry from Tellson's Bank came by late and sat down next to Lucie and her husband by the dark window.
tr: One night in mid-July of the year 1789, Mr. Lorry came from Tellson's late and sat down beside Lucie and her husband in front of the dark window.
es: One night in the month of July in the year seventeen eighty-nine, Lorry appeared and took a seat by the window between Lucía and her husband.

en: It was a hot, wild night, and they were all three reminded of the old Sunday night when they had looked at the lightning from the same place.
vi: That night was sultry and thunderous, and all three remembered a past Sunday night when they also sat here watching the lightning tear through the sky.
tr: It was a hot and sultry night, and all three of them remembered that past Sunday night when they had watched the lightning strike in the same place.
es: It was a stormy night with a scorching breath that reminded the three of that other night when they were watching the lightning from that same window.

en: “I began to think,” said mr Lorry, pushing his brown wig back, “that I should have to pass the night at Tellson’s.
vi: Mr. Lorry said while pushing back his brown wig: − I'm starting to think about having to stay the night at Tellson's.
tr: "I suppose," said Mr. Lorry, pushing his brown wig back, "I will have to spend the night at Tellson's.
es: —I am beginning to think—said Lorry, pushing his wig back to his nape—that I must have spent the whole night at the Bank.

en: We have been so full of business all day, that we have not known what to do first, or which way to turn.
vi: The work there is so overwhelming that no one knows what to do first or how to manage.
tr: We had so much work all day that we didn't know where to start or how to do it.
es: Today, such an unbridled storm of business has rained down upon us that we haven't known where to start or where to finish.

en: There is such an uneasiness in Paris, that we have actually a run of confidence upon us!
vi: There is such great unrest in Paris that people are rushing to deposit their money in this bank!
tr: Paris is in a tremendous state of unrest, and all the clients are flocking to us!
es: Distrust is spreading in Paris to such an extent that confidence is coming to us like a rushing torrent.

en: Our customers over there, seem not to be able to confide their property to us fast enough.
vi: Clients over there are entrusting their assets to Tellson's so overwhelmingly that it can't keep up.
tr: Our clients there are bewildered about how to transfer their assets to us.
es: Our clients there can't wait to entrust us with their goods and properties. Nothing, nothing!

en: There is positively a mania among some of them for sending it to England.”
vi: Clearly, many of them have gone mad in their desire to transfer their wealth to England.
tr: Some of them are struggling like mad to send them to England."
es: It's a true mania of sending everything to England that has suddenly seized them!

en: “That has a bad look,” said Darnay—
vi: − That's concerning - Darnay said.
tr: "This is not at all pleasant," said Darnay.
es: —What in my opinion is a very bad sign—observed Darnay.

en: “A bad look, you say, my dear Darnay?
vi: − You said it's concerning, didn't you, Darnay?
tr: "Isn't it quite unpleasant, dear Darnay?"
es: —A bad sign, my dear Darnay?

en: Yes, but we don’t know what reason there is in it.
vi: That's right, but I don't know why.
tr: "Yes, but we don't know the reason for it."
es: Perhaps, if it obeyed justified reasons; but the world is so irrational!

en: People are so unreasonable!
vi: People are really unreasonable!
tr: "People are acting irrationally!" "Some of the people at Tellson's have aged like me, so we can't just change the bank's operations for no reason.""
es: Perhaps, if it obeyed justified reasons; but the world is so irrational!

en: Some of us at Tellson’s are getting old, and we really can’t be troubled out of the ordinary course without due occasion.”
vi: Many of us at Tellson are already old, and we truly cannot be bothered with unusual matters without a valid reason.
tr: "People are acting irrationally!" "Some of the people at Tellson's have aged like me, so we can't just change the bank's operations for no reason.""
es: The only positive thing so far is that they are overwhelming us with work, surely without reason, without consideration that at Tellson's Bank there are many of us who are already old.

en: “Still,” said Darnay, “you know how gloomy and threatening the sky is.”
vi: − Anyway, you know the situation is worryingly unstable, Darnay said.
tr: "That's true," said Darnay, "you can see how gloomy and dark the weather is."
es: —However—objected Darnay,—you know perfectly well that there is a closure on the horizon, that the clouds have been condensing for a long time, threatening a storm.

en: “I know that, to be sure,” assented mr Lorry, trying to persuade himself that his sweet temper was soured, and that he grumbled, “but I am determined to be peevish after my long day’s botheration.
vi: − Certainly, - Mr. Lorry agreed, trying to convince himself that he was just in a bad mood and merely complaining to get it off his chest. - But after a long troublesome day, I'm irritated and want to grumble.
tr: "Of course I see," Mr. Lorry immediately conceded, trying to convince himself that he was no longer in his usual calm state and was complaining. "But after such a terrible and long day, I'm also quite annoyed now.
es: —I know... of course I know—replied Lorry, trying to persuade himself of the need to appear a little grumpy and discontented;—so much so, that I come resolved to quarrel with anyone to make up for the fatigues of this devilish day.

en: Where is Manette?”
vi: Where is Mr. Manette? −
tr: Where is Manette?"
es: Where is Manette?

en: “Here he is,” said the Doctor, entering the dark room at the moment.
vi: Here I am, - said the doctor, entering the dark living room at that very moment.
tr: At that moment, the Doctor who entered the dark room called out, "I'm here."
es: —Here is a piece—replied the doctor, entering the room at that moment.

en: “I am quite glad you are at home; for these hurries and forebodings by which I have been surrounded all day long, have made me nervous without reason.
vi: − I'm so glad you're home; because all these urgent and worrying matters have been surrounding me all day, causing me to lose my temper unreasonably.
tr: "I am very glad that you are home; because my nerves have been unnecessarily frayed all day by the hustle and premonitions surrounding me.
es: —I'm glad you're home, as today's rush and premonitions have made me nervous for no reason or cause.

en: You are not going out, I hope?”
vi: You didn't go out for a walk, did you? −
tr: I hope you are not going out."
es: I suppose you don't plan on going out, do you?

en: “No; I am going to play backgammon with you, if you like,” said the Doctor.
vi: No, I was planning to play chess with you, if you like, - the doctor said.
tr: "No; if you want, we can play backgammon together," said the Doctor.
es: —No; if you want, we can play a game of backgammon.

en: “I don’t think I do like, if I may speak my mind.
vi: − I think I don't like it, to be honest.
tr: "To tell the truth, I don't really want to, I guess.
es: —I prefer not to play, as tonight I am not in the mood to contend with you.

en: I am not fit to be pitted against you to-night.
vi: I can't compete with you tonight.
tr: I don't have the strength to argue with you tonight.
es: —I prefer not to play, as tonight I am not in the mood to contend with you.

en: Is the teaboard still there, Lucie?
vi: Is there any tea left, Lucie?
tr: Is the tea tray still here, Lucie?
es: Is the board here, Lucía?

en: I can’t see.”
vi: I can't see any.
tr: I couldn't see it."
es: You have this room in darkness and, since I am not a cat, I see nothing.

en: “Of course, it has been kept for you.”
vi: − Of course there is, I have saved it for you.
tr: "Of course, I waited for you.""
es: —Here it is, waiting for you.

en: “Thank ye, my dear.
vi: − Thank you, my dear.
tr: "Thank you, my dear.
es: —Thank you very much, dear.

en: The precious child is safe in bed?”
vi: And has my little darling already gone to bed with a warm and cozy mattress? −
tr: Did the sweet girl go to bed?"
es: Is the precious one in her little bed?

en: “And sleeping soundly.”
vi: And she is sleeping soundly.
tr: "Yes, sleeping soundly.""
es: —Sleeping like a log.

en: “That’s right; all safe and well!
vi: − That's good; everything is peaceful!
tr: "I'm fine, everything is alright!
es: —Very well... very well!

en: I don’t know why anything should be otherwise than safe and well here, thank God; but I have been so put out all day, and I am not as young as I was!
vi: I see no reason why this place wouldn't be peaceful, thank God; but I'm exhausted from today, I don't have the energy I used to when I was young!
tr: Although, thank God, everything is always alright here of course; but today my nerves are very frayed, well, I'm not as young as I used to be anymore!
es: The truth is that I don't know why everything shouldn't go very well here... thank God! But of course: they have worn me out so much today... And then, I'm not as young as you all are... as I was thirty years ago...!

en: My tea, my dear!
vi: Here's the tea, you're so considerate!
tr: Oh, is that my tea, dear!
es: My little cup of tea... That's right, Lucía...

en: Thank ye.
vi: Thank you.
tr: Thank you.
es: Thank you!

en: Now, come and take your place in the circle, and let us sit quiet, and hear the echoes about which you have your theory.”
vi: Now, come sit around this table with us, let's sit quietly and listen to the echoes that you have hypothesized about.
tr: Now you come join us too, and let's all sit quietly together and listen to those echoes you've been creating various theories about."
es: Now, make some room for me, I will sit in the circle, and I will try to listen to those echoes about which you have very peculiar theories.

en: “Not a theory; it was a fancy.”
vi: − Hypothesis? It's just imagination.
tr: "It wasn't actually a theory; just an idea."
es: —They are not theories, but whims of my imagination.

en: “A fancy, then, my wise pet,” said mr Lorry, patting her hand.
vi: − Just imagine, my dear, - Mr. Lorry said while gently patting Lucie's hand. -
tr: "Well, let it be a thought then, my clever girl," said Mr. Lorry, gently tapping Lucie's hand with affection.
es: —Perfectly, dear; we will call them whims—replied Lorry.

en: “They are very numerous and very loud, though, are they not?
vi: These echoes are many and very loud, aren't they?
tr: "How loud and high their voices are, aren't they?
es: They are numerous, varied, and thunderous, aren't they?

en: Only hear them!”
vi: Just listen and you'll see!
tr: Just listen!"
es: Of course! You just have to pay attention!

en: Headlong, mad, and dangerous footsteps to force their way into anybody’s life, footsteps not easily made clean again if once stained red, the footsteps raging in Saint Antoine afar off, as the little circle sat in the dark London window.
vi: Footsteps rushing in, frenzied, dangerous, invading anyone's life, footsteps not easily washed clean once stained with blood, the furious footsteps in distant Saint Antoine, while everyone sits around the dark window in London.
tr: As this small community sat in front of a dark window in London, hurried, frantic, and dangerous steps advanced with great determination as if they would destroy anything in their path, and once these steps approaching from beyond St. Antoine were stained with madness and fury, they could not be easily cleansed.
es: Hurried steps, hard steps, dangerous steps that violently penetrate someone's vital center, and once they have been stained red, they are difficult to clean, echoed in the distance, in the San Antonio neighborhood of Paris, and their resounding echoes reached the quiet corner of Soho in London.

en: Saint Antoine had been, that morning, a vast dusky mass of scarecrows heaving to and fro, with frequent gleams of light above the billowy heads, where steel blades and bayonets shone in the sun.
vi: That same morning in Saint Antoine, a forest of ragged, dark-skinned people, resembling scarecrows, was bustling and overflowing. The sunlight glinted off this wave of heads, reflecting the steel gleam of bayonets and swords.
tr: That morning, St. Antoine was like a vast and dark sea of railings swaying back and forth, and the light of steel swords and bayonets glistening under the sun occasionally struck the tops of the heads moving up and down.
es: That morning, San Antonio had been a field covered by a vast and stern mass of shirtless people who moved impatiently, adorned with steel sabers and bayonets on whose cold surfaces the sun's rays broke.

en: A tremendous roar arose from the throat of Saint Antoine, and a forest of naked arms struggled in the air like shrivelled branches of trees in a winter wind: all the fingers convulsively clutching at every weapon or semblance of a weapon that was thrown up from the depths below, no matter how far off.
vi: A terrifying roar erupted from the throat of Saint Antoine, and a sea of bare arms rose to the sky, looking like withered branches in the winter wind, with every finger fiercely gripping any weapon or anything that could be used as a weapon, scavenged from every possible depth.
tr: Then a tremendous roar rose from the narrow passage of St. Antoine; a forest of bare arms, like tree branches dried by winter winds, were raised to the sky. All fingers, no matter how far they had been thrown from, were striving to grab whatever weapon or weapon-like object was hurled at them.
es: The jaws of San Antonio let out tremendous screams while an immense forest of bare arms waved in the air, resembling branches of trees whipped by a terrible gale. There was no hand that did not wield some weapon or semblance of a weapon; there was no window that did not throw instruments of slaughter to the mobs.

en: Who gave them out, whence they last came, where they began, through what agency they crookedly quivered and jerked, scores at a time, over the heads of the crowd, like a kind of lightning, no eye in the throng could have told; but, muskets were being distributed—so were cartridges, powder, and ball, bars of iron and wood, knives, axes, pikes, every weapon that distracted ingenuity could discover or devise.
vi: Who distributed the weapons, where they came from, through which intermediaries, no one in that sea of people knew; they only saw the weapons, batch after batch of twenty, being thrown out and then suddenly raised above the crowd like lightning; not only muskets - there were also ammunition, gunpowder, lead bullets, iron bars, wooden sticks, knives, axes, pickaxes, every kind of weapon that a frenzied mind could find or create.
tr: Who was giving these weapons, where were they coming from, how had everything started, how had all these crooked and trembling weapons, standing like a lightning bolt above the crowd, reached them, there was no one among them who could answer these questions; on the other hand, rifles were being distributed continuously – and of course cartridges, gunpowder, cannonballs, iron rods, clubs, knives, axes, spears, and every kind of weapon imaginable and useful were being passed from hand to hand.
es: Where they came from, who provided them, where the rain of those elements of destruction that crossed over their heads like brilliant rays began, no one could have said; but it is certain that invisible hands distributed muskets, cartridges, gunpowder, bullets, iron bars, wooden beams, knives, axes, spears, pikes.

en: People who could lay hold of nothing else, set themselves with bleeding hands to force stones and bricks out of their places in walls.
vi: Those who couldn't grab anything to use as a weapon used their bleeding hands to pry bricks from the walls.
tr: Those who were not closing anything were busy tearing stones and bricks from the walls with bloody hands.
es: Those who could not procure anything else, drove their bloodied fingers into the joints of the stones or bricks and tore blocks or cobblestones from the walls.

en: Every pulse and heart in Saint Antoine was on high-fever strain and at high-fever heat.
vi: Every pulse and heartbeat in Saint Antoine was throbbing, burning hot.
tr: Every heart and pulse in St. Antoine was beating wildly.
es: There was no pulse in San Antonio that did not beat erratically, no heart that did not crave blood, no living being that valued life in any way, nor any person who did not cry out to sacrifice it.

en: Every living creature there held life as of no account, and was demented with a passionate readiness to sacrifice it.
vi: Everyone here considered their lives as nothing and were madly ready to sacrifice them.
tr: Every living being there was disregarding their life, madly eager to sacrifice themselves with ambitious impatience.
es: There was no pulse in San Antonio that did not beat erratically, no heart that did not crave blood, no living being that valued life in any way, nor any person who did not cry out to sacrifice it.

en: As a whirlpool of boiling waters has a centre point, so, all this raging circled round Defarge’s wine-shop, and every human drop in the caldron had a tendency to be sucked towards the vortex where Defarge himself, already begrimed with gunpowder and sweat, issued orders, issued arms, thrust this man back, dragged this man forward, disarmed one to arm another, laboured and strove in the thickest of the uproar.
vi: Just as all boiling, swirling waters are drawn towards the center, all the fierce upheavals here revolve around Defarge's tavern, and every person immersed in this cauldron of fire is pulled into the most furious vortex, where Defarge himself, smeared with sweat and gunpowder, is strenuously issuing orders, distributing weapons, shoving one person back, pushing another forward, and taking guns from some to give to others.
tr: Just as every boiling whirlpool has a center, the center of this frothing crowd was Defarge's wine shop, and every drop boiling in the cauldron was eager to be drawn into the vortex where Defarge was already steeped in gunpowder and sweat, issuing commands, distributing weapons, pushing one person and pulling another, taking a weapon from one and giving it to another, and toiling amidst all this intense chaos.
es: Just as all whirlpools of boiling waters have their central point, so that choppy sea roared around Defarge's tavern, all the human drops falling into the cauldron showed a determined tendency to approach the vortex where Defarge himself, already blackened by gunpowder and sweat, dictated orders, handed out weapons, forced this man to retreat and dragged that one towards him, disarmed one to arm another with his weapons, and worked and moved and multiplied in the center of the storm.

en: “Keep near to me, Jacques Three,” cried Defarge; “and do you, Jacques One and Two, separate and put yourselves at the head of as many of these patriots as you can.
vi: − Stand close to me, Jacques Three, - Defarge shouted, - and you, Jacques One and Two, split up and lead those patriots over there, as many as possible.
tr: "Stand close to me, Jacques Three," shouted Defarge; "and you, Jacques One and Jacques Two, go immediately and take command of as many patriots as you can.
es: —Don't leave my side, Santiago Tercero! —roared Defarge.—You, Santiago Primero and Santiago Segundo, lead other groups of patriots!

en: Where is my wife?”
vi: Have you seen my wife? −
tr: Where is my wife?"
es: Where is my wife?

en: “Eh, well!
vi: Here I am! Here I am!
tr: "Well, here I am!" said the madam with her usual calmness, but today she wasn't knitting.
es: —Here I am!

en: Here you see me!” said madame, composed as ever, but not knitting to-day.
vi: - her voice was as calm as ever, but today she was not knitting.
tr: "Well, here I am!" said the madam with her usual calmness, but today she wasn't knitting.
es: —replied Madame Defarge, as composed as ever, but without knitting.

en: Madame’s resolute right hand was occupied with an axe, in place of the usual softer implements, and in her girdle were a pistol and a cruel knife.
vi: Instead of holding the familiar soft tools, her right hand was gripping a hatchet, and tucked into her belt were a pistol and a formidable knife.
tr: In the madam's determined right hand, instead of her usual and relatively soft tools, there was an axe, and on her belt, there was a gun and a terrifying knife.
es: The sweet lady wielded an axe instead of needles, and at her waist she displayed two unique ornaments: a pistol and a long knife.

en: “Where do you go, my wife?”
vi: − Where are you planning to go? −
tr: "Where are you going?""
es: —Where are you, my little woman?—asked Defarge.

en: “I go,” said madame, “with you at present.
vi: Right now, I'm going with you, - she said.
tr: "I will come with you," said the lady, "and later you will see me leading the women.""
es: —At this moment with you: in an instant, at the head of the women—replied the innkeeper.

en: You shall see me at the head of women, by-and-bye.”
vi: - You'll see me leading the sisters right away.
tr: "I will come with you," said the lady, "and later you will see me leading the women.""
es: —At this moment with you: in an instant, at the head of the women—replied the innkeeper.

en: “Come, then!” cried Defarge, in a resounding voice.
vi: − Then let's go! - Defarge shouted loudly, his voice booming.
tr: "Then let's go!" shouted Defarge, with his ringing voice.
es: —Forward, then! —shouted Defarge with a thunderous voice.

en: “Patriots and friends, we are ready!
vi: - Patriots and friends, be ready!
tr: "Patriots, my friends, we are ready now!
es: —Patriots...! My friends...!

en: The Bastille!”
vi: The Bastille!
tr: To the Bastille!"
es: To the Bastille!

en: With a roar that sounded as if all the breath in France had been shaped into the detested word, the living sea rose, wave on wave, depth on depth, and overflowed the city to that point.
vi: With a roar as if every breath in France had crystallized into that dreadful name, the sea of people surged, wave after wave, layer after layer, flooding into the city, heading towards that place.
tr: As if all the breaths in France had uttered this disgusting word, a great noise erupted, and the living sea surged wave upon wave, piling on top of each other and furiously carrying the entire city to that point.
es: As if this last hateful word had given shape to all the breaths of France, a terrifying roar tore through the air, that living sea swelled, its depths churned, its waves rose and engulfed the entire city.

en: Alarm-bells ringing, drums beating, the sea raging and thundering on its new beach, the attack began.
vi: The alarm bells rang loudly, drums beat incessantly, the furious sea roared, crashing waves into a new shore, the attack began.
tr: As the bells rang, the drums beat, and the sea swelled with rage, pounding its new shore, the attack began.
es: All the alarm bells rang, all the drums thundered, the sea bellowed and roared, and the attack began.

en: Deep ditches, double drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great towers, cannon, muskets, fire and smoke.
vi: Crossing deep moats, rushing over suspension bridges, overcoming massive stone walls, surging towards eight large towers, cannons and muskets exchanging fire, flames and smoke enveloping everything.
tr: Deep trenches, two suspension bridges, huge stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, rifles, fire, and smoke.
es: Deep moats, double drawbridges, massive stone walls, eight huge towers, cannons, muskets, fire and smoke... No matter!

en: Through the fire and through the smoke—in the fire and in the smoke, for the sea cast him up against a cannon, and on the instant he became a cannonier—Defarge of the wine-shop worked like a manful soldier, Two fierce hours.
vi: Through the smoke and fire - in the thick haze of flames and smoke, the sea of people lifted Defarge onto the cannon and he immediately became an artilleryman. The innkeeper fired continuously like a valiant warrior. For two hours straight.
tr: The owner of the wine shop, Defarge, fought bravely like a valiant soldier for two fierce hours amidst all that fire and smoke – the sea had carried him through the fire and smoke to the cannon, and as soon as he took charge, he became an artilleryman.
es: Amid seas of fire and clouds of thick smoke... floating through the smoke and riding on the fire, for the sea threw him against a cannon and immediately turned him into a terrible artilleryman..., Defarge, the tavern keeper, worked like an infernal soldier for two hours.

en: Deep ditch, single drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great towers, cannon, muskets, fire and smoke.
vi: Deep trenches, suspension bridges, massive stone walls, leading to eight large towers, cannons, fire tubes, smoke and flames.
tr: A deep trench, a suspension bridge, huge stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, rifles, fire, and smoke.
es: A wide and deep moat, a single drawbridge, robust stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, muskets, fire and smoke... A drawbridge falls... «Forward, comrades, forward!

en: One drawbridge down!
vi: A suspension bridge has been blown up! −
tr: One of the bridges came down!
es: Forward, Santiago First!

en: “Work, comrades all, work!
vi: Take action, all of you, take action!
tr: "Come on, friends, come on!
es: Forward, Santiago Second!

en: Work, Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques One Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Five-and-Twenty Thousand; in the name of all the Angels or the Devils—which you prefer—work!”
vi: Take action, Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques One Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Twenty-Five Thousand; in the name of all Angels and Demons... Any demon or god will do... Take action!
tr: Come on Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Twenty-five Thousand; all Angels and Demons –whichever you choose– come on!"
es: Forward, Santiago Thousand, forward, Santiago Two Thousand, Santiago Five Thousand, Santiago Twenty Thousand...! By all the angels in Heaven... by all the demons in hell... as you wish... forward!»

en: Thus Defarge of the wine-shop, still at his gun, which had long grown hot.
vi: - Tavern owner Defarge kept firing, the cannon had heated up. − In my opinion, sisters! -
tr: The wine shop owner Defarge never left the side of the cannon that had become quite hot.
es: Such are the cries that come from the throat of the innkeeper, turned hours before into a terrible gunner, the innkeeper, who gives no rest to his already reddened cannon!

en: “To me, women!” cried madame his wife.
vi: His wife shouted.
tr: "Come closer, women!" his wife shouted.
es: “All the women, to me!”—his wife was shouting in the meantime.

en: “What!
vi: - Come on!
tr: "What are you saying?
es: “Well, why not...!

en: We can kill as well as the men when the place is taken!”
vi: We women are just as good at killing as men when it comes to it!
tr: After the Bastille is taken, can we kill like men too?"
es: Can't we kill just like they do, once the town falls into our hands?”

en: And to her, with a shrill thirsty cry, trooping women variously armed, but all armed alike in hunger and revenge.
