vi: - And her words were met with a deafening, eager scream from a forest of women armed with all kinds of weapons but sharing the same hunger and hatred.
tr: Though their hands were filled with various weapons, driven by hunger and revenge, the women, who were the only weapon, screamed with their shrill voices and all their might.
es: And towards her ran herds of women, hoarse, bellowing, armed with different weapons, but all animated by the same spirit: the spirit of vengeance!

en: Cannon, muskets, fire and smoke; but, still the deep ditch, the single drawbridge, the massive stone walls, and the eight great towers.
vi: Artillery, fire tubes, smoke and flames; but still not past the deep moat, the hanging bridge, the massive stone walls, and not yet reaching the eight large towers.
tr: Cannon, rifle, fire and smoke; but still, there were deep trenches, a solitary suspension bridge, massive stone walls, and eight large towers before them.
es: Cannons, muskets, fire, and smoke; but there remained a deep moat, a drawbridge, robust stone walls, and eight large towers.

en: Slight displacements of the raging sea, made by the falling wounded.
vi: The raging sea transformed by the waves of fallen casualties.
tr: Those who were wounded and fell to the ground caused small shifts in the swelling sea.
es: The wounded who fell left some gaps in the boiling sea.

en: Flashing weapons, blazing torches, smoking waggonloads of wet straw, hard work at neighbouring barricades in all directions, shrieks, volleys, execrations, bravery without stint, boom smash and rattle, and the furious sounding of the living sea; but, still the deep ditch, and the single drawbridge, and the massive stone walls, and the eight great towers, and still Defarge of the wine-shop at his gun, grown doubly hot by the service of Four fierce hours.
vi: Weapons gleaming, torches blazing brightly, convoys of carts carrying wet straw, layers upon layers of people from all directions charging towards the nearby obstacles, the shouts, the gunfire, the curses, death as light as a feather, the thunderous destruction, the sea of people roaring and surging forward; but still not past the deep moat, the hanging bridge, the massive stone walls, and not yet reaching the eight large towers, and the tavern keeper Defarge still beside the cannon, hot from four hours of fierce firepower.
tr: Exploding weapons, burning torches, carts loaded with wet straw emitting smoke, frantic activity in every direction from nearby trenches, screams, volleys of gunfire, curses, relentless courage, the hum, the clamor, and the angry sound of the living sea; but still, there were deep trenches, a solitary suspension bridge, massive stone walls, eight large towers, and the wine shop owner Defarge still at the cannon, thoroughly enraged after four fierce hours.
es: Weapons gleam, torches burn, carts loaded with dampened straw emit clouds of smoke, barricades spring up everywhere, fierce howls resound, repeated volleys thunder through the space, dreadful curses pierce the ears, everyone displays bravery, the living sea roars with redoubled fury... and still there remains the deep moat, and the drawbridge, and the robust stone walls, and the eight large towers, and Defarge, the innkeeper, continues at the cannon, heated to a white-hot glow as a result of four uninterrupted hours of service!

en: A white flag from within the fortress, and a parley—this dimly perceptible through the raging storm, nothing audible in it—suddenly the sea rose immeasurably wider and higher, and swept Defarge of the wine-shop over the lowered drawbridge, past the massive stone outer walls, in among the eight great towers surrendered!
vi: A white flag was raised from within the fortress, then negotiations - an event that occurred vaguely amidst this frenzied storm, no one could hear anything - suddenly the sea of people surged higher and higher, spreading wider and wider, and swept the tavern owner Defarge onto a lowered drawbridge, crossing the massive outer stone walls, and into the midst of the eight towers that had just fallen!
tr: After the white flag was raised at the castle and the negotiations began – but in this furious storm, nothing could be seen or heard properly – the sea suddenly swelled and foamed incredibly, and hurled Defarge over the drawbridge, delivering him among the eight large towers over the massive stone walls!
es: Within the fortress, a white flag appears... the waves roar more than ever, they swell, rise to the clouds, and drag Defarge the innkeeper, throwing him beyond the drawbridge, beyond the sturdy stone walls, among the eight great towers.

en: So resistless was the force of the ocean bearing him on, that even to draw his breath or turn his head was as impracticable as if he had been struggling in the surf at the South Sea, until he was landed in the outer courtyard of the Bastille.
vi: That sea of people pushed him forward irresistibly, he couldn't even stop to catch his breath or look back, as if he were struggling in the fierce waves of the Southern sea, until he was herded into the forecourt of the Bastille prison.
tr: The power of the ocean that hurled him there was so irresistible that, until he reached the outer courtyard of the Bastille, it was impossible to breathe or turn his head as if he were struggling with the waves in the South Sea.
es: The force of the ocean that dragged him was so irresistible that even taking a breath, even turning his head, was as impracticable for him as if he were struggling against the undertow of the South Sea, until he found himself in the inner courtyard of the Bastille.

en: There, against an angle of a wall, he made a struggle to look about him.
vi: There, leaning against a corner of the wall, he strained to look around.
tr: When he arrived, he tried to look around at the base of the wall.
es: There, leaning against an angle of the wall, he tried to look around.

en: Jacques
vi: Jacques
tr: Jacques
es: There, leaning against an angle of the wall, he tried to look around.

en: Three was nearly at his side; Madame Defarge, still heading some of her women, was visible in the inner distance, and her knife was in her hand.
vi: Three was nearby; the shadow of Madame Defarge, still commanding her group of women, appeared far inside, a knife gleaming in her hand.
tr: Three was right beside him; Madame Defarge, who still led the women, was within sight with a knife in her hand.
es: Next to him was Santiago Tercero, and a short distance away he saw his wife, leading the women and brandishing a knife.

en: Everywhere was tumult, exultation, deafening and maniacal bewilderment, astounding noise, yet furious dumb-show.
vi: Everywhere was tumultuous, joyous, the deafening sound of madness, no one could hear anyone else and everyone gestured wildly like a brutal pantomime.
tr: Everywhere there was. chaos, joy, deafening and mad frenzy, astonishing noise, and despite everything, an angry pantomime.
es: Everything was tumult, all joy, deafening and maniacal astonishment, noises, furious drum rolls.

en: “The Prisoners!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Prisoners!"
es: —The prisoners!

en: “The Records!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Records!"
es: —The records!

en: “The secret cells!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Secret cells!"
es: —The records!

en: “The instruments of torture!”
vi: − Torture instruments!
tr: "Torture devices!"
es: —The instruments of torture!

en: “The Prisoners!”
vi: − Prisoner!
tr: "Prisoners!"
es: —The prisoners!

en: Of all these cries, and ten thousand incoherences, “The Prisoners!” was the cry most taken up by the sea that rushed in, as if there were an eternity of people, as well as of time and space.
vi: Among those shouts and the countless indistinct clamors, "Prisoner!" was the loudest roar carried by the sea of people, echoing, continuing seemingly endlessly.
tr: Amidst all these screams and tens of thousands of contradictions, the most heard scream in the sea that flowed inside like a human flood as infinite as time and space was "Prisoners!"
es: Of all these shouts, and of ten thousand incoherencies of the sort, the one most repeated by that raging sea was "The prisoners!".

en: When the foremost billows rolled past, bearing the prison officers with them, and threatening them all with instant death if any secret nook remained undisclosed, Defarge laid his strong hand on the breast of one of these men—a man with a grey head, who had a lighted torch in his hand—separated him from the rest, and got him between himself and the wall.
vi: When the first waves of people surged through, dragging along the prison wardens, threatening to kill them immediately if they did not reveal any secret corners, Defarge used his strong hand to grab the neck of a jailer - a gray-haired man holding a burning torch - pulled him out, pushed him against the wall, and then stood blocking in front of him.
tr: When the foremost waves dragged the guards in front of them and threatened them with death to ensure that no hidden corner remained unopened, Defarge placed his hand on the chest of one of these men – a gray-haired man holding a torch – and separated him from the others, pinning him between the wall and himself.
es: When the first waves penetrated, dragging the officers of the fortress ahead of them and threatening them with immediate death if they left a single hiding place unrevealed, Defarge grabbed one of them with his powerful claw, a gray-haired man who was holding a lit torch, separated him from the others, and said to him:

en: “Show me the North Tower!” said Defarge.
vi: − Show the way to the North Tower! - Defarge said.
tr: "Show me the North Tower!" said Defarge.
es: —Show me the North Tower... quickly!

en: “Quick!”
vi: - Hurry up! − I will show you right away if you come with me, - the person replied.
tr: "Quick!"
es: —Show me the North Tower... quickly!

en: “I will faithfully,” replied the man, “if you will come with me.
tr: "Of course, I'll show you," the man replied, "come with me.
es: —I will do it with great pleasure, if you want—replied the man—but there is no one in there.

en: But there is no one there.”
vi: But there is no one there.
tr: But there's no one there."
es: —I will do it with great pleasure, if you want—replied the man—but there is no one in there.

en: “What is the meaning of One Hundred and Five, North Tower?” asked Defarge.
vi: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower, what does it mean? - Defarge asked.
tr: "What is the meaning of the One Hundred and Five North Tower?" asked Defarge.
es: —What does One Hundred and Five, North Tower mean?—asked Defarge—Answer... quickly!

en: “Quick!”
vi: - Speak quickly.
tr: "Quickly, tell me!"
es: —What does One Hundred and Five, North Tower mean?—asked Defarge—Answer... quickly!

en: “The meaning, monsieur?”
vi: − What do you mean, sir? −
tr: "Did you ask for the meaning, monsieur?"
es: —What does it mean, sir?

en: “Does it mean a captive, or a place of captivity?
vi: Is that the prisoner or the cell?
tr: "Is this a prisoner or a cell?
es: —Does it mean a captive or a dungeon to imprison captives?

en: Or do you mean that I shall strike you dead?”
vi: Or do you want me to punch you to death!
tr: Or does it mean I can kill you right here and now?"
es: Answer!

en: “Kill him!” croaked Jacques
vi: − Kill him!
tr: Jacques
es: Do you want me to kill you like a dog?

en: Three, who had come close up.
vi: - Jacques Ba shouted, having just approached.
tr: Three, who approached them, shouted in a hoarse voice, "Kill him!"
es: "Kill him!" shouted Santiago Tercero.

en: “Monsieur, it is a cell.”
vi: − Sir, that is the prison cell.
tr: "Monsieur, that is a cell."
es: —It's a cell, sir.

en: “Show it me!”
vi: − Take me there! −
tr: "Show me that place!"
es: —Show it to me.

en: “Pass this way, then.”
vi: Then go this way.
tr: "Let's go this way then."
es: —This way, sir.

en: Jacques
vi: With a familiar hunger, Jacques Three was clearly disappointed when the conversation turned away from the promise of bloodshed, so he grabbed Defarge's arm and the arm of the prison guard.
tr: With his usual greedy demeanor and disappointed by the dialogue between the man and Defarge progressing towards a point where no blood would be shed, Jacques Three had grabbed Defarge's arm, and Defarge had grabbed the guard's arm.
es: Santiago Tercero, insatiable hydropic as always, evidently disappointed to see that the dialogue was taking a turn that reduced the chances of bloodshed, clung to Defarge's arm at the same time that Defarge clung to the jailer's arm.

en: Three, with his usual craving on him, and evidently disappointed by the dialogue taking a turn that did not seem to promise bloodshed, held by Defarge’s arm as he held by the turnkey’s.
vi: With a familiar hunger, Jacques Three was clearly disappointed when the conversation turned away from the promise of bloodshed, so he grabbed Defarge's arm and the arm of the prison guard.
tr: With his usual greedy demeanor and disappointed by the dialogue between the man and Defarge progressing towards a point where no blood would be shed, Jacques Three had grabbed Defarge's arm, and Defarge had grabbed the guard's arm.
es: Santiago Tercero, insatiable hydropic as always, evidently disappointed to see that the dialogue was taking a turn that reduced the chances of bloodshed, clung to Defarge's arm at the same time that Defarge clung to the jailer's arm.

en: Their three heads had been close together during this brief discourse, and it had been as much as they could do to hear one another, even then: so tremendous was the noise of the living ocean, in its irruption into the Fortress, and its inundation of the courts and passages and staircases.
vi: The three heads huddled together in a brief exchange, and even then they could barely hear each other, the deafening roar of the surrounding sea of people storming the fortress, flooding the courtyards, passageways, and staircases.
tr: During this brief conversation. The three heads were closely huddled together, but even in that state, they could barely hear each other. As the living ocean invaded the Bastille and surged through its courtyards, corridors, and stairways, it made a tremendous noise.
es: During the brief dialogue transcribed above, the heads of the three men were close together, and even so, they could barely hear each other; such was the tremendous roar produced by that living ocean as it penetrated the fortress and flooded the rooms, cells, corridors, and staircases.

en: All around outside, too, it beat the walls with a deep, hoarse roar, from which, occasionally, some partial shouts of tumult broke and leaped into the air like spray.
vi: All around outside, the roar of the crowd was deafening, and every now and then, a chaotic scream would burst forth like a wave crashing into the sky.
tr: Outside, the ocean was pounding the walls with a deep, muffled roar, and the screams rising from this chaos were scattering in the air.
es: The shouting outside was no less, where from time to time thunderclaps that foretold turmoil erupted, and lightning bolts crossed the heated atmosphere like immeasurable whips wielded by titans.

en: Through gloomy vaults where the light of day had never shone, past hideous doors of dark dens and cages, down cavernous flights of steps, and again up steep rugged ascents of stone and brick, more like dry waterfalls than staircases, Defarge, the turnkey, and Jacques Three, linked hand and arm, went with all the speed they could make.
vi: Passing through the dark dungeons that had never seen daylight, crossing the prison doors, the grimy and ghastly cells, descending the cavern-like steps, then climbing up the jagged stone stairs steeper than a dry waterfall rather than a staircase, Defarge, the jailer, and Jacques Three, holding hands tightly, tried to move as quickly as possible.
tr: Defarge, the guard, and Jacques Three, arm in arm, hurried along at full speed, passing by the gloomy cellars where daylight had never once entered, and the disgusting doors of dark dungeons, descending steps that resembled caves, and climbing steep slopes of stone and brick that resembled dried-up waterfalls.
es: Defarge, the jailer, and Santiago Tercero, holding each other by the arms, hurried through dark corridors never visited by daylight, passed by terrifying doors of gloomy and damp dungeons, descended through cavernous stairways, and then climbed rough stone and brick steps, more akin to dry waterfalls than to stairs.

en: Here and there, especially at first, the inundation started on them and swept by; but when they had done descending, and were winding and climbing up a tower, they were alone.
vi: From time to time, especially at the beginning, the sea of people surged forward, sweeping them along; but when they had finished descending and continued up a spiral staircase to a high tower, only the three of them remained.
tr: In many places, especially in the first places they passed, they too were swept away by the flood, but as their descent ended and they spiraled up the tower, they were left alone.
es: From time to time, especially at the beginning, the flood blocked their way or swept them along; but after a while, once they entered a spiral staircase and began to ascend a tower, they were left alone.

en: Hemmed in here by the massive thickness of walls and arches, the storm within the fortress and without was only audible to them in a dull, subdued way, as if the noise out of which they had come had almost destroyed their sense of hearing.
vi: Here, surrounded by thick walls and arches, the storm inside and outside the fortress was just a faint sound, unlike the noise they had just escaped that had nearly destroyed the hearing ability of the three.
tr: Now, surrounded by the imposing thick walls and arches, the sound of the storm both inside and outside the castle came very muffled and deep, as if all that noise would destroy their sense of hearing.
es: The walls that isolated them from the world were so thick that their ears, as if shattered by the previous furious roars, could barely perceive muffled sounds.

en: The turnkey stopped at a low door, put a key in a clashing lock, swung the door slowly open, and said, as they all bent their heads and passed in:
vi: The jailer stopped at a low door, inserted a creaky key into the lock, slowly opened the door, and said as all three bowed their heads to enter: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower!
tr: The guard stood in front of a low door, inserted the key into the lock with a clatter, slowly opened the door, and as they all bowed their heads and entered, he said:
es: The jailer stopped in front of a very low door, took out a key, opened it, and said while bending his body to be able to enter:

en: “One hundred and five, North Tower!”
vi: The jailer stopped at a low door, inserted a creaky key into the lock, slowly opened the door, and said as all three bowed their heads to enter: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower!
tr: "Here is One Hundred and Five, North Tower!"
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: There was a small, heavily-grated, unglazed window high in the wall, with a stone screen before it, so that the sky could be only seen by stooping low and looking up.
vi: Inside, there was a window without glass, densely barred, high on the wall, and in front of the door, a stone slab blocked the view, so one had to crouch down and look up to see a patch of sky.
tr: On top of the wall, there was a small window with thick iron bars and no glass, with a stone partition in front of it, so one had to crouch down to the ground and look up to see the sky.
es: They found themselves in a square formed by four blackened walls.

en: There was a small chimney, heavily barred across, a few feet within.
vi: A few steps away was a small chimney, also densely barred.
tr: A little further away, there was a small chimney covered with thick grates.
es: In one of them, there was a rusty iron ring, and in another, at the height of the vaulted ceiling, a small window defended by thick iron bars and arranged in such a way that it barely allowed a very narrow line of blue sky to be seen.

en: There was a heap of old feathery wood-ashes on the hearth.
vi: On the hearth was a pile of long-burned wood ashes.
tr: A little further away, there was a small chimney covered with thick grates.
es: Piles of ashes covered the floor, and its furniture consisted of a bench, a table, and a straw mattress.

en: There was a stool, and table, and a straw bed.
vi: A stool, a table, a straw bed.
tr: Inside, there was a stool, a table, and a straw bed.
es: Piles of ashes covered the floor, and its furniture consisted of a bench, a table, and a straw mattress.

en: There were the four blackened walls, and a rusted iron ring in one of them.
vi: Four blackened walls, and on one wall, a rusty iron ring was attached.
tr: All four walls were pitch black, and on one of them, a ring was hanging.
es: —Pass the torch slowly along the walls so that I can see—said Defarge to the jailer.

en: “Pass that torch slowly along these walls, that I may see them,” said Defarge to the turnkey.
vi: − Slowly move the torch along these walls so I can take a look, - Defarge said to the jailer.
tr: "Hold the torch up to these walls so I can see," Defarge said to the guard.
es: —Pass the torch slowly along the walls so that I can see—said Defarge to the jailer.

en: The man obeyed, and Defarge followed the light closely with his eyes.
vi: This person obeyed, and Defarge attentively followed the beam of light.
tr: Adam followed what was said. Defarge also carefully followed the light with his eyes.
es: The man obeyed. Defarge was examining the walls with a penetrating gaze.

en: “Stop!—Look here, Jacques!”
vi: − Stop!... Look, Jacques! − “A. M.”!
tr: "Stop! – Look over there, Jacques!"
es: —Stop...! Look, Santiago!

en: “A. M.!” croaked Jacques
vi: − Stop!... Look, Jacques! − “A. M.”!
tr: "Stop! – Look over there, Jacques!"
es: —A. M.—roared Santiago Tercero with a longing expression.

en: Three, as he read greedily.
vi: - Jacques Ba said, almost groaning as he read those initials eagerly.
tr: As Jacques was reading with a greedy attitude, he shouted in a muffled voice, "A. M!"
es: —A. M.—roared Santiago Tercero with a longing expression.

en: “Alexandre Manette,” said Defarge in his ear, following the letters with his swart forefinger, deeply engrained with gunpowder.
vi: − "Alexandre Manette," Defarge whispered, tracing the letters with his gunpowder-stained dark finger. -
tr: Defarge, running his dark finger stained with gunpowder over the letters, said into his friend's ear, "Alexandre Manette."
es: —Alejandro Manette—whispered Defarge in his ear, placing the tip of his index finger on the initials.

en: “And here he wrote ‘a poor physician.’
vi: And here he carved the words "poor doctor".
tr: "Look, he also wrote 'A poor doctor' here.""
es: —Here he has written "poor doctor."

en: And it was he, without doubt, who scratched a calendar on this stone.
vi: And it was certainly him, no one else, who carved these tally marks on this stone.
tr: He was definitely the one who drew the calendar on this stone.
es: No doubt about it! He was the one who engraved his epitaph here!

en: What is that in your hand?
vi: What are you holding?
tr: What is that in your hand?
es: What do you have in your hand?

en: A crowbar?
vi: A crowbar?
tr: A shackle?
es: An iron bar?

en: Give it me!”
vi: Give it to me!
tr: Give it to me!"
es: Give it to me!

en: He had still the linstock of his gun in his own hand.
vi: Defarge still held the cannon's firing stick in his hand.
tr: Defarge still had the rifle in his hand.
es: Defarge, who still held the cannon's firebrand in his hand, exchanged it for the iron bar that Santiago Tercero handed to him and, in less time than it takes to tell, smashed the bench and the table to pieces.

en: He made a sudden exchange of the two instruments, and turning on the worm-eaten stool and table, beat them to pieces in a few blows.
vi: He immediately exchanged tools with Jacques Three and then turned to smash the worm-eaten stool and table with a few heavy blows.
tr: He quickly handed it to Jacques, took the crowbar, and shattered the worm-eaten stool and table with a few blows.
es: Defarge, who still held the cannon's firebrand in his hand, exchanged it for the iron bar that Santiago Tercero handed to him and, in less time than it takes to tell, smashed the bench and the table to pieces.

en: “Hold the light higher!” he said, wrathfully, to the turnkey.
vi: − Hold the torch a little higher! - In an indignant voice, he said to the jailer and then turned to Jacques.
tr: Defarge said angrily to the guard, "Hold the light a little higher!"
es: —Raise the light!

en: “Look among those fragments with care, Jacques.
vi: - Search thoroughly in that pile of debris, Jacques.
tr: "Look carefully between those pieces, Jacques!
es: —he shouted furiously at the jailer.

en: And see!
vi: Here!
tr: "Look carefully between those pieces, Jacques!

en: Here is my knife,” throwing it to him; “rip open that bed, and search the straw.
vi: Take my knife! - He tossed the knife to his friend. - Rip the bed apart, search in the straw mattress.
tr: Take my knife," he said, throwing it to him; "tear open the bed, look inside the straw.
es: And you, Santiago, take my knife,—he added, throwing it to him—tear that mattress, and search through the straw...!

en: Hold the light higher, you!”
vi: Hold the torch higher, you!
tr: You, lift that light a little higher too!"
es: Raise the light!

en: With a menacing look at the turnkey he crawled upon the hearth, and, peering up the chimney, struck and prised at its sides with the crowbar, and worked at the iron grating across it.
vi: After glaring and intimidating the jailer, Defarge crawled on the fireplace floor, intently looking up the chimney, using a crowbar to tap, pry at the sides of the fireplace, and try to dislodge the iron bars crisscrossing the chimney hole.
tr: After looking at the guard menacingly, he bent over the stove and looked up the chimney, then struck its edges with the iron poker in his hand and tried to remove the iron grate on top.
es: After casting a threatening look at the jailer, Defarge, while Santiago Tercero carried out his order, dug with the iron bar between the joints of the pavement slabs, stirred the ashes, and tried to move the stones of the walls.

en: In a few minutes, some mortar and dust came dropping down, which he averted his face to avoid; and in it, and in the old wood-ashes, and in a crevice in the chimney into which his weapon had slipped or wrought itself, he groped with a cautious touch.
vi: A few minutes later, plaster and dust fell down, he turned his face away to avoid it; then carefully groped and searched through the old ashes and in the chimney nook where the crowbar had managed to reach.
tr: A few minutes later, when plaster and dust started falling from above, he turned his head to the side; amidst all this dust and old ashes, he cautiously felt around with his weapon inside a crack in the chimney.
es: After casting a threatening look at the jailer, Defarge, while Santiago Tercero carried out his order, dug with the iron bar between the joints of the pavement slabs, stirred the ashes, and tried to move the stones of the walls.

en: “Nothing in the wood, and nothing in the straw, Jacques?”
vi: − Is there nothing in that pile of straw, Jacques? −
tr: "Isn't there something in the ashes or the straw, Jacques?"
es: —Haven't you found anything, Santiago?—he asked after a while.

en: “Nothing.”
vi: There's nothing.
tr: "Nothing."
es: —Nothing.

en: “Let us collect them together, in the middle of the cell.
vi: − Gather everything in the middle of the room.
tr: "Let's gather these in the middle of the cell.
es: —We are going to make a pile with the straw and the chips...

en: So!
vi: Alright!
tr: Now, burn them!" .
es: Like this!

en: Light them, you!”
vi: Burn it, you there!
tr: Now, burn them!" .
es: Light the fire, jailer!

en: The turnkey fired the little pile, which blazed high and hot.
vi: The jailer lit a torch to that pile, and the straw and wood blazed fiercely.
tr: With the guard's ignition, the small pile burned brightly.
es: The jailer immediately obeyed the order.

en: Stooping again to come out at the low-arched door, they left it burning, and retraced their way to the courtyard; seeming to recover their sense of hearing as they came down, until they were in the raging flood once more.
vi: Bending down again to pass through the low archway, all three left the fire burning and retraced their steps back to the courtyard; with each step downward, their hearing seemed to recover, until they were once again in the midst of the frenzied crowd.
tr: Leaving the fire burning, they bent down again and exited through the low-arched door, following the path to the courtyard; as they descended, their sense of hearing improved; until they found themselves once again in the midst of the angry human flood.
es: The three men left the dungeon, leaving the combustible materials burning, and returned once again to the courtyard, where the disorder was as dreadful, if not more so, than before.

en: They found it surging and tossing, in quest of Defarge himself.
vi: The sea of people was still surging, fervently searching for Defarge.
tr: People were running around excitedly, looking for Defarge.
es: The mob was frantically, madly searching for Defarge; they wanted the tavern keeper to be the head of the guard in charge of watching over the governor who had defended the Bastille and fired upon the people.

en: Saint Antoine was clamorous to have its wine-shop keeper foremost in the guard upon the governor who had defended the Bastille and shot the people.
vi: The people of Saint Antoine were clamoring for the tavern owner to lead the group guarding the chief officer, who had fired upon the populace to protect the Bastille prison.
tr: St. Antoine was clamoring to unleash the wine shop owner upon the governor who defended the Bastille and fired upon the people.
es: The mob was frantically, madly searching for Defarge; they wanted the tavern keeper to be the head of the guard in charge of watching over the governor who had defended the Bastille and fired upon the people.

en: Otherwise, the governor would not be marched to the Hotel de Ville for judgment.
vi: Otherwise, they would not be able to bring the officer to the Town Hall for trial.
tr: Otherwise, the governor would not be taken to the Town Hall for trial.
es: How else would the governor be taken to the Hôtel de Ville to be judged?

en: Otherwise, the governor would escape, and the people’s blood (suddenly of some value, after many years of worthlessness) be unavenged.
vi: If not, the officer would escape, and those who had shed blood would not get their revenge (after so many worthless years, the blood of commoners suddenly had some value).
tr: Otherwise, the governor would escape, and the blood of the people (which had suddenly become valuable after years of being worthless) would be left unavenged.
es: How else would they prevent him from escaping, leaving the blood of the people unavenged, which had suddenly gained some value after so many years of being worth nothing?

en: In the howling universe of passion and contention that seemed to encompass this grim old officer conspicuous in his grey coat and red decoration, there was but one quite steady figure, and that was a woman’s.
vi: Amidst the sea of humanity roaring and arguing aggressively as if wanting to drown the old official wearing a gray coat and a red medal, there was only one person who remained completely calm, and that was a woman.
tr: With his eye-catching gray jacket and red insignia, surrounded by the crowd groaning with passion and ambition, there was only one person who remained calm among them, and that was a woman.
es: Among the countless mobs that roared with rage and moved restlessly around the stern figure of the elderly official, whose gray overcoat with red trimmings made him more visible, there was only one calm and serene person, and that person was a woman.

en: “See, there is my husband!” she cried, pointing him out.
vi: − There, my husband is here! - She shouted loudly, pointing.
tr: "Here comes my husband!" she shouted, pointing at Defarge.
es: —There is my husband—she said, extending an arm towards Defarge.

en: “See Defarge!”
vi: - There's Defarge!
tr: "Look at Defarge!"
es: —There is my husband—she said, extending an arm towards Defarge.

en: She stood immovable close to the grim old officer, and remained immovable close to him; remained immovable close to him through the streets, as Defarge and the rest bore him along; remained immovable close to him when he was got near his destination, and began to be struck at from behind; remained immovable close to him when the long-gathering rain of stabs and blows fell heavy; was so close to him when he dropped dead under it, that, suddenly animated, she put her foot upon his neck, and with her cruel knife—long ready—hewed off his head.
vi: She stood close beside the fierce old official; and still remained close beside him; she stayed close beside him as the crowd moved through the streets while Defarge and the mob led that person away; still close beside him when he was struck from behind; still close beside him when he endured a long-accumulated rain of punches and kicks; still close beside him when that person collapsed under the blows, and then suddenly she became very excited, stepping on his neck and drawing a very long, cruel knife - chopping off his head.
tr: The woman stood motionless right next to the stern-faced old official, even as Defarge and the rest of the crowd dragged the man through the streets, pushed him from behind as they approached their intended spot, and as knives and fists rained down on the man, the woman remained motionless, always close to the man, and when the man finally collapsed lifelessly to the ground, she was right beside him and suddenly moved, placing her foot on the man's neck and with the cruel knife she had been holding for a long time, severed the man's head from his body.
es: She stood motionless beside the governor when her husband appeared, and she continued motionless without separating from his person. By his side, she remained rigid and calm while Defarge and his men led him through the streets, and she did not separate when they were about to reach their destination, nor when the mobs began to strike him from behind, nor when the tips of innumerable knives tore into his flesh, nor when, riddled with wounds, he fell dead on the street stones. She was so close to him that upon seeing him fall, suddenly animated, she placed her foot on the neck of the dead man and with her sharp knife cut off his head.

en: The hour was come, when Saint Antoine was to execute his horrible idea of hoisting up men for lamps to show what he could be and do.
vi: It was time for the people of Saint Antoine to carry out the horrifying idea of hanging someone from a lamppost to show who they were and what they could do.
tr: It was time to implement the horrific idea of hanging people instead of lamps, to show what St. Antoine was and what he could do.
es: Very soon the time would come when San Antonio would lower the lanterns that illuminated his brutalities and replace them with the corpses of aristocrats.

en: Saint Antoine’s blood was up, and the blood of tyranny and domination by the iron hand was down—down on the steps of the Hotel de Ville where the governor’s body lay—down on the sole of the shoe of Madame Defarge where she had trodden on the body to steady it for mutilation.
vi: The blood of the people of Saint Antoine had boiled, and the blood of the cruel, iron-fisted regime had flowed - on the steps of the City Hall where the body of the governor lay - under the shoes of Madame Defarge where she stepped on the body to steady herself and sever the head.
tr: Blood had rushed to St. Antoine's head, and the blood of iron-handed tyranny and domination had been spilled – it was flowing down from the steps of the Town Hall, from where the governor's body lay – and from the sole of Madam Defarge's shoe, which she had planted on the man's body to behead him.
es: The blood of San Antonio grew fervent as that of the iron hand of tyranny cooled... as it ran down the steps leading to the doors of the Hôtel de Ville, that of the governor, as the sole of Madame Defarge's shoe was stained red from pressing the neck of the unfortunate man whom she made the object of horrible mutilation.

en: “Lower the lamp yonder!” cried Saint Antoine, after glaring round for a new means of death; “here is one of his soldiers to be left on guard!”
vi: − Down with the lamppost over there! - The people of Saint Antoine shouted after glaring around to find more new people to execute. - There's another one of the old officer's guards here! -
tr: After looking around to see if there were any other men to kill, St. Antoine shouted, "Lower the lamp over here! Let's put one of his soldiers on guard!"
es: —Lower that lantern! —roared San Antonio, after turning his bloodshot eyes around. —Do you want a sentinel? Here you have one! He is a soldier of our enemies!

en: The swinging sentinel was posted, and the sea rushed on.
vi: The guard was hanged and dangled, and the sea of people surged forward, surged forward.
tr: As the guard swung from the lamp post, the sea surged again.
es: And there remained the sentinel, swaying gloomily, while the mob moved away roaring.

en: The sea of black and threatening waters, and of destructive upheaving of wave against wave, whose depths were yet unfathomed and whose forces were yet unknown.
vi: The sea is endlessly threatening and dark; the sea rises in waves, wave after wave of destruction; the sea is unfathomably deep; the sea is immensely powerful.
tr: The depth of this terrifying dark water and the destructive waves crashing over each other is beyond comprehension, and its power is unknown.
es: It was a sea of black and threatening waters, a sea whose waves carried destruction in each of their movements, a sea of unfathomable depth, a sea whose forces no one knew.

en: The remorseless sea of turbulently swaying shapes, voices of vengeance, and faces hardened in the furnaces of suffering until the touch of pity could make no mark on them.
vi: The sea is brutally turbulent, causing people to sway, roaring with the call for revenge, forging ruthless faces in the furnace of suffering until no trace of compassion remains.
tr: The merciless sea, with all its cruelty, was tossing bodies, voices of revenge, and faces hardened by pain, devoid of any trace of mercy.
es: A sea shielded against the sting of remorse, a sea of turbulent agitations, of cries for vengeance, of hearts hardened in the furnaces of suffering, upon whose diamond-like surface pity slid without leaving the slightest trace.

en: But, in the ocean of faces where every fierce and furious expression was in vivid life, there were two groups of faces—each seven in number—so fixedly contrasting with the rest, that never did sea roll which bore more memorable wrecks with it.
vi: But in the sea of people with faces brimming with vigorous energy and rage, there were two groups completely different from the crowd - each group consisting of seven faces - so different that the surging waves carrying more and more drifting fragments of memories could not submerge them.
tr: But within this torrent of people filled with furious and angry expressions, there were two groups of seven people each who, unlike the others, were in a more devastated state than anyone else swept away by this crowd.
es: But in that ocean of faces, a living reflection of all furies, of all violences, two groups of faces could be observed, each formed by seven faces that stood out from the boiling human waves that carried them, shipwreck remnants like none that have ever floated on any sea.

en: Seven faces of prisoners, suddenly released by the storm that had burst their tomb, were carried high overhead: all scared, all lost, all wondering and amazed, as if the Last Day were come, and those who rejoiced around them were lost spirits.
vi: The seven faces belong to seven prisoners, unexpectedly freed by a storm that shattered their prison, now being carried on the heads of a sea of people; all are terrified, all are lost, all are bewildered as if the Last Judgment has come and the rejoicing crowd are the souls of the dead.
tr: The seven prisoners, suddenly freed by the storm that scattered their graves, were now being carried on hands; all of them were frightened, as if they had fallen into a void, bewildered by what had happened to them, as if Judgment Day had come and the people surrounding them were lost souls.
es: Above the heads of the crowds, seven faces of prisoners could be seen, unexpectedly pulled from their graves by the human storm that visited them, seven frightened, stunned, bewildered faces, as if they were being taken to execution on the shoulders of rejoicing demons; and another seven faces, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-closed eyes awaited the arrival of Judgment Day; impassive faces whose life did not seem extinguished, but suspended, faces that seemed as if they were about to raise their eyelids again and open their blood-covered lips to say: "You murdered me!"

en: Other seven faces there were, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-seen eyes awaited the Last Day.
vi: Another seven faces, held higher, are seven heads, with eyelids half-closed over eyes staring blankly, awaiting Judgment Day.
tr: The other seven faces being carried a little higher up were lifeless, their eyelids drooped, their eyes half-open, waiting for Judgment Day.
es: Above the heads of the crowds, seven faces of prisoners could be seen, unexpectedly pulled from their graves by the human storm that visited them, seven frightened, stunned, bewildered faces, as if they were being taken to execution on the shoulders of rejoicing demons; and another seven faces, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-closed eyes awaited the arrival of Judgment Day; impassive faces whose life did not seem extinguished, but suspended, faces that seemed as if they were about to raise their eyelids again and open their blood-covered lips to say: "You murdered me!"

en: Impassive faces, yet with a suspended—not an abolished—expression on them; faces, rather, in a fearful pause, as having yet to raise the dropped lids of the eyes, and bear witness with the bloodless lips, “Thou Didst It!”
vi: These faces are motionless, frozen with a concentrated emotion; faces turned to stone in the midst of horror, not yet able to open wide their eyes to witness the pale lips screaming "MURDERERS!".
tr: These were indifferent faces, yet they bore an expression that was postponed but never altered; after a fearful wait, their drooped eyelids would open with effort and those lifeless lips would testify, "YOU DID THIS!"
es: Above the heads of the crowds, seven faces of prisoners could be seen, unexpectedly pulled from their graves by the human storm that visited them, seven frightened, stunned, bewildered faces, as if they were being taken to execution on the shoulders of rejoicing demons; and another seven faces, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-closed eyes awaited the arrival of Judgment Day; impassive faces whose life did not seem extinguished, but suspended, faces that seemed as if they were about to raise their eyelids again and open their blood-covered lips to say: "You murdered me!"

en: Seven prisoners released, seven gory heads on pikes, the keys of the accursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some discovered letters and other memorials of prisoners of old time, long dead of broken hearts,—such, and such—like, the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine.
vi: Seven prisoners were set free, seven heads were displayed on sharp stakes, the keys to the cursed fortress of eight towers, some letters found, and many other memories of prisoners who had long died from suffering - so many things like that - all echoed in the footsteps of the people of Saint Antoine marching through the streets of Paris in mid-July 1789.
tr: The seven released prisoners, the seven bloody heads on the tips of spears, the keys to the cursed castle with its eight sturdy towers, some letters and belongings left by former prisoners, the broken hearts that died years ago –and a lot of similar things– walked through the streets of Paris in mid-July of the year 1789, accompanied by the thunderous footsteps of St. Antoine.
es: Seven prisoners freed, seven bloody heads carried as horrible trophies on the spikes of pikes, the keys of the cursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some letters, a few memorials of ancient prisoners who had died of sorrow many years before... and something else of the sort, paraded through the streets of Paris amidst a very numerous escort, one day in mid-July of the year seventeen eighty-nine.

en: Now, Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay, and keep these feet far out of her life!
vi: At this moment, may Lucie Darnay's imagination be blocked so that those footsteps stay far from her life!
tr: May Lucie Darnay's predictions not come true, and may these distant footsteps remain far from them!
es: May Heaven keep the echo of the steps of the aforementioned escort away from the life of Lucie Darnay!

en: For, they are headlong, mad, and dangerous; and in the years so long after the breaking of the cask at Defarge’s wine-shop door, they are not easily purified when once stained red.
vi: For those are the footsteps of madness, danger; because many years after the day the wine cask broke in front of Defarge's wine shop, those footsteps are not easily washed clean once they are stained with blood.
tr: The crowd sees nothing because they are like madmen, dangerous, and it is not at all easy to clean the streets stained red again years after the wine barrel broke in front of Defarge's shop.
es: For they are echoes of hurried steps, of hard steps, of dangerous steps that violently penetrate the vital core of someone, echoes produced by feet that years before were stained red as a result of a barrel breaking near the door of Defarge's tavern, and when those feet are stained red, they are hardly ever cleaned.

en: CHAPTER XXII.
vi: For those are the footsteps of madness, danger; because many years after the day the wine cask broke in front of Defarge's wine shop, those footsteps are not easily washed clean once they are stained with blood.
tr: XXII
es: XXII.

en: The Sea Still Rises
vi: 22. The sea still has turbulent waves
tr: The Sea is Still Rising
es: THE TIDE RISES

en: Haggard Saint Antoine had had only one exultant week, in which to soften his modicum of hard and bitter bread to such extent as he could, with the relish of fraternal embraces and congratulations, when Madame Defarge sat at her counter, as usual, presiding over the customers.
vi: Saint Antoine, gaunt and haggard, had only one victorious week to temporarily soothe the bitter, gnawing crumbs of bread with the sweetness of brotherly embraces and words of praise, while Madame Defarge sat at the wine shop as usual, overseeing the customers.
tr: Madam Defarge was sitting behind her counter as usual, scrutinizing the customers, while the weary St. Antoine was so joyful from a week of embracing and congratulating each other like brothers that he could soften the little bread he had.
es: For only a week had the terrible San Antonio sweetened the harshness of the hard and bitter bread he put in his mouth, for only a week had he had the satisfaction of doing whatever he pleased and of alternating his outbursts with fraternal hugs and cordial congratulations. Madame Defarge presided over her patrons from her usual spot.

en: Madame Defarge wore no rose in her head, for the great brotherhood of Spies had become, even in one short week, extremely chary of trusting themselves to the saint’s mercies.
vi: Madame Defarge did not wear a rose in her hair because, in the short span of the past week, the numerous spies had been extremely reluctant to entrust their lives to the mercy of Saint Antoine.
tr: There was no rose in Madam Defarge's hair, because even in that short week, the spies were strangely cautious about leaving themselves to the mercy of the saints.
es: She no longer wore a rose in her hair, for the great brotherhood of spies had become so circumspect in the brief span of seven days that not even by a miracle could one find someone willing to entrust themselves to the tender care of the Saint.

en: The lamps across his streets had a portentously elastic swing with them.
vi: The street lamps at the intersections in the area named after the saint always swung and swayed on their posts like ominous omens.
tr: The street lamps were swinging ominously.
es: The street lamps of those streets exerted a wondrous influence over them.

en: Madame Defarge, with her arms folded, sat in the morning light and heat, contemplating the wine-shop and the street.
vi: Mrs. Defarge sat with her arms crossed in the hot morning sunlight, silently watching the tavern and the street.
tr: Madame Defarge, with her arms crossed, was thoughtfully looking at the wine shop and the road under the morning sun.
es: With arms crossed, Mrs. Defarge watched the street from behind the counter, while also keeping an eye on her establishment.

en: In both, there were several knots of loungers, squalid and miserable, but now with a manifest sense of power enthroned on their distress.
vi: Both inside and outside, many groups of idle people gathered, dirty and miserable individuals whose dire circumstances now granted them a palpable sense of power.
tr: On both, there were groups of idle people in filthy and miserable conditions, but now a clear power seemed to have settled over all their troubles.
es: Neither in the street nor in the establishment were there any shortages of well-nourished groups of loafers, scrawny and ragged, but with faces that reflected the power they had enthroned over their miseries.

en: The raggedest nightcap, awry on the wretchedest head, had this crooked significance in it: “I know how hard it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to support life in myself; but do you know how easy it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to destroy life in you?”
vi: The most tattered nightcaps, askew on the most unfortunate heads, seemed to convey a sinister message: "I know it is increasingly difficult for me, the wearer of this cap, to sustain myself; but do you know that it is becoming easier for me, the wearer of this cap, to destroy your life?"
tr: From the most wretched nightcap, worn on the most miserable head, this could be read: "I, who wear this cap, know how hard it is to sustain my life, but do you know how easy it is for me, who wears this cap, to take your life?"
es: Even the dirtiest and most tattered cap, scowling from atop the head it half-covered, seemed to say: "I know how hard you made life for me: but do you know how easy it has become for me to take away the comfortable and happy life you lead?"

en: Every lean bare arm, that had been without work before, had this work always ready for it now, that it could strike.
vi: Every emaciated arm that had long been without work now always had a job ready in raising a fist.
tr: Every skinny and bare arm that previously had no work was now ready to do this at any moment.
es: All the bare arms that had previously lacked work now had it in abundance and perpetuity: to wound, to kill.

en: The fingers of the knitting women were vicious, with the experience that they could tear.
vi: The fingers of the women who had been knitting malevolently for so long knew they could tear flesh and rip skin.
tr: The fingers of the women knitting were in a terrible state from the experiences they had lived through before.
es: The fingers of the women, previously occupied with knitting, had taken to other tasks since they realized they knew how to tear.

en: There was a change in the appearance of Saint Antoine; the image had been hammering into this for hundreds of years, and the last finishing blows had told mightily on the expression.
vi: The appearance of the Saint Antoine district has completely changed; this image has been carved out over hundreds of years, and the final finishing blows have been struck to shape that face.
tr: The face of St. Antoine had changed; this image had been ingrained in it for centuries, and with the final strong blow, its expression had changed completely.
es: Saint Anthony had undergone a radical transformation: the image, after hundreds of years of tranquility, was now in motion and delivering terrifying blows.

en: Madame Defarge sat observing it, with such suppressed approval as was to be desired in the leader of the Saint Antoine women.
vi: Mrs. Defarge sat observing the neighborhood with a satisfied look, carefully concealed to fit her role as the leader of the Saint Antoine women's group.
tr: Madame Defarge was sitting, watching her surroundings with the secret satisfaction expected from the leader of the women of St Antoine.
es: All this was observed by Madame Defarge from behind the counter of her establishment with the complacency of the leader of the women of Saint Antoine.

en: One of her sisterhood knitted beside her.
vi: A sister sat knitting beside her.
tr: One of her friends was also knitting beside her.
es: One of her sisters was knitting beside her.

en: The short, rather plump wife of a starved grocer, and the mother of two children withal, this lieutenant had already earned the complimentary name of The Vengeance.
vi: She was the short, rather plump wife of the starving grocer, and also the mother of two children. This deputy leader was praised with the nickname Goddess of Vengeance.
tr: This short, plump woman, who was the wife of a skin-and-bones grocer and mother of two children, was named Vengeance because she was Madame Defarge's right hand.
es: She was a short and somewhat plump woman, married to a shopkeeper and mother of two children to boot, who had earned the glorious nickname of "The Vengeance."

en: “Hark!” said The Vengeance.
vi: − Look! - said the Goddess of Vengeance.
tr: "Listen!" said Revenge.
es: She was a short and somewhat plump woman, married to a shopkeeper and mother of two children to boot, who had earned the glorious nickname of "The Vengeance."

en: “Listen, then!
vi: - Listen!
tr: "Listen, look!
es: —Attention!

en: Who comes?”
vi: Is someone coming?
tr: Who is coming?"
es: —exclaimed La Venganza—Who goes there?

en: As if a train of powder laid from the outermost bound of Saint Antoine Quarter to the wine-shop door, had been suddenly fired, a fast-spreading murmur came rushing along.
vi: Like a trail of gunpowder suddenly ignited from the outer edge of the Saint Antoine district stretching to the tavern door, there was a growing murmur approaching faster and faster.
tr: A series of gunpowder-like, powerful hums spread from the borders of the St. Antoine district towards the door of the wine shop, as if ignited.
es: As if they had set fire to a trail of gunpowder that extended from the borders of San Antonio's domains to Defarge's tavern, thus rumors reached the shop, born far away, and spread with dizzying speed in all directions.

en: “It is Defarge,” said madame.
vi: − That's Defarge, - she said.
tr: "Here is Defarge," said madam.
es: —It's Defarge! —said the tavern keeper.

en: “Silence, patriots!”
vi: - Silence, patriots!
tr: "Silence, friends!"
es: —Silence, patriots!

en: Defarge came in breathless, pulled off a red cap he wore, and looked around him!
vi: Defarge ran in, panting, pulled off the red cap from his head, and looked around.
tr: Defarge arrived out of breath, took off the red cap on his head, and looked around!
es: Defarge entered, panting, out of breath; he tore the red cap from his head that adorned it, and cast quick glances around him.

en: “Listen, everywhere!” said madame again.
vi: − Listen, everyone! - Her voice again.
tr: "Everyone be quiet!" said madam again.
es: —Attention everyone!

en: “Listen to him!”
vi: - Listen to what he has to say!
tr: "Listen to him!"
es: —shouted the innkeeper.—Listen to him!

en: Defarge stood, panting, against a background of eager eyes and open mouths, formed outside the door; all those within the wine-shop had sprung to their feet.
vi: Defarge stood panting, with eager eyes and gaping mouths behind him at the door; everyone in the tavern stood up abruptly.
tr: Defarge was standing breathlessly in front of the eager eyes and open mouths gathered at the door; everyone in the wine shop had jumped to their feet.
es: Defarge had remained on the threshold, contemplating the sea of open eyes and even more open mouths that filled the street. The people inside the tavern stood up. —Speak, Defarge!

en: “Say then, my husband.
vi: - Speak, my dear.
tr: "Tell me, my dear husband.
es: —replied the tavern keeper.

en: What is it?”
vi: What's the matter?
tr: What happened?"
es: —What's happening?

en: “News from the other world!”
vi: − News from the dead! −
tr: "There is news from the other world!"
es: —News from the other world!

en: “How, then?” cried madame, contemptuously.
vi: How can that be? - She exclaimed, her voice scornful. -
tr: "What do you mean?" shouted the madam, with a disdainful tone.
es: —Really?—asked his wife, putting a strong sarcastic tone in her words.

en: “The other world?”
vi: The dead?
tr: "The other world?"
es: —From the other world?

en: “Does everybody here recall old Foulon, who told the famished people that they might eat grass, and who died, and went to Hell?”
vi: − Does anyone here still remember old Foulon*, the one who told the starving people to eat grass to fill their bellies, and who has already gone to the underworld?
tr: "Does everyone here remember old Foulon, who suggested that starving people eat grass and then went on to meet his end in hell?""
es: —Do you all remember that individual named Foulon, who told the starving people to eat grass, and to try to die quickly and go to hell?

en: “Everybody!” from all throats.
vi: − Remember! - Every throat shouted.
tr: They all shouted together, "We remember."
es: —Yes...! —shouted the mobs in unison.

en: “The news is of him.
vi: − There is news about the old man.
tr: "The news is about him.
es: —My news refers to him.

en: He is among us!”
vi: The old man is right here! − Right here!
tr: He is among us!"
es: We have him among us.

en: “Among us!” from the universal throat again.
vi: - Those throats shouted in unison again. -
tr: "Is he among us?" they shouted all together again.
es: —Among us! —they all roared.

en: “And dead?”
vi: And dead? −
tr: "Wasn't he dead?"
es: —Dead?

en: “Not dead!
vi: Not dead yet!
tr: "He didn't die!
es: —No; he is alive.

en: He feared us so much—and with reason—that he caused himself to be represented as dead, and had a grand mock-funeral.
vi: He's so scared of us... and rightly so... so scared that he had to pretend to be dead and staged a fake funeral.
tr: He was so scared of us –and not without reason– that he spread the news of his death and arranged a grand funeral for himself.
es: Such was the terror he had of us... and rightly so, that he pretended to be dead and ordered a grand funeral for himself.

en: But they have found him alive, hiding in the country, and have brought him in.
vi: But people found out he was still alive, hiding in the countryside, and brought him back here.
tr: But they found him hiding in a rural area and brought him back.
es: But he has been found alive, hiding in the countryside, and they have brought him here.

en: I have seen him but now, on his way to the Hotel de Ville, a prisoner.
vi: I just saw him, the criminal, being escorted to the City Hall.
tr: I had seen him, but now he is being taken to the City Hall as a prisoner.
es: I just saw him this moment while they were taking him prisoner to the Hôtel de Ville.

en: I have said that he had reason to fear us.
vi: I said that this old man is afraid of us, and that's true.
tr: I said he was right to be afraid of us.
es: I said that he feared us with reason...

en: Say all!
vi: Everyone, speak up!
tr: Tell me!
es: Tell me...!

en: Had he reason?”
vi: Isn't that right?
tr: Is he right or not?"
es: Did he fear us with reason?

en: Wretched old sinner of more than threescore years and ten, if he had never known it yet, he would have known it in his heart of hearts if he could have heard the answering cry.
vi: If that unfortunate old criminal, over seventy years old, had never known this before, he would now remember it deeply if he heard the unanimous shout of everyone's response.
tr: If this miserable sinner, who had reached the age of seventy, had heard these cries, even if he had not yet found the answer, he would certainly have felt it deep in his heart.
es: The blood of that ancient sinner would have frozen if the fierce cry that came from the monster's jaws had reached his ears.

en: A moment of profound silence followed.
vi: A moment of profound silence followed.
tr: Then there was a silence that penetrated deep into the soul.
es: A few moments of deep silence followed.

en: Defarge and his wife looked steadfastly at one another.
vi: Defarge and his wife looked straight at each other.
tr: Defarge and his wife looked at each other resolutely.
es: Defarge and his wife stared at each other with a terrifying intensity; La Vengeance remained motionless, and a drum rolled in the distance while behind the counter there was a sound like moving feet.

en: The Vengeance stooped, and the jar of a drum was heard as she moved it at her feet behind the counter.
vi: The Goddess of Retribution bent down, and a sound like a loud drum was the noise of her feet stomping hard behind the wine counter.
tr: Revenge was leaning behind the counter, moving the drum at his feet.
es: Defarge and his wife stared at each other with a terrifying intensity; La Vengeance remained motionless, and a drum rolled in the distance while behind the counter there was a sound like moving feet.

en: “Patriots!” said Defarge, in a determined voice, “are we ready?”
vi: − O patriots! - Defarge shouted resolutely. Ready?
tr: "Comrades!" cried Defarge in a determined voice. "Are we ready?"
es: —Patriots! —shouted Defarge with a resolute voice. —Are we ready?

en: Instantly Madame Defarge’s knife was in her girdle; the drum was beating in the streets, as if it and a drummer had flown together by magic; and The Vengeance, uttering terrific shrieks, and flinging her arms about her head like all the forty Furies at once, was tearing from house to house, rousing the women.
vi: Immediately, Madame Defarge's knife was tucked into her back; the footsteps thundered on the road as if some magic had granted the crowd a drummer to accompany them; the Goddess of Vengeance screamed a terrifying cry, raising both hands above her head as if summoning all forty avenging deities at once, running from house to house inciting the women.
tr: Madame Defarge immediately tucked her knife into her belt; the drum was thundering in the streets, as if the drummer and his drum had magically vanished, and Vengeance, with terrifying screams and her arms raised like the Furies, was going door to door rousing the women.
es: Immediately, the long knife appeared at the waist of the innkeeper, drums rolled through the streets, as if they and those who struck their patches had sprung up by magical arts, and La Venganza, letting out ferocious screams, with her hair loose and waving her arms above her head, resembling not one, but all forty Furies together, ran from house to house inciting the women.

vi: Immediately, Madame Defarge's knife was tucked into her back; the footsteps thundered on the road as if some magic had granted the crowd a drummer to accompany them; the Goddess of Vengeance screamed a terrifying cry, raising both hands above her head as if summoning all forty avenging deities at once, running from house to house inciting the women.
tr: Madame Defarge immediately tucked her knife into her belt; the drum was thundering in the streets, as if the drummer and his drum had magically vanished, and Vengeance, with terrifying screams and her arms raised like the Furies, was going door to door rousing the women.
es: Immediately, the long knife appeared at the waist of the innkeeper, drums rolled through the streets, as if they and those who struck their patches had sprung up by magical arts, and La Venganza, letting out ferocious screams, with her hair loose and waving her arms above her head, resembling not one, but all forty Furies together, ran from house to house inciting the women.

en: Original
vi: Immediately, Madame Defarge's knife was tucked into her back; the footsteps thundered on the road as if some magic had granted the crowd a drummer to accompany them; the Goddess of Vengeance screamed a terrifying cry, raising both hands above her head as if summoning all forty avenging deities at once, running from house to house inciting the women.
tr: Men were terrifying as they looked out from the windows with their cruel rage, armed with whatever weapons they could find, mingling with the flood of people in the streets, but the state of the women was enough to freeze the blood of even the bravest person.
es: Immediately, the long knife appeared at the waist of the innkeeper, drums rolled through the streets, as if they and those who struck their patches had sprung up by magical arts, and La Venganza, letting out ferocious screams, with her hair loose and waving her arms above her head, resembling not one, but all forty Furies together, ran from house to house inciting the women.

en: The men were terrible, in the bloody-minded anger with which they looked from windows, caught up what arms they had, and came pouring down into the streets; but, the women were a sight to chill the boldest.
vi: The terrifying men, their hearts boiling with rage, stood in the windows looking out, grabbing any weapon they could find, and rushed out into the streets; but it was the women who presented a sight that made even the bravest shudder.
tr: Men were terrifying as they looked out from the windows with their cruel rage, armed with whatever weapons they could find, mingling with the flood of people in the streets, but the state of the women was enough to freeze the blood of even the bravest person.
es: Terrible was the expression of the men who, thirsty for blood, stuck their heads out of the windows; even more terrible was that of those who, wielding the most deadly weapons they could get their hands on, came out of the doors of the houses and spread furiously through the streets; but the expression of the women was enough to freeze the blood of the most fearless man.

en: From such household occupations as their bare poverty yielded, from their children, from their aged and their sick crouching on the bare ground famished and naked, they ran out with streaming hair, urging one another, and themselves, to madness with the wildest cries and actions.
vi: Leaving behind the remnants of their household chores in poverty, leaving behind their young children, the elderly, and the sick, who were crawling in hunger on the bare ground, the women let their hair down and ran out, urging each other and themselves to join the frenzy with the wildest screams and actions.
tr: Leaving behind all the work in their barely subsisting homes, their children, their elderly, and their starving, ailing loved ones who were languishing in desolate places, they threw themselves into the streets with their hair flowing, inciting both each other and themselves with wild screams and behaviors.
es: Abandoning the domestic tasks imposed by their misery, leaving their old and their children, naked and starving, lying on the hard ground, they went out into the street, their hair loose, trampling over each other, howling like maddened beasts and acting as such.

en: Villain Foulon taken, my sister!
vi: The thug Foulon has been caught, sisters!
tr: Foulon the murderer has been caught, my brother!
es: —Die, Foulon, who stole my sister!

en: Old Foulon taken, my mother!
vi: Foulon has been caught, mother!
tr: Foulon the murderer has been caught, my mother!
es: —Death to the villain Foulon, who robbed my mother!

en: Miscreant Foulon taken, my daughter!
vi: The scoundrel Foulon has been caught, daughters!
tr: Foulon the tyrant has been caught, my daughter!
es: —Die, scoundrel Foulon, who stole my daughter from me!

en: Then, a score of others ran into the midst of these, beating their breasts, tearing their hair, and screaming, Foulon alive!
vi: Then dozens and dozens of women ran into the crowd, beating their chests, tearing their hair, screaming, Foulon is still alive!
tr: Then a group joined them, beating their chests, tearing their hair, and shouting, Foulon is alive!
es: Others, in large groups, penetrated among those who had previously shouted and, striking their chests fiercely and tearing at their hair, they vociferated: —Foulon alive!

en: Foulon who told the starving people they might eat grass!
vi: Foulon told the starving to eat grass!
tr: Foulon, who told the starving people to eat grass!
es: He who told the starving people to eat grass must not live!

en: Foulon who told my old father that he might eat grass, when I had no bread to give him!
vi: Foulon told my old father to eat grass when I had no bread left for him!
tr: Foulon, who told my old father, to whom I couldn't give a piece of bread, to eat grass!
es: The demon who told me to give grass to my mother when bread was lacking cannot live!

en: Foulon who told my baby it might suck grass, when these breasts were dry with want!
vi: Foulon told my nursing infant to eat grass when my breasts had dried up and had no milk for my child!
tr: Foulon, who told the baby that couldn't suckle from its mother's dry breast to suck on grass!
es: The monster who told me to give grass to suck on, when my breasts, dried up from hunger, could not provide the milk needed to live, will not live!

en: O mother of God, this Foulon!
vi: Oh Mother Mary, this name Foulon!
tr: Oh, this Foulon!
es: —Holy Virgin!

en: O Heaven our suffering!
vi: Oh God, why is this suffering so great!
tr: My God, what pains we have suffered!
es: —others exclaimed.

en: Hear me, my dead baby and my withered father: I swear on my knees, on these stones, to avenge you on Foulon!
vi: Hear me, oh my dead child! Hear me, oh my withered old father! I kneel on these stones and swear to kill Foulon to avenge you, my child, my father!
tr: Hear me, my dead baby and my withering father! I swear on this stone and soil that I will take revenge on Foulon for you!
es: —Listen to me, my son, from the other world to which the inhuman Foulon took you! Listen to me, my father, who died of hunger because of him! By your bones, by your soul, I swear to avenge you on the person of Foulon!

en: Husbands, and brothers, and young men, Give us the blood of Foulon, Give us the head of Foulon, Give us the heart of Foulon, Give us the body and soul of Foulon, Rend Foulon to pieces, and dig him into the ground, that grass may grow from him!
vi: Husband, brother, give me Foulon's blood to drink! Cut off Foulon's head for me! Tear out Foulon's heart for me! Give me Foulon's body and soul! Dismember Foulon, bury him so that grass will grow green on his grave!
tr: Husbands, brothers, and young men, bring us Foulon's blood! Bring us Foulon's head! Bring us Foulon's heart, bring us Foulon's body and soul, tear Foulon apart and bury him so that grass grows on him!
es: —Husbands... give us the blood of Foulon! Young fathers, give us the head of Foulon! Brothers, give us the heart of Foulon! Young patriots, give us the body and soul of Foulon, tear apart the miserable corpse of Foulon, bury it, so that it may fertilize the land and grass may grow over his remains, the grass he advised us to eat!

en: With these cries, numbers of the women, lashed into blind frenzy, whirled about, striking and tearing at their own friends until they dropped into a passionate swoon, and were only saved by the men belonging to them from being trampled under foot.
vi: Screaming like this, waves of women driven to blind madness, kept spinning, hitting, and tearing at each other until they collapsed unconscious from the frenzy, only to be saved from being trampled by their husbands, fathers, and brothers.
tr: A multitude of women, screaming like mad, attacked everything around them, whirling about, hitting their friends and tearing their clothes until they fainted from rage, and only their men could save them from being trampled underfoot.
es: These and other no less terrifying screams drove many women to frenzy, who, after running with insane fury, howling like beasts, and hitting and scratching their own friends, rolled on the ground with their eyes out of their sockets and their mouths foaming. Thanks to their relatives or friends lifting them up, they did not die crushed under the thousands of beastly feet.

en: Nevertheless, not a moment was lost; not a moment!
vi: However, the group did not delay at all; not for a single moment!
tr: Still, no time had been wasted!
es: Not a moment was lost.

en: This Foulon was at the Hotel de Ville, and might be loosed.
vi: This Fouton guy is at City Hall and could escape.
tr: This man called Foulon was at the City Hall and could be released.
es: Foulon was at the Hôtel de Ville where he might be set free...

en: Never, if Saint Antoine knew his own sufferings, insults, and wrongs!
vi: No way, if the people of Saint Antoine knew all the suffering, humiliation, and wrongs they had to endure!
tr: However, St Antoine, who had suffered so much pain, insult, and injustice, would never allow this!
es: Would San Antonio tolerate such mockery? Never, if he had not lost the notion of his dignity, the memory of his sufferings, of his insults, of his injustices!

en: Armed men and women flocked out of the Quarter so fast, and drew even these last dregs after them with such a force of suction, that within a quarter of an hour there was not a human creature in Saint Antoine’s bosom but a few old crones and the wailing children.
vi: A group of men and women, armed, quickly surged out of this area, with a powerful force sweeping everyone along, rushing so fast that within fifteen minutes, there was no one left in the heart of Saint Antoine except for a few elderly and crying children.
tr: Armed men and women swiftly left the neighborhood in droves, and they pulled the remaining stragglers towards them with such force that within fifteen minutes, there was no one left in the heart of St Antoine except for a few old women and wailing children.
es: A flood of armed men and disheveled women soon overflowed the district's boundaries, dragging with it every human creature raised on the dry breasts of San Antonio, with the exception of a few decrepit old men and some children unable to walk.

en: No.
vi: No.
tr: No one.
es: A flood of armed men and disheveled women soon overflowed the district's boundaries, dragging with it every human creature raised on the dry breasts of San Antonio, with the exception of a few decrepit old men and some children unable to walk.

en: They were all by that time choking the Hall of Examination where this old man, ugly and wicked, was, and overflowing into the adjacent open space and streets.
vi: By that time, everyone had crowded into the City Hall, now turned into the Court of Justice - where that vile, evil old man was present - or spilled out into the nearby open spaces and streets.
tr: At that moment, they had all crowded into the interrogation room where this old, ugly, and treacherous man was, and they had even spilled into the adjacent courtyard and streets.
es: The mobs have already entered the room where they are taking the old man's statement, who may have been ruthless, but at that moment was deserving of compassion.

en: The Defarges, husband and wife, The Vengeance, and Jacques Three, were in the first press, and at no great distance from him in the Hall.
vi: The Defarges, both husband and wife, the Goddess of Vengeance, and Jacques Three, were among the first to push in, and stood not far from Foulon.
tr: The Defarges, husband and wife, Revenge, and Jacques Three were always at the forefront, and in the room, they were standing just a little away from Foulon.
es: In a prominent place, in the front row, a short distance from the prisoner, are the Defarges, husband and wife, La Vengeance, and Jacques Three.

en: “See!” cried madame, pointing with her knife.
vi: − Kia! - Mrs. Defarge shouted loudly, raising her knife.
tr: Pointing with her knife, "Look at that!" shouted the madam.
es: —Look at him! —shouts the innkeeper, pointing at him with the tip of the knife. —

en: “See the old villain bound with ropes.
vi: - Look at that wicked old man tied up over there.
tr: "Look, they've tied up the old man with ropes.
es: There you have the old villain tied up with ropes!

en: That was well done to tie a bunch of grass upon his back.
vi: They've tied a bundle of grass on his back too, how wonderful.
tr: It's a good idea to tie a bunch of grass to his back.
es: It wouldn't be a bad idea to tie a bundle of grass to his back!

en: Ha, ha!
vi: Ha ha!
tr: Ha ha!
es: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

en: That was well done.
vi: So wonderful.
tr: They had a very clever idea.
es: It's the best we can do... force him to eat grass!

en: Let him eat it now!”
vi: Make him eat the grass! -
tr: Now let him eat it!"
es: It's the best we can do... force him to eat grass!

en: Madame put her knife under her arm, and clapped her hands as at a play.
vi: She tucked the knife under her arm and clapped her hands as if watching a play.
tr: The madam had tucked her knife under her arm and was clapping her hands as if she were in a play.
es: The innkeeper placed her knife under her arm and applauded herself.

en: The people immediately behind Madame Defarge, explaining the cause of her satisfaction to those behind them, and those again explaining to others, and those to others, the neighbouring streets resounded with the clapping of hands.
vi: The people standing right behind Madame Defarge explained the reason for her satisfaction to those behind them, and these people would explain to others, and so on; thus, the nearby streets also resounded with applause.
tr: The people standing right behind Madam Defarge explained to those behind them why the woman was so delighted, then they explained to those behind them, and they to those behind them, until all the surrounding streets echoed with applause.
es: As the people who were positioned behind Madame Defarge hurried to explain to those following them the cause of her satisfaction, and the explanation spread from ear to ear like wildfire, soon deafening applause resounded in the hall, in the street, and in the nearby squares.
