vi: Perhaps Mr. Gabelle had spent a long night on the rooftop, with the distant castle as a lantern, and the sound of knocking along with the jubilant church bells as music; not to mention the ominous lantern swaying across the street in front of the post station gate where the excited villagers wanted to hang him instead.
tr: The night, accompanied by the image of the distant castle that gave him warmth and light, the knocking door, and the cheerful bell music, probably seemed never-ending for Monsieur Gabelle; the ominous lamp swinging directly opposite the post office door only added salt to the wound, as the villagers were very eager to use it in his honor.
es: It is more than likely that the night seemed eternal to Mr. Gabelle, for it is indeed not very pleasant to spend it on the roof, watching from afar the sinister glow of a burning castle, listening to the blows that an enraged crowd delivers against the door of his house, and above all, seeing a lantern hanging from its post, which the crowd looked at from time to time with the desire to replace it with another object, which very well could be his body.

en: A trying suspense, to be passing a whole summer night on the brink of the black ocean, ready to take that plunge into it upon which Monsieur Gabelle had resolved!
vi: A perilous and tense situation when having to spend the entire summer night on that dark brink, ready to plunge into the sea of people as Mr. Gabelle had resolved!
tr: Spending an entire summer night waiting on the shore of a dark ocean, ready to jump at any moment according to his decision, was a highly distressing situation for Monsieur Gabelle!
es: It is indeed sad to spend an entire summer night on the eaves of a roof, watching at your feet an ocean of tumultuous black waves, and resolved to throw yourself headfirst into its center; but at last a cheerful dawn appeared, the lights went out, the crowd dispersed, and Mr. Gabelle was able to come out of the ordeal alive.

en: But, the friendly dawn appearing at last, and the rush-candles of the village guttering out, the people happily dispersed, and Monsieur Gabelle came down bringing his life with him for that while.
vi: But the friendly dawn finally arrived, the village candles had burned out, the people cheerfully dispersed, and Mr. Gabelle descended from the rooftop, temporarily preserving his life.
tr: But finally, when the sweet dawn broke, and the flickering candles burning in the village melted away, people dispersed in joy, and Monsieur Gabelle, with his life still intact for now, descended.
es: It is indeed sad to spend an entire summer night on the eaves of a roof, watching at your feet an ocean of tumultuous black waves, and resolved to throw yourself headfirst into its center; but at last a cheerful dawn appeared, the lights went out, the crowd dispersed, and Mr. Gabelle was able to come out of the ordeal alive.

en: Within a hundred miles, and in the light of other fires, there were other functionaries less fortunate, that night and other nights, whom the rising sun found hanging across once-peaceful streets, where they had been born and bred; also, there were other villagers and townspeople less fortunate than the mender of roads and his fellows, upon whom the functionaries and soldiery turned with success, and whom they strung up in their turn.
vi: Within a hundred miles, in the light of the fires of other blazes that night and many more nights, there were officials less fortunate when the sun rose to witness their bodies hanging on the once peaceful streets where they had grown up. And there were also villagers and townsfolk less fortunate than the road worker and his village friends, when the authorities and soldiers reversed the situation and it was their turn to hang civilians.
tr: Within an area of approximately one hundred and seventy kilometers and in the light of other fires, the sun rising at the end of that night and other nights found other tax collectors who were not as lucky as Gabelle hanging in the old peaceful streets where they were born and raised; on the other hand, there were other peasants and townspeople who were not as lucky as the road worker and his comrades, and in situations where the tax collectors and soldiers prevailed, this time they were the ones hanging from the poles.
es: Within a radius of one hundred miles, and in the light of other fires, there were that night, and other nights, many officials less fortunate than Mr. Gabelle, whom the sun of the new day found hanging in the same streets, peaceful in better times, where they were born and grew up. It is true that there were also other villagers, other citizens who, less fortunate than the road worker and his two hundred and fifty particular friends, fell to the blows of the officials and soldiers.

en: But, the fierce figures were steadily wending East, West, North, and South, be that as it would; and whosoever hung, fire burned.
vi: But those fierce figures still steadily moved in all four directions—east, west, south, north—marching regardless of the circumstances; and no matter who was hanged, the fires still burned.
tr: But the furious four continued to advance steadily to the east, west, north, and south, hanging whoever came in their way, burning and destroying everything.
es: But the fierce bearers of the fire continued their race towards the East and the West, to the North and the South, marking their passage with trails of flames, and there was no official, however versed in mathematics, capable of calculating the height of the gallows necessary to contain or divert the course of the plunging torrent.

en: The altitude of the gallows that would turn to water and quench it, no functionary, by any stretch of mathematics, was able to calculate successfully.
vi: How high must the gallows be to stop those flames?
tr: No official, no matter how much they thought and calculated, could bring the water to the height of the gallows to extinguish it.
es: But the fierce bearers of the fire continued their race towards the East and the West, to the North and the South, marking their passage with trails of flames, and there was no official, however versed in mathematics, capable of calculating the height of the gallows necessary to contain or divert the course of the plunging torrent.

en: CHAPTER XXIV.
vi: No matter how many calculations were made, no official could find the answer.
tr: XXIV
es: XXIV.

en: Drawn to the Loadstone Rock
vi: 24. Magnet Mountain
tr: Drifting Towards the "Magnet Rock Cliff"
es: ATTRACTED BY THE MAGNETIC MOUNTAIN

en: In such risings of fire and risings of sea—the firm earth shaken by the rushes of an angry ocean which had now no ebb, but was always on the flow, higher and higher, to the terror and wonder of the beholders on the shore—three years of tempest were consumed.
vi: Three years of devastating storms have passed, waves of blazing fire and fierce currents, the solid ground trembling under the hurried steps of an unrelenting ocean that only ever surged, growing more ferocious with each moment, to the horror and astonishment of those witnessing from the shore.
tr: Amidst rising fires and swelling seas – even the land, which stood firm against the raging ocean's assault, had shifted, and the receding of the seawater was out of the question now, it kept rising continuously in front of the anxious and curious eyes waiting on the shore – three stormy years had passed.
es: Three years the storms lasted, three years during which the oceans roared incessantly and flames raged everywhere, three years of continuous terrors for those who watched from the shore the ever-growing fury of the seas.

en: Three more birthdays of little Lucie had been woven by the golden thread into the peaceful tissue of the life of her home.
vi: Three more of little Lucie's birthdays have been woven with golden threads into the fabric of peace of the home.
tr: In little Lucie's house, three birthdays had been woven into the peaceful fabric of the home with golden threads.
es: Three more birthdays did little Lucia see, in whose peaceful existence her loving mother never ceased to weave new threads of gold.

en: Many a night and many a day had its inmates listened to the echoes in the corner, with hearts that failed them when they heard the thronging feet.
vi: For days and nights, the members of that family listened to the echoes on the street corner, their hearts nearly stopping at the sound of the numerous, hurried footsteps.
tr: There were such days and nights that the residents of the house listened to the sounds coming from the corner, and when they realized these were footsteps, their hearts skipped a beat.
es: More than a day and more than a night, the residents of the quiet corner of Soho listened with bitter pain to the sound of footsteps that hurt their ears, for they knew they were the footsteps of enraged people, running tumultuously under the shadow of red banners, they knew their homeland had been declared in danger, that its inhabitants had transformed from human beings into ferocious beasts.

en: For, the footsteps had become to their minds as the footsteps of a people, tumultuous under a red flag and with their country declared in danger, changed into wild beasts, by terrible enchantment long persisted in.
vi: Because in their minds, those footsteps were the steps of a nation, bustling under the red flag, and when that country declared a state of emergency, the dreadful, long-lasting spell turned everyone into a pack of wild beasts.
tr: For according to them, these sounds were from noisy people walking under a red flag, who turned into terrifying creatures when it was declared that their country was in danger, and who had long been part of this spell.
es: More than a day and more than a night, the residents of the quiet corner of Soho listened with bitter pain to the sound of footsteps that hurt their ears, for they knew they were the footsteps of enraged people, running tumultuously under the shadow of red banners, they knew their homeland had been declared in danger, that its inhabitants had transformed from human beings into ferocious beasts.

en: Monseigneur, as a class, had dissociated himself from the phenomenon of his not being appreciated: of his being so little wanted in France, as to incur considerable danger of receiving his dismissal from it, and this life together.
vi: The aristocracy, as a class, has isolated itself in the face of the public no longer respecting them: hardly anyone wants to see them in France, to the extent that their fate is at risk of being excluded from both that country and this world.
tr: Like others in his class, the Monsignor had not spent much time pondering the thought of being unappreciated, but he was quick to realize the fact that he was no longer wanted in France, and thus was in danger of being sent away from here, or even from this world.
es: The gentleman, as a class, could not understand the phenomenon of not being appreciated, of not being needed in France, of not being loved, of being hated to the point of facing imminent danger of being expelled from French soil and from the world of the living at the same time.

en: Like the fabled rustic who raised the Devil with infinite pains, and was so terrified at the sight of him that he could ask the Enemy no question, but immediately fled; so, Monseigneur, after boldly reading the Lord’s Prayer backwards for a great number of years, and performing many other potent spells for compelling the Evil One, no sooner beheld him in his terrors than he took to his noble heels.
vi: Just like the peasant in the fairy tale who spent so much effort summoning the devil but fled in terror upon seeing its face, not daring to ask the enemy a single question; the aristocracy, after brazenly reciting the Lord's Prayer backwards for so many years*, and using countless powerful spells to lure Satan, were terrified and fled at the sight of the Devil, losing their noble legs in the process.
tr: The Monsignor's situation was just like the peasant in the fable, who, after raising the Devil with great difficulty and then being terrified by its appearance, fled without asking his Enemy anything; after years of recklessly disregarding God's commands and performing powerful spells that revived Evil, he chose to grease his noble heels and run away instead of standing there and continuing to watch this horror.
es: Similar to the rustic man in the fable who, after having managed to summon the devil through persistent invocations, was so terrified upon seeing him that he couldn't even muster the voice to ask a question of the enemy, so too did the gentleman, after having the audacity to pray the Lord's Prayer backwards for several years and employing the most potent spells and charms to awaken the demon, hasten to show his noble and high-born heels as soon as he caught a glimpse of him.

en: The shining Bull’s Eye of the Court was gone, or it would have been the mark for a hurricane of national bullets.
vi: The brilliant elite group of the court has disappeared; otherwise, they would have become the target of the national guard's storm of bullets.
tr: The palace no longer had its glittering window, and even if it had remained, it would have been a target for the people's rain of bullets.
es: The brilliant sky of the court had been eclipsed, convinced that it would be the inevitable target of the relentless rain of bullets from the people.

en: It had never been a good eye to see with—had long had the mote in it of Lucifer’s pride, Sardanapalus’s luxury, and a mole’s blindness—but it had dropped out and was gone.
vi: These elites have always been an eyesore - they have long been as arrogant as Lucifer*, as extravagant as King Sardanapalus*, and as blind as a mole - but now they have completely vanished.
tr: This had never been a window looked upon favorably by people – it always contained traces of Lucifer's pride, Sardanapalus's splendor, and a mole's blindness – but it had now disappeared.
es: It was never a favorite of theirs, for according to malicious tongues, Satan had inoculated him with his pride and Sardanapalus with his luxury and indulgence.

en: The Court, from that exclusive inner circle to its outermost rotten ring of intrigue, corruption, and dissimulation, was all gone together.
vi: The court, from the privileged inner circle to the corrupt, scheming, degenerate, and deceitful ones on the fringes, all have gone at once.
tr: Everything from the privileged inner circle of the palace to its intrigue, corruption, and hypocrisy-filled outer circle had come to an end.
es: The entire court, from its central and exclusive point to all the rotten points of its circumference of intrigues, corruption, and dissimulation, had abandoned that unhealthy atmosphere.

en: Royalty was gone; had been besieged in its Palace and “suspended,” when the last tidings came over.
vi: The royal family is no more; they have been confined in the palace and "suspended," according to the latest circulating news.
tr: The monarchy had ended; with the arrival of the final waves, it had been cornered and "suspended" in its own Palace."
es: The royalty had also disappeared: besieged in its palace, it was "suspended" when the furious waves reached it.

en: The August of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two was come, and Monseigneur was by this time scattered far and wide.
vi: By August 1792, the high-ranking officials had dispersed in all directions.
tr: By the time August of the year 1792 arrived, Monseigneur was already far away.
es: In the month of August in the year seventeen ninety-two, the caste of the lords was scattered around the world.

en: As was natural, the head-quarters and great gathering-place of Monseigneur, in London, was Tellson’s Bank.
vi: Of course, the headquarters and the meeting place of the high-ranking French officials in London was Tellson's Bank.
tr: Naturally, the headquarters of the Monsignor in London and the meeting place with others was Tellson Bank.
es: As is natural, the headquarters, the meeting center of the gentry in London was the Tellson Bank.

en: Spirits are supposed to haunt the places where their bodies most resorted, and Monseigneur without a guinea haunted the spot where his guineas used to be.
vi: It is said that spirits often haunt the places they frequented most in life, and the destitute nobles would haunt the place that once held their wealth.
tr: Spirits are said to wander where their bodies were most often during their lifetime; the penniless Monsignor was now where his money once lay.
es: They say that spirits haunt the places where their bodies are buried, and in accordance with this law, the penniless gentleman haunted the place where in better times his money had been deposited.

en: Moreover, it was the spot to which such French intelligence as was most to be relied upon, came quickest.
vi: Moreover, it was the place where news from France arrived the fastest and was the most reliable.
tr: Moreover, this was the first point where the most reliable news from France arrived.
es: Moreover, the Tellson Bank was the center where news from France arrived most quickly: it extended its generosity to the point of making advances to those who had been its clients in prosperous times; it kept immense sums deposited by nobles who, more foresighted than the majority, saw the storm brewing and preempted thefts and confiscations, and finally, all the people arriving from France began by showing up at the Tellson Bank, where they recounted the latest events.

en: Again: Tellson’s was a munificent house, and extended great liberality to old customers who had fallen from their high estate.
vi: Furthermore, Tellson's was a generous firm, extremely kind to its former clients who had fallen on hard times.
tr: Furthermore, Tellson Bank was a generous institution and behaved with great liberality towards its former clients who had lost their property.
es: Moreover, the Tellson Bank was the center where news from France arrived most quickly: it extended its generosity to the point of making advances to those who had been its clients in prosperous times; it kept immense sums deposited by nobles who, more foresighted than the majority, saw the storm brewing and preempted thefts and confiscations, and finally, all the people arriving from France began by showing up at the Tellson Bank, where they recounted the latest events.

en: Again: those nobles who had seen the coming storm in time, and anticipating plunder or confiscation, had made provident remittances to Tellson’s, were always to be heard of there by their needy brethren.
vi: Additionally, the nobles who foresaw the coming storm and feared looting or confiscation had prudently entrusted their money to Tellson's, making it also a place where their impoverished brethren came to inquire.
tr: Additionally, some nobles, who foresaw the approaching storm and expected looting and foreclosure, prudently transferred their money to Tellson in England, which was known to other impoverished members of the order.
es: Moreover, the Tellson Bank was the center where news from France arrived most quickly: it extended its generosity to the point of making advances to those who had been its clients in prosperous times; it kept immense sums deposited by nobles who, more foresighted than the majority, saw the storm brewing and preempted thefts and confiscations, and finally, all the people arriving from France began by showing up at the Tellson Bank, where they recounted the latest events.

en: To which it must be added that every new-comer from France reported himself and his tidings at Tellson’s, almost as a matter of course.
vi: It must also be mentioned that anyone newly arrived from France would come to Tellson's to report news and describe the situation, almost as a matter of course.
tr: It should be added at this point that every newcomer from France both provided information about themselves and brought news to Tellson.
es: Moreover, the Tellson Bank was the center where news from France arrived most quickly: it extended its generosity to the point of making advances to those who had been its clients in prosperous times; it kept immense sums deposited by nobles who, more foresighted than the majority, saw the storm brewing and preempted thefts and confiscations, and finally, all the people arriving from France began by showing up at the Tellson Bank, where they recounted the latest events.

en: For such variety of reasons, Tellson’s was at that time, as to French intelligence, a kind of High Exchange; and this was so well known to the public, and the inquiries made there were in consequence so numerous, that Tellson’s sometimes wrote the latest news out in a line or so and posted it in the Bank windows, for all who ran through Temple Bar to read.
vi: For these reasons, Tellson's at that time resembled a hub for information from France; this was well known and people flocked there in such numbers to seek news that Tellson's often had to write brief notes of the latest news and post them on the bank's window for everyone passing by Temple Bar to read.
tr: For these reasons, at that time, Tellson had become a kind of information repository for the French; this was well known by the public, and the number of those asking questions to obtain information had increased so much that Tellson sometimes posted the latest news in a few lines on the windows of the bank for those coming and going at Temple Bar to read.
es: For all these various reasons, the Tellson Bank at that time was a kind of Stock Exchange Palace as far as French matters or people were concerned, a circumstance so well known to the public, and which gave rise to so many questions and commissions, that the latest news was often posted on placards hung from the building's windows, so that all who passed in front of the Temple Bar could read them.

en: On a steaming, misty afternoon, mr Lorry sat at his desk, and Charles Darnay stood leaning on it, talking with him in a low voice.
vi: On a foggy afternoon, Mr. Lorry sat by the desk, while Charles Darnay leaned against it, speaking in a low voice.
tr: On a hazy and murky afternoon, Mr. Lorry was seated at his desk, with Charles Darnay leaning over beside him, whispering something to him in a low voice.
es: A misty and sweltering afternoon, Lorry and Charles Darnay, seated across from each other at the former's desk, were conversing in low voices.

en: The penitential den once set apart for interviews with the House, was now the news-Exchange, and was filled to overflowing.
vi: This confessional room, once reserved for meetings with the Master, had now become an information center, overflowing with news.
tr: In the sanctuary of atonement, which was initially reserved for company meetings, a tremendous exchange of information was now taking place, and the room was overflowing.
es: A misty and sweltering afternoon, Lorry and Charles Darnay, seated across from each other at the former's desk, were conversing in low voices.

en: It was within half an hour or so of the time of closing.
vi: There was about half an hour left until closing time.
tr: There was approximately half an hour left until the bank closed.
es: There would be about half an hour left before closing the establishment.

en: “But, although you are the youngest man that ever lived,” said Charles Darnay, rather hesitating, “I must still suggest to you—”
vi: − But although no one has ever matched your strength, Charles Darnay said, hesitating slightly, - I must suggest to you that...
tr: "But despite being the most youthful-spirited person I have ever seen," said Darnay, hesitating a bit, "what I want to say is..."
es: —I know that you are the youngest man who has ever existed in the world;—said Charles Darnay with signs of hesitation,—but even so, forgive me for saying...

en: “I understand.
vi: − I understand.
tr: "I understand, okay.
es: —I understand: that I am very old, right?—interrupted Lorry.

en: That I am too old?” said mr Lorry.
vi: It's because I'm too old, right? - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: Am I too old?" asked Mr. Lorry.
es: —I understand: that I am very old, right?—interrupted Lorry.

en: “Unsettled weather, a long journey, uncertain means of travelling, a disorganised country, a city that may not be even safe for you.”
vi: − The weather is unpredictable, the journey is long, the means of travel are uncertain, the country is in chaos, and the capital city might not even be safe for you.
tr: "What I mean is, the weather is unstable, the road is very long, it's unclear how you will travel, the country is in chaos, and the city is not safe for you at all."
es: —Uncertain weather, long journey, uncertain means, and a country in a state of anarchy, not to mention a city that cannot even offer you guarantees.

en: “My dear Charles,” said mr Lorry, with cheerful confidence, “you touch some of the reasons for my going: not for my staying away.
vi: − Charles, - Mr. Lorry said, in a confident and cheerful voice, - you have pointed out exactly the reasons why I must go, not why I should stay.
tr: "Dear Charles!" said Mr. Lorry, in a cheerful confidence, "You mentioned some reasons explaining my departure, not reasons requiring me to stay elsewhere.
es: —My dear Carlos—replied Lorry confidently,—the reasons you have just pointed out, far from discouraging me, far from conspiring against my plan to make the trip, conspire for me to do it.

en: It is safe enough for me; nobody will care to interfere with an old fellow of hard upon fourscore when there are so many people there much better worth interfering with.
vi: What is there that is not safe; no one would want to mess with an old man nearly eighty when there are many others more worth messing with.
tr: There is nothing to fear; with so many people worth dealing with around, no one would bother with an old man like me who is nearing eighty.
es: No one will have the bad taste to mess with an old man of almost eighty years, when they can do so with so many other young, robust people, who are more worthy of that honor than I am.

en: As to its being a disorganised city, if it were not a disorganised city there would be no occasion to send somebody from our House here to our House there, who knows the city and the business, of old, and is in Tellson’s confidence.
vi: As for the chaos in the capital, if there were no chaotic cities, there would be no occasion for this company to send someone from here to a branch there, someone familiar with the place and the old job, and trusted by Tellson.
tr: As for the city's turmoil, if there wasn't such a situation, they wouldn't send someone to that branch, someone who has known the city and the business for a long time, on behalf of Tellson.
es: You say that it is a disorganized city, and I reply that, if order reigned there, I don't know why our house here would have to send to our house there someone who has long known the city and the city's business, and also possesses Tellson's trust.

en: As to the uncertain travelling, the long journey, and the winter weather, if I were not prepared to submit myself to a few inconveniences for the sake of Tellson’s, after all these years, who ought to be?”
vi: As for the unsafe roads, the long journey, and the winter weather, if we are not ready to accept a few inconveniences for the benefit of Tellson, after all these years, then who else will?
tr: As for the uncertainty of travel means, the length of the journey, and adverse weather conditions, if I don't endure this small hardship for Tellson after all these years, who will?"
es: As for the inconveniences that may arise from the uncertainty of the means of transportation, the length of the trip, and the unpredictability of the weather, if I were not willing to face all those inconveniences in service to the house, after having grown old in it, who would be?

en: “I wish I were going myself,” said Charles Darnay, somewhat restlessly, and like one thinking aloud.
vi: − I wish I could go myself, - Charles Darnay said, somewhat regretfully, like a man thinking out loud.
tr: "I wish I had gone," said Charles Darnay, somewhat uneasy and as if thinking aloud.
es: —I wish I could go myself—said Carlos, as if thinking out loud.

en: “Indeed!
vi: − Really! It's surprising that you want to intervene!
tr: "Oh dear, oh dear!"
es: —Man! —exclaimed Lorry.

en: You are a pretty fellow to object and advise!” exclaimed mr Lorry.
vi: - Mr. Lorry exclaimed.
tr: "Look at this sweet man who objects and gives me advice!" shouted Mr. Lorry.
es: —I see that you are a top-notch advisor and a counselor without equal!

en: “You wish you were going yourself?
vi: - Do you want to go yourself?
tr: "Did you say you wish you had gone instead?
es: So it’s you yourself, eh?

en: And you a Frenchman born?
vi: And you are French?
tr: And you are French.
es: And born in France, eh?

en: You are a wise counsellor.”
vi: What a wise idea!
tr: You are a smart man."
es: Good advice, my friend, good advice!

en: “My dear mr Lorry, it is because I am a Frenchman born, that the thought (which I did not mean to utter here, however) has passed through my mind often.
vi: Mr. Lorry, it's precisely because I am French that I often have that thought in my head, but I never intended to say it here.
tr: "Dear Mr. Lorry, since I am already French (actually, I didn't want to bring up this matter here), I want to go.
es: —Precisely because I was born in France, my dear Mr. Lorry, that thought has crossed and frequently crosses my mind.

en: One cannot help thinking, having had some sympathy for the miserable people, and having abandoned something to them,” he spoke here in his former thoughtful manner, “that one might be listened to, and might have the power to persuade to some restraint.
vi: I can't stop myself from having some sympathy for those wretched people, and having given up something for them, - he said again with a contemplative look as before, who knows, they might listen to me, who knows, I might have the ability to persuade them to restrain themselves somewhat.
tr: Those poor people can only listen to and be calmed by someone who understands their situation and has sacrificed a lot for them," Darnay said thoughtfully, as before.
es: I find it very natural for someone who retains some sympathy for that unfortunate people, who has left behind something that was theirs, and consequently believes that their voice would be heard, and that perhaps they could manage to contain the disorder a little bit, to think that way.

en: Only last night, after you had left us, when I was talking to Lucie—”
vi: Just last night, after you left, when I was talking to Lucie...
tr: Just last night, while talking to Lucie after you left..."
es: Just last night, after you said goodbye to us, I was telling Lucie...

en: “When you were talking to Lucie,” mr Lorry repeated.
vi: − When you were talking to Lucie, - Mr. Lorry repeated.
tr: "While talking to Lucie?" repeated Mr. Lorry.
es: —You were saying to Lucía!...—repeated Lorry.

en: “Yes.
vi: - Right.
tr: "Of course."
es: —Frankly!

en: I wonder you are not ashamed to mention the name of Lucie!
vi: I'm surprised you're not ashamed to mention Lucie's name!
tr: You say you wish to go to France, and then you don't feel ashamed to mention Lucie's name!"
es: I am amazed that you are not ashamed to mention Lucía's name at this moment! Good heavens!

en: Wishing you were going to France at this time of day!”
vi: And you want to go to France at this very moment too! −
tr: You say you wish to go to France, and then you don't feel ashamed to mention Lucie's name!"
es: Mentioning Lucía when you want to go to France under these circumstances!

en: “However, I am not going,” said Charles Darnay, with a smile.
vi: But I won't go, - Charles Darnay smiled.
tr: "I'm not going anyway," said Charles Darnay with a smile.
es: —I haven't gone yet! —replied Carlos, smiling.

en: “It is more to the purpose that you say you are.”
vi: - It is precisely for the reasons you mentioned that you must go.
tr: "You are the one who is actually planning this trip."
es: —More than for any other reason, I speak this way in order to counteract the intention you claim to have formed of going.

en: “And I am, in plain reality.
vi: − And obviously, we will go.
tr: "You are right.
es: —Yes, I have formed it, Carlos: nothing could be more certain. I am going to speak to you frankly, my dear friend.

en: The truth is, my dear Charles,” mr Lorry glanced at the distant House, and lowered his voice, “you can have no conception of the difficulty with which our business is transacted, and of the peril in which our books and papers over yonder are involved.
vi: Charles, the truth is, - Mr. Lorry glanced towards the Boss in the distance, then lowered his voice, - you can't imagine the difficulties in the firm's transactions and the risks related to the documents over there.
tr: Honestly, dear Charles," said Mr. Lorry, glancing at the distant bank manager and lowering his voice, "you cannot even imagine how difficult our work is and the danger that the papers and documents over there are in.
es: You cannot even imagine the difficulties that all our businesses encounter, nor the danger that threatens our books and documents over there.

en: The Lord above knows what the compromising consequences would be to numbers of people, if some of our documents were seized or destroyed; and they might be, at any time, you know, for who can say that Paris is not set afire to-day, or sacked to-morrow!
vi: Only God above knows what damage might befall many people if some of those documents were confiscated or destroyed; and it could happen at any time, you know, because who can say that Paris won't be set on fire today, or looted tomorrow!
tr: If some of our documents are seized or destroyed, God knows what troubles will befall us, how many lives will be turned upside down, and you know, this can happen at any moment. Who can say that Paris won't be set on fire or looted any day now?
es: Only God can know the fatal consequences that the loss or destruction of some of the documents stored there would entail for many people, and they are in danger of being lost, in danger of being destroyed, you know it as well as I do, as everyone knows. Who can say if today Paris will have burned from the four cardinal points, if tomorrow it will be looted in an orderly manner!

en: Now, a judicious selection from these with the least possible delay, and the burying of them, or otherwise getting of them out of harm’s way, is within the power (without loss of precious time) of scarcely any one but myself, if any one.
vi: So, if someone has to rush over there to carefully select those documents, bury them or store them in a safe place, only I am capable of doing it, and it must be done urgently.
tr: Therefore, without much delay, it falls to me to make a reasonable selection from these documents and eliminate them before any disaster befalls them (without wasting this precious time).
es: Now then: only I can prevent the harm, by making a prudent selection and hiding the documents in question underground or moving them to a safe place, and for that, it is essential that I do not waste a second of time.

en: And shall I hang back, when Tellson’s knows this and says this—Tellson’s, whose bread I have eaten these sixty years—because I am a little stiff about the joints?
vi: Can I delay just because of a bit of stiff joints when Tellson knows the situation well and tells me to go; Tellson, whose bread I've eaten for sixty years!
tr: While Tellson's – the institution I've served for sixty years – is aware of this situation and asks this of me, should I abandon them just because my joints are a bit stiff? Why would I do that?
es: Can I dawdle when the house knows what I have just said, and when the house says it... the house whose bread I have been eating for sixty years, the house into one of whose joints I have inserted myself like a wedge?

en: Why, I am a boy, sir, to half a dozen old codgers here!”
vi: Oh, compared to half a dozen old fogeys here, I'm still quite spry, sir!
tr: Among the half dozen antique men over there, I am considered a young man!"
es: Get out of here, man!

en: “How I admire the gallantry of your youthful spirit, mr Lorry.”
vi: I truly admire your youthful and courageous spirit, Mr. Lorry.
tr: "I admire the courage of your young spirit, Mr. Lorry.""
es: Do you not know that I am a youngster compared to many who boast of being young and are nothing but decrepit old men? —I admire the gallantry of your youthful spirit, Mr. Lorry!

en: “Tut!
vi: − Tsk!
tr: "No way!
es: —Quiet!

en: Nonsense, sir!
vi: Just talking nonsense!...
tr: It's not like that actually!
es: —Quiet!

en: —And, my dear Charles,” said mr Lorry, glancing at the House again, “you are to remember, that getting things out of Paris at this present time, no matter what things, is next to an impossibility.
vi: Ah, Charles, - Mr. Lorry said while glancing towards the Master once more, - you must remember that getting anything out of Paris right now, anything at all, is nearly impossible.
tr: –Now dear Charles," said Mr. Lorry, glancing at the bank again, "remember, at this time, getting anything out of Paris, whatever it may be, is next to impossible.
es: Do not forget, my dear Carlos, that taking even the most insignificant object out of Paris today is next to impossible.

en: Papers and precious matters were this very day brought to us here (I speak in strict confidence; it is not business-like to whisper it, even to you), by the strangest bearers you can imagine, every one of whom had his head hanging on by a single hair as he passed the Barriers.
vi: Just today, many documents, many valuable things have been brought to this firm; I'm telling you this in confidence because revealing this secret even to you is unprofessional; the people who brought them here are unbelievably strange, they could lose their heads just by stepping through the gates of Paris.
tr: Just today, they brought us some documents and valuable items (I can't give too much information, I can't even hint at it to you, it's that kind of job) and you can probably guess the state of the people who brought them, since each of them was walking on a razor's edge while crossing the border.
es: Today we have received precious documents—I need not stress the utmost discretion,—and we have received them from the most unusual couriers you can imagine, couriers whose heads were hanging by a thread as they crossed the Barriers.

en: At another time, our parcels would come and go, as easily as in business-like Old England; but now, everything is stopped.”
vi: In the past, the firm's parcels moved back and forth to France as easily as in this commercially accustomed England; but now everything is cut off.
tr: In the past, our parcels used to come and go easily for business, just like in old England, but now everything has stopped."
es: In the past, our packages circulated from one nation to another without any difficulty: today everything is paralyzed.

en: “And do you really go to-night?”
vi: − So, are you really going tonight? −
tr: "So, are you really leaving tonight?"
es: —And do you plan to undertake the journey tonight? —Tonight without fail.

en: “I really go to-night, for the case has become too pressing to admit of delay.”
vi: Yes, I am really going tonight because the situation is too urgent to delay any longer.
tr: "Yes, I'm leaving tonight; events have escalated, there's no time to waste anymore.""
es: Things have gotten to the point where not a second can be wasted.

en: “And do you take no one with you?”
vi: − So you're not taking anyone with you? −
tr: "Aren't you taking someone with you?"
es: —Is no one accompanying you?

en: “All sorts of people have been proposed to me, but I will have nothing to say to any of them.
vi: They offered me many people, but I didn't want any of them.
tr: "They suggested a lot of men to accompany me, but none of them felt right.
es: —People of all classes and conditions have been proposed to me, but I have not said a word to anyone.

en: I intend to take Jerry.
vi: I intend to take Jerry along.
tr: I'm planning to take Jerry.
es: I plan to take Jeremiah with me.

en: Jerry has been my bodyguard on Sunday nights for a long time past and I am used to him.
vi: Jerry has long been my guard on Sunday nights, and I have grown accustomed to him.
tr: He's been guarding me on Sunday nights for a long time, and I've gotten quite used to him.
es: For many years, he has been my guard dog, my obligatory companion on my Sunday outings, and I am used to him.

en: Nobody will suspect Jerry of being anything but an English bull-dog, or of having any design in his head but to fly at anybody who touches his master.”
vi: To everyone else, Jerry is clearly nothing more than a vicious dog, always ready to attack anyone who touches his master.
tr: Nobody would suspect Jerry; everyone immediately understands that he's the kind of English guard dog that would pounce on anyone who tries to attack his owner."
es: No one should see anything in Jeremiah other than an English bulldog, incapable of harboring any other intentions than to pounce on anyone who dares to touch a hair of his master's clothing.

en: “I must say again that I heartily admire your gallantry and youthfulness.”
vi: − I must say once again that I wholeheartedly admire your brave and valiant spirit.
tr: "I cannot help but once again express my sincere admiration for your courage and youth.""
es: —I repeat that I admire your bravery and your courage.

en: “I must say again, nonsense, nonsense!
vi: − I must say it again, you are speaking nonsense, nonsense!
tr: "No way, it's not that bad!
es: —And I repeat that you are talking nonsense, my friend Carlos.

en: When I have executed this little commission, I shall, perhaps, accept Tellson’s proposal to retire and live at my ease.
vi: Once I have completed this petty commission, I will probably accept Tellson's retirement proposal and live comfortably.
tr: After completing this small task, I might accept Tellson's retirement offer and retreat to my own corner.
es: Once I have finished this small commission, it is possible that I will accept Tellson's proposition to retire and live peacefully.

en: Time enough, then, to think about growing old.”
vi: At that time, there will be plenty of time to reflect on old age.
tr: Then, I suppose, I would have enough time to consider myself old."
es: Then I will have plenty of time to think about the fact that I am getting old.

en: This dialogue had taken place at mr Lorry’s usual desk, with Monseigneur swarming within a yard or two of it, boastful of what he would do to avenge himself on the rascal-people before long.
vi: The conversation took place at Mr. Lorry's usual desk, just a meter away from the crowd of French aristocrats boasting about soon taking revenge on the unruly commoners.
tr: While they were talking about these things at Mr. Lorry's desk, a little further away, the Monsignor, foaming with rage, was boasting about how he would soon take revenge on those scoundrels.
es: The dialogue that is transcribed here had taken place in Mr. Lorry's office, a yard or two away from a swarm of gentlemen, whose conversation, quite animated indeed, revolved around the revenge they would soon take on the vile populace.

en: It was too much the way of Monseigneur under his reverses as a refugee, and it was much too much the way of native British orthodoxy, to talk of this terrible Revolution as if it were the only harvest ever known under the skies that had not been sown—as if nothing had ever been done, or omitted to be done, that had led to it—as if observers of the wretched millions in France, and of the misused and perverted resources that should have made them prosperous, had not seen it inevitably coming, years before, and had not in plain words recorded what they saw.
vi: The aristocrats, who were down on their luck and had to flee abroad, were still accustomed to such habits, no different from the English establishment. They talked about the terrible Revolution as if it were a storm they were reaping without ever having sown the wind—as if they had done nothing at all, or made no mistakes that led to this—as if they had not seen that this was inevitably coming, many years before, and had not clearly recorded what they had witnessed. (They—those who watched millions of impoverished people in France, saw the resources that should have made the people prosperous but were instead abused and wasted by them.)
tr: It was too much for a refugee of the Monsignor's status, and in a manner not at all befitting English conservatism, to speak of this terrible revolution as if it were the only crop ever harvested under the sky despite never being sown – as if nothing had been done to cause all this or as if the necessary actions had not been neglected; as if those who had observed the miserable condition of millions in France and the misuse and corruption of resources that could provide them with a prosperous life had not seen the revolution inevitably approaching years ago and had not recorded what they saw in plain language.
es: It was truly inconceivable that the gentlemen, in their capacity as emigrants, and as such, victims of countless setbacks, and the native English orthodoxy, spoke of that terrible Revolution as if it were a harvest of unsown fruits, as if all human means had not been employed to produce it, as if many observers, who necessarily had to understand the intolerable misery afflicting millions of France's children and the disastrous use of resources that could have made them prosperous and happy, had not seen and clearly announced its inevitable arrival.

en: Such vapouring, combined with the extravagant plots of Monseigneur for the restoration of a state of things that had utterly exhausted itself, and worn out Heaven and earth as well as itself, was hard to be endured without some remonstrance by any sane man who knew the truth.
vi: Those who were clear-headed and understood the truth could hardly endure such empty words along with the wild schemes of the high officials who wanted to restore a state of affairs that was already completely exhausted, that had already declined to the utmost.
tr: While things were boiling over like this, and the Monsignor was engaging in endless intrigues to remedy the current state that had exhausted itself and, along with it, the earth and the sky, any sensible man who knew the truth would not tolerate this situation and would object.
es: No man of sound mind and knowledge of the truth could hardly endure the series of nonsense spoken in a doctrinal tone, combined with extravagant plots to restore a state of affairs worn out and rotten to the core.

en: And it was such vapouring all about his ears, like a troublesome confusion of blood in his own head, added to a latent uneasiness in his mind, which had already made Charles Darnay restless, and which still kept him so.
vi: And it was precisely those empty words, along with the anxiety and worry that surged to his head, that made Charles Darnay's mind simmer with persistent discomfort and restlessness.
tr: Already uneasy, Charles Darnay's anxiety increased even more after all this talk, as if his blood had rushed to his head.
es: The nonsense and extravagances, combined with the unrest in which Charles Darnay found himself, had made him impatient and nervous for several days, and the conversation he was hearing only served to exacerbate his impatience.

en: Among the talkers, was Stryver, of the King’s Bench Bar, far on his way to state promotion, and, therefore, loud on the theme: broaching to Monseigneur, his devices for blowing the people up and exterminating them from the face of the earth, and doing without them: and for accomplishing many similar objects akin in their nature to the abolition of eagles by sprinkling salt on the tails of the race.
vi: Among those speaking was Stryver, a man of the Supreme Court, who was advancing far in his career, and thus very vocal on this topic. He was plotting for the French aristocrats to annihilate the common people, to sweep them off the face of the earth to be rid of them; along with various plans to achieve similar goals through fantastical and absurd methods akin to reaching for the stars.
tr: Among the speakers was Stryver from the Royal Bar, whose voice was loud because his promotion was at risk. He was telling the Monsignor about finishing off the people, wiping them off the face of the earth, and what needed to be done for a life without them, and he was talking about what they aimed to do to eradicate eagles, a race close to them by nature.
es: Among the talkers was Stryver, a man who had already climbed several rungs of the ladder of glory, and who was destined to climb many more, so it was not surprising that he leaned decidedly towards the noble class. He was speaking on this occasion with great fervor about the need to put an end to the common people once and for all, to mercilessly exterminate the vile rabble, to make the scum disappear from the earth, for which he advocated methods that, in effectiveness, were on par with that of the wise man who, wanting to permanently eliminate eagles, proposed that their tails be sprinkled with ground salt.

en: Him, Darnay heard with a particular feeling of objection; and Darnay stood divided between going away that he might hear no more, and remaining to interpose his word, when the thing that was to be, went on to shape itself out.
vi: Listening to Stryver made Darnay extremely annoyed, and he was hesitating whether to leave to avoid the irritation or to stay and contribute a few words when an event occurred that determined his choice.
tr: Darnay could not stand his speech the most, and stood there wavering between leaving to avoid hearing these words and staying to give them a piece of his mind.
es: Darnay listened to the lawyer with deep aversion, with repugnance. He even had thoughts of leaving so as not to hear him, and it is more than likely that he would have acted on them if the events themselves had not shown him the path he should follow.

en: The House approached mr Lorry, and laying a soiled and unopened letter before him, asked if he had yet discovered any traces of the person to whom it was addressed?
vi: The Boss went to Mr. Lorry, placed an unopened letter in front of him, and asked if he knew anything about the whereabouts of the recipient named on the address.
tr: The Bank Manager approached Mr. Lorry and placed a dirty and unopened letter in front of him, asking if there was any news regarding the person to whom it was sent.
es: The House had just approached Lorry and, leaving a closed and extremely worn sheet on the table, asked him if he had found any traces of the person to whom it was addressed.

en: The House laid the letter down so close to Darnay that he saw the direction—the more quickly because it was his own right name.
vi: The Boss placed the letter close enough to where Darnay was standing that he could see the message - and immediately took notice because it was his name.
tr: The letter was so close to Darnay that he immediately read the name on it – he read it very quickly, because it was his own name.
es: The House left the letter so close to Darnay that he had to read the address. It is true that it did not take him much effort, since the name written on the envelope was precisely his own.

en: The address, turned into English, ran:
vi: The address, translated into English, was: “Urgent.
tr: In the address section, translated into English, the following was written:
es: It read as follows.

en: “Very pressing.
vi: The address, translated into English, was: “Urgent.
tr: "Very urgent.
es: "Very urgent."

en: To Monsieur heretofore the Marquis St. Evrémonde, of France.
vi: To the former Marquis St. Evrémonde, France.
tr: To the former Marquis of St Evremonde of France.
es: "To the Marquis de Saint-Evrémond of France."

en: Confided to the cares of Messrs.
vi: Forwarded through Tellson & Co. Bank, London, England.
tr: To the former Marquis of St Evremonde of France.
es: "Entrusted to Messrs. Tellson and Company, Bankers, London, England."

en: Tellson and Co., Bankers, London, England.”
vi: Forwarded through Tellson & Co. Bank, London, England.
tr: By the hand of Tellson's Bank, London, England."
es: "Entrusted to Messrs. Tellson and Company, Bankers, London, England."

en: On the marriage morning, Doctor Manette had made it his one urgent and express request to Charles Darnay, that the secret of this name should be—unless he, the Doctor, dissolved the obligation—kept inviolate between them.
vi: On the morning of the wedding years ago, Dr. Manette had earnestly requested Charles Darnay that this secret identity be known only to the two of them unless the doctor himself annulled the agreement.
tr: On the morning of the wedding, Dr. Manette had only one special request from Charles Darnay, and that was for this name to remain a secret between them – unless he, the Doctor, wished otherwise.
es: Dr. Manette, on the very morning of his daughter's marriage to Charles Darnay, demanded that he keep his last name a secret until the doctor released him from the obligation.

en: Nobody else knew it to be his name; his own wife had no suspicion of the fact; mr Lorry could have none.
vi: No one else knew that it was his name; not even his wife had the slightest idea; and Mr. Lorry even less so.
tr: Nobody else knew his real name; his wife had not the slightest suspicion, and Mr. Lorry could not have had any either.
es: No one knew his title, which was a secret even to his wife. As for Lorry, he could not have suspected it in the slightest.

en: “No,” said mr Lorry, in reply to the House; “I have referred it, I think, to everybody now here, and no one can tell me where this gentleman is to be found.”
vi: − No, - Mr. Lorry answered his employer, - I think I have asked everyone present here, and no one knows anything about the whereabouts of this gentleman.
tr: "No," replied Mr. Lorry to the manager, "I asked everyone who came here, but no one knows where this gentleman is.""
es: —No—answered Lorry to the House. —I have asked everyone who has come to this house, but no one has been able to tell me where that gentleman is.

en: The hands of the clock verging upon the hour of closing the Bank, there was a general set of the current of talkers past mr Lorry’s desk.
vi: The clock hands were nearing the bank's closing hour, a group of people chatting as they passed by Mr. Lorry's desk.
tr: When the clock showed the bank's closing time, a crowd of people began to pass by Mr. Lorry's desk, chatting away.
es: As the hour to close the Bank had struck, almost all the friends of chattering had taken refuge in Lorry's office.

en: He held the letter out inquiringly; and Monseigneur looked at it, in the person of this plotting and indignant refugee; and Monseigneur looked at it in the person of that plotting and indignant refugee; and This, That, and The Other, all had something disparaging to say, in French or in English, concerning the Marquis who was not to be found.
vi: He held out the letter to inquire; then one official after another looked at it with the expression of a distressed and scheming refugee, followed by another high-ranking official who looked at it with the expression of a scheming and distressed exile; then Mr. This, Mr. That, Mr. Other, all said something disparaging, in either French or English, about the missing Marquis.
tr: Mr. Lorry tried to gather information from people by showing the letter one by one; an angry refugee in the position of a scheming Monsignor looked, another angry refugee in the position of a scheming Monsignor looked; this one, that one, and the other one all looked, and each had something derogatory to say in French or English about the missing Marquis.
es: He was holding the letter in his hands, looking at it with evident perplexity. The noble caste was also looking at it, but with anger, with a frown, as if instead of a piece of paper they were seeing an unworthy refugee of the race to which they belonged. This one, that one, the one over there, all had something to say against the Marquis who did not seem to appear anywhere.

en: “Nephew, I believe—but in any case degenerate successor—of the polished Marquis who was murdered,” said one.
vi: − I think this is the nephew... but anyway, he is the degenerate heir... of the noble Marquis who was assassinated, - one person said.
tr: "Apparently, the nephew of the murdered kind Marquis – but in any case, a degenerate heir – I think it's this person," said one of them.
es: —Nephew, if I am not mistaken... but of course, a degenerate successor of that illustrious and refined Marquis who was vilely murdered—said one.

en: “Happy to say, I never knew him.”
vi: To be honest, I'm glad, I don't know this guy.
tr: "Luckily, I never knew him."
es: —I have the fortune of never having seen him in my life.

en: “A craven who abandoned his post,” said another—this Monseigneur had been got out of Paris, legs uppermost and half suffocated, in a load of hay—“some years ago.”
vi: − A coward who gave up his position years ago, - another person said, this high-ranking official fled from Paris, head tucked between his legs, burrowing to suffocate in a pile of straw.
tr: "A coward who abandoned his home and country a few years ago," said another – "this Monsignor was also smuggled out of Paris with his head buried in straw, legs up in the air, barely able to breathe."
es: —A coward who abandoned his post a few years ago—interjected another gentleman, who had left Paris with his head buried in the middle of a cartload of straw, feet in the air and half suffocated.

en: “Infected with the new doctrines,” said a third, eyeing the direction through his glass in passing; “set himself in opposition to the last Marquis, abandoned the estates when he inherited them, and left them to the ruffian herd.
vi: "− Influenced by new doctrines," the third person said while glancing at the address line as he walked by, "he voluntarily confronted the late Marquis, abandoned the inheritance he was entitled to, and left everything to those ruffians."
tr: "He was influenced by the new doctrines," said the third person as he passed by, holding his single monocle in that direction; "he opposed the last Marquis, rejected all the property inherited from him, and left it all to those coarse human masses.
es: —Corrupted by the new doctrines—replied a third,—he declared open opposition against the last Marquis, abandoned his lands as soon as he inherited them, and entrusted them to a gang of ruffians.

en: They will recompense him now, I hope, as he deserves.”
vi: "They will now repay the favor, I hope, because he deserves it."
tr: Now, whatever he deserves, they will probably give it to him."
es: I hope they themselves will now give him the reward he has earned.

en: “Hey?” cried the blatant Stryver.
vi: − What? - Stryver's voice boomed arrogantly.
tr: "Come on, really?" shouted the loudmouth Stryver; "Did he really do that?
es: —Did he do that?—shouted Stryver.—Is that man such a scoundrel?

en: “Did he though?
vi: - Did he really do that?
tr: "Come on, really?" shouted the loudmouth Stryver; "Did he really do that?
es: —Did he do that?—shouted Stryver.—Is that man such a scoundrel?

en: Is that the sort of fellow?
vi: Is he that kind of person?
tr: What kind of man is this?
es: —Did he do that?—shouted Stryver.—Is that man such a scoundrel?

en: Let us look at his infamous name.
vi: Let's take a look at his disgrace.
tr: Show me the name of that scoundrel.
es: Let's see... let's see his infamous surname.

en: D—n the fellow!”
vi: The bastard!
tr: Damn bastard!"
es: Let's see... let's see his infamous surname.

en: Darnay, unable to restrain himself any longer, touched mr Stryver on the shoulder, and said:
vi: Unable to bear it any longer, Darnay gently patted Stryver on the shoulder and said: − I know this man.
tr: Darnay, unable to restrain himself any longer, touched Mr. Stryver's shoulder and said:
es: Darnay, whose resistance was nearing its end, touched Stryver on the shoulder and said:

en: “I know the fellow.”
vi: Unable to bear it any longer, Darnay gently patted Stryver on the shoulder and said: − I know this man.
tr: "I know that man."
es: —I know that gentleman. —By all the devils together!...

en: “Do you, by Jupiter?” said Stryver.
vi: − Oh my, dear God? - Stryver said.
tr: "Really?" said Stryver.
es: Do you know him?

en: “I am sorry for it.”
vi: - I feel sorry for you.
tr: "I'm sorry to hear that.""
es: I feel it in my soul.

en: “Why?”
vi: − The reason? −
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why?

en: “Why, mr Darnay?
vi: The reason, Darnay?
tr: "Why, Mr. Darnay?
es: —Are you asking why, Darnay?

en: D’ye hear what he did?
vi: Have you heard about the things he's done?
tr: Haven't you heard what he has done?
es: But haven't you heard what he has done?

en: Don’t ask, why, in these times.”
vi: Don't ask for reasons in these times.
tr: In such a time, is it appropriate to ask why?"
es: —I've heard it, yes; but I ask you why you feel that I know you.

en: “But I do ask why?”
vi: − But I want to ask for that reason? −
tr: "But I am asking.""
es: —I've heard it, yes; but I ask you why you feel that I know you.

en: “Then I tell you again, mr Darnay, I am sorry for it.
vi: Then I will say it again, Mr. Darnay, I feel sorry for you.
tr: "Then let me say it again, Mr. Darnay, I am sorry that you know this man.
es: —In that case, I will repeat to you, Mr. Darnay, that I regret that you know that unworthy man, and that I am sorry you do not understand why I feel this way.

en: I am sorry to hear you putting any such extraordinary questions.
vi: I regret hearing you raise such strange questions.
tr: I am also sorry that you ask me such strange questions.
es: It greatly distresses me to hear the inconceivable questions you ask.

en: Here is a fellow, who, infected by the most pestilent and blasphemous code of devilry that ever was known, abandoned his property to the vilest scum of the earth that ever did murder by wholesale, and you ask me why I am sorry that a man who instructs youth knows him?
vi: This is a person who has been infected with the most harmful and blasphemous rules ever, who has given up their property to the most despicable scum of the earth who only know how to commit mass murder, yet you still ask why I regret that a teacher of children like you knows such a person?
tr: This man has conformed to the most miserable and vile devilries ever, left his property to the world's most despicable scum who commit mass murder, and a gentleman like you asks me why I am sorry.
es: We are told here of a subject corrupted by the most pestilent and impious of rottenness, of an individual the vilest that has ever existed in the world, who abandons his goods to the scum of the earth, to the scoundrels whose creed is murder and theft, and you ask me why I regret that a man who dedicates himself to teaching youth knows him? Do you insist on knowing?

en: Well, but I’ll answer you.
vi: Alright, I will tell you.
tr: But I will still explain.
es: Well, I will tell you!

en: I am sorry because I believe there is contamination in such a scoundrel.
vi: I regret it because I believe that such scoundrels also spread their infection widely.
tr: I am sorry because such vile ideas are contagious.
es: I regret it because I believe that wretches like the one in question contaminate those who know them.

en: That’s why.”
vi: That is the reason.
tr: That's how it is."
es: And you know it.

en: Mindful of the secret, Darnay with great difficulty checked himself, and said: “You may not understand the gentleman.”
vi: Remembering the secret, Darnay tried his best to stay calm, he said: "Perhaps you do not know this gentleman."
tr: Darnay, keeping his secret in mind and making a great effort not to reveal it, said: "Perhaps you misunderstood this gentleman.""
es: Darnay, containing himself with difficulty, replied: —Perhaps you do not understand the gentleman to whom you are referring.

en: “I understand how to put you in a corner, mr Darnay,” said Bully Stryver, “and I’ll do it.
vi: − But I know how to corner you, Mr. Darnay, Stryver said in a bullying tone, - and I will do just that.
tr: "I understand how to corner you, Mr. Darnay," said Zorba Stryver, "and I will corner you.
es: —But I know very well how to put you between a rock and a hard place, and I am going to do it—shouted Stryver.

en: If this fellow is a gentleman, I don’t understand him.
vi: And if that person is indeed a gentleman, then I do not know him.
tr: If he is a gentleman, I couldn't understand it.
es: —If that individual is a gentleman, I certainly do not understand him; you can tell him that from me, and give him my regards in passing.

en: You may tell him so, with my compliments.
vi: You can tell him that, along with my regards.
tr: You can convey this to him with my respects.
es: —If that individual is a gentleman, I certainly do not understand him; you can tell him that from me, and give him my regards in passing.

en: You may also tell him, from me, that after abandoning his worldly goods and position to this butcherly mob, I wonder he is not at the head of them.
vi: You can also tell him that, I say this myself, after having given up wealth and status to that crowd of butchers, I don't understand why he doesn't just lead them.
tr: Please ask him for me why, after leaving all his property and reputation to that bloodthirsty mob, he didn't stay at the forefront.
es: You can also add on my behalf that after abandoning the patrimonial goods to the rabble, I am greatly astonished that he has not put himself at the head of the thieves and murderers...

en: But, no, gentlemen,” said Stryver, looking all round, and snapping his fingers, “I know something of human nature, and I tell you that you’ll never find a fellow like this fellow, trusting himself to the mercies of such precious protégés.
vi: But no, gentlemen, - Stryver said while looking around and snapping his fingers, - I know a little about human nature, and I tell you that you will never see someone like him entrust himself to the mercy of such a precious group of disciples.
tr: But no, gentlemen," said Stryver, looking around and snapping his fingers, "I understand a bit about human nature, and believe me, men like him do not sacrifice themselves in life for those very precious men they favor.
es: But no, gentlemen, no; I, who know a little about human nature, dare to assure you that you will never find a subject like that who entrusts himself to the tender care of your humble protégés.

en: No, gentlemen; he’ll always show ’em a clean pair of heels very early in the scuffle, and sneak away.”
vi: No, gentlemen, he will always run for his life at the first sign of trouble, and disappear.
tr: No, gentlemen; these people show up at the very beginning of the hustle and bustle with their shiny shoes, and then they vanish."
es: No, gentlemen, no; if he shows anything of himself to those people, it will be, in any case, a pair of heels, and even then, only for the time it takes to put distance between them.

en: With those words, and a final snap of his fingers, mr Stryver shouldered himself into Fleet-street, amidst the general approbation of his hearers.
vi: Finishing his words and snapping his fingers one last time, Stryver stormed out onto Fleet Street to the applause of the crowd gathered around him.
tr: Mr. Stryver, after snapping his fingers one last time following these words, headed towards Fleet Street amidst the admiring glances of those listening to his speech.
es: Having said these words, which earned the unanimous approval of his listeners, he went out onto Fleet Street.

en: mr Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the desk, in the general departure from the Bank.
vi: At the desk, only Lorry and Charles Darnay remained as everyone else left the bank.
tr: Everyone had left, and Mr. Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the table.
es: Seconds later, Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone in the office.

en: “Will you take charge of the letter?” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Will you take care of this letter? - Mr. Lorry said. -
tr: "Will you take care of the letter?" said Mr. Lorry.
es: "Since you know the person to whom the letter is addressed," said Lorry, "would you take charge of delivering it to them?"

en: “You know where to deliver it?”
vi: Do you know where to deliver it?
tr: "Do you know where to take it?"
es: "Since you know the person to whom the letter is addressed," said Lorry, "would you take charge of delivering it to them?"

en: “I do.”
vi: − I know.
tr: "I know."
es: —With great pleasure.

en: “Will you undertake to explain, that we suppose it to have been addressed here, on the chance of our knowing where to forward it, and that it has been here some time?”
vi: − So please explain that the letter was sent to this address because it was thought that we would know who to forward it to, and that the letter has been here for quite a while, okay?
tr: "Can you explain to him that we assumed this letter was sent here, thinking we knew where it was to be delivered, and that it has been here for a while?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to explain to him that it was undoubtedly sent here because they believed we knew him, and that, not knowing who he was or where he was, the letter has been held up for some time?

en: “I will do so.
vi: − I will say that.
tr: "Okay, I'll tell you.
es: —I will do so.

en: Do you start for Paris from here?”
vi: Are you leaving for Paris from here directly? −
tr: Are you departing for Paris from here?"
es: When are you leaving for Paris?

en: “From here, at eight.”
vi: From here, at eight o'clock.
tr: "Yes, at eight o'clock.""
es: —At eight, I leave from right here.

en: “I will come back, to see you off.”
vi: − I will come back to see you off.
tr: "I will come again to see you off.""
es: —I will return to say goodbye to him.

en: Very ill at ease with himself, and with Stryver and most other men, Darnay made the best of his way into the quiet of the Temple, opened the letter, and read it.
vi: Very frustrated with himself, with Stryver, and with others, Darnay tried to find a quiet place in the Temple Bar area, opened the letter, and read it.
tr: Extremely uncomfortable with himself, Stryver, and the other men, Darnay withdrew to a quiet corner of the Temple, opened the letter, and read it.
es: Discontented with himself, and even more so with Stryver and his compatriots, Darnay left the Bank building and, as soon as he reached a corner where he believed he was out of sight of prying eyes, he opened the letter, which was written in the following terms:

en: These were its contents:
vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: It contained the following:
es: Discontented with himself, and even more so with Stryver and his compatriots, Darnay left the Bank building and, as soon as he reached a corner where he believed he was out of sight of prying eyes, he opened the letter, which was written in the following terms:

en: “Prison of the Abbaye, Paris.
vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: Abbaye Prison, Paris
es: "Abbey Prison, Paris."

vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS

en: “Monsieur Heretofore The Marquis.
vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: The Former Marquis of France, Monsieur,
es: Mr. Marquis:

en: “After having long been in danger of my life at the hands of the village, I have been seized, with great violence and indignity, and brought a long journey on foot to Paris.
vi: After a long period of life-threatening danger at the hands of the villagers, I was forcibly and humiliatingly captured, and had to walk a long distance to Paris.
tr: After being captured, I was brought to Paris on foot following the terrible days I spent in the hands of the villagers under great violence and insult.
es: »After running for a long time in imminent danger of losing my life at the hands of the villagers, I have been captured, subjected to a thousand violences and outrages, and finally taken to Paris, which I was forced to travel to on foot.

en: On the road I have suffered a great deal.
vi: On the way, I endured countless hardships.
tr: I suffered greatly during this long journey.
es: »After running for a long time in imminent danger of losing my life at the hands of the villagers, I have been captured, subjected to a thousand violences and outrages, and finally taken to Paris, which I was forced to travel to on foot.

en: Nor is that all; my house has been destroyed—razed to the ground.
vi: But that's not all; the tiles of my house have been destroyed - leveled to the ground.
tr: As if that wasn't enough, they also destroyed my home – they razed it to the ground.
es: The bitterness I endured on the way is not to be recounted here; and that is not all; my house has been destroyed... razed to the ground.

en: “The crime for which I am imprisoned, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, and for which I shall be summoned before the tribunal, and shall lose my life (without your so generous help), is, they tell me, treason against the majesty of the people, in that I have acted against them for an emigrant.
vi: The crime for which I am imprisoned, dear Marquis, and for which I will be tried and lose my life (without your noble assistance), is the crime of treason against the glorious people, they say, by acting on behalf of an exile against them.
tr: The former Marquis of France, Monsieur, the crime that caused my arrest and my imminent appearance before the judge, and (if deprived of your generous help) will cost me my life, they say, is that I betrayed the vast majority of the people and turned them against me because of a refugee.
es: "The crime of which I am accused, the one that has me buried in jail, Mr. Marquis, the crime for which I will appear before the Court and which will cost me my head (if you do not lend me your generous assistance) is, according to them, that of treason against the majesty of the people, whom they claim I have sold out to protect an emigrant."

en: It is in vain I represent that I have acted for them, and not against, according to your commands.
vi: I have wasted my efforts trying to convince them that I was helping them and not acting against them, in accordance with your orders.
tr: It does no good to say that I acted not against them, but for them, according to your orders.
es: "In vain have I made it clear to them that, far from acting against them, I have acted in their favor, adhering to your instructions, Mr. Marquis; in vain have I argued that prior to the confiscation of the emigrants' properties, I had forgiven the taxes that the people stopped paying, that I did not collect the rents, that I did not resort to the courts."

en: It is in vain I represent that, before the sequestration of emigrant property, I had remitted the imposts they had ceased to pay; that I had collected no rent; that I had had recourse to no process.
vi: I wasted my efforts trying to convince them that, before confiscating the property of the exiled person, I had paid all the taxes they had not paid; that I did not collect any rent; that I did not pursue any debts.
tr: It also does no good to explain that before the confiscation of refugee properties, I forgave tax debts, did not collect rent, and took no action.
es: "In vain have I made it clear to them that, far from acting against them, I have acted in their favor, adhering to your instructions, Mr. Marquis; in vain have I argued that prior to the confiscation of the emigrants' properties, I had forgiven the taxes that the people stopped paying, that I did not collect the rents, that I did not resort to the courts."

en: The only response is, that I have acted for an emigrant, and where is that emigrant?
vi: They still insisted that I was acting on behalf of an exiled person and were determined to know where that exiled person was.
tr: The only thing they tell me is, you worked for a refugee, and where is that refugee.
es: "To all my representations they reply that I acted in favor of an emigrant, and I ask myself: where is that emigrant?"

en: “Ah! most gracious Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, where is that emigrant?
vi: Oh! Dear kind sirs, formerly the Marquis, where is that exiled person?
tr: Ah! Former Marquis of France, dear Monsieur, where do you think this refugee is?
es: "Ah, my good Lord Marquis!"

en: I cry in my sleep where is he?
vi: I weep in my sleep asking where they are?
tr: Even in my sleep, I mutter about where he might be.
es: "Where is that emigrant?" "I ask while I sleep; where is he?"

en: I demand of Heaven, will he not come to deliver me?
vi: I ask the heavens if that person will come to rescue me?
tr: I pray to God to send him to me.
es: "I turn my eyes to the heavens, and ask them; will he come to save me?"

en: No answer.
vi: There is no answer.
tr: But it is of no use.
es: "They do not answer me."

en: Ah Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, I send my desolate cry across the sea, hoping it may perhaps reach your ears through the great bank of Tilson known at Paris!
vi: Oh dear sirs, formerly the Marquis, I send my forlorn cries across the sea, hoping they might reach your ears through the renowned and prestigious Tilson* bank in Paris!
tr: Ah, Former Marquis of France, Monsieur, in the hope that something might reach your ears through Tellson's Bank in Paris, I send my desperate cries across the seas!
es: "Ah, Lord Marquis!" "I send my cry of anguish across the seas, in case God wills it to reach his ears through the mediation of the great Tellson's Bank, so well known in Paris."

en: “For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity, of the honour of your noble name, I supplicate you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, to succour and release me.
vi: For the love of God, justice, generosity, and the honor of your noble lineage, I earnestly beg you, dear sirs, formerly the Marquis, to help and liberate me.
tr: For the love of God, in the name of justice, and for the greatness and honor of your noble name, I beg you to save me, Monsieur the Former Marquis of France.
es: "For the love of God, for fairness, for justice, for generosity, for the immaculate honor of your noble surname, Mr. Marquis, I beg you to come to my aid and save me from the death that threatens me."

en: My fault is, that I have been true to you.
vi: My fault is my loyalty to you.
tr: My only fault was being loyal to you.
es: "My only crime is having been faithful to you... Oh Mr. Marquis!" "I trust that you will reciprocate my loyalty."

en: Oh Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, I pray you be you true to me!
vi: Oh dear sirs, formerly the Marquis, I pray you do not forsake me.
tr: Oh Monsieur the Former Marquis of France, I beg you to be loyal to me as well!
es: "My only crime is having been faithful to you... Oh Mr. Marquis!" "I trust that you will reciprocate my loyalty."

en: “From this prison here of horror, whence I every hour tend nearer and nearer to destruction, I send you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, the assurance of my dolorous and unhappy service.
vi: From this dreadful prison, where with each passing hour I draw closer to death, I send to you, my lord who was once a Marquis, my sorrowful and unfortunate loyalty.
