vi: Some people, knowing their turn was far off, lay down on the ground to sleep or smoke, while others chatted or wandered around.
tr: While some, seeing that they had a long wait ahead, lay down to sleep or smoke tobacco, others chatted with each other or loitered around.
es: Those who knew it would be a long time before their turn came waited lying in the street, where they slept or smoked, while others engaged in lively conversations or passed the time walking around.

en: The red cap and tri-colour cockade were universal, both among men and women.
vi: Everywhere you look, you see the red hat and the tricolor badge, on the heads of both men and women.
tr: The red cap and the tricolor rosette were very popular among both women and men.
es: The red caps and tricolor cockades were mandatory attire that everyone wore, regardless of age or gender.

en: When he had sat in his saddle some half-hour, taking note of these things, Darnay found himself confronted by the same man in authority, who directed the guard to open the barrier.
vi: When Darnay had been sitting on his horse for about half an hour, observing the scenery, the authoritative figure from earlier appeared before him again, ordering the guards to open the barricade.
tr: Darnay, who had been sitting on his horse's saddle for about half an hour observing the surroundings, found the same official in front of him again, the man was telling the guards to open the barrier.
es: The wait for Charles Darnay would last half an hour, during which time he was able to make the observations that are noted, when the same character, apparently the chief of the barrier guard, came out again, who, after giving the escort a receipt for the person escorted, ordered him to dismount.

en: Then he delivered to the escort, drunk and sober, a receipt for the escorted, and requested him to dismount.
vi: He then handed a receipt to the two escorts, one drunk and one sober, and requested Darnay to dismount.
tr: Then, one drunk and the other sober, the escorts gave a receipt for the person they were accompanying and asked Darnay to dismount.
es: The wait for Charles Darnay would last half an hour, during which time he was able to make the observations that are noted, when the same character, apparently the chief of the barrier guard, came out again, who, after giving the escort a receipt for the person escorted, ordered him to dismount.

en: He did so, and the two patriots, leading his tired horse, turned and rode away without entering the city.
vi: He complied, and the two patriots led his weary horse away, turning their backs and speeding off without entering the capital.
tr: Darnay did as he was told, and the two citizens took his tired horse with them and returned the way they had come without entering the city.
es: Darnay obeyed, and the men who had accompanied him there took charge of his horse and left without entering the city.

en: He accompanied his conductor into a guard-room, smelling of common wine and tobacco, where certain soldiers and patriots, asleep and awake, drunk and sober, and in various neutral states between sleeping and waking, drunkenness and sobriety, were standing and lying about.
vi: He followed that guide into the guard station reeking of cheap alcohol and cigarettes, where it was full of soldiers and patriots, some lying down, some sitting, some asleep, some awake, some drunk, some sober, and in every state between waking and sleeping, between sobriety and drunkenness.
tr: Darnay, along with the official, went to the police station, which reeked of cheap wine and tobacco, where some soldiers and citizens were sleeping and waking, sitting or lying down, transitioning between sleep and wakefulness, and between drunkenness and sobriety.
es: The head of the guard led Darnay to the guardhouse, which reeked of cheap wine and tobacco, where there were several groups of soldiers and patriots, some asleep and others awake, the latter drunk and the former sober, and some on the borders of wakefulness and sleep, and of sobriety and drunkenness.

en: The light in the guard-house, half derived from the waning oil-lamps of the night, and half from the overcast day, was in a correspondingly uncertain condition.
vi: The light in the guard station, partly cast from oil lamps lit since the night and partly from the dim daylight, continuously flickered and swayed.
tr: The light, partly from the gas lamp left on overnight and partly from the enclosed atmosphere, reflected an equally ambiguous situation.
es: Two oil lamps cast a very questionable light over the guardhouse, on one of whose walls there was a table, upon which some records could be seen.

en: Some registers were lying open on a desk, and an officer of a coarse, dark aspect, presided over these.
vi: A pile of books lay open on the desk, and a dark-skinned, coarse officer was presiding over the table.
tr: Some record books were open on one of the tables, and a rough-looking, sullen clerk was bent over them.
es: A coarse-looking officer, seated in front of the table, was in charge of the records.

en: “Citizen Defarge,” said he to Darnay’s conductor, as he took a slip of paper to write on.
vi: − Citizen Defarge, - he said to the person who brought Darnay in, while taking out a piece of paper to make a note. -
tr: Taking a paper to write something about the man, "Citizen Defarge," said the official who brought Darnay.
es: —Citizen Defarge—said the character who had introduced Darnay, while taking a sheet of paper—Is this the emigrant Evrémonde?

en: “Is this the emigrant Evrémonde?”
vi: Is this the exiled Evrémonde? −
tr: "Is this the refugee Evremonde?""
es: —Citizen Defarge—said the character who had introduced Darnay, while taking a sheet of paper—Is this the emigrant Evrémonde?

en: “This is the man.”
vi: This is the one.
tr: "Yes, it's him."
es: —This is it.

en: “Your age, Evrémonde?”
vi: − How old are you, Evrémonde? −
tr: "How old are you, Evremonde?"
es: —How old are you, Evrémonde?

en: “Thirty-seven.”
vi: Thirty-seven.
tr: "Thirty-seven."
es: —Thirty-seven.

en: “Married, Evrémonde?”
vi: − Do you have a family, Evrémonde? −
tr: "Are you married, Evremonde?"
es: —Married, Evrémonde?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes, I do.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Where married?”
vi: − Where did you get married?
tr: "Where is your house?"
es: —Where?

en: “In England.”
vi: − In the United Kingdom.
tr: "In England."
es: —In England.

en: “Without doubt.
vi: − Certainly.
tr: "Without a doubt.
es: —I believe it.

en: Where is your wife, Evrémonde?”
vi: Where is your wife, Evrémonde? −
tr: Where is your wife, Evremonde?"
es: Where is your wife, Evrémonde?

en: “In England.”
vi: In England.
tr: "In England."
es: —In England.

en: “Without doubt.
vi: − Surely so.
tr: "No doubt.
es: —I believe so too.

en: You are consigned, Evrémonde, to the prison of La Force.”
vi: Evrémonde, you are consigned to La Force prison.
tr: You have been sent to La Force Prison, Evremonde."
es: You are consigned, Evrémonde, to the prison of La Force.

en: “Just Heaven!” exclaimed Darnay.
vi: − My God! - exclaimed Darnay. -
tr: "My God, how is this possible!" cried Darnay.
es: —God in Heaven!

en: “Under what law, and for what offence?”
vi: By what law, and for what crime?
tr: "According to which law, for what crime?"
es: —exclaimed Darnay—By virtue of what law, and for what crime or offense?

en: The officer looked up from his slip of paper for a moment.
vi: The officer looked up from the paper for a moment.
tr: The attendant lifted his head from the paper he was filling out and looked up for a moment.
es: After a few seconds of silent contemplation, the official replied:

en: “We have new laws, Evrémonde, and new offences, since you were here.”
vi: − We have had many new laws, Evrémonde, and many new crimes, since the last time you were here. -
tr: "Since you left here, we have new laws, Evremonde, and of course, new crimes."
es: —Since you left France, Evrémonde, we have been governed by new laws, and what pertains to crimes and offenses has changed profoundly.

en: He said it with a hard smile, and went on writing.
vi: He said with a malicious smile, then continued writing.
tr: As he said this, there was a rough smile on his face, and he continued writing.
es: "I beg you to bear in mind, citizen, that I have come voluntarily, yielding to the written plea on that paper before your eyes," replied Darnay.

en: “I entreat you to observe that I have come here voluntarily, in response to that written appeal of a fellow-countryman which lies before you.
vi: − I ask you to note that I have come here voluntarily, in response to the request of a compatriot written in the letter that is lying before you.
tr: "I would like to state that I have come here of my own accord to help the citizen whose request is written on the paper in front of you.
es: "I beg you to bear in mind, citizen, that I have come voluntarily, yielding to the written plea on that paper before your eyes," replied Darnay.

en: I demand no more than the opportunity to do so without delay.
vi: I just want to have the opportunity to fulfill that request without delay.
tr: I hope you will give me this opportunity without delay.
es: "I ask for nothing more than the opportunity to do what a fellow countryman of mine requests.

en: Is not that my right?”
vi: Don't I have that right?
tr: Do I not have this right?"
es: Am I not within my rights?"

vi: Don't I have that right?
tr: The official replied emotionlessly, "Refugees have no rights, Evremonde!"
es: "Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde," was the stolid reply of the official.

en: Original
tr: The official replied emotionlessly, "Refugees have no rights, Evremonde!"
es: "Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde," was the stolid reply of the official.

en: “Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde,” was the stolid reply.
vi: An exile has no rights at all, Evrémonde, - came the indifferent reply.
tr: The official replied emotionlessly, "Refugees have no rights, Evremonde!"
es: "Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde," was the stolid reply of the official.

en: The officer wrote until he had finished, read over to himself what he had written, sanded it, and handed it to Defarge, with the words “In secret.”
vi: The officer wrote until he was finished, read over what he had written, sprinkled sand to dry the ink, and then handed the paper to Defarge with a word: “Solitary confinement.”
tr: He finished his writing, read it once more to himself, then sealed it and handed it to Defarge, saying "Secret."
es: After giving Darnay a sinister smile, he wrote a few lines, folded the paper, and handed it to Defarge, saying: —Secret.

en: Defarge motioned with the paper to the prisoner that he must accompany him.
vi: Defarge waved the paper to signal the prisoner to go with him.
tr: Defarge signaled the prisoner to come with the paper in his hand.
es: Defarge indicated to the prisoner to follow him.

en: The prisoner obeyed, and a guard of two armed patriots attended them.
vi: The prisoner obeyed, and two armed patriotic Citizens escorted him.
tr: The prisoner complied, and two armed patriotic citizens joined them.
es: The prisoner obeyed, accompanied by two armed patriots who positioned themselves to his right and left.

en: “Is it you,” said Defarge, in a low voice, as they went down the guardhouse steps and turned into Paris, “who married the daughter of Doctor Manette, once a prisoner in the Bastille that is no more?”
vi: − Is it true that you... - Defarge asked in a lowered voice as they descended the guardhouse steps and entered Paris, - ...are the husband of Dr. Manette's daughter, who was once a prisoner in the Bastille? −
tr: As they descended the steps of the station and headed towards Paris, Defarge asked Darnay in a low voice, "Are you the one who married the daughter of Doctor Manette, who once lay in the Bastille?"
es: As they left the guardhouse to enter Paris, Defarge asked the prisoner in a low voice: —Are you the one who married the daughter of Dr. Manette, once a prisoner in the now non-existent Bastille?

en: “Yes,” replied Darnay, looking at him with surprise.
vi: Yes, - Darnay replied, looking at the questioner with surprise.
tr: "Yes!" replied Darnay, looking at her in astonishment.
es: —Yes—replied Darnay, looking at him with surprise.

en: “My name is Defarge, and I keep a wine-shop in the Quarter Saint Antoine.
vi: − I am Defarge, the owner of the tavern in the Saint Antoine district.
tr: "My name is Defarge and I have a wine shop in St Antoine Square.
es: —My name is Defarge and I own a tavern in the San Antonio neighborhood.

en: Possibly you have heard of me.”
vi: Surely you have heard of me.
tr: You have probably heard of me before."
es: You may know me by reputation.

en: “My wife came to your house to reclaim her father?
vi: − Has my wife gone to your house to bring her father back?
tr: "My wife had come to your house to pick up her father, right?"
es: —My wife went to your house to claim her father...

en: Yes!”
vi: That's right!
tr: "Of course!"
es: Yes, yes!

en: The word “wife” seemed to serve as a gloomy reminder to Defarge, to say with sudden impatience, “In the name of that sharp female newly-born, and called La Guillotine, why did you come to France?”
vi: The word "wife" seemed to be a dark reminder for Defarge, making him suddenly irritable. − In the name of the newly born sharp lady named La Guillotine*, I ask why you returned to France? −
tr: When Defarge heard the word "wife," he suddenly became tense and impatiently asked, "For the love of the newly born stern lady Guillotine, answer; why did you come to France?"
es: It seems that the word "woman" awakened somber memories in Defarge, for he said with brusque impatience: —Do you want to tell me, in the name of that newly born woman called Guillotine, why on earth you have come to France?

en: “You heard me say why, a minute ago.
vi: You heard me give the new reason just now.
tr: "You just heard why I came.
es: —Not a minute ago you heard me explain what was the cause of my trip.

en: Do you not believe it is the truth?”
vi: Do you not believe that is the truth?
tr: Don't you believe what I said is true?"
es: Do you think I didn't tell the truth?

en: “A bad truth for you,” said Defarge, speaking with knitted brows, and looking straight before him.
vi: − A terrible truth for you, - Defarge said, frowning, looking straight ahead.
tr: "A fact to your detriment," said Defarge, looking straight ahead with furrowed brows.
es: —True, it couldn't be more fatal for you—replied Defarge, furrowing his brow and looking intently at his interlocutor.

en: “Indeed I am lost here.
vi: − Honestly, I am bewildered to be here.
tr: "I was taken aback here.
es: —It is true that I find myself lost here.

en: All here is so unprecedented, so changed, so sudden and unfair, that I am absolutely lost.
vi: Everything here is too strange, too changed, too unexpected, and unfair, to the point of not understanding anything at all.
tr: Everything has changed so unexpectedly, mercilessly, and quickly that I was taken aback.
es: I see everything so disrupted, so different from what it used to be, so unpleasant, that I confess I don't even know where to turn my eyes.

en: Will you render me a little help?”
vi: Can you help me a little?
tr: Can't you help me a little?"
es: Would you do me a small favor?

en: “None.” Defarge spoke, always looking straight before him.
vi: − No. - Defarge said, his eyes still looking straight ahead.
tr: "No." Defarge was speaking while looking straight ahead.
es: —Absolutely none—replied Defarge, with a gaze as if lost in space.

en: “Will you answer me a single question?”
vi: − Can you answer just one question for me?
tr: "If I ask you something, can you answer?"
es: —You don't want to answer a question for me, not even one?

en: “Perhaps.
vi: − Maybe.
tr: "It could be.
es: —We'll see... Depending on how it is.

en: According to its nature.
vi: It depends on the nature of the question.
tr: It depends on the question you're going to ask.
es: —We'll see... Depending on how it is.

en: You can say what it is.”
vi: Just say it straight out.
tr: What is the matter?"
es: You can do it.

en: “In this prison that I am going to so unjustly, shall I have some free communication with the world outside?”
vi: − In that prison where I will be unjustly detained, will I have any freedom to communicate with the outside world? −
tr: "In this prison where I have been so unjustly taken, will I be able to communicate freely with the outside?""
es: —In the prison where I am so unjustly confined, will I be able to communicate freely with the outside world?

en: “You will see.”
vi: You will find out soon enough.
tr: "You will see."
es: —You will see it yourself.

en: “I am not to be buried there, prejudged, and without any means of presenting my case?”
vi: − Will I be buried there for life, will I be judged, is there any way to justify myself? −
tr: "I won't be locked up there without a trial or a chance to explain my situation, will I?"
es: —Do you intend to bury me in it, without judging me, without condemning me, without giving me the means to justify and defend myself?

en: “You will see.
vi: You will know soon.
tr: "You will see.
es: —You'll see for yourself...

en: But, what then?
vi: But what if there is?
tr: But then what will happen?
es: But if that were the case, so what?

en: Other people have been similarly buried in worse prisons, before now.”
vi: Many people have been buried like that in prison before.
tr: Many people in similar situations before you were imprisoned in much worse dungeons."
es: Many others as good as you have found themselves buried in worse prisons.

en: “But never by me, Citizen Defarge.”
vi: − But it wasn't caused by me, Citizen Defarge.
tr: "But such a thing wouldn't happen to me, right Citizen Defarge?"
es: —But not because of me, citizen Defarge.

en: Defarge glanced darkly at him for answer, and walked on in a steady and set silence.
vi: Defarge responded with a dark look and continued walking, silent and unspeaking.
tr: Defarge looked at him mysteriously as if he were about to say something, and then sank into a long and stern silence.
es: The somber expression on Defarge's face became extraordinarily pronounced upon hearing the response, after which he continued walking in silence.

en: The deeper he sank into this silence, the fainter hope there was—or so Darnay thought—of his softening in any slight degree.
vi: The more sullen and silent he became, Darnay thought, the less hope he had that Defarge would soften even a little.
tr: As the silence prolonged, the possibility of the man softening was diminishing – or so Darnay thought.
es: As his taciturnity increased, the hopes that Darnay initially had of softening the man dissipated.

en: He, therefore, made haste to say:
vi: Darnay hurriedly continued speaking: − There is something extremely important to me; you know, Citizen, even better than I do about its importance; I need to inform Mr. Lorry of Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman currently in Paris, a simple matter, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.
tr: Therefore, he hastily said:
es: —For me, it is of exceptional importance, as you know as well as I do, citizen Defarge, to inform Mr. Lorry, from Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman who is currently in Paris, of the simple fact, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.

en: “It is of the utmost importance to me (you know, Citizen, even better than I, of how much importance), that I should be able to communicate to mr Lorry of Tellson’s Bank, an English gentleman who is now in Paris, the simple fact, without comment, that I have been thrown into the prison of La Force.
vi: Darnay hurriedly continued speaking: − There is something extremely important to me; you know, Citizen, even better than I do about its importance; I need to inform Mr. Lorry of Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman currently in Paris, a simple matter, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.
tr: "Considering the fact that I will be confined to La Force Prison, it is extremely important for me to be able to speak with the English gentleman Mr. Lorry, who works at Tellson's Bank and is currently in Paris.
es: —For me, it is of exceptional importance, as you know as well as I do, citizen Defarge, to inform Mr. Lorry, from Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman who is currently in Paris, of the simple fact, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.

en: Will you cause that to be done for me?”
vi: Can you help me with that?
tr: Can you arrange this for me?"
es: Would you do me the favor of making him aware of this?

en: “I will do,” Defarge doggedly rejoined, “nothing for you.
vi: − I will do nothing for you, - Defarge insisted.
tr: "For you," said Defarge and continued resolutely, "there is nothing I can do.
es: —I will do absolutely nothing in your favor—replied Defarge.

en: My duty is to my country and the People.
vi: My duty is to serve my country and my people.
tr: My obligation is to my country and my people.
es: —I owe myself to my country and the people.

en: I am the sworn servant of both, against you.
vi: I have sworn to oppose people like you for those two reasons.
tr: I am their sworn servant against you.
es: I have sworn to serve both against you.

en: I will do nothing for you.”
vi: I will do nothing for you.
tr: I can do nothing for you."
es: Expect nothing from me.

en: Charles Darnay felt it hopeless to entreat him further, and his pride was touched besides.
vi: Charles Darnay found that making another request was hopeless; moreover, his pride would be hurt.
tr: Darnay felt that there was no point in pleading any further, moreover, his pride was hurt.
es: Darnay fell silent, both because he considered all chances of obtaining even the slightest favor from that man to be definitively lost, and because his wounded pride led him to view his pleas as humiliations.

en: As they walked on in silence, he could not but see how used the people were to the spectacle of prisoners passing along the streets.
vi: As they walked quietly, he couldn't help but notice that the people had become too accustomed to the sight of prisoners being escorted through the streets.
tr: As he proceeded in silence, he saw how familiar the public was with prisoners passing by.
es: He couldn't help but notice, as he silently walked through the streets, how accustomed the people were to the sight of prisoners passing by.

en: The very children scarcely noticed him.
vi: Even children didn't bother to pay attention to him.
tr: Except for a few children, no one noticed him.
es: Not even the children paid attention to him.

en: A few passers turned their heads, and a few shook their fingers at him as an aristocrat; otherwise, that a man in good clothes should be going to prison, was no more remarkable than that a labourer in working clothes should be going to work.
vi: A few people passing by turned to look, a few gestured at him as if he were a nobleman; besides that, the sight of a well-dressed person going to prison was no more special than that of a laborer in shabby clothes going to work.
tr: Two or three passersby turned their heads to look, and a few, thinking he was an aristocrat, pointed their fingers and shook them; after all, a well-dressed man being taken to prison had become as normal as a worker going to his job in his work clothes.
es: Some passersby turned their heads and pointed at him, indicating that he was an aristocrat, and nothing more. Indeed, seeing a well-dressed man being taken to prison was as common and natural as seeing a worker heading to his job with his tools in hand.

en: In one narrow, dark, and dirty street through which they passed, an excited orator, mounted on a stool, was addressing an excited audience on the crimes against the people, of the king and the royal family.
vi: In a narrow, dark, filthy street they passed through, an impassioned orator stood on a stool, speaking to an eager crowd about the crimes against the people committed by the king and the royal family.
tr: In a narrow, dark, and dirty street they passed, an excited speaker standing on a stool was telling an enthusiastic crowd about the crimes the king and the royal family had committed against the people.
es: In a narrow, dark, and dirty alley they had to cross, they encountered a highly agitated street orator, delivering fervent speeches to an equally agitated audience, extolling the crimes committed against the sovereign people by the King, the royal family, and the nobles.

en: The few words that he caught from this man’s lips, first made it known to Charles Darnay that the king was in prison, and that the foreign ambassadors had one and all left Paris.
vi: Now, hearing a few words from this person, Charles Darnay learned that the king had been imprisoned and all foreign envoys had left Paris, leaving no one behind.
tr: As far as Charles Darnay could catch from this man's lips, the king was in prison and all the foreign ambassadors had left Paris.
es: From the few words that reached Darnay's ears, he was able to infer that the King had been imprisoned and that foreign ambassadors had left Paris en masse, news of which he was entirely unaware, as during his journey, the individuals escorting him, along with the universal surveillance, had kept him in such absolute isolation that he had heard nothing.

en: On the road (except at Beauvais) he had heard absolutely nothing.
vi: Along the way (except when in Beauvais), he hadn't heard any news.
tr: He had heard nothing on the road (except outside Beauvais).
es: From the few words that reached Darnay's ears, he was able to infer that the King had been imprisoned and that foreign ambassadors had left Paris en masse, news of which he was entirely unaware, as during his journey, the individuals escorting him, along with the universal surveillance, had kept him in such absolute isolation that he had heard nothing.

en: The escort and the universal watchfulness had completely isolated him.
vi: The escort and the surveillance everywhere had completely isolated him.
tr: His escorts and his great anxiety must have isolated him from everything.
es: From the few words that reached Darnay's ears, he was able to infer that the King had been imprisoned and that foreign ambassadors had left Paris en masse, news of which he was entirely unaware, as during his journey, the individuals escorting him, along with the universal surveillance, had kept him in such absolute isolation that he had heard nothing.

en: That he had fallen among far greater dangers than those which had developed themselves when he left England, he of course knew now.
vi: Now, of course, he knew that he had fallen into dangers far greater than those that had arisen since he left England.
tr: He knew now that he was in much greater dangers than those he was in when he left England.
es: As is natural, he understood that the dangers threatening him were infinitely greater and infinitely more numerous than he had supposed when leaving England; he understood that the dangers were multiplying at an alarming rate and that they would multiply even more; he could not help but confess to himself that the idea of making the journey would never have crossed his mind had he foreseen the events that had unfolded in recent days.

en: That perils had thickened about him fast, and might thicken faster and faster yet, he of course knew now.
vi: Now, of course, he knew that those dangers were quickly closing in on him and the situation had become increasingly urgent.
tr: He also knew now that the threat was rapidly increasing and would continue to increase.
es: As is natural, he understood that the dangers threatening him were infinitely greater and infinitely more numerous than he had supposed when leaving England; he understood that the dangers were multiplying at an alarming rate and that they would multiply even more; he could not help but confess to himself that the idea of making the journey would never have crossed his mind had he foreseen the events that had unfolded in recent days.

en: He could not but admit to himself that he might not have made this journey, if he could have foreseen the events of a few days.
vi: He had to admit to himself that if he had known about these developments a few days earlier, he would not have taken that trip.
tr: If he had known what he would experience in the last few days, he might never have embarked on this journey.
es: As is natural, he understood that the dangers threatening him were infinitely greater and infinitely more numerous than he had supposed when leaving England; he understood that the dangers were multiplying at an alarming rate and that they would multiply even more; he could not help but confess to himself that the idea of making the journey would never have crossed his mind had he foreseen the events that had unfolded in recent days.

en: And yet his misgivings were not so dark as, imagined by the light of this later time, they would appear.
vi: However, looking back more clearly later, we will see that Darnay's worries were not as bleak as he thought.
tr: Still, his anxieties were not as dark as they seemed; there was a faint light, it seemed.
es: And yet, his fears, when examined in the light of the most recent incidents, were not as great as they seem they should have been.

en: Troubled as the future was, it was the unknown future, and in its obscurity there was ignorant hope.
vi: Even if the future is uncertain, it remains an unknown future, and it is precisely because of this uncertainty that we still have hope.
tr: The future was as uncertain as it was troubled, and within all this uncertainty, there was an ignorant hope.
es: No matter how nebulous the future appeared to him, it was an unknown future that, in its very obscurity, held a certain hope.

en: The horrible massacre, days and nights long, which, within a few rounds of the clock, was to set a great mark of blood upon the blessed garnering time of harvest, was as far out of his knowledge as if it had been a hundred thousand years away.
vi: In his understanding, there was no hint of the horrific massacre that lasted many days and nights, a massacre that, in just a few turns of the clock's hands, had stained an entire season of fortunate fruits with blood; that image seemed as distant as if it had been a hundred thousand years ago.
tr: The massacre that would begin in a few hours and last for days and nights would stain the sacred harvest time with blood, but to Darnay, it felt like something that would happen a hundred thousand years later.
es: As unaware as those who lived thousands of years before him, he was to the horrible massacres that, continuing day after day, night after night, would drown the always blessed harvest season in torrents of blood.

en: The “sharp female newly-born, and called La Guillotine,” was hardly known to him, or to the generality of people, by name.
vi: Neither he nor the French populace knew anything about "the newly born sharp lady named La Guillotine".
tr: "The newly born harsh lady guillotine" was not yet well-known by name.
es: He barely knew by name the "newly born woman called Guillotine," just as the general populace barely knew her by name, for in those days, even those who had brought her into the world could not have imagined the dreadful deeds that would soon envelop her in an immense bloody aura.

en: The frightful deeds that were to be soon done, were probably unimagined at that time in the brains of the doers.
vi: The terrible things that will be done perhaps even at this moment cannot be imagined even by those who will carry them out.
tr: The terrible actions that would soon take place perhaps had not yet formed in the minds of those who would carry them out.
es: He barely knew by name the "newly born woman called Guillotine," just as the general populace barely knew her by name, for in those days, even those who had brought her into the world could not have imagined the dreadful deeds that would soon envelop her in an immense bloody aura.

en: How could they have a place in the shadowy conceptions of a gentle mind?
vi: So how can a gentle mind possibly conceive of that in its own obscure awareness?
tr: How could all these fit into the vague concepts within a polite mind?
es: He barely knew by name the "newly born woman called Guillotine," just as the general populace barely knew her by name, for in those days, even those who had brought her into the world could not have imagined the dreadful deeds that would soon envelop her in an immense bloody aura.

en: Of unjust treatment in detention and hardship, and in cruel separation from his wife and child, he foreshadowed the likelihood, or the certainty; but, beyond this, he dreaded nothing distinctly.
vi: He had anticipated the possibility, or certainty, of being unjustly mistreated in harsh captivity, suffering the pain of separation from his wife and children; but beyond those things, he had no specific fears.
tr: While cruelly separated from his wife and child, he could foresee the unjust treatment he would endure in custody and the difficulties he would face, he was even certain of it; but beyond that, there was nothing specific he feared.
es: He suspected that he would be the victim of an arbitrary arrest, that he would be treated with irritating injustice, that he would have to endure deprivations and hardships, of which the least would not be being separated from his beloved wife and his idolized daughter; he suspected all of this; moreover, he considered it undeniable; but beyond that, he feared nothing.

en: With this on his mind, which was enough to carry into a dreary prison courtyard, he arrived at the prison of La Force.
vi: With that mindset, he stepped into the bleak courtyard of La Force prison - he had arrived.
tr: His mind filled with these thoughts, enough to fill a gloomy prison courtyard, they arrived at La Force Prison.
es: Such were the reflections that overwhelmed him when he arrived at the prison called La Force.

en: A man with a bloated face opened the strong wicket, to whom Defarge presented “The Emigrant Evrémonde.”
vi: A fat-faced man opened a small hatch in the iron gate for Defarge to hand over the "Exiled Evrémonde".
tr: A man with a swollen face opened the heavy door, and Defarge introduced Darnay by saying, "Refugee Evremonde."
es: A man with a fierce face opened the wicket. —The emigrant Evrémonde—said Defarge, introducing the prisoner.

en: “What the Devil!
vi: − Oh my god!
tr: "May God punish them!
es: —Crowned demons!

en: How many more of them!” exclaimed the man with the bloated face.
vi: How many more people are there! - The fat-faced guy exclaimed.
tr: Will they never end?" shouted the fat-faced man.
es: But is this procession never going to end?—exclaimed the one with the fierce face.

en: Defarge took his receipt without noticing the exclamation, and withdrew, with his two fellow-patriots.
vi: Not bothering to pay attention to the complaints, Defarge took the certificate and withdrew, along with his two patriotic Citizens. − Oh my God! I can't keep quiet! -
tr: Defarge took the receipt without paying attention to the man's shouting and returned with his two guards.
es: Defarge took the receipt that the jailer handed him, without paying attention to his exclamation, and withdrew along with the two patriots.

en: “What the Devil, I say again!” exclaimed the gaoler, left with his wife.
vi: The jailer exclaimed again when he was alone with his wife.
tr: The guard who remained with his wife shouted again, "May God punish them!"
es: —Thunder and lightning! —grumbled the jailer, now alone with his wife.—

en: “How many more!”
vi: - How much more! −
tr: "Will these never end?"
es: This is a river that always flows!

en: The gaoler’s wife, being provided with no answer to the question, merely replied, “One must have patience, my dear!”
vi: We must be patient, dear!
tr: His wife, who had no answer to this question, simply said, "You need to be patient, dear!"
es: The jailer's wife, who probably did not have the appropriate response in her repository of replies for the previous exclamation, simply answered: —You have to be patient, my friend.

en: Three turnkeys who entered responsive to a bell she rang, echoed the sentiment, and one added, “For the love of Liberty;” which sounded in that place like an inappropriate conclusion.
vi: - Unable to give a precise answer, the jailer's wife only responded like that and then rang the bell to call in the three wardens. They also agreed with her, and one person added, "For the love of Freedom," a phrase that echoed in this place like a paradoxical conclusion.
tr: The three guards who came upon hearing the woman's bell were of the same opinion, and one of them, although it wasn't quite appropriate for the situation, added, "For the love of freedom!"
es: The sounds of a bell that the woman rang evoked three jailers, who said in unison: —Long live Freedom! The choir did not seem the most appropriate to be sung in a place like that, but greater anomalies are seen in the world.

en: The prison of La Force was a gloomy prison, dark and filthy, and with a horrible smell of foul sleep in it.
vi: La Force Prison is a gloomy, dark, and filthy place, reeking of the foul stench of death.
tr: The dark and filthy La Force Prison was a gloomy prison, and inside there was a disgusting smell caused by heavy sleep.
es: La Force prison was a gloomy, repugnant, and filthy building, where one could breathe the foul atmosphere of death.

en: Extraordinary how soon the noisome flavour of imprisoned sleep, becomes manifest in all such places that are ill cared for!
vi: The overpowering smell of death, confined within, manifests so quickly and terribly in any place that is not properly cared for! − Solitary confinement again! -
tr: How quickly the disgusting smell of sleep, which was not properly attended to, would permeate such places where detainees were held!
es: It is truly astonishing how quickly the sense of smell detects the odor of flesh stored in places like that, especially when they are not suitable for the purpose and, in addition, are neglected.

en: “In secret, too,” grumbled the gaoler, looking at the written paper.
vi: The jailer grumbled, looking at the paper. -
tr: The guard grumbled, looking at the paper, "And it's supposed to be secret!"
es: —And also secret! —murmured the warden while reading the paper.—

en: “As if I was not already full to bursting!”
vi: As if it weren't already overcrowded here!
tr: "I'm already looking for a reason to explode!"
es: As if I weren't already so full of them that one of these days I'll explode!

en: He stuck the paper on a file, in an ill-humour, and Charles Darnay awaited his further pleasure for half an hour: sometimes, pacing to and fro in the strong arched room: sometimes, resting on a stone seat: in either case detained to be imprinted on the memory of the chief and his subordinates.
vi: He filed the paper away irritably, and Charles Darnay patiently waited for another half hour; sometimes he paced back and forth in the sturdy vaulted room, sometimes he sat on the stone bench - long enough for the jailer and his subordinates to remember him.
tr: Adam grumpily put the paper into a file, and Charles Darnay waited for about half an hour for him to regain his mood; sometimes walking up and down in the room filled with sharp belts, sometimes resting on a heavy stone; in any case, he was etched into the memory of the man standing over him and those beside him.
es: With signs of very bad temper, he skewered the paper with a spike that pierced many others, and began to pace around the vaulted room without paying the slightest attention to the prisoner, whom he kept waiting for more than half an hour.

en: “Come!” said the chief, at length taking up his keys, “come with me, emigrant.”
vi: − Let's go! - Finally, the warden picked up the bunch of keys. - Follow me, exile.
tr: "Come!" called the guard at the head, while taking out his key, "come with me, refugee."
es: "Follow me, emigrant," he finally said, taking the keys.

en: Through the dismal prison twilight, his new charge accompanied him by corridor and staircase, many doors clanging and locking behind them, until they came into a large, low, vaulted chamber, crowded with prisoners of both sexes.
vi: In the gloomy twilight of the prison, the person who had just received Darnay led him through corridors and staircases, with many doors clicking open and shut, locking behind them, until they reached a low-ceilinged, vaulted room crowded with both male and female prisoners.
tr: In the gloomy dim light of the prison, they walked through corridors and stairs accompanied by the new warden, many doors opened and locked behind them, and finally, they arrived at a large, low-ceilinged, domed hall filled with a multitude of inmates, both men and women.
es: The warden led the new inmate through a corridor and a staircase, and after several minutes, and not without opening many doors during the walk and closing them again after passing through, they arrived at a large, low-ceilinged, vaulted room, crowded with prisoners of both sexes.

en: The women were seated at a long table, reading and writing, knitting, sewing, and embroidering; the men were for the most part standing behind their chairs, or lingering up and down the room.
vi: The women sat at a long table, reading, writing, knitting, and embroidering; most of the men were leaning against the backs of chairs or pacing back and forth in the room.
tr: The women were seated at the head of a long table, some reading and writing, some knitting, and some sewing and embroidering; many of the men were either leaning back in their chairs or wandering up and down the hall.
es: The women were sitting around a table, reading or writing, knitting, sewing, or embroidering, while the men, for the most part, were standing behind the chairs occupied by the women, except for a few who were amusing themselves by walking around.

en: In the instinctive association of prisoners with shameful crime and disgrace, the new-comer recoiled from this company.
vi: The newcomer instinctively wanted to retreat and stay away when encountering this group of prisoners full of shameful sins.
tr: The newly arrived prisoner instinctively recoiled and stepped back upon seeing the inmates he associated with disgraceful crimes and scandals.
es: So gloomy was the room, so somber the expression of the people crowded there, so pronounced the yellowness that privations and misery had created on their faces, that Carlos Darnay believed he was among a large collection of the dead.

en: But the crowning unreality of his long unreal ride, was, their all at once rising to receive him, with every refinement of manner known to the time, and with all the engaging graces and courtesies of life.
vi: But the surreal, dream-like feeling throughout his long journey reached its peak when all those prisoners immediately stood up to welcome him with the most elegant, refined, and graceful manners of the contemporary nobility.
tr: But the most surreal part of this long and unreal journey was that they all stood up at that moment to greet him with the most polite manners of the time and all the elegance and grace that beautify life.
es: So gloomy was the room, so somber the expression of the people crowded there, so pronounced the yellowness that privations and misery had created on their faces, that Carlos Darnay believed he was among a large collection of the dead.

en: So strangely clouded were these refinements by the prison manners and gloom, so spectral did they become in the inappropriate squalor and misery through which they were seen, that Charles Darnay seemed to stand in a company of the dead.
vi: How tragic those delicate gestures were in the desolate scene of this prison, how ghostly they appeared in this wretched, filthy, ironic place, to the point that Charles Darnay felt as if he were standing before a crowd of corpses.
tr: The style and gloom of the prison had so strangely overshadowed these subtleties, and the prisoners had fallen into such bizarre states, resembling ghosts amidst all this inappropriate filth and misery, that Charles Darnay felt as if he were among a community of the dead.
es: So gloomy was the room, so somber the expression of the people crowded there, so pronounced the yellowness that privations and misery had created on their faces, that Carlos Darnay believed he was among a large collection of the dead.

en: Ghosts all!
vi: All ghosts!
tr: They all seemed like ghosts!
es: There were only ghosts there.

en: The ghost of beauty, the ghost of stateliness, the ghost of elegance, the ghost of pride, the ghost of frivolity, the ghost of wit, the ghost of youth, the ghost of age, all waiting their dismissal from the desolate shore, all turning on him eyes that were changed by the death they had died in coming there.
vi: Ghosts of beauty, ghosts of dignity, ghosts of grace, ghosts of pride, ghosts of frivolity, ghosts of cunning, ghosts of youth, ghosts of old age, all waiting to leave this desolate shore, all turning their eyes, transformed by the torment of death, towards him as they buried their lives in this prison.
tr: The ghost of beauty, the ghost of splendor, the ghost of grace, the ghost of pride, the ghost of frivolity, the ghost of intelligence, the ghosts of youth and old age, all were waiting for the day they would escape from this desolate shore, and all had turned their dead eyes, which had died upon entering the prison, towards him.
es: Ghosts of beauty, ghosts of elegance, ghosts of haughtiness, ghosts of pride, ghosts of frivolity, ghosts of talent, ghosts of youth, ghosts of old age, all of them waiting for the hour to leave the inhospitable shore of the world, all of them fixing their eyes on the newcomer, eyes that death had altered as soon as they entered the antechamber of its domains.

en: It struck him motionless.
vi: He stood there stunned and silent.
tr: Charles Darnay was frozen in place at the sight.
es: Darnay remained motionless, rigid, due to his astonishment.

en: The gaoler standing at his side, and the other gaolers moving about, who would have been well enough as to appearance in the ordinary exercise of their functions, looked so extravagantly coarse contrasted with sorrowing mothers and blooming daughters who were there—with the apparitions of the coquette, the young beauty, and the mature woman delicately bred—that the inversion of all experience and likelihood which the scene of shadows presented, was heightened to its utmost.
vi: The prison warden stood next to him and the other wardens around, who would not look so bad in their normal daily work, but compared to the grieving mothers, the young girls in their prime in this prison, the ghosts with their graceful appearance, the youthful beauty and mature elegance of the noblewomen - they looked strangely rough, contrasting to the extent that this dark scene became extremely eerie.
tr: The guard was beside him, others were wandering around, and although they appeared normal with their usual busyness, they stood so crudely next to the sorrowful mothers and young girls in the prime of their lives – all those fancy women, beautiful young women, and well-mannered mature women ghosts – that the contrast created by every kind of experience and possibility represented by these silhouettes was at its extremes.
es: The appearance of the warden, who stood beside him, no less than that of the jailers who moved from one place to another, undoubtedly in full exercise of their high functions, was so rough, so brutal, so ferocious, especially when compared to that of the distressed mothers and the beautiful daughters stored there, with the coquetry and distinction typical of well-born young women and the refined manners of the high-ranking lady, that Darnay had to reinforce his belief that he had been confined in the mansion of specters.

en: Surely, ghosts all.
vi: Yes, all ghosts.
tr: They must all have been ghosts.
es: The appearance of the warden, who stood beside him, no less than that of the jailers who moved from one place to another, undoubtedly in full exercise of their high functions, was so rough, so brutal, so ferocious, especially when compared to that of the distressed mothers and the beautiful daughters stored there, with the coquetry and distinction typical of well-born young women and the refined manners of the high-ranking lady, that Darnay had to reinforce his belief that he had been confined in the mansion of specters.

en: Surely, the long unreal ride some progress of disease that had brought him to these gloomy shades!
vi: Yes, the long, illusory journey, the miserable miles, had brought him to meet these sorrowful ghosts! −
tr: At the end of this long, surreal, and afflicted road, these gloomy figures had appeared before him!
es: The appearance of the warden, who stood beside him, no less than that of the jailers who moved from one place to another, undoubtedly in full exercise of their high functions, was so rough, so brutal, so ferocious, especially when compared to that of the distressed mothers and the beautiful daughters stored there, with the coquetry and distinction typical of well-born young women and the refined manners of the high-ranking lady, that Darnay had to reinforce his belief that he had been confined in the mansion of specters.

en: “In the name of the assembled companions in misfortune,” said a gentleman of courtly appearance and address, coming forward, “I have the honour of giving you welcome to La Force, and of condoling with you on the calamity that has brought you among us.
vi: In the name of the friends met in misfortune, - a man of noble appearance and polite speech approached, - I am honored to welcome you to La Force, and to sympathize with the misfortune that has brought you to us.
tr: A distinguished-looking gentleman approached and said, "On behalf of this unfortunate community, I am honored to welcome you to La Force and to share in whatever misfortune has brought you among us.
es: "—In my own name and on behalf of all the unfortunate companions gathered here," said a gentleman with courtly manners, stepping forward, "I have the honor of welcoming you to La Force, and to lament with you the calamity that brings you here."

en: May it soon terminate happily!
vi: May it quickly have a happy ending!
tr: We hope that your sufferings will come to an end as soon as possible.
es: "May it be of brief duration and end with happiness!"

en: It would be an impertinence elsewhere, but it is not so here, to ask your name and condition?”
vi: Elsewhere it might be rude to ask, but not here, may I know your name and status?
tr: In any other place, it would certainly be inappropriate to ask, but given the circumstances here, may we know your name and situation?"
es: "Now then, expressing our wishes would be an unforgivable impertinence anywhere else, but not here." "We take the liberty of asking your name and status."

en: Charles Darnay roused himself, and gave the required information, in words as suitable as he could find.
vi: Charles Darnay awoke and responded with the words he found most appropriate.
tr: Charles Darnay composed himself and introduced himself with the most appropriate words he could find.
es: Darnay hastened to comply with the wishes expressed by the gentleman.

en: “But I hope,” said the gentleman, following the chief gaoler with his eyes, who moved across the room, “that you are not in secret?”
vi: − But I hope that, - the nobleman said while glancing at the chief warden who was walking across the room, - you are not in solitary confinement?
tr: "But I hope," said the polite gentleman, watching the chief warden roaming the room with his eyes, "you are not one of the secret ones.""
es: —I suppose you are not here "in secret"—replied the gentleman, following with his gaze the warden who was crossing the room at that moment.

en: “I do not understand the meaning of the term, but I have heard them say so.”
vi: − I don't fully understand the meaning of that word but I have heard them say it.
tr: "I don't know what this statement means, but I heard them say it like this.""
es: —Two or three times I have heard that password mentioned in reference to me, but I do not know what it could mean.

en: “Ah, what a pity!
vi: − Ah, how pitiful!
tr: "Ah, what a pity!"
es: —Oh, what a pity!

en: We so much regret it!
vi: We are very sorry!
tr: "We are very sorry about this!"
es: We truly regret it...

en: But take courage; several members of our society have been in secret, at first, and it has lasted but a short time.”
vi: But be brave; many people in our circle have been in solitary confinement at first, but only for a short time. -
tr: "But don't lose your courage; many people here were secretive when they first arrived, but this situation didn't last long."
es: But do not be discouraged. Many have come here "in secret" and then their situation has changed.

en: Then he added, raising his voice, “I grieve to inform the society—in secret.”
vi: Then he raised his voice and spoke to everyone. - It is with great sadness that I must inform you... solitary confinement.
tr: Then, raising his voice, he added, "I'm sorry to say this, but – it was secretive.""
es: Then he added, raising his voice: —With deep regret, I inform my colleagues that... in secret.

en: There was a murmur of commiseration as Charles Darnay crossed the room to a grated door where the gaoler awaited him, and many voices—among which, the soft and compassionate voices of women were conspicuous—gave him good wishes and encouragement.
vi: The murmurs of concern echoed as Charles Darnay walked through the room to the barred door where the jailer was waiting for him, many blessings and encouragements were given to him - among which the most distinct was the sympathetic, gentle voice of a woman.
tr: As Charles Darnay crossed the room and advanced towards the barred door where the guard awaited him, murmurs of compassion rose from the crowd, many of which – the most distinct being from women with soft and affectionate voices – encouraged him with well-wishes.
es: As Charles Darnay approached the door defended with a thick grate, next to which the jailer awaited him, strong murmurs of commiseration arose, mixed with phrases of pity from the women, who strove to encourage him.

en: He turned at the grated door, to render the thanks of his heart; it closed under the gaoler’s hand; and the apparitions vanished from his sight forever.
vi: At the barred door, he turned to express his gratitude; the door closed under the jailer's hand; and those shadows disappeared forever.
tr: When Darnay reached the barred door, he turned to offer them his thanks; the guard closed the iron door, and the phantoms vanished from his sight forever.
es: Having reached the mentioned door, Charles turned and thanked those he was leaving from the bottom of his heart. The door was closed by the hand of the jailer, and the spectral apparitions faded away forever.

en: The wicket opened on a stone staircase, leading upward.
vi: That doorway led to a stone staircase, leading upwards.
tr: The door opened to a stone staircase leading upwards.
es: The door gave access to a spiral staircase, which Darnay ascended following his guide.

en: When they had ascended forty steps (the prisoner of half an hour already counted them), the gaoler opened a low black door, and they passed into a solitary cell.
vi: When they had climbed about forty steps (the prisoner, having been confined for half an hour, had counted the steps), the jailer opened a low, black door, and they entered the confinement cell.
tr: After climbing forty steps together (the half-hour prisoner had counted each step), the guard opened a low black door and they entered an empty cell.
es: After climbing forty steps, carefully counted by the prisoner of half an hour, the jailer opened a low and very black door and entered a solitary cell.

en: It struck cold and damp, but was not dark.
vi: Cold, damp, but not dark.
tr: It was cold and damp but not dark.
es: It was very cold, smelled of mold, but it was not dark.

en: “Yours,” said the gaoler.
vi: − It's yours, - the jailer said.
tr: "This is yours," said the guard.
es: —Yours—said the warden.

en: “Why am I confined alone?”
vi: − Why am I being held in solitary confinement? −
tr: "Why are they keeping me alone?"
es: —Why are they locking me up alone?

en: “How do I know!”
vi: How would I know?
tr: "How should I know?""
es: —That is what I don't know.

en: “I can buy pen, ink, and paper?”
vi: − Can I buy a pen, paper, and ink? − I don't know if you can.
tr: "Can I get a pen, ink, and paper?"
es: —I suppose I will be allowed to buy paper, pen, and ink?

en: “Such are not my orders.
vi: Someone will come to see you, and you can ask them then.
tr: "I was not given such an order.
es: —For the moment, no.

en: You will be visited, and can ask then.
vi: Someone will come to see you, and you can ask them then.
tr: You can ask when they come to see you.
es: They will visit you... I don't know when, and then you can request that favor.

en: At present, you may buy your food, and nothing more.”
vi: For now, you can only buy food and nothing else.
tr: For now, you can only get food."
es: You can buy food, but nothing else.

en: There were in the cell, a chair, a table, and a straw mattress.
vi: In the cell, there was a chair, a table, and a straw mattress.
tr: There was a table, a chair, and a straw-filled mattress in the cell.
es: In the cell, there was a chair, a table, and a straw mattress.

en: As the gaoler made a general inspection of these objects, and of the four walls, before going out, a wandering fancy wandered through the mind of the prisoner leaning against the wall opposite to him, that this gaoler was so unwholesomely bloated, both in face and person, as to look like a man who had been drowned and filled with water.
vi: While the guard was inspecting these items and the four walls before leaving, a vague delusion flitted through the mind of the prisoner who was standing leaning against the opposite wall: this guard was swelling up in a morbid way, both his face and body, like a drowned man bloated with water.
tr: Before the guard left, while inspecting these items and the walls of the cell, a flood of thoughts passed through Darnay's distracted mind as he leaned against the wall directly opposite the guard; the guard's face and body were so unhealthily swollen that he looked like a drowned man filled with water.
es: The warden, after subjecting the cell's furniture to a meticulous inspection, left, leaving Darnay alone.

en: When the gaoler was gone, he thought in the same wandering way, “Now am I left, as if I were dead.”
vi: After the guard left, he also thought vaguely, "Now it's just me, as if I were already dead."
tr: When the guard left, in the same distraction, he thought, "I have been abandoned as if I were dead."
es: —I can say that I am dead and buried—murmured the unfortunate one.

en: Stopping then, to look down at the mattress, he turned from it with a sick feeling, and thought, “And here in these crawling creatures is the first condition of the body after death.”
vi: Cutting off his thoughts, he looked down at the mattress and then turned away in disgust, "Seeing the bugs crawling here is the first stage of a corpse's decay."
tr: Then he stopped and looked at the mattress, turned his head away in disgust, and thought, "and the first thing my body encountered after death were the creatures crawling over there."

en: “Five paces by four and a half, five paces by four and a half, five paces by four and a half.”
vi: “One side five steps, one side four and a half, one side five steps, one side four and a half, one side five steps, one side four and a half.”
tr: "Five and a half steps, five and a half steps, five and a half steps."
es: Five steps by four and a half... five steps by four and a half—he repeated mechanically, pacing the cell in all directions and counting at the same time.

en: The prisoner walked to and fro in his cell, counting its measurement, and the roar of the city arose like muffled drums with a wild swell of voices added to them.
vi: The prisoner walked back and forth in the cell, counting the length, and the roar of the city below echoed up like a muffled drum accompanied by a chaotic wave of human voices.
tr: The prisoner was pacing up and down in the cell, measuring the room, and the city's hum, mixed with the maddening sounds, was increasing like the muffled sounds of drums.
es: The noise of the city reached his ears transformed into a kind of muffled drumbeat mixed with shrill human voices.

en: “He made shoes, he made shoes, he made shoes.”
vi: “He makes shoes, he makes shoes, he makes shoes.”
tr: "Those shoes would do, those shoes would do, those shoes would do."
es: —Five steps by four and a half... Made shoes... five steps by four and a half... made shoes... shoes...

en: The prisoner counted the measurement again, and paced faster, to draw his mind with him from that latter repetition.
vi: The prisoner counted the length again, quickening his pace, to drive that thought from resurfacing in his mind.
tr: The prisoner measured the room again and, as if trying to keep his mind away from these words, took his steps faster this time.
es: The prisoner quickened his pace and tried to count, in order to drive away the thought of the one making shoes, which threatened to become a fixed idea.

en: “The ghosts that vanished when the wicket closed.
vi: “The ghosts disappear when that door closes.
tr: "The ghosts that disappear when the door closes.
es: —The specters vanished as soon as I crossed the gate's door—he kept thinking.

en: There was one among them, the appearance of a lady dressed in black, who was leaning in the embrasure of a window, and she had a light shining upon her golden hair, and she looked like  *
vi: Among them is a lady in black leaning against the window, and she has bright golden hair, and she looks like...
tr: Among them was one, a woman in a black dress leaning against the window sill with golden hair illuminated by the light, as if a...
es: —I saw among them a lady dressed in black, who was leaning on the windowsill. The light shone fully on her golden hair, and she seemed to...

en: Let us ride on again, for God’s sake, through the illuminated villages with the people all awake!
vi: Let us rush on, dear God, through the lit houses and the sleepless people!...
tr: For God's sake, let's keep going, let's pass through the bright villages where everyone is awake!..
es: My God... My God!...

vi: Let us rush on, dear God, through the lit houses and the sleepless people!...
tr: For God's sake, let's keep going, let's pass through the bright villages where everyone is awake!..
es: Will I ever walk again through the villages visited by the sunlight, through the villages where people awaken?

en: He made shoes, he made shoes, he made shoes.
vi: He makes shoes, he makes shoes, he makes shoes...
tr: Those shoes would do, shoes would do, shoes would do... Five and a half steps."
es: Making shoes... making shoes... making shoes...

en: * Five paces by four and a half.”
vi: One side five steps, one side four and a half.”
tr: Those shoes would do, shoes would do, shoes would do... Five and a half steps."
es: Five steps by four and a half... five steps by four and a half...

en: With such scraps tossing and rolling upward from the depths of his mind, the prisoner walked faster and faster, obstinately counting and counting; and the roar of the city changed to this extent—that it still rolled in like muffled drums, but with the wail of voices that he knew, in the swell that rose above them.
vi: With those fragmented thoughts raging inside, the prisoner walked faster, faster, stubbornly counting his steps; and the roar of the city changed its tone... it still droned like a muffled drum but a rising chaotic wave of human voices turned into the lament of dear brothers.
tr: With these thoughts coming from the deepest parts of his mind and struggling, the prisoner kept counting his steps faster and faster; the city's hum also kept increasing in the same way –the well-known screams accompanying the muffled drum sounds were relentless.
es: The prisoner walked with increasing speed, always absorbed in the same thoughts, always counting, always having before his mind's eye the vision of the shoemaker, while the din of the city continued to sound in his ears like a muffled drumroll mixed with cries from voices he knew and loved, with heart-wrenching wails emitted by throats that until then had barely given voice to sounds other than those reflecting the joy of the heart.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: 2. Grinding wheel
tr: II
es: II.

en: The Grindstone
vi: 2. Grinding wheel
tr: Whetstone
es: THE WHETSTONE

en: Tellson’s Bank, established in the Saint Germain Quarter of Paris, was in a wing of a large house, approached by a courtyard and shut off from the street by a high wall and a strong gate.
vi: The Tellson Bank in Paris was located in the Saint Germain area in an annex of a large mansion, deep at the end of a courtyard, separated from the street by a high wall and a sturdy gate.
tr: Tellson Bank in the Saint Germain area of Paris was located in a wing of a large building separated from the street by a high wall and a sturdy gate, with a courtyard in front of it.
es: The Tellson Bank, established in the Saint Germain district of Paris, occupied a wing of an immense building, preceded by a garden separated from the street by a fairly high wall and a very solid gate.

en: The house belonged to a great nobleman who had lived in it until he made a flight from the troubles, in his own cook’s dress, and got across the borders.
vi: This house belonged to a grand noble before he fled from danger, disguised in the clothes of his own chef, and crossed the border.
tr: The building belonged to a significant nobleman who, when troubles arose, donned his cook's attire, greased his heels, and successfully crossed the border.
es: The building was the property of one of the most powerful nobles in the kingdom, who had lived in it until the disturbances of the time forced him to flee, disguised in his cook's attire, and cross the border.

en: A mere beast of the chase flying from hunters, he was still in his metempsychosis no other than the same Monseigneur, the preparation of whose chocolate for whose lips had once occupied three strong men besides the cook in question.
vi: He was merely a beast being hunted, but in his previous life, he was the Lord who, every morning, needed three servants along with the aforementioned chef to lift the chocolate cup to his lips.
tr: This cunning individual, who managed to escape from the hunters and whose soul migration had yet to occur, was none other than the Monsignor who once needed three strong men in addition to his cook to bring his cocoa to his lips.
es: Although in reality he was reduced to the condition of a game piece that managed to evade the attacks of the beaters and hunters, he was still the same lord, whose important operation of preparing chocolate and bringing it to his glorious lips required the efforts of three servants, apart from those of the cook.

en: Monseigneur gone, and the three strong men absolving themselves from the sin of having drawn his high wages, by being more than ready and willing to cut his throat on the altar of the dawning Republic one and indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, Monseigneur’s house had been first sequestrated, and then confiscated.
vi: The lord had departed, and the three servants had absolved themselves of the guilt of receiving high wages from the noble by eagerly resolving to cut the throat of their former master to offer as a sacrifice on the altar of the nascent United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, when the mansion of this grand official had been confiscated and nationalized.
tr: The Monsignor had fled, and the three powerful men who sinned while drawing high salaries from him had exonerated themselves at the altar of the newborn "Republic One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death," eager and impatient to slit his throat, had seized the Monsignor's house and confiscated all his property.
es: The master had left; his servants absolved themselves of the horrendous sin of having received his wages by showing themselves perfectly willing to slit his throat on the brand-new altar of the One and Indivisible Republic, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death, and the master's sumptuous property was first seized and then confiscated.

en: For, all things moved so fast, and decree followed decree with that fierce precipitation, that now upon the third night of the autumn month of September, patriot emissaries of the law were in possession of Monseigneur’s house, and had marked it with the tri-colour, and were drinking brandy in its state apartments.
vi: The situation developed too swiftly, with one decree following another, frantically and urgently, so on the third night of September in the autumn, the patriotic delegation of the new government took over the lord's mansion, marked it with the tricolor flag, and drank brandy in the luxurious rooms inside.
tr: Events were progressing so rapidly, and laws were being passed in such a frenzied rush one after another, that by the third night of September, the patriotic representatives of the laws had taken over the Monsignor's house, painted everything in three colors, and were drinking brandy in his rooms.
es: Things were done with such dizzying speed, and the decrees followed one another with such fierce haste, that by the third night of September, patriotic emissaries of the law had taken possession of the house in question, purified it by raising the tricolor flag over it, and were smoking and getting nicely drunk in its luxurious rooms.

en: A place of business in London like Tellson’s place of business in Paris, would soon have driven the House out of its mind and into the Gazette.
vi: A business place in London like Tellson's in Paris would quickly drive the Owner mad and declare bankruptcy in the Gazette.
tr: If Tellson's London branch had been no different from its Paris branch, it would soon have driven the manager insane and caused the bank's bankruptcy.
es: If the Tellson House in London had resembled the Tellson House in Paris, the Londoners would surely have soon seen it listed among the bankrupt entities deserving to appear in the Gazette.

en: For, what would staid British responsibility and respectability have said to orange-trees in boxes in a Bank courtyard, and even to a Cupid over the counter?
vi: How would these calm, responsible, and respectable Englishmen react to the orange trees in pots in front of the bank, and to the statue of Cupid on the counter?
tr: Who knows what the dignified and respectable Englishmen, symbols of sobriety and respectability, would say when they saw the orange trees planted in wooden boxes in the bank's courtyard and Cupid behind the counter?
es: What would the staunch English respectability have said if, in the lobby of a Bank, they had found abundant pots planted with orange trees and... horror! the figure of a Cupid presiding over the cash register?

en: Yet such things were.
vi: But Tellson's in Paris was like that.
tr: But such things were happening.
es: And yet, as inconceivable as it may seem, such was the case at the Tellson Bank in Paris.

en: Tellson’s had whitewashed the Cupid, but he was still to be seen on the ceiling, in the coolest linen, aiming (as he very often does) at money from morning to night.
vi: The staff here had painted the statue of Cupid white, but it could still be seen hanging from the ceiling, dressed in thin fabric, aiming its bow at money from morning till night (often the target of love).
tr: Although Tellson had plastered over Cupid, he could still be seen on the ceiling in his light attire, aiming at money from morning till night, as he often did.
es: True, Tellson had whitewashed the Cupid on the wall with several coats of lime, but the one on the ceiling remained, scantily clad, gazing anxiously at the cash register (as it usually does) from dawn until nightfall.

en: Bankruptcy must inevitably have come of this young Pagan, in Lombard-street, London, and also of a curtained alcove in the rear of the immortal boy, and also of a looking-glass let into the wall, and also of clerks not at all old, who danced in public on the slightest provocation.
vi: In Lombard Street, London, if one saw this little deity, saw the alcove draped behind it, saw the mirror mounted on the wall, and saw all the young employees easily getting angry with customers, it would only lead to bankruptcy.
tr: This young pagan must have inevitably brought bankruptcy to London, to Lombard Street, and of course, the partitioned area behind this immortal child, the mirror set into the wall, and the not-so-old clerks who would come out and dance among the people at the slightest provocation.
es: The most tremendous bankruptcy would have been the fatal and inevitable consequence of the presence of that pleasant pagan on Lombard Street in London, if it had not already been enough to cause it, a half-hidden alcove among rich curtains, in front of which stood the mischievous child, the immense mirror left on the wall, and the employees themselves, not as old as one would desire, who had no qualms about dancing in public with little encouragement.

en: Yet, a French Tellson’s could get on with these things exceedingly well, and, as long as the times held together, no man had taken fright at them, and drawn out his money.
vi: Yet at Tellson's in France, these things did not matter; the bank thrived, as long as the situation remained under control and no one panicked and withdrew all their money.
tr: Tellson in France could handle such things quite well, and as long as things were going smoothly, no one had been frightened enough to withdraw their money.
es: It is true that a French Tellson could afford all that and even more, without scandalizing anyone, without any capitalist even dreaming of withdrawing their capitals for such insignificant reasons.

en: What money would be drawn out of Tellson’s henceforth, and what would lie there, lost and forgotten; what plate and jewels would tarnish in Tellson’s hiding-places, while the depositors rusted in prisons, and when they should have violently perished; how many accounts with Tellson’s never to be balanced in this world, must be carried over into the next; no man could have said, that night, any more than mr Jarvis Lorry could, though he thought heavily of these questions.
vi: From now on, how much money will be withdrawn from Tellson, how much will remain there, lost and forgotten; how many gold and silver treasures will tarnish in Tellson's vaults while their owners, who deposited them, rot in prison or will one day die in pieces; how many Tellson accounts will never be settled in this world and must be transferred to the next? No one could answer that, on that night, not even Mr. Jarvis Lorry, although he was pondering those very questions.
tr: From now on, what money would be withdrawn from Tellson's and what money would lie there, lost and forgotten; while their owners rotted in prisons and were violently punished and destroyed, what gold and jewels would tarnish in Tellson's vaults; how many accounts at Tellson's would remain open in this world and be left to be settled in the next; that night, there was no one who could answer these questions, immersed in deep thoughts, other than Mr. Jarvis Lorry.
es: How much money would henceforth come out of the coffers of the Tellson House in Paris, how much would remain there lost and forgotten, how much silver, how many jewels would lose their immaculate shine in the establishment's secret chambers, while their owners lost it in the dungeons or on the scaffold, how many current accounts of the Bank would remain unsettled in this world and pass to the next, is what no mortal could have said, what not even approximately managed to conjecture that night the very same Maurice Lorry, despite having repeated these questions hundreds of times.

en: He sat by a newly-lighted wood fire (the blighted and unfruitful year was prematurely cold), and on his honest and courageous face there was a deeper shade than the pendent lamp could throw, or any object in the room distortedly reflect—a shade of horror.
vi: He sat by the newly lit fireplace (this withering year turned cold early), on his brave and honest face was a dark shadow that neither the hanging lamp nor any distorted reflection in this room could dispel the darkness of horror.
tr: The honest and brave face of Mr. Lorry, sitting by the newly lit fireplace (amidst all the chaos and scarcity, winter had also come early), was covered by a shadow deeper than anything the hanging lamp or anything else in the room could reflect – the shadow of terror.
es: Sitting by the fireplace where some logs were crackling and burning (that barren and unproductive year had brought forward the cold season), his face, a reflection of honesty, showed shadows that were not cast by the hanging lamp from the ceiling nor by any of the objects in the room.

en: He occupied rooms in the Bank, in his fidelity to the House of which he had grown to be a part, like strong root-ivy.
vi: Dedicated to the club that had become intimately attached to his entire life, he stayed permanently in this bank.
tr: Mr. Lorry, like a well-rooted ivy, was staying in one of the rooms at the bank due to his long-standing loyalty to the company he had served for years.
es: Lorry occupied rooms in the Bank building, to which his proven loyalty to the house, of which he was an integral part, gave him indisputable right.

en: It chanced that they derived a kind of security from the patriotic occupation of the main building, but the true-hearted old gentleman never calculated about that.
vi: It was also by chance that the Tellson Bank in Paris was safely protected by a group of patriots who had occupied the main building, but this honest old man never considered that.
tr: In this way, they were providing a kind of security against the patriotic occupation of the main building; but the kind-hearted old gentleman never gave it a thought.
es: Many believed that the patriotic occupation of almost the entire building was a guarantee of security for the establishment, although the loyal Lorry never shared such a belief.

en: All such circumstances were indifferent to him, so that he did his duty.
vi: He was indifferent to all circumstances, only knowing to perform his duty.
tr: He minded his own business and never concerned himself with such matters.
es: Whatever happened in Paris was indifferent to him, for the only thing that aroused his interest was the fulfillment of his duty.

en: On the opposite side of the courtyard, under a colonnade, was extensive standing—for carriages—where, indeed, some carriages of Monseigneur yet stood.
vi: At the other end of the courtyard, under the colonnade, was a long stretch of ground reserved for carriages, in fact, a few old lordly carriages were still there.
tr: At the bottom of the courtyard, under the columns, there was a wide area for carriages – even the carriages of Monseigneur were parked there.
