es: It had been implemented some time before by the most fervent patriots, but by the time we refer to, it was mandatory for everyone.

en: “Walking here again, citizeness?”
vi: − Here again, Citizeness? −
tr: "Gene buralarda mı dolaşıyorsun yurttaş?"
es: —Taking a walk around here, citizen?

en: “You see me, citizen!”
vi: Well, you see, Citizen!
tr: "As you can see, citizen!"
es: —You are already seeing it, citizen.

en: The wood-sawyer, who was a little man with a redundancy of gesture (he had once been a mender of roads), cast a glance at the prison, pointed at the prison, and putting his ten fingers before his face to represent bars, peeped through them jocosely.
vi: The sawyer was a short man accustomed to exaggerated gestures (he used to be a road worker). He glanced towards the prison, pointed, then held up ten fingers in front of his face as if they were bars, and humorously pretended to peer through them.
tr: The small and overly gesticulative sawyer (who was once a road worker) glanced at the prison, pointed at it, and in a comical manner, brought his ten fingers in front of his face like bars, pretending to look through them.
es: The sawyer, who in earlier times had been a road worker, raised his eyes, extended his arm in the direction of the prison, brought both hands to his face placing his fingers in a way that represented bars, looked through them, and let out a significant laugh.

en: “But it’s not my business,” said he.
vi: − But that's not my business, - he said.
tr: "Whatever, it's none of my business," he said.
es: —It's not my business—he said,—and continued sawing.

en: And went on sawing his wood.
vi: And continued sawing wood.
tr: Then he continued chopping the wood.
es: —It's not my business—he said,—and continued sawing.

en: Next day he was looking out for her, and accosted her the moment she appeared.
vi: The next day he waited for Lucie, and as soon as she arrived, he started a conversation.
tr: The next day, he waited for Lucie and approached her as soon as she arrived.
es: The next day, it seemed that the sawyer was waiting for Lucía, as he approached her as soon as she appeared in the alley.

en: “What?
vi: − What?
tr: "Huh?
es: —Out for a walk here again, citizen?

en: Walking here again, citizeness?”
vi: Walking again, Citizeness?
tr: Are you wandering around here again, citizen?"
es: —Out for a walk here again, citizen?

en: “Yes, citizen.”
vi: − Yes, Citizen.
tr: "Yes, citizen."
es: —Yes, citizen.

en: “Ah!
vi: − Ah! Another child!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Ah!

en: A child too!
vi: − Ah! Another child!
tr: You've brought a child too!
es: And with a little girl?

en: Your mother, is it not, my little citizeness?”
vi: This is your mother, isn't it, little Citizen? −
tr: This is your mother, isn't it, little citizen?"
es: Your mom, little citizen, isn't that right?

en: “Do I say yes, mamma?” whispered little Lucie, drawing close to her.
vi: Can I speak, mom? - Little Lucie whispered, snuggling close to her mother.
tr: Little Lucie snuggled up to her mother and whispered, "Should I say yes, mom?"
es: —Should I say yes, mom?—asked the girl in a low voice, approaching her mother.

en: “Yes, dearest.”
vi: − Okay, my dear.
tr: "Yes, my dear.""
es: —Yes, dear, yes.

en: “Yes, citizen.”
vi: − Yes, sir Citizen.
tr: "Yes, citizen.""
es: —Yes, citizen—replied Lucita.

en: “Ah!
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Ah!

en: But it’s not my business.
vi: But that is not my business.
tr: But it doesn't concern me.
es: It's not my business.

en: My work is my business.
vi: My business is to work.
tr: I'll mind my own business.
es: It's not my business.

en: See my saw!
vi: Look at my saw!
tr: Have you seen my saw?
es: The only thing that interests me is working...

en: I call it my Little Guillotine.
vi: I call it Little Guillotine.
tr: I call it my little guillotine.
es: Look at my saw, citizen... I call it my dear Guillotine... La, la, la, la, la... and a head falls.

en: La, la, la; La, la, la!
vi: La, la, la; La, la, la!
tr: La, la, la; la, la, la!
es: Look at my saw, citizen... I call it my dear Guillotine... La, la, la, la, la... and a head falls.

en: And off his head comes!”
vi: And his head falls!
tr: There goes the man's head!"
es: Look at my saw, citizen... I call it my dear Guillotine... La, la, la, la, la... and a head falls.

en: The billet fell as he spoke, and he threw it into a basket.
vi: A short piece of wood fell down while he was talking and sawing, then he threw the piece of wood into the basket.
tr: While Adam was talking, the log fell to the ground, and he picked it up and threw it into the basket.
es: Indeed; while he was speaking, the piece of wood fell, and the sawyer put it into a basket.

en: “I call myself the Samson of the firewood guillotine.
vi: − I call myself the Samson of the woodchopper.
tr: "I call myself the Samson of the wood guillotine.
es: —I give myself the name of Samson, the Fuel Guillotine.

en: See here again!
vi: Look here!
tr: Look now, again!
es: —I give myself the name of Samson, the Fuel Guillotine.

en: Loo, loo, loo; Loo, loo, loo!
vi: Chop, chop, chop; Chop, chop, chop!
tr: Loo, loo, loo; loo, loo, loo!
es: —I give myself the name of Samson, the Fuel Guillotine.

en: And off her head comes!
vi: And her head falls!
tr: There goes the woman's head too!
es: I handle my device, and a head falls...

en: Now, a child.
vi: Now for the child.
tr: Now a child.
es: Now a woman's head falls... are you watching, citizen?

en: Tickle, tickle; Pickle, pickle!
vi: Chop, chop; Chop, chop!
tr: Come on, giddy giddy; biddy biddy!
es: It's the girl's turn... whack!

en: And off its head comes.
vi: And its head falls.
tr: There goes his head too.
es: Goodbye, little head!

en: All the family!”
vi: The whole family!
tr: We've taken care of the whole family!"
es: I finished with the whole family.

en: Lucie shuddered as he threw two more billets into his basket, but it was impossible to be there while the wood-sawyer was at work, and not be in his sight.
vi: Lucie shuddered as he threw two more logs into the basket, but she couldn't avoid the woodcutter while he was working.
tr: Lucie shuddered when the man threw two logs into the basket; but it was impossible to be there and not be seen by the sawyer while he was at work.
es: Lucía found it repugnant to watch the logs being sawed and could not see the act of placing them in the basket without feeling a shudder, but it was impossible for her to stay in that place during the sawyer's working hours without him seeing her.

en: Thenceforth, to secure his good will, she always spoke to him first, and often gave him drink-money, which he readily received.
vi: Since then, to avoid his ill-will, she always initiated conversation with him first and often sent him some money for drinks, which he readily accepted.
tr: Since that day, Lucie would first chat with him every time she went there to ensure he wouldn't cause any harm, and she often gave him money for drinks; he would accept it without any hesitation.
es: Henceforth, in order to win his sympathies, not only did she take the initiative to speak to him, but she also gave him some coins for a drink, which he accepted without hesitation.

en: He was an inquisitive fellow, and sometimes when she had quite forgotten him in gazing at the prison roof and grates, and in lifting her heart up to her husband, she would come to herself to find him looking at her, with his knee on his bench and his saw stopped in its work.
vi: He was a curious man, and often Lucie would forget about him as she gazed at the roof and the barred windows of the prison, her mind on her husband, only to suddenly realize that he was watching her, kneeling on the carpenter's bench but with his saw no longer working.
tr: The sawyer was a curious man; sometimes, when Lucie would forget him and, with her eyes lost in the prison's roof and bars, open her heart to her husband, she would suddenly come to herself and find the man, with his saw halted in his hand, his knee braced against his stool, watching her.
es: The sawyer was an extremely curious individual. Many times, when Lucía, forgetting his presence, would remain for a long time with her gaze fixed on the prison bars and her heart set on her husband, upon realizing her imprudence, she would lower her gaze and see the sawyer looking at her with a smile, his knee on the bench and holding the saw, but not working.

en: “But it’s not my business!” he would generally say at those times, and would briskly fall to his sawing again.
vi: "But that's none of my business!" he would often say at such times, then hastily return to his sawing.
tr: At such times, he would again, saying "This doesn't concern me!" desperately continue to cut the wood.
es: When this happened, as a general rule, he would say, "it's none of my business," and resume his work without further comment.

en: In all weathers, in the snow and frost of winter, in the bitter winds of spring, in the hot sunshine of summer, in the rains of autumn, and again in the snow and frost of winter, Lucie passed two hours of every day at this place; and every day on leaving it, she kissed the prison wall.
vi: In all weather conditions, whether it was the freezing snow of winter or the cold winds of spring, whether the scorching heat of summer or the drizzle of autumn, and then back to the freezing snow of winter, Lucie would stand there for two hours every day; each day when she left, she would send a kiss towards the prison wall.
tr: In all kinds of weather, in snow, in winter, in the harsh winds of spring, under the scorching sun of summer, in the autumn rains, and then again in snow, in winter, Lucie stood and waited in the same place for two hours every day, and every day, as she left, she kissed the wall of the prison.
es: At all times, whether during the snows and ice of winter or enduring the furious gales of spring, whether under the scorching summer sun or the torrential autumn rains, not a single day did Lucía fail to spend two hours in that place, not a single day did she fail to kiss, upon leaving, the walls of the prison.

en: Her husband saw her (so she learned from her father) it might be once in five or six times: it might be twice or thrice running: it might be, not for a week or a fortnight together.
vi: About five or six times, Charles would see her once (she heard her father say so); sometimes two or three times in a row; sometimes it would take one or two weeks before he could see her again.
tr: Her husband (according to what she learned from her father) sometimes saw her only once in five or six attempts, sometimes he saw her two or three days in a row, and sometimes he didn't see her at all for one or two weeks.
es: Her husband saw her (Lucía knew this through her father) once for every five or six times she went out, sometimes two or three consecutive days, although it also happened that he was deprived of that joy for an entire week.

en: It was enough that he could and did see her when the chances served, and on that possibility she would have waited out the day, seven days a week.
vi: As long as her husband had the chance to see her, that was enough, and for that chance, she was willing to stand there all day, seven days a week.
tr: But the possibility of her husband seeing her and sometimes actually seeing her was enough for her, and for this reason, she could stand there like that seven days a week.
es: Lucía was satisfied with him seeing her as many times as he had the opportunity to reach the window, and in exchange for not disappointing him even once, she would have gone out not for a day, not for a week; but for entire years.

en: These occupations brought her round to the December month, wherein her father walked among the terrors with a steady head.
vi: She kept coming to that corner regularly until December, while her father calmly walked through the scene of horror.
tr: As Lucie kept going back and forth and her father continued to march forward with his head held high amidst all that horror, December arrived.
es: December arrived. Her father continued walking among dreadful horrors, always with a firm step, always with a solid head.

en: On a lightly-snowing afternoon she arrived at the usual corner.
vi: On a lightly snowy afternoon, she came to her usual spot again.
tr: As the snow lightly fell, Lucie reached her usual corner.
es: One cold and rainy afternoon, Lucía arrived at the usual little corner.

en: It was a day of some wild rejoicing, and a festival.
vi: That day was a chaotic celebration.
tr: The people were celebrating with wild joy.
es: It was a day of general rejoicing.

en: She had seen the houses, as she came along, decorated with little pikes, and with little red caps stuck upon them; also, with tricoloured ribbons; also, with the standard inscription (tricoloured letters were the favourite), Republic One and Indivisible.
vi: On her way there, she saw many houses decorated with small spears, topped with tiny red hats; there were also tricolor ribbons and the familiar slogan "The Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!" - the letters also bore the three favored colors.
tr: On her way, she had seen houses decorated with small spears topped with little red hats; and also standard writing adorned with tricolored ribbons (the most popular were the tricolored letters): "The Republic is One and Indivisible.
es: She had seen the houses adorned with an abundance of hats pierced by small spears, and decorated with tricolor ribbons and with the inscription, also tricolor (tricolor letters were very fashionable): "One and Indivisible Republic.

en: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
vi: On her way there, she saw many houses decorated with small spears, topped with tiny red hats; there were also tricolor ribbons and the familiar slogan "The Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!" - the letters also bore the three favored colors.
tr: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death!"
es: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death."

en: The miserable shop of the wood-sawyer was so small, that its whole surface furnished very indifferent space for this legend.
vi: The shabby shop of the small sawyer was so tiny that there wasn't enough space to write the entire slogan.
tr: The wretched shop of the sawyer was so small that its facade was not enough to bear this inscription.
es: So miserable and cramped was the sawyer's workshop that its entire surface was almost insufficient for the copied inscription.

en: He had got somebody to scrawl it up for him, however, who had squeezed Death in with most inappropriate difficulty.
vi: He had someone hastily write it on the door, and this person struggled to fit in the final word "Death."
tr: But then he had found someone who could barely squeeze the word death into it.
es: So miserable and cramped was the sawyer's workshop that its entire surface was almost insufficient for the copied inscription.

en: On his house-top, he displayed pike and cap, as a good citizen must, and in a window he had stationed his saw inscribed as his “Little Sainte Guillotine”—for the great sharp female was by that time popularly canonised.
vi: On the roof, he erected a spear with a hat on it, as every good Citizen should, and in the window, he displayed his saw with the inscription "Little Saint Guillotine" - because by that time, the sharp lady had been canonized by the people.
tr: As a duty of being a good citizen, he had placed a spear and a hat on top of the shop and had put his saw, which he called "Little Saint Guillotine," in one of the windows – after all, this sharp lady was now known by everyone at that time.
es: The house was topped with its corresponding spear equipped with its indispensable red cap, as befitted any citizen who considered himself good, and in a window, he had placed his saw, under which the following inscription could be read: "The Holy Guillotine."

en: His shop was shut and he was not there, which was a relief to Lucie, and left her quite alone.
vi: His shop was closed and he had gone somewhere; seeing this, Lucie felt relieved to be standing alone.
tr: The shop was closed, and the sawyer was not there; thus, Lucie was left alone and took a deep breath.
es: The workshop was closed, the sawyer was absent, and Lucía could savor the pleasure of being completely alone. However, the sawyer was not very far away.

en: But, he was not far off, for presently she heard a troubled movement and a shouting coming along, which filled her with fear.
vi: But he was not far away, because right after that, Lucie became terrified when she heard the noisy footsteps and the shouting voices approaching.
tr: But the sawyer was not far away, soon there was some commotion and Luice heard approaching shouts; she was filled with great fear.
es: Lucía's wait lasted only a few minutes when loud shouts echoed in the street, filling her with terror.

en: A moment afterwards, and a throng of people came pouring round the corner by the prison wall, in the midst of whom was the wood-sawyer hand in hand with The Vengeance.
vi: Just a moment later, a crowd of people passed by the corner near the prison, with the woodcutter holding the hand of the Goddess of Vengeance in the middle.
tr: Before long, a large group of people, with Vengeance and the Sawyer in the very middle, hand in hand, flowed like a torrent from the corner of the prison wall.
es: Seconds later, compact crowds turned the corner of the prison, with the sawyer in the center holding hands with La Venganza.

en: There could not be fewer than five hundred people, and they were dancing like five thousand demons.
vi: The crowd, which must have been up to five hundred people, was dancing enthusiastically like five thousand demons.
tr: There were roughly five hundred people, and they danced as if they were five thousand demons.
es: There would be no fewer than five hundred people, dancing as if they were five hundred thousand demons.

en: There was no other music than their own singing.
vi: There was no other music except for their singing and shouting.
tr: There was no music other than the songs they sang themselves.
es: Nor did they have music, for their devilish dances were sufficiently accompanied by the hoarse and discordant shouting from their throats.

en: They danced to the popular Revolution song, keeping a ferocious time that was like a gnashing of teeth in unison.
vi: They danced to their favorite Revolutionary song, maintaining a fierce rhythm as if they were all grinding their teeth in unison.
tr: They danced to the popular song of the Revolution, keeping a cruel tempo that resembled the grinding of teeth.
es: They sang the popular hymn of the Revolution, accompanied by a fierce clashing of teeth.

en: Men and women danced together, women danced together, men danced together, as hazard had brought them together.
vi: Men danced with women; women danced with each other; men danced with each other; they danced with anyone they happened to pair up with.
tr: Men and women danced together; sometimes only women, sometimes only men, as if this calamity had brought them together.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: At first, they were a mere storm of coarse red caps and coarse woollen rags; but, as they filled the place, and stopped to dance about Lucie, some ghastly apparition of a dance-figure gone raving mad arose among them.
vi: At first, they were just a whirlwind of tattered red hats and ragged coats; but as they flooded this corner and began dancing around Lucie, some of them went wild like terrifying ghosts.
tr: At first, they were a storm of rough red caps and coarse woolen clothes; but when they filled the street and stopped to dance around Lucie, the spirit of a terrible creature that danced in a frenzy awoke within them all.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: They advanced, retreated, struck at one another’s hands, clutched at one another’s heads, spun round alone, caught one another and spun round in pairs, until many of them dropped.
vi: They advanced, retreated, clapped each other's hands, grabbed each other's heads, spun alone, seized anyone, and the pairs spun together until many collapsed.
tr: They moved forward and backward, slapped each other's hands, then grabbed each other by the heads and spun alone, then held onto each other again and spun in pairs until many of them collapsed to the ground.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: While those were down, the rest linked hand in hand, and all spun round together: then the ring broke, and in separate rings of two and four they turned and turned until they all stopped at once, began again, struck, clutched, and tore, and then reversed the spin, and all spun round another way.
vi: Those who did not fall grabbed each other's hands to form a circle and spun around, then the circle broke into smaller circles of two or four people, and these circles kept spinning until they all suddenly stopped, started again, clapped, grabbed, separated, then reversed the direction of the spin, and all spun in the opposite direction.
tr: While they were on the ground, the others held hands and spun in a circle together; then the circle broke up again, and after spinning in pairs and fours, they all stopped together, then started again, slapped each other again, grabbed each other by the heads and broke up, then turned in the opposite direction, and then all began to turn in different directions.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: Suddenly they stopped again, paused, struck out the time afresh, formed into lines the width of the public way, and, with their heads low down and their hands high up, swooped screaming off.
vi: Suddenly, they stopped, rested, started again, formed lines that took up the entire width of the street, then, with heads bowed low and hands raised high, they ran off while screaming.
tr: Suddenly they stopped again, waited, and as if turning back time, lined up along the road in rows and advanced with their heads down and fists in the air, shouting.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: No fight could have been half so terrible as this dance.
vi: No battle scene was half as terrifying as this dance.
tr: No fight could be as terrifying as this dance.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: It was so emphatically a fallen sport—a something, once innocent, delivered over to all devilry—a healthy pastime changed into a means of angering the blood, bewildering the senses, and steeling the heart.
vi: It was entirely a corrupt amusement - an innocent game turned malicious - a healthy pastime turned into something that boiled the blood with anger, paralyzed the mind, and froze the heart.
tr: It was such a strange thing – once innocent but now containing devilry – a healthy amusement that had turned into an event that ignited people's blood, upset their emotions, and hardened their hearts.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: Such grace as was visible in it, made it the uglier, showing how warped and perverted all things good by nature were become.
vi: If any movements revealed a bit of beauty, the horror increased all the more as everything that was once good now became distorted and misguided.
tr: The visible measure of finesse it contained made this dance even uglier, showing how everything good could be twisted and corrupted.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: The maidenly bosom bared to this, the pretty almost-child’s head thus distracted, the delicate foot mincing in this slough of blood and dirt, were types of the disjointed time.
vi: The breasts of young girls exposed in dance, or their pretty, innocent heads frenzied with the rhythm, their nimble feet lifted high in this blood-soaked mud, these are the epitomes of a chaotic era.
tr: The bare flanks of young girls, the wildly swaying beautiful heads almost childlike in age, and the delicate feet advancing through this swamp of blood and filth were all part of this maddened moment.
es: They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: This was the Carmagnole.
vi: That is the Carmagnole dance.
tr: It was the Carmagnole dance.
es: It was the Carmagnole.

en: As it passed, leaving Lucie frightened and bewildered in the doorway of the wood-sawyer’s house, the feathery snow fell as quietly and lay as white and soft, as if it had never been.
vi: While the crowd passed by, leaving Lucie terrified and trembling in front of the woodcutter's house, light, gentle snowflakes fell, softly covering the ground as if nothing had happened.
tr: When the crowd left Lucie at the door of the woodcutter's hut, frightened and bewildered, snowflakes began to fall gently like feathers, covering the ground whiter and softer than ever before.
es: Lucía, horrified, frozen with fear, had taken refuge in the doorway of the sawyer, covering her face with her hands.

en: “O my father!” for he stood before her when she lifted up the eyes she had momentarily darkened with her hand; “such a cruel, bad sight.”
vi: − Oh! Father! - She lowered her hands that were covering her face and saw her father standing in front of her. - The scene is truly horrifying, brutal!
tr: "Ah, daddy!" said Lucie, lifting her eyes, which she had momentarily covered with her hands, and seeing her father in front of her, "what a terrible, what an awful sight it was!"
es: —Oh my father! —she exclaimed as she separated her hands and unexpectedly found herself facing the doctor. — What a cruel, so repugnant spectacle!

en: “I know, my dear, I know.
vi: − I know, my dear, I know.
tr: "I know, my dear, I know.
es: —I know, my dear, I know.

en: I have seen it many times.
vi: I have seen it many times.
tr: I've seen these before.
es: I have witnessed it many times.

en: Don’t be frightened!
vi: Don't panic!
tr: Don't be afraid!
es: Don't be afraid, no one will harm you in the slightest.

en: Not one of them would harm you.”
vi: No one will harm you.
tr: None of them can harm you."
es: Don't be afraid, no one will harm you in the slightest.

en: “I am not frightened for myself, my father.
vi: − I'm not afraid for myself, Father.
tr: "I am not afraid for myself, daddy.
es: —I am not afraid for myself, my father; but when I think of my husband and the outbursts of those people...

en: But when I think of my husband, and the mercies of these people—”
vi: But when I think about my husband being at the mercy of these people...
tr: But when I think about my husband and how he is at the mercy of these people..."
es: —I am not afraid for myself, my father; but when I think of my husband and the outbursts of those people...

en: “We will set him above their mercies very soon.
vi: − Soon, no one will have the power of life and death over Charles anymore.
tr: "We will rescue him from their mercy very soon.
es: —Soon we will protect you from his outbursts.

en: I left him climbing to the window, and I came to tell you.
vi: When your father came here, your husband was going up to that window, and your father came to tell you.
tr: As I was coming, he was also going to the window, I came to tell you this.
es: I left him climbing to the window and came to tell you.

en: There is no one here to see.
vi: There is no one else watching here.
tr: There is no one around to see now.
es: Since today there is no one around here who can see you, it doesn't matter if you send a kiss with your hand to the highest part of the roof, to the very eaves.

en: You may kiss your hand towards that highest shelving roof.”
vi: You can send a kiss towards the highest sloping roof.
tr: You can blow a kiss to the window on the top floor."
es: Since today there is no one around here who can see you, it doesn't matter if you send a kiss with your hand to the highest part of the roof, to the very eaves.

en: “I do so, father, and I send him my Soul with it!”
vi: − I will do it right away, father, and send my soul as well!
tr: "Okay, Dad, and with this kiss, I will also send my soul to him now."
es: —I will send it, my father, and with the kiss, I will send my entire soul.

en: “You cannot see him, my poor dear?”
vi: − You cannot see Charles, can you, my poor daughter.
tr: "But you can't see him, can you, my poor little one?""
es: —You can't see him, my poor daughter; can you?

en: “No, father,” said Lucie, yearning and weeping as she kissed her hand, “no.”
vi: − No, father, - Lucie said while crying full of longing as she sent a kiss with the wind, - I don't see.
tr: "No, father!" said Lucie, kissing his hand and sending a longing kiss while crying, "No!"
es: —No, my father, I can't—replied Lucía, crying.

en: A footstep in the snow.
vi: Footsteps on the snow.
tr: Then, a footstep was heard in the snow.
es: Some footsteps were heard, and Madame Defarge appeared.

en: Madame Defarge.
vi: Madame Defarge.
tr: The one approaching was Madame Defarge.
es: Some footsteps were heard, and Madame Defarge appeared.

en: “I salute you, citizeness,” from the Doctor.
vi: − Hello, female Citizen, - said the doctor.
tr: "Greetings, citizen," said the Doctor.
es: —Greetings, citizen—said the doctor.

en: “I salute you, citizen.”
vi: − Hello, Citizen. -
tr: "Greetings, citizen," she replied.
es: —Greetings, citizen—said the doctor.

en: This in passing.
vi: The greeting passed by, just like that.
tr: "Greetings, citizen," she replied.
es: —Greetings, citizen—replied the innkeeper, continuing on her way without stopping.

en: Nothing more.
vi: The greeting passed by, just like that.
tr: They said nothing else.
es: —Greetings, citizen—replied the innkeeper, continuing on her way without stopping.

en: Madame Defarge gone, like a shadow over the white road.
vi: Mrs. Defarge left, like a shadow on the white snow.
tr: Madame Defarge moved forward like a shadow on the white path and disappeared from sight.
es: —Greetings, citizen—replied the innkeeper, continuing on her way without stopping.

en: “Give me your arm, my love.
vi: − Now, I'll take you home, my dear.
tr: "Come into my arms, my dear.
es: —Give me your arm, my dear.

en: Pass from here with an air of cheerfulness and courage, for his sake.
vi: For Charles' sake, be cheerful and brave as you leave this place.
tr: For his sake, pass through here with a cheerful and brave demeanor now.
es: Leave here, but pretend to be cheerful, even though I know you cannot feel it...

en: That was well done;” they had left the spot; “it shall not be in vain.
vi: Good job, - the father and daughter left that corner of the street. - It won't be in vain.
tr: Well done," they had started walking; "and this cheerfulness is not in vain.
es: That's it, very good.

en: Charles is summoned for to-morrow.”
vi: Tomorrow, Charles will be called to trial.
tr: Charles will appear in court again tomorrow."
es: Tomorrow, Carlos will appear before his judges.

en: “For to-morrow!”
vi: − Tomorrow! −
tr: "Tomorrow!"
es: —Tomorrow!

en: “There is no time to lose.
vi: There is no more time to hesitate.
tr: "We have no time to lose.
es: —We cannot waste time.

en: I am well prepared, but there are precautions to be taken, that could not be taken until he was actually summoned before the Tribunal.
vi: I have prepared thoroughly, but many things need to be guarded against; we must be cautious until Charles actually goes to trial.
tr: I am well prepared, but there are precautions we need to take; these precautions could not be taken without him being formally summoned to court.
es: I have everything admirably arranged, but there is a need to take precautions that cannot be finalized until the very moment Carlos appears before the Tribunal.

en: He has not received the notice yet, but I know that he will presently be summoned for to-morrow, and removed to the Conciergerie; I have timely information.
vi: Your husband has not yet received the notice, but I know that tomorrow Charles will be transferred to the Conciergerie prison to await trial; I have timely information.
tr: The decision has not yet been communicated to him, but I am sure he will be brought to court tomorrow and sent to the Conciergerie Prison; I received the news just in time.
es: He has not yet received the summons, but I know for a fact that he will be summoned for tomorrow and that he will be transferred to the Consulate. As you can see, I receive the news in a timely manner.

en: You are not afraid?”
vi: Are you not afraid?
tr: You're not afraid, are you?"
es: I suppose you won't be scared, right?

en: She could scarcely answer, “I trust in you.”
vi: − I trust you, - Lucie could not speak.
tr: Lucie could barely say, "I trust you."
es: The unfortunate woman could barely stammer. —I trust you. —You can trust, in the certainty of not being disappointed.

en: “Do so, implicitly.
vi: − You must trust your father completely.
tr: "You must trust.
es: Your agonies are coming to an end, my love.

en: Your suspense is nearly ended, my darling; he shall be restored to you within a few hours; I have encompassed him with every protection.
vi: Your long wait is almost over; in just a few hours, Charles will be back with you; I have done everything to protect your husband.
tr: All your worries will soon come to an end, my dear; a few hours after the trial, you will be reunited with your beloved; I have ensured his safety in every way.
es: Within a few hours, you will have him in your arms. I have surrounded him with all imaginable protections.

en: I must see Lorry.”
vi: Now I must go see Mr. Lorry.
tr: Now I need to see Lorry."
es: I need to see Lorry...

en: He stopped.
vi: He stopped walking.
tr: He stopped.
es: The doctor was interrupted.

en: There was a heavy lumbering of wheels within hearing.
vi: The sound of a creaking wheel could be heard in the distance.
tr: The sound of a slowly approaching car was heard.
es: In the nearby street, there was a heavy noise of carts.

en: They both knew too well what it meant.
vi: Both father and son understood all too well the meaning of that sound.
tr: They both knew very well what this meant.
es: One... two... three...

en: One.
vi: One.
tr: One.
es: One... two... three...

en: Two.
vi: Two.
tr: Two.
es: One... two... three...

en: Three.
vi: Three.
tr: Two.
es: One... two... three...

en: Three tumbrils faring away with their dread loads over the hushing snow.
vi: Three carts loaded with a terrifying tribute for La Guillotine were crossing the snow, which lay silent and dreadful.
tr: The three cars carrying the prisoners to the guillotine were moving over the calm snow with their dreadful loads.
es: Three carts loaded with condemned men being taken to their execution.

en: “I must see Lorry,” the Doctor repeated, turning her another way.
vi: − We must meet Lorry, - the doctor repeated and then led Lucie in another direction.
tr: "I need to see Lorry," he repeated.
es: —I need to see Lorry—repeated the doctor, turning his head to the other side to avoid seeing the funeral procession.

en: The staunch old gentleman was still in his trust; had never left it.
vi: The faithful old man maintained the job that had been entrusted to him; he never left the bank.
tr: This sturdy old man was still the person he trusted the most; this situation had never changed.
es: The good Lorry remained motionless in the Bank building.

en: He and his books were in frequent requisition as to property confiscated and made national.
vi: He and his books were always needed when it came to confiscated and nationalized assets.
tr: He was frequently consulted, along with his records, for properties that had been confiscated and become state property.
es: Both he and the books were frequently requisitioned as confiscated property and converted into national assets, which did not prevent him from saving as much as possible through sheer determination and self-sacrifice.

en: What he could save for the owners, he saved.
vi: He did everything he could to preserve the assets for the owners.
tr: He also protected the property owners as much as he could.
es: Both he and the books were frequently requisitioned as confiscated property and converted into national assets, which did not prevent him from saving as much as possible through sheer determination and self-sacrifice.

en: No better man living to hold fast by what Tellson’s had in keeping, and to hold his peace.
vi: No one in this world could be more reliable than Mr. Lorry in protecting the assets entrusted to Tellson's Bank and keeping silent.
tr: No one could protect what Tellson had as well as he did and do it with such composure.
es: Both he and the books were frequently requisitioned as confiscated property and converted into national assets, which did not prevent him from saving as much as possible through sheer determination and self-sacrifice.

en: A murky red and yellow sky, and a rising mist from the Seine, denoted the approach of darkness.
vi: The sky turned a gloomy shade of yellow and red, with mist rising from the Seine River, heralding the approach of night.
tr: The yellow tinged with red and the murky sky, along with the mist rising from the Seine River, heralded the evening.
es: It was getting dark when the father and daughter arrived at the Bank.

en: It was almost dark when they arrived at the Bank.
vi: It was already dark when the father and son arrived at the bank.
tr: By the time they reached the bank, it was almost dark.
es: It was getting dark when the father and daughter arrived at the Bank.

en: The stately residence of Monseigneur was altogether blighted and deserted.
vi: The once magnificent mansion of the Lord was now completely ruined and desolate.
tr: The grand residence of the Monsignor was now in a state of ruin and abandonment.
es: The sumptuous residence of the gentleman remained deserted.

en: Above a heap of dust and ashes in the court, ran the letters: National Property.
vi: Above a pile of ashes in the yard was a banner bearing the words: The United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
tr: On the piles of dust and ash in the courtyard, these words were written: "National Property.
es: On the garden gate there was an inscription that read: "National Property.

en: Republic One and Indivisible.
vi: Above a pile of ashes in the yard was a banner bearing the words: The United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
tr: The Republic is One and Indivisible.
es: One and Indivisible Republic.

en: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
vi: Above a pile of ashes in the yard was a banner bearing the words: The United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
tr: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!"
es: Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death."

en: Who could that be with mr Lorry—the owner of the riding-coat upon the chair—who must not be seen?
vi: Who is with Mr. Lorry? The owner of the coat draped over the chair, whose face is unseen?
tr: I wonder who was next to Mr. Lorry – the one with the riding jacket on the chair – and who was the person that was not supposed to be seen?
es: What had become of Mr. Lorry, who was not in his office?

en: From whom newly arrived, did he come out, agitated and surprised, to take his favourite in his arms?
vi: Who is the person Mr. Lorry paused his conversation to go outside, anxious and astonished, to embrace his beloved niece Lucie?
tr: In a nervous and bewildered state, who had this person, who emerged to embrace their loved one, just come from?
es: Whom had he just dismissed when he came out, agitated and surprised, to embrace his beloved little friend?

en: To whom did he appear to repeat her faltering words, when, raising his voice and turning his head towards the door of the room from which he had issued, he said: “Removed to the Conciergerie, and summoned for to-morrow?”
vi: Who is the person Mr. Lorry, raising his voice towards the door just exited, repeated the words he had just heard Lucie hesitantly say?
tr: Raising his voice and turning his head towards the door he entered, to whom could he have repeated Lucie's trembling words, "Sent to the Conciergerie and to be tried tomorrow?"
es: To whom did he repeat the words that had just been addressed to him in a faltering voice, saying from the door he was crossing: "Transferred to the Conciergerie and summoned for tomorrow?"

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Mr. Lorry exclaimed: − Transferred to the Conciergerie prison tomorrow awaiting trial?
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: Triumph
vi: 6. Success
tr: Victory
es: TRIUMPH

en: The dread tribunal of five Judges, Public Prosecutor, and determined Jury, sat every day.
vi: The terrifying court of five judges, a prosecutor, and a jury that decides daily trials.
tr: The terrifying court panel, consisting of five judges, a prosecutor, and a determined jury, convened every day.
es: Without exaggeration, it can be said that the formidable Tribunal of the Five not only operated every day but was also in permanent session.

en: Their lists went forth every evening, and were read out by the gaolers of the various prisons to their prisoners.
vi: The trial list is issued every evening and read to the prisoners by the wardens in various prisons.
tr: The lists were sent to various prisons every evening and were read to the prisoners by the guards there.
es: The lists of prisoners who were to appear before the Tribunal the following day were delivered every afternoon to the wardens of the prisons, who, in turn, read them to those concerned.

en: The standard gaoler-joke was, “Come out and listen to the Evening Paper, you inside there!”
vi: The wardens' familiar joke is: "Come here to hear the evening news, folks inside!"
tr: "Inmates, come closer and listen to the evening newspaper!" was a joke made by many guards.
es: In prison jargon, these lists were called "Nightly Journals."

en: “Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay!”
vi: − Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay!
tr: "Charles Evremonde, that is, Darnay!"
es: "Carlos Evrémonde, alias Darnay."

en: So at last began the Evening Paper at La Force.
vi: Thus, the final hour of the afternoon reading of the news had begun at La Force prison.
tr: Thus, the evening newspaper session finally began at La Force.
es: Such was the name that headed the "Evening Journal" corresponding to La Force.

en: When a name was called, its owner stepped apart into a spot reserved for those who were announced as being thus fatally recorded.
vi: When a name was called, the person with that name stepped out to a place reserved for those whose fate was to be judged.
tr: The people whose names were called would move to the place reserved for prisoners awaiting death.
es: As soon as the name was pronounced, the interested party separated from the group of his unfortunate companions and took his place in the spot designated for those called.

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, had reason to know the usage; he had seen hundreds pass away so.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, understood this well because he had seen hundreds of people go to their deaths in that manner.
tr: Charles Evremonde, that is, Darnay, knew what this meant; for hundreds had gone this way before.
es: Since Charles Darnay had witnessed that scene hundreds of times, it goes without saying that he had plenty of reasons to be familiar with the custom.

en: His bloated gaoler, who wore spectacles to read with, glanced over them to assure himself that he had taken his place, and went through the list, making a similar short pause at each name.
vi: The plump jailer, wearing glasses to read the list, glanced over the prisoners to make sure Darnay had stepped out, then continued reading, pausing briefly after each name to glance up in the same manner.
tr: The chubby-faced guard, who had put on glasses to read the names, looked up to make sure the person he called was in place, then returned to his list and repeated the same process for each name.
es: The chubby warden gave him a look through the dirty lenses of his spectacles, without which he could not read, to make sure he had moved to the place he was supposed to occupy, and having confirmed this, he continued reading the list, making a similar pause after each name.

en: There were twenty-three names, but only twenty were responded to; for one of the prisoners so summoned had died in gaol and been forgotten, and two had already been guillotined and forgotten.
vi: The list had twenty-three names but only twenty people stepped out; because one prisoner on the list had died in the cell without anyone remembering, and two others had gone to the guillotine without anyone remembering.
tr: There were twenty-three names on the list, but only twenty people responded, because one of those called had died and been forgotten in his cell, and two others had already been executed by guillotine and forgotten.
es: Twenty-three were named, but since one of them had died in jail, and the Holy Guillotine had beheaded two others, although no one remembered them, only twenty answered the call.

en: The list was read, in the vaulted chamber where Darnay had seen the associated prisoners on the night of his arrival.
vi: The list was finished, in the vaulted room where Darnay first met the prisoners of his class on the night he was brought here.
tr: The list was being read in the domed hall where Charles Darnay had first encountered the other prisoners on the night he arrived at the prison.
es: The list was read in the same vaulted room where Charles found so many prisoners gathered the night he entered the jail.

en: Every one of those had perished in the massacre; every human creature he had since cared for and parted with, had died on the scaffold.
vi: All those people had lost their lives in the massacre, none remained, every person he had cared about and then bid farewell to since that day had died on the scaffold.
tr: All those prisoners had been wiped out in the massacre; everyone Darnay had grown close to and then parted from since his arrival had died on the gallows.
es: All of them had been torn apart by the mobs on the day of the general massacre, and those who entered later left again to take their passage to the other world on the scaffold.

en: There were hurried words of farewell and kindness, but the parting was soon over.
vi: Hasty yet tender farewells echoed, but the parting quickly ended.
tr: After the hasty farewell words and good wishes they exchanged, they quickly parted ways.
es: Some farewell and encouraging phrases were exchanged between those who were leaving and those who were staying, not many, as aside from being an incident that repeated every day, the society of La Force had planned for that night the celebration of some games, and they needed to make the most of the time to finalize the program.

en: It was the incident of every day, and the society of La Force were engaged in the preparation of some games of forfeits and a little concert, for that evening.
vi: It was a daily occurrence, and the prisoners at La Force that night were busy preparing for some games of reward and punishment along with a small concert.
tr: This was a daily occurrence, and then the La Force community plunged into preparations for the evening's games to be held for the losses of the day, and a small concert.
es: Some farewell and encouraging phrases were exchanged between those who were leaving and those who were staying, not many, as aside from being an incident that repeated every day, the society of La Force had planned for that night the celebration of some games, and they needed to make the most of the time to finalize the program.

en: They crowded to the grates and shed tears there; but, twenty places in the projected entertainments had to be refilled, and the time was, at best, short to the lock-up hour, when the common rooms and corridors would be delivered over to the great dogs who kept watch there through the night.
vi: They huddled together and shed tears at the barred windows, watching the number of people being called away; but the planned entertainments were short by twenty people who needed to be replaced, and time was pressing, nearing the hour to return to their cells, the time when the common rooms and corridors would be entrusted to the large dogs guarding throughout the night.
tr: They gathered in front of the bars and wept; but the twenty people who left for the evening's entertainment needed to be replaced, and there was little time left until the doors were locked; the large dogs were handed over to guard the common rooms and corridors throughout the night.
es: Those who stayed accompanied those who were leaving to the exit gate of the room, shed some tears, and turned back, as it was necessary to fill the twenty gaps left vacant by the absentees if they did not want to forgo the evening's entertainments, and this had to be done before the hour of silence, when the establishment's vigilance was entrusted to armies of ferocious mastiffs that filled the corridors and adjoining rooms.

en: The prisoners were far from insensible or unfeeling; their ways arose out of the condition of the time.
vi: The prisoners were not insensitive or indifferent; it was this prison environment that made them behave that way.
tr: The prisoners were not insensitive or callous; they were merely acting in the manner required by the times.
es: And it is not that the prisoners were insensitive or hard-hearted; but in their character, in their way of being, the condition of the era inevitably had an influence.

en: Similarly, though with a subtle difference, a species of fervour or intoxication, known, without doubt, to have led some persons to brave the guillotine unnecessarily, and to die by it, was not mere boastfulness, but a wild infection of the wildly shaken public mind.
vi: This same environment also gave rise to another, more incomprehensible expression: the wild attitudes that surely led many to face the guillotine unnecessarily and lose their lives unjustly - it was not arrogance but a kind of epidemic as if it had spread from the madness of the populace.
tr: Similarly, albeit with a subtle difference, a kind of exhilaration or intoxication undoubtedly gave some of them unnecessary courage as they went to the guillotine, and because of this, dying was not only something to be proud of but also like a dreadful infection spreading from the frenzied minds of the public.
es: Just as those saw their unfortunate companions leave almost impassively, there were many who, intoxicated, undoubtedly yielding to a kind of fervor that is barely understood today but was very natural at that time, challenged the people without any need and spontaneously ran in search of the caresses of the guillotine, without their act being influenced much or little by boastfulness, but by the general infection consequent to the brutal shaking of the public soul.

en: In seasons of pestilence, some of us will have a secret attraction to the disease—a terrible passing inclination to die of it.
vi: In the time of an epidemic, many of us silently suffer from this - a most dreadful temporary tendency to want to die from the epidemic.
tr: Like the desire some had to contract the disease during the plague – strangely, they wanted to die from it.
es: In times of pestilence, one sees people who are mysteriously attracted to the contagion, people who would wish to die from it.

en: And all of us have like wonders hidden in our breasts, only needing circumstances to evoke them.
vi: We all harbor strange desires within us, just waiting for the right conditions to erupt.
tr: In fact, there are such oddities hidden within all of us, waiting for certain conditions to emerge.
es: And it is that we all carry within the depths of our souls dormant oddities that need only the concurrence of certain circumstances to awaken.

en: The passage to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night in its vermin-haunted cells was long and cold.
vi: The road to the Conciergerie prison was short and dark; the night in the cold, rat-infested cells dragged on endlessly.
tr: The road to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night spent in its vermin-filled cells, however, was long and cold.
es: Short and dark was the passage from La Force to the Conciergerie, long and cold the nights spent in the pestilential cells of the latter.

en: Next day, fifteen prisoners were put to the bar before Charles Darnay’s name was called.
vi: The next day, fifteen prisoners were brought to trial before Charles Darnay was called.
tr: The next day, fifteen prisoners were tried before Charles Darnay's name was called.
es: Fifteen prisoners appeared before the Tribunal the next morning, before Charles Darnay was called to appear.

en: All the fifteen were condemned, and the trials of the whole occupied an hour and a half.
vi: All fifteen were convicted, and the trials lasted a full hour and a half.
tr: All of them were found guilty, and their trial lasted an hour and a half.
es: The hearings of the fifteen lasted an hour and a half, and all fifteen were condemned to death.

en: “Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay,” was at length arraigned.
vi: − Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - it is finally his turn.
tr: After a while, they called him to the stand, saying, "Charles Evremonde, who goes by the name Darnay."
es: “Charles Evrémonde, alias Darnay,” they finally called.

en: His judges sat upon the Bench in feathered hats; but the rough red cap and tricoloured cockade was the head-dress otherwise prevailing.
vi: The judges sat on the bench wearing hats adorned with feathers; but the courtroom was filled with tattered red hats bearing the tricolor emblem.
tr: The jurors were sitting with furry hats; but many others had coarse red hats and tricolor rosettes.
es: The judges wore hats adorned with feathers, but aside from them, the entire audience wore red woolen caps with their corresponding tricolor cockades.

en: Looking at the Jury and the turbulent audience, he might have thought that the usual order of things was reversed, and that the felons were trying the honest men.
vi: Looking at the jury and the chaotic crowd, Darnay felt as if the normal order had been overturned, with criminals now judging the honest people.
tr: When Charles Darnay looked at the jury and the noisy crowd, he perhaps thought that everything had turned upside down and that criminals were judging honest people.
es: A mere glance at the Tribunal was enough to suspect that the natural order of things had been inverted and that criminals were judging honorable men.

en: The lowest, cruelest, and worst populace of a city, never without its quantity of low, cruel, and bad, were the directing spirits of the scene: noisily commenting, applauding, disapproving, anticipating, and precipitating the result, without a check.
vi: The lowest, most vicious, and most despicable class of a city teeming with the low, vicious, and despicable, was running the trial: commenting, applauding, objecting, anticipating, and urging the outcome, noisily and incessantly.
tr: The lowest, most cruel, and most vile segment of the city, with their not at all low and vile numbers, was directing the spirit of the hall; they were loudly expressing opinions, applauding, opposing, speculating, and making the jury decide in an instant.
es: The sentences were inspired by the vilest, most cruel, most criminal mob in the city, and they inspired them by injecting immense amounts of baseness, cruelty, and wickedness into their inspirations, sometimes commenting loudly, sometimes applauding, sometimes anticipating and precipitating the outcome of the deliberations.

en: Of the men, the greater part were armed in various ways; of the women, some wore knives, some daggers, some ate and drank as they looked on, many knitted.
vi: Most of the men were armed with various weapons; some of the women held knives, some held swords, others ate and drank while watching the trial, and many were knitting.
tr: Most of the men had various kinds of weapons; the women were carrying knives or daggers, and while some were following the trial by eating and drinking, many were knitting.
es: All the men filling the room were armed to the teeth; all the women carried knives and daggers, some were eating, others drinking, others knitting.

en: Among these last, was one, with a spare piece of knitting under her arm as she worked.
vi: Among those knitting was one who never stopped with a distinctive knitting pattern.
tr: Among those knitting was a woman who, besides her knitting, had an empty bottle tucked under her arm.
es: Among the latter, there was one who stood out for her industriousness.

en: She was in a front row, by the side of a man whom he had never seen since his arrival at the Barrier, but whom he directly remembered as Defarge.
vi: The woman sat in the front row, next to a man whom Darnay had not seen since he arrived at the gates of Paris, but he clearly remembered him as Defarge.
tr: She was in the front row, next to Defarge, whom Charles had not seen since the first day he reached the barrier but recognized immediately upon seeing.
es: She was seated in one of the front rows next to a man whom Charles had not seen since the day he arrived at the Barrier of Paris, but who reminded him of Defarge.

en: He noticed that she once or twice whispered in his ear, and that she seemed to be his wife; but, what he most noticed in the two figures was, that although they were posted as close to himself as they could be, they never looked towards him.
vi: He noticed that a few times she whispered into Defarge's ear and seemed to be his wife; but what he noticed most about these two was that although they sat very close to him, they never looked in his direction.
tr: He saw the woman whispering something into the man's ear a few times and thought she was his wife; but what caught his attention the most while looking at these two was that, despite standing so close to him, they never looked at him.
es: He observed that the woman spoke two or three times in a very low voice to her neighbor, which led him to suppose that she was his wife, but what most powerfully caught his attention was that despite being as close as possible to him, they did not look at him even once.

en: They seemed to be waiting for something with a dogged determination, and they looked at the Jury, but at nothing else.
vi: It seemed they were waiting for something very patiently, and did not take their eyes off the jury.
tr: It was as if they were waiting for something with stubborn determination and never took their eyes off the jury for even a moment.
es: They frequently turned their eyes to the judges, as if expecting something, but nothing more.

en: Under the President sat Doctor Manette, in his usual quiet dress.
vi: Sitting below the Judge was Doctor Manette, in his usual simple attire.
tr: In front of the president, in his usual plain attire, sat Doctor Manette.
es: Near the President of the Tribunal sat Doctor Manette, calm as always and dressed as always.

en: As well as the prisoner could see, he and mr Lorry were the only men there, unconnected with the Tribunal, who wore their usual clothes, and had not assumed the coarse garb of the Carmagnole.
vi: Darnay clearly saw that, apart from the officials, Mr. Manette and Mr. Lorry were the only two there dressed in ordinary clothes rather than the Carmagnole dance attire.
tr: As far as the prisoner could see, there were only himself and Mr. Lorry, who had not donned the coarse carmagnole outfits but were in their usual clothes and had no connection with the court.
es: The prisoner noticed that only the doctor and Mr. Lorry, seated next to him, were dressed as usual and did not display the coarse attire of the Carmagnole.

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, was accused by the public prosecutor as an emigrant, whose life was forfeit to the Republic, under the decree which banished all emigrants on pain of Death.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, was accused by the prosecutor of being an exiled nobleman who must pay with his life for the Republic, according to the decree that orders the execution of all exiled nobles.
tr: Charles Evremonde, that is Darnay, was accused of being an émigré by the prosecutor and, based on the law that condemned all émigrés to death, he too had to pay the price of the Republic with his life.
es: Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay, was accused by the public prosecutor of being an emigrant whose life was forfeit to the Republic according to the decree that proscribed all emigrants under penalty of death.

en: It was nothing that the decree bore date since his return to France.
vi: This was regardless of the fact that the decree was issued after Darnay had already returned to France.
tr: It did not matter that the law had been enacted after he had returned to France.
es: The fact that the decree in question had been promulgated when the accused was already in France was a trivial circumstance that did not deserve consideration.

en: There he was, and there was the decree; he had been taken in France, and his head was demanded.
vi: He was in France, the decree was in effect; he was arrested in France, and he must lose his head. − Off with his head! -
tr: He was before them now, and the law was before them as well; Evremonde had come to France secretly and his head was demanded.
es: The decree existed, they had the accused in front of them who had been arrested within the borders of France, and the Republic demanded his head.

en: “Take off his head!” cried the audience.
vi: The crowd shouted.
tr: "Off with his head!" shouted the people, "He's an enemy of the Republic!"
es: —Let his head roll!

en: “An enemy to the Republic!”
vi: - Enemy of the Republic!
tr: "Off with his head!" shouted the people, "He's an enemy of the Republic!"
es: —roared the crowd—Death to that enemy of the Republic!

en: The President rang his bell to silence those cries, and asked the prisoner whether it was not true that he had lived many years in England?
vi: The judge rang the bell to silence the crowd and asked the prisoner if it was true that he had lived in England for many years.
tr: The chairman rang his bell to silence the shouting and asked the prisoner if it was true that he had been living in England for a long time.
es: The President rang the bell to silence those shouts and asked the accused if it was not true that he had resided in England for many years.

en: Undoubtedly it was.
vi: It was certainly true.
tr: Undoubtedly, it was so.
es: Darnay answered affirmatively.

en: Was he not an emigrant then?
vi: So, you are not an exiled nobleman?
tr: Wasn't he a refugee then?
es: —And you say you're not an emigrant?

en: What did he call himself?
vi: Then what do you call yourself?
tr: What did he call himself?
es: What name do you give yourself, then?

en: Not an emigrant, he hoped, within the sense and spirit of the law.
vi: Not an exiled nobleman, Charles Darnay hopes, in the meaning and spirit of this law.
tr: He did not consider himself a refugee in the sense contained in the law.
es: —I do not consider myself an emigrant according to the letter and spirit of the law.

en: Why not?
vi: Why not?
tr: Why was he thinking this way?
es: —Why not?

en: the President desired to know.
vi: The judge wants to know.
tr: The president wanted to know.
es: That is what I wish to know.

en: Because he had voluntarily relinquished a title that was distasteful to him, and a station that was distasteful to him, and had left his country—he submitted before the word emigrant in the present acceptation by the Tribunal was in use—to live by his own industry in England, rather than on the industry of the overladen people of France.
vi: Because Charles voluntarily renounced the title he detested, the status he despised, and left the country - before the term "exile" was used to refer to the nobility in the sense accepted by this court - to work for a living in England rather than living off the labor of the oppressed people in France.
tr: Because he had willingly given up a title he never liked and a position he never liked, he had left his country – he accepted the current refugee definition of the court – but in France, instead of living off others, he wanted to make a name for himself in England through his own efforts.
es: —Because I freely and willingly renounced a title that was not to my liking and a social position that displeased me, and I left my homeland to live off my work in England rather than off rents collected from the people of France, burdened under the weight of so many taxes and levies.

en: What proof had he of this?
vi: Do you have any evidence for this?
tr: How was he going to prove this?
es: —How do you prove the accuracy of your statements?

en: He handed in the names of two witnesses; Theophile Gabelle, and Alexandre Manette.
vi: You named two witnesses: Theophile Gabelle, and Alexandre Manette.
tr: He gave the names of two witnesses: Theophile Gabelle and Alexandre Manette.
es: —With the testimony of Théophile Gabelle and Alexandre Manette.

en: But he had married in England?
vi: But you have already started a family in England?
tr: But didn't she get married in England?
es: —But you got married in England—objected the President.

en: the President reminded him.
vi: The judge reminded.
tr: The president immediately reminded.
es: —But you got married in England—objected the President.

en: True, but not an English woman.
vi: Yes, but not with an English woman.
tr: It was true, but not with an Englishman.
es: —True; but not with an English woman.

en: A citizeness of France?
vi: A French female citizen?
tr: Was he/she a French citizen?
es: —With a citizen of France?

en: Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: By birth.
vi: Born in France.
tr: By birth.
es: —Yes.

en: Her name and family?
vi: Her name and her family's?
tr: What was their name, who was their family?
es: —Your last name and family?

en: “Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette, the good physician who sits there.”
vi: Lucie Manette, the only daughter of Dr. Manette, the esteemed doctor currently present in the court.
tr: "Lucie Manette, the only daughter of the kind-hearted Doctor Manette sitting over there.""
es: —Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette, the excellent physician present here.

en: This answer had a happy effect upon the audience.
vi: This answer made the crowd quite cheerful.
tr: This response had a positive effect on the public.
es: This response produced an effect in the audience that is impossible to describe with words.

en: Cries in exaltation of the well-known good physician rent the hall.
vi: The entire courtroom echoed with cheers for the famous doctor.
tr: When they heard the name of the well-known, kind-hearted doctor, the people in the hall shouted with enthusiasm.
es: The hall trembled under the cries of delirious enthusiasm that the mere mention of Doctor Manette's name elicited.

en: So capriciously were the people moved, that tears immediately rolled down several ferocious countenances which had been glaring at the prisoner a moment before, as if with impatience to pluck him out into the streets and kill him.
vi: These people were so impulsive that some who just moments ago were glaring fiercely at the prisoner as if they wanted to drag him out and kill him, were now immediately in tears.
tr: People's emotions were so fickle that, just a minute ago, the savage faces that were looking at the convict with the thought of dragging him out and killing him were now shedding tears.
es: So capricious were the movements of the people that many eyes, which a second before had been watching the accused with ferocity as if their impatience to have him delivered to them to tear him apart was overflowing, immediately filled with tears.

en: On these few steps of his dangerous way, Charles Darnay had set his foot according to Doctor Manette’s reiterated instructions.
vi: On this dangerous path, Charles Darnay followed the repeated instructions of Dr. Manette to the letter.
tr: Charles Darnay took his first steps on this dangerous path. He had taken them in accordance with the advice that Doctor Manette had repeatedly given him.
es: Carlos Darnay, in his statements, had followed the doctor's instructions to the letter.

en: The same cautious counsel directed every step that lay before him, and had prepared every inch of his road.
vi: The upcoming steps had also been meticulously guided by the doctor, and he was thoroughly prepared.
tr: Every step ahead of him had been determined by this cautious advisor, who had calculated every inch of the path he would take.
es: Carlos Darnay, in his statements, had followed the doctor's instructions to the letter.

en: The President asked, why had he returned to France when he did, and not sooner?
vi: The judge asked why he returned to France at that time and not earlier?
tr: The chairman asked him why he returned to France on the date he was arrested instead of earlier.
es: —Why did the accused return to France when he did, and not earlier?—asked the President.

en: He had not returned sooner, he replied, simply because he had no means of living in France, save those he had resigned; whereas, in England, he lived by giving instruction in the French language and literature.
vi: He replied that he did not return earlier simply because he had no means of livelihood in France, unless he relied on what he had abandoned; whereas in England, he lived by teaching the French language and literature.
tr: He hadn't returned before; because in France, apart from those things he had abandoned, he had nothing to sustain himself with; whereas in England, he made a living by teaching French language and literature.
es: —I did not return earlier—answered Carlos—simply because in France I had no other means of livelihood than the assets I had renounced, whereas in England I earned enough for my subsistence by giving lessons in French and French literature.

en: He had returned when he did, on the pressing and written entreaty of a French citizen, who represented that his life was endangered by his absence.
vi: He returned at that time because of an urgent plea from a French Citizen, who said that his life would be in danger due to his absence.
tr: He had returned here at the persistent and written request of a French citizen who claimed that his life was in danger due to his absence.
es: If I returned when I did, it was in response to a written plea from a French citizen, who informed me that my absence was very seriously compromising his life.

en: He had come back, to save a citizen’s life, and to bear his testimony, at whatever personal hazard, to the truth.
vi: He returned to save this person's life and to face the truth, regardless of any risks to himself.
tr: He had come to save a citizen's life and to testify for him, to tell the truth, no matter the cost.
es: I returned to save the life of the citizen in question, and to declare the truth without regard to dangers or inconveniences.

en: Was that criminal in the eyes of the Republic?
vi: Was this a crime against the Republic?
tr: Could this have been a crime committed against the Republic?
es: What crime does the Republic see in this?

en: The populace cried enthusiastically, “No!” and the President rang his bell to quiet them.
vi: "No!" The crowd enthusiastically shouted, and the judge's ringing of the bell to call for silence was in vain.
tr: The crowd shouted enthusiastically, "No!" and the President rang his bell to silence them.
es: The mob shouted, drunk with enthusiasm:

en: Which it did not, for they continued to cry “No!” until they left off, of their own will.
vi: The crowd continued to shout "No!" until they stopped on their own.
tr: But it didn't work, because they were still shouting "No!", then suddenly the voices stopped on their own.
es: —None... none!

en: The President required the name of that citizen.
vi: The judge asked for the name of that Citizen.
tr: The President wanted to learn the name of this citizen.
es: The President rang the bell, but he could not impose silence until the audience grew tired of shouting. —What was the name of the citizen to whom the defendant refers?—asked the President.

en: The accused explained that the citizen was his first witness.
vi: The convict explained that the Citizen was the first witness he had mentioned.
tr: The defendant said that the person in question was his first witness.
es: —Teófilo Gabelle, present here.

en: He also referred with confidence to the citizen’s letter, which had been taken from him at the Barrier, but which he did not doubt would be found among the papers then before the President.
vi: He also confidently referred to the letter from that Citizen, which had been taken from him at the gates of Paris, but he was sure it would be found in the files before the judge.
tr: Then, confidently, he spoke about the letter that had been taken from him at the barrier but should now be among the papers in front of the President.
es: The letter I have mentioned, which, although it was taken from me at the Barrier, I have no doubt will be among the documents the President has on the table, confirms my statements.

en: The Doctor had taken care that it should be there—had assured him that it would be there—and at this stage of the proceedings it was produced and read.
vi: Dr. Manette had arranged for the letter to be there - he assured Charles that it would be there - and at this point, the letter was taken out and read.
tr: The doctor – as he had previously promised Darnay – had ensured that the letter was there, and when it came time for the trial records, it was produced and read.
es: The doctor had taken good care to ensure that the letter in question was on the table. The President found it effortlessly and read it aloud.

en: Citizen Gabelle was called to confirm it, and did so.
vi: Citizen Gabelle was called out to verify, and he confirmed the truth.
tr: Citizen Gabelle was called to verify its authenticity, and he confirmed it.
es: Next, Gabelle was called to confirm the statements of the accused and to declare himself the author of the letter, which he did with great precision and a tone of truth.

en: Citizen Gabelle hinted, with infinite delicacy and politeness, that in the pressure of business imposed on the Tribunal by the multitude of enemies of the Republic with which it had to deal, he had been slightly overlooked in his prison of the Abbaye—in fact, had rather passed out of the Tribunal’s patriotic remembrance—until three days ago; when he had been summoned before it, and had been set at liberty on the Jury’s declaring themselves satisfied that the accusation against him was answered, as to himself, by the surrender of the citizen Evrémonde, called Darnay.
vi: Citizen Gabelle very delicately and politely implied that under the pressure of work that this Court had to deal with countless enemies of the Republic, he had almost been forgotten in the Abbaye prison—in fact, the patriotic Court had completely forgotten him—until three days ago; when he was called out for trial and the jury decided to release him, finding no grounds for charges since Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, had surrendered himself.
tr: Then Citizen Gabelle subtly and politely implied that the court had forgotten him in the Abbaye Prison due to the abundance of enemies of the Republic it had to deal with – in fact, he had been completely erased from the court's patriotic memory – and this situation had come to light three days before his trial, and with the surrender of Citizen Evremonde, that is, Darnay, the jury declared that the charge against Gabelle had been dropped and he was released.
es: Citizen Gabelle delicately and tactfully suggested that the Tribunal, short on time due to the countless enemies of the Republic demanding all its attention, had left him in the Abbey prison until three days prior, an insignificant and very natural oversight; and that, when he appeared before the Tribunal, he was declared innocent and set free, having satisfactorily dispelled the accusations against him.

en: Doctor Manette was next questioned.
vi: The next person to be questioned was Dr. Manette.
tr: The next person to be questioned was Doctor Manette.
es: The next person to be questioned was Dr. Manette.

en: His high personal popularity, and the clearness of his answers, made a great impression; but, as he proceeded, as he showed that the Accused was his first friend on his release from his long imprisonment; that, the accused had remained in England, always faithful and devoted to his daughter and himself in their exile; that, so far from being in favour with the Aristocrat government there, he had actually been tried for his life by it, as the foe of England and friend of the United States—as he brought these circumstances into view, with the greatest discretion and with the straightforward force of truth and earnestness, the Jury and the populace became one.
vi: His personal credibility and clear answers made a strong impression; however, he continued to testify that the defendant was his first friend when he was freed after a long period of imprisonment; that the defendant had stayed in England, always loyal and devoted to him and his daughter during their exile; that, not only was he not favored by the aristocratic government in England, but this defendant had actually been sentenced to death there for the crime of opposing England and sympathizing with the United States. While he presented these circumstances, with utmost caution and sincere, straightforward persuasiveness, the jury and the crowd watching the trial unanimously sympathized.
