tr: His beloved personality and the clarity of his answers had a great impact on the people; but when he continued speaking and said that the first friend he made after being freed from his long imprisonment was this defendant, and when he stated that during the defendant's years of exile in England, he had always been loyal and devoted to his daughter and himself, that he had no connection with the aristocratic government there, and that he was even judged for being an enemy of England and a friend of America – when he revealed all these details with all his common sense, reality, and sincerity, the jury agreed with the public.
es: His great personal popularity and the clarity and precision of his answers created an indescribable impression on the audience; but when he demonstrated that the accused was the one who most effectively contributed to freeing him from his eternal captivity, when he stated that the accused remained in England, surrounding not only his daughter but also himself with tender care and devoted affection, affection and care that made their exile sweet, when he added that far from being a supporter and defender of the aristocratic government of the country where he lived, he was prosecuted and almost condemned to death as an enemy of England and a friend of the United States. After he made a clear and eloquent exposition of all these circumstances, the Tribunal and the audience identified with him.

en: At last, when he appealed by name to Monsieur Lorry, an English gentleman then and there present, who, like himself, had been a witness on that English trial and could corroborate his account of it, the Jury declared that they had heard enough, and that they were ready with their votes if the President were content to receive them.
vi: Finally, when he mentioned Mr. Lorry, an English gentleman currently present in the court, who, like him, had been a witness in the trial of this defendant in England and could corroborate his testimony, the jury declared they had heard enough and were ready to vote if the Judge agreed.
tr: Finally, when Doctor Manette said that the English gentleman named Mr. Lorry, who was present there, had testified just like him in the court in England and could confirm what he had just said, the jury stated that this was sufficient and that they could announce their decision if it was also suitable for the President.
es: So much so, that when he invoked the testimony of Mr. Lorry, an English gentleman present there, a witness, like him, of the trial held in England against Darnay, and ready to corroborate all his statements, the judges replied that they were satisfied with what they had heard, and that they would gladly vote if the President was willing to receive the votes.

en: At every vote (the Jurymen voted aloud and individually), the populace set up a shout of applause.
vi: As each juror's vote was announced loudly, the crowd in the courtroom cheered and clapped.
tr: In each vote, the Jury members were announcing their votes one by one, out loud, and the crowd was applauding with great enthusiasm.
es: As the judges voted (doing so individually and aloud), the audience burst into frenzied applause.

en: All the voices were in the prisoner’s favour, and the President declared him free.
vi: All the votes were in favor of the prisoner, and the Judge declared that Charles Darnay was free.
tr: They had all voted in favor of the defendant, and the President announced that he was acquitted.
es: Unanimously, they declared the prisoner innocent, and as a result, the President declared him free.

en: Then, began one of those extraordinary scenes with which the populace sometimes gratified their fickleness, or their better impulses towards generosity and mercy, or which they regarded as some set-off against their swollen account of cruel rage.
vi: Then began a strange scene of the people in the court, similar to when a crowd sometimes wants to satisfy its own inconsistency or indulge in feelings of kindness and generosity, or perhaps it is a way for them to make amends for a past full of violent rage.
tr: Then one of those strange scenes began to unfold, revealing how fickle a crowd can be, or how impulses can turn into generosity and compassion, or how a swelling cruel rage can come to an end.
es: Then followed one of those extraordinary scenes that highlight the fickleness of the mob, or the impulses towards generosity and pity, dormant in the depths of their soul, or what they consider to be a demonstration that they are not carried away by the explosive force of cruel rage.

en: No man can decide now to which of these motives such extraordinary scenes were referable; it is probable, to a blending of all the three, with the second predominating.
vi: At this moment, no one could determine the motive behind this strange scene; it could be a combination of all three motives, but the feelings of kindness and generosity were more overwhelming.
tr: No one could say which of these strange scenes was the main reason; perhaps it was a mixture of all of them, especially the second one.
es: It is impossible to determine which of these three motives decisively influenced the extraordinary scenes that followed; probably all three influenced, with the second one predominating.

en: No sooner was the acquittal pronounced, than tears were shed as freely as blood at another time, and such fraternal embraces were bestowed upon the prisoner by as many of both sexes as could rush at him, that after his long and unwholesome confinement he was in danger of fainting from exhaustion; none the less because he knew very well, that the very same people, carried by another current, would have rushed at him with the very same intensity, to rend him to pieces and strew him over the streets.
vi: As soon as the acquittal was announced, tears flowed abundantly like blood in other moments, both men and women rushed to Charles, embracing him with such fervent affection that he felt he might faint from exhaustion after a long period of miserable imprisonment; however, he knew very well that these same people, driven by the tides of events, would also rush at him with the same fervor to tear him apart and throw his remains into the street.
tr: Not long after the blood had been shed, the courtroom was flooded with tears due to the acquittal, and so many men and women ran to him at once, embracing him with brotherly feelings, that Darnay, after that tedious and long imprisonment, felt he might collapse from exhaustion; on the other hand, he knew very well that the same crowd, if swept by a different current, would have rushed at him with the same intensity to tear him to pieces and scatter him in the streets.
es: The fact is that, as soon as the acquittal was pronounced, tears flowed as abundantly as blood had on other occasions, and the prisoner received so many and such tight embraces from everyone, regardless of gender, that he was in real danger of his prolonged captivity ending in a full-blown suffocation; it is noteworthy that these embraces were given by the same people who, driven by a different current, would have pounced on him with the same intensity to tear him apart with their nails and drag his palpitating remains through the streets.

en: His removal, to make way for other accused persons who were to be tried, rescued him from these caresses for the moment.
vi: He temporarily escaped those tight embraces due to having to make way for other defendants to be tried.
tr: When they took Darnay out to make room for the other prisoners to be tried, he was freed from all those embraces.
es: Thanks to having to leave the room to make way for other defendants awaiting sentencing, he was able to escape for the moment from that overwhelming torrent of caresses.

en: Five were to be tried together, next, as enemies of the Republic, forasmuch as they had not assisted it by word or deed.
vi: After that, five people were tried for the same crime of being enemies of the Republic, because they had not supported it in word or deed.
tr: The next five people were to be tried collectively as enemies of the Republic, for they had neither supported the Republic in word nor in deed.
es: Next, five accused individuals appeared together, who were charged with being enemies of the Republic, not because they had worked against it, but because they had done nothing, neither in word nor deed, in its favor.

en: So quick was the Tribunal to compensate itself and the nation for a chance lost, that these five came down to him before he left the place, condemned to die within twenty-four hours.
vi: Missing the opportunity to execute Charles Darnay, the court compensated itself and the nation with another opportunity that came so quickly that before he left the court, the five new defendants had been sentenced to death within twenty-four hours.
tr: The court, as if eager to quickly make up for the gap and this national loss, decided that these five men, who were brought in before Darnay even left the hall, would be executed within twenty-four hours.
es: The Tribunal hurried to compensate the nation for the freedom granted to one accused, so much so that he had not yet left the room when the death sentence already weighed upon the five unfortunate ones, to be executed within twenty-four hours.

en: The first of them told him so, with the customary prison sign of Death—a raised finger—and they all added in words, “Long live the Republic!”
vi: The first person in this group informed him by raising one finger - the familiar prison sign for death - and all five exclaimed, “Long live the Republic!”.
tr: The foremost prisoner conveyed this decision to Darnay with the death sign that had become customary in the prisons – by raising his finger – and they all shouted together, "Long live the Republic!"
es: The first of the condemned indicated to Darnay the fate that awaited him by raising a finger, a symbol of death among the prisoners, and his companions shouted in unison with a sarcastic tone: —Long live the Republic!

en: The five had had, it is true, no audience to lengthen their proceedings, for when he and Doctor Manette emerged from the gate, there was a great crowd about it, in which there seemed to be every face he had seen in Court—except two, for which he looked in vain.
vi: In reality, there were no longer any spectators at the trial to prolong the judgment, because when Charles and Dr. Manette exited the gate, they saw a dense crowd that seemed to include every face he had seen in the courtroom - except for two faces he kept searching for but could not find.
tr: In truth, these five people no longer had any spectators to prolong their trials, because the moment Darnay and Doctor Manette stepped out the door, a huge crowd accompanied them, and they were all the types seen in the courtroom – except for the two people Darnay had looked for in vain.
es: It is true that Darnay did not have more time to listen to the explanations that the condemned could or wished to give him, for no sooner had he stepped out into the street in the company of Doctor Manette than he found himself surrounded by a dense crowd, in which he saw almost all the faces he had seen before in the courtroom, with the exception of two, which he searched for in vain with his eyes.

en: On his coming out, the concourse made at him anew, weeping, embracing, and shouting, all by turns and all together, until the very tide of the river on the bank of which the mad scene was acted, seemed to run mad, like the people on the shore.
vi: Seeing him come out, the crowd showered him with tears, embraces, and shouts, individually or in unison, to the point that the waters of the river next to the courthouse seemed to go mad just like the people on the shore.
tr: As soon as they stepped outside, the crowd, with tearful eyes and shouting, surrounded them again, until the waters of the river, where this mad scene took place, swelled and overflowed, they pounced on them sometimes one by one, sometimes in groups.
es: Once again, he was enveloped by the furious whirlwind that had earlier nearly suffocated him, as they kissed him, embraced him, cried, shouted, and gave themselves over to other outbursts more fitting for madmen than for sane people.

en: They put him into a great chair they had among them, and which they had taken either out of the Court itself, or one of its rooms or passages.
vi: They placed him on a large armchair in the midst of the crowd, the chair they had taken from the courtroom, or from a room or hallway of the courthouse.
tr: They seated Darnay on a rather large chair that must have been found either in the courtroom, one of the rooms of the courthouse, or one of its corridors.
es: They forcefully sat him down in a large armchair that they had either taken from the Tribunal's hall or from one of the nearby houses.

en: Over the chair they had thrown a red flag, and to the back of it they had bound a pike with a red cap on its top.
vi: On the chair, they had draped a red flag, and behind the chair, they had fastened a spear with a red cap on top.
tr: They had draped a red flag over the chair and tied a spear with a red cap at its end to the back of it.
es: They adorned the armchair with a red flag and a spear whose iron tip displayed a red cap.

en: In this car of triumph, not even the Doctor’s entreaties could prevent his being carried to his home on men’s shoulders, with a confused sea of red caps heaving about him, and casting up to sight from the stormy deep such wrecks of faces, that he more than once misdoubted his mind being in confusion, and that he was in the tumbril on his way to the Guillotine.
vi: Despite the doctor's pleas, the crowd still carried Charles on this triumphal chair, surrounded by a chaotic sea of red caps surging violently into his view with drifting faces, making him feel at times as if he were losing his mind and being taken on a cart to meet La Guillotine.
tr: While he was on this triumphal chariot, not even the Doctor's pleas could prevent him from being carried on shoulders all the way to his home, and when he saw those excited faces rising from the depths and reaching a crescendo in the sea of red caps swirling around him, Darnay's mind became confused and disoriented, and he felt as though he were in an execution cart on the way to the guillotine.
es: All the doctor's pleas were not enough to prevent him from being triumphantly carried to his house, seated in that armchair which, borne on shoulders, resembled a throne placed upon a turbulent sea of red caps.

en: In wild dreamlike procession, embracing whom they met and pointing him out, they carried him on.
vi: In that nightmare-like procession, the crowd carried Charles and embraced anyone they met on the road, pointing towards him.
tr: They continued this dreamlike wild procession, hugging everyone they encountered and showing them Darnay.
es: Getting ahead of that wild procession, which embraced everyone it encountered on the way, the doctor arrived at his house in order to properly prepare his daughter.

en: Reddening the snowy streets with the prevailing Republican colour, in winding and tramping through them, as they had reddened them below the snow with a deeper dye, they carried him thus into the courtyard of the building where he lived.
vi: The snow-covered streets were filled with the red color of the Republic, as if stained with blood, as the winding crowd advanced, carrying Darnay all the way to the courtyard of the family house.
tr: They wound their way through those snowy streets, which they had previously painted a deep red, and this time carried him to the courtyard of the house where he lived, painting everything in the color of the Republic.
es: Getting ahead of that wild procession, which embraced everyone it encountered on the way, the doctor arrived at his house in order to properly prepare his daughter.

en: Her father had gone on before, to prepare her, and when her husband stood upon his feet, she dropped insensible in his arms.
vi: Mr. Manette had gone ahead to inform Lucie, and when her husband stepped down to stand on the ground, she fainted in his arms.
tr: His father had gone to the house earlier to prepare his daughter, and when Lucie saw her husband in front of her, she let herself fall into his arms.
es: Nevertheless, when Carlos was able to descend from his improvised throne and opened his arms to his beloved wife, she fainted in them.

en: As he held her to his heart and turned her beautiful head between his face and the brawling crowd, so that his tears and her lips might come together unseen, a few of the people fell to dancing.
vi: While Charles held his wife tightly and turned her face towards him so that no one could see his tears and their lips met, a few people in the crowd began to dance.
tr: When Darnay pressed his wife to his heart and turned her beautiful head so that their lips, joined by his own tears, would not be seen by the crowd, a group of people began to dance.
es: While Darnay held Lucie, supporting her against his chest, her head bent so that the crowd would not see the copious tears running down her cheeks, some of those who had carried him in triumph began to dance, the others caught on, and seconds later an unrestrained Carmagnole was improvised in the courtyard of the house.

en: Instantly, all the rest fell to dancing, and the courtyard overflowed with the Carmagnole.
vi: Immediately, the remaining people also joined in the dance, and the courtyard was filled with the Carmagnole dance.
tr: Then the others also started to dance, and the courtyard was suddenly filled with the enthusiasm of the carmagnole.
es: While Darnay held Lucie, supporting her against his chest, her head bent so that the crowd would not see the copious tears running down her cheeks, some of those who had carried him in triumph began to dance, the others caught on, and seconds later an unrestrained Carmagnole was improvised in the courtyard of the house.

en: Then, they elevated into the vacant chair a young woman from the crowd to be carried as the Goddess of Liberty, and then swelling and overflowing out into the adjacent streets, and along the river’s bank, and over the bridge, the Carmagnole absorbed them every one and whirled them away.
vi: Then, they placed a girl from the crowd on an empty chair to carry her like a Goddess of Liberty, and the throng surged into the nearby streets, along the riverbank, across the bridge, and the Carmagnole dance attracted everyone, sweeping them away like a whirlwind.
tr: Later, they seated a young woman from the crowd on the empty chair as the "goddess of liberty" and carried her through the streets with the same enthusiasm, flowing from there to the riverbank, and then to the bridge, spinning everyone they encountered into the carmagnole.
es: Later, they installed a young woman on the vacant chair, proclaiming her the Goddess of Liberty, carrying her on their shoulders through the adjacent streets, amidst deafening shouts and discordant songs.

en: After grasping the Doctor’s hand, as he stood victorious and proud before him; after grasping the hand of mr Lorry, who came panting in breathless from his struggle against the waterspout of the Carmagnole; after kissing little Lucie, who was lifted up to clasp her arms round his neck; and after embracing the ever zealous and faithful Pross who lifted her; he took his wife in his arms, and carried her up to their rooms.
vi: After tightly holding Dr. Manette's hand while he stood proudly and triumphantly beside; after tightly holding Mr. Lorry's hand as he breathlessly ran to escape the Carmagnole flood; after kissing little Lucie who was lifted high to hug her father's neck; and after embracing the loyal and eager Miss Pross who was holding little Lucie; Charles held Lucie in his arms and guided his wife upstairs.
tr: After shaking hands firmly with Mr. Lorry, who was breathless from the struggle to resist the cannagnole flood, and standing before him with a triumphant and proud demeanor, Charles Darnay kissed little Lucie, who had been lifted up to hug him, embraced the sturdy and loyal Miss Pross who had lifted her, and then carried his wife in his arms to their rooms.
es: Carlos, after embracing the doctor, whose face bore the look of a victor, after hugging Mr. Lorry, who, panting and breathless, managed to reach him by swimming against the immense wave that danced the Carmagnole, after kissing Lucita, whom he lifted from the ground so she could wrap her little arms around his neck, after hugging the faithful Pross, lifted Lucía in his arms and carried her to her rooms.

en: “Lucie!
vi: − Lucie!
tr: "Lucie!
es: —Lucía... my Lucía... Free... Free!...

en: My own!
vi: My love!
tr: My darling!
es: —Oh my dear Carlos!

en: I am safe.”
vi: I am safe.
tr: I am free now.""
es: Allow me, kneeling, to give thanks to God with the same fervor with which I prayed for you!

en: “O dearest Charles, let me thank God for this on my knees as I have prayed to Him.”
vi: − Oh dear Charles, let me kneel down and thank God as I have always prayed.
tr: "Ah Charles, my love, after all my pleading, now I will kneel and give thanks to God.""
es: Lucía fell to her knees.

en: They all reverently bowed their heads and hearts.
vi: They sincerely bowed their heads in prayer.
tr: They all bowed their heads with respect and placed their hands on their hearts.
es: All those present bowed their heads reverently and prayed from the depths of their hearts.

en: When she was again in his arms, he said to her:
vi: When Lucie had returned to his arms, Charles said to her: −
tr: When Darnay took Lucie into his arms again, he said to her;
es: When, the prayer finished, Lucía returned to his arms, Carlos said.

en: “And now speak to your father, dearest.
vi: It's all thanks to your father, my love.
tr: "Now pray for your father, my love.
es: —Now thank your father, my little woman!

en: No other man in all this France could have done what he has done for me.”
vi: Throughout all of France, no one could have done what your father did for me.
tr: No one in France would do what he did for me," she said.
es: No man in France could have done as much for me as he has!

en: She laid her head upon her father’s breast, as she had laid his poor head on her own breast, long, long ago.
vi: She rested her head on her father's chest, just like in the old days, long ago when she had held him in her arms.
tr: Long ago, just as she had rested her poor father's head on her chest, this time Lucie rested her head on her father's chest.
es: Lucía rested her head on her father's chest, just as she had done many years before.

en: He was happy in the return he had made her, he was recompensed for his suffering, he was proud of his strength.
vi: Dr. Manette was very happy to be able to repay what Lucie had done for him, all the past suffering now compensated, he was proud of his strength: − “Don't be so weak, my dear,” he gently chided, “don't tremble so.
tr: The doctor was happy that he could do this for his daughter; he had paid the price for his suffering and was proud of the strength he possessed.
es: The doctor considered himself happy to be able to repay in some way the selfless affection shown by his daughter, deemed all his sufferings worthwhile, and felt a noble pride when thinking of his strength. —Be strong in prosperity as you were in the storm, my daughter.

en: “You must not be weak, my darling,” he remonstrated; “don’t tremble so.
vi: Dr. Manette was very happy to be able to repay what Lucie had done for him, all the past suffering now compensated, he was proud of his strength: − “Don't be so weak, my dear,” he gently chided, “don't tremble so.
tr: "Pull yourself together now, my dear," he said, as if reproaching her; "what is there to be so afraid of?
es: Do not tremble... Do not cry.

en: I have saved him.”
vi: I have saved Charles.”
tr: I saved him, didn't I."
es: I have saved him.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: I have saved Charles.”
tr: VII
es: VII.

en: A Knock at the Door
vi: 7. The sound of knocking
tr: The Door is Knocking
es: UNEXPECTED VISIT

en: I have saved him.”
vi: "Father has saved Charles."
tr: "I saved him, that's it."
es: UNEXPECTED VISIT

en: It was not another of the dreams in which he had often come back; he was really here.
vi: It was not another dream where Charles often dreamed of being free; he had truly come back.
tr: This wasn't one of the dreams he often had; Charles was really beside them.
es: It was not a dream like so many other times; there was Carlos, and yet, his wife trembled, seized by a vague but intense terror.

en: And yet his wife trembled, and a vague but heavy fear was upon her.
vi: However, Lucie still trembled in a vague but heavy fear.
tr: His wife, however, was still trembling and had a vague but intense fear inside her.
es: It was not a dream like so many other times; there was Carlos, and yet, his wife trembled, seized by a vague but intense terror.

en: All the air round was so thick and dark, the people were so passionately revengeful and fitful, the innocent were so constantly put to death on vague suspicion and black malice, it was so impossible to forget that many as blameless as her husband and as dear to others as he was to her, every day shared the fate from which he had been clutched, that her heart could not be as lightened of its load as she felt it ought to be.
vi: The atmosphere around them was thick and gloomy, the people were bloodthirsty for revenge and impulsive, causing innocent people to constantly lose their lives due to vague suspicions and dark malice. How could Lucie forget that so many innocent people like her husband, who were loved by many, faced the same fragile fate as Charles every day. With that thought, how could her heart ease this fear?
tr: The weather was so foggy and dark, people were so filled with intense hatred and fickleness, innocent people were being sent to death so frequently due to a small suspicion or sheer malice, and it was so impossible to forget that every day many men, who were as innocent as their husbands and as valuable to their wives as their husbands, were experiencing the same fate as their husbands, that Lucie's heart could not lighten as much as she had hoped.
es: The atmosphere was so black and corrupted, the people were so brutally vengeful and cruel, the innocent who had the misfortune to inspire any suspicion, however vague, or to awaken malice, were taken to the slaughterhouse with such terrible regularity, it was so impossible to forget how many, as free of guilt as her husband, and as idolized by their loved ones as Charles was by Lucie, fell to the blows that Dr. Manette's son-in-law had managed to evade, that the heart of his afflicted wife could not free itself from the horrible weight that oppressed it.

en: The shadows of the wintry afternoon were beginning to fall, and even now the dreadful carts were rolling through the streets.
vi: The darkness of the winter evening had begun to fall, and even now those terrifying carriages were still rolling through the streets.
tr: The shadows of the winter noon had begun to fall, and even now those dreadful carts were rumbling through the streets.
es: The shadows of the winter evening twilight began to envelop the city, and the fateful carts of death continued to roll through the streets.

en: Her mind pursued them, looking for him among the Condemned; and then she clung closer to his real presence and trembled more.
vi: Her mind thought of the people sitting in those carriages, imagining her husband among the convicted; she pressed closer to her present husband and trembled even more.
tr: Her mind drifted there, and her eyes searched for her husband among the convicts; then she clung to the body right next to her and shivered a little more.
es: With her imagination, Lucie followed them, the eyes of her soul searched for her husband among the condemned, and seeing him with her fleshly eyes by her side, she clung to him and trembled more than ever.

en: Her father, cheering her, showed a compassionate superiority to this woman’s weakness, which was wonderful to see.
vi: Her father, while encouraging his daughter, displayed a powerful hidden strength far surpassing Lucie's frailty - a truly wonderful image.
tr: His father, who was trying to cheer him up, showed such a loving strength in response to this woman's weakness that it was wonderful to see.
es: Her father, striving to calm her, laughing at her fears, showed signs of an admirable compassionate superiority, of a manly fortitude that contrasted with the womanly weakness of his daughter.

en: No garret, no shoemaking, no One Hundred and Five, North Tower, now!
vi: No more the attic in the Saint Antoine district, no more the diligent shoemaking, no more Cell One Hundred and Five, North Tower!
tr: Now there was neither the attic, nor the shoemaking, nor the One Hundred and Five North Tower!
es: The attic, the shoemaker's bench, the old man who spent his days sewing shoes, the One Hundred Five, North Tower, were past events of which no traces remained.

en: He had accomplished the task he had set himself, his promise was redeemed, he had saved Charles.
vi: He had completed his self-imposed mission, kept his promise, and saved Charles.
tr: He had accomplished the task he had set his mind to, kept his promise, and saved Charles.
es: He had successfully completed the endeavor he had undertaken with manly courage, he had fulfilled his promise, Carlos was free, why fear?

en: Let them all lean upon him.
vi: Everyone relied on him.
tr: They could now trust him in every matter.
es: The doctor had more than enough strength to serve as a robust support for all those who felt their own waning.

en: Their housekeeping was of a very frugal kind: not only because that was the safest way of life, involving the least offence to the people, but because they were not rich, and Charles, throughout his imprisonment, had had to pay heavily for his bad food, and for his guard, and towards the living of the poorer prisoners.
vi: They lived very frugally; not only because it was the safest way of life, causing the least discomfort to the surrounding populace, but also because they were not wealthy; and Charles, during his imprisonment, had to spend a lot of money on poor meals, on guards, and on poorer fellow prisoners.
tr: They managed the house in a very frugal manner; not because it was the safest way to live or because it prevented them from despising people, but because they had no money, and during Charles's imprisonment, he had spent a lot of money on the bad food given to him, for his guard, and for other poorer prisoners.
es: The furnishings of their house could not be more modest; not only because prudence advised it so, to avoid hurting the poverty of the people, but also because they were not rich, for Carlos, during the extended period of his captivity, had to pay an exorbitant price for food, the allowances of his guards, and a proportional part to cover the expenses of prisoners poorer than himself.

en: Partly on this account, and partly to avoid a domestic spy, they kept no servant; the citizen and citizeness who acted as porters at the courtyard gate, rendered them occasional service; and Jerry (almost wholly transferred to them by mr Lorry) had become their daily retainer, and had his bed there every night.
vi: Partly because of this, and partly to avoid harboring spies in their home, they had no servants; they only occasionally asked the male and female Citizens who guarded the outer yard to help with some tasks; Jerry (Mr. Lorry had almost entirely entrusted him to the Manette family) became their daily attendant and slept there every night.
tr: Both for this reason and to avoid having a spy in the house, they did not hire a servant; only the citizens, one woman and one man, who were occasionally on duty at the gate of the courtyard, served them; Jerry (whom Mr. Lorry had completely put at their disposal) took care of their daily chores and stayed with them at night.
es: Due in part to the aforementioned reasons, and in part to avoid the danger of being spied on within their own home, they had no servants. The citizen and the citizeness in charge of the porter’s lodge provided the necessary services to the family if circumstances required it, apart from Jeremiah, who had been almost entirely given to them by the good Lorry, and was at their disposal during the day and slept in the house at night.

en: It was an ordinance of the Republic One and Indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, that on the door or doorpost of every house, the name of every inmate must be legibly inscribed in letters of a certain size, at a certain convenient height from the ground.
vi: According to the regulations of the Indivisible Unified Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, the name of every person living inside must be written clearly in a certain font size on the door or doorpost of every house, at a certain convenient height from the ground.
tr: "The Republic is One and Indivisible. According to the decree of 'Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death,' the name of the residents of each house had to be engraved on the door or side of the house, in letters of a certain size, at a certain height from the ground, and in a legible manner.
es: The Republic One and Indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death had decreed that above the doors of all houses, at a specified height, there should be a large signboard on which the names of all the inhabitants of the house would be inscribed in letters of a specified size.

en: mr Jerry Cruncher’s name, therefore, duly embellished the doorpost down below; and, as the afternoon shadows deepened, the owner of that name himself appeared, from overlooking a painter whom Doctor Manette had employed to add to the list the name of Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay.
vi: Therefore, the name of Jerry Cruncher was also properly displayed on the doorpost of his house; and as the evening shadows fell, the owner of that name appeared, keeping an eye on the painter whom Dr. Manette had hired to add to that list the name of Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay.
tr: Thus, the name of Mr. Jerry Cruncher also adorned the bottom of the list as required, and when the shadows began to lengthen in the afternoon, the owner of this name appeared, observing the painter whom Doctor Manette had assigned the task of adding the name Charles Evremonde, also known as Darnay, to the list.
es: As a result, among the names inscribed on the signboard placed on the door of the doctor's residence was that of Jeremiah Lapa, and on the occasion referred to in this story, not only the name but also the owner of the name was standing by the door, watching the painter called by Doctor Manette to add the name of Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, to the signboard.

en: In the universal fear and distrust that darkened the time, all the usual harmless ways of life were changed.
vi: In the fear and suspicion that enveloped that dark era, all harmless and normal ways of life changed.
tr: In the universal fear and insecurity that darkened the era, all harmless lifestyles had changed.
es: The atmosphere of terror and distrust in which people lived had profoundly altered even the most innocent and harmless habits of life.

en: In the Doctor’s little household, as in very many others, the articles of daily consumption that were wanted were purchased every evening, in small quantities and at various small shops.
vi: In the doctor's family, as in every other household, essential daily items were bought in the evening, in small quantities from various shops.
tr: In the doctor's small house, as in many other houses, all the necessities for the next day were bought in small amounts from various small shops every evening.
es: In the doctor's house, as in almost all the others, essential and daily consumption items were bought every afternoon in small quantities and from different small shops.

en: To avoid attracting notice, and to give as little occasion as possible for talk and envy, was the general desire.
vi: Everyone wanted to avoid attracting attention, the less opportunity for others to be jealous and gossip, the better.
tr: The important thing was not to attract attention, to avoid gossip and jealousy.
es: It was the way to avoid attracting attention and to provide the least possible occasion for gossip and envy.

en: For some months past, Miss Pross and mr Cruncher had discharged the office of purveyors; the former carrying the money; the latter, the basket.
vi: For the past few months, Miss Pross and Cruncher were entrusted with the task of shopping; Miss Pross carried the money; Cruncher carried the basket.
tr: For a few months, Miss Pross and Mr. Cruncher had been buying the provisions; Miss Pross carried the money, and the other carried the basket.
es: For several months prior, Miss Pross and Jeremiah Lapa had been in charge of the shopping; the latter carried the basket, the former the money.

en: Every afternoon at about the time when the public lamps were lighted, they fared forth on this duty, and made and brought home such purchases as were needful.
vi: Every evening when the street lamps were lit, they would go out on their mission and bring home such essential goods.
tr: Every evening when the street lamps were lit, they would set out to perform this duty, and after purchasing the necessary provisions, they would bring them home.
es: Every evening, when the streetlights were lit, both would go out and bring back the necessary consumables for the following day.

en: Although Miss Pross, through her long association with a French family, might have known as much of their language as of her own, if she had had a mind, she had no mind in that direction; consequently she knew no more of that “nonsense” (as she was pleased to call it) than mr Cruncher did.
vi: Though Miss Pross had been in a French family for a very long time, she could have been as fluent in French as in English if she wanted to learn; but she had no such intention, so in the end, regarding that "gibberish" language (as she often called it), she was no better than Cruncher.
tr: Although Miss Pross had been with a French family for a long time, she couldn't speak French at all; yet, if she had a bit of sense, she could speak it as if it were her native language; after all, (in her own words) she knew no more about this "nonsense" than Mr. Cruncher did.
es: Although Miss Pross, given the many years she had lived with a French family, seemed like she should speak French with as much correctness and fluency as English, she knew exactly as much as Jeremiah Lapa, who didn't know a single word, and that was either she lacked the talent or she didn't want to apply it to nonsense (as she called it) like that.

en: So her manner of marketing was to plump a noun-substantive at the head of a shopkeeper without any introduction in the nature of an article, and, if it happened not to be the name of the thing she wanted, to look round for that thing, lay hold of it, and hold on by it until the bargain was concluded.
vi: Therefore, her way of shopping was to throw the name of an item at the shopkeeper's head, regardless of the masculine or feminine article preceding it, and if it wasn't the name of the item she wanted, she would look around for it, grab it, and hold onto it until the price was settled.
tr: Therefore, upon entering the shop, she had developed a way of shopping where she would say the first word that came to mind without knowing what it meant; if that thing wasn't what she wanted, she would look around with this item in her hand and not put it down until the bargaining was over.
es: As a result, her commercial system consisted of firing a noun point-blank as soon as she faced the shopkeeper, and if the noun didn't match the item she needed, as was almost always the case, she would look around, grab the item, and not let go until the deal was closed.

en: She always made a bargain for it, by holding up, as a statement of its just price, one finger less than the merchant held up, whatever his number might be.
vi: She always bargained by holding up a few fingers to indicate her offer, always one finger less than the number the shopkeeper indicated, regardless of the price.
tr: She would always negotiate while holding this item, and regardless of the price, she would always indicate one finger less than the price the merchant indicated with his fingers.
es: As for the price, it was understood without difficulty by raising one finger less than the shopkeeper, regardless of the number of fingers he raised.

en: “Now, mr Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose eyes were red with felicity; “if you are ready, I am.”
vi: − Mr. Cruncher, - said Miss Pross, her eyes red from tears of joy, - if you are ready, then I am done as well.
tr: Miss Pross, her eyes red with happiness, said, "Well Mr. Cruncher, if you're ready, let's go.""
es: —Mr. Lapa—said Miss Pross, whose eyes sparkled with happiness,—I am ready; and you?

en: Jerry hoarsely professed himself at Miss Pross’s service.
vi: Jerry hoarsely declared his request to serve Miss Pross.
tr: Jerry joined Miss Pross in a hoarse voice.
es: Jeremiah replied that he was at Miss Pross's service.

en: He had worn all his rust off long ago, but nothing would file his spiky head down.
vi: He had long since rid his fingers of the rusty smell, but nothing could tame his spiky hair.
tr: The rust color on his hands had long gone, but nothing could blunt his spiky hair.
es: Jeremiah replied that he was at Miss Pross's service.

en: “There’s all manner of things wanted,” said Miss Pross, “and we shall have a precious time of it.
vi: − We need to buy so many things, - said Miss Pross, - and we have so little time.
tr: "We have a lot of things to get," said Miss Pross, "it will take quite some time.
es: —Today we are in need of everything,—observed Miss Pross,—and among other things, wine.

en: We want wine, among the rest.
vi: We also need to buy wine.
tr: We also need to get some wine.
es: A tough time awaits us.

en: Nice toasts these Redheads will be drinking, wherever we buy it.”
vi: Everywhere we buy wine, we encounter Red Caps toasting.
tr: No matter where we get it from, these red-capped people are toasting everywhere."
es: Wherever we buy it, we are bound to find plenty of red caps toasting like the damned.

en: “It will be much the same to your knowledge, miss, I should think,” retorted Jerry, “whether they drink your health or the Old Un’s.”
vi: − For you, I think it doesn't matter what you're drinking to celebrate, - Jerry retorted, - whether they're toasting to you or to an old brain.
tr: Jerry immediately responded, "Whether they drink to your health or the old man's, I think it all comes down to the same thing for you, Miss."
es: —They don't break their heads too much to come up with their toasts—observed Jeremías. —I always hear them toast for the same thing; for the One.

en: “Who’s he?” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Which old man? - Miss Pross asked.
tr: "Who is the old man?" said Miss Pross.
es: —And who is that one? —Who knows.

en: mr Cruncher, with some diffidence, explained himself as meaning “Old Nick’s.”
vi: − That Satan, - Cruncher stammered to explain.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, somewhat hesitantly, said, "Old Nick."
es: Unless they are referring to Noah... the one who planted the first vineyard...

en: “Ha!” said Miss Pross, “it doesn’t need an interpreter to explain the meaning of these creatures.
vi: − Ah! - Miss Pross said. - But with those people, no explanation is needed to understand.
tr: Miss Pross said, "Haa! There is no need to explain what these men are up to.
es: —Ah... I see! You don't have to be very wise to understand who those wretches are toasting to.

en: They have but one, and it’s Midnight Murder, and Mischief.”
vi: They are all about darkness, murder, and destruction.
tr: They have only one occupation, which is to kill people and cause trouble at midnight."
es: They are toasting to the Killer... to the Evil One.

en: “Hush, dear!
vi: − Shh, watch your words!
tr: "Shh!
es: —Careful, my friend!

en: Pray, pray, be cautious!” cried Lucie.
vi: - Lucie exclaimed.
tr: Please, please be careful, dear!" Lucie shouted.
es: —interjected Lucía—Caution, please, a lot of caution!

en: “Yes, yes, yes, I’ll be cautious,” said Miss Pross; “but I may say among ourselves, that I do hope there will be no oniony and tobaccoey smotherings in the form of embracings all round, going on in the streets.
vi: − Yes, yes, yes, I will be careful, - said Miss Pross, - but we can speak privately that I hope not to see those people reeking of onions and tobacco hugging each other all over the streets anymore.
tr: "Alright, alright, I'll be careful," said Miss Pross; "between you and me, I hope we don't run into any types on the road whose breath smells like onions and tobacco.
es: —Yes, yes, yes! I will be very prudent; but it seems to me that among us I can say that it is not very pleasant to receive sighs that reek of onions, liquor, and tobacco, mixed with hugs, on those streets.

en: Now, Ladybird, never you stir from that fire till I come back!
vi: Now, my dear mistress, you must sit by the fireplace without moving and wait for me to return!
tr: Now my little bird, don't get up from this fire until I return, okay?
es: I am going out; but do not move from beside the fire until I return, my dear young lady.

en: Take care of the dear husband you have recovered, and don’t move your pretty head from his shoulder as you have it now, till you see me again!
vi: Take care of your husband who has just returned, and keep your beautiful head on your neck without turning it around like you are now, wait for me to come back!
tr: Take good care of your husband until I come back and keep that beautiful head of yours, just like now, resting on his shoulder!
es: Take care of the husband you have recovered and fear nothing.

en: May I ask a question, Doctor Manette, before I go?”
vi: Doctor Manette, may I ask one question before I go? − I think you can ask freely. -
tr: Before I leave, may I ask you something, Mr. Manette?"
es: May I ask a question before leaving, Doctor?

en: “I think you may take that liberty,” the Doctor answered, smiling.
vi: The doctor replied with a smile.
tr: The Doctor replied with a smile, "Of course, it's your right."
es: —I think you can take that liberty—replied the doctor with a humorous tone.

en: “For gracious sake, don’t talk about Liberty; we have quite enough of that,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Oh heavens, don't mention the word freedom; we are tired of hearing it, - said Miss Pross.
tr: "For God's sake, don't talk to me about justice; I hear enough about it already," said Miss Pross.
es: —For all the saints in Heaven, do not speak of freedom, doctor. I am fed up with freedom—exclaimed Pross.

en: “Hush, dear!
vi: − Shh, there she goes again!
tr: Luice, "Hush!
es: —For God's sake, dear; again?—said Lucía.

en: Again?” Lucie remonstrated.
vi: - Lucie scolded.
tr: Again, my dear?" she reproached.
es: —For God's sake, dear; again?—said Lucía.

en: “Well, my sweet,” said Miss Pross, nodding her head emphatically, “the short and the long of it is, that I am a subject of His Most Gracious Majesty King George the Third;” Miss Pross curtseyed at the name; “and as such, my maxim is, Confound their politics, Frustrate their knavish tricks, On him our hopes we fix, God save the King!”
vi: − All right, dear, - said Miss Pross, nodding emphatically, - in short, I am a subject of the kind King George the Third of England, - she curtsied when mentioning the king's name, - and therefore, my motto is "Crush the plot, thwart the scheme, hope of the people, God save the King*".
tr: Miss Pross nodded her head vigorously forward, "Alright darling," she said, "in short, I am loyal to His Majesty King George III." Miss Pross had curtsied as she mentioned the king's name, "and as I always say, may their policies fail, their deceitful schemes collapse, and subsequently may we achieve our hopes, God save the King!"
es: —Well, miss—replied Pross, shaking her head solemnly;—if you want me to say what I feel, I will declare that I, as a subject of His Gracious Majesty King George III, laugh at those ragamuffins. My maxim is: "Cursed be their politics by God; may God thwart their criminal purposes; in God I trust, and long live the King."

en: mr Cruncher, in an access of loyalty, growlingly repeated the words after Miss Pross, like somebody at church.
vi: To show his loyalty, Cruncher also growled and repeated those words after Miss Pross, as if he were in a church.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, with a faithful demeanor and a gruff voice, as if he were in church, repeated Miss Pross's words.
es: Lapa, in a burst of loyalty to his sovereign, repeated the cheer in a stentorian voice.

en: “I am glad you have so much of the Englishman in you, though I wish you had never taken that cold in your voice,” said Miss Pross, approvingly.
vi: − I am glad that you still have plenty of English blood in you, although I hope you don't catch a cold to the point of losing your voice, - Miss Pross said with satisfaction.
tr: "I'm glad you're a true Englishwoman, but of course, I wish you hadn't caught a cold and lost your voice," said Miss Pross approvingly.
es: —I celebrate that you are a true Englishman, Mr. Lapa,—said Miss Pross with an approving tone,—although it would have been desirable if you hadn't put so much energy into your shout.

en: “But the question, Doctor Manette.
vi: - But the question is, Dr. Manette, is...
tr: "But Doctor Manette, my question to you is this.
es: But let's get to the question, Doctor; haven't you yet found a way to leave this damned city forever?

en: Is there”—it was the good creature’s way to affect to make light of anything that was a great anxiety with them all, and to come at it in this chance manner—“is there any prospect yet, of our getting out of this place?”
vi: - This kind-hearted person always has a way of casually addressing everything that everyone else considers very serious, - ... do we have any prospects of leaving this place yet?
tr: Is there" –she was trying to shed a light of hope on a matter that worried everyone– "is there any chance of us getting out of here?"
es: —No, for now; going out under these circumstances would be dangerous for Carlos.

en: “I fear not yet.
vi: − I'm afraid not, it's still dangerous for Charles.
tr: "Unfortunately, there is no more.
es: —What can you do!

en: It would be dangerous for Charles yet.”
vi: − Oh my!
tr: This could still be dangerous for Charles."
es: —exclaimed Miss Pross, holding back a sigh and looking at Lucie.

en: “Heigh-ho-hum!” said Miss Pross, cheerfully repressing a sigh as she glanced at her darling’s golden hair in the light of the fire, “then we must have patience and wait: that’s all.
vi: - Miss Pross cheerfully suppressed a sigh while glancing at her beloved mistress's blonde hair by the fireplace. - Then we just have to be patient and wait, that's all.
tr: Miss Pross, looking at the golden hair of her sweet child shining in the fireplace, sighed deeply and said, "Well, what can we do!"
es: —We will have patience and wait...

en: We must hold up our heads and fight low, as my brother Solomon used to say.
vi: We have to hold our heads high and endure, as my brother Solomon often says.
tr: "Then there's nothing to do but to be patient and wait, as my brother Solomon said, we will hold our heads high and fight."
es: Courage, and let the storm rage over the neighbor's head, as my brother Solomon used to say.

en: Now, mr Cruncher!
vi: Let's go, Mr. Cruncher!...
tr: "Come on, Mr. Cruncher!
es: Let's go now, Mr. Lorry...

en: —Don’t you move, Ladybird!”
vi: And you, my dear mistress, don't move!
tr: –You stay right where you are, my little bird!""
es: Don't move, miss.

en: They went out, leaving Lucie, and her husband, her father, and the child, by a bright fire.
vi: The two of them left, leaving Lucie, her husband, her father, and the child by the bright fireplace.
tr: They left Lucie, her husband, her father, and her child by the bright fire and went out.
es: The Pross and Lapa left, leaving Lucía, her husband, the doctor, and Lucita sitting by the warmth of the fire.

en: mr Lorry was expected back presently from the Banking House.
vi: The whole family was expecting Mr. Lorry to visit soon after finishing his work at the bank.
tr: Mr. Lorry would arrive from the bank shortly.
es: They were expecting Mr. Lorry to arrive at any moment.

en: Miss Pross had lighted the lamp, but had put it aside in a corner, that they might enjoy the fire-light undisturbed.
vi: Miss Pross had lit the lamp but placed it in the corner so they could enjoy the firelight undisturbed.
tr: Miss Pross had lit the lamp, but she had placed it in a distant corner so they could enjoy the fireplace.
es: Miss Pross had lit a light, but she placed it in a corner so that the family could exclusively enjoy the faint light radiating from the fireplace.

en: Little Lucie sat by her grandfather with her hands clasped through his arm: and he, in a tone not rising much above a whisper, began to tell her a story of a great and powerful Fairy who had opened a prison-wall and let out a captive who had once done the Fairy a service.
vi: Little Lucie sat beside her grandfather, her small hands holding his arm; and Dr. Manette, in an almost whispering voice, began to tell her the story of a wonderful fairy who broke through the prison walls to rescue a prisoner who had once helped her.
tr: Little Lucie sat next to her grandfather and held his arm tightly, and her grandfather began to tell, in a whispering voice, the story of a great and powerful fairy who had done him a favor beforehand by opening the wall of a prison and freeing a prisoner.
es: Lucita, sitting on her grandfather's knee, was listening to the story of a great and powerful fairy who once broke the strong walls of a dungeon to free a captive who had once rendered a service to the fairy.

en: All was subdued and quiet, and Lucie was more at ease than she had been.
vi: All around was quiet and peaceful, and Lucie felt more at ease than ever before. − What is that? -
tr: A sense of tranquility enveloped everything, and Lucie felt much more at ease.
es: Lucita, sitting on her grandfather's knee, was listening to the story of a great and powerful fairy who once broke the strong walls of a dungeon to free a captive who had once rendered a service to the fairy.

en: “What is that?” she cried, all at once.
vi: She suddenly exclaimed.
tr: "What was that?" he suddenly shouted.
es: —What is that? —Lucía suddenly exclaimed.

en: “My dear!” said her father, stopping in his story, and laying his hand on hers, “command yourself.
vi: − My dear! - Her father said, pausing the story and holding Lucie's hand, Calm down.
tr: The father paused his story, took his daughter's hand, and said, "Calm down, my dear.
es: —My dear! —replied the doctor, pausing the story—Calm yourself.

en: What a disordered state you are in!
vi: Why are you so startled!
tr: How tense you are!
es: Your nervous disorder is extraordinary.

en: The least thing—nothing—startles you!
vi: Even the smallest things... things that are insignificant... can make you jump!
tr: Such things –nothing– should not scare you!
es: The most insignificant thing... even without any reason... alarms you.

en: You, your father’s daughter!”
vi: You, my daughter! −
tr: You are your father's daughter!"
es: You have me... your father, my daughter.

en: “I thought, my father,” said Lucie, excusing herself, with a pale face and in a faltering voice, “that I heard strange feet upon the stairs.”
vi: Father, I think that... - Lucie, pale-faced, stammered in defense, - ... I heard strange footsteps coming up the stairs.
tr: Lucie, with a pale face and a trembling voice, as if apologizing, said, "I thought I heard a footstep on the stairs, father."
es: —I thought I heard the sound of footsteps on the stairs—Lucía stammered.

en: “My love, the staircase is as still as Death.”
vi: − My dear, the staircase is as silent as a sheet.
tr: "My dear, the stairs are as silent as a dead person."
es: —Silly girl...! The staircase is as silent as a tomb.

en: As he said the word, a blow was struck upon the door.
vi: As soon as he finished speaking, there was a loud knock on the door.
tr: As soon as the doctor said this, a knock was heard at the door.
es: As the last word left his lips, there was a knock at the door.

en: “Oh father, father.
vi: − Oh father, father.
tr: "Oh father, father.
es: —Oh, father... my father!

en: What can this be!
vi: What is happening!
tr: Who could this be!
es: What could it be?

en: Hide Charles.
vi: Hide Charles.
tr: Hide Charles, save him!"
es: Let Carlos hide...!

en: Save him!”
vi: Save him! −
tr: Hide Charles, save him!"
es: Save him! —Dear daughter!

en: “My child,” said the Doctor, rising, and laying his hand upon her shoulder, “I have saved him.
vi: My child, - the doctor said as he stood up, placing his hand on Lucie's shoulder, I have already saved Charles.
tr: When the doctor stood up and placed his hand on his daughter's shoulder, he said, "My dear, I have already saved him."
es: —replied the doctor, standing up and placing his hand on Lucía's shoulder. —I have already saved him.

en: What weakness is this, my dear!
vi: Why so weak, my dear!
tr: What is this weakness, my child!
es: I don't understand your weakness... I'm going to open the door.

en: Let me go to the door.”
vi: Let me go open the door and see.
tr: Let me go and check that door."
es: I don't understand your weakness... I'm going to open the door.

en: He took the lamp in his hand, crossed the two intervening outer rooms, and opened it.
vi: He held the lamp in his hand, crossed the two separating outer rooms, and opened the main door.
tr: He took the lamp in his hand, passed through the two rooms in between, and opened the door.
es: He took the candlestick in his hand, crossed the two intermediate rooms, and opened the door.

en: A rude clattering of feet over the floor, and four rough men in red caps, armed with sabres and pistols, entered the room.
vi: The sound of heavy footsteps echoed on the floor, and four ruffians wearing red hats, armed with swords and pistols, entered the inner room.
tr: In front of the door, there were feet making clattering noises, and four rough men wearing red hats, armed with swords and pistols, rushed in immediately.
es: Four men of wild appearance, covered with red caps and armed with sabers and pistols, entered the reception area, from where they proceeded to the room where the family was.

vi: − Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - the first one to speak.
tr: "Where is the citizen Evremonde known as Darnay?" said the one in front.
es: "Citizen Evrémonde?" asked the one who entered first.

en: Original
vi: − Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - the first one to speak.
tr: "Where is the citizen Evremonde known as Darnay?" said the one in front.
es: "Citizen Evrémonde?" asked the one who entered first.

en: “The Citizen Evrémonde, called Darnay,” said the first.
vi: − Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - the first one to speak.
tr: "Where is the citizen Evremonde known as Darnay?" said the one in front.
es: "Citizen Evrémonde?" asked the one who entered first.

en: “Who seeks him?” answered Darnay.
vi: − Who are you looking for? - Darnay responded.
tr: "Who is looking for him?" replied Darnay.
es: —Who is looking for him?—asked Darnay.

en: “I seek him.
vi: − I need to find.
tr: "I am searching.
es: —I... we will look for him.

en: We seek him.
vi: We need to find.
tr: We are searching.
es: —I... we will look for him.

en: I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you before the Tribunal to-day.
vi: I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you at the court today.
tr: I know you, Evremonde; I saw you before the court today.
es: I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you yesterday in the Tribunal room.

en: You are again the prisoner of the Republic.”
vi: You are now again a prisoner of the Republic.
tr: We are arresting you again in the name of the Republic."
es: You are once again a prisoner of the Republic.

en: The four surrounded him, where he stood with his wife and child clinging to him.
vi: Four strangers surrounded the place where Charles stood with his wife and children clinging tightly to him.
tr: All four of them immediately surrounded Darnay, who was tightly held by his wife and child.
es: The four men surrounded the group formed by Darnay, his wife, and their little daughter, who had embraced him.

en: “Tell me how and why am I again a prisoner?”
vi: − Tell me why and how I am a prisoner? −
tr: "Can you tell me how and why I am being arrested again?"
es: —How and why am I a prisoner again?

en: “It is enough that you return straight to the Conciergerie, and will know to-morrow.
vi: You just need to know that you must return to the Conciergerie prison immediately, and tomorrow it will be clear.
tr: "You need to go straight to the Conciergerie, you will learn there.
es: —Come with us to the Consulate, and tomorrow you will be able to satisfy your curiosity.

en: You are summoned for to-morrow.”
vi: Tomorrow you will be retried.
tr: You will appear in court tomorrow."
es: Tomorrow you must appear before the Court.

en: Doctor Manette, whom this visitation had so turned into stone, that he stood with the lamp in his hand, as if he were a statue made to hold it, moved after these words were spoken, put the lamp down, and confronting the speaker, and taking him, not ungently, by the loose front of his red woollen shirt, said:
vi: Dr. Manette was stunned by this visit, standing as if turned to stone with the lamp in his hand. The words he just heard awakened him, and he set the lamp down and faced the speaker, gently grasping the edge of his red coat: −
tr: Dr. Manette was so petrified by this visit that he stood holding the lamp as if he were a statue made to hold it, and upon hearing these words, he moved and placed the lamp on the ground; then he stood in front of the person who had spoken, and without being rude, he grabbed the loose collar of his red woolen shirt and said:
es: Dr. Manette, whom the unexpected visit had left in a perfectly astonished state, to the point of seeming like a statue with a candlestick in hand, shook off his stupor after hearing the last words, placed the candlestick on the mantelpiece, faced the one who was leading the conversation, and, grabbing him by the collar of his shirt, red like his cap, said:

en: “You know him, you have said.
vi: You say you know this person.
tr: "You said you knew him.
es: —You said you know him; do you know me as well?

en: Do you know me?”
vi: Do you know me?
tr: Do you know me then?"
es: —You said you know him; do you know me as well?

en: “Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor.”
vi: − Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor.
tr: "Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor."
es: —Yes; I know you, citizen doctor.

en: “We all know you, Citizen Doctor,” said the other three.
vi: − We all know you, Citizen Doctor, - the other three also said.
tr: "We all know you, Citizen Doctor," said the other three as well.
es: —We all know you, citizen doctor—added the remaining three.

en: He looked abstractedly from one to another, and said, in a lower voice, after a pause:
vi: Mr. Manette looked dazedly from one person to another, then after a moment of silence, he softly asked: −
tr: After the doctor thoughtfully scrutinized them, he said in a low voice:
es: The old man let his gaze wander over the faces of the four men, and after a pause, he replied, lowering his voice:

en: “Will you answer his question to me then?
vi: Then will you answer this question for me?
tr: "So, will you give me the answer to his question?
es: —Do you want to answer me the question he asked you?

en: How does this happen?”
vi: Why is this happening?
tr: How did this happen?"
es: Why does it catch on again?

en: “Citizen Doctor,” said the first, reluctantly, “he has been denounced to the Section of Saint Antoine.
vi: − Citizen doctor, - the first person reluctantly said, - this person has been accused by the Saint Antoine district.
tr: The man in front reluctantly said, "Citizen Doctor, this man has been denounced to the St Antoine district.
es: —Citizen doctor,—replied the first speaker with evident repugnance,—he has been denounced by the San Antonio Section... to which this citizen belongs—he added, pointing with his hand to the individual who was beside him.

en: This citizen,” pointing out the second who had entered, “is from Saint Antoine.”
vi: This citizen is from Saint Antoine, - he pointed to the second person in the group.
tr: This citizen," he said, pointing to the second man who had entered, "is from St Antoine."
es: —Citizen doctor,—replied the first speaker with evident repugnance,—he has been denounced by the San Antonio Section... to which this citizen belongs—he added, pointing with his hand to the individual who was beside him.

en: The citizen here indicated nodded his head, and added:
vi: The person who was instructed nodded and added: − He was accused by Saint Antoine.
tr: The indicated citizen nodded and added:
es: The mentioned citizen made an affirmative nod and said:

en: “He is accused by Saint Antoine.”
vi: − For what crime? -
tr: "Found guilty by St Antoine.""
es: —He has been accused by San Antonio.

en: “Of what?” asked the Doctor.
vi: The doctor asked.
tr: "Why?" asked the Doctor.
es: —Of what?

en: “Citizen Doctor,” said the first, with his former reluctance, “ask no more.
vi: − Citizen doctor, - the first person said, still in that reluctant tone, - please don't ask anymore.
tr: The man in front said reluctantly, "Citizen Doctor, don't ask any more questions.
es: "Citizen doctor," replied the first, "ask no more questions."

en: If the Republic demands sacrifices from you, without doubt you as a good patriot will be happy to make them.
vi: If the Republic demands that you sacrifice, you will surely be willing to sacrifice, if you are a good Citizen.
tr: If the Republic asks you to make a sacrifice, a good citizen fulfills it without hesitation and with pleasure.
es: "If the Republic demands sacrifices from you, you, as the good patriot that you are, will consider yourself happy to make them."

en: The Republic goes before all.
vi: The Republic is above all.
tr: The Republic comes before everything.
es: "Above all and before all, the Republic."

en: The People is supreme.
vi: The People are supreme.
tr: The people are noble.
es: "The People are sovereign."

en: Evrémonde, we are pressed.”
vi: Evrémonde, let's go immediately.
tr: Evremonde, our time is running out."
es: "Evrémonde, we are in a hurry."

en: “One word,” the Doctor entreated.
vi: − Just one word, - the doctor pleaded.
tr: "One minute," insisted the Doctor.
es: —One more word—objected the doctor.

en: “Will you tell me who denounced him?”
vi: - Please tell me who accused this person?
tr: "Can you tell me who reported him?"
es: —Do you want to tell me who reported him?

en: “It is against rule,” answered the first; “but you can ask Him of Saint Antoine here.”
vi: − − It's against the law to say, - the first person replied, - but you can ask the people in the Saint Antoine area.
tr: The man in front replied, "This is against the rules," he said, "but you can ask Citizen St. Antoine about it."
es: —I would be neglecting my duty...

en: The Doctor turned his eyes upon that man.
vi: The doctor turned to look at the person.
tr: The doctor turned his eyes towards the man.
es: Tomorrow you can ask Saint Anthony.

en: Who moved uneasily on his feet, rubbed his beard a little, and at length said:
vi: He fidgeted nervously, twirling his beard for a moment before saying: − Well!
tr: After the man fidgeted nervously and lightly stroked his beard, he said:
es: The doctor then directed a look at another of the men, who moved with a certain expression of discomfort, rubbed his beard, and said:

en: “Well!
vi: He fidgeted nervously, twirling his beard for a moment before saying: − Well!
tr: "Hey!
es: —Well!

en: Truly it is against rule.
vi: That is indeed against the law.
tr: This is really against the rules.
es: It is true that we cannot say it without failing in our duty; but I have no objection to stating that he has been accused... indeed of great crimes, by Citizen and Citizeness Defarge... and also, by another person.

en: But he is denounced—and gravely—by the Citizen and Citizeness Defarge.
vi: But this person has been accused... and heavily charged... by both Citizen Defarge, male and female.
tr: But –personally– He was denounced by Citizen Defarge and his wife.
es: It is true that we cannot say it without failing in our duty; but I have no objection to stating that he has been accused... indeed of great crimes, by Citizen and Citizeness Defarge... and also, by another person.

en: And by one other.”
vi: And by another person.
tr: There was another one."
es: —Who is this other person?

en: “What other?”
vi: − Who is it? −
tr: "Who is that?"
es: —Who is this other person?

en: “Do you ask, Citizen Doctor?”
vi: Are you still asking, Citizen Doctor? −
tr: "Do you really want to know this, Citizen Doctor?"
es: —Are you asking that, citizen doctor?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Then,” said he of Saint Antoine, with a strange look, “you will be answered to-morrow.
vi: − Then you will have your answer tomorrow, - the man from the Saint Antoine district said with a strange expression.
tr: With a strange expression on his face, the man from St. Antoine said, "Then you will learn the answer to this question tomorrow.
es: —You'll know tomorrow—replied the one from San Antonio with a strange intonation.

en: Now, I am dumb!”
tr: Now I am mute!"
es: —Now, I am mute!

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: For now, I will say no more!
tr: VIII
es: VIII.

en: A Hand at Cards
vi: 8. The card game
tr: Cards in Hand
es: AN ORIGINAL GAME

en: Happily unconscious of the new calamity at home, Miss Pross threaded her way along the narrow streets and crossed the river by the bridge of the Pont-Neuf, reckoning in her mind the number of indispensable purchases she had to make.
vi: Whether it was joy or disaster that had just occurred at home, Miss Pross weaved through the narrow streets and crossed the river via the Pont-Neuf bridge, calculating in her mind the essential items she needed to buy.
tr: Miss Pross, unaware of the new disaster at home, happily passed through the narrow streets and crossed the Pont-Neuf Bridge with a list of things she needed to get in her mind.
es: Immersed in the blissful ignorance of the new misfortune that had befallen the family, Miss Pross left behind a portion of narrow alleyways and crossed the river by the New Bridge, mentally reviewing the number of purchases she had to make.

en: mr Cruncher, with the basket, walked at her side.
vi: Cruncher walked beside her, carrying the basket.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was walking beside her with a basket in his hand.
es: Walking beside her was Lapa, carrying the basket.

en: They both looked to the right and to the left into most of the shops they passed, had a wary eye for all gregarious assemblages of people, and turned out of their road to avoid any very excited group of talkers.
vi: The two of them kept glancing left and right past the shops, their eyes wary of any gathering crowds, and avoiding any groups of people who were speaking excitedly.
tr: They looked to the right and left of the shops they passed, cautiously examined every kind of crowded group huddled together, and if they saw them talking heatedly, they changed their route.
es: Both of them, although seemingly only focused on examining the shops open to the right and left of the streets they traversed, were on the lookout for groups of patriots, especially if they were very numerous, and frequently changed their route to avoid encountering those who spoke with excessive animation.

en: It was a raw evening, and the misty river, blurred to the eye with blazing lights and to the ear with harsh noises, showed where the barges were stationed in which the smiths worked, making guns for the Army of the Republic.
vi: That evening was bitterly cold and the river was shrouded in mist, the dazzling lights and the deafening sounds indicating the positions of the barges that had been transformed into workshops where workers were making guns for the army of the Republic.
tr: It was a cold and damp evening, and the barges where blacksmiths working for the Republic Army were making weapons blurred their eyes with bright lights and made their ears ring with loud noises on the misty river.
es: It was a cold and damp afternoon. The points of light that dotted the gray layer covering the river indicated the places where barges converted into workshops by those manufacturing weapons for the Republic's army were anchored.

en: Woe to the man who played tricks with that Army, or got undeserved promotion in it!
vi: Woe to anyone who dares to mock that army, or whose value does not match their rank within it!
tr: The situation was dire for those playing tricks on the Army or those who were unjustly promoted here!
es: Woe to the mortal who dared to mock that army! Woe to the one who held a rank in that army that they did not deserve!

en: Better for him that his beard had never grown, for the National Razor shaved him close.
vi: That person had better not grow a beard because the National Razor will cut their throat.
tr: "The National Razor" would give them a deep shave, so it was better if their beards didn't grow.
es: They would have been better off if their beard had never grown, for the National Barber's Razor would shave it off as a blessing.

en: Having purchased a few small articles of grocery, and a measure of oil for the lamp, Miss Pross bethought herself of the wine they wanted.
vi: Having bought some miscellaneous food items and a bit of lamp oil, Miss Pross suddenly remembered she needed to buy wine.
tr: After buying a few small grocery items and some oil for the lamp, Miss Pross remembered that they wanted wine.
es: After buying a portion of food items and a quantity of oil for the lamp, Miss Pross thought about acquiring the wine she needed.

en: After peeping into several wine-shops, she stopped at the sign of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, not far from the National Palace, once (and twice) the Tuileries, where the aspect of things rather took her fancy.
vi: After looking into a few wine shops, she stopped in front of the sign "The Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity" not far from the National Palace - formerly the Tuileries Palace - which seemed to suit her taste.
tr: After glancing at a few wine shops, she stopped in front of a place near the National Palace, formerly the Tuileries, which had a sign that read "Good Republican of Antiquity Brutus"; its exterior had caught her interest.
es: She scorned a number of taverns and finally favored one, placed under the patronage of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, situated a short distance from the National Palace, formerly the Tuileries, an establishment quieter than any of its counterparts found up to that point, in which it was true that many red caps were seen, but they were less abundant than in the others.

en: It had a quieter look than any other place of the same description they had passed, and, though red with patriotic caps, was not so red as the rest.
vi: This shop is less noisy than the other similar shops they had passed by, and although there were patriotic red hats, they were not as bright red as in other places.
tr: It appeared calmer compared to similar places they had passed by, and although there were patriots with red hats inside, it wasn't as red as the others.
es: She scorned a number of taverns and finally favored one, placed under the patronage of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, situated a short distance from the National Palace, formerly the Tuileries, an establishment quieter than any of its counterparts found up to that point, in which it was true that many red caps were seen, but they were less abundant than in the others.

en: Sounding mr Cruncher, and finding him of her opinion, Miss Pross resorted to the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, attended by her cavalier.
vi: Upon asking Cruncher and seeing him agree, Miss Pross and her knight entered the shop Brutus de l’Antiquité.
tr: After checking with Mr. Cruncher and seeing that they were of the same mind, she entered the Good Republican Brutus's shop with her escort.
es: After consulting Lapa, and seeing that he was of the same opinion, Miss Pross entered the temple of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, accompanied by her gentleman.

en: Slightly observant of the smoky lights; of the people, pipe in mouth, playing with limp cards and yellow dominoes; of the one bare-breasted, bare-armed, soot-begrimed workman reading a journal aloud, and of the others listening to him; of the weapons worn, or laid aside to be resumed; of the two or three customers fallen forward asleep, who in the popular high-shouldered shaggy black spencer looked, in that attitude, like slumbering bears or dogs; the two outlandish customers approached the counter, and showed what they wanted.
vi: These two strangers went straight to the counter, signaling that they wanted to buy what they needed; paying no attention to the dim light; to the people with pipes in their mouths playing limp cards and yellowed dominoes; to a half-naked worker, covered in soot, reading a newspaper aloud while others listened; to the weapons worn on their bodies or placed beside them, ready for action; to the two or three customers dressed in the popular short black coats with high shoulders of the time, dozing off at the table like bears or dogs.
tr: The inside was a bit smoky; men playing with worn-out playing cards and domino tiles, with pipes in their mouths; a worker, covered in soot, with one chest and arm bare, reading a newspaper loudly, surrounded by people listening to him; two or three customers, resembling bears or dogs, dozing off, with their weapons either strapped on or set aside, lounging in their padded black coats; while these two foreign customers approached the counter and pointed out what they wanted.
es: Without paying much attention to the dim lights, to the men with pipes in their mouths playing with grimy cards or yellowed dominoes, to the laborer who, with his shirt sleeves rolled up to his shoulders and his chest bare, loudly read a newspaper to a group of people listening with their mouths open, to the weapons that filled the tables or hung from the drinkers' waists, nor to the three or four patrons who were sleeping off their drunkenness, sprawled face down on the floor, and who, more than men, looked like lying bears or mastiffs, the two buyers approached the counter and asked for what they needed.

en: As their wine was measuring out, a man parted from another man in a corner, and rose to depart.
vi: While the two were waiting for the wine to be measured, a customer in the corner bid farewell to his friend, stood up, and walked out, facing Ms. Pross.
tr: While the wines were being filled, a man in a corner stood up after saying goodbye to another man.
es: While the innkeeper measured the wine, a man, who was talking with another in a corner of the establishment, stood up and began to walk.

en: In going, he had to face Miss Pross.
vi: While the two were waiting for the wine to be measured, a customer in the corner bid farewell to his friend, stood up, and walked out, facing Ms. Pross.
