tr: As he was leaving, he came face to face with Miss Pross, who, upon seeing him, let out a scream and clapped her hands.
es: To get out to the street, he had to pass by Miss Pross, which is nothing unusual, but what was unusual was that, as soon as he bumped into her, a piercing scream tore through the air followed by a semi-fainting of the lady.

en: No sooner did he face her, than Miss Pross uttered a scream, and clapped her hands.
vi: As soon as she saw him, Ms. Pross clapped her hands and screamed.
tr: As he was leaving, he came face to face with Miss Pross, who, upon seeing him, let out a scream and clapped her hands.
es: To get out to the street, he had to pass by Miss Pross, which is nothing unusual, but what was unusual was that, as soon as he bumped into her, a piercing scream tore through the air followed by a semi-fainting of the lady.

en: In a moment, the whole company were on their feet.
vi: Immediately, everyone in the café stood up abruptly.
tr: Suddenly, everyone jumped to their feet.
es: All the people in the tavern stood up.

en: That somebody was assassinated by somebody vindicating a difference of opinion was the likeliest occurrence.
vi: Everyone thought that someone had killed someone else due to a disagreement, as often seen.
tr: It was a common occurrence for someone to be killed as a result of a disagreement.
es: It was so common to see people being killed outright for such a justified reason as defending any opinion, that everyone looked to see who was the mortal falling lifeless to the ground, but to their general astonishment, the only thing they saw was a couple, a man and a woman, staring at each other with extraordinary intensity, and the man seemed French, and a red republican, and the woman was undoubtedly English.

en: Everybody looked to see somebody fall, but only saw a man and a woman standing staring at each other; the man with all the outward aspect of a Frenchman and a thorough Republican; the woman, evidently English.
vi: Everyone looked to see if anyone had fallen, but they only saw a man and a woman staring at each other intently; the man appeared to be completely French while the woman was clearly English.
tr: Everyone looked to see who had fallen, but they only saw a man and a woman standing and looking at each other; the man appeared to be a Frenchman and a staunch Republican, while the woman was evidently English.
es: It was so common to see people being killed outright for such a justified reason as defending any opinion, that everyone looked to see who was the mortal falling lifeless to the ground, but to their general astonishment, the only thing they saw was a couple, a man and a woman, staring at each other with extraordinary intensity, and the man seemed French, and a red republican, and the woman was undoubtedly English.

vi: The disappointing anticlimax caused every drinker in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern to loudly argue and chatter, but even if Miss Pross and her protector were listening, it was like water off a duck's back, they understood nothing.
tr: Everyone looked to see who had fallen, but they only saw a man and a woman standing and looking at each other; the man appeared to be a Frenchman and a staunch Republican, while the woman was evidently English.
es: The picturesque phrases with which the good disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity expressed their disillusionment sounded in the ears of Miss Pross and her companion as if they had been spoken in Hebrew or Chaldean.

en: Original
vi: The disappointing anticlimax caused every drinker in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern to loudly argue and chatter, but even if Miss Pross and her protector were listening, it was like water off a duck's back, they understood nothing.
tr: After this disappointment, the words spoken loudly and fluently by the disciples of the Ancient Good Republican Brutus, no matter how much they listened, were no different from Hebrew or Chaldean for Miss Pross and her protector.
es: The picturesque phrases with which the good disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity expressed their disillusionment sounded in the ears of Miss Pross and her companion as if they had been spoken in Hebrew or Chaldean.

en: What was said in this disappointing anti-climax, by the disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, except that it was something very voluble and loud, would have been as so much Hebrew or Chaldean to Miss Pross and her protector, though they had been all ears.
vi: The disappointing anticlimax caused every drinker in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern to loudly argue and chatter, but even if Miss Pross and her protector were listening, it was like water off a duck's back, they understood nothing.
tr: After this disappointment, the words spoken loudly and fluently by the disciples of the Ancient Good Republican Brutus, no matter how much they listened, were no different from Hebrew or Chaldean for Miss Pross and her protector.
es: The picturesque phrases with which the good disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity expressed their disillusionment sounded in the ears of Miss Pross and her companion as if they had been spoken in Hebrew or Chaldean.

en: But, they had no ears for anything in their surprise.
vi: But in their astonishment, the two heard nothing at all.
tr: But they were in no state to listen to anyone out of astonishment anyway.
es: They only understood that they were shouted, as their surprise allowed them no more.

en: For, it must be recorded, that not only was Miss Pross lost in amazement and agitation, but, mr Cruncher—though it seemed on his own separate and individual account—was in a state of the greatest wonder.
vi: Because it must be said, not only was Miss Pross stunned and emotional, but Cruncher was also extremely surprised - for his own personal reasons.
tr: For Miss Pross had become blind to her surroundings due to the amazement and worry she had fallen into, and Mr. Cruncher – in his own way and measures – was engulfed in tremendous curiosity.
es: We speak in the plural because, if Miss Pross was surprised, Jeremiah Lapa was on the verge of falling to the ground under the violent blow of his stupefaction.

en: “What is the matter?” said the man who had caused Miss Pross to scream; speaking in a vexed, abrupt voice (though in a low tone), and in English.
vi: − What happened? - The person who made Miss Pross scream lowered their voice and spoke hastily and irritably in English.
tr: The man who caused Miss Pross to scream asked in a nervous and rude manner (but in a low voice) and in English, "What happened?"
es: —What is it?—asked the man who was the cause of Miss Pross's scream. The two words had been spoken in English, with a brusque and threatening accent and a very low tone of voice.

en: “Oh, Solomon, dear Solomon!” cried Miss Pross, clapping her hands again.
vi: − Oh Solomon, my dear Solomon! - Miss Pross exclaimed while clapping her hands.
tr: Miss Pross clapped her hands again, shouting, "Oh Solomon, dear Solomon!"
es: —Oh Solomon... Dear Solomon! —exclaimed Miss Pross, clasping her hands.

en: “After not setting eyes upon you or hearing of you for so long a time, do I find you here!”
vi: It's been so many years since you disappeared, and now I see you here!
tr: "I haven't seen your face or heard your voice for so long, I can't believe you're standing before me now!"
es: —At last I find you, after so many years of absence, after so many years without news of you!

en: “Don’t call me Solomon.
vi: − Don't call me Solomon.
tr: Adam said, "Don't call me Solomon.
es: —Don't call me Solomon.

en: Do you want to be the death of me?” asked the man, in a furtive, frightened way.
vi: Do you want me to die or what? - The man said, looking stealthy and fearful. − Oh, my dear, my dear!
tr: Do you want me to die?" he asked in a voice full of fear and evasion.
es: Are you seeking my death, wretched woman?—asked the man, casting frightened glances around.

en: “Brother, brother!” cried Miss Pross, bursting into tears.
vi: - Miss Pross burst into tears.
tr: "My brother, my brother!" Miss Pross cried out, bursting into tears.
es: —Brother... my brother!

en: “Have I ever been so hard with you that you ask me such a cruel question?”
vi: - Have I ever treated you badly that you ask me such a cruel question? −
tr: "Have I ever done you any harm that you ask me such a cruel question?"
es: —exclaimed Miss Pross, in a flood of tears—Have I behaved so badly towards you that you ask me such a cruel question?

en: “Then hold your meddlesome tongue,” said Solomon, “and come out, if you want to speak to me.
vi: Then stop wagging your tongue, - Solomon said. - Go outside if you want to talk to me.
tr: "Then hold that busybody tongue of yours now," said Solomon, "if you want to talk to me, come outside.
es: —Well, put that devilish tongue of yours in your pocket! —grumbled Salomón. —If you want to tell me something, let's go outside.

en: Pay for your wine, and come out.
vi: Pay for your drink, then go outside.
tr: Pay for your wine and come outside.
es: Pay for the wine and let's go...

en: Who’s this man?”
vi: Who is this man?
tr: Who is this man?"
es: Who is that man?

en: Miss Pross, shaking her loving and dejected head at her by no means affectionate brother, said through her tears, “mr Cruncher.”
vi: Miss Pross shook her head in despair at her brother's indifference to familial bonds and spoke through her tears: − Mr. Cruncher.
tr: Miss Pross, shaking her loving and sorrowful head at her not-at-all affectionate brother, said tearfully, "Mr. Cruncher."
es: —It is Mr. Lapa—answered Miss Pross with dismay.

en: “Let him come out too,” said Solomon.
vi: − Tell him to go outside immediately, - Solomon replied. -
tr: Solomon said, "Let him come."
es: —Well, let him come out too...

en: “Does he think me a ghost?”
vi: Does he think I'm a ghost or something?
tr: "Why is he looking at me as if I'm a ghost?""
es: But what is that? Does that person take me for a ghost?

en: Apparently, mr Cruncher did, to judge from his looks.
vi: Just looking at Cruncher's face, it seemed so.
tr: Judging by his looks, Mr. Cruncher seemed to have truly mistaken him for a ghost.
es: The question was very much in place, for Lapa was indeed looking at him as one looks at a specter.

en: He said not a word, however, and Miss Pross, exploring the depths of her reticule through her tears with great difficulty paid for her wine.
vi: But Cruncher didn't say a word, and Miss Pross, trying to hold back her tears, rummaged through her bag to pay for the drink.
tr: Not a single word came out of his mouth, but Miss Pross, in tears, barely managed to rummage through the bottom of her bag to pay for the wine.
es: However, he did not part his lips, and Miss Pross, shedding tears, paid for the wine.

en: As she did so, Solomon turned to the followers of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, and offered a few words of explanation in the French language, which caused them all to relapse into their former places and pursuits.
vi: Meanwhile, Solomon turned to the other patrons in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern and offered a few explanations in French, causing everyone to return to their previous positions and concerns.
tr: After Miss Pross paid the money, Solomon turned to the patrons of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity and made an announcement in French, after which everyone sat down and returned to their occupations.
es: Meanwhile, Solomon addressed the disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity and gave them, in French, some explanations that were enough for all of them to return to their respective posts.

en: “Now,” said Solomon, stopping at the dark street corner, “what do you want?”
vi: − Alright, - Solomon spoke as he stopped at a dark corner, - what do you want now? −
tr: Solomon, "Tell me," he said, standing on a dark street corner, "what do you want?"
es: —Let's see—said Solomon, once he reached a dark corner of the street—What is it that you want from me?

en: “How dreadfully unkind in a brother nothing has ever turned my love away from!” cried Miss Pross, “to give me such a greeting, and show me no affection.”
vi: You love me, but you treat me so terribly! - Sister Pross cried. - No greeting, no affection.
tr: Miss Pross, still teary-eyed, said, "Is this how one greets a sister who loves them so much, speaking to her so rudely, so badly?"
es: —It is horrifying to meet a beloved brother who shows not the slightest sign of affection to the sister who was always tender and loving towards him!

en: “There.
vi: − There.
tr: "Alright, alright!"
es: —Bah!

en: Confound it!
vi: Damn it!
tr: "Alright, alright!"
es: Nonsense!

en: There,” said Solomon, making a dab at Miss Pross’s lips with his own.
vi: There, - Solomon said as he quickly brushed his lips against Miss Pross's lips. -
tr: "Here you go," said Solomon and planted a small kiss on his sister's lips.
es: —exclaimed Solomon, brushing Miss Pross's forehead with his lips—Are you happy now?

en: “Now are you content?”
vi: Are you satisfied now?
tr: "Are you happy now?"
es: —exclaimed Solomon, brushing Miss Pross's forehead with his lips—Are you happy now?

en: Miss Pross only shook her head and wept in silence.
vi: Miss Pross just shook her head and cried silently.
tr: Miss Pross silently cried, only nodding her head.
es: Miss Pross shook her head and burst into tears again.

en: “If you expect me to be surprised,” said her brother Solomon, “I am not surprised; I knew you were here; I know of most people who are here.
vi: − If you think I'm surprised, I'm not surprised, - the younger brother said. - I know you're here; I know most people are here.
tr: "If you expect me to be surprised," said his brother Solomon, "I am not surprised at all; I knew you were here, I know most of the people here.
es: —If you think that you have surprised me, you are completely mistaken; I was not surprised to find you. I knew you were in Paris, so it's good for you to know that there are very few people in Paris who live without me knowing about it.

en: If you really don’t want to endanger my existence—which I half believe you do—go your ways as soon as possible, and let me go mine.
vi: If you truly do not want my life to be in danger, although you might actually want that, then you go your way, and I'll go mine, the sooner the better.
tr: If you don't want to put my life in danger – which I think is what you're doing – you should go your own way as soon as possible, and I'll go mine.
es: If you don't want to put my existence in grave danger... I'm tempted to believe that this is your intention... continue on your way as soon as possible, and let me continue on mine.

en: I am busy.
vi: I am busy.
tr: I have a lot of work to do.
es: I have many occupations... I am a public official.

en: I am an official.”
vi: I am now an official.
tr: I am on duty."
es: I have many occupations... I am a public official.

en: “My English brother Solomon,” mourned Miss Pross, casting up her tear-fraught eyes, “that had the makings in him of one of the best and greatest of men in his native country, an official among foreigners, and such foreigners!
vi: − My younger brother Solomon from England, - Sister Pross lamented while raising her tearful eyes to the sky, - a person who had the qualities to become someone important in his homeland, now works as an official for foreigners, and such foreigners at that!
tr: Miss Pross lifted her tearful eyes and lamented, "My English brother Solomon, who could have been one of the best and foremost men of his own country, has become an officer serving foreigners, and such foreigners at that!
es: —My brother Solomon, English by birth and soul, my brother Solomon, who in his homeland could have been one of the greatest men, a public official in a country that is not his own, depending on men who are not English... and what men, Good heavens!

en: I would almost sooner have seen the dear boy lying in his—”
vi: I would rather see my beloved younger brother lying dead in... − See that! -
tr: To see you like this..."
es: I would have preferred to find you dead in his...!

en: “I said so!” cried her brother, interrupting.
vi: The younger brother shouted, interrupting.
tr: His brother interrupted him, shouting, "I know, I know!"
es: —I believe it!... I supposed it!...

en: “I knew it.
vi: - I knew it.
tr: "It's obvious.
es: I knew it for sure! —exclaimed her brother, interrupting her.—

en: You want to be the death of me.
vi: You just want me to die.
tr: You'd prefer me dead.
es: What you want is my death.

en: I shall be rendered Suspected, by my own sister.
vi: My own sister has made me a suspect.
tr: I'll be suspected because of my own brother.
es: My tender, my loving sister will make them list me among the suspects...

en: Just as I am getting on!”
vi: Right when I am advancing!
tr: And just when I had everything under control!"
es: That is to say; she is already doing it.

en: “The gracious and merciful Heavens forbid!” cried Miss Pross.
vi: − Oh my God! - Sister Pross exclaimed.
tr: "May the Almighty God undo it if He has written it!" cried Miss Pross.
es: —God forbid!

en: “Far rather would I never see you again, dear Solomon, though I have ever loved you truly, and ever shall.
vi: - I'd rather never see you again, Solomon, even though I always love you and will always love you.
tr: "Dear Solomon, even though I love you with all my heart, it is better that I never see you again than to be the cause of your death.
es: —cried Miss Pross.—I have loved you much, Solomon, I love you much; but I would have preferred never to see you again, than to find you as I find you.

en: Say but one affectionate word to me, and tell me there is nothing angry or estranged between us, and I will detain you no longer.”
vi: Just say one kind word to me, and say that there is no anger or coldness between us, and I will not stop you anymore.
tr: But tell me one nice thing so that I know there is no resentment or anger between us! Then I will get out of your way."
es: Tell me a word of affection, tell me that you do not hate me, that hatred does not separate us, and I will leave without detaining you a second longer.

en: Good Miss Pross!
vi: Poor Miss Pross!
tr: Kind-hearted Miss Pross!
es: Tell me a word of affection, tell me that you do not hate me, that hatred does not separate us, and I will leave without detaining you a second longer.

en: As if the estrangement between them had come of any culpability of hers.
vi: As if the coldness between the siblings was her fault.
tr: She acted as if she were the reason for the coldness between them.
es: Solomon was uttering the requested word of affection, providing evidence of a condescension that surely would not have existed had their respective positions been reversed, when unexpectedly Jeremiah Lapa interjected into the conversation, placing a paw on the affectionate brother's shoulder and saying in a hoarse voice:

en: As if mr Lorry had not known it for a fact, years ago, in the quiet corner in Soho, that this precious brother had spent her money and left her!
vi: As if Mr. Lorry hadn't known the truth, that many years ago, in a quiet corner of Soho, this precious brother had spent all her money and then disappeared!
tr: As if Mr. Lorry didn't know the fact that years ago this dear brother had squandered all of Miss Pross's money and fled from the quiet corner in Soho!
es: Solomon was uttering the requested word of affection, providing evidence of a condescension that surely would not have existed had their respective positions been reversed, when unexpectedly Jeremiah Lapa interjected into the conversation, placing a paw on the affectionate brother's shoulder and saying in a hoarse voice:

en: He was saying the affectionate word, however, with a far more grudging condescension and patronage than he could have shown if their relative merits and positions had been reversed (which is invariably the case, all the world over), when mr Cruncher, touching him on the shoulder, hoarsely and unexpectedly interposed with the following singular question:
vi: Solomon was speaking some sentimental words, but with a sharp, condescending tone, as if the value and relative positions between the siblings had reversed (a common occurrence in this world), when Cruncher patted him on the shoulder and, in a hoarse voice, interrupted with an unexpected question: − Hey!
tr: Finally, Solomon uttered a few words of affection, but he did so with a spiteful condescension that was excessive, even though familial values and roles had been reversed (yet this was the case everywhere in the world), and at that moment, Mr. Cruncher, unexpectedly intervening, touched Solomon's shoulder and said to him in a gruff voice;
es: Solomon was uttering the requested word of affection, providing evidence of a condescension that surely would not have existed had their respective positions been reversed, when unexpectedly Jeremiah Lapa interjected into the conversation, placing a paw on the affectionate brother's shoulder and saying in a hoarse voice:

en: “I say!
vi: Solomon was speaking some sentimental words, but with a sharp, condescending tone, as if the value and relative positions between the siblings had reversed (a common occurrence in this world), when Cruncher patted him on the shoulder and, in a hoarse voice, interrupted with an unexpected question: − Hey!
tr: "Hey, can I ask you something?
es: —It seems to me that I will also be allowed to ask a question.

en: Might I ask the favour?
vi: May I ask you something?
tr: "Hey, can I ask you something?
es: —It seems to me that I will also be allowed to ask a question.

en: As to whether your name is John Solomon, or Solomon John?”
vi: Is your name John Solomon, or Solomon John?
tr: Is your name John Solomon or Solomon John?"
es: Would you tell me if your name is Juan Salomón or Salomón Juan?

en: The official turned towards him with sudden distrust.
vi: The man turned to look at Cruncher with sudden suspicion.
tr: The officer turned to him with sudden suspicion.
es: The public official, in response, turned towards the person breaking their silence to ask a question that unsettled him, and stood staring at him intently with visible suspicion.

en: He had not previously uttered a word.
vi: Cruncher hadn't uttered a word until now.
tr: Not a single word had come out of his mouth before.
es: —I am waiting—replied Lapa.—Have you suddenly become mute?

en: “Come!” said mr Cruncher.
vi: − Hey!
tr: "Come on!" said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —I am waiting—replied Lapa.—Have you suddenly become mute?

en: “Speak out, you know.”
vi: Speak clearly now, - Cruncher continued.
tr: "Speak up, have you lost your tongue?"
es: Juan Salomón or Salomón Juan?

en: (Which, by the way, was more than he could do himself.)
vi: With that hoarse voice, even Cruncher couldn't speak clearly.
tr: (He couldn't do more on his own anyway.)
es: Which one is it?

en: “John Solomon, or Solomon John?
vi: – Are you John Solomon, or Solomon John?
tr: "Is it John Solomon or Solomon John?
es: The young lady calls you Salomón, and it is to be assumed that she knows your name well, since she is your sister, as I see.

en: She calls you Solomon, and she must know, being your sister.
vi: This lady calls you Solomon, so she must know, she's your sister after all.
tr: He calls you Solomon and since he is your brother, he must know it correctly.
es: The young lady calls you Salomón, and it is to be assumed that she knows your name well, since she is your sister, as I see.

en: And I know you’re John, you know.
vi: And I know you as John.
tr: But I know your name as John.
es: But the fact is that I know you as Juan.

en: Which of the two goes first?
vi: Which one is the surname, which one is the first name?
tr: Which of these two names comes first now?
es: Which of the two names is the real one?

en: And regarding that name of Pross, likewise.
vi: And then there's the surname Pross.
tr: The same goes for the name Pross.
es: I say the same about the last name.

en: That warn’t your name over the water.”
vi: That's not your surname in England.
tr: You weren't using this name on the other side, were you?"
es: In England, you were not called Pross.

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: − What do you mean? −
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: —But what are you saying?

en: “Well, I don’t know all I mean, for I can’t call to mind what your name was, over the water.”
vi: Oh, I don't know exactly either, because I can't remember your last name from back then.
tr: "Honestly, I don't know what I mean either, because I can't remember which name you used in England.""
es: —I don't even know it very well myself, for I confess that I don't remember the last name you had on the opposite shore of the Canal.

en: “No?”
vi: − No? − No. But I swear it's a surname with two syllables.
tr: "Don't you really remember?"
es: —Have you forgotten?

en: “No.
vi: − No? − No. But I swear it's a surname with two syllables.
tr: "I don't remember.
es: —Have you forgotten?

en: But I’ll swear it was a name of two syllables.”
vi: − No? − No. But I swear it's a surname with two syllables.
tr: But I'm sure it was a two-syllable name."
es: —Yes; but I would swear it was a two-syllable surname.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? − Really.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Really!

en: “Yes.
vi: And the name has only one syllable.
tr: "It is so.
es: —Really.

en: T’other one’s was one syllable.
vi: And the name has only one syllable.
tr: The other was a single syllable.
es: Pross has only one syllable; the other had two...

en: I know you.
vi: I know you.
tr: I know you.
es: In the name of the Father of Lies, who is undoubtedly your father, could you tell me what your name was when you practiced the honorable profession of informer at the Old Bailey?

en: You was a spy—witness at the Bailey.
vi: Back then, you were a spy... a witness at the Bailey Court.
tr: You are the spy witness in Bailey.
es: In the name of the Father of Lies, who is undoubtedly your father, could you tell me what your name was when you practiced the honorable profession of informer at the Old Bailey?

en: What, in the name of the Father of Lies, own father to yourself, was you called at that time?”
vi: What was your last name back then, tell me?
tr: In the name of the god of liars, who is probably your father, what was your name back then?"
es: In the name of the Father of Lies, who is undoubtedly your father, could you tell me what your name was when you practiced the honorable profession of informer at the Old Bailey?

en: “Barsad,” said another voice, striking in.
vi: − Barsad, - another voice interjected. − That's right!
tr: "Barsad," someone interrupted.
es: —Barsad!

en: “That’s the name for a thousand pound!” cried Jerry.
vi: I bet a thousand pounds! - Jerry shouted.
tr: "This is the name of the thousand-pound man!" shouted Jerry.
es: —answered another voice, joining the conversation.

en: The speaker who struck in, was Sydney Carton.
vi: The person who just spoke was Sydney Carton.
tr: The man who joined the conversation was Sydney Carton.
es: The one who had just spoken was our old friend Sydney Carton.

en: He had his hands behind him under the skirts of his riding-coat, and he stood at mr Cruncher’s elbow as negligently as he might have stood at the Old Bailey itself.
vi: He was standing next to Cruncher, with his hands hidden behind his back under the cloak of his traveling coat, looking as nonchalant as when he stood at the Old Bailey Criminal Court.
tr: He stood with his hands clasped behind his rider's jacket, right next to Mr. Cruncher's elbow, with an indifferent attitude as if he were in the Old Bailey court.
es: With both hands placed behind his back under the tails of his coat, he had positioned himself next to Lapa, affecting the same nonchalance with which he used to attend the sessions at the Old Bailey.

en: “Don’t be alarmed, my dear Miss Pross.
vi: − Don't panic, dear Miss Pross.
tr: "Don't be afraid, dear Miss Pross.
es: —Do not be alarmed, Miss Pross—he replied.—

en: I arrived at mr Lorry’s, to his surprise, yesterday evening; we agreed that I would not present myself elsewhere until all was well, or unless I could be useful; I present myself here, to beg a little talk with your brother.
vi: I went to see Mr. Lorry last night, much to his surprise; we agreed that I would not let anyone else know of my presence unless I was needed; I am here to have a little talk with your younger sister.
tr: I went to see Mr. Lorry last evening, he was very surprised; we decided that it would be best for me to stay out of sight until everything is settled or until I can be of some help; I came here to have a short conversation with your brother.
es: Yesterday afternoon I presented myself at Mr. Lorry's residence, much to the surprise of this gentleman, who was far from expecting my visit. We both agreed that I would not be seen anywhere until the matter was definitively and satisfactorily resolved, or until my presence was necessary.

en: I wish you had a better employed brother than mr Barsad.
vi: I hope your sister has a better job than Mr. Barsad had before, and for your sake, I also hope Mr. Barsad is not a prisoner.
tr: I wish your brother had a better job than Mr. Barsad.
es: Adhering to the agreement, I have come here because it is essential that I exchange a few words with your brother.

en: I wish for your sake mr Barsad was not a Sheep of the Prisons.”
vi: I hope your sister has a better job than Mr. Barsad had before, and for your sake, I also hope Mr. Barsad is not a prisoner.
tr: I felt sorry on your behalf that your brother is a jailbird."
es: I very much regret that you are the sister of such an untrustworthy individual; I very much regret that you have for a brother a hangman's blackbird.

en: Sheep was a cant word of the time for a spy, under the gaolers.
vi: "Sheep" was the slang used by the prison guards at that time to refer to spies.
tr: Kuzu, in those times, was a slang term used by guards for spies.
es: This was the name by which spies were usually referred to.

en: The spy, who was pale, turned paler, and asked him how he dared—
vi: The spy's face, already pale, turned even paler as he asked Carton how he dared...
tr: The pale-faced spy's face turned even paler, and he asked with what courage he spoke to him like that.
es: —How dare you—asked the spy, pale as a corpse—to tell me...?

en: “I’ll tell you,” said Sydney.
vi: − I will let you know, - said Sydney.
tr: "I will tell you," said Sydney.
es: —I will explain myself, so that you see I am not speaking nonsense—replied Carton. —

en: “I lighted on you, mr Barsad, coming out of the prison of the Conciergerie while I was contemplating the walls, an hour or more ago.
vi: - Mr. Barsad, I saw you coming out of the Conciergerie prison while I was looking at those walls more than an hour ago.
tr: "Mr. Barsad, about an hour ago, while I was lost in thought by the walls of the Conciergerie Prison, I saw you coming out of there.
es: Half an hour ago, I was contemplating the walls of the Conciergerie when I saw you coming out of its doors.

en: You have a face to be remembered, and I remember faces well.
vi: You have a memorable face and I am good at remembering faces.
tr: You have an unforgettable face, and I do not forget a face I have seen.
es: Among other qualities, some good, some bad, I have the ability to remember faces well, and you can count that yours is one that is hard to forget.

en: Made curious by seeing you in that connection, and having a reason, to which you are no stranger, for associating you with the misfortunes of a friend now very unfortunate, I walked in your direction.
vi: Curious to see you there, and not unfamiliar with you, I had reason to associate you with the misfortune of my currently very unfortunate friend, so I followed you.
tr: I was indeed surprised to see you there, and as you know, I thought you might have something to do with the misfortunes that have befallen our extremely unfortunate friend, so I followed you.
es: I was surprised to see you in that place, and since, on the other hand, I have my reasons to associate your person with the misfortunes of a friend, who is now more unfortunate than ever, the idea occurred to me to follow you.

en: I walked into the wine-shop here, close after you, and sat near you.
vi: I followed you closely straight into this tavern, sitting next to you.
tr: I entered this wine shop right behind you and sat next to you.
es: Trailing closely behind you, I entered the tavern and sat next to you.

en: I had no difficulty in deducing from your unreserved conversation, and the rumour openly going about among your admirers, the nature of your calling.
vi: From your loose words and the public rumors of your admirers there, it was not difficult for me to deduce the nature of your work.
tr: It was not at all difficult to understand what kind of work you do from your frank conversations and the rumors circulating among your admirers.
es: From your conversation, and from the murmurs of admiration you elicited from your listeners, it was not difficult for me to infer what your profession is.

en: And gradually, what I had done at random, seemed to shape itself into a purpose, mr Barsad.”
vi: And gradually my impulsive act of following you also had a specific purpose, Mr. Barsad. − What is the purpose? -
tr: Then, what I started by chance turned into a specific purpose, Mr. Barsad."
es: What I initially did by chance gradually became a determined objective, Mr. Barsad.

en: “What purpose?” the spy asked.
vi: The spy asked.
tr: "What is the purpose?" asked the spy.
es: —And that objective?...—asked the spy.

en: “It would be troublesome, and might be dangerous, to explain in the street.
vi: − It would be troublesome and possibly dangerous to explain on the street.
tr: "It wouldn't be appropriate to explain this in the middle of the street; it could be dangerous.
es: —It would be bothersome, and even dangerous, to explain it on the street.

en: Could you favour me, in confidence, with some minutes of your company—at the office of Tellson’s Bank, for instance?”
vi: Please, could you allow a private conversation for a few minutes... in the office of Tellson's Bank, for instance?
tr: For instance, could we talk for a few minutes, privately, at Tellson's Bank?"
es: Would you be so kind as to accompany me for a few minutes... to Tellson's Bank, for example?

en: “Under a threat?”
vi: − Threatening, huh? −
tr: "Is this a threat?"
es: —Under threat?

en: “Oh!
vi: Oh!
tr: "Ah!
es: —Bah!

en: Did I say that?”
vi: Did I say anything? −
tr: Did I ever say such a thing?"
es: Did I talk about threats?

en: “Then, why should I go there?”
vi: Then why should I go there?
tr: "Then why should I go?""
es: —So, why on earth would I go there?

en: “Really, mr Barsad, I can’t say, if you can’t.”
vi: − Honestly, Mr. Barsad, I can't explain the reason if you don't go there.
tr: "Honestly, Mr. Barsad, I cannot say that.""
es: —Frankly, Mr. Barsad; I can't say.

en: “Do you mean that you won’t say, sir?” the spy irresolutely asked.
vi: "So you mean you won't talk, right?" - The spy hesitated.
tr: "So, are you not going to tell me even then, sir?" the spy asked hesitantly.
es: —Can't you, or won't you, sir?—asked the spy with a certain hesitation.

en: “You apprehend me very clearly, mr Barsad.
vi: − You understand me very well, Mr. Barsad.
tr: "You have understood me very well, Mr. Barsad.
es: —You interpret me wonderfully well; I do not want to.

en: I won’t.”
vi: I won't say anything.
tr: Yes, I will not tell you!"
es: —You interpret me wonderfully well; I do not want to.

en: Carton’s negligent recklessness of manner came powerfully in aid of his quickness and skill, in such a business as he had in his secret mind, and with such a man as he had to do with.
vi: Carton's indifferent and nonchalant attitude greatly aided his quick thinking and cleverness with the plan he had in mind and with the person he needed to deal with.
tr: In contrast to the man's irritability and resourcefulness, Carton's indifferent and reckless demeanor was sufficient both for what he had in mind and to deal with this man.
es: The tone of glacial indifference with which Carton spoke was a very powerful auxiliary to his prodigious skill.

en: His practised eye saw it, and made the most of it.
vi: His experienced eye recognized this and he took full advantage of it.
tr: His experienced eyes had seen this situation and acknowledged it.
es: His lynx-like vision noticed it from the first moment, and it is said that he took full advantage of it.

en: “Now, I told you so,” said the spy, casting a reproachful look at his sister; “if any trouble comes of this, it’s your doing.”
vi: − Hey, I already told you, - the spy directed a reproachful look towards the sister, - if there's any trouble with this matter, it's all your fault.
tr: Throwing a reproachful look at his sister, the spy said, "I'm telling you, if anything bad happens to me, it's your fault.""
es: —Remember what I tell you and never forget it! —exclaimed Barsad, directing a furious look of reproach at his sister. —It will be your doing if something bad happens to me.

en: “Come, come, mr Barsad!” exclaimed Sydney.
vi: − Oh, come on, Mr. Barsad! - Sydney exclaimed. -
tr: "Come, come Mr. Barsad!" shouted Sydney.
es: "Come on, come on, Mr. Barsad!" said Carton.

en: “Don’t be ungrateful.
vi: Don't be ungrateful.
tr: "Don't be ungrateful.
es: "Don't be ungrateful."

en: But for my great respect for your sister, I might not have led up so pleasantly to a little proposal that I wish to make for our mutual satisfaction.
vi: If it weren't for my utmost respect for your sister, I would have comfortably made the small proposal that I want both sides to be satisfied with.
tr: If I didn't have so much respect for your sister, I wouldn't be able to talk so comfortably about my little proposal, which I think would satisfy both of us.
es: "Be thankful for the respect your sister inspires in me and the kindness with which I am making you a proposition that should leave us all satisfied."

en: Do you go with me to the Bank?”
vi: Will you go with me to the bank?
tr: Are you coming to the bank with me now?"
es: "Will you accompany me to the Bank?" —Yes; I will accompany you.

en: “I’ll hear what you have got to say.
vi: − I will listen to what you need to say.
tr: "I was curious about what you wanted to say.
es: I am ready to hear what you wish to tell me.

en: Yes, I’ll go with you.”
vi: Alright, I will go with you.
tr: Yes, I am coming with you."
es: —First of all, we will escort your sister to the corner of the house where she lives.

en: “I propose that we first conduct your sister safely to the corner of her own street.
vi: − I suggest that first we safely take your sister back to the corner of her street.
tr: "First of all, I suggest taking your sister safely to the corner of her own street.
es: —First of all, we will escort your sister to the corner of the house where she lives.

en: Let me take your arm, Miss Pross.
vi: Let me take your arm, Miss Pross.
tr: Take my arm, Miss Pross.
es: Please accept my arm, Miss Pross.

en: This is not a good city, at this time, for you to be out in, unprotected; and as your escort knows mr Barsad, I will invite him to mr Lorry’s with us.
vi: This city is not safe, and at this hour, letting you walk outside without protection; the person accompanying you knows Mr. Barsad, so I invite him to come with us to Mr. Lorry's place, ready?
tr: It is not good for you to be outside unprotected at this time, in this city; moreover, since your companion knows Mr. Barsad, I also invite him to join Mr. Lorry.
es: Given the circumstances the city is going through, you should not go alone and unprotected, and since the man accompanying you knows Mr. Barsad, I take the liberty of inviting him to come with us to Mr. Lorry's residence.

en: Are we ready?
vi: Let's go!
tr: Is everyone ready?
es: Are we ready? Yes?

en: Come then!”
vi: Let's go!
tr: Then let's go!"
es: Then let's go.

en: Miss Pross recalled soon afterwards, and to the end of her life remembered, that as she pressed her hands on Sydney’s arm and looked up in his face, imploring him to do no hurt to Solomon, there was a braced purpose in the arm and a kind of inspiration in the eyes, which not only contradicted his light manner, but changed and raised the man.
vi: Afterwards, Miss Pross would remember and remember for the rest of her life that, when she held Sydney's arm and looked up at his face, pleading with him not to harm Solomon, what she felt was the resolute strength in his arm and the fervor in his eyes, something not only contrary to his usual indifferent demeanor but also adding to his admirable qualities.
tr: When Miss Pross, holding onto Sydney's arm and looking at his face, pleaded with him not to harm Solomon, she would remember very shortly and even for the rest of her life, the determined strength in his arm and the inspiration in his eyes that not only contradicted his indifferent demeanor but also transformed and elevated him.
es: Later, Miss Pross remembered, and never forgot in her life, that when she clung to Carton's arm and looked into his face to make a silent but eloquent plea on behalf of her brother, she noticed in the strength of his arm and in the expression of his eyes something that not only contradicted Carton's lightness of tone and manner, but also transformed and elevated the man.

en: She was too much occupied then with fears for the brother who so little deserved her affection, and with Sydney’s friendly reassurances, adequately to heed what she observed.
vi: But at that moment, Miss Pross was too worried about her brother, who was unworthy of her affection, combined with Sydney's sincere reassurances, so she did not pay much attention to that feeling.
tr: Miss Pross was very afraid for her brother, who was not at all deserving of her love, and it could not be said that she heeded Sydney's friendly advice.
es: If at the moment it did not catch her attention, it was because she was too preoccupied with the fears inspired by the fate of a brother so undeserving of her affection to make observations.

en: They left her at the corner of the street, and Carton led the way to mr Lorry’s, which was within a few minutes’ walk.
vi: They left Miss Pross at the corner of her street and then Carton led the way to Mr. Lorry's place, a few minutes' walk away.
tr: They left Miss Pross at the corner of her street, and Carton headed towards Mr. Lorry's place, which was a few minutes' walk away.
es: After bidding farewell to Miss Pross in the vicinity of the doctor's house, Carton, walking between Barsad and Jeremiah Cruncher, headed towards the building of Tellson's Bank, which was very close by.

en: John Barsad, or Solomon Pross, walked at his side.
vi: John Barsad, or Solomon Pross, walked beside him.
tr: John Barsad or Solomon Pross was also walking alongside him.
es: After bidding farewell to Miss Pross in the vicinity of the doctor's house, Carton, walking between Barsad and Jeremiah Cruncher, headed towards the building of Tellson's Bank, which was very close by.

en: mr Lorry had just finished his dinner, and was sitting before a cheery little log or two of fire—perhaps looking into their blaze for the picture of that younger elderly gentleman from Tellson’s, who had looked into the red coals at the Royal George at Dover, now a good many years ago.
vi: Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner and was sitting in front of a small crackling fireplace - perhaps seeing in the flames an image of himself many years ago: a distinguished gentleman of Tellson's Bank gazing at the glowing embers in the fireplace of the Royal George Hotel in Dover.
tr: Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner and was sitting in front of a few pieces of wood burning in the fireplace – perhaps seeing in the glow of the fire the young clerk of Tellson's watching the embers at the Royal George Hotel in Dover years ago.
es: Lorry, who had just finished eating and was sitting by the warmth of the fire, turned his head upon hearing the footsteps of his visitors, and could not help but show a gesture of surprise when he saw an unfamiliar face.

en: He turned his head as they entered, and showed the surprise with which he saw a stranger.
vi: Hearing footsteps approaching, he turned around and was surprised to see a stranger.
tr: As they entered, Mr. Lorry turned his head towards them and was surprised to see a stranger with them.
es: Lorry, who had just finished eating and was sitting by the warmth of the fire, turned his head upon hearing the footsteps of his visitors, and could not help but show a gesture of surprise when he saw an unfamiliar face.

en: “Miss Pross’s brother, sir,” said Sydney.
vi: − Miss Pross's brother, sir, - said Sydney.
tr: "Sir, this gentleman is Miss Pross's brother," said Sydney, "Mr. Barsad.""
es: "I present to you Miss Pross's brother," said Carton, "Mr. Barsad."

en: “mr Barsad.”
vi: - Mr. Barsad.
tr: "Sir, this gentleman is Miss Pross's brother," said Sydney, "Mr. Barsad.""
es: "I present to you Miss Pross's brother," said Carton, "Mr. Barsad."

en: “Barsad?” repeated the old gentleman, “Barsad?
vi: − Barsad? - The distinguished old man repeated, - Barsad?
tr: The old man repeated, "Barsad?" "Barsad?
es: —Barsad?—repeated Lorry. —Barsad?

en: I have an association with the name—and with the face.”
vi: I do remember that name... and the face.
tr: I remember this name from somewhere – and the face too."
es: I seem to remember that surname... and the face of the one who bears it.

en: “I told you you had a remarkable face, mr Barsad,” observed Carton, coolly.
vi: − I told you that you have a memorable face, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said nonchalantly.
tr: Carton said with an insolent manner, "I told you that you have an unforgettable face, Mr. Barsad."
es: —Didn't I tell you before that you have a face that is hard to forget, Mr. Barsad?—asked Carton coldly.

en: “Pray sit down.”
vi: - Please have a seat.
tr: "Please sit down."
es: —Do me the favor of sitting down.

en: As he took a chair himself, he supplied the link that mr Lorry wanted, by saying to him with a frown, “Witness at that trial.” mr Lorry immediately remembered, and regarded his new visitor with an undisguised look of abhorrence.
vi: He also sat down and reminded Mr. Lorry with a word accompanied by a raised eyebrow: − The witness at the trial years ago. Mr. Lorry immediately remembered and looked at the new guest with undisguised disgust.
tr: As Carton pulled up a chair for himself, he frowned and gave Mr. Lorry the answer he wanted, "The witness at the trial." Mr. Lorry immediately remembered the man and scrutinized his new visitor with evident disdain.
es: Carton, at the same time as he brought a chair closer, provided Lorry with the link he had been searching for to connect the chain of his memories. —Witness of that case—said Carton simply. It was enough for Lorry to remember, and also for him to look at Barsad with visible disgust.

en: “mr Barsad has been recognised by Miss Pross as the affectionate brother you have heard of,” said Sydney, “and has acknowledged the relationship.
vi: Sydney continued: "Miss Pross recognized Mr. Barsad as her beloved brother that you had heard about, and he confirmed this relationship."
tr: "Mr. Barsad is Miss Pross's dear brother, you must have heard," said Sydney, "and he himself confirmed this relationship.
es: —Miss Pross has recognized in Mr. Barsad the affectionate brother she has so often heard you speak of—observed Carton. —Barsad has not denied the relationship...

en: I pass to worse news.
vi: Now for the worse news.
tr: Now I move on to the bad news.
es: But let's move on to worse news; Darnay has been imprisoned again.

en: Darnay has been arrested again.”
vi: Darnay has been re-arrested.
tr: Darnay has been arrested again."
es: But let's move on to worse news; Darnay has been imprisoned again.

en: Struck with consternation, the old gentleman exclaimed, “What do you tell me!
vi: Stunned, the old man exclaimed: − How can that be!
tr: The old man, frozen by this news, exclaimed, "What are you saying?
es: —What are you telling me! —exclaimed Lorry, deeply dismayed.

en: I left him safe and free within these two hours, and am about to return to him!”
vi: Just two hours ago when I said goodbye, Darnay was safe and free, I intended to return to see him! −
tr: Just two hours ago, when I left him, he was safe and free, and I was about to go to him now!"
es: —It hasn't been two hours since I left him at his house free and happy, and I was just about to go see him.

en: “Arrested for all that.
vi: He has been arrested again anyway.
tr: "How did they arrest him?
es: —Well, he is imprisoned.

en: When was it done, mr Barsad?”
vi: When was he arrested, Mr. Barsad? −
tr: When did this happen, Mr. Barsad?"
es: When did they arrest him, Barsad?

en: “Just now, if at all.”
vi: Right now, if not already.
tr: "I think just now."
es: —In any case, it must have been just a moment ago.

en: “mr Barsad is the best authority possible, sir,” said Sydney, “and I have it from mr Barsad’s communication to a friend and brother Sheep over a bottle of wine, that the arrest has taken place.
vi: − Mr. Barsad knows best, - Sydney said, - I heard Mr. Barsad tell another "sheep" in the tavern that he went to arrest Darnay.
tr: "Mr. Barsad is the most knowledgeable person on this matter, sir," said Sydney, "I heard about this issue, that is, Darnay's arrest, while Mr. Barsad was drinking wine and talking with a friend and another fellow brother.
es: —Barsad is a reliable source of information in this matter—observed Carton. —I heard the news from his lips when he was telling it, between glasses of brandy, to a friend of his, an informer like him.

en: He left the messengers at the gate, and saw them admitted by the porter.
vi: Barsad went with the escort team to the gate of Darnay's house and saw them go inside.
tr: He left the messengers at the door, then saw them coming in.
es: It seems that he accompanied those in charge of arresting him up to the door of the doctor's house, leaving when he saw that the doorman was letting them in.

en: There is no earthly doubt that he is retaken.”
vi: His re-arrest is completely certain.
tr: There is no doubt that he has been arrested again."
es: Therefore, doubt is impossible.

en: mr Lorry’s business eye read in the speaker’s face that it was loss of time to dwell upon the point.
vi: Through Sydney's expression, Mr. Lorry's keen eye immediately understood that there was no time to doubt any longer.
tr: Mr. Lorry's businesslike eyes read on the speaker's face that dwelling further on this subject would be a waste of time.
es: Lorry understood that the misfortune was real.

en: Confused, but sensible that something might depend on his presence of mind, he commanded himself, and was silently attentive.
vi: Although confused, he still understood the need to keep a clear mind, so he calmed himself and listened attentively.
tr: He was bewildered but aware that he needed to gather his thoughts, so he composed himself and listened quietly.
es: In his mind, he felt the harsh struggle of a thousand confused and contradictory ideas, but he realized how crucial it was not to lose his presence of mind and, with titanic efforts, he controlled himself, regained his composure, and remained silent and attentive.

en: “Now, I trust,” said Sydney to him, “that the name and influence of Doctor Manette may stand him in as good stead to-morrow—you said he would be before the Tribunal again to-morrow, mr Barsad?—”
vi: Sydney continued: − At this moment, I believe that the name and influence of Dr. Manette could be very useful for Darnay tomorrow... Mr. Barsad, you said that Darnay will be retried tomorrow, didn't you? −
tr: "If you ask me," Sydney said to him, "Doctor Manette's name and reputation might be useful again tomorrow –you mentioned that he would appear in court again tomorrow, didn't you Mr. Barsad?"
es: —It is to be hoped... I have that confidence—replied Carton—that the doctor's name and his influence on the masses will be so effective tomorrow... Did you not say, Barsad, that he is to appear before the Tribunal tomorrow?

en: “Yes; I believe so.”
vi: Yes, I believe so. − ...
tr: "Yes, I think so.""
es: —Yes; I think the appearance will be tomorrow.

en: “—In as good stead to-morrow as to-day.
vi: It could be very useful for Darnay tomorrow as well as today.
tr: "It might work, of course.

en: But it may not be so.
vi: But it's not certain.
tr: But it might not work either.
es: As effective tomorrow, and as decisive, as today; but it is not impossible that the opposite may occur.

en: I own to you, I am shaken, mr Lorry, by Doctor Manette’s not having had the power to prevent this arrest.”
vi: Mr. Lorry, to be honest, I am also astonished that Dr. Manette was unable to prevent this arrest.
tr: To tell the truth, Mr. Lorry, I am very worried that Doctor Manette's influence cannot prevent this arrest."
es: I will confess, Mr. Lorry, that the fact that the doctor has not been able to prevent the imprisonment inspires me with great fears.

en: “He may not have known of it beforehand,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Perhaps he didn't know beforehand, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Maybe he didn't know about this," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Perhaps he didn't even suspect the possibility of danger—replied Lorry.

en: “But that very circumstance would be alarming, when we remember how identified he is with his son-in-law.”
vi: − But this situation is truly alarming when we know how closely he has been attached to his son-in-law.
tr: "That's the worst part, after all, everyone knows how much he is identified with his son-in-law."
es: —What, in my opinion, would be a highly alarming circumstance, given how closely he is identified with his son-in-law.

en: “That’s true,” mr Lorry acknowledged, with his troubled hand at his chin, and his troubled eyes on Carton.
vi: − That's right, - Mr. Lorry admitted, his hand anxiously stroking his chin, his eyes anxiously looking at Carton.
tr: With his nervous hands on his chin and his nervous eyes again on Carton, Mr. Lorry accepted, saying, "You are right."
es: —It's true—replied Lorry, resting his chin on the palm of his hand and looking at Carton with a downcast expression.

en: “In short,” said Sydney, “this is a desperate time, when desperate games are played for desperate stakes.
vi: − In short, - Sydney said, - this is a time of desperation, so we must play desperate games with desperate stakes.
tr: "In short," said Sydney, "this is a desperate time where desperate games are played for desperate stakes.
es: —In short—continued Carton:—when a desperate game is played and desperate bets are placed, one must also resort to desperate measures.

en: Let the Doctor play the winning game; I will play the losing one.
vi: Let the doctor play the winning hand, and I will play the losing one.
tr: Let the Doctor play to win, I will play to lose.
es: Let the doctor play with the winning cards, while I will handle the losing ones.

en: No man’s life here is worth purchase.
vi: No life here is worth anything anymore.
tr: In this environment, no one's life has any value.
es: Let the doctor play with the winning cards, while I will handle the losing ones.

en: Any one carried home by the people to-day, may be condemned tomorrow.
vi: Anyone who is celebrated by the people today could be condemned tomorrow.
tr: Today, a man carried home on shoulders can be condemned to death the next day.
es: Let the doctor play with the winning cards, while I will handle the losing ones.

en: Now, the stake I have resolved to play for, in case of the worst, is a friend in the Conciergerie.
vi: Now the stake I am determined to win, in the worst case scenario, is a friend in the Conciergerie prison.
tr: Now, as a last resort, I will put forward a friend from the Conciergerie as a trump card.
es: Let the doctor engage in the game aimed at getting his son-in-law out of the Consistory; meanwhile, I will play another independent game with the goal of putting a friend into the Consistory.

en: And the friend I purpose to myself to win, is mr Barsad.”
vi: And the friend I want to win is Mr. Barsad.
tr: The person I am determined to win over is Mr. Barsad."
es: The friend I intend to put in, Mr. Barsad, is you.

en: “You need have good cards, sir,” said the spy.
vi: − You need good cards, sir, - the spy said.
tr: "For that, you need to have very good cards, sir," replied the spy.
es: —You will need to gather very good cards to win that game, replied the spy.

en: “I’ll run them over.
vi: − You need good cards, sir, - the spy said.
tr: "I will reveal it soon.
es: "I have already gathered them, and I am going to lay them face up... but you know, Mr. Lorry, how clumsy I am if I don't spur my wits with a few drinks."

en: I’ll see what I hold,—mr Lorry, you know what a brute I am; I wish you’d give me a little brandy.”
vi: − Let me see what cards I have... Mr. Lorry, you know how rude I can be; I wish you would give me some strong liquor.
tr: First, let me fully see what I have. Mr. Lorry, you know what a miserable man I am. Could you give me some brandy?"
es: "If you could give me a little brandy, I would appreciate it."

en: It was put before him, and he drank off a glassful—drank off another glassful—pushed the bottle thoughtfully away.
vi: The wine was brought out and he drank a full glass - another full glass - then pensively pushed the bottle aside.
tr: They placed the brandy in front of him, and he drank it in one gulp – then another – then pushed the bottle aside thoughtfully.
es: He was served the liquor, of which he took two consecutive glasses.

en: “mr Barsad,” he went on, in the tone of one who really was looking over a hand at cards: “Sheep of the prisons, emissary of Republican committees, now turnkey, now prisoner, always spy and secret informer, so much the more valuable here for being English that an Englishman is less open to suspicion of subornation in those characters than a Frenchman, represents himself to his employers under a false name.
vi: − Mr. Barsad, - he continued in a tone as if he were examining the cards in his hand - the sheep of the prisons, the envoy of the Republican committees, sometimes a jailer, sometimes a prisoner, always a spy and informer, all the more valuable because he is English, as the English are generally less suspected of being easily bribed than the French, you represent your recruiter under a false name.
tr: As if he really had cards in his hand and was looking at them, he continued his speech, "Mr. Barsad, the prison lamb, spy of the Republican committees, sometimes a guard, sometimes a prisoner, but always a spy and informant, much more valuable here because he is English, as he does not arouse much suspicion in inciting perjury compared to a Frenchman and introduces himself to his superiors with a pseudonym.
es: —Mr. Barsad—he said, setting the bottle aside and speaking as if he held a collection of cards in his hand,—executioner's blackbird, emissary of the republican committees, today a jailer, yesterday a prisoner, always a spy and secret informer, whose value here increases considerably due to the circumstance of being English, and therefore less exposed to suspicion than any Frenchman, presents himself to the very ones he serves under a false name; this triumph is of the first order.

en: That’s a very good card.
vi: That is a very good card.
tr: This is a very good card.
es: —Mr. Barsad—he said, setting the bottle aside and speaking as if he held a collection of cards in his hand,—executioner's blackbird, emissary of the republican committees, today a jailer, yesterday a prisoner, always a spy and secret informer, whose value here increases considerably due to the circumstance of being English, and therefore less exposed to suspicion than any Frenchman, presents himself to the very ones he serves under a false name; this triumph is of the first order.

en: mr Barsad, now in the employ of the republican French government, was formerly in the employ of the aristocratic English government, the enemy of France and freedom.
vi: Mr. Barsad, currently working for the government of the French Republic, formerly worked for the aristocratic government of England, the enemy of France and freedom.
tr: Mr. Barsad, who is currently working on behalf of the Republican French government, previously worked on behalf of the aristocratic English government, which was an enemy of France and freedom.
es: Mr. Barsad, today in the pay of the French revolutionary government, served, not long ago, the aristocratic English government, sworn enemy of France and its liberties; it seems to me that I have just shown another card that is hard to beat.

en: That’s an excellent card.
vi: That is an excellent card.
tr: This is an excellent card.
es: Mr. Barsad, today in the pay of the French revolutionary government, served, not long ago, the aristocratic English government, sworn enemy of France and its liberties; it seems to me that I have just shown another card that is hard to beat.

en: Inference clear as day in this region of suspicion, that mr Barsad, still in the pay of the aristocratic English government, is the spy of Pitt, the treacherous foe of the Republic crouching in its bosom, the English traitor and agent of all mischief so much spoken of and so difficult to find.
vi: In an age of suspicion like this country, it is easy to deduce that Mr. Barsad is still on the payroll of the aristocratic government of England, spying for Pitt*, the treacherous enemy of the Republic lurking within France, the dangerous English spy and traitor often spoken of but hard to detect.
tr: In all this atmosphere of suspicion, it is as clear as day that Mr. Barsad, who still works on behalf of the aristocratic English government, is Pitt's spy, an enemy traitor nestled in the heart of the Republic, and the ever-mentioned but never-found English traitor and representative of all kinds of treachery.
es: If we now enter the realm of suspicions and deductions, we will find one, clear as daylight, a suspicion that I will express with the following words: Mr. Barsad, salaried informer of the aristocratic English government, is at the same time an agent of Pitt, a cunning enemy who will strike the Republic at its heart, a treacherous Englishman, agent, instrument, author of all those indignities that everyone talks about and no one is able to prove.

en: That’s a card not to be beaten.
vi: That is the trump card.
tr: This trump card can never be beaten.
es: This is a triumph that almost assures the game.

en: Have you followed my hand, mr Barsad?”
vi: Have you seen my cards, Mr. Barsad? − I don't understand your game, - the spy replied, somewhat uneasy.
tr: Could you see the cards I have, Mr. Barsad?"
es: Are you following my game, Mr. Barsad?

en: “Not to understand your play,” returned the spy, somewhat uneasily.
vi: Have you seen my cards, Mr. Barsad? − I don't understand your game, - the spy replied, somewhat uneasy.
tr: A bit uneasy, the spy replied, "I can't say that I understand your game."
es: —I am beginning to understand the importance of the letters, but I still don't know how you plan to play them—replied the spy, visibly uneasy.

en: “I play my Ace, Denunciation of mr Barsad to the nearest Section Committee.
vi: − I will play the ace which is to denounce Mr. Barsad to the nearest District Committee.
tr: "I am playing Asım, the nearest regional committee has been informed by Mr. Barsad.
es: —I begin by playing the next trump card: A denunciation against the so-called Barsad before the nearest district Committee.

en: Look over your hand, mr Barsad, and see what you have.
vi: Review your cards, Mr. Barsad, and see what you have.
tr: You also take a look at your hand, Mr. Barsad, what do you see?
es: Look at your cards, Barsad, and play... without haste, no one is rushing us.

en: Don’t hurry.”
vi: Don't be hasty.
tr: But don't rush."
es: Look at your cards, Barsad, and play... without haste, no one is rushing us.

en: He drew the bottle near, poured out another glassful of brandy, and drank it off.
vi: He pulled the bottle of wine closer, filled another glass, and drank it all.
tr: Carton pulled the bottle and filled another glass with cognac, drinking it in one gulp.
es: He took the bottle again, poured himself another glass, drank it with unperturbed calmness, and waited.

en: He saw that the spy was fearful of his drinking himself into a fit state for the immediate denunciation of him.
vi: He saw that the spy was afraid he would get drunk and wanted to expose him immediately.
tr: The spy saw that Carton was afraid he would report him immediately, that he would drink it in one gulp like that.
es: He saw that the spy feared that the libations would result in an immediate denunciation, and, no doubt to increase the fear, he poured and downed the fourth glass.

en: Seeing it, he poured out and drank another glassful.
vi: He poured himself another full glass of wine and drank it.
tr: Noticing this, Carton filled another one and downed it.
es: He saw that the spy feared that the libations would result in an immediate denunciation, and, no doubt to increase the fear, he poured and downed the fourth glass.

en: “Look over your hand carefully, mr Barsad.
vi: − Take a good look at your card, Mr. Barsad.
tr: "Look carefully at your hand, Mr. Barsad.
es: —Take all the time you need, Barsad, lest you lose the game on the first move.

en: Take time.”
vi: Take your time.
tr: Think carefully."
es: —Take all the time you need, Barsad, lest you lose the game on the first move.

en: It was a poorer hand than he suspected.
vi: The card was weaker than he thought.
tr: Barsad's hand was worse than he had anticipated.
es: Barsad was a weaker adversary than Carton had supposed.

en: mr Barsad saw losing cards in it that Sydney Carton knew nothing of.
vi: Barsad saw the losing cards that Sydney Carton was unaware of.
tr: Mr. Barsad saw that he was losing the cards in this hand, about which Sydney Carton knew nothing, one by one.
es: To tell the truth, he had very bad cards in his game, and he knew it, although Carton did not.

en: Thrown out of his honourable employment in England, through too much unsuccessful hard swearing there—not because he was not wanted there; our English reasons for vaunting our superiority to secrecy and spies are of very modern date—he knew that he had crossed the Channel, and accepted service in France: first, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among his own countrymen there: gradually, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among the natives.
vi: Having been expelled from his prestigious job in England after too many unsuccessful attempts at perjury - not because he was no longer needed there; England at that time, as now, boasted of its superiority in schemes and espionage - he knew that he had voluntarily crossed the English Channel to take up a job in France; initially, he lured and eavesdropped on expatriates there, and gradually began to lure and eavesdrop on the locals as well.
tr: He had been dismissed from his honorable job in England—not because he was unwanted there, but because our pride in secrecy and espionage coincides with recent times—due to too much perjury, and he had crossed the Channel to accept the job in France. At first, he had engaged in incitement and spying among his own citizens, and then gradually tried the same activities among the French.
es: He knew, for example, that, dismissed from his honorable position in England as a result of unforgivable blunders committed in the exercise of it, he crossed the Channel and offered his services in France, where they were accepted, at first, to tempt and extract information from his compatriots, and later, to tempt and extract information from the French.

en: He knew that under the overthrown government he had been a spy upon Saint Antoine and Defarge’s wine-shop; had received from the watchful police such heads of information concerning Doctor Manette’s imprisonment, release, and history, as should serve him for an introduction to familiar conversation with the Defarges; and tried them on Madame Defarge, and had broken down with them signally.
vi: He knew that under the overthrown regime, he had been a spy in the Saint Antoine area and Defarge's wine shop; he had been provided with information by the sharp-nosed police about Dr. Manette's imprisonment, release, and background. He had used that information to strike up a conversation with the Defarges and tried to exploit Madame Defarge but failed miserably.
tr: Carton knew that he had been spying in the St. Antoine district and in Defarge's wine shop under the orders of the overthrown government; to establish dialogue with the Defarges, he had gathered information about Dr. Manette's imprisonment, release, and life from vigilant police officers, then used this information against Madame Defarge but had achieved nothing.
es: He knew that, during the overthrown government, he was in charge of monitoring the Saint Antoine district and Defarge's tavern; that he received from the police the necessary data about the captivity, freedom, and history of Dr. Manette, thanks to which he believed he would manage to become a confidential friend of the Defarges, although he soon had to convince himself that, on some occasions, those who seek wool come back shorn.

en: He always remembered with fear and trembling, that that terrible woman had knitted when he talked with her, and had looked ominously at him as her fingers moved.
vi: He always shuddered when he remembered that while he was trying to strike up a conversation, that dreadful woman had looked at him in a terrifying way, her fingers still deftly knitting.
tr: He shuddered with fear, recalling how the dreadful woman always knitted while talking to him and how she glared at him menacingly as her fingers moved.
es: He always remembered with terror that that terrible tavern keeper had been knitting while he tried to extract information from her, and he would tremble every time he recalled that she looked at him with a somber expression while her fingers moved swiftly.

en: He had since seen her, in the Section of Saint Antoine, over and over again produce her knitted registers, and denounce people whose lives the guillotine then surely swallowed up.
vi: Since then, he had encountered her many times in the Saint Antoine district, always holding out a list knitted into the fabric and denouncing many people, victims who would surely meet their end at the guillotine.
tr: He had seen her many times later in St. Antoine, the woman constantly reading the names she knitted into her work, and the lives of these people she denounced soon ended at the guillotine.
es: He had seen her countless times since then in the Saint Antoine district, armed with her knitting records and denouncing people whose heads were soon severed by the guillotine.

en: He knew, as every one employed as he was did, that he was never safe; that flight was impossible; that he was tied fast under the shadow of the axe; and that in spite of his utmost tergiversation and treachery in furtherance of the reigning terror, a word might bring it down upon him.
vi: He knew, just like many others recruited for the same job, that his life would never be safe; there was no way to escape; he would always be under the shadow of death; and despite having switched sides to serve this reigning terror, a single word could put him in danger.
tr: As everyone involved in these matters knew, he was never safe; escape was impossible; he was tightly bound under the shadow of the blade, and despite all the treachery and betrayal he had committed to contribute to the surrounding savagery, a single word could cause that blade to fall on his head.
es: He knew, as all those who hold jobs like his do, that the storm raged over his head at all hours; that his head was in danger, that escape was impossible, that with each moment he brought his neck closer to the blade, and that, despite the services rendered to the cause of the reigning terror, a single word was enough to send him to the scaffold.

en: Once denounced, and on such grave grounds as had just now been suggested to his mind, he foresaw that the dreadful woman of whose unrelenting character he had seen many proofs, would produce against him that fatal register, and would quash his last chance of life.
vi: Once denounced, with the serious crimes he had just reviewed in his mind, he foresaw that the dreadful woman with a cruel personality, whom he had witnessed many times, would certainly bring out that deadly list to accuse him and extinguish his last chance of survival.
tr: With things in this state, once a denunciation was made, that dreadful woman, whose ruthlessness he had witnessed many times, could bring out her deadly records and ruin his life.
es: No sooner had he been denounced, with all or part of the grave charges just insinuated against him, than he understood that that formidable woman, of whose implacable character he had seen ample proof, would exhibit the fatal record that would dispel the last possibility of salvation.

en: Besides that all secret men are men soon terrified, here were surely cards enough of one black suit, to justify the holder in growing rather livid as he turned them over.
vi: Moreover, everyone living a secret life is easily panicked, and the cards in his hand were unlucky enough to prove his increasingly livid face due to rage.
tr: Moreover, men involved in such secret affairs are quickly terrified, and there were cards in this hand that, when revealed, would inevitably cause the holder to turn pale.
es: Add to this the law, proven a thousand times, that all informers, all secret informers, are cowards by temperament, men who are easily frightened, and one can understand the state of mind in which Barsad was left.

en: “You scarcely seem to like your hand,” said Sydney, with the greatest composure.
vi: − It seems you don't like your card, - Sydney said very calmly. -
tr: "It seems you are not very satisfied with your own hand," said Sydney with great composure.
es: —It seems that your letters are not much to their liking—said Carton with his usual calm.

en: “Do you play?”
vi: Are you going to play?
tr: "Shall we continue the game?"
es: —Don't you play?

en: “I think, sir,” said the spy, in the meanest manner, as he turned to mr Lorry, “I may appeal to a gentleman of your years and benevolence, to put it to this other gentleman, so much your junior, whether he can under any circumstances reconcile it to his station to play that Ace of which he has spoken.
vi: − I think, sir, - the despicable spy humbly turned to Mr. Lorry, - I earnestly implore this venerable and generous gentleman to speak to that other gentleman, who is much younger than you, and ask him not to demean himself by playing the trump card he mentioned.
tr: "I think it's ongoing, sir," said the spy, turning to Mr. Lorry, "It would actually be good to get the opinion of an experienced and helpful gentleman like yourself. Can this gentleman, who is much younger than you, really play the card he mentioned?"
es: —I believe, sir—responded Barsad, turning towards Lorry and speaking with fawning humility,—that I find myself in the position of requesting from a gentleman of your years and benevolence the favor of asking this other gentleman, much younger than you, to refrain from playing the card he just mentioned to me.

en: I admit that I am a spy, and that it is considered a discreditable station—though it must be filled by somebody; but this gentleman is no spy, and why should he so demean himself as to make himself one?”
vi: I confess I am a spy, and this is a profession considered to be dishonorable... although someone has to do this job; but this gentleman is not a spy, why should he demean himself like spies do?
tr: "I admit that I am a spy and that it is a disgraceful situation – but someone has to do it; however, why does this gentleman lower himself by pretending to be a spy when he is not one?""
es: I confess that I am a spy, and I acknowledge that the profession honors no one, although you will admit that someone has to perform it; but this gentleman is not a spy, this gentleman is not an informer; and since he is not one now, what need is there for him to be one in the future?

en: “I play my Ace, mr Barsad,” said Carton, taking the answer on himself, and looking at his watch, “without any scruple, in a very few minutes.”
vi: − I play my ace, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said without waiting for Mr. Lorry to respond, and looking at the clock, - without hesitation, in just a few minutes.
tr: "I will play the ace I have, Mr. Barsad," said Carton, who took the remark personally, and looking at his watch, he added, "without any hesitation, in a little while."
es: —I will play my card, Mr. Barsad—said Carton, without waiting for Lorry to reply,—without the slightest scruple and within five minutes.

en: “I should have hoped, gentlemen both,” said the spy, always striving to hook mr Lorry into the discussion, “that your respect for my sister—”
vi: − Gentlemen, - the spy always tried to draw Mr. Lorry into the conversation, - I keep hoping that because you both respect my sister...
tr: The spy, trying to draw Mr. Lorry into the conversation, replied, "Out of respect for my sister from two such courteous gentlemen like yourselves..."
es: —I had harbored the hope, gentlemen, that, out of consideration for my sister...

en: “I could not better testify my respect for your sister than by finally relieving her of her brother,” said Sydney Carton.
vi: − The best way for me to show respect to your sister is that I will ultimately help her be free from her brother, - Sydney Carton said.
tr: "I cannot better prove my respect for your sister than by finally freeing her from her brother," said Sydney Carton.
es: "The greatest favor we can do for your sister is to free her forever from a brother like you," replied Carton.

en: “You think not, sir?”
vi: − Is there no other way, sir? − I have made up my mind.
tr: "So, this is what you think, sir?"
es: —Do you believe so, sir?

en: “I have thoroughly made up my mind about it.”
vi: − Is there no other way, sir? − I have made up my mind.
tr: "My decision on this matter is final."
es: —I am absolutely convinced of it.

en: The smooth manner of the spy, curiously in dissonance with his ostentatiously rough dress, and probably with his usual demeanour, received such a check from the inscrutability of Carton,—who was a mystery to wiser and honester men than he,—that it faltered here and failed him.
vi: In stark contrast to his ragged exterior, and perhaps to his usual behavior, the detective's courteous demeanor had lost its effect in the face of Carton's enigmatic attitude - a man who was a mystery even to those more intelligent and virtuous than Barsad.
tr: Barsad was so affected by the spy's calm demeanor, which was completely at odds with his flashy yet coarse clothing, and perhaps by his ordinary behavior, that he was left bewildered, not knowing what to do. This mysteriousness of Carton – which was an enigma even for men much wiser and more honest than him – left Barsad in a state of confusion.
es: The spy, with all his humility, which so greatly contrasted with his terrorist attire and probably with his ordinary manner of being, received such a harsh blow from the inscrutability of Carton, who had always been a mystery to men more honest and clever than he, that he wavered, trembled, and gave himself up for lost.
