en: While he was at a loss, Carton said, resuming his former air of contemplating cards:
vi: While he was still bewildered, Carton continued in the manner of someone contemplating his next move: − And indeed, now that I think about it, I realize I have an even better card to play that I haven't mentioned yet.
tr: While he was in this state of not knowing what to say, Carton, adopting the manner of a man arranging his cards, said:
es: While disconcerted, stupefied, he remained silent, not knowing how to get out of the predicament, Carton replied:

en: “And indeed, now I think again, I have a strong impression that I have another good card here, not yet enumerated.
vi: While he was still bewildered, Carton continued in the manner of someone contemplating his next move: − And indeed, now that I think about it, I realize I have an even better card to play that I haven't mentioned yet.
tr: "Actually, now that I think about it again, I realized I had one more good card in my hand, which I hadn't noticed before.
es: —I am examining my letters again, and I find one, as good as the ones listed, that I had not mentioned.

en: That friend and fellow-Sheep, who spoke of himself as pasturing in the country prisons; who was he?”
vi: My friend... the one who claims to be a sheep grazing in this country's prison; who is that?
tr: You know, that guy and his prison lamb friend who said he grazed in many prisons; who was that?"
es: Who is that colleague of yours, who spoke as if he had spent his entire life grazing in prisons?

en: “French.
vi: − A Frenchman.
tr: "The French one.
es: —He is a Frenchman; you do not know him—replied the spy quickly.

en: You don’t know him,” said the spy, quickly.
vi: You wouldn't know him, - the detective quickly replied.
tr: You wouldn't know him," the spy quickly replied.
es: —He is a Frenchman; you do not know him—replied the spy quickly.

en: “French, eh?” repeated Carton, musing, and not appearing to notice him at all, though he echoed his word.
vi: − The Frenchman? - Carton repeated, looking pensive, as if he wasn't paying attention to Barsad but was speaking to himself.
tr: "French, huh!" Carton repeated, lost in thought and seemingly unaware of her, yet he had echoed the exact word she had said.
es: —French, eh?—exclaimed Carton, as if he wasn't thinking about what he was saying—could be.

en: “Well; he may be.”
vi: - Ah, it could be him.
tr: "Well, it could be, of course."
es: —French, eh?—exclaimed Carton, as if he wasn't thinking about what he was saying—could be.

en: “Is, I assure you,” said the spy; “though it’s not important.”
vi: − It's him, I assure you, - the spy said, - though this matter is not important.
tr: "Yes, you can be sure," said the spy; "but it doesn't matter."
es: —It is... I assure you... although that is the least of it—said the spy.

en: “Though it’s not important,” repeated Carton, in the same mechanical way—“though it’s not important—No, it’s not important.
vi: − Even though this matter is not important, - Carton repeated mechanically as before, -... even though this matter is not important...
tr: "But it doesn't matter," repeated Carton in the same mechanical manner –"but it doesn't matter–
es: —Although that is the least of it...—repeated Carton mechanically—although that is the least of it... Yes... it is the least of it...

en: No.
vi: No, not important. No.
tr: No, it doesn't matter at all. It doesn't.
es: But the fact is that I know that face.

en: Yet I know the face.”
vi: But I remember that face.
tr: But I know it."
es: But the fact is that I know that face.

en: “I think not.
vi: − I don't think so.
tr: "Sanmam.
es: —I don't think so...

en: I am sure not.
vi: I'm sure it's not.
tr: I'm not sure about this.
es: Of course, I assure you that no...

en: It can’t be,” said the spy.
vi: No way, - the spy said.
tr: It can't be," said the spy.
es: It's not possible...

en: “It-can’t-be,” muttered Sydney Carton, retrospectively, and idling his glass (which fortunately was a small one) again.
vi: − No... way... - Sydney Carton murmured as if reminiscing, his hand fondling the glass of wine (luckily it was a small glass).
tr: "Un-be-liev-able," murmured Sydney Carton, in the same manner as before, and refilled his glass (fortunately, this time it was a small one).
es: —It's not possible...—murmured Carton, filling his cup for the fifth time, which fortunately was small.

en: “Can’t-be.
vi: - No... way.
tr: "Un-be-liev-able.
es: —It's not possible...

en: Spoke good French.
vi: Speaks French well.
tr: His French was good.
es: He speaks French correctly... but with a slightly foreign accent...

en: Yet like a foreigner, I thought?”
vi: But still with a foreign accent, right?
tr: But it sounded foreign to me."
es: He speaks French correctly... but with a slightly foreign accent...

en: “Provincial,” said the spy.
vi: − A provincial accent, - the spy said.
tr: "Provincial," said the spy.
es: —Provincial accent—explained the spy.

en: “No. Foreign!” cried Carton, striking his open hand on the table, as a light broke clearly on his mind.
vi: − No. Foreigner! - Carton exclaimed, slamming the table as he suddenly remembered.
tr: Carton, as if a lightning bolt had struck his mind, slammed his hand on the table and said, "No. It was a stranger!" he shouted.
es: —No! Foreign accent! —replied Carton, slamming his fist on the table.

en: “Cly!
vi: - Cly!
tr: "Cly!
es: —It's Cly!

en: Disguised, but the same man.
vi: Disguised, but still a person.
tr: He had hidden his face, but it was the same man.
es: Disguised, disfigured, but the very same Cly!

en: We had that man before us at the Old Bailey.”
vi: We saw him standing in front of us at the Old Bailey Court.
tr: He was standing right in front of us at Old Bailey."
es: I've had him in my sight many times at the Old Bailey.

en: “Now, there you are hasty, sir,” said Barsad, with a smile that gave his aquiline nose an extra inclination to one side; “there you really give me an advantage over you.
vi: − There you go, you jumped to conclusions too quickly, sir, - Barsad said with a smile that made his hooked nose seem to bend to one side, - in this matter, you have given me the advantage.
tr: With a smile that made the curve of his nose more pronounced to one side, "Now you have rushed a bit, sir," said Barsad, "you have given me an advantage."
es: —You get worked up easily, sir—said Barsad with a smile that accentuated the tilt of his aquiline nose,—which gives me an advantage over you.

en: Cly (who I will unreservedly admit, at this distance of time, was a partner of mine) has been dead several years.
vi: Cly, whom I admit without hesitation was my friend in the past; but he has been dead for many years now.
tr: Of course, I admit that he was once my partner, but Cly has been dead for a long time.
es: Cly, my colleague from another time, I have no hesitation in confessing, died a number of years ago.

en: I attended him in his last illness.
vi: I took care of him when he was sick and dying.
tr: I was even with him during his illness.
es: I took care of him myself during his final illness.

en: He was buried in London, at the church of Saint Pancras-in-the-Fields.
vi: He was buried in London in the cemetery of Saint Pancras Church.
tr: He was buried in the garden of Saint Pancras Church in London.
es: He was buried in London, in the cemetery of the parish of St. Pancras.

en: His unpopularity with the blackguard multitude at the moment prevented my following his remains, but I helped to lay him in his coffin.”
vi: At that time, the common folk hated him so much that I couldn’t attend his funeral, but I personally helped place him in the coffin.
tr: Since he was not a man much favored among that blasphemous crowd, I couldn't attend his funeral, but I helped put him in the coffin."
es: I did not accompany him to the cemetery, because I feared the crowds, as my friend and colleague had the misfortune of becoming extraordinarily unpopular; but I helped those who placed him in the coffin.

en: Here, mr Lorry became aware, from where he sat, of a most remarkable goblin shadow on the wall.
vi: At that moment, from where he was sitting, Mr. Lorry suddenly noticed the shadow of a goblin prominently on the wall.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Lorry, from where he was sitting, noticed a shadow on the wall that distinctly resembled that of a goblin.
es: Suddenly, Lorry saw the shadow of a goblin or something similar projected on the wall.

en: Tracing it to its source, he discovered it to be caused by a sudden extraordinary rising and stiffening of all the risen and stiff hair on mr Cruncher’s head.
vi: Tracing where the shadow originated from, he realized that the unusually upright shadow was actually Cruncher's head with his hair standing on end.
tr: Upon looking carefully, he realized that it was formed by Mr. Cruncher's hair standing even more upright than usual.
es: He turned his head looking for the source of the projection, and with indescribable surprise, noticed that it was on the head of Jeremiah Lapa, whose hair, resembling steel spikes, had stood on end.

en: “Let us be reasonable,” said the spy, “and let us be fair.
vi: − We must be thoughtful and fair, - the spy said.
tr: "We need to be reasonable," said the spy, "and fair.
es: "—Come to your senses, sir, and do not be deceived by suspicions that have no rational basis," replied the spy."

en: To show you how mistaken you are, and what an unfounded assumption yours is, I will lay before you a certificate of Cly’s burial, which I happened to have carried in my pocket-book,” with a hurried hand he produced and opened it, “ever since.
vi: To prove that you are mistaken and that your assumption is unfounded, I will show you Cly's burial certificate, which I happen to have in my notebook all this time, - his hand hastily pulled out the notebook and opened it.
tr: To show you how wrong you are and how unfounded these claims are, I will show you Cly's burial certificate, which I carry in my notebook," he said, taking it out and opening it with hurried hands, "luckily, it has been with me since then.
es: —To demonstrate to you how mistaken you are, and the lack of any basis for your assumption, I am going to present you with a proper death certificate for Cly, a certificate that I always carry in my pocket."

en: There it is.
vi: Here it is.
tr: Here it is.
es: "Take it," he added, offering his interlocutor a folded paper."

en: Oh, look at it, look at it!
vi: Ah, take a look, take a look!
tr: Go ahead, look, read it!
es: —Read it, read it... take it in your hands, examine it carefully... it is not fake, no, but authentic and very authentic!"

en: You may take it in your hand; it’s no forgery.”
vi: You can pick it up and examine it; it's not a forgery.
tr: You can take it; it's not fake."
es: —Read it, read it... take it in your hands, examine it carefully... it is not fake, no, but authentic and very authentic!"

en: Here, mr Lorry perceived the reflection on the wall to elongate, and mr Cruncher rose and stepped forward.
vi: At this moment, Mr. Lorry saw the shadow on the wall lengthen, and Cruncher stood up and walked over.
tr: Mr. Lorry now noticed that the reflection on the wall had lengthened; Mr. Cruncher had gotten up and was approaching them.
es: Lorry observed that the shadow cast on the wall was lengthening.

en: His hair could not have been more violently on end, if it had been that moment dressed by the Cow with the crumpled horn in the house that Jack built.
vi: His hair now stood up like spikes, each strand stiff and fierce as if anger wanted to shoot out of his head.
tr: In this house that Jack built, even if he had horns of a cow on his head, his hair could not look this wild.
es: It was because Lapa had risen from his seat and was approaching the spy, beside whom he positioned himself without being seen or heard by him.

en: Unseen by the spy, mr Cruncher stood at his side, and touched him on the shoulder like a ghostly bailiff.
vi: The spy did not see that Cruncher was standing beside him.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, standing over the unsuspecting spy like a ghostly bailiff, touched his shoulder.
es: It was because Lapa had risen from his seat and was approaching the spy, beside whom he positioned himself without being seen or heard by him.

en: “That there Roger Cly, master,” said mr Cruncher, with a taciturn and iron-bound visage.
vi: Like a ghostly law enforcer, Cruncher grabbed Barsad's shoulder and said: − So it turns out that name Roger Cly.
tr: "So, Roger Cly, your master, is dead," said Mr. Cruncher, with a silent and steely expression.
es: Placing his right hand on Barsad's shoulder, he asked:

en: “So you put him in his coffin?”
vi: Hey you, did you put him in the coffin? −
tr: "Did you put him in the coffin?"
es: —So it was you who put Rogerio Cly inside the coffin?

en: “I did.”
vi: Who else but me.
tr: "Yes."
es: —I went; yes.

en: “Who took him out of it?”
vi: − So who took him out of the coffin? −
tr: "Well, then who took him out of there?"
es: —And who got him out of it?

en: Barsad leaned back in his chair, and stammered, “What do you mean?”
vi: What do you mean? - Barsad leaned back in his chair, stammering.
tr: Barsad leaned back in his chair and stammered, "What do you mean?"
es: Barsad, leaning back in his chair, stammered: —What do your words mean?

en: “I mean,” said mr Cruncher, “that he warn’t never in it.
vi: − What I mean is, - Cruncher said, - is that he was not in the coffin at all.
tr: "So," said Mr. Cruncher, "he actually never got into that coffin.
es: —It means—Lapa replied—that Cly's corpse was never inside the coffin.

en: No!
vi: No!
tr: No!
es: No... and no!

en: Not he!
vi: Not at all!
tr: He wasn't!
es: No... and no!

en: I’ll have my head took off, if he was ever in it.”
vi: If he's in there, you can cut off my head.
tr: If he did, they can cut off my head."
es: Off with my head if it was!

en: The spy looked round at the two gentlemen; they both looked in unspeakable astonishment at Jerry.
vi: The spy darted his eyes between the two noble people, both of whom were looking at Jerry in astonishment, unable to utter a word.
tr: Casus looked at the two gentlemen beside him; both were staring at Jerry in a bewildered state.
es: The spy alternately looked at the two gentlemen, who, in turn, gazed with infinite astonishment at Lapa.

en: “I tell you,” said Jerry, “that you buried paving-stones and earth in that there coffin.
vi: Jerry continued: − I'm telling you, in that coffin, you only buried dirt and rocks.
tr: "In that coffin," said Jerry, "you had only put cobblestones and dirt.
es: —And I add—replied Jeremías Lapa—that you buried street cobblestones and dirt inside that coffin.

en: Don’t go and tell me that you buried Cly.
vi: Don't tell me you actually buried Cly.
tr: Don't tell me you buried Cly.
es: Don't come here with nonsense or with pretensions of making me believe that they buried Cly, because I, and two other men, know very well what was inside the coffin.

en: It was a take in.
vi: That's a scam.
tr: This was a trick.
es: Don't come here with nonsense or with pretensions of making me believe that they buried Cly, because I, and two other men, know very well what was inside the coffin.

en: Me and two more knows it.”
vi: Two others and I have known for a long time.
tr: Two other people and I know this."
es: Don't come here with nonsense or with pretensions of making me believe that they buried Cly, because I, and two other men, know very well what was inside the coffin.

en: “How do you know it?”
vi: − How do you know? −
tr: "How do you know?"
es: —But how do you know?

en: “What’s that to you?
vi: That doesn't matter.
tr: "What's it to you?
es: —And what business is it of yours?

en: Ecod!” growled mr Cruncher, “it’s you I have got a old grudge again, is it, with your shameful impositions upon tradesmen!
vi: - Cruncher growled. - By God! You are my old grudge, for daring to deceive an honest working man with such shameful tricks!
tr: Oh my God!" muttered Mr. Cruncher, "I already have an old grudge against you for those miserable taxes you collect from all the tradesmen!"
es: —Lapa growled. —I have despised you for a long time, yes, sir, because even in matters as serious as death, you dare to deceive honest workers who only aspire to work.

en: I’d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a guinea.”
vi: If I could strangle you to death, I would do it even if it cost me half a Guinea.
tr: "I'll strangle you right here for half a guinea."
es: Know this, my good sir, for less than half a guinea, I would grab you by the neck and strangle you!

en: Sydney Carton, who, with mr Lorry, had been lost in amazement at this turn of the business, here requested mr Cruncher to moderate and explain himself.
vi: Sydney Carton and Mr. Lorry were both astonished by this turn of events. Hearing this, both of them asked Cruncher to calm down and explain clearly.
tr: Sydney Carton, who was as bewildered by the turn of events as Mr. Lorry, at this point asked Mr. Cruncher to calm down and explain the situation.
es: Both Carton and Lorry, whose astonishment had reached its peak, begged Jeremiah Lapa to moderate himself and to explain to them what was an enigma of impossible solution.

en: “At another time, sir,” he returned, evasively, “the present time is ill-conwenient for explainin’.
vi: − Another time, sir, - he replied evasively, - it's not convenient to explain now.
tr: "Another time, sir," Mr. Cruncher replied evasively, "this is not the right time to explain."
es: —Another day I will do it, sir—replied Lapa, not inclined to give the explanations that were asked of him,—for this is not a suitable occasion to enter into explanations.

en: What I stand to, is, that he knows well wot that there Cly was never in that there coffin.
vi: And I dare say this fellow knows full well that Cly was never in that coffin.
tr: "What I mean to say is that he knows very well that Cly is not in that coffin."
es: What I want to make clear is that that individual knows very well that Cly never intended to be locked in that coffin.

en: Let him say he was, in so much as a word of one syllable, and I’ll either catch hold of his throat and choke him for half a guinea;” mr Cruncher dwelt upon this as quite a liberal offer; “or I’ll out and announce him.”
vi: If he dares to say that again, just one more time, I'd gladly pay half a guinea to strangle him on the spot, - Cruncher continued his generous offer, - or I'll go out and report him.
tr: "If he says otherwise, I'll either strangle him on the spot," Mr. Cruncher offered this quite generously, "or I'll go and report him immediately.""
es: Let that liar dare to repeat it, and I will strangle him with my claws or run off to denounce him.

en: “Humph!
vi: − Hm!
tr: "Hmm!
es: —Hmm!

en: I see one thing,” said Carton.
vi: I see an additional opportunity, - Carton said.
tr: There is just one thing," said Carton.
es: —grumbled Carton.—I encounter another triumph, Barsad.

en: “I hold another card, mr Barsad.
vi: - I have another card to play, Mr. Barsad.
tr: "I have one more card in my hand, Mr. Barsad.
es: —grumbled Carton.—I encounter another triumph, Barsad.

en: Impossible, here in raging Paris, with Suspicion filling the air, for you to outlive denunciation, when you are in communication with another aristocratic spy of the same antecedents as yourself, who, moreover, has the mystery about him of having feigned death and come to life again!
vi: In this crazy Paris, where everyone suspects everyone else, you cannot escape being denounced while you are in contact with another aristocratic spy of the same background as you, who also has the secret of faking his death and coming back to life!
tr: In this agitated Paris, where suspicion is everywhere, it is quite a mysterious situation for you to have a connection with an aristocratic spy with a similar past as yours, and for this person to come back to life after a fake death. It is hardly possible for you to stay away from being informed!
es: Here in Paris, where the atmosphere is filled with suspicion, it is quite certain that one who, like you, maintains close relations with another aristocratic spy of your same ilk, who bears the mystery of having pretended to be dead and buried only to resurrect against all divine and human laws, does not escape alive from a denunciation.

en: A plot in the prisons, of the foreigner against the Republic.
vi: A conspiracy in the prison, by foreigners wanting to oppose the Republic.
tr: A foreigner playing a game against the Republic in the prisons.
es: Machinations against the Republic concocted by foreigners whom the Republic has on its payroll... Bad, bad!

en: A strong card—a certain Guillotine card!
vi: The sure-win card... the Guillotine card!
tr: A strong card – definitely a guillotine card!
es: It is a very great triumph... the triumph of the Guillotine, Barsad.

en: Do you play?”
vi: Do you play?
tr: Shall we continue the game?"
es: Are you not playing? —No! I don't play!

en: “No!” returned the spy.
vi: − No! - The spy replied.
tr: "No!" said the spy.
es: —replied the spy.

en: “I throw up.
vi: - I give up.
tr: "Alright, I'll tell you.
es: —I surrender!

en: I confess that we were so unpopular with the outrageous mob, that I only got away from England at the risk of being ducked to death, and that Cly was so ferreted up and down, that he never would have got away at all but for that sham.
vi: I admit that the brutal crowd hates both of us so much that I had no choice but to risk drowning to escape from England, while Cly was hunted everywhere, so if he hadn't faked his death, he wouldn't have escaped.
tr: In that maddened crowd, we had so little space that I risked death and fled from England; as for Cly, he was so trapped that if we hadn't turned that cabinet, he would never have escaped.
es: I confess that we had become so unpopular with the vile rabble, that I managed to escape from England where I was at risk of being hanged, and Cly was so compromised that if he didn't die, it's certain that he wouldn't have been able to get out even by air.

en: Though how this man knows it was a sham, is a wonder of wonders to me.”
vi: As for how this person knew about the fake death, I have no idea.
tr: But what I'm curious about is how this man learned that it was a game."
es: What amazes me, what stuns me, what drives me crazy, is that this man knows that Cly wasn't buried.

en: “Never you trouble your head about this man,” retorted the contentious mr Cruncher; “you’ll have trouble enough with giving your attention to that gentleman.
vi: − You guys don't waste your time with this one, - Cruncher often retorted. - You guys don't need to waste your time paying attention to him.
tr: The combative Mr. Cruncher replied harshly, "Don't waste your thoughts on that man, you'll already have enough trouble dealing with this gentleman."
es: What amazes me, what stuns me, what drives me crazy, is that this man knows that Cly wasn't buried.

en: And look here!
vi: Look here! Just one more time!
tr: One more thing! I'm telling you again!"
es: How did he find out?

en: Once more!”—mr Cruncher could not be restrained from making rather an ostentatious parade of his liberality—“I’d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a guinea.”
vi: - Cruncher couldn't help but propose his boastful exchange, - I'd give up half a guinea to strangle you to death right now.
tr: –Mr. Cruncher once again flaunted his generosity– "I'll choke and strangle you!"
es: —Don't get worked up, my good sir—replied Lapa—You'd do well to pay attention to what these gentlemen are telling you. But don't forget that for less than half a guinea, I'll strangle you with my own hands.

en: The Sheep of the prisons turned from him to Sydney Carton, and said, with more decision, “It has come to a point.
vi: The prison sheep looked from Cruncher to Sydney Carton, then spoke more decisively: −
tr: The prison turnkey then turned to Sydney Carton and said more resolutely, "We are at a certain point now.
es: The executioner's blackbird turned to Carton and spoke with a decisiveness he had not shown until that moment:

en: I go on duty soon, and can’t overstay my time.
vi: It's time to lay everything out plainly. My shift is about to start and I can't stay much longer.
tr: Soon I will return to my work, I can't stay here any longer.
es: —I go on duty very soon, and I cannot afford to linger any longer.

en: You told me you had a proposal; what is it?
vi: You said you had a proposal; what is it?
tr: You said you had a proposal for me; what is it?
es: You told me you wanted to make me a proposition; would you be so kind as to state it?

en: Now, it is of no use asking too much of me.
vi: Well, demanding too much from me won't be of any use.
tr: Don't ask me for something I can't do.
es: I will start by telling you not to ask me for great things, not to demand anything that conflicts with my position, nothing that puts my head at greater risk than it already is, for I prefer to risk my life on the contingencies of a refusal rather than on those of consent.

en: Ask me to do anything in my office, putting my head in great extra danger, and I had better trust my life to the chances of a refusal than the chances of consent.
vi: Forcing me to do anything in my position that might risk my head, I'd rather risk refusing than agreeing.
tr: If you ask for something that would put my head in danger, of course, I can't agree to that.
es: I will start by telling you not to ask me for great things, not to demand anything that conflicts with my position, nothing that puts my head at greater risk than it already is, for I prefer to risk my life on the contingencies of a refusal rather than on those of consent.

en: In short, I should make that choice.
vi: In short, the choice is mine.
tr: In short, I must make this choice.
es: I will start by telling you not to ask me for great things, not to demand anything that conflicts with my position, nothing that puts my head at greater risk than it already is, for I prefer to risk my life on the contingencies of a refusal rather than on those of consent.

en: You talk of desperation.
vi: You mentioned desperation.
tr: You are talking to me about despair.
es: You spoke earlier of a desperate venture; we are all desperate now; for my part, I confess that I am as desperate as anyone.

en: We are all desperate here.
vi: We are all desperate here.
tr: We are all desperate here.
es: You spoke earlier of a desperate venture; we are all desperate now; for my part, I confess that I am as desperate as anyone.

en: Remember!
vi: Remember that!
tr: Remember!
es: You spoke earlier of a desperate venture; we are all desperate now; for my part, I confess that I am as desperate as anyone.

en: I may denounce you if I think proper, and I can swear my way through stone walls, and so can others.
vi: I could also betray you if I see fit, and I can lie under oath as well as anyone.
tr: If we think about it, I can also report you and swear falsely to get out of those stone walls, as can others.
es: Another thing; without the slightest scruple, I will betray you if I see it suits me, for when the house collapses, one seeks an exit among the heaps of ruins.

en: Now, what do you want with me?”
vi: Now, what do you want from me? −
tr: Now tell me, what do you want from me?"
es: Having made these warnings, which you should not lose sight of, tell me what you want from me.

en: “Not very much.
vi: Not much.
tr: "It's not much.
es: —Very little.

en: You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?”
vi: You are the warden at the Conciergerie, right?
tr: You are a guard at the Conciergerie, aren't you?"
es: Aren't you the jailer of the Ministry?

en: “I tell you once for all, there is no such thing as an escape possible,” said the spy, firmly.
vi: − I'm telling you plainly, there's no chance of escape from there, - the spy asserted.
tr: "I'm telling you for the first and last time, it's impossible to escape from there," said the spy with a firm attitude.
es: —Instead of answering your question, I will tell you that there is no possible escape—replied the spy with determination.

en: “Why need you tell me what I have not asked?
vi: − Why are you talking about something I didn't ask?
tr: "Why are you telling me something I didn't ask you about?
es: —And I demand that you answer what I just asked.

en: You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?”
vi: Are you the jailer at the Conciergerie? −
tr: Are you a guard at the Conciergerie?"
es: —I am sometimes.

en: “I am sometimes.”
vi: At times, I do that job.
tr: "Yes, sometimes."
es: —I am sometimes.

en: “You can be when you choose?”
vi: − When you need to, can you do that?
tr: "Can you do this whenever you want?"
es: —Can he be when he wants to?

en: “I can pass in and out when I choose.”
vi: − I can come and go whenever I want.
tr: "I can come and go as I please.""
es: —I can enter and leave the Concierge's office whenever I want.

en: Sydney Carton filled another glass with brandy, poured it slowly out upon the hearth, and watched it as it dropped.
vi: Sydney Carton poured another glass of strong liquor, then slowly spilled it onto the hearth, watching the liquid drip until it was empty.
tr: Sydney Carton filled another glass of cognac, then slowly poured it onto the base of the fireplace and watched it spill.
es: Carton filled another small glass of liquor, poured it drop by drop on the ground, and after a few moments of reflection said:

en: It being all spent, he said, rising:
vi: He stood up and said: −
tr: When it was all over, he stood up and said:
es: Carton filled another small glass of liquor, poured it drop by drop on the ground, and after a few moments of reflection said:

en: “So far, we have spoken before these two, because it was as well that the merits of the cards should not rest solely between you and me.
vi: We have been talking in front of these two because they also need to understand that the value of these cards is not just between you and me.
tr: "Up until now, we have spoken in front of these two people because the value of our cards needed to be known by others as well.
es: —Up to this point, we have spoken in the presence of these two gentlemen because it was convenient for me that someone, besides the two of us, should be aware of the value of the letters I have, but what remains is something that should stay between you and me.

en: Come into the dark room here, and let us have one final word alone.”
vi: Let's go into that dark room and have a final word in private.
tr: Now, come to that dark room so we can talk alone about my final words."
es: Accompany me to that room, where we will exchange the few remaining words.

en: CHAPTER
vi: Let's go into that dark room and have a final word in private.
tr: Now, come to that dark room so we can talk alone about my final words."
es: Accompany me to that room, where we will exchange the few remaining words.

en: IX.
vi: 9. Betting
tr: IX
es: IX.

en: The Game Made
vi: 9. Betting
tr: The Game Begins
es: THE GAME IS ON

en: While Sydney Carton and the Sheep of the prisons were in the adjoining dark room, speaking so low that not a sound was heard, mr Lorry looked at Jerry in considerable doubt and mistrust.
vi: While Sydney Carton and the prison sheep were in the dark room next door, talking so quietly that no sound could be heard, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry with apprehension and suspicion.
tr: While Sydney Carton and the prison lamb were talking in the dark room next door, in a voice so low that no one could hear, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry with evident suspicion and distrust.
es: While Sydney Carton and the executioner's blackbird, locked in the adjoining room, conferred in such low voices that not the slightest sound filtered through the door's cracks, Lorry watched Jeremiah Lapa with manifest suspicion and deep distrust.

en: That honest tradesman’s manner of receiving the look, did not inspire confidence; he changed the leg on which he rested, as often as if he had fifty of those limbs, and were trying them all; he examined his finger-nails with a very questionable closeness of attention; and whenever mr Lorry’s eye caught his, he was taken with that peculiar kind of short cough requiring the hollow of a hand before it, which is seldom, if ever, known to be an infirmity attendant on perfect openness of character.
vi: The way the "honest businessman" reacted to Mr. Lorry's gaze only increased the suspicion; Jerry fidgeted as if he had fifty feet and was constantly trying to balance himself on each one; he examined his nails with suspiciously intense focus; whenever he caught Mr. Lorry's eye, he would cough to bring his palm to his mouth out of politeness, but this only added to his appearance of concealment and lack of straightforwardness.
tr: The response of this honest tradesman to these looks was not very reassuring either; he was frequently shifting his legs as if he had forty of them and was trying each one; he was examining his nails with quite a suspicious interest, and whenever he made eye contact with Mr. Lorry, he would cover his mouth with his hand as if struck by a strange coughing fit, which could not be seen as a very honest behavior.
es: It should be noted that the effect produced by the good banker's persistent gaze on the honest craftsman was not the most suitable for dispelling apprehensions; he shifted the leg on which the weight of his body rested as frequently as if he had fifty limbs and wished to test the sturdiness of each; he examined his nails with such scrupulous attention that it aroused suspicion, and whenever his eyes met Lorry's scrutinizing ones, he was seized by a fit of coughing that forced him to bring his hand to his mouth, a symptom that rarely, if ever, accompanies perfect frankness of character.

en: “Jerry,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Jerry, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Jerry," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Jeremiah! —exclaimed Lorry suddenly.

en: “Come here.”
vi: - Come here.
tr: "Come here.""
es: —Come here!

en: mr Cruncher came forward sideways, with one of his shoulders in advance of him.
vi: Cruncher moved his shoulder forward, walking sideways towards him.
tr: Mr. Cruncher came over, standing with one shoulder forward.
es: Lapa approached walking in the manner of a crab, that is, sideways.

en: “What have you been, besides a messenger?”
vi: − What did you do before when you were both a messenger for the company and something else?
tr: "What do you do besides carrying news?"
es: —What jobs have you had besides being a bank messenger?

en: After some cogitation, accompanied with an intent look at his patron, mr Cruncher conceived the luminous idea of replying, “Agicultooral character.”
vi: After a moment of pondering, accompanied by a fixed stare at his boss, Cruncher came up with a creative answer: − Doing manual labor.
tr: After thinking for a bit and looking carefully at his boss, Mr. Cruncher finally came up with the brilliant idea to say, "I am engaged in farming."
es: After a rather thorough meditation, and after seeking an illuminating idea in the fixed gaze of his superior, Lapa replied: —I have been a farmer.

en: “My mind misgives me much,” said mr Lorry, angrily shaking a forefinger at him, “that you have used the respectable and great house of Tellson’s as a blind, and that you have had an unlawful occupation of an infamous description.
vi: − I am very suspicious, - Mr. Lorry angrily waved his index finger in front of Cruncher, - daring to use the name and reputation of Tellson's Bank to cover up your vile illegal activities.
tr: "This matter has upset me," said Mr. Lorry, shaking his index finger at him angrily, "because you have engaged in disgraceful illegal activities hiding behind the respectable and grand bank of Tellson.
es: —I harbor well-founded fears—replied Lorry, moving his hand with a fierce gesture—that you have been an errand man for the respectable Tellson's Bank to mislead, to have a screen that covered other occupations contrary to the Law, occupations simply infamous.

en: If you have, don’t expect me to befriend you when you get back to England.
vi: If so, don't expect me to remain friendly with you when we return to England.
tr: Don't think that I will help you when you return to England.
es: If so, do not expect any consideration from me as soon as we reach England; if so, do not expect me to keep the secret either.

en: If you have, don’t expect me to keep your secret.
vi: If so, don't expect me to stay silent about your actions.
tr: Don't ever think that I will keep this secret.
es: If so, do not expect any consideration from me as soon as we reach England; if so, do not expect me to keep the secret either.

en: Tellson’s shall not be imposed upon.”
vi: Don't hope to exploit Tellson's Bank any further.
tr: Tellson can never be misused in such a way."
es: Tellson must know it, and they will know it.

en: “I hope, sir,” pleaded the abashed mr Cruncher, “that a gentleman like yourself wot I’ve had the honour of odd jobbing till I’m grey at it, would think twice about harming of me, even if it wos so—I don’t say it is, but even if it wos.
vi: − Sir, - Cruncher pleaded nervously, - a nobleman like you, for whom I have had the fortune of doing odd jobs until now, please don't harm me in haste, even if it is true... I'm not saying that you are telling the truth, but let's suppose it is so.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, whose face turned red with shame, began to plead, "I hope, sir," he said, "that a gentleman like you, whom I have had the honor of working for until my hair turned gray, would think twice before harming me, even if I did such a thing, not that I am saying I did, but if I had."
es: —I cannot believe, sir,—replied Lapa humbly—that a gentleman like you, a gentleman in whose service I have grown old, would decide to cause me such considerable harm without thinking it over very well first..., even if what you suspect were true.

en: And which it is to be took into account that if it wos, it wouldn’t, even then, be all o’ one side.
vi: But you must reconsider that even if you are telling the truth, it's not just me involved.
tr: And if I had done it, there would be an explanation for it.
es: I am not saying that it is; but if it were, I would always trust that you would not treat me so badly.

en: There’d be two sides to it.
vi: It's a matter of both sides.
tr: One must look at it from both sides.
es: Assuming that it were what you fear, even then the matter would have to be studied from two points of view, since it does not have just one, but two.

en: There might be medical doctors at the present hour, a picking up their guineas where a honest tradesman don’t pick up his fardens—fardens!
vi: At this moment, there are doctors making a lot of money while an honest worker struggles to earn a few pennies...
tr: Right now, while doctors are filling their pockets with guineas, an honest tradesman might be shooting at a penny –not a single penny going into his pocket!
es: There are doctors in medicine, and not a few, who find gold guineas where an honest tradesman finds nothing but miserable pennies...

en: no, nor yet his half fardens—half fardens!
vi: Pennies! No, they can't even earn half a penny... Half a penny!
tr: Nothing at all, not even half a penny –penniless men!
es: Not even pennies!

en: no, nor yet his quarter—a banking away like smoke at Tellson’s, and a cocking their medical eyes at that tradesman on the sly, a going in and going out to their own carriages—ah!
vi: No, even earning a quarter of a penny is difficult...
tr: No, not even a quarter penny –while those men are slipping in and out of Tellson's like they are looting from a fire, giving the honest tradesman a sidelong glance as they pass by, getting into their carriages, getting out of their carriages –ah!
es: Half pennies...

en: equally like smoke, if not more so.
vi: Those doctors borrow carriages and rush to Tellson's as fast as smoke or even faster, secretly winking at the worker...
tr: just like looting from a fire.
es: And not even half pennies; quarter pennies... and that's generous.

en: Well, that ’ud be imposing, too, on Tellson’s.
vi: Well, that's also taking advantage of Tellson's, sir.
tr: Aren't they using Tellson's too?
es: And what do you say about those who enter and leave Tellson's Bank, passing by the honest tradesman who is sitting by the door on an old stool, while they ride in luxurious carriages?

en: For you cannot sarse the goose and not the gander.
vi: You can't treat people differently based on their appearance.
tr: These things should not be overlooked.
es: Isn't it a sight to awaken the most dormant appetite?

en: And here’s ms Cruncher, or leastways wos in the Old England times, and would be to-morrow, if cause given, a floppin’ again the business to that degree as is ruinating—stark ruinating!
vi: And then there's my wife, Mrs. Cruncher, not now but at least back in England and probably in the future too, she would just sit down and curse, so I couldn't do any business... always running into bad luck!
tr: I have a wife, I mean I had one when I was in England, and I hope I will have one in the future, a woman who prays morning and night, to the point of being tiresome –and what prayers!
es: Add to all that the presence in England of a Mrs. Lapa who spends day and night on her knees praying to ruin all her husband's business, while the wives of the doctors and those who ride in luxurious carriages pray for the prosperity of their respective households.

en: Whereas them medical doctors’ wives don’t flop—catch ’em at it!
vi: At that time, the wives of those doctors didn't curse their husbands... they consumed everything!
tr: But they, they don't even compare to the doctors' wives –have you ever seen them?
es: Add to all that the presence in England of a Mrs. Lapa who spends day and night on her knees praying to ruin all her husband's business, while the wives of the doctors and those who ride in luxurious carriages pray for the prosperity of their respective households.

en: Or, if they flop, their floppings goes in favour of more patients, and how can you rightly have one without t’other?
vi: And if they did sit down, they would curse for more people to get sick so their husbands would have more work, is it wrong for me but right for them?
tr: Or if they do pray, it's for more patients to come, so how can you fully understand one side without looking at the other?
es: Add to all that the presence in England of a Mrs. Lapa who spends day and night on her knees praying to ruin all her husband's business, while the wives of the doctors and those who ride in luxurious carriages pray for the prosperity of their respective households.

en: Then, wot with undertakers, and wot with parish clerks, and wot with sextons, and wot with private watchmen (all awaricious and all in it), a man wouldn’t get much by it, even if it wos so.
vi: Then there's the need to bribe the undertakers, the parish wardens, the gravediggers, the cemetery keepers, all of them are equally greedy, so how much can an honest worker make, even if it is true.
tr: Then even if that were the case, among all those undertakers, church clerks, gravediggers, and private guards (by the way, they are all greedy and all involved in it), what falls to men like us?
es: Another thing; if what you suspect were true, which I am not saying it is, do you think I would become very rich by taking the leftovers from the undertakers, what the sacristans didn't want, what the cemetery watchmen scorned?

en: And wot little a man did get, would never prosper with him, mr Lorry.
vi: Even if they earn a little, it's not enough to prosper, Mr. Lorry.
tr: So even if a person deals with such things, he doesn't get much out of it, Mr. Lorry.
es: No, Mr. Lorry, no!

en: He’d never have no good of it; he’d want all along to be out of the line, if he, could see his way out, being once in—even if it wos so.”
vi: It's not a pleasant job, sir; anyone who falls into that job would want to leave if they had the chance to change... the job you're talking about.
tr: He sees no benefit; and once he gets involved, if he could foresee it, he would always want to get out of this path –I mean, if I had done it, that's how it would be."
es: It's a lost trade; believe me.

en: “Ugh!” cried mr Lorry, rather relenting, nevertheless, “I am shocked at the sight of you.”
vi: − Oh! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, his voice somewhat softening. - You are truly terrible.
tr: "Off!" shouted Mr. Lorry, though he had softened a bit. "I am amazed as I look at you."
es: —Ugh! —exclaimed Lorry—You horrify me!

en: “Now, what I would humbly offer to you, sir,” pursued mr Cruncher, “even if it wos so, which I don’t say it is—”
vi: − So, sir, I beg you, - Cruncher still tried to say, - that matter, I will not speak of it...
tr: "Now sir, the thing that I will presumptuously propose to you," continued Mr. Cruncher, "even if there were such a thing, which I am not saying there is..."
es: —The offer that I humbly dare to make to you, even if what you suspect were true, which I am not saying it is, is...

en: “Don’t prevaricate,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − Don't beat around the bush anymore, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Don't drag it out," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Don't come with lies!

en: “No, I will not, sir,” returned mr Crunches as if nothing were further from his thoughts or practice—“which I don’t say it is—wot I would humbly offer to you, sir, would be this.
vi: − No, I will not do it anymore, sir, - Cruncher kept speaking according to his thoughts and habits. - I will not reveal... the matter I beg of you is this.
tr: "No, I'm not prolonging it," replied Mr. Cruncher as if he were just about to express exactly what was on his mind or his proposal –"I'm not saying that –but if that's the case, what I would presumptuously offer you, sir, is this:
es: —No, sir; I will speak truthfully.

en: Upon that there stool, at that there Bar, sets that there boy of mine, brought up and growed up to be a man, wot will errand you, message you, general-light-job you, till your heels is where your head is, if such should be your wishes.
vi: Sitting on that chair, at the Temple gate, is my son, I have raised him to adulthood, he will run errands for you, work for you, do everything you command until death, if you wish.
tr: Over there on the stool, you know the boy sitting by the Bar, that's my son, he's hardworking, he's good, if you want, he can do your errands, carry letters, handle your daily small tasks.
es: The humble offer I wish to make is the following: on the bench placed on the sidewalk of the Tribunal, my son, who is almost a man, will sit, run errands, keep watch, and strive to perform the duties that I have carried out until now, if you so wish.

en: If it wos so, which I still don’t say it is (for I will not prewaricate to you, sir), let that there boy keep his father’s place, and take care of his mother; don’t blow upon that boy’s father—do not do it, sir—and let that father go into the line of the reg’lar diggin’, and make amends for what he would have undug—if it wos so—by diggin’ of ’em in with a will, and with conwictions respectin’ the futur’ keepin’ of ’em safe.
vi: That matter, I will not speak of it, because I will not beat around the bush with you anymore, sir, please let that boy take his father's place, take care of his mother, please do not accuse his father... do not do that, sir... and please let his father go to work digging graves properly to make up for what he should not have dug... that matter, and I will perform the burial properly and decently from now on.
tr: If that's the case, which I still say it isn't (because I don't want to prolong the matter, sir), let that boy take his father's place and look after his mother; have pity on that boy's father –don't do it, sir– and let his father become an ordinary gravedigger and give up grave robbing –if this is true– and with this wish and belief, he would honor and protect the future of the dead, how wonderful.
es: If what you fear were true, which I am not saying it is, nor that it isn't, because I do not want to lie to you, give my son his father's position and let him take care of his mother at the same time, and meanwhile, let the father be free to dig the earth as he pleases.

en: That, mr Lorry,” said mr Cruncher, wiping his forehead with his arm, as an announcement that he had arrived at the peroration of his discourse, “is wot I would respectfully offer to you, sir.
vi: That's it, Mr. Lorry, - Cruncher said while wiping his forehead, as a way of declaring that he had reached the end of his speech, - that is what I respectfully present to you.
tr: That's my offer to you, Mr. Lorry," said Mr. Cruncher, wiping his forehead with his arm as if to indicate he had reached the end of his speech, "that was my offer, sir.
es: That is, Mr. Lorry—added Lapa, wiping the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand,—what I wish to offer you.

en: A man don’t see all this here a goin’ on dreadful round him, in the way of Subjects without heads, dear me, plentiful enough fur to bring the price down to porterage and hardly that, without havin’ his serious thoughts of things.
vi: With so many terrible things happening around like this, anyone who sees it must think carefully, oh my, just seeing so many citizens losing their heads is enough to know that the wages for porters have dropped drastically.
tr: People don't ever think about the terrible things happening around them, just look, citizens with their heads chopped off, oh there are so many of them, porters are everywhere.
es: That is, Mr. Lorry—added Lapa, wiping the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand,—what I wish to offer you.

en: And these here would be mine, if it wos so, entreatin’ of you fur to bear in mind that wot I said just now, I up and said in the good cause when I might have kep’ it back.”
vi: And I also ask you to remember the recent matter, that matter, those things I said earlier to expose that guy, I helped Mr. Carton when I could have said nothing at all.
tr: That's what I would have to say, if the situation were as you said, I would beg you not to forget what I said and I would do it all for a good cause, otherwise, I might not have said any of this at all."
es: That is, Mr. Lorry—added Lapa, wiping the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand,—what I wish to offer you.

en: “That at least is true,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − At least this is true, - Mr. Lorry said. -
tr: "At least this is true," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Quiet, Jeremías!

en: “Say no more now.
vi: Now don't say anything more.
tr: "Don't say anything else anymore.
es: Quiet, and don't say another word!

en: It may be that I shall yet stand your friend, if you deserve it, and repent in action—not in words.
vi: Perhaps I would still be close to you, if you were worthy, and repented through actions... not words.
tr: If this is what you deserve and you show your remorse through your actions – not just words – I might be able to help you.
es: Who knows if I will decide to treat you as I have until now, if with actions, not words, you show me your repentance.

en: I want no more words.”
vi: I don't want to hear another word.
tr: Don't say anything else anymore."
es: Words, I do not want them; they do not convince me.

en: mr Cruncher knuckled his forehead, as Sydney Carton and the spy returned from the dark room.
vi: Cruncher tapped his forehead as Sydney Carton and the spy emerged from the dark room. − Goodbye, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was rubbing his forehead with his fingers when Sydney Carton and the spy came from the dark room.
es: Carton and Barsad left at that moment.

en: “Adieu, mr Barsad,” said the former; “our arrangement thus made, you have nothing to fear from me.”
vi: - Since we have agreed, you have nothing to fear from me anymore.
tr: "Adieu Mr. Barsad," said Carton; "now that we have an agreement, you have no reason to fear me."
es: —Goodbye, Barsad—said the first;—we have an understanding. Have no fear of me.

en: He sat down in a chair on the hearth, over against mr Lorry.
vi: He sat down on the chair by the fireplace, facing Mr. Lorry as before.
tr: She sat in a chair next to the fireplace, directly across from Mr. Lorry.
es: He took a seat next to Lorry, who asked him.

en: When they were alone, mr Lorry asked him what he had done?
vi: When only they were left, Mr. Lorry asked what he had done? −
tr: When they were alone, Mr. Lorry asked her what she was doing.
es: He took a seat next to Lorry, who asked him.

en: “Not much.
vi: Not much.
tr: "There isn't much.
es: —What have they done?

en: If it should go ill with the prisoner, I have ensured access to him, once.”
vi: If something unfortunate happened to Darnay, I had ensured a way to see him once in prison.
tr: If the prisoner gets into trouble, I said I would make sure he is reached."
es: —Not much; if the prisoner's fate becomes uncertain, they will allow me to visit him; nothing more.

en: mr Lorry’s countenance fell.
vi: Mr. Lorry's face darkened.
tr: Mr. Lorry's face fell.
es: Lorry's discouragement deepened.

en: “It is all I could do,” said Carton.
vi: − I can only do this much. - Carton said.
tr: "This is all I can do," said Carton.
es: —I can do no more—replied Carton.

en: “To propose too much, would be to put this man’s head under the axe, and, as he himself said, nothing worse could happen to him if he were denounced.
vi: - Excessive demands would get this person sent to the guillotine, and as he himself said, if he were to be denounced, he would die just the same.
tr: "Asking for more would mean putting the man's head under the guillotine, and as he said, being reported would be his end.
es: —Asking too much would be equivalent to sending that man to the guillotine, and, as he very well said, no greater misfortune could befall him even if we betrayed him.

en: It was obviously the weakness of the position.
vi: Clearly, this is a weak point in my position.
tr: That's what makes it difficult.
es: Let us be thankful for the precariousness of his position, for otherwise, we would have achieved nothing.

en: There is no help for it.”
vi: There's nothing else to be done.
tr: There's nothing to be done."
es: —But reaching him, in the event that he is condemned, is not saving him—objected Lorry.

en: “But access to him,” said mr Lorry, “if it should go ill before the Tribunal, will not save him.”
vi: − But the matter of meeting Darnay, - Mr. Lorry said, - if something unfortunate happens in court, it won't save him.
tr: "But if things go wrong before the trial," said Mr. Lorry, "reaching him won't be enough to save him.""
es: —But reaching him, in the event that he is condemned, is not saving him—objected Lorry.

en: “I never said it would.”
vi: − I did not say that at all.
tr: "I didn't say we could save it either."
es: —I never said I would save him—replied Carton.

en: mr Lorry’s eyes gradually sought the fire; his sympathy with his darling, and the heavy disappointment of his second arrest, gradually weakened them; he was an old man now, overborne with anxiety of late, and his tears fell.
vi: Mr. Lorry's eyes slowly turned towards the fire; the love he had for Lucie and the profound disappointment when Darnay was arrested again had left his eyes vacant; he was now an old man, recently having endured excessive worries, and tears streamed down his cheeks.
tr: Mr. Lorry's gaze slowly drifted towards the fire; his love for the one and only Lucie and the heavy disappointment brought by this second arrest had weakened him; now he was an old man, crushed under the weight of recent troubles, drowned in tears.
es: Lorry's eyes gradually sought the fire burning in the fireplace. The pain caused by the second imprisonment of the husband of the girl he loved so much drained all his energy. He was no longer a young man, despite his many years; he was an old man crushed by anxiety. The tears stored in his chest rose to his eyes and rolled silently down his wrinkled cheeks.

en: “You are a good man and a true friend,” said Carton, in an altered voice.
vi: − You are a kind-hearted man and a sincere friend, - Carton said, changing his tone.
tr: "You are a good man and a true friend," said Carton, in a different tone of voice.
es: —You have a great heart and are a loyal friend to your friends—said Carton with a disturbed voice.

en: “Forgive me if I notice that you are affected.
vi: - Please forgive me for seeing you so emotional.
tr: "Forgive me for giving you such bad news.
es: —Forgive me if I have been the bearer of news that has affected you so painfully.

en: I could not see my father weep, and sit by, careless.
vi: If you were my father, I could not sit by and watch my father cry without caring.
tr: If I saw my father crying, I couldn't sit idly by, and if you were my father, I couldn't show more respect to your sorrow than I do now.
es: It would be impossible for me to see my father cry and remain calm, and I swear to you that I respect your pain no less than I would respect my father's.

en: And I could not respect your sorrow more, if you were my father.
vi: I respect your suffering as if it were my own father's.
tr: If I saw my father crying, I couldn't sit idly by, and if you were my father, I couldn't show more respect to your sorrow than I do now.
es: It would be impossible for me to see my father cry and remain calm, and I swear to you that I respect your pain no less than I would respect my father's.

en: You are free from that misfortune, however.”
vi: But fortunately for you, I am not your son.
tr: But fortunately, you have not had the misfortune of being my father."
es: So much respect, so much interest, so much feeling was in the tone and expression of the words that are transcribed, that Lorry, who had not had the opportunity to appreciate the good side of Carton, experienced one of the greatest surprises of his life.

en: Though he said the last words, with a slip into his usual manner, there was a true feeling and respect both in his tone and in his touch, that mr Lorry, who had never seen the better side of him, was wholly unprepared for.
vi: Even though he spoke the last sentence with the same indifferent attitude as before, his tone and emotions were still full of affection and respect to the extent that Mr. Lorry was completely surprised because he had never seen him express himself in such a way.
tr: Despite saying his final words in his usual manner, there was a sincere feeling and respect both in his tone of voice and in his touch, and Mr. Lorry, who had never seen this good side of him before, was completely caught off guard.
es: So much respect, so much interest, so much feeling was in the tone and expression of the words that are transcribed, that Lorry, who had not had the opportunity to appreciate the good side of Carton, experienced one of the greatest surprises of his life.

en: He gave him his hand, and Carton gently pressed it.
vi: He extended his hand to Carton, and he gently grasped it.
tr: He extended his hand to him, and Carton gently shook it.
es: He silently extended a hand to his interlocutor, who shook it warmly.

en: “To return to poor Darnay,” said Carton.
vi: − Returning to poor Darnay's matter, - Carton said.
tr: "Returning to poor Darnay," said Carton.
es: —Returning to poor Darnay—replied Carton,—I will say that it is not convenient for you to speak to your wife about the conference we just had, nor about what I have obtained from the spy.

en: “Don’t tell Her of this interview, or this arrangement.
vi: - Please do not let Lucie know about this exchange, or this agreement.
tr: "Do not mention this meeting or this arrangement to his wife.
es: —Returning to poor Darnay—replied Carton,—I will say that it is not convenient for you to speak to your wife about the conference we just had, nor about what I have obtained from the spy.

en: It would not enable Her to go to see him.
vi: She cannot possibly go to see Darnay.
tr: This will not enable her to see her husband.
es: She could not reach the dungeon, and if she knew that I was going, she might think that my intention was to provide her husband with the means to advance the execution of the sentence.

en: She might think it was contrived, in case of the worse, to convey to him the means of anticipating the sentence.”
vi: She might think that this is a plan so that in the worst case, he would be given a means to commit suicide before being taken to the guillotine.
tr: She might think that this plan, at worst, was made to bring the necessary things for him to carry out his own execution."
es: She could not reach the dungeon, and if she knew that I was going, she might think that my intention was to provide her husband with the means to advance the execution of the sentence.

en: mr Lorry had not thought of that, and he looked quickly at Carton to see if it were in his mind.
vi: Mr. Lorry did not think of that at all, and quickly glanced towards Carton to see if he really thought so.
tr: Mr. Lorry had never thought of this and quickly looked at Carton to see if such a thing had occurred to him.
es: Lorry had not thought of it, who upon hearing the previous words, quickly turned his eyes towards Carton, as if to ascertain whether what he did not want Lucía to think was precisely what he had in mind.

en: It seemed to be; he returned the look, and evidently understood it.
vi: It seemed true; he returned Mr. Lorry's look and clearly understood the meaning.
tr: It seemed it had; this was plainly evident from Carton's expression.
es: Lorry had not thought of it, who upon hearing the previous words, quickly turned his eyes towards Carton, as if to ascertain whether what he did not want Lucía to think was precisely what he had in mind.

en: “She might think a thousand things,” Carton said, “and any of them would only add to her trouble.
vi: − She can imagine a thousand things, - Carton said, - and each one only makes her more miserable.
tr: "Thousands of things might come to Lucie's mind," said Carton, "and each one of them would only increase her distress.
es: —Perhaps she would think that—added Carton,—and she might suspect a thousand other things, each of which would be an added torture to those already besieging her.

en: Don’t speak of me to her.
vi: Don't tell her about me.
tr: Do not mention me to her.
es: Do not even speak to her about me.

en: As I said to you when I first came, I had better not see her.
vi: As I told you when I first came here, it's best that I don't meet her.
tr: As I said when I first came, it is better if I do not see her.
es: As I told you upon arriving in Paris, I will not see her; it is best that I do not see her.

en: I can put my hand out, to do any little helpful work for her that my hand can find to do, without that.
vi: I can still do anything useful for Lucie within my ability without having to meet her.
tr: I can do everything I can without seeing her.
es: Whatever I can do for her, I will do better by not seeing her.

en: You are going to her, I hope?
vi: You're going to Lucie's house, aren't you? I hope so.
tr: You are going to her now, aren't you?
es: Are you going to visit her now?

en: She must be very desolate to-night.”
vi: She must be very desperate tonight.
tr: She must be in a wretched state tonight."
es: Go as soon as possible, yes, for tonight she must be in despair.

en: “I am going now, directly.”
vi: − I'm going now, right away.
tr: "Now I will go directly to him.""
es: —I'm going right now.

en: “I am glad of that.
vi: − Then I am very glad.
tr: "I'm glad to hear that.
es: —Which makes me very happy.

en: She has such a strong attachment to you and reliance on you.
vi: She is extremely attached to and trusts you.
tr: He is very attached to you and trusts you.
es: He loves you very much and has limitless confidence in you.

en: How does she look?”
vi: How does she look now, I wonder?
tr: How does he look?"
es: How is he now?

en: “Anxious and unhappy, but very beautiful.”
vi: − Worried and distressed, but very beautiful.
tr: "Anxious and unhappy, but very beautiful."
es: —Swimming in a dreadful sea of anxieties, but beautiful as always.

en: “Ah!”
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Ahh!"
es: —Ah!

en: It was a long, grieving sound, like a sigh—almost like a sob.
vi: A prolonged, sorrowful sound, like a sigh - almost like a sob.
tr: It was a long and sorrowful sound, like a sigh – almost like a sob.
es: It was a deep, long exclamation, similar to a groan, to a stifled sob.

en: It attracted mr Lorry’s eyes to Carton’s face, which was turned to the fire.
vi: The utterance made Mr. Lorry attentively look at Carton's face, which was turned towards the firelight.
tr: Mr. Lorry turned his eyes to Carton, whose face was turned toward the fire, at the sound.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: A light, or a shade (the old gentleman could not have said which), passed from it as swiftly as a change will sweep over a hill-side on a wild bright day, and he lifted his foot to put back one of the little flaming logs, which was tumbling forward.
vi: The light, or the darkness (the old man couldn't determine), was swiftly passing over Carton's face like patches of light and shadow sweeping quickly over a hillside on a bright sunny day, and he lifted a foot to push a small burning log, causing it to tumble into the fireplace.
tr: On a bright sunny day, a light or shadow passed quickly over Carton's face, like a broken coin rolling downhill, and he extended his foot to push back a burning log that had rolled forward.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: He wore the white riding-coat and top-boots, then in vogue, and the light of the fire touching their light surfaces made him look very pale, with his long brown hair, all untrimmed, hanging loose about him.
vi: He wore a white coat and high boots, which were in fashion: the firelight reflecting off his light-colored attire made him appear even more pale under his long, disheveled brown hair.
tr: He was wearing a white riding jacket, which was fashionable at the time, and long boots, and the light from the fire reflecting off his clothes made him look quite pale, while his long, disheveled brown hair was untied.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: His indifference to fire was sufficiently remarkable to elicit a word of remonstrance from mr Lorry; his boot was still upon the hot embers of the flaming log, when it had broken under the weight of his foot.
vi: His indifference to the fire was enough to prompt Mr. Lorry to utter a reminder; his boot was still placed on the glowing embers of the burning log as it crumbled under the weight of his foot.
tr: Carton was so indifferent to the fire that Mr. Lorry couldn't help but warn him; for when the burning log broke under the weight of his foot, Carton's booted foot was still standing on its hot embers.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: “I forgot it,” he said.
vi: − I forgot, - he said.
tr: "I forgot," said Carton.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: mr Lorry’s eyes were again attracted to his face.
vi: Mr. Lorry's eyes once again looked up at his face.
tr: Mr. Lorry's eyes again drifted to the young man's face.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: Taking note of the wasted air which clouded the naturally handsome features, and having the expression of prisoners’ faces fresh in his mind, he was strongly reminded of that expression.
vi: Noticing the weariness that covered Carton's once delicate features, he immediately recalled the face of the prisoner still etched deeply in his mind.
tr: He noticed the air of wasted potential that overshadowed his naturally handsome features and the expression on his face reminded him of the expressions on the faces of the prisoners he had recently seen.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: “And your duties here have drawn to an end, sir?” said Carton, turning to him.
vi: − Has your work here almost finished? - Carton said as he turned to look at him.
tr: Turning to him, Carton asked, "Have you finished your duties here, sir?"
es: —Have you already finished the task that brought you here?—asked Carton after a few brief seconds.

en: “Yes.
vi: − It's done.
tr: "Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: As I was telling you last night when Lucie came in so unexpectedly, I have at length done all that I can do here.
vi: As I was telling you last night when Lucie came here suddenly, I finally finished what needed to be done here.
tr: As I explained last night when Lucie arrived unexpectedly, I did everything I could here.
es: As I was telling you last night, when Lucía arrived so unexpectedly, I have done everything that could be done.

en: I hoped to have left them in perfect safety, and then to have quitted Paris.
vi: I hope they will stay here in complete peace, then I will bid farewell to Paris.
tr: I was hoping to leave Paris, leaving them here safely.
es: I only hoped to see you safe from danger and happy before leaving Paris.

en: I have my Leave to Pass.
vi: I have a pass.
tr: I have my exit document.
es: I was planning to leave very soon; but...

en: I was ready to go.”
vi: I am ready to leave.
tr: I was ready to go."
es: I was planning to leave very soon; but...

en: They were both silent.
vi: Both were silent.
tr: They were both silent.
es: Both remained silent.

en: “Yours is a long life to look back upon, sir?” said Carton, wistfully.
vi: − You have a whole long life to look back on, don't you? - Carton said, thoughtfully.
tr: "You are a person who has seen and experienced a lot, aren't you, sir?" said Carton thoughtfully.
es: —Long is the book of his life, Mr. Lorry, isn't it?—asked Carton, undoubtedly just to say something.

en: “I am in my seventy-eighth year.”
vi: − I am already seventy-eight years old.
tr: "I am seventy-eight years old.""
es: —I have turned seventy-eight years old.

en: “You have been useful all your life; steadily and constantly occupied; trusted, respected, and looked up to?”
vi: − You have had a useful life, always stable and busy; trusted; respected; and admired.
tr: "Throughout your life, you have always done useful things; you have always worked; you have become a person whom everyone trusts, respects, and values, right?"
es: —Seventy-eight well-spent years; seventy-eight years during which he has been useful to his fellow men and respected by them; eh?

en: “I have been a man of business, ever since I have been a man.
vi: − Since I became an adult, I have only known how to do business.
tr: "I have been a businessman for as long as I can remember.
es: —Almost since I can remember, I have been involved in business; without exaggeration, I can say that, since I was a boy, I have been a businessman.

en: Indeed, I may say that I was a man of business when a boy.”
vi: In fact, I can say that I've been doing business since I was young.
tr: I can say that I was involved in the business world even as a child."
es: —Almost since I can remember, I have been involved in business; without exaggeration, I can say that, since I was a boy, I have been a businessman.

en: “See what a place you fill at seventy-eight.
vi: − Look at you, at seventy-eight years old, and the company still needs you so much.
tr: "Do you see, at seventy-eight years old, how much space you occupy in this world.
es: —His diligence has earned him an enviable position.

en: How many people will miss you when you leave it empty!”
vi: How many people will remember you when you are gone! −
tr: There will be many people who will look for you in your absence."
es: How many will miss him when he leaves that position vacant!

en: “A solitary old bachelor,” answered mr Lorry, shaking his head.
vi: An old, lonely bachelor, - Mr. Lorry replied, shaking his head.
tr: "I am an old man with no one," replied Mr. Lorry, shaking his head from side to side.
es: "Don't believe it," replied Lorry, shaking his head.

en: “There is nobody to weep for me.”
vi: No one will mourn me.
tr: "There is no one to mourn for me.""
es: "Who would shed a tear for the memory of an old and lonely bachelor like me?"

en: “How can you say that?
vi: − How can you say that?
tr: "How can you say this?
es: —Don't say that!

en: Wouldn’t She weep for you?
vi: Wouldn't Lucie cry for you?
tr: Doesn't Lucie cry for you?
es: Won't she cry for you?

en: Wouldn’t her child?”
vi: And her child too? −
tr: Doesn't her child cry too?"
es: Won't your daughter cry?

en: “Yes, yes, thank God.
vi: Yes, yes, thank God.
tr: "Yes, yes, thank God they exist.
es: —Yes... yes... They will cry... Thank God!

en: I didn’t quite mean what I said.”
vi: That's not exactly what I meant.
tr: That's not exactly what I meant."
es: Excuse me; I didn't know what I was saying.

en: “It is a thing to thank God for; is it not?”
vi: − That is something to be thankful to God for, isn't it? −
tr: "This is something to be thankful to God for, isn't it?"
es: —It is a comfort that well deserves to be thanked to God for; isn't it true?

en: “Surely, surely.”
vi: Surely it is.
tr: "Of course.""
es: —A lot, yes... agreed.

en: “If you could say, with truth, to your own solitary heart, to-night, ‘I have secured to myself the love and attachment, the gratitude or respect, of no human creature; I have won myself a tender place in no regard; I have done nothing good or serviceable to be remembered by!’ your seventy-eight years would be seventy-eight heavy curses; would they not?”
vi: − If tonight, you can honestly say to your lonely heart, "no one has ever loved, cherished, been grateful to, or respected me; no one has shown me any affection; I haven't done anything good or useful for anyone to remember me by!", if so, then your seventy-eight years of life would be seventy-eight curses, wouldn't they? −
tr: "If tonight you could turn to your lonely heart and honestly say, 'In this life, I have neither gained anyone's love, nor loyalty, nor gratitude, nor respect; I have not secured a compassionate place in any way; I have not done any good or been of any benefit to anyone that would be remembered!' this seventy-eight years would weigh upon you like a heavy curse; wouldn't it?"
es: —If tonight you could truthfully say the following words to yourself: "I have not managed to earn anyone's affection, esteem, gratitude, or respect; I have not succeeded in awakening echoes of sympathy in any human heart, I have done nothing good, nothing useful to my fellow men, nothing worthy of being remembered," your seventy-eight years of age would be seventy-eight thousand years of remorse; isn't that true?

en: “You say truly, mr Carton; I think they would be.”
vi: That's right, Mr. Carton; I think so.
tr: "You are right, Mr. Carton; it would probably be so."
es: —You are right, Carton; I think I would never get tired of cursing them.

en: Sydney turned his eyes again upon the fire, and, after a silence of a few moments, said:
vi: Sydney again looked towards the fireplace, and after a moment of silence he said: − I want to ask you...
tr: Sydney turned her eyes back to the fire and after a few minutes of silence, she said:
es: Carton fixed his gaze on the fire once again, remained thoughtful for a long time, and finally said:

en: “I should like to ask you:—Does your childhood seem far off?
vi: Your childhood must be a distant memory, right?
tr: "What I want to ask you is this: Does it feel like your childhood is far behind you?
es: —I would like to ask you another question; when you remember your childhood, do you find it too distant?

en: Do the days when you sat at your mother’s knee, seem days of very long ago?”
vi: The time when you sat on your mother's lap must be hazy?
tr: Do the days when you sat on your mother's lap seem very distant?"
es: Does it seem to you that a lot of time has passed since the happy days when you sat on your sweet mother's knees?

en: Responding to his softened manner, mr Lorry answered:
vi: In response to his sudden tenderness, Mr. Lorry replied: − Twenty years ago, yes; but at this age, no.
tr: Mr. Lorry replied to Carton's emotional state as follows:
es: Lorry, with a tone of voice made uncertain by the effect of the emotion that overwhelmed him, replied:

en: “Twenty years back, yes; at this time of my life, no.
vi: In response to his sudden tenderness, Mr. Lorry replied: − Twenty years ago, yes; but at this age, no.
tr: "Twenty years ago it seemed that way, yes; but at this stage of my life, no.
es: —Twenty years ago, yes; today, no.

en: For, as I draw closer and closer to the end, I travel in the circle, nearer and nearer to the beginning.
vi: Because, as I get closer to the final moment, I have completed the cycle, getting closer and closer to the starting point.
tr: Because I am getting closer to the end with each passing day, I am progressing towards the beginning by turning in a circle.
es: What happens to me is like someone traveling in a circle; they start by moving away from the starting point, but as they reach the end, they get closer and closer to the beginning.

en: It seems to be one of the kind smoothings and preparings of the way.
vi: It seems that this is how we slowly prepare for the end.
tr: It seems like a good method found to prepare ourselves for that long journey in a soft and calm manner.
es: What happens to me is like someone traveling in a circle; they start by moving away from the starting point, but as they reach the end, they get closer and closer to the beginning.

en: My heart is touched now, by many remembrances that had long fallen asleep, of my pretty young mother (and I so old!), and by many associations of the days when what we call the World was not so real with me, and my faults were not confirmed in me.”
vi: Our hearts now tremble with many long-forgotten memories of the beautiful young mother from before; because we are now too old!... And about many things related to that time, the time when the reality we call this world did not yet exist for us, and the mistakes within us had not yet become habits.
tr: The revival of many memories that have been dormant for a long time makes my heart ache, many memories of my young and beautiful mother (while I am so old!) and of those days when the thing called the world had a completely different meaning for me and my mistakes did not matter."
