es: Often today, tender memories long dormant awaken in my heart, often I see my saintly mother, so young, so beautiful... my mother very young and I very old... often I remember incidents from life that occurred when the world was not as real to me as it is today, nor had faults taken root in me.

en: “I understand the feeling!” exclaimed Carton, with a bright flush.
vi: − I understand that feeling! - Carton exclaimed, his face flushed with excitement. -
tr: "I can understand this feeling!" shouted Carton with sudden enthusiasm.
es: —I understand—exclaimed Carton, blushing deeply.

en: “And you are the better for it?”
vi: And does that make you feel better? −
tr: "Well, do these make you feel any better?"
es: —And those memories, far from leaving a bitter taste, will be pleasant for you, right?

en: “I hope so.”
vi: We hope so.
tr: "I guess.""
es: —Indeed; they give me a feeling of sweet sorrow.

en: Carton terminated the conversation here, by rising to help him on with his outer coat; “But you,” said mr Lorry, reverting to the theme, “you are young.”
vi: Carton ended the conversation by standing up and helping the old man put on his coat. − Like you, you are still young, - Mr. Lorry returned to that topic.
tr: Carton stood up to help Mr. Lorry put on his coat, ending the conversation, "But you," said the old man, returning to the subject again, "you are still young."
es: Carton helped his interlocutor put on the overcoat.

en: “Yes,” said Carton.
vi: − Yes, - Carton replied.
tr: "True," said Carton.
es: —You, on the other hand, are very young—replied Lorry, returning to the same topic.

en: “I am not old, but my young way was never the way to age.
vi: - I'm not old yet, but my youth was not the kind that allows for a peaceful old age.
tr: "I am not old, but the path I am on is not a good one for aging.
es: —Yes... I am not old; but my youthful paths were never the ones that lead to old age.

en: Enough of me.”
vi: That's enough about me.
tr: Anyway, let's forget about me."
es: —Yes... I am not old; but my youthful paths were never the ones that lead to old age.

en: “And of me, I am sure,” said mr Lorry.
vi: − About me, it's the same, no need to say more, - Mr. Lorry replied. -
tr: "Then let's forget about me as well," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Are you going out?—asked Lorry.

en: “Are you going out?”
vi: Are you going out?
tr: "Are you leaving?"
es: —Are you going out?—asked Lorry.

en: “I’ll walk with you to her gate.
vi: − I will take you to Miss Lucie's gate.
tr: "I will accompany you to Lucie's door.
es: —I will accompany you to the door of your house.

en: You know my vagabond and restless habits.
vi: You know my habit of not being able to sit still.
tr: You know how aimless and restless I am.
es: You already know my restless nature and my wandering habits, so if I spend many hours roaming aimlessly through those streets without returning home, rest assured, I will reappear if not today, then tomorrow.

en: If I should prowl about the streets a long time, don’t be uneasy; I shall reappear in the morning.
vi: If I wander outside for a long time, don't worry; I will reappear in the morning.
tr: If I wander the streets too much, don't worry; I'll be in front of you again in the morning.
es: You already know my restless nature and my wandering habits, so if I spend many hours roaming aimlessly through those streets without returning home, rest assured, I will reappear if not today, then tomorrow.

en: You go to the Court to-morrow?”
vi: Are you going to the court tomorrow? −
tr: Are you going to the trial tomorrow?"
es: Do you plan to attend the trial hearing tomorrow?

en: “Yes, unhappily.”
vi: Yes, unfortunately.
tr: "Yes, unfortunately.""
es: —With great pain in my soul, I will have to attend.

en: “I shall be there, but only as one of the crowd.
vi: − I will come too, but I will just stand in the crowd.
tr: "I will be there too, but only as one of the crowd.
es: —I will be there, but among the audience.

en: My Spy will find a place for me.
vi: My secret agent will find a spot for me.
tr: My spy will find me a place.
es: My spy will find me a seat...

en: Take my arm, sir.”
vi: Take my arm, sir.
tr: Take my arm, sir."
es: Would you like to take my arm?

en: mr Lorry did so, and they went down-stairs and out in the streets.
vi: Mr. Lorry followed, and they went downstairs and out to the street.
tr: Mr. Lorry did as Carton said, and the two of them went down the stairs and out into the street.
es: Arm in arm, they went down the stairs and out into the street.

en: A few minutes brought them to mr Lorry’s destination.
vi: In just a few minutes, they reached Mr. Lorry's destination.
tr: A few minutes later, they arrived at the place where Mr. Lorry was going.
es: Minutes later, they arrived in front of Dr. Manette's house, where they parted ways.

en: Carton left him there; but lingered at a little distance, and turned back to the gate again when it was shut, and touched it.
vi: Carton left him there; but lingered a little distance away, then returned when the gate had closed and touched the gate.
tr: Carton left him there; but after lingering a bit nearby, he returned and touched the door when it closed.
es: Lorry entered the house, and Carton walked away but only for a short time, as moments later, he returned to stand by the closed door.

en: He had heard of her going to the prison every day.
vi: He had heard about her going to the prison every day.
tr: He had heard that Lucie went to the prison every day.
es: —She goes out this way every day—Carton said to himself;—she takes that direction...

en: “She came out here,” he said, looking about him, “turned this way, must have trod on these stones often.
vi: − She went out from this place, - he said while looking around, - turned this way, and surely often walked on these paving stones.
tr: "She must have come out from here," he said, looking around, "then turned and walked over these stones.
es: How many times must she have stepped on those stones!...

en: Let me follow in her steps.”
vi: Let's follow her footsteps.
tr: Let me follow her steps."
es: I will follow her steps!

en: It was ten o’clock at night when he stood before the prison of La Force, where she had stood hundreds of times.
vi: It was ten o'clock at night when he arrived in front of La Force prison, where she had stood hundreds of times.
tr: When Carton arrived at La Force Prison, where Lucie had stood in front of hundreds of times, it was ten o'clock at night.
es: The city clocks were striking ten at night when Carton ended his walk in front of the grim walls of La Force prison.

en: A little wood-sawyer, having closed his shop, was smoking his pipe at his shop-door.
vi: The short carpenter had just closed his shop and was standing in the doorway smoking a pipe.
tr: A small, slight woodcutter had closed his shop and was smoking his pipe in front of his door.
es: A wood sawyer, after closing his workshop, was calmly smoking his pipe in front of his establishment.

en: “Good night, citizen,” said Sydney Carton, pausing in going by; for, the man eyed him inquisitively.
vi: − Hello, Citizen, - Sydney Carton greeted, stopping on his way; because this man was looking at him inquisitively.
tr: When he saw the man looking at him with curious eyes, he stopped and said, "Good evening, citizen," said Sydney Carton.
es: —Good evening, citizen—said Carton, noticing that the sawyer was giving him inquisitive looks.

en: “Good night, citizen.”
vi: Hello, Citizen.
tr: "Good night, citizen."
es: —Good evening, citizen.

en: “How goes the Republic?”
vi: − How is the Republic? −
tr: "How is the Republic going?"
es: —How is the Republic doing?

en: “You mean the Guillotine.
vi: You mean the guillotine?
tr: "I guess you meant guillotine.
es: —I suppose you are referring to the Guillotine...

en: Not ill.
vi: − Still going strong.
tr: Not bad.
es: It's not doing badly.

en: Sixty-three to-day.
vi: − Sixty-three heads today, soon it will quickly rise to a hundred.
tr: Sixty-three people went today.
es: Today sixty-three; we won't take long to reach a hundred per day.

en: We shall mount to a hundred soon.
vi: − Sixty-three heads today, soon it will quickly rise to a hundred.
tr: Soon we'll reach a hundred.
es: Today sixty-three; we won't take long to reach a hundred per day.

en: Samson and his men complain sometimes, of being exhausted.
vi: − Sometimes Samson and his men also complain of exhaustion. −
tr: Samson and his men sometimes complain of fatigue.
es: Sansón and his assistants complain that the work is excessive, that their strength is running out...

en: Ha, ha, ha!
vi: Ha, ha, ha!
tr: Ha, ha, ha!
es: Ha, ha, ha!

en: He is so droll, that Samson.
vi: That Samson is very humorous.
tr: What a strange man that Samson is.
es: How funny good Sansón is!

en: Such a Barber!”
vi: − A real skilled barber! −
tr: A true barber!"
es: Have you ever seen a busier barber in your life?

en: “Do you often go to see him—”
vi: Do you often see him... −
tr: "Do you go to see him often?"
es: —Do you see him often...?

en: “Shave?
vi: − Shaving?
tr: "Shaving?
es: —Shaving?

en: Always.
vi: I see it all the time.
tr: Always.
es: Every day...

en: Every day.
vi: Every day.
tr: Every day.
es: Every day...

en: What a barber!
vi: A real skilled barber!
tr: What a barber!
es: What a barber!

en: You have seen him at work?”
vi: Have you seen him work?
tr: Have you ever seen him at work?"
es: Have you ever seen him in action?

en: “Never.”
vi: − Never.
tr: "No, I have never seen it."
es: —Never.

en: “Go and see him when he has a good batch.
vi: − Go see when he has to shave a whole bunch.
tr: "When you have a group in your hand, you must go and see it.
es: —Well, don't forget to go see him when he has work to do. It's a delight to watch him work...

en: Figure this to yourself, citizen; he shaved the sixty-three to-day, in less than two pipes!
vi: Just imagine, Citizen; today he shaved sixty-three people, in the time it takes to smoke two pipes!
tr: Imagine, citizen; while I finished two pipes, the man beheaded sixty-three people today!
es: Just imagine, citizen; today, sixty-three in less than two hours...

en: Less than two pipes.
vi: Not even two pipes.
tr: I'm saying without smoking two pipes.
es: In less than two hours, word of honor!

en: Word of honour!”
vi: That's the honest truth!
tr: I swear on my honor!"
es: In less than two hours, word of honor!

en: As the grinning little man held out the pipe he was smoking, to explain how he timed the executioner, Carton was so sensible of a rising desire to strike the life out of him, that he turned away.
vi: While this short, grinning man extended his smoking pipe to explain how he timed the executioner, Carton turned away to suppress the rising urge to beat this man to death.
tr: As the grinning little man showed the pipe he was smoking to demonstrate how the executioner measured his speed, Carton felt such an unbearable urge to kill him right then and there that he turned around and walked away immediately.
es: Carton was so repulsed by the relish with which the sawyer described the executioner's tasks that he turned his back to avoid strangling him, as was his most fervent desire.

en: “But you are not English,” said the wood-sawyer, “though you wear English dress?”
vi: − But you're not English, - the woodcutter said, - even though you're dressed like an Englishman?
tr: "Even if you wear English clothes," said the sawyer, "you're not English, are you?"
es: —But you are not English, even though you dress like an Englishman, right?—asked the sawyer.

en: “Yes,” said Carton, pausing again, and answering over his shoulder.
vi: − Indeed, - Carton said, stopping again, answering over his shoulder.
tr: Carton stopped again and replied over his shoulder, "I am an Englishman."
es: —I am English—replied Carton, turning his head.

en: “You speak like a Frenchman.”
vi: − You speak French like a French person.
tr: "You speak like a French person."
es: —Well, you speak like a true Frenchman.

en: “I am an old student here.”
vi: − I used to study here before.
tr: "I used to be a student here."
es: —I was a student here.

en: “Aha, a perfect Frenchman!
vi: − Ah ha, just like the French!
tr: "Ah, you are just like a Frenchman!
es: —Ah...! Almost French, then.

en: Good night, Englishman.”
vi: Goodbye, Mr. Englishman.
tr: Good night, Englishman.""
es: Good night, Englishman.

en: “Good night, citizen.”
vi: − Goodbye, Citizen.
tr: "Good night, citizen."
es: —Good evening, citizen.

en: “But go and see that droll dog,” the little man persisted, calling after him.
vi: − But remember to go see that barber clown, - the little guy kept insisting. -
tr: Shouting after him, "But go and see that strange fellow," insisted the little man.
es: —Don't forget to go see our friend Samson.

en: “And take a pipe with you!”
vi: And remember to bring the pipe!
tr: "Don't forget to take a pipe with you!"
es: Carton moved away, but he had not gone far from the sawyer's workshop when he stopped under a streetlamp and wrote a few words with a pencil on a piece of paper.

en: Sydney had not gone far out of sight, when he stopped in the middle of the street under a glimmering lamp, and wrote with his pencil on a scrap of paper.
vi: Sydney hadn't gone far before he stopped right in the middle of the road under a flickering lamp and took out a pencil to write on a piece of paper.
tr: Sydney had not gone far when he stopped under a dim street lamp and wrote something on a small piece of paper with his pen.
es: Carton moved away, but he had not gone far from the sawyer's workshop when he stopped under a streetlamp and wrote a few words with a pencil on a piece of paper.

en: Then, traversing with the decided step of one who remembered the way well, several dark and dirty streets—much dirtier than usual, for the best public thoroughfares remained uncleansed in those times of terror—he stopped at a chemist’s shop, which the owner was closing with his own hands.
vi: Then, with the determined steps of someone familiar with the way, he crossed many dark and dirty streets - dirtier than usual because even the busiest main streets were not being cleaned during this time of terror. He stopped in front of a pharmacy, where the owner himself was closing up.
tr: Then, with the steps of someone who knew the way well, he zigzagged through many dark and dirty streets –the streets were much dirtier than usual, because even the busiest avenues had not been cleaned during the Reign of Terror– and stopped in front of a pharmacy, whose owner was about to close the shop with his own hands.
es: Then, crossing a number of dark and dirty streets with the determined step of someone who knows exactly where they are going, he stopped in front of a drugstore, whose door the druggist was closing at that moment.

en: A small, dim, crooked shop, kept in a tortuous, up-hill thoroughfare, by a small, dim, crooked man.
vi: A small, dim, gloomy shop, located on a winding road leading uphill, owned by a small, dim, gloomy man.
tr: The owner of this tiny, obscure, and crooked shop on a winding and busy slope was a tiny, obscure, and crooked man.
es: Then, crossing a number of dark and dirty streets with the determined step of someone who knows exactly where they are going, he stopped in front of a drugstore, whose door the druggist was closing at that moment.

en: Giving this citizen, too, good night, as he confronted him at his counter, he laid the scrap of paper before him.
vi: After greeting this Citizen, he went straight to the pharmacy counter and placed a piece of paper in front of him.
tr: He placed the small piece of paper in front of the citizen at the cardboard counter, saying good night to him as well.
es: After bidding goodnight to the druggist, whose appearance was as dirty and repugnant as the shop itself, he placed on the counter the piece of paper on which he had written with a pencil a short while ago.

en: “Whew!” the chemist whistled softly, as he read it.
vi: − Whew! - The apothecary owner softly whistled as he read the note. -
tr: When the pharmacist read this, he said, "Wow!" and let out a soft whistle:
es: —Damn!

en: “Hi! hi! hi!”
vi: Oh dear! Oh dear! Oh dear!
tr: "Whew! Whew! Whew!"
es: —exclaimed the druggist.

en: Sydney Carton took no heed, and the chemist said:
vi: - Seeing that Sydney Carton was uninterested, he continued to ask.
tr: Sydney Carton paid no attention to him, the pharmacist asked:
es: —Hee, hee, hee!

en: “For you, citizen?”
vi: For you, Citizen? −
tr: "Are these for you, citizen?"
es: Is it for you, citizen?

en: “For me.”
vi: For me.
tr: "For me."
es: —For me.

en: “You will be careful to keep them separate, citizen?
vi: − You must be careful to separate things, Citizen?
tr: "Put these in separate places, will you, citizen?
es: —Will you be careful to keep them separate, citizen?

en: You know the consequences of mixing them?”
vi: Do you know the consequences if they get mixed together?
tr: You know what happens if you mix them up, right?"
es: Do you know the consequences of mixing them?

en: “Perfectly.”
vi: − I know well.
tr: "I know very well.""
es: —Perfectly.

en: Certain small packets were made and given to him.
vi: The small packets were prepared and then handed to him.
tr: The pharmacist prepared the requested items in small packages and gave them to Carton.
es: The druggist prepared some papers, which Carton put in the inner pocket of his frock coat.

en: He put them, one by one, in the breast of his inner coat, counted out the money for them, and deliberately left the shop.
vi: Carton placed each packet into the pocket of his inner coat, counted the payment, and leisurely walked out.
tr: He then placed them one by one into the inner pocket of his coat, paid, and walked out with confident steps.
es: He paid the amount, and without further words, went out to the street.

en: “There is nothing more to do,” said he, glancing upward at the moon, “until to-morrow.
vi: − There's nothing left to do until tomorrow, - he looked up at the moon and spoke to himself.
tr: "Until tomorrow," he said, looking up at the moon, "there is nothing else to do.
es: —For tonight, I have nothing left to do—he murmured, raising his head. —Tomorrow we will continue...

en: I can’t sleep.”
vi: - I can't sleep.
tr: I can't sleep either."
es: It is impossible for me to sleep.

en: It was not a reckless manner, the manner in which he said these words aloud under the fast-sailing clouds, nor was it more expressive of negligence than defiance.
vi: It was not an attitude of defiance or a display of recklessness, but a challenge when he uttered those words under the swiftly moving clouds.
tr: While saying these things under the swiftly drifting clouds, Carton had neither a careless attitude nor a defiant manner.
es: The tone with which Carton pronounced the previous words reflected neither indifference nor bewilderment, nor was there despair or defiance in them; his accent resonated with the resolution of a man who, after many years of traveling down twisted paths without a fixed direction or destination, finally enters one whose end is known to him.

en: It was the settled manner of a tired man, who had wandered and struggled and got lost, but who at length struck into his road and saw its end.
vi: It was the determination of a weary soul, one who had wandered, struggled, and erred, but had finally found the right path and the ultimate destination.
tr: He had more the calmness of a weary man who had wandered the roads, overcome many hardships, lost his way but ultimately found it, and now saw the end of it.
es: The tone with which Carton pronounced the previous words reflected neither indifference nor bewilderment, nor was there despair or defiance in them; his accent resonated with the resolution of a man who, after many years of traveling down twisted paths without a fixed direction or destination, finally enters one whose end is known to him.

en: Long ago, when he had been famous among his earliest competitors as a youth of great promise, he had followed his father to the grave.
vi: In the old days, when he was famous as a promising young man among his competitive peers, his father passed away.
tr: Years ago, as a young man full of great promise, he had walked behind his father's coffin to the cemetery, standing out among his rivals.
es: Many years ago, when he stood out among the talented young people, among the students who promised great things, he accompanied his father to the cemetery.

en: His mother had died, years before.
vi: His mother had died many years before that.
tr: His mother had died many years before his father.
es: His mother had passed away much earlier.

en: These solemn words, which had been read at his father’s grave, arose in his mind as he went down the dark streets, among the heavy shadows, with the moon and the clouds sailing on high above him.
vi: The solemn words he had heard read when standing before his father's grave at that time now resurfaced in his mind as he walked through dark alleys, submerged in thick darkness, with the moon and drifting clouds high above.
tr: With the moon and drifting clouds overhead, passing through heavy shadows as he moved along the dark streets, Carton recalled the sacred words spoken at his father's grave: "I am the resurrection and the life, said the Lord; whoever believes in me, even if he dies, shall live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die."
es: Well then; those solemn words that the priest read over the grave of the one who gave him life, words forgotten amidst the disorder of a licentious life, emerged powerfully in his memory as he walked through the sad and lonely streets tonight, under a sky covered with dark clouds.

en: “I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die.”
vi: "The Lord said: I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me will live, even though they have died. And whoever lives by believing in me will never die."
tr: With the moon and drifting clouds overhead, passing through heavy shadows as he moved along the dark streets, Carton recalled the sacred words spoken at his father's grave: "I am the resurrection and the life, said the Lord; whoever believes in me, even if he dies, shall live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die."
es: "I am the resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, even if he dies, will live; and he who lives and believes in Me, will never die."

en: In a city dominated by the axe, alone at night, with natural sorrow rising in him for the sixty-three who had been that day put to death, and for to-morrow’s victims then awaiting their doom in the prisons, and still of to-morrow’s and to-morrow’s, the chain of association that brought the words home, like a rusty old ship’s anchor from the deep, might have been easily found.
vi: In a dreadful city under the shadow of the guillotine, he wandered alone in the sorrowful night for the sixty-three people who had been executed today, and for the victims of tomorrow who were currently awaiting their fate in the prisons, for the victims of the days to come, this chain of thoughts made it easy for him to recall the holy words of the past, like finding the anchor of an old rusty ship that had sunk to the depths.
tr: In a city ruled by the guillotine, alone at night, with the pain of sixty-three people sent to death that day and the agony of the victims in prisons waiting to be executed tomorrow, the next day, or the day after, weighing heavily on his heart, successive associations brought forth these words from the past, like the emergence of the rusty anchor of an old ship from the depths.
es: It would not have been difficult to find the mysterious force that evoked those memories from the depths of his soul, similar to the chain that pulls the rusted anchor from the depths of the silt, long embedded there, by simply noticing that he was walking alone and at night, through the streets of a city under the law of the guillotine, painfully recalling the sixty-three heads that had rolled that day, and thinking of the wretches who would die on the scaffold the next day, and the day after, and the day after that.

en: He did not seek it, but repeated them and went on.
vi: He repeated those words and continued on.
tr: He hadn't actually searched for them, but he found himself constantly repeating these words.
es: However, he did not attempt to seek it; he merely repeated over and over the words that have been copied, and continued walking.

en: With a solemn interest in the lighted windows where the people were going to rest, forgetful through a few calm hours of the horrors surrounding them; in the towers of the churches, where no prayers were said, for the popular revulsion had even travelled that length of self-destruction from years of priestly impostors, plunderers, and profligates; in the distant burial-places, reserved, as they wrote upon the gates, for Eternal Sleep; in the abounding gaols; and in the streets along which the sixties rolled to a death which had become so common and material, that no sorrowful story of a haunting Spirit ever arose among the people out of all the working of the Guillotine; with a solemn interest in the whole life and death of the city settling down to its short nightly pause in fury; Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again for the lighter streets.
vi: He attentively looked at the brightly lit windows where people were about to go to sleep for a few hours of peace to forget the surrounding horrors; he looked at the church towers where no prayers were heard anymore because years of imposture, usurpation, and degradation under the guise of clergy had made the people lose faith; he looked at the distant cemeteries reserved for the Eternal Sleep, as the inscriptions on the gates read; looked at the overcrowded prisons; looked at the streets where groups of sixty people at a time were taken on carts to their deaths, a sight so common and familiar that people had become indifferent to all the sorrowful tales of the souls who perished under the guillotine. Thinking of all the living and the dead in the city temporarily suspending their wrath each night as they slept, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine once more, heading towards the brighter streets.
tr: Sydney Carton looked with a dignified curiosity at the people visible in the lit windows, who would soon retire to rest and forget the surrounding horrors for a few tranquil hours; then at the towers of churches where no prayers were read anymore, and from which everyone fled due to their reaction to the charlatans, looters, and immoral people who had been masquerading as priests for years; at the distant cemeteries with signs reading "for eternal sleep" at their gates; at the prisons and the streets where people, having grown accustomed to groups of sixty being taken to their deaths by cart, could no longer conjure up any tragic ghost stories in front of the guillotine; and with the same dignified curiosity that gave his anger a brief respite every night, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again to reach the brighter avenues of the city whose life and death he observed.
es: Focusing all his interest on the illuminated windows corresponding to rooms where people were preparing to rest, eager to forget during the brief hours of nighttime calm the horrors that surrounded them during the day, in the church towers, where divine services were no longer held, as popular revulsion had made priests the main target of their wrath, accusing them of being impostors, libertines, and thieves; in those sacred places, destined, according to the inscriptions placed above the doors, for eternal rest; in the dungeons, overflowing with prisoners, and in the streets, where people ran to meet a death already considered, by force of habit, so common and natural that even those in charge of handling the guillotine did not have their dreams disturbed by spectral apparitions; in short, with all his attention focused on the life of that city rushing headlong to death, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine looking for better-lit and more lively streets.

en: Few coaches were abroad, for riders in coaches were liable to be suspected, and gentility hid its head in red nightcaps, and put on heavy shoes, and trudged.
vi: Few horse-drawn carriages were seen on the road because passengers in such carriages were easily suspected; those with status hid their faces under red hats, wore coarse shoes, and trudged along on foot.
tr: There weren't many cars around, because those who rode in cars aroused a lot of suspicion; therefore, nobility had hidden its head under red caps, put on clumsy shoes, and was progressing slowly and awkwardly.
es: There were very few cars to be seen, for those who could afford the luxury of having them, knowing that using them was as much as requesting to be inscribed in the Book of Suspects, preferred to walk on foot, wearing red caps and the most ordinary shoes.

en: But, the theatres were all well filled, and the people poured cheerfully out as he passed, and went chatting home.
vi: But the theaters were crowded; as he passed by, people were spilling out of the doors, cheerfully chatting on their way home.
tr: On the other hand, all the theaters were full, and as Carton passed by one of them, people cheerfully came out and went home chatting.
es: The theaters, however, were full, and they began to empty at the hour when Carton strolled through the central streets where they were located.

en: At one of the theatre doors, there was a little girl with a mother, looking for a way across the street through the mud.
vi: In front of one theater, a little girl stood with her mother, trying to navigate through the mud to cross the street.
tr: In front of one of the theater doors, a mother and her daughter were standing, thinking about how to cross the muddy road.
es: Next to the door of a theater, from which compact masses of cheerful people were emerging, singing as they headed to their homes, Carton saw a little girl, holding her mother's hand, looking for a spot that would allow her to cross the street without getting knee-deep in the mud.

en: He carried the child over, and before the timid arm was loosed from his neck asked her for a kiss.
vi: He helped carry the child across, and before the timid little arms let go of his neck, Carton asked the girl for a kiss.
tr: Carton picked up the child and carried her across, and before that timid arm let go of his neck, she asked for a kiss from him.
es: Carton took the little girl in his arms, carried her to the opposite sidewalk, and before the timid little angel let go of the arms that encircled his neck, he asked her to give him a kiss.

en: “I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die.”
vi: “The Lord said: I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me will live, even though they have died. And whoever lives by believing in me will never die.”
tr: "I am the resurrection and the life," said God, "whoever believes in me, even if they die, will still live, and whoever lives and believes in me will never die."
es: “I am the resurrection and the life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, he shall live; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die.”

en: Now, that the streets were quiet, and the night wore on, the words were in the echoes of his feet, and were in the air.
vi: At this moment, when the streets are quiet and the night is late, those words echoed in his footsteps and in the surrounding space.
tr: Since the streets had become completely silent and the night had fallen with all its darkness, the words seemed to echo at his feet and then spread into the air.
es: Later in the night, when the tranquility in the streets was complete and the silence absolute, it seemed to him that the sound of his own footsteps modulated those sentences, which the breeze brought wrapped in its subtle whispers.

en: Perfectly calm and steady, he sometimes repeated them to himself as he walked; but, he heard them always.
vi: Completely calm and steadfast, he sometimes repeated those words on his way; but this prayer always resonated within him.
tr: Carton was walking on one hand, and on the other, he was repeating these words in an extremely calm manner and at regular intervals; but these words never left his ear.
es: Master of himself, calm, resolute, he frequently repeated them with his lips; but they always sounded in his ears.

en: The night wore out, and, as he stood upon the bridge listening to the water as it splashed the river-walls of the Island of Paris, where the picturesque confusion of houses and cathedral shone bright in the light of the moon, the day came coldly, looking like a dead face out of the sky.
vi: The night gradually faded, as he stood on the bridge listening to the river lapping against the embankment around the Ile de la Cité, where a picturesque jumble of buildings and churches shone brightly under the moonlight, the cold dawn emerging like the face of a corpse on the horizon.
tr: Sydney Carton stood on the bridge, listening to the waters hitting the river walls on the Paris island, where the dazzling chaos of houses and the cathedral shone brightly in the moonlight, as the night was about to end, the day came cold like a dead face looking from the sky.
es: And the night continued advancing while Carton, leaning over the parapet of the bridge, listened to the murmuring kisses of the river against the walls of the Island of Paris, and contemplated the picturesque confusion of buildings wrapped in gray shadows, over which the dome of the cathedral, bathed in the whitish light of the moon, rose arrogantly. The day came.

en: Then, the night, with the moon and the stars, turned pale and died, and for a little while it seemed as if Creation were delivered over to Death’s dominion.
vi: Then the night and the stars dimmed and faded, and for a moment it seemed as if all things had entered the realm of death.
tr: Then the night, along with the moon and stars, faded away; it was as if death had taken over the entire universe for a while.
es: The night, with the moon and the stars, paled and died, and for a few minutes, it seemed that all of creation fell under the yellowish scepter of Death.

en: But, the glorious sun, rising, seemed to strike those words, that burden of the night, straight and warm to his heart in its long bright rays.
vi: But the glorious sun is rising, its rays spreading wide as if shattering the oppression of the night, as if repeating those sacred words that warm his heart.
tr: When the sun rose with all its grandeur today, it seemed to have cast aside all those words and the night's troubles, warming the heart of Sydney with its bright lights.
es: The river's current, rapid, impetuous, deep, seemed to him like a loving friend.

en: And looking along them, with reverently shaded eyes, a bridge of light appeared to span the air between him and the sun, while the river sparkled under it.
vi: Raising his hand respectfully to shield his eyes, he looked straight into the morning sun; a bridge of light seemed to connect him with the sun while the river below sparkled in the morning light.
tr: When she shielded her eyes and looked at them, it was as if a bridge of light formed between her and the sun, and the river below sparkled brilliantly.
es: The river's current, rapid, impetuous, deep, seemed to him like a loving friend.

en: The strong tide, so swift, so deep, and certain, was like a congenial friend, in the morning stillness.
vi: The water flowed swiftly, deeply, and unchangingly, like a kindred spirit in the tranquil morning.
tr: The powerful current in the river, which was exceedingly fast, deep, and distinct, had become like a companion to him in the morning silence.
es: The river's current, rapid, impetuous, deep, seemed to him like a loving friend.

en: He walked by the stream, far from the houses, and in the light and warmth of the sun fell asleep on the bank.
vi: He strolled along the riverbank, gradually distancing himself from the residential area, and in the warm sunlight, he dozed off by the water's edge.
tr: Sydney, far from the houses, fell asleep on the riverbank under the sunlight and warmth after walking along this current for a while.
es: He started walking along its banks, moving away from the city's bustle.

en: When he awoke and was afoot again, he lingered there yet a little longer, watching an eddy that turned and turned purposeless, until the stream absorbed it, and carried it on to the sea.—“Like me.”
vi: Upon waking and continuing his walk, he lingered there a bit longer, watching a whirlpool spinning aimlessly until the river carried it out to sea.
tr: When he woke up and got up, he lingered there a bit more, watching a whirlpool that was aimlessly turning, until the current swallowed it and carried it to the sea.
es: He fell asleep on the shore; when he woke up, he continued walking for a few more minutes, his eyes fixed on a whirlpool spinning vertiginously, until the current swallowed him and dragged him to the sea.

en: A trading-boat, with a sail of the softened colour of a dead leaf, then glided into his view, floated by him, and died away.
vi: - "Just like me." A merchant ship with sails drooping like dead leaves came into view, drifted past, and faded away.
tr: –"Just like me!" Then, a boat with a sail faded like a dead leaf came into view, and after gliding in front for a while, it disappeared from sight.
es: —Like me!

en: As its silent track in the water disappeared, the prayer that had broken up out of his heart for a merciful consideration of all his poor blindnesses and errors, ended in the words, “I am the resurrection and the life.”
vi: As the silent water behind the ship disappeared, so too did the prayer - still echoing in his heart, asking for divine mercy for all his blind mistakes - end with the words: "I am the resurrection and the life."
tr: When the boat's traces on the water vanished, the prayer that sprang from Sydney's heart for the forgiveness of his own negligence and mistakes ended with these words, "I am the resurrection, I am the life.""
es: —murmured Carton.

en: mr Lorry was already out when he got back, and it was easy to surmise where the good old man was gone.
vi: Mr. Lorry was away when he got home, it was not hard to guess where this kind-hearted old man had gone.
tr: When he returned, Mr. Lorry had left, and it was not at all difficult to guess where this kind-hearted man had gone.
es: When he arrived home, Lorry had already left.

en: Sydney Carton drank nothing but a little coffee, ate some bread, and, having washed and changed to refresh himself, went out to the place of trial.
vi: Sydney Carton only drank a little coffee, ate some bread, then bathed and changed clothes for comfort, and went to the courthouse.
tr: Sydney Carton drank a little coffee, ate some bread, and after washing up and putting on clean clothes, he went to the courthouse.
es: Carton did not ask where he had gone, as with little effort of imagination he could guess it.

en: The court was all astir and a-buzz, when the black sheep—whom many fell away from in dread—pressed him into an obscure corner among the crowd.
vi: In the courthouse's commotion and clamor, the black sheep - the people whom many commoners fearfully avoid - cornered him into a secluded spot within the crowd.
tr: The black sheep, which many people avoided out of fear, had seated Sydney in a secluded corner amidst the crowd, filling the courtroom with great excitement and murmurs.
es: He had a small cup of coffee, washed and got ready, and went without delay to the Tribunal.

en: mr Lorry was there, and Doctor Manette was there.
vi: Mr. Lorry was there, and Dr. Manette was there.
tr: Mr. Lorry and Doctor Manette were there.
es: There he found Lorry, there he found Dr. Manette, there he found her, sitting next to her father.

en: She was there, sitting beside her father.
vi: She was there too, sitting next to her father.
tr: Lucie was also sitting right next to her father.
es: There he found Lorry, there he found Dr. Manette, there he found her, sitting next to her father.

en: When her husband was brought in, she turned a look upon him, so sustaining, so encouraging, so full of admiring love and pitying tenderness, yet so courageous for his sake, that it called the healthy blood into his face, brightened his glance, and animated his heart.
vi: When Darnay was brought to trial, to reassure him, she sent her husband a look full of sympathy and encouragement, full of loving admiration and tender sorrow, but also full of courage, which made Darnay's face flush, his eyes shine, and his heart beat faster.
tr: When her husband was brought in, Lucie looked at him with such supportive, encouraging, deep love and pain-laden compassion that color instantly returned to Charles's face, his eyes sparkled, and his heart skipped a beat.
es: When Charles Darnay appeared, Lucie directed a look at him so encouraging, so full of boundless love and tender compassion, that it brought blood to the prisoner's cheeks, brightened his gaze, and lifted his heart.

en: If there had been any eyes to notice the influence of her look, on Sydney Carton, it would have been seen to be the same influence exactly.
vi: If anyone had noticed how her presence affected Sydney Carton, they would have seen that he shared the same exhilaration as Darnay himself.
tr: If at that moment someone had observed the effect of Lucie's gaze on Sydney Carton, they would have seen that it was exactly the same as Charles's reaction.
es: If anyone had had their eyes on Sydney Carton, they would have noticed that the look, although not directed at him, had the same effect on him as it did on the prisoner.

en: Before that unjust Tribunal, there was little or no order of procedure, ensuring to any accused person any reasonable hearing.
vi: In that unjust court, there was almost no procedural order to ensure that anyone accused would be fairly tried.
tr: In the unjust court, there was no reasonable method or rule that allowed the defendants to speak.
es: Before that unjust tribunal, which had begun by banishing order in its proceedings, it was perfectly useless for any accused person to attempt to be heard; it would not have been worth bringing the Revolution to not simultaneously scatter all the laws, regulations, and ceremonies to the four winds, to not abolish once and for all the social order that the world had so monstrously abused, to not deny the accused the right to justify themselves.

en: There could have been no such Revolution, if all laws, forms, and ceremonies, had not first been so monstrously abused, that the suicidal vengeance of the Revolution was to scatter them all to the winds.
vi: There would not have been such a Revolution if all laws, procedures, and rituals had not been brutally trampled from the beginning, to the extent that the Revolution now discards all laws to exact a mad revenge akin to suicide.
tr: In any case, if all the laws, methods, and protocols had not been so monstrously abused, there would not have been such a revolution, yet the death-thirsty revolution, driven by feelings of vengeance, had swept them all away into the wind.
es: Before that unjust tribunal, which had begun by banishing order in its proceedings, it was perfectly useless for any accused person to attempt to be heard; it would not have been worth bringing the Revolution to not simultaneously scatter all the laws, regulations, and ceremonies to the four winds, to not abolish once and for all the social order that the world had so monstrously abused, to not deny the accused the right to justify themselves.

en: Every eye was turned to the jury.
vi: Everyone was focused on the jury.
tr: All eyes turned to the jury.
es: The Jury was from the very first moments the focus of all eyes.

en: The same determined patriots and good republicans as yesterday and the day before, and to-morrow and the day after.
vi: The same determined patriots and reputable republicans as yesterday and the day before, as well as tomorrow and the day after.
tr: They were all the same determined patriots and good republicans as yesterday, the day before, tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow.
es: It was composed of the same resolute patriots, the same excellent republicans who formed it the day before, the same who would form it the next day.

en: Eager and prominent among them, one man with a craving face, and his fingers perpetually hovering about his lips, whose appearance gave great satisfaction to the spectators.
vi: The most eager and notable among them was a man with a greedy face and fingers constantly hovering around his mouth; his presence made the crowd watching the trial extremely delighted.
tr: Among them, one man with a greedy expression, impatient and with fingers constantly roaming over his lips, stood out immediately, and the audience was immensely pleased with his demeanor.
es: Among them stood out a man with a repulsive face, a fierce cannibal in every sense of the word, an individual who drank blood, bathed in blood, and breathed blood.

en: A life-thirsting, cannibal-looking, bloody-minded juryman, the Jacques Three of St. Antoine.
vi: The bloodthirsty juror, with a demeanor as if he wanted to devour someone alive, was none other than Jacques Three of the Saint Antoine district.
tr: This bloodthirsty, cannibalistic-looking, and cruel jury member was Jacques Three from St. Antoine.
es: It was Santiago Tercero, the one we met in the San Antonio neighborhood.

en: The whole jury, as a jury of dogs empannelled to try the deer.
vi: The entire jury was like a pack of hunting dogs gathered to judge a fallen deer.
tr: The entire jury stood like dogs gathered to judge a deer.
es: The others resembled a pack of dogs eager to tear apart the prey.

en: Every eye then turned to the five judges and the public prosecutor.
vi: Everyone then turned towards the five magistrates and the prosecutor.
tr: All eyes turned to the five judges and the prosecutor.
es: All eyes were fixed on the five jurors and the public prosecutor, who spoke, more or less, in the following terms:

en: No favourable leaning in that quarter to-day.
vi: Today, no one in this group seemed tolerant; everyone appeared ruthless, steely, and cruel.
tr: There was no positive atmosphere in that part today.
es: All eyes were fixed on the five jurors and the public prosecutor, who spoke, more or less, in the following terms:

en: A fell, uncompromising, murderous business-meaning there.
vi: Today, no one in this group seemed tolerant; everyone appeared ruthless, steely, and cruel.
tr: Instead, something cruel, savage, and deadly was brewing there.
es: All eyes were fixed on the five jurors and the public prosecutor, who spoke, more or less, in the following terms:

en: Every eye then sought some other eye in the crowd, and gleamed at it approvingly; and heads nodded at one another, before bending forward with a strained attention.
vi: Then the crowd looked at each other, eyes showing approval, heads nodding in satisfaction, and then craned their necks forward, paying attention to the trial.
tr: Then they looked around at the thousands in the crowd, their eyes gleaming as if in approval, and nodded to each other before leaning forward tensely and giving their attention.
es: All eyes were fixed on the five jurors and the public prosecutor, who spoke, more or less, in the following terms:

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay.
tr: Charles Evremonde, known as Darnay, was released yesterday.
es: —Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay.

en: Released yesterday.
vi: Released yesterday.
tr: Charles Evremonde, known as Darnay, was released yesterday.
es: Yesterday he was released, and on the same day he was accused again and re-arrested.

en: Reaccused and retaken yesterday.
vi: Accused again and re-imprisoned yesterday.
tr: On the same day, he was found guilty again and imprisoned.
es: Yesterday he was released, and on the same day he was accused again and re-arrested.

en: Indictment delivered to him last night.
vi: The indictment was issued to him yesterday.
tr: The indictment was delivered to him last night.
es: Last night he was informed of the charges brought against him.

en: Suspected and Denounced enemy of the Republic, Aristocrat, one of a family of tyrants, one of a race proscribed, for that they had used their abolished privileges to the infamous oppression of the people.
vi: The suspect is condemned as an enemy of the Republic, a member of the aristocracy, belonging to a tyrannical family, of the type to be eliminated, for having exploited their privileges to brutally oppress the common people.
tr: He was accused and denounced as an enemy of the Republic and an aristocrat. He comes from a family of a cruel ruler, exiled due to the oppressions they inflicted on people despite their abolished privileges.
es: He is charged with being an enemy of the Republic, an aristocrat, a member of a family of tyrants, a member of a proscribed race, who abused his privileges, now happily abolished, oppressing the people in the most villainous manner.

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, in right of such proscription, absolutely Dead in Law.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, according to that law of elimination, is certain to face the death penalty.
tr: Charles Evremonde, known as Darnay, is legally dead because of this exile decree.
es: Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay, guilty of the mentioned crimes, is a dead man in the eyes of the Law.

en: To this effect, in as few or fewer words, the Public Prosecutor.
vi: With just a few brief words, the prosecutor had finished the accusation.
tr: What the prosecutor said was basically this.
es: His head rightfully belongs to the executioner.

en: The President asked, was the Accused openly denounced or secretly?
vi: The judge asked the defendant if they were publicly or secretly accused.
tr: The president asked whether the defendant was reported openly or secretly.
es: —Is the accusation against the defendant public or secret?—asked the president.

en: “Openly, President.”
vi: − Publicly, Your Honor.
tr: "Openly, Mr. President."
es: —Is the accusation against the defendant public or secret?—asked the president.

en: “By whom?”
vi: − Who is it for? −
tr: "Who did it?""
es: —Who made it?

en: “Three voices.
vi: Three people.
tr: "Three people.
es: —Three people.

en: Ernest Defarge, wine-vendor of St. Antoine.”
vi: Ernest Defarge, a wine seller in Saint Antoine.
tr: Ernest Defarge, the wine-seller from St Antoine."
es: Ernesto Defarge, innkeeper of San Antonio.

en: “Good.”
vi: − Okay.
tr: "Beautiful."
es: —Very well.

en: “Thérèse Defarge, his wife.”
vi: − Thérèse Defarge, his wife.
tr: "Therese Defarge, his wife.""
es: —Teresa Defarge, wife of the aforementioned.

en: “Good.”
vi: − Okay.
tr: "Beautiful."
es: —Perfectly.

en: “Alexandre Manette, physician.”
vi: − Alexandre Manette, doctor.
tr: "And also Alexandre Manette, doctor.""
es: —Alejandro Manette, doctor.

en: A great uproar took place in the court, and in the midst of it, Doctor Manette was seen, pale and trembling, standing where he had been seated.
vi: The entire courtroom was in an uproar, and in the midst of the crowd, Dr. Manette, pale and trembling, stood up from where he had been sitting.
tr: A great commotion erupted in the salon, and in the midst of all this chaos, Doctor Manette, trembling with a pale face, suddenly stood up from where he was seated.
es: This last name raised a storm of deafening shouts in the room. In the midst of the tumult, the doctor was seen to rise, pale as a corpse and trembling like a leaf.

en: “President, I indignantly protest to you that this is a forgery and a fraud.
vi: − Your Honor, I am indignant and object that it is a forgery and deceit.
tr: "Mr. President, this is unacceptable, I object to this fraud and deceit.
es: —President—he shouted,—I indignantly protest against the vile lie that has just been uttered here.

en: You know the accused to be the husband of my daughter.
vi: You are well aware that the defendant is my daughter's husband.
tr: You know that the accused person is my daughter's husband.
es: I could not have denounced my daughter's husband, and the Court knows very well that the accused is my son-in-law.

en: My daughter, and those dear to her, are far dearer to me than my life.
vi: My daughter and those dear to her are more important than my own life.
tr: My daughter and her loved ones are more precious to me than my own life.
es: My daughter, and the people who are dear to her, are worth a thousand times more to me than my own life.

en: Who and where is the false conspirator who says that I denounce the husband of my child!”
vi: Who is this schemer and where is he that he dares to say I accused my son-in-law!
tr: Who is this deceitful conspirator saying that I reported my own child's husband, where is this person?"
es: Where is the impostor who dares to claim that I have denounced my daughter's husband? Where is the false patriot who dares to lie so shamelessly?

en: “Citizen Manette, be tranquil.
vi: − Citizen Manette, please calm down.
tr: "Citizen Manette, calm down.
es: —Calm yourself, citizen Manette.

en: To fail in submission to the authority of the Tribunal would be to put yourself out of Law.
vi: Not complying with the Court's authority means you are violating the law.
tr: If you disobey the authority of the court, you will also be acting unlawfully.
es: To disrespect the authority of the Tribunal would be tantamount to stepping outside the Law.

en: As to what is dearer to you than life, nothing can be so dear to a good citizen as the Republic.”
vi: As for what is more important than one's own life, for a good Citizen, nothing is more important than the Republic itself.
tr: As for the people you mentioned being more precious than your life, for a good citizen, nothing can be more precious than the Republic."
es: You have said that there is something worth a thousand times more than your life; and I do not know that for a good patriot there is anything worth as much as the Republic.

en: Loud acclamations hailed this rebuke.
vi: The rebuke was met with loud applause.
tr: After the president's scolding, a thunderous applause erupted.
es: Frenzied applause rewarded the president's reply.

en: The President rang his bell, and with warmth resumed.
vi: The judge rang the bell and eagerly continued: −
tr: The president rang his bell and continued his speech with the same enthusiasm.
es: He, after imposing silence with the force of bell rings, continued passionately:

en: “If the Republic should demand of you the sacrifice of your child herself, you would have no duty but to sacrifice her.
vi: If the Republic demands that we sacrifice our own children, then it is our duty to do so.
tr: "If the Republic asks you to sacrifice your child, the only thing you should do is to sacrifice them.
es: —If the Republic demanded the sacrifice of your own daughter, your duty would be to sacrifice her.

en: Listen to what is to follow.
vi: Let us proceed with the trial.
tr: Now be silent and listen carefully to what I have to say!"
es: —If the Republic demanded the sacrifice of your own daughter, your duty would be to sacrifice her.

en: In the meanwhile, be silent!”
vi: For now, silence!
tr: Now be silent and listen carefully to what I have to say!"
es: Let's continue, and silence.

en: Frantic acclamations were again raised.
vi: The crowd once again erupted in wild applause.
tr: The people in the salon applauded wildly again.
es: The doctor Manette collapsed into the chair.

en: Doctor Manette sat down, with his eyes looking around, and his lips trembling; his daughter drew closer to him.
vi: Dr. Manette sat down, looking around, his lips trembling; his daughter clung closely to him.
tr: Dr. Manette sat down, looking around and with trembling lips; his daughter snuggled closely next to him.
es: His lips trembled, and his eyes looked around in terror.

en: The craving man on the jury rubbed his hands together, and restored the usual hand to his mouth.
vi: The bloodthirsty member of the jury rubbed his hands together, then habitually brought one hand to his mouth.
tr: The greedy man on the jury rubbed his hands and, as usual, brought his hand to his mouth.
es: The cannibal-faced jury rubbed their hands with visible relish.

en: Defarge was produced, when the court was quiet enough to admit of his being heard, and rapidly expounded the story of the imprisonment, and of his having been a mere boy in the Doctor’s service, and of the release, and of the state of the prisoner when released and delivered to him.
vi: Defarge was called out. When the noise in the court had subsided, he quickly recounted the story of Dr. Manette's imprisonment, how he had served the doctor since he was young, how the doctor was released from prison, and the state he was in when entrusted to him.
tr: When the sounds in the courtroom died down and he was sure his voice could be heard, Defarge spoke up and recounted the Doctor's imprisonment, how he was a small child working alongside him at the time of his incarceration, then the prisoner's release, and the state he was in when he was freed and brought to him.
es: Once silence was restored, Defarge presented himself, who gave a succinct account of the doctor's captivity and release; he stated that he had been his servant, and described the condition in which the captive was found when he was handed over.

en: This short examination followed, for the court was quick with its work.
vi: Then came the brief examination because the court worked very quickly: − You played a role in the storming of the Bastille, didn't you, Citizen?
tr: When the sounds in the courtroom died down and he was sure his voice could be heard, Defarge spoke up and recounted the Doctor's imprisonment, how he was a small child working alongside him at the time of his incarceration, then the prisoner's release, and the state he was in when he was freed and brought to him.
es: After the story was finished, the Tribunal addressed him with the following questions:

en: “You did good service at the taking of the Bastille, citizen?”
vi: Then came the brief examination because the court worked very quickly: − You played a role in the storming of the Bastille, didn't you, Citizen?
tr: "You played a significant role in the capture of the Bastille, didn't you, citizen?"
es: —Did you render good services in the storming of the Bastille, citizen?

en: “I believe so.”
vi: − I believe so.
tr: "I think so."
es: —I believe so.

en: Here, an excited woman screeched from the crowd: “You were one of the best patriots there.
vi: At this point, in the crowd, a woman's agitated voice shouted loudly: − You are one of the most patriotic people there.
tr: At that moment, a woman in the crowd shouted in a shrill voice; "You were one of the most patriotic people there.
es: —You were one of the best patriots!

en: Why not say so?
vi: Why don't you say it all?
tr: Why don't you tell us?
es: —shouted a woman, overcome with enthusiasm—Why not say it like that?

en: You were a cannonier that day there, and you were among the first to enter the accursed fortress when it fell.
vi: You were the one who fired the cannon that day, and you were in the first group to enter that accursed fortress when it fell.
tr: You were the artilleryman there that day, and when that damned fortress fell, you were among the first to enter.
es: That day you were an artilleryman, you fought with fury, and you were the first to enter the damned fortress after it fell into the hands of the people.

en: Patriots, I speak the truth!”
vi: Dear patriots, I speak the truth!
tr: Patriots, that's the truth!"
es: Patriots... believe me, because I tell the truth!

en: It was The Vengeance who, amidst the warm commendations of the audience, thus assisted the proceedings.
vi: It was the Goddess of Retribution, in the enthusiastic cheers of the crowd, manipulating the trial.
tr: The person trying to steer the case with the enthusiastic approval of the audience was İntikam.
es: The one who had just spoken was La Venganza. The applause from the crowd was deafening.

en: The President rang his bell; but, The Vengeance, warming with encouragement, shrieked, “I defy that bell!” wherein she was likewise much commended.
vi: The judge rang the bell; but the Goddess of Retribution, still excited, shouted loudly: − I challenge that bell! - And the crowd cheered in response.
tr: The chairman rang the bell; but İntikam, further encouraged by those in the hall, shouted even more fervently, "That bell doesn't work on me!" and the crowd once again applauded wildly.
es: The President rang the bell, but La Venganza, incited by the mobs, howled: —I don't feel like being quiet! I laugh at the bell and at whoever rings it! Finally, he fell silent when his strength was exhausted.

en: “Inform the Tribunal of what you did that day within the Bastille, citizen.”
vi: − Please present to the court what you did that day in the Bastille prison, Citizen.
tr: "Then tell the court what you did at the Bastille that day, citizen."
es: —Report to the Tribunal what you did inside the Bastille, citizen.

en: “I knew,” said Defarge, looking down at his wife, who stood at the bottom of the steps on which he was raised, looking steadily up at him; “I knew that this prisoner, of whom I speak, had been confined in a cell known as One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
vi: − I knew beforehand, - Defarge said while looking at his wife, who was standing at the bottom of the steps leading up to where he was standing, her eyes looking up at her husband.
tr: Defarge, sitting at the foot of the witness stand, looked towards his wife who was staring at him unblinkingly, and said, "The prisoner in question. I knew he was held in a cell known as One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
es: —I knew—replied Defarge, looking at his wife who was staring at him from a short distance with her eyes—that the captive I speak of had been buried in a cell they called One Hundred and Five, North Tower.

en: I knew it from himself.
vi: I knew that the prisoner I mentioned was locked in Cell One Hundred and Five, North Tower, when he was making shoes under my protection.
tr: He had told me this himself.
es: —I knew—replied Defarge, looking at his wife who was staring at him from a short distance with her eyes—that the captive I speak of had been buried in a cell they called One Hundred and Five, North Tower.

en: He knew himself by no other name than One Hundred and Five, North Tower, when he made shoes under my care.
vi: I knew that the prisoner I mentioned was locked in Cell One Hundred and Five, North Tower, when he was making shoes under my protection.
tr: During the days when he was making shoes and I was looking after him, if you asked his name, he would say One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
es: The secret was revealed to me by him, for while he stayed in my house, making shoes, he did not know that he had any other name than One Hundred and Five, North Tower.

en: As I serve my gun that day, I resolve, when the place shall fall, to examine that cell.
vi: When I fired the cannon that day, I decided that when the place fell, I would go and inspect that cell.
tr: On that day, when the cannon was fired, I decided to examine that cell when the Bastille fell.
es: On the day of the storming of the Bastille, while I was firing my cannon, I decided to inspect the cell in question as soon as the fortress fell into our hands.

en: It falls.
vi: The Bastille fell.
tr: Then it fell.
es: On the day of the storming of the Bastille, while I was firing my cannon, I decided to inspect the cell in question as soon as the fortress fell into our hands.

en: I mount to the cell, with a fellow-citizen who is one of the Jury, directed by a gaoler.
vi: I went up to that cell with a Citizen who is now on this jury, with a guard leading the way.
tr: Accompanied by a guard and a citizen friend who is now on the Jury, we went up to the cell.
es: It fell; and I immediately went up to the mentioned dungeon, along with a companion who is on the jury, and a jailer who took charge of guiding us.

en: I examine it, very closely.
vi: I inspected it very carefully.
tr: I examined the cell thoroughly.
es: I inspected it very carefully, and in a hole in the wall, concealed behind a stone that had been removed and replaced, I found a written paper.

en: In a hole in the chimney, where a stone has been worked out and replaced, I find a written paper.
vi: In a hole in the chimney, where a stone had been pried out and replaced, I found a bundle of handwritten papers.
tr: One of the stones of the chimney had been removed and then replaced, and here I found a paper with something written on it.
es: I inspected it very carefully, and in a hole in the wall, concealed behind a stone that had been removed and replaced, I found a written paper.

en: This is that written paper.
vi: This is that bundle of handwritten papers.
tr: This is that paper.
es: This is the written paper.

en: I have made it my business to examine some specimens of the writing of Doctor Manette.
vi: I took the trouble to examine some samples of Dr. Manette's handwriting.
tr: Later, I found and examined some writing samples of Doctor Manette.
es: I have examined several writings of Doctor Manette, and the handwriting on this paper is in Doctor Manette's own hand.

en: This is the writing of Doctor Manette.
vi: It is indeed his handwriting.
tr: This was his writing.
es: I have examined several writings of Doctor Manette, and the handwriting on this paper is in Doctor Manette's own hand.

en: I confide this paper, in the writing of Doctor Manette, to the hands of the President.”
vi: I respectfully submit that bundle of papers, written in Dr. Manette's own handwriting, to the Chief Judge.
tr: I am handing this paper containing Doctor Manette's writing to the President."
es: I hand this paper, written in Doctor Manette's own hand, to the President.

en: “Let it be read.”
vi: − Let the court read it aloud.
tr: "Let the text be read."
es: —Let it be read.

en: In a dead silence and stillness—the prisoner under trial looking lovingly at his wife, his wife only looking from him to look with solicitude at her father, Doctor Manette keeping his eyes fixed on the reader, Madame Defarge never taking hers from the prisoner, Defarge never taking his from his feasting wife, and all the other eyes there intent upon the Doctor, who saw none of them—the paper was read, as follows.
vi: The courtroom was as silent as a grave - the prisoner being tried looked lovingly at his wife, his wife only took her eyes off her husband to anxiously look at her father, Dr. Manette stared intently at the person holding the papers, Madame Defarge never took her eyes off the prisoner, Defarge only saw the wife gloating, and all other eyes were directed towards the doctor, who paid no attention to anyone.
tr: Everyone held their breath, and while not a sound was heard in the hall, the defendant looked at his wife with loving eyes, and she only took her worried eyes off him to look at her father. While Doctor Manette's eyes were fixed on the person who would read the paper. Madame Defarge did not take her eyes off the defendant, Monsieur Defarge did not take his eyes off his wife whose face was beaming, and all other eyes were turned to the Doctor who saw none of this – the paper began to be read.
es: The document, read in the midst of a sepulchral silence, while the convict looked lovingly at his wife, and she looked now at him, now at her father, and Dr. Manette did not take his eyes off the reader, and Mrs. Defarge fixed hers insistently on the prisoner, and Defarge did not take his eyes off his wife, and everyone in the room watched the doctor who saw no one, said thus:

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: The stack of papers was read aloud.
tr: X
es: X.

en: The Substance of the Shadow
vi: 10. The Entity of Darkness
tr: The Shadow's Form
es: THE SUBSTANCE OF THE SHADOW

en: I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate physician, native of Beauvais, and afterwards resident in Paris, write this melancholy paper in my doleful cell in the Bastille, during the last month of the year, 1767.
vi: I, Alexandre Manette, an unfortunate doctor, born in Beauvais, later living in Paris, write this sorrowful testament in the sorrowful Bastille prison, in the last month of the year 1767.
tr: Ben, Alexandre Manette, born in Beauvais, the unfortunate doctor who lived in Paris, am writing this sorrowful note in the gloomy cell of the Bastille in the last month of the year 1767.
es: "I, Alejandro Manette, unfortunate doctor, native of Beauvais, and resident of Paris, write this painful document in my horrendous cell in the Bastille in the last month of the year 1767."

en: I write it at stolen intervals, under every difficulty.
vi: I secretly write it piece by piece in extremely difficult circumstances.
tr: I am writing this note in stolen intervals, under very difficult conditions.
es: "I write it taking advantage of moments that I steal from vigilance and overcoming immense difficulties."

en: I design to secrete it in the wall of the chimney, where I have slowly and laboriously made a place of concealment for it.
vi: I intentionally hide it in the wall cavity of the chimney, where I have painstakingly created a hiding spot over a long period.
tr: To hide it, I have slowly and laboriously prepared a place in the wall of the chimney.
es: "My purpose is to hide it inside the wall of my tomb, where through hard work I have managed to open a hole."

en: Some pitying hand may find it there, when I and my sorrows are dust.
vi: A compassionate hand may find it there when I and my sufferings have turned to dust.
tr: Perhaps a compassionate hand will find it one day when I and my sufferings have turned to dust.
es: "Perhaps some merciful hand will find it when I and my misfortunes have passed into the world of oblivion."

en: “These words are formed by the rusty iron point with which I write with difficulty in scrapings of soot and charcoal from the chimney, mixed with blood, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity.
vi: These lines were written with a sharp, rusty iron nib dipped in soot scraped from the chimney, mixed with blood, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity.
tr: I am writing these words in the last month of my ten-year imprisonment, with great difficulty, by mixing soot and coal dust that I scraped from the chimney with blood and using a rusty iron tip to write.
es: "I trace these lines with the rust I have scraped from the moldy bars of the grille mixed with blood from my veins, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity."

en: Hope has quite departed from my breast.
vi: My heart was completely in despair.
tr: There is no hope left inside me anymore.
es: "In my chest, there is not a single atom of hope left."

en: I know from terrible warnings I have noted in myself that my reason will not long remain unimpaired, but I solemnly declare that I am at this time in the possession of my right mind—that my memory is exact and circumstantial—and that I write the truth as I shall answer for these my last recorded words, whether they be ever read by men or not, at the Eternal Judgment-seat.
vi: Through the terrifying signs that I had noticed in myself, I knew that my sanity would not remain intact for much longer, but I swear that at this very moment, I am completely lucid - my memory is still accurate and detailed - and I swear to write down the truth as if these were my last words, whether this testament is read by anyone or not on the Day of Final Judgment.
tr: From the symptoms that have recently emerged, I understand that losing my sanity is near, but I swear that right now my mind is fully intact – my memory is strong, even the details are vivid in my mind – and I am ready to account for all these recorded last words to humanity and to God on Judgment Day.
es: "Terrible phenomena that I have observed in myself announce that very soon reason will also abandon me, but I solemnly declare that at this moment I am in full possession of my mental faculties... that my memory is exact and detailed, that I write the truth, and that I am ready to vouch for the veracity of my words, whether they are read by men someday or condemned to eternal secrecy, before the Eternal Judge whose gaze reads into the depths of hearts."

en: “One cloudy moonlight night, in the third week of December (I think the twenty-second of the month) in the year 1757, I was walking on a retired part of the quay by the Seine for the refreshment of the frosty air, at an hour’s distance from my place of residence in the Street of the School of Medicine, when a carriage came along behind me, driven very fast.
vi: On a moonlit night covered with clouds, in the third week of December (I remember it was the 22nd of the month) in the year 1757, I was taking a walk along a deserted section of the Seine River dock to enjoy the cool air, about an hour's walk from my house on École de Médecine street, when a carriage came speeding from behind.
tr: In the third week of December in the year 1757 (I believe it was the twenty-second), on a moonlit and cloudy night, in the freezing weather, I had gone for a walk to get some fresh air on a deserted quay an hour's distance from my home on the street of the Faculty of Medicine, by the banks of the Seine River, when I heard the sound of a rapidly approaching carriage from behind.
es: One night during the fourth week of December (I believe it was the twenty-second of the month) in the year 1757, I found myself walking in a secluded area of the promenade that borders the Seine, an hour's distance from my home, located on the street of the Faculty of Medicine, when I saw a carriage approaching from behind, drawn by two horses, at a gallop.

en: As I stood aside to let that carriage pass, apprehensive that it might otherwise run me down, a head was put out at the window, and a voice called to the driver to stop.
vi: As I cautiously stepped aside to avoid being run over, a head protruded from the carriage window and a voice shouted to the coachman to stop the horses.
tr: As I stepped aside to give way so that it wouldn't run me over, a head leaned out of the carriage window and told the driver to stop.
es: As I stepped aside to let the carriage pass and avoid being run over, a head appeared in the window, and a voice commanded the coachman to stop.

en: “The carriage stopped as soon as the driver could rein in his horses, and the same voice called to me by my name.
vi: The carriage came to a halt as soon as the coachman pulled the reins, and that same voice called me by name.
tr: The moment the driver managed to pull on the reins of his horse, the carriage stopped, and the same person called out to me by name.
es: "The carriage came to a halt as soon as the coachman could rein in the horses, and the same voice that had given the order to stop called me by my name."

en: I answered.
vi: I responded.
tr: I responded in kind.
es: "The carriage did not stop in front of me, but at a distance sufficient for two gentlemen to have time to open the door and jump onto the path before I arrived, responding to the call."

en: The carriage was then so far in advance of me that two gentlemen had time to open the door and alight before I came up with it.
vi: The carriage had stopped far ahead, so the two gentlemen had time to open the door and step down before I arrived.
tr: The carriage had stopped a bit ahead of me, so by the time I reached them, the two gentlemen had already opened the carriage door and stepped out.
es: "The carriage did not stop in front of me, but at a distance sufficient for two gentlemen to have time to open the door and jump onto the path before I arrived, responding to the call."

en: “I observed that they were both wrapped in cloaks, and appeared to conceal themselves.
vi: I saw that both were wrapped tightly in cloaks, and seemed to be hiding their identities.
tr: I noticed that both of them were wrapped in cloaks, as if hiding from something.
es: "I observed that both were perfectly cloaked in their capes and that they tried to conceal their faces."

en: As they stood side by side near the carriage door, I also observed that they both looked of about my own age, or rather younger, and that they were greatly alike, in stature, manner, voice, and (as far as I could see) face too.
vi: When they stood next to each other near the car door, I also noticed that both were about my age, or a little younger, and very similar in terms of build, demeanor, voice, and (as far as I could tell) even their faces.
tr: When they stood side by side next to the carriage door, I saw that they were both around my age, perhaps a bit younger, and that they resembled each other greatly in height, build, demeanor, voice, and (as far as I could see) facial features.
es: "When I reached their side and found them standing on either side of the door, I also noticed that both seemed to be of my age, perhaps younger, and that they resembled each other greatly in height, movements, voice, and (from the little I could see) even in their faces."

en: “‘You are Doctor Manette?’ said one.
vi: − Are you Dr. Manette? - Someone asked.
tr: "Are you Doctor Manette?" said one.
es: "—Are you Dr. Manette?—one of them asked me.

en: “I am.”
vi: − It's me.
tr: "Yes, it's me."
es: "—I am— I replied.

en: “‘Doctor Manette, formerly of Beauvais,’ said the other; ‘the young physician, originally an expert surgeon, who within the last year or two has made a rising reputation in Paris?’
vi: − Doctor Manette, formerly in Beauvais, - another person said, - the young doctor, originally a surgeon, who has become famous quickly in Paris in the past one or two years?
tr: "Isn't it Doctor Manette from Beauvais?" said the other; "you know, the one who was originally a surgeon and has gained fame in Paris over the last few years, young Doctor Manette?"
es: »—The doctor Manette, a native of Beauvais, a young and skilled physician and surgeon, who for the past one or two years has become a true notable in Paris?—interjected the other.

en: “‘Gentlemen,’ I returned, ‘I am that Doctor Manette of whom you speak so graciously.’
vi: − Sir, - I replied, - I am indeed Doctor Manette to whom you have given those kind words.
tr: "Gentlemen," I said, "yes. I am Doctor Manette, about whom you have spoken so elegantly."
es: "—Gentlemen; I am, indeed, Doctor Manette, of whom you speak with excessive benevolence— I replied.

en: “‘We have been to your residence,’ said the first, ‘and not being so fortunate as to find you there, and being informed that you were probably walking in this direction, we followed, in the hope of overtaking you.
vi: − We went to your residence, - the first person said, - but unfortunately, we didn't find you at home, and we were told that you might be taking a walk in this direction, so we followed in hopes of catching up with you.
tr: "First, we went to your house," said the first one, "but unfortunately, we couldn't find you there; they told us that you might have walked this way, so we came here hoping to catch you.
