es: "—We have been to your house—replied the one who had spoken first,—and not having had the luck to find you, although we were fortunate enough to be told that you were probably walking around these places, we followed you driven by the hope of catching up with you."

en: Will you please to enter the carriage?’
vi: Would you kindly get into this car and come with us?
tr: Now, would you please get in the car?"
es: Would you be so kind as to get into the carriage?

en: “The manner of both was imperious, and they both moved, as these words were spoken, so as to place me between themselves and the carriage door.
vi: Both of them had a threatening demeanor, and as soon as they finished speaking, they moved to force me towards the car door.
tr: They both had a commanding demeanor, and as they said these things, they moved to position me between the car door and themselves.
es: "The tone of his voice was imperious; while the words he left recorded were exchanged, they moved in such a way that left me positioned between them and the car door, and moreover, they were armed and I was not."

en: They were armed.
vi: They had weapons.
tr: They were armed.
es: "The tone of his voice was imperious; while the words he left recorded were exchanged, they moved in such a way that left me positioned between them and the car door, and moreover, they were armed and I was not."

en: I was not.
vi: I did not.
tr: I was not.
es: "The tone of his voice was imperious; while the words he left recorded were exchanged, they moved in such a way that left me positioned between them and the car door, and moreover, they were armed and I was not."

en: “‘Gentlemen,’ said I, ‘pardon me; but I usually inquire who does me the honour to seek my assistance, and what is the nature of the case to which I am summoned.’
vi: − Sir, - I said, - please excuse me, but I often like to know who I have the honor of being needed by, and what condition the illness that requires me is in.
tr: "Gentlemen," I said, "excuse me, but I usually like to know in advance which person is honoring me by needing my help and what kind of ailment the patient has."
es: "—I beg you to forgive me, gentlemen— I replied,—but it is my custom to ask who the people are who do me the honor of requesting my services and the nature of the case that makes my assistance necessary or convenient."

en: “The reply to this was made by him who had spoken second.
vi: − Doctor, - the second person replied, - your patient is a noble person.
tr: The response came from the second speaker.
es: "The one who had spoken second replied to me:

en: ‘Doctor, your clients are people of condition.
vi: − Doctor, - the second person replied, - your patient is a noble person.
tr: "Doctor, your patients are always distinguished individuals.
es: "—Your clients, doctor, are people of high social standing."

en: As to the nature of the case, our confidence in your skill assures us that you will ascertain it for yourself better than we can describe it.
vi: As for the condition, we believe that your expertise will ensure that you understand it better than we can describe.
tr: As for the nature of the illness, based on our confidence in your skill, we know that when you see the patient, you will understand it much better than we could ever explain to you.
es: "As far as the nature of the case that necessitates your assistance is concerned, the confidence we have in your science and skill is a guarantee for us that you will understand it without the need for our explanations, which would surely be inadequate."

en: Enough.
vi: That's enough.
tr: This information should suffice.
es: "I believe what has been said is sufficient."

en: Will you please to enter the carriage?’
vi: Would you be willing to get in the car?
tr: Now, would you please get in the car?"
es: "Would you be so kind as to mount?"

en: “I could do nothing but comply, and I entered it in silence.
vi: I had to comply and silently got into the car.
tr: There was no choice but to submit; I got into the car silently.
es: "I had no other recourse but to obey, and I did so without saying a word."

en: They both entered after me—the last springing in, after putting up the steps.
vi: Both of them got into the car after me, the last one jumping in after folding up the steps.
tr: Both of them got in after me – the last one jumped into the car after lifting the step.
es: Immediately, the two gentlemen followed me, with the one who entered last having picked up the stirrup.

en: The carriage turned about, and drove on at its former speed.
vi: The horse-drawn carriage turned around and sped off as before.
tr: The car turned around and sped off as quickly as it had come.
es: The carriage turned around and departed at a gallop.

en: “I repeat this conversation exactly as it occurred.
vi: I recount this conversation exactly as it happened.
tr: I'm writing this as it is.
es: "I record the conversation here exactly as it happened; I can assure you that I am repeating it verbatim, word for word."

en: I have no doubt that it is, word for word, the same.
vi: I am certain that every word is correct.
tr: I have no doubt that this conversation is exactly word for word the same.
es: "I record the conversation here exactly as it happened; I can assure you that I am repeating it verbatim, word for word."

en: I describe everything exactly as it took place, constraining my mind not to wander from the task.
vi: I describe everything exactly as it occurred and force my mind to focus on this task.
tr: Without allowing my mind to stray from the event, I am conveying everything exactly as it happened.
es: "I describe everything exactly as it took place, restraining my imagination and preventing it from wandering."

en: Where I make the broken marks that follow here, I leave off for the time, and put my paper in its hiding-place.
vi: The parts I left unfinished later on are because I had to temporarily stop writing and hide this pen...
tr: Now, I will mark the end of this part, take a break from writing, and hide this paper in its secret place.
es: "The ellipses that you find in my account mean that I am pausing the task for another occasion and that I am hiding the document in the designated hiding place..."

en: “The carriage left the streets behind, passed the North Barrier, and emerged upon the country road.
vi: The carriage crossed many roads, passed through the northern city gate, and then went out to the countryside road.
tr: The car left the streets behind and passed through the northern exit gate, heading out onto the highway outside the city.
es: "The carriage passed through many streets, went through the North Barrier, and soon advanced along a road outside the city."

en: At two-thirds of a league from the Barrier—I did not estimate the distance at that time, but afterwards when I traversed it—it struck out of the main avenue, and presently stopped at a solitary house, We all three alighted, and walked, by a damp soft footpath in a garden where a neglected fountain had overflowed, to the door of the house.
vi: About two-thirds of a mile from the city gate - at that time I did not estimate the distance, but on the way back I paid attention - the carriage turned off the main road and soon stopped at a secluded house. The three of us got off the carriage and followed a soft, wet dirt path in a garden with a neglected overflowing fountain, heading to the main door.
tr: After moving about two-thirds of a league from the barrier – at that moment, I couldn't estimate the distance exactly, but I paid attention later – the car left the highway and stopped in front of an isolated house. The three of us got out of the car and started walking, passing through the wet and soft path of a garden with a neglected fountain overflowing with water, until we reached the door of the house.
es: "At two-thirds of a league from the Barrier (I didn't calculate the distance then, but I did when I traveled it again), the carriage left the main road, and moments later it stopped in front of a solitary house." "The three of us jumped to the ground and advanced along a soft path in a garden, covered with grass, in the center of which a fountain had once flowed, until we reached the door of the house."

en: It was not opened immediately, in answer to the ringing of the bell, and one of my two conductors struck the man who opened it, with his heavy riding glove, across the face.
vi: The door did not open immediately after ringing the bell, and one of my two guides swung a thick riding glove and struck the face of the person who opened the door.
tr: Even though we rang the bell, it wasn't opened immediately, and after it was opened, one of my guides struck the man who opened the door in the face with the heavy riding glove in his hand.
es: "We were granted entry as soon as the bell rang, and the one who opened the door received a terrible slap from one of my companions."

en: “There was nothing in this action to attract my particular attention, for I had seen common people struck more commonly than dogs.
vi: That action didn't bother me much, as I had seen more people being beaten than dogs.
tr: I didn't find this behavior very strange, as I had often witnessed people being more infatuated with dogs than with ordinary humans.
es: "I confess that the act did not catch my attention, as I was very accustomed to seeing men of the lower class being treated by the nobles with less regard than if they were dogs."

en: But, the other of the two, being angry likewise, struck the man in like manner with his arm; the look and bearing of the brothers were then so exactly alike, that I then first perceived them to be twin brothers.
vi: But the second person, just as angry, also swung his hand to hit the person opening the door in that manner; the appearance and demeanor of these two were identical, so at that moment I thought they were twins.
tr: But the other man struck the person with his arm just as angrily and in the same manner; the brothers resembled each other so much in both appearance and behavior that it was only then that I realized they were twins.
es: "Once inside the house, I could observe that the resemblance between my two companions was so remarkable that I immediately took them for twin brothers."

en: “From the time of our alighting at the outer gate (which we found locked, and which one of the brothers had opened to admit us, and had relocked), I had heard cries proceeding from an upper chamber.
vi: From the moment we got off the car at the outer gate (the gate was tightly locked and one of the two brothers had to open it for us to enter and then lock it again), I heard many screams echoing from an upstairs room.
tr: As soon as we got out there at the outer door (the door was locked, but one of the brothers opened it and then locked it again), I heard the shouting coming from one of the rooms upstairs.
es: "Since we jumped out of the carriage in front of the garden gate, which we found closed and was opened by one of the brothers, closing it again after we passed through, I had been hearing screams that originated from one of the upper rooms of the house."

en: I was conducted to this chamber straight, the cries growing louder as we ascended the stairs, and I found a patient in a high fever of the brain, lying on a bed.
vi: I was taken directly to that room, the screams growing louder as we ascended the stairs, and I saw a patient suffering from encephalitis fever lying on the bed.
tr: I was directed straight to this room; with each step on the stairs, the screams grew louder; finally, I found in front of me a patient lying in bed, suffering from brain fever.
es: "They led me straight to the room from which the screams were coming, where I found a sick woman lying on the bed, suffering from a terrible brain fever."

en: “The patient was a woman of great beauty, and young; assuredly not much past twenty.
vi: The patient is a stunningly beautiful woman, still young; certainly not over twenty.
tr: The patient was an extraordinarily beautiful woman and young; she was definitely not more than twenty years old.
es: "The patient was a woman of wonderful beauty and very young; surely she was no more than twenty years old."

en: Her hair was torn and ragged, and her arms were bound to her sides with sashes and handkerchiefs.
vi: Her hair is disheveled and her arms are tied to her sides with various scarves and handkerchiefs.
tr: Her hair was disheveled and messy, and her arms were tied on both sides with sashes and handkerchiefs.
es: "Her beautiful hair was in such complete disarray that it saddened the spirit, and the patient's arms were bound with strips of cloth."

en: I noticed that these bonds were all portions of a gentleman’s dress.
vi: I noticed that all these bindings were items belonging to a gentleman's attire.
tr: I noticed that these bindings were parts of a man's clothing.
es: "I observed that these strips were pieces of a gentleman's suit, on one of which I saw the coat of arms of a noble with the initial E."

en: On one of them, which was a fringed scarf for a dress of ceremony, I saw the armorial bearings of a Noble, and the letter E.
vi: Among them was a fringed sash to be worn across formal attire, embroidered with the coat of arms of a noble family and the letter E.
tr: One of them had the letter E and a coat of arms on a fringed scarf used for a ceremonial dress.
es: "I observed that these strips were pieces of a gentleman's suit, on one of which I saw the coat of arms of a noble with the initial E."

en: “I saw this, within the first minute of my contemplation of the patient; for, in her restless strivings she had turned over on her face on the edge of the bed, had drawn the end of the scarf into her mouth, and was in danger of suffocation.
vi: I noticed this in the very first minute I looked at the patient; because in her restless struggle, she had turned her face towards the edge of the bed, one end of the bandage was in her mouth, and there was a risk of suffocation.
tr: I saw this as soon as I began to examine the patient; because during all her restless thrashing, the poor woman had turned face down towards the edge of the bed and the tip of her scarf had entered her mouth; she seemed to be suffocating.
es: “I made all these observations within a minute of having entered the room. It happened that the patient, whose agitation was dreadful, turned face down, one of the straps holding her got into her mouth, and I saw that she was in danger of suffocating.

en: My first act was to put out my hand to relieve her breathing; and in moving the scarf aside, the embroidery in the corner caught my sight.
vi: My first action was to reach out and pull the bandage so she could breathe easier; and at that moment, I immediately saw that sign embroidered in one corner.
tr: My first task was to ease her breathing, and as I put the scarf aside, the embroidered crest on its corner caught my eye.
es: Naturally, I removed the strip, and that was when I discovered the little embroidered coat of arms on it.

en: “I turned her gently over, placed my hands upon her breast to calm her and keep her down, and looked into her face.
vi: I gently turned her around, placed my hand on her chest to calm her and keep her still, and looked at that face.
tr: I gently turned him over, placed my hand on his chest to calm him down, and looked at his face.
es: "I turned the patient onto her back, placed my hand on her chest to calm her and make her stay still, and looked at her face."

en: Her eyes were dilated and wild, and she constantly uttered piercing shrieks, and repeated the words, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ and then counted up to twelve, and said, ‘Hush!’
vi: In her eyes, the pupils had dilated and become vacant; she kept screaming shrilly and repeatedly saying, "My husband, my father, my brother!" then counting from one to twelve, and then exclaiming, "Hush!".
tr: His eyes opened wide like saucers, and he frequently let out piercing screams that penetrated one's soul, muttering, "My husband, my father, my brother!"; then he counted to twelve and said, "Shh!"
es: "Her gaze was horribly dilated, and her clenched lips were repeatedly shouting these words: 'My husband... my father... my brother.'"

en: For an instant, and no more, she would pause to listen, and then the piercing shrieks would begin again, and she would repeat the cry, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ and would count up to twelve, and say, ‘Hush!’
vi: She only paused to listen for a moment, no more, then the shrill screams continued, and the same words repeated, "My husband, my father, my brother!" and then counting to twelve, and again, "Hush!".
tr: He paused for a moment to listen to his surroundings, then resumed the piercing screams, followed by again saying, "My husband, my father, my brother!" counting to twelve, and saying, "Shh!"
es: "Then she would count to twelve, remain silent for a few seconds listening with all the attention of her soul, and start shouting again 'My husband... my father... my brother,' and again count to twelve and again pause to listen."

en: There was no variation in the order, or the manner.
vi: It kept repeating like that, unchanged.
tr: There was no difference in either the sequence or the manner of these actions.
es: "There was not the slightest variation in her tone, gestures, or voice."

en: There was no cessation, but the regular moment’s pause, in the utterance of these sounds.
vi: Never stopping, except for the brief pauses between the delirious words.
tr: He did not take any breaks except for the brief pause before saying those words.
es: "—When did this state of affairs begin?

en: “‘How long,’ I asked, ‘has this lasted?’
vi: − How long have you been like this? - I asked.
tr: "Since when has it been like this?" I asked.
es: —I asked.

en: “To distinguish the brothers, I will call them the elder and the younger; by the elder, I mean him who exercised the most authority.
vi: To distinguish between these two brothers, I will refer to them as the older brother and the younger brother; I call one the older brother because he appears to have the most authority.
tr: To distinguish between the brothers, I will call one big and the other small; the one I call big, who is more authoritative, responded, "Since around this time last night."
es: "In order to distinguish between the two brothers, I will call one the elder brother and the other the younger, understanding by the elder the one who exercised greater authority."

en: It was the elder who replied, ‘Since about this hour last night.’
vi: It was the elder brother who answered: − Since around this time last night.
tr: To distinguish between the brothers, I will call one big and the other small; the one I call big, who is more authoritative, responded, "Since around this time last night."
es: "—Since last night at this time—replied the older brother.

en: “‘She has a husband, a father, and a brother?’
vi: − Does she have a husband, father, and sibling?
tr: "Does she have a husband, a father, and a brother?"
es: "—Does she have a husband, father, and brother?"

en: “‘A brother.’
vi: − A younger brother.
tr: "He/She has a sibling.""
es: »—He has a brother.

en: “‘I do not address her brother?’
vi: − Aren't you her brother? −
tr: "Am I speaking with the sibling right now?"
es: »—And am I not speaking with that brother at this very moment?

en: “He answered with great contempt, ‘No.’
vi: No, - he answered with utmost contempt.
tr: "No," replied the man with a sneer.
es: "—No—he replied with a tone of deep contempt.

en: “‘She has some recent association with the number twelve?’
vi: − Has she recently been involved with the number twelve?
tr: "Has something happened recently with the number twelve?"
es: »—Has anything related to the number twelve happened to her recently?»

en: “The younger brother impatiently rejoined, ‘With twelve o’clock?’
vi: The impatient younger one interrupted: − Twelve o'clock? −
tr: The little brother impatiently interrupted, "It's about twelve o'clock."
es: "—With number twelve?—repeated the younger brother impatiently.

en: “‘See, gentlemen,’ said I, still keeping my hands upon her breast, ‘how useless I am, as you have brought me!
vi: There, gentlemen, - I said, still keeping my hand on her chest, - if you take me like this, I am helpless!
tr: My hand is still on the patient's chest, "Look, gentlemen," I said, "you brought me here but it was of no use!
es: "—You can convince yourselves, gentlemen, of how uselessly you have brought me here, just as I am," I said, my hands still placed on the patient's chest.

en: If I had known what I was coming to see, I could have come provided.
vi: If I had known beforehand what I would see, I would have brought the necessary items.
tr: If you had explained the situation, I would have come prepared accordingly.
es: "If I had known what was happening, I would have come equipped with what was necessary, whereas now we are wasting time miserably."

en: As it is, time must be lost.
vi: But like this, it's a waste of time.
tr: Now we will waste time.
es: "If I had known what was happening, I would have come equipped with what was necessary, whereas now we are wasting time miserably."

en: There are no medicines to be obtained in this lonely place.’
vi: In this desolate place, how can we find any medicine?
tr: There is no place to find medicine in this desolate area.'"
es: "In a place as isolated as this, it is not possible to find medicines."

en: “The elder brother looked to the younger, who said haughtily, ‘There is a case of medicines here;’ and brought it from a closet, and put it on the table.
vi: The older brother looked at the younger brother. − There is a chest full of medicine here, - the younger brother said arrogantly, then pulled a small chest out of the cupboard and placed it on the table...
tr: The younger brother, with an arrogant air, said, "There is a medicine box here," and took the box out of a cupboard, placing it on the table, while the elder one looked at him.
es: "The older brother looked at the younger one, who replied in a haughty voice: "—We have a first aid kit here." »Moments later, he took it out of a cupboard and placed it on the table...

en: “I opened some of the bottles, smelt them, and put the stoppers to my lips.
vi: I opened several bottles, sniffed them, and brought the lids to my lips.
tr: I opened and smelled some of the bottles and brought the stoppers to my lips.
es: "I opened some jars, smelled them, and brought their caps to my lips."

en: If I had wanted to use anything save narcotic medicines that were poisons in themselves, I would not have administered any of those.
vi: I certainly wouldn't use these unless I needed anesthetic drugs with toxic substances.
tr: Under different circumstances, I wouldn't have been able to give any of these drug pills that act as poison on their own.
es: "If I had needed to administer any non-narcotic or non-toxic substance to the patient, I certainly wouldn't have medicated her with anything that the medicine cabinet contained."

en: “‘Do you doubt them?’ asked the younger brother.
vi: The younger one asked: "Can't use them?"
tr: "Did you not trust the medicines?" asked the little brother.
es: "—Don't they inspire confidence in you?—asked the younger brother.

en: “‘You see, monsieur, I am going to use them,’ I replied, and said no more.
vi: "Sir, I have no choice but to use them," I replied and said nothing more.
tr: "Alright, monsieur, I will give it to you in a moment," I replied, and said nothing more.
es: "—You can see, sir, that I am going to use them— I replied simply.

en: “I made the patient swallow, with great difficulty, and after many efforts, the dose that I desired to give.
vi: I had a very hard time giving the patient the medication, and after many attempts, I finally managed to administer the desired dosage.
tr: After a considerable struggle, I managed to administer the dose I wanted to the patient.
es: »Not without having to struggle with great difficulties, and after a long while, I managed to get the patient to take the dose of medicine that I deemed appropriate.

en: As I intended to repeat it after a while, and as it was necessary to watch its influence, I then sat down by the side of the bed.
vi: Since I planned to give the medication again shortly to monitor its effects, I sat down next to the bed.
tr: Since I intended to give the same amount again shortly and observe its effects, I sat right by the bed.
es: Since my intention was to repeat the medication and observe the effects that the first dose had on the patient, I sat at the head of her bed.

en: There was a timid and suppressed woman in attendance (wife of the man down-stairs), who had retreated into a corner.
vi: Sitting in the corner of the room was a timid and frightened woman assisting (she was the wife of the person who had opened the door).
tr: A timid and downcast woman (the wife of the man downstairs) who was taking care of the patient had shrunk into a corner of the room.
es: Sitting timidly and obviously shy in a corner, there was a woman who was taking care of her, married to one of the individuals from downstairs.

en: The house was damp and decayed, indifferently furnished—evidently, recently occupied and temporarily used.
vi: The house was damp and decaying, with sparse furnishings - clearly, it had only been recently occupied temporarily.
tr: The house was damp, falling apart everywhere, and very carelessly furnished – it was clearly being used temporarily and had been recently moved into.
es: The house was dirty, poorly maintained, and furnished, evident signs that they had occupied it very recently and that their intention was to stay there for a very short time.

en: Some thick old hangings had been nailed up before the windows, to deaden the sound of the shrieks.
vi: Some old, thick curtains had been nailed to the windows to muffle the sound of the screaming.
tr: Old thick fabrics had been nailed to the windows to reduce the intensity of the sharp screams.
es: They had temporarily hung some drapes in front of the windows, undoubtedly to prevent the patient's screams from reaching the outside.

en: They continued to be uttered in their regular succession, with the cry, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ the counting up to twelve, and ‘Hush!’
vi: The patient continued to scream in the same rhythm, after "My husband, my father, my brother!" she would count to twelve, then "Shh!".
tr: These screams, cries of "My husband, my father, my brother!", counting up to twelve, and "Shh!" sounds followed each other in a regular pattern.
es: She continued screaming as she had when I arrived, repeating the same words in the same order: «My husband... my father... my brother», and then counting up to twelve.

en: The frenzy was so violent, that I had not unfastened the bandages restraining the arms; but, I had looked to them, to see that they were not painful.
vi: Her madness was so intense that I had to remove the straps binding her hands, but I was careful not to let her flailing arms cause her harm.
tr: The fit was so severe that I hadn't untied the restraints preventing him from moving his arms, but I checked to make sure they weren't causing pain.
es: Her convulsions were so violent that I did not deem it prudent to free her from the straps that restrained her, although I adjusted them to make them less bothersome.

en: The only spark of encouragement in the case, was, that my hand upon the sufferer’s breast had this much soothing influence, that for minutes at a time it tranquillised the figure.
vi: The only small consolation in this situation was that my hand placed on the patient's chest had a calming effect, helping her to stay calm for a few minutes.
tr: The only thing that encouraged me in this situation was seeing that my hand placed on the poor man's chest had a calming effect and that this comforted him, even if only for three to five minutes.
es: The crisis did not respond to the medication, but I observed that the pressure of my hand on the patient's chest had such an influence on her that after a few minutes she calmed down.

en: It had no effect upon the cries; no pendulum could be more regular.
vi: But it did not stop the screams; they were more regular than the swinging of a pendulum.
tr: On the other hand, it had no effect on the screams; frankly, no pendulum could operate so regularly.
es: However, it did not have the same effect on the screams, which continued with the regularity of a pendulum.

en: “For the reason that my hand had this effect (I assume), I had sat by the side of the bed for half an hour, with the two brothers looking on, before the elder said:
vi: Because my hand seemed to have the effect of calming the madness (I thought so), I sat by the bedside for half an hour, while the two brothers stood watching, and finally the older brother spoke up: −
tr: Since the elimination had such an effect (I think it did), I sat on the edge of the bed for about half an hour with my siblings' eyes on me; then the older one said:
es: "I had been sitting by the bed for half an hour under the gaze of the two brothers when the elder said:

en: “‘There is another patient.’
vi: There is another patient.
tr: "There is one more patient."
es: "—We have another patient."

en: “I was startled, and asked, ‘Is it a pressing case?’
vi: I startled and asked: "Is it urgent?" −
tr: I was taken aback; "Is it an emergency then?" I asked.
es: "The news alarmed me, and I asked: "—Is the case urgent?"

en: “‘You had better see,’ he carelessly answered; and took up a light.
vi: "It's best if you go check on the patient," he replied nonchalantly; then he picked up the lamp...
tr: With a nonchalant air, he said, "You'd better see it," and took a lamp in his hand.
es: "—It would be better if you saw it with your own eyes—he replied to me in a negligent tone, taking a light...

en: “The other patient lay in a back room across a second staircase, which was a species of loft over a stable.
vi: The patient is in the room behind the second staircase.
tr: The other patient was lying in one of the back rooms opposite the second staircase, in a place like an attic above a stable.
es: "The second patient lay in a room situated at the back of the house, a room that was really nothing more than an attic placed above a stable."

en: There was a low plastered ceiling to a part of it; the rest was open, to the ridge of the tiled roof, and there were beams across.
vi: The room was like an attic above the horse stable; part of the ceiling was low and whitewashed, while the rest was open up to the edge of the tiled roof, exposing the crossbeams.
tr: A part of this area was covered by a low ceiling with plaster; the remaining part opened to the roof covered with tiles, and there were beams across.
es: "Part of the attic had a very low roof and part did not."

en: Hay and straw were stored in that portion of the place, fagots for firing, and a heap of apples in sand.
vi: In that open-ceiling area, there were straw, bundles of firewood, and a pile of apples stored in sand.
tr: In this section, dry grass and straw were piled up for burning, and apples were placed on a pile of sand.
es: "Under the covered part, there was hay and straw stored, and the rest contained firewood and farming tools."

en: I had to pass through that part, to get at the other.
vi: I had to pass through that area to get to the other side.
tr: I had to pass through here to get to the other section.
es: "I remember all these details so well that it seems as if I am seeing them at this moment just as I saw them that night, despite being locked up for ten years in my cell in the Bastille."

en: My memory is circumstantial and unshaken.
vi: I remember it very clearly and precisely.
tr: All the details remain vividly in my memory.
es: "I remember all these details so well that it seems as if I am seeing them at this moment just as I saw them that night, despite being locked up for ten years in my cell in the Bastille."

en: I try it with these details, and I see them all, in this my cell in the Bastille, near the close of the tenth year of my captivity, as I saw them all that night.
vi: I remember every detail vividly, and even in the Bastille prison, after nearly ten years of captivity, I still remember it as if I had seen it that night.
tr: As I approach the end of my tenth year of imprisonment in this cell in the Bastille, everything is in my mind with all the details as it was that night.
es: "I remember all these details so well that it seems as if I am seeing them at this moment just as I saw them that night, despite being locked up for ten years in my cell in the Bastille."

en: “On some hay on the ground, with a cushion thrown under his head, lay a handsome peasant boy—a boy of not more than seventeen at the most.
vi: Lying on his back on a layer of straw on the ground, with his head resting on a pillow, was a handsome young farmer - a youth of about seventeen years old at most.
tr: On the dry grass on the ground, with a pillow under his head, lay a handsome peasant boy – he couldn't have been older than seventeen.
es: "On a pile of hay and with his head resting on a pillow, lay a young man with a peasant-like appearance, a handsome face, and who could not have been more than seventeen years old."

en: He lay on his back, with his teeth set, his right hand clenched on his breast, and his glaring eyes looking straight upward.
vi: He lay on his back, teeth clenched, his right hand clutching his chest, and his eyes blazing as he stared straight up.
tr: His teeth were tightly clenched, his right hand claw-like on his chest, and his fiery eyes stared straight at the ceiling as he lay on his back.
es: "He was lying on his back, with clenched teeth, his right hand clenched over his chest, and his gaze fixed on the ceiling."

en: I could not see where his wound was, as I kneeled on one knee over him; but, I could see that he was dying of a wound from a sharp point.
vi: I couldn't see his wound when I knelt on one knee beside him, but I could tell he was about to die from a stab wound.
tr: When I knelt on one knee and leaned over him, I couldn't see where his wound was; but it was not hard to tell that he had been injured by something sharp and was about to die.
es: "I knelt beside him; and although I could not find the wound he had received, I immediately saw that he was dying from a wound caused by a sharp instrument."

en: “‘I am a doctor, my poor fellow,’ said I.
vi: − I am a doctor, poor you, - I said. -
tr: "I am a doctor, my friend," I said.
es: "—I am a doctor, my poor friend— I said; —let me examine you."

en: ‘Let me examine it.’
vi: Let me examine you.
tr: "Let me take a look at your wound.""
es: "—I am a doctor, my poor friend— I said; —let me examine you."

en: “‘I do not want it examined,’ he answered; ‘let it be.’
vi: − I don't need an examination, - he replied, - just leave it be.
tr: "I don't want you to look," said the boy; "never mind."
es: "—I don't want to be recognized; leave me alone—he replied."

en: “It was under his hand, and I soothed him to let me move his hand away.
vi: The wound lay under his hand, and I coaxed him to lift his hand away.
tr: The wound was under my hand, and I eased it a bit to allow me to pull my hand away.
es: "The wound was located below his right hand, which took me no small effort and many attempts to separate."

en: The wound was a sword-thrust, received from twenty to twenty-four hours before, but no skill could have saved him if it had been looked to without delay.
vi: It was a sword wound that had pierced his chest twenty or twenty-four hours ago, but even if treated immediately, it would have been impossible to save him.
tr: It was a sword wound that had occurred twenty to twenty-four hours ago, but even if it had been immediately attended to by skilled hands, there was no chance of survival.
es: "It was a stab wound received twenty to twenty-four hours earlier, a mortal stab wound, even if all the aid of science had been provided the second it was inflicted."

en: He was then dying fast.
vi: In just a moment, he would die.
tr: The boy was dying rapidly.
es: "He was dying in spurts."

en: As I turned my eyes to the elder brother, I saw him looking down at this handsome boy whose life was ebbing out, as if he were a wounded bird, or hare, or rabbit; not at all as if he were a fellow-creature.
vi: When I turned towards his brother, I saw him looking down at the handsome young man who was dying with an indifferent gaze, as if the victim were a bird or a hare rather than a fellow human being.
tr: When I turned my eyes to the older brother, I saw that he was looking at this handsome young man, whose life was fading away, not as if he were a wounded person, but as if he were a wounded bird or rabbit.
es: "I searched with my gaze for the older brother's, and observed that he was watching the wounded boy with the same indifference with which he would watch a bird, a hare, or a wounded rabbit." "It was clearly noticeable that he did not see a human being in the boy."

en: “‘How has this been done, monsieur?’ said I.
vi: − How did it come to this, sir? - I asked.
tr: "How did this happen, monsieur?" I asked.
es: "—Who caused you that wound, sir?—I asked.

en: “‘A crazed young common dog!
vi: − A rabid dog gone mad!
tr: "This boy is a rabid, common dog!
es: "—Bah!" "Why talk about a miserable servant... a dog?"

en: A serf!
vi: A serf!
tr: Villager!
es: "—Bah!" "Why talk about a miserable servant... a dog?"

en: Forced my brother to draw upon him, and has fallen by my brother’s sword—like a gentleman.’
vi: Forcing my brother to draw his sword and he fell under my brother's blade... like a nobleman.
tr: He forced my brother to draw his sword and got wounded by his sword –like a gentleman."
es: "He forced my brother to fight against him, and fell under his sword as if he had been a knight."

en: “There was no touch of pity, sorrow, or kindred humanity, in this answer.
vi: There was no trace of compassion, sorrow, or humanity in that response.
tr: His response did not contain the slightest bit of pity, sadness, or humanity.
es: "In the tone of the reply, there was neither a shadow of pity, nor a shadow of sorrow, nor a shadow of remorse."

en: The speaker seemed to acknowledge that it was inconvenient to have that different order of creature dying there, and that it would have been better if he had died in the usual obscure routine of his vermin kind.
vi: The speaker seemed to acknowledge the inconvenience of having someone from a different social class die here, and it would have been better if he had died in some obscure corner like other lowly beings.
tr: He seemed more disturbed by the fact that this creature from another world was dying there; it would have been better if it died in its own dark corner like a parasitic animal.
es: "In the tone of the reply, there was neither a shadow of pity, nor a shadow of sorrow, nor a shadow of remorse."

en: He was quite incapable of any compassionate feeling about the boy, or about his fate.
vi: He had no compassion whatsoever for the young man or his fate.
tr: There was not an ounce of compassion in his heart for either that young boy or his fate.
es: "In the tone of the reply, there was neither a shadow of pity, nor a shadow of sorrow, nor a shadow of remorse."

en: “The boy’s eyes had slowly moved to him as he had spoken, and they now slowly moved to me.
vi: The farmer's gaze slowly turned towards the speaker and then slowly turned towards me.
tr: While he was talking, the boy's eyes slowly turned towards him, and then slowly turned towards me.
es: "The eyes of the dying man turned towards the one who had just spoken, then fixed on me."

en: “‘Doctor, they are very proud, these Nobles; but we common dogs are proud too, sometimes.
vi: − Doctor, they are very arrogant, these nobles; but we lowly peasants also have moments of pride.
tr: "Doctor, these nobles are very proud; but we, the common dogs, can also be proud, sometimes.
es: "—Doctor—he told me;—those nobles are very haughty; but we too, the miserable dogs, have our pride.

en: They plunder us, outrage us, beat us, kill us; but we have a little pride left, sometimes.
vi: They rob us, seize us, beat us, kill us, but sometimes we still have a bit of pride left.
tr: They rob us, crush us, beat us, kill us, but we still have a bit of pride left, sometimes.
es: They rob us, they loot us, they outrage us, they vilify us, they beat us, but all of that is not enough to drown our haughtiness.

en: She—have you seen her, Doctor?’
vi: My sister... have you met my sister, doctor?
tr: Have you seen her... the girl, Doctor?"
es: She... have you seen her, doctor?

en: “The shrieks and the cries were audible there, though subdued by the distance.
vi: You can still hear the screams here, even though the distance has muffled the sound.
tr: "Even though there was a distance, the screams and wails could be heard from there.
es: The cries of the unfortunate woman reached there, albeit very muffled by the distance.

en: He referred to them, as if she were lying in our presence.
vi: He talks as if his sister is present here.
tr: The boy had talked about the girl as if she were lying next to us.
es: The wounded man referred to the one who gave them as if she had been by his side.

en: “I said, ‘I have seen her.’
vi: − I met, - I said.
tr: "I saw," I said.
es: "—I have seen her, yes— I replied.

en: “‘She is my sister, Doctor.
vi: − That is my sister, doctor.
tr: "She is my sister, Doctor.
es: "—She is my sister, doctor.

en: They have had their shameful rights, these Nobles, in the modesty and virtue of our sisters, many years, but we have had good girls among us.
vi: These people, these aristocrats, have had the outrageous right to violate the chastity of our sisters for many years, but we still have virtuous girls.
tr: These nobles have every kind of disgraceful right, for years they used our sisters' chastity and virtue as they wished. But there were good girls among them too.
es: Those nobles may have had shameful rights over the modesty and virtue of our sisters for many years; but among us, there are still good girls, girls who know how to resist their violence.

en: I know it, and have heard my father say so.
vi: I know that, and I have heard my father say so.
tr: I know, I had heard this from my father too.
es: I know it, and I have heard my father affirm it as such.

en: She was a good girl.
vi: My sister is a virtuous girl.
tr: My sister was a good girl.
es: My sister is one of them.

en: She was betrothed to a good young man, too: a tenant of his.
vi: She was betrothed to a good man, who was also a tenant of his.
tr: She was engaged to a good young man, one of this man's tenants.
es: She had a romantic relationship with a young man, also good and honest, a vassal of this noble who is there... we were all his vassals...

en: We were all tenants of his—that man’s who stands there.
vi: We are all his tenants... the one standing there.
tr: We were all tenants of his – the man standing over there.
es: She had a romantic relationship with a young man, also good and honest, a vassal of this noble who is there... we were all his vassals...

en: The other is his brother, the worst of a bad race.’
vi: And the other one is his brother, the worst of this vile family.
tr: The other one is his brother, the worst of a bad lineage."
es: The other is his brother, the vilest representative of his despicable race.

en: “It was with the greatest difficulty that the boy gathered bodily force to speak; but, his spirit spoke with a dreadful emphasis.
vi: He had to exert all his strength to speak, but he spoke with a truly terrifyingly strong voice.
tr: The boy's body could barely find the strength to speak; but his soul was screaming as if it were shouting.
es: "The unfortunate man had to make truly superhuman efforts to be able to speak; but if he lacked physical strength, he had an abundance of spiritual strength, and he spoke with extraordinary fortitude."

en: “‘We were so robbed by that man who stands there, as all we common dogs are by those superior Beings—taxed by him without mercy, obliged to work for him without pay, obliged to grind our corn at his mill, obliged to feed scores of his tame birds on our wretched crops, and forbidden for our lives to keep a single tame bird of our own, pillaged and plundered to that degree that when we chanced to have a bit of meat, we ate it in fear, with the door barred and the shutters closed, that his people should not see it and take it from us—I say, we were so robbed, and hunted, and were made so poor, that our father told us it was a dreadful thing to bring a child into the world, and that what we should most pray for, was, that our women might be barren and our miserable race die out!’
vi: − We have been excessively plundered by the one standing over there, just like any other destitute peasant... forced to pay taxes without any mercy, forced to work for him without pay, forced to grind our grain at his mill, forced to use our meager harvests to feed his flock, while we couldn't even keep a single bird, plundered to the extent that if we had a bit of meat to eat, we had to eat it in fear, behind locked doors, hiding it from his men for fear of having our food snatched away... That's right, we were robbed, hunted, and stripped to such poverty that my father said bringing a child into this world was a crime, and the best prayer was for our women to be barren so that this wretched race would perish!
tr: "Here, the man standing over there robbed us; after all, they are superior beings, and we are the dogs beside them – they collect merciless taxes from us, make us work for them without any payment, force us to grind our wheat in their mill, compel us to feed their pet birds with the handful of wheat we have, and do not allow us to keep even a single bird of our own. Robbery and plundering had become so rampant that if we found a small piece of meat, we would eat it behind closed doors in fear that their men might see it and take it from us – in other words, we were so robbed, so captured, and so impoverished that my father would tell us how terrifying it was to bring a child into this world and would say that we should pray for our women to be barren so that our wretched lineage would come to an end.""
es: "—That man over there robbed us with the coldness and indifference with which those beings of a nature superior to the human rob us, the common dogs... he stripped us without compassion, forced us to work without paying us, to take our wheat to his mill, to feed his poultry with our crops, but imposing the death penalty on anyone who dared to take one of them, he plundered and robbed us to such an extent that if ever, by God's mercy, we had a scrap of meat to put in our mouths, we ate it terrified, first barricading the doors and windows of our poor houses, so that his people wouldn't see it and steal it from us. I repeat that they stripped us in such a way, harassed us in such a way, made life so impossible for us, that a thousand times I heard my father say that it was an immense misfortune for us to bring a child into the world, and that we should pray to God to condemn all the women of our caste to sterility, so that it would be extinguished once and for all.

en: “I had never before seen the sense of being oppressed, bursting forth like a fire.
vi: I have never seen anyone speak about their oppression with such blazing indignation.
tr: I had never seen the feeling of oppression erupt in such a way and turn into a fire before.
es: "Never had I witnessed the explosion of the feelings of the unfortunate oppressed; I supposed, yes, that deep in their souls they harbored immense amounts of hatred against their oppressors; but their outburst was a new spectacle for me until that night."

en: I had supposed that it must be latent in the people somewhere; but, I had never seen it break out, until I saw it in the dying boy.
vi: I think that feeling must have been simmering within them, but I had never seen it erupt until I met this dying farmer.
tr: I had guessed that this feeling was hidden somewhere inside people, but I had never seen it manifest in this way before this struggling child.
es: "Never had I witnessed the explosion of the feelings of the unfortunate oppressed; I supposed, yes, that deep in their souls they harbored immense amounts of hatred against their oppressors; but their outburst was a new spectacle for me until that night."

en: “‘Nevertheless, Doctor, my sister married.
vi: − But doctor, my sister is already married.
tr: "Still, my sister got married, Doctor.
es: "—Doctor, my sister got married, despite everything.

en: He was ailing at that time, poor fellow, and she married her lover, that she might tend and comfort him in our cottage—our dog-hut, as that man would call it.
vi: My brother-in-law, poor thing, was sick at that time, and my sister married the man she loved to take care of him in our little hut... which that person over there calls a doghouse.
tr: The poor man had an ailment at the time, my sister married this man she loved, so she could take care of him in our cabin –that man would probably call it a doghouse.
es: Her poor fiancé was in bad health at the time, and my sister married him to care for him in our cabin... our kennel, as that monster in front of us would say.

en: She had not been married many weeks, when that man’s brother saw her and admired her, and asked that man to lend her to him—for what are husbands among us!
vi: Just a few weeks after my sister got married, that guy's brother met my sister and developed a desire for her, demanding that his brother lend my sister to him... Such is the fate of us men as husbands!
tr: It had only been a few weeks since they got married when that man's brother saw her, liked her, and asked her husband to lend her to him –the authority of husbands like ours means nothing!
es: She had been married for only a few weeks when she had the misfortune of being seen by that man's brother; he liked her, and with the greatest naturalness in the world, he asked his older brother to lend her to him. What did it matter that she was married? Husbands are such insignificant things among us!...

en: He was willing enough, but my sister was good and virtuous, and hated his brother with a hatred as strong as mine.
vi: His brother agreed, but my sister, being virtuous and modest, ended up hating his brother just as much as I did.
tr: The man was quite willing, but my sister was a good and honorable woman and hated that man's brother at least as much as I did.
es: The older brother agreed without any inconvenience, but my sister was good and virtuous, and moreover, she detested her admirer as much as I do.

en: What did the two then, to persuade her husband to use his influence with her, to make her willing?’
vi: I don't know what those two did to force my brother-in-law to persuade his wife to comply.
tr: So what did these two do to persuade her husband to convince my sister, to influence her in this matter?"
es: What do you think the two brothers did then to get my sister's husband to exert all his influence over her until she was forced to yield to their vile desires?

en: “The boy’s eyes, which had been fixed on mine, slowly turned to the looker-on, and I saw in the two faces that all he said was true.
vi: Staring intently at me, the young man's gaze slowly shifted to the person standing there, and through both faces, I knew that everything he said was true.
tr: The child's eyes, fixed on me, slowly turned to the men watching him, and when I looked at these two faces, I saw that everything the boy had said was true.
es: "The boy's eyes, fixed until then on mine, slowly turned towards those of the nobleman, in whose face it was not difficult for me to read the truth of the charges made against him."

en: The two opposing kinds of pride confronting one another, I can see, even in this Bastille; the gentleman’s, all negligent indifference; the peasant’s, all trodden-down sentiment, and passionate revenge.
vi: Two distinct prides were confronting each other, and even here in the Bastille dungeon, I could clearly see the indifferent defiance of the nobleman clashing with the trampled emotions and seething hatred of the peasant.
tr: Even here, in the Bastille, I can see the clash of two opposing kinds of pride; the utter indifference of the noble gentleman and the intense emotions and passionate revenge of the peasant.
es: Even here, in the interior of the Bastille's tomb where I have been for so many years, I believe I can see the two kinds of pride, perfectly distinct, reflected in the two faces: indifference and coldness breathed from the gentleman's; furious desires for revenge from the peasant boy's.

en: “‘You know, Doctor, that it is among the Rights of these Nobles to harness us common dogs to carts, and drive us.
vi: − You know, doctor, these nobles have the right to harness us lowly folks to their carriage and whip us to pull it.
tr: "You know, Doctor, it is among the rights of these nobles to harness and drive dogs like us in front of their carriages.
es: "—You know, doctor, that one of the rights of those nobles consists of harnessing us, who are miserable dogs, to their carts and forcing us to pull."

en: They so harnessed him and drove him.
vi: They treated my brother-in-law like that.
tr: They harnessed and drove my sister's husband to the carriage:
es: "Well, they harnessed my sister's husband, properly geared, to a cart, and forced him to pull it."

en: You know that it is among their Rights to keep us in their grounds all night, quieting the frogs, in order that their noble sleep may not be disturbed.
vi: You know they have the right to make us stay out in the garden all night to keep the frogs quiet so the nobles can sleep peacefully.
tr: You know, it is also among their rights to keep us on their lands all night to chase away the frogs and ensure they sleep well: they made the poor man wait in that terrible fog all night and harnessed him to the carriage the next day.
es: "You know, doctor, that among the rights of those nobles is the right to force us to spend the nights on their lands, imposing silence on the frogs so that their croaking does not disturb their noble sleep; my sister's husband spent the nights in the open and the days pulling the cart."

en: They kept him out in the unwholesome mists at night, and ordered him back into his harness in the day.
vi: They kept my brother-in-law out in the cold frost all night, and in the morning, they tied my brother to the cart again.
tr: You know, it is also among their rights to keep us on their lands all night to chase away the frogs and ensure they sleep well: they made the poor man wait in that terrible fog all night and harnessed him to the carriage the next day.
es: "You know, doctor, that among the rights of those nobles is the right to force us to spend the nights on their lands, imposing silence on the frogs so that their croaking does not disturb their noble sleep; my sister's husband spent the nights in the open and the days pulling the cart."

en: But he was not persuaded.
vi: But my brother did not submit.
tr: But he still wasn't convinced.
es: "He did not let himself be persuaded... No!"

en: No!
vi: No!
tr: No!
es: "He did not let himself be persuaded... No!"

en: Taken out of harness one day at noon, to feed—if he could find food—he sobbed twelve times, once for every stroke of the bell, and died on her bosom.’
vi: One day, he was unbridled at noon to eat... if my brother could find food... my brother sobbed twelve times, each sob like the chime of a clock striking noon, and then died in my sister's arms.
tr: Then one noon, while he was unhitched from the harness to eat –if he could find any– he cried, sobbing exactly twelve times, breaking into sobs every time the bell struck the hour, and died in his wife's arms."
es: "One day, when they freed him from the harness and dismissed him to go eat... if he could find something, he exhaled twelve sobs, one for each chime of the clock—it was noon—and died in my sister's arms."

en: “Nothing human could have held life in the boy but his determination to tell all his wrong.
vi: Only an extraordinary determination to expose the crime could prolong his life.
tr: The boy was clearly determined to stay alive until he finished recounting all this cruelty.
es: »Only the desire to explain the grievance received sustained life in that dying body.

en: He forced back the gathering shadows of death, as he forced his clenched right hand to remain clenched, and to cover his wound.
vi: The young man struggled against the encroaching darkness of death and continued to tightly grip his right hand, pressing down on the wound.
tr: Just as he exerted strength to tightly clasp his hand to his chest like a claw to close his wound, he was also pushing back the shadows of death attacking him with the same force.
es: Searching in his determination for energies he could not find in his body, he pushed away the shadows of death that invaded him and pressed his wound, through which his life was escaping, harder than ever.

en: “‘Then, with that man’s permission and even with his aid, his brother took her away; in spite of what I know she must have told his brother—and what that is, will not be long unknown to you, Doctor, if it is now—his brother took her away—for his pleasure and diversion, for a little while.
vi: − Then, with the agreement and even the assistance of the person standing there, his younger brother took my sister away, despite the things I know my sister surely told his younger brother... what those things are, you will soon know, doctor... He took my sister away... to indulge himself for a while.
tr: "Then, with the permission and even the help of this man, his brother took my sister away: despite all the things my sister told him –and you will soon learn what she said, Doctor, perhaps you already understand– he took my sister away for a moment of pleasure and amusement.
es: "—With the death of my sister's husband, with the authorization of this man, and even with his material support, his brother violently took possession of the poor widow, whom he needed for his pleasures, for his momentary amusement."

en: I saw her pass me on the road.
vi: I saw my sister crossing the street.
tr: I saw them as they passed by me on the road.
es: "I stumbled upon her on the road when they were taking her away."

en: When I took the tidings home, our father’s heart burst; he never spoke one of the words that filled it.
vi: When I got home to report the news, my father had a heart attack and died immediately, without a chance to say a word that was weighing on his mind.
tr: When I told what happened to the people at home, my father had a heart attack; but not a single word came out of his mouth that could express his pain.
es: "I brought the news to our house, and upon hearing it, my father's heart shattered into a thousand pieces."

en: I took my young sister (for I have another) to a place beyond the reach of this man, and where, at least, she will never be his vassal.
vi: I took my younger sister, I have another younger sister, to a hidden place far away from that savage, where at least my sister would never become his slave.
tr: I took my little sister (I have another sister) to a place where this man couldn't reach her, at least where she couldn't be his slave.
es: "Immediately, I accompanied my younger sister—I have two... to a place where she would be out of that man's reach, to a place where she would not be his vassal."

en: Then, I tracked the brother here, and last night climbed in—a common dog, but sword in hand.
vi: Then, I followed the guy's trail all the way here, and last night climbed into the house... a lowly dog, but with a sword in hand...
tr: Then I followed his brother here and last night I climbed in like a dog but with a sword in my hand... I entered.
es: "I then returned, followed that noble's brother, and last night I confronted him, I, a despicable dog, but with a sword in my hand..."

en: —Where is the loft window?
vi: Where is the attic window?
tr: –Where is the attic window?
es: "Where is the window?...

en: It was somewhere here?’
vi: Somewhere around here, right?
tr: Wasn't it somewhere around here?'
es: Wasn't there a window here?"

en: “The room was darkening to his sight; the world was narrowing around him.
vi: The room darkened in his eyes; the world around him was shrinking.
tr: His vision began to darken; the world around him was gradually closing in.
es: »Life was abandoning him, and with life, the light.

en: I glanced about me, and saw that the hay and straw were trampled over the floor, as if there had been a struggle.
vi: I glanced around and saw trampled straw on the floor as if there had been a scuffle.
tr: When I looked around, I saw that the grass and hay were crushed, as if a struggle had taken place.
es: I cast my eyes around and noticed that the hay and straw covering the ground were trampled and crushed, as if a fierce struggle had taken place there.

en: “‘She heard me, and ran in.
vi: − Hearing my voice, my sister ran in.
tr: "When my brother heard me, he immediately ran.
es: "—My sister heard me and came running.

en: I told her not to come near us till he was dead.
vi: I told my sister not to come near until he was dead.
tr: I told him not to come inside until the man was dead.
es: I told her not to come closer until her infamous abductor was dead.

en: He came in and first tossed me some pieces of money; then struck at me with a whip.
vi: He came in here, first throwing some money at me; then he whipped me with a cane.
tr: This man came inside and first threw some money at me; then he hit me with a whip.
es: He threw some coins at me, and then struck my face with his whip; but I, despite being a despicable dog, slapped him until he was forced to draw his sword.

en: But I, though a common dog, so struck at him as to make him draw.
vi: But even though I was a lowly person, I struck back, forcing him to draw his sword.
tr: But I, as a lowly dog, hit him so hard that he drew his sword.
es: He threw some coins at me, and then struck my face with his whip; but I, despite being a despicable dog, slapped him until he was forced to draw his sword.

en: Let him break into as many pieces as he will, the sword that he stained with my common blood; he drew to defend himself—thrust at me with all his skill for his life.’
vi: Let him break his blood-stained sword into as many pieces as he wants; he had to use all his swordsmanship just to keep himself alive.
tr: With the sword stained by my lowly blood, he could cut me into a thousand pieces if he wanted; after all, he had drawn it to defend himself – and with all the skill he had acquired throughout his life, he stabbed me with it."
es: Let him now break the blade of a sword stained with the blood of a villain, let him shatter it into a thousand pieces, it will always be true that he had to draw it to defend his life, and if he wounded me, it was by resorting to all his skill!

en: “My glance had fallen, but a few moments before, on the fragments of a broken sword, lying among the hay.
vi: A few minutes ago, I saw broken sword fragments lying in the straw.
tr: My eyes had caught the pieces of a broken sword lying among the straw on the ground a few minutes ago.
es: Moments before, I had seen pieces of a sword scattered on the ground; it was a knight's sword.

en: That weapon was a gentleman’s.
vi: The nobleman's sword.
tr: This belonged to a noble.
es: Moments before, I had seen pieces of a sword scattered on the ground; it was a knight's sword.

en: In another place, lay an old sword that seemed to have been a soldier’s.
vi: Lying elsewhere was an old sword, likely the type used by a soldier.
tr: The old sword lying a little further away seemed to belong to a soldier.
es: A little further on, on the straw, there was another old sword, a soldier's sword.

en: “‘Now, lift me up, Doctor; lift me up.
vi: − Now lift me up, doctor; lift me up.
tr: "Lift me up, Doctor; lift me up, come on.
es: "—Help me up, doctor, help me up; where is that man?"

en: Where is he?’
vi: Where is he?
tr: Where is it?"
es: "—Help me up, doctor, help me up; where is that man?"

en: “‘He is not here,’ I said, supporting the boy, and thinking that he referred to the brother.
vi: − He is not here, - I said as I lifted the young man, thinking he meant his twin brother.
tr: Thinking that he meant his brother, I said, "He is not here," while supporting the boy to sit up.
es: »—He is not here— I replied, holding the dying man, believing he was referring to his brother.

en: “‘He!
vi: − Him!
tr: "Oh man!
es: "—Of course!" "With all his noble arrogance, he is afraid of me!"

en: Proud as these nobles are, he is afraid to see me.
vi: The arrogant nobles are like that, but he is afraid to meet me.
tr: Like all nobles, he is so proud that he is afraid to look at me.
es: "—Of course!" "With all his noble arrogance, he is afraid of me!"

en: Where is the man who was here?
vi: Where is the person who was standing here just now?
tr: Where is the man standing over there?
es: "And the man who was here?"

en: Turn my face to him.’
vi: Turn my face towards him.
tr: Turn my face to him."
es: "Turn me towards him... I want to see him!"

en: “I did so, raising the boy’s head against my knee.
vi: I followed, lifting the boy's head to rest on my knee.
tr: I rested my head on my knee and lifted it as the boy had instructed.
es: "I did so, resting the boy's head on my knee; but he, with all his energies revived for a moment, stood up, forcing me to do the same to support him."

en: But, invested for the moment with extraordinary power, he raised himself completely: obliging me to rise too, or I could not have still supported him.
vi: But at that moment, he suddenly had extraordinary strength; he stood up completely, forcing me to stand up to support him.
tr: But suddenly, an extraordinary strength came over the boy, and he stood up completely. He had forced me to straighten up with him, otherwise, I wouldn't have been able to support him.
es: "I did so, resting the boy's head on my knee; but he, with all his energies revived for a moment, stood up, forcing me to do the same to support him."

en: “‘Marquis,’ said the boy, turned to him with his eyes opened wide, and his right hand raised, ‘in the days when all these things are to be answered for, I summon you and yours, to the last of your bad race, to answer for them.
vi: − Marquis, - he said, opening his eyes wide and turning towards the other person, his right hand raised high, - when the day of judgment comes, I will make you and your entire family, down to the last person, pay for your crimes.
tr: Turning to the man with eyes wide open and raising his right hand in the air, the boy said, "Marquis, when the day comes that you are held accountable for your actions, you and the worst of your lineage will answer for each and every one of them."
es: "—Marquis! —he shouted, with wide eyes and raising his arm.— The day will come when all men will have to give a strict account of their actions; for that day I summon you and all of yours, from the first to the last of your cursed race, to answer for your crimes.

en: I mark this cross of blood upon you, as a sign that I do it.
vi: I will make this blood cross mark and swear to you.
tr: "So that it is clear what I have done, I now draw a cross on you with my blood."
es: Let this cross that I stamp with blood on your face be a testimony of my summons.

en: In the days when all these things are to be answered for, I summon your brother, the worst of the bad race, to answer for them separately.
vi: On the Day of Judgment, I will make your sibling, the worst of this evil lineage, pay for their own sins.
tr: "When the day comes that you are held accountable for your actions, the worst person of this evil lineage will also answer for each and every one of them."
es: For the day when all men will have to give a strict account of their actions, I also summon your brother, the vilest of a vile and miserable race, to answer for his separately; on his face I stamp this other cross with my blood, as a testimony of my summons.

en: I mark this cross of blood upon him, as a sign that I do it.’
vi: I will make this blood cross mark and swear to you.
tr: "So that it is clear what I have done, I now draw a cross on him with my blood.""
es: For the day when all men will have to give a strict account of their actions, I also summon your brother, the vilest of a vile and miserable race, to answer for his separately; on his face I stamp this other cross with my blood, as a testimony of my summons.

en: “Twice, he put his hand to the wound in his breast, and with his forefinger drew a cross in the air.
vi: Twice, the young man placed his hand on the wound on his chest, and with his index finger, he drew a cross in the air.
tr: Then he placed his hand on the wound on his chest and drew two crosses in the air with his index finger.
es: »Twice he brought his hand to the bloody wound on his chest and with his index finger traced two crosses in the air.

en: He stood for an instant with the finger yet raised, and as it dropped, he dropped with it, and I laid him down dead.
vi: He stood still for a moment with his finger still raised, and when his arm dropped, his body also collapsed, and I laid him down, already dead...
tr: After his finger remained in the air for a short while, it fell to the ground; then he fell himself, and I straightened his dead body.
es: He remained for a few seconds with his index finger rigid, raised, and then fell dead...

en: “When I returned to the bedside of the young woman, I found her raving in precisely the same order of continuity.
vi: When I returned to the woman's bedside, I saw that she was still deliriously screaming just like before.
tr: When I returned to the young woman, I saw that her madness continued with the same order and continuity.
es: "When I returned to the room where I had left the sick woman, I found her delirious as I had left her, repeating the same words in the same order as always."

en: I knew that this might last for many hours, and that it would probably end in the silence of the grave.
vi: I knew this condition could last for many hours and perhaps only be silent in the grave...
tr: I knew that this could last for hours and perhaps end in the silence of the grave.
es: "I immediately guessed that the crisis would last many hours and that it would probably end with her death."

en: “I repeated the medicines I had given her, and I sat at the side of the bed until the night was far advanced.
vi: I gave her the same doses of medicine as before and sat by the bed until late at night.
tr: I gave her another dose of the medicine I had given her before and sat by her bedside until late at night.
es: "I repeated the medicines and sat by the bed, where I remained until the night was already very advanced."

en: She never abated the piercing quality of her shrieks, never stumbled in the distinctness or the order of her words.
vi: She did not stop her ear-piercing screams, nor did she mix up the exact order of her cries.
tr: There was no decrease in her sharp screams, nor any change in the sequence of the words she was saying.
es: "The cries of the sick woman continued with the same intensity, in the same order, without varying a single word."

en: They were always ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!
vi: Always "My husband, my father, my brother!
tr: She kept saying the same thing: "My husband, my father, my brother!
es: "My husband... my father... my brother...

en: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve.
vi: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve.
tr: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve.
es: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve."

en: Hush!’
vi: Shh!".
tr: Shh!"
es: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve."

en: “This lasted twenty-six hours from the time when I first saw her.
vi: It was like that for twenty-six hours since the first time I met her.
tr: All of this lasted twenty-six hours from the moment I first saw him.
es: »Thirty-six hours had passed since I first saw her, and the condition of the patient had not changed at all.

en: I had come and gone twice, and was again sitting by her, when she began to falter.
vi: I went back and forth twice and then sat next to her, and she began to weaken.
tr: I had gone back and forth twice and sat next to him again when he started to hesitate.
es: I was sitting at the head of her bed when the crisis began to subside.

en: I did what little could be done to assist that opportunity, and by-and-bye she sank into a lethargy, and lay like the dead.
vi: I did everything I could to treat her, and after a while, she fell into a coma, lying still as if dead.
tr: In that short time, I did everything I could to take advantage of the opportunity, and he gradually became numb and lay there like a dead man.
es: The screams ceased, the tremors ended, and shortly after she was left lethargic, as if dead.

en: “It was as if the wind and rain had lulled at last, after a long and fearful storm.
vi: Just like the wind and rain finally ceased after the prolonged fierce storm.
tr: After a long and terrifying storm, the rain and wind had finally subsided, it seemed..
es: The screams ceased, the tremors ended, and shortly after she was left lethargic, as if dead.

en: I released her arms, and called the woman to assist me to compose her figure and the dress she had torn.
vi: I released her arms and called the maid to help me adjust her posture and attire.
tr: I uncrossed my arms and called the woman to help better position her on the bed and to fix her torn dress.
es: »I then called the nurse to help me place her properly in bed and arrange her clothes, torn in a thousand places, and then I realized that the unfortunate woman was pregnant, and I lost the little hope I had of saving her.

en: It was then that I knew her condition to be that of one in whom the first expectations of being a mother have arisen; and it was then that I lost the little hope I had had of her.
vi: It was only then that I realized she was newly pregnant; and by that time, I had lost all hope of saving her.
tr: That's when I realized she was a woman carrying a baby in her womb, and thus, I lost the little hope I had for her recovery.
es: »I then called the nurse to help me place her properly in bed and arrange her clothes, torn in a thousand places, and then I realized that the unfortunate woman was pregnant, and I lost the little hope I had of saving her.

en: “‘Is she dead?’ asked the Marquis, whom I will still describe as the elder brother, coming booted into the room from his horse.
vi: − Is it dead yet? - The voice of the Marquis, whom I call my brother. He had just dismounted and entered the room, still wearing his riding boots.
tr: The Marquis, whom I will still refer to as the elder brother, dismounted from his horse and came into the room in his boots, asking, "Is he dead?"
es: "—Is he dead yet?—asked the Marquis, who had just entered the room after a horseback ride.

en: “‘Not dead,’ said I; ‘but like to die.’
vi: − Not dead yet, - I said, - but about to die. − These lowlifes are so persistent! -
tr: "No," I said; "but death is very near."
es: "—She hasn't died, but she seems dead—I replied."

en: “‘What strength there is in these common bodies!’ he said, looking down at her with some curiosity.
vi: He said while looking down at her with curiosity.
tr: "How strong the bodies of these miserable creatures are!" he said, looking at the woman with curious eyes.
es: "—What resilience these villains have! —he exclaimed, looking at her with curiosity.

en: “‘There is prodigious strength,’ I answered him, ‘in sorrow and despair.’
vi: − In suffering and despair, there is extraordinary strength, - I replied.
tr: "Pain and despair," I said, "harbor a tremendous power within.""
es: "—Sorrows and despair often endure the unspeakable— I replied.

en: “He first laughed at my words, and then frowned at them.
vi: At first, he laughed mockingly, then he became uncomfortable.
tr: First, he laughed at my words, then he frowned.
es: "My words initially provoked his laughter, but then he furrowed his brow.

en: He moved a chair with his foot near to mine, ordered the woman away, and said in a subdued voice,
vi: He pushed a chair towards me with his foot, ordered the maid to leave, and lowered his voice to say: − Doctor, seeing my brother having trouble with these tenants, I suggested that he invite you to help.
tr: He pulled a chair next to mine with his feet; he ordered the woman to leave, then lowered his voice and said the following.
es: He pushed a chair towards me with his foot, told the nurse to leave us alone, and said in a low voice:

en: “‘Doctor, finding my brother in this difficulty with these hinds, I recommended that your aid should be invited.
vi: He pushed a chair towards me with his foot, ordered the maid to leave, and lowered his voice to say: − Doctor, seeing my brother having trouble with these tenants, I suggested that he invite you to help.
tr: "Doctor, when my brother got into trouble with these villagers, the first thing that came to my mind was to call you.
es: "—Doctor, seeing my brother in the difficulty he was in, I advised him to seek you out."

en: Your reputation is high, and, as a young man with your fortune to make, you are probably mindful of your interest.
vi: You have a reputation, and you are a doctor building a career, so you probably know how to look out for your own interests.
tr: You are a person of high repute and, as a young man with a bright future, you must be smart enough to look out for your own interests.
es: "You enjoy an enviable reputation, but you still have to build your fortune, and I suppose that what affects your interests cannot be indifferent to you."

en: The things that you see here, are things to be seen, and not spoken of.’
vi: What you see here is something to be seen but not spoken of.
tr: Let what you have seen here stay here, do not let it go outside."
es: "You are witnessing things that can be seen, but never spoken of."

en: “I listened to the patient’s breathing, and avoided answering.
vi: I listened to the patient's breathing and avoided answering.
tr: I listened to the patient's breathing and avoided responding.
es: "I pretended to pay attention to the patient's breathing and did not respond."

en: “‘Do you honour me with your attention, Doctor?’
vi: − Will you deign to listen to me, doctor?
tr: "Will you grant me the honor of listening to me, Doctor?"
es: "—Do you grant me the honor of listening to me, doctor?"

en: “‘Monsieur,’ said I, ‘in my profession, the communications of patients are always received in confidence.’
vi: − Sir, - I said - my profession requires me to always keep the patient's secrets.
tr: "Monsieur," I said, "in my profession, the secrets of patients always remain secret."
es: "—In my profession, sir, any information given to the doctor regarding the patients is understood to be confidential," I replied, avoiding any commitment, as what I had heard and seen filled my soul with misgivings.

en: I was guarded in my answer, for I was troubled in my mind with what I had heard and seen.
vi: - I answered cautiously because I was secretly worried about the things I had seen and heard.
