tr: I was being cautious while answering, as what I had seen and heard had greatly disturbed me.
es: "—In my profession, sir, any information given to the doctor regarding the patients is understood to be confidential," I replied, avoiding any commitment, as what I had heard and seen filled my soul with misgivings.

en: “Her breathing was so difficult to trace, that I carefully tried the pulse and the heart.
vi: The girl's breath was so weak that I carefully checked her pulse and listened to her heartbeat.
tr: It was so difficult to hear the patient's breath that I tried to carefully check his pulse and heartbeats.
es: "The breathing of the unfortunate woman was becoming so difficult that I had to search for signs of life in her pulse and the beats of her heart."

en: There was life, and no more.
vi: She was still alive, but very weak.
tr: He was alive, but just barely.
es: "The breathing of the unfortunate woman was becoming so difficult that I had to search for signs of life in her pulse and the beats of her heart."

en: Looking round as I resumed my seat, I found both the brothers intent upon me.
vi: Returning to my seat and looking around, I saw both siblings staring intently at me...
tr: As I sat back down and looked around, I saw the siblings scrutinizing me with attentive eyes.
es: "For this, I had to get up from the chair, and when I sat back down, I found myself face to face with the two brothers..."

en: “I write with so much difficulty, the cold is so severe, I am so fearful of being detected and consigned to an underground cell and total darkness, that I must abridge this narrative.
vi: I write with great difficulty because the weather is as cold as a knife, and I also fear being discovered and thrown into a completely dark underground dungeon, so I have to simplify this story.
tr: I am writing these lines with great difficulty; the weather is very cold, and I am so afraid of being caught and sent to an underground cell and being left in complete darkness that I will keep this writing short.
es: "I struggle to write with horrible difficulties. First of all, the cold is unbearable, and, on the other hand, I have a well-founded fear that they will find out that I am writing, in which case they would lock me in an underground dungeon where not a thread of light reaches, so I consider it prudent to shorten my narration as much as possible.

en: There is no confusion or failure in my memory; it can recall, and could detail, every word that was ever spoken between me and those brothers.
vi: My memory is still completely clear and accurate; I can remember and recount every word spoken between me and those two brothers.
tr: There is no impairment or trouble in my memory; I remember everything I talked about with the brothers very clearly, word for word.
es: My memory could not be fresher; I retain in it all the details, all the words that were exchanged between me and the two brothers.

en: “She lingered for a week.
vi: She held on for a week.
tr: The young woman agonized for a week.
es: »For the span of a week, the sick woman was between life and death; closer to the latter than to the former.

en: Towards the last, I could understand some few syllables that she said to me, by placing my ear close to her lips.
vi: Until the last moment, I could only understand a few words she said to me by putting my ear close to her lips.
tr: As she was about to take her last breath, I could understand very little of what she said when I brought my ear close to her lips.
es: Towards the end of the week, I managed to understand some words she said to me, by placing my ear to her lips.

en: She asked me where she was, and I told her; who I was, and I told her.
vi: The girl asked me where she was, and I told her; she asked who I was, and I told her.
tr: She asked me where she was, I told her; she asked who I was, I told her.
es: She asked me where she was, and I told her; she wanted to know who I was, and I satisfied her curiosity; but it was in vain that I asked her for her last name; her head fell onto the pillow, and she kept her secret, as her brother had before her.

en: It was in vain that I asked her for her family name.
vi: But trying to ask her name was in vain.
tr: I also asked her surname, but it was in vain.
es: She asked me where she was, and I told her; she wanted to know who I was, and I satisfied her curiosity; but it was in vain that I asked her for her last name; her head fell onto the pillow, and she kept her secret, as her brother had before her.

en: She faintly shook her head upon the pillow, and kept her secret, as the boy had done.
vi: She just gently shook her head on the pillow and kept the secret, like her younger brother.
tr: She gently shook her head on the pillow and, just like her sister, she kept her secret.
es: She asked me where she was, and I told her; she wanted to know who I was, and I satisfied her curiosity; but it was in vain that I asked her for her last name; her head fell onto the pillow, and she kept her secret, as her brother had before her.

en: “I had no opportunity of asking her any question, until I had told the brothers she was sinking fast, and could not live another day.
vi: I didn't have the chance to ask any more questions until I informed the two brothers that she was rapidly deteriorating and could not survive another day.
tr: I didn't have the opportunity to ask her another question until I told the siblings that she was rapidly deteriorating and didn't have much time left.
es: "I had no opportunity to ask her new questions until after I informed the brothers that the sick woman was dying and would not live another day."

en: Until then, though no one was ever presented to her consciousness save the woman and myself, one or other of them had always jealously sat behind the curtain at the head of the bed when I was there.
vi: Until then, although no one was present when she was conscious except the maid and me, one of the brothers always suspiciously sat behind the curtain at the head of her bed when I was there.
tr: Until then, even though there was no one else with the young woman besides me and the peasant woman, one of the siblings was always sitting enviously just behind the curtain at the head of the bed where I was.
es: "Until then, although neither of them let themselves be seen by the sick woman, sometimes one, sometimes the other, they were invariably found behind a curtain drawn at the head of the bed; but when I communicated my prognosis to them, it seemed they no longer cared if I spoke with the dying woman; they no longer tried to prevent the confidences that the one who was about to leave the world might make to someone who... was probably in the same situation."

en: But when it came to that, they seemed careless what communication I might hold with her; as if—the thought passed through my mind—I were dying too.
vi: But when it reached this stage, they seemed indifferent to any words she might entrust to me, as if I were about to die too - I had that thought.
tr: But after the woman worsened, they didn't pay much attention to what we were talking about, so much so that I couldn't help but wonder if I was dying too.
es: "Until then, although neither of them let themselves be seen by the sick woman, sometimes one, sometimes the other, they were invariably found behind a curtain drawn at the head of the bed; but when I communicated my prognosis to them, it seemed they no longer cared if I spoke with the dying woman; they no longer tried to prevent the confidences that the one who was about to leave the world might make to someone who... was probably in the same situation."

en: “I always observed that their pride bitterly resented the younger brother’s (as I call him) having crossed swords with a peasant, and that peasant a boy.
vi: I always noticed that they, out of pride, were very uncomfortable with the fact that the younger brother (as I called him) had dueled with a farmer, and moreover, a young farmer.
tr: Every time I looked at them, I saw that both of them could not stomach the fact that the younger brother (that's what I call him) had fought a duel with a peasant boy.
es: "I always observed that the fact that the younger brother (I will continue to call him that) had crossed swords with a boy, and moreover a peasant and commoner, deeply wounded the pride of the two."

en: The only consideration that appeared to affect the mind of either of them was the consideration that this was highly degrading to the family, and was ridiculous.
vi: The only thing that concerned them was probably that the duel was extremely humiliating to the family's honor; truly ridiculous.
tr: It seemed that the only thing that bothered them and stuck in their minds was the thought that this matter had dishonored the family and made them look ridiculous.
es: "What seemed to affect them was not the misfortunes they had caused, but the thought that the aforementioned incident degraded the family and placed it in a highly ridiculous situation."

en: As often as I caught the younger brother’s eyes, their expression reminded me that he disliked me deeply, for knowing what I knew from the boy.
vi: I often caught the younger brother's gaze, a gaze that always reminded me that he harbored a strange hatred for me because he knew I had heard the farmer recount the story.
tr: Whenever I made eye contact with the younger brother, I understood from his gaze how much he hated me, after all, he knew what I had learned from the boy.
es: "Countless times I caught looks in the younger brother's eyes that overflowed with hatred, although he apparently treated me with greater refinement than the elder."

en: He was smoother and more polite to me than the elder; but I saw this.
vi: He appeared more gentle and courteous to me than the older brother; but I still recognized that hatred.
tr: He might have treated me more properly and politely than the older brother, but I could see it.
es: "Countless times I caught looks in the younger brother's eyes that overflowed with hatred, although he apparently treated me with greater refinement than the elder."

en: I also saw that I was an incumbrance in the mind of the elder, too.
vi: I also realized that I was a nuisance in the older brother's mind as well.
tr: Moreover, it was not hard to see that I was a burden on the older brother's mind as well.
es: "Nor was it hidden from me that for the latter, I was an annoying obstacle."

en: “My patient died, two hours before midnight—at a time, by my watch, answering almost to the minute when I had first seen her.
vi: My patient died, two hours before midnight - according to my watch, almost exactly at the same time I first met her.
tr: Two hours before midnight, my patient died – according to my watch, it coincided with the time I first saw him.
es: "My patient died at ten o'clock at night."

en: I was alone with her, when her forlorn young head drooped gently on one side, and all her earthly wrongs and sorrows ended.
vi: Only I was beside her when that young, desperate head slowly tilted to one side, ending all earthly suffering.
tr: When his young, distraught head gently fell to the side and all the worldly injustices and pains he had endured came to an end, I was the only one by his side.
es: "I was alone by her side, she bowed her youthful head, her misfortunes on earth ended forever."

en: “The brothers were waiting in a room down-stairs, impatient to ride away.
vi: Two brothers are waiting in the room downstairs, eager to set off.
tr: The brothers were impatient to set off and were waiting in a room downstairs.
es: "On the ground floor of the house, the brothers were waiting."

en: I had heard them, alone at the bedside, striking their boots with their riding-whips, and loitering up and down.
vi: When I was alone by the patient's bed, I heard them whipping their boots with riding crops, pacing back and forth.
tr: While I was by the bed, I heard them hitting their boots with their whips and pacing up and down the room.
es: "On the ground floor of the house, the brothers were waiting."

en: “‘At last she is dead?’ said the elder, when I went in.
vi: − So, is it finally dead? - The brother asked when I came downstairs.
tr: When I went down to them, the older one asked, "Did he finally die?"
es: "—Has he finally died?—asked the elder, upon seeing me enter.

en: “‘She is dead,’ said I.
vi: − She is dead, - I said.
tr: "He died," I said.
es: »—He just died— I replied.

en: “‘I congratulate you, my brother,’ were his words as he turned round.
vi: − Congratulations, - he turned back and said to his younger brother.
tr: "Congratulations, brother," said the older brother who was turning around.
es: "—Be it well, brother—he replied, turning towards the younger one.

en: “He had before offered me money, which I had postponed taking.
vi: Previously, he had paid me, but I had declined.
tr: He had previously offered money, but I had postponed it.
es: "They had already offered me money before, which I did not accept, saying that we would finalize that detail at the end."

en: He now gave me a rouleau of gold.
vi: Now he handed me a bundle of gold coins wrapped in paper.
tr: This time, he handed me a pouch of gold.
es: The older brother handed me a cartridge of gold coins, which I received from his hand, but then left on the table.

en: I took it from his hand, but laid it on the table.
vi: I took it but placed it on the table.
tr: I took it from his hand, but I placed it on the table.
es: The older brother handed me a cartridge of gold coins, which I received from his hand, but then left on the table.

en: I had considered the question, and had resolved to accept nothing.
vi: I had thought about this and decided not to accept anything.
tr: I had thought about this matter and decided not to take anything.
es: I had thought over the matter, and from that reflection came the determined purpose not to accept anything.

en: “‘Pray excuse me,’ said I.
vi: − Excuse me, - I said. -
tr: "Please forgive me," I said.
es: "—Excuse me— I said; —given the circumstances, I must not accept anything."

en: ‘Under the circumstances, no.’
vi: Not in this case.
tr: "But under these conditions, I cannot accept."
es: "—Excuse me— I said; —given the circumstances, I must not accept anything."

en: “They exchanged looks, but bent their heads to me as I bent mine to them, and we parted without another word on either side.
vi: The two brothers looked at each other, but then they bowed their heads to greet me, I greeted them back, and then we went our separate ways without saying a word...
tr: First, they looked at each other, then when I nodded in greeting, they responded in kind, and we parted without saying anything else to each other.
es: "The brothers exchanged a look, gave me a nod, which I returned with another, mounted their horses, and left...."

en: “I am weary, weary, weary—worn down by misery.
vi: I am tired, tired, exhausted from my misery.
tr: I am tired, tired, very tired –these pains have finished me.
es: "I feel tired, exhausted, worn out... I can't even read what my bony hand has written."

en: I cannot read what I have written with this gaunt hand.
vi: I cannot read what has been written by this thin hand.
tr: I cannot read what I have written with these skinny fingers.
es: "I feel tired, exhausted, worn out... I can't even read what my bony hand has written."

en: “Early in the morning, the rouleau of gold was left at my door in a little box, with my name on the outside.
vi: Early in the morning, someone had left a small box with gold coins and my name written on it at my doorstep.
tr: Early in the morning, a small box with my name on it and a pouch of gold inside was left in front of my door.
es: »The next morning, very early, they brought to my house the cartridge of gold coins, placed inside a small box addressed to my name.

en: From the first, I had anxiously considered what I ought to do.
vi: From the very beginning, I was worried about what I should do.
tr: From the very first moment, I felt uneasy and was thinking about what I should do.
es: I, meanwhile, after long meditations, had already resolved the code of conduct I was to follow.

en: I decided, that day, to write privately to the Minister, stating the nature of the two cases to which I had been summoned, and the place to which I had gone: in effect, stating all the circumstances.
vi: That day, I decided to write a private letter to the Minister about the two patients I was called to treat, describing the place I had visited; in fact, recounting everything.
tr: That day, I decided to write a special letter to the Minister about what had happened to these two patients I encountered and the place I visited; I was going to tell him everything.
es: I decided to write that very day to the Minister, recounting the history of the two cases in which I had intervened and detailing the place where they occurred; in a word: to send him a detailed report, albeit with a private character.

en: I knew what Court influence was, and what the immunities of the Nobles were, and I expected that the matter would never be heard of; but, I wished to relieve my own mind.
vi: I knew the power of the court and the privileges of the nobility, so I wouldn't be surprised if this matter was never addressed; but I wanted to write it down to ease my mind.
tr: I knew the power of the Palace and how privileged the nobles were, and I didn't expect them to take this matter seriously, but at least I would have eased my own mind.
es: I knew how far the influences at the Court reached, the privileges and immunities enjoyed by the nobles were no secret to me, and, as a consequence, I supposed that my letter would yield no result; but even so, I wanted to ease my conscience.

en: I had kept the matter a profound secret, even from my wife; and this, too, I resolved to state in my letter.
vi: I kept this matter a secret, even from my wife; and I made this clear in my letter.
tr: I had kept the incident a secret even from my own wife, and I found it appropriate to mention this in my letter.
es: I decided not to reveal my secret to anyone, not even to my wife, and I made this clear in the letter addressed to the Minister.

en: I had no apprehension whatever of my real danger; but I was conscious that there might be danger for others, if others were compromised by possessing the knowledge that I possessed.
vi: I was not afraid for my own safety; but I understood clearly that disaster could befall others if they knew what I knew.
tr: I wasn't aware of the danger I would be in if others learned about it, but I was conscious that it could be dangerous for others.
es: I did not believe that I was threatened by any danger; but I supposed that others would be, if I compromised them by making them privy to the secret I possessed.

en: “I was much engaged that day, and could not complete my letter that night.
vi: I was too busy that day, so by evening I still hadn't finished writing the letter.
tr: I was so busy that day that I couldn't finish the letter that night.
es: "I was so busy that day that I couldn't finish the letter until after nightfall."

en: I rose long before my usual time next morning to finish it.
vi: The next morning, I woke up earlier than usual to finish it.
tr: The next morning, I got up much earlier than usual to be able to finish it.
es: The next morning, I left the bed earlier than usual.

en: It was the last day of the year.
vi: It was the last day of the year.
tr: It was the last day of the year.
es: It was the last day of the year.

en: The letter was lying before me just completed, when I was told that a lady waited, who wished to see me.
vi: Just as the letter was finished and lying in front of me, I heard that a lady was waiting and wanted to meet me...
tr: Just as my letter was newly finished and was in front of me, they told me that a lady who wanted to see me had arrived:
es: I had just put the finishing touches on the letter when I was informed that a lady was waiting to see me...

en: “I am growing more and more unequal to the task I have set myself.
vi: I'm increasingly exhausted and unable to complete the tasks I've set for myself.
tr: Every day, I am drifting further away from the task I have committed myself to.
es: "At times I consider myself more incapable of completing the task I have imposed on myself."

en: It is so cold, so dark, my senses are so benumbed, and the gloom upon me is so dreadful.
vi: It's too cold, too gloomy, my senses have become numb, and the darkness surrounding me is terrifying.
tr: This place is so cold, dark, and my feelings are so numb, with such a great gloom weighing down on me.
es: "The cold is so unbearable, the light so scarce, the paralysis of my faculties so complete, the darkness of my soul so horrible!..."

en: “The lady was young, engaging, and handsome, but not marked for long life.
vi: She is still young, graceful, and beautiful, but seems to have a short life expectancy.
tr: The young person who came to see me was an attractive and very charming woman, but she seemed to have little time left to live.
es: »She was a young, kind, and beautiful lady, but marked by the bony finger of death.

en: She was in great agitation.
vi: She looks very worried.
tr: She was in great distress.
es: I found her in a state of intense agitation.

en: She presented herself to me as the wife of the Marquis St. Evrémonde.
vi: She introduced herself as the wife of Marquis St. Evrémonde.
tr: She introduced herself as the wife of Marquis Evremonde.
es: She told me she was the wife of the Marquis of Evrémonde.

en: I connected the title by which the boy had addressed the elder brother, with the initial letter embroidered on the scarf, and had no difficulty in arriving at the conclusion that I had seen that nobleman very lately.
vi: I thought of the title the peasant had called the brother, and the initials embroidered on that scarf, then easily concluded that I had recently met the very nobleman.
tr: At that moment, I connected the name the boy used when talking about the elder brother with the letter embroidered on the scarf in my mind, and it was not difficult to conclude that I had seen that nobleman very recently.
es: I connected the title of Marquis that the dying boy had given to the older brother with the initial I discovered on the crested tie, and with such information at hand, it was not difficult for me to guess that the man from whom I had parted and the Marquis of Evrémonde were one and the same person.

en: “My memory is still accurate, but I cannot write the words of our conversation.
vi: My memory is still accurate, but I cannot recall every word of this conversation.
tr: My memory is still intact, but I can't write down our conversation exactly.
es: "Although my memory remains clear, it is impossible for me to record here the words that were exchanged in our conversation."

en: I suspect that I am watched more closely than I was, and I know not at what times I may be watched.
vi: I suspect that I am being watched more closely than before, and I do not know when I will be monitored.
tr: I suspect that I am being watched much more than before, but I can't be sure exactly when I am being watched.
es: "It seems that the lady had knowledge of the intervention I had in an event that she partly knew and partly suspected."

en: She had in part suspected, and in part discovered, the main facts of the cruel story, of her husband’s share in it, and my being resorted to.
vi: She partly suspects, partly discovers the main events in that cruel story, the story involving her husband, and the story of my being invited.
tr: She had suspected some of the truths in the story of brutality, her husband's involvement in the incident, and my being taken there, and had discovered some on her own.
es: "It seems that the lady had knowledge of the intervention I had in an event that she partly knew and partly suspected."

en: She did not know that the girl was dead.
vi: She does not know that the other girl is dead.
tr: But she didn't know that the young woman had died.
es: "She did not know that the unfortunate young woman had died."

en: Her hope had been, she said in great distress, to show her, in secret, a woman’s sympathy.
vi: Very distressed, she expressed her hope that she could silently share the compassion of a woman.
tr: According to what she said in great pain, she hoped to secretly meet with the young woman and show her mercy.
es: "Her wishes, as she expressed to me while flooded with tears, were to visit her in secret and show her sympathy, and her desires, to avert the wrath of God suspended over a house that had long been the object of the hatred of so many whom it had plunged into the dark abysses of misfortune."

en: Her hope had been to avert the wrath of Heaven from a House that had long been hateful to the suffering many.
vi: She hopes that the heavens will not punish the noble family that has long been hated for causing so much suffering to many people.
tr: Moreover, she hoped to keep God's wrath away from the house of those who had long suffered.
es: "Her wishes, as she expressed to me while flooded with tears, were to visit her in secret and show her sympathy, and her desires, to avert the wrath of God suspended over a house that had long been the object of the hatred of so many whom it had plunged into the dark abysses of misfortune."

en: “She had reasons for believing that there was a young sister living, and her greatest desire was, to help that sister.
vi: She had reason to believe that the other girl still had a younger sister, and her greatest desire was to help that younger sister.
tr: He thought he had a sister and his greatest desire was to help her.
es: "The purpose of that lady's visit, who had reasons to believe that the unfortunate victim of her husband left behind a younger sister, was to implore me to provide her with the name and location of the sister's residence, in order to help and protect her."

en: I could tell her nothing but that there was such a sister; beyond that, I knew nothing.
vi: I can only say that there indeed is a younger sister, but beyond that, I know nothing more.
tr: I told him that I was aware of the existence of such a sister; but I didn't know anything more.
es: "I could only respond that, indeed, such a sister existed; but I could not provide her with information that I did not know at the time, and still do not know as I write these lines..."

en: Her inducement to come to me, relying on my confidence, had been the hope that I could tell her the name and place of abode.
vi: Relying on my discretion, she eagerly came to see me, hoping I would reveal the name and whereabouts of this younger sister.
tr: The reason he trusted me and came was the hope that I could tell him the name of that girl and where she lived.
es: "I could only respond that, indeed, such a sister existed; but I could not provide her with information that I did not know at the time, and still do not know as I write these lines..."

en: Whereas, to this wretched hour I am ignorant of both.
vi: But both of those things, up to now, I do not know...
tr: However, I was unaware of both.
es: "I could only respond that, indeed, such a sister existed; but I could not provide her with information that I did not know at the time, and still do not know as I write these lines..."

en: “These scraps of paper fail me.
vi: These pieces of paper are getting me into trouble.
tr: These pieces of paper got me into trouble.
es: "I'm already out of paper."

en: One was taken from me, with a warning, yesterday.
vi: Yesterday, one was confiscated and I was warned.
tr: Yesterday, a guard took one and gave me a warning.
es: "Yesterday they took a sheet from me, I fear that the surveillance I'm under is tighter than ever, and today I must finish my story."

en: I must finish my record to-day.
vi: I have to finish writing the story today.
tr: That's all for today.
es: "Yesterday they took a sheet from me, I fear that the surveillance I'm under is tighter than ever, and today I must finish my story."

en: “She was a good, compassionate lady, and not happy in her marriage.
vi: She is a good person, compassionate, and unhappy in her marriage.
tr: She was a kind-hearted, compassionate woman and was unhappy in her marriage.
es: "The lady was kind, with a compassionate heart, and very unfortunate in her marriage."

en: How could she be!
vi: How can one be happy!
tr: How could it be!
es: "The lady was kind, with a compassionate heart, and very unfortunate in her marriage."

en: The brother distrusted and disliked her, and his influence was all opposed to her; she stood in dread of him, and in dread of her husband too.
vi: Her brother-in-law does not trust her and even hates her; he uses every means to oppose his sister-in-law; she is terrified of him and also terrified of her own husband.
tr: Her husband's brother didn't trust her at all and didn't love her, and he influenced everyone by saying bad things about her; the woman had come to fear both him and her husband.
es: "Her husband's brother hated her, distrusted her, and used all his influence against her." "She feared him, and also feared her husband."

en: When I handed her down to the door, there was a child, a pretty boy from two to three years old, in her carriage.
vi: When I escorted her to the door, I saw a beautiful little boy, about two or three years old, in her carriage.
tr: When I escorted her to the door, I saw that there was a sweet little boy, about two or three years old, in her car.
es: "When I accompanied her to the door of my house, after she said goodbye to me, I saw one of her children, who was waiting for her in the car, a beautiful child of about two to three years old."

en: “‘For his sake, Doctor,’ she said, pointing to him in tears, ‘I would do all I can to make what poor amends I can.
vi: − Because of my child, doctor, - she said through her tears while pointing to the baby, - for my child, I do everything I can to make up for it.
tr: "For his sake, Doctor," she said, pointing to the child with tears in her eyes, "I will do whatever I can.
es: "—For the love of this innocent one, doctor," the poor mother, awash in tears, told me, "I must go, on the path of reparations, as far as my scant strength will allow."

en: He will never prosper in his inheritance otherwise.
vi: If not, my child will inherit all the grudges.
tr: Otherwise, with this name he has inherited, he will never see the light of day.
es: An inner voice tells me that the innocent son must atone for the crimes of his guilty father, if I do not offer some expiation for them in time.

en: I have a presentiment that if no other innocent atonement is made for this, it will one day be required of him.
vi: I have a feeling that if this wrongdoing is not compensated by someone, one day my own child will have to repay that debt.
tr: It seems to me that if the price of these sins is not paid, one day he will suffer for it.
es: An inner voice tells me that the innocent son must atone for the crimes of his guilty father, if I do not offer some expiation for them in time.

en: What I have left to call my own—it is little beyond the worth of a few jewels—I will make it the first charge of his life to bestow, with the compassion and lamenting of his dead mother, on this injured family, if the sister can be discovered.’
vi: All that I have... worth not much more than a few jewels... I am determined to entrust to my child as a primary duty to use it to compensate the harmed family out of compassion for the deceased mother, if it is possible to find that younger sister. -
tr: Whatever I have left – which is only slightly more than the worth of a few jewels – I will leave to my son so that his first task, if his sister can be found, will be to bestow this burden of mercy and sorrow from his late mother upon this wounded family."
es: My primary concern must be to instill in his tender heart compassion for his fellow beings, and my final charge, to watch over the sister I seek, if I can find her.

en: “She kissed the boy, and said, caressing him, ‘It is for thine own dear sake.
vi: She kissed the little boy, then spoke while tenderly caressing her child. - It's all for you.
tr: Then the woman kissed and caressed her son, saying, "All of this is for you, my dear son."
es: »He then kissed the child and said to him:

en: Thou wilt be faithful, little Charles?’
vi: You must do exactly what I tell you, Charles.
tr: "You will do as I say, won't you little Charles?" she said.
es: »—I do everything for you, Carlos.

en: The child answered her bravely, ‘Yes!’ I kissed her hand, and she took him in her arms, and went away caressing him.
vi: - Yes! - The child replied bravely. I kissed her hand, she lovingly embraced the child, and then left.
tr: The child bravely replied, "Yes!" I kissed the woman's hand, and she took her son in her arms, kissed and caressed him, and left.
es: Will you forget my errands?

en: I never saw her more.
vi: Since then, I have not seen her again.
tr: I never saw that woman again.
es: "—Never—responded the boy resolutely.

en: “As she had mentioned her husband’s name in the faith that I knew it, I added no mention of it to my letter.
vi: Because she mentioned her husband's name, thinking I already knew it, I did not include this in my letter anymore.
tr: Thinking that the woman pronounced her husband's name knowing that I knew it, I did not mention his name in my letter.
es: "I did not include in my letter a name that had been communicated to me confidentially."

en: I sealed my letter, and, not trusting it out of my own hands, delivered it myself that day.
vi: I sealed the letter and, trusting no one, personally sent it that very day.
tr: I sealed the letter and, since I could not trust anyone, I personally delivered it that day.
es: I closed it, and not wanting to entrust it to anyone, that day I took it myself to its destination.

en: “That night, the last night of the year, towards nine o’clock, a man in a black dress rang at my gate, demanded to see me, and softly followed my servant, Ernest Defarge, a youth, up-stairs.
vi: That evening, the last night of the year, around nine o'clock, a man in black rang the bell at the gate demanding to see me and quietly followed my young servant, Ernest Defarge, upstairs.
tr: That night, the last night of the year, around nine o'clock, a man in black clothes rang my doorbell, wanted to see me, and quietly followed my young servant Ernest Defarge upstairs.
es: "At night, it was the last of the year, around nine o'clock, a man dressed in black knocked at my door, said he needed to see me, and my servant Ernesto Defarge led him to my presence."

en: When my servant came into the room where I sat with my wife—O my wife, beloved of my heart!
vi: I was sitting beside my wife. - Oh, my beloved wife! My lovely English wife! -
tr: When my servant entered the room where I was sitting with my wife –oh my wife, my dear wife!
es: "At night, it was the last of the year, around nine o'clock, a man dressed in black knocked at my door, said he needed to see me, and my servant Ernesto Defarge led him to my presence."

en: My fair young English wife!—we saw the man, who was supposed to be at the gate, standing silent behind him.
vi: When the servant entered the room, we saw behind Defarge the silent stranger, who should have been waiting outside the gate.
tr: My beautiful young English wife!– we saw that the man who should have been waiting at the door was silently standing behind my servant.
es: "At night, it was the last of the year, around nine o'clock, a man dressed in black knocked at my door, said he needed to see me, and my servant Ernesto Defarge led him to my presence."

en: “An urgent case in the Rue St. Honore, he said.
vi: There is an urgent case on St. Honoré Street, he said.
tr: "There is an urgent case on Rue St Honore," said the man.
es: "—An urgent case on St. Honoré Street—he said.

en: It would not detain me, he had a coach in waiting.
vi: It won't take much of my time because he already has a carriage waiting.
tr: He said it wouldn't take much of my time and that a car was waiting downstairs.
es: "I left immediately."

en: “It brought me here, it brought me to my grave.
vi: The vehicle brought me here, to this grave.
tr: The car brought me here, to my grave.
es: "In the street, a car was waiting for me... which brought me here, to the tomb."

en: When I was clear of the house, a black muffler was drawn tightly over my mouth from behind, and my arms were pinioned.
vi: As soon as I stepped out of the house, a black cloth from behind tightly gagged my mouth and bound my hands.
tr: As soon as the house disappeared from view, someone from behind reached out and tightly wrapped my mouth with a black cloth and tied my arms.
es: "We had barely lost sight of my house when unexpectedly they gagged me and tied my arms with ropes."

en: The two brothers crossed the road from a dark corner, and identified me with a single gesture.
vi: From a dark corner across the street, those two brothers crossed over and just waved a hand to signal that they had recognized me.
tr: From a dark corner, those two brothers emerged and approached us, indicating with a single gesture that they recognized me.
es: "It didn't take long for the two brothers to come out to meet the car."

en: The Marquis took from his pocket the letter I had written, showed it me, burnt it in the light of a lantern that was held, and extinguished the ashes with his foot.
vi: The Marquis took out the letter I had sent from his pocket, showed it to me, then burned it in the flame of the lantern he held and used his foot to extinguish the ashes.
tr: The marquis took out the letter I had written from his pocket and showed it to me, then burned it with the flame of a lantern he was holding and scattered the ashes with his foot.
es: "The Marquis took the letter I had delivered to the Minister out of his pocket, showed it to me, burned it with the flame of a lantern he was holding, and trampled on the ashes."

en: Not a word was spoken.
vi: Not a word was spoken.
tr: No one said a single word.
es: "Not a word was spoken."

en: I was brought here, I was brought to my living grave.
vi: I was brought here, I was brought to this living grave.
tr: I was brought here, to the grave where I was buried alive.
es: "They brought me to this tomb, and here I remain."

en: “If it had pleased God to put it in the hard heart of either of the brothers, in all these frightful years, to grant me any tidings of my dearest wife—so much as to let me know by a word whether alive or dead—I might have thought that He had not quite abandoned them.
vi: If only during the many terrible years that have just passed, God had made one of those two brothers take pity and inform me of any news about my beloved wife - even just a word to let me know whether she was alive or dead - then I would still think that God had not abandoned them.
tr: If during these terrible years God had touched the hard heart of either of these two brothers and brought me news of my dear wife –at least to tell me whether she was dead or alive– then I might have thought that God had not entirely abandoned these brothers.
es: »If during the span of these horrible years, God had deigned to touch the heart of either of the two brothers, not to put an end to my dreadful captivity, but to give me news of my beloved wife... to tell me, if nothing else, whether she lives or has died, I would believe that, despite their wickedness, He has not completely abandoned them; but today I believe that the red crosses traced with blood by the dying boy have been fatal for them, I believe that Heaven has condemned them.

en: But, now I believe that the mark of the red cross is fatal to them, and that they have no part in His mercies.
vi: But now I believe that the mark of the cross is their fate because God has refused to show mercy.
tr: But now I know that the red cross is a deadly sign for them and that they will never partake in God's mercy.
es: »If during the span of these horrible years, God had deigned to touch the heart of either of the two brothers, not to put an end to my dreadful captivity, but to give me news of my beloved wife... to tell me, if nothing else, whether she lives or has died, I would believe that, despite their wickedness, He has not completely abandoned them; but today I believe that the red crosses traced with blood by the dying boy have been fatal for them, I believe that Heaven has condemned them.

en: And them and their descendants, to the last of their race, I, Alexandre Manette, unhappy prisoner, do this last night of the year 1767, in my unbearable agony, denounce to the times when all these things shall be answered for.
vi: For them and their descendants, to the last one, I, Alexandre Manette, an unfortunate prisoner, on this last night of the year 1767, in unbearable agony, swear that there will come a time when all these sins will be judged.
tr: I, Alexandre Manette, sorrowful prisoner, on this last night of the year 1767, in unbearable agony, consign them and all their lineage to the day they will account for all their deeds, down to the last member.
es: As a consequence, I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate captive, on the last night of the year 1767, denounce the two brothers and all their descendants, to the very last one, to the times that must inevitably come, when men will punish wickedness like that of which they have been guilty.

en: I denounce them to Heaven and to earth.”
vi: I denounce them to both Heaven and Earth.
tr: Surely, they will be held accountable both in this world and in the presence of God.
es: I also denounce them to heaven and earth.»

en: A terrible sound arose when the reading of this document was done.
vi: As soon as the reading of this document ended, the entire courtroom erupted in chaos.
tr: When the document was finished being read, a terrible noise erupted in the hall.
es: Terrible roars followed the reading of this document.

en: A sound of craving and eagerness that had nothing articulate in it but blood.
vi: A sound full of longing and eagerness resonated with only one thing: blood.
tr: It was the sound of an immense bloodthirstiness and agitation.
es: No words were heard, which the throats could not modulate, but roars that revealed an insatiable thirst for blood.

en: The narrative called up the most revengeful passions of the time, and there was not a head in the nation but must have dropped before it.
vi: This story had incited the most frenzied fits of revengeful rage of that time, and surely there was not a single head in all of France that did not bow in trembling fear before that wrath.
tr: The Doctor's writings had fanned the flames of the most vengeful passions of the time, and in this atmosphere, the people would not calm down until a head rolled before them.
es: Before that tribunal, and before that audience, there was no need to explain how Defarge possessed that terrible document that had just been made public, nor was there any need to make known that the name of that hated family had long been listed in the formidable records of Saint Antoine.

en: Little need, in presence of that tribunal and that auditory, to show how the Defarges had not made the paper public, with the other captured Bastille memorials borne in procession, and had kept it, biding their time.
vi: In the chaotic courtroom and amidst the jeers, it goes without saying that the Defarges had hidden these papers, along with other records taken from the Bastille prison, which had been circulated and awaited the opportunity to be revealed.
tr: There was no need to ask the Defarges in front of the court and the spectators why they did not show this document along with the other Bastille documents that came into their hands during the ceremonial procession and why they kept these in their possession.
es: Before that tribunal, and before that audience, there was no need to explain how Defarge possessed that terrible document that had just been made public, nor was there any need to make known that the name of that hated family had long been listed in the formidable records of Saint Antoine.

en: Little need to show that this detested family name had long been anathematised by Saint Antoine, and was wrought into the fatal register.
vi: It goes without saying that this hated family had long been cursed by the people of the Saint Antoine district and was on the death list.
tr: There was also no need to show that this vile family had long been cursed by St. Antoine and recorded in the deadly register.
es: Before that tribunal, and before that audience, there was no need to explain how Defarge possessed that terrible document that had just been made public, nor was there any need to make known that the name of that hated family had long been listed in the formidable records of Saint Antoine.

en: The man never trod ground whose virtues and services would have sustained him in that place that day, against such denunciation.
vi: No one, no matter how virtuous and meritorious, could escape that day with such an accusation.
tr: No matter how virtuous a man was, no matter how important services he had rendered, it was unlikely that he would escape such an accusation on that day.
es: The man capable of defending the mortal upon whom such a grave accusation weighed had not been born.

en: And all the worse for the doomed man, that the denouncer was a well-known citizen, his own attached friend, the father of his wife.
vi: And even worse for the convicted person, the accuser was a renowned Citizen, his close friend, and his father-in-law.
tr: The worst part for this man condemned to death was that the person accusing him was a citizen known to the public, a friend to whom he was deeply devoted, and at the same time, his father-in-law.
es: The situation of the condemned was infinitely aggravated by the fact that his accuser was a very well-known and highly respectable citizen, his soul friend, none other than his wife's father.

en: One of the frenzied aspirations of the populace was, for imitations of the questionable public virtues of antiquity, and for sacrifices and self-immolations on the people’s altar.
vi: One of the mad aspirations of the masses is to emulate the dubious virtues of ancient times by sacrificing and self-sacrificing before the altar of the people.
tr: One of the most outrageous demands of the people was to hold sacrificial ceremonies on the altar, taking national virtues from ancient times as an example.
es: One of the most common aspirations among the populace was to imitate the public virtues of antiquity, to sacrifice oneself for the cause of the people, to immolate the tenderest affections on the altar of the Republic.

en: Therefore when the President said (else had his own head quivered on his shoulders), that the good physician of the Republic would deserve better still of the Republic by rooting out an obnoxious family of Aristocrats, and would doubtless feel a sacred glow and joy in making his daughter a widow and her child an orphan, there was wild excitement, patriotic fervour, not a touch of human sympathy.
vi: Therefore, when the Judge said (for saying otherwise would risk his head being chopped off) that the reputable doctor had greatly served the Republic by exterminating a detestable noble family, that he must surely feel secretly proud and joyful for having made his daughter a widow and his grandchild an orphan, those words incited a frenzied patriotic emotion devoid of any humanity.
tr: Therefore, when the President said that this good doctor of the Republic had done a great favor to the Republic by eradicating the roots of the disgusting aristocratic family and that he should undoubtedly feel a noble excitement and pleasure from this event, which left his daughter a widow and her child an orphan (if he hadn't said it, it would have been his own head on the line), there was an outburst of excitement and patriotic fervor in the hall; no one felt the slightest bit of pity.
es: This is why, when the President said that the good republican doctor did not hesitate to leave his daughter a widow and his grandson an orphan, in exchange for exterminating a family of pernicious aristocrats, the mobs gave free rein to a wild patriotic fervor, without any heartstrings vibrating with human sympathy.

en: “Much influence around him, has that Doctor?” murmured Madame Defarge, smiling to The Vengeance.
vi: − Can the doctor influence the people here? - Madame Defarge whispered while smiling at the Goddess of Vengeance. -
tr: Madam Defarge, smiling at Revenge, murmured, "The Doctor is quite influential, isn't he?"
es: "So you have surrounded him with powerful influences, eh, doctor?" murmured Mrs. Defarge, looking and smiling at The Vengeance.

en: “Save him now, my Doctor, save him!”
vi: Now save him, doctor, save him!
tr: "Now let's see you save him, Doctor dear, go on, save him!"
es: "Save him, doctor, save him now, if you can!"

en: At every juryman’s vote, there was a roar.
vi: With each vote of the jury member came a roar from the crowd.
tr: A murmur rose with each jury member's vote.
es: The jurors expressed themselves through roars.

en: Another and another.
vi: Vote after vote.
tr: Again, and again.
es: The jurors expressed themselves through roars.

en: Roar and roar.
vi: Roar after roar.
tr: The murmurs followed one another.
es: Each vote cast was a roar, the verdict, a succession of roars.

en: Unanimously voted.
vi: All with one heart.
tr: The decision was unanimously approved.
es: The verdict did not take long to arrive.

en: At heart and by descent an Aristocrat, an enemy of the Republic, a notorious oppressor of the People.
vi: He is a noble by lineage and by nature, an enemy of the Republic, a notorious oppressor of the people.
tr: He was both a heartfelt and a born aristocrat and an enemy of the Republic; he was a tyrant who had become the talk of everyone.
es: Carlos Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, aristocrat by heart and blood, enemy of the Republic and fierce oppressor of the people, would return to the Conciergerie to be beheaded within twenty-four hours.

en: Back to the Conciergerie, and Death within four-and-twenty hours!
vi: Return to the Conciergerie prison, and face execution within the next twenty-four hours!
tr: He would return to the Conciergerie and be executed within twenty-four hours!
es: Carlos Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, aristocrat by heart and blood, enemy of the Republic and fierce oppressor of the people, would return to the Conciergerie to be beheaded within twenty-four hours.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: Return to the Conciergerie prison, and face execution within the next twenty-four hours!
tr: XI
es: XI.

en: Dusk
vi: 11. In the dark
tr: Twilight
es: SHADOWS

en: The wretched wife of the innocent man thus doomed to die, fell under the sentence, as if she had been mortally stricken.
vi: The unfortunate wife of the innocent man who had just been sentenced to death collapsed as if the verdict had ended her life.
tr: The poor wife of the innocent man condemned to death was struck as if hit in the head when she heard the verdict.
es: The fierce sentence that condemned an innocent man to the ultimate penalty was for the unfortunate wife a sharp dagger that pierced her tender heart.

en: But, she uttered no sound; and so strong was the voice within her, representing that it was she of all the world who must uphold him in his misery and not augment it, that it quickly raised her, even from that shock.
vi: But she did not utter a word; quickly overcoming the horror because the strong voice within urged her to remember that in this world, only she could help her husband face it rather than endure more suffering.
tr: But she did not utter a word, and the voice inside her that said she was the only person in this world who could support her husband through this agony without exacerbating it was so strong that she quickly regained her composure, even shaking off the shock she had experienced.
es: However, the unhappy woman did not utter a complaint; in the depths of her soul, a powerful voice arose, marking the path of her duty, telling her that her obligation was to support her beloved husband instead of increasing his agonies with her own, and before the incantation of that voice, the young woman stood up proudly, overcoming the effects of the tremendous blow she had received.

en: The Judges having to take part in a public demonstration out of doors, the Tribunal adjourned.
vi: The judges had to join the street protest march, and the court postponed the trial.
tr: The court had adjourned because the judges needed to attend the demonstration outside.
es: The judges adjourned the session to take part in the boisterous public demonstration that inevitably followed the incident at the hearing, and very soon, with all the doors of the Hall of Justice open, the public exited, indifferent to Lucía's pain, who stretched her yearning arms towards the platform where her husband remained.

en: The quick noise and movement of the court’s emptying itself by many passages had not ceased, when Lucie stood stretching out her arms towards her husband, with nothing in her face but love and consolation.
vi: The noise of people bustling out of the court from all directions still echoed as Lucie stood with her hand raised towards her husband, her face filled with love and comfort.
tr: As the crowd noisily made their way through the rows and emptied the hall, Lucie stood with a loving and comforting expression on her face, arms open to her husband.
es: The judges adjourned the session to take part in the boisterous public demonstration that inevitably followed the incident at the hearing, and very soon, with all the doors of the Hall of Justice open, the public exited, indifferent to Lucía's pain, who stretched her yearning arms towards the platform where her husband remained.

en: “If I might touch him!
vi: − If only I could touch that person!
tr: "If only I could touch her!
es: —If I could reach him, my God!

en: If I might embrace him once!
vi: If only I could hug that person just once!
tr: If only I could hug her just once!
es: If I could give him a hug, just one!

en: O, good citizens, if you would have so much compassion for us!”
vi: Oh, good citizens, if only you could sympathize with us!
tr: Oh kind-hearted citizens, please have mercy on us!"
es: Oh citizens! Search in your hearts for a remnant of pity and grant a plea that I make to you on my knees!

en: There was but a gaoler left, along with two of the four men who had taken him last night, and Barsad.
vi: Only one jailer remained along with two of the four who had arrested Darnay last night, and Barsad.
tr: Only two of the four men who came to get him last night, Barsad and a guard, remained beside Charles.
es: There were no more people left there except a jailer with two of the four individuals who had gone to arrest Carlos the day before, and Barsad.

en: The people had all poured out to the show in the streets.
vi: The people had all poured out to watch the spectacle on the street.
tr: Everyone had poured into the street to watch the show.
es: The public was already bustling through the streets.

en: Barsad proposed to the rest, “Let her embrace him then; it is but a moment.”
vi: Barsad suggested to the others: − Then let her hug this person; just for a moment.
tr: Turning to those beside him, Barsad said, "Let her embrace him; but only for a minute."
es: —Let him give a hug—proposed Barsad to his companions;—it's a matter of a moment. Those beasts softened.

en: It was silently acquiesced in, and they passed her over the seats in the hall to a raised place, where he, by leaning over the dock, could fold her in his arms.
vi: They silently agreed and led Lucie across the rows of seats to the high platform where Darnay, if he leaned over the railing, could reach out to embrace his wife.
tr: Barsad's suggestion was silently accepted, and they led Lucie through the chairs in the hall to a high place where, when her husband leaned from the dock, he could take her into his arms.
es: Lucía was able to reach the foot of the platform, and her husband, leaning over the railing, embraced her in his arms.

en: “Farewell, dear darling of my soul.
vi: − Farewell, my love.
tr: "Goodbye, my one and only love.
es: —Goodbye, my sweet soul! —he said.

en: My parting blessing on my love.
vi: This is the final blessing for my beloved.
tr: Our child is entrusted to you.
es: —I leave this world blessing the loves I leave behind in it.

en: We shall meet again, where the weary are at rest!”
vi: We will meet again in the resting place of the weary souls!
tr: One day, we will meet again in the place where weary bodies rest!"
es: In the mansion where hatreds and human passions sleep, we will meet again.

en: They were her husband’s words, as he held her to his bosom.
vi: These were the words of the husband as he embraced his wife.
tr: These were the words that fell from Charles's mouth as he pressed his wife to his chest.
es: In the mansion where hatreds and human passions sleep, we will meet again.

en: “I can bear it, dear Charles.
vi: − I can endure it, Charles.
tr: "I can endure this, dear Charles.
es: —My misfortune is dreadful, dear Carlos; but I accept it with resignation.

en: I am supported from above: don’t suffer for me.
vi: There is a blessing protecting me; don't be sorrowful for me.
tr: God gave me strength.
es: Do not suffer for me, for God protects me and sustains my strength.

en: A parting blessing for our child.”
vi: Send our final blessings to our child.
tr: Pray for our child."
es: The last blessing for our angel, and farewell!

en: “I send it to her by you.
vi: − Please send this to our child for me.
tr: "I send my prayers with you.
es: —I send it with you, and by kissing you, I kiss both of you, and by saying goodbye to you, I say goodbye to both of you.

en: I kiss her by you.
vi: Send this kiss to our child on my behalf.
tr: I send my kisses with you.
es: —I send it with you, and by kissing you, I kiss both of you, and by saying goodbye to you, I say goodbye to both of you.

en: I say farewell to her by you.”
vi: Send this farewell to our child on my behalf.
tr: Say goodbye to him for me."
es: —I send it with you, and by kissing you, I kiss both of you, and by saying goodbye to you, I say goodbye to both of you.

en: “My husband.
vi: − Darling.
tr: "My dear husband.
es: —No... Dear Carlos, no!

en: No! A moment!”
vi: Wait! Just a minute!
tr: No! Wait a minute!"
es: —No... Dear Carlos, no! One more moment!

en: He was tearing himself apart from her.
vi: - Charles Darnay was letting her go. -
tr: Charles was trying to pull himself away from her.
es: —exclaimed Lucía, seeing that the condemned man was trying to free himself from her arms.

en: “We shall not be separated long.
vi: We won't be apart for long.
tr: "Our separation won't last long.
es: —Our separation will not be long.

en: I feel that this will break my heart by-and-bye; but I will do my duty while I can, and when I leave her, God will raise up friends for her, as He did for me.”
vi: This suffering will soon end my life; but I will fulfill my duty to our child as long as I can, so that when I pass away, God will send friends to help our child as He has helped me.
tr: This separation will break my heart more with each passing day; but I will fulfill my duty until the last moment, and when I leave our child one day, God will grant him good friends, just as He granted me."
es: I sense that my sorrows will soon put an end to my sad life; but as long as I have a breath of energy left, I will fulfill my duty, and when I leave our daughter, the merciful God who provided me with good souls that, with their love and selflessness, brightened my existence, will not withhold them from her.

en: Her father had followed her, and would have fallen on his knees to both of them, but that Darnay put out a hand and seized him, crying:
vi: Dr. Manette had been following his daughter, and would have knelt before both Charles and Lucie if his son-in-law had not reached out to stop him.
tr: Her father had followed Lucie and was just about to kneel before both of them when Darnay extended his hand to stop him and called out:
es: Her father had followed her, turned into a mute statue of grief, who would have fallen to his knees at their feet, had Carlos not prevented it.

en: “No, no!
vi: Charles exclaimed: "No, no!
tr: "No, no!
es: —No... no! —he shouted, extending his arms—Have you committed any fault, to prostrate yourself on your knees before us? Ah, no!

en: What have you done, what have you done, that you should kneel to us!
vi: You have done nothing, you have done nothing, that you should kneel before us!
tr: What have you done, what have you done to make us kneel before you!
es: Quite the opposite!

en: We know now, what a struggle you made of old.
vi: We now know how hard you struggled in the past."
tr: We now know the great struggle you put up in the old days.
es: Now is when I fully realize the horrible tortures that tore your soul apart!

en: We know, now what you underwent when you suspected my descent, and when you knew it.
vi: We now know what you went through when you doubted my lineage, and when you knew for certain.
tr: We now know what you went through when you doubted my lineage and then became certain of it.
es: Now is when I can gauge what you suffered when you suspected the blood that ran through my veins and the despair you must have felt when those suspicions turned into certainty!

en: We know now, the natural antipathy you strove against, and conquered, for her dear sake.
vi: We now know that you resisted and overcame your aversion to me because of the love you have for Lucie.
tr: We also know that for the sake of your dear daughter, you suppressed and overcame the justified hatred within you.
es: Now is when I understand the fierce struggles you had to fight against a natural antipathy, the efforts you necessarily had to make to overcome it!

en: We thank you with all our hearts, and all our love and duty.
vi: We are deeply grateful to you, with all our love and filial piety, may heaven bless you!
tr: We thank you with all our hearts, with our love and respect.
es: With all our hearts, we thank you! All our gratitude is yours, all our affection is yours.

en: Heaven be with you!”
vi: We are deeply grateful to you, with all our love and filial piety, may heaven bless you!
tr: May God protect you!"
es: May Heaven bless you, as we bless you!

en: Her father’s only answer was to draw his hands through his white hair, and wring them with a shriek of anguish.
vi: The father could say nothing more than to run his hands through his silver hair in anguish and let out a cry of despair.
tr: The only response Lucie's father could give was to run his hands through his white hair and tug at it with a scream of pain.
es: The old man could not answer, for his constricted throat was unable to articulate a word, and his body had no energy left except to tear at his hair and let out an occasional moan of anguish.

en: “It could not be otherwise,” said the prisoner.
vi: − There's nothing else to be done, - Charles said.
tr: "It couldn't have been any other way," said the prisoner.
es: —It had to happen this way—replied the convict.

en: “All things have worked together as they have fallen out.
vi: - Everything has been decided.
tr: "Everything has come to pass as it was meant to.
es: —Everything has conspired to reach the fatal outcome we have arrived at.

en: It was the always-vain endeavour to discharge my poor mother’s trust that first brought my fatal presence near you.
vi: You have always strived in vain to fulfill the wish your mother entrusted to you, which from the beginning led you to meet me.
tr: The first thing that brought my mortal existence to you was my poor mother's futile desire to fulfill what she asked of me.
es: All the efforts I have made to satisfy that aspiration of my saintly mother, which she expressed the first day you met her and me, have been in vain.

en: Good could never come of such evil, a happier end was not in nature to so unhappy a beginning.
vi: Such cruelty cannot give birth to anything good, such an unfortunate beginning cannot have a happier ending.
tr: No good would come from so much evil, and such a painful beginning would naturally not end with a happy conclusion.
es: It would have been foolish to expect any good from such an abundant sowing of evils, to delude oneself into thinking that what began with fatal principles could have a happy ending.

en: Be comforted, and forgive me.
vi: Please be calm and forgive me.
tr: Rest assured and forgive me.
es: Have courage, and forgive me.

en: Heaven bless you!”
vi: May the heavens bless you!
tr: May God protect you all!"
es: May the merciful God shower you with blessings!

en: As he was drawn away, his wife released him, and stood looking after him with her hands touching one another in the attitude of prayer, and with a radiant look upon her face, in which there was even a comforting smile.
vi: Lucie let go of her hand when Charles was taken away and she stood watching her husband, hands clasped as if in prayer, her face glowing with affection, even with a reassuring smile.
tr: As Darnay was taken away, his wife had to let him go and looked after him with her hands clasped as if in prayer, a radiant expression on her face, and a comforting smile.
es: The spouses separated; and while the convict moved away among his guards, his wife remained looking at him, hands together in an attitude of supplication and with a radiant face on which a caressing and comforting smile predominated.

en: As he went out at the prisoners’ door, she turned, laid her head lovingly on her father’s breast, tried to speak to him, and fell at his feet.
vi: As Charles disappeared behind the door for the condemned, she turned back, resting her head on her father's chest, intending to say something but then collapsed.
tr: When her husband reached the prison door, Lucie turned and rested her head lovingly on her father's chest, tried to say something to him, and then collapsed to the ground.
es: However, no sooner had the condemned disappeared through the door that led to the prison, Lucia bowed her head like a flower cut at the stem, tried to speak, and collapsed to the ground.

vi: As Charles disappeared behind the door for the condemned, she turned back, resting her head on her father's chest, intending to say something but then collapsed.
tr: When her husband reached the prison door, Lucie turned and rested her head lovingly on her father's chest, tried to say something to him, and then collapsed to the ground.
es: However, no sooner had the condemned disappeared through the door that led to the prison, Lucia bowed her head like a flower cut at the stem, tried to speak, and collapsed to the ground.

en: Original
vi: As Charles disappeared behind the door for the condemned, she turned back, resting her head on her father's chest, intending to say something but then collapsed.
tr: Sydney Carton, who had been standing motionless in a remote corner until then, sprang up and lifted the young woman.
es: However, no sooner had the condemned disappeared through the door that led to the prison, Lucia bowed her head like a flower cut at the stem, tried to speak, and collapsed to the ground.

en: Then, issuing from the obscure corner from which he had never moved, Sydney Carton came and took her up.
vi: At that moment, from a hidden corner where he had been standing motionless, Sydney Carton stepped forward to support her.
tr: Sydney Carton, who had been standing motionless in a remote corner until then, sprang up and lifted the young woman.
es: From the dark corner where he had remained hidden since the beginning of the trial, Sydney Carton then emerged and lifted the unfortunate woman from the ground.

en: Only her father and mr Lorry were with her.
vi: His demeanor was not entirely one of compassion - there was a certain proud intensity on his face.
tr: Only her father and Mr. Lorry were beside Lucie.
es: Only her father and Lorry remained with her.

en: His arm trembled as it raised her, and supported her head.
vi: His demeanor was not entirely one of compassion - there was a certain proud intensity on his face.
tr: As he lifted her from the ground and supported her head, Carton's arms were trembling.
es: Carton's arm trembled as he lifted her, and yet his expression was not solely one of pity; there was a strong mix of pride in it.

en: Yet, there was an air about him that was not all of pity—that had a flush of pride in it.
vi: His demeanor was not entirely one of compassion - there was a certain proud intensity on his face.
tr: However, he had an air that contained not just mercy, but also a hint of pride.
es: Carton's arm trembled as he lifted her, and yet his expression was not solely one of pity; there was a strong mix of pride in it.

en: “Shall I take her to a coach?
vi: − Should I take her to the carriage?
tr: "Shall I carry it to the car?
es: —Shall I take her to the car?—he asked.

en: I shall never feel her weight.”
vi: She is very light, let me carry her.
tr: It's very light anyway."
es: —I won't feel her weight.

en: He carried her lightly to the door, and laid her tenderly down in a coach.
vi: Sydney gently carried Lucie to the door and softly placed her on the seat cushion.
tr: He carried Lucie to the car without difficulty and gently laid her on the seat.
es: In his arms, he carried her to the car waiting at the door, where he settled her in.

en: Her father and their old friend got into it, and he took his seat beside the driver.
vi: Doctor Manette and the old friend got into the carriage, while he took the seat next to the coachman.
tr: Following them, Lucie's father and her old friend Mr. Lorry also got into the car, and Carton took his place next to the driver.
es: The elderly doctor and the good Lorry sat beside her, and Carton settled on the box seat, next to the coachman.

en: When they arrived at the gateway where he had paused in the dark not many hours before, to picture to himself on which of the rough stones of the street her feet had trodden, he lifted her again, and carried her up the staircase to their rooms.
vi: When the car arrived at the gate of the house where Sydney had stopped in the darkness just a few hours earlier, imagining himself walking on the rough stone that had once supported her steps, he carried her out of the car and up the stairs into the apartment.
tr: Just a few hours earlier, when they arrived at the entrance where Lucie imagined stepping on uneven stones in the dark, Sydney Carton lifted Lucie into his arms again and carried her up the stairs to her room.
es: Arriving in front of the gate, at the spot where hours earlier Carton had stopped trying to guess which stones Lucia's feet had tread upon, he took her out of the carriage, and in his arms, he proudly carried her up to her rooms, laying her down on a sofa.

en: There, he laid her down on a couch, where her child and Miss Pross wept over her.
vi: Once there, he laid Lucie down on the couch while the little girl and Miss Pross stood beside them, crying out loud.
tr: When he laid her down on a couch there, her daughter and Miss Pross knelt beside her and cried.
es: Lucita and Miss Pross were crying inconsolably.

en: “Don’t recall her to herself,” he said, softly, to the latter, “she is better so.
vi: − Don't wake her up, - he said softly to Miss Pross, - it's better to let her be.
tr: Carton said to Miss Pross in a low voice, "Don't try to bring him around, it's better this way.
es: —Do nothing to dispel her fainting.—said Carton to the last one in a very low voice.

en: Don’t revive her to consciousness, while she only faints.”
vi: She just fainted, don't wake her up.
tr: Don't wake him up, he just fainted."
es: —She is better this way.

en: “Oh, Carton, Carton, dear Carton!” cried little Lucie, springing up and throwing her arms passionately round him, in a burst of grief.
vi: − Oh, Mr. Carton, Mr. Carton! - Little Lucie exclaimed as she jumped to hug him in her sorrow. -
tr: Little Lucie jumped up and threw herself around Carton's neck with great distress, crying out, "Oh Carton, Carton, dear Carton!"
es: —Oh Carton, Carton! —cried Lucie, jumping onto Carton's neck and wrapping her arms around him.

en: “Now that you have come, I think you will do something to help mamma, something to save papa!
vi: Now that you're here, please do something to help mama, do something to save papa!
tr: "I'm so glad you came, I think you'll do something to save my mother, and my father too!
es: —Now that you have come, I don't doubt that you will do something to console mother, to save father.

en: O, look at her, dear Carton!
vi: Oh, look at my mother, Mr. Carton!
tr: Oh, look at my mother, Carton!
es: Look at her, Carton!

en: Can you, of all the people who love her, bear to see her so?”
vi: Among all the people who love her, how can you bear to see her like this?
tr: Can those who love her bear to see her like this?"
es: Can you, can anyone who loves her look at her without their heart breaking into pieces?

en: He bent over the child, and laid her blooming cheek against his face.
vi: He bent down to little Lucie, pressing his cheek against the child's rosy one.
tr: Carton leaned down to the child and pressed his own face against the child's glowing cheeks.
es: Can you, can anyone who loves her look at her without their heart breaking into pieces?

en: He put her gently from him, and looked at her unconscious mother.
vi: He gently pushed the little girl away and looked at Lucie who had fainted.
tr: Then he gently moved the child away and looked at the mother lying unconscious.
es: Carton gave the girl a kiss, gently separated her little arms, gazed at the mother for a few seconds, and said:

en: “Before I go,” he said, and paused—“I may kiss her?”
vi: − Before you go, - he said, hesitating - ... may I kiss your mother?
tr: "Before leaving," he said and paused –"can I kiss her?"
es: —Before I leave... can I kiss her?

en: It was remembered afterwards that when he bent down and touched her face with his lips, he murmured some words.
vi: The words he whispered when his lips touched hers would be remembered forever.
tr: Later, it would be remembered that at the moment when Carton leaned down and touched the woman's face with his lips, he murmured something.
es: Later, witnesses of this scene recalled that, while their lips brushed the cheeks of the fainted one, they murmured a few words.

en: The child, who was nearest to him, told them afterwards, and told her grandchildren when she was a handsome old lady, that she heard him say, “A life you love.”
vi: The child, standing beside him, would recount it later and even in old age would tell it to his descendants, that Carton had said: “For the life of the one you love.”
tr: At that moment, little Lucie, who was closest to him, would later tell them and, when she became a sweet old woman, her grandchildren, that she heard Carton say to his mother, "A life you love."
es: The girl, who was the closest, said later, and repeated many times to her grandchildren when she was an old lady bent under the weight of the years: "It is a life you love."

en: When he had gone out into the next room, he turned suddenly on mr Lorry and her father, who were following, and said to the latter:
vi: As he walked into the next room, he suddenly turned to Mr. Lorry and Dr. Manette who were following him, and he said to the doctor: − Just yesterday you still had a lot of influence, Dr. Manette; at least try once more today.
tr: When Carton moved to the other room, he turned to Lucie's father, who followed him along with Mr. Lorry, and said;
es: In the adjoining room, where he found the doctor and Lorry, he said to the former:

en: “You had great influence but yesterday, Doctor Manette; let it at least be tried.
vi: As he walked into the next room, he suddenly turned to Mr. Lorry and Dr. Manette who were following him, and he said to the doctor: − Just yesterday you still had a lot of influence, Dr. Manette; at least try once more today.
tr: "You were very effective yesterday, but Doctor Manette; try once more.
es: —Yesterday you had a lot of influence, Doctor Manette; you must use it all.

en: These judges, and all the men in power, are very friendly to you, and very recognisant of your services; are they not?”
vi: The officials and everyone in authority are very friendly with you, acknowledging your merits, aren't they? −
tr: All those judges and influential people are very kind to you and are aware of your services, aren't they?"
es: The judges, and all those who have some power today, are your friends and are grateful for your services; isn't that right?

en: “Nothing connected with Charles was concealed from me.
vi: There is nothing that could save Charles that I haven't tried.
tr: "Nothing about Charles was hidden from me.
es: —They hid nothing from me regarding Carlos.

en: I had the strongest assurances that I should save him; and I did.”
vi: I was very confident that I could save him; and I did so. -
tr: My belief in saving him was very strong; and I did save him."
es: I harbored hopes, almost absolute certainty of saving him, and I saved him—replied the doctor, speaking very slowly and with a troubled expression.

en: He returned the answer in great trouble, and very slowly.
vi: He replied with great difficulty, word by word.
tr: He had spoken this answer with great difficulty and very slowly.
es: I harbored hopes, almost absolute certainty of saving him, and I saved him—replied the doctor, speaking very slowly and with a troubled expression.

en: “Try them again.
vi: − Try again.
tr: "Try again.
es: —Try again.

en: The hours between this and to-morrow afternoon are few and short, but try.”
vi: There isn't much time left until tomorrow afternoon, but keep trying.
tr: We don't have much time until noon tomorrow, but try."
es: Brief are the hours that separate today from tomorrow; but try.

en: “I intend to try.
vi: − I have the same idea.
tr: "I intend to try.
es: —I will try... I will not rest for a moment.

en: I will not rest a moment.”
vi: I won't sit still for a minute.
tr: There is no time to lose."
es: —I will try... I will not rest for a moment.

en: “That’s well.
vi: − That's good.
tr: "Beautiful.
es: —It is what you must do.

en: I have known such energy as yours do great things before now—though never,” he added, with a smile and a sigh together, “such great things as this.
vi: I know that capable people like you have done many great things before... although never, - he added with a smile and a sigh, - anything as extraordinary as this.
tr: I know that you can do amazing things with the energy you have, just like you did before – but of course," he said, smiling and sighing, "this is truly a challenging situation.
es: I have seen men with your energy accomplish great things, although never—he added, smiling and sighing at the same time—anything as great as what I am proposing to you.

en: But try!
vi: But give it a try!
tr: Still, try!
es: Try, however.

en: Of little worth as life is when we misuse it, it is worth that effort.
vi: Life isn't worth much when we waste it, but it's worth trying.
tr: When we waste our lives, it has no value, whereas life is worth this effort.
es: The salvation of a beloved life is well worth that effort.

en: It would cost nothing to lay down if it were not.”
vi: If you don't try, life isn't worth a penny.
tr: If it weren't, it wouldn't be so hard to set it aside."
