es: —I will present myself to the Attorney General of the Republic and to the President—replied Doctor Manette,—as well as to others who need not be named.

en: “I will go,” said Doctor Manette, “to the Prosecutor and the President straight, and I will go to others whom it is better not to name.
vi: − I will go, - Dr. Manette said, - go immediately to meet the prosecutor and the judge, I will go meet others whose names are not convenient to mention.
tr: "Now directly," said Doctor Manette, "I will go to the Prosecutor and the President and to other people whose names I do not wish to mention.
es: —I will present myself to the Attorney General of the Republic and to the President—replied Doctor Manette,—as well as to others who need not be named.

en: I will write too, and—But stay!
vi: I will also write letters, and... But wait!
tr: I will write where I need to write and – But wait a minute!
es: I will also write, and...

en: There is a Celebration in the streets, and no one will be accessible until dark.”
vi: There is a festival on the street, and no one will be available until evening.
tr: There is a celebration in the street and I won't be able to reach anyone until it gets dark."
es: But now I remember that public celebrations are being held today and that I will not be able to see anyone until it is night.

en: “That’s true.
vi: − That's right.
tr: "Correct.
es: —It's true.

en: Well!
vi: Oh!
tr: Well!
es: Bah!

en: It is a forlorn hope at the best, and not much the forlorner for being delayed till dark.
vi: Such a vain hope, and even more vain to delay until evening.
tr: This is already a weak hope at best, and the situation won't be more hopeless just because it remains in the dark.
es: In any case, it's a very remote hope; little is lost by waiting until night.

en: I should like to know how you speed; though, mind!
vi: Anyway, I still want to know how you plan to do it, that's all!
tr: But I would like to know what course of action you will take!
es: In any case, it's a very remote hope; little is lost by waiting until night.

en: I expect nothing!
vi: I don't dare to expect anything!
tr: Even if I have no expectations.
es: I begin by saying that I expect nothing.

en: When are you likely to have seen these dread powers, Doctor Manette?”
vi: When can you meet those formidable authorities, Dr. Manette? −
tr: When will you probably meet with those terrible powers, Doctor Manette?"
es: Tell me, Doctor Manette, when do you think you will be able to see those formidable authorities?

en: “Immediately after dark, I should hope.
vi: As soon as it gets dark, I hope so.
tr: "I hope, as soon as darkness falls.
es: —Immediately after nightfall; I believe within one or two hours.

en: Within an hour or two from this.”
vi: Within one or two hours.
tr: That is, in a few hours."
es: —Immediately after nightfall; I believe within one or two hours.

en: “It will be dark soon after four.
vi: − It will get dark quickly after four o'clock.
tr: "The weather gets dark around four.
es: —It will get dark shortly after four...

en: Let us stretch the hour or two.
vi: Let's assume one or two more hours.
tr: Let's extend the time by a few more hours.
es: Let's make the most of the hour or two we have ahead of us.

en: If I go to mr Lorry’s at nine, shall I hear what you have done, either from our friend or from yourself?”
vi: If I arrive at Mr. Lorry's place at nine o'clock, hopefully, I will know the results of what you did, either from Mr. Lorry or from you yourself?
tr: If I go to Mr. Lorry at nine o'clock, can I learn what you are doing from our friend or directly from you?"
es: If I show up at Mr. Lorry's house at nine, will I be able to know the result of his efforts?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − Alright.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Of course.

en: “May you prosper!”
vi: − Wishing you success!
tr: "Good luck with your work!"
es: —I hope they have good success!

en: mr Lorry followed Sydney to the outer door, and, touching him on the shoulder as he was going away, caused him to turn.
vi: Mr. Lorry followed Sydney to the door and, as he was about to leave, he held him back by the shoulder.
tr: Mr. Lorry accompanied Sydney to the outer door and, as he was leaving, touched his shoulder and turned him back.
es: He accompanied Lorry to the street door, where he said to him in a very low and sorrowful voice:

en: “I have no hope,” said mr Lorry, in a low and sorrowful whisper.
vi: − I have no hope, - Mr. Lorry said, his voice a whisper of sorrow.
tr: "I have no hope," said Mr. Lorry, in a low and sorrowful whisper.
es: —I expect nothing.

en: “Nor have I.”
vi: − Me too.
tr: "I don't have one either.""
es: —Nor I.

en: “If any one of these men, or all of these men, were disposed to spare him—which is a large supposition; for what is his life, or any man’s to them!
vi: − If any of those people, or the whole crowd, had any intention of sparing Darnay; this is an illusion because his life or anyone else's means nothing to them!...
tr: "Even if any or all of those men had the intention to spare his life – which is a very big expectation; after all, what meaning does his or any human's life have for them!
es: —Even if any one of those men... even if all of those men were willing to grant him life... which is assuming too much, after what happened at the trial, I highly doubt they would dare to do so.

en: —I doubt if they durst spare him after the demonstration in the court.”
vi: But I think that even if they wanted to, they wouldn't dare to spare Darnay's life after the public's reactions during the trial.
tr: – I don't know if they could dare to do it after all the commotion in the courtroom."
es: —Even if any one of those men... even if all of those men were willing to grant him life... which is assuming too much, after what happened at the trial, I highly doubt they would dare to do so.

en: “And so do I.
vi: − I think so too.
tr: "I think so too.
es: —I doubt it too...

en: I heard the fall of the axe in that sound.”
vi: I smelled the scent of blood in their shouts.
tr: In that noise, I felt like I heard the guillotine drop."
es: The blade will not stop.

en: mr Lorry leaned his arm upon the door-post, and bowed his face upon it.
vi: Mr. Lorry leaned against the door frame, hiding his face in his arm.
tr: Mr. Lorry leaned his arm against the edge of the door and buried his head in his arm.
es: Lorry brought her hands to her face and let out some sobs.

en: “Don’t despond,” said Carton, very gently; “don’t grieve.
vi: − Don't be discouraged, - Carton said very gently, - don't be distressed.
tr: "Don't lose hope," said Carton softly, "don't be upset.
es: —Do not despair... do not give in to despondency—said Carton with extreme gentleness.

en: I encouraged Doctor Manette in this idea, because I felt that it might one day be consolatory to her.
vi: I intended to encourage Dr. Manette in that way because I thought it might bring some comfort and solace to Lucie.
tr: I encouraged Doctor Manette to this idea, thinking it might be a consolation for Lucie in the future.
es: —If I have advised the doctor to work tirelessly, it is because his efforts, though they may be fruitless, will one day bring comfort to his daughter.

en: Otherwise, she might think ‘his life was wantonly thrown away or wasted,’ and that might trouble her.”
vi: Otherwise, she might think that everyone had given up on Darnay's life, and that would trouble her greatly.
tr: Otherwise, Lucie might think, 'My husband's life was wasted for nothing, it ended,' and put herself in distress."
es: If her father were to fold his arms, she might think that a life had been sacrificed without anyone making the effort to dispute it with the executioner.

en: “Yes, yes, yes,” returned mr Lorry, drying his eyes, “you are right.
vi: − Yes, yes, that's right, - Mr. Lorry replied while wiping his tears, you're right.
tr: "Yes, yes, correct," replied Mr. Lorry, wiping his eyes, "you are right.
es: —Yes, yes, yes! You are right! —responded Lorry, wiping his eyes.

en: But he will perish; there is no real hope.”
vi: But Darnay will lose his life; there is no more hope.
tr: But the end is very near; there is really no hope."
es: —We will work; but he will die... there isn't an atom of hope left!

en: “Yes.
vi: − Correct.
tr: "True."
es: —It's true.

en: He will perish: there is no real hope,” echoed Carton.
vi: Darnay will lose his life; there is no more hope, - Carton repeated.
tr: "The end is very near, there is really no hope," repeated Carton.
es: He will die... There isn't an atom of hope left! —repeated Carton like an echo.

en: And walked with a settled step, down-stairs.
vi: Then he confidently stepped down the stairs.
tr: Then he walked down the road with determined steps.
es: Then he started walking with a firm step.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: 12. Darkness
tr: XII
es: Chapter XII.

en: Darkness
vi: 12. Darkness
tr: Darkness
es: DARKNESS

en: Sydney Carton paused in the street, not quite decided where to go.
vi: Sydney Carton stopped on the street, not yet knowing where he would go.
tr: Sydney Carton stood in the middle of the street, unable to decide where to go.
es: Carton had traveled very little distance when he stopped, not yet decided about the place he would head to.

en: “At Tellson’s banking-house at nine,” he said, with a musing face.
vi: − At Tellson's Bank at nine o'clock, - he thoughtfully said to himself.
tr: He said to himself, "At nine, at Tellson's," with a distracted expression.
es: —At nine o'clock at Tellson's Bank—he murmured. —

en: “Shall I do well, in the mean time, to show myself?
vi: - Should I reveal myself at this moment?
tr: "Should I do something to make myself seen in the meantime?
es: From now until then, would it be wise for me to be seen?

en: I think so.
vi: Probably yes.
tr: It would be good.
es: I think so.

en: It is best that these people should know there is such a man as I here; it is a sound precaution, and may be a necessary preparation.
vi: It is best for the people here to know that there is someone like me around; that is a wise precaution, and possibly a necessary preparation.
tr: It would be good for these people here to know that a man like me exists; it is both a prudent measure and a necessary preparation.
es: It wouldn't hurt for those people to know that a man like me is around here... it might be a wise precaution... a necessary precaution... Careful, Carton, careful...!

en: But care, care, care!
vi: But be careful, be careful!
tr: But one must be careful, very careful!
es: It wouldn't hurt for those people to know that a man like me is around here... it might be a wise precaution... a necessary precaution... Careful, Carton, careful...!

en: Let me think it out!”
vi: Think carefully!
tr: I must think it over thoroughly!"
es: Let's think it over again!

en: Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object, he took a turn or two in the already darkening street, and traced the thought in his mind to its possible consequences.
vi: The steps that had just become familiar with the chosen path, he hesitated, turned into two or three alleys that were gradually darkening, weighing the possible consequences in his mind.
tr: Weighing his steps directed towards a certain object, he turned into a few streets on the road that was beginning to darken and tried to see the possible outcomes of the thought in his mind.
es: Suspending the journey already begun in a certain direction, he entered a dark and lonely alley and tried to weigh the pros and cons of his project, measuring with his imagination the scope and probable consequences that it might have.

en: His first impression was confirmed.
vi: The initial thoughts were confirmed.
tr: His initial impression was confirmed.
es: —No doubt; it's the best—he thought.

en: “It is best,” he said, finally resolved, “that these people should know there is such a man as I here.”
vi: − So it's for the best, - he finally decided, - the people here must know that there is someone who looks like me. -
tr: Finally, with a determined attitude, he said, "Absolutely, these people need to know that there is a man like me here."
es: —Those people must know that there is a man named Carton in the city.

en: And he turned his face towards Saint Antoine.
vi: And he headed towards Saint Antoine.
tr: Then he turned his face towards St Antoine.
es: With determined steps, he set off towards San Antonio.

en: Defarge had described himself, that day, as the keeper of a wine-shop in the Saint Antoine suburb.
vi: Today, Defarge has proclaimed himself as the wine seller in the Saint Antoine district.
tr: That day, Defarge introduced himself as the owner of a wine shop in the outskirts of St. Antoine.
es: As Defarge had said that same day during the trial that he owned a tavern located in the Saint Antoine district, anyone who knew the city well would have little difficulty finding the tavern in question, without needing to ask anyone.

en: It was not difficult for one who knew the city well, to find his house without asking any question.
vi: For someone familiar with the capital, it is easy to find that place without asking anyone.
tr: For someone who knew the city well, finding his house without asking anyone was not a difficult thing.
es: As Defarge had said that same day during the trial that he owned a tavern located in the Saint Antoine district, anyone who knew the city well would have little difficulty finding the tavern in question, without needing to ask anyone.

en: Having ascertained its situation, Carton came out of those closer streets again, and dined at a place of refreshment and fell sound asleep after dinner.
vi: After identifying the location, Carton walked out from the nearby streets, went into a restaurant to have dinner, and slept there.
tr: Carton learned the location of the shop well and, after leaving the nearby streets again, he had a meal at a restaurant and then fell into a deep sleep.
es: Carton, therefore, left the dark alley and ate at a dining house, subsequently taking a nap.

en: For the first time in many years, he had no strong drink.
vi: For the first time in many years, he did not drink strong liquor.
tr: For the first time in many years, he had not consumed much alcohol that night.
es: In many years, he had not drunk as little as he did that day.

en: Since last night he had taken nothing but a little light thin wine, and last night he had dropped the brandy slowly down on mr Lorry’s hearth like a man who had done with it.
vi: Since last night, he had not drunk anything except a bit of thin, weak wine, and last night he had slowly poured all the brandy into Mr. Lorry's fireplace as if he had severed ties with it.
tr: Since last night, he had only drunk slightly diluted wine, and last night he had slowly poured the cognac onto Mr. Lorry's hearthstone like a man who no longer had any use for it.
es: Since the previous night, he had only had a bit of watered-down wine.

en: It was as late as seven o’clock when he awoke refreshed, and went out into the streets again.
vi: At seven o'clock, he woke up comfortably and went out again.
tr: When he hit the streets again after waking up refreshed, it was already seven o'clock.
es: Around seven o'clock he woke up and resumed his march.

en: As he passed along towards Saint Antoine, he stopped at a shop-window where there was a mirror, and slightly altered the disordered arrangement of his loose cravat, and his coat-collar, and his wild hair.
vi: While heading towards Saint Antoine, he stopped in front of a display window with a mirror, adjusted his attire a bit, tightened his loose tie, raised the collar of his coat, and smoothed his messy hair.
tr: As he was heading towards St Antoine, he stopped in front of a shop window with a mirror and roughly adjusted his loosened tie, the collar of his coat, and his disheveled hair.
es: Upon reaching the San Antonio neighborhood, he stopped for a moment in front of a shop where he saw a mirror, and slightly adjusted the knot of his tie and disheveled his collar and hair.

en: This done, he went on direct to Defarge’s, and went in.
vi: Then he went straight to Defarge's tavern and went inside.
tr: Once this task was done, he headed straight to Defarge's shop and went inside.
es: Having done this, he headed straight to the Defarge tavern and entered resolutely.

en: There happened to be no customer in the shop but Jacques Three, of the restless fingers and the croaking voice.
vi: By chance, there were no other customers in the tavern except for Jacques Ba, the man with restless fingers and a booming voice.
tr: In the shop, there was no one but Jacques Three with his crow-like voice, constantly moving his fingers.
es: He found no one in the establishment except Santiago Tercero, whom he remembered seeing that afternoon among the jurors, who was drinking and conversing with the Defarges, husband and wife.

en: This man, whom he had seen upon the Jury, stood drinking at the little counter, in conversation with the Defarges, man and wife.
vi: This man he had seen sitting on the jury; he was at the small bar, drinking and chatting with Mr. and Mrs. Defarge.
tr: This man, whom he saw among the jury members, was leaning on the small counter, drinking his liquor, and chatting with the Defarge couple.
es: He found no one in the establishment except Santiago Tercero, whom he remembered seeing that afternoon among the jurors, who was drinking and conversing with the Defarges, husband and wife.

en: The Vengeance assisted in the conversation, like a regular member of the establishment.
vi: The Goddess of Revenge also joined the conversation, as a regular patron of this tavern.
tr: Revenge, as if it were an ordinary member of this group, was mingling into the conversation.
es: La Venganza, in her capacity as a member of the tavern, was attending the conversation.

en: As Carton walked in, took his seat and asked (in very indifferent French) for a small measure of wine, Madame Defarge cast a careless glance at him, and then a keener, and then a keener, and then advanced to him herself, and asked him what it was he had ordered.
vi: When Carton entered, chose a seat, and ordered (in very poor French) a small portion of wine, Madame Defarge glanced at him indifferently, then looked more closely, and even more closely, and personally went over to ask what he had ordered.
tr: When Carton entered the shop and sat down, asking for a small wine (in poor French), Madam Defarge first gave him an indifferent look; then she examined him with a bit more curiosity, and soon after with even more curious eyes, and approached him to ask what he had ordered.
es: Carton, after taking a seat, ordered a glass of wine. Madame Defarge gave him an indifferent glance, then a more scrutinizing one, followed by an extraordinarily penetrating look, and finally approached him to ask what he wanted.

en: He repeated what he had already said.
vi: He repeats what he said.
tr: He repeated what he had just said.
es: Carton repeated what he had said before.

en: “English?” asked Madame Defarge, inquisitively raising her dark eyebrows.
vi: − The Englishman? - Madame Defarge raised her thick black eyebrows inquisitively.
tr: Madam Defarge raised her black eyebrows curiously and asked, "Are you English?"
es: —English?—asked the innkeeper, raising her eyebrows.

en: After looking at her, as if the sound of even a single French word were slow to express itself to him, he answered, in his former strong foreign accent.
vi: After looking at her as if it was very difficult to understand a single French word, Carton responded in the same foreign accent as before.
tr: Carton looked at the woman as if he had difficulty understanding even the smallest French word, and then, with the same foreign accent as before, said, "Yes madam, yes!
es: Carton, after looking at her for a long while, as if it were very difficult for him to pronounce a French word, replied with a very strong foreign accent:

en: “Yes, madame, yes.
vi: − Yes, madame, yes.
tr: Carton looked at the woman as if he had difficulty understanding even the smallest French word, and then, with the same foreign accent as before, said, "Yes madam, yes!
es: —Yes, ma'am, yes; English.

en: I am English!”
vi: I am English!
tr: I am English!"
es: —Yes, ma'am, yes; English.

en: Madame Defarge returned to her counter to get the wine, and, as he took up a Jacobin journal and feigned to pore over it puzzling out its meaning, he heard her say, “I swear to you, like Evrémonde!”
vi: Madame Defarge turned back to the counter to get the wine, and while he held the Jacobin newspaper, pretending to try to understand the tangled words, he heard her say: − Swear to you, exactly like Evrémonde!
tr: Madam Defarge returned to her counter to fetch the wine, and while Carton had taken a Jacobin newspaper in his hand, bending over the words as if trying to decipher what they said, he heard the woman exclaim, "I swear, just like Evremonde!"
es: The barmaid went to the counter to serve the wine, and Carton, while he took a Jacobin newspaper in his hands and pretended to make efforts to interpret the language in which it was written, heard the first one say: —I swear he looks like Evrémonde.

en: Defarge brought him the wine, and gave him Good Evening.
vi: Defarge brought the wine and greeted.
tr: Defarge brought the wine and wished him a good evening.
es: Defarge served the wine, bidding the customer goodnight.

en: “How?”
vi: − What? − Hello.
tr: "Sir?""
es: —What?—asked Carton.

en: “Good evening.”
vi: − Ah! Hello, Citizen, - Carton poured wine into his glass.
tr: "Good evening."
es: —Good evening.

en: “Oh!
vi: - Ah!
tr: "Good evening."
es: —Good evening.

en: Good evening, citizen,” filling his glass.
vi: Good wine.
tr: "Ha, good evening citizen," said Carton, while filling his glass.
es: —Good evening.

en: “Ah! and good wine.
vi: Good wine.
tr: "Ahh! The wine is also very good.
es: —Oh... very good evening, citizen... and very good wine!

en: I drink to the Republic.”
vi: I drink to the Republic.
tr: I drink to the Republic."
es: I toast to the Republic!

en: Defarge went back to the counter, and said, “Certainly, a little like.”
vi: Defarge returned to the counter and said, "It does look a bit similar."
tr: When Defarge returned to the counter, he said, "Yes, it does resemble a bit indeed."
es: Defarge returned to the counter, saying: —It's true; he looks a bit like him.

en: Madame sternly retorted, “I tell you a good deal like.”
vi: − I told you it was exactly the same, - the wife responded coldly. − He haunts her mind, madame.
tr: Upon this, Madam replied sharply, "I tell you, it looks exactly like him."
es: —And I repeat that he looks a lot like him!

en: Jacques
vi: - Jacques Ba reconciled.
tr: As if trying to ease the atmosphere, Jacques Three said, "Look madam, your mind is always on him."
es: —replied the innkeeper harshly.

en: Three pacifically remarked, “He is so much in your mind, see you, madame.”
vi: − What else!
tr: As if trying to ease the atmosphere, Jacques Three said, "Look madam, your mind is always on him."
es: —You have it so present in your memory...—observed Santiago Tercero. —I swear I don't forget him for a moment either!

en: The amiable Vengeance added, with a laugh, “Yes, my faith!
vi: - The Goddess of Vengeance burst out laughing, interjecting.
tr: Warm-hearted Revenge laughed, "Indeed!
es: —exclaimed La Venganza, laughing.

en: And you are looking forward with so much pleasure to seeing him once more to-morrow!”
vi: − And you are eagerly excited to see him again tomorrow.
tr: You are eager to see him once more tomorrow!"
es: —And if I'm not mistaken, you're waiting for tomorrow to see him again.

en: Carton followed the lines and words of his paper, with a slow forefinger, and with a studious and absorbed face.
vi: Carton slowly traced his index finger along each line and word on the newspaper page, his face feigning concentration.
tr: Carton followed the lines and words in the newspaper with a diligent and pensive expression on his face, slowly tracing them with his index finger.
es: Carton continued reading, following the lines of the newspaper with his index finger and giving his full attention to the reading.

en: They were all leaning their arms on the counter close together, speaking low.
vi: The group of people leaned against the bar, huddling close together and speaking softly.
tr: The others, with their arms resting side by side on the counter, were speaking in low voices.
es: The Defarges, La Vengeance, and Jacques Three, heads together and elbows on the counter, were conversing in very low voices.

en: After a silence of a few moments, during which they all looked towards him without disturbing his outward attention from the Jacobin editor, they resumed their conversation.
vi: After a while, they all fell silent and looked towards Carton without disturbing his focus on reading the Jacobin newspaper. They then continued their conversation.
tr: After a few minutes of silence, during which they watched Carton focused on his newspaper without disturbing him, they resumed their conversation.
es: After a few moments of silence, during which the four people had their eyes fixed on the diligent reader, who had neither eyes nor ears for anything but the newspaper, they resumed their conversation.

en: “It is true what madame says,” observed Jacques Three.
vi: − What madame says is true, - Jacques Ba spoke up. -
tr: "Madam is right," said Jacques Three.
es: —I think your wife is right.

en: “Why stop?
vi: Why stop?
tr: "Why should we stop?
es: Why stop until the end of the journey?

en: There is great force in that.
vi: It's very reasonable.
tr: This is an incredible power.
es: The argument is very strong.

en: Why stop?”
vi: Why stop? −
tr: Why should we stop?"
es: —Whatever you want—objected Defarge—but we will have to stop somewhere.

en: “Well, well,” reasoned Defarge, “but one must stop somewhere.
vi: Ah, ah, - Defarge argued, - but one must stop somewhere.
tr: "It's all well and good," said Defarge, "but we need to stop somewhere.
es: —Whatever you want—objected Defarge—but we will have to stop somewhere.

en: After all, the question is still where?”
vi: After all, where is the limit? −
tr: The whole issue is, where will we stop?"
es: In reality, the only thing to agree upon is where to make that stop.

en: “At extermination,” said madame.
vi: When everything is destroyed, - Madame Defarge said.
tr: "When they are all destroyed," said the madam.
es: —After the extermination! —replied the innkeeper.

en: “Magnificent!” croaked Jacques Three.
vi: − Great! - Jacques Ba said in a booming voice.
tr: Jacques Three shouted, "Wonderful!" in a hoarse voice.
es: —Magnificent! —howled Santiago Tercero.

en: The Vengeance, also, highly approved.
vi: The Goddess of Vengeance also enthusiastically agreed.
tr: Revenge also loved this idea.
es: —Superb! —shouted Revenge.

en: “Extermination is good doctrine, my wife,” said Defarge, rather troubled; “in general, I say nothing against it.
vi: − Extermination is the best strategy, my dear, - Defarge said somewhat uneasily. - In general, I am not against it.
tr: "Destroying them all is a nice idea, my dear," said Defarge, a bit troubled; "I am not generally against it.
es: —I profess the holy doctrine of extermination, and it goes without saying that, in general, I have nothing against it—observed Defarge.

en: But this Doctor has suffered much; you have seen him to-day; you have observed his face when the paper was read.”
vi: But this doctor has suffered too much; today you saw him; you saw his face when those papers were read out. − I have seen that face! -
tr: But that Doctor has suffered a lot; you saw the man today; his face when the paper was read."
es: — But we must take into account that this poor doctor has already suffered a lot. Today you have been able to see it for yourselves, as you all must have noticed the expression on his face while the paper was being read.

en: “I have observed his face!” repeated madame, contemptuously and angrily.
vi: The wife's voice was furious and contemptuous.
tr: "Of course, I noticed what happened to your face!" the madam repeated, in a contemptuous and angry manner.
es: —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes!

en: “Yes.
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes.
es: —replied the innkeeper, putting all the contempt and hatred of her fierce heart into her words.

en: I have observed his face.
vi: I have seen that face!
tr: I saw your face.
es: —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes; and I have seen that it was not the face of a true friend of the Republic; that is what I have seen.

en: I have observed his face to be not the face of a true friend of the Republic.
vi: I have seen that his face is not the face of a true friend of the Republic.
tr: This face was definitely not the face of a loyal citizen to the Republic.
es: —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes; and I have seen that it was not the face of a true friend of the Republic; that is what I have seen.

en: Let him take care of his face!”
vi: Let him take care of his own face! −
tr: Let them deal with it however they want!"
es: —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes; and I have seen that it was not the face of a true friend of the Republic; that is what I have seen.

en: “And you have observed, my wife,” said Defarge, in a deprecatory manner, “the anguish of his daughter, which must be a dreadful anguish to him!”
vi: You have also seen how his daughter suffers, - Defarge said urgently, - that also causes him terrible pain! − I have seen his daughter, - said Madame Defarge. -
tr: Defarge, as if objecting, continued his speech, "Well, my wife," he said, "did you see the pain your daughter went through? Who knows how great a pain this is for her father!"
es: —And the cruel agonies of his daughter, agonies that must have greatly exacerbated his own, would not have escaped your notice—replied Defarge.

en: “I have observed his daughter,” repeated madame; “yes, I have observed his daughter, more times than one.
vi: Yes, I have seen his daughter, not just once.
tr: "I saw your daughter too," replied the madam; "yes, I looked at her from time to time.
es: —I have also observed your daughter, yes—replied the innkeeper;—I have observed her many times; not just today.

en: I have observed her to-day, and I have observed her other days.
vi: I saw her today and many other times.
tr: Today I examined her closely, and I had examined her on previous days as well.
es: I observed her today in the Tribunal, and I have observed her on other days in the street, gazing at the prison walls.

en: I have observed her in the court, and I have observed her in the street by the prison.
vi: I saw her in the courtroom, and I saw her on the street next to the prison.
tr: I examined her both in court and on the street next to the prison.
es: I observed her today in the Tribunal, and I have observed her on other days in the street, gazing at the prison walls.

en: Let me but lift my finger—!”
vi: I just need to lift a finger!... - Madame Defarge seemed to raise her index finger and let it drop heavily on the counter in front of her, like the blade of a guillotine coming down.
tr: But now, it's necessary to raise this finger!"
es: It is enough for me to lift a finger, for the blade to immediately drop and make her head roll.

en: She seemed to raise it (the listener’s eyes were always on his paper), and to let it fall with a rattle on the ledge before her, as if the axe had dropped.
vi: The eavesdropper's eyes remained fixed on the newspaper.
tr: She raised her finger (the person listening to them never took his eyes off the newspaper) and brought it down on the edge of the counter with a loud thud, as if she were lowering the blade of a guillotine.
es: It is enough for me to lift a finger, for the blade to immediately drop and make her head roll.

en: “The citizeness is superb!” croaked the Juryman.
vi: − Outstanding Female Citizen! - Jacques Ba said loudly.
tr: "This is an amazing citizen!" shouted the jury member in a hoarse voice.
es: —You are a prodigious citizen! —roared Santiago Tercero.

en: “She is an Angel!” said The Vengeance, and embraced her.
vi: − You are an angel! - The Goddess of Vengeance hugged Madame Defarge tightly.
tr: "She is an angel!" said Revenge and hugged the madam.
es: —An angel! —sighed Revenge.

en: “As to thee,” pursued madame, implacably, addressing her husband, “if it depended on thee—which, happily, it does not—thou wouldst rescue this man even now.”
vi: − As for you, - she insisted to her husband, - luckily, you have no power; if you did, you would definitely save that son-in-law right now.
tr: Turning to her husband, "As for you," the lady continued mercilessly, "if it were up to you –thankfully it's not– you would still save this man even now."
es: —As for you—continued the implacable innkeeper, addressing her husband,—I am sure that, if it were up to you... which fortunately it is not... you would still be capable of saving that man.

en: “No!” protested Defarge.
vi: − No! - Defarge objected.
tr: "Hey!" objected Defarge.
es: —No!

en: “Not if to lift this glass would do it!
vi: - Not at all, even if I had the strength to do so!
tr: "Even if it were an easy thing, I wouldn't bother.
es: —protested Defarge—If by raising this glass I could save him, be sure that I would not raise it!

en: But I would leave the matter there.
vi: But I stop this matter here.
tr: But I would leave this job here.
es: But I would stop there; I repeat that I would consider my work finished.

en: I say, stop there.”
vi: I say, stop here.
tr: I'm saying, let's stop now."
es: But I would stop there; I repeat that I would consider my work finished.

en: “See you then, Jacques,” said Madame Defarge, wrathfully; “and see you, too, my little Vengeance; see you both!
vi: − Then see you again, Jacques, - said Madame Defarge, her voice full of anger. See you again too, Goddess of Vengeance. We will meet again, both of you!
tr: "Look at me, Jacques," said Madame Defarge angrily; "you too, little Vengeance; both of you look at me!
es: —You can see it now, Santiago—exclaimed the innkeeper, her eyes blazing with rage—You can see it too, my dear Vengeance... You both see it...

en: Listen!
vi: Remember that!
tr: Listen now!
es: You both hear it...

en: For other crimes as tyrants and oppressors, I have this race a long time on my register, doomed to destruction and extermination.
vi: I have long placed this entire family on the list for condemnation and extermination, for all kinds of crimes of tyranny and oppression.
tr: I had already recorded this cruel and oppressive family to be destroyed for all the crimes they committed.
es: For a long time, that race has been listed in my records as condemned to destruction, to extermination, for crimes that have nothing to do with tyranny and oppression.

en: Ask my husband, is that so.”
vi: Ask my husband if it's true.
tr: If you want, ask my husband."
es: Ask my husband if I'm lying.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge, without being asked.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge confirmed without anyone asking.
tr: Without being asked anything further, Defarge confirmed, "Yes, that's correct."
es: —It's true—replied Defarge, without waiting to be asked.

en: “In the beginning of the great days, when the Bastille falls, he finds this paper of to-day, and he brings it home, and in the middle of the night when this place is clear and shut, we read it, here on this spot, by the light of this lamp.
vi: − On the day this glorious era began, when the Bastille fell, my husband found the stack of papers read in court today, my husband brought them home, at midnight, when the tavern was closed and quiet, we read them, right here, under this lamp.
tr: "At the beginning of these tremendous days, when the Bastille fell, he found that letter which is read today and brought it home, then at midnight, when no one was left in the shop, he closed the door and we read it right here, under the light of this lamp.
es: —In the early days of the great times, when the Bastille fell, my husband found the document that has been made public today, brought it home, and after midnight, when the establishment was closed and deserted, we read it in this very place and by the light of this very lamp.

en: Ask him, is that so.”
vi: Just ask my husband if it's true.
tr: If you want, ask him."
es: Ask him if I speak the truth.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge confirmed.
tr: "Yes, that's right," confirmed Defarge.
es: —It's true, yes—replied Defarge.

en: “That night, I tell him, when the paper is read through, and the lamp is burnt out, and the day is gleaming in above those shutters and between those iron bars, that I have now a secret to communicate.
vi: − That night, I told my husband after finishing reading the stack of papers, the lamp had run out of oil, and dawn had begun to break through the shutters and those bars, I said I needed to reveal a secret.
tr: "That night, after we finished reading the letter and the lamp went out, and when the first light of day filtered through the shutters and those iron bars, I told her that I would reveal a secret to her."
es: —That very night, after reading the paper and extinguishing the lamp, when the day began to filter through the cracks in the windows and the bars of the grilles, I told him that I had a secret to share with him.

en: Ask him, is that so.”
vi: Just ask my husband if it's true.
tr: "If you want, ask her.""
es: Let him tell you if I lie.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge again.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge confirmed again.
tr: "Yes, that's right," Defarge confirmed again.
es: —It's true—agreed Defarge.

en: “I communicate to him that secret.
vi: − I told that secret to my husband.
tr: "I revealed my secret to her.
es: —And I told him the secret.

en: I smite this bosom with these two hands as I smite it now, and I tell him, ‘Defarge, I was brought up among the fishermen of the sea-shore, and that peasant family so injured by the two Evrémonde brothers, as that Bastille paper describes, is my family.
vi: I pounded my chest with these two hands just as I am pounding my chest now, and I said, "Defarge, I was raised by the fishermen on the coast, but my real family is the peasant family that was harmed by the Evrémonde brothers, as the papers in the Bastille prison recounted.
tr: Striking my chest with both hands as I am doing now, I said to her, 'Defarge, I grew up among the fishermen by the sea, and as it is written in that paper found in the Bastille, that peasant family abused by the two Evremonde brothers was my family.
es: I struck his chest with these two hands, as I strike it now, and I said: "Defarge; I was raised among fishermen on the beach, and the peasant family so outraged by the Evrémonde brothers, that family described in the paper found in the Bastille, is my family.

en: Defarge, that sister of the mortally wounded boy upon the ground was my sister, that husband was my sister’s husband, that unborn child was their child, that brother was my brother, that father was my father, those dead are my dead, and that summons to answer for those things descends to me!’
vi: Defarge, the sister of the farmer who was wounded and lying on the floor, is my sister, that husband is my brother-in-law, the unborn child is their child, that farmer is my brother, that father is my father, those who died are all my relatives, and only I am left to demand justice from them!
tr: Defarge, the sister of the boy lying on the ground, wounded and at death's door, was my sister, that husband was my sister's husband, that unborn child was their child, that boy was my brother, that father was my father, those who died were my dead, and it falls upon me to seek justice for all of them!'
es: Defarge, the dying sister of the mortally wounded peasant boy was my sister, the husband was my sister's husband, the fruit of their love that never opened its eyes to the light was my sister's child, and that peasant brother was my brother, and the father who died of grief was my father, those who died were my dead, and their cries for vengeance have been directed at me ever since..."

en: Ask him, is that so.”
vi: Ask my husband if it's true.
tr: If you want, ask her."
es: Ask him if what I say is true.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge once more.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge confirmed once again.
tr: Defarge was now tired of confirming, simply listening to the woman, and when she wanted him to confirm, he reluctantly agreed. It was time to confirm once again. "Yes, that's right," confirmed Defarge once again.
es: —That's right—confessed Defarge.

en: “Then tell Wind and Fire where to stop,” returned madame; “but don’t tell me.”
vi: − Then show me where the wind and fire stop! - Madame Defarge replied. Don't talk to me!
tr: "Then go and tell 'Wind' and 'Fire' where they should stop," replied the lady; "not me."
es: —And now, tell me if it is possible to put gates on the gale or extinguish the fire of hell! —replied the innkeeper.—But no; it is not necessary for you to tell me.

en: Both her hearers derived a horrible enjoyment from the deadly nature of her wrath—the listener could feel how white she was, without seeing her—and both highly commended it.
vi: Knowing the reason for Madame Defarge's terrible hatred, the two listeners were disgustingly delighted and both wholeheartedly encouraged her, while the solitary guest over there, eyes glued to the newspaper, could still feel the woman's livid hatred.
tr: Both listeners took a dreadful pleasure in the woman's deadly nature of anger – the other listener could sense that the woman had turned deathly pale even without seeing her – and both received it with deep respect.
es: The two listeners savored a horrible pleasure in convincing themselves of the implacable nature of the innkeeper's hatred, whose ghostly pallor the newspaper reader was seeing without seeing her face.

en: Defarge, a weak minority, interposed a few words for the memory of the compassionate wife of the Marquis; but only elicited from his own wife a repetition of her last reply.
vi: Defarge, the weak minority, interjected a few words reminding them of the Marquis's compassionate wife, but it only made his wife repeat her earlier statement: −
tr: Defarge, as the powerless minority, attempted to say a few words reminding of the Marquis' compassionate wife; but his wife merely repeated her last words.
es: Defarge, a minor insignificant, ventured a few words highlighting the compassion of the Marquis's wife; but he achieved nothing more than the repetition of his wife's last words:

en: “Tell the Wind and the Fire where to stop; not me!”
vi: Then show me where the wind and fire stop! Don't talk to me!
tr: "Go tell 'Wind' and 'Fire' where they should stop, not me."
es: —Tell me if it is possible to put gates on the gale or extinguish the fire of hell!

en: Customers entered, and the group was broken up.
vi: A few customers entered the tavern and the group inside dispersed.
tr: Customers entered and the group dispersed.
es: The entrance of some patrons put an end to the conference.

en: The English customer paid for what he had had, perplexedly counted his change, and asked, as a stranger, to be directed towards the National Palace.
vi: The English guest paid for the wine, awkwardly counted the change, and then asked for directions to the National Castle like a stranger.
tr: The English customer paid for what he drank, counted the coins with a bewildered expression, and as a foreigner. He asked how he could get to the National Palace.
es: The Englishman paid the incurred expense and asked where the National Palace was.

en: Madame Defarge took him to the door, and put her arm on his, in pointing out the road.
vi: Madame Defarge escorted the guest to the door, grabbed the guest's arm, and pointed the way.
tr: Madame Defarge escorted him to the door and pointed in the direction he should go, holding his arm.
es: Mrs. Defarge accompanied him to the door, and there, placing her arm over his, indicated the way he should follow.

en: The English customer was not without his reflections then, that it might be a good deed to seize that arm, lift it, and strike under it sharp and deep.
vi: The guest couldn't suppress the thought that if only he could grab the innkeeper's wife's arm, lift her up, and stab her deeply in the side with a sword, it would be a blessing for many people.
tr: At that moment, what crossed the English customer's mind was how good it would be to grab that arm, lift it, and deliver a hard and deep stab underneath it.
es: The English patron felt the urge to lift that arm and strike its owner with a sure hand.

en: But, he went his way, and was soon swallowed up in the shadow of the prison wall.
vi: But then Carton silently left and soon disappeared into the darkness of the prison wall.
tr: Ama yoluna devam etti ve çok geçmeden hapishane duvarının gölgesinde kayboldu.
es: Carton moved away from those places, soon circling the prison walls.

en: At the appointed hour, he emerged from it to present himself in mr Lorry’s room again, where he found the old gentleman walking to and fro in restless anxiety.
vi: At the appointed time, he went from there to Mr. Lorry's place and found the old man anxiously pacing back and forth.
tr: Kararlaştırdıkları saatte bu gölgeden çıkarak tekrar Mr. Lorry'nin evine vardığında yaşlı adamı huzursuz bir sıkıntı içinde odanın içinde bir aşağı bir yukarı yürürken buldu.
es: At the appointed hour, he presented himself at Lorry's house, where he found the old man waiting for him, anxious and full of worry.

en: He said he had been with Lucie until just now, and had only left her for a few minutes, to come and keep his appointment.
vi: He had been with Lucie until just a few minutes ago before leaving to make it to this appointment on time.
tr: Şu ana dek Lucie ile olduğunu ve onun yanından bu randevuya gelebilmek için birkaç dakikalığına ayrıldığını söyledi.
es: The good banker informed him that he had been accompanying Lucía until moments before, and that he had parted from her to attend the agreed meeting; that they had not seen her father since he left at four in the afternoon; that Lucía harbored some hope that, through the doctor's intervention, Carlos might be saved, but that the hopes were very weak.

en: Her father had not been seen, since he quitted the banking-house towards four o’clock.
vi: There has been no sign of Dr. Manette since he left this bank at nearly four o'clock.
tr: Lucie'nin babası dörde doğru bankadan çıkmış ve bir daha görünmemişti.
es: The good banker informed him that he had been accompanying Lucía until moments before, and that he had parted from her to attend the agreed meeting; that they had not seen her father since he left at four in the afternoon; that Lucía harbored some hope that, through the doctor's intervention, Carlos might be saved, but that the hopes were very weak.

en: She had some faint hopes that his mediation might save Charles, but they were very slight.
vi: Lucie still clings to the faint hope that her father might be able to arrange something to save Charles.
tr: Babasının arabuluculuğunun Charles'ı kurtaracağına dair bir ümidi vardı Lucie'nin, ama bu yok denecek kadar azdı. Babası gideli beş saati geçmişti.
es: The good banker informed him that he had been accompanying Lucía until moments before, and that he had parted from her to attend the agreed meeting; that they had not seen her father since he left at four in the afternoon; that Lucía harbored some hope that, through the doctor's intervention, Carlos might be saved, but that the hopes were very weak.

en: He had been more than five hours gone: where could he be?
vi: The doctor has been gone for five hours now; no one knows where he has gone.
tr: Nerede olabilirdi?
es: The doctor's absence lasted five hours: where could he be?

en: mr Lorry waited until ten; but, Doctor Manette not returning, and he being unwilling to leave Lucie any longer, it was arranged that he should go back to her, and come to the banking-house again at midnight.
vi: Mr. Lorry waited until ten o'clock but still did not see Dr. Manette return. Not wanting to worry Lucie any further, he arranged to return to Lucie's house and would come back to the Bank at midnight.
tr: Mr. Lorry waited until ten o'clock; but Doctor Manette did not come, and since he did not want to leave Lucie alone any longer, they decided it would be a good idea for Mr. Lorry to return to her and come back to the bank at midnight.
es: Lorry waited for him until ten, and since he could not resign himself to leaving Lucía alone and without news for so long, they decided that Lorry would return to the house of the unfortunate woman, and that Carton would wait for the doctor's arrival.

en: In the meanwhile, Carton would wait alone by the fire for the Doctor.
vi: Meanwhile, Carton sat alone by the fireplace waiting for the doctor.
tr: In the meantime, Carton would wait by the fireplace for the Doctor.
es: Lorry was to return to the Bank at midnight.

en: He waited and waited, and the clock struck twelve; but Doctor Manette did not come back.
vi: He waited, waited endlessly, and the clock had struck twelve times but still there was no sign of Dr. Manette returning.
tr: Carton waited and waited, the clock struck twelve; but the Doctor was nowhere to be seen.
es: Twelve o'clock struck and the doctor did not appear.

en: mr Lorry returned, and found no tidings of him, and brought none.
vi: Mr. Lorry returned, without any news from the doctor or from anyone else.
tr: When Mr. Lorry returned, he had neither heard from him nor brought any news.
es: Lorry returned, and neither found any news nor brought any.

en: Where could he be?
vi: Where could he have gone?
tr: Where could he be?
es: Where could he be?

en: They were discussing this question, and were almost building up some weak structure of hope on his prolonged absence, when they heard him on the stairs.
vi: The two were discussing this, almost concluding that Dr. Manette's prolonged absence was a faint sign of hope when they heard the doctor's footsteps on the stairs.
tr: They were trying to find the answer to this question, and just as a faint hope began to sprout within them during the Doctor's prolonged absence, they heard his voice on the stairs.
es: This was the point they were discussing, almost opening their hearts to hope, founded on the prolonged absence, when they heard his footsteps on the stairs.

en: The instant he entered the room, it was plain that all was lost.
vi: As soon as Dr. Manette stepped into the room, it was clear that all hope had vanished.
tr: As soon as he entered, they realized that everything was lost.
es: As soon as he appeared in the room, they saw that all was lost.

en: Whether he had really been to any one, or whether he had been all that time traversing the streets, was never known.
vi: Never knew if the doctor actually met someone or was just wandering back and forth on the road.
tr: Had he really gone to see someone, or had he just wandered the streets all this time, it's unknown.
es: It has never been known whether he spent all the long hours of absence wandering aimlessly through the streets, or if he visited his acquaintances.

en: As he stood staring at them, they asked him no question, for his face told them everything.
vi: When Dr. Manette stared at them, no one asked any questions because the doctor's face had already said everything.
tr: While standing and looking at them, they didn't ask him anything, for his face told everything.
es: He entered the room, remained with his gaze fixed on those who were waiting for him, and did not utter a word, nor did anyone speak to him, for the expression on his face clearly said that all was lost.

en: “I cannot find it,” said he, “and I must have it.
vi: − I can't find it, - the doctor said, - I must find it.
tr: "I couldn't find it," said the Doctor, "I absolutely must find it.
es: —I can't find it—he said.

en: Where is it?”
vi: Where is it?
tr: Where is it?"
es: —Where is it? I need it.

en: His head and throat were bare, and, as he spoke with a helpless look straying all around, he took his coat off, and let it drop on the floor.
vi: Head without a hat, neck without a scarf, and while the doctor spoke and helplessly scanned the room, he took off his coat and let it drop to the floor.
tr: Her head and neck were uncovered, and with a helpless expression in her eyes, she took off her coat and threw it on the floor while speaking.
es: He came with his head bare and the front of his shirt open. After casting anguished glances around, he took off his coat and sat on the ground.

en: “Where is my bench?
vi: − Where is my cobbler's bench?
tr: "Where is my workbench?
es: —But where is my stool?

en: I have been looking everywhere for my bench, and I can’t find it.
vi: I've looked everywhere for it but can't find it.
tr: I looked everywhere but couldn't find my workbench.
es: I've been looking for it everywhere without being able to find it.

en: What have they done with my work?
vi: What did they do with my unfinished shoes?
tr: What happened to the tasks I had?
es: What have they done with my work?

en: Time presses: I must finish those shoes.”
vi: It's urgent, I need to finish those shoes.
tr: I don't have much time left. I need to finish those shoes."
es: I need to finish those shoes... they are urgently awaited.

en: They looked at one another, and their hearts died within them.
vi: Carton and Mr. Lorry looked at each other, their hearts frozen. − Mau, mau!
tr: Mr. Lorry and Carton looked at each other and their hearts broke.
es: The two listeners looked at each other, dismayed.

en: “Come, come!” said he, in a whimpering miserable way; “let me get to work.
vi: - Doctor Manette still spoke in a miserable, whining voice.
tr: "Come on!" said the Doctor, whining in a miserable state; "let me get back to my work.
es: —Well... well!

en: Give me my work.”
vi: Let me work. Give me back my shoes.
tr: Give me my bench."
es: —replied the old man.—My stool... my work started...! I repeat, it is very urgent!...

en: Receiving no answer, he tore his hair, and beat his feet upon the ground, like a distracted child.
vi: Hearing no response from anyone, he ruffled his hair, stomped his feet on the floor, like an angry child.
tr: When he received no response, he started pulling his hair and stomping his foot like a child gone mad.
es: Not receiving a response, he pulled his hair and stomped on the ground, similar to an angry child.

en: “Don’t torture a poor forlorn wretch,” he implored them, with a dreadful cry; “but give me my work!
vi: − Don't torment this poor, lonely, miserable man anymore, - Mr. Manette pleaded with them in a terrifying scream.
tr: He cried out in a heart-wrenching manner, "Stop tormenting that poor man already," he pleaded with them; "give me back my workbench already!
es: —Don't torment a wretched man! —he exclaimed, letting out a formidable cry. — Give me my work... for God's sake!

en: What is to become of us, if those shoes are not done to-night?”
vi: - Give me back the shoes! What will happen if I don't finish the shoes tonight?
tr: If I can't finish those shoes tonight, what will we do then?"
es: What will become of us if I don't finish the shoes tonight?

en: Lost, utterly lost!
vi: Madness, complete madness!
tr: He had completely lost himself!
es: Lost, completely lost!

en: It was so clearly beyond hope to reason with him, or try to restore him, that—as if by agreement—they each put a hand upon his shoulder, and soothed him to sit down before the fire, with a promise that he should have his work presently.
vi: Clearly, there was no hope of persuading or calming the doctor, without a word, Carton and Mr. Lorry both placed their hands on the doctor's shoulders, coaxing him to sit down by the fireplace and promising him that he could make the shoes immediately.
tr: It was so clear that talking to him rationally or trying to bring him to his senses would be of no use – as if they had agreed among themselves – both of them placed their hands soothingly on the Doctor's shoulder and sat him down in front of the fire, telling him that his workbench would be brought to him shortly.
es: It was useless to try to light a lamp that the fierce hurricane of misfortune had extinguished forever.

en: He sank into the chair, and brooded over the embers, and shed tears.
vi: Mr. Manette sank into the chair, dejectedly staring at the embers, and cried.
tr: The Doctor sank into the chair, gazing at the embers, and fell into deep thoughts, crying uncontrollably.
es: To Lorry's horror, to Sydney Carton's terror, Dr. Manette was once again the shoemaker of the garret, the unfortunate idiot who years before had been handed over to the innkeeper Defarge.

en: As if all that had happened since the garret time were a momentary fancy, or a dream, mr Lorry saw him shrink into the exact figure that Defarge had had in keeping.
vi: Everything that had happened since the doctor left the attic in Saint Antoine seemed like a fleeting dream or illusion, and in Mr. Lorry's eyes, the doctor had reverted to the very person Defarge had once watched over.
tr: As if everything that had happened since those days in the attic was just a fleeting dream or illusion, Mr. Lorry watched him shrink back into the state he was in while staying with Defarge.
es: To Lorry's horror, to Sydney Carton's terror, Dr. Manette was once again the shoemaker of the garret, the unfortunate idiot who years before had been handed over to the innkeeper Defarge.

en: Affected, and impressed with terror as they both were, by this spectacle of ruin, it was not a time to yield to such emotions.
vi: Though stunned and heartbroken by this terrible collapse, both Carton and Mr. Lorry knew that now was not the time to give in to their emotions.
tr: Even though both were horrified and deeply affected by this desolate scene, it was not the time to succumb to such emotions.
es: Both impressed, affected by the same idea and understanding the need to overcome their emotions, they devoted themselves not to trying to revive that completely extinguished intelligence, but to calming the unhappy old man, promising him that very soon the bench, the tools, and the shoes would be returned to him.

en: His lonely daughter, bereft of her final hope and reliance, appealed to them both too strongly.
vi: They were forced to be strong as the doctor's only daughter could no longer rely on this last hope.
tr: They thought of the utterly alone Lucie, who had lost her last hope and confidence.
es: Both impressed, affected by the same idea and understanding the need to overcome their emotions, they devoted themselves not to trying to revive that completely extinguished intelligence, but to calming the unhappy old man, promising him that very soon the bench, the tools, and the shoes would be returned to him.

en: Again, as if by agreement, they looked at one another with one meaning in their faces.
vi: Once again, without a word, the two looked at each other, their faces full of meaning.
tr: As if they had agreed once again, they looked at each other with the same expression on their faces.
es: Both impressed, affected by the same idea and understanding the need to overcome their emotions, they devoted themselves not to trying to revive that completely extinguished intelligence, but to calming the unhappy old man, promising him that very soon the bench, the tools, and the shoes would be returned to him.

en: Carton was the first to speak:
vi: Carton was the first to speak: − The last chance, which was already slim, is now lost.
tr: Carton was the first to speak:
es: —He has succumbed to the blow, excessively harsh for him—said Carton.

en: “The last chance is gone: it was not much.
vi: Carton was the first to speak: − The last chance, which was already slim, is now lost.
tr: "Our last hope has also ended, it wasn't much anyway.

en: Yes; he had better be taken to her.
vi: Yes, we should bring him back to Lucie.
tr: Yes, the best thing is to take him to his daughter.
es: Yes; there is no choice but to take him to his daughter; but before doing so, would you be so kind as to give me a moment of your attention?

en: But, before you go, will you, for a moment, steadily attend to me?
vi: But before you go, please listen to me carefully for a minute.
tr: But before you go, will you carefully listen to what I have to say?
es: Yes; there is no choice but to take him to his daughter; but before doing so, would you be so kind as to give me a moment of your attention?

en: Don’t ask me why I make the stipulations I am going to make, and exact the promise I am going to exact; I have a reason—a good one.”
vi: Do not ask why there are conditions as I will set, do not ask why there are promises as I will demand. I have reasons... legitimate reasons.
tr: But don't ask why I will propose these conditions and why I will ask you to promise me; there is a reason – and a good one at that."
es: I need to impose some conditions and extract a promise from you; but do not ask me the reason for the former nor the why of the latter, for I have a reason to keep them silent... and it is of great importance.

en: “I do not doubt it,” answered mr Lorry.
vi: − I have no doubt, - Mr. Lorry replied.
tr: "I'm sure it is," replied Mr. Lorry.
es: —I don't doubt it—replied Lorry.

en: “Say on.”
vi: - Please go ahead.
tr: "Please continue."
es: —Go on.

en: The figure in the chair between them, was all the time monotonously rocking itself to and fro, and moaning.
vi: The person sitting on the chair between them kept rocking back and forth in a peculiar manner and lamenting.
tr: Meanwhile, the person sitting in the seat between them was monotonously rocking back and forth and groaning.
es: In a chair placed between the two interlocutors sat the old man, rocking monotonously and sobbing.

en: They spoke in such a tone as they would have used if they had been watching by a sick-bed in the night.
vi: The two people lowered their voices to talk as if they were sitting beside a patient's bed in the middle of the night.
tr: They were speaking in low voices as if they were at the bedside of a patient at night.
es: The interlocutors spoke in very low voices, as if they were beside the bed of a sick person.

en: Carton stooped to pick up the coat, which lay almost entangling his feet.
vi: Carton bent down to pick up the doctor's coat that was tangled under his feet.
tr: Carton bent down to pick up the coat that was lying under his feet.
es: Carton got down to pick up the doctor's frock coat from the ground.

en: As he did so, a small case in which the Doctor was accustomed to carry the lists of his day’s duties, fell lightly on the floor.
vi: As he picked it up, a small box that the doctor often used to store his daily work notes fell to the floor from the coat.
tr: At that moment, the small case in which the Doctor carried the list of his daily tasks fell to the ground.
es: As he did so, a small box fell to the ground where the doctor used to keep the list of visits he had to make during the day.

en: Carton took it up, and there was a folded paper in it.
vi: Carton picked up the box, and inside was a folded piece of paper.
tr: When Carton picked it up, he saw a folded paper inside.
es: He picked it up and opened it, finding a folded paper inside.

en: “We should look at this!” he said.
vi: − We should take a look at this! - He said.
tr: "We need to look at this!" he said.
es: —Do you want us to see what this is?—he asked.

en: mr Lorry nodded his consent.
vi: Mr. Lorry nodded in agreement.
tr: Mr. Lorry nodded in agreement.
es: Lorry nodded with a movement of his head.

en: He opened it, and exclaimed, “Thank God!”
vi: He opened it and exclaimed: − Thank God! −
tr: Carton opened the paper and exclaimed, "Thank God!"
es: —Thank you, my God! —exclaimed Carton as soon as he unfolded the paper.

en: “What is it?” asked mr Lorry, eagerly.
vi: What's the matter? - Mr. Lorry asked anxiously.
tr: "What is it?" asked Mr. Lorry, curiously.
es: —What is it?—asked Lorry with a longing tone.

en: “A moment!
vi: − Wait!
tr: "One minute!
es: —A little patience; I will explain it to you in due time.

en: Let me speak of it in its place.
vi: I will explain clearly later.
tr: With your permission, let me explain this when the time comes," said Carton, and he put his hand into the pocket of his coat and took out another paper, "now this is the document that will allow me to leave this city.
es: —A little patience; I will explain it to you in due time.

en: First,” he put his hand in his coat, and took another paper from it, “that is the certificate which enables me to pass out of this city.
vi: First, - he reached into his coat pocket and took out another piece of paper, - this is a pass that allows me to leave this capital city.
tr: With your permission, let me explain this when the time comes," said Carton, and he put his hand into the pocket of his coat and took out another paper, "now this is the document that will allow me to leave this city.
es: First of all—he said, reaching into the inner pocket of his frock coat and taking out another paper,—you should see this, which is a certificate, thanks to which I can leave the city without inconvenience.

en: Look at it.
vi: Take a look. See...?
tr: Look what it says – Sydney Carton, English, right?"
es: Read it.... Sydney Carton, English subject...

en: You see—Sydney Carton, an Englishman?”
vi: Sydney Carton, an Englishman?
tr: Look what it says – Sydney Carton, English, right?"
es: Read it.... Sydney Carton, English subject...

en: mr Lorry held it open in his hand, gazing in his earnest face.
vi: Mr. Lorry held the paper open in his hand, attentively looking at Carton's eager face.
tr: Mr. Lorry took the document and fixed his eyes on Carton's excited face.
es: Lorry was left contemplating the paper.

en: “Keep it for me until to-morrow.
vi: − Please keep this for me until tomorrow.
tr: "Please keep this for me until tomorrow.
es: —Keep it until tomorrow.

en: I shall see him to-morrow, you remember, and I had better not take it into the prison.”
vi: Tomorrow I will meet Darnay in prison, remember, and I should not bring this paper with me.
tr: You know I am going to see him tomorrow, and it would be better if I didn't have this with me when I go to the prison."
es: You will remember that I have to visit the prisoner, and I don't think it's wise to take it with me to the jail.

en: “Why not?”
vi: − Why not? − I don't know; I don't want to carry it.
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why not?

en: “I don’t know; I prefer not to do so.
vi: − Why not? − I don't know; I don't want to carry it.
tr: "I don't know; I found it appropriate not to take it.
es: —I don't know... A whim, perhaps, but I prefer not to wear it.

en: Now, take this paper that Doctor Manette has carried about him.
vi: Now let's look at the paper that Dr. Manette is carrying with him.
tr: Now take this paper that Doctor Manette carries with him.
es: Also take the paper that Doctor Manette carried in his pocket, which is another similar certificate, a safe-conduct allowing him, his daughter, and his granddaughter to pass through the Barrier and the border at any time.

en: It is a similar certificate, enabling him and his daughter and her child, at any time, to pass the barrier and the frontier!
vi: It is also a similar pass, allowing him, his daughter, and the child to pass through the city gates and borders at any time!
tr: This is a document, just like mine, that will allow the Doctor, his daughter, and his grandchild to pass the barrier and the border whenever they want; do you understand?"
es: Also take the paper that Doctor Manette carried in his pocket, which is another similar certificate, a safe-conduct allowing him, his daughter, and his granddaughter to pass through the Barrier and the border at any time.

en: You see?”
vi: See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this paper yesterday, as a last resort to prevent any misfortune.
tr: "Yes!"
es: Do you see it?

en: “Yes!”
vi: See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this paper yesterday, as a last resort to prevent any misfortune.
tr: "Yes!"
es: —Yes.

en: “Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday.
vi: See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this paper yesterday, as a last resort to prevent any misfortune.
tr: "Maybe he did this as a last precaution against all the disasters that befell them yesterday.
es: —Probably he provided it yesterday, in order to take all kinds of precautions against the storm.

en: When is it dated?
vi: What date is it signed?
tr: Is there a date on it?
es: What date does it have?

en: But no matter; don’t stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own.
vi: But it doesn't matter; don't waste time finding out; keep it safe along with my pass and yours.
tr: But it doesn't matter; no need to look; put mine next to theirs.
es: But it doesn't matter; there's no need to take note of that detail.

en: Now, observe!
vi: Now, listen to me!
tr: Now look!
es: The essential thing is that you keep it together with mine and yours.

en: I never doubted until within this hour or two, that he had, or could have such a paper.
vi: Until one or two hours ago, I never thought the doctor had such a pass.
tr: Until an hour or two ago, I didn't think he had or could have such a document.
es: Now then; listen carefully to my words, and do not forget them; until two hours ago, it didn't cross my mind that you might need that paper, which today is firm and valid, and will be so as long as it is not revoked.

en: It is good, until recalled.
vi: The pass is still valid until it expires.
tr: This is very good, that is, until it is canceled.
es: Now then; listen carefully to my words, and do not forget them; until two hours ago, it didn't cross my mind that you might need that paper, which today is firm and valid, and will be so as long as it is not revoked.

en: But it may be soon recalled, and, I have reason to think, will be.”
vi: But it may soon expire, and I have reason to believe so, certainly.
tr: It could be canceled soon because I have valid reasons to think so."
es: But they can revoke it; and moreover: powerful reasons make me believe that they will revoke it very soon.

en: “They are not in danger?”
vi: − They are not in any danger, are they? −
tr: "They are not in danger, are they?"
es: —Are they in danger?

en: “They are in great danger.
vi: They are in extreme danger.
tr: "They are facing a very great danger.
es: —They are in imminent danger.

en: They are in danger of denunciation by Madame Defarge.
vi: They risk being denounced by Madame Defarge.
tr: The danger is something like Madam Defarge denouncing them.
es: —They are in imminent danger.

en: I know it from her own lips.
vi: I heard it from her own mouth.
tr: I heard this from her own mouth.
es: They are in danger of being denounced by the innkeeper Defarge; no one told me this; I heard it from her own lips.

en: I have overheard words of that woman’s, to-night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours.
vi: Tonight, I overheard her words which made me clearly see the danger awaiting them.
tr: According to the words I overheard tonight, they are in big trouble.
es: Tonight I overheard a conversation of that woman, and the conversation made me see the danger that threatens the doctor's family.

en: I have lost no time, and since then, I have seen the spy.
vi: Without delay, immediately after that I went to meet the spy.
tr: I found the spy without wasting any time.
es: Since I heard it, I have not wasted any time, I visited my spy, and my initial impressions have been fully confirmed.

en: He confirms me.
vi: He confirmed it to me.
tr: He confirmed what I said.
es: Since I heard it, I have not wasted any time, I visited my spy, and my initial impressions have been fully confirmed.

en: He knows that a wood-sawyer, living by the prison wall, is under the control of the Defarges, and has been rehearsed by Madame Defarge as to his having seen Her”—he never mentioned Lucie’s name—“making signs and signals to prisoners.
vi: He knew of a woodcutter, living next to the prison wall, who was under the control of the Defarges, and he had informed Madame Defarge that he had seen Lucie frequenting that place... he did not mention Lucie's name... saw Lucie signaling and gesturing to the prisoner.
tr: He mentioned that a sawyer living near the prison wall was Defarge's man and that this man had told Madam Defarge about the woman who frequently signaled to the prisoners –Carton had not mentioned Lucie's name–.
es: He knows that a wood sawyer, a creation of the Defarges, is ready to declare that he saw her (Carton never pronounced Lucie's name) signaling to the prisoners.

en: It is easy to foresee that the pretence will be the common one, a prison plot, and that it will involve her life—and perhaps her child’s—and perhaps her father’s—for both have been seen with her at that place.
vi: It was very clear that this was previously a pretext for a common crime, conspiring with a prisoner, which would endanger Lucie's life... and perhaps her child's as well... because both were seen standing there.
tr: It is not hard to see that they will be subjected to an ordinary accusation, a prison conspiracy; such an accusation could cost them their lives –perhaps even the child's and maybe the father's too– because both of them have been seen there, beside her.
es: It is not difficult to guess that there are plenty of reasons to base any accusation on the mentioned fact, a plot against the Republic, for example, whose consequence would be her death, who knows if also that of her daughter... perhaps even that of her father, for both have also been seen in the same place...

en: Don’t look so horrified.
vi: Don't panic like that.
tr: Do not be afraid.
es: Do not be afraid... you will save them all.

en: You will save them all.”
vi: He will save everyone.
tr: You will save them all."
es: Do not be afraid... you will save them all.

en: “Heaven grant I may, Carton!
vi: − God help us save them, Carton!
tr: "I wish I could save Carton!
es: —May Heaven will it, Carton!

en: But how?”
vi: But how?
tr: But how?"
es: But how?

en: “I am going to tell you how.
vi: − I will tell you how.
tr: "I will tell you how it will be.
es: —That is what I am going to tell you right now.

en: It will depend on you, and it could depend on no better man.
vi: Everything depends on you and there is no one better.
tr: This depends on you, and no one else can save them but you.
es: I trust you, convinced that I could not put the matter in better hands.

en: This new denunciation will certainly not take place until after to-morrow; probably not until two or three days afterwards; more probably a week afterwards.
vi: This denunciation will certainly not happen from now until the day after tomorrow; perhaps not even in two or three days; but a week later, it is possible.
tr: This new report won't be made by tomorrow; it will probably take two or three days; maybe even a week.
es: The new denunciation will not be made until the day after tomorrow... they will probably leave it for two or three days later, and it is even more likely that they will delay it for a week.

en: You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine.
vi: You know that even mourning, or sympathizing with a victim of the guillotine, is a serious crime.
tr: You know, mourning and crying for the guillotine's criminals is a great crime.
es: You know perfectly well that in this blessed country, anyone who cries or sympathizes with a victim of the guillotine incurs the death penalty.

en: She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure.
vi: Lucie and her father will certainly be guilty of this, and that woman, with her deep-seated, indescribable hatred, will be waiting to denounce them further to strengthen her position and to ensure the conviction.
tr: It is as clear as day that he and his father will commit this crime, and this woman will wait to add this heavy accusation to her charges, then she will show them as guilty.
es: There is no doubt that both she and her father will be guilty of the aforementioned crime, and I can assure you that the innkeeper, whose fierce hatred reaches inconceivable extremes, will wait until she has weapons that increase the strength of her denunciation and make the result doubly certain.

en: You follow me?”
vi: Do you understand what I mean?
tr: Were you able to follow me?"
es: Do you understand?

en: “So attentively, and with so much confidence in what you say, that for the moment I lose sight,” touching the back of the Doctor’s chair, “even of this distress.”
vi: − Listening very carefully, and believing in your words so much that, hearing you speak, we forget all this sorrow, - Mr. Lorry touched the back of Dr. Manette's chair.
tr: "You speak so carefully and so confidently," said Mr. Lorry, touching the back of the Doctor's chair, "for a moment I even forgot the pain inside me."
es: —With such attention, and so deeply convinced of the accuracy of what you assert, that I even momentarily forget this misfortune—he replied, extending his right hand towards the doctor's chair.

en: “You have money, and can buy the means of travelling to the seacoast as quickly as the journey can be made.
vi: − You have money, and you can buy the fastest means to get to the coast to undertake the journey.
tr: "You have money and can obtain the necessary things as soon as you can travel to the opposite shore.
es: —You should not encounter difficulties, as you have plenty of money, to reach the coast using the fastest means of transportation.

en: Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England.
vi: A few days ago, you had already prepared your part to return to England.
tr: Your preparations for the return to England were already complete.
es: You have already completed your preparations to return to England several days ago.

en: Early to-morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o’clock in the afternoon.”
vi: Early tomorrow morning, you must arrange for horses and carriages to be ready so you can depart exactly at two in the afternoon.
tr: Have your horses ready early tomorrow, so you can set off at two in the afternoon."
es: Give orders for the horses to be harnessed tomorrow to start the journey at two in the afternoon.

en: “It shall be done!”
vi: − It will be taken care of!
tr: "Alright!""
es: —They will be.

en: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that mr Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.
vi: Carton's enthusiastic and infectious demeanor made Mr. Lorry feel invigorated and as spry as a young man.
tr: Carton was in such an enthusiastic and excited state that this fire had also engulfed Mr. Lorry, suddenly making him feel younger and more lively.
es: —Didn't I say before that it was impossible to put the matter in better hands?

en: “You are a noble heart.
vi: − He is a noble man.
tr: "You have a noble heart.
es: You have a heart full of nobility.

en: Did I say we could depend upon no better man?
vi: I said that no one could be more reliable, didn't I?
tr: Did I mention that there couldn't be a better man for this job than you?
es: Tonight, tell her that you know the danger looming over her head, and that this danger may also involve her daughter and her father.
