en: Tell her, to-night, what you know of her danger as involving her child and her father.
vi: Tonight, tell Lucie what you know about the danger that awaits and involves both her father and her child.
tr: Tonight, tell her about the danger she is in, which also includes her child and her father.
es: Tonight, tell her that you know the danger looming over her head, and that this danger may also involve her daughter and her father.

en: Dwell upon that, for she would lay her own fair head beside her husband’s cheerfully.”
vi: Emphasize that because Lucie is willing to die with her husband. -
tr: Emphasize this well, or else she will gladly lay her beautiful head next to her husband's."
es: Insist on this point, because if you don't, it's likely that you won't achieve anything, as she, without hesitation, and even full of joy, would place her beautiful head next to her husband's, so that the same blow would make both of their heads roll.

en: He faltered for an instant; then went on as before.
vi: He hesitated for a moment and then continued.
tr: After a moment of hesitation, he continued as before.
es: Insist on this point, because if you don't, it's likely that you won't achieve anything, as she, without hesitation, and even full of joy, would place her beautiful head next to her husband's, so that the same blow would make both of their heads roll.

en: “For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour.
vi: - For the sake of the child and her father, urge Lucie to leave Paris immediately, at that hour, you and the whole family will go with her.
tr: "For the sake of her child and her father, convince her that it is essential to leave Paris with you all at that hour.
es: By insisting on the danger her daughter faces and the threat to her father, make her see the imperative need to leave Paris tomorrow at the indicated time, with them and with you.

en: Tell her that it was her husband’s last arrangement.
vi: Say that this is her husband's final arrangement.
tr: Tell her that this is her husband's last wish.
es: Tell her that it is her husband's wish, an express wish on whose fulfillment much more depends than she can suppose or expect.

en: Tell her that more depends upon it than she dare believe, or hope.
vi: Tell Lucie that everyone is relying on this, more than she can imagine or hope for.
tr: Tell her that much more than she thinks or hopes depends on this.
es: Tell her that it is her husband's wish, an express wish on whose fulfillment much more depends than she can suppose or expect.

en: You think that her father, even in this sad state, will submit himself to her; do you not?”
vi: According to him, would her father in this unfortunate situation comply with his daughter's wishes?
tr: Do you think her father, in his current state of distress, would follow her advice?"
es: Don't you think that her father, despite the lamentable condition of his mind, will submit to his daughter's wishes?

en: “I am sure of it.”
vi: − I am sure he would.
tr: "I'm sure of this."
es: —I am sure of it.

en: “I thought so.
vi: − I think so too.
tr: "I thought the same."
es: —I supposed so.

en: Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage.
vi: Just quietly and silently prepare everything right here in the yard, even have you sit ready in the car.
tr: "Make your preparations in the courtyard here, quietly and quickly, and even take your place in the car."
es: Above all, have everything ready for the indicated time. The car prepared, the horses hitched, and you all seated in your places.

en: The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away.”
vi: The moment I come to see you, I get in the car and we leave immediately.
tr: "As soon as I come to you, you will let me in and we will set off.""
es: The moment I arrive, place me in the car, and off we go.

en: “I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?”
vi: − So, in any situation, we have to wait for you?
tr: "Whatever happens, we should wait for you, is that right?"
es: —Should I await your arrival, no matter what happens?

en: “You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place.
vi: − You have already kept my passport along with everyone else's, and you must reserve a place for me.
tr: "You know you have my exit document along with the others, make sure to reserve my spot.
es: —You have my safe-conduct in your possession, along with the others, a safe-conduct that entitles me to a seat.

en: Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!”
vi: Without any hesitation, I will leave immediately for England when I arrive!
tr: Just wait for me to arrive, then straight to England!"
es: You will wait until that seat is occupied, and as soon as it is, to England as quickly as possible.

en: “Why, then,” said mr Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, “it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side.”
vi: − Oh, - Mr. Lorry tightly grasped Carton's calm and determined hand, - then everything doesn't just rely on this old man alone, but we also have a passionate young man by our side.
tr: "Well, then," said Mr. Lorry, shaking Carton's excited but firm and strong hand, "this matter does not depend solely on an old man like me, because there will be a young and eager man by my side."
es: —In that case—remarked Lorry, giving Carton a firm handshake,—everything no longer depends on a poor old man, since I will have by my side a passionate and determined young man.

en: “By the help of Heaven you shall!
vi: − With God's help, you will be fulfilled!
tr: "With God's help, everything will happen!"
es: —With God's help, you will have it!

en: Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another.”
vi: You must promise me firmly that nothing can change the plan we have committed to here.
tr: "Now, please promise me that you will not change this plan we have made, no matter what.""
es: Promise me now solemnly that for nothing in the world will you alter or modify anything we have agreed upon.

en: “Nothing, Carton.”
vi: − Certainly, Carton.
tr: "I promise, Carton.""
es: —Nothing, Carton; I swear.

en: “Remember these words to-morrow: change the course, or delay in it—for any reason—and no life can possibly be saved, and many lives must inevitably be sacrificed.”
vi: − Tomorrow, you must remember these words; if you change the plan or delay for any reason, you will not be able to save anyone and will certainly cause many people to sacrifice their lives.
tr: "Do not forget these words tomorrow; for whatever reason, if there is any change or delay in our plan, no one's life will be saved and unfortunately, many lives will be wasted.""
es: —Tomorrow, try to frequently remember these words: "A variation... a delay... whatever the cause it obeys, it can jeopardize the salvation of everyone's lives and inevitably lead to the sacrifice of many others."

en: “I will remember them.
vi: − I will remember.
tr: "I will not forget.
es: —I will remember them.

en: I hope to do my part faithfully.”
vi: I hope to fulfill my part well.
tr: I will try to fulfill my part exactly."
es: I hope that God will give me the strength to faithfully fulfill my mission.

en: “And I hope to do mine.
vi: − And I hope to fulfill my part completely.
tr: "I hope I can do it too.
es: —I also hope that I will not lack anything to fulfill mine.

en: Now, good bye!”
vi: Now, goodbye!
tr: Goodbye!"
es: And now... goodbye.

en: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man’s hand to his lips, he did not part from him then.
vi: Though he spoke with a solemn and sincere smile and even kissed the old man's hand, he did not leave immediately.
tr: Carton said these words with a sincere and dignified smile, and even kissed the old man's hand, but he did not leave his side immediately.
es: He did not leave, however, although after pronouncing the farewell word, he brought to his lips and kissed the hand that Lorry extended to him.

en: He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have.
vi: He helped Mr. Lorry lift Dr. Manette, who had been sitting and rocking in front of the gradually dying embers in the fireplace, put on his hat and coat for the doctor, and soothed him to stop lamenting about having to find the hidden workbench with the shoes.
tr: He helped Mr. Lorry to lift the swaying body from in front of the dying embers, to put on his coat and hat, and to persuade this person, who was groaning and pleading about his bench and work, to go outside to find them.
es: First, he helped the doctor up from the chair, put on his coat and hat, and encouraged him to leave, telling him they were going to fetch the stool and shoes he desired.

en: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart—so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it—outwatched the awful night.
vi: He walked beside the doctor, guiding him to Lucie's courtyard, where that sorrowful girl still kept vigil through the dreadful night, the girl who had once been happy when he revealed his lonely heart to her.
tr: He walked beside him and supported him by directing him to the courtyard of the house; his sorrowful heart was watching the dreadful night – whereas once, when he opened his own ruined heart to him, he was so happy.
es: He accompanied the two elderly men to the garden of the house where a wounded heart wept, so happy in other times, and when they left him alone, he remained for a few moments contemplating a window, whose shutters let out some threads of light, the window of her room.

en: He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of her room.
vi: He stepped into the courtyard and stood alone for a few minutes, looking up at the light in her window.
tr: Carton entered the courtyard and, looking at the light of his window, waited there for a few minutes.
es: He accompanied the two elderly men to the garden of the house where a wounded heart wept, so happy in other times, and when they left him alone, he remained for a few moments contemplating a window, whose shutters let out some threads of light, the window of her room.

en: Before he went away, he breathed a blessing towards it, and a Farewell.
vi: Before leaving, he sent a kiss on the wind to that place, and a final farewell.
tr: Before leaving, with his eyes still on the light, he prayed silently for him and said, "Farewell," to him.
es: Before leaving, his heart sent a solemn farewell to the window wrapped in a beautiful cloud of blessings.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: 13. Fifty-two
tr: Thirteen
es: Chapter XIII.

en: Fifty-two
vi: 13. Fifty-two
tr: Fifty Two
es: FIFTY-TWO

en: In the black prison of the Conciergerie, the doomed of the day awaited their fate.
vi: In the dark prison of Conciergerie, those who have been condemned await their fateful day, their number equal to the weeks of a year.
tr: In the dark prison of the Conciergerie, the prisoners of the day were awaiting their fate.
es: Enclosed within blackened walls, the condemned of the day awaited the hour to ascend the scaffold in the sinister prison of the Concierge.

en: They were in number as the weeks of the year.
vi: In the dark prison of Conciergerie, those who have been condemned await their fateful day, their number equal to the weeks of a year.
tr: Their number was as many as the weeks in a year.
es: They were as many as the weeks in a year.

en: Fifty-two were to roll that afternoon on the life-tide of the city to the boundless everlasting sea.
vi: Fifty-two people that evening will be swept away by the current of the city into the boundless sea.
tr: These fifty-two people would be swept away that afternoon by the tide of life in the city into the vast and immortal sea.
es: Fifty-two human lives were to be lost that afternoon in the insatiable sea that absorbs them all.

en: Before their cells were quit of them, new occupants were appointed; before their blood ran into the blood spilled yesterday, the blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow was already set apart.
vi: They have not yet left the dungeon, but new occupants have already been assigned; their blood has not yet mingled with the blood spilled yesterday, but the blood that will mix with theirs tomorrow has already been chosen.
tr: Even before their cells were emptied, they had found new occupants; before their blood could mix with the blood spilled the previous day, it would mix with the blood to be spilled the next day.
es: Before their cells were emptied, those who would replace them had already been designated; before their blood flowed over the blood spilled the previous day, the blood that would mix with theirs the following day had already been set aside in a separate place.

en: Two score and twelve were told off.
vi: Fifty-two people have been sentenced.
tr: Two people's names were read aloud.
es: Fifty-two lives cut short, fifty-two victims, belonging to all social classes; from the wealthy seventy-year-old landowner, whose riches were of no use in prolonging his life, to the wretched laborer, whose obscurity and misery could not save him either.

en: From the farmer-general of seventy, whose riches could not buy his life, to the seamstress of twenty, whose poverty and obscurity could not save her.
vi: From the seventy-year-old tax collector whose wealth could not buy his life, to the twenty-year-old seamstress whose poor and obscure status could not save her future.
tr: Among them were many individuals, ranging from the seventy-year-old landowner whose immense wealth was not enough to buy his own life, to the twenty-year-old seamstress whose poverty and invisibility were not enough to save her.
es: Fifty-two lives cut short, fifty-two victims, belonging to all social classes; from the wealthy seventy-year-old landowner, whose riches were of no use in prolonging his life, to the wretched laborer, whose obscurity and misery could not save him either.

en: Physical diseases, engendered in the vices and neglects of men, will seize on victims of all degrees; and the frightful moral disorder, born of unspeakable suffering, intolerable oppression, and heartless indifference, smote equally without distinction.
vi: The plague, originating from the cruel and indifferent habits of humans, will seize victims from all walks of life; and the terrifying moral madness, born from indescribable suffering, unbearable oppression, and callous indifference, will strike down anyone.
tr: The diseases born from the evils and neglect affected all the victims equally; that dreadful moral decay, the unbearable pressure born from unspeakable hardships, and the heartless indifference struck everyone in the same way without any discrimination.
es: In the same way that physical diseases, which originate from the vices and neglects of men, claim their victims without regard to categories or ages, so too do the dreadful moral ailments, engendered by unspeakable sufferings, intolerable oppressions, and cruel indifferences, strike equally and without distinction of persons.

en: Charles Darnay, alone in a cell, had sustained himself with no flattering delusion since he came to it from the Tribunal.
vi: Alone in the dungeon, Charles Darnay harbored no illusions since he left the courtroom.
tr: Charles Darnay, who was waiting alone in his cell, had not indulged in any idle fantasies since he came from the trial.
es: Carlos Darnay, locked in his cell alone with his thoughts, harbored no illusions since he left the Hall of Justice.

en: In every line of the narrative he had heard, he had heard his condemnation.
vi: In every line of the narrative read there, he had heard his sentence.
tr: In every line of the read statement, he had heard his own condemnation.
es: In every word of the terrible narrative read there, he saw a death sentence, and it was clear to him that no human influence could save him, that virtually a sentence pronounced by millions of votes weighed upon him, against which individual efforts were of no use.

en: He had fully comprehended that no personal influence could possibly save him, that he was virtually sentenced by the millions, and that units could avail him nothing.
vi: He understood clearly that no personal force could save him; he had been condemned by millions of people, and no one could do anything for him anymore.
tr: He had understood very well that no individual effort would be enough to save him, that he was judged by millions, and that individual efforts would be of no use.
es: In every word of the terrible narrative read there, he saw a death sentence, and it was clear to him that no human influence could save him, that virtually a sentence pronounced by millions of votes weighed upon him, against which individual efforts were of no use.

en: Nevertheless, it was not easy, with the face of his beloved wife fresh before him, to compose his mind to what it must bear.
vi: However, he did not easily accept the fate awaiting him as the image of his beloved wife's face remained vividly imprinted in his mind.
tr: On the other hand, enduring all this was not easy while the face of his beloved wife was on his mind.
es: It was not, however, an easy task to resign oneself to dying, for someone like him who still kept the image of his beloved wife fresh in his mind.

en: His hold on life was strong, and it was very, very hard, to loosen; by gradual efforts and degrees unclosed a little here, it clenched the tighter there; and when he brought his strength to bear on that hand and it yielded, this was closed again.
vi: He clung tightly to life, unwilling to let go; if one hand grew weary and lost its grip slightly, the other hand would grasp even tighter; and when one hand, having exhausted its strength to hold on to life, loosened its grip, the other hand would hold firmly.
tr: He was tightly bound to life, and loosening this bond was difficult; if he tried to loosen it slightly from one point, it would strengthen even more at another point; even if he managed to break it with all his might, it would soon reattach.
es: Very strong ties bound him to life, and it was hard, very hard, to see so closely the blade that would cut them forever.

en: There was a hurry, too, in all his thoughts, a turbulent and heated working of his heart, that contended against resignation.
vi: Thoughts surged through his mind, and the passionate beating of his heart did not allow him to surrender to death.
tr: There was also an urgency in his thoughts, his heart was beating with great excitement and anger, resisting to not submit to his fate.
es: His thoughts tumbled over each other, agitated tumultuously in his chest, fought fierce battles among themselves, and in the end, they joined forces to contend against resignation.

en: If, for a moment, he did feel resigned, then his wife and child who had to live after him, seemed to protest and to make it a selfish thing.
vi: If at any moment he felt discouraged by the thought of his wife becoming a widow and his children becoming orphans, he would see giving up as selfish and continue to resist.
tr: If for a moment he seemed to submit to his fate, his wife and child, who would be left behind, would object, pointing out how selfish this situation was.
es: If he momentarily managed to calm them, the image of his wife immediately surfaced, the image of his tender daughter, he remembered that he was leaving them in the world, and he protested against it with all the strength of his soul, no less than if the sharpest selfishness were encouraging him in his chest.

en: But, all this was at first.
vi: But that was only at the beginning.
tr: But all these were his initial feelings.
es: It is true that these struggles did not last long.

en: Before long, the consideration that there was no disgrace in the fate he must meet, and that numbers went the same road wrongfully, and trod it firmly every day, sprang up to stimulate him.
vi: Soon after, he realized that the death he had to face was not shameful at all, and he felt more encouraged when he thought about how many people had walked that unjust path daily, and they still bravely tread upon death.
tr: Soon, the idea that the fate awaiting him was not something to be ashamed of, that many people were driven to this unjust path every day and faced it bravely, gave him strength.
es: It wasn't long before the consideration that the death awaiting him did not carry the appendage of dishonor acted as a powerful stimulant, and the thought that many, as innocent as he, walked the same painful path he had to walk every day and with firm steps.

en: Next followed the thought that much of the future peace of mind enjoyable by the dear ones, depended on his quiet fortitude.
vi: Then he thought that it was his own calm resilience that would help his loved ones live peacefully in the future.
tr: What followed was the thought that the inner peace and comfort of his loved ones depended on his own calm composure.
es: He then thought of the future peace of mind that, after the initial moments, his loved ones left in the world would enjoy if they saw him accept death with manly fortitude, and in this way, little by little and by degrees, he began to regain his calm and immerse himself in reflections of a higher nature.

en: So, by degrees he calmed into the better state, when he could raise his thoughts much higher, and draw comfort down.
vi: So gradually, he felt more at ease and could think of happier things for his peace of mind.
tr: Thus, as a result of these positive thoughts, Charles was able to gradually relax and calm down a bit.
es: He then thought of the future peace of mind that, after the initial moments, his loved ones left in the world would enjoy if they saw him accept death with manly fortitude, and in this way, little by little and by degrees, he began to regain his calm and immerse himself in reflections of a higher nature.

en: Before it had set in dark on the night of his condemnation, he had travelled thus far on his last way.
vi: Before nightfall on the day he was sentenced to death, Darnay was in that calm state of mind.
tr: These were the last thoughts wandering in his mind before night fell and everything turned dark, following his conviction.
es: Before the night closed in, he had advanced most of the way on the journey of his resignation.

en: Being allowed to purchase the means of writing, and a light, he sat down to write until such time as the prison lamps should be extinguished.
vi: Allowed to buy paper, pen, and a lamp, he sat down to write letters until the prison mandated lights out.
tr: Since he had permission to get materials and light for writing, he sat down to write until the dungeon lanterns went out.
es: Equipped with writing materials and a light, he took up the pen and did not put it down until the hour came when the prison regulations required the lamps to be extinguished.

en: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, showing her that he had known nothing of her father’s imprisonment, until he had heard of it from herself, and that he had been as ignorant as she of his father’s and uncle’s responsibility for that misery, until the paper had been read.
vi: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, expressing that he was completely unaware of her father's imprisonment until he heard it from her, and that neither he nor she knew that the ones responsible for this suffering were his own father and uncle until they heard the court read those papers.
tr: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, explaining that until he heard from her, he knew nothing about his father's imprisonment, just like her, he was unaware of his father's and uncle's involvement in this disaster, and he learned about it when the paper was read.
es: He wrote a very lengthy letter to Lucía, demonstrating to her that he had never had any news of her father's eternal captivity until he heard it from the man's own lips, and that, prior to reading the document found in the Bastille, he was as ignorant as she was of the direct culpability of her father and uncle in that sad event.

en: He had already explained to her that his concealment from herself of the name he had relinquished, was the one condition—fully intelligible now—that her father had attached to their betrothal, and was the one promise he had still exacted on the morning of their marriage.
vi: He explained to her that concealing from her the name he had renounced was a condition—now clear—that her father had attached to his daughter's marriage contract, and it was a promise he had fulfilled on the morning of the wedding.
tr: He had already explained to her that the reason he hid the name he had stopped using was because it was a condition set by his father before their engagement – the reason for this was now understood – and that he still insisted on this on the morning of their wedding.
es: He had already explained to her that, if he had concealed his true surname, a surname he had renounced, it was to fulfill a condition, whose reason he now perfectly understood, imposed by the doctor when giving his consent to the romantic relationship with his daughter, and ratified on the morning of their wedding.

en: He entreated her, for her father’s sake, never to seek to know whether her father had become oblivious of the existence of the paper, or had had it recalled to him (for the moment, or for good), by the story of the Tower, on that old Sunday under the dear old plane-tree in the garden.
vi: He begged her, for the sake of Dr. Manette, never to try to find out whether her father had forgotten the existence of that testament or had been reminded of it (temporarily or permanently) by the story of the Tower of London prison he had told one Sunday afternoon under the shade of the plane tree in their garden.
tr: For the sake of his father, he begged his wife never to ask his father whether he had forgotten about the existence of this paper or whether he remembered it during the story of the tower told under that beautiful old plane tree in the garden on a Sunday.
es: He earnestly begged her that, for the love of her father, she should never attempt to find out whether he had forgotten the existence of the document, or whether the story of the Tower of London told under the plane tree in the garden that summer night had reminded him of it.

en: If he had preserved any definite remembrance of it, there could be no doubt that he had supposed it destroyed with the Bastille, when he had found no mention of it among the relics of prisoners which the populace had discovered there, and which had been described to all the world.
vi: If Dr. Manette remembered anything about that testament, he would surely believe it had been destroyed along with the Bastille prison, as he had never heard any mention of those papers among the remnants of the prisoners that the crowd had found and displayed to the world.
tr: Even if it had occurred to him, he undoubtedly assumed it had been destroyed along with the Bastille, because among the belongings of the prisoners that the public disclosed, there was no mention of this writing.
es: If he retained any memory of the document in question, he undoubtedly assumed it had been destroyed with the Bastille, seeing that it was not among the relics of the prisoners found by the mob and made so public that the entire world knew of them.

en: He besought her—though he added that he knew it was needless—to console her father, by impressing him through every tender means she could think of, with the truth that he had done nothing for which he could justly reproach himself, but had uniformly forgotten himself for their joint sakes.
vi: He implored—though he added that he knew this was unnecessary—that she console Dr. Manette with all the affection she could muster for her father, because he had done nothing to blame himself for, and in fact, he had only selflessly united her and him.
tr: Using every conceivable means, he asked his wife to comfort his father by reiterating that there was no need for him to blame himself, only that he had forgotten himself for their well-being and unity – adding that there was no need to say this.
es: He urged her—though adding that he already knew the recommendation was futile—to console her father, convincing him, by all imaginable means, that not only had he done nothing reprehensible, nothing that would have caused his misfortune, but that, on the contrary, he had always sacrificed himself for the happiness of his daughter and his daughter's husband.

en: Next to her preservation of his own last grateful love and blessing, and her overcoming of her sorrow, to devote herself to their dear child, he adjured her, as they would meet in Heaven, to comfort her father.
vi: At the end of the letter, after thanking her for giving him all her love and happiness, and after advising her to overcome her sorrow to care for their beloved child, he asked her to think of their reunion in Heaven to comfort her old father.
tr: Then he begged her not to forget how much he loved her and how grateful he was to her, to bury her sorrow and dedicate herself to their beloved children and to comforting his father, saying that they would one day be reunited in heaven.
es: He ended by recommending that she try to overcome her sorrow, devote herself to her beloved daughter, and above all, that through sheer tenderness she console her father.

en: To her father himself, he wrote in the same strain; but, he told her father that he expressly confided his wife and child to his care.
vi: The letter to Dr. Manette, he also wrote with that intention, but he entrusted his wife and children to the doctor's care.
tr: He wrote a letter to Lucie's father in the same tone and expressed that he particularly entrusted his wife and child to him.
es: He wrote another letter to the doctor inspired by the same thoughts, telling him that he entrusted his wife and daughter to his care.

en: And he told him this, very strongly, with the hope of rousing him from any despondency or dangerous retrospect towards which he foresaw he might be tending.
vi: He wrote very strong words relying on the doctor with the hope that his father-in-law would escape all the depressing and dangerous recollections of past writings that he foresaw the doctor would inevitably be troubled by.
tr: The reason he emphasized this so much was his hope to keep him away from a potential state of despair and negative thoughts about the past.
es: With vibrant phrasing, he made this request, not because he considered it necessary, but rather to lift his spirits and drive away retrospective thoughts, which he assumed would arise more strongly than ever.

en: To mr Lorry, he commended them all, and explained his worldly affairs.
vi: Write to Mr. Lorry, entrusting everyone to him and explaining his property matters.
tr: In the letter he wrote to Mr. Lorry, he entrusted everything to him and provided explanations regarding worldly matters.
es: He addressed a letter to Mr. Lorry, entrusting to his care the loved ones he was leaving behind and explaining all his earthly matters.

en: That done, with many added sentences of grateful friendship and warm attachment, all was done.
vi: Then, he adds a few lines of gratitude and affection at the end of the letter, and it's done.
tr: Then, adding sentences expressing how grateful he was for his friendship and warm interest, he finished the letter, and everything was over.
es: He addressed a letter to Mr. Lorry, entrusting to his care the loved ones he was leaving behind and explaining all his earthly matters.

en: He never thought of Carton.
vi: Darnay never thought of Carton.
tr: Carton never crossed his mind.
es: He did not remember Carton.

en: His mind was so full of the others, that he never once thought of him.
vi: His mind was filled with images of other people, not once remembering that friend.
tr: His mind was so occupied with others that he didn't think of him even for a moment.
es: There were so many thoughts overwhelming him that they left no room for a person with whom he never had frequent interactions.

en: He had time to finish these letters before the lights were put out.
vi: He managed to finish writing the letters before having to extinguish the light.
tr: He had managed to finish all these letters before the lamps were extinguished.
es: When the lights went out and he lay down on the miserable straw mattress, he thought he had already finished with the world.

en: When he lay down on his straw bed, he thought he had done with this world.
vi: As he lay down on the straw bed, he thought he was ready to die.
tr: When he lay down on his bed, he thought that his work in this world was over.
es: When the lights went out and he lay down on the miserable straw mattress, he thought he had already finished with the world.

en: But, it beckoned him back in his sleep, and showed itself in shining forms.
vi: But life calls him back and manifests in many radiant forms.
tr: However, the world in its slumber called him back and showed itself to him in all its brilliance.
es: However, he resurfaced during his sleep, and he resurfaced brilliant, charming.

en: Free and happy, back in the old house in Soho (though it had nothing in it like the real house), unaccountably released and light of heart, he was with Lucie again, and she told him it was all a dream, and he had never gone away.
vi: Free and happy, he returns to the old house in Soho (though inside it resembles nothing like the real house), somehow escaping death, joyfully reunited with Lucie, and she tells him that all the hardships endured were just a dream, and he had never left at all.
tr: Free and happy, he was back in the old house in Soho (though nothing inside matched the reality), with an incredible sense of peace and relief, he was with Lucie again, and his wife was telling him that it had all been a dream and that he hadn't gone anywhere.
es: He found himself again in the quiet little corner of Soho, free, happy, content, in the company of his Lucia, who assured him that it had all been a dream, a nightmare, that they had never left England, that he had never been separated from her.

en: A pause of forgetfulness, and then he had even suffered, and had come back to her, dead and at peace, and yet there was no difference in him.
vi: For a moment, he forgets everything, then finds himself sentenced to death and returns to her, dying peacefully, but nothing changes in him.
tr: A sleep interval where he remembered nothing, then he saw the pains he had endured and returned to his wife's side, dead but peaceful, and there was no difference in between.
es: This dream was followed by a pause of complete forgetfulness, after which he imagined that he lived with his wife, but dead, decapitated.

en: Another pause of oblivion, and he awoke in the sombre morning, unconscious where he was or what had happened, until it flashed upon his mind, “this is the day of my death!”
vi: Another moment of forgetfulness, and he wakes up in a misty morning, not knowing where he is or what has happened, until he suddenly realizes, "Today is the day I die!".
tr: Then another interval where he remembered nothing, and then he opened his eyes to a gloomy morning, unable to understand where he was or what he was for a moment, until that thought flashed in his mind, "Today is my execution day!"
es: Another pause of forgetfulness ensued, and he finally woke up in the morning, without realizing where he was or remembering what had happened the day before, until these words sprang into his mind in fiery characters: "Today is the day of your death."

en: Thus, had he come through the hours, to the day when the fifty-two heads were to fall.
vi: He had gone through such moments until the day when fifty-two heads would fall.
tr: That's why the hours had passed like this until the day fifty-two heads would be cut off.
es: It was the day when fifty-two heads were to roll, one of them his own, and while resigned to his sad fate, he gathered his courage to endure it with calm heroism, his thoughts, very difficult to control, feverishly embarked on new paths.

en: And now, while he was composed, and hoped that he could meet the end with quiet heroism, a new action began in his waking thoughts, which was very difficult to master.
vi: At this moment, although he was calm and hoped to face death with silent bravery, new thoughts emerged in his mind, causing him concern.
tr: Now, no matter how calm he was and hoped to face death with quiet heroism, a new idea, which was very difficult to control, had begun to emerge in his mind.
es: It was the day when fifty-two heads were to roll, one of them his own, and while resigned to his sad fate, he gathered his courage to endure it with calm heroism, his thoughts, very difficult to control, feverishly embarked on new paths.

en: He had never seen the instrument that was to terminate his life.
vi: He had never seen the instrument that would end his life.
tr: He had never seen the device that would end his life before.
es: He had never seen the terrible instrument that hours later would cut his life short.

en: How high it was from the ground, how many steps it had, where he would be stood, how he would be touched, whether the touching hands would be dyed red, which way his face would be turned, whether he would be the first, or might be the last: these and many similar questions, in nowise directed by his will, obtruded themselves over and over again, countless times.
vi: How tall was it compared to the ground, how many steps led up to it, where would he stand, how would he be pushed, were the hands touching him stained with blood, which direction would his face be turned, would he be the first or the last?... Even though he didn't want to, such questions kept intruding into his mind incessantly.
tr: How high was it from the ground, how many steps did it have, where would he stand, how would they touch him, would the hands that touched him be stained red, which way would his face be turned, would he go first or last? These and many similar questions kept swirling in his mind, beyond his control, refusing to leave his thoughts.
es: How high above the ground the gloomy machine would be, how many steps the fatal staircase had, where it would be placed, whose hands would be responsible for placing him on the block, whether they would be stained with blood, which way he would turn his head, whether he would be the first or the last; these and other similar questions he asked himself over and over, hurriedly, not by his will, but by his overexcited imagination.

en: Neither were they connected with fear: he was conscious of no fear.
vi: They had nothing to do with fear; he was not afraid at all.
tr: None of them stemmed from fear; there was no specific fear within him.
es: Neither were they inspired by fear, but rather by a strange desire to know what he would do when the time came, a desire that was disproportionate to the fleeting moments to which it referred, an inexplicable curiosity felt by a soul different from his own.

en: Rather, they originated in a strange besetting desire to know what to do when the time came; a desire gigantically disproportionate to the few swift moments to which it referred; a wondering that was more like the wondering of some other spirit within his, than his own.
vi: On the contrary, they stemmed from a strange longing that kept haunting him, a desire to know what to do when the time came; a desire so immense compared to the fleeting moments on the scaffold; a bewilderment as if another soul, not him, was trying to understand.
tr: Rather, it was an unsettling and strange desire to know what to do when the time came, and this desire was much greater compared to the brief time he would spend there; it was as if there was another soul within him wanting to learn all these things.
es: Neither were they inspired by fear, but rather by a strange desire to know what he would do when the time came, a desire that was disproportionate to the fleeting moments to which it referred, an inexplicable curiosity felt by a soul different from his own.

en: The hours went on as he walked to and fro, and the clocks struck the numbers he would never hear again.
vi: The moments kept passing by as he paced back and forth, the clock striking chimes that he would never hear again.
tr: As he paced back and forth in his cell, time was slipping away, the hours striking minutes he would never hear again.
es: Time passed and the clock struck hours that the unfortunate man would never hear again.

en: Nine gone for ever, ten gone for ever, eleven gone for ever, twelve coming on to pass away.
vi: Nine o'clock gone forever, ten o'clock gone forever, eleven o'clock gone forever, twelve o'clock about to pass.
tr: Nine passed, ten passed, eleven passed, and twelve was approaching to pass forever as well.
es: Nine, ten, eleven o'clock struck, and it was about to strike twelve.

en: After a hard contest with that eccentric action of thought which had last perplexed him, he had got the better of it.
vi: After a difficult struggle with the strange thoughts that had disturbed his mind, he finally managed to overcome them.
tr: After struggling with all these confusing thoughts for quite a while, he regained some composure.
es: Nine, ten, eleven o'clock struck, and it was about to strike twelve.

en: He walked up and down, softly repeating their names to himself.
vi: He walked back and forth, silently calling the names of his loved ones.
tr: Then, softly repeating their names, he walked up and down.
es: The condemned man walked more calmly each time.

en: The worst of the strife was over.
vi: The most uncomfortable inner conflicts had ended.
tr: The most challenging part of the inner struggle had ended.
es: The worst of the internal struggle had passed.

en: He could walk up and down, free from distracting fancies, praying for himself and for them.
vi: He could walk back and forth, free from disturbing thoughts, to pray for himself and his loved ones.
tr: Setting aside the dreams that clouded his mind, he was able to walk up and down, praying for himself and his loved ones.
es: His imagination was no longer disturbed by absurd thoughts, he could now pray for himself and his loved ones.

en: Twelve gone for ever.
vi: Twelve o'clock, gone forever.
tr: Twelve went on forever.
es: The clock struck twelve.

en: He had been apprised that the final hour was Three, and he knew he would be summoned some time earlier, inasmuch as the tumbrils jolted heavily and slowly through the streets.
vi: He had been informed that the final hour was three o'clock, and he knew that they would call him before that time because the carts carrying the condemned would rumble slowly and heavily through the streets.
tr: He had been told that he would be taken at three o'clock; but he knew he would be called earlier because the cars were moving very slowly and heavily on the streets.
es: They had told him that the final hour that would strike for him in the world would be three o'clock, and he knew that they would take him out of the dungeon well before the indicated hour, as the death carts traveled very slowly on the way to the gallows.

en: Therefore, he resolved to keep
vi: Therefore, he resolved that by two o'clock he must strengthen his own spirit firmly so that he could then bolster the spirits of others.
tr: Therefore, he prepared himself for two o'clock; this way, he would have time to both strengthen himself and give strength to others.
es: He supposed, therefore, that they would call him at two.

en: Two before his mind, as the hour, and so to strengthen himself in the interval that he might be able, after that time, to strengthen others.
vi: Therefore, he resolved that by two o'clock he must strengthen his own spirit firmly so that he could then bolster the spirits of others.
tr: Therefore, he prepared himself for two o'clock; this way, he would have time to both strengthen himself and give strength to others.
es: He supposed, therefore, that they would call him at two.

en: Walking regularly to and fro with his arms folded on his breast, a very different man from the prisoner, who had walked to and fro at La Force, he heard
vi: Steadily pacing back and forth, with arms crossed over his chest, a completely different person from the prisoner who once paced in the La Force prison before, he heard the clock strike one without any surprise.
tr: With his hands clasped on his chest, he walked back and forth with steady steps.
es: With his arms crossed in front of his chest, he was pacing his cell when the clock struck one; he did not lose his heroic calm.

en: One struck away from him, without surprise.
vi: Steadily pacing back and forth, with arms crossed over his chest, a completely different person from the prisoner who once paced in the La Force prison before, he heard the clock strike one without any surprise.
tr: He was a different man from the prisoner walking back and forth in La Force, and he was not surprised when he heard the clock strike one.
es: Fervently, he gave thanks to God for having given him the strength to regain his composure, and he thought:

en: The hour had measured like most other hours.
vi: An hour passed like every other hour.
tr: This was no different from other hours.
es: "I have another hour left."

en: Devoutly thankful to Heaven for his recovered self-possession, he thought, “There is but another now,” and turned to walk again.
vi: Wholeheartedly thanking God for allowing him to regain his composure, he thought to himself, "Just one more hour," and continued walking.
tr: Thanking God with great sincerity for being able to pull himself together, he thought, "Now there's just one hour left," and turned around to continue walking.
es: "I have another hour left."

en: Footsteps in the stone passage outside the door.
vi: There were footsteps in the stone-paved corridor outside the prison cell.
tr: Then, he heard footsteps in the stone passage.
es: The sound of footsteps echoed in the outer passage.

en: He stopped.
vi: He stopped.
tr: He paused his walk.
es: The door of his cell opened and closed again without a sound.

en: The key was put in the lock, and turned.
vi: The sound of a key being inserted into the lock, and turning.
tr: The key was inserted into the lock and turned.
es: The door of his cell opened and closed again without a sound.

en: Before the door was opened, or as it opened, a man said in a low voice, in English: “He has never seen me here; I have kept out of his way.
vi: The door had not yet opened when a voice was heard speaking softly, in English: − He has no idea I'm here; I've been avoiding him for a long time.
tr: Before the door opened or just as it was opening, a man said in a low voice in English, "You never saw me here; we didn't meet.
es: Someone said these words by the door, already open, or while they were opening it:

en: Go you in alone; I wait near.
vi: You go in alone; I will wait nearby.
tr: Now go alone; I will wait here.
es: "He has never seen me here, as I have always taken care to stay out of his way.

en: Lose no time!”
vi: Don't waste time!
tr: Come on, don't waste time!"
es: Go in... I will wait outside... Don't waste time."

en: The door was quickly opened and closed, and there stood before him face to face, quiet, intent upon him, with the light of a smile on his features, and a cautionary finger on his lip, Sydney Carton.
vi: The door opened and closed quickly, and standing there opposite him, silently, attentively, with a fleeting smile on his face, a warning finger placed on his lips, was Sydney Carton.
tr: The door had quickly opened and closed, and standing directly opposite, silently and resolutely, with a sparkling smile on his face, and his finger brought to his lips as if to warn for silence, was Sydney Carton.
es: In front of the prisoner appeared a man who looked at him smiling, calm. It was Sydney Carton.

en: There was something so bright and remarkable in his look, that, for the first moment, the prisoner misdoubted him to be an apparition of his own imagining.
vi: Carton's face showed an unusually radiant expression, making the prisoner Darnay think for a moment that it was a ghost appearing from his imagination.
tr: His gaze was so bright and impressive that, at first, the prisoner thought he was his own imagination.
es: Such was the expression on his face, so remarkable his gaze, that in the first instant the prisoner feared it was an unreal apparition, a product of his agitated imagination.

en: But, he spoke, and it was his voice; he took the prisoner’s hand, and it was his real grasp.
vi: But Carton spoke, and it was indeed his voice; Carton took the prisoner's hand, and it was truly his hand that was gripping tightly.
tr: But when he opened his mouth, he realized it was his voice; Carton took the prisoner's hand, and the hand that grasped his was indeed his own.
es: But the apparition spoke, and the tone of his voice was that of Carton; he clasped the prisoner's hand, and his hand was a real hand, of flesh and bone.

en: “Of all the people upon earth, you least expected to see me?” he said.
vi: − You couldn't have imagined that it would be me you met and not someone else? Carton said.
tr: "I was probably the last person you expected to see, wasn't I?" said Carton.
es: —I bet I am the last human being you would expect to see: am I wrong?

en: “I could not believe it to be you.
vi: − I can't believe it's you.
tr: "I can't believe I'm seeing you.
es: —I bet I am the last human being you would expect to see: am I wrong?

en: I can scarcely believe it now.
vi: Even now, I still don't believe it.
tr: I really can't believe it.
es: —Not only did I not expect to see you, but even seeing you, I am doubting that the Sydney Carton I have known is standing before me...

en: You are not”—the apprehension came suddenly into his mind—“a prisoner?”
vi: Not you... - A sudden worry sprang into Darnay's mind. - ... You haven't been imprisoned, have you?
tr: Or have you also" –he suddenly became worried– "been condemned?"
es: Are you also a prisoner?

en: “No.
vi: − No.
tr: "No.
es: —No.

en: I am accidentally possessed of a power over one of the keepers here, and in virtue of it I stand before you.
vi: By chance, I have authority over a jailer here, and thanks to that, I am able to stand before you.
tr: By a stroke of luck, I managed to influence one of the guards here, and that's why I'm standing before you now.
es: Chance has made me the master of one of the jailers of this prison, and to that circumstance, I owe the fact that I am beside you.

en: I come from her—your wife, dear Darnay.”
vi: She... your wife asked me to come, Mr. Darnay.
tr: I'm coming from her side now – from your wife's side, dear Darnay."
es: I come on her behalf... on behalf of your wife, my dear Darnay.

en: The prisoner wrung his hand.
vi: The prisoner tightly grasped Carton's hand.
tr: The prisoner rubbed his hands.
es: The prisoner silently extended his hand.

en: “I bring you a request from her.”
vi: − I am conveying her request to you.
tr: "Your wife has a request from you.""
es: —And I bring the task of making a plea to you.

en: “What is it?”
vi: − What is it? −
tr: "What is it?"
es: —What is it?

en: “A most earnest, pressing, and emphatic entreaty, addressed to you in the most pathetic tones of the voice so dear to you, that you well remember.”
vi: The most urgent and serious plea she had spoken in the most plaintive voice that he was surely too familiar with and missed dearly.
tr: "With that touching voice you know and love so well, in the most heartfelt manner, persistently and stubbornly, they are begging you.""
es: —It is the most fervent plea, the most urgent, the most ardent of those that have been addressed to him by that voice which is so dear to him. Do not ignore it, because that dear voice addresses him with the most pathetic tone that has ever sounded in his ears.

en: The prisoner turned his face partly aside.
vi: The prisoner slightly turned his face away.
tr: The prisoner slightly turned his head to the side.
es: The prisoner bowed his head without answering.

en: “You have no time to ask me why I bring it, or what it means; I have no time to tell you.
vi: − There is no time left, don't ask why I am passing on the message or want to know the details; it's very urgent.
tr: "I don't have time to explain why I'm telling you this or what it means.
es: —You don't have the time to ask me why I am the emissary tasked with making the plea in question, or to ask me for explanations about what it means, nor do I have the time to give them to you.

en: You must comply with it—take off those boots you wear, and draw on these of mine.”
vi: You must follow... Take off the shoes you are wearing, and put on my shoes.
tr: You just need to do what I say – now take off your boots and put on mine."
es: Your duty... a sacred duty, is to obey without question... Take off your boots, and put on mine!

en: There was a chair against the wall of the cell, behind the prisoner.
vi: There is a chair placed against the room wall, behind the prisoner.
tr: There was a chair leaning against the wall behind the prisoner.
es: Attached to one of the walls, behind the convict, there was a chair.

en: Carton, pressing forward, had already, with the speed of lightning, got him down into it, and stood over him, barefoot.
vi: Carton swiftly pushed Darnay to sit down, then he stood up straight, his shoes already removed.
tr: Carton lunged forward, pushed him onto it at lightning speed, and stood barefoot at his head.
es: Carton, while speaking with lightning speed, had forced him to sit in the chair in question.

en: “Draw on these boots of mine.
vi: − Bring me my shoes.
tr: "Put on my boots.
es: —Take off your shoes and put on these boots of mine...

en: Put your hands to them; put your will to them.
vi: Do it, use all your willpower.
tr: "Put on my boots.
es: —Take off your shoes and put on these boots of mine...

en: Quick!”
vi: Quickly!
tr: Be quick; hurry up. Quick!"
es: Quickly!...

en: “Carton, there is no escaping from this place; it never can be done.
vi: − Carton, there is no way to escape from here; it's impossible to escape.
tr: "Carton, there's no escape from here; we can never do this.
es: —Carton... It is impossible to escape from here—replied Carlos, completely bewildered;—utterly impossible...

en: You will only die with me.
vi: You will die with me.
tr: You will die with me.
es: You will achieve nothing but dying with me...

en: It is madness.”
vi: It's madness.
tr: This is madness."
es: It is madness....

en: “It would be madness if I asked you to escape; but do I?
vi: − It would be madness if I asked you to escape; but did I say that?
tr: "If I had asked you to run away with me, it would have been madness; but did I say such a thing?
es: —It would be madness if I told you to escape; but have I even hinted at it?

en: When I ask you to pass out at that door, tell me it is madness and remain here.
vi: When I tell you to walk out that door, then call me mad and stay here.
tr: If I ask you to walk out that door, then tell me it's madness and wait for the scrap.
es: When I tell you to go through that door, answer me that it's madness and don't pay attention to me...

en: Change that cravat for this of mine, that coat for this of mine.
vi: Exchange your tie with mine; exchange your coat with mine.
tr: Take off your tie and put on mine, take off your coat and wear mine.
es: Take off that tie and put on mine... That's it... Now the coat... We will exchange coats... Magnificent!

en: While you do it, let me take this ribbon from your hair, and shake out your hair like this of mine!”
vi: While you are putting on the coat, let me untie your hair ribbon, and you must shake your head to make your hair as disheveled as mine!
tr: While you are changing these, I will take off that ribbon on your head and you also mess up your hair like mine!"
es: Allow me to remove that ribbon that holds your hair, and to mess up your hairstyle a bit... that's it! Now you are as poorly groomed as I am.

en: With wonderful quickness, and with a strength both of will and action, that appeared quite supernatural, he forced all these changes upon him.
vi: With extraordinary swiftness, and with a nearly superhuman strength of will and action, Carton forced Darnay to change clothes.
tr: It was with tremendous speed, a supernatural will, and an efficient power that all this was accomplished by Darnay.
es: With astonishing speed, with a willpower that seemed more supernatural than human, he transformed the prisoner in the blink of an eye.

en: The prisoner was like a young child in his hands.
vi: The prisoner was like a child in his hands.
tr: The prisoner was like a child in his hands.
es: The convict seemed like a child without will in his hands.

en: “Carton! Dear Carton!
vi: − Carton! Carton!
tr: "Carton! Dear Carton!
es: —Carton... My dear Carton!

en: It is madness.
vi: This is madness.
tr: This is madness.
es: It's madness... a folly!

en: It cannot be accomplished, it never can be done, it has been attempted, and has always failed.
vi: It's impossible to escape, never has anyone escaped, many have tried and always failed.
tr: We will never succeed, we can never do this, it was tried before but no one succeeded.
es: It's not possible to carry it out... It has never been achieved... Dozens of times they have tried and it has always resulted in the most resounding failure...

en: I implore you not to add your death to the bitterness of mine.”
vi: Please don't let my bitter fate drag you to your death.
tr: I beg you, do not add your own death to the pity."
es: For God's sake, my dear friend, I beg you not to increase my sorrows by sacrificing your life in vain...! Isn't it enough that I die?

en: “Do I ask you, my dear Darnay, to pass the door?
vi: − Darnay, did I ask you to leave the room?
tr: "Do I want you to step out of that door, Darnay?
es: —Have I by any chance told you, my dear Darnay, to go beyond that door?

en: When I ask that, refuse.
vi: When I say so, then refuse.
tr: If I ask for such a thing, oppose me.
es: When I tell you, answer firmly that no, and the matter will be settled.

en: There are pen and ink and paper on this table.
vi: There is paper and ink on the table.
tr: There are pen, ink, and paper on that table.
es: I see paper, ink, and a pen on that table; do you have a steady hand?

en: Is your hand steady enough to write?”
vi: Can you still hold a pen steadily?
tr: Can you write without your hand trembling?"
es: Can you write?

en: “It was when you came in.”
vi: I was writing when you came in.
tr: "He wasn't trembling when he arrived."
es: —I had it firm when you came in.

en: “Steady it again, and write what I shall dictate.
vi: − Then pick up the pen again and write as I dictate.
tr: "Gene, take a note of what I'm saying.
es: —Well, it is necessary for him to be so again, so that he writes very clearly what I am going to dictate...

en: Quick, friend, quick!”
vi: Quickly, my friend, quickly!
tr: Come on, buddy, hurry up!"
es: Quickly, my friend, quickly!

en: Pressing his hand to his bewildered head, Darnay sat down at the table.
vi: Clutching his bewildered forehead, Darnay sat down at the table.
tr: Darnay sat holding his head in a state of confusion.
es: Darnay, astonished, amazed, stunned, took a seat in front of the table.

en: Carton, with his right hand in his breast, stood close beside him.
vi: Carton, with his right hand placed on his chest, stood nearby.
tr: Carton, on the other hand, stood right next to him with his right hand in the breast pocket of his coat.
es: Carton, with his right hand placed on his chest, stood beside him.

en: “Write exactly as I speak.”
vi: − Write exactly as I read.
tr: "Write exactly what I say."
es: —Write down point by point what I dictate to you.

en: “To whom do I address it?”
vi: − Send it to whom? −
tr: "To whom shall I write?""
es: —To whom should I address the document?

en: “To no one.”
vi: No one.
tr: "To no one."
es: —Nobody.

en: Carton still had his hand in his breast.
vi: - Carton's hand still rested on his chest.
tr: Carton's hand was still on his chest.
es: Carton's right hand remained fixed over his chest.

en: “Do I date it?”
vi: − Write the date? − No.
tr: "Shall I write history?""
es: —Shall I set a date?

en: “No.”
vi: − Write the date? − No.
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: The prisoner looked up, at each question.
vi: The prisoner looked up after each question.
tr: The prisoner was looking up at every question.
es: The prisoner raised his head every time he asked a question; Carton, without moving his right hand, looked at the ground.

en: Carton, standing over him with his hand in his breast, looked down.
vi: With his hand still on his chest, Carton looked down.
tr: Carton, with his hand in his pocket, was looking down at him.
es: The prisoner raised his head every time he asked a question; Carton, without moving his right hand, looked at the ground.

en: “‘If you remember,’” said Carton, dictating, “‘the words that passed between us, long ago, you will readily comprehend this when you see it.
vi: − “If you remember,” - Carton dictated for Darnay to write, - “the private words between us long ago, you will understand immediately when you read these lines.
tr: "If you remember the conversation we had a long time ago," said Carton, slowly, "you will immediately understand what it means.
es: "If you have not forgotten the words that passed between us," said Carton dictating, "you will easily understand this letter as soon as you read it."

en: You do remember them, I know.
vi: You will remember those private words, I know.
tr: You definitely remember it, I know.
es: "I know positively that you remember them, for you are not one to forget quickly."

en: It is not in your nature to forget them.’”
vi: Because you are not one to easily forget.”
tr: Forgetting is not something you would do."
es: "I know positively that you remember them, for you are not one to forget quickly."

en: He was drawing his hand from his breast; the prisoner chancing to look up in his hurried wonder as he wrote, the hand stopped, closing upon something.
vi: He intended to lower his hand from his chest when the prisoner happened to look up in confusion at this urgent matter. Carton's hand stopped, gripping something tightly.
tr: At this moment, Carton took his hand out of the pocket on his chest; the prisoner, taking advantage of the opportunity, lifted his head and looked at him with anxious curiosity and noticed that he had something in his hand.
es: The prisoner, who did not understand the meaning of what he was writing, unexpectedly raised his eyes and caught Carton in the act of taking his hand out of his chest. It stopped.

en: “Have you written ‘forget them’?”
vi: − Have you finished writing "easily forgotten"?
tr: "It's not for you, have you written it?" asked Carton.
es: —Have you written "they forget quickly?"

en: Carton asked.
vi: - Carton asked.
tr: "It's not for you, have you written it?" asked Carton.
es: —Have you written "they forget quickly?"

en: “I have.
vi: − Done.
tr: "It's not for you, have you written it?" asked Carton.
es: —Yes.

en: Is that a weapon in your hand?”
vi: Is that a weapon in your hand? −
tr: "I wrote, do you have a gun in your hand?"
es: Do you have any weapon in your hand?

en: “No; I am not armed.”
vi: No, I don't have any weapons.
tr: "No, I don't have any weapons on me."
es: —No; I don't have any weapons.

en: “What is it in your hand?”
vi: − What are you holding in your hand? −
tr: "What do you have in your hand then?"
es: —What does he/she have, then?

en: “You shall know directly.
vi: You will know right away.
tr: "You will learn soon."
es: —In a moment you will know...

en: Write on; there are but a few words more.”
vi: Keep writing; just a few more words.
tr: "Keep writing; it's almost done."
es: Continue writing, as there are very few words left... «I thank God who allows me to prove them with deeds.

en: He dictated again.
vi: - Carton continued reading.
tr: Then he dictated again.
es: Continue writing, as there are very few words left... «I thank God who allows me to prove them with deeds.

en: “‘I am thankful that the time has come, when I can prove them.
vi: - “How grateful I am that the time has come when I can prove the old saying.
tr: "I am very happy to see the days when I can prove the truth of my words."
es: Continue writing, as there are very few words left... «I thank God who allows me to prove them with deeds.

en: That I do so is no subject for regret or grief.’”
vi: I do it without any regret or sorrow.”
tr: "Don't be upset or distressed because I did this."
es: I would not want what I do to be a cause of sorrow or sadness for anyone.»

en: As he said these words with his eyes fixed on the writer, his hand slowly and softly moved down close to the writer’s face.
vi: - As he read, he stared intently at the writer, Carton's hand slowly and discreetly moved closer to Darnay's face.
tr: While saying these words, his hand slowly, gently descended to the prisoner's face, his eyes fixed on him.
es: While he dictated these words, his eyes fixed on the one who was writing, his right hand moved cautiously closer to the face of the prisoner.

en: The pen dropped from Darnay’s fingers on the table, and he looked about him vacantly.
vi: The pen fell from Darnay's fingers onto the table, and he stared blankly around.
tr: The pen fell from Darnay's fingers onto the table, and Darnay looked at Carton with empty eyes.
es: The pen fell from Darnay's hand, who looked around with a dazed expression.

en: “What vapour is that?” he asked.
vi: − What kind of smell is that?
tr: "Where did this mist come from?" he asked. "What is this steam?"
es: —What steamer is this?—he asked.

en: “Vapour?”
vi: - Darnay asked.
tr: "Something passed before my eyes."
es: —Steam?

en: “Something that crossed me?”
vi: − A breath? − A strange breath wafted across my face?
tr: "Did I smell something?""
es: —Yes... a smell that bothers and stuns me.

en: “I am conscious of nothing; there can be nothing here.
vi: − I don't see anything; there's nothing strange here.
tr: "I didn't notice anything; but such a thing can't happen here.
es: —I perceive nothing... It is not possible that vapors are being inhaled here...

en: Take up the pen and finish.
vi: Pick up the pen and finish writing.
tr: Take the pen and finish this.
es: Take up the pen again and let us finish...

en: Hurry, hurry!”
vi: Quickly, quickly!
tr: Hurry up, come on!"
es: Quickly, quickly!

en: As if his memory were impaired, or his faculties disordered, the prisoner made an effort to rally his attention.
vi: As if his memory had deteriorated, or his faculties had become disordered, the prisoner tried to concentrate.
tr: The prisoner, who seemed to have his memory damaged or lost his faculties, tried to concentrate.
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: As he looked at Carton with clouded eyes and with an altered manner of breathing, Carton—his hand again in his breast—looked steadily at him.
vi: While Darnay looked up with a dull gaze and his breath changed to rapid gasps, Carton still stared intently at Darnay, his hand once again placed inside his coat.
tr: With blurred eyes, barely breathing, he looked at Carton, who –with his hand again on his chest– was staring back at him intently.
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: “Hurry, hurry!”
vi: − Hurry up, hurry!
tr: "Come on, hurry up!"
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: The prisoner bent over the paper, once more.
vi: The prisoner bent down over the paper again.
tr: The prisoner leaned over the paper once more.
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: “‘If it had been otherwise;’” Carton’s hand was again watchfully and softly stealing down; “‘I never should have used the longer opportunity.
vi: − "If not for this opportunity," - Carton's hand cautiously and discreetly lowered, - "we will never have another chance."
tr: "If it had been otherwise," said Carton as his hand slowly, carefully descended again; "I would not have seized that great opportunity.
es: "Had the course of events been different—continued dictating Carton, whose right hand was under the scribe's nose,—it is natural that I would have missed this opportunity; had the course of events been different..."

en: If it had been otherwise;’” the hand was at the prisoner’s face; “‘I should but have had so much the more to answer for.
vi: "If not for this opportunity," - Carton's hand next to the prisoner's face, - "so many difficulties will pile up later."
tr: If it had been otherwise," and his hand was now in front of the prisoner's face; "There would be many more questions I would have to answer. If it had been otherwise..."
es: "Had the course of events been different—continued dictating Carton, whose right hand was under the scribe's nose,—it is natural that I would have missed this opportunity; had the course of events been different..."

en: If it had been otherwise—’” Carton looked at the pen and saw it was trailing off into unintelligible signs.
vi: "If not for this opportunity..." - Carton looked at the pen and saw the writing becoming illegible.
tr: Carton looked at the pen and saw that the writing was gradually turning into illegible marks.
es: Carton fixed his eyes on the pen and saw that it was scribbling unintelligible signs.

en: Carton’s hand moved back to his breast no more.
vi: Carton's hand no longer moved to his chest.
tr: Carton did not bring his hand to his chest again.
es: The prisoner straightened up suddenly, directing a look full of reproaches at Carton; but the latter's right hand moved closer and closer to his nose, while his left arm encircled his waist.

en: The prisoner sprang up with a reproachful look, but Carton’s hand was close and firm at his nostrils, and Carton’s left arm caught him round the waist.
vi: The prisoner stood up abruptly with a reproachful look, but his nose was already covered by Carton's right hand, and his waist was tightly held by Carton's left hand.
tr: The prisoner sprang up with a reproachful look, but Carton immediately clamped his hand over the prisoner's nostrils and wrapped his left arm around his waist, holding him tightly.
es: The prisoner straightened up suddenly, directing a look full of reproaches at Carton; but the latter's right hand moved closer and closer to his nose, while his left arm encircled his waist.

en: For a few seconds he faintly struggled with the man who had come to lay down his life for him; but, within a minute or so, he was stretched insensible on the ground.
vi: Darnay weakly resisted for a few seconds against the person who risked his life to save him; but after just a minute, Darnay lay unconscious on the floor.
tr: Darnay struggled faintly with the man who was risking his life for him; but soon he lost consciousness and collapsed to the ground.
es: The prisoner struggled weakly and for a few seconds with the man who had come to give his life for his; but before a minute had passed, he lay motionless on the ground.

en: Quickly, but with hands as true to the purpose as his heart was, Carton dressed himself in the clothes the prisoner had laid aside, combed back his hair, and tied it with the ribbon the prisoner had worn.
vi: With swift hands and a resolute heart, Carton donned the clothes the prisoner had taken off, combed his hair, and tied it with the ribbon that had tied the prisoner's hair.
tr: Carton, with hands as faithful to his purpose as his heart, quickly donned the clothes the prisoner had set aside and tied his hair back with the prisoner's ribbon.
es: Carton immediately put on the clothes that the prisoner had left minutes before, combed his hair better than ever, tied his hair with the ribbon that had previously held Darnay's, and said in a very low voice:

en: Then, he softly called, “Enter there!
vi: Then he called softly: − Come in!
tr: Then he called out quietly, "Come in! Come on!" and the Spy entered.
es: —Come in... come in!...

en: Come in!” and the Spy presented himself.
vi: Quickly! - And the spy Barsad entered.
tr: Then he called out quietly, "Come in! Come on!" and the Spy entered.
es: Two seconds later, the spy appeared.

en: “You see?” said Carton, looking up, as he kneeled on one knee beside the insensible figure, putting the paper in the breast: “is your hazard very great?”
vi: - See? Carton looked up. He was kneeling on one knee beside the unconscious prisoner, placing the letter into his coat. - Is your risk too great?
tr: Carton, who was kneeling beside the man lying in a state of unconsciousness, lifted his head and said, "Did you see?" as he tucked the letter into his bosom, "how great the danger you are in is.""
es: —Do you see it?—asked Carton, raising his head, and then kneeling down to place the paper he had written into Charles's pocket. —

en: “mr Carton,” the Spy answered, with a timid snap of his fingers, “my hazard is not that, in the thick of business here, if you are true to the whole of your bargain.”
vi: − Mr. Carton, - the spy replied with a hesitant snap of his fingers, my risk does not lie there, in this matter, if you do as promised.
tr: "Mr. Carton," said the Spy, snapping his fingers in an embarrassed manner, "if you stick to the bargain we made, I won't get into trouble.""
es: Didn't I tell you that your risk was insignificant? —My risk, Mr. Carton, is not in this—replied the spy,—but in you faithfully fulfilling what was stipulated.

en: “Don’t fear me.
vi: − Don't worry.
tr: "Don't be afraid.
es: —Rest assured, I will adhere to the agreement until death.

en: I will be true to the death.”
vi: I swear I will do exactly as I said.
tr: I am faithful to my word until death."
es: —Rest assured, I will adhere to the agreement until death.

en: “You must be, mr Carton, if the tale of fifty-two is to be right.
vi: − That's how it must be, Mr. Carton, if the story of beheading fifty-two people is true.
tr: "If these fifty-two stories are true, you must already keep your word, Mr. Carton.
es: —That is how it must be for the number fifty-two to be exact.

en: Being made right by you in that dress, I shall have no fear.”
vi: If you keep dressing like that and do as you say, then I am not afraid of anything.
tr: If you can get through this situation in these clothes, there is nothing to fear."
es: As long as you complete it, dressed as you are right now, I fear nothing.

en: “Have no fear!
vi: − No need to be afraid!
tr: "Don't be afraid!
es: —You have nothing to fear.

en: I shall soon be out of the way of harming you, and the rest will soon be far from here, please God!
vi: Soon I will no longer be a danger to you, and as for the others, God willing, they will quickly leave this place!
tr: Soon, I won't be in a position to harm you, and hopefully, the others will have left here too!
es: I, who could harm you, will soon disappear from this world, thank God...

en: Now, get assistance and take me to the coach.”
vi: Now call someone to help take me to the car.
tr: Now, someone help put 'me' in the car.""
es: Now, help me; or rather; take me to the car.

en: “You?” said the Spy nervously.
vi: − You? - The detective worriedly.
tr: "You?" asked the Spy, nervously.
es: —To you?—asked the spy with visible apprehension.

en: “Him, man, with whom I have exchanged.
vi: − So this person, the one whose clothes I changed.
tr: "Him," I say, "the man I switched places with.
es: —To him, man of God, to the prisoner with whom I exchange fate!

en: You go out at the gate by which you brought me in?”
vi: You exited through the gate you brought me in, right? −
tr: Will you leave through the door you brought me in from?"
es: Will he leave through the same door through which I entered?

en: “Of course.”
vi: Of course.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Of course.

en: “I was weak and faint when you brought me in, and I am fainter now you take me out.
vi: − I was weak and dizzy when you brought me in, and now as you take me out, I have fainted.
tr: "When you brought me here, I felt weak and exhausted, and now as I leave, I feel even more exhausted.
es: —Well then; since I was weak and faint when I entered, it is only natural that I leave even weaker and fainter.

en: The parting interview has overpowered me.
vi: I cannot bear this eternal farewell.
tr: This farewell scene has worn me out too much.
es: The eternal farewell has affected me so much that I lost consciousness; this has happened here very often... too often.

en: Such a thing has happened here, often, and too often.
vi: Such things often happen here, very often, life and death are up to you.
tr: Such scenes must happen frequently here.
es: The eternal farewell has affected me so much that I lost consciousness; this has happened here very often... too often.

en: Your life is in your own hands.
vi: Such things often happen here, very often, life and death are up to you.
tr: Life is in your own hands.
es: It is your responsibility not to make any blunders...

en: Quick!
vi: Quickly!
tr: Hurry up!
es: Quickly...

en: Call assistance!”
vi: Call for help! −
tr: Call for help!"
es: Call for help.

en: “You swear not to betray me?” said the trembling Spy, as he paused for a last moment.
vi: You swear not to betray me, right? - The spy trembled as he hesitated one last time.
tr: The spy, trembling all over, paused for a moment and asked, "Do you swear not to betray me?"
es: —Do you swear that you will not betray me?—asked the spy, trembling.

en: “Man, man!” returned Carton, stamping his foot; “have I sworn by no solemn vow already, to go through with this, that you waste the precious moments now?
vi: − This man! - Carton said, stomping his foot. - I have sworn already, proceed without wasting any more precious time!
tr: Carton stomped his foot and said, "What are you talking about! Didn't I swear earlier that I would handle this, why are you wasting these precious minutes now?
es: —But man! Haven't I already solemnly sworn it?—replied Carton, stomping impatiently. —Why, then, waste now moments that are precious?

en: Take him yourself to the courtyard you know of, place him yourself in the carriage, show him yourself to mr Lorry, tell him yourself to give him no restorative but air, and to remember my words of last night, and his promise of last night, and drive away!”
vi: You yourself must take this person to that courtyard, you know the place, you yourself must put this person into the waiting carriage there, you yourself must let Mr. Lorry see this person, tell him that just fresh air is enough for this person to recover, no need for any medicine, remind him of my instructions last night, along with his promise last night, and set off immediately!
