tr: Take him to the courtyard we talked about, place him in the carriage yourself, hand him over to Mr. Lorry and tell him not to give any stimulants, that fresh air will be enough, and to remember what I said the last night and the promise he made to me, then leave quickly!"
es: Take him to the courtyard you know, place him in the carriage, take him to Mr. Lorry's side, tell him not to give him any medicine, that all he needs is air, to remember my words from last night, to keep the promise he made to me last night, and nothing more.

en: The Spy withdrew, and Carton seated himself at the table, resting his forehead on his hands.
vi: The spy withdrew and Carton sat at the table, holding his head in his hands.
tr: The spy left and Carton sat at the head of the table, resting his hands on his forehead.
es: The spy withdrew, and Carton sat at the table, resting his elbows on it.

en: The Spy returned immediately, with two men.
vi: The spy returned immediately with two other people. − What's going on here? -
tr: The spy returned immediately with two men beside him.
es: Seconds later, the spy re-entered with two men. —Man!

en: “How, then?” said one of them, contemplating the fallen figure.
vi: One person said while looking at the body lying on the floor. -
tr: One of them, looking at the body lying on the ground, said, "What happened to this man?"
es: —exclaimed one of them, upon seeing Carlos lying on the ground. —

en: “So afflicted to find that his friend has drawn a prize in the lottery of Sainte Guillotine?”
vi: Too emotional upon seeing his friend win the Guillotine lottery?
tr: "Did he find out that his friend won the grand prize in the 'Saint Guillotine lottery'?"
es: Has it shocked him so much to see that his friend won the jackpot in the Santa Guillotina lottery?

en: “A good patriot,” said the other, “could hardly have been more afflicted if the Aristocrat had drawn a blank.”
vi: Too emotional upon seeing his friend win the Guillotine lottery?
tr: "If nothing had come out of the lottery for the aristocrat, a good patriot could not have been more saddened," said the other.
es: —Indeed, a good patriot would not have been more distressed if the aristocrat had been declared acquitted! —observed the other.

en: They raised the unconscious figure, placed it on a litter they had brought to the door, and bent to carry it away.
vi: They lifted the unconscious person, placed him on a stretcher they had brought to the door, and then bent down to lift it up.
tr: They lifted the unconscious body, laid it on the stretcher they had left in front of the door, and bent down to take it away.
es: Between the two of them, they placed the unconscious person on a stretcher they had brought and took him away.

en: “The time is short, Evrémonde,” said the Spy, in a warning voice.
vi: − There's no more time, Evrémonde, - the spy said in a warning tone.
tr: "We don't have much time, Evremonde," said the Spy, as if warning.
es: —Few hours of life remain for you, Evrémonde! —said the spy.

en: “I know it well,” answered Carton.
vi: − I know well, - Carton replied.
tr: "I know," said Carton.
es: —I know it very well—responded Carton.

en: “Be careful of my friend, I entreat you, and leave me.”
vi: - Please take care of my friend and leave me alone.
tr: "Please take care of my friend, now leave me alone."
es: —Take care of my friend and leave me alone.

en: “Come, then, my children,” said Barsad.
vi: − Then let's go, you guys, - Barsad said. -
tr: "Alright then, children," said Barsad.
es: —Let's go, my children—said the spy to his companions.

en: “Lift him, and come away!”
vi: Lift this man up and let's go!
tr: "Lift it up and let's go already!"
es: — Let's move.

en: The door closed, and Carton was left alone.
vi: The door closed and only Carton was left alone.
tr: The door closed and Carton was left alone.
es: The door closed, leaving Carton alone.

en: Straining his powers of listening to the utmost, he listened for any sound that might denote suspicion or alarm.
vi: Using all his hearing, he stood up, straining to catch any sounds that might indicate suspicion or alarm.
tr: He listened intently outside to hear any suspicious situation or any sound suggesting danger.
es: He concentrated all the faculties of his soul in his hearing in case something sounded that indicated suspicions or alarms; nothing was heard.

en: There was none.
vi: There were none.
tr: There was no sound.
es: He concentrated all the faculties of his soul in his hearing in case something sounded that indicated suspicions or alarms; nothing was heard.

en: Keys turned, doors clashed, footsteps passed along distant passages: no cry was raised, or hurry made, that seemed unusual.
vi: The sound of keys turning, the door slamming shut, footsteps receding down the corridors; no loud cries, no unusual hurried footsteps.
tr: Locks turned, doors closed, footsteps passing through distant corridors were heard; no scream arose, nor was there any unusual commotion.
es: Keys turned in the locks, doors closed with a crash, footsteps receded, but no scream was heard nor was the usual order or tranquility disturbed.

en: Breathing more freely in a little while, he sat down at the table, and listened again until the clock struck Two.
vi: Feeling more at ease, after a while he sat down again and continued to listen until the clock struck two.
tr: Soon, when he started to breathe a bit more comfortably, he sat down at the table again and listened until the clock struck two.
es: Carton, now calmer, remained seated in front of the table until two o'clock struck.

en: Sounds that he was not afraid of, for he divined their meaning, then began to be audible.
vi: Then he began to hear sounds that he was not afraid of, for he himself had given them a sacred meaning.
tr: Then some sounds rose, but Carton was not afraid because he knew what they were.
es: Then, sounds reached his ears that neither alarmed nor surprised him, simply because he knew perfectly well what they meant.

en: Several doors were opened in succession, and finally his own.
vi: Many prison doors were opened in succession, and finally the door to his cell.
tr: Doors opened one after another, and finally, it was his turn.
es: Many doors were successively opened, until finally it was the turn of his cell.

en: A gaoler, with a list in his hand, looked in, merely saying, “Follow me, Evrémonde!” and he followed into a large dark room, at a distance.
vi: A jailer holding a list in his hand looked at it and briefly said, "Follow me, Evrémonde!" And he followed to a large, gloomy room in the distance.
tr: A guard, with a list in hand, looked inside and simply said, "Follow me, Evremonde!" and took him to a large dark room in the distance.
es: A jailer, equipped with a list, without stepping over the threshold, merely said: —Follow me, Evrémonde. Carton followed the jailer until they reached a dark, large cell, located quite a distance away, crowded with prisoners.

en: It was a dark winter day, and what with the shadows within, and what with the shadows without, he could but dimly discern the others who were brought there to have their arms bound.
vi: That day was a dreary winter day, with darkness both outside and inside, he could only faintly see the others who were brought here to have their hands tied.
tr: It was a dark winter day, and Carton could barely make out the other prisoners, who had been brought in with their arms bound, in the gloom both inside and outside.
es: Although the light was very dim, Carton could see that everyone had their arms tied, some were standing and others sitting, some were complaining while others were pacing restlessly and nervously.

en: Some were standing; some seated.
vi: Some stood, some sat.
tr: Some were standing; some were sitting.
es: Although the light was very dim, Carton could see that everyone had their arms tied, some were standing and others sitting, some were complaining while others were pacing restlessly and nervously.

en: Some were lamenting, and in restless motion; but, these were few.
vi: Some were crying, panicking; but they were few.
tr: Some were crying and wailing, unable to stay still, but they were few in number.
es: Although the light was very dim, Carton could see that everyone had their arms tied, some were standing and others sitting, some were complaining while others were pacing restlessly and nervously.

en: The great majority were silent and still, looking fixedly at the ground.
vi: Most were silent, their eyes looking down at the floor.
tr: The vast majority were silent and had fixed their eyes on the ground without moving.
es: Most of them, however, remained silent and motionless, with their eyes fixed on the ground.

en: As he stood by the wall in a dim corner, while some of the fifty-two were brought in after him, one man stopped in passing, to embrace him, as having a knowledge of him.
vi: While he was standing in a dark corner of the wall and some others from the list of fifty-two people were brought in after him, a passerby suddenly stopped and hugged him as if they had known each other before.
tr: Leaning against a wall in a dark corner, watching those brought in after him among fifty-two people, a man passing in front of him stopped and wanted to hug him as if he knew him.
es: While standing next to the blackish wall, he gazed at his fifty-one gallows companions, some of whom had entered after him, when a man stopped to embrace him.

en: It thrilled him with a great dread of discovery; but the man went on.
vi: Carton was secretly terrified of being discovered; but the person continued on.
tr: Carton panicked, thinking the man would notice the situation; but the man continued on his way.
es: Carton shuddered, fearing he had been discovered, but the man continued on his way after giving him a hug.

en: A very few moments after that, a young woman, with a slight girlish form, a sweet spare face in which there was no vestige of colour, and large widely opened patient eyes, rose from the seat where he had observed her sitting, and came to speak to him.
vi: Just a moment later, a girl he saw sitting on the bench suddenly stood up and walked towards him.
tr: Shortly after, a young woman with a delicate young girl's body, with a pale, charming, and thin face and wide-open eyes full of patience, got up from the place where Carton had just been observing and came to talk to him.
es: Moments later, a graceful little girl with lovely features rose from the ground and approached Carton.

en: “Citizen Evrémonde,” she said, touching him with her cold hand.
vi: With a figure still retaining the features of youth, a gentle face unadorned exposing pale skin and wide, patient eyes, the girl started a conversation: − Citizen Evrémonde, - she touched him with her cold hand.
tr: "Citizen Evremonde," he said, touching him with his cold hand, "I am the poor little tailor who stayed with you in La Force, do you remember?"
es: —Citizen Evrémonde—she said, extending her cold hand;—I am a little seamstress who was your fellow prisoner in La Force.

en: “I am a poor little seamstress, who was with you in La Force.”
vi: - I am a poor seamstress, who was imprisoned in La Force with you.
tr: "Citizen Evremonde," he said, touching him with his cold hand, "I am the poor little tailor who stayed with you in La Force, do you remember?"
es: —Ah, yes!

en: He murmured for answer: “True. I forget what you were accused of?”
vi: − That's right, - he whispered in response. - I forgot, what were you accused of?
tr: Carton murmured in response: "Correct. But I have forgotten what you are accused of."
es: —murmured Carton.

en: “Plots.
vi: − Conspiracy.
tr: "With plotting a conspiracy.
es: —It's true!

en: Though the just Heaven knows that I am innocent of any.
vi: Even though God knows I am completely innocent.
tr: But God knows, I haven't committed any crime.
es: What I don't remember is the accusation that brought you to jail.

en: Is it likely?
vi: How could that be?
tr: Can such a thing be possible?
es: —They accused me of being a conspirator; but the good Lord knows that I am innocent.

en: Who would think of plotting with a poor little weak creature like me?”
vi: Who could conspire against someone as weak and poor as me?
tr: Who would think of plotting a conspiracy with a poor and small creature like me?"
es: Can there be a conspirator who entrusts their machinations to a weak girl like me?

en: The forlorn smile with which she said it, so touched him, that tears started from his eyes.
vi: Her desperate smile moved him, his eyes welling up with tears.
tr: As she said this, the sad smile that appeared on the woman's face touched Carton so deeply that tears began to flow from his eyes.
es: The smile with which the young girl accompanied her words moved Carton so deeply that tears came to his eyes.

en: “I am not afraid to die, Citizen Evrémonde, but I have done nothing.
vi: − I am not afraid to die, Citizen Evrémonde, but I have done nothing.
tr: "I am not afraid of death, Citizen Evremonde, but I have done nothing.
es: —I am not afraid to die, citizen Evrémonde, but I repeat that I have done nothing.

en: I am not unwilling to die, if the Republic which is to do so much good to us poor, will profit by my death; but I do not know how that can be, Citizen Evrémonde.
vi: I am ready to die if it is useful for the Republic, which has done many good things for the poor; but I do not understand why it has come to this, Citizen Evrémonde.
tr: If my death will benefit the Republic, which will bring a smile to the faces of poor people like us, I certainly do not mind death; but I do not know how this will happen, Citizen Evremonde.
es: I would even die with joy if the Republic, which they say is to make the poor happy, could gain some benefit from my death; but if I am to say what I feel, I do not believe that my death will serve any purpose, Evrémonde.

en: Such a poor weak little creature!”
vi: I am such a poor and weak person!
tr: After all, I am just a poor little creature!"
es: What benefits could the Republic gain from the death of a weak creature like me?

en: As the last thing on earth that his heart was to warm and soften to, it warmed and softened to this pitiable girl.
vi: That poor girl moved him deeply, the last person in this world to make his heart ache.
tr: In this life, the last thing that would warm and ache your heart was this poor girl who warmed and ached Carton's heart.
es: The compassion that the girl inspired in Carton was infinite.

en: “I heard you were released, Citizen Evrémonde.
vi: − I heard that you have been set free, Citizen Evrémonde.
tr: "I had heard that you were released, Citizen Evremonde.
es: —I heard that you had been acquitted, Citizen Evrémonde, and I truly regret that it is not true.

en: I hoped it was true?”
vi: I hope that is true? −
tr: If only it were true!"
es: —I heard that you had been acquitted, Citizen Evrémonde, and I truly regret that it is not true.

en: “It was.
vi: It is true.
tr: "It was like that.
es: —I was; but then they caught me again and have condemned me.

en: But, I was again taken and condemned.”
vi: But I was re-arrested and sentenced.
tr: But then I was caught again and sentenced."
es: —I was; but then they caught me again and have condemned me.

en: “If I may ride with you, Citizen Evrémonde, will you let me hold your hand?
vi: − If I were to ride with you, Citizen Evrémonde, may I hold your hand?
tr: "Citizen Evremonde, if we end up in the same carriage, may I hold your hand?
es: —If they place us in the same cart, Citizen Evrémonde, will you allow me to hold your hand?

en: I am not afraid, but I am little and weak, and it will give me more courage.”
vi: I am not afraid, but I am weak and small, and it would give me more courage.
tr: I am not afraid, but I am small and weak, it will give me courage."
es: It's not that I'm afraid; but since I am a child, your hand will give me the courage I lack.

en: As the patient eyes were lifted to his face, he saw a sudden doubt in them, and then astonishment.
vi: When those patient eyes looked up, he suddenly noticed the doubt and then the astonishment in them.
tr: When patience-filled eyes turned to his face, Carton saw a sudden doubt in them, followed by astonishment.
es: Carton saw that through the girl's eyes, as she fixed them on his face, first a cloud of doubt passed, and then one of astonishment.

en: He pressed the work-worn, hunger-worn young fingers, and touched his lips.
vi: He tightly grasped her thin, hungry, and weary fingers, bringing them to his lips.
tr: He held the young fingers, worn from work and hunger, and brought them to his lips.
es: Carton saw that through the girl's eyes, as she fixed them on his face, first a cloud of doubt passed, and then one of astonishment.

en: “Are you dying for him?” she whispered.
vi: − You died in his place? - The girl whispered.
tr: "Are you sacrificing yourself for him?"
es: —Are you going to die for him?

en: “And his wife and child.
vi: − And because of his wife and children.
tr: "For his wife and child too.
es: —And for his wife and daughter... yes!

en: Hush!
vi: Shh!
tr: Shh! Yes."
es: —Oh!

en: Yes.”
vi: That's right.
tr: Shh! Yes."
es: Will you allow me to hold your valiant hand in mine?

en: “O you will let me hold your brave hand, stranger?”
vi: − Oh, may I hold your brave hand, stranger?
tr: "Ah, allow me to hold your brave hand, stranger!"
es: Will you allow me to hold your valiant hand in mine?

en: “Hush!
vi: − Shh!
tr: "Shh!
es: —Yes, my unfortunate sister... until the very last moment.

en: Yes, my poor sister; to the last.”
vi: Alright, my poor sister, let's hold hands until the very end.
tr: Alright, my poor brother, hold my hand until the very end."
es: —Yes, my unfortunate sister... until the very last moment.

en: The same shadows that are falling on the prison, are falling, in that same hour of the early afternoon, on the Barrier with the crowd about it, when a coach going out of Paris drives up to be examined.
vi: Just like the shadows enveloping the prison, at that same early afternoon hour, darkness was descending upon the city gate, covering the crowd surrounding it as a four-horse carriage leaving Paris stopped for inspection.
tr: When the shadows falling over the prison fell upon the barricades surrounded by crowds at the same hours in the afternoon, a car that had set out to leave Paris was stopped for inspection.
es: The same shadows that envelop the condemned surround the crowds stationed at the same hour in the vicinity of the Barrier at the moment when a road coach, coming from the interior of the city, approaches to present the documents of its occupants.

en: “Who goes here?
vi: − Who is going there?
tr: "Who are you?
es: —Who are the travelers?

en: Whom have we within?
vi: Who is in the car?
tr: Who are the people with you?
es: —Who are the travelers?

en: Papers!”
vi: Present your papers!
tr: Let's see your documents!"
es: Let's see... the documents!

en: The papers are handed out, and read.
vi: The papers were presented for inspection.
tr: The documents were handed over and he read them.
es: A hand presents the documents, which are read.

en: “Alexandre Manette.
vi: − Alexandre Manette.
tr: "Alexandre Manette.
es: —Alejandro Manette... doctor... French...

en: Physician.
vi: Doctor.
tr: Doctor.
es: —Alejandro Manette... doctor... French...

en: French.
vi: French.
tr: French.
es: —Alejandro Manette... doctor... French...

en: Which is he?”
vi: Who is he?
tr: Which one of you is this?"
es: Let's see; who is it?

en: This is he; this helpless, inarticulately murmuring, wandering old man pointed out.
vi: That's him; a finger pointed at an absent-minded, helpless old man, muttering incoherent words.
tr: Here it is; the old man, who is muttering and babbling incomprehensible things, is pointed out.
es: An extended arm indicates an exhausted old man who murmurs unintelligible words.

en: “Apparently the Citizen-Doctor is not in his right mind?
vi: − Clearly, this Citizen Doctor is mentally unstable?
tr: "It seems that Citizen Doctor is not quite in his right mind, is he?
es: —It seems that the citizen doctor has his faculties disturbed, doesn't he?

en: The Revolution-fever will have been too much for him?”
vi: Can't withstand the fever of the Revolution?
tr: The revolution's fire must have been too much for him."
es: The fever of the Revolution has burned his brain.

en: Greatly too much for him.
vi: It's beyond his endurance.
tr: Indeed, this was too much for him.
es: —It seems so.

en: “Hah!
vi: − Hmph!
tr: "Eh!
es: —Bah!

en: Many suffer with it.
vi: Many people can still bear it.
tr: Many people suffer from the same problem.
es: There are many who find themselves in his situation... Lucía, his daughter... French...

en: Lucie.
vi: Lucie.
tr: His daughter Lucie.
es: There are many who find themselves in his situation... Lucía, his daughter... French...

en: His daughter.
vi: This man's daughter.
tr: His daughter Lucie.
es: There are many who find themselves in his situation... Lucía, his daughter... French...

en: French.
vi: French.
tr: French.
es: There are many who find themselves in his situation... Lucía, his daughter... French...

en: Which is she?”
vi: Where is she?
tr: Who is this?"
es: Who is she?

en: This is she.
vi: There she is.
tr: That's it.
es: Who is she?

en: “Apparently it must be.
vi: − Surely it is.
tr: "That's right, who else could it be?
es: —This one.

en: Lucie, the wife of Evrémonde; is it not?”
vi: Lucie, the wife of Evrémonde, right?
tr: Lucie, the wife of Evremonde, isn't she?"
es: —This one.

en: It is.
vi: Exactly.
tr: Correct.
es: —This one.

en: “Hah!
vi: − Hmph!
tr: "Eh! Evremonde has an appointment elsewhere.
es: —Very well.

en: Evrémonde has an assignation elsewhere.
vi: Evrémonde has been assigned elsewhere, Lucie, her daughter.
tr: "Eh! Evremonde has an appointment elsewhere.
es: Evrémonde embarks on another different journey... Lucie, daughter of Lucie... English...

en: Lucie, her child.
vi: Evrémonde has been assigned elsewhere, Lucie, her daughter.
tr: Lucie, his daughter.
es: Evrémonde embarks on another different journey... Lucie, daughter of Lucie... English...

en: English.
vi: The Englishman.
tr: English.
es: Evrémonde embarks on another different journey... Lucie, daughter of Lucie... English...

en: This is she?”
vi: Is this it?
tr: That's it."
es: Is this her?

en: She and no other.
vi: It's the girl.
tr: There it is, who else would be there?
es: —The same one.

en: “Kiss me, child of Evrémonde.
vi: − Kiss me, little Evrémonde.
tr: "Kiss me, daughter of Evremonde.
es: —Give me a kiss, daughter of Evrémonde...

en: Now, thou hast kissed a good Republican; something new in thy family; remember it!
vi: There, you have kissed a good Republican; a new experience for your family; don't forget!
tr: Now that you've kissed a good Republican, this is something new for your family; remember this!
es: You have kissed a good republican, a new thing in your family, don't forget it.

en: Sydney Carton.
vi: Sydney Carton.
tr: Sydney Carton.
es: Sydney Carton, lawyer, English...

en: Advocate.
vi: Lawyer.
tr: Lawyer.
es: Sydney Carton, lawyer, English...

en: English.
vi: Englishman.
tr: Englishman.
es: Sydney Carton, lawyer, English...

en: Which is he?”
vi: Who is he?
tr: Which one?"
es: Who is he?

en: He lies here, in this corner of the carriage.
vi: He is lying there, in the corner of the carriage.
tr: He is lying in a corner of the carriage.
es: This one lying at the bottom of the car.

en: He, too, is pointed out.
vi: A finger points in that direction.
tr: He is also pointed out.
es: —Is the English lawyer unconscious?

en: “Apparently the English advocate is in a swoon?”
vi: − This English barrister seems to be unconscious?
tr: "It seems the English lawyer has fainted, huh?"
es: —Is the English lawyer unconscious?

en: It is hoped he will recover in the fresher air.
vi: Everyone hopes that the fresh air will help him regain consciousness.
tr: It is hoped that he will recover in the fresh air.
es: —Yes... his health is very broken, but the fresh air will undoubtedly do him good.

en: It is represented that he is not in strong health, and has separated sadly from a friend who is under the displeasure of the Republic.
vi: It is clear that he is unwell, and he has just sorrowfully bid farewell to a friend who was not well-liked by the Republic.
tr: It is explained to the attendant that he is not in good health and is experiencing the sorrow of parting from a friend who has been subjected to the wrath of the Republic.
es: He has just said goodbye to a friend of his who has had the misfortune of falling into the disfavor of the Republic.

en: “Is that all?
vi: − Just because of that?
tr: "Is this the reason?
es: —Does he faint over such a small thing?

en: It is not a great deal, that!
vi: It's nothing to make a fuss about!
tr: This is not such an important thing!
es: —Does he faint over such a small thing?

en: Many are under the displeasure of the Republic, and must look out at the little window.
vi: Many people are not in the favor of the Republic and have to stick their heads into the guillotine.
tr: There are many who have faced the wrath of the Republic and had to look through that tiny guillotine window.
es: Many are those who incur the displeasure of the Republic, and the misfortune of many... Mauricio Lorry, banker, English...

en: Jarvis Lorry.
vi: Jarvis Lorry.
tr: Jarvis Lorry.
es: Many are those who incur the displeasure of the Republic, and the misfortune of many... Mauricio Lorry, banker, English...

en: Banker.
vi: Bank employee.
tr: Banker.
es: Who is the banker?

en: English.
vi: Englishman.
tr: Englishman.
es: Who is the banker?

en: Which is he?”
vi: Who is he? −
tr: Who is this?"
es: Who is the banker?

en: “I am he.
vi: He is me.
tr: "It's me.
es: —It's me; it can't be anyone else, since no one else is left in the car.

en: Necessarily, being the last.”
vi: Of course, the last one.
tr: I was the only one left anyway."
es: —It's me; it can't be anyone else, since no one else is left in the car.

en: It is Jarvis Lorry who has replied to all the previous questions.
vi: It was Mr. Jarvis Lorry who answered all the questions.
tr: It was Jarvis Lorry who answered all these questions.
es: Mauricio Lorry was the one who had answered the previous questions, Mauricio Lorry the one who had dismounted and, with his right hand resting on the carriage door, was responding to the interrogation of the barrier guard.

en: It is Jarvis Lorry who has alighted and stands with his hand on the coach door, replying to a group of officials.
vi: It was Mr. Jarvis Lorry who got off the carriage and stood leaning against the door to answer a group of officials.
tr: He had gotten out of the carriage and answered a group of officials at the door.
es: Mauricio Lorry was the one who had answered the previous questions, Mauricio Lorry the one who had dismounted and, with his right hand resting on the carriage door, was responding to the interrogation of the barrier guard.

en: They leisurely walk round the carriage and leisurely mount the box, to look at what little luggage it carries on the roof; the country-people hanging about, press nearer to the coach doors and greedily stare in; a little child, carried by its mother, has its short arm held out for it, that it may touch the wife of an aristocrat who has gone to the Guillotine.
vi: This group leisurely walked around the carriage, leisurely climbed onto the coachman's seat, and examined the few pieces of luggage on the roof; the villagers loitered around, crowded near the carriage doors, and looked inside with longing eyes; a child being held by its mother stretched out its short arm as if wanting to touch the wife of the nobleman who had gone to the guillotine.
tr: The men slowly walked around the carriage and then slowly climbed up to the coachman's seat to look at the luggage on top; the crowd swarming around the carriage was pushing each other at the door, peering inside with greedy eyes; a small child in his mother's arms was reaching out to touch the wife of an aristocrat on her way to the guillotine.
es: Mauricio Lorry was the one who had answered the previous questions, Mauricio Lorry the one who had dismounted and, with his right hand resting on the carriage door, was responding to the interrogation of the barrier guard.

en: “Behold your papers, Jarvis Lorry, countersigned.”
vi: − Check the documents again, Jarvis Lorry, they have been signed and confirmed.
tr: "Here are your documents, Jarvis Lorry, signed.""
es: —Take your documents, Mauricio Lorry...

en: “One can depart, citizen?”
vi: − Can we go, Citizen? −
tr: "Can we leave now, citizen?"
es: Endorsed! —Can we proceed with the journey?

en: “One can depart.
vi: You are permitted.
tr: "You may go.
es: —Whenever it suits you.

en: Forward, my postilions!
vi: Whip the horses, driver!
tr: Come on, coachman!
es: Onward, postilions, and have a good journey.

en: A good journey!”
vi: Safe journey!
tr: Have a good journey!"
es: Onward, postilions, and have a good journey.

en: “I salute you, citizens.
vi: − Farewell, Citizens...
tr: "Goodbye, fellow citizens.
es: —Greetings, citizens...

en: —And the first danger passed!”
vi: And the first danger has passed!
tr: –Yes, we have overcome the first danger!"
es: The first danger has passed.

en: These are again the words of Jarvis Lorry, as he clasps his hands, and looks upward.
vi: It was Mr. Jarvis Lorry speaking as he clasped his hands, eyes raised to the sky.
tr: These words also belonged to Jarvis Lorry, who was looking up with his hands clasped.
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: There is terror in the carriage, there is weeping, there is the heavy breathing of the insensible traveller.
vi: Inside the carriage, there was fear, the sound of crying, and the heavy breathing of the unconscious traveler.
tr: There was terror in the carriage, there were tears, and the heavy breath of the unconscious passenger filled the air.
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: “Are we not going too slowly?
vi: − Why is the car moving so slowly?
tr: Lucie grabbed the old man's arm and asked, "Aren't we going too slow?
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: Can they not be induced to go faster?” asks Lucie, clinging to the old man.
vi: Can't we tell them to go faster? - Lucie asked, holding onto the old man.
tr: Can't we go faster?"
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: “It would seem like flight, my darling.
vi: − That would be like running away, my dear.
tr: "Then we would look like we're running away, my dear.
es: —If we ran faster, it would look like we were fleeing; it's not advisable; we would arouse suspicion.

en: I must not urge them too much; it would rouse suspicion.”
vi: We must not urge them too much; doing so would arouse suspicion.
tr: We shouldn't push them too hard; it would arouse suspicion later."
es: —If we ran faster, it would look like we were fleeing; it's not advisable; we would arouse suspicion.

en: “Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued!”
vi: − Look behind, look behind, see if we are being chased? −
tr: "Look back, are they following us?"
es: —Look back...

en: “The road is clear, my dearest.
vi: The road is clear, my dear.
tr: "There is no one on the road, my beautiful child.
es: Are they not chasing us?

en: So far, we are not pursued.”
vi: So far, no one is chasing us.
tr: They are not following us."
es: —No, my dear, no; so far they are not chasing us.

en: Houses in twos and threes pass by us, solitary farms, ruinous buildings, dye-works, tanneries, and the like, open country, avenues of leafless trees.
vi: The carriage passed through clusters of scattered houses, solitary farms, ruined buildings, dye works; tanneries, and similar places, then open fields and roads lined with bare trees.
tr: We pass by houses in twos and threes, deserted farms, dilapidated buildings, paint shops, and tanneries, and then through streets lined with wide fields and leafless trees.
es: The fugitives leave behind one or two-story houses that line the road, farms, abandoned labor houses, ruined tanneries, lonely fields, avenues winding between rows of leafless trees.

en: The hard uneven pavement is under us, the soft deep mud is on either side.
vi: The cobblestones were uneven under the horse's hooves, then deep mud engulfed the sides of the carriage.
tr: In front of us, randomly laid hard cobblestones, and on either side of us, soft and deep mud.
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Sometimes, we strike into the skirting mud, to avoid the stones that clatter us and shake us; sometimes, we stick in ruts and sloughs there.
vi: At times, the carriage veered into the slippery mud to avoid the uneven stones in the middle of the road; at other times, the carriage got stuck in muddy ditches.
tr: Sometimes, to escape the stones that clatter and shake the carriage, we plunge into the mud at the edges; sometimes into the wheel tracks and puddles.
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: The agony of our impatience is then so great, that in our wild alarm and hurry we are for getting out and running—hiding—doing anything but stopping.
vi: The agony of impatience was so great that in a frantic panic, those in the carriage just wanted to escape and run away - hide - do anything as long as they didn't have to stop.
tr: At such moments, the torment of our impatience increases so much that, in a frantic rush and hurry to escape –and hide– we move forward without stopping.
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Out of the open country, in again among ruinous buildings, solitary farms, dye-works, tanneries, and the like, cottages in twos and threes, avenues of leafless trees.
vi: Leaving the open fields, the carriage passed through ruined buildings, solitary farms, dye works; tanneries, and similar places, then again through clusters of a few scattered houses, and leafless tree-lined roads.
tr: We are passing again through wide fields, dilapidated buildings, deserted farms, dye houses, tanneries, and then again through streets covered with leafless trees where there are houses in twos and threes.
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Have these men deceived us, and taken us back by another road?
vi: Have these people deceived us into turning the carriage back by another route?
tr: Were these men deceiving us and taking us back by another route?
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Is not this the same place twice over?
vi: Is this not the place we crossed twice already?
tr: Hadn't we passed through the same place before?
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Thank Heaven, no.
vi: Thank God, it is not.
tr: Thank God, no.
es: Their impatience, their agony is so great that they see nothing, notice nothing, think of nothing but reaching the port of salvation as soon as possible.

en: A village.
vi: A village.
tr: A village.
es: Their impatience, their agony is so great that they see nothing, notice nothing, think of nothing but reaching the port of salvation as soon as possible.

en: Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued!
vi: Look behind, look behind, see if we are being followed?
tr: Look back, look back and see if we are being followed?
es: Their impatience, their agony is so great that they see nothing, notice nothing, think of nothing but reaching the port of salvation as soon as possible.

en: Hush!
vi: Hush!
tr: Shh!
es: The horses are harnessed again.

en: the posting-house.
vi: We've reached the relay station!
tr: The resting place of the postal carriages.
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: Leisurely, our four horses are taken out; leisurely, the coach stands in the little street, bereft of horses, and with no likelihood upon it of ever moving again; leisurely, the new horses come into visible existence, one by one; leisurely, the new postilions follow, sucking and plaiting the lashes of their whips; leisurely, the old postilions count their money, make wrong additions, and arrive at dissatisfied results.
vi: Leisurely, the four horses were unharnessed; leisurely, the carriage stood in the narrow road, no longer drawn by horses, and incapable of moving; leisurely, four new horses appeared, one by one; leisurely, two new grooms followed the horses, drinking wine and coiling their whips; leisurely, the two old grooms counted money, miscalculated the total, and were dissatisfied with the result.
tr: Our four horses are slowly being untied from their reins; the carriage, without its horses and as if it will never move again, stands slowly on the tiny road; then slowly, one by one, new horses come into view; the old coachmen slowly count their money, making mistakes and coming up with improbable results.
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: All the time, our overfraught hearts are beating at a rate that would far outstrip the fastest gallop of the fastest horses ever foaled.
vi: All the while, our fearful hearts were beating in a rhythm even more urgent than the fastest galloping horse in the world.
tr: Throughout this entire time, our burdened hearts beat so fast that even the fastest horses in history couldn't make such a noise while galloping.
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: At length the new postilions are in their saddles, and the old are left behind.
vi: Finally, the two new horsemen mounted their saddles, while the two old ones stayed behind.
tr: Soon, the new coachmen take their places and the old ones fall behind.
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: We are through the village, up the hill, and down the hill, and on the low watery grounds.
vi: The carriage once again traversed through villages, up hills and down slopes, and ran on the waterlogged lowlands.
tr: We pass the village, climb the hill, descend, and then reach the low-lying wetlands.
es: They pass through a village, laboriously climb a ramp, crest the hill, descend the opposite slope, and enter less arid lands...

en: Suddenly, the postilions exchange speech with animated gesticulation, and the horses are pulled up, almost on their haunches.
vi: Suddenly, the two coachmen waved their hands and talked animatedly, and the carriage came to an abrupt stop, causing the four horses to almost rear up.
tr: Suddenly, the coachmen's conversations become lively and cheerful, and they quickly pull the reins to stop the horses.
es: Good heavens!

en: We are pursued?
vi: Is someone chasing us?
tr: Are we being followed?
es: They are being chased!

en: “Ho!
vi: − Hey!
tr: "Hey!
es: —Ah, the carriage...!

en: Within the carriage there.
vi: You in the carriage!
tr: You in the car."
es: —Ah, the carriage...!

en: Speak then!”
vi: Speak up! −
tr: "Tell me, let's see!""
es: Stop!

en: “What is it?” asks mr Lorry, looking out at window.
vi: What's the matter? - Mr. Lorry asked, looking out the carriage window.
tr: "What?" asks Mr. Lorry, sticking his head out the window.
es: —What's happening?—asks Lorry, sticking her head out the door.

en: “How many did they say?”
vi: − How many people did they say?
tr: "How many were they?""
es: —How many have there been today?

en: “I do not understand you.”
vi: − I don't understand what you mean?
tr: "I don't understand you." "...
es: —I don't understand.

en: “—At the last post.
vi: − ... At the final station.
tr: In the last post.
es: —I don't understand.

en: How many to the Guillotine to-day?”
vi: How many people are going to the guillotine today?
tr: How many people went to the guillotine today?"
es: —How many have kissed the Holy Guillotine today?

en: “Fifty-two.”
vi: − Fifty-two.
tr: "Fifty-two.""
es: —Fifty-two.

en: “I said so!
vi: − I was right!
tr: "I told you!
es: —Good!

en: A brave number!
vi: A beautiful number!
tr: The number is big!
es: Good number!

en: My fellow-citizen here would have it forty-two; ten more heads are worth having.
vi: My fellow Citizen here keeps saying it's forty-two; it deserves ten more heads.
tr: The guy next to me was saying forty-two; so it means ten more heads will roll.
es: My good fellow citizens here would have liked to dispatch so many; but they were ten less... The Guillotine works admirably... Good for the Guillotine...!

en: The Guillotine goes handsomely.
vi: The guillotine is magnificent.
tr: The guillotine will take care of them nicely.
es: Long live the Guillotine...!

en: I love it.
vi: I like it that way.
tr: Very nice.
es: I adore it...!

en: Hi forward.
vi: Hey!
tr: Let's go then.
es: Onward!

en: Whoop!”
vi: Move on! Hoo!
tr: Deeh!"
es: Onward!

en: The night comes on dark.
vi: The night is falling.
tr: The night is falling pitch dark.
es: The night closes in.

en: He moves more; he is beginning to revive, and to speak intelligibly; he thinks they are still together; he asks him, by his name, what he has in his hand.
vi: The unconscious traveler began to move; he was regaining consciousness; and he spoke coherently; he thought he was still with his friend; he asked his friend, by name, what he was holding in his hand.
tr: The faint passenger is stirring; he has started to come to his senses and say understandable things; he still thinks you are beside him; he addresses you by name and asks what you are holding in your hand.
es: Carlos begins to move... he comes back to life... he says intelligible words. He thinks he is still next to Carton and asks him what he has in his hand...

en: O pity us, kind Heaven, and help us!
vi: Oh merciful God, have mercy on us, and help us!
tr: Oh, Almighty God, please have mercy on us and help us!
es: God in Heaven!

en: Look out, look out, and see if we are pursued.
vi: Watch out, watch out, are we being chased?
tr: Be careful, look and see if they are following us.
es: Have mercy on the fugitives!

en: The wind is rushing after us, and the clouds are flying after us, and the moon is plunging after us, and the whole wild night is in pursuit of us; but, so far, we are pursued by nothing else.
vi: Only the wind whistling behind; and the clouds swirling behind, and the moon plunging behind, and the wild night chasing them; besides that, up to this moment, nothing was chasing them.
tr: The wind is chasing us, the clouds are flying after us, the moon is circling above us, and the wild night is pursuing us, but so far nothing else has followed us.
es: Behind them flies the swift wind, behind them rush the clouds, behind them runs the moon, the shadows of the night follow them tirelessly; but, fortunately, until then, no one else runs in their pursuit.

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: Only the wind whistling behind; and the clouds swirling behind, and the moon plunging behind, and the wild night chasing them; besides that, up to this moment, nothing was chasing them.
tr: Fourteen
es: Chapter XIV.

en: The Knitting Done
vi: 14. The last knitting stitch
tr: The Knitting is Finished
es: END OF THE SOCK

en: In that same juncture of time when the Fifty-Two awaited their fate Madame Defarge held darkly ominous council with The Vengeance and Jacques Three of the Revolutionary Jury.
vi: At the same time, fifty-two people were awaiting their fate, Madame Defarge organized a dark and terrifying meeting with the Goddess of Retribution and Jacques Three of the Revolutionary Tribunal.
tr: At the same hours, while fifty-two people awaited their fate, Madam Defarge, along with Jacques Three from the Committee of Vengeance and Revolution, had formed a dark and ominous council.
es: At the very hour when the fifty-two were awaiting the moment to form too close a relationship with the Guillotine, Madame Defarge, The Vengeance, and Jacques Three were holding a sinister secret council.

en: Not in the wine-shop did Madame Defarge confer with these ministers, but in the shed of the wood-sawyer, erst a mender of roads.
vi: Madame Defarge did not consult with these executors at the tavern but in the hut of the sawyer, who was formerly a road mender.
tr: Madam Defarge was meeting with these deputies not in the wine shop, but in the hut of the sawyer who was formerly a road worker.
es: The conference did not take place in the tavern, but in the wood-sawyer's workshop, who had once been a road mender, and he was not admitted to it, but forced to remain outside at a respectable distance.

en: The sawyer himself did not participate in the conference, but abided at a little distance, like an outer satellite who was not to speak until required, or to offer an opinion until invited.
vi: The sawyer was not allowed to participate in the meeting but stood waiting at a distance, like a lowly subordinate who could only speak when permitted, and could only have an opinion when needed.
tr: The sawyer did not personally attend this meeting; like a satellite that neither spoke unless asked nor expressed opinions unless solicited, he waited a little distance away.
es: The conference did not take place in the tavern, but in the wood-sawyer's workshop, who had once been a road mender, and he was not admitted to it, but forced to remain outside at a respectable distance.

en: “But our Defarge,” said Jacques Three, “is undoubtedly a good Republican?
vi: − But our Defarge, - Jacques Ba said, - is clearly a good Republican, isn't he?
tr: "But our Defarge," said Jacques Three, "is undoubtedly a good Republican, isn't he?"
es: —In any case, our Defarge is a good republican, isn't he?—asked Santiago the Third.

en: Eh?”
vi: Why so? −
tr: "But our Defarge," said Jacques Three, "is undoubtedly a good Republican, isn't he?"
es: —In any case, our Defarge is a good republican, isn't he?—asked Santiago the Third.

en: “There is no better,” the voluble Vengeance protested in her shrill notes, “in France.”
vi: No one is better in this France, - the shrill, rapid protest of the Goddess of Vengeance replied.
tr: Chatterbox Revenge shouted in a shrill voice, "There is no one better than him in France."
es: —There is none better in all of France—responded La Venganza warmly.

en: “Peace, little Vengeance,” said Madame Defarge, laying her hand with a slight frown on her lieutenant’s lips, “hear me speak.
vi: − Quiet now, Goddess of Vengeance, - Madame Defarge gently frowned and placed her hand on her assistant's lips - listen to me.
tr: Madam Defarge, with her eyebrows slightly furrowed, brought her hand to her assistant's lips and said, "Calm down, Vengeance, listen to me carefully.
es: —Calm down, my dear Vengeance—replied the innkeeper, placing a hand on her lieutenant's arm and slightly furrowing her brow. —Before expressing opinions, it's advisable that you listen to what I'm going to say.

en: My husband, fellow-citizen, is a good Republican and a bold man; he has deserved well of the Republic, and possesses its confidence.
vi: My husband, Citizen Defarge, is a good Republican and a brave man; he deserves to be valued and trusted by the Republic.
tr: Citizen husband, is a good Republican and a brave man; he has rendered great services to the Republic and has earned its trust.
es: My husband, as a citizen, is a good republican and a man of valor; he has served the Republic well and has its trust; but my husband has his weaknesses, and one of the greatest, surely the greatest, is his fondness for the doctor.

en: But my husband has his weaknesses, and he is so weak as to relent towards this Doctor.”
vi: But my husband also has a weakness, he is so soft-hearted that he feels pity for that old doctor.
tr: But he has some weaknesses, he is weak enough to show mercy to this Doctor."
es: My husband, as a citizen, is a good republican and a man of valor; he has served the Republic well and has its trust; but my husband has his weaknesses, and one of the greatest, surely the greatest, is his fondness for the doctor.

en: “It is a great pity,” croaked Jacques
vi: − What a pity, - Jacques Ba said gruffly, shaking his head doubtfully, his cruel fingers hovering over the hungry mouth.
tr: Jacques
es: —It's a disgrace!

en: Three, dubiously shaking his head, with his cruel fingers at his hungry mouth; “it is not quite like a good citizen; it is a thing to regret.”
vi: Then he is not exactly a good Citizen; truly unfortunate.
tr: Three shouted in a hoarse voice, "What a pity," and shook his head skeptically with his cruel fingers in his open mouth; "this is not befitting a good citizen at all; very bad."
es: —exclaimed Santiago Tercero, shaking his head with an enigmatic expression. —Those weaknesses are unbecoming of a good citizen... What a pity!

en: “See you,” said madame, “I care nothing for this Doctor, I.
vi: − You see, - said Madame Defarge, - I don't care about this doctor.
tr: "Look," said the madam, "I don't care about this Doctor at all.
es: —What matters least to me is the doctor—replied the innkeeper.—

en: He may wear his head or lose it, for any interest I have in him; it is all one to me.
vi: Whether he loses his head or not, it doesn't matter to me.
tr: Whether his head stays or goes, it's all the same to me.
es: As for me, he can keep his head on his shoulders or lose it; it makes no difference to me; but the Evrémonde race must be exterminated, it must disappear from the earth, and consequently, the wife and daughter must follow the husband and father to the other world.

en: But, the Evrémonde people are to be exterminated, and the wife and child must follow the husband and father.”
vi: But the Evrémonde family must be exterminated, his wife and child must follow him to the grave.
tr: But no one from the Evremonde family should remain; his wife and child should follow him."
es: As for me, he can keep his head on his shoulders or lose it; it makes no difference to me; but the Evrémonde race must be exterminated, it must disappear from the earth, and consequently, the wife and daughter must follow the husband and father to the other world.

en: “She has a fine head for it,” croaked Jacques Three.
vi: − His wife has a head fit for the guillotine, - Jacques Three bellowed.
tr: Jacques Three shouted again in his hoarse voice, "The woman's head is too beautiful for this job."
es: —And what a beautiful head it is, if there ever was one; a head that is screaming for the Guillotine—replied Santiago Tercero.

en: “I have seen blue eyes and golden hair there, and they looked charming when Samson held them up.”
vi: - I have seen the heads of women with blue eyes and blonde hair, and each one was appealing when Samson raised it.
tr: "I had seen blue eyes and blonde hair there before; when Samson lifted them, they looked magnificent."

en: Ogre that he was, he spoke like an epicure.
vi: This bloodthirsty person speaks like a gourmet.
tr: He spoke with all his cruelty, like a connoisseur of taste.
es: There is nothing as thrilling as seeing a little head with blue eyes and golden hair hanging from the hands of our good Samson.

en: Madame Defarge cast down her eyes, and reflected a little.
vi: Madame Defarge bowed her head and thought for a moment.
tr: Madam Defarge lowered her eyes and thought for a while.
es: Mrs. Defarge lowered her eyes and remained in a reflective attitude for a few moments.

en: “The child also,” observed Jacques Three, with a meditative enjoyment of his words, “has golden hair and blue eyes.
vi: − The child too, - said Jacques Ba, savoring each word with delight, - also has blond hair and blue eyes.
tr: Jacques Üç, "Also, the child has blonde hair and blue eyes," he said with absent-minded pleasure, "and we don't often see children there.
es: —The girl also has golden hair and blue eyes—replied Santiago Tercero.

en: And we seldom have a child there.
vi: I rarely see children being sent to the guillotine.
tr: Jacques Üç, "Also, the child has blonde hair and blue eyes," he said with absent-minded pleasure, "and we don't often see children there.
es: —Moreover, we are rarely granted the pleasure of seeing girls of her age on the stage.

en: It is a pretty sight!”
vi: It must be known!
tr: It's a pleasant sight!"
es: It will be a magnificent spectacle.

en: “In a word,” said Madame Defarge, coming out of her short abstraction, “I cannot trust my husband in this matter.
vi: - In short, - Madame Defarge had passed her moment of reflection, - in this matter, I do not trust my husband.
tr: Madam Defarge, "In short," she said, snapping out of her reverie, "I cannot trust my husband on this matter.
es: —Speaking frankly—said the innkeeper's wife, shaking off her abstraction,—in this matter, I do not trust my husband.

en: Not only do I feel, since last night, that I dare not confide to him the details of my projects; but also I feel that if I delay, there is danger of his giving warning, and then they might escape.”
vi: Since last night, not only do I feel that I cannot disclose the details of this plan to him; but I also see that if I hesitate, there is a risk he will alert them to escape.
tr: I've been thinking since last night, and it's not a good idea to tell him the details of my plan. Moreover, if I delay, there's a danger that my husband might warn them, and thus they could escape."
es: Not only am I convinced since last night that I should not confide the details of my plans to him, but also that, if we lose any time, he is very capable of warning them of the danger they are in, in which case, they will escape us.

en: “That must never be,” croaked Jacques Three; “no one must escape.
vi: − Absolutely not, - Jacques Ba exclaimed, - no one is allowed to escape.
tr: "Such a thing must never happen," shouted Jacques Three; "no one should escape.
es: —They won't escape, no... not one or half!

en: We have not half enough as it is.
vi: At the moment, we have only half the number that needs to be executed.
tr: We are only at half the number we want.
es: —grumbled Santiago Tercero.—They will all fall, to the last one!

en: We ought to have six score a day.”
vi: We should be executing one hundred and twenty heads each day.
tr: A hundred and twenty heads must roll every day."
es: We must reach sixty daily!

en: “In a word,” Madame Defarge went on, “my husband has not my reason for pursuing this family to annihilation, and I have not his reason for regarding this Doctor with any sensibility.
vi: − In short, - Madam Defarge continued, - my husband has no reason like I do to exterminate this entire family, and I have no reason like he does to pity the old doctor.
tr: "In short," continued Madam Defarge, "my husband does not care as much as I do whether this whole family is exterminated, and I am not in a position to show understanding to the Doctor.
es: —In a word—added the innkeeper's wife,—neither my husband has the reasons I do to demand the total extermination of that race, nor do I have the reasons he does to treat the doctor with consideration.

en: I must act for myself, therefore.
vi: Therefore, I must act on my own.
tr: Therefore, I must fend for myself.
es: Consequently, I must disregard him and act on my own.

en: Come hither, little citizen.”
vi: Come here, little Citizen.
tr: Come here, little citizen."
es: You may enter, citizen—she concluded, addressing the sawyer.

en: The wood-sawyer, who held her in the respect, and himself in the submission, of mortal fear, advanced with his hand to his red cap.
vi: The sawyer, holding a red hat in his hand, approached, respectfully and obsequiously before Madame Defarge out of fear of death.
tr: Under the influence of the mortal fear he felt, the sawyer, showing respect and obedience to the woman, approached with his red hat in hand.
es: He obeyed, trembling, the sawyer, who appeared with the red cap in hand.

en: “Touching those signals, little citizen,” said Madame Defarge, sternly, “that she made to the prisoners; you are ready to bear witness to them this very day?”
vi: − Citizen Short, - Madame Defarge's voice was cold, - regarding the matter of Madame Evrémonde signaling to the prisoners; are you ready to testify today? −
tr: Madam Defarge, "Little citizen, regarding the signals the woman sent to the prisoners," she said in a stern tone, "are you ready to testify?""
es: —Regarding the signals you saw that woman making to the prisoners, are you willing to support them with your statement at any time, citizen?—asked the innkeeper.

en: “Ay, ay, why not!” cried the sawyer.
vi: Yes, yes, why not! - The wood-sawyer exclaimed.
tr: "Of course, why not!" shouted the sawyer.
es: —Why not?

en: “Every day, in all weathers, from two to four, always signalling, sometimes with the little one, sometimes without.
vi: - Every day, rain or shine, from two to four in the afternoon, she always signals, sometimes with a child, sometimes alone.
tr: "The woman, regardless of snow or cold, sent signals every day from two to four o'clock, sometimes with a child, sometimes without.
es: From here, I have seen her every day, rainy or clear, cold or hot, from two in the afternoon until four, sometimes with the girl, other times alone, and always making signals.

en: I know what I know.
vi: I know for sure.
tr: I know what it was.
es: These very eyes have seen it.

en: I have seen with my eyes.”
vi: I saw it with my own eyes.
tr: I saw it with my own eyes."
es: These very eyes have seen it.

en: He made all manner of gestures while he spoke, as if in incidental imitation of some few of the great diversity of signals that he had never seen.
vi: He spoke while gesticulating wildly, as if mimicking various random signs that he actually did not see.
tr: While saying these things, he made all sorts of hand and arm gestures, as if he were repeating some of the various signs he had never actually seen.
es: While speaking, he made a great variety of gestures with his hands that I had never seen before.

en: “Clearly plots,” said Jacques Three.
vi: − The scheme is clear, - said Jacques Three.
tr: "It is clear that there is a conspiracy," said Jacques Three.
es: —Plots... machinations... it's undeniable—replied Santiago Tercero.

en: “Transparently!”
tr: "Very obvious!"
es: —Can we count on the jury?—asked the innkeeper.

en: “There is no doubt of the Jury?” inquired Madame Defarge, letting her eyes turn to him with a gloomy smile.
vi: There's no mistaking it! − Is the jury certain of that? - Madame Defarge turned to ask this person, with a sinister smile.
tr: Madam Defarge, with a sorrowful smile, turned her eyes to him and asked, "Well, what will the jury say to this?"
es: —Not at all.

en: “Rely upon the patriotic Jury, dear citizeness.
vi: − Trust the patriotic jury, Citizeness.
tr: "You can trust the patriotic jury, dear citizen.
es: It is a patriotic jury, citizen.

en: I answer for my fellow-Jurymen.”
vi: I vouch for the Citizen jurors.
tr: I say this on behalf of my friends on the jury."
es: I vouch for all its members.

en: “Now, let me see,” said Madame Defarge, pondering again.
vi: − Now let's see, - Madame Defarge pondered again.
tr: "Wait a moment," said Madam Defarge and fell into thoughts again.
es: —Another thing...—added the innkeeper, pondering. —

en: “Yet once more!
vi: - Another matter!
tr: "Alright then!
es: Let's see.....

en: Can I spare this Doctor to my husband?
vi: Can I spare the old doctor for my husband's sake?
tr: Shall we spare that Doctor for my husband's sake?
es: Can I forgive the doctor for my husband's sake?

en: I have no feeling either way.
vi: I don't care about him.
tr: For me, his presence or absence does not matter.
es: It's all the same to me... the doctor is indifferent to me...

en: Can I spare him?”
vi: Can I spare him? −
tr: But shall we spare him for my husband's sake?"
es: Can I forgive him?

en: “He would count as one head,” observed Jacques Three, in a low voice.
vi: He counts as a head too, - Jacques Three whispered.
tr: "Another head for the doctor," said Jacques Three, in a low voice.
es: —It would be one more head—observed Santiago Tercero.

en: “We really have not heads enough; it would be a pity, I think.”
vi: - At the moment, we are short of heads; it would be a waste to let him go, I think.
tr: "We haven't reached a sufficient number of heads yet; I think it would be a pity."
es: —Heads are beginning to be scarce... soon they will be even scarcer... I think it would be a shame to pardon him.

en: “He was signalling with her when I saw her,” argued Madame Defarge; “I cannot speak of one without the other; and I must not be silent, and trust the case wholly to him, this little citizen here.
vi: − He also made signs along with his daughter when I met her, - Mrs. Defarge reasoned. - I cannot accuse one without accusing the other; and I cannot remain silent and leave this matter entirely to that man, Citizen Short.
tr: "When I saw him, he was also signaling next to his daughter," Madam Defarge supported; "it wouldn't be right to accuse the daughter and not the father; that's why I must not remain silent and should not place all the blame on this little citizen.
es: —When I found him in front of the place where we are, he was making the same signs as his daughter—said Mrs. Defarge. —If I speak of one, I must necessarily speak of the other. On the other hand, it is not possible for me to remain silent, so I place all the responsibility of the case on this citizen. He will declare whatever he wants.

en: For, I am not a bad witness.”
vi: Because I am also a legitimate witness.
tr: I'm not a bad witness either."
es: As for me, the only thing I can say is that I will never be a false witness.

en: The Vengeance and Jacques Three vied with each other in their fervent protestations that she was the most admirable and marvellous of witnesses.
vi: The Goddess of Vengeance and Jacques Three loudly competed to praise Madame Defarge as the most wonderful and admirable witness.
tr: Revenge and Jacques Three, heatedly objected and competed with each other to say that the madam was the most commendable and magnificent witness.
es: La Venganza and Santiago Tercero demonstrated as clear as daylight that, far from being a false witness, they had always been a mirror of admirable and wonderful witnesses, and the citizen sawyer, not wanting to be left behind, protested to heaven and earth that Mrs. Defarge was a celestial witness.

en: The little citizen, not to be outdone, declared her to be a celestial witness.
vi: Not to be outdone, the short Citizen also called her a divine witness.
tr: The little citizen, on the other hand, claimed she was a divine witness in order not to be left out.
es: La Venganza and Santiago Tercero demonstrated as clear as daylight that, far from being a false witness, they had always been a mirror of admirable and wonderful witnesses, and the citizen sawyer, not wanting to be left behind, protested to heaven and earth that Mrs. Defarge was a celestial witness.

en: “He must take his chance,” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − You must accept the risks, - said Madame Defarge. -
tr: "Let the man try his luck," said Madam Defarge.
es: —Let his fate be fulfilled! —said the innkeeper.

en: “No, I cannot spare him!
vi: No, I cannot spare him!
tr: "Alright, I won't keep him separate from the others!
es: —No; I cannot forgive him...

en: You are engaged at three o’clock; you are going to see the batch of to-day executed.
vi: You have an appointment at three o'clock; you will go to see the execution of the people today...
tr: At three o'clock, you are on duty; you will go to watch the group to be executed today.
es: I suppose, citizen, that you cannot make yourself available at three today, for I believe you won't deny yourself the pleasure of watching today's batch, right?

en: —You?”
vi: And you?
tr: –And you?"
es: I suppose, citizen, that you cannot make yourself available at three today, for I believe you won't deny yourself the pleasure of watching today's batch, right?

en: The question was addressed to the wood-sawyer, who hurriedly replied in the affirmative: seizing the occasion to add that he was the most ardent of Republicans, and that he would be in effect the most desolate of Republicans, if anything prevented him from enjoying the pleasure of smoking his afternoon pipe in the contemplation of the droll national barber.
vi: This question was directed at the wood-sawyer, who hastily responded affirmatively and took the opportunity to add that he was the most enthusiastic Republican, and in fact, would be the most miserable Republican if anything prevented him from enjoying the pleasure of smoking his pipe every afternoon while watching the fun of the national razor.
tr: The question was directed at the sawyer, and he immediately responded positively. He was already looking for an opportunity to declare himself the most enthusiastic Republican, and if anything were to deprive him of the pleasure of puffing on his pipe while watching that peculiar national barber in the afternoon, he would turn into the most miserable Republican.
es: The sawyer immediately replied that he would not miss such a beautiful spectacle for anything in the world, which gave him the opportunity to add that he was the most fervent republican, and that he would consider himself the most desolate of republicans if one day he was prevented from smoking his pipe while watching the beautiful operation of the National Barber's Razor.

en: He was so very demonstrative herein, that he might have been suspected (perhaps was, by the dark eyes that looked contemptuously at him out of Madame Defarge’s head) of having his small individual fears for his own personal safety, every hour in the day.
vi: He said this so fervently that it could be suspected that he himself feared for his own safety every day and every hour; and from the dark look of contempt that Madame Defarge gave him, it seemed she might also be suspecting this.
tr: His mannerisms were so exaggerated while saying these things that one might suspect he had small personal fears about his own safety at every moment (which, judging by the contemptuous dark eyes Madam Defarge fixed on him, was probably the case).
es: The sawyer immediately replied that he would not miss such a beautiful spectacle for anything in the world, which gave him the opportunity to add that he was the most fervent republican, and that he would consider himself the most desolate of republicans if one day he was prevented from smoking his pipe while watching the beautiful operation of the National Barber's Razor.

en: “I,” said madame, “am equally engaged at the same place.
vi: She said: − I also have business there.
tr: "Me too," said the madam, "I will be there.
es: —I will also attend—replied the innkeeper.

en: After it is over—say at eight to-night—come you to me, in Saint Antoine, and we will give information against these people at my Section.”
vi: After it's all done, come see me at eight o'clock tonight, at Saint Antoine, and we will go denounce these people at my district's Committee.
tr: When the work is done – that is, around eight in the evening – come to me, to St Antoine, so we can report these to the people in my area."
es: —After the performance ends... at eight... yes; it's a good time... at eight you will come to find me at San Antonio to denounce those individuals in my section.

en: The wood-sawyer said he would be proud and flattered to attend the citizeness.
vi: The sawyer said he would be proud and honored to accompany Citizeness Defarge. Citizeness
tr: The sawyer said he would be greatly honored and pleased to serve her.
es: The sawyer replied that it would be a great honor and immense satisfaction for him to attend the appointment given by the lady.

en: The citizeness looking at him, he became embarrassed, evaded her glance as a small dog would have done, retreated among his wood, and hid his confusion over the handle of his saw.
vi: Defarge glared at him, and he nervously avoided her gaze like a frightened dog, retreating to stand among his pile of wood, hiding his embarrassment behind the handle of his saw.
tr: But then, feeling ashamed of her gaze, he scurried out of her sight like a small dog and retreated among his logs, taking up his saw to try to conceal the turmoil within him.
es: The sawyer replied that it would be a great honor and immense satisfaction for him to attend the appointment given by the lady.

en: Madame Defarge beckoned the Juryman and The Vengeance a little nearer to the door, and there expounded her further views to them thus:
vi: Madame Defarge signaled to the juryman and the Vengeance to move closer to the door and explained her intention more clearly to them: −
tr: Madam Defarge signaled to the jury member and Revenge to come a little closer to the door and elaborated on her thoughts to them:
es: Mrs. Defarge approached the workshop door, signaled to Santiago Tercero and La Venganza, and once they were by her side, she clearly explained her points of view to them.

en: “She will now be at home, awaiting the moment of his death.
vi: His wife will be at home now, waiting for her husband to die.
tr: "His wife will arrive home soon, waiting for her husband's death.
es: —Surely she is at this moment in her house, waiting for the news of her husband's death—he said.

en: She will be mourning and grieving.
vi: She will mourn and grieve.
tr: She mourns and sheds tears.
es: —In her pain and despair, she will not only mourn the misfortune that afflicts her, but she will also criticize the justice of the Republic.

en: She will be in a state of mind to impeach the justice of the Republic.
vi: She will be in a state of violating the laws of the Republic.
tr: She is now in a state of doubting the justice of the Republic.
es: —In her pain and despair, she will not only mourn the misfortune that afflicts her, but she will also criticize the justice of the Republic.

en: She will be full of sympathy with its enemies.
vi: It will fully reveal its affection for the national enemy.
tr: Therefore, she has sympathy for its enemies.
es: All her sympathies will be with the enemies of the people; thus, I will go to see her without losing a moment.

en: I will go to her.”
vi: I will go to its place.
tr: I will go to her."
es: All her sympathies will be with the enemies of the people; thus, I will go to see her without losing a moment.

en: “What an admirable woman; what an adorable woman!” exclaimed Jacques
vi: − You are truly admirable; you are truly admirable! - Jacques Ba exclaimed joyfully.
tr: Jacques Üç, in a drunken state, exclaimed, "What a magnificent woman, what a magnificent woman!"
es: —What an admirable woman! What an adorable patriot!

en: Three, rapturously.
vi: − Oh, how adorable!
tr: Jacques Üç, in a drunken state, exclaimed, "What a magnificent woman, what a magnificent woman!"
es: —exclaimed Santiago Tercero, whose enthusiasm reached the indescribable.

en: “Ah, my cherished!” cried The Vengeance; and embraced her.
vi: - The Vengeance Goddess exclaimed as she hugged Madame Defarge.
tr: Revenge also shouted, "Ah, you are a saint!" and embraced her.
es: Revenge embraced her, crying in a rapture of admiration.

en: “Take you my knitting,” said Madame Defarge, placing it in her lieutenant’s hands, “and have it ready for me in my usual seat.
vi: − Bring my knitting, - Madame Defarge handed the items to her assistant, - and have it ready for me at my usual seat.
tr: Madam Defarge said, "Take my knitting," and handed it to her assistant, "and put it where I always sit."
es: —Take my knitting—replied Madame Defarge, placing it in the hands of The Vengeance,—and have it ready for me in my usual seat.

en: Keep me my usual chair.
vi: Keep my seat as usual.
tr: "Hold my usual chair for me."
es: —Take my knitting—replied Madame Defarge, placing it in the hands of The Vengeance,—and have it ready for me in my usual seat.

en: Go you there, straight, for there will probably be a greater concourse than usual, to-day.”
vi: Go there now, go immediately, because there will be more spectators today than usual.
tr: "Go there directly now, there might be a bigger crowd than usual today.""
es: Go straight there, don't waste time, as it is almost certain that there will be more people than usual today.

en: “I willingly obey the orders of my Chief,” said The Vengeance with alacrity, and kissing her cheek.
vi: − Ready to obey the leader, - The Vengeful Goddess eagerly said and kissed Madame Defarge on the cheek. -
tr: With enthusiasm for revenge, "I will gladly carry out your orders, chief," he said, kissing him on the cheeks.
es: —With all my soul, I will obey my boss's orders—answered La Venganza, kissing the barmaid on the cheek.

en: “You will not be late?”
vi: You won't be late, will you?
tr: "You won't be late, right?"
es: — Will you take long?

en: “I shall be there before the commencement.”
vi: − I will be there before it starts.
tr: "I'll be out of there before they start."
es: —I'll be there before the show starts.

en: “And before the tumbrils arrive.
vi: − And before the executioner's cart arrives.
tr: Revenge, "Come before the cars arrive.
es: —I'll be there before the show starts.

en: Be sure you are there, my soul,” said The Vengeance, calling after her, for she had already turned into the street, “before the tumbrils arrive!”
vi: Make sure to come early, dear, the Vengeance Goddess called after her, as the other woman had already stepped onto the street - before the executioner's cart arrives!
tr: Don't be late, my dear," he shouted after her, for madam had already turned into the street "before the cars arrive!"
es: —Try to arrive before the carts—replied La Venganza.

en: Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand, to imply that she heard, and might be relied upon to arrive in good time, and so went through the mud, and round the corner of the prison wall.
vi: With a slight wave to indicate she had heard and would surely be on time, Madame Defarge walked through the mud and rounded the corner of the prison wall.
tr: Madam Defarge lightly waved her hand as if to indicate that she had heard and would be there on time, and trudged through the mud, turning the corner of the prison wall.
es: The tavern keeper left the workshop at a brisk pace, soon disappearing from sight.

en: The Vengeance and the Juryman, looking after her as she walked away, were highly appreciative of her fine figure, and her superb moral endowments.
vi: The Vengeance Goddess and the juryman watched her, admiring the graceful figure and resolute spirit of the woman who was walking away.
tr: As Madam walked away, Vengeance and the jury member, who were watching her, spoke with great admiration about her graceful demeanor and superior morals.
es: Many were the women in that era whose moral silhouettes cannot be contemplated, despite the distance of time, without horror and disgust; but among them, there was none so inhuman, so fierce, so ruthless, as the one we now leave heading to the residence of the unfortunate Dr. Manette.

en: There were many women at that time, upon whom the time laid a dreadfully disfiguring hand; but, there was not one among them more to be dreaded than this ruthless woman, now taking her way along the streets.
vi: In those times, the terrifying molding hand of fate had caused many women to become horribly corrupted, but none were as frightening as the cruel woman walking down the road.
tr: In that era, there were many women who had been worn down by the harsh effects of the times; but none were as terrifying as this ruthless woman who marched forward resolutely.
es: Many were the women in that era whose moral silhouettes cannot be contemplated, despite the distance of time, without horror and disgust; but among them, there was none so inhuman, so fierce, so ruthless, as the one we now leave heading to the residence of the unfortunate Dr. Manette.

en: Of a strong and fearless character, of shrewd sense and readiness, of great determination, of that kind of beauty which not only seems to impart to its possessor firmness and animosity, but to strike into others an instinctive recognition of those qualities; the troubled time would have heaved her up, under any circumstances.
vi: With a strong and tenacious personality, sharp and quick-witted, a heart of stone, and even her beauty exuding hatred and determination, anyone who saw her would immediately recognize her as a product of chaotic times.
tr: Her strong and fearless character, solid intuition and swiftness, and tremendous determination not only made her appear stern and harsh but also allowed her beauty, which instinctively highlighted these traits, to become even more pronounced during these challenging times.
es: She was a woman inaccessible to fear, inflexible, intelligent, cunning, and resolute, endowed with that special beauty that instills in the spirit of its possessor a firmness and animosity that forces others to pay instinctive homage to the expressed qualities.

en: But, imbued from her childhood with a brooding sense of wrong, and an inveterate hatred of a class, opportunity had developed her into a tigress.
vi: But from a young age, she harbored a deep awareness of injustice and profound class hatred, which the circumstances had turned into a fierce tiger.
tr: Since childhood, she had turned into a tigress due to her contemplation of injustices and the class hatred that had taken root within her.
es: Had she lived in a less troubled time, had she moved in a different theater, who knows if she might have been the glory of her sex; but a victim from childhood of social injustices, grown in an atmosphere of implacable class hatred, she became a tiger.

en: She was absolutely without pity.
vi: She knew no compassion.
tr: There wasn't the slightest bit of mercy in her.
es: She was utterly devoid of pity; and if ever virtue nested in her soul, she had extirpated it many years before, leaving not a trace of it.

en: If she had ever had the virtue in her, it had quite gone out of her.
vi: If she ever had any compassion, that sentiment had long since died.
tr: If she ever possessed this virtue once, it was now completely gone.
es: She was utterly devoid of pity; and if ever virtue nested in her soul, she had extirpated it many years before, leaving not a trace of it.

en: It was nothing to her, that an innocent man was to die for the sins of his forefathers; she saw, not him, but them.
vi: It meant nothing to her that an innocent person had to die for the sins of their forefathers; she did not see this person but only saw the evil predecessor.
tr: It meant nothing to him that an innocent person was going to death because of the sins of their ancestors; it wasn't just him in front of him, they were all there.
es: What did it matter that an innocent person died for sins committed by their ancestors? Her relentless fury did not see the first, but the last.

en: It was nothing to her, that his wife was to be made a widow and his daughter an orphan; that was insufficient punishment, because they were her natural enemies and her prey, and as such had no right to live.
