vi: It meant nothing to her that this person's wife would become a widow and this person's daughter would become an orphan. She only knew that the punishment was not enough, because they were natural enemies and her prey, therefore they had no right to live.
tr: It also meant nothing to him that his wife would be a widow and his daughter an orphan; this punishment was too little, because they were his natural enemies and prey; therefore, they had no right to live.
es: Nor did it matter to leave a poor woman widowed or her daughter orphaned; rather, she considered the punishment insufficient since it involved her natural enemies, her prey, beings who had no right to live.

en: To appeal to her, was made hopeless by her having no sense of pity, even for herself.
vi: Appealing to her was hopeless because this woman no longer had any compassion, not even for herself.
tr: Since there was no mercy within him, there was no point in begging him, not even for himself.
es: Trying to appease her was useless, for she lacked the ability to feel compassion, not only for others but even for herself.

en: If she had been laid low in the streets, in any of the many encounters in which she had been engaged, she would not have pitied herself; nor, if she had been ordered to the axe to-morrow, would she have gone to it with any softer feeling than a fierce desire to change places with the man who sent her there.
vi: If she were to collapse in the middle of a battle she participated in, she wouldn't regret it; and if she herself were to be sent to the guillotine tomorrow, she would feel nothing but a fierce desire to behead the person who brought her to the scaffold.
tr: If he were to be defeated and laid low in one of those frequent struggles in the streets, he would not pity himself, or if he were to go to the guillotine tomorrow, he would feel nothing but the desire to send the man who sent him there to death in his place.
es: If in any of the many encounters in which she took part she had fallen under the hand of her enemies, she would have accepted her misfortune as something natural and ordinary, and if they had forced her to climb the fatal staircase ending at the guillotine, she would have offered her neck without any other feelings arising in her fierce soul than a rabid desire to trade places with the man who sent her there.

en: Such a heart Madame Defarge carried under her rough robe.
vi: That is the sentiment that Madame Defarge harbors beneath her tattered cloak.
tr: Here is Madam Defarge, carrying such a heart under that coarse attire.
es: Such was the heart that beat beneath the coarse dress of Madame Defarge.

en: Carelessly worn, it was a becoming robe enough, in a certain weird way, and her dark hair looked rich under her coarse red cap.
vi: The wrinkled cloth, draped haphazardly over her body to form a cloak, was peculiar, and her jet-black hair seemed even more lustrous under the coarse red hat.
tr: The outfit she wore carelessly suited her in a strange way, and her black hair looked much fuller under that cheap red cap.
es: Dirty, ragged, it was still a dress, even if it presented a gloomy appearance, just as her abundant mass of black hair, poorly contained within the red cap, did not fail to offer some attraction.

en: Lying hidden in her bosom, was a loaded pistol.
vi: Hidden in her chest was a loaded pistol.
tr: She had a loaded pistol hidden in her bosom.
es: Hidden in her bosom she always carried a loaded pistol and at her waist a long, sharp dagger.

en: Lying hidden at her waist, was a sharpened dagger.
vi: Concealed at her waist was a sharpened short sword.
tr: And a sharp dagger at her waist.
es: Hidden in her bosom she always carried a loaded pistol and at her waist a long, sharp dagger.

en: Thus accoutred, and walking with the confident tread of such a character, and with the supple freedom of a woman who had habitually walked in her girlhood, bare-foot and bare-legged, on the brown sea-sand, Madame Defarge took her way along the streets.
vi: Equipped as such, Madame Defarge set out with the confident stride of a determined person, with the comfortable grace of a woman who had been accustomed to walking barefoot on brown sand since childhood.
tr: Madam Defarge, fully equipped like this, moved through the streets with the confident demeanor of a character of this style and the agile ease of someone accustomed to walking barefoot and bare-legged on the beach since her girlhood.
es: Thus attired, walking with a confident step, with that freedom of movement typical of a woman who since childhood has gone wherever her desires or whims have taken her, barefoot and bare-legged, the tavern keeper Defarge left street after street behind her.

en: Now, when the journey of the travelling coach, at that very moment waiting for the completion of its load, had been planned out last night, the difficulty of taking Miss Pross in it had much engaged mr Lorry’s attention.
vi: At this moment, as the carriage on the road was waiting to complete its journey, the escape plan for Miss Pross and Jerry Cruncher had been carefully devised; this was the pressing issue that had caused Mr. Lorry to worry the previous night.
tr: While making plans for the carriage that was now waiting to take its final load and for this journey, the matter of how to take Miss Pross had greatly occupied Mr. Lorry's mind last night.
es: It will be necessary for us to make a small digression in order to clarify some points that the reader might find obscure. The previous night, when Lorry was finalizing the preparations for the fugitives' journey, the difficulty of bringing Miss Pross with him was a source of great concern for him.

en: It was not merely desirable to avoid overloading the coach, but it was of the highest importance that the time occupied in examining it and its passengers, should be reduced to the utmost; since their escape might depend on the saving of only a few seconds here and there.
vi: Having Miss Pross follow later would be the best way to lighten the load on the carriage and minimize the time spent on document checks and passenger interrogations; because the success of this escape depended on shaving off every second along the way.
tr: This was necessary not only to avoid overloading the carriage but also to minimize the time spent during the inspection of the carriage and passengers at the barricades; for their escape could depend on the few seconds gained here and there.
es: Not only was it highly desirable to avoid excess baggage that might hinder their progress, but also to minimize the time spent at the Barrier for examining documents and identifying travelers, as the salvation of all could depend on taking advantage of or losing mere seconds of time.

en: Finally, he had proposed, after anxious consideration, that Miss Pross and Jerry, who were at liberty to leave the city, should leave it at three o’clock in the lightest-wheeled conveyance known to that period.
vi: Finally, after careful consideration, he suggested that Miss Pross and Jerry, who were the two people free to leave the capital, should depart at three o'clock using the fastest carriage available at that time.
tr: After a series of anxious thoughts, Mr. Lorry finally suggested that Miss Pross and Jerry, who had permits to leave the city, should depart at three o'clock by the fastest means available at that time.
es: After long considerations, and not without carefully weighing the disadvantages and advantages, he had proposed leaving Miss Pross and Jeremiah Lapa, who could leave the city whenever it suited them, with orders to start their journey at three in the morning, using one of the lightest carriages then known.

en: Unencumbered with luggage, they would soon overtake the coach, and, passing it and preceding it on the road, would order its horses in advance, and greatly facilitate its progress during the precious hours of the night, when delay was the most to be dreaded.
vi: Without being burdened by luggage, they would quickly catch up with the four-horse carriage, overtake it, and run ahead to hire horses in advance; this way, they would save precious time during the night, which is usually when the most dreadful delays occur.
tr: Since they had no luggage, they would catch up with them shortly, or even get ahead to prepare the horses in advance, and while everyone was in fear of being late, they would have made this journey in the valuable hours of the night much easier.
es: Free from the encumbrance of luggage, they would soon catch up with the gentlemen, and might even leave them behind.

en: Seeing in this arrangement the hope of rendering real service in that pressing emergency, Miss Pross hailed it with joy.
vi: Seeing that this arrangement had the potential to aid the urgent situation, Ms. Pross gladly accepted.
tr: Miss Pross, who had the opportunity to provide a real service in this urgent and dangerous situation, welcomed all these arrangements with joy.
es: Miss Pross gladly accepted a proposition that offered her the opportunity to render some important service to her loved ones.

en: She and Jerry had beheld the coach start, had known who it was that Solomon brought, had passed some ten minutes in tortures of suspense, and were now concluding their arrangements to follow the coach, even as Madame Defarge, taking her way through the streets, now drew nearer and nearer to the else-deserted lodging in which they held their consultation.
vi: She and Jerry had seen Mr. Lorry's carriage depart, knew who Solomon had brought, endured ten tense and miserable minutes, and were now making the final arrangements to follow the earlier carriage. Meanwhile, Madame Defarge was making her way through the streets, getting closer and closer to the deserted house where only two servants were discussing.
tr: Together with Jerry, they had seen the departure of the carriage, understood who the person brought by Solomon was, and after writhing in curiosity for about ten minutes, they had followed the carriage as the final stage of the plan. Meanwhile, Madam Defarge, advancing through the streets, was getting closer to the deserted house where all those plans were made.
es: She and Jeremiah had met the person whom her brother Solomon had brought in a fainting state in a carriage, had seen off the travelers, had spent ten minutes in terrible anxiety, and were making the final preparations to set off and catch up with the carriage at the moment when the tavern keeper Defarge was approaching the house, with intentions that the readers know perfectly well.

en: “Now what do you think, mr Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose agitation was so great that she could hardly speak, or stand, or move, or live: “what do you think of our not starting from this courtyard?
vi: − What do you plan to do now, Mr. Cruncher, - said Miss Pross, so tense that she didn't know how to move or speak. - What do you think about not departing from this courtyard?
tr: "What do you think now, Mr. Cruncher?" said Miss Pross, she was so distressed that she could barely speak, stand, move, or even live; "Shouldn't we start our journey from this courtyard?
es: —What do you think, Mr. Lapa?—asked Miss Pross, whose agitation was so great that it neither let her speak, nor move, nor stand, nor live.— What do you think of our trip?

en: Another carriage having already gone from here to-day, it might awaken suspicion.”
vi: Another carriage leaving from here might arouse suspicion.
tr: A carriage already left from here today, it might arouse suspicion."
es: The departure of two carriages in such a short period of time is bound to arouse suspicion; at least, that is what I fear.

en: “My opinion, miss,” returned mr Cruncher, “is as you’re right.
vi: − What you said is right, - Cruncher replied.
tr: "If you ask me, madam," said Mr. Cruncher, "you are right.
es: —My opinion, miss, is that you are right—replied Lapa—.

en: Likewise wot I’ll stand by you, right or wrong.”
vi: - Whether it's right or wrong, I'll do as you say.
tr: In the end, whether right or wrong, I will do whatever you say."
es: I also believe that I will always support whatever you say, whether you are right or wrong.

en: “I am so distracted with fear and hope for our precious creatures,” said Miss Pross, wildly crying, “that I am incapable of forming any plan.
vi: − I am confused because I am both scared and hopeful for our dear loved ones, - Miss Pross cried. -
tr: "I have such great fear and hope for our dear ones," said Miss Pross, exclaiming excitedly, "that I am not in a position to make any plans.
es: —To such an extent do fear and hope for the fate of our masters drive me mad—replied Miss Pross, crying inconsolably,—that I am incapable of forming any rational plan.

en: Are you capable of forming any plan, my dear good mr Cruncher?”
vi: And can you think of anything, dear Mr. Cruncher? −
tr: Dear Mr. Cruncher, are you in a position to make a plan?"
es: And you, Mr. Lorry, my dear Mr. Lorry, do you feel capable of forming any reasonably rational plan?

en: “Respectin’ a future spear o’ life, miss,” returned mr Cruncher, “I hope so.
vi: As for the future, there is a lifetime to think about it, - Cruncher replied, - I hope so.
tr: "Well ma'am, something like this might happen in the future," said Mr. Cruncher, "but right now, in my old age, I can't think of anything.
es: —Regarding the afterlife, miss, I believe so—replied Jeremiah Lapa;—but regarding the present use of this blessed head I carry on my shoulders, I fear not.

en: Respectin’ any present use o’ this here blessed old head o’ mine, I think not.
vi: But right now, I am sure this head of mine can't think of anything.
tr: "Well ma'am, something like this might happen in the future," said Mr. Cruncher, "but right now, in my old age, I can't think of anything.
es: —Regarding the afterlife, miss, I believe so—replied Jeremiah Lapa;—but regarding the present use of this blessed head I carry on my shoulders, I fear not.

en: Would you do me the favour, miss, to take notice o’ two promises and wows wot it is my wishes fur to record in this here crisis?”
vi: Would you be so kind as to listen to two promises and also oaths that I want to be acknowledged right at this moment of crisis? −
tr: Would you like to hear the two promises I made and the oaths I took during this difficult time, ma'am?"
es: Would you, miss, take charge of two promises or vows that I wish to make, as a perpetual reminder of the crisis we are in?

en: “Oh, for gracious sake!” cried Miss Pross, still wildly crying, “record them at once, and get them out of the way, like an excellent man.”
vi: Oh, Lord! - Miss Pross exclaimed, still sobbing, - acknowledge them immediately, speak right away so we can discuss, please speak quickly.
tr: "Oh my God!" Miss Pross exclaimed excitedly again, "say it properly so we can continue on our way."
es: —God help us! —exclaimed Miss Pross, crying out loud.— Make those vows or promises immediately, do them without losing a moment like the good Christian you are.

en: “First,” said mr Cruncher, who was all in a tremble, and who spoke with an ashy and solemn visage, “them poor things well out o’ this, never no more will I do it, never no more!”
vi: − First, - Cruncher trembled all over, speaking with a pale, serious face, - if those poor people get out of this, I will never do that job again, never!
tr: "First of all," said the trembling Mr. Cruncher, with an ashen pale and serious face, "let these poor souls be saved, I will never do this job again, never!"
es: —The first thing I promise—said Lapa, trembling like a leaf and with a pathetic expression,—the first thing I swear, is never to do again some little things I used to do before... No; never again.

en: “I am quite sure, mr Cruncher,” returned Miss Pross, “that you never will do it again, whatever it is, and I beg you not to think it necessary to mention more particularly what it is.”
vi: − Surely, Mr. Cruncher, you will never do it again, whatever it is, and I ask you not to specify what that thing is.
tr: "Whatever that thing is you mentioned, Mr. Cruncher," said Miss Pross, "I am sure you will not do it again and please do not think that you need to explain to me what it is.""
es: —I am quite sure, Mr. Lapa, that he will never do them again, whatever those little things may be, which do not need to be mentioned.

en: “No, miss,” returned Jerry, “it shall not be named to you.
vi: − No, ma'am, I won't say anything.
tr: "No, madam," replied Jerry, "I will not tell you.
es: —No, miss; I will not mention them.

en: Second: them poor things well out o’ this, and never no more will I interfere with ms Cruncher’s flopping, never no more!”
vi: Secondly, if those poor people get out of this, I will never again stop Mrs. Cruncher, my wife, from sitting down to pray, never!
tr: Secondly, once these poor souls are freed, I will never interfere with Ms. Cruncher's work again!"
es: The second thing I promise, the second thing I swear, is not to involve myself again in Mrs. Lapa's prayers. No; I will never again prevent her from spending her entire life on her knees.

en: “Whatever housekeeping arrangement that may be,” said Miss Pross, striving to dry her eyes and compose herself, “I have no doubt it is best that ms Cruncher should have it entirely under her own superintendence.
vi: No matter what happens in your household, - Miss Pross tried to wipe her tears and calm down, - I am sure that Mrs. Cruncher has every right to do whatever she wants...
tr: "Whatever this matter is in your house," said Miss Pross, wiping the tears from her eyes and trying to pull herself together, "it would be best if Ms. Cruncher had complete control over it, of course.
es: —You will do very well.—replied Miss Pross, drying the tears that blinded her. — Let your wife take care of the household matters...

en: —O my poor darlings!”
vi: Oh, my poor dear ones!
tr: –Oh my poor ones!"
es: Oh... my poor young lady!

en: “I go so far as to say, miss, moreover,” proceeded mr Cruncher, with a most alarming tendency to hold forth as from a pulpit—“and let my words be took down and took to ms Cruncher through yourself—that wot my opinions respectin’ flopping has undergone a change, and that wot I only hope with all my heart as ms Cruncher may be a flopping at the present time.”
vi: − I even dare to say... - Cruncher continued in a long-winded and very worrying manner as if he were preaching, - ... and I want you to remember my words and tell Mrs. Cruncher... that my thoughts about her sitting down have changed and I sincerely hope that right now Mrs. Cruncher is at home sitting down.
tr: Leaning forward anxiously as if giving a speech from a podium, "In fact, madam," continued Mr. Cruncher, "you personally remember what I said and tell Ms. Cruncher, explain to her how much my thoughts on praying have changed and how much I now wish she were praying.""
es: —I believe it is appropriate to state, miss—replied Lapa as if he were speaking from the top of a pulpit,—and I would like you to convey my words to Mrs. Lapa, that my opinions regarding prayers have undergone a radical change, and that with all my heart I wish that Mrs. Lapa were on her knees and praying at this moment.

en: “There, there, there!
vi: − That's right, that's right!
tr: "Yes, yes, yes!
es: —Oh, yes!

en: I hope she is, my dear man,” cried the distracted Miss Pross, “and I hope she finds it answering her expectations.”
vi: I hope so too, sir, - cried out Ms. Pross in despair, - and I hope she gets everything she wishes for.
tr: I hope he is praying now, dear Jerry," cried the ecstatic Miss Pross, "I hope all his prayers are answered."
es: I hope she is praying, and I hope Heaven kindly listens to her prayers!

en: “Forbid it,” proceeded mr Cruncher, with additional solemnity, additional slowness, and additional tendency to hold forth and hold out, “as anything wot I have ever said or done should be wisited on my earnest wishes for them poor creeturs now!
vi: − God will punish... - Cruncher kept saying, becoming more and more solemn, slower, and increasingly verbose, - ... if I say or do anything to harm these poor dear ones!
tr: Mr. Cruncher, in a very solemn, very slow manner, and even more as if he were giving a speech, continued, "God help us," he said, "whatever I have said or done, may it benefit these poor creatures!
es: —I curse—continued Mr. Lapa with greater solemnity than ever—I curse everything I have done and said against the good souls who pray and spend their time on their knees!

en: Forbid it as we shouldn’t all flop (if it was anyways conwenient) to get ’em out o’ this here dismal risk!
vi: God will punish if we do not sit down, if convenient, to pray for them to escape from this danger!
tr: God help us, (if it will help them get out of this terrible situation) let us kneel and pray!
es: I curse all mortals who at this very moment are not on their knees and praying for the Lord to deliver us safely from this mortal danger in which we find ourselves!

en: Forbid it, miss!
vi: God will punish, sister!
tr: God help us, madam!
es: I curse, miss... I curse...!

en: Wot I say, for-bid it!”
vi: I'm telling you, punish! -
tr: Please help us, God!"
es: I curse, miss... I curse...!

en: This was mr Cruncher’s conclusion after a protracted but vain endeavour to find a better one.
vi: That was Cruncher's conclusion after rambling on without finding a better phrase.
tr: Mr. Cruncher had tried to end his words in a better way, but it had not worked.
es: The good Lapa lowered his head after searching in vain for a few seconds for something else to curse.

en: And still Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came nearer and nearer.
vi: Madame Defarge was still advancing on the road, getting closer and closer.
tr: Meanwhile, Madam Defarge, who was progressing steadily on her path, had approached the house.
es: —If divine mercy wills that we ever reach our homeland—replied Miss Pross,—you can be absolutely certain that I will repeat to Mrs. Lapa everything you have just said in such eloquent language; and whatever happens, at all times you will find me ready to testify to your excellent intentions...

en: “If we ever get back to our native land,” said Miss Pross, “you may rely upon my telling ms Cruncher as much as I may be able to remember and understand of what you have so impressively said; and at all events you may be sure that I shall bear witness to your being thoroughly in earnest at this dreadful time.
vi: − If we can return to our homeland, - said Ms. Pross, - you can trust that I will tell Mrs. Cruncher everything I remember and understand from your very eloquent words; I will certainly testify that you were entirely sincere in this dreadful moment.
tr: "If we can return to our homeland one day," said Miss Pross, "you can be sure that I will tell Ms. Cruncher as much of your impressive words as I can remember and understand, and you can trust that I will testify that you were completely serious about this matter during this terrible time.
es: —If divine mercy wills that we ever reach our homeland—replied Miss Pross,—you can be absolutely certain that I will repeat to Mrs. Lapa everything you have just said in such eloquent language; and whatever happens, at all times you will find me ready to testify to your excellent intentions...

en: Now, pray let us think!
vi: Now, pray that we think of something!
tr: Now let's think, please!
es: But let us think, Mr. Lapa... let us think!

en: My esteemed mr Cruncher, let us think!”
vi: Dear Mr. Cruncher, let's think of a way!
tr: Dear Mr. Cruncher, let's think, come on!"
es: But let us think, Mr. Lapa... let us think!

en: Still, Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came nearer and nearer.
vi: Meanwhile, Madame Defarge is still advancing on the road, getting closer and closer.
tr: Madame Defarge, still advancing steadily, was now much closer to home.
es: After a long period of deep meditation, Miss Pross said:

en: “If you were to go before,” said Miss Pross, “and stop the vehicle and horses from coming here, and were to wait somewhere for me; wouldn’t that be best?”
vi: − If you go ahead, - said Miss Pross, - and prevent the carriage from coming here while waiting for me somewhere, wouldn't that be better?
tr: "If you go ahead," said Miss Pross, "and prevent the carriage and horses from coming here, and wait for me somewhere, wouldn't that be better?"
es: —Don't you think it would be wise, Mr. Lapa, to order the car to wait somewhere else instead of coming here? If you like my suggestion, you could go out to give the notice, and I would go to the agreed-upon spot.

en: mr Cruncher thought it might be best.
vi: Cruncher thought that was the best way.
tr: Mr. Cruncher thought that this was a very good idea.
es: Jeremías Lapa replied that the plan seemed right to him.

en: “Where could you wait for me?” asked Miss Pross.
vi: − Where can you wait for me? - Miss Pross asked.
tr: "Where can you wait for me?" asked Miss Pross.
es: —Where could they be waiting for me?—asked Miss Pross.

en: mr Cruncher was so bewildered that he could think of no locality but Temple Bar.
vi: Cruncher was so bewildered that he couldn't think of any place other than the Temple Bar gate.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he couldn't think of any place other than Temple Bar.
es: So bewildered was Mr. Lapa that he could not think of a more suitable place than the sidewalk of the Temple Bar in London, next to Tellson's Bank.

en: Alas!
vi: Alas!
tr: Oh no!
es: Unfortunate luck!

en: Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and Madame Defarge was drawing very near indeed.
vi: Temple Bar was all the way in London, hundreds of miles away, while Madame Defarge was already very close.
tr: Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and Madame Defarge had already gotten very close to the house.
es: The Tribunal of the Temple was hundreds of miles away, while the innkeeper Defarge was very close to the house.

en: “By the cathedral door,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − By the church gate, - said Miss Pross. - Meet me there, near the church gate with the two towers, is that convenient for you?
tr: "At the cathedral door," said Miss Pross.
es: —Next to the cathedral door—said Miss Pross.

en: “Would it be much out of the way, to take me in, near the great cathedral door between the two towers?”
vi: − By the church gate, - said Miss Pross. - Meet me there, near the church gate with the two towers, is that convenient for you?
tr: "Would we be taking a much longer route if you picked me up at the cathedral door between the two towers?"
es: —Do you think the cathedral door, between the two towers, is a good spot?

en: “No, miss,” answered mr Cruncher.
vi: − Convenient, ma'am, - Cruncher replied.
tr: "No, ma'am," said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —It seems unbeatable, miss.

en: “Then, like the best of men,” said Miss Pross, “go to the posting-house straight, and make that change.”
vi: − Then please, sir, - said Miss Pross, - go immediately to the post station and tell them to change the location.
tr: "Then like a proper man," said Miss Pross, "go straight to the relay station and change your horses.""
es: —Then, go to the post house and give the appropriate orders.

en: “I am doubtful,” said mr Cruncher, hesitating and shaking his head, “about leaving of you, you see.
vi: − I'm worried about you staying here alone, - Cruncher hesitated, then shook his head. -
tr: Mr. Cruncher shook his head hesitantly, "I'm not sure about leaving you here alone.
es: —The only thing that worries me—said Lapa, scratching his head,—is leaving you.

en: We don’t know what may happen.”
vi: What if something happens.
tr: What if something happens to you?"
es: We don't know what might happen.

en: “Heaven knows we don’t,” returned Miss Pross, “but have no fear for me.
vi: − Only God knows, - replied Miss Pross, - but don't worry about me.
tr: "That is up to God now," said Miss Pross, "don't you worry.
es: —Only God knows, it's true; but do not worry about me.

en: Take me in at the cathedral, at Three o’Clock, or as near it as you can, and I am sure it will be better than our going from here.
vi: Meet me at the church, at three o'clock, or earlier if possible, I am sure that leaving from there will be better than leaving from here.
tr: Pick me up at three o'clock or around three from the cathedral; it will definitely be much better than leaving from here.
es: Wait for me with the car at three o'clock sharp by the cathedral door, or as close as possible, which will certainly be less prone to mishaps than if we were to leave from here.

en: I feel certain of it.
vi: I am sure of it.
tr: I am very sure of this.
es: Wait for me with the car at three o'clock sharp by the cathedral door, or as close as possible, which will certainly be less prone to mishaps than if we were to leave from here.

en: There!
vi: Go now!
tr: Let's go!
es: God bless you, Mr. Lapa!

en: Bless you, mr Cruncher!
vi: God bless you, Mr. Cruncher!
tr: God help you, Mr. Cruncher!
es: God bless you, Mr. Lapa!

en: Think-not of me, but of the lives that may depend on both of us!”
vi: Don't think about me, but think about the lives that are depending on the two of us!
tr: Think not of me, but of those poor souls whose lives may depend on us!"
es: Think not of our lives, which are of little value, but of the other more precious ones that probably depend on ours.

en: This exordium, and Miss Pross’s two hands in quite agonised entreaty clasping his, decided mr Cruncher.
vi: These words, along with Miss Pross's hands tightly grasping Cruncher's, earnestly pleading, convinced him.
tr: These words and Miss Pross's pleading grip on his hands had convinced Mr. Cruncher.
es: These words, and Miss Pross's attitude, who was extending her pleading hands towards him, finally convinced Lapa, who immediately left, ready to carry out the task.

en: With an encouraging nod or two, he immediately went out to alter the arrangements, and left her by herself to follow as she had proposed.
vi: With a few encouraging nods, Cruncher immediately went to make arrangements, leaving Miss Pross alone as she had requested.
tr: After nodding encouragingly a couple of times, he immediately went out to get ready and left Miss Pross alone, as she had suggested.
es: These words, and Miss Pross's attitude, who was extending her pleading hands towards him, finally convinced Lapa, who immediately left, ready to carry out the task.

en: The having originated a precaution which was already in course of execution, was a great relief to Miss Pross.
vi: Miss Pross felt very relieved after thinking of a precautionary measure that was being implemented.
tr: That they had taken such a precaution and implemented it immediately had greatly relieved Miss Pross.
es: It greatly helped to calm Miss Pross to see the precautionary measures being put into action.

en: The necessity of composing her appearance so that it should attract no special notice in the streets, was another relief.
vi: Another comforting thought was that she had the necessary time to tidy up her appearance so as not to attract attention when going out.
tr: Changing her appearance so as not to be recognized on the streets was another source of relief.
es: She also found comfort in the need to compose her outward appearance so as not to attract attention in the streets that could be dangerous.

en: She looked at her watch, and it was twenty minutes past two.
vi: She looked at the clock. Two twenty.
tr: She looked at her watch; it was twenty past two.
es: She checked the clock and saw that it was twenty past two.

en: She had no time to lose, but must get ready at once.
vi: There was no time to waste, she had to get ready immediately.
tr: There was no time to lose; she had to get ready immediately.
es: She couldn't afford to waste time.

en: Afraid, in her extreme perturbation, of the loneliness of the deserted rooms, and of half-imagined faces peeping from behind every open door in them, Miss Pross got a basin of cold water and began laving her eyes, which were swollen and red.
vi: In this chaotic emotion, Ms. Pross became afraid of being alone in the empty apartment and saw phantom faces looking out from every window frame. She then took a basin of cold water and began to wash her red and swollen eyes.
tr: Miss Pross, with the unease and fear brought on by being alone in deserted rooms and the feeling that someone was watching from behind every door, began to wash her red and swollen eyes with a bowl of cold water.
es: Frightened at the thought of the loneliness in those deserted rooms, fearing to see eyes watching her from everywhere, gripped by unspeakable terrors, Miss Pross put cold water in a basin and began to wash her eyes, red and swollen from so much crying.

en: Haunted by her feverish apprehensions, she could not bear to have her sight obscured for a minute at a time by the dripping water, but constantly paused and looked round to see that there was no one watching her.
vi: Haunted by a burning fear, she dared not let the streaming water blur her vision for even a moment; she continually paused to look around to see if anyone was watching her.
tr: She was so anxious and uneasy that she was disturbed by the momentary loss of vision when the water hit her face, constantly pausing to look around and make sure no one was watching her.
es: Harassed by her apprehensions, she interrupted the washing every second to cast fearful glances around her.

en: In one of those pauses she recoiled and cried out, for she saw a figure standing in the room.
vi: And during one such pause, she was startled and cried out upon seeing a figure standing in the room.
tr: During one of these pauses, she let out a scream, startled, because there was someone standing in the middle of the room.
es: In one of those interruptions, she stepped back and let out a piercing scream, for she indeed discovered a person standing in the center of the room, looking at her.

en: The basin fell to the ground broken, and the water flowed to the feet of Madame Defarge.
vi: The pot fell to the floor and shattered, water spreading to Madame Defarge's feet.
tr: The cup fell to the ground and broke, and the water flowed towards Madam Defarge's feet.
es: The basin shattered into a thousand pieces, and the spilled water reached the bare feet of the innkeeper Defarge.

en: By strange stern ways, and through much staining blood, those feet had come to meet that water.
vi: Through many harsh and bloody paths, those feet had arrived here.
tr: These feet had traversed such merciless paths and had been stained with so much blood before meeting this water.
es: Strangely enough, those feet, which were seeking blood, encountered water.

en: Madame Defarge looked coldly at her, and said, “The wife of Evrémonde; where is she?”
vi: Coldly looking at Miss Pross, Madame Defarge asked: "Where is Evrémonde's wife?"
tr: Madame Defarge looked at Miss Pross with a cold expression and asked, "Where is Evremonde's wife?"
es: —Where is Evrémonde's wife?—asked the innkeeper coldly.

en: It flashed upon Miss Pross’s mind that the doors were all standing open, and would suggest the flight.
vi: Miss Pross suddenly remembered that all the doors of the room were open and would reveal the escape plan.
tr: Suddenly, it occurred to Miss Pross that all the doors in the rooms were open, which could make it seem like they had escaped.
es: Quick as lightning, the idea struck Miss Pross's mind that the fact that all the doors were wide open would arouse suspicion of an escape plan.

en: Her first act was to shut them.
vi: Her first reaction was to close all the doors.
tr: Miss Pross's first task was to close them.
es: So she began by closing them all, and then positioned herself in front of the door leading to the room that Lucie had occupied until that day.

en: There were four in the room, and she shut them all.
vi: All four doors leading to this room.
tr: She closed all four doors inside the room.
es: So she began by closing them all, and then positioned herself in front of the door leading to the room that Lucie had occupied until that day.

en: She then placed herself before the door of the chamber which Lucie had occupied.
vi: Then she stood blocking the door to Lucie's private room.
tr: Then she stood in front of the door to the room where Lucie was staying.
es: So she began by closing them all, and then positioned herself in front of the door leading to the room that Lucie had occupied until that day.

en: Madame Defarge’s dark eyes followed her through this rapid movement, and rested on her when it was finished.
vi: The dark eyes of Madame Defarge followed the swift actions of Miss Pross and fixed on her when the four doors were tightly closed.
tr: Madame Defarge's dark eyes followed all this movement and, when it was over, fixed on Miss Pross.
es: With a fiery gaze, the innkeeper Defarge followed all the movements of Miss Pross, fixing them on her face once she saw her motionless by the door.

en: Miss Pross had nothing beautiful about her; years had not tamed the wildness, or softened the grimness, of her appearance; but, she too was a determined woman in her different way, and she measured Madame Defarge with her eyes, every inch.
vi: Miss Pross had no beauty at all, the years had not tamed her stubbornness nor softened the rough features on her face; but she was also a tenacious woman in a different way, her eyes roamed over Madame Defarge, scrutinizing every bit.
tr: There was nothing about Miss Pross that could be called beautiful; the years had not tamed her wildness nor softened the harshness of her appearance; but she was a determined woman in her own way, and she fixed her eyes on Madame Defarge, scrutinizing her from head to toe.
es: Miss Pross was devoid of any kind of physical attractiveness. The years had not tamed her rustic roughness nor softened the sullen frown on her face. At the same time, she was a resolute woman; personal dangers did not frighten her, and far from being intimidated upon seeing Madame Defarge, she measured her from head to toe with a look of profound disdain.

en: “You might, from your appearance, be the wife of Lucifer,” said Miss Pross, in her breathing.
vi: − Your face is just like Satan's, - said Miss Pross, breathing heavily. -
tr: "You must be the devil's wife," said Miss Pross, breathlessly.
es: —From your appearance, you could be the wife of Lucifer himself—Miss Pross said to herself.

en: “Nevertheless, you shall not get the better of me.
vi: But you won't defeat me.
tr: "But you cannot defeat me.
es: —But if you think you scare me, you're mistaken; I am English.

en: I am an Englishwoman.”
vi: I am an Englishwoman.
tr: I am an Englishwoman."
es: —But if you think you scare me, you're mistaken; I am English.

en: Madame Defarge looked at her scornfully, but still with something of Miss Pross’s own perception that they two were at bay.
vi: Madame Defarge looked at Miss Pross with contempt, but in that look, Miss Pross still recognized one thing: they were two adversaries.
tr: Madam Defarge looked disdainfully, but it had not escaped Miss Pross's notice that she actually saw her as an equal.
es: The innkeeper's wife looked at her with contempt in her eyes, though understanding that she was facing a formidable enemy.

en: She saw a tight, hard, wiry woman before her, as mr Lorry had seen in the same figure a woman with a strong hand, in the years gone by.
vi: Madame Defarge saw that her opponent was a tough, tenacious woman, just as Mr. Lorry had realized many years ago when he first met the woman with the strong hands.
tr: The firm, hard, and sturdy woman in front of her was the same woman with strong hands that Mr. Lorry had seen years ago.
es: She knew very well that Miss Pross was capable of losing her life for the doctor's family, just as Miss Pross knew that the innkeeper's wife, Defarge, was capable of any evil when it came to the indicated family.

en: She knew full well that Miss Pross was the family’s devoted friend; Miss Pross knew full well that Madame Defarge was the family’s malevolent enemy.
vi: Madame Defarge knew well that Miss Pross was a devoted friend to this family; and Miss Pross also knew all too well that Madame Defarge was the family's vicious enemy.
tr: Madam Defarge knew very well that Miss Pross was the loyal friend of the family, and Miss Pross knew very well that Madam Defarge was the stone-hearted enemy of the family.
es: She knew very well that Miss Pross was capable of losing her life for the doctor's family, just as Miss Pross knew that the innkeeper's wife, Defarge, was capable of any evil when it came to the indicated family.

en: “On my way yonder,” said Madame Defarge, with a slight movement of her hand towards the fatal spot, “where they reserve my chair and my knitting for me, I am come to make my compliments to her in passing.
vi: − On the way there, - Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand as a sign towards the scaffold, - where someone has already saved a spot and kept the knitting for me, I stopped by to visit the mistress.
tr: Madam Defarge said, "While I go to the place where they put my chair and knitting," lightly waving her hand towards the deadly area, "I thought I would stop by and convey my best wishes to Lucie.
es: —I was going to the place where I have a reserved seat—said Defarge, extending an arm towards the spot where the guillotine was set up,—and in passing, I wanted to congratulate the wife of Evrémonde.

en: I wish to see her.”
vi: I want to meet Lucie.
tr: I want to see her."
es: I need to see her.

en: “I know that your intentions are evil,” said Miss Pross, “and you may depend upon it, I’ll hold my own against them.”
vi: − I know your wicked scheme now, - said Miss Pross, - don't think I won't resist.
tr: "I know how malicious you are," said Miss Pross, "but remember that you are facing me."
es: —I know your intentions are bad, and you can certainly count on the fact that you will find in me someone who will oppose you in carrying them out—replied Miss Pross.

en: Each spoke in her own language; neither understood the other’s words; both were very watchful, and intent to deduce from look and manner, what the unintelligible words meant.
vi: One speaks French, the other speaks English; neither understands the other; both are cautious, and through each other's facial expressions and gestures, they try to guess the meaning of the words they do not understand.
tr: Both were speaking in their own language; neither understood the other; both were on alert, trying to deduce what the other was saying from their expressions and demeanor.
es: Each one spoke in their native tongue. Neither the barmaid understood a word of what Miss Pross was saying, nor did Miss Pross understand a word of what the barmaid was saying. However, they watched each other so intently that their gestures, their expressions, made the words intelligible that otherwise said nothing to their ears.

en: “It will do her no good to keep herself concealed from me at this moment,” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − If Miss Lucie avoids me at this moment, it will be of no use, - said Madame Defarge. -
tr: "At this point, there is no benefit for Lucie to hide from me," said Madam Defarge.
es: —Worse for her if you don't let me see her right now—replied the innkeeper.—The good patriots will soon know what that means.

en: “Good patriots will know what that means.
vi: True patriots will understand the meaning of such avoidance.
tr: "Good citizens know what this means.
es: —Worse for her if you don't let me see her right now—replied the innkeeper.—The good patriots will soon know what that means.

en: Let me see her.
vi: Let me meet her.
tr: Let me see her.
es: I want to see her... I need to see her...

en: Go tell her that I wish to see her.
vi: Tell her I want to meet.
tr: Go and tell her that I want to see her.
es: Go and tell her that I won't leave here without seeing her.

en: Do you hear?”
vi: Do you hear me?
tr: Do you hear me?"
es: Don't you hear me?

en: “If those eyes of yours were bed-winches,” returned Miss Pross, “and I was an English four-poster, they shouldn’t loose a splinter of me.
vi: − What's fair for you is fair for me, - replied Miss Pross.
tr: "If your eyes were a crane," said Miss Pross, "I would be a four-poster English bed, and you still couldn't move me an inch from my place.
es: —You insist on being left without eyes, and you are going to achieve it—replied Miss Pross.

en: No, you wicked foreign woman; I am your match.”
vi: - You wicked foreign woman, I won't lose to you.
tr: It's not that easy, you foreign woman. You can't defeat me."
es: —Look at me, look at me with those fierce beast eyes, but don't push your luck, because I have a short temper. You might come for wool and leave yours between my nails.

en: Madame Defarge was not likely to follow these idiomatic remarks in detail; but, she so far understood them as to perceive that she was set at naught.
vi: Mrs. Defarge could not fully understand that peculiar language, but she knew well enough that the other party would not listen.
tr: Although Madam Defarge did not understand much of what he said, she could sense that a barrier had been put up in front of her.
es: Of course, Madame Defarge did not understand a word of the phrases that have been copied, but she fully realized that her interlocutor flatly refused to obey her commands.

en: “Woman imbecile and pig-like!” said Madame Defarge, frowning.
vi: − You stupid pig! - Madame Defarge frowned.
tr: Madam Defarge, "What a fool, what a pig of a woman you are!" she said, frowning.
es: —Idiot... hungry pig face!

en: “I take no answer from you.
vi: - I don't need to hear you speak.
tr: "Do not answer me.
es: —he muttered.

en: I demand to see her.
vi: I need to meet your master.
tr: I want to see Lucie.
es: —I want to see Evrémonde's wife!

en: Either tell her that I demand to see her, or stand out of the way of the door and let me go to her!”
vi: Either tell him that I need to meet, or get out of the way so I can meet him! -
tr: Either tell her that I want to see her or get out of my way so I can find her!"
es: Either you go tell her right now, or you step away from that door and let me through!

en: This, with an angry explanatory wave of her right arm.
vi: The right arm angrily swung up to explain.
tr: As she said this, she waved her right arm angrily.
es: Either you go tell her right now, or you step away from that door and let me through!

en: “I little thought,” said Miss Pross, “that I should ever want to understand your nonsensical language; but I would give all I have, except the clothes I wear, to know whether you suspect the truth, or any part of it.”
vi: − Never in my life would I want to understand your nonsense language, - said Miss Pross. - But I would dare to give up everything, except the clothes on my back, to know if you have any suspicions.
tr: "I never thought I would ever want to understand your ridiculous language, but right now, I would give everything I have except the clothes on my back to find out if you doubt what the truth is or any part of it."
es: —I never imagined that I might need to understand that stupid language you speak; but the truth is that right now I would give everything I have, except the shirt on my back, to know if you suspect the whole truth or part of it.

en: Neither of them for a single moment released the other’s eyes.
vi: No one took their eyes off each other for a minute.
tr: For a moment, both of them looked at each other without blinking.
es: The two women stared at each other intently.

en: Madame Defarge had not moved from the spot where she stood when Miss Pross first became aware of her; but, she now advanced one step.
vi: Madame Defarge was standing in the same position as when Miss Pross first saw her; but now she had taken a step forward.
tr: Madam Defarge had been standing at the spot where Miss Pross first saw her until that moment, but now she had taken a step forward.
es: The innkeeper, who until now had not moved from the spot where Miss Pross saw her when she was washing her eyes, took a step forward.

en: “I am a Briton,” said Miss Pross, “I am desperate.
vi: Miss Pross said: "I am an Englishwoman," Miss Pross said. "I can't take it anymore."
tr: "I am British," said Miss Pross. "I can risk everything.
es: —I am Breton and I am furious—said Miss Pross.

en: I don’t care an English Twopence for myself.
vi: My life isn't worth a penny, losing it wouldn't matter at all.
tr: My life is not valuable.
es: —I don't give a damn about my life.

en: I know that the longer I keep you here, the greater hope there is for my Ladybird.
vi: But as long as I keep you here, my dear mistress still has hope.
tr: The longer I keep you here, the better it will be for my little bird.
es: I know that the longer I delay you, the more I ensure my lady's salvation...

en: I’ll not leave a handful of that dark hair upon your head, if you lay a finger on me!”
vi: If you lay a hand on me, I'll make sure you end up bald with not a hair left on your head!
tr: If you dare to touch me, know that I will not leave a single hair on your dark head.""
es: If you come any closer, I assure you I won't leave a hair on that head of yours.

en: Thus Miss Pross, with a shake of her head and a flash of her eyes between every rapid sentence, and every rapid sentence a whole breath.
vi: Miss Pross said while shaking her head, eyes glaring, and breathing heavily between her hurried words.
tr: Miss Pross was shaking her head from side to side and glaring at Madam during all these rapid sentences, and each sentence was coming out of her mouth in a single breath.
es: It was the sentimental nature of Miss Pross's courage, a courage that filled her eyes with tears.

en: Thus Miss Pross, who had never struck a blow in her life.
vi: Her voice was full of threats even though she had never hit anyone in her life.
tr: On the other hand, Miss Pross had never struck anyone in her life.
es: It was the sentimental nature of Miss Pross's courage, a courage that filled her eyes with tears.

en: But, her courage was of that emotional nature that it brought the irrepressible tears into her eyes.
vi: That indomitable spirit moved Miss Pross to tears, which Madame Defarge mistakenly took as a sign of weakness.
tr: Her courage stemmed from her emotions, and suddenly tears streamed from her eyes.
es: It was the sentimental nature of Miss Pross's courage, a courage that filled her eyes with tears.

en: This was a courage that Madame Defarge so little comprehended as to mistake for weakness.
vi: That indomitable spirit moved Miss Pross to tears, which Madame Defarge mistakenly took as a sign of weakness.
tr: Madame Defarge could not understand this courage and saw the tears as a sign of weakness.
es: The tavern keeper, not very practical in matters of sentiment, mistook the tears for weakness.

en: “Ha, ha!” she laughed, “you poor wretch!
vi: − Ha ha, - Madame Defarge laughed loudly, - you coward!
tr: "Ha ha ha!" she laughed, "you poor thing!
es: —Ha, ha, ha, ha!

en: What are you worth!
vi: You useless thing!
tr: What did you think of yourself!
es: Poor thing, and how little you're worth! —he exclaimed.

en: I address myself to that Doctor.”
vi: I will call the doctor. -
tr: I'd better talk to the Doctor."
es: —I want nothing to do with you... Citizen doctor!

en: Then she raised her voice and called out, “Citizen Doctor!
vi: Then she shouted loudly, - Citizen Doctor!
tr: Then she shouted loudly, "Citizen Doctor!
es: —he shouted.

en: Wife of Evrémonde!
vi: Wife of Evrémonde!
tr: The wife of Evremonde!
es: —Woman of Evrémonde, daughter of Evrémonde!

en: Child of Evrémonde!
vi: Child of Evrémonde!
tr: The daughter of Evremonde!
es: —Woman of Evrémonde, daughter of Evrémonde!

en: Any person but this miserable fool, answer the Citizeness Defarge!”
vi: Anyone but that miserable fool, answer Citizeness Defarge!
tr: Whoever is there besides this miserable creature I am speaking to, answer Citizen Defarge!"
es: Answer the citizen Defarge, miserable inhabitants of this house!

en: Perhaps the following silence, perhaps some latent disclosure in the expression of Miss Pross’s face, perhaps a sudden misgiving apart from either suggestion, whispered to Madame Defarge that they were gone.
vi: Perhaps because of the silence that followed, perhaps because of the expression on Miss Pross's face, or perhaps due to a suspicion unrelated to the other two, Madame Defarge suddenly thought that those people had left.
tr: Maybe it was the ensuing silence, maybe it was the revealing expression on Miss Pross's face, or perhaps an independent suspicion whispered to Madam Defarge that they had left.
es: Perhaps the silence that followed her screams, perhaps the expression on Miss Pross's face, perhaps premonitions born in her dark soul, suggested to the innkeeper's wife the suspicion that the people whose blood she sought had fled.

en: Three of the doors she opened swiftly, and looked in.
vi: She quickly opened the three room doors and looked inside.
tr: She quickly opened the three doors and looked inside.
es: The fact was that of the four doors in the room she was in, she opened three and looked inside the rooms to which they gave access.

en: “Those rooms are all in disorder, there has been hurried packing, there are odds and ends upon the ground.
vi: − Every room is messy, showing signs of hurried packing, with all sorts of things scattered on the floor.
tr: "All these rooms are scattered, as if someone quickly tidied up around here, a lot of knick-knacks are strewn on the floor.
es: —I see everything in disarray, there is no one in these rooms, and I suspect that the one you guard is also deserted!

en: There is no one in that room behind you!
vi: So there's no one in the room behind you!
tr: There must be someone in the room behind you!
es: —I see everything in disarray, there is no one in these rooms, and I suspect that the one you guard is also deserted!

en: Let me look.”
vi: Let me see.
tr: Let me take a look."
es: I want to inspect it!

en: “Never!” said Miss Pross, who understood the request as perfectly as Madame Defarge understood the answer.
vi: − No! - Miss Pross understood the demand just as clearly as Madame Defarge understood the response.
tr: "Never!" said Miss Pross, and Madam Defarge understood this reply as well as Miss Pross understood her own intention.
es: —he shouted. —Never! —responded Miss Pross, who understood the words of the landlady as well as the latter understood her response.

en: “If they are not in that room, they are gone, and can be pursued and brought back,” said Madame Defarge to herself.
vi: − If they are not in that room, they have escaped, then we can chase and capture them, - Madame Defarge said to herself.
tr: Madam Defarge said to herself, "If they are not in the room, they have gone, but they can be caught and brought back, of course."
es: —If they are not in that room, they have left; and there is still time to pursue them and catch up with them—thought Defarge.

en: “As long as you don’t know whether they are in that room or not, you are uncertain what to do,” said Miss Pross to herself; “and you shall not know that, if I can prevent your knowing it; and know that, or not know that, you shall not leave here while I can hold you.”
vi: − As long as you don't know whether they are in that room or not, you still don't know what to do, - Miss Pross also said to herself. And you don't know that I won't let you know; whether you know or not, I will still prevent you from leaving here.
tr: Miss Pross said, "You won't know what to do unless you know whether they are in that room or not," she said to herself, "and if I don't give you the chance, you won't learn it; moreover, whether you learn it or not, I won't let you out of here."
es: —As long as you don't find out whether they are in this room or not, you won't know what to do—Miss Pross said to herself;—and I assure you that you won't find out if it's in my power to prevent it. Another thing; you won't leave here as long as I have hands to hold you.

en: “I have been in the streets from the first, nothing has stopped me, I will tear you to pieces, but I will have you from that door,” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − Since I was little, I've been hustling on the streets, nothing could stop me. I'll tear you apart if you don't let me into that room.
tr: "I have been on the streets since the first day, nothing has stopped me yet, I will tear you apart and still pass by that door," said Madam Defarge.
es: —I have not found a wall capable of blocking my way until today; be sure that I will tear you to pieces if you don't come out of that door—roared the innkeeper.

en: “We are alone at the top of a high house in a solitary courtyard, we are not likely to be heard, and I pray for bodily strength to keep you here, while every minute you are here is worth a hundred thousand guineas to my darling,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − It's just you and me on this tall building with an empty courtyard, no one will hear anything. I hope I have enough strength to keep you here; every minute I keep you here is worth hundreds of thousands of guineas to my mistress.
tr: "We are alone with you at the top of this large house in a desolate courtyard, no one can hear us, may God give me strength so that I can keep you here longer, after all, every minute you spend here is worth the world for my little bird," said Miss Pross.
es: —We are alone in an interior room of a solitary house in a solitary neighborhood. It is not likely that they will hear us. You will not leave here, beast, for every minute I detain you is worth a world to my dear lady.

en: Madame Defarge made at the door.
vi: Madame Defarge rushed to the door.
tr: Madam Defarge rushed towards the door.
es: The innkeeper, having lost her patience, advanced resolutely towards the door.

en: Miss Pross, on the instinct of the moment, seized her round the waist in both her arms, and held her tight.
vi: Miss Pross immediately threw her arms around her opponent's waist and held on tightly.
tr: Miss Pross, however, instinctively grabbed her tightly around the waist with both hands.
es: Miss Pross, guided by the instinct of the moment, grabbed her around the waist with both arms.

en: It was in vain for Madame Defarge to struggle and to strike; Miss Pross, with the vigorous tenacity of love, always so much stronger than hate, clasped her tight, and even lifted her from the floor in the struggle that they had.
vi: Madame Defarge's struggles, punches, and kicks were futile; Miss Pross, with the fierce determination of love, which is always stronger than hatred, held on tightly, even lifting her adversary off the ground during the struggle.
tr: Although Madam Defarge struggled and tried to hit, it was to no avail; Miss Pross, with the determination of love which is always much stronger than hatred, held her tightly, even lifting her from where they had fallen during the struggle.
es: In vain did the first try to resist and strike, for her antagonist, with that giant tenacity that love gives, always stronger than hate, not only held her but also lifted her off the ground in her arms.

en: The two hands of Madame Defarge buffeted and tore her face; but, Miss Pross, with her head down, held her round the waist, and clung to her with more than the hold of a drowning woman.
vi: Madame Defarge's hands slapped and scratched at Miss Pross's face, but she ducked her head and tightened her grip around the other's waist, refusing to let go, like a drowning person clinging desperately to their rescuer.
tr: Madam Defarge was punching and scratching Miss Pross's face with both hands; but Miss Pross, with her head down, continued to hold her around the waist, clinging to her as if holding a drowning woman.
es: Defarge struggled furiously, slapped and slapped her enemy's face, scratched her mercilessly, but Miss Pross, who had lowered her head to defend herself, tightened the steel grip with which she imprisoned her waist more and more.

en: Soon, Madame Defarge’s hands ceased to strike, and felt at her encircled waist.
vi: Immediately afterward, Madame Defarge's hands stopped beating and lowered to grope around her waist.
tr: Soon, Madam Defarge's hands stopped struggling and reached for her wrapped waist.
es: The hands of the innkeeper stopped pounding and dropped to her waist.

en: “It is under my arm,” said Miss Pross, in smothered tones, “you shall not draw it.
vi: Miss Pross said in a breathless voice: "It's under my arm, you can't pull it out."
tr: Miss Pross, in a muffled voice, said, "Under my arm," she said, "you can't take it out.
es: —Don't bother yourself—said Miss Pross;—it is under my arm and you won't be able to draw it.

en: I am stronger than you, I bless Heaven for it.
vi: I'm stronger than you, thank God.
tr: Thank goodness, I'm stronger than you.
es: I am stronger than you, thank God, and I won't let you go until you faint or die.

en: I hold you till one or other of us faints or dies!”
vi: I'll hold you tight until one or both of us faints or dies!
tr: I'll hold you like this until one of us faints or dies!"
es: I am stronger than you, thank God, and I won't let you go until you faint or die.

en: Madame Defarge’s hands were at her bosom.
vi: Madame Defarge's hands moved to her chest.
tr: Madam Defarge's hands went to her bosom.
es: Mrs. Defarge brought her right hand to her chest.

en: Miss Pross looked up, saw what it was, struck at it, struck out a flash and a crash, and stood alone—blinded with smoke.
vi: Miss Pross looked up, saw the object, swung her arm hard, a flash, a bang, and she was left standing alone - her eyes blurred by the gun smoke.
tr: Miss Pross looked up, and seeing what was happening, struck with her hand, and with the strike, there was a sudden flash of light and an explosion, leaving her alone there, her eyes dazzled by the smoke.
es: Miss Pross saw the object that hand was drawing out. Quick as lightning, she raised an arm, struck a blow, and... a flash flared, thunder sounded, and she recoiled. The room was filled with smoke.

en: All this was in a second.
vi: Everything happened in the blink of an eye.
tr: It all happened in an instant.
es: All of it lasted no more than a second.

en: As the smoke cleared, leaving an awful stillness, it passed out on the air, like the soul of the furious woman whose body lay lifeless on the ground.
vi: The terrifying silence as the smoke gradually dissipated, rising into the air like the soul of an enraged woman just departed from the motionless body lying on the floor.
tr: The smoke dispersed, leaving behind a dreadful silence, and mingled with the air like the soul of the angry woman lying lifeless on the ground.
es: The smoke began to pour out of the window, carrying within its black spirals the soul of the woman who lay lifeless on the pavement.

en: In the first fright and horror of her situation, Miss Pross passed the body as far from it as she could, and ran down the stairs to call for fruitless help.
vi: At first, Miss Pross was terrified and stood far away from the corpse, then ran down the stairs calling for help in vain.
tr: After the initial fear and horror she experienced, Miss Pross moved as far away as she could from the lifeless body and went downstairs to call for help in vain.
es: The terribleness of the situation she found herself in made Miss Pross, at first, try to flee from the corpse and run down the stairs with the intention of seeking unnecessary and belated help; but fortunately, she realized the consequences in time to stop and retrace her steps.

en: Happily, she bethought herself of the consequences of what she did, in time to check herself and go back.
vi: Fortunately, she remembered the importance of this outcome, calmed herself in time, and ran back up.
tr: Fortunately, she then thought about the consequences of her actions, came to her senses, and returned.
es: The terribleness of the situation she found herself in made Miss Pross, at first, try to flee from the corpse and run down the stairs with the intention of seeking unnecessary and belated help; but fortunately, she realized the consequences in time to stop and retrace her steps.

en: It was dreadful to go in at the door again; but, she did go in, and even went near it, to get the bonnet and other things that she must wear.
vi: Suppressing her fear, she went inside the house, even approaching the corpse to retrieve the bonnet and necessary clothing.
tr: Entering through that door again was terrifying, but she did it, and even went up to it to retrieve her bonnet and other belongings.
es: It was horrible to pass over the corpse, lying across the doorway; but she did so to retrieve the hat and other items she needed to take with her.

en: These she put on, out on the staircase, first shutting and locking the door and taking away the key.
vi: She dressed quickly, rushed outside, closed all the doors tightly, locked them, and took the key with her.
tr: She put these on by the stairs, closed and locked the door, and took the key.
es: She took them to the landing of the stairs, locked the door, sat down to let the terror that was choking her escape through her eyes, and once calmer, she got up and left.

en: She then sat down on the stairs a few moments to breathe and to cry, and then got up and hurried away.
vi: Afterwards, she sat on the stairs for a moment to breathe and cry, then stood up hurriedly and left.
tr: Then, after sitting on the steps to catch her breath and cry for a bit, she got up and hurried away.
es: She took them to the landing of the stairs, locked the door, sat down to let the terror that was choking her escape through her eyes, and once calmer, she got up and left.

en: By good fortune she had a veil on her bonnet, or she could hardly have gone along the streets without being stopped.
vi: Fortunately, her bonnet had a veil; otherwise, she would have had a hard time walking outside without being stopped and questioned.
tr: Luckily, there was a veil over her hat, otherwise, it would have been impossible for her to walk through those streets without being stopped.
es: Fortunately for her, the veil of the hat was quite thick, because otherwise, it is likely that she would have been detained on the street.

en: By good fortune, too, she was naturally so peculiar in appearance as not to show disfigurement like any other woman.
vi: It was also fortunate that her appearance was naturally unusual, so her odd look didn't stand out as much as other women.
tr: Luckily, there was such a natural oddity in her appearance that her ugliness did not attract attention as it did in other women.
es: Fortunately for her, she was so ugly that the deep scratches she had received in the fight did not leave marks on her face that would have been left on another face more favored by nature.

en: She needed both advantages, for the marks of gripping fingers were deep in her face, and her hair was torn, and her dress (hastily composed with unsteady hands) was clutched and dragged a hundred ways.
vi: She needed both of these advantages because her face bore clear scratch marks, her hair was disheveled, and her hastily donned outfit was extremely rumpled and untidy.
tr: Both were to her advantage, because there were deep scratch marks on her face, her hair was disheveled, and her outfit (hastily adjusted with trembling hands) looked as if it had been tugged at hundreds of times.
es: Fortunately for her, she was so ugly that the deep scratches she had received in the fight did not leave marks on her face that would have been left on another face more favored by nature.

en: In crossing the bridge, she dropped the door key in the river.
vi: When crossing the bridge, she dropped the house keys into the river.
tr: While crossing the bridge, he threw the key to the door into the river.
es: Upon crossing the bridge, she threw the house key into the river.

en: Arriving at the cathedral some few minutes before her escort, and waiting there, she thought, what if the key were already taken in a net, what if it were identified, what if the door were opened and the remains discovered, what if she were stopped at the gate, sent to prison, and charged with murder!
vi: Arriving at the church a few minutes before Cruncher and standing there waiting, she was lost in thought. If the key got caught in some fishing net, if they identified whose house the key belonged to, if they opened the door and found a corpse, if she was stopped at the city gate, thrown into prison, and accused of murder!
tr: Arriving at the cathedral a few minutes before his companion and waiting there, his mind was occupied with questions like, what if the key got caught in a net, what if they figured out what it was, what if they opened the door and saw what was inside, what if he was stopped at the exit and sent to prison and tried for murder!
es: She arrived in front of the cathedral door a few minutes before the time agreed upon with Lapa, and waited, filled with terror, at the thought that they might fish out the key she had just thrown, discover which house it belonged to, open the door, find a corpse, arrest her, and condemn her to death for the crime of murder.

en: In the midst of these fluttering thoughts, the escort appeared, took her in, and took her away.
vi: While she was lost in these anxious thoughts, the escort appeared, picked her up, and took her away.
tr: While Miss Pross was immersed in all these anxious thoughts, her companion appeared and took her along to continue on their way.
es: Such were the thoughts that agitated her when Lapa arrived.

en: “Is there any noise in the streets?” she asked him.
vi: − Is there any noise outside? - Miss Pross asked.
tr: "Is there any noise in the streets?" asked Miss Pross.
es: —Is there noise in the streets?—asked Miss Pross.

en: “The usual noises,” mr Cruncher replied; and looked surprised by the question and by her aspect.
vi: − Noisier than usual, - Cruncher replied; surprised by the question and her demeanor.
tr: "The usual sounds, that's all," said Mr. Cruncher; he seemed surprised both by the woman's condition and her question.
es: —The ordinary one—Lapa replied, not a little surprised both by the question and by the appearance of the one who asked it.

en: “I don’t hear you,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − I can't hear you, - said Miss Pross. -
tr: "I can't hear you," said Miss Pross.
es: —I can't hear you...

en: “What do you say?”
vi: What did you say?
tr: "What did you say?"
es: What are you saying?

en: It was in vain for mr Cruncher to repeat what he said; Miss Pross could not hear him.
vi: Cruncher repeating it was useless; Miss Pross couldn't hear a thing.
tr: Mr. Cruncher repeated his words in vain; Miss Pross could not hear him.
es: In vain did Lapa repeat over and over what he had said; Miss Pross did not hear him.

en: “So I’ll nod my head,” thought mr Cruncher, amazed, “at all events she’ll see that.”
vi: Cruncher thought in amazement, “Then I'll just nod, she will definitely see and understand.”
tr: "Then I'll nod my head," thought Mr. Cruncher, in amazement, "she'll see that in any case."
es: —Wow!

en: And she did.
vi: And indeed, she did.
tr: And she did.
es: —thought Lapa.—I will make myself understood through gestures.

en: “Is there any noise in the streets now?” asked Miss Pross again, presently.
vi: − Is it noisy outside right now? - Miss Pross asked immediately afterward.
tr: Miss Pross asked again shortly after, "Is there any noise in the streets right now?"
es: —Is there noise in the streets?

en: Again mr Cruncher nodded his head.
vi: Cruncher nodded again.
tr: Mr. Cruncher nodded his head forward again.
es: Lapa nodded affirmatively.

en: “I don’t hear it.”
vi: I can't hear.
tr: "I can't hear."
es: —I don't hear anything.

en: “Gone deaf in an hour?” said mr Cruncher, ruminating, with his mind much disturbed; “wot’s come to her?”
vi: − Only after an hour and already deaf? - Cruncher wondered, filled with worry. - What happened to her?
tr: "Did she go deaf in an hour?" said Mr. Cruncher, confused and disturbed; "what happened to this woman?""
es: —Deaf as a post in an hour? That's strange! —thought Lapa—What could have happened to her?

en: “I feel,” said Miss Pross, “as if there had been a flash and a crash, and that crash was the last thing I should ever hear in this life.”
vi: − I felt like there was lightning and thunder, that explosion was the last sound I heard in this world. − This woman looks really strange!
tr: "It was as if," said Miss Pross, "there was a flash of light and an explosion, and that explosion was the last thing I heard."
es: —I saw a lightning bolt, I heard a thunderclap; and the thunderclap was the last thing I heard in my life—explained Miss Pross.

en: “Blest if she ain’t in a queer condition!” said mr Cruncher, more and more disturbed.
vi: - Cruncher grew increasingly anxious. -
tr: "How strange he has become!" said Mr. Cruncher, now thoroughly disturbed.
es: —I find her completely changed...

en: “Wot can she have been a takin’, to keep her courage up?
vi: Did she do something to muster up courage?
tr: "Did he drink something to boost his courage?
es: What could she have taken to gain courage?

en: Hark!
vi: Listen!
tr: Listen!
es: Because the truth is she doesn't seem to have a bit of fear...

en: There’s the roll of them dreadful carts!
vi: Those terrifying carriages are running on the road!
tr: A lot of death carts are passing by!
es: The noise of those damn carts...!

en: You can hear that, miss?”
vi: Do you hear them, sister? − I can't hear anything, - Miss Pross said as she saw him mouthing words at her.
tr: Do you hear, madam?"
es: Do you hear them, miss?

en: “I can hear,” said Miss Pross, seeing that he spoke to her, “nothing.
tr: Seeing that Mr. Cruncher was saying something to her, Miss Pross said, "I can't hear anything.
es: —I can't hear anything, absolutely nothing—replied the good Pross, noticing the movement of her companion's lips.

en: O, my good man, there was first a great crash, and then a great stillness, and that stillness seems to be fixed and unchangeable, never to be broken any more as long as my life lasts.”
vi: Oh, dear sir, at first there was a loud bang, then complete silence, absolute stillness, as if it would stay that way forever, as if it would remain silent for eternity.
tr: Oh my friend, first there was a great explosion, then a great silence covered everything, and this silence never ends, it never changes, it feels like it will never end until the end of my life.""
es: —A lightning, a thunder, and nothing more.

en: “If she don’t hear the roll of those dreadful carts, now very nigh their journey’s end,” said mr Cruncher, glancing over his shoulder, “it’s my opinion that indeed she never will hear anything else in this world.”
vi: − If she can't hear the sound of those dreadful carts approaching the execution ground, - Cruncher glanced over his shoulder at Miss Pross, - then I think she won't be able to hear anything else in this world anymore.
tr: "If he can't hear the sound of these death carts coming to the end of the road," said Mr. Cruncher, looking over his shoulder, "he will never hear anything again in his life."
es: —If he doesn't hear the rumbling of those horrible carts, I think he won't hear anything else in this world again—murmured Lapa.

en: And indeed she never did.
vi: And indeed it is so.
tr: Indeed, Miss Pross never heard it again.
es: He was not mistaken. Miss Pross remained deaf forever.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: And indeed it is so.
tr: XV
es: XV.

en: The Footsteps Die Out For Ever
vi: 15. The Last Echo
tr: The Footsteps Fall Silent Forever
es: THE ECHOES FADE AWAY FOREVER

en: Along the Paris streets, the death-carts rumble, hollow and harsh.
vi: On the streets of Paris, the carts of the condemned rumbled loudly and harshly; vibrating.
tr: The death carts proceed along the streets of Paris with creaks and rumbles.
es: The vehicles of death bounce on the cobblestones of the streets of Paris, creaking lugubriously.

en: Six tumbrils carry the day’s wine to La Guillotine.
vi: Six carts carried the daily ration of wine offered to Madame La Guillotine.
tr: Six carts carry the wines of the day to the guillotine.
es: Six carts carry to the guillotine the ration of wine with which it daily entertains its thirst.

en: All the devouring and insatiate Monsters imagined since imagination could record itself, are fused in the one realisation, Guillotine.
vi: All the greedy, hungry monsters from the depths of imagination combined into one entity: the guillotine.
tr: All those unimaginable greedy, all-consuming monsters seem to have gathered in a single body, transformed into the guillotine.
es: The devouring monsters, the insatiable monsters that human imaginations have forged since the very first moment of their activity, have merged into a unique realization, and this unique realization is called the guillotine.

en: And yet there is not in France, with its rich variety of soil and climate, a blade, a leaf, a root, a sprig, a peppercorn, which will grow to maturity under conditions more certain than those that have produced this horror.
vi: However, in France, with its fertile land and climate, not a single blade of grass, leaf, root, bud, or ear of corn can grow under conditions as certain as those that have produced that terror.
tr: In the rich soil and diverse climate of France, no bush, leaf, root, sprout, or peppercorn matures more distinctly than the conditions that create this fear.
es: And yet, in France, with all its rich variety of climate and soil, there is not a blade of grass, a leaf, a root, a shoot, capable of reaching ripeness and maturity under more favorable conditions than those that produced that horror.

en: Crush humanity out of shape once more, under similar hammers, and it will twist itself into the same tortured forms.
vi: Keep crushing humanity once more, and it will immediately writhe and proliferate right under the hammer blow in the same deformed and distorted shape.
tr: If you were to crush humanity similarly with hammers, it would return to its former troubled state.
es: The day that similar hammers crush and pound humanity, twisting it and erasing its form, it will reappear under the same violent and misshapen forms under which it reappeared then; the day the seed of rapacious license and oppression is sown, the same fruits that flourished and ripened then will flourish and ripen.

en: Sow the same seed of rapacious license and oppression over again, and it will surely yield the same fruit according to its kind.
vi: Keep sowing the same seeds of tyrannical privilege and oppression, and it will surely yield corresponding fruits.
tr: If you sow the same seeds of greed and oppression, it is clear that you will achieve the same result.
es: The day that similar hammers crush and pound humanity, twisting it and erasing its form, it will reappear under the same violent and misshapen forms under which it reappeared then; the day the seed of rapacious license and oppression is sown, the same fruits that flourished and ripened then will flourish and ripen.

en: Six tumbrils roll along the streets.
vi: Six death carts rolled through the streets.
tr: Six cars are moving along the streets.
es: Six carts roll creaking along the streets.

en: Change these back again to what they were, thou powerful enchanter, Time, and they shall be seen to be the carriages of absolute monarchs, the equipages of feudal nobles, the toilettes of flaring Jezebels, the churches that are not my father’s house but dens of thieves, the huts of millions of starving peasants!
