vi: Oh Time, powerful sorcerer, bring them back, they will become the royal carriages of supreme sovereignty, the horse-drawn carriages of the feudal aristocracy, the jewelry of the resplendent courtesans, the churches that are not houses of God but dens of thieves, the huts of millions of starving peasants!
tr: If the powerful magician, namely "time," were to transform them into the past, they would appear as the chariots of absolute rulers, the materials of feudal nobles, the dressing rooms of radiant and glamorous women, churches that are more nests of thieves than houses of God, and the huts of millions of starving peasants!
es: Transform them into what they once were, you, Time, powerful enchanter, reintegrate them to their former shape and condition, and we will see them changed into as many splendid carriages of absolute monarchs, into trains of noble feudal lords, into luxurious galas of dazzling Jezebels, into Synagogues that have ceased to be the House of My Father to become dens of thieves, into miserable huts of millions of famished peasants!

en: No; the great magician who majestically works out the appointed order of the Creator, never reverses his transformations.
vi: No; this great and majestic sorcerer, under the command of the Creator, will never reverse all changes.
tr: But no; the mighty magician who enforces the order set by the Creator never turns the things he transforms back to their original state.
es: No; the great magician who majestically disrupts the order established by the Creator, never destroys his transformations.

en: “If thou be changed into this shape by the will of God,” say the seers to the enchanted, in the wise Arabian stories, “then remain so!
vi: In the ancient wise tales of Arabia, the prophets told those transformed by magic, "If you have taken this form by the will of God, then remain so!
tr: In the wise tales of One Thousand and One Nights, he says to the enchanted ones, "If God has made you this way," "then remain so!
es: "If the will of God has given you the form you affect, do not attempt to change it; but if you owe it to transient human conspiracies, regain the one you received from the Most High," say the magicians to the enchanted beings in the Arabian tales.

en: But, if thou wear this form through mere passing conjuration, then resume thy former aspect!”
vi: But if you bear this shape only due to temporary enchantment, then return to your former self!".
tr: But if you have come to this state through a temporary spell, then return to your former state!"
es: "If the will of God has given you the form you affect, do not attempt to change it; but if you owe it to transient human conspiracies, regain the one you received from the Most High," say the magicians to the enchanted beings in the Arabian tales.

en: Changeless and hopeless, the tumbrils roll along.
vi: Unchanged and without hope, the death carts continued to roll.
tr: The cars, in the same way, are moving forward desperately.
es: The shadowy wheels of the carts, as they turn over the cobblestones, resemble a powerful plow that opens a deep furrow among the populace that fills the streets, with human heads on either side.

en: As the sombre wheels of the six carts go round, they seem to plough up a long crooked furrow among the populace in the streets.
vi: The sorrowful wheels turn as if plowing winding furrows through the crowded streets.
tr: As the gloomy wheels of six carts turn, a crooked furrow forms among the crowd in the streets.
es: The shadowy wheels of the carts, as they turn over the cobblestones, resemble a powerful plow that opens a deep furrow among the populace that fills the streets, with human heads on either side.

en: Ridges of faces are thrown to this side and to that, and the ploughs go steadily onward.
vi: The furrows of faces are plowed aside as the wheels roll steadily down the road.
tr: Faces turn one way, then the other, and the plow moves forward smoothly.
es: The shadowy wheels of the carts, as they turn over the cobblestones, resemble a powerful plow that opens a deep furrow among the populace that fills the streets, with human heads on either side.

en: So used are the regular inhabitants of the houses to the spectacle, that in many windows there are no people, and in some the occupation of the hands is not so much as suspended, while the eyes survey the faces in the tumbrils.
vi: The residents of the houses along the street have become so accustomed to this scene that many don't even bother to stand by the windows to watch, and some, even as their eyes glance over the faces of the condemned on the vehicles, continue their work without pause.
tr: The people living in the nearby houses are so accustomed to this sight that many windows are empty; some just glance at the people inside the carts without pausing their work.
es: The neighbors of the houses are so accustomed to the horrendous spectacle that not a single face is seen on many balconies, and it is very common to see people engaged in some occupation who do not stop the movement of their hands as the carts pass, although their eyes turn to the carts to see who the unfortunate ones occupying them are.

en: Here and there, the inmate has visitors to see the sight; then he points his finger, with something of the complacency of a curator or authorised exponent, to this cart and to this, and seems to tell who sat here yesterday, and who there the day before.
vi: In some places, residents with guests take the opportunity to watch the procession; the hosts proudly point out one prison wagon after another, like collectors of antiques or connoisseurs explaining who had sat on those fateful vehicles the day before or the day before that.
tr: In some houses, there are guests who come just to watch this; then the host, with the indifference of an exhibition organizer or an official, points to the carts one by one and tells them who was inside yesterday and the day before.
es: The neighbors of the houses are so accustomed to the horrendous spectacle that not a single face is seen on many balconies, and it is very common to see people engaged in some occupation who do not stop the movement of their hands as the carts pass, although their eyes turn to the carts to see who the unfortunate ones occupying them are.

en: Of the riders in the tumbrils, some observe these things, and all things on their last roadside, with an impassive stare; others, with a lingering interest in the ways of life and men.
vi: There were people on the vehicle who indifferently observed those scenes and everything on the final journey of their life; some looked at life and the people passing by with regretful eyes.
tr: Some of the passengers in the cars are watching the surroundings and everything happening on their final journey with indifferent eyes, while others are observing with a lethargic interest.
es: Among those who ride the fateful carts, there are some who observe their surroundings with an impassive gaze and others who focus on it with fleeting interest.

en: Some, seated with drooping heads, are sunk in silent despair; again, there are some so heedful of their looks that they cast upon the multitude such glances as they have seen in theatres, and in pictures.
vi: Some sat with their heads down, immersed in despair; others were so concerned with their appearance that they cast heroic glances at the crowd, as often seen in plays or paintings.
tr: Some have their heads bowed, immersed in silent despair; others, aware of the significance of their gaze, are looking at the crowd with attitudes reminiscent of what they have seen in theaters and paintings.
es: Some give palpable signs of silent despair, making the final journey with their heads bowed over their chests, while others hold them arrogantly high and cast looks of haughty disdain at the crowds.

en: Several close their eyes, and think, or try to get their straying thoughts together.
vi: A few closed their eyes to think or tried to concentrate their thoughts.
tr: A few have closed their eyes, thinking or trying to gather their scattered thoughts.
es: Many meditate or try to gather their wandering thoughts, closing their eyes for that purpose, while one, just one, a wretched being of repulsive appearance, seems so crazed with terror that he sings and even tries to dance.

en: Only one, and he a miserable creature, of a crazed aspect, is so shattered and made drunk by horror, that he sings, and tries to dance.
vi: There was only one person, a miserable wretch, who seemed to have gone mad, so stunned and exhausted by terror that he burst into song and tried to dance on the vehicle.
tr: Only one, a poor creature driven mad, is so overwhelmed and intoxicated by fear that they are trying to sing and dance.
es: Many meditate or try to gather their wandering thoughts, closing their eyes for that purpose, while one, just one, a wretched being of repulsive appearance, seems so crazed with terror that he sings and even tries to dance.

en: Not one of the whole number appeals by look or gesture, to the pity of the people.
vi: Not a single person, through gaze or gesture, showed any plea for mercy from the people along the road.
tr: Among all these people, not a single one is begging for mercy from others with their looks or movements.
es: The expressions of the condemned vary infinitely, but not a single one awakens pity in the diamond-hard hearts of the people.

en: There is a guard of sundry horsemen riding abreast of the tumbrils, and faces are often turned up to some of them, and they are asked some question.
vi: There was a motley group of cavalrymen riding alongside the convoy of condemned prisoners, and the faces of passersby often turned towards them, uttering a few questions.
tr: There are a number of mounted guards right next to the cars, and people frequently turn their faces to them and ask something.
es: Some riders with a brutish appearance break the march, to whom the curious occasionally direct questions.

en: It would seem to be always the same question, for, it is always followed by a press of people towards the third cart.
vi: It always seems to be a question because there is always a crowd jostling around the third carriage.
tr: It seems that the question asked is the same, as people always rush to the third car afterward.
es: Undoubtedly, these are always the same, as the answer invariably leads to a movement of the crowds towards the third cart.

en: The horsemen abreast of that cart, frequently point out one man in it with their swords.
vi: The guards riding alongside that carriage always brandish their swords towards someone inside.
tr: The mounted guards next to that car constantly point to a man inside with their swords.
es: The riders with brutish faces who ride ahead also frequently point with the tips of their sabers to a man among those occupying it.

en: The leading curiosity is, to know which is he; he stands at the back of the tumbril with his head bent down, to converse with a mere girl who sits on the side of the cart, and holds his hand.
vi: Everyone is curious to know who the condemned person is; he stands at the back of the carriage, head bowed, talking to an ordinary girl sitting by the side of the carriage and holding his hand.
tr: Everyone is curious about who he is; he, however, stands at the back of the car, head bowed, talking to a poor girl who is sitting on the side of the car and holding his hand.
es: The condemned man in question has aroused general curiosity; everyone wants to know who the man is who, with his back against the backrest of the third cart, is conversing with a little girl sitting beside him.

en: He has no curiosity or care for the scene about him, and always speaks to the girl.
vi: He is neither curious nor concerned about the scene around him and only talks to that girl.
tr: He doesn't care about being watched or the commotion he has caused and continues to talk to the girl.
es: He does not seem interested in the scene nor does he care about anything around him.

en: Here and there in the long street of St. Honore, cries are raised against him.
vi: Occasionally, along the long St. Honoré street, many shouts are heard cursing him.
tr: Along the long St Honore Street, people are shouting against him.
es: In the street of San Honorato, the crowds shout against him; he responds to the shouts with a smile and energetic head movements that further dishevel his long hair, fallen over his face, which he cannot move away because his arms are tied.

en: If they move him at all, it is only to a quiet smile, as he shakes his hair a little more loosely about his face.
vi: If those words affected him, he only gave a faint smile while shaking his head, causing his disheveled hair to fall a bit more around his face.
tr: He, however, does nothing but silently smile while shaking his head to push back the hair that falls on his face.
es: In the street of San Honorato, the crowds shout against him; he responds to the shouts with a smile and energetic head movements that further dishevel his long hair, fallen over his face, which he cannot move away because his arms are tied.

en: He cannot easily touch his face, his arms being bound.
vi: He couldn't raise his hands to his face, as both arms were tied.
tr: Since his arms are tied, he cannot touch his face.
es: In the street of San Honorato, the crowds shout against him; he responds to the shouts with a smile and energetic head movements that further dishevel his long hair, fallen over his face, which he cannot move away because his arms are tied.

en: On the steps of a church, awaiting the coming-up of the tumbrils, stands the Spy and prison-sheep.
vi: On the church steps, waiting for the convoy of condemned prisoners, stood a spy and a prison guard.
tr: The prison rat Spy is standing on the steps of a church, waiting for the cars to arrive.
es: At the top of a church's staircase, the spy whom Sydney Carton called the hangman's blackbird awaits the passing of the funeral procession.

en: He looks into the first of them: not there.
vi: The spy looked into the first carriage: nothing.
tr: He looks at the first car, it's not there.
es: He fixes his gaze on the first cart: he is not there.

en: He looks into the second: not there.
vi: He looked into the second carriage: nothing.
tr: He looks at the second car, it's not there.
es: He anxiously looks at the second... Neither there.

en: He already asks himself, “Has he sacrificed me?” when his face clears, as he looks into the third.
vi: He was thinking to himself, "Could he have betrayed me?" when his face lit up as he looked into the third carriage.
tr: Just as he is thinking to himself, "Did he sacrifice me?" he sees the third car and feels relieved.
es: His face reflects the fear that begins to invade him, but when he scrutinizes the third, he smiles with satisfaction.

en: “Which is Evrémonde?” says a man behind him.
vi: − Who is Evrémonde? - The man standing next to him asked.
tr: "Which one is Evremonde?" asks the man behind him.
es: —Who is Evrémonde?—asks a man positioned behind him.

en: “That.
vi: - There.
tr: "That one.
es: —That one... the one from the third cart.

en: At the back there.”
vi: Standing at the back of the bus.
tr: The one standing at the back."
es: —That one... the one from the third cart.

en: “With his hand in the girl’s?”
vi: − The person holding the child's hand? −
tr: "The man holding the girl's hand?""
es: —The one who talks with the girl?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: The man cries, “Down, Evrémonde!
vi: − Down with Evrémonde! - The man shouted.
tr: Adam, "Die Evremonde!
es: —Die, Evrémonde! —immediately shouts the man in question.

en: To the Guillotine all aristocrats!
vi: - Send all the aristocrats to the guillotine!
tr: All aristocrats to the guillotine!
es: —To the guillotine with all the aristocrats!

en: Down, Evrémonde!”
vi: Down with Evrémonde!
tr: Die already, Evremonde!"
es: Die, Evrémonde!

en: “Hush, hush!” the Spy entreats him, timidly.
vi: − Shh, shh! - The spy fearfully pleaded.
tr: "Shh, shh!" says the Spy immediately, timidly.
es: —Quiet... quiet...! —the spy exclaims timidly.

en: “And why not, citizen?”
vi: − Why are you shushing, Citizen? −
tr: "Why shouldn't we say it, citizen?"
es: —Why should I be silent?

en: “He is going to pay the forfeit: it will be paid in five minutes more.
vi: He's about to pay for his crimes; in just over five minutes, his debt will be settled.
tr: "He will pay for what he has done, he has five minutes.
es: —Because he is about to pay for his crimes... In five minutes, he will have atoned for them...

en: Let him be at peace.”
vi: Let him be.
tr: Let's leave him alone now."
es: Leave him alone now.

en: But the man continuing to exclaim, “Down, Evrémonde!” the face of Evrémonde is for a moment turned towards him.
vi: But the other man continued to shout slogans, and for a moment Evrémonde turned to face him and saw the spy standing next to him.
tr: But the man keeps shouting, "Die Evremonde!" and Evremonde turns his face towards him for a moment.
es: —Die, Evrémonde! —continues shouting that barbarian.

en: Evrémonde then sees the Spy, and looks attentively at him, and goes his way.
vi: He stared intently, then the carriage passed by.
tr: Then he sees the Spy, looks at him carefully, and continues on his way.
es: Evrémonde turns his face towards the one who is shouting; he sees the spy, looks at him attentively, and continues on his way undaunted.

en: The clocks are on the stroke of three, and the furrow ploughed among the populace is turning round, to come on into the place of execution, and end.
vi: The clocks all struck three o'clock, the furrow plowed by the crowd parted, advanced to the place of execution, and stopped.
tr: The clocks show three, and the furrow moving through the crowd meanders and ends at the execution site.
es: The city clocks are about to strike three, and the plow veers off the straight path to reach the designated execution site.

en: The ridges thrown to this side and to that, now crumble in and close behind the last plough as it passes on, for all are following to the Guillotine.
vi: The furrows of people plowed to the sides had now filled back in behind the last cart arriving, as everyone followed it to the place where the guillotine was set up.
tr: People scattered to the sides approach the last plow in small groups, as they all head towards the Guillotine.
es: The lines of human heads that flanked the furrow opened by the plow up to that point gather in a throng around the guillotine that is about to be put into operation.

en: In front of it, seated in chairs, as in a garden of public diversion, are a number of women, busily knitting.
vi: Right in front of the guillotine, sitting on chairs as if watching public entertainment in a park, were many women busy knitting.
tr: Right in front of it, there are many women sitting on chairs, knitting as if they have come to the park for amusement.
es: In the front row, comfortably seated in chairs, exactly as if they were at the theater, there is a group of women, knitting with true fervor; among them, it was not difficult to spot La Vengeance, who seems restless and nervous.

en: On one of the fore-most chairs, stands The Vengeance, looking about for her friend.
vi: Standing on a chair in the front row, looking around, was the Goddess of Vengeance searching for her friend.
tr: Vengeance, standing up on one of the front chairs, is looking around for her friend.
es: In the front row, comfortably seated in chairs, exactly as if they were at the theater, there is a group of women, knitting with true fervor; among them, it was not difficult to spot La Vengeance, who seems restless and nervous.

en: “Thérèse!” she cries, in her shrill tones.
vi: − Thérèse! - The old woman shouted, her voice shrill. -
tr: "Therese!" screams Revenge in its shrillest voice.
es: —Teresa!

en: “Who has seen her? Thérèse Defarge!”
vi: Has anyone seen her? Thérèse Defarge! −
tr: "Has anyone seen her?" Therese Defarge!"
es: —she shouts, appealing to her most shrill register.—Who has seen Teresa... Teresa Defarge?

en: “She never missed before,” says a knitting-woman of the sisterhood.
vi: She has never missed a time before, - a woman in the knitting crowd spoke up.
tr: "She had never missed one before," says a woman knitting in the group.
es: —It's the first time she's missed—replies one of the workers.

en: “No; nor will she miss now,” cries The Vengeance, petulantly.
vi: − No, not this time either, - the Goddess of Vengeance shouted impatiently.
tr: "No; now he won't miss it either," shouts İntikam, grumpily.
es: —No... it won't be missing today either...!

en: “Thérèse.”
vi: - Thérèse.
tr: "Therese!"
es: Teresa! —roars La Venganza.

en: “Louder,” the woman recommends.
vi: − Speak louder, - the woman suggested.
tr: "Louder," advises the woman.
es: —Scream louder—advises the woman who spoke earlier.

en: Ay!
vi: Correct!
tr: Yeah!
es: Ah!

en: Louder, Vengeance, much louder, and still she will scarcely hear thee.
vi: Louder, Goddess of Vengeance, shout louder, and she still can't hear.
tr: Scream Revenge louder, much louder, but he still can barely hear you.
es: Scream, Vengeance, scream: for as loud as your screams may be, it is difficult for you to be heard!

en: Louder yet, Vengeance, with a little oath or so added, and yet it will hardly bring her.
vi: Shout louder, Goddess of Vengeance, add some curses, but she still doesn't appear.
tr: Even if you scream louder, Revenge, and even add an oath at the end, he won't come anymore.
es: Scream, Vengeance, scream... it doesn't matter if you accompany your screams with curses; neither the screams nor the curses will reach the ears of your boss!

en: Send other women up and down to seek her, lingering somewhere; and yet, although the messengers have done dread deeds, it is questionable whether of their own wills they will go far enough to find her!
vi: Order some other women to search for her up and down; but these female messengers, despite having done many terrible things, might not want to go far to find Madame Defarge!
tr: If you want, send other women to search for that madam who is writhing in pain somewhere; even if these women have committed terrible acts in the past, how hard will they try to find her?
es: Send emissaries to search for her everywhere; even though it cannot be denied that these emissaries have accomplished difficult tasks, it is certain that they will not go to look for her where she is! She has made a journey too long!

en: “Bad Fortune!” cries
vi: − Bad luck!
tr: "What luck!" shouts Revenge, stomping her foot hard on the chair, "the cars have arrived!
es: —Bad luck!

en: The Vengeance, stamping her foot in the chair, “and here are the tumbrils!
vi: - The Goddess of Vengeance shouted while stomping on the chair. - The death cart has arrived!
tr: "What luck!" shouts Revenge, stomping her foot hard on the chair, "the cars have arrived!
es: —silences La Venganza, furiously kicking—And the carts are already here...!

en: And Evrémonde will be despatched in a wink, and she not here!
vi: Just a little longer and Evrémonde's life will be over, yet she isn't here!
tr: Evremonde's shipment is imminent, and he's nowhere to be found!
es: And Evrémonde will be dispatched without her being here!

en: See her knitting in my hand, and her empty chair ready for her.
vi: I still have Thérèse's knitting here.
tr: I have his knitting in my hand, his chair is ready.
es: And Evrémonde will be dispatched without her being here!

en: I cry with vexation and disappointment!”
vi: I'm so frustrated, disappointed to the point of tears!
tr: I'm going to cry out of anger and disappointment now!"
es: While Vengeance calls out loudly for Teresa Defarge, the carts are unloaded.

en: As The Vengeance descends from her elevation to do it, the tumbrils begin to discharge their loads.
vi: As the Goddess of Vengeance stepped down to sit and cry, the carts began to unload the condemned.
tr: As revenge descends from the top of the chair for this purpose, the cars also begin to unload their cargo.
es: While Vengeance calls out loudly for Teresa Defarge, the carts are unloaded.

en: The ministers of Sainte Guillotine are robed and ready.
vi: The executioners were already dressed and ready. Thud! - A head was raised, the women who were knitting a moment ago didn't even glance up when the condemned were still breathing, now they all counted in unison:
tr: The deputies of Saint Guillotine are waiting ready in their robes.
es: The ministers of Saint Guillotine are dressed and ready to work...

en: Crash!
vi: One!
tr: Thud! – A head flies off and is shown to the crowd; the women knitting, who just a minute ago didn't deign to look at it while it was thinking and speaking, are now counting.
es: The ministers of Saint Guillotine are dressed and ready to work...

en: —A head is held up, and the knitting-women who scarcely lifted their eyes to look at it a moment ago when it could think and speak, count One.
vi: The second cart unloaded the condemned and drove away; the third cart arrived.
tr: One.
es: A blow is heard, a head rolls which one of the ministers immediately lifts in his hand, and the women, barely looking, continue knitting, saying as their only comment:

en: The second tumbril empties and moves on; the third comes up.
vi: The second cart unloaded the condemned and drove away; the third cart arrived.
tr: The second car also unloads its cargo and leaves; then the third one comes.
es: A blow is heard, a head rolls which one of the ministers immediately lifts in his hand, and the women, barely looking, continue knitting, saying as their only comment:

en: Crash!
vi: Thud! -
tr: Click!
es: —One.

en: —And the knitting-women, never faltering or pausing in their Work, count Two.
vi: And the group of women knitting did not stop their knitting for a minute, and counted: Two!
tr: The women knitting continue to count without pausing or hesitating in their work. Two.
es: The scene repeats several times, without the women interrupting their work or stopping their counting.

en: The supposed Evrémonde descends, and the seamstress is lifted out next after him.
vi: The one considered to be Evrémonde got off the carriage and the seamstress was helped down next.
tr: So-called Evremonde descends, followed by the seamstress girl.
es: The supposed Evrémonde ascends the fatal platform, holding the hand of the unfortunate girl, as he had promised, placing her with her back to the terrible blade, which rises and falls without interruption.

en: He has not relinquished her patient hand in getting out, but still holds it as he promised.
vi: He did not let go but still held the humble hand of the girl as he had promised.
tr: As promised, he has never let go of the girl's hand, not even while descending, keeping his patient hand steady.
es: The supposed Evrémonde ascends the fatal platform, holding the hand of the unfortunate girl, as he had promised, placing her with her back to the terrible blade, which rises and falls without interruption.

en: He gently places her with her back to the crashing engine that constantly whirrs up and falls, and she looks into his face and thanks him.
vi: He gently turned her back to the machine that was ceaselessly thudding up and down nearby, and she looked at him gratefully.
tr: He gently presses the girl's back against the ever-working cutting mechanism, and she looks at him and thanks Evremonde.
es: The supposed Evrémonde ascends the fatal platform, holding the hand of the unfortunate girl, as he had promised, placing her with her back to the terrible blade, which rises and falls without interruption.

en: “But for you, dear stranger, I should not be so composed, for I am naturally a poor little thing, faint of heart; nor should I have been able to raise my thoughts to Him who was put to death, that we might have hope and comfort here to-day.
vi: − O stranger, without you, I could not be this calm, for I am humble and timid; without you, I could not think that the Lord who died for us today might still bring hope and peace.
tr: "If it weren't for you, dear stranger, I could neither be this calm –for I am a wretched person by nature and my heart is very weak– nor could I share these thoughts with the person condemned to death and feel the hope and comfort that I feel here today.
es: —If it hadn't been for you, my dear stranger, I wouldn't have the calm and resignation that I have, for I am a poor girl and my heart is weak. Nor would I have known how to elevate my thoughts towards Him who died for us, to Him whose mercy is today my only hope.

en: I think you were sent to me by Heaven.”
vi: I believe that the Lord sent you to help me.
tr: Surely, God sent you to me."
es: I believe that it is the Heavens that have sent you to me on this day of trial. —Perhaps you are the messenger that the Heavens have sent to me—replied Carton.

en: “Or you to me,” says Sydney Carton.
vi: − Or perhaps she was sent to help me, - Sydney Carton said.
tr: "Or you to me," says Sydney Carton.

en: “Keep your eyes upon me, dear child, and mind no other object.”
vi: - Just look straight at me, girl, don't worry about anything.
tr: "Keep your eyes on me, dear child, and don't worry about anything else."
es: Fix your eyes on me, dear girl, and forget everything else.

en: “I mind nothing while I hold your hand.
vi: − I am not worried at all when I hold your hand.
tr: "When I'm holding your hand, nothing else matters to me.
es: —As long as I have yours in my hands, I will be calm; and if I have to let go to embark on the journey, if the blow is swift, I will not fear it either.

en: I shall mind nothing when I let it go, if they are rapid.”
vi: I will not be worried at all when I let go, if it happens quickly.
tr: If they finish this quickly when I let go of your hands, I won't care either."
es: —As long as I have yours in my hands, I will be calm; and if I have to let go to embark on the journey, if the blow is swift, I will not fear it either.

en: “They will be rapid.
vi: − It will be very quick.
tr: "It will be over quickly.
es: —The strike will be swift; don't worry.

en: Fear not!”
vi: Don't be afraid!
tr: Don't be afraid!"
es: —The strike will be swift; don't worry.

en: The two stand in the fast-thinning throng of victims, but they speak as if they were alone.
vi: The two stood among the thinning crowd of victims, yet they conversed as if they were the only ones there.
tr: Even though they stand among a rapidly dwindling heap of victims, they speak as if they are alone.
es: Although they were among the other victims, they spoke with as much freedom as if they had been alone.

en: Eye to eye, voice to voice, hand to hand, heart to heart, these two children of the Universal Mother, else so wide apart and differing, have come together on the dark highway, to repair home together, and to rest in her bosom.
vi: Eye to eye, word for word, hand in hand, heart to heart, two children of Mother Nature, two beings so distant and different from each other now meeting on the path to death, together returning to rest in the embrace of Mother.
tr: These two children of Mother Earth, although very different from each other under different circumstances, have come together on this dark path, eye to eye, hand in hand, heart to heart, to support each other and rest in their mother's embrace.
es: Those two children of the Universal Mother, unknown to each other until then, were going to make the final journey together, to appear together before the Creator, to rest together in Heaven.

en: “Brave and generous friend, will you let me ask you one last question?
vi: − Brave and chivalrous friend, may I ask you one last question?
tr: "Brave and honorable friend, may I ask you one last question?
es: —Brave and generous friend! —exclaimed the girl—May I ask you a question?

en: I am very ignorant, and it troubles me—just a little.”
vi: I am ignorant and have a small query... just a minor thing.
tr: I am very ignorant, and this bothers me a bit."
es: I am very ignorant, and it is about something that troubles and mortifies me... a little bit.

en: “Tell me what it is.”
vi: − Go ahead and speak.
tr: "Tell me."
es: —Ask whatever you want.

en: “I have a cousin, an only relative and an orphan, like myself, whom I love very dearly.
vi: − I have a cousin, my only relative and also an orphan like me, whom I care for deeply.
tr: "I have a cousin whom I love very much, my only relative, and like me, he is also an orphan.
es: —I have a cousin, my only relative, an orphan like me, whom I love very much.

en: She is five years younger than I, and she lives in a farmer’s house in the south country.
vi: She is five years younger than me and is living on a farm in the south.
tr: He is five years younger than me and lives on a farm in the south.
es: She is five years younger than I am and lives in a farmhouse, in the South.

en: Poverty parted us, and she knows nothing of my fate—for I cannot write—and if I could, how should I tell her!
vi: Poverty has separated us, and she knows nothing about my fate... because I am illiterate and cannot write letters... But if I knew how to write, how could I tell my story here!
tr: Poverty separated us, and he has no idea what has happened to me –I can't write anyway– even if I could write, how could I tell him this!
es: Poverty separated us; she is unaware of my misfortune and I cannot write to her... and even if I could... what would I say?

en: It is better as it is.”
vi: It's better that my younger sibling doesn't know.
tr: Maybe it's better this way."
es: It is better this way.

en: “Yes, yes: better as it is.”
vi: − Yes, yes, that would be better.
tr: "Yes, yes; this way is better."
es: —It's true: it's better this way.

en: “What I have been thinking as we came along, and what I am still thinking now, as I look into your kind strong face which gives me so much support, is this:—If the Republic really does good to the poor, and they come to be less hungry, and in all ways to suffer less, she may live a long time: she may even live to be old.”
vi: − What I thought on the way here, and now still wonder when I look at the resolute face that has supported me, is... If this Republic truly brings good things to the poor, helping them be less hungry, less miserable in every way, my brother would surely have lived longer, perhaps even to old age...
tr: "I was thinking while coming on the road and I am still thinking while looking at your kind and strong face that gives me strength, if the Republic truly helps the poor and reduces their hunger and suffering, my cousin may live long, even grow old.""
es: —What I have been thinking while they were bringing us here, and what I continued thinking now, is the following: if the Republic is truly to bring happiness to the poor, if thanks to it they suffer less hunger and their suffering is alleviated, my cousin may still live many years; it is even possible that she might grow old.

en: “What then, my gentle sister?”
vi: − And then what, little sister? −
tr: "What does it matter, my dear brother?"
es: —And what, my dear little sister?

en: “Do you think:” the uncomplaining eyes in which there is so much endurance, fill with tears, and the lips part a little more and tremble: “that it will seem long to me, while I wait for her in the better land where I trust both you and I will be mercifully sheltered?”
vi: Do you think that... - tears welling up in eyes resigned without a complaint, lips slightly trembling, - will I have to wait too long for my sister in Heaven, where I believe both you and I will be welcomed by God's grace? −
tr: "I wonder," the girl's gentle, non-pleading eyes filled with tears and her lips parted further and began to tremble, "while I wait for him where I'm going – and I'm sure we will be protected with mercy there – will this time feel long to me?"
es: —If that is so, don't you think the wait will feel very long for me, there in that better world where I trust to be mercifully welcomed with you, in that world where you, she, and I will live eternally?

en: “It cannot be, my child; there is no Time there, and no trouble there.”
vi: Not long, little sister; there is no Time there, and no sorrow.
tr: "He won't come, my dear; there is no Time there, nor is there any trouble."
es: —No, my daughter, no; in that better world you allude to, Time does not exist, nor is there room for suffering.

en: “You comfort me so much!
vi: − You have greatly reassured me!
tr: "How you put my mind at ease!
es: —How much your words console me!

en: I am so ignorant.
vi: I am so ignorant.
tr: I am very ignorant.
es: I am so ignorant!

en: Am I to kiss you now?
vi: Can I kiss you now?
tr: Can I kiss you now?
es: Should I kiss you now?

en: Is the moment come?”
vi: Is it almost time?
tr: Has the time come?"
es: Has the moment arrived?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, my daughter, yes.

en: She kisses his lips; he kisses hers; they solemnly bless each other.
vi: The girl kissed him on the lips; he kissed her lips; they solemnly blessed each other.
tr: They kiss each other on the lips and bless each other with a solemn air.
es: The girl kisses Sydney Carton's lips and Sydney Carton kisses the girl's lips.

en: The spare hand does not tremble as he releases it; nothing worse than a sweet, bright constancy is in the patient face.
vi: The lonely hand no longer trembled when he let go; without a trace of impurity, that patient face was completely radiant, joyful.
tr: When he lets go of the girl's hand, it no longer trembles. A sweet, radiant determination has enveloped his patient face.
es: Their hands do not tremble as they part.

en: She goes next before him—is gone; the knitting-women count Twenty-Two.
vi: The girl went to the guillotine before him - and passed away; the knitting women counted: Twenty-Two.
tr: The next person, the one who will go immediately in front, is him; the women knitting are counting. Twenty-two.
es: "Goodbye." The girl's head rolls first... The women who knit count TWENTY-TWO.

en: “I am the Resurrection and the Life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me shall never die.”
vi: “The Lord said: I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me will live, even though they have died. And whoever lives by believing in me will never die.”
tr: "I am the Resurrection and the Life," said God. Whoever believes in me,. even if they die, will live, and whoever lives and believes in me will never die."
es: "I am the Resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, shall live eternally; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die."

en: The murmuring of many voices, the upturning of many faces, the pressing on of many footsteps in the outskirts of the crowd, so that it swells forward in a mass, like one great heave of water, all flashes away.
vi: Many voices murmured, many faces looked up, many footsteps crowded closer from the outer circle of the crowd, causing a wave of people to surge forward, then suddenly disappear.
tr: Murmurs are rising, everyone's face is turning that way, there's such a jostling at the edge of the crowd that the whole mass swells forward like a huge wave and then disappears.
es: "I am the Resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, shall live eternally; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die."

en: Twenty-Three.
vi: Twenty-Three.
tr: Twenty-three.
es: The blade descends again, and the women count; TWENTY-THREE.

en: They said of him, about the city that night, that it was the peacefullest man’s face ever beheld there.
vi: Throughout the capital that night, people told each other that among all those who went to the guillotine in Paris, he had the most serene face.
tr: That night, everyone in the city talked about how they had never seen a face as peaceful as his.
es: That night, nothing else was talked about in the city. Everyone said they had never seen a human face that reflected so much calm, so much serenity of spirit.

en: Many added that he looked sublime and prophetic.
vi: Many people also say that he looks majestic and extraordinary, like a prophet.
tr: Many people added that he looked so transcendent and sublime.
es: Many added that his appearance was sublime and that a prophetic light shone in his eyes.

en: One of the most remarkable sufferers by the same axe—a woman—had asked at the foot of the same scaffold, not long before, to be allowed to write down the thoughts that were inspiring her.
vi: Not long before, one of the most famous condemned criminals of that guillotine - a woman - had asked to record her final thoughts as she stood at the foot of the scaffold.
tr: One of the most notable victims of the same knife – a woman – had asked for permission to write down her thoughts shortly before her execution, at the foot of the same gallows.
es: Some time before, one of the most notable victims of the guillotine, a woman, had written down, placed upon the dreadful platform, the thoughts that the horrible machine inspired in her.

en: If he had given any utterance to his, and they were prophetic, they would have been these:
vi: If you were to utter what you are thinking, if you could see into the future, you would have said: "I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, the Goddess of Vengeance, the jurors, the Judge, so many new oppressors arising as the old oppressors are destroyed, all will perish under this punitive machine before it is discarded and no longer used.
tr: If Carton were also given the opportunity to express himself, he would have uttered these sublime words:
es: If Sydney Carton had given sensible expression to his own, and if they had been prophetic, they would have been the following:

en: “I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, The Vengeance, the Juryman, the Judge, long ranks of the new oppressors who have risen on the destruction of the old, perishing by this retributive instrument, before it shall cease out of its present use.
vi: If you were to utter what you are thinking, if you could see into the future, you would have said: "I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, the Goddess of Vengeance, the jurors, the Judge, so many new oppressors arising as the old oppressors are destroyed, all will perish under this punitive machine before it is discarded and no longer used.
tr: "I see that Barsad, Cly, Defarge, Vengeance, the Jury, the Judge, and the new tyrants rising from the destruction of the old order will perish by this treacherous instrument before its current use ends.
es: "I see Barsad, Cly, Defarge, La Vengeance, the Jurors, the Judges, all the new oppressors of humanity who have risen terribly to destroy the old ones, fall under the sharp blade of the just instrument.

en: I see a beautiful city and a brilliant people rising from this abyss, and, in their struggles to be truly free, in their triumphs and defeats, through long years to come, I see the evil of this time and of the previous time of which this is the natural birth, gradually making expiation for itself and wearing out.
vi: I see a magnificent city and a wise people rising from this abyss; in their true struggle for freedom, in their victories and defeats, after many long years, I see this country gradually atoning for the evils of the present time and for those that caused this turmoil."
tr: I see a beautiful city and brilliant people emerging from this abyss, and for many years, in their struggle to remain truly free, in their victories and defeats, I see the evil of the past, which slowly pays its penalty and fades away, in these times.
es: I see from the depths of the black abyss a beautiful city and an educated people emerge, who, in their struggles for true freedom, in their triumphs and defeats, atone, for many long years, for the horrors of the current era and those of previous eras, and eventually erase them."

en: “I see the lives for which I lay down my life, peaceful, useful, prosperous and happy, in that England which I shall see no more.
vi: I see those for whom I have sacrificed my life, living peacefully, usefully, prosperously, and happily, never to be seen again in England.
tr: The lives for which I gave my life, in that England I will never see again, I see them peaceful, useful, prosperous, and happy.
es: "I see the lives of those for whom I give my own, gliding peacefully, prosperously, and happily, in that England that my eyes will never see again."

en: I see Her with a child upon her bosom, who bears my name.
vi: I see her holding in her arms a child named after me.
tr: I see her with a child in her arms, bearing my name.
es: I see her gently rocking in her lap a child who bears my name.

en: I see her father, aged and bent, but otherwise restored, and faithful to all men in his healing office, and at peace.
vi: I see her father, old and frail, but recovered, devotedly treating the sick, and living comfortably.
tr: I see his father aged and worn; on the other hand, improved and serving people in his clinic, and peaceful.
es: I see her father bowed under the weight of years, but providing until the last moment of his life the aid of his science to his fellow men.

en: I see the good old man, so long their friend, in ten years’ time enriching them with all he has, and passing tranquilly to his reward.
vi: I see that kind old friend, close to this family for a long time, still wholeheartedly dedicated to them ten years from now, and peacefully receiving his reward in the hereafter.
tr: I see the kind-hearted old man, their former friend who enriched their lives for ten years and peacefully received his reward.
es: I see the good old man, who for so many years has been her tender and selfless friend, enriching them with all he possesses and flying to the world where the reward awaits him that his virtues have earned him.

en: “I see that I hold a sanctuary in their hearts, and in the hearts of their descendants, generations hence.
vi: I see myself being given a revered place in their hearts, in the hearts of their descendants, for many generations to come.
tr: I see that I will have a sacred place in the hearts of their grandchildren and all subsequent generations.
es: "I see that in their hearts they have erected an altar for me, and that this altar is passed down to their descendants, and that, many generations later, all the descendants of that beloved family pay sincere homage to the memory of the man who sacrificed his life for the sake of a sacred affection."

en: I see her, an old woman, weeping for me on the anniversary of this day.
vi: I see her, an old woman, shedding tears in mourning for me on this day every year.
tr: I see her, as an old woman, crying on this day every year.
es: I see her, already very old, crying for me on every anniversary of my death.

en: I see her and her husband, their course done, lying side by side in their last earthly bed, and I know that each was not more honoured and held sacred in the other’s soul, than I was in the souls of both.
vi: I see her with her husband, at the end of their lives, lying together in a shared grave, and I know that I also hold a sacred and honorable place in their souls, no less cherished than the respect they have for each other.
tr: I see her and her husband lying side by side in their final resting place in this mortal world, their lives having ended, and I know that both have reserved the most honorable and sacred place for me in their hearts, just as they have for each other.
es: I see her and her husband, sleeping in the earth the final sleep, and I know that, even after death, they honor and exalt my memory.

en: “I see that child who lay upon her bosom and who bore my name, a man winning his way up in that path of life which once was mine.
vi: I see the child in her arms bearing my name becoming a successful person on the career path that I left unfinished.
tr: I see the child, who carries my name and rests on his chest, walking the path I once walked and making a living.
es: "I see the child she rocked in her lap, who bears my name, grown into a strong man making his way in the world, dedicated to the career that was once mine, and doing so brilliantly, that the glows illuminating his name also illuminate mine."

en: I see him winning it so well, that my name is made illustrious there by the light of his.
vi: I see that young man gaining widespread fame, causing my name to be honored and erasing the stains I had inadvertently brought upon that name.
tr: I see that he is very successful in his work, and my name shines with his light.
es: "I see the child she rocked in her lap, who bears my name, grown into a strong man making his way in the world, dedicated to the career that was once mine, and doing so brilliantly, that the glows illuminating his name also illuminate mine."

en: I see the blots I threw upon it, faded away.
vi: I see that young man gaining widespread fame, causing my name to be honored and erasing the stains I had inadvertently brought upon that name.
tr: I see the stains I placed on my name being cleaned.
es: I see the stains that tarnished the brilliance of my soul erased.

en: I see him, fore-most of just judges and honoured men, bringing a boy of my name, with a forehead that I know and golden hair, to this place—then fair to look upon, with not a trace of this day’s disfigurement—and I hear him tell the child my story, with a tender and a faltering voice.
vi: I see that young man becoming the most just judge, a revered person, who will bring the son also bearing my name, with the familiar forehead and golden hair, to this place - which by then will be magnificent, free from the blemishes of today - and I hear that person, moved and emotional, recounting my story to his son.
tr: I see this man, the foremost of conscientious judges and honorable men, bringing his son, who also carries my name and has a familiar brow and golden hair, here – of course, by then, there will be no trace of the current ugly state here – and I hear him telling my story to his son in a compassionate and hesitant voice.
es: I see the illustrious lawyer who bears my name, the most just of judges on earth, who has earned the respect and admiration of his fellow citizens, now old, very old, with a golden-haired child on his unsteady knees, who also bears my name, and narrating my story in a faltering voice.

en: “It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.”
vi: It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to, than I have ever known.”
tr: This is the best, the most correct thing I have ever done, and the end of this road is a sleep as beautiful, as wonderful as I have never known before."
es: "A thousand times more beautiful is what I do now than what I ever did."
